text: It is indeed unfortunate that human society should
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: To attempt to expand on an account of the evolution of the
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Movement in architecture at the time of writing is a
label: Paragraph

text: contradictory and disturbing experience. While the level of
label: Paragraph

text: professional talent and skill in the field is higher today,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: confused state of total political paralysis, so much so that
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: no longer has the capacity to act in its own best interests. At
label: Paragraph

text: the micro-level, the techno-scientific division of labour is
label: Paragraph

text: such that we are able to penetrate ever more deeply into
label: Paragraph

text: the mysteries of nature, but simultaneously we are the
label: Paragraph

text: perennial victims of a triumphant globalized capitalism
label: Title

text: through which, at the macro-level, we are locked in a titanic
label: Paragraph

text: struggle with a rebarbative nature, which is now already
label: Paragraph

text: beyond our control.

label: Title

text: All of this begs the question as to what do we mean by a
label: Paragraph

text: culture of architecture and how do we begin to perceive it in
label: Paragraph

text: the first place? We surely have to concede that the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement in architecture has had, and continues to have, a
label: Paragraph

text: decidedly wave-like character: it comes into being,
label: Paragraph

text: somewhat unannounced, rises to its maturity and then
label: Paragraph

text: eventually declines, possibly arising again in virtually the
label: Paragraph

text: same place but at an entirely different time and ina
label: Paragraph

text: different form, to begin the cycle all over again. Throughout
label: Paragraph

text: this history | have made an effort to reveal this cyclical
label: Paragraph

text: character not only with regard to the movement’s
label: Paragraph

text: Eurocentric beginnings, but also its manifestation in
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary architecture in the world at large. To this end |
label: Paragraph

text: have indicated from time to time the way in which certain
label: Paragraph

text: political and socio-economic transformations have had an
label: Paragraph

text: impact not only on the lifecycle of a given cultural
label: Paragraph

text: momentum, but also on the programme and the character
label: Paragraph

text: of an emerging environmental form.
label: Paragraph

text: All of this has now shaped my approach to documenting
label: Paragraph

text: the dissemination of the Modern Movement across time. In
label: Paragraph

text: dealing with each vast continental sector and the national
label: Paragraph

text: subsets of which it is necessarily comprised, | have
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to adopt the same procedure throughout:
label: Paragraph

text: beginning with a brief documentation of the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement and then passing abruptly to more recent
label: Paragraph

text: manifestations of a similar impulse. This constant double-
label: Paragraph

text: take across large lapses of time has meant that | have had
label: Paragraph

text: to rely on illustrations to a much greater extent than in
label: Paragraph

text: earlier editions of this history, because it is difficult to
label: Paragraph

text: convey the often highly inflected nature of recent
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, which, while not in any way Post-Modern,
label: Paragraph

text: nonetheless incorporates a tactile, microcosmic character
label: Paragraph

text: that is difficult to convey in words.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the challenges of writing an account over such a
label: Paragraph

text: broad front is the quandary of the criteria by which one
label: Paragraph

text: decides to include or exclude a particular work. Despite a
label: Paragraph

text: constant attempt to maintain a certain level of objectivity,
label: Paragraph

text: there is an inescapable subjectivity determining one’s
label: Paragraph

text: choices. Perhaps this is the ultimate meaning of the term ‘a
label: Paragraph

text: critical history’ inasmuch as the historical account fuses
label: Paragraph

text: with both criticism and theory, serving to justify expansion
label: Paragraph

text: on a particular work or subject matter that one values, at
label: Paragraph

text: the expense of the others that, because of time, space and
label: Paragraph

text: polemical prejudices, one elects to ignore. Of course, there
label: Paragraph

text: is no absolute history, for, as E.H. Carr made clear in his
label: Paragraph

text: book What is History?, each age writes its own history and
label: Paragraph

text: in this sense creates a purview with which we may hopefully
label: Paragraph

text: proceed in a culturally significant way.
label: Paragraph

text: It is ironic that the first edition of this history, written by
label: Paragraph

text: an architect, committed to ‘the unfinished modern project’,
label: Paragraph

text: to coin Jurgen Habermas’s memorable phrase, should have
label: Paragraph

text: been published in the same year as the first architectural
label: Paragraph

text: biennale, staged in Venice in 1980. This exhibition, curated
label: Paragraph

text: by Paolo Portoghesi, was dedicated to celebrating the
label: Paragraph

text: historicizing pastiche of Post-Modern architecture, under the
label: Paragraph

text: slogan, ‘The End of Prohibition and the Presence of the Past’.
label: Paragraph

text: Since this time, subsequent editions of this history, of
label: Paragraph

text: which this is the greatly expanded fifth edition, have been
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated, in one way or another, to the continuation of the
label: Paragraph

text: modern project in terms of a liberative architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: However, it has become increasingly clear that under the
label: Paragraph

text: aegis of an anti-ecological, neo-liberal consumerism,
label: Paragraph

text: continually exacerbating the the maldistribution of wealth,
label: Paragraph

text: the prospects for any kind of rational land settlement, let
label: Paragraph

text: alone urbanism, are extremely limited, if not totally
label: Paragraph

text: unavailable. At best what is left for the critical practice of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture at a large scale are predominantly horizontal
label: Paragraph

text: megaforms designed as artificial landscapes in order to
label: Paragraph

text: encapsulate some vestige of the civic and to stand against
label: Paragraph

text: The Baroque system had operated as a kind of double
label: Paragraph

text: intersection. It had often contrasted with rationalized
label: Paragraph

text: gardens, building facades decorated with plant motifs. The
label: Paragraph

text: reign of man and the reign of nature had certainly remained
label: Paragraph

text: distinct but they had exchanged their characteristics,
label: Paragraph

text: merging into each other for the sake of ornamentation and
label: Paragraph

text: prestige. On the other hand the ‘English style’ park, in which
label: Paragraph

text: man’s intervention was supposed to remain invisible, was
label: Paragraph

text: intended to offer the purposefulness of nature; while within,
label: Paragraph

text: but separate from the actual park, the houses constructed
label: Paragraph

text: by Morris or Adam manifested the will of man, isolating
label: Paragraph

text: Clearly the presence of human reason in the midst of the
label: Paragraph

text: irrational domains of freely growing vegetation. The
label: Paragraph

text: Baroque interpenetration of man and nature was now
label: Paragraph

text: replaced by a separation, thus establishing the distance
label: Paragraph

text: between man and nature which was a prerequisite for
label: Paragraph

text: nostalgic contemplation. Now ... this contemplative
label: Paragraph

text: separation arose as a compensatory or expiatory reaction
label: Paragraph

text: against the growing attitude of practical men towards
label: Title

text: nature. While technical exploitation tended to wage war on
label: Paragraph

text: nature, houses and parks attempted a reconciliation, a local
label: Paragraph

text: armistice, introducing the dream of an impossible peace:
label: Paragraph

text: and to this end man had continued to retain the image of
label: Paragraph

text: untouched natural surroundings.

text: Jean Starobinski
label: Title

text: L’Invention de la liberté, 19641
label: Caption

text: The architecture of Neo-Classicism seems to have emerged
label: Paragraph

text: out of two different but related developments which
label: Paragraph

text: radically transformed the relationship between man and
label: Paragraph

text: nature. The first was a sudden increase in man’s capacity to
label: Paragraph

text: exercise control over nature, which by the mid-17th century
label: Paragraph

text: had begun to advance beyond the technical frontiers of the
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance. The second was a fundamental shift in the
label: Paragraph

text: nature of human consciousness, in response to major
label: Paragraph

text: changes taking place in society, which gave birth to a new
label: Paragraph

text: cultural formation that was equally appropriate to the
label: Paragraph

text: lifestyles of the declining aristocracy and the rising
label: Title

text: bourgeoisie. Whereas technological changes led to a new
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructure and to the exploitation of an increased
label: Title

text: productive capacity, the change in human consciousness
label: Title

text: yielded new categories of knowledge and a historicist mode
label: Paragraph

text: of thought that was so reflexive as to question its own
label: Paragraph

text: identity. Where the one, grounded in science, took
label: Paragraph

text: immediate form in the extensive road and canal works of
label: Paragraph

text: the 17th and 18th centuries and gave rise to new technical
label: Paragraph

text: institutions, such as the Ecole des Ponts et Chaussées,
label: Paragraph

text: founded in 1747, the other led to the emergence of the
label: Paragraph

text: humanist disciplines of the Enlightenment, including the
label: Paragraph

text: pioneer works of modern sociology, aesthetics, history and
label: Paragraph

text: archaeology - Montesquieu’s De /’esprit des lois (1748),
label: Paragraph

text: Baumgarten’s Aesthetica (1750), Voltaire’s Le Siécle de
label: Paragraph

text: Louis XIV(1751) and J. J. Winckelmann’s Geschichte der
label: Paragraph

text: Kunst des Altertums of 1764.
label: Paragraph

text: The over-elaboration of architectural language in the
label: Paragraph

text: Rococo interiors of the Ancien Régime and the secularization
label: Caption

text: of Enlightenment thought compelled the architects of the
label: Paragraph

text: 18th century, by now aware of the emergent and unstable
label: Paragraph

text: nature of their age, to search for a true style through a
label: Paragraph

text: precise reappraisal of antiquity. Their motivation was not
label: Paragraph

text: simply to copy the ancients but to obey the principles on
label: Paragraph

text: which their work had been based. The archaeological
label: Paragraph

text: research that arose from this impulse soon led to a major
label: Paragraph

text: controversy: to which, of four Mediterranean cultures - the
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptians, the Etruscans, the Greeks and the Romans -
label: Paragraph

text: should they look for a true style?
label: Paragraph

text: One of the first consequences of reassessing the antique
label: Paragraph

text: world was to extend the itinerary of the traditional Grand
label: Paragraph

text: Tour beyond the frontiers of Rome, so as to study at its
label: Paragraph

text: periphery those cultures on which, according to Vitruvius,
label: Paragraph

text: Roman architecture had been based. The discovery and
label: Paragraph

text: excavation of Roman cities at Herculaneum and Pompeii,
label: Paragraph

text: during the first half of the 18th century, encouraged
label: Paragraph

text: expeditions further afield and visits were soon being made
label: Paragraph

text: to ancient Greek sites in both Sicily and Greece. The
label: Paragraph

text: received Vitruvian dictum of the Renaissance - the
label: Paragraph

text: catechism of Classicism - was now to be checked against
label: Paragraph

text: the actual ruins. The measured drawings that were
label: Paragraph

text: published in the 1750s and 1760s, Julien-David Le Roy’s
label: Paragraph

text: Ruines des plus beaux monuments de la Gréce (1758),
label: Caption

text: James Stuart and Nicholas Revett’s Antiquities of Athens
label: Title

text: (1762), and Robert Adam and Charles-Louis Clérisseau’s
label: Paragraph

text: documentation of Diocletian’s palace at Split (1764), testify
label: Caption

text: to the intensity with which these studies were pursued. It
label: Paragraph

text: was Le Roy’s promotion of Greek architecture as the origin
label: Paragraph

text: of the ‘true style’ that raised the chauvinist ire of the Italian
label: Paragraph

text: architect-engraver Giovanni Battista Piranesi.
label: Caption

text: Piranesi’s Della Magnificenza ed Architettura de’ Romani
label: Caption

text: of 1761 was a direct attack on Le Roy’s polemic: he asserted
label: Paragraph

text: not only that the Etruscans had antedated the Greeks but
label: Paragraph

text: that, together with their successors the Romans, they had
label: Paragraph

text: raised architecture to a higher level of refinement. The only
label: Paragraph

text: evidence that he could cite in support of his claim was the
label: Paragraph

text: few Etruscan structures that had survived the ravages of
label: Paragraph

text: Rome - tombs and engineering works - and these seem to
label: Paragraph

text: have orientated the remainder of his career in a remarkable
label: Paragraph

text: way. In one set of etchings after another he represented the
label: Paragraph

text: dark side of that sensation already classified by Edmund
label: Paragraph

text: Burke in 1757 as the Sublime, that tranquil terror induced
label: Paragraph

text: by the contemplation of great size, extreme antiquity and
label: Paragraph

text: decay. These qualities acquired their full force in Piranesi’s
label: Paragraph

text: work through the infinite grandeur of the images that he
label: Paragraph

text: portrayed. Such nostalgic Classical images were, however,
label: Paragraph

text: as Manfredo Tafuri has observed, treated ‘as a myth to be
label: Paragraph

text: contested ... as mere fragments, as deformed symbols, as
label: Paragraph

text: hallucinating organisms of an “order” in a state of decay’.
label: Paragraph

text: Between his Parere su i’Architettura of 1765 and his
label: Paragraph

text: Paestum etchings, published only after his death in 1778,
label: Paragraph

text: Piranesi abandoned architectural verisimilitude and gave his
label: Paragraph

text: imagination full rein. In one publication after another,
label: Paragraph

text: culminating in his extravagantly eclectic work on interior
label: Paragraph

text: ornamentation of 1769, he indulged in hallucinatory
label: Paragraph

text: manipulations of historicist form. Indifferent to
label: Paragraph

text: Winckelmann’s pro-Hellenic distinction between innate
label: Paragraph

text: beauty and gratuitous ornament, his delirious inventions
label: Paragraph

text: exercised an irresistible attraction on his contemporaries,
label: Paragraph

text: and the Adam brothers’ Graeco-Roman interiors were
label: Paragraph

text: greatly indebted to his flights of imagination.

text: l’architecture (1706), where he replaced the Vitruvian
label: Paragraph

text: attributes of architecture, namely utilitas, firmitas and
label: Paragraph

text: venustas (utility, solidity and beauty) by his own trinity of
label: Paragraph

text: ordonnance, distribution and bienséance. While the first two
label: Paragraph

text: of his categories concerned the correct proportioning of the
label: Paragraph

text: Classical orders and their appropriate disposition, the third
label: Paragraph

text: introduced the notion of fitness, with which Cordemoy
label: Paragraph

text: warned against the inappropriate application of Classical or
label: Paragraph

text: honorific elements to utilitarian or commercial structures.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus, in addition to being critical of the Baroque, which was
label: Paragraph

text: the last rhetorical, public manner of the Ancien Régime,
label: Paragraph

text: Cordemoy’s Traité anticipated Jacques-Frangois Blondel’s
label: Paragraph

text: preoccupation with appropriate formal expression and with
label: Paragraph

text: a differentiated physiognomy to accord with the varying
label: Paragraph

text: social character of different building types. The age was
label: Paragraph

text: already having to confront the articulation of a much more
label: Paragraph

text: complex society.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from insisting on the judicious application of
label: Paragraph

text: Classical elements, Cordemoy was concerned with their
label: Paragraph

text: geometrical purity, in reaction against such Baroque devices
label: Paragraph

text: as irregular columniation, broken pediments and twisted
label: Paragraph

text: columns. Ornamentation too had to be subject to propriety,
label: Paragraph

text: and Cordemoy, anticipating Adolf Loos’s Ornament und
label: Paragraph

text: Verbrechen (Ornament and Crime) by two hundred years,
label: Paragraph

text: argued that many buildings required no ornament at all. His
label: Paragraph

text: preference was for astylar masonry and orthogonal
label: Paragraph

text: structures. For him, the free-standing column was the
label: Paragraph

text: essence of a pure architecture such as had been made
label: Paragraph

text: manifest in the Gothic cathedral and the Greek temple.
label: Paragraph

text: The Abbé Laugier in his Essai sur l’architecture (1753)
label: Caption

text: reinterpreted Cordemoy, to posit a universal ‘natural’
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, the primordial ‘primitive hut’ consisting of four
label: Paragraph

text: tree trunks supporting a rustic pitched roof. After Cordemoy,
label: Paragraph

text: he asserted this primal form as the basis for a sort of
label: Paragraph

text: classicized Gothic structure in which there would be neither
label: Paragraph

text: arches nor pilasters nor pedestals nor any other kind of
label: Paragraph

text: formal articulation, and where the interstices between the
label: Paragraph

text: columns would be as fully glazed as possible.
label: Paragraph

text: Such a ‘translucent’ structure was realized in Jacques-
label: Paragraph

text: Germain Soufflot’s church of Ste-Geneviéve in Paris [2],
label: Caption

text: begun in 1755. Soufflot, who in 1750 had been one of the
label: Paragraph

text: first architects to visit the Doric temples at Paestum, was
label: Paragraph

text: determined to recreate the lightness, the spaciousness and
label: Paragraph

text: the proportion of Gothic architecture in Classical (not to say
label: Paragraph

text: Roman) terms. To this end he adopted a Greek cross plan,
label: Paragraph

text: the nave and aisles being formed by a system of flat domes
label: Paragraph

text: and semicircular arches supported on a continuous internal
label: Paragraph

text: peristyle.
label: Paragraph

text: The task of integrating the theory of Cordemoy and the
label: Paragraph

text: magnum opus of Soufflot into the French academic tradition
label: Title

text: fell to Blondel, who, after opening his architectural school in
label: Paragraph

text: Rue de la Harpe in 1743, became the master of that so-
label: Paragraph

text: called ‘visionary’ generation of architects that included
label: Paragraph

text: Etienne-Louis Boullée, Jacques Gondoin, Pierre Patte, Marie-
label: Caption

text: Joseph Peyre, Jean-Baptiste Rondelet and, probably the most
label: Paragraph

text: visionary of all, Claude-Nicolas Ledoux. Blondel set out his
label: Paragraph

text: main precepts, concerning composition, type and character,
label: Paragraph

text: in his Cours d’architecture, published from 1750 to 1770.
label: Paragraph

text: His ideal church design, published in the second volume of
label: Paragraph

text: his Cours, was related to Ste-Geneviéve and prominently
label: Paragraph

text: displayed a representational front, while articulating each
label: Paragraph

text: internal element as part of a continuous spatial system
label: Paragraph

text: whose infinite vistas evoked a sense of the Sublime. This
label: Paragraph

text: church project hints at the simplicity and grandeur that
label: Paragraph

text: were to inform the work of many of his pupils, most notably
label: Paragraph

text: Boullée, who after 1772 devoted his life to the projection of
label: Paragraph

text: buildings so vast as to preclude their realization.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition to representing the social character of his
label: Paragraph

text: creations in accordance with the teachings of Blondel,
label: Paragraph

text: Boullée evoked the sublime emotions of terror and
label: Paragraph

text: tranquillity through the grandeur of his conceptions.
label: Paragraph

text: Influenced by Le Camus de Méziéres’ Génie de
label: Paragraph

text: l'architecture, ou l’analogie de cet art avec nos sensations
label: Title

text: (1780), he began to develop his genre terrible, in which the
label: Paragraph

text: immensity of the vista and the unadorned geometrical
label: Title

text: purity of monumental form are combined in such a way as
label: Paragraph

text: to promote exhilaration and anxiety. More than any other
label: Paragraph

text: Enlightenment architect, Boullée was obsessed with the
label: Paragraph

text: capacity of light to evoke the presence of the divine. This
label: Paragraph

text: intention is evident in the sunlit diaphanous haze that
label: Paragraph

text: illuminates the interior of his ‘Métropole’, modelled partly on
label: Paragraph

text: Ste-Geneviéve. A similar light is portrayed in the vast
label: Paragraph

text: masonry sphere of his projected cenotaph for Isaac Newton
label: Caption

text: [3], where by night a fire was suspended to represent the
label: Paragraph

text: sun, while by day it was extinguished to reveal the illusion
label: Paragraph

text: of the firmament produced by the daylight shining through
label: Paragraph

text: the sphere’s perforated walls.
label: Paragraph

text: 3 Boullée, project for a cenotaph for Isaac Newton, c. 1785. Section by ‘night’.
label: Caption

text: While Boullée’s political sentiments were solidly
label: Paragraph

text: republican, he remained obsessed with imagining the
label: Paragraph

text: monuments of some omnipotent state dedicated to the
label: Paragraph

text: worship of the Supreme Being. Unlike Ledoux, he was
label: Paragraph

text: unimpressed by the rural decentralized utopias of Morelly or
label: Paragraph

text: Jean-Jacques Rousseau. Despite this, his influence in post-
label: Paragraph

text: Revolutionary Europe was considerable, primarily through
label: Paragraph

text: the activity of his pupil Jean-Nicolas-Louis Durand, who
label: Paragraph

text: reduced his extravagant ideas to a normative and economic
label: Paragraph

text: building typology, set out in the Précis des lecons données a
label: Paragraph

text: l’Ecole Polytechnique (1802-09) [4].
label: Caption

text: 4 Durand, possible combinations and permutations of plan forms, from his
label: Caption

text: Précis, 1802-09.
label: Caption

text: After fifteen years of millennial disarray the Napoleonic
label: Paragraph

text: era required useful structures of appropriate grandeur and
label: Paragraph

text: authority, on the condition that they be achieved as cheaply
label: Paragraph

text: as possible. Durand, the first tutor in architecture at the
label: Paragraph

text: Ecole Polytechnique, sought to establish a universal building
label: Paragraph

text: methodology, an architectural counterpart to the Napoleonic
label: Paragraph

text: Code, by which economic and appropriate structures could
label: Paragraph

text: be created through the modular permutation of fixed plan
label: Paragraph

text: types and alternative elevations. Thus Boullée’s obsession
label: Paragraph

text: with vast Platonic volumes was exploited as a means to
label: Paragraph

text: achieve an appropriate character at a reasonable cost.
label: Paragraph

text: Durand’s criticism of Ste-Geneviéve, for example, with its
label: Paragraph

text: 206 columns and 612 metres (2,008 feet) of wall, involved
label: Caption

text: him in making a counter-proposal for a circular temple of
label: Paragraph

text: comparable area that would require only 112 columns and
label: Paragraph

text: 248 metres (814 feet) of wall - a considerable economy,
label: Paragraph

text: with which, according to him, one would have achieved a far
label: Paragraph

text: more impressive aura.
label: Paragraph

text: Ledoux, after his career had been terminated by the
label: Paragraph

text: Revolution, returned during his imprisonment to develop the
label: Paragraph

text: scheme of the salt works that he had built for Louis XVI at
label: Paragraph

text: Arc-et-Senans in 1773-79. He expanded the semicircular
label: Paragraph

text: form of this complex into the representational core of his
label: Paragraph

text: ideal city of Chaux [5], published in 1804 under the title
label: Paragraph

text: L’Architecture considérée sous le rapport de I’art, des
label: Caption

text: moeurs et de la législation. The semicircular salt works itself
label: Paragraph

text: (which he developed into the oval centre of his city) may be
label: Paragraph

text: seen as one of the first essays in industrial architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: inasmuch as it consciously integrated productive units with
label: Paragraph

text: workers’ housing. Each element in this physiocratic complex
label: Paragraph

text: was rendered according to its character. Thus the salt
label: Paragraph

text: evaporation sheds on the axis were high-roofed like
label: Paragraph

text: agricultural buildings and finished in smooth ashlar, with
label: Paragraph

text: rusticated dressings, while the director’s house in the centre
label: Paragraph

text: was low-roofed and pedimented, rusticated throughout and
label: Paragraph

text: embellished with Classical porticos. Here and there the walls
label: Paragraph

text: of the salt sheds and the workers’ houses were relieved by
label: Paragraph

text: grotesque ‘spouts’ of petrified water, which not only
label: Paragraph

text: symbolized the saline solution on which the enterprise was
label: Paragraph

text: based but also suggested that the productive system and
label: Paragraph

text: the labour force had an equally processal status.
label: Paragraph

text: 5 Ledoux, ideal city of Chaux, 1804.
label: Caption

text: In fictitiously developing this limited typology to include
label: Paragraph

text: all the institutions of his ideal city, Ledoux extended the
label: Paragraph

text: idea of an architectural ‘physiognomy’ to symbolize the
label: Paragraph

text: social intention of his otherwise abstract forms. The
label: Paragraph

text: meanings are established either by conventional symbols,
label: Paragraph

text: such as the fasces evoking justice and unity on the
label: Paragraph

text: courthouse, the so-called Pacifére, or by isomorphism, as in
label: Paragraph

text: the case of the Oikema, planned in the shape of a penis.
label: Paragraph

text: This last structure was dedicated to libertinage, whose
label: Paragraph

text: curious social purpose was to induce virtue through sexual
label: Paragraph

text: satiety.
label: Paragraph

text: A whole world separates Durand’s rational permutation
label: Paragraph

text: of received Classical elements from Ledoux’s arbitrary but
label: Paragraph

text: purgative reconstitution of fragmented Classical parts
label: Title

text: demonstrated in the toll-gates that he designed for Paris
label: Paragraph

text: between 1785 and 1789. These barriéres were just as
label: Paragraph

text: disconnected from the culture of their time as the idealized
label: Paragraph

text: institutions of Chaux. With their gradual demolition after
label: Paragraph

text: 1789 they suffered the same fate as the abstract and
label: Paragraph

text: unpopular customs boundary that they were intended to
label: Paragraph

text: administer, the Enceinte des Fermiers Généraux, of which it
label: Paragraph

text: was said, ‘Le mur murant Paris rend Paris murmurant.’
label: Paragraph

text: After the Revolution, the evolution of Neo-Classicism was
label: Paragraph

text: largely inseparable from the need to accommodate the new
label: Paragraph

text: institutions of bourgeois society and to represent the
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of the new republican state. That these forces
label: Paragraph

text: were initially resolved in the compromise of constitutional
label: Paragraph

text: monarchy hardly detracted from the role that Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Classicism played in the formation of the bourgeois
label: Paragraph

text: imperialist style. The creation of Napoleon’s ‘Style Empire’
label: Paragraph

text: in Paris and Frederick Il’s Francophile ‘Kulturnation’ in Berlin
label: Paragraph

text: are but separate manifestations of the same cultural
label: Paragraph

text: tendency. The former made an eclectic use of antique
label: Paragraph

text: motifs, be they Roman, Greek or Egyptian, to create the
label: Paragraph

text: instant heritage of a republican dynasty - a style that
label: Paragraph

text: revealed itself significantly in the theatrical tented interiors
label: Paragraph

text: of the Napoleonic campaigns and in the solid Roman
label: Title

text: embellishments of the capital city, such as Percier and
label: Paragraph

text: Fontaine’s Rue de Rivoli and Arc du Carrousel and Gondoin’s
label: Caption

text: Place Vendéme column dedicated to the Grande Armée. In
label: Caption

text: Germany the tendency was first manifested in Carl Gotthard
label: Paragraph

text: Langhans’s Brandenburg Gate, built as the western entry to
label: Paragraph

text: Berlin in 1793, and in Friedrich Gilly’s design for a
label: Paragraph

text: monument to Frederick the Great, of 1797. Ledoux’s
label: Caption

text: primary forms inspired Gilly to emulate the severity of the
label: Paragraph

text: Doric, thereby echoing the ‘archaic’ power of the Sturm und
label: Paragraph

text: Drang movement in German literature. Like his
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary Friedrich Weinbrenner, he projected a spartan
label: Paragraph

text: Ur-civilization of high moral value, with which to celebrate
label: Paragraph

text: the myth of the ideal Prussian state. His remarkable
label: Paragraph

text: monument would have taken the form of an artificial
label: Paragraph

text: acropolis on the Leipzigerplatz. This temenos would have
label: Paragraph

text: been entered from Potsdam through a squat triumphal arch
label: Paragraph

text: capped by a quadriga.
label: Paragraph

text: Gilly’s colleague and successor, the Prussian architect
label: Paragraph

text: Karl Friedrich Schinkel, acquired his early enthusiasm for
label: Paragraph

text: Gothic not from Berlin or Paris, but from his own first-hand
label: Paragraph

text: experience of Italian cathedrals. Yet after the defeat of
label: Paragraph

text: Napoleon in 1815, this Romantic taste was largely eclipsed
label: Paragraph

text: by the need to find an appropriate expression for the
label: Paragraph

text: triumph of Prussian nationalism. The combination of political
label: Paragraph

text: idealism and military prowess seems to have demanded a
label: Paragraph

text: return to the Classic. In any event this was the style that
label: Paragraph

text: linked Schinkel not only to Gilly but also to Durand, in the
label: Paragraph

text: creation of his masterpieces in Berlin: his Neue Wache of
label: Paragraph

text: 1816, his Schauspielhaus of 1821 and his Altes Museum of
label: Paragraph

text: 1830 [6]. While both the guard-house and the theatre show
label: Paragraph

text: characteristic features of Schinkel’s mature style, the
label: Paragraph

text: massive corners of the one and the mullioned wings of the
label: Paragraph

text: other, the influence of Durand is most clearly revealed in
label: Paragraph

text: the museum, which is a prototypical museum plan taken
label: Paragraph

text: from the Précis and split in half - a transformation in which
label: Paragraph

text: the central rotunda, peristyle and courtyards are retained
label: Paragraph

text: and the side wings eliminated (see p. 269). While the wide
label: Paragraph

text: entry steps, the peristyle and the eagles and Dioscuri on the
label: Caption

text: roof symbolized the cultural aspirations of the Prussian
label: Paragraph

text: state, Schinkel departed from the typological and
label: Paragraph

text: representational methods of Durand to create a spatial
label: Paragraph

text: articulation of extraordinary delicacy and power, as the wide
label: Paragraph

text: peristyle gives way to a narrow portico containing a
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrical entry stair and its mezzanine (an arrangement
label: Paragraph

text: which would be remembered by Mies van der Rohe).
label: Paragraph

text: 6 Schinkel, Altes Museum, Berlin, 1828-30.
label: Caption

text: The main line of Blondel’s Neo-Classicism was continued
label: Paragraph

text: in the mid-19th century in the career of Henri Labrouste,
label: Paragraph

text: who had studied at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts (the institution
label: Paragraph

text: that succeeded the Académie Royale d’Architecture after
label: Paragraph

text: the Revolution) with Antoine-Laurent-Thomas Vaudoyer, who
label: Paragraph

text: had been a pupil of Peyre. After winning the Prix de Rome in
label: Paragraph

text: 1824 Labrouste spent the next five years at the French
label: Paragraph

text: Academy, devoting much of his time in Italy to a study of
label: Paragraph

text: the Greek temples at Paestum. Inspired by the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Jakob-Ignaz Hittorff, Labrouste was among the first to argue
label: Paragraph

text: that such structures had originally been brightly coloured.
label: Paragraph

text: This, and his insistence on the primacy of structure and on
label: Paragraph

text: the derivation of all ornament from construction, brought
label: Paragraph

text: him into conflict with the authorities after the opening of his
label: Paragraph

text: own atelier in 1830.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1840 Labrouste was named architect of the
label: Paragraph

text: Bibliotheque Ste-Geneviéve in Paris which had been created
label: Paragraph

text: to house part of the library impounded by the French state
label: Paragraph

text: in 1789. Based apparently on Boullée’s project for a library
label: Paragraph

text: in the Palais Mazarin, of 1785, Labrouste’s design consists of
label: Paragraph

text: a perimeter wall of books enclosing a rectilinear space and
label: Paragraph

text: supporting an iron-framed, barrel-vaulted roof which is
label: Paragraph

text: divided into two halves and further supported in the centre
label: Paragraph

text: of the space by a line of iron columns.
label: Paragraph

text: Such Structural Rationalism was further refined in the
label: Paragraph

text: main reading room and book stack that Labrouste built for
label: Caption

text: the Bibliotheque Nationale in 1860-68 [7]. This complex,
label: Paragraph

text: inserted into the courtyard of the Palais Mazarin, consists of
label: Paragraph

text: a reading room covered by an iron and glass roof carried on
label: Caption

text: sixteen cast-iron columns and a multi-storey wrought- and
label: Caption

text: cast-iron book stack. Dispensing with the last trace of
label: Caption

text: historicism, Labrouste designed the latter as a top-lit cage,
label: Paragraph

text: in which light filters down through iron landings from the
label: Paragraph

text: roof to the lowest floor. Although this solution was derived
label: Paragraph

text: from Sydney Smirke’s cast-iron reading room and stack built
label: Caption

text: in the courtyard of Robert Smirke’s Neo-Classical British
label: Caption

text: Museum in 1854, the precise form of its execution implied a
label: Paragraph

text: new aesthetic whose potential was not to be realized until
label: Paragraph

text: the Constructivist work of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: oS
label: Title

text: 7 Labrouste, book stack of the Bibliotheque Nationale, Paris, 1860-68.
label: Caption

text: The middle of the 19th century saw the Neo-Classical
label: Paragraph

text: heritage divided between two closely related lines of
label: Paragraph

text: development: the Structural Classicism of Labrouste and the
label: Title

text: Romantic Classicism of Schinkel. Both ‘schools’ were
label: Paragraph

text: confronted by the same 19th-century proliferation of new
label: Paragraph

text: institutions and had to respond equally to the task of
label: Paragraph

text: creating new building types. They differed largely in the
label: Paragraph

text: manner in which they achieved these representative
label: Paragraph

text: qualities: the Structural Classicists tended to emphasize
label: Paragraph

text: structure - the line of Cordemoy, Laugier and Soufflot; while
label: Paragraph

text: the Romantic Classicists tended to stress the physiognomic
label: Paragraph

text: character of the form itself - the line of Ledoux, Boullée and
label: Paragraph

text: Gilly. Where one ‘school’ seems to have concentrated on
label: Paragraph

text: such types as prisons, hospitals and railway stations, in the
label: Paragraph

text: work of men like Emile-Jacques Gilbert and Francois-
label: Paragraph

text: Alexandre Duquesney (designer of the Gare de I’Est, Paris,
label: Caption

text: in 1852), the other addressed itself more to representational
label: Paragraph

text: structures, such as the university museum and library of
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Robert Cockerell in England or the more grandiose
label: Title

text: monuments erected by Leo von Klenze in Germany - above
label: Caption

text: all the latter’s highly Romantic Walhalla, completed at
label: Paragraph

text: Regensburg in 1842.
label: Paragraph

text: In terms of theory, Structural Classicism began with
label: Paragraph

text: Rondelet’s Traité de /’art de batir (1802) and culminated at
label: Paragraph

text: the end of the century in the writing of the engineer
label: Paragraph

text: Auguste Choisy, particularly his Histoire de I’architecture
label: Paragraph

text: (1899). For Choisy the essence of architecture is
label: Paragraph

text: construction, and all stylistic transformations are merely the
label: Paragraph

text: logical consequence of technical development: ‘To parade
label: Title

text: your Art Nouveau is to ignore the whole teaching of history.
label: Paragraph

text: Not so did the great styles of the past come into being. It
label: Paragraph

text: was in the suggestion of construction that the architect of
label: Paragraph

text: the great artistic ages found his truest inspiration.’ Choisy
label: Paragraph

text: illustrated the structural determination of his Histoire with
label: Paragraph

text: axonometric projections [8] which revealed the essence of a
label: Paragraph

text: type of form in a single graphic image, comprising plan,
label: Paragraph

text: section and elevation. As Reyner Banham has observed,
label: Paragraph

text: these objective illustrations reduce the architecture that
label: Paragraph

text: they represent to pure abstraction, and it was this, plus the
label: Paragraph

text: amount of the information they synthesized, that endeared
label: Paragraph

text: them to the pioneers of the Modern Movement after the turn
label: Title

text: of the century.
label: Paragraph

text: 8 Choisy, axonometric projection of part of the Panthéon, Paris (fig. 2), from his
label: Caption

text: Histoire de l’architecture, 1899.
label: Caption

text: The emphasis that Choisy’s history placed on Greek and
label: Paragraph

text: Gothic architecture was a late 19th-century rationalization
label: Paragraph

text: of that Graeco-Gothic ideal which had first been formulated
label: Paragraph

text: over a century before by Cordemoy. This 18th-century
label: Paragraph

text: projection of Gothic structure into Classical syntax found its
label: Paragraph

text: parallel in Choisy’s characterization of the Doric as wooden
label: Paragraph

text: structure transposed into masonry. Just such a transposition
label: Paragraph

text: was to be practised by Choisy’s disciple, Auguste Perret,
label: Paragraph

text: who insisted on detailing his reinforced-concrete structures
label: Paragraph

text: after the manner of traditional wood framing.
label: Paragraph

text: A Structural Rationalist to the core, Choisy was
label: Paragraph

text: nonetheless capable of responding to the Romantic
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility when he wrote of the Acropolis: ‘The Greeks
label: Paragraph

text: never visualized a building without the site that framed it
label: Paragraph

text: and the other buildings that surrounded it... each
label: Paragraph

text: architectural motif, on its own, is symmetrical, but every
label: Paragraph

text: group is treated like a landscape where the masses alone
label: Paragraph

text: balance out.’
label: Paragraph

text: Such a Picturesque notion of partially symmetrical
label: Paragraph

text: balance would have been as foreign to the teaching of the
label: Paragraph

text: Beaux-Arts as it was to the polytechnical approach of
label: Paragraph

text: Durand. Certainly it would have had a limited appeal for
label: Paragraph

text: Julien Guadet, who sought, in his lecture course E/éments et
label: Paragraph

text: théorie de I’architecture (1902), to establish a normative
label: Paragraph

text: approach to the composition of structures from technically
label: Title

text: up-to-date elements, arranged as far as possible according
label: Paragraph

text: to the tradition of axial composition. It was through
label: Paragraph

text: Guadet’s teaching at the Beaux-Arts, and his influence on
label: Paragraph

text: his pupils Auguste Perret and Tony Garnier, that the
label: Paragraph

text: principles of Classical ‘Elementarist’ composition were
label: Paragraph

text: handed down to the pioneer architects of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 2
label: Title

text: Territorial
label: Title

text: Transformations: Urban
label: Title

text: Developments 1800-1909
label: Title

text: [With] the development of increasingly abstract means of
label: Paragraph

text: communication the continuity of rooted communication is
label: Paragraph

text: replaced by new systems which continue to perfect
label: Paragraph

text: themselves throughout the 19th century, allowing the
label: Paragraph

text: population greater mobility and providing information that is
label: Paragraph

text: more precisely synchronized with the accelerating rhythm of
label: Paragraph

text: history. Railway, daily press and telegraph will gradually
label: Paragraph

text: supplant space in its previous informative and formative
label: Paragraph

text: role.
label: Paragraph

text: Francoise Choay
label: Title

text: The Modern City: Planning in the 19th Century, 19691
label: Caption

text: The finite city, as it had come into being in Europe over the
label: Paragraph

text: previous 500 years, was totally transformed in the space of
label: Paragraph

text: a century by the interaction of a number of unprecedented
label: Paragraph

text: technical and socio-economic forces, many of which first
label: Paragraph

text: emerged in England during the second half of the 18th
label: Paragraph

text: century. Prominent among them from a technical point of
label: Paragraph

text: view must be counted such innovations as Abraham Darby’s
label: Paragraph

text: mass production of cast-iron rails, from 1767, and Jethro
label: Paragraph

text: Tull’s seed-drill cultivation of crops in rows, generally
label: Paragraph

text: adopted after 1731. Where Darby’s invention led to Henry
label: Paragraph

text: Cort’s development of the puddling process for the
label: Paragraph

text: simplified conversion of cast to wrought iron in 1784, Tull’s
label: Paragraph

text: drill was essential to the perfection of Charles Townshend’s
label: Paragraph

text: four-crop rotational system - the principle of ‘high farming’
label: Paragraph

text: that became general towards the end of the century.
label: Paragraph

text: Such productive innovations had multiple repercussions.
label: Paragraph

text: In the case of metallurgy, English iron production increased
label: Paragraph

text: forty-fold between 1750 and 1850 (rising to two million tons
label: Paragraph

text: a year by 1850); in the case of agriculture, after the
label: Paragraph

text: Enclosures Act of 1771 inefficient husbandry was replaced
label: Paragraph

text: by the four-crop system. Where the one was boosted by the
label: Paragraph

text: Napoleonic Wars, the other was motivated by the need to
label: Paragraph

text: feed a rapidly growing industrial population.
label: Paragraph

text: At the same time the cottage-weaving industry, which
label: Paragraph

text: had helped to sustain the agrarian economy of the first half
label: Paragraph

text: of the 18th century, was rapidly changed, first by James
label: Paragraph

text: Hargreaves’s spinning jenny of 1764, which greatly
label: Paragraph

text: increased the individual’s spinning capacity, and then by
label: Paragraph

text: Edmund Cartwright’s steam-powered loom, first used for
label: Paragraph

text: factory production in 1784. This last event not only
label: Paragraph

text: established textile production as a large-scale industry, but
label: Paragraph

text: also led immediately to the invention of the multistorey
label: Paragraph

text: fireproof mill. Thus traditional textile manufacturing was
label: Paragraph

text: forced to abandon its predominantly rural base and to
label: Paragraph

text: concentrate both labour and plant, first next to
label: Paragraph

text: watercourses and then, with the advent of steam power,
label: Paragraph

text: close to coal deposits. With 24,000 power looms in
label: Paragraph

text: production by 1820, the English mill town was already an
label: Paragraph

text: established fact.
label: Paragraph

text: This process of uprooting - enracinement, as Simone Weil
label: Paragraph

text: has called it - was further accelerated by the use of steam
label: Paragraph

text: traction for transport. Richard Trevithick first demonstrated
label: Paragraph

text: the locomotive on cast-iron rails in 1804. The opening of the
label: Paragraph

text: first public rail service between Stockton and Darlington in
label: Caption

text: 1825 was followed by the rapid development of a
label: Paragraph

text: completely new infrastructure, Britain having some 10,000
label: Paragraph

text: miles of track in place by 1860. The advent of long-distance
label: Paragraph

text: steam navigation after 1865 greatly increased European
label: Paragraph

text: migration to the Americas, Africa and Australia. While this
label: Paragraph

text: migration brought the populations needed to expand the
label: Paragraph

text: economy of colonial terrirories and to fill the growing grid-
label: Paragraph

text: plan cities of the New World, the military, political and
label: Title

text: economic obsolescence of the traditional European walled
label: Title

text: city led, after the liberal-national revolutions of 1848, to the
label: Paragraph

text: wholesale demolition of ramparts and to the extension of
label: Paragraph

text: the formerly finite city into its already burgeoning suburbs.
label: Paragraph

text: These general developments, accompanied by a sudden
label: Paragraph

text: drop in mortality due to improved standards in nutrition and
label: Paragraph

text: medical techniques, gave rise to unprecedented urban
label: Paragraph

text: concentrations, first in England and then, at differing rates
label: Paragraph

text: of growth, throughout the developing world. Manchester’s
label: Paragraph

text: population grew eight-fold in the course of the century, from
label: Paragraph

text: 75,000 in 1801 to 600,000 by 1901, as compared to
label: Paragraph

text: London's six-fold increase over the same period, from
label: Paragraph

text: around one million in 1801 to six and a half million by the
label: Paragraph

text: turn of the century. Paris grew at a comparable rate but had
label: Paragraph

text: a more modest beginning, expanding from 500,000 in 1801
label: Paragraph

text: to 3 million by 1901. Even these six- to eight-fold increases
label: Paragraph

text: are modest compared with New York’s growth over the
label: Paragraph

text: same period. New York was first laid out as a gridded city in
label: Paragraph

text: 1811, in accordance with the Commissioners’ Plan of that
label: Paragraph

text: year, and grew from its 1801 population of 33,000 to
label: Paragraph

text: 500,000 by 1850 and 3% million by 1901. Chicago grew at
label: Paragraph

text: an even more astronomical rate, rising from 300 people at
label: Paragraph

text: the time of Thompson’s grid of 1833 to around 30,000 (of
label: Paragraph

text: whom something under half had been born in the States) by
label: Paragraph

text: 1850, and going on to become a city of two million by the
label: Paragraph

text: turn of the century.
label: Paragraph

text: The accommodation of such volatile growth led to the
label: Paragraph

text: transformation of old neighbourhoods into slums, and also
label: Paragraph

text: to jerry-built new houses and tenements whose main
label: Paragraph

text: purpose, given the general lack of municipal transport, was
label: Paragraph

text: to provide as cheaply as possible the maximum amount of
label: Paragraph

text: rudimentary shelter within walking distance of the centres
label: Caption

text: of production. Naturally such congested developments had
label: Paragraph

text: inadequate standards of light, ventilation and open space
label: Title

text: and poor sanitary facilities, such as communal outside
label: Paragraph

text: lavatories, wash-houses and refuse storage. With primitive
label: Paragraph

text: drainage and inadequate maintenance, this pattern could
label: Paragraph

text: lead to the piling up of excrement and garbage and to
label: Paragraph

text: flooding, and these conditions naturally provoked a high
label: Paragraph

text: incidence of disease - first tuberculosis and then, more
label: Paragraph

text: alarmingly for the authorities, a number of outbreaks of
label: Paragraph

text: cholera in both England and Continental Europe in the
label: Paragraph

text: These epidemics had the effect of precipitating health
label: Paragraph

text: reform and of bringing about some of the earliest legislation
label: Title

text: governing the construction and maintenance of dense
label: Title

text: conurbations. In 1833 the London authorities instructed the
label: Paragraph

text: Poor Law Commission, headed by Edwin Chadwick, to make
label: Paragraph

text: enquiries about the origins of a cholera outbreak in
label: Paragraph

text: Whitechapel. This led to Chadwick’s report, An Inquiry into
label: Paragraph

text: the Sanitary Conditions of the Labouring Population in Great
label: Title

text: Britain (1842), to the Royal Commission on the State of
label: Paragraph

text: Large Towns and Populous Districts of 1844 and, eventually,
label: Paragraph

text: to the Public Health Act of 1848. This Act, in addition to
label: Paragraph

text: others, made local authorities legally responsible for
label: Paragraph

text: sewerage, refuse collection, water supply, roads, the
label: Title

text: inspection of slaughter-houses and the burial of the dead.
label: Paragraph

text: Similar provisions were to occupy Haussmann during the
label: Paragraph

text: rebuilding of Paris between 1853 and 1870.
label: Paragraph

text: The result of this legislation in England was to make
label: Paragraph

text: society vaguely aware of the need to upgrade working-class
label: Paragraph

text: housing; but as to the models and means by which this
label: Paragraph

text: should be achieved there was little initial agreement.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, the Chadwick-inspired Society for Improving
label: Paragraph

text: the Conditions of the Labouring Classes sponsored the
label: Paragraph

text: erection of the first working-class flats in London in 1844 to
label: Paragraph

text: the design of the architect Henry Roberts, and followed this
label: Paragraph

text: resolute beginning with its Streatham Street flats of 1848-
label: Paragraph

text: 50 and a prototypical two-storey worker's cottage
label: Caption

text: containing four flats, again to the design of Roberts, for the
label: Paragraph

text: Great Exhibition of 1851. This generic model for the
label: Paragraph

text: stacking of apartments in pairs around a common staircase
label: Paragraph

text: was to influence the planning of working-class housing for
label: Paragraph

text: the rest of the century.
label: Paragraph

text: The American-backed philanthropic Peabody Trust and
label: Paragraph

text: various English benevolent societies and local authorities
label: Title

text: attempted, after 1864, to upgrade the quality of working-
label: Paragraph

text: class housing, but little of significance was achieved until
label: Paragraph

text: the slum clearance Acts of 1868 and 1875 and the Housing
label: Title

text: of the Working Classes Act of 1890, under which local
label: Paragraph

text: authorities were required to provide public housing. In 1893,
label: Paragraph

text: when the London County Council (established in 1890)
label: Title

text: began to build workers’ flats under the auspices of this Act,
label: Paragraph

text: its Architects’ Department made a remarkable effort to
label: Paragraph

text: deinstitutionalize the image of such housing by adapting the
label: Paragraph

text: Arts and Crafts domestic style (see p. 53) to the realization
label: Paragraph

text: of six-storey blocks of flats. Typical of this development is
label: Paragraph

text: the Millbank Estate, begun in 1897.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout the 19th century the effort of industry to take
label: Paragraph

text: care of its own assumed many forms, from the ‘model’ mill,
label: Paragraph

text: railway and factory towns to projected utopian communities
label: Title

text: intended as prototypes for some future enlightened state.
label: Paragraph

text: Among those who manifested an early concern for
label: Paragraph

text: integrated industrial settlements one must acknowledge
label: Title

text: Robert Owen, whose New Lanark in Scotland (1815) was
label: Paragraph

text: designed as a pioneering institution of the co-operative
label: Paragraph

text: movement, and Sir Titus Salt, whose Saltaire, near Bradford
label: Paragraph

text: in Yorkshire (founded in 1850), was a paternalistic mill town,
label: Paragraph

text: complete with traditional urban institutions such as a
label: Paragraph

text: church, an infirmary, a secondary school, public baths,
label: Paragraph

text: almshouses and a park.
label: Paragraph

text: Neither of these realizations could match in scope and
label: Paragraph

text: liberating potential the radical vision of Charles Fourier’s
label: Paragraph

text: ‘new industrial world’, as formulated in his essay of that title
label: Paragraph

text: (Le Nouveau Monde industriel) published in 1829. Fourier’s
label: Paragraph

text: non-repressive society was to depend on the establishment
label: Paragraph

text: of ideal communities or ‘phalanxes’, housed in pha/anstéres,
label: Paragraph

text: where people were to be related in accordance with
label: Paragraph

text: Fourier’s psychological principle of ‘passional attraction’.
label: Paragraph

text: Since the phalanstery was projected as being in open
label: Paragraph

text: country, its economy was to be predominantly agricultural,
label: Paragraph

text: supplemented by light manufacturing. In his earliest
label: Paragraph

text: writings Fourier outlined the physical attributes of his
label: Paragraph

text: communal settlement; it was modelled on the layout of
label: Paragraph

text: Versailles, its central wing being given over to public
label: Paragraph

text: functions (dining hall, library, winter-garden, etc.), while its
label: Paragraph

text: side wings were devoted to the workshops and the
label: Paragraph

text: caravanseray. In his Traité de l'association domestique
label: Paragraph

text: agricole (1822) Fourier wrote of the phalanstery as being a
label: Paragraph

text: miniature town whose streets would have the advantage of
label: Paragraph

text: not being exposed to the weather. He saw it as a structure
label: Paragraph

text: whose grandeur, if generally adopted, would replace the
label: Paragraph

text: petit-bourgeois squalor of the small individual free-standing
label: Paragraph

text: houses that were, by then, already filling the outer
label: Paragraph

text: interstices of towns.
label: Paragraph

text: Fourier’s disciple Victor Considérant, writing in 1838,
label: Paragraph

text: mixed the metaphor of Versailles with that of the steamship
label: Paragraph

text: and questioned whether it was ‘easier to house 1,800 men
label: Paragraph

text: right in the middle of the ocean, six hundred leagues from
label: Paragraph

text: every shore, ... than to house in a unitary construction some
label: Paragraph

text: 1,800 good peasants in the heart of Champagne or firmly on
label: Caption

text: the soil of Beauce?’ This particular conflation of commune
label: Paragraph

text: and ship was to be returned to by Le Corbusier, over a
label: Paragraph

text: century later, in his self-contained commune or Unité
label: Paragraph

text: d’Habitation, realized with Fourierist overtones at Marseilles
label: Paragraph

text: The enduring importance of Fourier lies in his radical
label: Paragraph

text: criticism of industrialized production and social organization,
label: Paragraph

text: for, despite numerous attempts to create phalansteries in
label: Paragraph

text: both Europe and America, his new industrial world was fated
label: Paragraph

text: to remain a dream. Its closest realization was the Familistére
label: Paragraph

text: [9], built by the industrialist Jean-Baptiste André Godin next
label: Caption

text: to his factory at Guise in 1859-70. This complex comprised
label: Paragraph

text: three residential blocks, a créche, a kindergarten, a theatre,
label: Paragraph

text: schools, public baths and a laundry. Each residential block
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed a top-lit central courtyard which took the place of
label: Paragraph

text: the elevated corridor streets of the phalanstery. In his book
label: Paragraph

text: Solutions sociales (1870) Godin absorbed the more radical
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of Fourierism by showing how the system could be
label: Paragraph

text: adapted to co-operative family living without resorting to
label: Paragraph

text: the eccentric theories of ‘passional attraction’.
label: Paragraph

text: 9 Godin, Familistére, Guise, 1859-70.
label: Caption

text: Aside from accommodating the labouring masses,
label: Paragraph

text: London’s 18th-century matrix of streets and squares was
label: Paragraph

text: extended throughout the 19th century to meet the
label: Paragraph

text: residential requirements of a growing urban middle class.
label: Paragraph

text: No longer satisfied, however, with the scale and texture of
label: Paragraph

text: the occasional green square - delimited on all sides by
label: Paragraph

text: streets and continuous terraces - the English Park
label: Title

text: Movement, founded by the gardener Humphry Repton,
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to project the ‘landscaped country estate’ into
label: Paragraph

text: the city. Repton himself succeeded in demonstrating this, in
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration with the architect John Nash, in their layout of
label: Paragraph

text: Regent’s Park in London (1812-27). After the victory over
label: Paragraph

text: Napoleon in 1815, the proposed development enclosing the
label: Paragraph

text: park was augmented, under royal patronage, by a
label: Paragraph

text: continuous ‘display’ facade, penetrating into the existing
label: Paragraph

text: urban fabric and extending as a more or less uninterrupted
label: Paragraph

text: ribbon of terraced accommodation from the aristocratic
label: Caption

text: vistas of Regent’s Park in the north to the palatial urbanity
label: Paragraph

text: of St James’s Park and Carlton House Terrace in the south.
label: Caption

text: The squirearchical concept of the Neo-Classical country
label: Paragraph

text: house set in an irregular landscape (an image derived from
label: Paragraph

text: the Picturesque work of Capability Brown and Uvedale Price)
label: Title

text: was thus translated by Nash to the provision of terraced
label: Paragraph

text: housing on the perimeter of an urban park. This model was
label: Paragraph

text: first systematically adapted to general use by Sir Joseph
label: Paragraph

text: Paxton, at Birkenhead Park, built outside Liverpool in 1844.
label: Caption

text: Frederick Law Olmsted’s Central Park in New York,
label: Caption

text: inaugurated in 1857, was directly influenced by Paxton’s
label: Paragraph

text: example, even down to its separation of carriage traffic from
label: Paragraph

text: pedestrians. The concept received its final elaboration in the
label: Paragraph

text: Parisian parks created by Jean Charles Adolphe Alphand,
label: Paragraph

text: where the circulation system totally dictated the manner in
label: Paragraph

text: which the park was to be used. With Alphand, the park
label: Paragraph

text: becomes a civilizing influence for the newly urbanized
label: Paragraph

text: masses.
label: Paragraph

text: The irregular lake that Nash created in St James’s Park in
label: Paragraph

text: 1828 out of the rectangular basin that the Mollet brothers
label: Paragraph

text: had made in 1662 may be taken to symbolize the victory of
label: Paragraph

text: the English Picturesque over the French Cartesian
label: Title

text: conception of landscape dating from the 17th century. The
label: Paragraph

text: French, who had hitherto regarded greenery as another
label: Paragraph

text: order of architecture and had rendered their avenues as
label: Paragraph

text: colonnades of trees, were to find the romantic appeal of
label: Paragraph

text: Repton’s irregular landscape irresistible. After the Revolution
label: Paragraph

text: they remodelled their aristocratic parks into Picturesque
label: Paragraph

text: sequences.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet, for all the power of the Picturesque, the French
label: Paragraph

text: impulse towards rationality remained, first in the
label: Paragraph

text: percements (wholesale demolition in a straight line to
label: Paragraph

text: create an entirely new street) of the Artists’ Plan for Paris,
label: Paragraph

text: drawn up in 1793 by a committee of revolutionary artists
label: Paragraph

text: under the leadership of the painter Jacques-Louis David; and
label: Paragraph

text: then in Napoleon’s arcaded Rue de Rivoli, built after 1806 to
label: Paragraph

text: the designs of Percier and Fontaine. Where the Rue de Rivoli
label: Caption

text: was to serve as the architectural model not only for Nash’s
label: Paragraph

text: Regent Street but also for the scenographic ‘facade’ of
label: Paragraph

text: Second Empire Paris, the Artists’ Plan demonstrated the
label: Paragraph

text: instrumental strategy of the a//ée, which was to become the
label: Paragraph

text: prime tool for the rebuilding of Paris under Napoleon Ill.
label: Paragraph

text: Napoleon Ill and Baron Georges Haussmann left their
label: Paragraph

text: indelible mark not only on Paris [10] but also on a number
label: Paragraph

text: of major cities in France and Central Europe which
label: Paragraph

text: underwent Haussmann-like regularizations throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: second half of the century. Their influence is even present in
label: Paragraph

text: Daniel Burnham's 1909 plan for the gridded city of Chicago,
label: Paragraph

text: of which Burnham wrote: ‘The task which Haussmann
label: Paragraph

text: accomplished for Paris corresponds with the work which
label: Paragraph

text: must be done for Chicago in order to overcome the
label: Paragraph

text: intolerable conditions which invariably arise from a rapid
label: Paragraph

text: growth in population.’
label: Paragraph

text: 10 The regularization of Paris: streets cut by Haussmann are shown in black.
label: Caption

text: In 1853 Haussmann, as the newly appointed Prefect for
label: Paragraph

text: the Seine, saw these conditions in Paris as being polluted
label: Paragraph

text: water supply, lack of an adequate sewer system, insufficient
label: Paragraph

text: open space for both cemeteries and parks, large areas of
label: Paragraph

text: squalid housing and last, but by no means least, congested
label: Paragraph

text: circulation. Of these, the first two were undoubtedly the
label: Paragraph

text: most critical for the everyday welfare of the population. As a
label: Paragraph

text: consequence of drawing the bulk of its water from the
label: Paragraph

text: Seine, which also served as the main collector sewer, Paris
label: Paragraph

text: had suffered two serious outbreaks of cholera in the first
label: Paragraph

text: half of the century. At the same time, the existing street
label: Paragraph

text: system was no longer adequate for the administrative
label: Paragraph

text: centre of an expanding capitalist economy. Under the brief
label: Paragraph

text: autocracy of Napoleon IIl Haussmann’s radical solution to
label: Paragraph

text: the physical aspect of this complex problem was percement.
label: Paragraph

text: His broad purpose was, as Francoise Choay has written, ‘to
label: Paragraph

text: give unity and transform into an operative whole the “huge
label: Paragraph

text: consumer market, the immense workshop” of the Parisian
label: Paragraph

text: agglomerate’. Although the Artists’ Plan of 1793 and before
label: Paragraph

text: that Pierre Patte’s plan of 1765 had clearly anticipated the
label: Paragraph

text: axial and focal structure of Haussmann’s Paris, there is, as
label: Paragraph

text: Choay points out, a discernible shift in the actual location of
label: Paragraph

text: the axes, from a city organized around traditional quartiers,
label: Paragraph

text: as in the plan made under David, to a metropolis united by
label: Paragraph

text: the ‘fever of capitalism’.
label: Paragraph

text: Saint-Simonian economists and technocrats, mostly from
label: Paragraph

text: the Ecole Polytechnique, influenced Napoleon Ill’s views as
label: Paragraph

text: to the economic means and the systematic ends to be
label: Paragraph

text: adopted in the rebuilding of Paris, emphasizing the
label: Paragraph

text: importance of rapid and efficient systems of
label: Paragraph

text: communication. Haussmann converted Paris into a regional
label: Paragraph

text: metropolis, cutting through its existing fabric with streets
label: Paragraph

text: whose purpose was to link opposing cardinal points and
label: Paragraph

text: districts, across the traditional barrier of the Seine. He gave
label: Paragraph

text: top priority to the creation of more substantial north-south
label: Paragraph

text: and east-west axes, to the building of the Boulevard de
label: Paragraph

text: Sébastopol and the easterly extension of the Rue de Rivoli.
label: Paragraph

text: This basic cross, which served the main railway termini to
label: Paragraph

text: the north and south, was encircled by a ‘ring’ boulevard
label: Paragraph

text: which in turn was tied into Haussmann’s major traffic
label: Paragraph

text: distributor, his Etoile complex built around Chalgrin’s Arc de
label: Paragraph

text: Triomphe.
label: Paragraph

text: During Haussmann’s tenure the city of Paris built some
label: Paragraph

text: 137 kilometres (85 miles) of new boulevards, which were
label: Paragraph

text: considerably wider, more thickly lined with trees and better
label: Paragraph

text: lit than the 536 kilometres (333 miles) of old thoroughfare
label: Paragraph

text: they replaced. With all this came standard residential plan
label: Paragraph

text: types and regularized facades, and equally standard
label: Paragraph

text: systems of street furniture - the pisso/rs, benches, shelters,
label: Paragraph

text: kiosks, clocks, lamp-posts, signs, etc., designed by
label: Caption

text: Haussmann’s engineers Eugéne Belgrand and Alphand. This
label: Paragraph

text: entire system was ‘ventilated’ whenever possible by large
label: Paragraph

text: areas of public open space, such as the Bois de Boulogne
label: Paragraph

text: and the Bois de Vincennes. In addition, new cemeteries and
label: Paragraph

text: many small parks, such as the Parc des Buttes Chaumont
label: Paragraph

text: and the Parc Monceau, were either created or upgraded
label: Paragraph

text: within the extended boundaries of the city. Above all, there
label: Paragraph

text: was an adequate sewer system and fresh water piped into
label: Paragraph

text: the city from the Dhuis valley. In achieving such a
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensive plan, Haussmann, the apolitical
label: Caption

text: administrator par excellence, refused to accept the political
label: Paragraph

text: logic of the régime he served. He was finally broken by an
label: Paragraph

text: ambivalent bourgeoisie, who throughout his tenure
label: Paragraph

text: supported his ‘profitable improvements’ while at the same
label: Paragraph

text: time defending their proprietorial rights against his
label: Paragraph

text: intervention.
label: Paragraph

text: Prior to the collapse of the Second Empire, the principle
label: Paragraph

text: of ‘regularization’ was already being practised outside Paris,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly in Vienna, where the replacement of demolished
label: Paragraph

text: fortifications by a display boulevard was taken to its logical
label: Paragraph

text: extreme in the ostentatious Ringstrasse, built around the
label: Paragraph

text: old centre between 1858 and 1914. The free-standing
label: Caption

text: monuments of this ‘open’ city expansion, structured around
label: Paragraph

text: a cranked thoroughfare of enormous width, provoked the
label: Paragraph

text: critical reaction of the architect Camillo Sitte, who in his
label: Paragraph

text: influential Der Stadtebau nach seinen kdnsterlerischen
label: Title

text: Grundsatzen (City Planning According to Artistic Principles)
label: Title

text: of 1889 argued for the enclosure of the major Ringstrasse
label: Paragraph

text: monuments by buildings and arcades. Sitte’s remedial
label: Caption

text: concern cannot be better characterized than in his critical
label: Paragraph

text: comparison of the traffic-ridden ‘open’ city of the late 19th
label: Paragraph

text: century with the tranquillity of the medieval or Renaissance
label: Title

text: urban core:
label: Title

text: During the Middle Ages and Renaissance public squares
label: Paragraph

text: were often used for practical purposes ... they formed an
label: Paragraph

text: entirety with the buildings which enclosed them. Today they
label: Paragraph

text: serve at best as places for parking vehicles, and they have
label: Paragraph

text: no relation to the buildings which dominate them .... In brief,
label: Paragraph

text: activity is lacking precisely in those places where, in ancient
label: Paragraph

text: times, it was most intense, near public structures.2
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile, in Barcelona, the regional implications of
label: Paragraph

text: urban regularization were being developed by the Spanish
label: Paragraph

text: engineer Ildefonso Cerda, the inventor of the term
label: Paragraph

text: urbanizacion. |n 1859 Cerda projected the expansion of
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona as a gridded city [11], some twenty-two blocks
label: Paragraph

text: deep, bordered by the sea and intersected by two diagonal
label: Paragraph

text: avenues. Driven by industry and overseas trade, Barcelona
label: Paragraph

text: filled out this American-scale grid plan by the end of the
label: Paragraph

text: century. In his Teoria general de la urbanizacion (‘General
label: Paragraph

text: Theory of Urbanization’) of 1867 Cerda gave priority to a
label: Paragraph

text: system of circulation and, in particular, to steam traction.
label: Paragraph

text: For him transit was, in more ways than one, the point of
label: Paragraph

text: departure for all scientifically based urban structures. Léon
label: Paragraph

text: Jaussely’s plan for Barcelona of 1902, derived from Cerda’s,
label: Paragraph

text: incorporated this emphasis on movement into the form of a
label: Paragraph

text: protolinear city where the separate zones of
label: Paragraph

text: accommodation and transportation are organized into
label: Paragraph

text: bands. His design anticipated in certain respects the Russian
label: Paragraph

text: linear city proposals of the 1920s.

label: Paragraph

text: By 1891 intensive exploitation of the city centre was
label: Paragraph

text: possible, due to two developments essential to the erection
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: With the introduction of the underground railway (1863), the
label: Paragraph

text: electric tram (1884) and commuter rail transit (1890), the
label: Paragraph

text: garden suburb emerged as the ‘natural’ unit for future
label: Paragraph

text: urban expansion. The complementary relationship of these
label: Paragraph

text: two American forms of urban development - the high-rise
label: Paragraph

text: downtown and the low-rise garden suburb - was
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated in the building boom that followed the great
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago fire of 1871.
label: Paragraph

text: The process of suburbanization had already started
label: Paragraph

text: around Chicago with the layout in 1869 of the suburb of
label: Paragraph

text: Riverside, to the Picturesque designs of Olmsted [12].
label: Paragraph

text: Based in part on the mid-19th-century garden cemetery and
label: Paragraph

text: in part on the early East Coast suburb, it was linked to
label: Paragraph

text: downtown Chicago by both a railway and a bridle path.
label: Paragraph
