text: With the entry into Chicago in 1882 of the steam-
label: Paragraph

text: powered cable car, the way became open to further
label: Paragraph

text: expansion. The immediate beneficiary was Chicago’s South
label: Paragraph

text: Side. Yet suburban growth did not really prosper until the
label: Paragraph

text: 1890s, when, with the introduction of the electric streetcar,
label: Paragraph

text: suburban transit greatly extended its range, speed and
label: Paragraph

text: frequency. This led at the turn of the century to the opening
label: Paragraph

text: up of Chicago’s Oak Park suburb, which was to be the
label: Paragraph

text: proving ground for the early houses of Frank Lloyd Wright.
label: Paragraph

text: Between 1893 and 1897 an extensive elevated railway was
label: Paragraph

text: superimposed on the city, encircling its downtown area. All
label: Paragraph

text: these forms of transit were essential to Chicago’s growth.
label: Paragraph

text: Most important of all for the city’s prosperity was the
label: Paragraph

text: railway, for it brought the first piece of modern agricultural
label: Paragraph

text: equipment to the prairie - the essential McCormick
label: Title

text: mechanical reaper invented in 1831 - and collected in
label: Paragraph

text: return both grain and cattle from the great plains, trans-
label: Paragraph

text: shipping them to the lakeside silos and stockyards which
label: Paragraph

text: had begun to be built on Chicago’s South Side in 1865. It
label: Paragraph

text: was the railway that redistributed this abundance from the
label: Paragraph

text: 1880s on, in Gustavus Swift’s refrigerated packing cars, and
label: Paragraph

text: the corresponding growth in trade greatly augmented the
label: Paragraph

text: extensive passenger traffic centring on Chicago. Thus the
label: Paragraph

text: last decade of the century saw radical changes in both the
label: Paragraph

text: methods of town building and the means of urban access -
label: Title

text: changes which, in conjunction with the grid plan, were soon
label: Paragraph

text: to transform the traditional city into an ever-expanding
label: Paragraph

text: metropolitan region where dispersed homestead and
label: Paragraph

text: concentrated core are linked by continual commuting.
label: Paragraph

text: The puritanical entrepreneur George Pullman, who
label: Paragraph

text: helped to rebuild Chicago after the fire, had been one of the
label: Paragraph

text: first to appreciate the expanding market in long-distance
label: Paragraph

text: passenger travel, bringing out his first Pullman sleeping car
label: Paragraph

text: in 1865. After the achievement of the transcontinental rail
label: Paragraph

text: link in 1869, Pullman’s Palace Car Company prospered, and
label: Paragraph

text: in the early 1880s he established his ideal industrial town of
label: Paragraph

text: Pullman [13], south of Chicago, a settlement that combined
label: Paragraph

text: workers’ residences with a full range of communal facilities,
label: Paragraph

text: including a theatre and a library as well as schools, parks
label: Paragraph

text: and playgrounds, all in close proximity to the Pullman
label: Paragraph

text: factory. This well-ordered complex went far beyond the
label: Paragraph

text: facilities provided by Godin at Guise some twenty years
label: Paragraph

text: earlier. It also far exceeds, in its comprehensiveness and
label: Paragraph

text: clarity, the Picturesque model towns founded in England by
label: Paragraph

text: the confectioner George Cadbury at Bournville, Birmingham,
label: Caption

text: in 1879 and by the soap manufacturer W.H. Lever at Port
label: Paragraph

text: Sunlight, near Liverpool, in 1888. The paternalistic,
label: Paragraph

text: authoritarian precision of Pullman bears a closer
label: Paragraph

text: resemblance to Saltaire or to the workers’ settlements first
label: Paragraph

text: established as company policy by Krupp at Essen in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 13 Solon S. Berman, factory and town of Pullman, Chicago, illustrated in 1885.
label: Caption

text: Rail transit on a much smaller scale, by tram or by train,
label: Paragraph

text: was to be the main determinant of the two alternative
label: Paragraph

text: models of the European garden city. One was the axial
label: Paragraph

text: structure of the Spanish linear garden city, first described by
label: Paragraph

text: its inventor Arturo Soria y Mata in the early 1880s, and the
label: Paragraph

text: other was the English concentric garden city, shown as
label: Paragraph

text: circumnavigated by rail in Ebenezer Howard’s Tomorrow: A
label: Paragraph

text: Peaceful Path to Real Reform of 1898. Where Soria y Mata’s
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic interdependent ciudad linea! comprised, in his own
label: Paragraph

text: words of 1882, ‘A single street of some 500 metres [1,640
label: Paragraph

text: feet] width and of the length that may be necessary ... [a
label: Paragraph

text: city] whose extremities could be Cadiz or St Petersburg or
label: Paragraph

text: Peking or Brussels’, Howard's static yet supposedly
label: Paragraph

text: independent ‘Rurisville’ [L4] was encircled by its rail transit
label: Paragraph

text: and thereby fixed at an optimum size of between 32,000
label: Paragraph

text: and 58,000 people. Where the Spanish model was
label: Paragraph

text: inherently regional, undetermined and Continental, the
label: Paragraph

text: English version was self-contained, limited and provincial.
label: Paragraph

text: Soria y Mata described his ‘locomotion vertebrae’ as
label: Paragraph

text: incorporating, in addition to transit, the essential services of
label: Paragraph

text: the 19th-century city - water, gas, electricity and sewerage
label: Paragraph

text: - compatible with the distribution needs of 19th-century
label: Paragraph

text: industrial production.

label: Caption

text: Apart from being an antithesis to the radially planned
label: Paragraph

text: city, the linear city was a means for building along a
label: Paragraph

text: triangulated network of pre-existing routes connecting a set
label: Paragraph

text: of traditional regional centres. While the diagrammatic
label: Paragraph

text: projection of Howard’s city as a satellite town in open
label: Paragraph

text: country was equally regional, the form of the city itself was
label: Paragraph

text: less dynamic. On the model of Ruskin’s ill-fated St George’s
label: Paragraph

text: Guild of 1871, Howard conceived of his city as an
label: Paragraph

text: economically self-sufficient mutual aid community,
label: Paragraph

text: producing little beyond its own needs. The difference
label: Paragraph

text: between these city models lay finally in the fundamentally
label: Paragraph

text: different attitudes they adopted to rail transit. Whereas
label: Paragraph

text: Howard's Rurisville was intended to eliminate the journey to
label: Paragraph

text: work - the railway being reserved for objects rather than
label: Paragraph

text: men - the ciudad lineal was expressly designed to facilitate
label: Paragraph

text: communication.
label: Paragraph

text: It was, however, the English garden city in its modified
label: Paragraph

text: form that came to be widely adopted, rather than the linear
label: Paragraph

text: model sponsored by Soria y Mata’s Compafiia Madrilefia de
label: Paragraph

text: Urbanizacién, which only built some 22 kilometres (14
label: Paragraph

text: miles) of the 55-kilometre (34-mile) long ‘necklace’
label: Paragraph

text: originally projected for the encirclement of Madrid. The
label: Paragraph

text: failure of this sole example condemned the linear city to a
label: Paragraph

text: theoretical rather than practical future, and at this level it
label: Paragraph

text: persisted from the Russian linear cities of the late 1920s to
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s ASCORAL planning thesis, first published as
label: Paragraph

text: Les Trois Etablissements humains in 1945.
label: Paragraph

text: The radical reinterpretation of Howard’s original
label: Title

text: diagrams, reflected in the layout of the first garden city,
label: Paragraph

text: Letchworth in Hertfordshire (started in 1903), inaugurated
label: Paragraph

text: the neo-Sittesque phase in the English garden city
label: Paragraph

text: movement. That the engineer-planner Raymond Unwin was
label: Paragraph

text: impressed by Sitte is evident from his highly influential book
label: Paragraph

text: Town Planning in Practice, published in 1909. The
label: Paragraph

text: preoccupation of Unwin and his colleague Barry Parker with
label: Paragraph

text: ‘imaginary irregular towns’- of a kind exemplified for them
label: Paragraph

text: by such medieval German towns as Nuremberg and
label: Paragraph

text: Rothenburg-ob-der-Tauber - clearly lies behind their
label: Paragraph

text: picturesque layout for Hampstead Garden Suburb, designed
label: Caption

text: in 1907. Yet for all his contempt for ‘bye-law’ architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: Unwin remained as conditioned as any other planner by the
label: Paragraph

text: constraints imposed by modern standards of hygiene and
label: Paragraph

text: circulation. Thus, despite the renowned ‘empirical’ success
label: Paragraph

text: of these pioneering garden cities, the debilitating
label: Paragraph

text: environment produced subsequently by the English school
label: Paragraph

text: of town planning stems, at least in part, from Unwin’s failure
label: Paragraph

text: to resolve this implacable dichotomy, that is to reconcile
label: Paragraph

text: medieval nostalgia with bureaucratic control. The ‘train-
label: Paragraph

text: accident’ block layouts of the 20th century are among the
label: Paragraph

text: enduring formal legacies of this failure.
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 3
label: Title

text: Technical Transformations:
label: Title

text: Structural Engineering
label: Title

text: With iron, an artificial building material appeared for the
label: Paragraph

text: first time in the history of architecture. It went through a
label: Paragraph

text: development whose tempo accelerated during the course of
label: Paragraph

text: the century. This received its decisive impulse when it
label: Paragraph

text: turned out that the locomotive, with which experiments had
label: Paragraph

text: been made since the end of the twenties, could only be
label: Paragraph

text: utilized on iron rails. The rail was the first unit of
label: Paragraph

text: construction, the forerunner of the girder. lron was avoided
label: Paragraph

text: for dwelling-houses, and made use of for arcades, exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: halls, railway stations, buildings which served transitory
label: Paragraph

text: purposes. Simultaneously the architectonic areas in which
label: Paragraph

text: glass was employed were extended. But the social
label: Paragraph

text: conditions for its increased utilization as a building material
label: Paragraph

text: only came into being a hundred years later. In Scheerbart’s
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Glasarchitektur’ (1914) it still appeared in the context of a
label: Paragraph

text: Utopia.
label: Paragraph

text: Walter Benjamin
label: Title

text: Paris: Capital of the 19th Century, 19301
label: Caption

text: Rotary steam power and the iron frame came into being at
label: Paragraph

text: around the same time through the interdependent efforts of
label: Paragraph

text: three men: James Watt, Abraham Darby and John Wilkinson.
label: Paragraph

text: Of these, the last was the ‘iron-master’ of his day, whose
label: Paragraph

text: invention of the cylinder boring machine in 1775 was
label: Paragraph

text: essential to the perfection of Watt’s steam engine of 1789.
label: Paragraph

text: Wilkinson’s experience in working iron was to prove equally
label: Paragraph

text: indispensable to the first structural use of iron, since he
label: Paragraph

text: assisted Darby and his architect, Thomas Farnolls Pritchard,
label: Paragraph

text: in designing and erecting the first cast-iron bridge, a 30.5-
label: Paragraph

text: metre (100-foot) span built over the Severn near
label: Paragraph

text: Coalbrookdale in 1779. The Coalbrookdale achievement
label: Paragraph

text: aroused considerable interest, and in 1786 the Anglo-
label: Paragraph

text: American revolutionary, Tom Paine, designed a monument
label: Paragraph

text: to the American Revolution in the form of a cast-iron bridge
label: Paragraph

text: spanning the Schuylkill River. Paine had the parts for this
label: Paragraph

text: bridge made in England, where they were exhibited in 1791,
label: Paragraph

text: just a year before he was charged with treason and forced
label: Paragraph

text: into exile in France. In 1796 a 71-metre (236-foot) cast-iron
label: Paragraph

text: bridge was built across the Wear at Sunderland to the
label: Paragraph

text: designs of Thomas Wilson, who adopted Paine’s ‘voussoir’
label: Paragraph

text: method of assembly. About the same time Thomas Telford
label: Paragraph

text: made his début as a bridge builder with his 39.5-metre
label: Paragraph

text: (130-foot) Buildwas Bridge erected over the Severn, a
label: Caption

text: design which employed only 176 tonnes (173 tons) of iron,
label: Paragraph

text: as opposed to the 384 tonnes (378 tons) used at
label: Paragraph

text: Coalbrookdale.
label: Paragraph

text: Over the next thirty years Telford went on to prove his
label: Paragraph

text: unparalleled stature as a road and bridge builder and as the
label: Paragraph

text: last great canal engineer of the waning waterway era. His
label: Paragraph

text: pioneer career was brought to a close with his brick-
label: Paragraph

text: encased, iron-framed warehouses at St Katharine Dock in
label: Paragraph

text: London, designed with the architect Philip Hardwick and
label: Paragraph

text: erected in 1829. They were based on the system of fireproof
label: Paragraph

text: multi-storey mill construction developed in the Midlands
label: Paragraph

text: during the last decade of the 18th century. The main
label: Paragraph

text: structural antecedents for St Katharine’s were William
label: Paragraph

text: Strutt’s six-storey calico mill, built at Derby in 1792, and
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Bage’s flax-spinning mill erected at Shrewsbury in
label: Caption

text: 1796. While both of these structures employed cast-iron
label: Paragraph

text: columns, the pressing need to perfect a fireproof system for
label: Paragraph

text: mill buildings led, in the space of four years, to the
label: Paragraph

text: replacement of the timber beams used at Derby by T-
label: Paragraph

text: section iron beams. In each instance the beams carried
label: Paragraph

text: shallow brick vaults, the whole assembly being stiffened by
label: Paragraph

text: an outer shell and by wrought-iron tie rods restraining the
label: Paragraph

text: structure in a lateral direction. This use of vaulting seems to
label: Paragraph

text: have derived directly from the 18th-century development of
label: Paragraph

text: the Roussillon or Catalonian vault in France, which was first
label: Paragraph

text: adopted there as a means of achieving a fireproof structure
label: Paragraph

text: in Chateau Bizy, built at Vernon by Pierre Contant d’Ivry in
label: Caption

text: Aside from its use in 13th-century cathedrals, wrought-
label: Paragraph

text: iron masonry reinforcement in France had its origins in Paris,
label: Paragraph

text: in Perrault’s east facade of the Louvre (1667) and Soufflot’s
label: Caption

text: portico of Ste-Geneviéve (1772). Both works anticipate the
label: Paragraph

text: development of reinforced concrete. In 1776 Soufflot
label: Paragraph

text: proposed a wrought-iron trussed roof for part of the Louvre
label: Caption

text: that prepared the way for the pioneering work of Victor
label: Paragraph

text: Louis, that is for Louis’s wrought-iron roof for the Théatre
label: Paragraph

text: Francais of 1786 and his theatre in the Palais-Royal of 1790.
label: Paragraph

text: This last combined an iron roof with a hollow-pot, fireproof
label: Paragraph

text: floor structure, a system that once again was derived from
label: Paragraph

text: the Roussillon vault. That fire was a growing urban hazard
label: Paragraph

text: can be seen from the Halle au Blé, Paris, whose burnt-out
label: Caption

text: roof was replaced in 1808 by an iron-ribbed cupola,
label: Paragraph

text: designed by the architect Francois-Joseph Bélanger and the
label: Caption

text: engineer Francois Brunet - incidentally, one of the first
label: Paragraph

text: instances of a clear division of labour between architect and
label: Paragraph

text: constructor. In the meantime the earliest French application
label: Paragraph

text: of iron to bridge construction had occurred with the building
label: Paragraph

text: of the elegant Pont des Arts over the Seine, erected to the
label: Caption

text: designs of Louis-Alexandre de Cessart in 1803.
label: Caption

text: With the foundation of the Ecole Polytechnique in 1795,
label: Paragraph

text: the French strove towards establishing a technocracy
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate to the achievement of the Napoleonic Empire.
label: Paragraph

text: While this emphasis on applied technique only served to
label: Paragraph

text: reinforce the growing specialization of architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: engineering (a division already institutionalized through
label: Paragraph

text: Perronet’s Ecole des Ponts et Chaussées), architects such as
label: Paragraph

text: Jean-Baptiste Rondelet, who had supervised the completion
label: Paragraph

text: of Ste-Geneviéve after Soufflot’s death, began to record the
label: Paragraph

text: pioneering work of Soufflot, Louis, Brunet, de Cessart and
label: Paragraph

text: others. And while Rondelet documented the ‘means’ in his
label: Paragraph

text: Traité de I’art de b&atir (1802), Jean-Nicolas-Louis Durand,
label: Caption

text: lecturer in architecture at the Ecole Polytechnique,
label: Paragraph

text: catalogued the ‘ends’ in his Précis des lecons données a
label: Paragraph

text: l’Ecole Polytechnique (1802-09). Durand’s book
label: Caption

text: disseminated a system whereby Classical forms, conceived
label: Paragraph

text: as modular elements, could be arranged at will for the
label: Paragraph

text: accommodation of unprecedented building programmes, i.e.
label: Paragraph

text: the market halls, libraries and barracks of the Napoleonic
label: Caption

text: Empire. First Rondelet and then Durand codified a technique
label: Paragraph

text: and a design method whereby a rationalized Classicism
label: Title

text: could be brought to accommodate not only new social
label: Paragraph

text: demands but also new techniques. This comprehensive
label: Paragraph

text: programme influenced Schinkel who, at the beginning of his
label: Paragraph

text: architectural career in 1816, began to incorporate elaborate
label: Paragraph

text: iron elements into his Neo-Classical embellishments for the
label: Paragraph

text: city of Berlin.
label: Paragraph

text: Around this time the technique of iron suspension
label: Paragraph

text: construction underwent an independent evolution,
label: Paragraph

text: beginning with the American James Finley’s invention of the
label: Paragraph

text: stiffened, flat-deck suspension bridge in 1801, an
label: Paragraph

text: achievement that was disseminated by Thomas Pope’s
label: Paragraph

text: Treatise on Bridge Architecture published in 1811. The
label: Paragraph

text: climax of Finley’s brief but critical career was his 74.5-metre
label: Paragraph

text: (244-foot) span iron-chain suspension bridge across the
label: Caption

text: Merrimack River at Newburyport, Massachusetts, in 1810.
label: Caption

text: Finley’s work, as documented by Pope, had an immediate
label: Paragraph

text: influence on the application of chain suspension technique
label: Title

text: in Britain, where Samuel Brown and Telford became involved
label: Paragraph

text: in its development. Brown’s wrought-iron flat bar links were
label: Paragraph

text: patented in 1817 and applied with lasting success to his
label: Paragraph

text: 115-metre (378-foot) span Union Bridge, built over the
label: Caption

text: Tweed in 1820. Telford and Brown collaborated briefly on a
label: Paragraph

text: chain bridge for Runcorn, and this collaboration no doubt
label: Paragraph

text: informed Telford’s design for his 177-metre (580-foot) span
label: Paragraph

text: Menai Straits bridge, which after eight years of arduous
label: Paragraph

text: work was finally opened in 1825. British wrought-iron
label: Paragraph

text: suspension construction culminated in Isambard Kingdom
label: Paragraph

text: Brunel’s 214-metre (702-foot) span Clifton Bridge, Bristol,
label: Caption

text: designed in 1829 but not completed until 1864, five years
label: Paragraph

text: after Brunel’s death. Since the manufacture of wrought-iron
label: Paragraph

text: links capable of withstanding tension was always an
label: Paragraph

text: expensive and hazardous affair, the idea of using cables of
label: Paragraph

text: drawn wire instead of chains seems to have suggested
label: Paragraph

text: itself, first in 1816 to White and Hazard, in their footbridge
label: Paragraph

text: over the Schuylkill Falls in Pennsylvania, and then to the
label: Paragraph

text: Séguin brothers, who constructed a wire bridge over the
label: Paragraph

text: Rhéne at Tain-Tournon in 1825. The Séguins’ work formed
label: Paragraph

text: the subject for an exhaustive analytical study carried out for
label: Paragraph

text: the Ecole des Ponts et Chaussées by Louis-Joseph Vicat, and
label: Paragraph

text: the publication of this work in 1831 inaugurated the golden
label: Paragraph

text: age of the suspension bridge in France, where some
label: Paragraph

text: hundred such structures were built in the next decade. Vicat
label: Paragraph

text: recommended that all future suspension members should
label: Paragraph

text: be fabricated out of wire rather than bar iron, and to this
label: Paragraph

text: end he invented a method for spinning wire cable in place.
label: Paragraph

text: A similar device was eventually used by the American
label: Paragraph

text: engineer John Augustus Roebling, whose own patent for the
label: Paragraph

text: manufacture of wire cable was taken out in 1842, just two
label: Paragraph

text: years before he used this material for the suspension of an
label: Paragraph

text: aqueduct over the Allegheny River at Pittsburgh. Roebling’s
label: Caption

text: cables were spirally wrapped like those of Vicat, and he
label: Paragraph

text: used this basic suspension material for the rest of his heroic
label: Paragraph

text: career, from his 243.5-metre (800-foot) span Niagara Falls
label: Paragraph

text: railway viaduct of 1855 to his 487-metre (1600-foot) span
label: Paragraph

text: Brooklyn Bridge, New York [15], completed, after his death,
label: Caption

text: by his son Washington Roebling in 1883.

label: Caption

text: With the virtual completion of the British railway
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructure by 1860, British structural engineering
label: Title

text: entered a fallow period that lasted for the rest of the
label: Paragraph

text: century. Few works of outstanding brilliance and ingenuity
label: Paragraph

text: remained to be built after the middle of the century: these
label: Paragraph

text: included the Stephenson and Fairbairn Britannia Tubular
label: Paragraph

text: Bridge of 1852 over the Menai Straits [16] and Brunel's
label: Paragraph

text: Saltash Viaduct of 1859. Both made use of plated wrought
label: Paragraph

text: iron, that is to say of riveted rolled sheet, a technique which
label: Paragraph

text: had been greatly advanced by the studies of Eton
label: Paragraph

text: Hodgkinson and the experimental work of William Fairbairn.
label: Paragraph

text: Robert Stephenson had already utilized the findings of
label: Paragraph

text: Hodgkinson and Fairbairn in his development of the plate
label: Paragraph

text: girder in 1846, a system that was to be fully demonstrated
label: Paragraph

text: in the Britannia Bridge. This structure comprised two
label: Paragraph

text: independent, single-track, iron-plated box tunnels which
label: Paragraph

text: bridged the straits in two spans of 70 metres (230 feet)
label: Paragraph

text: each and one main span of 140 metres (460 feet).
label: Paragraph

text: Stephenson's stone towers had been intended for the
label: Paragraph

text: anchorage of supplementary suspension members, but the
label: Paragraph

text: plated ‘tubes’ acting alone proved more than adequate for
label: Paragraph

text: the span. Comparable spans were achieved in the Saltash
label: Paragraph

text: Viaduct, where a single track is carried over the Tamar River
label: Paragraph

text: on two bowstring trusses each spanning 138.5 metres (455
label: Paragraph

text: feet). Rolled, riveted plates were again used to form the
label: Paragraph

text: hollow elliptical chords, measuring 4.9 by 3.7 metres (16 by
label: Paragraph

text: 12 feet) across their respective axes. These chords
label: Paragraph

text: interacted with underslung iron chain catenaries to carry
label: Paragraph

text: vertical standards from which the road-bed was finally
label: Paragraph

text: suspended. In its imaginative stature Brunel’s last work
label: Paragraph

text: equalled the great viaducts which Gustave Eiffel was to
label: Paragraph

text: build in the Massif Central over the next thirty years, and its
label: Paragraph

text: use of hollow plated sections anticipated the gigantic
label: Paragraph

text: tubular steel framing to be employed by John Fowler and
label: Paragraph

text: Benjamin Baker in the 213-metre (700-foot) cantilevers of
label: Paragraph

text: their Forth Bridge, completed in 1890.
label: Paragraph

text: The railway development that had begun with George
label: Paragraph

text: Stephenson’s trial run from Stockton to Darlington in 1825
label: Title

text: expanded over the second quarter of the century ata
label: Paragraph

text: formidable rate. In England there were over 3,200
label: Paragraph

text: kilometres (2,000 miles) of track after less than twenty
label: Paragraph

text: years, while in North America 4,600 kilometres (3,000 miles)
label: Paragraph

text: had been laid by 1842. In the interim, the materials of the
label: Paragraph

text: railway, cast and wrought iron, gradually became integrated
label: Paragraph

text: into the general building vocabulary, where they constituted
label: Paragraph

text: the only available fireproof elements for the multi-storey
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: From the time of Boulton and Watt’s 33-centimetre (13-
label: Paragraph

text: inch) cast-iron beam, used in their Salford Mill, Manchester,
label: Paragraph

text: of 1801, a continual effort was made to improve the
label: Paragraph

text: spanning capacity of both cast- and wrought-iron beams and
label: Paragraph

text: rails. The typical section of the ‘railway’ evolved during the
label: Paragraph

text: first decades of the century, and from this section the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: cast-iron rail of 1789 gave way to Birkenshaw’s wrought-iron
label: Paragraph

text: T-rail of 1820, and this led in turn to the first American rail,
label: Paragraph

text: rolled in Wales in 1831, with a section in the form of an |
label: Paragraph

text: broader at the base than at the top. This form became
label: Paragraph

text: gradually adopted for the permanent way, but did not come
label: Paragraph

text: into general structural use until after 1854, when heavier
label: Paragraph

text: versions with greater spanning capacity were successfully
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the spanning capacity of the material by building up deep
label: Paragraph

text: members from the standard wrought-iron angles and plates
label: Paragraph

text: that were then being used in ship building. Fairbairn
label: Paragraph

text: reputedly made and tested such composite I-beams as early
label: Paragraph

text: These ingenious attempts to produce wide-span
label: Paragraph

text: elements through reinforcing or assembling iron
label: Title

text: components were more or less eclipsed at mid-century by
label: Paragraph

text: the successful rolling of a wrought-iron beam 17.8
label: Paragraph

text: centimetres (7 inches) deep. Fairbairn’s book On the
label: Caption

text: Application of Cast and Wrought Iron to Building Purposes
label: Title

text: (1854) presented an improved system of mill construction,
label: Paragraph

text: consisting of rolled iron beams 40.6 centimetres (16 inches)
label: Paragraph

text: deep that supported shallow vaults made of sheet iron, the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: In a similar vein, a remarkable four-storey cast- and
label: Paragraph

text: wrought-iron framed building was erected in the Naval
label: Paragraph

text: Dockyard at Sheerness. This boat store, clad in corrugated
label: Paragraph

text: iron, was designed by Colonel Greene and erected in 1860,
label: Paragraph

text: some twelve years before the pioneering all-iron, skeleton-
label: Paragraph

text: framed Menier chocolate factory was built by Jules Saulnier
label: Caption

text: at Noisiel-sur-Marne. In its systematic use of iron I-sections
label: Paragraph

text: throughout (cast in the case of the columns and wrought in
label: Paragraph

text: the case of the beams) the Sheerness boat store anticipated
label: Paragraph

text: both the standard section and the assembly method of
label: Paragraph

text: modern steel-frame construction.
label: Paragraph

text: By mid-century, cast-iron columns and wrought-iron rails,
label: Paragraph

text: used in conjunction with modular glazing, had become the
label: Paragraph

text: standard technique for the rapid prefabrication and erection
label: Paragraph

text: of urban distribution centres - market halls, exchanges and
label: Paragraph

text: arcades. This last type was developed in Paris. Fontaine’s
label: Paragraph

text: Galerie d'Orléans, built in the Palais-Royal in 1829, was the
label: Paragraph

text: earliest arcade to have a glass barrel vault. The
label: Caption

text: prefabricated nature of these cast-iron systems guaranteed
label: Paragraph

text: not only a certain speed of assembly but also the possibility
label: Paragraph

text: of transporting building ‘kits’ over large distances: from mid-
label: Paragraph

text: century onwards the industrialized countries began to
label: Paragraph

text: export prefabricated cast-iron structures all over the world.
label: Paragraph

text: The sudden expansion in urban growth and trade on the
label: Paragraph

text: eastern American seaboard in the 1840s encouraged men
label: Paragraph

text: such as James Bogardus and Daniel Badger to open casting
label: Paragraph

text: shops in New York for the manufacture of multistorey
label: Paragraph

text: architectural fronts in iron. Up to the late 1850s, however,
label: Paragraph

text: their ‘packaged’ structures relied on the use of large timber
label: Paragraph

text: beams to span the internal space, iron being reserved for
label: Paragraph

text: the internal columns and the facades. One of the finest
label: Paragraph

text: works of Badger’s extensive career is his Haughwout
label: Paragraph

text: Building, New York, of 1859, built to the designs of the
label: Caption

text: architect John P. Gaynor. This was the first building to be
label: Paragraph

text: served by a passenger elevator, just five years after Elisha
label: Paragraph

text: Graves Otis had made his historic demonstration of the
label: Paragraph

text: device in 1854.
label: Paragraph

text: The fully glazed structure, whose environmental
label: Paragraph

text: attributes were exhaustively discussed by J.C. Loudon in his
label: Paragraph

text: Remarks on Hot Houses (1817), had little chance of having a
label: Paragraph

text: more general application, at least in England, until the
label: Paragraph

text: repeal of the excise duty on glass in 1845. Richard Turner
label: Caption

text: and Decimus Burton’s Palm House at Kew Gardens, built in
label: Caption

text: 1845-48, was one of the first structures to take advantage
label: Paragraph

text: of the sudden availability of sheet glass. The first large
label: Paragraph

text: permanent enclosures to be significantly glazed thereafter
label: Paragraph

text: were the railway termini that were built during the second
label: Paragraph

text: half of the 19th century, a development that began with
label: Paragraph

text: Turner and Joseph Locke’s Lime Street Station, Liverpool, of
label: Caption

text: The railway terminus presented a peculiar challenge to
label: Paragraph

text: the received canons of architecture, since there was no type
label: Paragraph

text: available to express and articulate adequately the junction
label: Paragraph

text: between the head building and the train shed. This problem,
label: Paragraph

text: which saw its earliest architectural resolution in
label: Paragraph

text: Duquesney’s Gare de |’Est, Paris, of 1852, was of some
label: Paragraph

text: concern since these termini were effectively the new
label: Paragraph

text: gateways into the capital city. The engineer Léonce
label: Caption

text: Reynaud, designer of the first Gare du Nord in Paris (1847),
label: Paragraph

text: was aware of this issue of ‘representation’ when he wrote in
label: Paragraph

text: his Traité d’architecture (1850):
label: Paragraph

text: Art does not have the rapid progress and sudden
label: Paragraph

text: developments of industry, with the result that the majority
label: Paragraph

text: of buildings today for the service of railroads leave more or
label: Paragraph

text: less to be desired, be it in relation to form or arrangement.
label: Paragraph

text: Some stations appear to be appropriately arranged but
label: Paragraph

text: having the character of industrial or temporary construction
label: Paragraph

text: rather than that of a building for public use.?
label: Paragraph

text: Nothing could be more exemplary of this predicament than
label: Paragraph

text: St Pancras Station in London, where the vast shed, 74
label: Caption

text: metres (243 feet) in span, built in 1863-65 to the designs of
label: Paragraph

text: William Henry Barlow and Rowland Mason Ordish, was
label: Paragraph

text: totally divorced from the Gothic Revival hotel-cum-head
label: Paragraph

text: building completed in 1874 to the designs of George Gilbert
label: Caption

text: Scott. And what was true for St Pancras also applied to
label: Paragraph

text: Brunel's designs for Paddington in London (1852), where
label: Paragraph

text: once again, despite the conscientious efforts of the architect
label: Paragraph

text: Matthew Digby Wyatt, the rather rudimentary station
label: Caption

text: building was left inadequately related to the vaulted profiles
label: Paragraph

text: of the shed.
label: Paragraph

text: The free-standing exhibition structure presented none of
label: Paragraph

text: the problems of the terminus, for where the issues of
label: Paragraph

text: cultural context could scarcely arise the engineer reigned
label: Paragraph

text: supreme. This was never more so than in the case of the
label: Paragraph

text: Crystal Palace in London, built for the Great Exhibition of
label: Caption

text: 1851, where the gardener Joseph Paxton was given a free
label: Paragraph

text: hand to design in accordance with a method for the
label: Paragraph

text: fabrication of glasshouses that he had developed through a
label: Paragraph

text: rigorous application of Loudon’s hothouse principles. Paxton
label: Paragraph

text: had developed his method in a series of glasshouses built
label: Paragraph

text: for the Duke of Devonshire at Chatsworth. When
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned at the eleventh hour to design the Crystal
label: Paragraph

text: Palace, Paxton was able to produce, in just eight days, an
label: Paragraph

text: enormous orthogonal three-tiered glasshouse, whose
label: Paragraph

text: components were virtually identical to those of the giant lily
label: Paragraph

text: house that he had built at Chatsworth in the previous year.
label: Paragraph

text: Except for three entrance porches, symmetrically disposed,
label: Paragraph

text: its glazed perimeter was uninterrupted. During its
label: Paragraph

text: development, however, a revised scheme had to be
label: Paragraph

text: prepared in order to retain a group of mature trees. Since
label: Paragraph

text: the remaining public opposition to the Great Exhibition of
label: Paragraph

text: 1851 turned on this question of tree preservation, Paxton
label: Paragraph

text: was quick to realize that these troublesome items could
label: Paragraph

text: easily be accommodated by a central transept with a high
label: Paragraph

text: curved roof, and thus the double symmetry of the final form
label: Paragraph

text: emerged.
label: Paragraph

text: The Crystal Palace was not so much a particular form as
label: Paragraph

text: it was a building process made manifest as a total system,
label: Paragraph

text: from its initial conception, fabrication and trans-shipment, to
label: Paragraph

text: its final erection and dismantling. Like the railway buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: to which it was related, it was a highly flexible kit of parts
label: Paragraph

text: [17]. Its overall form was structured around a basic 2.44-
label: Paragraph

text: metre (8-foot) cladding module, assembled into a hierarchy
label: Paragraph

text: of structural spans varying from 7.31 to 21.95 metres (24 to
label: Paragraph

text: 72 feet). Its realization, which took barely four months, was
label: Paragraph

text: a simple matter of mass production and systematic
label: Title

text: assembly. As Konrad Wachsmann has remarked in his book
label: Paragraph

text: Wendepunkt im Bauen (The Turning Point of Building) of
label: Paragraph

text: 1961, ‘Its production requirements included studies which
label: Paragraph

text: indicated that for easy handling no part should weigh more
label: Paragraph

text: than one ton and that the greatest economies could be
label: Paragraph

text: obtained by using glass panels of the largest possible size.’
label: Paragraph

text: 17 Paxton, Crystal Palace, London, 1851. Component parts.
label: Caption

text: While the Crystal Palace engendered through its open
label: Paragraph

text: lattice work spectacular parallel and oblique perspectives
label: Title

text: whose lines diminished into a diaphanous haze of light, its
label: Paragraph

text: total envelope, comprising nearly 93,000 square metres (a
label: Paragraph

text: million square feet) of glass, presented a climatic problem of
label: Paragraph

text: unprecedented scale. The desirable environmental
label: Paragraph

text: conditions, however, remained the same as they had been
label: Paragraph

text: in Loudon’s curvilinear hothouses - to maintain comfortable
label: Paragraph

text: air movement and to moderate the heat of the sun. While
label: Paragraph

text: the elevation of the building off the ground and the
label: Paragraph

text: provision of a slatted floor, together with adjustable louvres
label: Caption

text: in the walls, provided satisfactory ventilation, the
label: Paragraph

text: accumulation of solar heat constituted a problem to which
label: Paragraph

text: the railway engineer Charles Fox, who was responsible for
label: Paragraph

text: the detailing of the structure, could find no adequate
label: Paragraph

text: solution. The eventual ad hoc use of canvas awnings to
label: Paragraph

text: shade the roof could hardly be regarded as an integral part
label: Paragraph

text: of the system, and many of the international exhibitors
label: Paragraph

text: chose to shield themselves from the ‘greenhouse’ effect by
label: Paragraph

text: canopies of festooned draperies, which were no doubt hung
label: Paragraph

text: as much against the unacceptable ‘objectivity’ of the
label: Paragraph

text: structure as they were against the sun.
label: Paragraph

text: The British abandonment of the international exhibition
label: Title

text: field, after the triumph of 1851 and a further exhibition in
label: Paragraph

text: 1862, was at once exploited by the French, who mounted
label: Paragraph

text: five major international exhibitions between 1855 and 1900.
label: Paragraph

text: The degree to which these displays were regarded as
label: Paragraph

text: national platforms from which to challenge the British
label: Title

text: command over industrial production and trade may be
label: Paragraph

text: judged from the emphasis placed each time on the structure
label: Paragraph

text: and content of the ‘Galerie des Machines’. The young
label: Paragraph

text: Gustave Eiffel worked with the engineer Jean-Baptiste
label: Paragraph

text: Krantz on the most significant exhibition building to be
label: Paragraph

text: erected after 1851, that for the Paris World Exhibition of
label: Paragraph

text: 1867. This collaboration revealed not only Eiffel’s expressive
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility but also his capacity as an engineer, since in
label: Paragraph

text: detailing the Galerie des Machines, with its 35-metre (114-
label: Paragraph

text: foot) span, he was able to verify the validity of Thomas
label: Paragraph

text: Young’s modulus of elasticity of 1807, a hitherto solely
label: Paragraph

text: theoretical formula for determining the elastic behaviour of
label: Paragraph

text: material under stress. The whole oval complex, of which the
label: Paragraph

text: Galerie des Machines was merely the outer ring, was itself a
label: Paragraph

text: testament to the conceptual genius of Pierre Guillaume
label: Title

text: Frédéric Le Play, who had suggested that the building be
label: Paragraph

text: arranged as concentric galleries exhibiting machinery,
label: Paragraph

text: clothing, furniture, liberal arts, fine arts and the history of
label: Title

text: labour.
label: Paragraph

text: After 1867 the sheer size and diversity of the objects
label: Paragraph

text: produced, and the independence demanded by international
label: Paragraph

text: competition, seem to have demanded multiple exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: structures. By the time of the International Exhibition of
label: Paragraph

text: 1889 no pretence was made of housing the exhibits in one
label: Paragraph

text: self-contained building. This penultimate exhibition of the
label: Paragraph

text: century was dominated by two of the most remarkable
label: Paragraph

text: structures that French engineering was ever to achieve -
label: Paragraph

text: Victor Contamin’s vast Galerie des Machines [18], 107
label: Caption

text: metres (350 feet) in span, designed with the architect
label: Caption

text: Charles Louis Ferdinand Dutert, and Eiffel’s tower, 300
label: Caption

text: metres (984 feet) high, designed in collaboration with the
label: Paragraph

text: engineers Nouguier and Koechlin and the architect Stephen
label: Title

text: Sauvestre. Contamin’s structure, based on statical methods
label: Paragraph

text: perfected by Eiffel in his hinged viaducts of the 1880s, was
label: Paragraph

text: one of the first to use the three-hinged arch form in the
label: Paragraph

text: achievement of a large span. Contamin’s shed not only
label: Paragraph

text: exhibited machines: it was itself an ‘exhibiting machine’, in
label: Paragraph

text: which mobile viewing platforms, running on elevated tracks,
label: Paragraph

text: passed over the exhibition space on either side of the
label: Paragraph

text: central axis, affording the visitor a fast and comprehensive
label: Paragraph

text: view of the entire show.

text: In the last half of the 19th century the Massif Central had
label: Paragraph

text: been found to be sufficiently rich in minerals to justify the
label: Paragraph

text: considerable expense of equipping it with a railway network.
label: Paragraph

text: The railway viaducts that Eiffel designed there between
label: Paragraph

text: 1869 and 1884 exemplify a method and an aesthetic that
label: Paragraph

text: found their ultimate celebration in the design of the Eiffel
label: Paragraph

text: Tower. The boat-shaped base and the parabolic vertical
label: Paragraph

text: section of the tubular iron pylon that Eiffel evolved for these
label: Paragraph

text: viaducts is formally indicative of his constant attempt to
label: Paragraph

text: resolve the dynamic interaction of water and wind.
label: Paragraph

text: The need to make wider river crossings led Eiffel and his
label: Paragraph

text: associates to devise an ingenious system of viaduct
label: Paragraph

text: support. The spur to such a solution came in 1875, with the
label: Paragraph

text: commission to construct a railway viaduct over the river
label: Caption

text: Douro in Portugal. The availability of cheap steel after 1870
label: Paragraph

text: afforded a material in which a wide-span solution might be
label: Paragraph

text: readily achieved. A decision was therefore made to cross
label: Paragraph

text: the ravine in five spans, two short spans supported on
label: Paragraph

text: pylons on either side and a central longer span of 160
label: Caption

text: metres (524 feet) carried on a two-pinned arch. The
label: Paragraph

text: procedure of erection, to be repeated a few years later at
label: Paragraph

text: Garabit, was to construct the flanking spans with their
label: Paragraph

text: supporting pylons and then to erect the central section from
label: Paragraph

text: these continuous structures on either side. Truss extensions
label: Paragraph

text: were cantilevered out at track level, and the hinged arch
label: Paragraph

text: was simultaneously constructed, in two halves, from the
label: Paragraph

text: water below. The initial hinged sections were floated and
label: Paragraph

text: jacked into position and then maintained at a correct incline
label: Paragraph

text: during their final assembly by cables suspended from the
label: Paragraph

text: caps of the adjacent pylons. The outstanding success of the
label: Paragraph

text: Douro Viaduct, completed in 1878, immediately brought
label: Paragraph

text: Eiffel a commission to build the Garabit Viaduct over the
label: Paragraph

text: River Truyére in the Massif Central.
label: Paragraph

text: Just as the Douro Viaduct provided the necessary
label: Paragraph

text: experience to build Garabit, so the achievement of Garabit
label: Paragraph

text: was essential to the design and conception of the Eiffel
label: Paragraph

text: Tower. Like the Crystal Palace, the tower was designed and
label: Paragraph

text: erected under considerable pressure, but at a slower rate.
label: Paragraph

text: First exhibited as a design in the spring of 1885, it was in
label: Paragraph

text: the ground by the summer of 1887 and well over 200
label: Paragraph

text: metres (654 feet) high by the winter of 1888. As in
label: Paragraph

text: Contamin’s Galerie des Machines, the structure had to be
label: Paragraph

text: provided with an access system for the rapid movement of
label: Paragraph

text: visitors. Speed was essential, since there was no way of
label: Paragraph

text: gaining access to the tower except via lifts that ran on
label: Paragraph

text: inclined tracks within its hyperbolic legs and rose vertically
label: Paragraph

text: from first platform to pinnacle. The guide rails for these lifts
label: Caption

text: were exploited during erection as tracks for climbing cranes,
label: Paragraph

text: an economy in working method reminiscent of the mounting
label: Paragraph

text: technique used in the case of the hinged viaducts. As much
label: Paragraph

text: a by-product of the railway as the Crystal Palace, the tower
label: Paragraph

text: was, in effect, a 300-metre (974-foot) high viaduct pylon,
label: Paragraph

text: whose type-form had originally been evolved out of the
label: Paragraph

text: interaction of wind, gravity, water and material resistance. It
label: Paragraph

text: was a hitherto unimaginable structure that could not be
label: Paragraph

text: experienced except by traversing the aerial matrix of the
label: Paragraph

text: space itself. Given the futuristic affinity of the tower to
label: Paragraph

text: aviation - celebrated by the aviator Alberto Santos-Dumont,
label: Paragraph

text: when he circled the structure with his dirigible in 1901 - it is
label: Paragraph

text: hardly surprising that thirty years after its erection it should
label: Paragraph

text: have been appropriated and reinterpreted as the prime
label: Paragraph

text: symbol of a new social and technical order, in Vladimir
label: Paragraph

text: Tatlin’s monument to the Third International, projected in
label: Caption

text: As iron technology developed through the exploitation of the
label: Paragraph

text: earth’s mineral wealth, so concrete technology, or at least
label: Paragraph

text: the development of hydraulic cement, seems to have arisen
label: Paragraph

text: out of traffic on sea. In 1774, John Smeaton established the
label: Paragraph

text: base of his Eddystone Lighthouse using a ‘concrete’
label: Caption

text: compound of quicklime, clay, sand and crushed iron slag,
label: Paragraph

text: and similar concrete mixes were used in England in bridge,
label: Paragraph

text: canal and harbour works throughout the last quarter of the
label: Paragraph

text: 18th century. Despite Joseph Aspdin’s pioneering
label: Paragraph

text: development of Portland cement for use as imitation stone
label: Paragraph

text: in 1824, and various other English proposals for metal-
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete construction, such as that made by the
label: Paragraph

text: ever-inventive Loudon in 1792, the initial English lead in the
label: Paragraph

text: pioneering of concrete gradually passed to France.
label: Paragraph

text: In France the economic restrictions that followed the
label: Paragraph

text: Revolution of 1789, the synthesis of hydraulic cement by
label: Paragraph

text: Vicat around 1800 and the tradition of building in pisé
label: Paragraph

text: (rammed earth) combined to create the optimum
label: Paragraph

text: circumstances for the invention of reinforced concrete. The
label: Paragraph

text: first consequential use of the new material was made by
label: Paragraph

text: Francois Coignet, who was already familiar with the pisé
label: Paragraph

text: building method of the Lyons district. In 1861 he developed
label: Paragraph

text: a technique for strengthening concrete with metal mesh,
label: Paragraph

text: and on the basis of this established the first limited
label: Paragraph

text: company to specialize in ferroconcrete construction. Coignet
label: Paragraph

text: worked in Paris under Haussmann’s direction, building
label: Paragraph

text: sewers and other public structures in ferroconcrete -
label: Paragraph

text: including, in 1867, a remarkable series of six-storey
label: Paragraph

text: apartment blocks. Despite these commissions, Coignet
label: Paragraph

text: failed to uphold his patent and by the end of the Second
label: Paragraph

text: Empire his company was dissolved.
label: Paragraph

text: Another French pioneer of concrete was the gardener
label: Paragraph

text: Joseph Monier, who, following his successful production of
label: Paragraph

text: concrete flower pots in 1850, took out, after 1867, a series
label: Paragraph

text: of patents for metal-reinforced applications, the partial
label: Paragraph

text: rights of which he ill-advisedly sold in 1880 to the engineers
label: Paragraph

text: Schuster and Wayss. Further rights were obtained from
label: Paragraph

text: Monier in 1884 by the firm of Freytag, and soon afterwards
label: Paragraph

text: the large German civil engineering concern of Wayss and
label: Paragraph

text: Freytag came into being. Their monopoly over the Monier
label: Paragraph

text: system was consolidated by Gustav Adolf Wayss’s standard
label: Paragraph

text: work on the Monier method (Monierbau), published in 1887.
label: Paragraph

text: The publication of important theoretical studies on
label: Paragraph

text: differential stress in reinforced concrete by the German
label: Paragraph

text: theorists Neumann and Koenen served to consolidate the
label: Paragraph

text: German lead in this type of construction.
label: Paragraph

text: The period of most intense development in reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete occurred between 1870 and 1900, with pioneering
label: Paragraph

text: work being carried on simultaneously in Germany, America,
label: Paragraph

text: England and France. In building his reinforced-concrete
label: Paragraph

text: Hudson River home in 1873, the American William E. Ward
label: Paragraph

text: became the first constructor to take full advantage of the
label: Paragraph

text: tensile strength of steel by situating bars below the neutral
label: Paragraph

text: axis of the beam. The inherent structural advantage of this
label: Paragraph

text: was almost immediately confirmed by the concrete beam
label: Paragraph

text: experiments conducted in England by Thaddeus Hyatt and
label: Paragraph

text: Thomas Rickets, whose joint results were published in 1877.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite these international developments, the
label: Paragraph

text: systematic exploitation of modern reinforced-concrete
label: Title

text: technique was to wait upon the inventive genius of Francois
label: Paragraph

text: Hennebique. Hennebique, a self-educated French builder,
label: Paragraph

text: first used concrete in 1879. He then conducted an extensive
label: Paragraph

text: programme of private research before patenting his own
label: Paragraph

text: uniquely comprehensive system in 1892. Before
label: Paragraph

text: Hennebique the great problem in ferroconcrete had been
label: Paragraph

text: the provision of a monolithic joint. The compound concrete
label: Paragraph

text: and steel systems that had been patented by Fairbairn in
label: Paragraph

text: 1845 were far from being monolithic, and the same
label: Paragraph

text: restrictions applied to the work of Hyatt and Rickets.
label: Paragraph

text: Hennebique overcame this difficulty through the use of bars
label: Paragraph

text: of cylindrical section which could be bent round and hooked
label: Paragraph

text: together. Integral to his system alone was the cranking up
label: Paragraph

text: of reinforcement bars and the binding of joints with stirrup
label: Title

text: hoops in order to resist local stress. With the perfection of
label: Paragraph

text: the monolithic joint [19], the monolithic frame could be
label: Paragraph

text: realized, leading promptly to the first large-scale application
label: Paragraph

text: of such a system to three spinning mills that Hennebique
label: Paragraph

text: built in the region of Tourcoing and Lille in 1896. The results
label: Paragraph

text: were at once acclaimed as a success, and Hennebique’s
label: Paragraph

text: firm immediately prospered. His partner, Louis Gustave
label: Paragraph

text: Mouchel, took the system to England in 1897, building the
label: Paragraph

text: first concrete road bridge there in 1901 and exhibiting a
label: Paragraph

text: spectacular free-standing, helical, reinforced-concrete stair
label: Caption

text: at the Franco-British exhibition of 1908.

text: The wide success of the Hennebique firm dates from
label: Paragraph

text: around 1898, with the regular publication of its house
label: Paragraph

text: magazine Le Béton armé (‘Reinforced Concrete’) and the
label: Paragraph

text: extensive use of its system in the eclectic structures of the
label: Paragraph

text: Paris Exhibition of 1900. Despite the false facades of the
label: Paragraph

text: Chateau d’Eau, constructed out of ferroconcrete by Francois
label: Caption

text: Coignet’s son, the Paris Exhibition of 1900 gave an
label: Paragraph

text: enormous boost to concrete construction, and by 1902, a
label: Paragraph

text: decade after its foundation, the Hennebique firm had grown
label: Paragraph

text: into a large international concern. By then innumerable
label: Paragraph

text: works were being constructed in concrete throughout
label: Paragraph

text: Europe, with Hennebique acting as the main contractor. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1904 he built his own reinforced-concrete villa at Bourg-la-
label: Paragraph

text: Reine, complete with roof garden and minaret. Its solid walls
label: Paragraph

text: were formed out of ferroconcrete poured in place between
label: Paragraph

text: permanent pre-cast concrete shuttering, and its almost
label: Paragraph

text: totally glazed facade was dramatically cantilevered out from
label: Paragraph

text: the main plane of the building. By the turn of the century,
label: Paragraph

text: Hennebique’s monopoly over his system began to wane,
label: Paragraph

text: although his patents still had a number of years to run. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1902 his chief assistant, Paul Christophe, popularized the
label: Paragraph

text: system by publishing Le Béton armé et ses applications.
label: Paragraph

text: Four years later Armand-Gabriel Considéré, who had already
label: Paragraph

text: carried out concrete research for the department of Ponts et
label: Paragraph

text: Chaussées, headed the national committee that established
label: Paragraph

text: the French code for reinforced-concrete practice.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1890 the engineer Paul Cottancin patented his own
label: Paragraph

text: system of ciment armé, which depended on the combined
label: Paragraph

text: reinforcement of concrete and brick, the bricks being
label: Paragraph

text: bonded into the concrete with wire reinforcement. In this
label: Paragraph

text: hybrid system the main function of the ferroconcrete
label: Paragraph

text: element was to maintain structural continuity in areas of
label: Paragraph

text: high tension. In areas of compression brick naturally
label: Paragraph

text: predominated. The system had a strong appeal for the
label: Paragraph

text: rationalist architect Anatole de Baudot who, as a pupil of the
label: Paragraph

text: great French ‘structural’ theorist Eugéne Viollet-le-Duc, was
label: Paragraph

text: preoccupied with revealed structure as the only valid basis
label: Paragraph

text: for expression in architecture. On these grounds, de Baudot
label: Paragraph

text: consigned monolithic béton armé to the field of engineering,
label: Paragraph

text: while reserving for the architect the statically more explicit
label: Paragraph

text: and articulate technique of ciment armé, a technology
label: Paragraph

text: whose expressive qualities were most fully demonstrated in
label: Paragraph

text: his church of St-Jean-de-Montmartre in Paris (begun in
label: Paragraph

text: The intricate vaulting there was closely related to a
label: Paragraph

text: whole sequence of grande salle projects which de Baudot
label: Paragraph

text: designed between 1910 and 1914. After Viollet-le-Duc, he
label: Paragraph

text: was concerned with the problem of the great space as the
label: Paragraph

text: necessary proving ground for any architectural culture. In
label: Paragraph

text: this context his grande salle series, which commenced with
label: Paragraph

text: a vast project for the 1900 Exhibition, may be seen as
label: Paragraph

text: anticipating the reticulated flat slabs and prefabricated
label: Paragraph

text: folded shells that were to be achieved half a century later
label: Paragraph

text: by the Italian engineer Pier Luigi Nervi, most typically in the
label: Paragraph

text: Turin Exhibition Hall of 1948 and the Gatti Wool Factory,
label: Paragraph

text: built outside Rome in 1953.
label: Paragraph

text: In opposition to de Baudot’s principle of reticulated form,
label: Paragraph

text: the challenge of the great space was answered by Max Berg
label: Paragraph

text: through the use of reinforced-concrete elements of
label: Paragraph

text: enormous size, in his Jahrhunderthalle [20] built by
label: Paragraph

text: Konwiarz and Trauer for the Breslau Exhibition of 1913.
label: Caption

text: Inside this vast, centralized hall, 65 metres (213 feet) in
label: Paragraph

text: diameter, the concrete ribs of the cupola sprang from a
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter ring beam which was in its turn supported by
label: Paragraph

text: massive pendentive arches. This awkward Herculean
label: Paragraph

text: structure was concealed on the outside by concentric tiers
label: Paragraph

text: of glazing, the organic plan and dynamic structure being
label: Paragraph

text: suppressed by the superimposition of Neo-Classical
label: Paragraph

text: elements.
label: Paragraph

text: 20 Berg, Jahrhunderthalle, Breslau (Wroctaw), 1913.
label: Caption

text: Up to 1895, ferroconcrete work in North America was
label: Paragraph

text: inhibited by its dependence on the importation of cement
label: Paragraph

text: from Europe. Soon after, however, the epoch of the grain
label: Paragraph

text: silo and the flatted factory commenced, first in Canada, with
label: Paragraph

text: the reinforced-concrete silo structures of Max Toltz, and
label: Paragraph

text: then, from 1900 onwards, in the United States, in the work
label: Paragraph

text: of Ernest L. Ransome, who was the inventor of twisted
label: Paragraph

text: reinforcement. With the building in 1902 of his 91-metre
label: Paragraph

text: (300-foot) machine shop at Greensburg, Pennsylvania,
label: Caption

text: Ransome became the pioneer of the monolithic concrete
label: Paragraph

text: frame in the United States. Here he applied for the first time
label: Paragraph

text: the principle of spiral column reinforcement in accordance
label: Paragraph

text: with the theories of Considéré. It says something for the
label: Paragraph

text: technical precociousness of Frank Lloyd Wright that he
label: Paragraph

text: began to design reinforced-concrete structures at around
label: Paragraph

text: the same time: his unrealized Village Bank project of 1901,
label: Paragraph

text: and the E-Z Polish factory and Unity Temple, completed in
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago in 1905 and 1906 respectively.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile, in Paris, Perret Freres had begun to design
label: Paragraph

text: and build their first all-concrete structures, beginning with
label: Paragraph

text: Auguste Perret’s seminal Rue Franklin apartment block of
label: Paragraph

text: 1903 and his Théatre des Champs-Elysées of 1913. At about
label: Paragraph

text: the same time, Henri Sauvage explored the expressive
label: Paragraph

text: ‘plastic’ potential of this new monolithic material in his set-
label: Paragraph

text: back apartments in the Rue Vavin, completed in 1912. By
label: Caption

text: this date the reinforced-concrete frame had become a
label: Paragraph

text: normative technique, and from now on most of the
label: Paragraph

text: development was to lie in the scale of its application and in
label: Paragraph

text: its assimilation as an expressive element. While its first use
label: Paragraph

text: on a megastructural scale was in Matté Trucco’s 40-hectare
label: Paragraph

text: (100-acre) Fiat Works, begun in Turin in 1915 [21], its
label: Paragraph

text: appropriation as the primary expressive element of an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural language came with Le Corbusier’s ‘Maison
label: Paragraph

text: Dom-Lno’ proposal of around the same date. Where the one
label: Paragraph

text: clearly demonstrated that flat concrete roofs could sustain
label: Paragraph

text: the vibration of dynamic moving loads - the Fiat factory has
label: Paragraph

text: a test track on its roof - the other postulated the
label: Paragraph

text: Hennebique system as a ‘patent’ primal structure to which,
label: Paragraph

text: after the manner of Laugier’s primitive hut, the
label: Paragraph

text: development of the new architecture would have to refer.
label: Paragraph

text: 21 Trucco, Fiat Works, Turin, 1915-21.
label: Caption

text: From an engineering standpoint, this period was to reach
label: Paragraph

text: its most sublime expression in the early work of the
label: Paragraph

text: engineers Robert Maillart and Eugéne Freyssinet. By 1905 in
label: Paragraph

text: his Rhine Bridge at Tavanasa, the great Swiss engineer
label: Paragraph

text: Maillart had already arrived at his characteristic bridge form
label: Paragraph

text: - a three-hinged arch of hollow box section, with triangular
label: Caption

text: openings cut into its sides to reduce unnecessary weight
label: Paragraph

text: and to impart a light and expressive character to the overall
label: Paragraph

text: form. By 1912, Maillart had achieved the first beamless floor
label: Paragraph

text: slab in Europe, in a five-storey warehouse that he built in
label: Paragraph

text: Altdorf. His beamless system seems to have been an
label: Paragraph

text: advance over the mushroom slab construction developed
label: Title

text: slightly earlier by the American engineer Claude Allen Porter
label: Caption

text: Turner. In Turner’s ‘four-way’ reinforcement, as opposed to
label: Paragraph

text: Maillart’s ‘two-way’ system, the bars were required to pass
label: Paragraph

text: over all column heads, with the consequence that the steel
label: Paragraph

text: could not be accommodated within an economic depth if the
label: Paragraph

text: tendency of the column to punch through the slab was to be
label: Paragraph

text: resisted. The floor structure in the Turner system was, in
label: Paragraph

text: effect, a network of heavily reinforced flat beams with large
label: Paragraph

text: column heads to resist the resulting shear. The beamless
label: Paragraph

text: ‘two-way’ Maillart system was lighter and generated far less
label: Paragraph

text: shear, with a corresponding reduction in the dimensions of
label: Paragraph

text: both the slab and the column heads.
label: Paragraph

text: In his Aare Bridge at Aarburg (1911) Maillart succeeded
label: Paragraph

text: in articulating the bridge platform from its supporting arch
label: Paragraph

text: while stiffening the platform through transverse frames set
label: Paragraph

text: into the haunch of the arch. He had still to articulate the
label: Paragraph

text: abutments of the bridge in relation to its overall form. In
label: Paragraph

text: almost all his bridges, even where supported by ribbed
label: Paragraph

text: arches, Maillart designed the platform as a box section so
label: Paragraph

text: that as far as possible the road bed was made to support
label: Paragraph

text: itself. He reached the height of his powers as a bridge
label: Paragraph

text: builder with his 90-metre (295-foot) span Salginatobel
label: Paragraph

text: Bridge, erected in the Alps in 1930, but the formula that he
label: Paragraph

text: had first worked out at Aarburg received its finest
label: Paragraph

text: expression in the Arve Bridge [22], built at Vessey near
label: Paragraph

text: Geneva in 1936.
label: Paragraph

text: 22 Maillart, Arve Bridge, Vessey, 1936. Half-section of bridge and section
label: Caption

text: through transverse ‘haunch’, with reinforcement layout.
label: Paragraph

text: The high twin airship hangars that the French engineer
label: Paragraph

text: Freyssinet realized at Orly between 1916 and 1924, each
label: Paragraph

text: 62.5 metres high and 300 metres long (205 by 984 feet),
label: Paragraph

text: were one of first attempts, after the projects of de Baudot,
label: Paragraph

text: to design monolithic structures whose assembled elements
label: Paragraph

text: were capable of supporting themselves. These pioneer
label: Paragraph

text: prefabricated folded slab constructions influenced a
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable series of aircraft hangars designed by Nervi in
label: Paragraph

text: the latter half of the 1930s. While still at work at Orly,
label: Paragraph

text: Freyssinet designed for the concrete contractor Limousin a
label: Caption

text: series of reinforced-concrete ‘bowstring’ warehouse
label: Caption

text: structures, including a number of hangars and factory
label: Paragraph

text: buildings lit through monitor lights in the shell roof. The
label: Paragraph

text: culmination of all this work was two large bowstring bridges
label: Paragraph

text: in reinforced concrete, at St-Pierre-du-Vauvray (1923) and at
label: Paragraph

text: Plougastel (1926-29) [23], the latter crossing the Elorn
label: Paragraph

text: estuary in Brittany in three spans with a total length of 975
label: Paragraph

text: metres (3,200 feet).

text: The problem of the intense compressive and tensile
label: Title

text: stresses induced in the curing and loading of large parabolic
label: Paragraph

text: arches led Freyssinet by the mid-1920s to experiment with
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph
