text: The enthusiasm of the Gothic revivalists died out when they
label: Paragraph

text: were confronted by the fact that they form part of a society
label: Paragraph

text: which will not and cannot have a living style, because it is
label: Paragraph

text: an economical necessity for its existence that the ordinary
label: Paragraph

text: everyday work of its population shall be mechanical
label: Paragraph

text: drudgery, and because it is the harmony of the ordinary
label: Paragraph

text: everyday work of the population which produces Gothic,
label: Paragraph

text: that is living architectural art, and mechanical drudgery
label: Paragraph

text: cannot be harmonized into art.
label: Paragraph

text: The hope of our ignorance has passed away, but it has
label: Paragraph

text: given place to the hope of fresh knowledge. History taught
label: Paragraph

text: us the evolution of architecture, it is now teaching us the
label: Paragraph

text: evolution of society; and it is clear to us (and even to many
label: Paragraph

text: who refuse to acknowledge it) that ... the new society will
label: Paragraph

text: not be hag ridden as we are by the necessity for producing
label: Paragraph

text: ever more and more market-wares for a profit, whether any
label: Paragraph

text: one needs them or not; that it will produce to live and not
label: Paragraph

text: live to produce, as we do,
label: Paragraph

text: William Morris
label: Title

text: The Revival of Architecture, 18881
label: Caption

text: Prefigured in the Puritan and apocalyptic works of Milton
label: Paragraph

text: and Blake, the Scottish phifosophe Thomas Carlyle and the
label: Title

text: English architect A.W.N. Pugin separately called forth the
label: Paragraph

text: spiritual and cultural discontents of the second half of the
label: Paragraph

text: 19th century. The former was atheistic and consciously
label: Paragraph

text: aligned to the radical Chartist movement of the late 1830s;
label: Paragraph

text: the latter was a Catholic convert who advocated a direct
label: Paragraph

text: return to the spiritual values and architectural forms of the
label: Paragraph

text: Middle Ages. After the publication, in 1836, of his Contrasts;
label: Paragraph

text: or a parallel between the noble edifices of the 14th and 15th
label: Paragraph

text: centuries and similar buildings of the present day, Pugin’s
label: Paragraph

text: influence was immediate and extensive. To him we owe
label: Paragraph

text: largely the homogeneity of the Gothic Revival, which
label: Paragraph

text: profoundly affected English building in the 19th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Carlyle, on the other hand, was in many respects in
label: Paragraph

text: opposition to Pugin. His Past and Present of 1843 was an
label: Paragraph

text: implicit critique of Catholicism in its decadence, presenting
label: Paragraph

text: the case for a brand of paternalistic socialism on the model
label: Paragraph

text: of Saint-Simon’s New Christianity, of 1825. Whereas
label: Paragraph

text: Carlyle’s radicalism was politically and socially progressive,
label: Paragraph

text: even if ultimately authoritarian, Pugin’s reformism was
label: Paragraph

text: essentially conservative and related to the right-wing, High
label: Paragraph

text: Church Oxford Movement, whose foundation preceded by
label: Paragraph

text: two years his conversion to Catholicism in 1835. What
label: Paragraph

text: Carlyle and Pugin had in common was distaste for their
label: Paragraph

text: materialistic age: through this shared antagonism they were
label: Paragraph

text: to influence that mid-19th-century prophet of cultural doom
label: Paragraph

text: and redemption, John Ruskin, who in his prime in 1868
label: Paragraph

text: became the first Slade Professor of Fine Art at the University
label: Paragraph

text: of Oxford.
label: Paragraph

text: Ruskin, who acquired his intellectual following in 1846
label: Paragraph

text: with the appearance of the second volume of his Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Painters, did not begin to declare himself unequivocally and
label: Paragraph

text: extensively on socio-cultural and economic matters until
label: Paragraph

text: 1853, when he published The Stones of Venice. There, ina
label: Paragraph

text: whole chapter devoted to the place of the craftsman in
label: Title

text: relation to the work of art, Ruskin first spoke out against the
label: Paragraph

text: industrialist ‘division of labour’ and the ‘degradation of the
label: Title

text: operative into a machine’ - a text that was to be reissued as
label: Paragraph

text: a pamphlet by the first Working Men’s College, at which
label: Paragraph

text: Ruskin subsequently taught. In it, after Adam Smith, Ruskin
label: Paragraph

text: compared traditional craftsmanship with the mechanical
label: Paragraph

text: labour of mass production. He wrote, ‘It is not, truly
label: Paragraph

text: speaking, the labour that is divided; but the men ... so that
label: Paragraph

text: all the little piece of intelligence that is left in a man is not
label: Paragraph

text: enough to make a pin or a nail, but exhausts itself in making
label: Paragraph

text: the point of a pin or the head of a nail.’ This was an
label: Paragraph

text: extension of his attitude to ornament, already outlined in
label: Paragraph

text: The Seven Lamps of Architecture (1849), where he wrote
label: Paragraph

text: that ‘the right question to ask, respecting all ornament, is
label: Paragraph

text: simply this: was it done with enjoyment?’ With this brand of
label: Paragraph

text: radicalism, Ruskin began to move away from his earlier High
label: Paragraph

text: Anglican sympathies to a position much closer to that of
label: Paragraph

text: Carlyle. On the publication in 1860 of his essays in political
label: Paragraph

text: economy, Unto this Last, Ruskin finally revealed himself as
label: Paragraph

text: an uncompromising socialist.
label: Paragraph

text: Through their influence on the English cultural climate
label: Paragraph

text: via Pugin, Friedrich Overbeck - whom Pugin described as
label: Paragraph

text: ‘that prince of Christian painters’ - and the German
label: Title

text: Nazarenes became the moral and artistic model for the
label: Paragraph

text: short-lived, Chartist-inspired, Pre-Raphaelite brotherhood,
label: Paragraph

text: formed at the instigation of the brothers Dante Gabriel and
label: Paragraph

text: William Michael Rossetti, and Holman Hunt and John Everett
label: Title

text: Millais in 1848.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1851 Ruskin became spiritually affiliated to this
label: Paragraph

text: movement, which had as its aim the foundation of a school
label: Paragraph

text: of painting which would be expressive of profound ideas and
label: Paragraph

text: emotions. The ideal was to create an art form derived
label: Paragraph

text: directly from nature and not from artistic conventions of
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance origin. This eminently anti-Classical, Romantic
label: Paragraph

text: attitude was propagated in 1850 in the Pre-Raphaelite
label: Paragraph

text: magazine, The Germ. Yet the brotherhood lacked the
label: Paragraph

text: monastic strictness and conviction of the Nazarenes. Both it
label: Paragraph

text: and its magazine were too individualistic to last for long,
label: Paragraph

text: and by 1853 Pre-Raphaelitism as a collective movement was
label: Paragraph

text: defunct.
label: Paragraph

text: The second, craft-orientated, phase of Pre-Raphaelite
label: Paragraph

text: activity turns upon the meeting of William Morris and
label: Paragraph

text: Edward Burne-Jones when undergraduates at Oxford, in
label: Paragraph

text: 1853. Oxford exposed them to the lectures of Ruskin and to
label: Paragraph

text: the all-pervasive influence of Pugin. After their graduation,
label: Paragraph

text: in 1856, they became closely involved with the poet and
label: Paragraph

text: painter Dante Gabriel Rossetti, eventually collaborating with
label: Paragraph

text: him in 1857 on murals for the Union Society building at
label: Caption

text: Oxford, an enterprise that deliberately echoed the Nazarene
label: Paragraph

text: frescoes in Rome. Although Burne-Jones had already
label: Paragraph

text: determined to become a painter, it was some months before
label: Paragraph

text: Rossetti could lure Morris to London, away from his articled
label: Paragraph

text: position in the Oxford office of the Gothic Revivalist
label: Paragraph

text: architect G.E. Street. Somewhat paradoxically, Morris’s
label: Paragraph

text: career as a designer dates from his decision, late in 1856, to
label: Paragraph

text: abandon architecture for painting; but that had to wait upon
label: Paragraph

text: the furnishing of his rooms in London, for which he designed
label: Paragraph

text: his first ‘intensely medieval furniture ... as firm and as
label: Paragraph

text: heavy as a rock’. These unpretentious pieces, no doubt
label: Paragraph

text: inspired by the craft ideals of Ruskin, were designed under
label: Paragraph

text: the guidance of Philip Webb, with whom Morris had
label: Paragraph

text: previously worked in Street’s office. In 1858 Pre-Raphaelite
label: Paragraph

text: domestic culture was crystallized, as it were, in Morris’s only
label: Paragraph

text: known easel work, a portrait of his wife, Jane Burden, as
label: Paragraph

text: Queen Guinevere or La Belle Iseu/t, wearing ornate clothes
label: Paragraph

text: in an ideal Pre-Raphaelite interior. Morris then gave up
label: Paragraph

text: painting entirely and addressed himself to the task of
label: Paragraph

text: furnishing his new home, the Red House [25, 26], which
label: Paragraph

text: Philip Webb built for him in 1859 at Bexleyheath, Kent, in a
label: Caption

text: style which except for minor details was close to the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Street and more particularly to William Butterfield’s Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: Revival vicarages dating from the 1840s and 1850s.
label: Caption

text: 25, 26 Webb, Red House, Bexleyheath, Kent, 1859. View, and plans of ground
label: Caption

text: and first floors.
label: Paragraph

text: In the Red House (so called on account of its brickwork)
label: Paragraph

text: Webb established the principles which were soon to inform
label: Paragraph

text: the work of his brilliant contemporaries William Eden
label: Paragraph

text: Nesfield and Richard Norman Shaw, and for which he was to
label: Paragraph

text: be known throughout his career - his concern for structural
label: Paragraph

text: integrity and his desire to integrate buildings into their site
label: Paragraph

text: and into the local culture. These aims he achieved through
label: Paragraph

text: practical design, sensitive site layout and the use of local
label: Title

text: materials, coupled with a profound respect for traditional
label: Paragraph

text: building methods. Like Morris, his first client and lifelong
label: Paragraph

text: colleague, Webb had an almost mystical respect for the
label: Paragraph

text: sacredness of craftsmanship and for the earth in which both
label: Paragraph

text: life and architecture were ultimately founded. Even more
label: Paragraph

text: than Morris, he was against any excessive use of ornament.
label: Paragraph

text: According to his biographer, W.R. Lethaby, Webb once
label: Paragraph

text: complained that an overelegant grate was ‘hardly fit for the
label: Paragraph

text: holy fire’. Such a sentiment could hardly be further removed
label: Paragraph

text: from the mannered interpretation that his approach was to
label: Paragraph

text: be given at the hands of Nesfield and Shaw, for instance in
label: Paragraph

text: the latter’s picturesque ‘Old English’ country house,
label: Paragraph

text: Leyswood, Sussex, designed in 1866 [27].
label: Caption

text: 27 Shaw, Leyswood, Sussex, 1866-69.
label: Caption

text: The whole exuberant unfolding of the English Free
label: Title

text: Architecture movement, from the eccentricities of A.H.
label: Paragraph

text: Mackmurdo and C.R. Ashbee to the refined professionalism
label: Paragraph

text: of Shaw, Lethaby and C.F.A. Voysey, may be said to have
label: Paragraph

text: had its origin in the creation of the Red House. At all events,
label: Paragraph

text: this work was Catalytic in launching Morris on his destined
label: Paragraph

text: career, and two years later he organized an association of
label: Paragraph

text: Pre-Raphaelite artists, including Webb, Rossetti, Burne-Jones
label: Paragraph

text: and Ford Madox Brown, into an atelier which would design
label: Paragraph

text: and execute on commission anything from murals to stained
label: Paragraph

text: glass and furniture, from embroidery to metalwork and
label: Title

text: carved wood. The aim, as in Pugin’s extensive furnishings
label: Paragraph

text: designed for the Houses of Parliament in the 1830s and
label: Paragraph

text: 1840s, was the creation of a total work of art. This much,
label: Paragraph

text: with all modesty, the prospectus of the firm made clear: ‘It
label: Paragraph

text: is anticipated that by such co-operation ... the work must
label: Paragraph

text: necessarily be of a much more complete order than if any
label: Paragraph

text: single artist were incidentally employed in the usual
label: Paragraph

text: manner.’ Apart from the precedent established by Pugin, the
label: Paragraph

text: foundation of this atelier may well have been influenced by
label: Paragraph

text: the Art Manufactures organization, started by Henry Cole
label: Paragraph

text: under the pseudonym of Felix Summerly in 1845. In any
label: Paragraph

text: event, the Pre-Raphaelite craft work that had hitherto
label: Paragraph

text: occurred spontaneously now took on a public character. It is
label: Paragraph

text: fitting that the first work to be sold at the London premises
label: Paragraph

text: of the firm was glass tableware designed by Webb.
label: Paragraph

text: With the prospering of the atelier, Morris was
label: Paragraph

text: paradoxically compelled to leave the idyllic Red House in
label: Paragraph

text: 1864 and to move permanently to London. A year later he
label: Paragraph

text: gave over the management of the firm to Warrington Taylor,
label: Paragraph

text: in order to devote himself exclusively to two-dimensional
label: Paragraph

text: design and to literature, the two activities which were to
label: Paragraph

text: consume the rest of his life. The first Morris wallpapers date
label: Paragraph

text: from this period, as do the earliest works in stained glass by
label: Paragraph

text: himself and Burne-Jones. Morris’s models varied from
label: Paragraph

text: Persian décor, illustrated in Owen Jones’s Grammar of
label: Paragraph

text: Ornament of 1856, to the medieval style which he naturally
label: Paragraph

text: adopted for his stained-glass work - a product for which
label: Paragraph

text: there was a steady, if limited, demand throughout his life.
label: Paragraph

text: Morris, Marshall, Faulkner & Co. achieved public recognition
label: Paragraph

text: in 1867 with the Green Dining Room or tea room that Webb
label: Paragraph

text: designed for the South Kensington (now the Victoria and
label: Caption

text: Albert) Museum in London. The room was entirely furnished
label: Paragraph

text: and decorated by Morris and the artist-craftsmen of his firm.
label: Paragraph

text: After this date, Webb started to design and execute large
label: Paragraph

text: domestic commissions on his own, culminating in his last
label: Paragraph

text: great house, Standen, built near East Grinstead, Sussex
label: Caption

text: (1891-94), with furnishings provided - as was usually the
label: Paragraph

text: case - by Morris’s firm. Morris became increasingly involved
label: Paragraph

text: with literature, from which he attempted fanatically to
label: Paragraph

text: expunge all words of Latin origin, producing by the mid-
label: Paragraph

text: 1870s extensive translations of Icelandic sagas, in addition
label: Paragraph

text: to numerous volumes of his own Romantic poetry. At that
label: Paragraph

text: time it would seem as if medieval Iceland was the final
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Nowhere’ that his idealistic spirit pined for, while it
label: Paragraph

text: remained sequestered within the industrial reality of the
label: Paragraph

text: 19th century.
label: Paragraph

text: The year 1875 was a watershed in Morris’s life. The firm
label: Paragraph

text: was dissolved and reorganized as Morris & Co. under his
label: Paragraph

text: sole control, and he began to increase the number of crafts
label: Paragraph

text: in which he and hence the firm could work. He taught
label: Paragraph

text: himself dyeing and carpet weaving and, in 1877,
label: Paragraph

text: established a London showroom as a prime commercial
label: Paragraph

text: outlet. From then on, aside from the management of the
label: Paragraph

text: firm and the design and production of a whole range of
label: Paragraph

text: wallpapers, hangings and carpets, Morris’s concerns
label: Paragraph

text: gradually became increasingly public and less ‘poetic’ and
label: Paragraph

text: craft-orientated. He seems to have felt it his duty to take up
label: Paragraph

text: publicly the socialist and preservationist causes of Ruskin,
label: Paragraph

text: who was by now mentally ill. Thus, in 1877 he wrote his first
label: Paragraph

text: political pamphlet and founded the Society for the
label: Paragraph

text: Protection of Ancient Buildings, in a successful attempt to
label: Paragraph

text: foil Sir George Gilbert Scott’s intentions to restore, or rather
label: Paragraph

text: partly to rebuild, Tewkesbury Abbey in Gloucestershire.
label: Caption

text: In the decade following his reorganization of the firm,
label: Paragraph

text: Morris divided his life equally between politics and design,
label: Paragraph

text: producing during this period, according to his first
label: Paragraph

text: biographer, Mackail, over 600 designs for various fabrics. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1883, however, Morris began to read the works of Karl Marx
label: Paragraph

text: and joined the Social Democratic Federation, headed by
label: Paragraph

text: Engels, in the company of such committed socialists as
label: Paragraph

text: Eleanor Marx and Edward Aveling. Two years later he left the
label: Paragraph

text: Federation and founded the Socialist League, shifting
label: Paragraph

text: virtually all of his energies from design to politics. At
label: Paragraph

text: frequent intervals, until his death in 1896, he wrote and
label: Paragraph

text: published essays on the related themes of socialism, culture
label: Paragraph

text: and society, beginning with his Fourierist essay of 1885
label: Paragraph

text: entitled How We Live and How We Might Live, and
label: Paragraph

text: culminating in his famous utopian romance, News from
label: Paragraph

text: Nowhere, of 1891.
label: Paragraph

text: To the coming generations, to Morris’s associate Walter
label: Paragraph

text: Crane, to Ruskin’s protégé Mackmurdo and to the principal
label: Paragraph

text: pupils of Shaw, namely Lethaby, E.S. Prior and Ernest
label: Paragraph

text: Newton, even to Shaw himself, and to relative outsiders
label: Paragraph

text: such as Ashbee and Voysey, Morris’s somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: contradictory position was patently clear. Above all there
label: Paragraph

text: was his utopian vision of ‘Nowhere’, a land where the state
label: Paragraph

text: had withered away according to Marxist prophecy and
label: Paragraph

text: where all distinction between town and country had
label: Paragraph

text: disappeared. The city no longer existed as a dense physical
label: Paragraph

text: entity and the great engineering achievements of the 19th
label: Title

text: century had been dismantled: wind and water were once
label: Paragraph

text: more the sole sources of power, and the waterway and the
label: Paragraph

text: road were the sole means of transport. A society without
label: Paragraph

text: money or property, without crime or punishment, without
label: Paragraph

text: prison or parliament, where social order depended solely
label: Paragraph

text: upon the free association of family groups within the
label: Paragraph

text: structure of the commune. Finally, a society where work was
label: Paragraph

text: based on the banded workshop, the guild or Werkbund, and
label: Paragraph

text: where education was free and like labour itself unforced.
label: Paragraph

text: This single-minded socialist vision stood out in strong
label: Paragraph

text: contrast to the context of Morris’s own life and to the latent
label: Paragraph

text: inconsistency of his thought. There was his prosperous firm
label: Paragraph

text: itself, a laissez-faire phenomenon par excellence, whose
label: Paragraph

text: diverse luxury goods were consumed by the upper middle
label: Paragraph

text: class; then there was his highly radical socialism, largely
label: Paragraph

text: unintegrated with his innate anarchic leanings - a
label: Paragraph

text: revolutionary socialism totally unacceptable to the more
label: Title

text: liberal of his followers, such as Ashbee; and finally, for
label: Paragraph

text: Fabian Socialists and architects alike, there was within
label: Paragraph

text: Morris’s theory and practice the ameliorative suggestion of
label: Paragraph

text: the garden city as a form of settlement to be based on the
label: Paragraph

text: craft guild or cooperative, as a means for achieving not only
label: Paragraph

text: work, but also evolutionary social reform and re-education,
label: Paragraph

text: and so, by degrees, some public recognition for both. In
label: Paragraph

text: contrast to this progressive (if somewhat disturbing) breadth
label: Paragraph

text: of concern, there was the latent phobic quality of Morris’s
label: Paragraph

text: own design and - more critical still - there was his stubborn
label: Paragraph

text: refusal to come to terms with industrial method and his
label: Paragraph

text: ambiguous, not to say hostile, attitude to all architecture
label: Paragraph

text: after the 15th century. Not only was the Classical past
label: Paragraph

text: condemned but even sympathetic contemporary work was
label: Paragraph

text: indifferently received: Webb’s fine designs singularly failed
label: Paragraph

text: to draw from Morris any public recognition. Could it be that
label: Paragraph

text: Webb's eclecticism was finally too much for Morris; that the
label: Paragraph

text: Classical and Elizabethan elements that were incorporated
label: Paragraph

text: into his houses between 1879 and 1891 were sufficient
label: Paragraph

text: cause for disaffection?
label: Title

text: In the event, the historicism of the period was hardly
label: Paragraph

text: capable of sustaining Morris’s anti-Classical line. By the
label: Paragraph

text: early 1870s worldly architects like Shaw were already
label: Paragraph

text: manipulating and classicizing, in an urban context, the
label: Paragraph

text: Queen Anne style that he, Webb and Nesfield had
label: Paragraph

text: developed out of the English and Dutch domestic traditions.
label: Paragraph

text: Before his wholesale conversion to Neo-Georgian in the
label: Paragraph

text: early 1890s, Shaw established a respectable precedent for
label: Paragraph

text: adopting a classic, if mannered, format in town, such as
label: Paragraph

text: Swan House, Chelsea, of 1875-77, and a free, Picturesque,
label: Paragraph

text: convenient one in the country, such as Pierrepoint, at
label: Paragraph

text: Frensham in Surrey, of 1876-78.
label: Caption

text: Despite his sophistry, Shaw was influenced by Ruskinian
label: Paragraph

text: sociocultural concerns. In 1877 he began to design, for the
label: Paragraph

text: artistic property speculator Jonathan T. Carr, houses for the
label: Caption

text: first garden suburb, located on the western outskirts of
label: Paragraph

text: London. The red brick and tile-hung style of this upper-
label: Paragraph

text: middle-class garden ‘village’, known as Bedford Park [28],
label: Paragraph

text: was celebrated in the flippant ‘Ballad of Bedford Park’,
label: Paragraph

text: published in the St j/ames’s Gazette in 1881:
label: Caption

text: 28 Voysey, house in Bedford Park, London, 1890.
label: Caption

text: Here trees are green and bricks are red
label: Paragraph

text: And clean the face of man.
label: Paragraph

text: We'll build our gardens here he said
label: Paragraph

text: In the style of good Queen Anne.
label: Paragraph

text: Tis here a village I'll erect
label: Paragraph

text: With Norman Shaw’s assistance
label: Title

text: Where man will lead a chaste
label: Title

text: Correct, aesthetical existence.”
label: Paragraph

text: This brick style extended even into the church, rendered
label: Paragraph

text: significantly secular by the absence of any vertical feature:
label: Paragraph

text: a structure which, although executed in a vague Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: Revival manner, audaciously displayed a Wren-like lantern
label: Paragraph

text: on its roof. The earliest houses of Bedford Park were built in
label: Paragraph

text: 1876 to the designs of the japoniste architect E.W. Godwin.
label: Caption

text: Shaw took over in 1877 and a number of different architects
label: Paragraph

text: worked there under his influence over the next decade,
label: Paragraph

text: including at the tail end Voysey, who built a remarkable
label: Paragraph

text: house in The Parade in 1890.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1878, Shaw published his Sketches for Cottages and
label: Paragraph

text: Other Buildings. This highly influential book illustrated
label: Paragraph

text: numerous designs for workers’ houses of various sizes. It
label: Paragraph

text: also included the essential public building typology for a
label: Paragraph

text: self-contained ideal village community, such as a school, a
label: Paragraph

text: village hall, an almshouse and a cottage hospital. In the
label: Caption

text: following year the first of the paternalistic garden cities
label: Paragraph

text: appeared: Bournville, Birmingham, founded by George
label: Caption

text: Cadbury and designed by Ralph Heaton and others. It was
label: Paragraph

text: largely the Bedford Park model that W.H. Lever followed
label: Paragraph

text: when, less than ten years later in 1888, he founded Port
label: Paragraph

text: Sunlight.
label: Paragraph

text: The evolution of the garden city movement in the last
label: Title

text: decade of the century was intimately linked to the
label: Paragraph

text: development of the Arts and Crafts movement. As
label: Paragraph

text: presented by Ebenezer Howard in 1898, its social policy
label: Paragraph

text: combined urban dispersal with rural colonization and
label: Paragraph

text: decentralized government. As a complement to the co-
label: Paragraph

text: operative movement, it advocated that such a city should
label: Paragraph

text: derive its revenue from a balanced combination of industry
label: Paragraph

text: and agriculture. Howard postulated trade union backing for
label: Paragraph

text: the financing of housing, co-operative ownership of land,
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensive planning and temperance reform. He fixed
label: Paragraph

text: the optimum size of the garden city at 32,000, to be
label: Paragraph

text: restricted from further growth by an isolating green belt.
label: Paragraph

text: Each city was to be regionally located as a satellite
label: Paragraph

text: settlement and linked to a major centre by means of a
label: Paragraph

text: railway. In this form the garden city complemented
label: Paragraph

text: continuing attempts to improve, by social reform, the living
label: Paragraph

text: and working conditions of the industrial proletariat. On his
label: Paragraph

text: return from America in 1876, Howard had become involved
label: Paragraph

text: in those socialist circles frequented by Bernard Shaw and
label: Paragraph

text: Sidney and Beatrice Webb, a group which later, as Fabian
label: Paragraph

text: Socialists, initially rejected the garden city idea. Howard’s
label: Paragraph

text: position, in accordance with the spirit if not with the letter of
label: Paragraph

text: Fabianism, was at once practical and ameliorative. The very
label: Paragraph

text: title of his book of 1898, Tomorrow: a Peaceful Path to Real
label: Paragraph

text: Reform, announced his position as a man of compromise.
label: Paragraph

text: Howard was committed to free enterprise within the limits of
label: Paragraph

text: social control and favoured a piecemeal approach to reform
label: Paragraph

text: rather than revolutionary action. Apart from Ruskin’s St
label: Paragraph

text: George’s Guild of 1871, Howard was to depend for the
label: Paragraph

text: socio-political model of his city on thinkers as diverse as the
label: Paragraph

text: anarchist Peter Kropotkin and the American economist
label: Title

text: Henry George, who in his Progress and Poverty of 1879 had
label: Paragraph

text: advocated a single tax on all ground rent. Howard was
label: Paragraph

text: equally eclectic in deriving the diagrammatic form of his city
label: Paragraph

text: from sources as varied as James Silk Buckingham’s ideal
label: Paragraph

text: town, Victoria, of 1849 and Paxton’s Great Victorian Way
label: Title

text: proposal of 1855.
label: Paragraph

text: It is hard to imagine anything further removed from
label: Paragraph

text: Howard’s initial diagram than the realization of Letchworth
label: Paragraph

text: Garden City, begun in 1904. The railway bisects the city, the
label: Paragraph

text: shopping area is exposed to the weather, and industry is
label: Paragraph

text: mixed with residential areas in a totally expedient way. Its
label: Paragraph

text: architects, Raymond Unwin and Barry Parker, had, it seems,
label: Paragraph

text: little to offer Howard save enfeebled essays in the style of
label: Paragraph

text: Shaw and Webb. Hampstead Garden Suburb, designed by
label: Caption

text: Unwin in 1907, would have been equally insipid had it not
label: Paragraph

text: been for his collaboration with Lutyens.
label: Paragraph

text: Following in the Arts and Crafts tradition of Cole and
label: Paragraph

text: Morris, Mackmurdo founded the Century Guild in 1882. Once
label: Paragraph

text: again this comprised a group of artists who were to engage
label: Paragraph

text: in the design and production of domestic objects. From the
label: Paragraph

text: outset Mackmurdo worked with equal facility as a graphic
label: Paragraph

text: artist and as a wallpaper and furniture designer. He
label: Paragraph

text: publicized his views in collaboration with Selwyn Image,
label: Paragraph

text: founding the Century Guild design group in 1882 and its
label: Paragraph

text: magazine, The Hobby Horse, in 1884. In his applied art of
label: Paragraph

text: the early 1880s Mackmurdo developed a unique style,
label: Paragraph

text: anticipatory of the Art Nouveau: a style which, deriving
label: Paragraph

text: directly from William Blake, was spiritually at variance with
label: Paragraph

text: the elegant but severe forms of his architecture. This found
label: Paragraph

text: its most strict expression in the highly original flat-roofed
label: Paragraph

text: house that he built at Enfield about 1883, and in his more
label: Paragraph

text: gratifying Century Guild Exhibition Stand of 1886.
label: Caption

text: In 1887, Ashbee followed the well-established guild
label: Paragraph

text: model with his foundation in the East End of London of the
label: Paragraph

text: Guild of Handicraft, which incorporated into its programme
label: Paragraph

text: the goal of direct social reform. His guild was established for
label: Paragraph

text: the express purpose of usefully employing and training
label: Paragraph

text: London journeymen and their apprentices, who would
label: Paragraph

text: otherwise have remained unemployed. Ashbee, as we may
label: Paragraph

text: judge from the house that he built for himself in Chelsea in
label: Paragraph

text: 1904, was a more delicate and correct designer than
label: Paragraph

text: Mackmurdo. With his postgraduate Toynbee Hall tutoring
label: Paragraph

text: experience, he was also more committed to direct social
label: Paragraph

text: action as a means of reform. However, although profoundly
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by Morris and Ruskin, he took issue with both for
label: Paragraph

text: their dogmatic antipathy to the machine and for their
label: Paragraph

text: revolutionary socialism. In opposition to his more radical
label: Paragraph

text: predecessors Ashbee styled himself a Constructive Socialist.
label: Paragraph

text: After his meeting with Frank Lloyd Wright, around the turn of
label: Paragraph

text: the century, he was confirmed in his belief that the
label: Paragraph

text: resolution of the cultural dilemma posed by modern industry
label: Title

text: depended on a proper use of the machine. Like Howard,
label: Paragraph

text: Ashbee was a man committed to compromise. He
label: Paragraph

text: advocated the decentralization of existing urban
label: Paragraph

text: concentrations and their institutions, thereby lending further
label: Paragraph

text: support to a link between the Arts and Crafts movement and
label: Paragraph

text: the garden city idea. Again following Howard, Ashbee
label: Paragraph

text: remained opposed to the nationalization of land. Convinced
label: Paragraph

text: that the cultural function of craftwork was to be that of
label: Paragraph

text: human ‘individuation’, Ashbee feared the reductionist
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of radical socialism. Thus later in life he welcomed
label: Paragraph

text: the foundering of the Socialist International on the ‘rock of
label: Paragraph

text: race’. In its place, he favoured a somewhat dated Disraeli
label: Paragraph

text: style of social reform and in consequence was unduly
label: Paragraph

text: sanguine about the virtues of British imperialism. A strong
label: Paragraph

text: sense of economic reality was not part of Ashbee’s make-
label: Paragraph

text: up, and his precious Guild of Handicraft, established as a
label: Paragraph

text: craft-based agrarian community at Chipping Campden in
label: Paragraph

text: Gloucestershire in 1906, collapsed after only two years.
label: Paragraph

text: Such ambitious social ends were not the concern of
label: Paragraph

text: Mackmurdo’s individualistic disciple Voysey, who in 1885
label: Paragraph

text: arrived at a strength and simplicity of style that was to
label: Paragraph

text: elude most of his contemporaries. Voysey derived his style
label: Paragraph

text: from Webb's principles of respect for traditional methods
label: Title

text: and local materials, rather than from Shaw’s inventiveness
label: Paragraph

text: and spatial virtuosity. In an unrealized house project of
label: Paragraph

text: 1885, intended for his own occupation, Voysey formulated
label: Paragraph

text: (despite Shavian half-timbering) the essential components
label: Paragraph

text: of his style: a slate roof with overhanging eaves, wrought-
label: Paragraph

text: iron gutter brackets, and rendered rough-cast walls pierced
label: Caption

text: by horizontal windows and marked at intervals by battered
label: Paragraph

text: buttresses and chimneys. These features were to
label: Paragraph

text: characterize his work for the next thirty years. Stylistically,
label: Paragraph

text: Voysey’s manner was a direct attempt to recover the basic
label: Paragraph

text: merits of English yeoman building. However, his early
label: Paragraph

text: association with Mackmurdo introduced a flowing and highly
label: Paragraph

text: sophisticated element into his work which became manifest
label: Paragraph

text: in his wallpaper and metalwork designs of about 1890.
label: Paragraph

text: These details provided accents in Voysey’s otherwise
label: Paragraph

text: austere interiors. Unlike Morris, Voysey was possessed by a
label: Paragraph

text: sense of restraint, almost to a fault. Thus he stipulated that
label: Paragraph

text: either the fabrics or wallpapers should be patterned, but
label: Paragraph

text: never both. His own house, The Orchard, built at Chorley
label: Paragraph

text: Wood, Hertfordshire, in 1899, exemplifies the lively restraint
label: Paragraph

text: of his interior style: gridded balusters flooded with light, low
label: Paragraph

text: picture rails, tiled fireplace surrounds, plain oak furniture
label: Caption

text: and thick carpets. While these elements were repeated with
label: Paragraph

text: little variation throughout his career, his designs became
label: Paragraph

text: less figurative as the years advanced, and where his early
label: Paragraph

text: furniture tended towards the organic, his later pieces are
label: Paragraph

text: based on Classical themes.
label: Paragraph

text: Between 1889 and 1910 Voysey designed some forty
label: Paragraph

text: houses, a number of which transcended the latent
label: Paragraph

text: historicism of his style. Among these are the artist’s
label: Paragraph

text: residence for J.W. Forster built in Bedford Park in 1890, the
label: Paragraph

text: Sturgis House in Guildford of 1896, and Broadleys [29] on
label: Caption

text: Lake Windermere, his finest house, realized in 1898.
label: Paragraph

text: Nowhere else did he equal the clarity of its plan, the
label: Paragraph

text: generosity of its layout and landscaping, and the boldness
label: Paragraph

text: of its massing and fenestration. In all this, Voysey’s
label: Paragraph

text: influence was as extensive as his career, Charles Rennie
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh, C.H. Townsend, and the Viennese architects
label: Caption

text: Joseph Maria Olbrich and Josef Hoffmann being among the
label: Paragraph

text: architects influenced by his work.
label: Paragraph

text: 29 Voysey, Broadleys, Cumbria, 1898.
label: Caption

text: During the first phase of Voysey’s career the English Arts
label: Paragraph

text: and Crafts movement became firmly institutionalized:
label: Paragraph

text: initially with the foundation in 1884 of the Art Workers’
label: Paragraph

text: Guild, at the instigation of Lethaby and other members of
label: Paragraph

text: Shaw's office, then in 1887 with the establishment of the
label: Paragraph

text: Arts and Crafts Exhibition Society, presided over by Morris’s
label: Paragraph

text: protégé, Walter Crane. The last twenty-five years of the
label: Paragraph

text: movement prior to the outbreak of the First World War are
label: Paragraph

text: inseparable from the career of Lethaby. After serving for
label: Paragraph

text: twelve years as Shaw's chief assistant, he set up on his own
label: Paragraph

text: in 1895 with the design of Avon Tyrrell, a large mansion in
label: Paragraph

text: the New Forest in southern England. Five years later he was
label: Paragraph

text: installed, jointly with George Frampton, as the first principal
label: Paragraph

text: of the Central School of Arts and Crafts in London. Thus,
label: Paragraph

text: apart from his very brief career as a designer, Lethaby’s role
label: Paragraph

text: within the Arts and Crafts movement turned upon his
label: Paragraph

text: marked abilities as a teacher. In 1892 he published his first
label: Paragraph

text: book, Architecture, Mysticism and Myth, in which he
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated how architecture in the past had always been
label: Paragraph

text: universally informed by cosmic and religious paradigms. He
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to incorporate such symbolism into his own work,
label: Paragraph

text: while his general argument seems to have had an impact on
label: Paragraph

text: the work of his close colleague, E.S. Prior, whose famous
label: Paragraph

text: ‘butterfly plan’ house, The Barn, built at Exmouth, Devon, in
label: Caption

text: 1897, exhibited certain features that were decidedly
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic. (Similar butterfly-plan forms were proposed by
label: Paragraph

text: M.H. Baillie Scott, for Yellowsands in 1902 and for
label: Caption

text: Hampstead Garden Suburb in 1908.)
label: Paragraph

text: With his entry into teaching, Lethaby shifted his attention
label: Paragraph

text: from poetic content to the problem of developing the correct
label: Paragraph

text: method for the evolution of form. Thus, by 1910, he argued
label: Paragraph

text: against his 1892 thesis that one cannot instil magic into
label: Paragraph

text: architecture when it is totally absent in the society.
label: Paragraph

text: For Lethaby, the tradition of which he had been a part
label: Paragraph

text: appeared quite suddenly to be played out. The last in a long
label: Paragraph

text: line of ‘Gothic Revival’ socialists, he was by the turn of the
label: Paragraph

text: century arguing for pure functionalism. In 1915, while
label: Paragraph

text: helping to organize the foundation of the Design and
label: Paragraph

text: Industries Association, he was urging his colleagues to look
label: Paragraph

text: to Germany and the Deutsche Werkbund for the way to the
label: Title

text: future.
label: Paragraph

text: As the first waves of the 1914 war broke across Europe,
label: Paragraph

text: that golden age of dreamlike English country houses,
label: Paragraph

text: ushered in by Webb, Shaw and Nesfield and rendered at its
label: Paragraph

text: most exotic in the elaborate Country Life creations of Edwin
label: Paragraph

text: Landseer Lutyens and Gertrude Jekyll, came definitely to a
label: Paragraph

text: close. Yet this era had effectively ended even earlier, in a
label: Paragraph

text: spate of large Neo-Georgian houses, built, as Robert
label: Paragraph

text: Furneaux Jordan has remarked, for ‘those aesthetic rich who
label: Paragraph

text: after the Boer War had beaten their swords into gold
label: Paragraph

text: shares’. Irrespective of this triumph of Neo-Palladianism in
label: Paragraph

text: Edwardian taste - Lutyens’s passion after the turn of the
label: Paragraph

text: century for what he called the ‘Wrenaissance’- it is unlikely
label: Paragraph

text: that the forms and ideals of the English Arts and Crafts
label: Paragraph

text: movement would have survived the socio-cultural trauma of
label: Paragraph

text: the first large-scale industrialized war. Something of this can
label: Paragraph

text: be sensed from the fate of Liberty & Co. after the war, for
label: Paragraph

text: the holocaust of 1914-18 effectively divided the craft output
label: Paragraph

text: of the firm like a guillotine. In the space of some five years,
label: Paragraph

text: the inventive rigour and brilliance of its Art Nouveau
label: Paragraph

text: silverware gave way to a décor of banal blue china, Tudor
label: Paragraph

text: furniture and the pastiche production of pseudo-Pre-
label: Title

text: Raphaelite stained glass. Liberty & Co. were to opt for this
label: Paragraph

text: degenerated style even in their new premises built in 1924
label: Paragraph

text: to the designs of E.T. Hall and E.S. Hall. This half-timbered
label: Caption

text: department store epitomized the so-called ‘Stockbroker’s
label: Paragraph

text: In the interim, Lutyens, now elevated to the position of

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: vision than these austere monuments isolated in the midst
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: construction in his Fair Store [32] of 1892, and then to
label: Paragraph

text: Dankmar Adler. Edelman’s unusual cultivation, including his
label: Paragraph

text: anarcho-socialist views, derived from Morris and Kropotkin,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: development, evidenced in the latter’s Kindergarten Chats
label: Paragraph

text: During their early careers, Adler and Sullivan were
label: Paragraph

text: preoccupied with meeting the urgent demands of a booming
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago, then being rebuilt as the Midwestern capital after
label: Paragraph

text: its destruction by fire in 1871. In the later 1870s, while Adler
label: Paragraph

text: was still establishing his practice, Sullivan worked for
label: Paragraph

text: Jenney, thereby becoming familiar with the technical
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of Chicago construction. In his 1926 essay, The
label: Paragraph

text: Autobiography of an Idea, Sullivan wrote of the powerful
label: Paragraph

text: forces that led to this method of building.
label: Paragraph

text: The tall commercial building arose from the pressure of land
label: Paragraph

text: prices, the land prices from pressure of population, the
label: Paragraph

text: pressure of population from external pressure ... But an
label: Paragraph

text: office building could not rise above stairway height without
label: Paragraph

text: a means of vertical transportation. Thus pressure was
label: Paragraph

text: brought on the brain of the mechanical engineer, whose
label: Paragraph

text: creative imagination and industry brought forth the
label: Paragraph

text: passenger elevator ... But it was inherent in the nature of
label: Paragraph

text: masonry construction to fix a new limit of height; as its ever-
label: Paragraph

text: thickening walls ate up ground and floor space of ever-
label: Paragraph

text: increasing price, as the pressure of population rapidly
label: Paragraph

text: increased. ... [This] Chicago activity in erecting high
label: Paragraph

text: buildings finally attracted the attention of the local sales
label: Paragraph

text: managers of Eastern rolling mills; and their engineers were
label: Paragraph

text: set to work. The mills for some time past had been rolling
label: Paragraph

text: those structural shapes that had long been in use in bridge
label: Paragraph

text: work. Their own ground work was thus prepared. It was a
label: Paragraph

text: matter of vision in salesmanship based upon engineering
label: Title

text: imagination and technique. Thus, the idea of a steel frame
label: Paragraph

text: which should carry all the load was tentatively presented to
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago architects ... the trick was turned; and there swiftly
label: Paragraph

text: came into being something new under the sun... The
label: Paragraph

text: architects of Chicago welcomed the steel frame and did
label: Paragraph

text: something with it. The architects of the East were appalled
label: Paragraph

text: by it and could make no contribution to it.?
label: Paragraph

text: As Sullivan indicated, the Chicago architects of the 1880s
label: Paragraph

text: had no choice but to master advanced modes of
label: Paragraph

text: construction if they wanted to remain in practice; and while
label: Paragraph

text: the great fire had demonstrated the vulnerability of cast
label: Paragraph

text: iron, the subsequent development of the fireproof steel
label: Paragraph

text: frame - with its ability to provide multistorey rentable space
label: Paragraph

text: - enabled speculators to develop downtown sites to the
label: Paragraph

text: absolute optimum. The contemporary critic Montgomery
label: Caption

text: Schuyler remarked in 1899, ‘the elevator doubled the height
label: Paragraph

text: of the office building and the steel frame doubled it again’.
label: Paragraph

text: Before 1886, Adler and Sullivan were occupied primarily
label: Paragraph

text: with small office structures, warehouses and department
label: Paragraph

text: stores, a commercial practice that was varied from time to
label: Paragraph

text: time by residential commissions. These early buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: limited to about six floors, afforded little scope, except for
label: Paragraph

text: the expression of the frame, be it in iron, masonry ora
label: Paragraph

text: mixture of the two, and one could do little save manipulate
label: Paragraph

text: the Classical division of the facade into base, middle and
label: Paragraph

text: top.
label: Paragraph

text: All this was changed in 1886 by the commission to
label: Paragraph

text: design the Auditorium Building [31, 33], a structure whose
label: Paragraph

text: overall contribution to Chicago culture was to be as much
label: Paragraph

text: technological as conceptual. The basic arrangement of this
label: Paragraph

text: multi-use complex was exemplary. The architects had been
label: Paragraph

text: asked to install, within a half-block of the Chicago grid, a
label: Paragraph

text: large modern opera house flanked on two sides by eleven
label: Caption

text: storeys of accommodation, to be given over in part to
label: Paragraph

text: offices and in part to a hotel. Their unique organization of
label: Paragraph

text: this brief incorporated such innovations as locating the hotel
label: Paragraph

text: kitchen and dining facilities on the roof so that the fumes
label: Paragraph

text: would not disturb the residents. At the same time the
label: Paragraph

text: auditorium itself offered plenty of scope for Adler’s
label: Paragraph

text: technological imagination. He met the demands for a
label: Paragraph

text: variable capacity by using folding ceiling panels and vertical
label: Paragraph

text: screens which could vary the auditorium from a concert size
label: Paragraph

text: of 2,500 to a convention capacity of 7,000. The client’s faith
label: Paragraph

text: in Adler’s technical ability finds some reflection in Adler’s
label: Paragraph

text: own description of the hall:

text: The architectural and decorative forms found in the
label: Paragraph

text: auditorium are unconventional in the extreme and are
label: Paragraph

text: determined to a great extent by the acoustic effects to be
label: Paragraph

text: attained. ... A series of concentric elliptical arches effect the
label: Paragraph

text: lateral and vertical expansion of sound from the proscenium
label: Title

text: opening to the body of the house. The soffits and faces of
label: Paragraph

text: these elliptical surfaces are ornamented in relief, the
label: Paragraph

text: incandescent electric lamps and... inlet openings of the
label: Paragraph

text: ventilating system forming an essential effective part of the
label: Paragraph

text: decoration ... Much attention has been paid to the heating,
label: Paragraph

text: cooling and ventilating apparatus. Fresh air, taken from the
label: Caption

text: top of the building, is forced into the house by a fan... 10
label: Paragraph

text: feet [3 metres] in diameter. ... This washes from the air
label: Paragraph

text: much dust and soot. ... Asystem of ducts carries the air into
label: Paragraph

text: different parts of the auditorium ... stage ... corridor foyers
label: Paragraph

text: and dressing-rooms. The general movement of air is from
label: Paragraph

text: the stage outward and from the ceiling downward ... Ducts
label: Paragraph

text: are carried to ... exhaust fans from openings in the risers of
label: Paragraph

text: all the steppings for the seats.>
label: Paragraph

text: Adler was possibly one of the last architect-engineers to
label: Paragraph

text: prove his competence over a wide technical range. He
label: Paragraph

text: mastered a multitude of difficulties: from the air
label: Paragraph

text: conditioning of the auditorium to the trussed steel girder
label: Caption

text: supporting its acoustical interior; from the accommodation
label: Paragraph

text: of a complex revolving stage to the provision of extensive
label: Paragraph

text: foyers to both the opera house and the hotel. The whole
label: Paragraph

text: complex was housed in a massive masonry and iron
label: Paragraph

text: structure, ingeniously ballasted during construction so as to
label: Paragraph

text: compensate for the differential loading of its foundations.
label: Paragraph

text: The aesthetic of this eleven-storey complex was based
label: Paragraph

text: on an attenuation of the syntax of Richardson’s Marshall
label: Paragraph

text: Field Store. Where Richardson had used rusticated stone
label: Paragraph

text: blocks throughout, Sullivan varied the facing material of the
label: Paragraph

text: Auditorium Building to modulate its greater height and
label: Paragraph

text: mass, changing from rusticated blocks to smooth ashlar
label: Paragraph

text: above the third floor. However, the bleakness and austerity
label: Paragraph

text: of the final result dismayed Adler, who wrote in 1892:
label: Paragraph

text: It is to be regretted that the severe simplicity ... rendered
label: Paragraph

text: necessary by the financial policy of the earlier days of the
label: Paragraph

text: enterprise, the deep impression made by Richardson's
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Marshall Field Building’ upon the Directors of the
label: Paragraph

text: Auditorium Association, and a reaction from a course of
label: Paragraph

text: indulgence in... highly decorative effects on the part of its
label: Paragraph

text: architects, should have happened to coincide ... and thereby
label: Paragraph

text: deprive the exterior of the building of those graces ... so
label: Paragraph

text: characteristic of its internal treatment.4
label: Caption

text: Nevertheless, there is something forceful, taut and
label: Paragraph

text: rhythmic about its overall character, while the colonnade of
label: Paragraph

text: the hotel veranda on the lake front is echoed by similar
label: Paragraph

text: delicate motifs in the tower. The slight hint of orientalism in
label: Paragraph

text: this veranda anticipates the decidedly Turkish feeling of the
label: Paragraph

text: Charnley House in Chicago that Sullivan was to design in
label: Paragraph

text: 1892, in close collaboration with his assistant Frank Lloyd
label: Paragraph

text: Wright.
label: Paragraph

text: Richardson was to remain the ultimate determinant of
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan’s early style. In Sullivan’s hands Richardson's finely
label: Paragraph

text: modulated use of the Romanesque became brutally
label: Paragraph

text: simplified into an almost Neo-Classical manner, which was
label: Paragraph

text: first developed in his Walker Warehouse of 1888 and in his
label: Paragraph

text: Dooly Block of 1890. These were surely those buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: ‘well formed and comely in the nude’, to which he referred
label: Paragraph

text: in Ornament in Architecture of 1892. From now on Sullivan’s
label: Paragraph

text: delimitation of mass depended on pronounced string-
label: Paragraph

text: courses and projecting cornices. Fenestration is grouped in
label: Paragraph

text: elongated arcades, while smooth, flush facades are
label: Paragraph

text: articulated by taut decorative episodes. The Getty [34] and
label: Paragraph

text: Wainwright tombs, designed in 1890 and 1892, epitomize
label: Paragraph

text: the consolidation and refinement of this approach, which
label: Paragraph

text: was rendered on a large scale in the Wainwright Building,
label: Paragraph

text: completed in St Louis, Missouri, in 1891. As in the work of
label: Paragraph

text: the Viennese architect Otto Wagner, the basic austerity of
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan’s stereometric structures was in opposition to the
label: Paragraph

text: ornamentation by which they were enriched and articulated.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet, in contrast to Wagner’s flowing ornament, there is
label: Paragraph

text: always something decidedly Islamic about Sullivan’s
label: Paragraph

text: disposition of decoration. Even where his ornament is not
label: Paragraph

text: intrinsically geometric it is almost always contained by
label: Paragraph

text: geometric form. In this recourse to the aesthetic and even
label: Paragraph

text: the symbolic content of the East, Sullivan sought to
label: Paragraph

text: reconcile that schism in Western culture between the
label: Paragraph

text: intellectual and the emotional, poles which he was to
label: Paragraph

text: associate later with the Greek and the Gothic. Between the
label: Paragraph

text: Auditorium and the Wainwright Building, the character of
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan’s ornament alternates from being organically free to
label: Paragraph

text: conforming to the outline of a precise geometry. In the
label: Paragraph

text: Transportation Building for the Chicago World’s Columbian
label: Caption

text: Exposition of 1893, it becomes predominantly geometric, or,
label: Paragraph

text: where free, strictly contained within a geometric grid. As
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright wrote in his book, Genius and the
label: Paragraph

text: Mobocracy (1949), this ‘crystallization’ finally arrived at its
label: Paragraph

text: definitive form in Sullivan’s Guaranty Building at Buffalo,
label: Paragraph

text: New York, of 1895.
label: Paragraph

text: 34 Sullivan, Getty tomb, Graceland cemetery, Chicago, 1890.
label: Caption

text: Neither Sullivan nor Jenney can be credited with the
label: Paragraph

text: invention of the skyscraper, if by that term one simply
label: Paragraph

text: means a multistorey structure of great height, since such
label: Paragraph

text: heights had already been achieved in load-bearing brick just
label: Paragraph

text: prior to Sullivan’s Wainwright structure, most notably in
label: Paragraph

text: Burnham and Root’s sixteen-storey Monadnock Block,
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago (1889-92). Sullivan, however, may be credited with
label: Paragraph

text: the evolution of an architectural language appropriate to the
label: Paragraph

text: high-rise frame. The Wainwright Building is the first
label: Paragraph

text: statement of this syntax, in which the suppression of the
label: Paragraph

text: transom already evident in Richardson’s Marshall Field
label: Paragraph

text: Warehouse is taken to its logical conclusion. The facade, no
label: Paragraph

text: longer arcaded, is articulated by gridded piers, clad in brick,
label: Paragraph

text: while transoms are recessed and faced in terracotta so as to
label: Paragraph

text: fuse with the fenestration. The piers rise out of a taut two-
label: Paragraph

text: storey stone base and terminate abruptly at a massive and
label: Paragraph

text: ornate terracotta cornice. Four years later Sullivan refined
label: Caption

text: this expressive formula in his second masterwork, the
label: Paragraph

text: Guaranty Building [35].
label: Caption

text: 35 Adler and Sullivan, Guaranty Building, Buffalo, 1895.
label: Caption

text: The Guaranty Building is Sullivan at the height of his
label: Paragraph

text: powers: it is without doubt the fullest realization of the
label: Paragraph

text: principles that he outlined in his essay of 1896, The Tall
label: Paragraph

text: Office Building Artistically Considered. |n this thirteen-storey
label: Caption

text: office building Sullivan created a decorative structure in
label: Paragraph

text: which, in his own words, ‘The ornament is applied in the
label: Paragraph

text: sense of being cut in or cut on... yet it should appear when
label: Paragraph

text: completed, as though by the outworking of some
label: Paragraph

text: beneficient agency, it had come forth from the very
label: Paragraph

text: substance of the material.’ Ornamental terracotta envelops
label: Paragraph

text: the exterior in an opaque filigree, whose motifs penetrate
label: Paragraph

text: even into the ornate metalwork of the lobby. Only the
label: Paragraph

text: ground-floor plate-glass windows and marble walls were
label: Paragraph

text: exempt from this intense, not to say delirious, treatment.
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan, like his pupil Frank Lloyd Wright, saw himself as
label: Paragraph

text: the lone creator of the culture of the New World. Nurtured
label: Paragraph

text: on Whitman, Darwin and Spencer and inspired by Nietzsche,
label: Paragraph

text: he regarded his buildings as emanations of some eternal life
label: Paragraph

text: force. For Sullivan nature manifested herself in art through
label: Paragraph

text: structure and ornamentation. His famous slogan, ‘form
label: Paragraph

text: follows function’, found its ultimate expression in the
label: Paragraph

text: concave cornice of the Guaranty Building, where the
label: Caption

text: ornamental ‘life force’ on the surface of the mullions
label: Paragraph

text: expands in swirls around the circular attic windows,
label: Paragraph

text: metaphorically reflecting the mechanical system of the
label: Paragraph

text: building which, to quote Sullivan, ‘completes itself and
label: Paragraph

text: makes its grand turn, ascending and descending.’ This
label: Paragraph

text: organic metaphor was established in a more fundamental
label: Paragraph

text: form in the significance which Sullivan attached to the
label: Paragraph

text: winged seed of the sycamore, the ‘germ’ featured on the
label: Caption

text: first page of his discourse on architectural ornament, A
label: Paragraph

text: System of Architectural Ornament According with a
label: Paragraph

text: Philosophy of Man's Powers, published in 1924, the year of
label: Paragraph

text: his death. Under this image Sullivan placed a Nietzschean
label: Paragraph

text: caption: ‘The Germ is the real thing; the seat of identity.
label: Paragraph

text: Within its delicate mechanism lies the will to power, the
label: Paragraph

text: function of which is to seek and eventually to find its full
label: Paragraph

text: expression in form.’
label: Paragraph

text: For Sullivan, as for Wright, this form could only evolve in
label: Paragraph

text: a millennialistic, democratic America, where it would
label: Paragraph

text: emerge as ‘an art that will live because it will be of the
label: Paragraph

text: people, for the people, and by the people’. As a self-
label: Paragraph

text: appointed cultural prophet of democracy Sullivan was
label: Paragraph

text: largely ignored. His overidealized egalitarian culture was
label: Paragraph

text: rejected by the people themselves. His morbid insistence on
label: Paragraph

text: the creation of a new civilization comparable to that of the
label: Paragraph

text: Assyrians, particularly as expressed in the coexistent
label: Paragraph

text: delirium and restraint of his orientalized architecture, left
label: Paragraph

text: them both confused and alienated. Uprooted in their very
label: Paragraph

text: essence and living through an economic depression on the
label: Paragraph

text: edge of a frontier, they preferred the gratifying distractions
label: Paragraph

text: of an imported Baroque, the ‘White-City’, East Coast
label: Paragraph

text: emblems of imperialistic fulfilment that were so seductively
label: Paragraph

text: presented to them in Daniel Burnham’s World's Columbian
label: Caption

text: Exposition in Chicago of 1893. This rejection destroyed
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan’s morale, and despite a residual brilliance his
label: Paragraph

text: powers began to decline. Separated from his urbane
label: Paragraph

text: partner, Adler, he lost control over his professional destiny
label: Paragraph

text: so that after the turn of the century he received few
label: Paragraph

text: commissions. Among these must be acknowledged his
label: Paragraph

text: inventive, eccentric and highly ornate Midwestern bank
label: Paragraph

text: buildings of the period 1907-19, and last but not least the
label: Paragraph

text: proportional magnificence and ornamental vitality of his
label: Paragraph

text: prophetic Schlesinger and Mayer department store (now
label: Title

text: These words written by Wright of the formative period that
label: Paragraph

text: he spent with Adler and Sullivan in the early 1890s hint at
label: Paragraph

text: the exotic vision that inspired his early career: the
label: Paragraph

text: transformation of industrial technique through art. Yet what
label: Paragraph

text: form this transformation should take was for Wright, at the
label: Paragraph

text: turn of the century, far from clear. Like his masters, Sullivan
label: Paragraph

text: and Richardson, he oscillated between the authority of
label: Paragraph

text: Classical order and the vitality of asymmetrical form.
label: Paragraph

text: Richardson, after the manorial and urban manner of Norman
label: Paragraph

text: Shaw, had adopted an asymmetrical style for domestic
label: Paragraph

text: settings while reserving the symmetrical mode for most of
label: Paragraph

text: his public institutions. Yet Richardson’s houses always
label: Paragraph

text: display a unifying density, and wherever possible he tried to
label: Paragraph

text: adapt the Romanesque gravity of Vaudremer’s Second
label: Paragraph

text: Empire manner and turn it into an appropriate style for the
label: Paragraph

text: New World. Even in his early timber houses a certain feeling
label: Paragraph

text: of weight pervades the shingled facades, while in his later
label: Paragraph

text: domestic work, such as the Glessner House in Chicago of
label: Paragraph

text: 1885, where shingle gave way to stone, the asymmetrical
label: Paragraph

text: composition was imbued with an irrefutable monumentality.
label: Paragraph

text: This issue of monumentality seems to have been equally
label: Paragraph

text: problematic for both Sullivan and Wright. Sullivan had
label: Paragraph

text: already used monumental forms in his Getty and Wainwright
label: Paragraph

text: tombs of the 1890s, but were they equally suitable to house
label: Paragraph

text: the living? The initial solution seems to have turned on the
label: Paragraph

text: doubly articulated formula of Classical and stone if urban,
label: Paragraph

text: and Gothic and shingle if rural. Wright, who was virtually in
label: Paragraph

text: charge of Sullivan’s domestic work after 1890,
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated this dual principle first in his own house,
label: Paragraph

text: erected in 1889 in what was still the prairie of American
label: Paragraph

text: mythology - the nascent Chicago suburb of Oak Park - and
label: Paragraph

text: then in the orientalizing, Italianate Charnley House that he
label: Paragraph

text: designed with Sullivan for downtown Chicago in 1892.
label: Caption

text: Wright’s own house was derived in both profile and plan, as
label: Paragraph

text: Vincent Scully has shown, from the cruciform and T-plan
label: Paragraph

text: Richardsonian pyramid-shaped houses that Bruce Price was
label: Paragraph

text: then building in Tuxedo Park, New York.
label: Caption

text: For Sullivan and Wright, the young, egalitarian culture of
label: Paragraph

text: the New World could not be based on something so
label: Paragraph

text: ponderous and conventionally Catholic as Richardson’s
label: Paragraph

text: Romanesque. In consequence they turned to the work of a
label: Paragraph

text: fellow Celt, Owen Jones, whose Grammar of Ornament had
label: Paragraph

text: first been published in 1856. Over sixty per cent of Jones’s
label: Paragraph

text: ornamental examples were exotic, that is of Indian, Chinese,
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian, Assyrian or Celtic origin, and it was to such
label: Paragraph

text: sources, all removed from the West, that Sullivan and Wright
label: Paragraph

text: resorted in their search for an appropriate style in which to
label: Paragraph

text: embody the New World. This not only accounts for the
label: Paragraph

text: Islamic motifs to be found in Sullivan’s work but also for the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘science-fiction’ semicircular décor over the playroom in
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s Oak Park studio of 1895, a mural featuring a
label: Paragraph

text: recumbent Arab, who is transfixed before the celestial muse
label: Paragraph

text: of an emergent civilization.
label: Paragraph

text: In Wright’s Winslow House [36], built at River Forest,
label: Caption

text: Illinois, in 1893, the problem of evolving an egalitarian but
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate format was provisionally resolved by providing
label: Paragraph

text: two distinctly different aspects to the building: the street or
label: Paragraph

text: ‘urban’ facade, being symmetrical and entered on axis, and
label: Paragraph

text: the garden or ‘rural’ facade, being asymmetrical and
label: Paragraph

text: entered to one side. This anticipates the planning strategy
label: Paragraph

text: of Wright’s Prairie Style, in which irregular distortions to the
label: Paragraph

text: rear of a formal facade conveniently accommodate awkward
label: Paragraph

text: ingredients such as service elements.
label: Paragraph

text: 36 Wright, Winslow House, River Forest, Illinois, 1893. View and site plan.
label: Caption

text: That the Winslow House was a transitional work is clearly
label: Paragraph

text: confirmed by the mixed fenestration, part sash and part
label: Paragraph

text: casement. Here, as Grant Carpenter Manson has written (in
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright to 1910, of 1958), Wright began ‘to
label: Paragraph

text: discard the sash window in favour of the casement, to
label: Paragraph

text: prepare his work for the final change from fenestration in
label: Paragraph

text: spots to fenestration in strips’: while the characteristic
label: Paragraph

text: Wrightian low-hipped Prairie roof appears here for the first
label: Caption

text: time, the animation of surfaces with Sullivanesque bands of
label: Paragraph

text: ornament and string courses testifies to the continued
label: Paragraph

text: influence of Wright’s master. The ornamented entrance
label: Caption

text: elevation clearly derives from Sullivan’s tombs of the early
label: Paragraph

text: 1890s, while the arcaded fireplace screen of the entry hall is
label: Paragraph

text: an introverted version of the facade of Sullivan’s Schiller
label: Caption

text: Theater.
label: Paragraph

text: This early emphasis on the fireplace testifies to another
label: Paragraph

text: more critical influence, that of Japanese architecture, to
label: Paragraph

text: which Wright on his own admission had been subject since
label: Paragraph

text: 1890, and certainly since the Chicago World’s Columbian
label: Paragraph

text: Exposition of 1893, when the Japanese Government housed
label: Paragraph

text: their national exhibit in a reconstruction of the Ho-o-den
label: Paragraph

text: Temple. The role that this structure may have played in
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s evolution has been best characterized by Manson:
label: Paragraph

text: If we assume that actual confrontation with a Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: building was the necessary mechanism at a certain juncture
label: Paragraph

text: in his career to give those concepts reality and direction,
label: Paragraph

text: then many of the steps in the evolution of his architecture
label: Paragraph

text: can be rationally explained. As examples: the translation of
label: Paragraph

text: the tokonoma, the permanent element of a Japanese interior
label: Paragraph

text: and the focus of domestic contemplation and ceremony,
label: Paragraph

text: into its Western counterpart, the fireplace, but a fireplace
label: Paragraph

text: expanded to unprecedented, animistic importance; the
label: Paragraph

text: frank revelation of the masonry of fireplace and chimney as
label: Paragraph

text: the one desired solid substance in an architecture of ever-
label: Paragraph

text: increasing movement; the opening out of interior spaces
label: Paragraph

text: away from the chimneybreast toward shifting planes of
label: Paragraph

text: glass at their further limits; the extension of the great eaves
label: Paragraph

text: beyond these planes to modify and control the intensity of
label: Paragraph

text: light which they admit and to protect them from weather;
label: Paragraph

text: the subdivision of interior space by suggesting rather than
label: Paragraph

text: partition, acknowledging and accommodating the
label: Paragraph

text: fluctuating human uses to which it is put; the elimination of
label: Paragraph

text: all sculptured and varnished trim in favor of flat surfaces
label: Paragraph

text: and natural wood - all these and more could have been
label: Paragraph

text: adduced from the lesson of the Ho-o-den.?
label: Paragraph

text: Irrespective of the final provenance of the tokonama
label: Paragraph

text: motif, by the time of the Winslow House, the fireplace,
label: Paragraph

text: despite the provision of central heating, had become even
label: Paragraph

text: more of a ceremonial core to the home than it had been in
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s own Oak Park house of four years before. Yet in
label: Paragraph

text: 1893 Wright remained uncommitted, for he could still
label: Paragraph

text: design a thoroughly Classical facade for the Milwaukee
label: Caption

text: Library. Two years later he extended his own home with a
label: Paragraph

text: studio in that quasi Pre-Columbian manner which we have
label: Paragraph

text: come to regard, after Manson, as his Froebel style: a
label: Paragraph

text: geometric proclivity supposedly influenced by the impact of
label: Paragraph

text: Froebel toys on his education. About 1895 he also produced
label: Paragraph

text: two surprisingly radical designs, his Luxfer Prism offices,
label: Paragraph

text: faced entirely in glass, and the McAfee House, which was an
label: Paragraph

text: ingenious reinterpretation of Richardson's parti for the Winn
label: Paragraph

text: Memorial Library of 1878.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright appears almost desperate at this point to break
label: Paragraph

text: through to a new style: his public work is still part Italianate,
label: Paragraph

text: part Richardsonian, while his domestic work is now
label: Paragraph

text: consistently characterized by low-pitched roofs, poised at
label: Paragraph

text: various heights over elongated asymmetrical plans. Typical
label: Paragraph

text: of these two modes are his Francisco Terrace apartments
label: Paragraph

text: and his Heller and Husser Houses, all built in Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: between 1895 and 1899.
label: Paragraph

text: It was to take Wright two more years to resolve all these
label: Paragraph

text: various influences into that integrated domestic style with
label: Paragraph

text: which he was to express his myth of the Prairie, and of
label: Paragraph

text: which he was to write in 1908: ‘The Prairie has a beauty of
label: Paragraph

text: its own and we should recognize and accentuate this natural
label: Paragraph

text: beauty, its quiet level. Hence ... sheltering overhangs, low
label: Paragraph

text: terraces and out reaching walls, sequestering private
label: Paragraph

text: gardens.’
label: Paragraph

text: The final emergence of the Prairie Style coincided with
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s theoretical maturity, as manifest in his famous
label: Paragraph

text: lecture of 1901, ‘The Art and Craft of the Machine’, which
label: Paragraph

text: was first delivered, appropriately enough, at Jane Addams’s
label: Paragraph

text: Hull House Settlement in Chicago. Taking as his point of
label: Paragraph

text: departure his youthful despair on reading Victor Hugo’s
label: Paragraph

text: Notre Dame de Paris (1832), in which the author had
label: Paragraph

text: concluded that printing would eventually eliminate
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, Wright countered that the machine could be
label: Paragraph

text: intelligently used, in accordance with its own laws, as an
label: Paragraph

text: agent for abstraction and purification - processes by which
label: Paragraph

text: architecture may be redeemed from the ravages of
label: Paragraph

text: industrialization. He led his audience to contemplate the
label: Paragraph

text: awe-inspiring panorama of Chicago as a giant machine, and
label: Paragraph

text: concluded with the exhortation that this was ‘the thing into
label: Paragraph

text: which the forces of Art are to breathe the thrill of ideality! A
label: Paragraph

text: SOUL!’
label: Title

text: From the early 1890s on, the sculptor Richard Bock
label: Paragraph

text: served as the iconographer of this ‘soul’, that is to say as
label: Paragraph

text: the image-maker of Wright’s Prairie Style. Bock’s early work,
label: Paragraph

text: in its nature symbolism, was close to the European
label: Paragraph

text: Secession Style and complemented the residual
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivanesque aspects in Wright’s work. After 1900,
label: Paragraph

text: however, under Wright’s influence, Bock’s sculpture became
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly abstract, as is evident from the ‘Muse’ that he
label: Paragraph

text: created for Wright’s Dana House of 1902 [37]. This figure,
label: Paragraph

text: situated in the entrance hall, was depicted as assembling
label: Paragraph

text: the abstract elements of an exotic machine culture, piece by
label: Paragraph

text: piece.
label: Paragraph

text: 37 Bock, ‘Muse’ for Wright’s Dana House, Springfield, Illinois, 1902.
label: Caption

text: Wright’s Prairie Style crystallized finally in the house
label: Paragraph

text: plans designed for the Ladies’ Home Journal in 1900 and
label: Caption

text: 1901. Its elements were now established: an open ground
label: Paragraph

text: plan contained within a horizontal format comprising low-
label: Paragraph

text: pitched roofs and low bounding walls - the low profile being
label: Paragraph

text: integrated deliberately into the site, in strong contrast to
label: Paragraph

text: the vertical chimneys and internal double-height volumes.
label: Caption

text: Yet Wright is still hesitant about the profile at this point,
label: Paragraph

text: oscillating between the Richardsonian density of his
label: Paragraph

text: Heurtley House of 1902 and the lightweight Japanese
label: Title

text: framing of his Hickox House, completed at Kankakee, Illinois,
label: Caption

text: two years before.
label: Paragraph

text: This split between a monolithic versus an articulate
label: Paragraph

text: expression resolved itself when Wright started to work for
label: Paragraph

text: the entrepreneurial Martin family in Buffalo. The Larkin
label: Paragraph

text: Building and the Martin House [38], both built in 1904 for
label: Paragraph

text: Darwin D. Martin, owner of the Larkin Mail Order Co.,
label: Caption

text: represent the emergence of Wright’s mature style. They
label: Paragraph
