text: were followed at once by Wright’s first visit to Japan in 1905
label: Paragraph

text: and by the realization of his first concrete building, the Unity
label: Paragraph

text: Temple at Oak Park, Illinois, in 1906. By now the Classical
label: Paragraph

text: base, overlaid with the exotic, had been transformed into a
label: Paragraph

text: style that was Wright’s own, a unique manner soon to be
label: Paragraph

text: made available in Europe through the portfolios of his work
label: Paragraph

text: issued by Wasmuth in Berlin in 1910 and 1911.
label: Paragraph

text: 38 Wright, Martin House, Buffalo, 1904.
label: Caption

text: The masterpieces of 1904-06, a house, a church and an
label: Paragraph

text: office building, all display essentially the same architectural
label: Paragraph

text: system. The Martin House is the first work by Wright to be
label: Paragraph

text: consistently based on a modulated tartan plan form. Similar
label: Paragraph

text: gridded articulations of support and void occur in the main
label: Paragraph

text: volumes of the Unity Temple and the Larkin Building,
label: Caption

text: although where the church is centralized about two axes the
label: Paragraph

text: office building is structured around one. Both these public
label: Paragraph

text: buildings comprise a single internal space, top-lit and
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by galleries on all four sides served by stairways
label: Paragraph

text: at each of the four corners [39, 40]. The elevations of the
label: Paragraph

text: church are effectively the same on all sides, symbolizing
label: Paragraph

text: ‘unity’, whereas those of the Larkin Building differ on the
label: Paragraph

text: longer and shorter sides. Apart from being monumental
label: Paragraph

text: variations of the same architectural parti, both buildings
label: Paragraph

text: pioneered ingenious systems of environmental control. The
label: Paragraph

text: Unity Temple was equipped with built-in ducted hot-air
label: Paragraph

text: heating, while the Larkin Building was one of the first ‘air-
label: Paragraph

text: conditioned’ office structures, inasmuch as its air was
label: Paragraph

text: cooled as well as heated.
label: Paragraph

text: 39 Wright, Unity Temple, Oak Park, Illinois, 1904-06.
label: Caption

text: 40 Wright, Larkin Building, Buffalo, 1904. Glazed central space.
label: Caption

text: In these works Wright, the Unitarian, appeared to imbue
label: Paragraph

text: his vision of a new life with a universal sense for the sacred,
label: Paragraph

text: running from the sacrament of the family hearth through to
label: Title

text: the sacrament of work and to the house of religious
label: Title

text: assembly. His goal, like that of many of his European
label: Paragraph

text: contemporaries, was the achievement of a total
label: Paragraph

text: environment, embracing and affecting the whole of society.
label: Paragraph

text: This would explain his obsessive exaltation of the hearth as
label: Paragraph

text: the moral and spiritual centre to be projected, with the aid
label: Paragraph

text: of well-placed inscriptions, into the more public realms of
label: Paragraph

text: worship and work. It would also in part account for Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: disappointment when, having designed the Larkin office
label: Paragraph

text: furniture, he was not permitted to restyle the telephones. It
label: Paragraph

text: is this same intent that embellished the main entrance to
label: Paragraph

text: the building, where employees entered dutifully past a
label: Paragraph

text: cascade of water falling from a symbolic relief by Bock
label: Caption

text: bearing the paternalistic inscription: ‘Honest labour needs
label: Paragraph

text: no master, simple justice needs no slaves.’ The same
label: Paragraph

text: idealistic spirit is manifest in Wright’s disgust at changes
label: Paragraph

text: made to the Larkin structure during the course of its daily
label: Paragraph

text: use. ‘They’, he wrote bitterly of the management, ‘never
label: Paragraph

text: hesitated to make sense-less changes ... it was just one of
label: Paragraph

text: their factory buildings.’ Despite his artistic patronage,
label: Paragraph

text: Martin was obviously unable to place restrictions on the
label: Paragraph

text: organization and management of his offices, and where the
label: Paragraph

text: home could be preserved in all its purity, the workplace
label: Paragraph

text: remained vulnerable to the dictates of production.
label: Paragraph

text: In these fertile years Wright carefully assembled an
label: Paragraph

text: atelier of technicians and artist-craftsmen to design and
label: Paragraph

text: realize his vision of a Gesamtkunstwerk, a ‘total work of art’.
label: Paragraph

text: This team included the engineer Paul Mueller, the landscape
label: Paragraph

text: architect Wilhelm Miller, the cabinet-maker George
label: Title

text: Niedecken, the mosaic designer Catherine Ostertag, the
label: Paragraph

text: sculptors Richard Bock and Alfonso lanelli, and the talented
label: Paragraph

text: Orlando Giannini, who served as Wright's fabricator of glass
label: Paragraph

text: and textiles from 1892.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1905 the syntax of the Prairie Style was firmly
label: Paragraph

text: established. Its expression, however, constantly oscillated
label: Paragraph

text: between two poles, the one rambling, asymmetric and
label: Paragraph

text: picturesque, as exemplified in the Avery Coonley House of
label: Paragraph

text: 1908, and the other compact, gridded, symmetrical and
label: Paragraph

text: architectonic, as displayed in the masterly Robie House of
label: Paragraph

text: 1908-09 [41]. The Hardy House, built in 1905 in Racine,
label: Caption

text: Wisconsin, is the purest formulation that Wright was ever to
label: Paragraph

text: make of a symmetrical, frontalized house.
label: Paragraph

text: 41 Wright, Robie House, Chicago, 1908-09.
label: Caption

text: Midway Gardens, built in 1914, was the last concerted
label: Paragraph

text: work of Wright’s design team in Chicago. With the Imperial
label: Paragraph

text: Hotel in Tokyo, it constituted the last attempt by the early
label: Paragraph

text: Wright to establish his vision as a universal expression. Built
label: Paragraph

text: in the short time of ninety days by the ever-ingenious
label: Paragraph

text: Mueller, Midway Gardens was, as Wright put it, ‘a social
label: Paragraph

text: response to the dance craze’. Based on the German beer
label: Paragraph

text: garden, it was the embodiment of a new social institution,
label: Paragraph

text: and took the form of a sequence of stepped terraces,
label: Paragraph

text: focused axially on an orchestra shell at one end and linked
label: Paragraph

text: by flanking arcades to a galleried restaurant and winter
label: Caption

text: garden complex at the other [42, 43]. It was in many
label: Paragraph

text: respects Wright’s most cogent attempt at a popular culture.
label: Paragraph

text: As such it afforded full scope to the rhetoric of his Prairie
label: Paragraph

text: Style, with Bock and lanelli designing figures, finials and
label: Paragraph

text: reliefs and Giannini providing the glass. Inside there were
label: Caption

text: large reliefs and abstract murals comprising concentric
label: Caption

text: circular elements, which were reminiscent of Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: fanciful idea of decorating the gardens with gas-filled
label: Paragraph

text: coloured balloons moored to the roof.
label: Caption

text: 42, 43 Wright, Midway Gardens, Chicago, 1914. Above, longitudinal section,
label: Caption

text: showing the restaurant and bandshell; befow, general view of the beer gardens
label: Caption

text: in their heyday.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright's Prairie subculture played itself out as a hermetic
label: Paragraph

text: style in the building of the Imperial Hotel in Tokyo during the
label: Caption

text: years 1916-22. This structure derived in both plan and
label: Paragraph

text: section from Midway Gardens. The restaurant/winter garden
label: Caption

text: of the Chicago complex reappeared as the auditorium and
label: Paragraph

text: lobby of the hotel, while the flanking arcades of the gardens
label: Paragraph

text: were transformed into its residential wings. The internal
label: Paragraph

text: murals and reliefs also extended Midway themes, while the
label: Paragraph

text: galleried accessways of the hotel recalled the café terraces
label: Paragraph

text: of the Midway layout.
label: Paragraph

text: Removed from an American context, Wright sought
label: Paragraph

text: affinities with the local masonry tradition by employing a
label: Paragraph

text: battered and castellated profile, executed in brick and
label: Caption

text: dressed in Oya stone. Internally this lava stone was
label: Paragraph

text: modelled so as to allude to Pre-Columbian profiles, as had
label: Paragraph

text: been done with the blockwork of Midway Gardens. Such
label: Paragraph

text: exotic references were to become a theatrical formula in
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s Hollywood houses of the 1920s. In the Imperial
label: Paragraph

text: Hotel they amounted to a petrification of his New World
label: Paragraph

text: culture.
label: Paragraph

text: As it happened, the Imperial Hotel was to be valued as
label: Paragraph

text: much for its structural ingenuity as for its architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: much of the credit for its miraculous survival amid the ruins
label: Paragraph

text: of the 1922 Tokyo earthquake disaster going to the
label: Paragraph

text: engineer, Mueller. Nevertheless, it was fitting that this final
label: Paragraph

text: work in the first phase of Wright’s brilliant career should be
label: Paragraph

text: praised by Sullivan, who just before his death in 1924 wrote
label: Paragraph

text: in mystical terms of its survival: ‘it stands today, uninjured,
label: Paragraph

text: because it was thought-built so to stand. It was not an
label: Paragraph

text: imposition upon the Japanese, but a free will contribution to
label: Paragraph

text: the finest elements in their culture.’
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 4
label: Title

text: Structural Rationalism and
label: Title

text: the Influence of Viollet-le-
label: Paragraph

text: Duc: Gaudi, Horta,
label: Title

text: Guimard and Berlage
label: Title

text: In architecture, there are two necessary ways of being true.
label: Paragraph

text: lt must be true according to the programme and true
label: Paragraph

text: according to the methods of construction. To be true
label: Paragraph

text: according to the programme is to fulfil exactly and simply
label: Paragraph

text: the conditions imposed by need; to be true according to the
label: Paragraph

text: methods of construction, is to employ the materials
label: Paragraph

text: according to their qualities and properties ... purely artistic
label: Paragraph

text: questions of symmetry and apparent form are only
label: Paragraph

text: secondary conditions in the presence of our dominant
label: Paragraph

text: principles.
label: Paragraph

text: Eugéne Viollet-le-Duc
label: Title

text: Entretiens sur I’architecture, 1863-721
label: Caption

text: For the great French architectural theorist Eugéne Viollet-le-
label: Paragraph

text: Duc these principles, first outlined in his lectures at the
label: Paragraph

text: Ecole des Beaux-Arts in 1853, clearly precluded the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural tradition of French Classical Rationalism. In
label: Paragraph

text: place of an ‘abstract’ international style, Viollet-le-Duc
label: Paragraph

text: advocated a return to regional building. His illustrations to
label: Paragraph

text: the Entretiens, which in certain aspects anticipated Art
label: Paragraph

text: Nouveau, ostensibly indicated the kind of architecture that
label: Paragraph

text: would evolve from his principles of Structural Rationalism.
label: Paragraph

text: To the envy of Ruskin, Viollet-le-Duc provided more than a
label: Paragraph

text: moral argument. He proffered not only models but also a
label: Paragraph

text: method which would theoretically free architecture from the
label: Paragraph

text: eclectic irrelevancies of historicism. In this way, his
label: Paragraph

text: Entretiens came to serve as an inspiration to the avant
label: Paragraph

text: garde of the last quarter of the 19th century, his method
label: Paragraph

text: penetrating to those European countries where French
label: Paragraph

text: cultural influence was strong but the tradition of Classicism
label: Paragraph

text: was weak. Eventually his ideas spread even to England,
label: Paragraph

text: where they influenced men such as Sir George Gilbert Scott,
label: Paragraph

text: Alfred Waterhouse and even Norman Shaw. Outside France
label: Caption

text: his thesis, in particular its implicit cultural nationalism, had
label: Paragraph

text: its most pronounced impact on the works of the Catalan
label: Paragraph

text: Antoni Gaudi, the Belgian Victor Horta and the Dutch
label: Title

text: architect Hendrik Petrus Berlage.
label: Caption

text: The writings of Viollet-le-Duc, Ruskin and Richard Wagner
label: Title

text: were all part of Gaudi’s adopted cultural background. Aside
label: Paragraph

text: from these extra-Mediterranean influences, his achievement
label: Paragraph

text: seems to have sprung from two rather antithetical impulses,
label: Paragraph

text: the desire to revive indigenous architecture and the
label: Paragraph

text: compulsion to create totally new forms of expression. In
label: Paragraph

text: this, of course, save for his unusual powers of fantasy,
label: Paragraph

text: Gaudi was hardly unique. This antithesis, latent in the whole
label: Paragraph

text: of the Arts and Crafts movement, was reflected in the Irish
label: Paragraph

text: Celtic literary revival which exercised such a strong
label: Paragraph

text: influence on the Glasgow School in the 1890s. A comparable
label: Paragraph

text: Catalan revival had arisen in Barcelona as early as the
label: Paragraph

text: 1860s, when Madrid asserted its sovereignty over Catalonia
label: Paragraph

text: by prohibiting the use of the Catalan language. First
label: Paragraph

text: confined to sociopolitical reform, the revival soon sued for
label: Paragraph

text: Catalan independence and, although such a status was
label: Paragraph

text: never granted, the claim to autonomy re-emerged as a
label: Paragraph

text: powerful factor in the Spanish Civil War and is alive again
label: Paragraph

text: today. In the second half of the 19th century the Church
label: Paragraph

text: supported Catalan claims to sovereignty and social reform,
label: Paragraph

text: so that Gaudi was free from any conflict between his faith
label: Paragraph

text: and his political allegiances.
label: Paragraph

text: Both Gaudi and his patron, the textile manufacturer and
label: Paragraph

text: shipping magnate Eusebio GUell Bacigalupi, grew to their
label: Paragraph

text: maturity under the influence of the Catalan separatist
label: Paragraph

text: movement. Although this movement had its conservative
label: Paragraph

text: aspects, it nonetheless supported various programmes for
label: Paragraph

text: social reform, which were largely the work of the Catalan
label: Paragraph

text: intelligentsia. Gaudi had in fact been subject to socialist
label: Paragraph

text: ideas before his meeting with GUell in 1882. Immediately
label: Paragraph

text: after his graduation he had been involved with the Mataré
label: Paragraph

text: Workers’ Co-operative, who commissioned him to design a
label: Paragraph

text: workers’ settlement comprising houses, a community
label: Paragraph

text: structure and a workshop, of which only the last was built, in
label: Paragraph

text: Soon after this, Gaudi began to work for the bourgeoisie,
label: Paragraph

text: building the exotic Casa Vicens in a quasi-Moorish style in
label: Paragraph

text: 1878. This house, like most of Gaudi’s work, testified to the
label: Paragraph

text: influence of Viollet-le-Duc, in particular the latter’s L’Art
label: Paragraph

text: russe (1870), where the constituent elements of a national
label: Paragraph

text: style were seen as being contingent on the principles of
label: Paragraph

text: Structural Rationalism. In the Casa Vicens, Gaudi first
label: Paragraph

text: formulated the essence of his style, which while Gothic in
label: Paragraph

text: structural principle was Mediterranean, not to say Islamic, in
label: Paragraph

text: much of its inspiration. As Ary Leblond wrote in 1910, Gaudi
label: Paragraph

text: sought ‘a Gothic which was full of sunlight, structurally
label: Paragraph

text: related to the great Catalan cathedrals, employing colour as
label: Paragraph

text: both the Greeks and the Moors did, logical for Spain; a
label: Paragraph

text: Gothic, half maritime, half continental, enlivened by
label: Paragraph

text: Pantheistic richness’. The result in the Casa Vicens was a
label: Paragraph

text: Mudéjar pastiche planned around a conservatory, which in
label: Paragraph

text: its banded brick, glazed tiles and decorative ironwork was
label: Paragraph

text: more exuberant than any house of comparable date
label: Paragraph

text: (compare Shaw’s Pierrepoint, at Frensham in Surrey, of
label: Paragraph

text: 1876). Yet the structure transcended its exotic expression;
label: Paragraph

text: for this was the first occasion on which Gaudi used the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional Catalan or Roussillon vault, in which archlike
label: Paragraph

text: forms are achieved through corbelling out laminated layers
label: Paragraph

text: of tiles. This vault became a key feature of his style,
label: Paragraph

text: appearing in its most delicate form in the thin shell structure
label: Paragraph

text: of his Sagrada Familia School, Barcelona, of 1909.
label: Caption

text: The initial achievements of Gaudi’s career are
label: Paragraph

text: inseparable from the various works that he and his
label: Paragraph

text: colleague, Francesc Berenguer, designed for Eusebio GUell.
label: Paragraph

text: Count Guell was a progressive, and his house in Barcelona,
label: Paragraph

text: the Palau Giell [45], which Gaudi designed for him in 1888,
label: Paragraph

text: became a Mecca for the intelligentsia of the 1890s. As the
label: Paragraph

text: Casa Vicens had been built around a conservatory, so the
label: Paragraph

text: Palau Guell was built around a music room, an organ loft
label: Paragraph

text: and chapel. This composite space echoed the form of the
label: Paragraph

text: typical Islamic court and ran through the entire upper
label: Paragraph

text: section of the house.
label: Paragraph

text: Prominent among Guell’s enthusiasms were Ruskin and
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner, and Gaudi seems to have been as much affected
label: Paragraph

text: by the theories of the one as by the music-dramas of the
label: Paragraph

text: other. At any event Ruskin’s reputation was at its height at
label: Paragraph

text: the turn of the century, and his dictum, so compatible with
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner, that the architect who was not a sculptor or a
label: Paragraph

text: painter was ‘nothing but a framemaker on a large scale’
label: Paragraph

text: would clearly have appealed to Gaudi.
label: Paragraph

text: For GUuell the transformation of society at large was to be
label: Paragraph

text: effected through the garden city. To this end in 1891 he
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned Gaudi and Berenguer to design a workers’
label: Paragraph

text: community for his textile plant at Santa Coloma de Cervelld,
label: Paragraph

text: later known as the Colonia GUell. This was to be followed by
label: Paragraph

text: a commission in 1900 for a middle-class suburb, the Park
label: Paragraph

text: GUell, situated on the Montafia Pelada overlooking
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona, a project eventually realized without its
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter of houses between 1903 and 1914. In the
label: Paragraph

text: meantime Berenguer continued with the sporadic
label: Paragraph

text: development of the Colonia Guell, until Gaudi succeeded
label: Paragraph

text: him there in 1908, to complete the work on the chapel. By
label: Paragraph

text: then Gaudi’s career as an ecclesiastical architect had
label: Paragraph

text: already begun, since he had taken over the building of the
label: Paragraph

text: Sagrada Familia Church [44] in Barcelona from Juan
label: Caption

text: Martorell in 1906.
label: Paragraph

text: 44 Gaudi, three progressive stages of the Sagrada Familia Church, Barcelona
label: Caption

text: (left to right, 1898, 1915, 1918) and (far right) Viollet-le-Duc, plan for a
label: Caption

text: cathedral, from his L’Art russe, 1870.
label: Caption

text: 45 Gaudi, Palau Guell, Barcelona, 1888.
label: Caption

text: Gaudi’s Park GUell emerged as the uninhibited
label: Paragraph

text: crystallization of his ecstatic vision. For all that the park
label: Paragraph

text: commanded a spectacular view, the only buildings to be
label: Paragraph

text: completed there were the gatehouse, the grand stairway
label: Paragraph

text: leading to the covered market above and Gaudi's own
label: Paragraph

text: house. The irregularly shaped undulating vault of the market
label: Caption

text: was carried on sixty-nine grotesque Doric columns, while its
label: Paragraph

text: roof, bounded by a continuous serpentine bench, was
label: Paragraph

text: intended to function as an arena or open-air stage. This
label: Paragraph

text: exotic, mosaic-faced perimeter terminated in an esplanade,
label: Paragraph

text: which in turn merged into the naturalistic random rubble
label: Paragraph

text: construction of the rest of the park. The park itself was
label: Paragraph

text: structured by serpentine pathways which, where necessary,
label: Paragraph

text: were supported on vaulted buttresses, shaped so as to
label: Paragraph

text: suggest petrified tree trunks.
label: Paragraph

text: The Park GUell is the first of Gaudi’s works to evoke
label: Paragraph

text: directly, through the undulating profile of its arena, the
label: Paragraph

text: obsessive image of his life - the famous mountain near
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona known as Montserrat. According to the medieval
label: Paragraph

text: legend, celebrated by Wagner in Parsifal, the Holy Grail was
label: Paragraph

text: concealed in the castle of Montsalvat, a site later identified
label: Paragraph

text: with Montserrat and its monastery, housing the patron saint
label: Paragraph

text: of Catalonia. Gaudi, who first worked for the monastery in
label: Paragraph

text: 1866, remained haunted by the serrated profile of the
label: Paragraph

text: mountain for the whole of his life.
label: Paragraph

text: The peaks and chimneys of the Casa Mila [46] rise out of
label: Paragraph

text: the rational grid of Barcelona as the crown of an undulating
label: Paragraph

text: cliff face, a cyclopean gesture whose overwhelming sense of
label: Paragraph

text: weight seems to contradict its free and delicate organization
label: Paragraph

text: about three irregularly shaped courts. This contradiction
label: Paragraph

text: finds its parallel in the perverse suppression of the
label: Paragraph

text: building’s steel structure behind massive stone facing. As in
label: Paragraph

text: the Park GUell, the articulation of the structure has been
label: Paragraph

text: sacrificed to the evocation of some primal force. Nothing
label: Paragraph

text: could have been further from Viollet-le-Duc, for neither the
label: Paragraph

text: fabric nor its mode of assembly was explicitly rendered.
label: Paragraph

text: Instead, huge blocks were laboriously worked so as to
label: Paragraph

text: suggest a rock face eroded by time. A similar cosmic
label: Paragraph

text: reference seems to be intended in the iron balconies,
label: Paragraph

text: wrought by the Gaudi atelier in such a way as to suggest
label: Paragraph

text: petrified strands of storm-tossed seaweed. Departing from
label: Paragraph

text: the principles of Viollet-le-Duc, Gaudi finally transformed his
label: Paragraph

text: raw material into an assembly of powerful images, whose
label: Paragraph

text: emotive force recalls the operatic genre of Wagner. Seen in
label: Paragraph

text: retrospect, the Casa Mila seems to anticipate something of
label: Paragraph

text: the ethos of the Expressionism that was soon to emerge in
label: Paragraph

text: Central Europe. In 1910, its symbolic solemnity served to
label: Paragraph

text: isolate Gaudi, not only from the tradition of Structural
label: Paragraph

text: Rationalism, but also from the lighter aspects of Symbolism,
label: Paragraph

text: those flutters of ‘farewells in space’ that constitute the
label: Paragraph

text: general tenor of Catalan ‘Modernismo’.
label: Paragraph

text: 46 Gaudi, Casa Mila, Barcelona, 1906-10.
label: Caption

text: The situation in Brussels at the end of the century was
label: Paragraph

text: similar in many respects to that in Barcelona. In the Flemish
label: Paragraph

text: capital a comparable accumulation of industrial wealth was
label: Paragraph

text: paralleled by an equally obsessive preoccupation with
label: Paragraph

text: national identity, although in Belgium the wealth was more
label: Paragraph

text: evenly distributed and the nationalism mitigated by actual
label: Paragraph

text: independence. All the same, Belgian architects were quite
label: Paragraph

text: as anxious as the Catalans for the evolution of a truly
label: Paragraph

text: modern but nonetheless national style. The architectural
label: Paragraph

text: avant garde of the 1870s accused the Beaux-Arts architect
label: Paragraph

text: Joseph Poelaert of cultural mendacity for his Neo-Classical
label: Paragraph

text: Palais de Justice, completed in 1883: not only was it
label: Paragraph

text: Piranesian and megalomaniacal, but it evoked a past which
label: Paragraph

text: was international and hence by definition un-Flemish. As far
label: Paragraph

text: as they were concerned, the model for a new ‘native’
label: Paragraph

text: architecture could be found in the local 16th-century brick
label: Paragraph

text: traditions, in which the principles of Viollet-le-Duc could
label: Paragraph

text: flourish.
label: Paragraph

text: One year after the publication of Entretiens, the newly
label: Paragraph

text: formed Société Centrale d’Architecture de Belgique started
label: Paragraph

text: to campaign vigorously in their magazine L’Emulation for a
label: Paragraph

text: new national style. The issue of 1872 declared: ‘We are
label: Paragraph

text: called to create something which is our own, something to
label: Paragraph

text: which we can give a new name. We are called upon to
label: Paragraph

text: invent a style.’ E. Allard, the major theorist of L’Emulation,
label: Paragraph

text: later wrote: ‘We must try first and foremost to create
label: Paragraph

text: Belgian artists - we must free ourselves from foreign
label: Title

text: influences.’ Throughout the 1870s L’Emulation continued to
label: Paragraph

text: propagate the principles of a hypothetical style that was
label: Paragraph

text: more constrained in its Structural Rationalism than that
label: Paragraph

text: adopted by Gaudi. ‘Nothing is beautiful in architecture
label: Paragraph

text: unless true.’ ‘Shun painted plaster and stucco.’ ‘Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: is drifting towards decadence; towards a veritable
label: Paragraph

text: cacophony.’
label: Paragraph

text: Despite these exhortations, a convincing style took its
label: Paragraph

text: time to materialize, and nothing of consequence was
label: Paragraph

text: achieved in Belgium until 1892, when Victor Horta began his
label: Paragraph

text: mature career with the realization of the Hétel Tassel in
label: Paragraph

text: Brussels [47]. In this narrow-fronted, three-storey town
label: Paragraph

text: house of traditional terrace format, Horta went beyond the
label: Paragraph

text: achievement of his early career to become one of the first
label: Paragraph

text: architects to make an extensive use of iron in domestic
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. He treated iron as though it were an organic
label: Paragraph

text: filament insinuated into the fabric to subvert the inertia of
label: Paragraph

text: stone. Other than the works of Eiffel and Contamin, which
label: Paragraph

text: he would have seen at the Paris Exhibition of 1889, the most
label: Paragraph

text: influential image behind Horta’s peculiar ‘strapwork’ style
label: Paragraph

text: was the contemporary graphic work of the Dutch-Indonesian
label: Paragraph

text: artist Jan Toorop. This connection underlines the importance
label: Paragraph

text: of painting in the Belgian Art Nouveau. Toorop was a
label: Paragraph

text: member of that influential Post-Impressionist group, Les XX,
label: Paragraph

text: whose later re-formation as La Libre Esthétique was to play
label: Paragraph

text: a key role in disseminating the aims and principles of the
label: Paragraph

text: English Arts and Crafts movement.
label: Paragraph

text: 47 Horta, Hétel Tassel, Brussels, 1892.
label: Caption

text: In the open planning of the Hétel Tassel, Horta exploded
label: Paragraph

text: the 18th-century Parisian hdéte/ formula. As the octagonal
label: Paragraph

text: vestibule on the ground floor rose upwards through a half-
label: Paragraph

text: level towards the garden, it expanded laterally into an
label: Paragraph

text: adjacent foyer space covered by an iron superstructure. The
label: Paragraph

text: free-standing columns of this space, embellished with iron
label: Caption

text: tendrils, echo similar serpentine forms throughout the rest
label: Paragraph

text: of the metalwork. From the balustrades to the light fittings
label: Paragraph

text: the same aesthetic is dominant, a linear exuberance that is
label: Paragraph

text: delicately echoed in the mosaic floor and wall finishes and
label: Paragraph

text: in the coloured glass panels of the door to the salon. Yet for
label: Paragraph

text: all this florid profusion the main volumes are still tempered
label: Paragraph

text: by the use of Rococo mouldings, which serve to relate the
label: Paragraph

text: more exotic elements to the received tradition of Louis
label: Paragraph

text: Quinze. A similar balance is achieved on the exterior, where
label: Paragraph

text: the ductile elements of the inner armature find their
label: Paragraph

text: discreet expression. In an otherwise Classical facade, the
label: Paragraph

text: stone quoins of an iron bay window are wrought in such a
label: Paragraph

text: way as to imply the thrust of the inner metallic structure.
label: Paragraph

text: Over the next decade Horta continued this dialogue
label: Paragraph

text: between the tensility of iron and the massiveness of stone
label: Paragraph

text: in a number of other town houses in Brussels, including
label: Paragraph

text: residences for the chemist Solvay and the industrialist Van
label: Caption

text: Eetvelde and his own house and studio in the Rue
label: Paragraph

text: Américaine, all built before 1900. All were partial
label: Paragraph

text: elaborations of the Hétel Tassel syntax, yet none, save the
label: Paragraph

text: Hotel Solvay, equalled its simplicity and impressiveness.
label: Paragraph

text: The Maison du Peuple [48], built for the Belgian Workers’
label: Caption

text: Socialist Party in 1897-1900, is the most original work of
label: Paragraph

text: Horta’s career and the only one in which he seems to have
label: Paragraph

text: felt free to pursue the principles of Viollet-le-Duc to their
label: Paragraph

text: logical conclusion. Here a native brick and stone vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: was brilliantly exploited to create an architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: revealed construction - brickwork being consistently
label: Paragraph

text: modulated and moulded to receive stone, and stone being
label: Paragraph

text: dressed to receive iron and glass. While externally this
label: Paragraph

text: tectonic was comprised by the elevational expression of a
label: Paragraph

text: complex programme and by the displacement of a concave
label: Paragraph

text: plan-form over a sloping site, internally it achieved a
label: Paragraph

text: dramatic and highly fluid expression through the exposed
label: Paragraph

text: steel framework of all the major volumes, the offices,
label: Paragraph

text: meeting rooms, lecture theatre and cafeteria. This
label: Paragraph

text: consistent but strangely unresolved ‘Neo-Gothic’ assembly
label: Paragraph

text: of masonry, iron and glass was Horta’s most influential
label: Paragraph

text: achievement and one which he was not to surpass in his
label: Paragraph

text: more resolved and last essay in this idiom, his Innovation
label: Paragraph

text: department store, built in Brussels in 1901.
label: Paragraph

text: 48 Horta, Maison du Peuple, Brussels, 1897-1900. Detail of facade.
label: Caption

text: In France, the line of succession linking Viollet-le-Duc to
label: Paragraph

text: Hector Guimard passes through Guimard’s master Anatole
label: Paragraph

text: de Baudot, who had been a pupil of both Viollet-le-Duc and
label: Paragraph

text: Labrouste. In 1894 de Baudot had designed, in association
label: Paragraph

text: with the engineer Paul Cottancin, the church of St-Jean-de-
label: Caption

text: Montmartre in Paris, a structure of reinforced brickwork and
label: Paragraph

text: ciment armé that was surely the most profound essay in
label: Paragraph

text: Structural Rationalism to date. Thus Guimard, in his early
label: Paragraph

text: Parisian works, reveals his debt to both de Baudot and
label: Paragraph

text: Viollet-le-Duc, particularly in his Ecole du Sacré Coeur and
label: Paragraph

text: his Maison Carpeaux in the Boulevard Exelmans, both
label: Paragraph

text: completed by 1895. While the former, a small school
label: Paragraph

text: building with V-supports to the upper floor, was almost a
label: Paragraph

text: direct realization of the famous illustration to Entretiens, the
label: Paragraph

text: latter, a bourgeois town house, displayed the same
label: Paragraph

text: tendencies towards a vestigial Classicism that we find in the
label: Paragraph

text: works of Horta.
label: Paragraph

text: In a letter to L.-C. Boileau in 1898, Guimard openly
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledged his debt to Viollet-le-Duc: ‘Decoratively, my
label: Paragraph

text: principles are perhaps new but they derive from those
label: Paragraph

text: already in use with the Greeks ... | have only applied the
label: Paragraph

text: theories of Viollet-le-Duc without being fascinated by the
label: Paragraph

text: Middle Ages.’ Yet Guimard was concerned to achieve that
label: Paragraph

text: native style prescribed by the French theorist as conforming
label: Paragraph

text: to usage, climate and national spirit and ‘to the progress
label: Title

text: which has been made in science and practical knowledge’.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus we find him writing in 1903:
label: Paragraph

text: A style of architecture, in order to be true, must be the
label: Paragraph

text: product of the soil where it exists and of the period which
label: Paragraph

text: needs it. The principles of the Middle Ages and those of the
label: Paragraph

text: 19th century, added to my doctrine, should supply us with a
label: Paragraph

text: foundation for a French Renaissance and an entirely new
label: Title

text: style. Let the Belgians, the Germans and the English evolve
label: Paragraph

text: for themselves a national art and assuredly in so doing they
label: Paragraph

text: will perform a true, sound and useful work.2
label: Paragraph

text: We may assume that what Guimard, like Gaudi and
label: Paragraph

text: Horta, had in mind was the evolution of the ‘constituent
label: Paragraph

text: elements’ of a national style as advocated by Viollet-le-Duc.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet by the turn of the century there were at least three
label: Paragraph

text: versions of Guimard’s own style: a loose, rustic, mixed-
label: Paragraph

text: media expression, as found in the country chalets that he
label: Paragraph

text: built between 1899 and 1908, of which his Castel Henriette
label: Paragraph

text: of 1900 is typical; an urban style of precisely assembled
label: Paragraph

text: brick and dramatically sculptured stonework such as we find
label: Paragraph

text: in his own house in the Avenue Mozart, Paris, of 1910; and
label: Paragraph

text: finally a spidery ferrovitreous manner which was mass-
label: Paragraph

text: produced soon after 1899, when he was awarded the
label: Paragraph

text: commission for the Paris Métro stations. The entrances were
label: Paragraph

text: made up of interchangeable standard iron pieces, cast in
label: Paragraph

text: the form of naturalistic elements and framing enamelled
label: Paragraph

text: steel and glass. Paradoxically, they were closer to the linear
label: Paragraph

text: expressiveness of Horta than to the moral rigour of de
label: Paragraph

text: Baudot; and Guimard even treated the typography and
label: Paragraph

text: illumination of these structures as the sinuous continuation
label: Paragraph

text: of their form. Thereafter, over the next four years, these
label: Paragraph

text: apparently natural emanations from a wondrous
label: Paragraph

text: subterranean world erupted over the streets of Paris, to
label: Paragraph

text: make Guimard notorious as the creator of the ‘Style Métro’
label: Paragraph

text: 49 Guimard, iron and glass Métro entrance, Paris, 1899-1904. Side and front
label: Caption

text: elevations.
label: Paragraph

text: This well-earned notoriety has unfortunately helped to
label: Paragraph

text: eclipse the one short-lived masterpiece of Guimard’s whole
label: Paragraph

text: career, his Humbert de Romans concert hall [50], completed
label: Paragraph

text: in Paris in 1901 and demolished in 1905. Like Horta’s Maison
label: Paragraph

text: du Peuple, this surely has to be regarded as one of the
label: Paragraph

text: major achievements of Structural Rationalism. Fernand
label: Caption

text: Mazade’s text of 1902 is still capable of evoking the power
label: Paragraph

text: of an interior that, save for a few faded photographs, is
label: Paragraph

text: entirely lost:
label: Title

text: 50 Guimard, Humbert de Romans concert hall, Paris, 1901. Composite of section
label: Caption

text: and elevation.
label: Paragraph

text: [its] main branches, eight in number, support a rather high
label: Paragraph

text: cupola, pierced, like the sides, with bays filled with pale
label: Paragraph

text: yellow stained glass, through which an abundance of light
label: Paragraph

text: finds its way into the hall. The framework is of steel, but the
label: Paragraph

text: metal is covered with mahogany ... the result is the most
label: Paragraph

text: elaborate roof ever conceived by a French architect.?
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout the two decades that spanned the turn of the
label: Paragraph

text: century, there remained quietly in the background the
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch architect Hendrik Petrus Berlage, who contrived to
label: Paragraph

text: practise in a consistent manner until his death in 1934.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike Horta, Berlage did not allow his principles to become
label: Paragraph

text: compromised by the acquired, ‘alien’ tastes of an arriviste
label: Paragraph

text: middle class. In Holland, in any case, the middle class was
label: Paragraph

text: fully integrated into the general society, social co-operation
label: Paragraph

text: being second nature in a country that was constantly
label: Paragraph

text: threatened with inundation. In such a stable context Berlage
label: Paragraph

text: enjoyed almost fifty years of uninterrupted practice, over a
label: Paragraph

text: period that due to Dutch neutrality was not even disturbed
label: Paragraph

text: by the hostilities of the First World War.
label: Paragraph

text: Berlage received his professional education at the
label: Paragraph

text: Eidgendssische Technische Hochschule, Zurich, in the late
label: Caption

text: 1870s. There he studied under the immediate followers of
label: Paragraph

text: Gottfried Semper, from whom he would have received an
label: Paragraph

text: extremely rational and typological education. On his return
label: Paragraph

text: to Amsterdam in 1881 he began to associate with PJ.H.
label: Paragraph

text: Cuijpers, nearly thirty years his senior, who was already a
label: Paragraph

text: disciple and correspondent of Viollet-le-Duc. In accordance
label: Paragraph

text: with the principles of Structural Rationalism, Cuijpers sought
label: Paragraph

text: to rationalize his own eclecticism in an effort to evolve a
label: Paragraph

text: new national style, an attempt which culminated in his Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Flemish Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam, of 1885. This work
label: Caption

text: strongly influenced Berlage’s entry for the Amsterdam
label: Paragraph

text: Exchange competition of 1883, which he designed in
label: Paragraph

text: association with Theodorus Sanders in a similar turreted and
label: Paragraph

text: gabled manner.
label: Paragraph

text: Twelve years later Berlage received the commission for
label: Paragraph

text: the Exchange, despite the fact that he had only been
label: Paragraph

text: awarded fourth place in the competition. At once he began
label: Paragraph

text: to rework the design after an arched brick syntax that he
label: Paragraph

text: had developed in the interim, first in a villa built at
label: Paragraph

text: Groningen in 1894, and then in an office building erected in
label: Paragraph

text: The Hague in the following year. These crenellated, Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Romanesque brick structures, influenced without doubt by
label: Paragraph

text: Richardson’s work in the United States, were vehicles for an
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of explicit construction, a fact that was most
label: Paragraph

text: evident in the brick-vaulted stair complex of the office
label: Caption

text: building. Yet for all the profundity of these early essays
label: Paragraph

text: (reminiscent in their structural probity of the rigour of de
label: Paragraph

text: Baudot) the final formulation of the Berlage idiom was to
label: Paragraph

text: depend on the realization of the Exchange.
label: Paragraph

text: The four versions of the Exchange [51, 52] that followed
label: Paragraph

text: the initial project represent different stages in an arduous
label: Paragraph

text: process of simplification. In this development Berlage seems
label: Paragraph

text: to have been guided by a complex of theoretical ideas,
label: Paragraph

text: some drawn from Viollet-le-Duc, some from Semper and
label: Paragraph

text: some from his colleague Jan Hessel de Groot, who was the
label: Paragraph

text: originator of the Amsterdam school of mathematical
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetics. After the Exchange was opened in 1903, Berlage
label: Paragraph

text: began to publish his own synthesis of these ideas in a series
label: Paragraph

text: of theoretical studies, first in his Gedanken uber den Stil in
label: Paragraph

text: der Baukunst (‘Thoughts on Style in Architecture’) of 1905
label: Paragraph

text: and then in his Grundlagen und Entwicklung der Architektur
label: Paragraph

text: (‘Principles and Evolution of Architecture’) of 1908. As
label: Paragraph

text: Reyner Banham has observed, the salient principles
label: Paragraph

text: stressed in these writings were ‘the primacy of space, the
label: Paragraph

text: importance of walls as creators of form and the need for
label: Paragraph

text: systematic proportion’. The distillation of the Exchange into
label: Paragraph

text: its final form takes on a richer significance once we become
label: Paragraph

text: aware of Berlage’s views on the essential role of masonry,
label: Paragraph

text: as first set forth in these texts. ‘Before all else the wall must
label: Paragraph

text: be shown naked in all its sleek beauty and anything fixed on
label: Paragraph

text: it must be shunned as an embarrassment.’ Or again, ‘The
label: Paragraph

text: art of the master builder lies in this, in the creation of space,
label: Paragraph

text: not the sketching of facades. A spatial envelope is
label: Paragraph

text: established by means of walls, whereby a space ... is
label: Paragraph

text: manifested according to the complexity of the walling.’
label: Paragraph

text: 51, 52 Berlage, Exchange, Amsterdam. Above, second design, 1896-97; be/ow,
label: Caption

text: In his gradual refinement of the Exchange, Berlage
label: Paragraph

text: largely retained the original plan of three top-lit rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: volumes, one for each exchange, housed in an orthogonal
label: Paragraph

text: matrix of four-storey perimeter walls. The progressive aim
label: Paragraph

text: was to simplify this parti and its structure into an extremely
label: Paragraph

text: astringent form, and to this end he gradually reduced the
label: Paragraph

text: number of gables and turrets and slowly eliminated all
label: Paragraph

text: lanterns and every trace of banded stonework. At one stage
label: Paragraph

text: the scheme vaguely resembled Gustav Gull’s
label: Paragraph

text: Landesmuseum, then nearing completion in Zurich, while at
label: Paragraph

text: the penultimate stage the reduced forms attained their final
label: Paragraph

text: definition through the superimposition of a diagonal lattice
label: Paragraph

text: derived from De Groot. After this all subsequent changes
label: Paragraph

text: were largely confined to the design of the main entrance
label: Paragraph

text: and its adjacent tower, which were conceived by Berlage as
label: Paragraph

text: the prime representative elements of both the institution
label: Paragraph

text: and the city.
label: Paragraph

text: The load-bearing brick structure of Berlage’s Exchange
label: Caption

text: was precisely articulated in accordance with the principles
label: Paragraph

text: of Structural Rationalism. Inside, a mosaic frieze or a
label: Paragraph

text: filigreed lamp are but inflections within large brick volumes
label: Paragraph

text: where granite abutments, quoins, corbels and cappings
label: Paragraph

text: consistently mark the points of structural transference and
label: Paragraph

text: bearing [53]. The same dressed stones which in one
label: Paragraph

text: instance are corbelled out to receive a steel truss in another
label: Paragraph

text: articulate the keying of an arch. In this way the ethos and
label: Paragraph

text: the logic of Viollet-le-Duc pervade the entire fabric as in no
label: Paragraph

text: other structure of the 19th century.
label: Paragraph

text: 53 Berlage, Exchange, Amsterdam, 1897-1903. Main hall.
label: Caption

text: To this achievement the philosophical tenor of Berlage’s
label: Paragraph

text: thought added dimensions which went beyond any single
label: Paragraph

text: structure, first into the immediate urban context and then,
label: Paragraph

text: by extension, into the body politic at large. His model for an
label: Paragraph

text: ideal urban society was first outlined in a set of essays
label: Paragraph

text: published in 1910, of which one in particular, Kunst en
label: Paragraph

text: Maatschappij (‘Art and Society’), most clearly reveals the
label: Paragraph

text: depth of his socio-political commitment. While socialism for
label: Paragraph

text: Berlage was a prime article of faith, he nonetheless
label: Paragraph

text: subscribed to Hermann Muthesius’s view that the general
label: Paragraph

text: level of a culture could only be raised through the
label: Paragraph

text: production of high-quality, well-designed objects. On the
label: Paragraph

text: other hand, he remained convinced as to the supreme
label: Paragraph

text: cultural importance of the city, and deplored the
label: Paragraph

text: disurbanizing tendency of the English garden city.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1901 Berlage was given an opportunity to put his
label: Paragraph

text: urban theory into practice, when the city of Amsterdam
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned him to prepare a plan for Amsterdam South.
label: Paragraph

text: For Berlage the street was essentially an outdoor room, the
label: Paragraph

text: necessary consequence of the housing lining its length. This
label: Paragraph

text: insistence on enclosure, prefigured in the medieval city, had
label: Paragraph

text: already been postulated by Berlage in his design for the
label: Paragraph

text: Exchange. After Alphand and the theories of the German
label: Paragraph

text: planner StUbben, the qualities of the street spaces in
label: Paragraph

text: Amsterdam South vary according to their width and
label: Paragraph

text: furnishing. The wider streets were furnished with parterres
label: Paragraph

text: and flanking avenues of trees; the narrower ones were
label: Paragraph

text: simply lined with trees and paving. At the major
label: Paragraph

text: intersections centralized spaces were created somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: after the principles of Stubben and Camillo Sitte (see p. 29).
label: Paragraph

text: The whole was fed by a modern system of mass transit in
label: Paragraph

text: the form of the electric tram.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1915 Berlage totally revised his plan [54] to
label: Paragraph

text: incorporate avenues of Haussmann-like scale, two of which,
label: Paragraph

text: converging at a sector known as Amstellaan, were
label: Paragraph

text: completed with their environs in the early 1920s. Their
label: Paragraph

text: realization, which unequivocally demonstrated Berlage’s
label: Paragraph

text: concern for the physical continuity of the urban
label: Paragraph

text: environment, eventually brought him into conflict with the
label: Paragraph

text: anti-street polemic of the Congrés Internationaux
label: Title

text: d’Architecture Moderne (CIAM), founded in 1928. Yet today
label: Paragraph

text: the value of his urban achievement seems to be more
label: Paragraph

text: pertinent than ever, for as Giorgio Grassi has written of
label: Paragraph

text: Amstellaan:
label: Title

text: 54 Berlage, revised development plan for Amsterdam South, 1917.
label: Caption

text: it is still the key point on the outskirts of Amsterdam, the
label: Paragraph

text: point where one finds expressed most clearly the concept of
label: Paragraph

text: collective living, where the civic value of single parts blends
label: Paragraph

text: into a unified vision that - being less concerned with the
label: Paragraph

text: optimum dwellings of certain rationalist experiments - has,
label: Paragraph

text: in its nuclear concept of housing, well expressed the values
label: Paragraph

text: of the city. And it has recognized not only the physical need
label: Paragraph

text: of the dwellers for recreation and rest, but their impulse to
label: Paragraph

text: form communities and to assume in this act a symbol of
label: Paragraph

text: life.*
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 5
label: Title

text: Charles Rennie
label: Title

text: Mackintosh and the
label: Title

text: Glasgow School 1896-1916
label: Title

text: On the second floor of a modest building in the great
label: Caption

text: industrial smoky town of Glasgow there is a drawing room
label: Caption

text: amazingly white and clean looking. Walls, ceiling and
label: Paragraph

text: furniture have all the virginal beauty of white satin. The note
label: Paragraph

text: throughout is white - white and violet. From the upper part
label: Paragraph

text: of two large violet plaques, which form centre pieces, there
label: Paragraph

text: hang long tendrils threaded with little globes of old silver. ...
label: Paragraph

text: The carpet and the leaded glass window are violet, and one
label: Paragraph

text: can trace the same colour note on the narrow frames of two
label: Paragraph

text: choice drawings. ... In the stillness of the studio, among a
label: Paragraph

text: bevy of plants and strewn with the novels of Maeterlinck,
label: Paragraph

text: two visionary souls, in ecstatic communion from the heights
label: Caption

text: of loving mate-ship, are wafted still further aloft to the
label: Paragraph

text: heavenly regions of creation.
label: Paragraph

text: E.B. Kalas
label: Title

text: De la Tamise a la Sprée
label: Title

text: l'essor des industries d’art, 19051
label: Caption

text: By 1905, Charles Rennie Mackintosh and his wife, Margaret
label: Paragraph

text: Macdonald, had already acquired an international
label: Paragraph

text: reputation. In England they had achieved notoriety in 1896,
label: Paragraph

text: when with Herbert McNair and Margaret’s sister Frances
label: Title

text: Macdonald, as the ‘Glasgow Four’, they had exhibited their
label: Paragraph

text: early works at the London Arts and Crafts Exhibition Society
label: Caption

text: show. Such was the impact of their work on this occasion
label: Paragraph

text: that, despite official disapproval stemming from Walter
label: Paragraph

text: Crane, they were appreciatively acclaimed as the ‘Spook
label: Paragraph

text: School’ by Gleeson White, editor of The Studio. This sudden
label: Paragraph

text: success, which had been preceded by an exhibition of their
label: Paragraph

text: student work at Liége in 1895, was further confirmed by the
label: Paragraph

text: acceptance in 1896 of Mackintosh’s design for the new
label: Paragraph

text: Glasgow School of Art, on which work commenced in the
label: Paragraph

text: following year.
label: Paragraph

text: The Four had been making furnishings since 1894, so
label: Paragraph

text: Gleeson White's article in The Studio of 1897 could
label: Paragraph

text: illustrate, in addition to their graphic work, repoussé metal
label: Paragraph

text: plaques, mirrors, sconces and clocks designed by the
label: Caption

text: Macdonald sisters and cupboards and cabinets designed by
label: Caption

text: McNair and Mackintosh. In all this, the Four had evolved a
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility which for White was the expression of a ‘quasi-
label: Paragraph

text: malignant paganism’, a style which took its linear manner
label: Paragraph

text: from the graphic work of William Blake, Aubrey Beardsley
label: Paragraph

text: and Jan Toorop and its sentiment, part nationalist and part
label: Paragraph

text: Symbolist, from old Cymric motifs of Celtic origin and from
label: Paragraph

text: names drawn from the mystical works of Maurice
label: Paragraph

text: Maeterlinck and Dante Gabriel Rossetti.
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh’s architecture also had other, somewhat less
label: Paragraph

text: exotic, origins. Through his education within the mainstream
label: Paragraph

text: of the Gothic Revival he had naturally acquired an affinity
label: Paragraph

text: for a solid craft approach to buildings. Like Philip Webb, his
label: Paragraph

text: architectural precursors were the Gothic Revivalists of the
label: Paragraph

text: mid-century, men such as Butterfield and Street. This much
label: Paragraph

text: is evident in his own early ecclesiastical work, such as his
label: Paragraph

text: Queens Cross Church of Scotland, Glasgow, of 1897. In his
label: Caption

text: secular work, however, he managed to temper the revivalist
label: Paragraph

text: impulse with a more direct approach, deriving partly from
label: Paragraph

text: Voysey and partly from the Scottish Baronial tradition
label: Title

text: (compare James MacLaren’s Fortingall cottages of 1892). His
label: Paragraph

text: first and last statements in this manner are incorporated in
label: Paragraph

text: the gradual realization of the Glasgow School of Art.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout Mackintosh’s unique and highly influential
label: Paragraph

text: development, Lethaby’s Architecture, Mysticism and Myth of
label: Paragraph

text: 1892 was to serve as an important catechism - not only
label: Paragraph

text: because it revealed the universal metaphysical basis of all
label: Paragraph

text: architectural symbolism but also because, coming from
label: Paragraph

text: Lethaby’s hand, it formed a bridge between the other-
label: Paragraph

text: worldliness of Celtic mysticism and the more pragmatic Arts
label: Title

text: and Crafts approach to the creation of form. With regard to
label: Paragraph

text: this last, Mackintosh took the traditionalist Ruskinian line
label: Paragraph

text: and argued that modern materials, such as iron and glass,
label: Paragraph

text: ‘will never worthily take the place of stone because of this
label: Paragraph

text: defect, the want of mass’.
label: Paragraph

text: There was to be no want of mass in the Glasgow School
label: Paragraph

text: of Art, which was built from a local grey granite on three of
label: Paragraph

text: its sides and from roughcast brickwork on the fourth. Yet,
label: Paragraph

text: despite Mackintosh’s avowed respect for masonry, glass and
label: Paragraph

text: iron were present in abundance in the extensive studio
label: Paragraph

text: northlights, which occupy the full length of the main facade.
label: Caption

text: At the same time, from a technical standpoint, Mackintosh -
label: Paragraph

text: like his American contemporary Frank Lloyd Wright - made
label: Paragraph

text: every effort to incorporate ingenious and up-to-date
label: Paragraph

text: systems for environmental control, such as the system of
label: Paragraph

text: ducted heating and ventilation, built into the school from
label: Paragraph

text: the beginning.
label: Paragraph

text: Following the Gothic Revival tradition, Mackintosh
label: Paragraph

text: designed the main body of the school as a loose-fitting
label: Paragraph

text: envelope, with the bulk of the studio space being stacked on
label: Paragraph

text: four floors. This mass, which was effectively read as two
label: Paragraph

text: storeys throughout the length of the main facade, was
label: Paragraph

text: complemented by ancillary elements (such as the library
label: Paragraph

text: and museum) located to the sides, the centre and the rear.
label: Paragraph

text: The result was an E plan-form [55], with an eccentrically
label: Paragraph

text: counterbalanced main elevation, in which subtle
label: Paragraph

text: displacements in both the main entrance and the forecourt
label: Paragraph

text: railings simultaneously engendered symmetrical and
label: Paragraph

text: asymmetrical readings. The return east and west facades,
label: Paragraph

text: steeply sloping down towards the rear of the site, were left
label: Paragraph

text: partly blank so as to express the depth of the studio space.
label: Paragraph

text: With the aid of finials, gables, projecting turrets and incised
label: Caption

text: windows, this inherent asymmetry imparted to the east
label: Paragraph

text: facade an overtly Gothic Revival character, which would
label: Paragraph

text: have been repeated on the west had it not been for
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh’s radical redesign of the second stage in 1906.
label: Paragraph

text: This west facade as finally completed represented
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh at the height of his power. In no other work was
label: Paragraph

text: he able to reach such authority and grandeur. Its three
label: Paragraph

text: vertical oriels with their gridded fenestration served
label: Paragraph

text: dramatically to light and express the rich volume of the
label: Paragraph

text: library [56] and its adjacent upper floor.
label: Paragraph

text: 55 Mackintosh, Glasgow School of Art, 1896-1909. Axonometric view and
label: Caption

text: ground plan.
label: Paragraph

text: 56 Mackintosh, Glasgow School of Art, Library, 1905-09.
label: Caption

text: Built in two stages, the art school was a record of
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh’s stylistic development from 1896 to 1909. The
label: Paragraph

text: difference between the Voyseyesque entry hall and stair of
label: Paragraph

text: the first stage and the double-height library of the final
label: Paragraph

text: stage, patently influenced by Norman Shaw, reflected the
label: Paragraph

text: full range of his development by that date. In a matter of a
label: Paragraph

text: few years he had fully crystallized that sinuous architectural
label: Paragraph

text: syntax which he had first used on a grand scale in the
label: Paragraph

text: design of the Willow Tea Rooms, Glasgow, in 1904. In
label: Caption

text: contrast to those ‘white and willowy’ interiors, the art school
label: Paragraph

text: library was austere and geometrical, and executed in dark
label: Paragraph

text: wood throughout. There was almost a Japanese quality
label: Paragraph

text: about its structural articulation. It must be seen as a
label: Paragraph

text: transitional work, lying somewhere between Mackintosh’s
label: Paragraph

text: Art Nouveau period and the later, modern, almost Art Deco
label: Title

text: manner that characterizes his final work for W.J. Bassett-
label: Paragraph

text: Lowke.
label: Paragraph

text: The brief and brilliant, violet and silver period of organic
label: Paragraph

text: ornamentation set against plain white surfaces, commonly
label: Paragraph

text: regarded as the touchstone of the Mackintosh style and
label: Paragraph

text: eulogized as such by Kalas in 1905, came to its maturity at
label: Paragraph

text: the turn of the century. It was already developed in full in
label: Paragraph

text: the furniture and décor of Mackintosh’s Glasgow apartment,
label: Paragraph

text: designed in 1900. It was further elaborated in the Scottish
label: Paragraph

text: section of the Viennese Secession Exhibition of the same
label: Caption

text: year and in the music salon built for Fritz Warndorfer in
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna in 1902. As a fully integrated aesthetic, both
label: Paragraph

text: internally and externally, it reached its apotheosis in the
label: Paragraph

text: Willow Tea Rooms, completed two years after the
label: Caption

text: Warndorfer salon.
label: Paragraph

text: Externally, the restrained yet moulded white facade of
label: Paragraph

text: the Willow Tea Rooms was of the same genre as
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh’s Voysey-like house projects of the turn of the
label: Paragraph

text: century or the two quasi-Baronial roughcast houses that he
label: Paragraph

text: realized at Kilmacolm and Helensburgh [57] between 1899
label: Caption

text: and 1903. As Robert Macleod has written, ‘these houses
label: Paragraph

text: were an expression of conscious gaucheness, and an anti-
label: Paragraph

text: pretty attitude that had as its chief historical exponents
label: Paragraph

text: William Butterfield and Philip Webb’. Mackintosh’s perverse
label: Caption

text: attempt to fuse the ornamental with the gauche was often
label: Paragraph

text: far from successful, and the houses appear somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: chaotic and unresolved when compared to the magnificent
label: Paragraph

text: and highly influential ‘Haus eines Kunst-freundes’ (‘House
label: Paragraph

text: for an Art-lover’), which Mackintosh designed as his entry to
label: Paragraph

text: the limited competition organized in Darmstadt by
label: Paragraph

text: Alexander Koch in 1901.
label: Paragraph

text: 57 Mackintosh, Hill House, Helensburgh, 1902-03.
label: Caption

text: The unrealized ‘House for an Art-lover’ and the Glasgow
label: Paragraph

text: School of Art represent Mackintosh’s essential contribution
label: Paragraph

text: to the mainstream of 20th-century architecture. In the
label: Paragraph

text: house he created a work which passed well beyond the
label: Paragraph

text: constraints of the traditional Voysey model to display a
label: Paragraph

text: formal plasticity of almost Cubist affinity. The organization of
label: Paragraph

text: the house around a number of countervailing axes and its
label: Paragraph

text: division into two major longitudinal masses that appear to
label: Paragraph

text: be on the point of sliding past each other resulted in a tense
label: Paragraph

text: but consolidated composition, and the enrichment of its
label: Paragraph

text: otherwise plain surface with precisely proportioned windows
label: Paragraph

text: and occasional accents of embossed ornament suggests at
label: Paragraph

text: once the strong influence it must have exercised over Josef
label: Paragraph

text: Hoffmann, in particular on his design for the Palais Stoclet,
label: Paragraph

text: Brussels, of 1905. Nothing in any event could have been
label: Paragraph

text: further from the yeoman rusticity of the winning design by
label: Paragraph

text: Baillie Scott.
label: Paragraph

text: It is ironic that Mackintosh should have begun and ended
label: Paragraph

text: his career as an independent architect with the Glasgow
label: Paragraph

text: School of Art, the effective years of his practice being from
label: Paragraph

text: 1897 to 1909. In 1914 the Mackintoshes moved from
label: Paragraph

text: Scotland to England, where Mackintosh, suddenly and
label: Paragraph

text: somewhat inexplicably discouraged as an architect, turned
label: Paragraph

text: to painting. In 1916, however, he made a brief comeback
label: Paragraph

text: with the brilliant remodelling of a small terrace house for
label: Paragraph

text: W.J. Bassett-Lowke, No. 78 Derngate in Northampton. The
label: Caption

text: rich, abstract interiors are equal to any Continental work of
label: Paragraph

text: comparable date. The plain geometrical bedroom furniture
label: Paragraph

text: and the striped graphic décor bonding the twin beds
label: Paragraph

text: together were well in advance of their time, inasmuch as
label: Paragraph

text: they anticipated the spatial and plastic devices to be
label: Paragraph

text: employed by the Continental avant garde after the First
label: Paragraph

text: World War (De Stijl, Art Deco, etc.). During the war
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh designed clocks, furniture and posters for
label: Paragraph

text: Bassett-Lowke, but even this patronage was withdrawn after
label: Paragraph

text: Rejected in Scotland and isolated in England, Mackintosh
label: Paragraph

text: could sustain neither the values of his earlier life nor the
label: Paragraph

text: creative impulse of his pre-war career. The last decade of
label: Paragraph

text: his life was one of progressive decline, in which the
label: Paragraph

text: commissioning in 1925 of the German architect Peter
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens to design a new house for Bassett-Lowke was but a
label: Paragraph

text: final blow. It was a tragic fate for one who, as P. Morton
label: Paragraph

text: Shand has written, ‘was the first British architect since
label: Paragraph

text: Adam to be a name abroad and the only one that has ever
label: Paragraph

text: become the rallying point for a Continental school of
label: Paragraph

text: design’.
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 6
label: Title

text: The Sacred Spring:
label: Title

text: Wagner, Olbrich and
label: Title

text: Hoffmann 1886-1912
label: Title

text: A series of edifices expressed the Bildungsideal of Liberal
label: Paragraph

text: Austria: university, museum, theatre and - grandest of all -
label: Paragraph

text: the opera. The culture once confined to the palace had
label: Paragraph

text: poured into the market place, accessible to all, Art ceased to
label: Paragraph

text: serve only as an expression of aristocratic grandeur or
label: Paragraph

text: ecclesiastical pomp; it became the ornament, the communal
label: Paragraph

text: property, of an enlightened citizenry. The splendiferous
label: Paragraph

text: structures of the Ringstrasse bore massive witness to the
label: Paragraph

text: fact that Austria had replaced despotism and religion with
label: Paragraph

text: constitutional politics and secular culture ... the economic
label: Paragraph

text: growth of Austria created the basis for an increasing number
label: Paragraph

text: of families to pursue an aristocratic style of life. Wealthy
label: Paragraph

text: burghers or successful bureaucrats, many of whom acquired
label: Paragraph

text: patents of nobility like Stifter’s Freiherr von Risach [in the
label: Paragraph

text: novel Der Nachsommer, 1857], established urban or
label: Paragraph

text: suburban variants of the Rosenhaus, museum-like villas
label: Paragraph

text: which became centres of a lively social life. Not only
label: Paragraph

text: gracious manners, but also intellectual substance were
label: Paragraph

text: cultivated in the salons and soirées of the new élite ... the
label: Paragraph

text: English Pre-Raphaelites inspired the Art-Nouveau movement
label: Paragraph

text: (under the name of ‘Secession’) in fin de siécle Austria, but
label: Paragraph

text: neither their pseudo-medieval spirituality nor their strong
label: Paragraph

text: social-reformist impulse penetrated to their Austrian
label: Paragraph

text: disciples. In brief, the Austrian aesthetes were neither as
label: Paragraph

text: alienated from their society as their French soul-mates nor
label: Paragraph

text: as engaged in it as their English ones. They lacked the bitter
label: Paragraph

text: anti-bourgeois spirit of the first and the warm melioristic
label: Title

text: thrust of the second. Neither degagé nor engagé, the
label: Paragraph

text: Austrian aesthetes were alienated not from their class, but
label: Paragraph

text: with it from a society that defeated its expectations and
label: Paragraph

text: rejected its values. Accordingly, Young Austria’s Garden of
label: Paragraph

text: Beauty was a retreat of the beati possidentes, a garden
label: Paragraph

text: strangely suspended between reality and utopia. It
label: Paragraph

text: expressed both the self-delight of the aesthetically
label: Paragraph

text: cultivated and the self-doubt of the socially functionless.
label: Paragraph

text: Carl Schorske
label: Title

text: The Transformation of the Garden: Ideal and Society in
label: Title

text: Austrian Literature, 19701
label: Title

text: As Carl Schorske informs us, that which realized itself in
label: Paragraph

text: 1898 as the ‘sacred spring’, through the appearance of the
label: Paragraph

text: Secessionist magazine Ver Sacrum, had some of its origins
label: Paragraph

text: at mid-century in Der Nachsommer, the Indian Summer of
label: Paragraph

text: Adalbert Stifter’s idealistic novel of 1857. Otto Wagner’s first
label: Paragraph

text: suburban villa of 1886 may be seen as a realization of the
label: Paragraph

text: Rosenhaus which Stifter had invented as the ideal location
label: Paragraph

text: for the cultivation of a private aesthetic life. While Wagner
label: Paragraph

text: had been born into the same class as Stifter’s Freiherr von
label: Paragraph

text: Risach, he did not attain immediate success. After a
label: Paragraph

text: distinguished academic career, first at the Vienna
label: Paragraph

text: Polytechnic and then at the prestigious Bauakademie in
label: Paragraph

text: Berlin, purveyor of the Schinkel tradition, he practised
label: Paragraph

text: independently for some fifteen years before receiving his
label: Paragraph

text: first state commission, the décor for the Emperor’s silver
label: Caption

text: wedding celebrations in 1879. Even this royal recognition
label: Paragraph

text: did not bring him wide acclaim, so that when in 1886 he
label: Paragraph

text: built his own Italianate version of the Rosenhaus at
label: Paragraph

text: Hutteldorf he was still far from being professionally
label: Paragraph

text: established. Four years later, however, he had not only
label: Paragraph

text: arrived artistically but had achieved some worldly success
label: Paragraph

text: with the building of a small but lavish town house in Vienna
label: Paragraph

text: for his own use.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner's influence as a teacher dates from his
label: Paragraph

text: succession in 1894 to Karl von Hasenauer as professor at
label: Paragraph

text: the school of architecture in the Academy of Fine Arts in
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna. In 1896, at the age of fifty-four, he published his
label: Paragraph

text: first theoretical work, Moderne Architektur. This was
label: Paragraph

text: followed in 1898 by the first publication of the work of his
label: Paragraph

text: students, given under the title Aus der Wagnerschule.
label: Paragraph

text: Having been formed in Berlin by one of Schinkel’s prime
label: Paragraph

text: pupils, Wagner’s architectural affinities at this time seem to
label: Paragraph

text: have lain somewhere between the rationalism of the
label: Paragraph

text: Schinkelschuler and the more rhetorical manner of those
label: Paragraph

text: last great architects of the Ringstrasse, Gottfried Semper
label: Caption

text: and Karl von Hasenauer, whose State Museums,
label: Paragraph

text: Burgtheater and Neue Hofburg were under construction in
label: Paragraph

text: the Ring throughout the last quarter of the century.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner's polytechnical education had left him acutely
label: Paragraph

text: aware of the technical and social realities of his epoch. At
label: Paragraph

text: the same time, his romantic imagination was drawn towards
label: Paragraph

text: the radical stirrings of his more talented pupils - to the anti-
label: Paragraph

text: academic art movement co-founded by his assistant Joseph
label: Paragraph

text: Maria Olbrich and by his most brilliant pupil, Josef Hoffmann,
label: Paragraph

text: who had graduated with a Prix de Rome in 1895. These men
label: Paragraph

text: were not only influenced by the work of the Glasgow Four,
label: Paragraph

text: then being illustrated in The Studio, but were also under the
label: Paragraph

text: spell of the exotic vision of two young Viennese painters,
label: Paragraph

text: Gustav Klimt and Koloman Moser. Under the leadership of
label: Paragraph

text: Klimt, Olbrich, Hoffmann and Moser banded together in their
label: Paragraph

text: revolt against the Academy and in 1897, with Wagner’s
label: Paragraph

text: blessing, they founded the Vienna Secession. In the
label: Paragraph

text: following year Wagner declared his own sympathies for the
label: Paragraph

text: Secession through the creation of a florid abstraction in
label: Paragraph

text: faience for the facade of his pseudo-ltalianate Majolica
label: Caption

text: House in Linke Wienzeile, and in 1899 he scandalized the
label: Paragraph

text: establishment by becoming a full member of the Secession.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1898 Olbrich built the Secession building [58],
label: Paragraph

text: apparently after a sketch by Klimt, who was to remain the
label: Paragraph

text: prime mover of the revolt. From Klimt came the battered
label: Paragraph

text: walls, the axiality and especially the laurel motif - with its
label: Paragraph

text: dedication to Apollo - the last being rendered by Olbrich as
label: Paragraph

text: a perforated metal dome, suspended between four short
label: Caption

text: pylons and set above planar masses whose severe
label: Paragraph

text: modelling recalls the work of such British architects as
label: Paragraph

text: Voysey and Charles Harrison Townsend. A comparable
label: Paragraph

text: symbol of organic vitality occurred on the cover of the first
label: Paragraph

text: issue of Ver Sacrum - an ornamental shrub whose vital roots
label: Paragraph

text: were depicted bursting through its tub into the earth
label: Paragraph

text: beneath. Such was Olbrich’s symbolic point of departure, a
label: Paragraph

text: conscious return to the fertility of the unconscious, from
label: Paragraph

text: which, ever subject to the influence of Voysey and
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh and the claims of Klimt’s pan-eroticism, he
label: Paragraph

text: began to evolve a style of his own.
label: Paragraph

text: 58 Olbrich, Secession building, Vienna, 1898.
label: Caption

text: This evolution took place largely in Darmstadt, where
label: Paragraph

text: Olbrich had been invited by the Grand Duke Ernst Ludwig in
label: Paragraph

text: 1899. Later in that year he was joined by six other artists,
label: Paragraph

text: the sculptors Ludwig Habich and Rudolf Bosselt, the painters
label: Paragraph

text: Peter Behrens, Paul BUrck and Hans Christiansen, and the
label: Paragraph

text: architect Patriz Huber. Two years later, this artists’ colony
label: Paragraph

text: exhibited its life style and ‘habitat’ as a total work of art,
label: Paragraph

text: under the title ‘Ein Dokument deutscher Kunst’. The
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition was opened in May 1901 by a mystical ceremony
label: Paragraph

text: called ‘Das Zeichen’ (‘The Sign’), which took place on the
label: Paragraph

text: steps of Olbrich’s Ernst Ludwig House. In this ceremony an
label: Paragraph

text: ‘unknown’ prophet descended from the golden portal of the
label: Paragraph

text: building to receive a crystalline form, as a symbol of base
label: Paragraph

text: material transformed into art, just as carbon may be
label: Paragraph

text: changed into the brilliance of a diamond.
label: Paragraph

text: The Ernst Ludwig House [60], built in 1901, was
label: Paragraph

text: undoubtedly the most progressive work that Olbrich
label: Paragraph

text: designed during his nine-year residence in Darmstadt.
label: Paragraph

text: Consisting of eight studio living spaces, four on each side of
label: Paragraph

text: a common meeting hall, it was in effect the colony’s initial
label: Paragraph

text: focus, around which a number of individual artists’ houses
label: Paragraph

text: were eventually built. With its high, blank, horizontally
label: Paragraph

text: fenestrated facade, shielding north lights to the rear, and its
label: Paragraph

text: ornate, recessed circular entrance flanked by giant statues
label: Caption

text: carved by Habich, it was the ultimate monumentalization of
label: Paragraph

text: themes that Olbrich had broached in the Secession building.
label: Paragraph

text: Between this early masterpiece and the final
label: Paragraph

text: ‘classicization’ of his style in 1908 - the year of his
label: Paragraph

text: premature death - Olbrich continued his search for a
label: Paragraph

text: uniquely expressive mode. Throughout the last decade of
label: Paragraph

text: his life he created works of exceptional originality,
label: Paragraph

text: culminating in his cryptic and brooding Hochzeitsturm or
