label: Paragraph

text: Wedding Tower, which, with the adjacent exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: buildings [59], was completed on the MathildenhGhe in
label: Paragraph

text: Darmstadt for the Hessische Landesausstellung of 1908.
label: Paragraph

text: With its pyramidal composition the Mathildenhéhe complex,
label: Paragraph

text: built on top of a reservoir, was in effect a ‘city crown’ whose
label: Paragraph

text: form anticipated the symbolic centre of Bruno Taut’s
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Stadtkrone’ of 1919. Girded by a series of tiered concrete
label: Caption

text: pergolas, it was drawn by Olbrich as a mountainous
label: Paragraph

text: labyrinth of dense foliage, whose colour would change with
label: Paragraph

text: the seasons from green to russet brown. Rising from the
label: Paragraph

text: high ground like a mystical mountain, it consciously
label: Paragraph

text: opposed the Edenic serenity of the formal plane-tree
label: Paragraph

text: garden, or Platanenhain, on which it fronted.
label: Paragraph

text: 59 Olbrich, Hochzeitsturm and exhibition buildings, Darmstadt, 1908.
label: Caption

text: 60 Olbrich, Ernst Ludwig House, Darmstadt. ‘Das Zeichen’, May 1901.
label: Caption

text: Over the whole of Olbrich’s career there stood the
label: Paragraph

text: challenging figure of Peter Behrens, initially a graphist and
label: Paragraph

text: painter, who had come to Darmstadt from the Munich
label: Paragraph

text: Secession in 1899. He emerged as an architect and a
label: Paragraph

text: designer with the building and furnishing of his own house
label: Paragraph

text: at Darmstadt in 1901. In their rivalry as Gesamtkunstler to
label: Paragraph

text: the house of Hesse-Darmstadt it was Olbrich rather than
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens who was to be the brilliant designer of objects,
label: Paragraph

text: while in their careers outside Darmstadt, as architects, it
label: Paragraph

text: was Behrens who became the more powerful creator of
label: Paragraph

text: form. Above all it was he who anticipated their common
label: Paragraph

text: return to the kind of crypto-Classicism that characterizes
label: Paragraph

text: the work of Olbrich’s final years, his Tietz department store
label: Paragraph

text: in Dusseldorf and the mansion that he built for the cigar
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturer Feinhals in Cologne, both completed in 1908.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1899 Josef Hoffmann began to teach at the applied art
label: Paragraph

text: school attached to the Austrian Museum for Art and Industry
label: Paragraph

text: in Vienna (which had been founded, in accordance with
label: Paragraph

text: Semper’s educational programme, some thirty-five years
label: Paragraph

text: before). A year later, he replaced Olbrich as the designer of
label: Paragraph

text: the élite Hohe Warte suburb on the outskirts of Vienna,
label: Paragraph

text: building four villas there between 1901 and 1905. He had
label: Paragraph

text: succeeded Olbrich as the leading architect to the Secession,
label: Paragraph

text: and his first work on this site, designed in the manner of
label: Paragraph

text: English Free Architecture, was for Koloman Moser. By 1902,
label: Paragraph

text: however, Hoffmann was already beginning to move towards
label: Paragraph

text: a more planar and Classical mode of expression, based
label: Paragraph

text: largely on the post-1898 work of Otto Wagner, that is
label: Paragraph

text: towards a handling of mass and surface which was far
label: Paragraph

text: removed from the British preoccupation with medieval,
label: Paragraph

text: yeoman form.
label: Paragraph

text: By the time of the Vienna Secession Exhibition of 1900,
label: Paragraph

text: at which Mackintosh’s actual work was shown in Austria for
label: Paragraph

text: the first time, Hoffmann had already arrived at a furnishing
label: Paragraph

text: style of refined rectilinear form. This was his initial move
label: Paragraph

text: away from the obsessive curvilinearity of his ‘Apollo’ shop in
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna of the previous year. By 1901 he was preoccupied
label: Paragraph

text: with the possibilities for abstract form in design. ‘| am
label: Paragraph

text: particularly interested in the square as such,’ he wrote, ‘and
label: Paragraph

text: in the use of black and white as dominant colours, because
label: Paragraph

text: these clear elements have never appeared in earlier styles.’
label: Paragraph

text: Together with Moser and other Secessionists, he became
label: Paragraph

text: interested in the craft production of decorative and applied
label: Paragraph

text: art objects, along the lines of Ashbee’s Guild of Handicraft.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1902, with his setting for Klinger’s Beethoven statue,
label: Paragraph

text: exhibited in the Secession Building, he had arrived at his
label: Paragraph

text: own abstract style, in which certain contours or proportions
label: Paragraph

text: are emphasized through the use of projecting beads and
label: Paragraph

text: clusters of small squares. A year later, in 1903, with the
label: Paragraph

text: backing of Fritz Warndorfer, the Hoffmann/Moser Wiener
label: Paragraph

text: Werkstatte was started for the design, production and
label: Paragraph

text: marketing of high-quality domestic objects. This
label: Paragraph

text: organization and its output had achieved world fame by the
label: Paragraph

text: time of its precipitate and inexplicable closure by Hoffmann
label: Paragraph

text: The last issue of Ver Sacrum was published in 1903: with
label: Paragraph

text: its demise the high period of the Secession was over. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1904, Hoffmann and Josef August Lux started to edit a new
label: Paragraph

text: periodical, entitled Hohe Warte, named after the garden
label: Paragraph

text: suburb. From the outset it was dedicated to the propagation
label: Paragraph

text: of ‘back to nature’ garden city values, and later, in less
label: Paragraph

text: liberal times, it became the garden city platform of the
label: Paragraph

text: Austrian National Socialist movement. Unlike Hoffmann, Lux
label: Paragraph

text: was quick to react against its chauvinistic exaggeration of
label: Paragraph

text: folklorish values, resigning his editorship in protest against
label: Paragraph

text: its Heimatstil policy as early as 1908.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1903 Hoffmann had moved closer to the style of his
label: Paragraph

text: master Wagner, particularly in the design of the Classical
label: Paragraph

text: and austere Purkersdorf Sanatorium, which was to have
label: Paragraph

text: such an influence on Le Corbusier’s early development. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1905 Hoffmann began to work on his masterpiece, the
label: Paragraph

text: Palais Stoclet, built in Brussels between 1905 and 1910 [61,
label: Caption

text: 62]. As in Perret’s Théatre des Champs-Elysées, its reduced
label: Paragraph

text: Classical decoration paid veiled homage to the Symbolist
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic of the Belle Epoque. But, unlike Perret’s theatre,
label: Paragraph

text: the Palais Stoclet is (as Eduard Sekler has observed)
label: Paragraph

text: essentially atectonic: its thin white marble facing with its
label: Paragraph

text: metal seams has all the mannered and handcrafted
label: Paragraph

text: elegance of a Wiener Werkstatte object on a large scale. Of
label: Paragraph

text: its conscious denial of structure and mass Sekler wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: 61, 62 Hoffmann, Palais Stoclet, Brussels, 1905-10.
label: Caption

text: A strongly linear element is introduced by these articulated
label: Paragraph

text: metal bands but it has nothing to do with ‘lines of force’, the
label: Paragraph

text: way linear elements did in the architecture of Victor Horta.
label: Paragraph

text: At the Stoclet house, we have fines which occur equally
label: Paragraph

text: along horizontal and vertical edges - they are tectonically
label: Paragraph

text: neutral. At the corners ... where two or more of these
label: Paragraph

text: parallel mouldings come together, the effect tends towards
label: Paragraph

text: a negation of the solidity of the built volumes. A feeling
label: Paragraph

text: persists as if the walls had not been built in a heavy
label: Paragraph

text: construction but consisted of large sheets of thin material,
label: Paragraph

text: joined at the corners with metal bands to protect the
label: Paragraph

text: edges.2
label: Paragraph

text: These bands, which issue from the apex of the stair
label: Paragraph

text: tower, where four male figures support a Secessionist dome
label: Paragraph

text: of laurels, are vaguely reminiscent of Wagner’s stylized
label: Paragraph

text: cable mouldings, and serve as they cascade down over the
label: Paragraph

text: corners to unite the whole building through the continuity of
label: Paragraph

text: the seam.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner’s mature style dates from his sixtieth year, with
label: Paragraph

text: the completion of his Vienna Stadtbahn network in 1901.
label: Paragraph

text: Not a trace of his Italianate manner remains in his Die Zeit
label: Paragraph

text: telegraph office of 1902, or in his Kaiserbad Dam Works of
label: Paragraph

text: 1906, both of which seem to relate in their engineered
label: Paragraph

text: elegance and punctilious revetment to the atectonic style of
label: Paragraph

text: Hoffmann. Yet the dematerialization of the Palais Stoclet
label: Paragraph

text: seems to have been anticipated by Wagner’s own
label: Paragraph

text: masterwork, his Imperial Post Office Savings Bank built in
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna in 1904 [63]. Wagner, unlike his Secessionist pupils,
label: Paragraph

text: always built for the reality of the present rather than for
label: Paragraph

text: some remote Symbolist utopia that looked towards the
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic redemption of man. Thus his ‘Grosstadt’ plan of
label: Paragraph

text: 1910, with its hierarchy of neighbourhood units, was
label: Paragraph

text: projected as a rationally planned and realizable
label: Paragraph

text: metropolitan future. In all his public work Wagner built with
label: Paragraph

text: great technical precision for a bureaucratic state which he
label: Paragraph

text: could only regard as lasting indefinitely. Crowned by an
label: Paragraph

text: honorific pergola hung with laurel wreaths and flanked by
label: Paragraph

text: winged Victories whose arms are raised skywards, the Post
label: Paragraph

text: Office Savings Bank represented the republican
label: Title

text: benevolence of the Austro-Hungarian Empire at the height
label: Paragraph

text: of its power.
label: Paragraph

text: 63 Wagner, Post Office Savings Bank, Vienna, 1904. Detail of facade.
label: Caption

text: Like the Palais Stoclet, the Post Office Savings Bank
label: Paragraph

text: resembles a gargantuan metal box, an effect due in no
label: Paragraph

text: small measure to the thin polished sheets of white Sterzing
label: Paragraph

text: marble that are anchored to its facade with aluminium
label: Paragraph

text: rivets. Its glazed canopy frame, entrance doors, balustrade
label: Caption

text: and parapet rail are also of aluminium, as are the metal
label: Paragraph

text: furnishings of the banking hall itself [64]. Faced in ceramic,
label: Caption

text: lit from above and resting in its turn on a suspended
label: Paragraph

text: concrete floor, studded with glass lenses for the illumination
label: Caption

text: of the basement, this hall existed until recently in its original
label: Paragraph

text: form. Its unadorned, riveted steelwork was formally related
label: Paragraph

text: to the industrial lighting standards and the aluminium
label: Title

text: heating cowls which flanked its perimeter. As Stanford
label: Paragraph

text: Anderson has observed,
label: Paragraph

text: 64 Wagner, Post Office Savings Bank, Vienna, 1904. Banking hall.
label: Caption

text: The details of an engineered building are not placed before
label: Paragraph

text: us in the sachlich manner of nineteenth-century exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: halls or railway sheds; the concept of an engineered
label: Paragraph

text: building is revealed to us instead through the building’s own
label: Paragraph

text: modernist symbols of exposed industrial materials, structure
label: Paragraph

text: and equipment.?
label: Paragraph

text: By 1911 the ‘classicization’ of the Secession was
label: Paragraph

text: complete, and for all his continuing interest in the evolution
label: Paragraph

text: of an appropriate Hejmatstil, Hoffmann represented Austria
label: Paragraph

text: at the Rome International Art Exhibition of that year with a
label: Paragraph

text: pavilion design whose atectonic Classicism anticipated the
label: Paragraph

text: rhetorical monumentality of Mussolini's New Rome. Equally
label: Paragraph

text: prophetic was Behrens’s representation of Prussia in St
label: Paragraph

text: Petersburg with an embassy whose solemnity would point
label: Paragraph

text: towards the official rhetoric of the Third Reich. In such a
label: Paragraph

text: climate it fell to Wagner to close the Secession as it had
label: Paragraph

text: begun, with the vigour of his extremely austere yet
label: Paragraph

text: elegantly proportioned second villa, built in HUtteldorf in
label: Caption

text: 1912. In this lucidly planned house, lyrically decorated by
label: Caption

text: Moser and influenced to an equal degree by the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner’s own pupils and the recently published works of
label: Paragraph

text: Wright, Wagner was to spend his last six years.

label: Title

text: Antonio Sant’Elia and
label: Title

text: Futurist Architecture
label: Title

text: We had stayed up all night, my friends and I, under hanging
label: Paragraph

text: mosque lamps with domes of filigreed brass, domes starred
label: Caption

text: like our spirits, shining like them with the prisoned radiance
label: Paragraph

text: of electric hearts. For hours we had trampled our atavistic
label: Paragraph

text: ennuit into rich oriental rugs, arguing up to the last confines
label: Paragraph

text: of logic and blackening many reams of paper with our
label: Paragraph

text: frenzied scribbling.
label: Paragraph

text: An immense pride was buoying us up, because we felt
label: Paragraph

text: ourselves alone at that hour, alone, awake, and on our feet,
label: Paragraph

text: like proud beacons or forward sentries against an army of
label: Paragraph

text: hostile stars glaring down at us from their celestial
label: Paragraph

text: encampments. Alone with stokers feeding the hellish fires of
label: Paragraph

text: great ships, alone with the black specters who grope in the
label: Paragraph

text: red-hot bellies of locomotives launched down their crazy
label: Title

text: courses, alone with drunkards reeling like wounded birds
label: Paragraph

text: along the city walls.
label: Paragraph

text: Suddenly we jumped, hearing the mighty noise of the
label: Paragraph

text: huge double-decker trams that rumbled by outside, ablaze
label: Paragraph

text: with colored lights, like villages on holiday suddenly struck
label: Paragraph

text: and uprooted by the flooding Po and dragged over falls and
label: Paragraph

text: through gorges to the sea.
label: Paragraph

text: Then silence deepened. But, as we listened to the old
label: Paragraph

text: canal muttering its feeble prayers and the creaking bones of
label: Paragraph

text: sickly palaces above their damp green beards, under the
label: Paragraph

text: windows we suddenly heard the famished roar of
label: Paragraph

text: automobiles.
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Let’s go’! said. ‘Friends, away! Let’s go! Mythology and
label: Paragraph

text: the Mystic Ideal are defeated at last. We’re about to see the
label: Paragraph

text: Centaur’s birth and, soon after, the first of Angels! ... We
label: Paragraph

text: must shake the gates of life, test the bolts and hinges. Let’s
label: Paragraph

text: go! Look there, on earth, the very first dawn! There’s
label: Paragraph

text: nothing to match the splendour of the sun’s red sword,
label: Paragraph

text: slashing for the first time through our millennial gloom!’
label: Paragraph

text: Filippo Tommaso Marinetti
label: Caption

text: ‘Le Futurisme’, Le Figaro, Paris, 20 February 1909!
label: Caption

text: With bombastic rhetoric, Italian Futurism announced its
label: Paragraph

text: iconoclastic principles to the complacent bourgeoisie of the
label: Paragraph

text: Belle Epoque. This millennialistic introduction was followed
label: Paragraph

text: by an account of an impromptu automobile race on the
label: Paragraph

text: outskirts of Milan ending in an accident which, as Reyner
label: Paragraph

text: Banham has observed, had all the overtones of being ‘the
label: Paragraph

text: mimic baptism of a new faith’. In a text that pretended to be
label: Paragraph

text: part autobiographical, Marinetti told of the overturning of
label: Paragraph

text: his car into a factory ditch:
label: Paragraph

text: Oh! Maternal ditch, almost full of muddy water! Fair factory
label: Paragraph

text: drain! | guilped down your nourishing sludge; and |
label: Paragraph

text: remembered the blessed black breast of my Sudanese
label: Title

text: nurse. ... When 1 came up - torn, filthy, and stinking - from
label: Paragraph

text: under the capsized car, | felt the white-hot iron of joy
label: Paragraph

text: deliciously pass through my heart! ...
label: Paragraph

text: And so, faces smeared with good factory muck -
label: Paragraph

text: plastered with metallic waste, with senseless sweat, with
label: Paragraph

text: celestial soot - we, bruised, our arms in slings, but unafraid,
label: Paragraph

text: declared our high intentions to all the living of earth.?
label: Paragraph

text: Then followed the eleven points of the Futurist Manifesto,
label: Paragraph

text: the first four of which extolled the virtues of temerity,
label: Paragraph

text: energy and audacity, while asserting the supreme
label: Paragraph

text: magnificence of mechanical speed in the now famous
label: Paragraph

text: passage that declared a racing car to be more beautiful
label: Paragraph

text: than the Winged Victory of Samothrace. Points five to nine
label: Paragraph

text: went on to idealize the driver of such a vehicle as being
label: Paragraph

text: integral with the trajectories of the universe and to
label: Paragraph

text: celebrate other diverse virtues, such as patriotism and the
label: Paragraph

text: glorification of war; point ten called for the destruction of
label: Paragraph

text: academic institutions of every kind; and point eleven
label: Paragraph

text: itemized the ideal context of a Futurist architecture:
label: Paragraph

text: We will sing of the stirring of great crowds - workers,
label: Paragraph

text: pleasure seekers, rioters and the confused sea of colour and
label: Title

text: sound as revolution sweeps through a modern metropolis.
label: Paragraph

text: We will sing of the midnight fervour of arsenals and
label: Paragraph

text: shipyards blazing with electric moons; insatiable stations
label: Paragraph

text: swallowing the smoking serpents of their trains; factories
label: Paragraph

text: hung from the clouds by the twisted threads of their smoke;
label: Paragraph

text: bridges flashing like knives in the sun, giant gymnasts that
label: Paragraph

text: leap over rivers; adventurous steamers that scent the
label: Paragraph

text: horizon, deep chested locomotives that paw the ground with
label: Paragraph

text: their wheels, like stallions harnessed with steel tubing; the
label: Paragraph

text: easy flight of aircraft, their propellers beating the wind like
label: Paragraph

text: banners with a sound like the applause of a mighty crowd.?
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from its debt to the aeropoesia of the nationalist
label: Paragraph

text: poet Gabriele D’Annunzio and a feeling for the ‘simultaneity’
label: Paragraph

text: of Cubist vision, this evocative passage was a
label: Paragraph

text: straightforward homage to the triumph of industrialization -
label: Paragraph

text: to the technical and social phenomena of the 19th century
label: Title

text: as they were then being extended through aviation and
label: Paragraph

text: electrical power. In the face of Italian Classical, passéist
label: Paragraph

text: values, it proclaimed the cultural primacy of a mechanized
label: Paragraph

text: environment that later informed to an equal degree the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural aesthetic of Italian Futurism and Russian
label: Title

text: Constructivism. In 1909, as Joshua Taylor has remarked,
label: Paragraph

text: Futurism was an impulse rather than a style, so that for all
label: Paragraph

text: its explicit opposition to both the Secession and to the
label: Paragraph

text: classicizing Post-Secession, the form that a Futurist
label: Paragraph

text: architecture might take was not immediately clear. After all,
label: Paragraph

text: Futurism had proclaimed itself as being fundamentally
label: Paragraph

text: opposed to culture, and this polemically negative stance
label: Paragraph

text: could hardly have excluded architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1910, with the crucial contribution of the artist
label: Paragraph

text: Umberto Boccioni, Futurism began to extend its ‘anti-
label: Paragraph

text: cultural’ polemic to the domain of plastic art. Boccioni
label: Caption

text: produced two Futurist manifestos on painting in that year,
label: Paragraph

text: and they were followed in April 1912 by his Manifesto
label: Paragraph

text: tecnico della scultura futurista (Technical Manifesto of
label: Paragraph

text: Futurist Sculpture). This later text, like most of the pre-war
label: Paragraph

text: Futurist writings, gave evidence of a developed architectural
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility. Thus Boccioni’s opening critique, while ostensibly
label: Paragraph

text: addressing itself to the pomp/er dead end that he wished to
label: Paragraph

text: confront in contemporary sculpture, could have applied,
label: Paragraph

text: with just as much pertinence, to the post-1904 work of
label: Paragraph

text: Secessionist architects such as Joseph Olbrich and Alfred
label: Paragraph

text: Messel - the former for his Tietz department store in
label: Paragraph

text: Dusseldorf and the latter for his Wertheim store in Berlin.
label: Paragraph

text: Boccioni wrote: ‘We find in Germanic countries a ridiculous
label: Paragraph

text: obsession with a Hellenized Gothic style that is
label: Paragraph

text: industrialized in Berlin and enervated in Munich.’ By the
label: Paragraph

text: same token Boccioni’s positive concern to extend the field
label: Paragraph

text: of the sculptural object to incorporate its immediate milieu
label: Paragraph

text: had connotations which were intrinsically architectural. This
label: Paragraph

text: he made explicit as a converse principle in his preface to
label: Paragraph

text: the catalogue of the first exhibition of Futurist sculpture in
label: Paragraph

text: 1913: ‘The search for naturalistic form removes sculpture
label: Title

text: (and painting also) from both its origins and its ultimate
label: Paragraph

text: end: architecture.’
label: Paragraph

text: In his concern for a non-naturalistic expression, Boccioni
label: Paragraph

text: developed a plastic aesthetic that was entirely removed
label: Paragraph

text: from the concerns of the 1896 Secession. Again in his
label: Paragraph

text: catalogue preface of 1913 he wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: In sculpture, therefore, we are not necessarily looking for
label: Paragraph

text: pure form, but for pure plastic rhythm, not the construction
label: Paragraph

text: of an object, but the construction of an object’s action. We
label: Paragraph

text: have abolished pyramidal architecture to arrive at spiral
label: Paragraph

text: architecture ...
label: Paragraph

text: We must, therefore, raise the concept of the object to
label: Paragraph

text: that of a plastic whole: object + environment. In this way we
label: Paragraph

text: shall have the object extended into the rays of light which
label: Paragraph

text: shine on to it, by uniting atmospherical blocks with
label: Paragraph

text: elements of a more concrete reality.‘
label: Paragraph

text: To achieve this sculptural simultaneity, Boccioni had
label: Paragraph

text: already recommended, in his sculpture manifesto of 1912,
label: Paragraph

text: that sculptors henceforth exclude the nude and exalted
label: Paragraph

text: subject matter and the use of honorific materials such as
label: Paragraph

text: marble or bronze in favour of heterogeneous media:
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Transparent planes of glass or celluloid, strips of metal,
label: Paragraph

text: wire, interior or exterior electric lights can indicate the
label: Paragraph

text: planes, the tendencies, the tones and half tones of a new
label: Paragraph

text: reality.” Paradoxically, this concept of a spirally structured,
label: Paragraph

text: non-monumental, mixed-media object to be extended into
label: Paragraph

text: the immediate environment was to have more influence on
label: Paragraph

text: Russian Post-Revolutionary ‘Cubo-Futurist’ Constructivism
label: Title

text: than on the evolution of Futurist architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Marinetti’s La Solendeur Géométrique et Mécanique
label: Title

text: (Geometric and Mechanical Splendour and the Numerical
label: Title

text: Sensibility) of 1914 jointly gave the intellectual and
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic frame of reference within which a Futurist
label: Paragraph

text: architecture could be postulated. Marinetti wrote: ‘Nothing
label: Paragraph

text: in the world is more beautiful than a great humming power-
label: Paragraph

text: station, holding back the hydraulic pressures of a whole
label: Paragraph

text: mountain range, and the electric power for a whole
label: Paragraph

text: landscape, synthesized in control panels bristling with levers
label: Paragraph

text: and gleaming commutators.’ This pristine vision of
label: Paragraph

text: mechanical splendour was fittingly paralleled by the young
label: Paragraph

text: Italian architect Antonio Sant’Elia’s power-station designs of
label: Paragraph

text: the same date.
label: Paragraph

text: Prior to 1912 Sant’Elia was still relatively isolated from
label: Paragraph

text: the Futurists, and involved with the Italian Secessionist
label: Paragraph

text: movement. This so-called ‘Stile Floreale’ was to enjoy an
label: Paragraph

text: extensive, if brief, national popularity after the resounding
label: Paragraph

text: success of Raimondo D’Aronco’s flamboyant pavilion for the
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition of Decorative Arts held in Turin in 1902.
label: Paragraph

text: Thereafter, in Udine, D’Aronco continued to follow the lead
label: Paragraph

text: of Olbrich, while the Milanese architects of the ‘Stile
label: Paragraph

text: Floreale’ attempted to integrate their taste for the Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Baroque with motifs drawn from the Wagnerschule. In Milan
label: Paragraph

text: this impulse found its most powerful synthesis in the works
label: Paragraph

text: of Giuseppe Sommaruga, who seems to have exercised a
label: Paragraph

text: particular influence over Sant’Elia’s early development.
label: Paragraph

text: Many of the characteristic elements of Sant’Elia’s
label: Paragraph

text: dinamismo architettonico were surely anticipated in
label: Paragraph

text: Sommaruga’s hotel at Campo de’ Fiori, while Sommaruga’s
label: Paragraph

text: Faccanoni Mausoleum [65], built at Sarnico in 1907, seems
label: Paragraph

text: to have served as the point of departure for Sant’Elia’s
label: Paragraph

text: design of 1912 for a cemetery at Monza [66].
label: Caption

text: 65 Sommaruga, Faccanoni Mausoleum, Sarnico, 1907.
label: Caption

text: 66 Sant’Elia, design for Monza Cemetery, 1912.
label: Caption

text: In 1905, at the age of seventeen, Sant’Elia obtained his
label: Paragraph

text: diploma as a master builder from a technical school in
label: Paragraph

text: Como. He then moved to Milan and started to work, first for
label: Paragraph

text: the Villoresi Canal Company and later for the city of Milan. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1911 he took architectural courses at the Brera Academy,
label: Paragraph

text: and in the same year he designed a small villa above Como
label: Paragraph

text: for the industrialist Romeo Longatti. By 1912 he was back in
label: Paragraph

text: Milan, working on a competition entry for the central
label: Paragraph

text: station. In the same year he collaborated with his friends
label: Paragraph

text: Ugo Nebbia, Mario Chiattone and others to form the group
label: Paragraph

text: Nuove Tendenze. At the first exhibition of this group, in
label: Paragraph

text: 1914, Sant’Elia showed his drawings for the Futurist ‘Citta
label: Paragraph

text: Nuova’. At what date he had first made contact with
label: Paragraph

text: Marinetti and the Futurist circle remains unclear, but he was
label: Paragraph

text: fully under their influence by the time of writing, with the
label: Paragraph

text: help of Nebbia, his Messaggio, as a preface to the 1914
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition.
label: Paragraph

text: The Messaggio, signed only by Sant’Elia, finally specifies
label: Paragraph

text: - without once using the word ‘Futurist’ - the rigorous form
label: Paragraph

text: that architecture should adopt in the future. The most
label: Paragraph

text: specific parts of this text, now categorically anti-
label: Paragraph

text: Secessionist, read:
label: Paragraph

text: The problem of modern architecture is not a problem of
label: Paragraph

text: rearranging its lines; not a question of finding new
label: Paragraph

text: mouldings, new architraves for doors and windows; nor of
label: Caption

text: replacing columns, pilasters and corbels with caryatids,
label: Paragraph

text: hornets and frogs, etc. ... but to raise the new built structure
label: Paragraph

text: on a sane plane, gleaning every benefit of science and
label: Paragraph

text: technology ... establishing new forms, new lines, new
label: Paragraph

text: reasons for existence solely out of the special conditions of
label: Paragraph

text: modern living and its projection as aesthetic value in our
label: Paragraph

text: sensibilities.>
label: Paragraph

text: The text then turns to contemplate the invigorating
label: Paragraph

text: large-scale landscape of a new industrial world,
label: Paragraph

text: paraphrasing the spirit if not the letter of Marinetti’s diatribe
label: Paragraph

text: against Ruskin and the whole of the English Arts and Crafts
label: Title

text: movement, delivered at the Lyceum Club in London in 1912.
label: Paragraph

text: Against the passéism of Morris’s ‘Nowhere’, Marinetti
label: Paragraph

text: asserted that
label: Paragraph

text: cosmopolitan travel, the spirit of democracy and the decay
label: Title

text: of religions had made completely useless the vast
label: Paragraph

text: permanent and ornate buildings that once used to express
label: Paragraph

text: royal authority, theocracy and mysticism ... the right to
label: Paragraph

text: strike, equality before the law, the authority of numbers, the
label: Paragraph

text: usurping power of the mob, the speed of international
label: Paragraph

text: communications and the habits of hygiene and comfort
label: Title

text: demand instead large well-ventilated apartment houses,
label: Paragraph

text: railways of absolute reliability, tunnels, iron bridges, vast
label: Paragraph

text: high-speed liners, hillside villas open to the breeze and
label: Paragraph

text: view, immense meeting halls and bathrooms designed for
label: Paragraph

text: the rapid daily care of the body.®
label: Paragraph

text: In short, he correctly recognized the implacable advent of
label: Paragraph

text: a new cultural milieu dedicated to a large-scale and highly
label: Paragraph

text: mobile society: a society to be equipped in detail according
label: Title

text: to Sant’Elia’s Messaggio, in which he wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: Calculations of the resistance of materials, the use of
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete and iron exclude ‘Architecture’ as
label: Paragraph

text: understood in the Classical or traditional sense. Modern
label: Paragraph

text: structural materials and our scientific concepts absolutely
label: Title

text: do not lend themselves to the disciplines of historical styles
label: Paragraph

text: ... We no longer feel ourselves to be the men of the
label: Paragraph

text: cathedrals and ancient moot halls, but men of the Grand
label: Paragraph

text: Hotels, railway stations, giant roads, colossal harbours,
label: Paragraph

text: covered markets, glittering arcades, reconstruction areas
label: Caption

text: and salutary slum clearances. We must invent and rebuild
label: Paragraph

text: ex novo our modern city like an immense and tumultuous
label: Paragraph

text: shipyard, active, mobile and everywhere dynamic, and the
label: Paragraph

text: modern building like a gigantic machine. Lifts must no
label: Paragraph

text: longer hide away like solitary worms in the stairwells, but
label: Paragraph

text: the stairs - now useless - must be abolished, and the lifts
label: Paragraph

text: must swarm up the facades like serpents of glass and iron.
label: Paragraph

text: The house of cement, iron and glass, without carved or
label: Paragraph

text: painted ornament, rich only in the inherent beauty of its
label: Paragraph

text: lines and modelling, extraordinarily brutish in its mechanical
label: Paragraph

text: simplicity, as big as need dictates, and not merely as zoning
label: Paragraph

text: rules permit, must rise from the brink of a tumultuous
label: Paragraph

text: abyss: the street which, itself, will no longer lie like a
label: Paragraph

text: doormat at the level of the thresholds but plunge storeys
label: Paragraph

text: deep into the earth, gathering up the traffic of the
label: Paragraph

text: metropolis connected for necessary transfers to metal cat-
label: Paragraph

text: walks and high-speed conveyor belts.’
label: Paragraph

text: This prescription, specifying the form of Sant’Elia’s casa a
label: Paragraph

text: gradinata designs of 1914 [67], is of such a dynamic nature
label: Paragraph

text: as to suggest precedents other than Henri Sauvage’s set-
label: Paragraph

text: back apartment block completed in Rue Vavin, Paris, in
label: Caption

text: 1912. The subtitle of the Nuove Tendenze exhibition, ‘Milano
label: Caption

text: l’'anno due mille’, suggests the precedent of Antoine Moilin’s
label: Paragraph

text: book Paris, l’an 2000 (1896), a work which Marinetti would
label: Paragraph

text: have known through his contact with the Parisian poet
label: Paragraph

text: Gustave Kahn.
label: Paragraph

text: 67 Sant’Elia, casa a gradinata for the Citta Nuova, 1914.
label: Caption

text: Sant’Elia’s sketches for the Citta Nuova are not entirely
label: Paragraph

text: consistent with his precepts. Where the Messaggio took a
label: Paragraph

text: stand against all commemorative architecture and, in
label: Paragraph

text: consequence, against all static and pyramidal forms,
label: Paragraph

text: Sant’Elia’s drawings are replete with such monumental
label: Paragraph

text: images. In retrospect it seems but a step from Sommaruga’s
label: Paragraph

text: Faccanoni Mausoleum to the soaring, massive and often
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrical powerhouses and tall blocks that rise like
label: Paragraph

text: mirages out of the scenographic landscape of the Citta
label: Paragraph

text: Nuova. In this context, it is fitting and ironic that Sant’Elia’s
label: Paragraph

text: memory should have been honoured in a monument to the
label: Paragraph

text: dead of the First World War, which was erected on the
label: Paragraph

text: shores of Lake Como in 1933 - to a design by Giuseppe
label: Caption

text: Terragni based on one of Sant’Elia’s sketches.
label: Paragraph

text: The official Manifesto dell’architettura futurista
label: Title

text: (Manifesto of Futurist Architecture), published in July 1914,
label: Paragraph

text: seems to have had as its prime goal the public recognition
label: Paragraph

text: of Sant’Elia as a Futurist. It amounted to a new version of
label: Paragraph

text: the Messaggio, edited, to all appearances, by Marinetti and
label: Paragraph

text: signed by Sant’Elia alone. Apart from the interjection of the
label: Caption

text: word ‘Futurist’ on every possible occasion, this text added
label: Paragraph

text: little to the original save a number of militant propositions
label: Paragraph

text: at the end, including the contradictory opposition to any
label: Paragraph

text: kind of permanence, the assertion that ‘our houses will last
label: Paragraph

text: less time than we do and that every generation will have to
label: Paragraph

text: make its own’.
label: Paragraph

text: By now Sant’Elia was fully involved in Futurism and in
label: Paragraph

text: 1915 he signed, with Boccioni, Marinetti, Piatti and Russolo,
label: Paragraph

text: the Futurist proto-Fascist political manifesto, /talian Pride. |n
label: Paragraph

text: July of that year he enlisted with other Futurists in the
label: Paragraph

text: Lombardy Volunteer Cyclist Battalion and entered ona
label: Title

text: military career that ended with his front-line death in 1916.
label: Paragraph

text: With the loss of Boccioni two months before (in a riding
label: Paragraph

text: accident) the generative period of Futurism was brought to
label: Paragraph

text: an abrupt end, ironically divested of its major talent in part
label: Paragraph

text: by the first industrialized war. Out of this Futurist holocaust,
label: Paragraph

text: Marinetti survived to remind his fellow Futurists, such as
label: Paragraph

text: Balla, Carra, Severini and Russolo, of their duty to lead the
label: Paragraph

text: post-war generation towards the final fulfilment of Italian
label: Paragraph

text: nationalism in the triumph of a Fascist state.
label: Paragraph

text: Typical of the confusion of Futurism in its decline, which
label: Paragraph

text: undoubtedly paralleled Mussolini’s rapprochement with the
label: Paragraph

text: Vatican, was Marinetti’s 1931 Manifesto of Sacred Futurist
label: Paragraph

text: Art, where he urged that church candlelight ‘must be
label: Paragraph

text: replaced by powerful electric bulbs of brilliant white and
label: Paragraph

text: blue light’, that ‘for the representations of Hell, Futurist
label: Paragraph

text: painters must depend on their memories of shell-scarred
label: Paragraph

text: battlefields’, and that ‘only Futurist artists ... can give form
label: Paragraph

text: to interpenetrated space-time, to the super-rational
label: Paragraph

text: mysteries of the Catholic dogmas’.
label: Paragraph

text: That this absurd bravado had been anticipated in the
label: Paragraph

text: initial manifesto (with its violence reminiscent of Georges
label: Paragraph

text: Sorel) does not entirely account for the state of decadence
label: Paragraph

text: to which Futurist ‘culture’ had descended by 1931. After
label: Paragraph

text: 1919 it was the revolutionary Russian Constructivists, and
label: Paragraph

text: not the Italians, who took up the early militant modernism of
label: Paragraph

text: Marinetti, Boccioni and Sant’Elia. Some time was to elapse
label: Paragraph

text: before the Italian Rationalist movement would begin to
label: Paragraph

text: respond to the images of the Citta Nuova, and even then it
label: Paragraph

text: would do so only in a climate that was concerned for the
label: Paragraph

text: integration of modern values into the Classical traditions of
label: Paragraph

text: Italian architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 8
label: Title

text: Adolf Loos and the Crisis
label: Title

text: of Culture 1896-1931
label: Title

text: May | lead you to the shores of a mountain lake? The sky is
label: Paragraph

text: blue, the water green and everything is profoundly peaceful.
label: Paragraph

text: Mountains and clouds are reflected in the lake, and so are
label: Paragraph

text: houses, farmyards, court-yards and chapels. They do not
label: Paragraph

text: seem man made, but more like the product of God's
label: Paragraph

text: workshop, like the mountains and trees, the clouds and the
label: Paragraph

text: blue sky. And everything breathes beauty and tranquillity.
label: Paragraph

text: Ah, what is that? A false note in this harmony. Like an
label: Paragraph

text: unwelcome scream. In the centre, beneath the peasants’
label: Paragraph

text: homes which were created not by them, but by God, stands
label: Paragraph

text: a villa. Is it the product of a good or a bad architect? | do not
label: Paragraph

text: know. | only know that peace, tranquillity and beauty are no
label: Paragraph

text: more. ...
label: Paragraph

text: And | ask yet again: Why does the architect both good
label: Paragraph

text: and bad violate the lake? Like almost every town dweller,
label: Paragraph

text: the architect possesses no culture. He does not have the
label: Paragraph

text: security of the peasant to whom this culture is innate. The
label: Paragraph

text: town dweller is an upstart.
label: Paragraph

text: | call culture, that balance of inner and outer man, which
label: Paragraph

text: alone can guarantee reasonable thought and action.
label: Paragraph

text: Adolf Loos
label: Title

text: Architektur, 19101
label: Caption

text: Adolf Loos, the son of a stonemason, was born in Brno,
label: Paragraph

text: Moravia, in 1870. Following a technical education at the
label: Paragraph

text: Royal and Imperial State Technical College and further
label: Title

text: studies at the Dresden College of Technology, he left for the
label: Paragraph

text: United States in 1893 - apparently to visit the World’s
label: Paragraph

text: Columbian Exposition in Chicago. Although he seems not to
label: Paragraph

text: have found work as an architect during his three-year stay
label: Paragraph

text: in the States, he nonetheless became familiar with the
label: Paragraph

text: pioneer achievements of the Chicago School and with the
label: Paragraph

text: theoretical writings of Louis Sullivan, in particular with
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan’s essay Ornament in Architecture (1892), which
label: Paragraph

text: patently influenced his own essay Ornament und
label: Paragraph

text: Verbrechen (Ornament and Crime), published sixteen years
label: Paragraph

text: later.
label: Paragraph

text: After his return to Vienna in 1896, Loos began his career
label: Paragraph

text: by designing interiors and writing articles for the liberal
label: Paragraph

text: Neue Freie Presse, on a wide variety of topics ranging from
label: Paragraph

text: clothes to architecture and from manners to music. In 1908
label: Paragraph

text: he published Ornament and Crime, in which he elaborated
label: Paragraph

text: the nature of his quarrel with the artists of the Viennese
label: Paragraph

text: Secession, an argument that he had already enjoined by
label: Paragraph

text: 1900 in the form of an anti-Gesamtkunstwerk fable, ‘The
label: Paragraph

text: Story of a Poor Rich Man’. There Loos portrayed the fate of a
label: Paragraph

text: wealthy businessman who had commissioned a Secessionist
label: Paragraph

text: architect to design a ‘total’ house for him, including not only
label: Paragraph

text: the furnishings but also the clothes of the occupants:
label: Paragraph

text: Once it happened that he was celebrating his birthday. His
label: Paragraph

text: wife and children had given him many presents. He liked
label: Paragraph

text: their choice immensely and enjoyed it all thoroughly. But
label: Paragraph

text: soon the architect arrived to set things right, and to take all
label: Paragraph

text: the decisions in difficult questions. He entered the room.
label: Paragraph

text: The master greeted him with pleasure, for he had much on
label: Paragraph

text: his mind. But the architect did not see the man’s joy. He had
label: Paragraph

text: discovered something quite different and grew pale. ‘What
label: Paragraph

text: kind of slippers are these you've got on?’ he ejaculated
label: Paragraph

text: painfully. The master of the house looked at his embroidered
label: Paragraph

text: slippers. Then he breathed in relief This time he felt quite
label: Paragraph

text: guiltless. The slippers had been made to the architect's
label: Paragraph

text: original designs. So he answered in a superior way. ‘But Mr
label: Paragraph

text: Architect! Have you already forgotten? You yourself
label: Paragraph

text: designed them!’ ‘Of course,’ thundered the architect, ‘but
label: Paragraph

text: for the bedroom! They completely disrupt the mood here
label: Paragraph

text: with these two impossible spots of colour. Can’t you see
label: Paragraph

text: that??
label: Paragraph

text: The Belgian artist Henry van de Velde is as much the
label: Paragraph

text: unidentified cultural martinet of this sardonic piece as
label: Paragraph

text: Joseph Maria Olbrich. For it was he and not Olbrich who
label: Paragraph

text: designed special clothes for his wife to harmonize with the
label: Paragraph

text: lines of their house, built at Uccle in 1895 (see p. 105).
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, Olbrich remained the essential focus of Loos’s
label: Paragraph

text: anti-Secessionist attacks throughout the next decade: he
label: Paragraph

text: was even cited by name in Ornament and Crime as the
label: Paragraph

text: progenitor of illegitimate ornament. ‘Where will Olbrich’s
label: Paragraph

text: work be in ten years’ time?’ wrote Loos. ‘Modern ornament
label: Paragraph

text: has no forebears and no descendants, no past and no
label: Paragraph

text: future. It is joyfully welcomed by uncultivated people to
label: Paragraph

text: whom the true greatness of our time is a closed book, and
label: Paragraph

text: after a short time is rejected.’
label: Paragraph

text: Loos’s ultimate argument against ornament was not only
label: Paragraph

text: that it was wasteful in labour and material, but that it
label: Paragraph

text: invariably entailed a punitive form of craft slavery that could
label: Paragraph

text: be justified only for those to whom the highest
label: Paragraph

text: achievements of bourgeois culture were inaccessible - for
label: Paragraph

text: those craftsmen who could find their aesthetic fulfilment
label: Paragraph

text: only in the spontaneous creation of ornament. Loos justified
label: Paragraph

text: the ornamentation of his bespoke footwear - which he would
label: Paragraph

text: have preferred to be plain - in the following terms: ‘We go to
label: Paragraph

text: Beethoven or Tristan after the cares of the day. My
label: Paragraph

text: shoemaker can’t. | must not take away his joy as | have
label: Paragraph

text: nothing to replace it with. But whoever goes to the Ninth
label: Paragraph

text: Symphony and then sits down to design a wallpaper is
label: Paragraph

text: either a rogue or a degenerate.’
label: Paragraph

text: Such challenging ethical and aesthetic pronouncements
label: Title

text: isolated Loos not only from the Secession and his
label: Paragraph

text: conservative contemporaries, but also from his true
label: Paragraph

text: successors, those latter-day ‘purists’ who even now have
label: Paragraph

text: yet to comprehend fully the profundity of his insights. By the
label: Paragraph

text: time of his critical essay Architektur of 1910, Loos had
label: Paragraph

text: already begun to sense the full force of a modern
label: Paragraph

text: predicament, which persists to this day. Given, as Loos
label: Paragraph

text: argued, that the architect from the city was uprooted by
label: Paragraph

text: definition and hence categorically alienated from the innate
label: Paragraph

text: agrarian (or alpine) vernacular of his distant forebears, then
label: Paragraph

text: it followed that he could not compensate for this loss by
label: Paragraph

text: pretending to inherit the aristocratic culture of Western
label: Paragraph

text: Classicism. For the urban bourgeoisie - whence he
label: Paragraph

text: invariably came and whom he naturally served - were,
label: Paragraph

text: whatever else they might be, patently not aristocrats. That
label: Paragraph

text: much was already clear to Loos in 1898 when he wrote in
label: Paragraph

text: Die potemkinsche Stadt, his satire on the Ringstrasse:
label: Paragraph

text: Whenever | stroll along the Ring, | always feel as if a modern
label: Paragraph

text: Potemkin had wanted to make somebody believe he had
label: Paragraph

text: been transported into a city of aristocrats. All that the Italian
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance could produce in noble mansions had been
label: Paragraph

text: plundered in order to conjure up for her Highness the
label: Paragraph

text: common people a New Vienna which only people ina
label: Title

text: position to own an entire palace from the cellars to the
label: Paragraph

text: chimney-pots could inhabit. ... Viennese landlords were
label: Paragraph

text: delighted with the idea of owning a mansion and the
label: Paragraph

text: tenants were equally pleased to be able to live in one.?
label: Paragraph

text: Loos’s solution to this dilemma, as posited in Architektur,
label: Paragraph

text: was to argue that most modern building tasks were
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate vehicles for bui/ding rather than architecture:
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Only a very small part of architecture belongs to art: the
label: Paragraph

text: tomb and the monument. Everything else, everything that
label: Paragraph

text: serves a purpose, should be excluded from the realms of
label: Paragraph

text: art.’
label: Paragraph

text: At the same time Loos considered that all culture
label: Paragraph

text: depended on a certain continuity with the past, above all,
label: Paragraph

text: on a consensus as to a typification. He could not accept the
label: Paragraph

text: romantic notion of the highly gifted individual transcending
label: Paragraph

text: the historical limits of his own epoch. Instead of self-
label: Paragraph

text: conscious ornamental design, Loos favoured understated
label: Paragraph

text: dress, anonymous furniture and efficient plumbing of the
label: Paragraph

text: Anglo-Saxon middle class. Naturally in this respect he had
label: Paragraph

text: America in mind rather than England. In this he anticipated
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier's notion of the objet-type, the refined,
label: Paragraph

text: normative object, spontaneously produced by the craft-
label: Paragraph

text: based industries of the society. To this end, objects of Anglo-
label: Paragraph

text: Saxon affinity, such as clothing, sportswear and personal
label: Paragraph

text: accessories, appeared as advertisements in Loos’s short-
label: Paragraph

text: lived periodical Das Andere (‘The Other’) of 1903 [69],
label: Paragraph

text: which was significantly subtitled ‘A Journal for the
label: Paragraph

text: Introduction of Western Civilization into Austria’.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite all his Anglophilia, the ‘vernacular’ of the English
label: Paragraph

text: Arts and Crafts movement (as documented in Hermann
label: Title

text: Muthesius’s book Das Englische Haus of 1904) presented
label: Paragraph

text: Loos with a problem: where was one to draw a line between
label: Paragraph

text: such architecture, however sensible and convenient, and
label: Paragraph

text: the self-conscious, craft-based, hermetic fantasies of the
label: Paragraph

text: Secession? Since for Loos the last Western architect of
label: Paragraph

text: stature had been Schinkel, his self-imposed predicament
label: Paragraph

text: seems to have been how to combine the informal comfort of
label: Paragraph

text: the Anglo-Saxon interior with the asperities of Classical
label: Paragraph

text: form.
label: Paragraph

text: Until 1910, Loos’s practice was largely confined to the
label: Paragraph

text: conversion of existing interiors. His best works of this period
label: Paragraph

text: were the luxury shops that he designed in Vienna around
label: Paragraph

text: the turn of the century, and his famous Karntner or
label: Paragraph

text: American Bar of 1907. Externally these works, designed for
label: Caption

text: the purveyors of Anglocentric civilization, were finished in
label: Paragraph

text: elegant, unobtrusive materials, while internally the style
label: Paragraph

text: varied from the Japanese ambience of his first interior for
label: Paragraph

text: Goldman & Salatsch [68] in the Graben (1898) to the
label: Paragraph

text: classicized club-room elegance of the Karntner Bar.
label: Paragraph

text: 68 A 1911 cartoonist’s comment on Loos’s Goldman and Salatsch facade (1910-
label: Caption

text: 11). The original caption read: ‘Brooding about art, the most modern man walks
label: Paragraph

text: through the streets. Suddenly he stops transfixed. He has found that for which
label: Paragraph

text: he has searched so long.’
label: Paragraph

text: 69 Cover of Das Andere, edited by Loos, Vienna, 1903.
label: Caption

text: In Loos’s domestic interiors the expression was even
label: Paragraph

text: more eclectic, reflecting the fundamental split in his work
label: Paragraph

text: between a comfortable rusticity on the one hand and a
label: Paragraph

text: severe monumentality on the other. He invariably panelled
label: Paragraph

text: his walls up to dado or picture-rail level in polished stone or
label: Paragraph

text: wood; above this they were either left blank or topped with
label: Paragraph

text: an ornamental pattern or Classical frieze in plaster. (In
label: Paragraph

text: Ornament and Crime, Loos had admitted the eclectic
label: Paragraph

text: appropriation of archaeological ornament, while
label: Paragraph

text: categorically excluding the invention of modern decoration.)
label: Paragraph

text: Ceilings, where public, were often blank; where private, they
label: Paragraph

text: were coffered in wood or metal. On other occasions,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly in dining spaces, they might be relieved by
label: Paragraph

text: Richardsonian timber beams, which were often of grotesque
label: Paragraph

text: proportions, as in the Steiner House in Vienna of 1910 [70,
label: Paragraph

text: 71]. Floors were generally of stone of parquet and always
label: Paragraph

text: covered with oriental carpets, while fireplace surrounds,
label: Paragraph

text: frequently of brick, stood out in textured contrast to the
label: Paragraph

text: highlights invariably provided by vitrines, mirrors, lamps and
label: Paragraph

text: sundry metalware. As far as possible furniture was always
label: Paragraph

text: built in. Otherwise it was selected by the client, although
label: Paragraph

text: where it was movable and the building public, Loos
label: Paragraph

text: restricted himself to standard Thonet bentwood furniture, as
label: Paragraph

text: in his somewhat Wagner-like Café Museum of 1899. In his
label: Paragraph

text: essay on the abolition of furniture he wrote: ‘The walls of a
label: Paragraph

text: building belong to the architect. There he rules at will. And
label: Paragraph

text: as with walls so with any furniture that is not movable.’ Of
label: Paragraph

text: movable pieces he wrote: ‘The wrought-iron bedstead, table
label: Paragraph

text: and chairs, hassocks and occasional chairs, desks and
label: Paragraph

text: smoking stands - all items made by our craftsmen in the
label: Paragraph

text: modern idiom (never by architects); everyone may buy
label: Paragraph

text: these for himself according to his own taste and inclination.’
label: Paragraph

text: This categorical anti-Gesamtkunstwerk attitude was
label: Paragraph

text: complemented by Loos’s passion for rich materials of which
label: Paragraph

text: he wrote in the vein of Semper: ‘Rich material and good
label: Paragraph

text: workmanship should not only be considered as making up
label: Paragraph

text: for lack of decoration, but as far surpassing it in
label: Paragraph

text: sumptuousness.’
label: Paragraph

text: 70, 71 Loos, Steiner House, Vienna, 1910. Below, dining room.
label: Caption

text: The Steiner House initiated a series of houses in which
label: Paragraph

text: Loos gradually evolved his conception of the Raumplan or
label: Paragraph

text: ‘plan of volumes’, a complex system of internal organization
label: Paragraph

text: that culminated in the split-level houses realized towards
label: Paragraph

text: the end of his life: the Moller House in Vienna and the Miller
label: Title

text: House near Prague. By the time of the Steiner House, Loos
label: Paragraph

text: had already arrived at a highly abstract external idiom - his
label: Paragraph

text: white unadorned prism, which anticipated by at least eight
label: Paragraph

text: years the so-called ‘International Style’. He began to
label: Paragraph

text: elaborate his Raump/an concept in his Rufer House, Vienna
label: Caption

text: (1912), where, in contrast to his later houses, the openings
label: Paragraph

text: are quite freely disposed, following the free disposition of
label: Paragraph

text: the internal volumes - an elevational counterpoint that
label: Paragraph

text: anticipated the canonical works of De Stijl.
label: Paragraph

text: Loos’s Raumplan reached its apotheosis in his last
label: Paragraph

text: domestic works, the Moller and Muller houses of 1928 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1930. As anticipated in the open stair hall of the Rufer
label: Caption

text: House, both these works are organized about displacements
label: Paragraph

text: in the respective levels of their principal floors, elisions that
label: Paragraph

text: serve not only to create spatial movement but also to
label: Paragraph

text: differentiate one living area from the next. The typically
label: Paragraph

text: irregular Gothic Revival plan, documented in Muthesius’s
label: Paragraph

text: Das Englische Haus, clearly inspired Loos’s wholly
label: Paragraph

text: unprecedented development of the Raumpi/an, yet with his
label: Paragraph

text: Classical predilection for cubic form he could not accept the
label: Paragraph

text: picturesque massing that was its natural consequence. From
label: Paragraph

text: this, no doubt, came the tortuous manipulation of the
label: Paragraph

text: available volume of the prism as though it were just so
label: Paragraph

text: much raw material from which to create a dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: composition in section.
label: Paragraph

text: Such plastic intentions were basically incompatible with
label: Paragraph

text: an architecture of consistent distinction between structural
label: Paragraph

text: and non-structural elements, and while Loos strove to
label: Paragraph

text: maintain such distinctions in his public work, at a domestic
label: Paragraph

text: level he gave primacy to the sensation of space, rather than
label: Paragraph

text: to the revelation of architectonic structure. The principles of
label: Paragraph

text: Viollet-le-Duc were in any event alien to him, since he
label: Paragraph

text: deliberately contorted plans for the sake of providing an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural promenade of sensual significance as Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier was to do. In almost all his domestic work
label: Paragraph

text: structural junctions are invariably masked by revetment,
label: Paragraph

text: either with the aim of hiding unresolved conditions or out of
label: Paragraph

text: a desire to provide an appropriate level of decorum.
label: Paragraph

text: During his tenure as chief architect to the Housing
label: Paragraph

text: Department of Vienna, from 1920 to 1922, in the austere
label: Paragraph

text: aftermath of the war, Loos applied his as yet undeveloped
label: Paragraph

text: Raumplan to the problem of mass housing. The result was a
label: Paragraph

text: number of remarkable housing studies, in which his
label: Paragraph

text: preferred form, the cube, became transformed into a
label: Paragraph

text: stepped terrace section. In 1920 he designed a brilliant and
label: Paragraph

text: economical housing scheme, known as the Heuberg Estate
label: Paragraph

text: [72]. Terrace houses were integrated with greenhouses and
label: Paragraph

text: allotments, in which the occupants were expected to grow
label: Paragraph

text: their own food - a typical urban survival strategy of the
label: Paragraph

text: inflationary post-war period, which became adopted as
label: Paragraph

text: general policy in many German housing settlements during
label: Paragraph

text: the 1920s.
label: Paragraph

text: 72 Loos, Heuberg Estate, Vienna, 1920, showing conservatories and allotments.
label: Caption

text: It is one of the paradoxes of Loos’s career that he, the
label: Paragraph

text: bourgeois architect and man of taste, should create his
label: Paragraph

text: most sensitive larger projects in the service of the
label: Paragraph

text: underprivileged. His disillusioned resignation as housing
label: Paragraph

text: architect in 1922 and his subsequent migration to Paris, at
label: Paragraph

text: the invitation of the Dadaist poet Tristan Tzara - for whom
label: Paragraph

text: he was to design a house in 1926 - restored him to the
label: Paragraph

text: cosmopolitan circles of the high bourgeoisie. There he
label: Paragraph

text: became part of the fashionable world that surrounded the
label: Paragraph

text: dancer Josephine Baker, for whom he designed a rather
label: Paragraph

text: ostentatious villa in 1928. Save for Tzara and his old
label: Caption

text: Viennese client, the internationally famous tailor Knize, for
label: Paragraph

text: whom he had first designed a store in Vienna in 1909, none
label: Paragraph

text: of his Parisian patrons had either the resources or the faith
label: Paragraph

text: to realize any of the large-scale projects that he designed
label: Paragraph

text: during his expatriate years. In 1928 he returned to Vienna,
label: Paragraph

text: five years before his death, his career virtually at an end.
label: Paragraph

text: In the final analysis Loos’s significance as a pioneer
label: Paragraph

text: depended not only on his extraordinary insights as a critic of
label: Paragraph

text: modern culture, but also on his formulation of the Raumplan
label: Paragraph

text: as an architectural strategy for transcending the
label: Paragraph

text: contradictory cultural legacy of bourgeois society which,
label: Paragraph

text: having deprived itself of the vernacular, could not claim in
label: Paragraph

text: exchange the culture of Classicism. No one was better
label: Paragraph

text: prepared to receive this hyperconscious sensibility than the
label: Paragraph

text: post-war Parisian avant garde, in particular the circle editing
label: Paragraph

text: L’Esprit Nouveau, namely the proto-Dadaist poet Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Dermée and the Purist painters Amédée Ozenfant and
label: Title

text: Charles-Edouard Jeanneret (Le Corbusier), who in 1920
label: Paragraph

text: reprinted the 1913 French translation of Ornament and
label: Paragraph

text: Crime. And while (as Reyner Banham has observed) the
label: Paragraph

text: roots of Purism lay in the abstract classicizing tendencies of
label: Paragraph

text: Parisian culture, notwithstanding the ‘ready-made’
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility of Marcel Duchamp, there is little reason to doubt
label: Paragraph

text: that the influence of Loos was decisive in refining the
label: Paragraph

text: typological programme of Purism: that impulse to
label: Title

text: synthesize, at every conceivable scale, the ‘type-objects’ of
label: Paragraph

text: the modern world.
label: Paragraph

text: Above all, Loos must now be seen as the first to
label: Paragraph

text: postulate the problem that Le Corbusier was eventually to
label: Paragraph

text: resolve with his full development of the free plan. The
label: Paragraph

text: typological issue posited by Loos was how to combine the
label: Paragraph

text: propriety of Platonic mass with the convenience of irregular
label: Paragraph

text: volume. This proposition was never more lyrically stated
label: Paragraph

text: than in his 1923 project for a villa on the Lido in Venice [73,
label: Paragraph

text: 74]; and this house was destined to become the type-form
label: Paragraph

text: for Le Corbusier’s canonical Purist villa, his villa at Garches
label: Paragraph

text: 73, 74 Loos, villa project for the Venice Lido, 1923. Above, transverse section
label: Caption

text: and plan of first floor: befow, model.

text: Empathy 1895-1914

text: | tell you that the time will come, when the furnishing of a
label: Paragraph
