label: Paragraph

text: Adolf Loos
label: Title

text: Trotzdem, 1931}
label: Title

text: The Belgian designer and theorist Henry van de Velde set
label: Title

text: out on what he called the voje sacrée of architecture in
label: Paragraph

text: 1894, at the age of thirty-one, when after ten years as a
label: Paragraph

text: Neo-Impressionist painter he published his famous essay,
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Déblaiement d'art’, in the Belgian Nietzschean journal La
label: Caption

text: Société nouvelle. This essay, which called for the
label: Paragraph

text: redeployment of art in the service of the society, was clearly
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by those Pre-Raphaelite precepts which Van de
label: Paragraph

text: Velde would have learned through his association with the
label: Paragraph

text: avant-garde group, Les XX. Since its inception in 1889, this
label: Paragraph

text: Belgian group of artists had had strong ties with England
label: Paragraph

text: and in particular with William Morris’s protégé Walter Crane.
label: Paragraph

text: Under Crane’s influence, the group turned from its fine art
label: Paragraph

text: preoccupations to a concern for the design of the
label: Paragraph

text: environment as a whole. Reorganized under the leadership
label: Paragraph

text: of Octave Maus, Les XX became the Salon de la Libre
label: Paragraph

text: Esthétique, whose first exhibition in 1894 featured the work
label: Paragraph

text: of the Belgian cabinetmaker Gustave Serrurier-Bovy.
label: Paragraph

text: Serrurier-Bovy brought back to Belgium an Arts and Crafts
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility that he had acquired in England during the
label: Paragraph

text: second half of the 1880s. In 1894 he displayed the
label: Paragraph

text: exceptional qualities of his unpainted furniture in a suite of
label: Paragraph

text: strikingly sculptural pieces that recalled that Anglo-Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: style, developed some twenty years before by Edward
label: Paragraph

text: Godwin and Christopher Dresser.
label: Paragraph

text: Van de Velde made his début as an architect and as a
label: Paragraph

text: designer in 1895, when he designed and built a house for
label: Paragraph

text: himself at Uccle near Brussels. This without question was
label: Paragraph

text: intended to demonstrate the ultimate synthesis of all the
label: Paragraph

text: arts, for apart from integrating the house with all its
label: Paragraph

text: furnishings, including the cutlery, Van de Velde attempted to
label: Paragraph

text: consummate the whole Gesamtkunstwerk through the
label: Paragraph

text: flowing forms of the dresses that he designed for his wife.
label: Paragraph

text: The fall, cut and decoration of these clothes [75] already
label: Paragraph

text: exhibited that energetic serpentine line that was to be Van
label: Paragraph

text: de Velde’s prime contribution to the vocabulary that he
label: Paragraph

text: inherited from Serrurier-Bovy. Derived from Gauguin, it was
label: Paragraph

text: used as an expressive device for imparting a more vigorous
label: Paragraph

text: profile to the formal legacy of the Arts and Crafts.
label: Paragraph

text: 75 Van de Velde’s wife, Maria Sethe, wearing a dress to his design, c. 1898.
label: Caption

text: For Van de Velde the ameliorative thrust of the English
label: Caption

text: Arts and Crafts movement was complemented by the more
label: Paragraph

text: anarchic but equally reformist visions of Tolstoy and
label: Paragraph

text: Kropotkin. While he could share with the Pre-Raphaelites
label: Paragraph

text: their intense antipathy to all architecture after the Gothic,
label: Paragraph

text: he could not accept their conscious drive towards the
label: Paragraph

text: medievalization of the present. As a socialist, he was more
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by the young militants of the Belgian Socialist
label: Paragraph

text: Party, with whom he had been in contact since the mid-
label: Paragraph

text: 1880s: Emile Vandervelde, the socialist client of Horta’s
label: Caption

text: Maison du Peuple, and the poet-critic Emile Verhaeren,
label: Paragraph

text: whose critical study of urbanization, Les Villes tentaculaires,
label: Paragraph

text: had been published in 1895. Yet in spite of these radical
label: Paragraph

text: affiliations, Van de Velde still believed in the reform of
label: Paragraph

text: society through the design of the environment; that is, he
label: Paragraph

text: still adhered to a sensationalist faith in the primacy of
label: Paragraph

text: physical form over programmatic content. For him, as for
label: Paragraph

text: the whole of the Arts and Crafts tradition, the single family
label: Paragraph

text: house was the prime social vehicle through which the values
label: Paragraph

text: of the society could be gradually transformed. ‘Ugliness’, he
label: Paragraph

text: held, ‘corrupts not only the eyes but also the heart and
label: Paragraph

text: mind.’ In his fight against ugliness, Van de Velde
label: Paragraph

text: concentrated on the design of every aspect of the domestic
label: Paragraph

text: environment [76, 77]. He was ill-equipped, either by
label: Paragraph

text: temperament or training, to think at an urban scale: in his
label: Paragraph

text: layout for the Hohenhagen garden colony, built at Hagen in
label: Caption

text: Germany for Karl Ernst Osthaus in 1906, he singularly failed
label: Paragraph

text: to demonstrate how the individual house might be
label: Paragraph

text: aggregated into larger and more significant social units. And
label: Paragraph

text: he was no more successful than William Morris in reconciling
label: Paragraph

text: the contradictions between his socialist commitments and
label: Paragraph

text: his patronage by the upper middle class.
label: Paragraph

text: 76 Van de Velde’s furniture atelier, Brussels, c. 1897. He is bending over a
label: Caption

text: drawing on the right.
label: Paragraph

text: 77 Van de Velde, desk for Meier-Graefe, 1896, and Ferdinand Hodler’s Symbolist
label: Caption

text: painting Day, c. 1896.
label: Caption

text: From the mid-1890s on, Van de Velde was profoundly
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by the aesthetic theories of the Viennese art
label: Paragraph

text: historian Alois Rieg] and the Munich psychologist Theodor
label: Title

text: Lipps. Where the one stressed the creative primacy of the
label: Paragraph

text: individual Kunstwollen or ‘will to form’, the other postulated
label: Paragraph

text: Einfahlung or ‘empathy’ as the quasi-mystical projection of
label: Paragraph

text: the creative ego into the art object. These complementary
label: Paragraph

text: ideas had already been given a more specific context in
label: Paragraph

text: Nietzsche’s essay of 1871, Die Geburt der Tragédie aus dem
label: Title

text: Geiste der Musik, wherein the Apollonian and the Dionysian
label: Title

text: were seen as the irreducible duality of Hellenic culture, the
label: Paragraph

text: former aspiring to the typical and freedom within the law
label: Title

text: and the later to superabundance and pantheistic
label: Title

text: expression. These loosely related ideas, which vaguely
label: Paragraph

text: informed Van de Velde’s work after 1896, found a certain
label: Paragraph

text: synthesis in Wilhelm Worringer’s Abstraktion und Einfuhlung
label: Paragraph

text: (Abstraction and Empathy), published in 1908. Van de Velde
label: Paragraph

text: studied Worringer’s text assiduously and found that his own
label: Paragraph

text: work seemed to combine in a single entity the two
label: Paragraph

text: antagonistic aspects of Worringer’s cultural model - on the
label: Paragraph

text: one hand the impulse towards the empathetic expression of
label: Paragraph

text: vital psychic states, and on the other the tendency towards
label: Paragraph

text: achieving transcendence through abstraction.
label: Paragraph

text: While Van de Velde strove for an empathetic and vital
label: Paragraph

text: culture of form, he was nonetheless aware of the innate
label: Paragraph

text: tendency of all architecture towards abstraction. In this
label: Paragraph

text: context, his lifelong respect for the Gothic may be regarded
label: Paragraph

text: as a nostalgia for an architecture in which the immediate
label: Paragraph

text: vitality of the form-force would come to be transcended by
label: Paragraph

text: the sublime structural abstraction of the whole. The
label: Paragraph

text: embodiment of such a force was the mainspring of his own
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic, from its initial appearance in the so-called
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Yachting Style’ suite of furniture that he designed in 1895
label: Paragraph

text: for Samuel Bing’s Maison de I|’Art Nouveau in Paris to his
label: Paragraph

text: theoretical formulation in 1902, in Weimar, of the principles
label: Paragraph

text: of what he called ‘structurally linear ornament’.
label: Paragraph

text: Van de Velde maintained a subtle distinction between
label: Paragraph

text: ornamentation and ornament, arguing that the former, by
label: Paragraph

text: virtue of being applied, was unrelated to its object, while the
label: Paragraph

text: latter, by virtue of being functionally (i.e. structurally)
label: Paragraph

text: determined, was integrated into it. This definition of
label: Paragraph

text: functional ornament was inseparable from the importance
label: Paragraph

text: that Van de Velde attached to the gestural ‘crafted’ line, as
label: Paragraph

text: the necessary anthropomorphic trace of human creation.
label: Paragraph

text: ‘The line’, he wrote in 1902, ‘carries the force and the
label: Paragraph

text: energy of that which has traced it.’ For him the ‘quasi-erotic’
label: Paragraph

text: impluses governing the course of a line were to be regarded
label: Paragraph

text: as a literature without an alphabet.
label: Paragraph

text: The powerful anti-decorative tendency of this purist view
label: Paragraph

text: of culture was reinforced in 1903 when Van de Velde
label: Paragraph

text: returned from a tour of Greece and the Middle East,
label: Paragraph

text: overwhelmed by the power and the purity of Mycenaean
label: Paragraph

text: and Assyrian form. From this point on he tried to avoid both
label: Paragraph

text: the gestural fantasy of the Secession and the rationality of
label: Paragraph

text: Classicism. He attempted to create ‘pure’ organic form, such
label: Paragraph

text: form as could be found, in his opinion, only in the cradle of
label: Paragraph

text: civilization or in the monumental cryptic gestures of
label: Paragraph

text: Neolithic man. This no doubt accounts for the telluric forms
label: Paragraph

text: of the houses that he built in Chemnitz and in Hagen
label: Paragraph

text: between 1903 and 1906. Yet despite the curious megalithic
label: Paragraph

text: quality of these works, there remained in all of Van de
label: Paragraph

text: Velde’s work after 1903 a trace of Classicism that was not
label: Paragraph

text: entirely mediated by his feeling for the archaic. This is most
label: Paragraph

text: evident in the domestic objects that he designed between
label: Paragraph

text: 1903 and 1915, pieces that seem to reflect his passionate
label: Paragraph

text: reaction to the classic, not to say ineffable, qualities that he
label: Paragraph

text: found in the Parthenon:
label: Paragraph

text: On the Acropolis the living standing columns teach us that
label: Paragraph

text: they do not exist, that they do not carry load, or rather that
label: Paragraph

text: they are interspaced according to and end very different
label: Paragraph

text: from that for which they were apparently erected. Even
label: Paragraph

text: where they are still joined by an entablature, they proclaim
label: Paragraph

text: in evidence that the columns around the Parthenon do not
label: Paragraph

text: exist, but that between them gigantic perfect vases are
label: Paragraph

text: poised, containing life, space and sun, sea and mountains,
label: Paragraph

text: night and the stars. The entasis of the columns is
label: Paragraph

text: transformed until the resultant space between one and the
label: Paragraph

text: other has attained a perfect, eternal form.?
label: Paragraph

text: Van de Velde’s Apollonian conversion, so to speak,
label: Paragraph

text: coincided with the climax of his career at Weimar. After
label: Paragraph

text: having been consultant to the craft industries of the Grand
label: Paragraph

text: Duchy of Saxe-Weimar since 1901, he was nominated in
label: Paragraph

text: 1904 to serve as the professor to the newly created Grand
label: Paragraph

text: Ducal School of Arts and Crafts. This appointment gave him
label: Paragraph

text: the commission to design new premises for both the school
label: Paragraph

text: and the existing Academy of Fine Art - the nucleus that
label: Paragraph

text: fourteen years later would become the Weimar Bauhaus.
label: Paragraph

text: Prior to the opening of these buildings in 1908, Van de Velde
label: Paragraph

text: continued to lecture in Weimar and to give his Kunstseminar
label: Paragraph

text: for the cultural instruction of trained artisans. Yet this most
label: Paragraph

text: triumphant moment of his entire career was overshadowed
label: Paragraph

text: by profound inner doubts, in which he began to question the
label: Paragraph

text: artist’s prerogative to determine the form of objects. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1905 he wrote: ‘At what point do | have this right to impose
label: Paragraph

text: on the world a taste and a wish which is so personal.
label: Paragraph

text: Suddenly | no longer see the ties between my ideal and the
label: Paragraph

text: world.’
label: Paragraph

text: After Gottfried Semper and Peter Behrens, Van de Velde
label: Paragraph

text: had always sought to strengthen such socio-cultural ties
label: Paragraph

text: through the agency of the theatre, conceiving its union of
label: Paragraph

text: actors and spectators as the highest form of social and
label: Paragraph

text: spiritual life. Directly influenced by scenographers such as
label: Paragraph

text: Max Reinhardt and Gordon Craig, he devoted himself to the
label: Paragraph

text: development of the tripartite stage, first formulated in a
label: Paragraph

text: project for the Dumont Theatre in Weimar in 1904. He
label: Paragraph

text: returned to this theme in 1911 in his compromise design for
label: Paragraph

text: the Théatre des Champs-Elysées, Paris (realized by Auguste
label: Caption

text: Perret in a modified form in 1913), and again in his Cologne
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund Exhibition Theatre of 1914 [78]. The highly
label: Paragraph

text: expressive but short-lived Werkbund Theatre was the
label: Paragraph

text: apotheosis of all his pre-war work. Erich Mendelsohn wrote
label: Paragraph

text: of it: ‘Only Van de Velde, with his theatre, is really searching
label: Paragraph

text: for new form. Concrete used in the Art Nouveau style, but
label: Paragraph

text: strong in conception and expression.’ Its surging masses
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated Van de Velde’s masterly control over form in
label: Paragraph

text: a manner that later served as a model for the profiling of
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn’s Einstein Tower, built at Potsdam in 1919.
label: Caption

text: 78 Van de Velde, Werkbund Exhibition Theatre, Cologne, 1914.
label: Caption

text: The much admired Werkbund Theatre was to be the last
label: Paragraph

text: formulation of Van de Velde’s ‘form-force’ aesthetic. Fusing
label: Paragraph

text: actor with audience and auditorium with landscape, as in
label: Paragraph

text: the open-air arenas of Neolithic man, it appeared as a
label: Paragraph

text: unique empathetic expression. Such expression could of
label: Paragraph

text: course find no place in the modest modular prefabricated
label: Paragraph

text: house that Van de Velde built for himself after the First
label: Paragraph

text: World War. The Werkbund dream of a world transformed by
label: Paragraph

text: gute Form and industrial monopoly had proven just as vain
label: Paragraph

text: as the reformist hopes of the socially conscious bourgeoisie
label: Paragraph

text: whose fifty-year-old patronage of the Arts and Crafts and Art
label: Paragraph

text: Nouveau had been brought to an abrupt end by the first
label: Paragraph

text: industrialized war. One could no longer fantasize about a
label: Paragraph

text: society transformed through art, industrial design and the
label: Paragraph

text: theatre, at a time when the provision of minimum shelter
label: Paragraph

text: was a matter of the greatest urgency.
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Tony Garnier and the
label: Title

text: Industrial City 1899-1918
label: Title

text: The city is imaginary: let us assume that the towns of Rive-
label: Paragraph

text: de-Gier, St-Etienne, St-Chaumond, Chasse and Givors have
label: Paragraph

text: conditions similar to those of this town. The site of this
label: Paragraph

text: study is located in a region of southeast France, and
label: Paragraph

text: regional materials have been used in its construction.
label: Paragraph

text: Determining factors in the establishment of a similar city
label: Paragraph

text: should be the proximity of raw materials, or the existence of
label: Paragraph

text: a natural force capable of being used for energy, or the
label: Paragraph

text: convenience of methods of transportation. In our case the
label: Paragraph

text: determining factor in the location of the city is the force of
label: Paragraph

text: the tributary river that is the power source; there are also
label: Paragraph

text: mines in the region, but they could be located further away.
label: Paragraph

text: The tributary is dammed, a hydroelectric plant
label: Paragraph

text: distributes power, light, and heat to the factories and to the
label: Paragraph

text: entire city. The principal factories are situated in the plain at
label: Paragraph

text: the confluence of the river and its tributary. A mainline
label: Paragraph

text: railroad passes between the factories and the town, which is
label: Paragraph

text: located above the factories on a plateau. Higher still are
label: Paragraph

text: placed the hospitals; they, as well as the city, are sheltered
label: Paragraph

text: from cold winds, and have their terraces oriented to the
label: Paragraph

text: south. Each of these main elements (factories, town,
label: Paragraph

text: hospitals) is isolated so that it can expand. ...
label: Paragraph

text: Investigation of the most satisfactory programme for the
label: Paragraph

text: material and moral needs of the individual has resulted in
label: Paragraph

text: the creation of rules concerning road use, hygiene, and so
label: Paragraph

text: on; the assumption is that a certain progress of social order
label: Paragraph

text: resulting in an automatic adoption of these rules already
label: Paragraph

text: has been realized, so that it will not be necessary to enact
label: Paragraph

text: the actual laws. Distribution of land, everything related to
label: Paragraph

text: supplies, as well as the re-utilization of refuse, will be given

text: Tony Garnier
label: Title

text: Preface to Une Cité industrielle, 19171
label: Caption

text: It would be hard to imagine a more concise statement of the
label: Paragraph

text: basic economic and technical precepts for the foundation
label: Title

text: and organization of a modern city. The very lucidity of this
label: Paragraph

text: outline - the sole theoretical statement of Garnier’s career -
label: Paragraph

text: reflects in its tone and content the fundamentally radical
label: Paragraph

text: nature of his life and work. Born in Lyons in 1869 and raised
label: Paragraph

text: in a radical workers’ quarter, he remained consistently
label: Paragraph

text: committed to the socialist cause up to his death in 1948.
label: Paragraph

text: Garnier’s education and the commitment of his
label: Paragraph

text: professional career are both inseparable from the city of
label: Paragraph

text: Lyons. The radical syndicalism and socialism that Lyons
label: Title

text: nurtured stemmed from the fact that it was one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: progressive industrial centres in 19th-century France, with
label: Paragraph

text: its silk and metallurgical industries well established by the
label: Paragraph

text: time of Garnier’s birth. In addition to its favourable location
label: Paragraph

text: in the Rhéne-Sa6ne corridor, the growth of Lyons had been
label: Paragraph

text: stimulated soon after mid-century by one of the first main
label: Paragraph

text: railway links in France. By the 1880s, with the electrification
label: Paragraph

text: of its trams and local railway systems, it was well placed to
label: Paragraph

text: become a main centre for technical and industrial
label: Paragraph

text: innovation. Photography, cinematography, hydroelectric
label: Paragraph

text: generation, automobile production and aviation all saw their
label: Paragraph

text: first beginnings there between 1882 and the turn of the
label: Paragraph

text: century. The influence of this technical milieu certainly
label: Paragraph

text: found its reflection in Garnier’s project for a ‘Cité
label: Paragraph

text: Industrielle’, first exhibited in 1904, a project which
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated his belief that the cities of the future would
label: Paragraph

text: have to be based on industry.
label: Paragraph

text: Other aspects of Lyons culture were also featured in the
label: Paragraph

text: plans of Garnier’s Cité, most notably the French regionalist
label: Paragraph

text: movement in favour of reviving local culture, which was as a
label: Paragraph

text: result committed to the broader political policies of
label: Paragraph

text: federalism and decentralization. Thus Garnier included an
label: Paragraph

text: old medieval town within the confines of his industrial city.
label: Paragraph

text: The importance that he attached to such foundations is
label: Paragraph

text: reflected in his location of the main railway station in close
label: Paragraph

text: proximity to this regional centre.
label: Paragraph

text: The municipality of Lyons was also important, even in
label: Paragraph

text: Garnier’s youth, for its progressive approach to
label: Paragraph

text: urbanization. Its streets had been regularized between 1853
label: Paragraph

text: and 1864; after 1880 - as part of a slum clearance
label: Paragraph

text: programme - the city began to improve its water and
label: Paragraph

text: sanitation systems; and about 1883 it began to provide a
label: Paragraph

text: range of welfare facilities, such as schools, workers’
label: Paragraph

text: housing, baths, hospitals and abattoirs.
label: Paragraph

text: Entering the Ecole des Beaux-Arts, first at Lyons in 1886
label: Paragraph

text: and then at Paris in 1889, Garnier came under the influence
label: Paragraph

text: of Julien Guadet who, as Professor of Theory after 1894,
label: Paragraph

text: taught not only the precepts of Rational Classicism but also
label: Paragraph

text: programmatic analysis and the classification of building
label: Title

text: types. Guadet’s E/éments et théories de I’architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: 1902 was a programmatic updating of Durand’s methods of
label: Paragraph

text: 1805 for the rational combination of typified architectural
label: Caption

text: forms, and it was this common elemental approach to
label: Paragraph

text: design that was to inform the careers of Guadet’s foremost
label: Paragraph

text: pupils, Garnier and Auguste Perret. These two men,
label: Paragraph

text: however, were to have very different careers, for while
label: Paragraph

text: Garnier, after ten years in Paris, won the Prix de Rome in
label: Paragraph

text: 1899 and spent another four years at the French Academy
label: Paragraph

text: in the Villa Medici, Perret left the Beaux-Arts in 1897 after
label: Paragraph

text: only three years of formal education to work for his father.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus when the Cité Industrielle was first exhibited, in 1904,
label: Paragraph

text: Perret had already made his mark as an architect and a
label: Paragraph

text: builder with his pioneer reinforced-concrete-frame
label: Paragraph

text: apartment building in the Rue Franklin.
label: Caption

text: From the time when Garnier was first a /ogiste for the Prix
label: Paragraph

text: de Rome in 1892, he had been immersed in the increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: radical climate of Paris, presided over by the figure of Jean
label: Paragraph

text: Jaurés, who became a socialist deputy in 1893. The Parisian
label: Paragraph

text: political scene was galvanized after 1897 by the Dreyfus
label: Paragraph

text: affair, an event which converted Emile Zola into a
label: Paragraph

text: passionate advocate of radical reform. Out of this came
label: Paragraph

text: Zola’s first utopian socialist novel, Fécondité, which was
label: Paragraph

text: serialized in 1899 in the socialist journal L’Aurore. Given
label: Paragraph

text: Garnier’s long-standing affiliation with the Société des Amis
label: Paragraph

text: d’Emile Zola, it is certain that he would have read these
label: Paragraph

text: excerpts. In any event, the early sketches for the industrial
label: Paragraph

text: city that he made in the same year seem to reflect Zola’s
label: Paragraph

text: vision of a new socio-economic order, which the writer was
label: Paragraph

text: to elaborate in his second utopian socialist novel, Travail
label: Paragraph

text: Against great opposition at the Villa Medici, Garnier
label: Paragraph

text: continued to work on his city project throughout his stay. For
label: Paragraph

text: the required ‘testimony of academic study’ he prepared an
label: Paragraph

text: imaginative and equally unprecedented reconstruction of
label: Paragraph

text: the Roman hill city of Tusculum. Tusculum and the first
label: Paragraph

text: version of the Cité Industrielle were jointly exhibited in Paris
label: Paragraph

text: in 1904, the year when Garnier returned in triumph to
label: Paragraph

text: Lyons. Over the next thirty-five years he was to work
label: Paragraph

text: exclusively in and for this city, largely at the command of
label: Paragraph

text: the progressive mayor, Edouard Herriot, and it was in Lyons,
label: Paragraph

text: at the beginning of his public career, that Le Corbusier first
label: Paragraph

text: met him in 1908.
label: Paragraph

text: Set on a river escarpment, in a mountainous landscape
label: Paragraph

text: that corresponded generally to that of the Lyons region,
label: Paragraph

text: Garnier’s industrial city of 35,000 inhabitants was not only a
label: Paragraph

text: regional centre of medium size, sensitively related to its
label: Paragraph

text: environment, but also an urban organization that
label: Paragraph

text: anticipated in its separate zoning the principles of the CIAM
label: Paragraph

text: Athens Charter of 1933 [79]. It was above all a socialist city,
label: Paragraph

text: without walls or private property, without church or
label: Paragraph

text: barracks, without police station or law courts, a city where
label: Paragraph

text: all the unbuilt surface was public parkland. Within the built
label: Paragraph

text: area Garnier eventually established a varied and
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensive housing typology, in accordance with strict
label: Paragraph

text: standards for the provision of light, ventilation and green
label: Paragraph

text: Space. These codes and the combinational patterns they
label: Paragraph

text: generated were inflected by a hierarchy of tree-lined streets
label: Paragraph

text: of varying widths. At an average height of only two storeys,
label: Paragraph

text: such an open layout yielded a low density, and Garnier
label: Paragraph

text: supplemented a 1932 edition of his scheme with residential
label: Paragraph

text: sectors at a higher density. Integral to the residential
label: Paragraph

text: quarters were different categories of schools, sited to serve
label: Paragraph

text: specific districts, while facilities for technical and
label: Paragraph

text: professional education were located between the residential
label: Paragraph

text: and industrial sectors.
label: Paragraph

text: 79 Garnier, Cité Industrielle: schematic plan, 1904-17. Below the hospitals is the
label: Caption

text: administrative/cultural centre, flanked by housing.
label: Paragraph

text: It has recently been shown that Garnier did not arrive at
label: Paragraph

text: the concept of his city in isolation, and that among the
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable young pensionnaires who were his colleagues at
label: Paragraph

text: the French Academy in Rome must be counted Léon
label: Paragraph

text: Jaussely, whose Prix de Rome entry of 1903, ‘A Metropolitan
label: Paragraph

text: Square in a Large Democratic State’, resembled in many
label: Paragraph

text: respects the layout, content and ethos of the cultural and
label: Paragraph

text: administrative centre of Garnier’s Cité [80], which was
label: Paragraph

text: rendered as a ‘space of public appearance’ where a
label: Paragraph

text: museum, a library, a theatre, a stadium and a vast public
label: Paragraph

text: indoor swimming pool or hydrothérapie building are grouped
label: Paragraph

text: around the axis of an assembly complex [81]. The prime
label: Paragraph

text: organizing principle of this last, lozenge-shaped structure is
label: Paragraph

text: a peristyle of reinforced-concrete columns which enclose a
label: Paragraph

text: cluster of union meeting rooms and a central circular 3,000-
label: Caption

text: seat assembly hall, flanked on one side by an auditorium
label: Caption

text: seating 1,000 and on the other by two 500-seat
label: Paragraph

text: amphitheatres set side by side. Ostensibly dedicated to
label: Caption

text: different democratic purposes, from parliamentary debate
label: Paragraph

text: to conferences, committee work and cinematic display, the
label: Paragraph

text: various kinds of assembly would have taken place here
label: Paragraph

text: beneath the rationalistic image of a twenty-four-hour clock
label: Paragraph

text: and an entablature which bore Courbet-like reliefs and was
label: Paragraph

text: inscribed with two quotations from Zola’s Travail. The first of
label: Paragraph

text: these texts alluded to the Saint-Simonian programme for
label: Paragraph

text: achieving international harmony through industrial
label: Title

text: production and communication, and the second to the
label: Paragraph

text: ritualistic celebration of a utopian socialist harvest:
label: Title

text: 80 Garnier, Cité Industrielle: the centre (with lozenge-shaped assembly building)
label: Caption

text: and housing, 1917.
label: Caption

text: 81 Garnier, Cité Industrielle: detail of assembly building, 1904-17.
label: Caption

text: This was the incessant production suitable for epochs of
label: Paragraph

text: peace, rails and yet more rails, so that all frontiers might be
label: Paragraph

text: passed over, and so that all peoples, reunited, might form a
label: Paragraph

text: single people, on an earth entirely furrowed by routes.
label: Paragraph

text: These were the great steel ships, no longer the abominable
label: Paragraph

text: ships of war carrying devastation and death, but ships of
label: Paragraph

text: solidarity and fraternity, exchanging the products of
label: Paragraph

text: continents, increasing the domestic riches of humanity ten-
label: Paragraph

text: fold, to that point when tremendous abundance reigned
label: Paragraph

text: throughout.
label: Paragraph

text: It was resolved that the feast would take place in the
label: Paragraph

text: open air, near to the town, in a vast field, where the high
label: Paragraph

text: corn sheaves stood, like the symmetrical columns of a giant
label: Paragraph

text: temple, the colour of gold under the clear sun. The
label: Paragraph

text: colonnade stretched to infinity, to the far horizon, sheaves
label: Paragraph

text: and yet more sheaves, telling of the inexhaustible fertility of
label: Paragraph

text: the earth. And there it was that they sang and danced, with
label: Paragraph

text: the good smell of the ripe corn, in the middle of the
label: Paragraph

text: immense fertile plain, from which the labour of men,
label: Paragraph

text: reconciled at last, obtained enough bread for the happiness
label: Paragraph

text: of all.2
label: Paragraph

text: This last passage directly evoked that Classical arcadian
label: Paragraph

text: life and landscape that Garnier had first fully understood
label: Paragraph

text: after his visit to Greece in 1903. Like the agora, of which it
label: Paragraph

text: was intended to be the modern counterpart, Garnier’s
label: Paragraph

text: assembly building was depicted as being populated by
label: Paragraph

text: shadowy figures whose latter-day Biedermeier clothing
label: Paragraph

text: evoked an appropriately Classical atmosphere. Their houses
label: Paragraph

text: were to be equally plain, without cornices and mouldings
label: Paragraph

text: and in many instances planned around courtyards and
label: Paragraph

text: drained by impluvia. In short, despite its use of advanced
label: Paragraph

text: constructional methods, its adoption of reinforced-concrete
label: Paragraph

text: construction throughout (Hennebique) and its use of large
label: Paragraph

text: steel spans in the industrial sector, after Contamin’s Galerie
label: Paragraph

text: des Machines of 1889, the Cité Industrielle remained above
label: Paragraph

text: all else the vision of a Mediterranean socialist arcadia.
label: Paragraph

text: For all that Garnier in Rome had been influenced by other
label: Paragraph

text: important French urbanists, such as Léon Jaussely and
label: Paragraph

text: Eugéne Hénard, whose first articles on urban transformation
label: Paragraph

text: appeared in 1903, the unique contribution of his city lay as
label: Paragraph

text: much in the extraordinary level of detail to which it was
label: Paragraph

text: developed as in the ‘modernity’ of its vision. Garnier’s
label: Paragraph

text: project not only stipulated the principles and the layout for a
label: Paragraph

text: hypothetical industrial city; it also delineated, at many
label: Paragraph

text: different scales, the specific substance of its urban typology,
label: Paragraph

text: while giving at the same time precise indications as to the
label: Paragraph

text: mode of its construction in concrete and steel. Nothing as
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensive as this had been attempted since Claude-
label: Paragraph

text: Nicolas Ledoux’s ideal city of Chaux of 1804. While Une Cité
label: Paragraph

text: industrielle was not published until 1917, its author’s
label: Paragraph

text: contribution to contemporary urbanism was already being
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledged by 1920, when Le Corbusier published
label: Paragraph

text: material from the Cité folio in the Purist review L’Esprit
label: Caption

text: Nouveau.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the obvious impact of the Cité on the urbanistic
label: Paragraph

text: thought of Le Corbusier, its overall influence was limited
label: Paragraph

text: since, aside from Garnier’s isolated works in Lyons, its basic
label: Paragraph

text: propositions were never tested or extensively published.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike Ebenezer Howard's garden city model of 1898, which
label: Paragraph

text: was realized as a developmental strategy at Letchworth
label: Paragraph

text: Garden City in 1903, it could hardly be referred to as a
label: Paragraph

text: proven model. These two alternatives could not in fact have
label: Paragraph

text: been more opposed, for where Garnier’s Cité was inherently
label: Paragraph

text: expandable and graced with a certain autonomy due to its
label: Paragraph

text: base in heavy industry, Howard’s Rurisville was limited in
label: Paragraph

text: size and economically dependent, with its base in light
label: Paragraph

text: industry and small-scale agriculture. And where Garnier’s
label: Paragraph

text: Cité, in conjunction with Jaussely’s Barcelona project of
label: Paragraph

text: 1904, was to influence the theoretical planning models
label: Paragraph

text: developed during the first decade of the Soviet Union,
label: Paragraph

text: Howard's schema was to lead to the reformist proliferation
label: Paragraph

text: of ‘garden city’ communities and eventually to the equally
label: Paragraph

text: pragmatic New Town programme that emerged in England
label: Title

text: after the Second World War.
label: Paragraph

text: Garnier’s urbanistic thought was expressed in his Grands
label: Paragraph

text: travaux de la ville de Lyons of 1920, his abattoirs of 1906-
label: Paragraph

text: 32 [82], his Grande Blanche hospital of 1909-30 and his
label: Caption

text: Etats-Unis quarter, designed in 1924 and built by 1935.
label: Paragraph

text: Each of these complexes amounted to a city in miniature
label: Paragraph

text: that reasserted through its amenities the sovereignty of the
label: Paragraph

text: city as a civilizing force - a mission for which the Anglo-
label: Paragraph

text: Saxon garden city had little capacity.
label: Paragraph

text: 82 Garnier, abattoir, La Mouche, Lyons, 1917.

text: Auguste Perret
label: Title

text: Contribution 4 une théorie de Il’architecture, Paris, 19521
label: Caption

text: In 1897, after abruptly terminating a brilliant career at the
label: Paragraph

text: Ecole des Beaux-Arts, Auguste Perret left the academic
label: Paragraph

text: guidance of his master Julien Guadet to work for his father.
label: Paragraph

text: This move consolidated his previous part-time involvement
label: Paragraph

text: in the family contracting firm. Of his works from this period,
label: Paragraph

text: starting as early as 1890, those designed after Perret left
label: Paragraph

text: the Beaux-Arts are the most interesting; since they set the
label: Paragraph

text: stage for the rest of his career. Of these, two are of
label: Paragraph

text: considerable significance: a casino at St Malo, of 1899 [83],
label: Paragraph

text: and an apartment building in the Avenue Wagram, Paris, of
label: Paragraph

text: 1902. Where the one was a Structural Rationalist essay in
label: Paragraph

text: the ‘national-romantic’ style then being popularized in the
label: Paragraph

text: rustic villas of Hector Guimard, the other was an eight-
label: Paragraph

text: storey Louis-Quinze-cum-Art-Nouveau essay in dressed
label: Paragraph

text: stone. Of the two, the latter has to be regarded as Perret’s
label: Paragraph

text: essential point of departure, since it demonstrated his
label: Paragraph

text: conscious return to the Classical tradition, a return that
label: Paragraph

text: even anticipated, by a few years, the 1907 ‘crystallization’
label: Paragraph

text: of the Secession Style in the work of such men as Behrens,
label: Paragraph

text: Hoffmann and Olbrich.
label: Paragraph

text: 83 Perret, Casino, St Malo, 1899.
label: Caption

text: The Avenue Wagram building projected by a bay-window
label: Caption

text: depth over the pavement as it ascended to its colonnaded
label: Paragraph

text: sixth floor. This swelling stone profile was subtly
label: Paragraph

text: complemented by a carved vine ornament which rose
label: Paragraph

text: sinuously from the threshold to blossom forth in petrified
label: Paragraph

text: abundance under the plinth of the sixth-floor colonnade.
label: Caption

text: Attached to Symbolism, Perret had designed the masonry of
label: Paragraph

text: this structure so as to evoke the floral imagery of the Belle
label: Paragraph

text: Epoque. At the same time, not wishing to violate the
label: Paragraph

text: ordonnance of a Parisian street, he took care to align its
label: Paragraph

text: moulded openings with those of the Classical fagades on
label: Paragraph

text: either side. All this, however, contradicted the Structural
label: Paragraph

text: Rationalist canon, for it was patently not the architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: articulate structure such as had been advocated by Viollet-
label: Paragraph

text: le-Duc. Nor was it the naturally expressive and vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: use of structure which Perret had displayed in the Casino at
label: Paragraph

text: St Malo.
label: Paragraph

text: Two books seem to have been influential in bringing
label: Paragraph

text: Perret to adopt a trabeated concrete structure for his
label: Paragraph

text: apartment block in the Rue Franklin of 1903: Auguste
label: Caption

text: Choisy’s monumental Histoire de I’architecture (1899) and
label: Paragraph

text: Paul Christophe’s text on the Hennebique system, Le Béton
label: Caption

text: armé et ses applications (1902). Where the first cited Greek
label: Paragraph

text: trabeation as the Classical precedent for such structures,
label: Paragraph

text: the second provided a definitive technique for the
label: Paragraph

text: fabrication and design of a reinforced-concrete frame.
label: Paragraph

text: Choisy, Professor of Architecture at the Ecole des Ponts
label: Paragraph

text: et Chaussées, cultivated a deterministic view of history in
label: Paragraph

text: which he argued that the various styles had arisen not as
label: Paragraph

text: the sports of fashion but as the logical consequence of
label: Paragraph

text: developments in building technique. His preferred examples
label: Paragraph

text: of such technically determined styles were (after Viollet-le-
label: Paragraph

text: Duc) the Greek and the Gothic, although it was, of course,
label: Paragraph

text: his reference to the former that made him the last
label: Paragraph

text: influential theorist of Classical Rationalism. Choisy
label: Caption

text: succeeded a long line of such Rationalists, dating back like
label: Paragraph

text: Guadet and Labrouste to the 18th-century theorists
label: Paragraph

text: Cordemoy and Laugier. Like most proponents of this school,
label: Paragraph

text: Choisy saw nothing irrational in the Greek transposition of
label: Paragraph

text: timber forms into the masonry components of the Doric
label: Paragraph

text: order.
label: Paragraph

text: Perret’s initial use of ferroconcrete accorded more closely
label: Paragraph

text: with Choisy’s characterization of the Gothic as an
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of ribwork and infill. In compositional terms, the
label: Paragraph

text: Rue Franklin block compressed the format adopted one year
label: Paragraph

text: earlier in the Avenue Wagram. In each case street facades,
label: Paragraph

text: divided into five bays, with end bays corbelling out over the
label: Paragraph

text: pavement, rise five or six storeys in height and terminate in
label: Paragraph

text: an additional ‘capping’ floor, before setting back. This floor
label: Paragraph

text: in the Avenue Wagram is emphasized through an attached
label: Paragraph

text: colonnade, while in the Rue Franklin its elemental character
label: Paragraph

text: is stressed by the frame of two open loggias. There,
label: Paragraph

text: however, all correspondence ends, for whereas the Wagram
label: Paragraph

text: building is monolithic and horizontally expansive, the Rue
label: Paragraph

text: Franklin block is articulated and vertically attenuated [84].
label: Paragraph

text: The articulation of its columns and the rise of its high
label: Paragraph

text: pitched set-back roof give something of a Gothic feeling to
label: Paragraph

text: this otherwise orthogonal structure, recalling the 17th-
label: Paragraph

text: century work of Mansart. This was the closest that Perret
label: Paragraph

text: was to come to the detailed prescription of Viollet-le-Duc.
label: Paragraph

text: The reason for its hollow U-form front, so suggestive of the
label: Paragraph

text: attentuations of the Gothic, was in fact eminently
label: Paragraph

text: pragmatic: Perret could get more floor area by providing the
label: Paragraph

text: regulation court at the front, rather than the rear. With equal
label: Paragraph

text: ingenuity, he clad the rear wall of the building with glass
label: Paragraph

text: lenses in order not to infringe an easement.
label: Paragraph

text: 84 Perret, 25 bis Rue Franklin, Paris, 1903.
label: Caption

text: After 1903 Perret, like Choisy, regarded the charpente or
label: Paragraph

text: structural frame as the quintessential expression of built
label: Paragraph

text: form. The ferroconcrete frame of the Rue Franklin block was
label: Paragraph

text: tiled in such a way as to suggest post-and-lintel construction
label: Paragraph

text: in wood - the remainder being either windows or solid
label: Paragraph

text: panels faced in ceramic mosaic. While the tessellated
label: Paragraph

text: sunflowers of the latter gave the building that quality of
label: Paragraph

text: fossilized Art Nouveau so peculiar to the end of the Belle
label: Paragraph

text: Epoque, the frame itself, and the open planning it
label: Paragraph

text: permitted, pointed towards Le Corbusier's later
label: Paragraph

text: development of the free plan.
label: Paragraph

text: brother Gustave, played an essential role in the

text: development of Perret’s style. In 1905 they erected a

text: Rue de Ponthieu. This was followed in 1912 by a house

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: of 1925 [86]. Whereas the art gallery, like the Le Raincy
label: Paragraph

text: With the Prussian suppression of the Saxon Revolt in 1849 -
label: Paragraph

text: a revolt in which both Mikhail Bakunin and Richard Wagner
label: Paragraph

text: played prominent roles - Gottfried Semper, architect and
label: Paragraph

text: liberal revolutionary, fled from Dresden, first to Paris, and
label: Paragraph

text: then two years later, as the result of a special commission,
label: Paragraph

text: to London. There, on the occasion of the 1851 Exhibition, he
label: Paragraph

text: wrote his famous essay Wissenschaft, Industrie und Kunst
label: Paragraph

text: (Science, Industry and Art), published in German in 1852,
label: Paragraph

text: where he examined the impact of industrialization and mass
label: Paragraph

text: consumption on the entire field of applied art and
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. A decade before William Morris and his
label: Paragraph

text: associates produced their first domestic objects, Semper
label: Paragraph

text: crystallized his critique of industrial civilization: ‘We have
label: Paragraph

text: artists but no actual art.’ In tough-minded opposition to the
label: Paragraph

text: Pre-Raphaelite dream of returning to a pre-industrial era,
label: Paragraph

text: Semper took the view that
label: Paragraph

text: Unremittingly science enriches itself and life with newly
label: Paragraph

text: discovered useful materials and natural powers that work
label: Paragraph

text: miracles, with new methods and techniques, with new tools
label: Paragraph

text: and machines. It is already evident that inventions no longer
label: Paragraph

text: are, as they had been in earlier times, means for warding off
label: Paragraph

text: want and for helping consumption; instead, want and
label: Paragraph

text: consumption are the means to market the inventions. The
label: Paragraph

text: order of things has been reversed.”
label: Paragraph

text: Later in the same text, he analyzed the impact on design
label: Paragraph

text: of new methods and materials:
label: Title

text: The hardest porphyry and granite are cut like chalk and
label: Paragraph

text: polished like wax. Ivory is softened and pressed into forms.
label: Paragraph

text: Rubber and gutta-percha are vulcanized and utilized in a
label: Paragraph

text: thousand imitations of wood, metal and stone carvings,
label: Paragraph

text: exceeding by far the natural limitations of the material they
label: Paragraph

text: purport to represent. ... The abundance of means is the first
label: Paragraph

text: great danger with which art has to struggle. This expression
label: Paragraph

text: is illogical, | admit (there is no abundance of means but only
label: Paragraph

text: inability to master them); however, it is justified in that it
label: Paragraph

text: correctly describes the inverted state of our conditions.>
label: Paragraph

text: He then went on to ask:
label: Paragraph

text: Where will the depreciation of material that results from its
label: Paragraph

text: treatment by machines, from substitutes for it from so many
label: Paragraph

text: new inventions, lead? And where the depreciation of labour,
label: Paragraph

text: of paintings, of fine art and furnishings, which originates
label: Paragraph

text: from the same causes ... How will time or science bring law
label: Paragraph

text: and order into this until now thoroughly confused state of
label: Paragraph

text: affairs? How will it prevent the general devaluation from
label: Paragraph

text: expanding into the area of work which is executed by hand
label: Paragraph

text: in the true old fashion, so that one may find in it more than
label: Paragraph

text: affection, antiquarianism, superficial appearance and
label: Paragraph

text: obstinacy?
label: Title

text: In this militant and incisive manner Semper raised the
label: Paragraph

text: prime issues of the century, and touched on a range of
label: Paragraph

text: cultural problems which even today are far from resolved.
label: Paragraph

text: His ideas gradually became integrated into 19th-century
label: Paragraph

text: German cultural theory, largely through the publication of
label: Paragraph

text: his major theoretical text, Der Stil in den technischen und
label: Paragraph

text: tektonischen Ktinsten oder praktische Asthetik (‘Style in
label: Paragraph

text: industrial and structural arts or practical aesthetics’) of
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: expansion that occurred in Germany during the last quarter
label: Paragraph

text: of the century. At the Philadelphia Centennial Exhibition of
label: Caption

text: 1876 German industrial and applied art products were
label: Title

text: regarded as inferior to those from England and America.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: been Semper’s colleague for ten years at the
label: Paragraph

text: Eidgendssische Technische Hochschule in Zurich, wrote from
label: Paragraph

text: Philadelphia in 1877 that German products were ‘cheap and
label: Paragraph

text: nasty’. ‘German industry must relinquish the principles of
label: Paragraph

text: competition in price alone’ and instead use ‘the intellectual
label: Paragraph

text: power and the skill of the worker to refine the product and
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: For twenty years after the unification of Germany in
label: Paragraph

text: 1870, German industry had neither the time nor the cause
label: Paragraph

text: to heed such criticism. Under Bismarck’s stable leadership it
label: Paragraph

text: was concerned solely with the task of development and
label: Paragraph

text: expansion. A crucial factor in this development was the
label: Paragraph

text: founding by Emil Rathenau in 1883 of the Allgemeine
label: Paragraph

text: Elektricitats Gesellschaft (AEG) in Berlin. This electrical
label: Paragraph

text: company grew, in the space of seven years, into a vast
label: Paragraph

text: industrial combine, with a wide range of products and
label: Paragraph

text: interests extending all over the world.
label: Paragraph

text: After the resignation of Bismarck in 1890, a great change
label: Paragraph

text: occurred in the cultural climate of Germany. Numerous
label: Paragraph

text: critics held that improved design in both craft and industry
label: Paragraph

text: was essential to future prosperity, and that Germany,
label: Paragraph

text: without a cheap source of materials or a ready outlet for
label: Paragraph

text: inexpensive goods, could only begin to compete for a share
label: Paragraph

text: of the world market with products of exceptionally high
label: Paragraph

text: quality. This argument was enlarged upon by the nationalist
label: Paragraph

text: and Christian-Social Democract Friedrich Naumann in his
label: Paragraph

text: 1904 essay Die Kunst im Maschinenzeitalter (‘Art in the
label: Caption

text: Epoch of the Machine’). There he argued, in opposition to
label: Paragraph

text: William Morris’s Luddism, that such quality could only be
label: Paragraph

text: economically achieved by an artistically cultivated people,
label: Paragraph

text: orientated towards machine production.
label: Paragraph

text: This spur of industrialism and pan-German nationalism
label: Title

text: made the Prussian bureaucracy react against the
label: Paragraph

text: Philistinism of Wilhelmine Germany and encourage the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: culture. To this end, in 1896, Hermann Muthesius was sent
label: Paragraph

text: to London as an attaché to the German Embassy, with a
label: Paragraph

text: charge to study English architecture and design. He
label: Paragraph

text: returned to Germany in 1904 and took up the post of privy
label: Paragraph

text: councillor to the Prussian Board of Trade, with a special
label: Paragraph

text: assignment to reform the national programme of education
label: Title

text: in applied art. This official Kunstgewerbeschule (school of
label: Paragraph

text: arts and crafts) reform movement had been anticipated by
label: Paragraph

text: Karl Schmidt’s foundation in 1898 of the Dresdner
label: Paragraph

text: Werkstatten fur Handwerkskunst (Dresden Workshop for
label: Paragraph

text: Manual Art) at Dresden. In 1903 the whole movement had
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Behrens as principal of the Dusseldorf Kunstgewerbeschule.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

text: The subsequent development of the Werkbund,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly in its relationship to industry, is inseparable
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: whom he was to evolve a house style ranging from graphics
label: Paragraph

text: to product design and industrial plant [87]. He brought to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: period at the Darmstadt colony in 1899-1903. His
label: Paragraph

text: Darmstadt style was to be transformed under the influence
label: Paragraph

text: of the Beuronic monastic school of geometrical proportion,
label: Paragraph

text: as then practised by the Dutch architect J.L.M. Lauweriks,
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Behrens’s ‘empathetic’ manner, his so-called
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Zarathustrastil’, was epitomized in his Vorhalle for the Turin
label: Paragraph

text: International Exhibition of 1902. Here energetic sinuous line
label: Paragraph

text: and expressive arcuated form were combined in an attempt
label: Paragraph

text: to evoke the Nietzschean ‘will to form’. This rhetoric gave
label: Paragraph

text: way, under the influence of Lauweriks, to an airless
label: Paragraph

text: atectonic style, first manifest in the pavilions that Behrens
label: Paragraph

text: built at Oldenburg in 1905. This Neo-Quattrocento-Beuronic
label: Paragraph

text: manner was elaborated by Behrens in his design for a
label: Paragraph

text: crematorium built at Hagen in 1906 and adapted, with Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Classical overtones, to the pavilion he designed for AEG at
label: Paragraph

text: the Berlin shipbuilding exhibition of 1908.
label: Paragraph

text: On joining AEG, Behrens was confronted with the brute
label: Paragraph

text: fact of industrial power. In exchange for his youthful visions
label: Paragraph

text: of revitalizing German cultural life through an elaborately
label: Paragraph

text: staged mystic ritual, he had to accept industrialization as
label: Paragraph

text: the manifest destiny of the German nation, or, as he
label: Paragraph

text: conceived of it, as the composite issue of Zeitgeist and
label: Paragraph

text: Volksgeist, to which it was his duty as an artist to give form.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus the Turbine Factory that he built for AEG in 1909 was a
label: Paragraph

text: deliberate reification of industry as the one vital rhythm of
label: Paragraph

text: modern life [88, 89]. Far from being a straightforward
label: Paragraph

text: design in iron and glass (such as the 19th-century railway
label: Paragraph

text: shed), Behrens’s Turbine Factory was a conscious work of
label: Paragraph

text: art, a temple to industrial power. While accepting the
label: Paragraph

text: ascendancy of science and industry with pessimistic
label: Title

text: resignation, Behrens sought to bring the factory under the
label: Paragraph

text: rubric of the farm - to restore to factory production that
label: Paragraph

text: sense of common purpose innate in agriculture, a feeling for
label: Paragraph

text: which the newly urbanized semi-skilled labour of Berlin
label: Paragraph

text: would supposedly still have a certain nostalgia. How else
label: Paragraph

text: should one account for the faceted gable roof of the Turbine
label: Paragraph

text: Hall or for the Sittesque farmyard layout of the AEG
label: Caption

text: Brunnenstrasse complex of 1910? On joining AEG, Behrens
label: Paragraph

text: had modified his Oldenburg manner, retaining its formal
label: Paragraph

text: strength but dispensing with its rigid geometry. Thus the
label: Paragraph

text: light steel frame of the street facade of the Turbine Factory
label: Caption

text: is terminated at the ends by solid battered corner elements
label: Paragraph

text: whose surfaces are rendered in such a way as to deny any
label: Paragraph

text: capacity for sustaining load. This atectonic formula of
label: Paragraph

text: flanking light trabeated frames with massive corners
label: Paragraph

text: characterizes virtually all the industrial structures that
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens designed for AEG. Where the skeletal frame was
label: Paragraph

text: not a functional prerequisite, as in his Neo-Classical German
label: Paragraph

text: Embassy in St Petersburg of 1912, this Schinkelesque corner
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis is evident but less pronounced.

label: Caption

text: In 1908 Behrens revealed his essentially conservative
label: Paragraph

text: nature in an essay entitled Was ist monumentale Kunst?
label: Paragraph

text: (‘What is Monumental Art?’), where he defined such art as
label: Paragraph

text: an expression of the dominant power group in any given
label: Paragraph

text: epoch. In this same text he took issue with Semper’s
label: Paragraph

text: theoretical derivation of environmental form from technical
label: Paragraph

text: and material exigencies. He rejected the importance which
label: Paragraph

text: Semper attached to the typical tectonic element - to the
label: Paragraph

text: expressive load-bearing column as it appears in Classical
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Instead Behrens was profoundly influenced by
label: Paragraph

text: Alois Riegl’s élitist theory of the Kunstwollen or ‘will to form’
label: Paragraph

text: which acts through the agency of talented individuals as an
label: Paragraph

text: ordained ‘atectonic’ principle. For Riegl this force was
label: Paragraph

text: destined to oppose the specific technical propensities of an
label: Paragraph

text: epoch. Consistent with this thesis, Behrens’s contribution to
label: Paragraph

text: AEG product design was to be in the realm of style rather
label: Paragraph

text: than technique.
label: Paragraph

text: This split between Norm and Form, between type and
label: Paragraph

text: individuality, was soon to preoccupy the Deutsche
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund. The issue came to a head with Hermann
label: Paragraph

text: Muthesius’s address to the Werkbund assembly on the
label: Paragraph

text: occasion of the Deutsche Werkbund Exhibition, held in
label: Paragraph

text: Cologne in 1914. Muthesius’s ten-point programme, highly
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by the writings of Naumann, concentrated on the
label: Paragraph

text: need for refining typical objects (compare Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: objet-type). In points 1 and 2 he argued that architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and industrial design can attain significance only through
label: Paragraph

text: the development and refinement of types (7Typisierung), and
label: Paragraph

text: in points 3-10 he dealt with the national need for products
label: Paragraph

text: of high standard, so that these could be readily sold on the
label: Paragraph

text: world market. Point 9 dealt with mass production: ‘A
label: Paragraph

text: precondition for export is the existence of efficient big firms,
label: Paragraph

text: whose taste is impeccable. Particular single objects
label: Paragraph

text: designed by artists would not even cover the demand in
label: Paragraph

text: Germany.’
