text: This opportunistic emphasis on designing cultural objects
label: Paragraph

text: for an international middle class was immediately
label: Paragraph

text: challenged by Henry van de Velde who, in presenting his
label: Paragraph

text: counter-thesis, at once rejected ‘export’ art and proclaimed
label: Paragraph

text: the essential creative sovereignty of the individual artist. For
label: Paragraph

text: him, as for Behrens, only the natural process of Riegl’s
label: Paragraph

text: Kunstwollen could gradually bring about the evolution of a
label: Paragraph

text: civilized Norm. Despite much controversy over this issue,
label: Paragraph

text: there was enough support for Van de Velde’s position, from
label: Paragraph

text: figures as diverse as Walter Gropius and Karl Ernst Osthaus,
label: Paragraph

text: for Muthesius to be forced to withdraw his programme. In
label: Paragraph

text: his ten-point presentation Muthesius had elaborated his idea
label: Paragraph

text: of type as follows: ‘The way from individualism to the
label: Paragraph

text: creation of types is the organic way of development’, he
label: Paragraph

text: argued. ‘This is, today, the way in manufacture, where the
label: Paragraph

text: product ... is steadily being improved’. Again, he declared:
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Essentially, architecture tends towards the typical. The type
label: Paragraph

text: discards the extraordinary and establishes order.’ Thus for
label: Paragraph

text: Muthesius, as for Semper before him, ‘type’ had two
label: Paragraph

text: connotations: the ‘product object’ gradually refined through
label: Paragraph

text: use and production, and the ‘tectonic object’, which was an
label: Paragraph

text: irreducible building element functioning as a basic unit of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural language.
label: Paragraph

text: The need for such a syntax, in the face of the sudden
label: Paragraph

text: collapse of the Jugendstil, brought most of the architects at
label: Paragraph

text: the 1914 Deutsche Werkbund Exhibition, including
label: Paragraph

text: Muthesius, Behrens and Hoffmann, to express themselves in
label: Paragraph

text: the language of a reinterpreted Neo-Classicism. The only
label: Paragraph

text: two exceptions to this were Van de Velde’s Werkbund
label: Paragraph

text: Theatre, endowed by his form-force aesthetic with a
label: Paragraph

text: quasitheosophical aura, and its close rival, Bruno Taut’s
label: Paragraph

text: Glass Pavilion, which evoked the ritualistic mysticism of
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens’s Turin Vorhalle of 1902.
label: Paragraph

text: The 1914 Exhibition introduced to a wide public a new
label: Paragraph

text: generation of Werkbund artists, including in particular
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius and Adolf Meyer, who up to 1910 had worked
label: Paragraph

text: together in the office of Behrens. Gropius’s activity between
label: Paragraph

text: 1910 and 1914 followed along the lines of Behrens’s Berlin
label: Paragraph

text: career. In March 1910 he submitted to Emil Rathenau of AEG
label: Paragraph

text: a memorandum on rationalized house production, as
label: Paragraph

text: exemplified by workers’ houses that he had projected for
label: Paragraph

text: Janikow in 1906. This text, written by Gropius at the age of
label: Paragraph

text: twenty-six, remains even today one of the most exhaustive
label: Paragraph

text: and lucid expositions ever made of the essential
label: Paragraph

text: preconditions for the successful prefabrication, assembly
label: Paragraph

text: and distribution of standardized housing units. In 1911 the
label: Paragraph

text: new partnership of Gropius and Meyer was commissioned
label: Paragraph

text: by Karl Benscheidt to design the Fagus shoe-last factory, at
label: Paragraph

text: Alfeld-an-der-Leine. In 1913 the Deutsche Werkbund
label: Paragraph

text: Jahrbuch carried an article by Gropius on industrial building,
label: Paragraph

text: illustrated by grain silos and multistorey factories taken
label: Caption

text: from the industrial vernacular of the New World. In the same
label: Paragraph

text: year he started to work as an industrial designer, designing
label: Paragraph

text: the bodywork and layout of a diesel locomotive and then
label: Paragraph

text: the interior of a railway sleeping car. Finally, he and Meyer
label: Paragraph

text: designed a model factory for the Werkbund Exhibition of
label: Caption

text: In the Faguswerk, Gropius and Meyer adapted the syntax
label: Paragraph

text: of Behrens’s Turbine Factory to a more open architectural
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic. The corners still serve to contain the composition,
label: Paragraph

text: as in all of Behrens’s large AEG structures, but where
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens’s corners are invariably of masonry here they are of
label: Paragraph

text: glass. The vertical panels of glazing, set forward from the
label: Caption

text: battered brick facing, give the illusion of being miraculously
label: Paragraph

text: suspended from the upstand at roof level. This ‘pendant’
label: Paragraph

text: effect, plus the translucent corner, inverts the composition
label: Paragraph

text: of the Turbine Factory, the sheer planar quality of the
label: Paragraph

text: vertical glass facade being accentuated by the ‘Classical’
label: Paragraph

text: entasis of the brick-faced frame. Despite such
label: Paragraph

text: transpositions, the Faguswerk, with its atectonic glazing and
label: Paragraph

text: its nostalgia for the Classical, remained subject to the
label: Paragraph

text: influence of Behrens.
label: Paragraph

text: This particular disposition, which manifested itself
label: Paragraph

text: compositionally in emphatic corners and string courses, was
label: Paragraph

text: to characterize all the public work of Gropius and Meyer up
label: Paragraph

text: to Gropius’s design for the Dessau Bauhaus in 1924.
label: Paragraph

text: Certainly it was the stratagem adopted in their model
label: Paragraph

text: factory complex designed for the Werkbund Exhibition of
label: Paragraph

text: 1914 [90]. Here the corporeality of the glass skin was
label: Paragraph

text: developed as a continuous membrane to embrace spiral
label: Paragraph

text: staircases at either end of the building. Within this sheer
label: Paragraph

text: glass envelope stood a brick armature, its separateness
label: Paragraph

text: being accentuated by two end pavilions, each capped by a
label: Paragraph

text: flat roof overhang after the style of Frank Lloyd Wright. In
label: Paragraph

text: spite of this dramatic reversal of the roles of glass and
label: Paragraph

text: masonry, the factory layout was highly conventional, not
label: Paragraph

text: only in its axiality but also in its hierarchic and syntactical
label: Paragraph

text: separation into ‘administrative’ and ‘productive’ elements.
label: Paragraph

text: The public, ‘Classical’, ‘white-collar’ fagade was placed to
label: Paragraph

text: the fore, thus screening the private, utilitarian, ‘blue-collar’
label: Paragraph

text: steel-frame structure to the rear. Such a dualistic solution,
label: Paragraph

text: however well articulated, would never have been acceptable
label: Paragraph

text: to Behrens.
label: Paragraph

text: 90 Gropius and A. Meyer, part of model factory complex, Werkbund Exhibition,
label: Caption

text: Cologne, 1914, with office block on the left.
label: Caption

text: The split between Muthesius and Van de Velde effectively
label: Paragraph

text: exposed the reactionary spirit that was already evident in
label: Paragraph

text: much of the Werkbund work by the time of the 1914
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition. Whereas the yearbooks of 1913 and 1914 were
label: Paragraph

text: respectively devoted to ‘Art in Industry and Trade’, and
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Transport’ recording the design of the furnishing of
label: Paragraph

text: industrial structures, rolling stock, shipping and aircraft, the
label: Title

text: 1915 yearbook bore the ominous title ‘German Form in the
label: Paragraph

text: War Year’, and nostalgically devoted its pages to the
label: Paragraph

text: predominantly Neo-Biedermeier work of the 1914 Exhibition.
label: Paragraph

text: That the promise and triumph of a progressive industrial
label: Paragraph

text: state would soon be consumed by an industrialized war
label: Paragraph

text: seems hardly to have been foreseen. This tragedy was not
label: Paragraph

text: to be transcended by the quality of the war graves that the
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund artists were commissioned to design, which
label: Paragraph

text: formed the exclusive subject of the Werkbund yearbook
label: Paragraph

text: issued in 1916/17.
label: Paragraph

text: After the war Behrens was a changed man, for the
label: Paragraph

text: Volksgeist was patently no longer the same. Accordingly he
label: Paragraph

text: gave up his frigid Classicism and his preoccupation with
label: Paragraph

text: symbolizing the authority of industrial power. His renewed
label: Paragraph

text: search for an art of building which would express the true
label: Paragraph

text: spirit of the German people led back, via the pages of Bruno
label: Paragraph

text: Taut’s magazine Fruhlicht, beyond Behrens’s own Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Romantic Nietzschean past to forms of medieval origin and
label: Paragraph

text: association. However, his faith in the redeeming power of
label: Paragraph

text: Riegl’s ‘will to form’ remained unshaken. When I.G. Farben
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned him to design their new premises at
label: Paragraph

text: Frankfurt-Héchst in 1920 he attempted in a brick and stone
label: Paragraph

text: structure to reinterpret the lost syntax of medieval civic
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The building has at its core a mystic space of
label: Paragraph

text: public ritual and renewal (going back to Behrens’s Turin
label: Title

text: Vorhalle of 1902) in the form of a faceted five-storey hall of
label: Paragraph

text: corbelled brickwork, capped by a crystalline roof light. This
label: Paragraph

text: was an allusion to that theatrical space of public
label: Paragraph

text: appearance which had inspired his youth, to the
label: Paragraph

text: Kultursymbol that obsessed, with equal intensity, the
label: Paragraph

text: members of Bruno Taut’s Glass Chain (see Chapter 13). A
label: Paragraph

text: similar impulse informed his small exhibition structures of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1920s - his steeply pitched Dombauhitte (cathedral
label: Paragraph

text: masons’ lodge) with its diagonal banded brickwork,
label: Paragraph

text: designed for the Munich Kunstgewerbeschau of 1922, and
label: Paragraph

text: his Wrightian glass conservatory built for the Paris
label: Paragraph

text: Exposition des Arts Décoratifs in 1925. From then on
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens’s work was to remain close to the Art Deco style,
label: Paragraph

text: while the future of the Deutsche Werkbund was to be
label: Paragraph

text: inseparable from the Neue Sachlichkeit movement, which
label: Paragraph

text: saw its apotheosis, under Werkbund auspices, in the
label: Paragraph

text: international housing exhibition (including the famous
label: Title

text: Weissenhofsiedlung) that opened at Stuttgart in 1927.
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 13
label: Title

text: The Glass Chain: European
label: Title

text: Architectural
label: Title

text: Expressionism 1910-25
label: Title

text: /f we want our culture to raise to a higher level, we are
label: Paragraph

text: obliged, for better or for worse, to change our architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: And this only becomes possible if we take away the closed
label: Paragraph

text: character from the rooms in which we live. We can only do
label: Paragraph

text: that by introducing glass architecture, which lets the light of
label: Paragraph

text: the sun, the moon, and the stars, not merely through a few
label: Paragraph

text: windows, but through every possible wall, which will be
label: Paragraph

text: made entirely of glass - of coloured glass.
label: Paragraph

text: Paul Scheerbart
label: Title

text: Glasarchitektur, 19141
label: Caption

text: The poet Paul Scheerbart’s vision of a culture elevated
label: Paragraph

text: through the use of glass served to consolidate those
label: Paragraph

text: aspirations towards a non-repressive sensibility that had
label: Paragraph

text: first emerged in Munich in 1909 with the foundation of the
label: Paragraph

text: Neue Kunstler Vereinigung. This proto-Expressionist art
label: Paragraph

text: movement, led by the painter Wassily Kandinsky, gained
label: Paragraph

text: immediate support in the following year from two anarchist
label: Paragraph

text: publications, Herwarth Walden’s journal Der Sturm and
label: Paragraph

text: Franz Pfemfert’s paper Die Aktion. These Berlin journals
label: Paragraph

text: promoted a counterculture, in opposition to the state culture
label: Paragraph

text: that had been initiated with the foundation of the Deutsche
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund. In 1907 Scheerbart had independently proffered
label: Paragraph

text: a ‘science-fiction’ image of a utopian future that was equally
label: Paragraph

text: inimical to both bourgeois reformism and the culture of the
label: Paragraph

text: industrial state.
label: Paragraph

text: The Cologne Werkbund Exhibition in 1914 gave
label: Paragraph

text: expression to an ideological split within the Werkbund
label: Paragraph

text: between the collective acceptance of normative form
label: Title

text: (Typisierung), on the one hand, and the individually
label: Paragraph

text: asserted, expressive ‘will to form’ (Kunstwollen) on the
label: Paragraph

text: other. This opposition, reflected in the contrast between
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens’s Neo-Classical Festhalle and the organic form of
label: Paragraph

text: Van de Velde’s theatre, was comparable in many respects to
label: Paragraph

text: the difference between the Gropius and Meyer model
label: Paragraph

text: factory and Bruno Taut’s phantasmagoric pavilion for the
label: Paragraph

text: glass industry [91], a parallelism which confirms that the
label: Paragraph

text: split affected more than one generation of Werkbund
label: Paragraph

text: designers. Where Behrens and Gropius tended towards the
label: Paragraph

text: normative mode, that is, the Classical, Van de Velde and
label: Paragraph

text: Taut in their buildings manifested a freely expressed
label: Paragraph

text: Kunstwollen.
label: Paragraph

text: 91 Taut, Glass Pavilion, Werkbund Exhibition, Cologne, 1914. Elevation and plan.
label: Caption

text: The aphoristic text of Scheerbart’s Glasarchitektur was
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated to Taut, whose Glass Pavilion was inscribed with
label: Paragraph

text: Scheerbart’s aphorisms: ‘Light wants crystal’; ‘Glass brings
label: Paragraph

text: a new era’; ‘We feel sorry for the brick culture’; ‘Without a
label: Paragraph

text: glass palace, life becomes a burden’; ‘Building in brick only
label: Paragraph

text: does us harm’; ‘Coloured glass destroys hatred’. These
label: Paragraph

text: words dedicated Taut’s pavilion to the light that filtered
label: Paragraph

text: through its faceted cupola and glass-block walls to
label: Paragraph

text: illuminate an axial seven-tiered chamber, lined with glass
label: Caption

text: mosaic. According to Taut this crystalline structure,
label: Paragraph

text: modelled after his Leipzig Steel Pavilion of 1913, had been
label: Paragraph

text: designed in the spirit of a Gothic cathedral. It was in effect a
label: Paragraph

text: Stadtkrone or ‘city crown’, that pyramidal form postulated
label: Paragraph

text: by Taut as the universal paradigm of all religious building,
label: Paragraph

text: which together with the faith it would inspire was an
label: Paragraph

text: essential urban element for the restructuring of society.
label: Paragraph

text: The socio-cultural implications of Scheerbart’s vision
label: Title

text: were enlarged on in 1918 by the architect Adolf Behne:
label: Paragraph

text: lt is not the crazy caprice of a poet that glass architecture
label: Paragraph

text: will bring a new culture. It is a fact! New social welfare
label: Paragraph

text: organizations, hospitals, inventions, or technical innovations
label: Title

text: and improvements - these will not bring a new culture- but
label: Paragraph

text: glass architecture will. ... Therefore, the European is right
label: Paragraph

text: when he fears that glass architecture might become
label: Paragraph

text: uncomfortable. Certainly, it will be so. And that is not its
label: Paragraph

text: least advantage. For first of all the European must be
label: Paragraph

text: wrenched out of his cosiness.?
label: Paragraph

text: With the armistice of November 1918, Taut and Behne
label: Paragraph

text: began to organize the Arbeitsrat fur Kunst, which eventually
label: Paragraph

text: merged with the somewhat larger Novembergruppe formed
label: Paragraph

text: at the same time. This Workers’ Council for Art declared its
label: Paragraph

text: basic aims in Taut’s Architektur-programm of December
label: Paragraph

text: 1918, which argued for a new total work of art, to be
label: Paragraph

text: created with the active participation of the people. In the
label: Paragraph

text: spring of 1919 the manifesto of the Arbeitsrat fur Kunst
label: Title

text: reasserted this general principle: ‘Art and people must form
label: Paragraph

text: an entity. Art shall no longer be a luxury of the few, but
label: Paragraph

text: should be enjoyed and experienced by the broad masses.
label: Paragraph

text: The aim is the alliance of the arts under the wing of a great
label: Paragraph

text: architecture’. Led by Behne, Gropius and Taut, and affiliated
label: Paragraph

text: to the painters of Die Brucke, the Arbeitsrat fur Kunst
label: Paragraph

text: comprised some fifty artists, architects and patrons living in
label: Paragraph

text: and around Berlin, including the artists Georg Kolbe,
label: Paragraph

text: Gerhard Marcks, Lyonel Feininger, Emil Nolde, Hermann
label: Caption

text: Finsterlin, Max Pechstein and Karl Schmidt-Rottluff, and the
label: Paragraph

text: architects Otto Bartning, Max Taut, Bernhard Hoetger, Adolf
label: Caption

text: Meyer and Erich Mendelsohn. In April 1919, these last five
label: Paragraph

text: staged an exhibition of visionary works under the title ‘An
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition of Unknown Architects’. The introduction that
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius wrote for this exhibition was, in effect, the first draft
label: Paragraph

text: of his Weimar Bauhaus programme, published in the same
label: Paragraph

text: month:
label: Title

text: We must want, imagine, and create the new architectural
label: Paragraph

text: concept co-operatively. Painters, sculptors, break down the
label: Paragraph

text: barriers around architecture and become co-builders and
label: Paragraph

text: comrades-in-arms towards art’s ultimate goal: the creative
label: Title

text: idea of the Cathedral of the Future [Zukunftskathedrale],
label: Paragraph

text: which will once more encompass everything in one form -
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and sculpture and painting.*
label: Paragraph

text: This call for a new religious building, capable of unifying
label: Paragraph

text: the creative energy of the society as in the Middle Ages,
label: Paragraph

text: was echoed by Behne in 1919, in his reply to a group
label: Paragraph

text: opinion poll, published under the title /a/ Stimmen des
label: Paragraph

text: Arbeitsrates fur Kunst in Berlin (‘Yes! Voices from the Art
label: Title

text: Soviet in Berlin’):
label: Title

text: The most important thing seems to me to be to construct an
label: Paragraph

text: ideal House of God, not a denominational one, but a
label: Paragraph

text: religious work. ... We must not wait until a new religiosity is
label: Paragraph

text: upon us, for it may be waiting for us while we are waiting for
label: Paragraph

text: it.4
label: Paragraph

text: The suppression of the Spartacist Revolt in 1919 put an
label: Paragraph

text: end to the overt activities of the Arbeitsrat fiir Kunst, and
label: Paragraph

text: the energies of the group were channelled into a series of
label: Paragraph

text: letters, known as ‘Die Glaserne Kette’ or the Glass Chain.
label: Paragraph

text: This was Bruno Taut’s ‘Utopian Correspondence,’ which
label: Paragraph

text: began in November 1919 after his suggestion that
label: Paragraph

text: ‘everyone of us will draw or write down at brief intervals of
label: Paragraph

text: time, informally and as the spirit moves him ... those ideas
label: Paragraph

text: which he would like to share with our circle.’ The
label: Paragraph

text: correspondence involved fourteen people, of whom only
label: Paragraph

text: about half created works of enduring importance. Apart
label: Paragraph

text: from Taut, who called himself G/as, there was Gropius
label: Paragraph

text: (Mass), Finsterlin (Prometh), and Bruno Taut’s brother Max,
label: Paragraph

text: who wrote under his own name. This inner circle was
label: Paragraph

text: complemented by architects who had previously only had a
label: Paragraph

text: peripheral involvement with the Arbeitsrat, notably the
label: Paragraph

text: brothers Hans and Wassili Luckhardt and Hans Scharoun.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from providing material for Taut’s magazine Fruihlicht
label: Paragraph

text: (‘Early Light’), the Utopian Correspondence served to
label: Paragraph

text: expose and develop the various attitudes represented by
label: Paragraph

text: the circle. Taut and Scharoun especially stressed the
label: Paragraph

text: important creative role of the unconscious, Scharoun writing
label: Paragraph

text: We must create just as the blood of our ancestors brought
label: Paragraph

text: on waves of creativity; and we shall be content if we are
label: Paragraph

text: ourselves thereafter able to reveal a complete
label: Paragraph

text: comprehension of the character and the causality of our
label: Title

text: creations.°
label: Paragraph

text: By 1920, however, the solidarity of the Glass Chain
label: Paragraph

text: began to break, with Hans Luckhardat’s recognition that free
label: Paragraph

text: unconscious form and rational prefabricated production
label: Title

text: were in certain respects incompatible. In that year he wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: Opposite to this profoundly spiritual striving is the trend
label: Paragraph

text: toward automatic processes. The invention of the Taylor
label: Paragraph

text: System is a typical characteristic of this. It would be
label: Paragraph

text: completely erroneous to refuse to recognize this tendency
label: Paragraph

text: of the time, as it is a historic fact. Moreover, it can in no way
label: Paragraph

text: be proven to be hostile toward art.®
label: Paragraph

text: While Luckhardt’s rationalism had the effect of returning
label: Paragraph

text: the debate to the issues that had divided the Werkbund in
label: Paragraph

text: 1914, Taut maintained the Scheerbartian views first
label: Paragraph

text: expressed in books such as Alpine Architektur and Die
label: Paragraph

text: Stadtkrone of 1919, publishing his famous Die Auflésung der
label: Paragraph

text: Stadte (‘The dissolution of cities’) in 1920. In common with
label: Paragraph

text: the socialist planners of the Russian Revolution, he
label: Paragraph

text: recommended the break-up of cities and the return of the
label: Paragraph

text: urbanized population to the land. At his most practical, he
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to formulate models for agrarian and handicraft-
label: Paragraph

text: based communities; at his most fantastic, he projected the
label: Paragraph

text: building of glass temples in the Alps. Typical of Taut’s
label: Paragraph

text: Kropotkinian propositions was his model of a circular,
label: Paragraph

text: radially subdivided, agricultural settlement. In its core were
label: Paragraph

text: three separate residential sections, one for each class of
label: Paragraph

text: citizen - Ktinder, Kunstler und Kinder (the ‘enlightened’,
label: Paragraph

text: artists and children) - each grouped around lozenge-shaped
label: Paragraph

text: courts. This tripartite organization led axially to the central
label: Paragraph

text: crystalline ‘Haus des Himmels’ or ‘House of Heaven’, where
label: Paragraph

text: the governors of the community convened. It is one of the
label: Paragraph

text: paradoxes of Taut’s anarchic socialism that the hierarchic,
label: Paragraph

text: not to say authoritarian, social institutions imagined for
label: Paragraph

text: these communities contained the seeds of a fascism that
label: Paragraph

text: was soon to find its vulgarization in the ‘blood and soil’
label: Paragraph

text: culture of the National Socialist movement.
label: Paragraph

text: After becoming city architect to Magdeburg in 1921, Taut
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to realize his Stadtkrone in the form of a
label: Paragraph

text: municipal exhibition hall, designed in the following year. By
label: Caption

text: that date, however, the movement propagated by Frehlicht
label: Paragraph

text: was losing its impetus. Taut, like Hans Luckhardt before him,
label: Paragraph

text: was beginning to come to terms with the harsh reality of the
label: Paragraph

text: Weimar Republic, where pragmatic social need gave little
label: Paragraph

text: scope for the achievement of Scheerbart’s glass paradise.
label: Paragraph

text: This much became explicit in 1923, when he started to work
label: Paragraph

text: with his brother on the design of the first low-cost housing
label: Paragraph

text: schemes commissioned by the government.
label: Paragraph

text: Paradoxically, it was not Taut but Hans Poelzig who was
label: Paragraph

text: to realize the quintessential image of the crystalline ‘city
label: Paragraph

text: crown’. The 5,000-seat theatre that he designed for Max
label: Paragraph

text: Reinhardt in Berlin in 1919 [92] came closer to Scheerbart
label: Paragraph

text: in its scintillating, luminous dissolution of form and space
label: Paragraph

text: than any post-war achievement by Taut. Of its fantastic
label: Paragraph

text: stalactite interior, Wassili Luckhardt wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: 92 Poelzig, Grosse Schauspielhaus, Berlin, 1919.
label: Caption

text: The interior of the large dome is hung with an infinite
label: Paragraph

text: variety of pendants which are given a softly curving
label: Paragraph

text: movement by the hollow of the cupola onto which they are
label: Paragraph

text: fastened so that especially when light is thrown against the
label: Paragraph

text: tiny reflectors on each tip, the impression of a certain
label: Paragraph

text: dissolution and infinity results.’
label: Paragraph

text: After establishing himself as an architect in Breslau in
label: Paragraph

text: 1911, Poelzig had realized two seminal works which
label: Paragraph

text: anticipated the later formal language of both Taut and
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn: a water tower for Posen (a Stadtkrone image if
label: Caption

text: ever there was one) and an office building for Breslau, which
label: Paragraph

text: led to the architectural format of Mendelsohn’s Berliner-
label: Paragraph

text: Tageblatt building of 1921. In addition, Poelzig’s highly
label: Paragraph

text: articulated brick chemical plant built at Luban in 1912 came
label: Paragraph

text: close to rivalling the industrial style that Behrens had just
label: Paragraph

text: invented for AEG.
label: Paragraph

text: After the war, in his address as chairman of the
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund in 1919, Poelzig returned to the controversy over
label: Paragraph

text: Typisierung and effectively argued yet again for the
label: Paragraph

text: principle of the Kunstwollen. A year later, he announced his
label: Paragraph

text: affinity with the artists of the Glass Chain, in his Salzburg
label: Paragraph

text: Festspielhaus project where his newly invented pendentive
label: Paragraph

text: motif was piled up into a Stadtkrone image of heroic
label: Paragraph

text: proportions. As in his Istanbul ‘Freundschaftshaus’ (House of
label: Paragraph

text: Friendship) project of 1917, these arched forms were
label: Paragraph

text: assembled in such a way as to create a ziggurat whose
label: Paragraph

text: interior was a prismatic cavern made up entirely of
label: Paragraph

text: pendentive elements. Apart from his sets for Paul Wegener’s
label: Paragraph

text: film The Golem (1920), the Schauspielhaus for Reinhardt
label: Caption

text: was Poelzig’s last fully Expressionist work. By 1925, with his
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn realized his own version of the Stadtkrone in
label: Paragraph

text: the observatory that he built for Albert Einstein at Potsdam
label: Paragraph

text: in 1917-21 [93]. Combining as it did the sculptural forms of
label: Paragraph

text: Van de Velde’s Werkbund Theatre and the overall profile of
label: Paragraph

text: Bruno Taut’s Glass Pavilion, the design’s point of departure
label: Paragraph

text: lay in the 1914 Werkbund Exhibition. In its final silhouette,
label: Paragraph

text: however, the Einstein Tower displayed a certain formal
label: Paragraph

text: affinity to the thatched-roof vernacular of the Dutch
label: Paragraph

text: architects Eibink and Snellebrand, who, with Theo
label: Paragraph

text: Wijdeveld, represented the extreme organic wing of Dutch
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionism, centred around Wijdeveld’s magazine
label: Paragraph

text: Wendingen (‘Turnings’). It is hardly surprising, therefore,
label: Paragraph

text: that soon after the completion of the observatory
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn visited Holland, at Wijdeveld’s invitation, to see
label: Paragraph

text: the work of the Wendingen circle for himself. In Amsterdam
label: Caption

text: he visited a number of Expressionist housing schemes which
label: Paragraph

text: were then under construction, as part of Berlage’s plan for
label: Paragraph

text: Amsterdam South, including Michel de Klerk’s Eigen Haard
label: Paragraph

text: (1913-19) and Piet Kramer’s De Dageraad (1918-23).
label: Paragraph

text: Executed in moulded brickwork and tile hanging, they
label: Paragraph

text: exemplified a much more structural approach than the
label: Paragraph

text: highly plastic and folkish preoccupations of Wijdeveld’s
label: Paragraph

text: ‘vernacular’ architects. Outside the Amsterdam School of
label: Paragraph

text: Wijdeveld, De Klerk and Kramer, Mendelsohn met and was
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by a number of Dutch architects of quite different
label: Paragraph

text: persuasion, such as the rationalist Rotterdam architect J.J.P.
label: Paragraph

text: Oud and the Wrightian architect W.M. Dudok, practising in
label: Paragraph

text: Hilversum. In a letter to his wife, Mendelsohn explained how
label: Paragraph

text: neither the Amsterdam nor the Rotterdam school met with
label: Paragraph

text: his full approval:
label: Paragraph

text: 93 Mendelsohn, Einstein Tower, Potsdam, 1917-21. Front and side elevations
label: Caption

text: and half-plan.
label: Paragraph

text: Analytical Rotterdam refuses vision; visionary Amsterdam
label: Title

text: does not understand objectivity. Certainly the primary
label: Paragraph

text: element is function but function without sensibility remains
label: Paragraph

text: mere construction. More than ever | stand by my
label: Paragraph

text: reconciliatory programme. ... Otherwise, Rotterdam will
label: Paragraph

text: pursue the way of mere construction, with deathly chill in its
label: Paragraph

text: veins, and Amsterdam will be destroyed by the fire of its
label: Paragraph

text: own dynamicism. Function plus dynamics is the challenge.®
label: Paragraph

text: As this letter suggests, the more structural of the Dutch
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionists had an immediate impact on Mendelsohn’s
label: Paragraph

text: own development: after his visit to Holland he turned from
label: Paragraph

text: the plasticity of his Potsdam observatory towards a concern
label: Paragraph

text: for the intrinsic structural expressiveness of materials. The
label: Paragraph

text: hat factory that he built at Luckenwalde in 1921-23 [94]
label: Caption

text: reflects this influence. Its ridged and pitched-roofed dye
label: Paragraph

text: shop and production sheds, modelled in the manner of De
label: Paragraph

text: Klerk, stood in strong contrast to the smooth flat-roofed
label: Paragraph

text: power house whose layered ‘cubist’ expression in brick and
label: Paragraph

text: concrete recalls the early work of Dudok. The principle
label: Paragraph

text: established here, of setting dramatic tall pitched industrial
label: Paragraph

text: forms against horizontal administrative elements, was
label: Paragraph

text: repeated by Mendelsohn in his Leningrad textile mill project
label: Paragraph

text: of 1925. In this instance, however, a further step was taken,
label: Paragraph

text: for the banded modelling of the administration block
label: Paragraph

text: anticipated the profiling of his metropolitan department
label: Paragraph

text: stores, built in Breslau, Stuttgart, Chemnitz and Berlin
label: Paragraph

text: between 1927 and 1931 [95]. From now on, as Reyner
label: Paragraph

text: Banham has observed, he thought ‘in terms of structural
label: Paragraph

text: assemblies of geometrical, simple units which presented
label: Paragraph

text: themselves as tidily profiled edges’.

label: Caption

text: In the masterwork of Hugo Haring, the farm complex at
label: Paragraph

text: Garkau near Lubeck built in 1924 [96], we find a somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: similar expressive use of pitched-roof forms contrasted with
label: Paragraph

text: bulky tectonic elements and rounded corners. A few years
label: Paragraph

text: earlier, Haring had shared an office in Berlin with Ludwig
label: Paragraph

text: Mies van der Rohe, who was four years his junior, and there
label: Paragraph

text: is evidence that for a brief while the two men exercised a
label: Paragraph

text: certain influence on each other. This is particularly
label: Paragraph

text: noticeable in their entries to the famous Friedrichstrasse
label: Paragraph

text: office building competition of 1921, where they adopted a
label: Paragraph

text: similar organic approach to the genesis of form. As one
label: Paragraph

text: might expect, however, it was Mies rather than Haring who
label: Paragraph

text: put forward a structure made entirely of glass. Mies’s
label: Paragraph

text: Scheerbartian obsession with the reflectivity of this material
label: Paragraph

text: also manifested itself in an extraordinary project for a glass
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper which was published in 1922 in the last issue of
label: Paragraph

text: Taut’s magazine Frtihlicht.
label: Paragraph

text: 96 Haring, farm at Garkau, 1924. Buildings for animals (upper left) and barns.
label: Caption

text: Although Haring, like Mendelsohn, believed in the
label: Paragraph

text: ultimate primacy of function, he sought to transcend the
label: Paragraph

text: primitive nature of mere utility by evolving his forms from a
label: Paragraph

text: more profound understanding of the programme. Like
label: Paragraph

text: Scharoun, however, his attitude to massing was often
label: Paragraph

text: naively imitative of biological form. In this respect, one may
label: Paragraph

text: see Scharoun’s Home and Work Exhibition building at
label: Caption

text: Breslau of 1928 as influenced by Haring’s Prinz Albrecht
label: Paragraph

text: Garten residential project of 1924. Despite an overtly
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionist tendency, Haring remained preoccupied with
label: Paragraph

text: the inner source of form, with that which he termed the
label: Paragraph

text: Organwerk or the programmatic essence of the ‘organism’,
label: Paragraph

text: as opposed to its surface expression or Gesta/twerk. Of this
label: Paragraph

text: duality he wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: We now attempt not to allow our attitudes towards function
label: Paragraph

text: to conflict with our needs for expression, but to keep them
label: Paragraph

text: side by side. We try to relate our ideas about expression to
label: Paragraph

text: life, creation, movement and nature; for in our creation of
label: Paragraph

text: functional forms we follow the path of nature. In nature form
label: Paragraph

text: is the result of the organisation of many individual entities in
label: Paragraph

text: space in order that life can unfold and action take place, a
label: Paragraph

text: fulfilment of both part and whole, (whereas in the world of
label: Paragraph

text: geometrical cultures form is derived from laws of geometry).
label: Paragraph

text: lf we prefer to search for shapes rather than to impose
label: Paragraph

text: them, to discover forms rather than to construct them, we
label: Paragraph

text: are in harmony with nature and act with her rather than
label: Paragraph

text: against her?
label: Title

text: At the Berlin Secession Exhibition in 1923 Hans and
label: Paragraph

text: Wassili Luckhardt, with Mies and some of his
label: Paragraph

text: contemporaries, had begun to show a more functional and
label: Paragraph

text: objective mode of building, a development which led in the
label: Paragraph

text: following year to their formation of the Zehnerring. By 1925,
label: Paragraph

text: when the Zehnerring became Der Ring, with Haring as its
label: Paragraph

text: secretary, no divisions between the various positions had
label: Paragraph

text: appeared, as their collective energy was devoted to
label: Paragraph

text: overcoming the reactionary policies of the Berlin city
label: Title

text: architect, Ludwig Hoffmann.
label: Caption

text: In 1928, however, when this battle had been won,
label: Paragraph

text: Haring’s concern for the ‘organic’ naturally led him into
label: Paragraph

text: conflict with Le Corbusier when, as secretary of Der Ring, he
label: Paragraph

text: participated in the foundation of the Congrés Internationaux
label: Paragraph

text: d’Architecture Moderne, at La Sarraz, Switzerland. While Le
label: Caption

text: Corbusier here proclaimed an architecture of functionalism
label: Paragraph

text: and pure geometrical form, Haring tried in vain to win the
label: Paragraph

text: Congress over to his own conception of ‘organic’ building.
label: Paragraph

text: His failure to do so not only emphasized the non-normative,
label: Paragraph

text: ‘place’-orientated nature of his approach but also denoted
label: Paragraph

text: the final eclipse of the Scheerbartian dream. For all that
label: Paragraph

text: Scharoun extended this vision into the post-war period, in
label: Paragraph

text: his Romeo and Juliet apartments, built in Stuttgart in 1954-
label: Paragraph

text: 59, and his last masterwork, the Philharmonie, built in Berlin
label: Caption

text: in 1956-63, the idiosyncratic nature of the ‘organic’
label: Paragraph

text: approach has since been given little chance to prevail.

label: Paragraph

text: Proclamation of the Weimar Bauhaus, 19191
label: Title

text: The Bauhaus was the outcome of a continuous effort to
label: Paragraph

text: reform applied art education in Germany around the turn of
label: Paragraph

text: the century, first with the establishment in 1898 of Karl
label: Paragraph

text: Schmidt's Dresdner Werkstatten (which became the
label: Paragraph

text: Deutsche Werkstatten, and moved to the garden city of
label: Paragraph

text: Hellerau in 1908), then with the appointment in 1903 of
label: Paragraph

text: Hans Poelzig and Peter Behrens to the directorships of
label: Paragraph

text: applied art schools in Breslau and Dusseldorf, and finally, in
label: Paragraph

text: 1906, with the founding of the Grand Ducal School of Arts
label: Paragraph

text: and Crafts in Weimar under the direction of the Belgian
label: Paragraph

text: architect Henry van de Velde.
label: Caption

text: Despite the ambitious structures that he designed for
label: Paragraph

text: both the Fine Arts Building and the School of Arts and Crafts,
label: Paragraph

text: Van de Velde did little more in his tenure than establish a
label: Paragraph

text: relatively modest Kunstseminar for craftsmen. After his
label: Paragraph

text: enforced resignation as an alien in 1915, he advised the
label: Paragraph

text: Saxon State Ministry that Walter Gropius, Hermann Obrist or
label: Paragraph

text: August Endell would make a suitable successor. Protracted
label: Paragraph

text: discussions took place throughout the war between the
label: Paragraph

text: Ministry and Fritz Mackensen, head of the Grand Ducal
label: Title

text: Academy of Fine Art, as to the relative pedagogical status of
label: Paragraph

text: fine and applied art, with Gropius arguing for the relative
label: Paragraph

text: autonomy of the latter. Gropius advocated a workshop-
label: Paragraph

text: based design education for both designers and craftsmen,
label: Paragraph

text: while Mackensen stuck to the Prussian idealist line, insisting
label: Paragraph

text: that artist-craftsmen should be trained in a fine art
label: Paragraph

text: academy. This ideological conflict was resolved in 1919 in
label: Paragraph

text: compromise: Gropius became director of a composite
label: Title

text: institution, consisting of the Academy of Art and the School
label: Paragraph

text: of Arts and Crafts, an arrangement that was to divide the
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus, conceptually, throughout its existence.
label: Paragraph

text: The principles of the Bauhaus Proclamation of 1919 [97]
label: Title

text: had been anticipated in Bruno Taut’s architectural
label: Paragraph

text: programme for the Arbeitsrat fur Kunst, published late in
label: Paragraph

text: 1918. Taut argued that a new cultural unity could be
label: Paragraph

text: attained only through a new art of building, wherein each
label: Paragraph

text: separate discipline would contribute to the final form. ‘At
label: Paragraph

text: this point,’ he wrote, ‘there will be no boundaries between
label: Paragraph

text: the crafts, sculpture and painting; all will be one:
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture.’
label: Paragraph

text: 97 Feininger, woodcut for the Bauhaus Proclamation, 1919. Zukunftskathedrale,
label: Caption

text: the cathedral of the future as the cathedral of socialism.
label: Paragraph

text: This anarchic reworking of the Gesamtkunstwerk ideal
label: Paragraph

text: was elaborated by Gropius first in the pamphlet written in
label: Paragraph

text: April 1919 for the ‘Exhibition of Unknown Architects’,
label: Caption

text: organized by the Arbeitsrat fur Kunst, and then in his
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus Proclamation of about the same date. Where the
label: Paragraph

text: one called on all fine artists to reject salon art and to return
label: Paragraph

text: to the crafts in the service of a metaphorical cathedral of
label: Paragraph

text: the future - ‘to go into buildings, endow them with fairy
label: Paragraph

text: tales ... and build in fantasy without regard for technical
label: Paragraph

text: difficulty’ - the other exhorted the members of the Bauhaus
label: Paragraph

text: ‘to create a new guild of craftsmen, without the class
label: Paragraph

text: distinctions which raise an arrogant barrier between
label: Paragraph

text: craftsman and artist’.
label: Paragraph

text: Even the word Bauhaus, which Gropius persuaded the
label: Paragraph

text: reluctant state government to adopt as the official title of
label: Paragraph

text: the new institution, intentionally recalled the medieval
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhutte or masons’ lodge. That such connotations were
label: Paragraph

text: deliberate is confirmed by a letter written by Oskar
label: Paragraph

text: Schlemmer in 1922:
label: Title

text: Originally the Bauhaus was founded with visions of erecting
label: Paragraph

text: the cathedral of socialism and the workshops were
label: Paragraph

text: established in the manner of the cathedral building lodges
label: Paragraph

text: [Dombauhttten]. The idea of the cathedral has for the time
label: Paragraph

text: being receded into the background and with it certain
label: Paragraph

text: definite ideas of an artistic nature. Today we must think at
label: Paragraph

text: best in terms of the house, perhaps even only think so. ... in
label: Paragraph

text: the face of the economic plight, it is our task to become
label: Paragraph

text: pioneers of simplicity, that is, to find a simple form for all
label: Paragraph

text: life’s necessities, which at the same time is respectable and
label: Paragraph

text: genuine.2
label: Paragraph

text: For the first three years of its existence the Bauhaus was
label: Paragraph

text: dominated by the charismatic presence of the Swiss painter
label: Paragraph

text: and teacher Johannes Itten, who arrived in the autumn of
label: Paragraph

text: 1919. Three years earlier he had started his own art school
label: Paragraph

text: in Vienna, under the influence of Franz Cizek. In a highly
label: Paragraph

text: charged milieu, coloured by the anarchic anti-Seccessionist
label: Paragraph

text: activities of the painter Oskar Kokoschka and the architect
label: Paragraph

text: Adolf Loos, Cizek had developed a unique system of
label: Paragraph

text: instruction based on stimulating individual creativity
label: Title

text: through the making of collages of different materials and
label: Paragraph

text: textures. His methods had matured in a cultural climate
label: Paragraph

text: impregnated with progressive educational theory, from the
label: Paragraph

text: systems of Froebel and Montessori to the ‘learning-through-
label: Paragraph

text: doing’ movement, initiated by the American John Dewey
label: Paragraph

text: and vigorously propagated in Germany after 1908 by the
label: Paragraph

text: educational reformer Georg Kerschensteiner. The teaching
label: Paragraph

text: in Itten’s Viennese school and in the Vorkurs, or preliminary
label: Paragraph

text: course, that he initiated in the Bauhaus was derived from
label: Paragraph

text: Cizek, although Itten enriched the method with the form and
label: Paragraph

text: colour theory of his own master Adolf Hélzel. The aims of
label: Paragraph

text: Itten’s foundation course, mandatory for all first-year
label: Paragraph

text: students, were to release individual creativity and to enable
label: Paragraph

text: each student to assess his own particular ability.
label: Paragraph

text: Up to 1920, when, at Itten’s request, the artists
label: Paragraph

text: Schlemmer, Paul Klee and Georg Muche joined the Bauhaus,
label: Paragraph

text: he taught, single-handed, four separate craft courses in
label: Paragraph

text: addition to the Vorkurs, while Gerhard Marcks and Lyonel
label: Paragraph

text: Feininger gave marginal courses in ceramics and printing
label: Paragraph

text: respectively. Itten’s anarchic position at the time may be
label: Paragraph

text: gleaned from his 1922 response to a referendum on the
label: Paragraph

text: provision of state welfare for artists:
label: Title

text: The mind stands outside any organization. Where it has
label: Paragraph

text: nevertheless been organized (religion, church), it has
label: Paragraph

text: become estranged from its innate nature. ... The state
label: Paragraph

text: should take care that none of its citizens starve but it should
label: Paragraph

text: not support art.3
label: Title

text: Itten’s anti-authoritarian, even mystical, position was
label: Paragraph

text: substantially reinforced in 1921 by his extended stay in the
label: Paragraph

text: Mazdaznan centre at Herrliberg near Zurich [98]. He
label: Paragraph

text: returned in the middle of the year to convert his pupils and
label: Paragraph

text: his colleague Muche to the rigours of this updated version of
label: Paragraph

text: an archaic Persian religion. The cult demanded an austere
label: Paragraph

text: lifestyle, periodic fasting, and a vegetarian diet flavoured
label: Paragraph

text: with cheese and garlic. The physical and spiritual well-being
label: Paragraph

text: deemed to be essential to creativity was further assured by
label: Paragraph

text: breathing and relaxation exercises. Of this inner-directed
label: Paragraph

text: orientation Itten later wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: 98 Itten, in the Mazdaznan work costume that he designed, 1921.
label: Caption

text: The terrible losses and horrible events of World War | and a
label: Title

text: close study of Spengler’s Decline of the West made me
label: Paragraph

text: realize that we had reached a crucial point in our scientific-
label: Paragraph

text: technological civilization. For me, it was not enough to
label: Paragraph

text: embrace the slogans ‘return to craft’ or ‘art and technology,
label: Paragraph

text: hand in hand’. | studied Eastern philosophy, delved into
label: Paragraph

text: Persian Mazdaism and Indian yoga teachings, and compared
label: Paragraph

text: them with early Christianity. | reached the conclusion that
label: Paragraph

text: we must counter-balance our externally-orientated scientific
label: Paragraph

text: research and technological speculation with inner-directed
label: Title

text: thought and practice. | searched for something, for myself
label: Paragraph

text: and my work, on which to base a new way of life.
label: Paragraph

text: The growing division between Gropius and Itten was
label: Paragraph

text: exacerbated by the appearance in Weimar of two equally
label: Paragraph

text: powerful personalities: the Dutch De Stijl artist Theo van
label: Title

text: Doesburg, who took up residence in the winter of 1921, and
label: Paragraph

text: the Russian painter Wassily Kandinsky, who joined the
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus, at Itten’s instigation, in the summer of 1922.
label: Paragraph

text: Where the former postulated a rational, anti-individualist
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic, the latter taught an emotive and ultimately
label: Paragraph

text: mystical approach to art. Although the two men did not
label: Paragraph

text: come into direct conflict, Van Doesburg’s extramural De Stijl
label: Paragraph

text: polemic instantly appealed to many Bauhaus students. His
label: Paragraph

text: teaching not only had an immediate impact on the
label: Paragraph

text: production of the workshops, but also directly challenged
label: Paragraph

text: the open-ended precepts of the original Bauhaus
label: Paragraph

text: programme. His influence was even reflected in the
label: Paragraph

text: furnishing of Gropius’s own office, and in the asymmetrical
label: Paragraph

text: composition [99] of Gropius’s entry for the 1922 Chicago
label: Caption

text: Tribune competition, designed with Adolf Meyer.
label: Paragraph

text: 99 Gropius and A. Meyer, project for the Chicago Tribune Building, 1922.
label: Caption

text: In 1922, after Van Doesburg had been proselytizing for
label: Paragraph

text: nine months, the generally critical socio-economic situation
label: Paragraph

text: brought Gropius to modify the craft orientation of the
label: Paragraph

text: original programme. His initial attack on Itten appeared in
label: Paragraph

text: his circular to the Bauhaus masters, where he indirectly
label: Paragraph

text: criticized Itten’s monastic rejection of the world. This text
label: Paragraph

text: was in effect a draft for his essay /dee und Aufbau des
label: Paragraph

text: Staatlichen Bauhauses Weimar (‘The Theory and
label: Title

text: Organization of the Bauhaus’), published on the occasion of
label: Paragraph

text: the first Bauhaus exhibition held in Weimar in 1923. He
label: Paragraph

text: wrote:
label: Title

text: The teaching of craft is meant to prepare for designing for
label: Paragraph

text: mass production. Starting with the simplest tools and least
label: Paragraph

text: complicated jobs, he [the Bauhaus apprentice] gradually
label: Paragraph

text: acquires ability to master more intricate problems and to
label: Paragraph

text: work with machines, while at the same time he keeps in
label: Paragraph

text: touch with the entire process of production from start to
label: Paragraph

text: finish.4
label: Paragraph

text: This carefully worded argument by Gropius for the
label: Paragraph

text: reconciliation of craft design and industrial production
label: Title

text: brought about Itten’s immediate resignation.
label: Paragraph

text: His position on the faculty was immediately filled by the
label: Paragraph

text: Hungarian artist and social radical Laszl6 Moholy-Nagy. On
label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: paper. At the other end of the telephone the factory

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: They are the Sommerfeld House, designed by Gropius and
label: Paragraph

text: Meyer and completed in Berlin-Dahlem in 1922, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus ‘Versuchshaus’ or Experimental House, designed
label: Paragraph

text: by Muche and Meyer for the Bauhaus Exhibition of 1923
label: Caption

text: [100]. Where the first was designed as a traditional
label: Paragraph

text: Heimatstil log house, with an interior enriched with carved
label: Caption

text: wood and stained glass so as to create a Gesarntkunstwerk,
label: Paragraph

text: the second was conceived as a sachlich, smoothly rendered
label: Paragraph

text: object, furnished with the latest labour-saving devices so as
label: Paragraph

text: to be a Wohnmaschine, or living machine. This minimum-
label: Paragraph

text: circulation house was organized around an ‘atrium’ - not an
label: Paragraph

text: open court but a clerestory-lit living-room surrounded on all
label: Paragraph

text: sides by bedrooms and other ancillary spaces. Each of these
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter rooms was equipped in an austere manner, with
label: Paragraph

text: exposed metal radiators, steel windows and door frames,
label: Caption

text: elemental furniture, and unshaded tubular light fittings.
label: Paragraph

text: While most of these pieces were handmade in the Bauhaus
label: Paragraph

text: workshops, Adolf Meyer, in his report on the house in
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhausbucher 3 (1923), emphasized its furnishing with
label: Paragraph

text: standard bathroom and kitchen equipment and its
label: Title

text: construction with entirely new materials and methods.
label: Paragraph

text: 100 Muche and A. Meyer, Experimental House, Bauhaus Exhibition, Weimar,
label: Caption

text: The changing ideology of the Bauhaus was further
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated in an article by Gropius in the same issue of
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhausbucher, entitled ‘Wohnhaus-Industrie’, it illustrated
label: Paragraph

text: a remarkable round house projected by Karl Fieger, the
label: Paragraph

text: centralized, light-weight conception of which anticipated
label: Paragraph

text: Buckminster Fuller’s Dymaxion House of 1927. In addition,
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius published his own ‘Serienhauser’, or extending
label: Paragraph

text: house units, intended as prototypes for the
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaussiedlung, a housing estate which he hoped to build
label: Paragraph

text: on the outskirts of Weimar. These serial houses were finally
label: Paragraph

text: realized as masters’ residences built at the Dessau Bauhaus
label: Paragraph

text: After 1923 the Bauhaus approach became extremely
label: Paragraph

text: ‘objective’, in the sense of being closely affiliated to the
label: Paragraph

text: Neue Sachlichkeit movement. This affiliation, which was
label: Paragraph

text: reflected, despite their rather formalistic massing, in the
label: Paragraph

text: buildings for the Dessau Bauhaus itself, was to become
label: Paragraph

text: more pronounced after Gropius’s resignation in 1928. The
label: Paragraph

text: last two years of Gropius’s tenure were distinguished by
label: Paragraph

text: three major developments: the politically enforced and well-
label: Paragraph

text: orchestrated move from Weimar to Dessau, the completion
label: Paragraph

text: of the Dessau Bauhaus [101, 102], and finally the gradual
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of a recognizable Bauhaus approach, in which a
label: Paragraph

text: greater emphasis was placed on deriving form from
label: Paragraph

text: productive method, material constraint and programmatic
label: Title

text: necessity.
label: Paragraph

text: 101, 102 Gropius, Bauhaus, Dessau, 1925-26. Exterior showing the pinwheel
label: Caption

text: composition (see p. 148); right, bridge linking administration and workshop
label: Paragraph

text: blocks, on inauguration day, 1926.
label: Caption

text: The furniture workshops, under Marcel Breuer’s brilliant
label: Paragraph

text: direction, started in 1926 to produce tubular steel
label: Paragraph

text: lightweight chairs and tables which were convenient, easy
label: Paragraph

text: to clean and economical. These pieces, together with the
label: Paragraph

text: light fittings [103, 104] from the metal workshop, were
label: Paragraph

text: used to furnish the interior of the new Bauhaus buildings
label: Paragraph

text: [105]. By 1927 the ‘licensed’ industrial production of such
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus designs was in full swing, including the Breuer
label: Paragraph

text: furniture, the textured fabrics of Gunta Stadler-Stélzl and
label: Paragraph

text: her colleagues, and the elegant lamps and metalware of
label: Paragraph

text: Marianne Brandt. In that year too, Bauhaus typography
label: Paragraph

text: finally matured with Bayer’s austere layout and sans serif
label: Paragraph

text: type, about to become world famous for its exclusion of
label: Paragraph

text: upper-case letters. The year 1927 also saw the formation of
label: Paragraph

text: the architectural department, under the leadership of the
label: Paragraph

text: Swiss architect Hannes Meyer. A number of Breuer’s
label: Paragraph

text: prefabricated house designs of around this time reflect the
label: Paragraph

text: immediate impact of Meyer’s influence. Meyer brought with
label: Paragraph

text: him his talented colleague Hans Wittwer who, like him, had
label: Paragraph

text: been a member of the left-wing ABC group in Basle (see p.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Caption

label: Caption

text: Early in 1928 Gropius tendered his resignation to the
label: Paragraph

text: Mayor of Dessau and appointed Meyer as his successor. The
label: Paragraph

text: relative maturity of the institution, the unremitting attacks
label: Paragraph

text: on himself and the growth of his practice all convinced him
label: Paragraph

text: that it was time for a change. This move radically
label: Paragraph

text: transformed the Bauhaus and, paradoxically enough, given
label: Paragraph

text: the growing reactionary climate of Dessau, shifted its
label: Paragraph

text: orientation still further left and even closer to the Neue
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit position. For a variety of reasons Moholy-Nagy,
label: Paragraph

text: Breuer and Bayer followed Gropius’s lead and resigned. As
label: Paragraph

text: Moholy-Nagy indicated in his letter of resignation, he
label: Paragraph

text: disliked Meyer’s immediate insistence on the adoption of a
label: Paragraph

text: rigorous design method:
label: Title

text: | can’t afford a continuation on this specialized purely
label: Paragraph

text: objective and efficient basis - either productively or
label: Paragraph

text: humanly. ... Under a programme of increased technology |
label: Paragraph

text: can only continue if | have a technical expert as my aide.
label: Paragraph

text: For economic reasons this will never be possible.
label: Paragraph

text: Largely liberated from the inhibiting influence of
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius’s star faculty, Meyer was able to steer the work of
label: Paragraph

text: the Bauhaus towards a more ‘socially responsible’ design
label: Paragraph

text: programme. Simple, demountable, inexpensive, plywood
label: Paragraph

text: furniture came to the fore and a range of wallpaper was
label: Paragraph

text: produced. More Bauhaus designs were being manufactured
label: Paragraph

text: than ever before, although the emphasis was now placed on
label: Paragraph

text: social rather than aesthetic considerations. Meyer organized
label: Paragraph

text: the Bauhaus into four major departments: architecture (now
label: Paragraph

text: called ‘building’ for polemical reasons), advertising, wood
label: Paragraph

text: and metal production, and textiles. Supplementary scientific
label: Paragraph

text: courses, such as industrial organization and psychology,
label: Paragraph

text: were introduced into all departments, while the building
label: Paragraph

text: section shifted its emphasis to the economic optimization of
label: Paragraph

text: plan arrangements and to methods for the precise
label: Title

text: calculation of light, sunlight, heat loss/gain and acoustics.
label: Paragraph

text: This ambitious programme required an increase in faculty,
label: Paragraph

text: so that Wittwer’s appointment as a technician was soon
label: Paragraph

text: complemented by that of the architect-planner Ludwig
label: Paragraph

text: Hilberseimer, the engineer Alcar Rudelt, and a studio staff
label: Paragraph

text: comprising Alfred Arndt, Karl Fieger, Edvard Heiberg and
label: Paragraph

text: Mart Stam.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite Meyer’s concern to prevent the Bauhaus from
label: Paragraph

text: becoming a tool of left-wing party politics (he resisted an
label: Paragraph

text: attempt to form a student Communist cell), a remorseless
label: Paragraph

text: campaign against him finally forced the mayor to demand
label: Paragraph

text: his resignation. Meyer revealed his understanding of the
label: Paragraph

text: situation in an open letter to the mayor, Fritz Hesse:
label: Paragraph

text: lt was no use explaining [to you] that a ‘Bauhaus Dessau’
label: Paragraph

text: group of the German Communist Party was an impossibility
label: Paragraph

text: from the party organization point of view, no use my
label: Paragraph

text: assuring you that my political activities were of a cultural
label: Paragraph

text: and never a party character. ... Municipal politics wants you
label: Paragraph

text: to provide resounding Bauhaus successes, a brilliant
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus facade and a prestigious Bauhaus director.®
label: Paragraph

text: Municipal politics and German right-wing reaction in the
label: Paragraph

text: event required considerably more. They required the
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus closed and its sachlich fagade capped by an
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Aryan’ pitched roof. They required the Marxists impeached
label: Paragraph

text: and the liberal émigrés banished along with their obscure
label: Paragraph

text: art works - later to be designated as decadent. The
label: Paragraph

text: desperate attempt of the Mayor of Dessau to shore up the
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus, in the name of liberal democracy, through the
label: Paragraph

text: patriarchal directorship of Mies van der Rohe, was doomed
label: Paragraph

text: to failure. The Bauhaus remained in Dessau for but two
label: Paragraph

text: more years. In October 1932 what was left of it moved into
label: Paragraph

text: an old warehouse on the outskirts of Berlin, but by now the
label: Paragraph

text: floodgates of reaction were open, and nine months later the
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus was finally closed [106].
label: Paragraph

text: 106 Yamawaki, ‘The End of the Dessau Bauhaus’, collage, 1932.
