text: Chapter 15
label: Title

text: The New Objectivity:
label: Title

text: Germany, Holland and
label: Title

text: Switzerland 1923-33
label: Title

text: The expression Neue Sachlichkeit was in fact coined by me
label: Paragraph

text: in the year 1924. A year later came the Mannheim
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition which bore the same name. The expression ought
label: Paragraph

text: really to apply as a label to the new realism bearing a
label: Paragraph

text: socialist flavour. It was related to the general contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: feeling in Germany of resignation and cynicism after a
label: Paragraph

text: period of exuberant hopes (which had found an outlet in
label: Paragraph

text: expressionism). Cynicism and resignation are the negative
label: Paragraph

text: side of the Neue Sachlichkeit, the positive side expresses
label: Paragraph

text: itself in the enthusiasm for the immediate reality as a result
label: Paragraph

text: of a desire to take things entirely objectively on a material
label: Paragraph

text: basis without immediately investing them with ideal
label: Paragraph

text: implications. This healthy disillusionment finds its clearest
label: Paragraph

text: expression in Germany in architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: G.F. Hartlaub
label: Caption

text: Letter to Alfred H. Barr, Jr, July 19291
label: Caption

text: The term Sachlichkeit had been current in German cultural
label: Paragraph

text: circles long before 1924, when the art critic G.F. Hartlaub hit
label: Paragraph

text: upon the phrase ‘die neue Sachlichkeit’ (‘the new
label: Paragraph

text: objectivity’) to identify a post-war school of anti-
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionist painting. Sachlichkeit seems to have been first
label: Paragraph

text: used in an architectural context in a series of articles written
label: Paragraph

text: by Hermann Muthesius for the journal Dekorative Kunst
label: Caption

text: between 1897 and 1903. These articles attributed the
label: Paragraph

text: quality of Sachlichkeit to the English Arts and Crafts
label: Title

text: movement, particularly as manifest in the handicraft guilds
label: Paragraph

text: (such as that of Ashbee) and the early garden suburbs.
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit for Muthesius seems to have meant an
label: Paragraph

text: ‘objective’, functionalist and eminently yeoman attitude to
label: Paragraph

text: the design of objects, tending towards the reform of
label: Paragraph

text: industrial society itself. The term was given somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: different connotations by Heinrich W6lfflin, in his book,
label: Paragraph

text: Kunstgeschichtliche Grundbegriffe (The Principles of Art
label: Title

text: History) of 1915, when he wrote of the ‘linear’ vision of
label: Paragraph

text: 1800: ‘The new line comes to serve a new objectivity.’
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit had thus been qualified by the objective ‘new’
label: Paragraph

text: well before Hartlaub gave the title ‘Die Neue Sachlichkeit’ to
label: Paragraph

text: his 1925 exhibition in Mannheim of ‘Magical Realist’
label: Paragraph

text: painters, artists who since the First World War had depicted
label: Paragraph

text: both the appearance and the essence of an austere social
label: Paragraph

text: reality. Yet, as Fritz Schmalenbach has observed,
label: Paragraph

text: In reality, it was not the ‘objectivity’ of the new painting
label: Paragraph

text: which the term was intended in the first place and above all
label: Paragraph

text: to formulate, but something more universal underlying this
label: Paragraph

text: objectivity and of which it was the expression, a revolution
label: Paragraph

text: in the general mental attitude of the times, a general new
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit of thought and feeling.”
label: Paragraph

text: By the early 1930s, the expression had achieved wide
label: Paragraph

text: circulation and had come to connote, as Hartlaub had
label: Paragraph

text: intended, an unsentimental approach to the nature of
label: Paragraph

text: society. In 1926 the phrase was first used to designate a
label: Paragraph

text: ‘new-objective’ and explicitly socialist attitude to
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, although, as Schmalenbach has noted, this
label: Paragraph

text: transference did not derive from a community of style
label: Paragraph

text: between Magical Realism and the new architecture. The first
label: Paragraph

text: polemical post-1918 use of the word ‘object’ (Gegenstana)
label: Paragraph

text: in Germany came directly from a Russian source, and this
label: Paragraph

text: interjected into the development of Neue Sachlichkeit
label: Paragraph

text: architecture a specific set of sociopolitical connotations.
label: Paragraph

text: With the advent of the Russian Revolution in 1917 and
label: Paragraph

text: the military collapse of Germany in the following year,
label: Paragraph

text: Russia and Germany both found themselves confronted by
label: Paragraph

text: hostile Western powers. While the Soviet Union had to
label: Paragraph

text: contend with foreign intervention in the midst of a civil war
label: Paragraph

text: and with the deprivations of an economic blockade,
label: Paragraph

text: Germany was crippled by the punitive reparation
label: Paragraph

text: agreements of Versailles. The end of the Russian Civil War in
label: Paragraph

text: 1921 and the easing of foreign pressure induced Lenin to
label: Paragraph

text: proclaim his new Economic Policy, designed to attract
label: Paragraph

text: foreign capital into corporate partnership with the Soviet
label: Title

text: Union. Soon afterwards Germany ratified a series of earlier
label: Paragraph

text: negotiations with the Soviets, signing in 1922 the Treaty of
label: Paragraph

text: Rapallo, which re-established diplomatic relations and
label: Paragraph

text: pledged both countries to economic co-operation. With the
label: Paragraph

text: opening up of Russo-German relations at the end of 1921, El
label: Paragraph

text: Lissitzky and Ilya Ehrenburg came to Berlin as unofficial
label: Paragraph

text: cultural ambassadors of the Soviet Union, their immediate
label: Paragraph

text: task being to organize an official exhibition of Russian
label: Paragraph

text: avant-garde art. In May 1922 they published the first
label: Paragraph

text: number of a trilingual art review, Veshch/Gegenstand/Objet,
label: Paragraph

text: which featured on its cover two significant images: a
label: Paragraph

text: photograph of a snow plough locomotive, and the basic
label: Caption

text: icons of Suprematism, a black square and a black circle
label: Title

text: [107]. Veshch thus invoked the sachlich engineered object
label: Paragraph

text: and the Suprematist ‘non-objective’ world.
label: Paragraph

text: 107 Lissitzky, cover of Veshch/Gegenstand/Objet, 1922.
label: Caption

text: In 1923 Lissitzky became further involved with such
label: Paragraph

text: cultural propaganda, editing, with Hans Richter and Werner
label: Title

text: Graeff, the first issue of the Berlin magazine G (for
label: Paragraph

text: Gestaltung, ‘Form’) and demonstrating his architectural
label: Paragraph

text: ideas in the Prounenraum built for the Grosse Berliner
label: Paragraph

text: Kunstausstellung of that year. By his invented term ‘Proun’
label: Paragraph

text: (from Pro-Unovis, ‘for the school of the new art’), Lissitzky
label: Paragraph

text: evoked a new realm of art somewhere between painting and
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Of the Proun room, comprising a small
label: Caption

text: rectilinear cell, articulated and animated by a continuous
label: Paragraph

text: relief extending over the floor and ceiling, Lissitzky wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: The room ... is designed with elementary forms and
label: Paragraph

text: materials ... and with surfaces which are spread flat on to
label: Paragraph

text: the wall (colour) and surfaces which are perpendicular to
label: Paragraph

text: the wall (wood) ... the equilibrium which | seek to attain in
label: Paragraph

text: the room must be elementary and capable of change so
label: Paragraph

text: that it cannot be disturbed by a telephone or a piece of
label: Paragraph

text: standard furniture. The room is there for the human being -
label: Paragraph

text: not the human being for the room.?
label: Paragraph

text: Here, as on the cover of Veshch, Suprematist abstraction
label: Paragraph

text: is seen as being compatible with standard objects. Unlike
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright in the Larkin Building, Lissitzky did not
label: Paragraph

text: feel any need to restyle such manufactured objects as
label: Paragraph

text: telephones, although as early as 1920 he had rejected the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘anti-art’ utilitarianism proclaimed by Tatlin’s Productivist
label: Paragraph

text: Group. While he recognized that empirically engineered
label: Paragraph

text: (sachlich) structures could possess both spatial beauty and
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic significance, his Lenin Tribune of 1920 exemplified
label: Paragraph

text: his own subtle combination of engineering and
label: Paragraph

text: Suprematism: the basic structure consisted of an inclined
label: Paragraph

text: lattice girder, with Lenin photomontaged into position at its
label: Paragraph

text: crown, while the rostrum and the base were treated as
label: Paragraph

text: Elementarist forms, miraculously suspended in space. This
label: Paragraph

text: incongruous juxtaposition of abstract, non-objective
label: Paragraph

text: elements with empirically engineered form was to
label: Paragraph

text: characterize Lissitzky’s work until the early 1930s. Although
label: Paragraph

text: this synthesis was not strictly compatible with the notion of
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit, Lissitzky’s approach came to be a point of
label: Paragraph

text: departure for an international and ‘objective’ style of
label: Paragraph

text: building.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1922 the Dutch architect Mart Stam, then twenty-three
label: Paragraph

text: years old, went to work for Max Taut in Berlin. There, while
label: Paragraph

text: working independently on a competition for an office block
label: Title

text: in K6nigsberg, he met Lissitzky and for the rest of their stay
label: Paragraph

text: in Berlin the two men remained in close contact. In 1923
label: Paragraph

text: Lissitzky projected his ‘suspended’ office block for Moscow,
label: Paragraph

text: the ‘Wolkenbugel’, of which two separate versions were
label: Paragraph

text: eventually produced, one by Lissitzky alone and the other in
label: Paragraph

text: conjunction with Stam. When, late in 1923, Lissitzky
label: Paragraph

text: contracted tuberculosis and was forced to move to Zurich,
label: Paragraph

text: Stam went with him. During the next year they acquired a
label: Paragraph

text: Swiss following and in 1925, largely at Lissitzky’s instigation,
label: Paragraph

text: they formed the left-wing ABC group, centred on Basle. The
label: Paragraph

text: Swiss members of the group included Emil Roth of Zurich
label: Paragraph

text: and Hans Schmidt, Hannes Meyer and Hans Wittwer of
label: Paragraph

text: Basle. These men dedicated themselves to the design of
label: Paragraph

text: socially relevant buildings in accordance with scientific
label: Paragraph

text: principles.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1924 the ABC group began to propagate their views in
label: Paragraph

text: the magazine ABC: Beitrage zum Bauen, edited by Stam,
label: Caption

text: Schmidt and Lissitzky in collaboration with Roth. Although
label: Paragraph

text: they did not adopt the phrase ‘Neue Sachlichkeit’, they
label: Paragraph

text: nonetheless made their sachlich orientation explicit. The
label: Paragraph

text: first number contained Stam’s essay ‘Kollektive Gestaltung’
label: Paragraph

text: (‘Collective Design’) and Lissitzky’s seminal text, ‘Element
label: Paragraph

text: und Erfindung’ (‘Element and Invention’), in which he
label: Paragraph

text: outlined the duality of his approach, his synthesis of
label: Paragraph

text: functional structure with abstract elements. The second
label: Paragraph

text: issue introduced the group’s characteristic preoccupation
label: Paragraph

text: with normative standards, particularly in Paul Artaria’s essay
label: Paragraph

text: on the standardization of paper sizes, while Nos 2 and 3, a
label: Paragraph

text: double issue, included an essay on reinforced-concrete
label: Paragraph

text: construction, as exemplified in Le Corbusier’s ‘Dom-Ino’
label: Paragraph

text: system of 1914-15, as well as in Mies van der Rohe’s glass
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper projects of 1922 and Stam’s K6nigsberg block
label: Title

text: and extendable house proposals of the same date. By
label: Paragraph

text: dramatically comparing the relative weights and thicknesses
label: Paragraph

text: of metal and wooden window frames the magazine stressed
label: Paragraph

text: the intrinsic economy of modern building technology. Soon
label: Paragraph

text: afterwards the ABC group summed up its distaste for
label: Paragraph

text: massive architecture in the equation: ‘building x weight =
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality’.
label: Paragraph

text: With the publication of Meyer and Wittwer’s Petersschule
label: Paragraph

text: project for Basel of 1926 [109], the ABC group crystallized
label: Paragraph

text: its Functionalist and anti-monumental programme. Meyer’s
label: Paragraph

text: description reveals the ABC preoccupation with precise
label: Paragraph

text: calculation and social relevance, both to be made manifest
label: Paragraph

text: through light-weight technique:
label: Title

text: The ideal would be to skylight all the rooms ... and to set
label: Paragraph

text: aside a new site as part of a planned development of the
label: Paragraph

text: town. At present there appears to be no prospect of such
label: Paragraph

text: demands being realized and the following is a compromise
label: Paragraph

text: solution on the basis of the old building. ...
label: Paragraph

text: The School itself is raised as far as possible above the
label: Paragraph

text: ground to a level where there is sunlight and fresh air.
label: Paragraph

text: On the ground floor there is only the swimming bath and
label: Paragraph

text: the gymnasium in an enclosed space. The remaining area of
label: Paragraph

text: the playground is released for public traffic and parking.
label: Paragraph

text: Instead of a playground, two open spaces (suspended
label: Paragraph

text: platforms) and all the flat roofs of the building are assigned
label: Paragraph

text: to the children for recreation. ... The dead weight of the
label: Paragraph

text: building is used to carry on four cables the unsupported
label: Paragraph

text: stee/ structure of the two suspended platforms.‘
label: Paragraph

text: This steel-frame ‘Constructivist’ work recalls a Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: Vkhutemas project for a suspended restaurant, published by
label: Caption

text: Stam in the ABC magazine in 1924. The machine-like
label: Paragraph

text: furnishing of the Petersschule proposal, its steel windows,
label: Paragraph

text: aluminium doors, rubber floors and asbestos-cement
label: Title

text: cladding, anticipated the finishes proposed in the
label: Paragraph

text: Meyer/Wittwer entry for the League of Nations competition
label: Title

text: 108 H. Meyer and Wittwer, project for the League of Nations Building, Geneva,
label: Caption

text: 1926-27. (Compare Le Corbusier’s entry, p. 174.)
label: Caption

text: 109 H. Meyer and Wittwer, project for the Petersschule, Basel, 1926.
label: Caption

text: The claim by Meyer and Wittwer that their League of
label: Paragraph

text: Nations design was a scientific solution merits examination.
label: Paragraph

text: Structurally the assertion appears tenable, inasmuch as
label: Paragraph

text: their use of a standard module throughout would have been
label: Paragraph

text: highly suitable for prefabrication. As in Paxton’s Crystal
label: Paragraph

text: Palace, the modular extension or contraction of any section
label: Title

text: would have been possible without altering the basic order of
label: Paragraph

text: the building. The raising of the assembly building on
label: Paragraph

text: columns was more than adequately justified by the
label: Paragraph

text: provision of parking beneath. Meyer’s much-proclaimed
label: Paragraph

text: ‘objectivity’ also found reflection in the determination of the
label: Paragraph

text: auditorium profile through elaborate acoustical calculation.
label: Paragraph

text: But one may question the designer’s ‘objectivity’ when
label: Paragraph

text: elevator shafts are glazed (after Russian Constructivist
label: Paragraph

text: models) so as to reveal the ‘machine aesthetic’ in action.
label: Paragraph

text: Further doubts arise when one considers the undeniably
label: Paragraph

text: picturesque qualities of the composition. And although
label: Paragraph

text: Meyer claimed in his report that ‘our building symbolizes
label: Paragraph

text: nothing’, and that its objective indifference to the site lay
label: Paragraph

text: beyond aesthetic evaluation, he disclosed a certain
label: Paragraph

text: symbolizing intent when he wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: If the intentions of the League of Nations are sincere, then it
label: Paragraph

text: cannot possibly cram such a novel social organization into
label: Paragraph

text: the straitjacket of traditional architecture. No pillared
label: Paragraph

text: reception rooms for weary monarchs but hygienic work-
label: Paragraph

text: rooms for the busy representatives of their people. No back
label: Paragraph

text: corridors for backstairs diplomacy but open glazed rooms
label: Caption

text: for public negotiation of honest men.°

text: The latent symbolism of Meyer’s functional approach also
label: Paragraph

text: finds expression in his proposal to classify the users of the
label: Paragraph

text: assembly building by their parking position and to conduct
label: Paragraph

text: them inconspicuously from this point to their assigned
label: Paragraph

text: places in the auditorium above.
label: Paragraph

text: The ABC commitment to an objective approach to both
label: Paragraph

text: building and life arose out of a determination to serve only
label: Paragraph

text: collective necessity, of which Stam wrote in ‘Kollektive
label: Paragraph

text: Gestaltung’:
label: Title

text: The dualistic view of life - heaven and earth, good and evil -
label: Paragraph

text: the idea that there is an eternal inner conflict, has thrown
label: Paragraph

text: the emphasis on the individual and drawn him away from
label: Paragraph

text: society. ... The individual's isolation has led him to be
label: Paragraph

text: dominated by his emotions. But the modern outlook ... sees
label: Paragraph

text: life as the single reaching out of a single force. This means
label: Paragraph

text: that what is special and individual must yield to what is
label: Paragraph

text: common to all.®
label: Paragraph

text: Meyer expressed a similar view in his essay ‘Die neue
label: Paragraph

text: Welt’ (‘The New World’) published in Das Werk (1926):
label: Paragraph

text: The standardization of our requirements is shown by: the
label: Paragraph

text: bowler hat, bobbed hair, the tango, jazz, the co-op product,
label: Paragraph

text: the DIN standard size, etc. ... Trade union, co-operative,
label: Paragraph

text: Ltd., Inc., cartel, trust, and the League of Nations are the
label: Paragraph

text: forms in which today’s social conglomerations find
label: Paragraph

text: expression, and the radio and the rotary press are their
label: Paragraph

text: media of communication. Co-operation rules the world. The
label: Paragraph

text: community rules the individual.’
label: Paragraph

text: In 1925, Stam returned to Holland to work under L.C. van
label: Paragraph

text: der Vlugt, as job captain on the reinforced-concrete
label: Paragraph

text: mushroom-columned Van Nelle Factory, completed in 1929
label: Caption

text: [110, 111]. If the Meyer/Wittwer project for the League of
label: Caption

text: Nations can be regarded as the canonical work of the ABC
label: Paragraph

text: group, then the Van Nelle tobacco, tea and coffee packing
label: Paragraph

text: plant may be considered as the realization of similar
label: Paragraph

text: technical and aesthetic premises. As in the Meyer/Wittwer
label: Paragraph

text: design, the structure and the movement systems were
label: Paragraph

text: explicitly revealed, although naturally in a packing process
label: Paragraph

text: the prime movers were not elevators but glazed conveyors,
label: Paragraph

text: running diagonally between the curtain-walled packing
label: Paragraph

text: block and the canal warehouse. The significance of such an
label: Paragraph

text: open and dynamic expression was not lost on an observer
label: Paragraph

text: as sensitive as Le Corbusier, who saw it as a confirmation of
label: Paragraph

text: his own utopian socialist convictions, and wrote in 1931:
label: Paragraph

text: 110, 111 Brinkman and Van der Vlugt (architect in charge: Stam), Van Nelle
label: Caption

text: Factory, Rotterdam, 1927-29. Transverse section showing concrete mushroom
label: Caption

text: column construction, and exterior.
label: Paragraph

text: The road that runs into the factory is smooth, flat, bordered
label: Paragraph

text: with brown-tiled sidewalks, it is as clean and bright as a
label: Paragraph

text: dance floor. The sheer facades of the building, bright glass
label: Paragraph

text: and gray metal, rise up ... against the sky.... The serenity of
label: Paragraph

text: the place is total. Everything is open to the outside. And this
label: Paragraph

text: is of enormous significance to all those who are working, on
label: Paragraph

text: all eight floors inside. ... The Van Nelle tobacco factory in
label: Paragraph

text: Rotterdam, a creation of the modern age, has removed all
label: Paragraph

text: the former connotations of despair from that word
label: Paragraph

text: ‘proletarian’, And this deflection of the egoistic property
label: Paragraph

text: instinct towards a feeling for collective action leads to a
label: Paragraph

text: most happy result: the phenomenon of personal
label: Title

text: participation in every stage of the human enterprise.®
label: Paragraph

text: Despite Stam’s major participation in this design, the role
label: Paragraph

text: of Van der Vlugt cannot be discounted, particularly as he
label: Paragraph

text: later designed a work of comparable ‘objectivity’ without
label: Paragraph

text: the aid of Stam - his Existenzminimum Bergpolder flats,
label: Paragraph

text: built in Rotterdam in 1933. Nonetheless Stam must be
label: Paragraph

text: credited for introducing the polemic of objectivity into Dutch
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, for all that J.J.P. Oud had by this date already
label: Paragraph

text: built extensive amounts of flat-roofed Functionalist workers’
label: Paragraph

text: housing, most particularly his Kiefhoek Estate in Rotterdam,
label: Paragraph

text: under construction by 1925. In all this work Oud, as
label: Paragraph

text: Rotterdam City Architect, remained committed to Berlage’s
label: Paragraph

text: traditional urban precept of the street, regarded as an
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed, external room.
label: Caption

text: The full measure of Stam’s revolt against this tradition
label: Title

text: may be judged from his 1926 project for the Rokin district of
label: Paragraph

text: Amsterdam, where the continuity of the existing street is
label: Paragraph

text: vitiated by a continuously elevated office block, served by
label: Paragraph

text: escalator access and an aerial railway, the ground being
label: Paragraph

text: reserved for traffic parking, display and pedestrian
label: Paragraph

text: movement. This provocative yet economically questionable
label: Paragraph

text: project was typical of Stam’s preoccupation with the
label: Paragraph

text: subversion of the traditional urban pattern. It epitomized his
label: Paragraph

text: concept of the ‘open city’.
label: Paragraph

text: Stam’s extreme materialism served to isolate him from
label: Paragraph

text: the Functionalist Opbouw group, already established in
label: Paragraph

text: Rotterdam by 1920. Despite their commitment to the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Nieuwe Zakelijkheid’ (‘New Objectivity’), Opbouw members
label: Paragraph

text: such as Brinkman and Van der Vlugt and their industrialist
label: Paragraph

text: client Kees van der Leeuw sought to transcend ‘objectivity’
label: Paragraph

text: through a concern for universal ‘spiritual’ values. This they
label: Paragraph

text: expressed through their participation in the Dutch
label: Paragraph

text: theosophical movement and through their building, in 1930,
label: Paragraph

text: of a small retreat at Ommen for Krishnamurti and his
label: Paragraph

text: followers.
label: Paragraph

text: Similar spiritual aspirations were inherent in the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Johannes Duiker and Bernard Bijvoet, who departed from
label: Paragraph

text: their initial Wrightian manner in the boarded house that
label: Paragraph

text: they built at Aalsmeer in 1924 [112]. This asymmetrical,
label: Paragraph

text: monopitched house initiated the Zakelijkheid period of
label: Paragraph

text: Duiker’s career, a period that culminated in two reinforced-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete and glass structures of a decidedly Constructivist
label: Title

text: character - his Zonnestraal Sanatorium at Hilversum of
label: Paragraph

text: 1928 [113] and his Open Air School in Amsterdam of 1930
label: Caption

text: [114]. Despite his receptivity to the necessity for
label: Paragraph

text: programmatic distortion, as in the asymmetrical gymnasium
label: Paragraph

text: wing of the Open Air School, Duiker’s latent idealism found
label: Paragraph

text: expression in his preference for symmetrical organization.
label: Paragraph

text: Only at the end of his life did he begin to abandon his
label: Paragraph

text: characteristic ‘butterfly’ parti, in favour of the more serial,
label: Paragraph

text: aformal approach of Stam. This came with his Cineac
label: Paragraph

text: Cinema, Amsterdam, of 1934 and with the Gooiland Hotel,
label: Caption

text: Hilversum, completed in 1936 by Bijvoet after Duiker’s
label: Paragraph

text: death.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1928, having designed housing for the 1927
label: Paragraph

text: Weissenhofsiedlung at Stuttgart, Stam once again left
label: Paragraph

text: Holland for Germany, this time for Frankfurt, where he was
label: Paragraph

text: to work under the City Architect Ernst May on the Hellerhof
label: Paragraph

text: housing scheme - a residential sector within May’s large
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Neue Frankfurt’ development. Later that year, in the
label: Paragraph

text: curious company of Rietveld and Berlage, Stam represented
label: Paragraph

text: Holland at the foundation meeting of the Congrés
label: Caption

text: Internationaux d’Architecture Moderne (CIAM) at La Sarraz
label: Caption

text: in Switzerland. Soon after this meeting the Dutch Nieuwe
label: Paragraph

text: Zakelijkheid movement became consolidated through the
label: Paragraph

text: fusion of the Amsterdam Functionalist circle known as De 8
label: Title

text: with the Opbouw group. This formation, called De 8 en
label: Paragraph

text: Opbouw, remained active as the Dutch wing of CIAM until
label: Paragraph

text: The emergence of the Neue Sachlichkeit in Germany was
label: Paragraph

text: inseparable from the Weimar Republic’s crash housing
label: Paragraph

text: programme, initiated by the stabilization of the Rentenmark
label: Paragraph

text: in November 1923. In that year, Otto Haesler, the pioneer of
label: Paragraph

text: Zeilenbau (row) housing, completed the Siedlung
label: Paragraph

text: Italienischer Garten at Celle, near Hanover. Flat-roofed, with
label: Caption

text: polychromatic rendered facades, its modernistic formula
label: Paragraph

text: was to be adopted by Ernst May as a model for the first
label: Paragraph

text: units to be built in Frankfurt, in 1925. In 1924, in the
label: Paragraph

text: Siedlung Georgsgarten, his second work at Celle, Haesler
label: Caption

text: developed Theodor Fischer’s Alte Heide row housing model
label: Paragraph

text: of 1919 into a general system, the housing being laid out in
label: Paragraph

text: rows an optimum distance apart for sun penetration and
label: Paragraph

text: ventilation. This pattern, based on Heiligenthal’s rule (fig.
label: Paragraph

text: 119, p. 149) that the rows should be spaced no less than
label: Paragraph

text: twice their block height apart, became the normative Neue
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit formula, to be repeated in any number of
label: Paragraph

text: housing schemes realized in Germany between 1925 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1933. In such layouts, following Haesler’s example, south-
label: Paragraph

text: or west-facing living rooms open onto communal green
label: Paragraph

text: space. In Georgsgarten, Haesler added short south-facing
label: Paragraph

text: blocks to the terraces, which ran north-south, thereby
label: Paragraph

text: creating a series of L-shaped green courts, extending out
label: Paragraph

text: into adjacent allotments. These allotments were subdivided
label: Paragraph

text: into family plots for the cultivation of food (compare Adolf
label: Paragraph

text: Loos’s Heuberg Estate, Vienna, of 1926). At Georgsgarten,
label: Caption

text: Haesler also evolved the basic apartment type, of which he
label: Paragraph

text: was to design many variations throughout his career. His
label: Paragraph

text: typical apartment, stacked on three floors, with staircase
label: Paragraph

text: access in pairs, consisted of a living/dining room, a small
label: Paragraph

text: kitchen, a WC, and three to six bedrooms. The replacement
label: Paragraph

text: of the traditional Wohnktiche by a separate kitchen was a
label: Paragraph

text: radical departure in mass housing, and had the critical
label: Paragraph

text: social impact of shifting the household focus towards an
label: Paragraph

text: austerity version of the bourgeois ‘salon’. Haesler was to
label: Paragraph

text: upgrade his typical apartment in the Siedlung Friedrich
label: Paragraph

text: Ebert-Ring at Rathenow, built in 1929, where a separate
label: Paragraph

text: bathroom was introduced into the standard walk-up unit.
label: Paragraph

text: Both these early settlements were equipped with
label: Paragraph

text: communal facilities such as laundries, meeting rooms,
label: Paragraph

text: libraries, sports fields, etc., while Georgsgarten was further
label: Paragraph

text: provided with a kindergarten, a café and a hairdresser. The
label: Paragraph

text: sparse furnishing of these spaces, with their standard
label: Paragraph

text: Thonet furniture and bare light bulbs, relieved by carefully
label: Paragraph

text: detailed pipework and electrical conduit, synthesized the
label: Paragraph

text: typical Neue Sachlichkeit interior: cold and austere and yet
label: Paragraph

text: at the same time scintillating. Such qualities were echoed
label: Paragraph

text: on the exterior, where plain rendered surfaces, steel
label: Paragraph

text: windows, patent glazing and metal railing were combined to
label: Paragraph

text: create the universal sachlich syntax.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the national and ideological divergence of the
label: Paragraph

text: seventeen architects involved - including, from Germany
label: Paragraph

text: alone, figures as diverse as Behrens, Décker, Gropius,
label: Paragraph

text: Hilberseimer, Rading, Scharoun, Schneck, Mies van der Rohe
label: Caption

text: and the brothers Taut - this objective mode of expression
label: Paragraph

text: was more or less universally adopted in the Deutsche
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund Weissenhofsiedlung, erected outside Stuttgart in
label: Caption

text: In the subsequent development of his own work, Haesler
label: Paragraph

text: began to move away from the expression of the Sied/ung as
label: Paragraph

text: a corporate entity to the assertion of the terraced block as a
label: Paragraph

text: free-standing, infinitely repeatable unit. His initial plan of
label: Paragraph

text: 1929 for the Siedlung Rothenberg at Kassel is typical in this
label: Paragraph

text: respect, not only of his own work, but of most other Neue
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit housing of comparable date.
label: Paragraph

text: With May’s appointment as City Architect of Frankfurt in
label: Paragraph

text: 1925, the building of workers’ settlements began there on
label: Paragraph

text: an unprecedented scale. Yet, owing to his early training with
label: Paragraph

text: both Theodor Fischer in Munich and Raymond Unwin in
label: Paragraph

text: England, May’s rationalism was tempered by a feeling for
label: Paragraph

text: tradition. Whereas Haesler had created an indented but
label: Paragraph

text: continuous form at Georgsgarten and a serried open-ended
label: Paragraph

text: layout at Rothenburg, May (like Bruno Taut and Martin
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner in their contemporary Berlin-Britz housing) was
label: Paragraph

text: more concerned with the creation of self-contained urban
label: Paragraph

text: space, after the model of the traditional Prussian Anger
label: Paragraph

text: village. Thus May’s first work for Frankfurt, his
label: Paragraph

text: Bruchfeldstrasse development of 1925 [115], designed with
label: Paragraph

text: C.H. Rudloff, consisted of a large courtyard of ‘zigzag’
label: Paragraph

text: housing, enclosing an elaborately landscaped communal
label: Paragraph

text: garden. This unique layout, formally reminiscent of the Cité
label: Paragraph

text: Moderne designed by Victor Bourgeois for Brussels in 1922,
label: Paragraph

text: gave way to a more generalized approach in May’s master
label: Paragraph

text: plan for Neue Frankfurt of 1926 and in his Romerstadt,
label: Paragraph

text: Praunheim, Westhausen and Héhenblick settlements built as
label: Paragraph

text: parts of the Nidda Valley complex between 1925 and 1930.
label: Paragraph

text: 115 May and Rudloff, Bruchfeldstrasse Estate, Frankfurt, 1925.
label: Caption

text: The 15,000 units completed under May’s direction
label: Paragraph

text: account for more than ninety per cent of the housing built in
label: Paragraph

text: Frankfurt over the entire period. This impressive figure could
label: Paragraph

text: hardly have been achieved without May’s insistence on
label: Paragraph

text: efficiency and economy in both design and construction.
label: Paragraph

text: Such an objective approach, reinforced by the realities of
label: Paragraph

text: building costs, led inevitably to the formulation of
label: Paragraph

text: ‘existence-minimum’ space standards, which became the
label: Paragraph

text: contentious theme of the CIAM Frankfurt Congress of 1929.
label: Paragraph

text: In contrast to Le Corbusier’s ‘idealistic’ appeal for an
label: Paragraph

text: ‘existence-maximum’, May’s minimum standards were
label: Paragraph

text: dependent on the extensive use of ingenious built-in
label: Paragraph

text: storage, foldaway beds and above all on the development of
label: Paragraph

text: the ultra-efficient, laboratory-like kitchen, the Frankfurter
label: Paragraph

text: Kdche, designed by the architect G. SchUtte-Lihotzky [116].
label: Caption

text: Escalating costs finally led May to pioneer prefabricated
label: Paragraph

text: concrete slab construction, the so-called ‘May System’ being
label: Paragraph

text: used for the Praunheim and Hohenblick housing sectors
label: Paragraph

text: started in 1927.
label: Paragraph

text: 116 Schutte-Lihotzky, Frankfurter Ktiche, 1926.
label: Caption

text: Walter Gropius’s Bauhaus complex of 1926 and his Térten
label: Title

text: housing of 1928 [117] represent two stages in his gradual
label: Paragraph

text: conversion to the principles of the Neue Sachlichkeit. While
label: Paragraph

text: the ‘railroad’ layout of Térten reflected not only the
label: Paragraph

text: standardization of its units but also the linear process of
label: Paragraph

text: their prefabricated assembly by travelling crane, the Dessau
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus still amounted to a formalist composition of
label: Paragraph

text: asymmetrical elements. Its centrifugal, pinwheeling form,
label: Paragraph

text: reminiscent of De Stijl planning, had first been attempted by
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius and Meyer in their Chicago Tribune project of 1922
label: Paragraph

text: (fig. 99, p. 135) and reformulated by them as an
label: Paragraph

text: asymmetrical, horizontal distribution of masses in their
label: Paragraph

text: Erlangen Academy design of 1924. While the expression of a
label: Paragraph

text: comparable aesthetic in the Dessau Bauhaus necessitated
label: Paragraph

text: the wilful suppression of its structural frame, this was
label: Paragraph

text: compensated for by the sachlich detailing of its secondary
label: Paragraph

text: components, such as the radiators, the fenestration, the
label: Paragraph

text: balustrading and the light fittings. All the same, the ultimate
label: Paragraph

text: articulation of these large intersecting masses could not be
label: Paragraph

text: achieved without recourse to changes in colour or toa
label: Paragraph

text: shallow modelling of the facade that effectively recalled the
label: Paragraph

text: Neo-Classical modenature of the Gropius and Meyer
label: Title

text: Werkbund Building of 1914.
label: Caption

text: 117 Gropius, rationalized housing, Dessau-Térten, 1928. The site layout is
label: Caption

text: apparently organized around tower crane tracks.
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius’s most unequivocal Neue Sachlichkeit work was
label: Paragraph

text: his 1927 Total Theatre project, designed for Erwin Piscator’s
label: Paragraph

text: Volksbuhne in Berlin. Piscator had founded his Proletarian
label: Paragraph

text: Theatre in 1924 after the model of the Russian revolutionary
label: Paragraph

text: producer Vsevolod Meyerhold, whose October Theatre had
label: Paragraph

text: been proclaimed in Moscow in 1920. Thus Gropius’s
label: Paragraph

text: ‘PiscatorbUhne’ was largely designed to satisfy the
label: Paragraph

text: requirements of a biomechanical stage, to provide the space
label: Paragraph

text: for a ‘theatre of action’ as outlined by Meyerhold and his
label: Paragraph

text: Proletkult colleagues. The actor-acrobat was the ideal type
label: Paragraph

text: for such a theatre, in which a circus-like mechanized
label: Paragraph

text: performance was presented on an apron stage.
label: Paragraph

text: In his remarkably elegant and flexible solution, Gropius
label: Paragraph

text: provided Piscator with an auditorium which could be rapidly
label: Paragraph

text: transformed into any one of the three ‘classic’ stage forms,
label: Paragraph

text: the proscenium, the apron or the arena [118]. How this
label: Paragraph

text: provision was to be made, and to what theatrical ends, has
label: Paragraph

text: been best described in Gropius’s own words. In 1934, ata
label: Paragraph

text: conference in Rome, he stated:
label: Paragraph

text: 118 Gropius, Total Theatre project, 1927. View from above, and alternative plans
label: Caption

text: showing proscenium, apron and arena stages.
label: Caption

text: A complete transformation of the building occurs by turning
label: Paragraph

text: the stage platform and part of the orchestra through 180°.
label: Paragraph

text: Then the former proscenium stage becomes a central arena
label: Paragraph

text: entirely surrounded by rows of spectators! This can even be
label: Paragraph

text: done during the play. ... This attack on the spectator,
label: Paragraph

text: moving him during the play and unexpectedly shifting the
label: Paragraph

text: stage area, alters the existing scale of values, presenting to
label: Paragraph

text: the spectator a new consciousness of space and making him
label: Paragraph

text: participate in the action.2
label: Title

text: The convertible auditorium was also equipped with a
label: Paragraph

text: peripheral stage, on which the action could encircle the
label: Paragraph

text: audience. Alternatively this Spie/ring could be sealed off by
label: Paragraph

text: a segmented back-projection screen, for the display of
label: Paragraph

text: cinematic images complementary to the action on the
label: Paragraph

text: stage. A similar demountable cyclorama was also available
label: Paragraph

text: for the stage itself. The adaptability of this auditorium was
label: Paragraph

text: to be further augmented by the provision for acrobatic
label: Paragraph

text: display, just above the central arena. This aerial stage
label: Paragraph

text: would have had the effect of transforming Gropius’s egglike
label: Paragraph

text: void into a truly three-dimensional ‘play’ space, with the
label: Paragraph

text: audience either surrounding or surrounded by the action on
label: Paragraph

text: every side. Finally, the auditorium itself was a transparent
label: Paragraph

text: box, through which its basic structure could be easily
label: Paragraph

text: perceived, the open lattice of the ovoid roof being
label: Paragraph

text: ingeniously reconciled with the column nodes of its elliptical
label: Paragraph

text: ‘ring’ support (compare the Meyer/Wittwer League of
label: Paragraph

text: Nations auditorium).
label: Paragraph

text: Of approximately the same date as the Total Theatre
label: Paragraph

text: were the Haselhorst housing and Elberfield Hospital
label: Paragraph

text: projects, designed by Marcel Breuer and Gustav
label: Paragraph

text: Hassenpflug in 1928, and Hannes Meyer’s Trades Union
label: Paragraph

text: School, completed at Bernau in 1930. Breuer’s unrealized
label: Paragraph

text: Elberfeld project and Meyer’s Bernau school were
label: Paragraph

text: comparable sachlich works, inasmuch as they each
label: Paragraph

text: comprised asymmetrical sequences of repeated elements,
label: Paragraph

text: arranged in stepped formation, responding ‘simultaneously’
label: Paragraph

text: to the respective demands of the programme, orientation
label: Paragraph

text: and topography. Where the ward units of the sanatorium,
label: Paragraph

text: supported on a concrete superstructure, were set back to
label: Paragraph

text: provide a stepped sequence of sun decks, one for each
label: Paragraph

text: ward, the bulk of Meyer’s school was made up of three-
label: Paragraph

text: storey residential blocks, set back at their corners in such a
label: Paragraph

text: way as to break up the overall length. Both these buildings
label: Paragraph

text: were stepped in relation to gently sloping sites, and yet both
label: Paragraph

text: were freely and functionally related to their major atypical
label: Paragraph

text: elements, such as operating suites and x-ray units in the
label: Paragraph

text: sanatorium or lecture halls and common facilities in the
label: Paragraph

text: case of the school.
label: Paragraph

text: After his resignation from the Bauhaus at the end of
label: Paragraph

text: 1927, Gropius became increasingly involved with the
label: Paragraph

text: problem of housing [119], so that apart from the extensive
label: Paragraph

text: low-cost schemes that he designed and saw built in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s, in Dessau, Karlsruhe and Berlin, he became
label: Paragraph

text: theoretically concerned with the improvement of housing
label: Paragraph

text: standards and the development of the housing block into a
label: Title

text: classless system for community settlement. His unrealized
label: Paragraph

text: housing projects for Berlin of 1929 were a significant
label: Paragraph

text: advance over his previous work, offering higher living
label: Paragraph

text: standards and more comprehensive social services, while
label: Paragraph

text: his 1931 proposal for high-rise middle-class housing, on the
label: Paragraph

text: Wannsee near Berlin, constituted his first attempt at a self-
label: Paragraph

text: contained commune block equipped with a restaurant and a
label: Paragraph

text: gymnasium-solarium on the roof. Gropius’s views in the late
label: Caption

text: 1920s lay to the left of the Social Democratic position, as his
label: Paragraph

text: essay, Die Soziologischen Grundlagen der Minimalwohnung
label: Title

text: (The Sociological Bases of Minimum Housing), of 1929
label: Paragraph

text: makes clear. There he put forward the familiar socialist
label: Paragraph

text: argument in favour of state involvement in the provision of
label: Paragraph

text: housing:
label: Title

text: 119 Gropius, diagram presented at CIAM in 1930 demonstrating the increased
label: Paragraph

text: density and open space to be obtained by using high-rise slabs.
