text: official housing policy of the Weimar Republic, which,
label: Paragraph

text: between 1927 and 1931, was to subsidize publicly through
label: Paragraph

text: social insurance and property tax the design and erection of
label: Title

text: around one million dwellings - about seventy per cent of the
label: Paragraph

text: new housing starts made over the entire period.
label: Paragraph

text: Such an extensive welfare state system could not,
label: Paragraph

text: however, be maintained in the face of the stock market
label: Paragraph

text: collapse, which accompanied the world economic
label: Paragraph

text: depression of 1929. Foreign trade slumped, loans were
label: Paragraph

text: called in, and Germany was once more plunged into
label: Paragraph

text: economic and political chaos. This had the effect of
label: Paragraph

text: swinging the opinion of the country to the right, and with
label: Paragraph

text: this political shift the fate of the German Neue Sachlichkeit
label: Paragraph

text: architects was more or less sealed. Nothing remained for
label: Paragraph

text: them but to emigrate, and this they did, each according to
label: Paragraph

text: the colour of his political conviction [120]. May left for the
label: Paragraph

text: Soviet Union early in 1930, with a team of architects and
label: Paragraph

text: planners, to work on a master plan for a steel smelting plant
label: Paragraph

text: and town at Magnitogorsk in the Urals. His team included
label: Paragraph

text: Fred Forbat, Gustav Hassenpflug, Hans Schmidt, Walter
label: Caption

text: Schwagenscheidt and Mart Stam. At the same time Meyer
label: Paragraph

text: left to take up a teaching post in Moscow. Others, such as
label: Paragraph

text: Arthur Korn and Bruno Taut, followed suit in the early 1930s.
label: Paragraph

text: On the National Socialist seizure of power in 1933, the
label: Paragraph

text: remaining Neue Sachlichkeit architects of more moderate
label: Paragraph

text: persuasion were either forced to retire or compelled to leave
label: Paragraph

text: the country, Gropius and Breuer hurriedly migrating to
label: Paragraph

text: England in 1934, en route to the United States.
label: Paragraph

text: 120 An architect leaves Germany for the Soviet Union: cover of Das Neue
label: Caption

text: Frankfurt, Sept. 1930, devoted to ‘Germans building in the USSR’.
label: Caption

text: Chapter 16
label: Title

text: Modern Architecture in
label: Title

text: Czechoslovakia 1918-38
label: Title

text: Until recently, historical narratives often described twentieth
label: Paragraph

text: century art more in terms of the intentions of artists and
label: Paragraph

text: movements than anything else. For instance, there was an
label: Paragraph

text: uncritical acceptance of avant-garde internationalism’s self-
label: Paragraph

text: proclaimed vision of the world as a homogenous continuum
label: Paragraph

text: developing in a linear progression, a vision that disregarded
label: Paragraph

text: regional idiosyncrasies. In reality, however, internationalism
label: Paragraph

text: frequently devolved into centralism, in which the center
label: Paragraph

text: exerted authority over its peripheries while overlooking their
label: Paragraph

text: contributions ... Czechoslovakia between the wars can serve
label: Paragraph

text: as a case Study for these exchanges for three reasons. First,
label: Paragraph

text: it was located in the middle of Europe and its cultural
label: Paragraph

text: heritage included contributions from Western and Eastern,
label: Paragraph

text: as well as southern and northern Europe. Second, it was a
label: Paragraph

text: multi-national country, whose population consisted of
label: Paragraph

text: several ethnic groups, notably Czechs, Slovaks, Germans,
label: Paragraph

text: Hungarians, Ruthenians, and Jews. Third, it was the only
label: Paragraph

text: democracy in Central Europe which, thanks to relatively
label: Paragraph

text: favorable political and economic circumstances, allowed
label: Paragraph

text: artists to further develop their ideas throughout the 1930s.
label: Paragraph

text: Jaroslav Andel
label: Title

text: Introduction to the Art of the Avant-Garde in Czechoslovakia
label: Title

text: The two most salient aspects of the Czech avant garde in
label: Paragraph

text: the 20th century were the Poetism of the Devétsil
label: Paragraph

text: association of artists and the Constructivism advocated by
label: Title

text: the Left Front political movement. The latter was culturally
label: Paragraph

text: complex, poised between the Neue Sachlichkeit (New
label: Paragraph

text: Objectivity) of German-speaking Europe and the more
label: Paragraph

text: utopian drive of Russian Constructivism as projected by
label: Paragraph

text: Soviet avant-garde architects between 1918 and 1932. The
label: Paragraph

text: key Czech critic mediating between Devétsil and
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivism was the polemical polymath Karel Teige.
label: Paragraph

text: During the first half of the 1920s, Teige was an advocate of
label: Paragraph

text: the ‘picture poem’ collages of Poetism, an amalgam of
label: Paragraph

text: graphics, typography and photography that veered into
label: Paragraph

text: kinetic art and film. Jaroslav Andel informs us that another
label: Paragraph

text: key figure at this time was Zdenék PeSanek, whose drive
label: Paragraph

text: towards a more dynamic form of art split the Devétsil
label: Paragraph

text: movement into its surrealist and functionalist factions, with
label: Paragraph

text: the latter tending towards Constructivism in architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: This last line was advanced by the journal Stavba
label: Paragraph

text: (Construction), edited by Oldrich Stary and Oldrich Tyl of the
label: Paragraph

text: Architects’ Club and strongly supported by the young
label: Paragraph

text: architect Ludvik Kysela. The second number of this
label: Paragraph

text: magazine, published in 1923, featured a Constructivist
label: Paragraph

text: Manifesto signed by Stary, Kysela, Bedrich Feuerstein and
label: Paragraph

text: the ubiquitous Teige, who was the journal’s managing editor.
label: Paragraph

text: This polemical publication was paralleled by the anthology
label: Paragraph

text: Zivot II (Life I, edited by the architect Jaromir Krejcar
label: Caption

text: [121]. Krejcar straddled the divide between the so-called
label: Paragraph

text: emotional functionalism of Devétsil and the objective
label: Title

text: functionalism of Stavba, the adherents of which included
label: Paragraph

text: Kysela, Tyl, Jan Koula, FrantiSek Libra and Josef Fuchs.
label: Paragraph

text: Mediating between the two factions, Krejcar arrived at his
label: Paragraph

text: own emotionally expressive form of Constructivism, as
label: Paragraph

text: found in the villa he designed for the writer Vladislav
label: Caption

text: Vancura on a site near Prague [123]. The brilliance of this
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivist design, which was realized in a somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: modified form, can only be fully appreciated if one
label: Paragraph

text: compares it to the Neo-Plastic formalism of the Rietveld-
label: Paragraph

text: Schréder House of 1924 and the Purism of Le Corbusier’s
label: Title

text: Maison Cook of 1926. Krejcar’s talent for invention in both
label: Paragraph

text: technical and tectonic terms remained with him throughout
label: Paragraph

text: his career, as seen in the high-tech, steel-framed Czech
label: Paragraph

text: State Pavilion that he built for the Paris World Exhibition of
label: Paragraph

text: 1937 [122], quite distinct from the significant pavilions
label: Paragraph

text: designed for the same event by Alvar Aalto, Le Corbusier
label: Caption

text: and Junzo Sakakura.
label: Paragraph

text: 121 Zivot if, 1922.
label: Caption

text: 122 Krejcar, Czech State Pavilion, Paris World Exhibition of 1937.
label: Caption

text: 123 Krejcar, Villa for Vancura, Zoraslav, near Prague, 1923.
label: Caption

text: Krejcar and Kysela both came to the fore with medium-
label: Paragraph

text: rise commercial structures in the second half of the 1920s,
label: Paragraph

text: the former through his Olympic and Jednota buildings and
label: Paragraph

text: the latter through his Lindt and Bata department stores,
label: Paragraph

text: erected next to each other in the centre of Prague (see pp.
label: Caption

text: 285-86). Where Kysela’s Lindt store of 1926 incorporated a
label: Paragraph

text: top-lit arcade running through the block, and his Bata store
label: Paragraph

text: of 1929 was faced with large sheets of plate glass -
label: Paragraph

text: spanning from floor to ceiling - Krejcar’s Olympic building
label: Caption

text: had a basement cinema and his Jednota building featured
label: Paragraph

text: an elegant café dansant at ground level. This combination of
label: Paragraph

text: commercial space with cultural amenities testifies to the
label: Paragraph

text: urbanity of the Prague bourgeoisie.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the most notable aspects of the Czech
label: Paragraph

text: architectural avant garde between the wars was the wide
label: Paragraph

text: scope of their production, with regard not only to the broad
label: Paragraph

text: spectrum of the society they served, but also to their
label: Paragraph

text: conceptual and technological capacity. They were able not
label: Paragraph

text: only to conceive but also to construct the necessary
label: Paragraph

text: institutional needs of a rapidly modernizing society, such as
label: Paragraph

text: we find in Josef Havliéek and Karel Honzik’s Pensions
label: Paragraph

text: Institute of 1933 and in Adolf Bens and Josef Kfiz’s
label: Title

text: Electricity Board Headquarters of 1935 [124, 125]. This was
label: Paragraph

text: an atrium office complex built around a seven-storey, top-lit
label: Paragraph

text: monumental stair hall. This last was roofed by a concrete
label: Paragraph

text: slab, perforated by inset cylindrical glass lenses. It
label: Paragraph

text: employed the same technique as the reinforced-concrete
label: Paragraph

text: shell vaults covering the city arcades. This is surely the lost
label: Paragraph

text: art of ferro cemento, perfected by Czech architects and
label: Paragraph

text: engineers of the interwar period. A typical arcade in this
label: Paragraph

text: regard was Oldrich Tyl’s Bondy Passage completed in Prague
label: Paragraph

text: two years before.
label: Paragraph

text: 124, 125 Bens and Kfiz, Electricity Board Headquarters, Prague, 1926-35. Aerial
label: Caption

text: perspective, and top-lit galleria and stair hall of main entrance.
label: Caption

text: In 1928, one year after the Deutsche Werkbund’s
label: Paragraph

text: Weissenhof housing exhibition in Stuttgart, a similar
label: Paragraph

text: demonstration of prototypical residences was constructed in
label: Paragraph

text: Brno and the comparable Baba housing estate was built
label: Paragraph

text: outside Prague. It is characteristic of the period that the
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch architect Mart Stam also designed a house in the
label: Paragraph

text: Baba estate. However, this impulse to build housing stock
label: Paragraph

text: comparable to that of the Weimar Republic was undercut by
label: Paragraph

text: the worldwide stock market crash of 1929. This fundamental
label: Paragraph

text: change in the cultural and political climate was summed up
label: Paragraph

text: in 1993 by Alena Kubova when she wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: In its quest for a social function for architecture, the
label: Paragraph

text: development of which would define its modernity, European
label: Paragraph

text: avant-garde theory had come up with the ideal of minimal
label: Paragraph

text: housing. Teige thought instead of modernity in terms of
label: Paragraph

text: Class struggle ... This became clear in 1929 when Devetsil
label: Paragraph

text: was replaced by Leva fronta (Left Front) and Czech
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism became intimately bound up with housing.
label: Paragraph

text: The Left Front dispatched its plans for a collective dwelling
label: Paragraph

text: to CIAM’s third congress.
label: Paragraph

text: The one Czech architect whose work transcended the
label: Paragraph

text: post-1929 economic and ideological crisis was the architect-
label: Paragraph

text: cum-industrial designer Ladislav Zak, whose Villa Hain of
label: Paragraph

text: 1933 [126] was realized for an aeronautical engineer. As
label: Paragraph

text: Vladimir Slapeta has remarked, Zak’s work as an architect
label: Paragraph

text: went beyond the principles of instrumental economic
label: Paragraph

text: production to engage in a more comprehensive approach to
label: Paragraph

text: psycho-physiological needs. According to Slapeta, this
label: Paragraph

text: approach was inspired by Honzik’s theory of biotechnics and
label: Paragraph

text: seems to have been close to similar theories then being
label: Paragraph

text: advanced by Moholy-Nagy. The Villa Hain was as ergonomic
label: Paragraph

text: as possible within the confines of a tight prism, combining
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal double-glazed windows with built-in ventilation
label: Caption

text: grilles and integrated curtain tracks. The cantilevered
label: Caption

text: sunbathing terrace at the end of the house was equipped
label: Paragraph

text: with roller blinds in order to shade it from the sun and to
label: Paragraph

text: ensure privacy. This house may be seen as a kind of
label: Paragraph

text: technological architecture parlante, as the cantilevered
label: Paragraph

text: viewing platform on top of the house enabled the engineer
label: Paragraph

text: to view his prototypes taking off from Prague’s Ruzyné
label: Paragraph

text: Airport, completed to the designs of Adolf Bens between
label: Paragraph

text: 1932 and 1934. The other prolific architect of the period
label: Paragraph

text: based in Brno was the local architect Bohuslav Fuchs, whose
label: Paragraph

text: most accomplished work was the narrow fronted Hotel Avion
label: Paragraph

text: built in the downtown of the city in 1928. The modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of Brno rivalled that of Prague, as was made
label: Paragraph

text: evident in the Brno Exhibition of 1928, designed in part by
label: Paragraph

text: Fuchs.
label: Paragraph

text: 126 Zak, Villa Hain, Prague, 1933.
label: Caption

text: Situated to the political left of Fuchs was the architect Jiri
label: Paragraph

text: Kroha, who, as a professor of architecture at Brno Technical
label: Paragraph

text: University, was affiliated with Karel Teige’s Marxist-
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivist position. This led him to initiate a programme
label: Paragraph

text: of rigorous research within the architectural school. With
label: Paragraph

text: Hannes Meyer and Mart Stam coming frequently to Brno and
label: Paragraph

text: Kroha visiting the Soviet Union in 1930, contacts between
label: Paragraph

text: the Czech progressive figures, the German left and the
label: Paragraph

text: Soviet Union were particularly intense during this period. All
label: Paragraph

text: this activity led to the foundation in 1933 of the Czech
label: Paragraph

text: Union of Socialist Architects, with Kroha at its head. In the
label: Paragraph

text: following year Kroha’s radical politics led to his
label: Paragraph

text: imprisonment for publically proclaiming Communist
label: Title

text: sympathies. Although he was restored to his professorship
label: Paragraph

text: in 1937, he was arrested yet again in 1938 by the Gestapo
label: Paragraph

text: and sent to a concentration camp soon after the annexation
label: Paragraph

text: of Czechoslovakia by Germany in that year.
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 17
label: Title

text: De Stijl: the Evolution and
label: Title

text: Dissolution of Neo-
label: Title

text: Plasticism 1917-31
label: Title

text: 1 There is an old and a new consciousness of the age. The
label: Caption

text: old one is directed towards the individual. The new one is
label: Paragraph

text: directed towards the universal. The conflict of the
label: Paragraph

text: individual and the universal is reflected in the World War
label: Paragraph

text: as well as in art today.
label: Paragraph

text: 2 The war is destroying the old world with all that it
label: Title

text: contains: the pre-eminence of the individual in every
label: Paragraph

text: field.
label: Paragraph

text: 3 The new art has revealed the substance of the new
label: Title

text: consciousness of the age: an equal balance between the
label: Title

text: universal and the individual.
label: Paragraph

text: 4 The new consciousness is ready to be realized in
label: Caption

text: everything, including the everyday things of life.
label: Paragraph

text: 5 Traditions, dogmas and the pre-eminence of the
label: Title

text: individual (the natural) stand in the way of this
label: Paragraph

text: realization.
label: Paragraph

text: 6 Therefore the founders of Neo-Plasticism call on all those
label: Caption

text: who believe in the reform of art and culture to destroy
label: Paragraph

text: those things which prevent further development, just as
label: Paragraph

text: in the new plastic art, by removing the restriction of
label: Paragraph

text: natural forms, they have eliminated what stands in the
label: Paragraph

text: way of the expression of pure art, the extreme
label: Paragraph

text: consequence of every concept of art.
label: Paragraph

text: From the first manifesto of De Stijl, 1918+
label: Caption

text: The Dutch De Stijl movement, which lasted for barely
label: Paragraph

text: fourteen years, was centred about the work of three men:
label: Paragraph

text: the painters Piet Mondrian and Theo van Doesburg and the
label: Paragraph

text: cabinetmaker and architect Gerrit Rietveld. The other artists
label: Paragraph

text: who constituted the original formation, in 1917, under Van
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg’s leadership - the painters Bart van der Leck,
label: Paragraph

text: Georges Vantongerloo and Vilmos Huszar, the architects
label: Caption

text: J.J.P. Oud, Robert van ‘t Hoff and Jan Wils, and the poet
label: Title

text: Antony Kok - soon departed in their various ways from the
label: Paragraph

text: main line of the movement. All, however, with the exception
label: Paragraph

text: of Van der Leck and Oud, were signatories of the eight-point
label: Paragraph

text: manifesto published in 1918 in the second issue of the
label: Paragraph

text: magazine De Stijl. This, the first manifesto of De Stijl, called
label: Paragraph

text: for a new balance between the individual and the universal
label: Title

text: and for the liberation of art from both the constraints of
label: Paragraph

text: tradition and the cult of individuality. Influenced as much by
label: Paragraph

text: the philosophical thought of Spinoza as by the Dutch
label: Paragraph

text: Calvinistic background from which they all came, they
label: Paragraph

text: sought a culture that would transcend the tragedy of the
label: Paragraph

text: individual by its emphasis on immutable laws. This universal
label: Paragraph

text: and utopian aspiration was succinctly summed up by their
label: Paragraph

text: aphorism: ‘The object of nature is man, the object of man is
label: Paragraph

text: style.’
label: Paragraph

text: By 1918 the movement had already been influenced by
label: Paragraph

text: the Neo-Platonic, not to say theosophical, philosophy of the
label: Paragraph

text: mathematician M.H. Schoenmaekers, whose major works,
label: Paragraph

text: Het nieuwe Wereldbeeld (‘The New Image of the World’) and
label: Paragraph

text: Beeldende Wiskunde (‘The Principles of Plastic
label: Title

text: Mathematics’), had been published in 1915 and 1916
label: Paragraph

text: respectively. Schoenmaeker’s metaphysical world view was
label: Paragraph

text: complemented by more concrete attitudes and concepts
label: Paragraph

text: drawn directly from Berlage and Wright, the latter having
label: Paragraph

text: become known in Europe through the publication in 1910
label: Paragraph

text: and 1911 of the two famous Wasmuth volumes dedicated to
label: Paragraph

text: his work. Berlage, on the other hand, was more influential
label: Paragraph

text: for his sociocultural criticism, and it was from him that the
label: Paragraph

text: De Stijl artists had appropriated the title ‘The Style’, which
label: Paragraph

text: he in turn had probably taken from Gottfried Semper’s
label: Paragraph

text: critical study, Der Stil in den technischen und tektonischen
label: Title

text: Kdnsten oder praktische Asthetik, of 1860.
label: Caption

text: The appearance of Mondrian’s first post-Cubist
label: Paragraph

text: compositions, consisting largely of broken horizontal and
label: Paragraph

text: vertical lines, coincided with his return to Holland from Paris
label: Paragraph

text: in July 1914 and with the period that he and Van der Leck
label: Paragraph

text: spent in Laren in almost daily contact with Schoenmaekers.
label: Paragraph

text: From Schoenmaekers came the term ‘Neo-Plasticism’ - from
label: Paragraph

text: his coinage of nieuwe beelding - and from him too came the
label: Paragraph

text: restriction of the palette to the primary colours of whose
label: Paragraph

text: cosmic significance he wrote in Het nieuwe Were/dbeela:
label: Paragraph

text: ‘The three principal colours are essentially yellow, blue and
label: Paragraph

text: red. They are the only colours existing ... yellow is the
label: Paragraph

text: movement of the ray (vertical) ... blue is the contrasting
label: Paragraph

text: colour to yellow (horizontal firmament) ... red is the mating
label: Paragraph

text: of yellow and blue.’ Elsewhere in the same text he provided
label: Paragraph

text: a comparable justification for limiting Neo-Plastic expression
label: Paragraph

text: to orthogonal elements: ‘The two fundamental, complete
label: Paragraph

text: contraries which shape our earth and all that is of the earth
label: Paragraph

text: are: the horizontal line of power, that is the course of the
label: Paragraph

text: earth around the sun, and the vertical, profoundly spatial
label: Paragraph

text: movement of rays that originate in the centre of the sun.’
label: Paragraph

text: For all his formative influence Schoenmaekers played no
label: Paragraph

text: direct role in the aesthetic evolution of De Stijl. This was left
label: Paragraph

text: to Van der Leck and Vantongerloo, whose very
label: Paragraph

text: independence as artists caused them to split from Van
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg at an early date. Yet without their contributions it
label: Paragraph

text: is doubtful if the characteristic De Stijl aesthetic could have
label: Paragraph

text: been formulated with such clarity in so short a time. It is
label: Paragraph

text: obvious, for example, that Van Doesburg’s famous
label: Paragraph

text: abstraction The Cow, of 1916, owes much to Van der Leck,
label: Paragraph

text: while Vantongerloo’s sculpture /nterrelation of Masses, of
label: Paragraph

text: 1919, clearly anticipates the general massing of the Van
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg and Cor van Eesteren house projects of 1923. And
label: Paragraph

text: even the aloof Mondrian, in the last number of De Stij/
label: Paragraph

text: (1932) - dedicated to the memory of Van Doesburg -
label: Caption

text: brought himself to acknowledge his debt to Van der Leck,
label: Paragraph

text: for the latter’s use, as early as 1917, of saturated primary
label: Paragraph

text: colours.
label: Paragraph

text: The years 1914-16 had seen Mondrian in Laren, in
label: Paragraph

text: frequent contact with Schoenmaekers. During this period he
label: Paragraph

text: wrote his basic theoretical text, ‘De Nieuwe Beelding in de
label: Paragraph

text: Schilderkunst’ (‘Neo-Plasticism in Painting’), which appeared
label: Paragraph

text: in 1917 in the first issue of De Stijl. The enforced seclusion
label: Paragraph

text: and meditation of the war years brought Mondrian to a new
label: Paragraph

text: point of departure. His work now comprised a series of
label: Paragraph

text: compositions consisting of floating, rectangular, coloured
label: Paragraph

text: planes. Both he and Van der Leck had now arrived at what
label: Paragraph

text: they each considered to be a totally new and pure plastic
label: Paragraph

text: order, with the much younger Van Doesburg closely
label: Paragraph

text: following their lead. Yet while Mondrian remained involved in
label: Paragraph

text: planar compositions set within the ‘shallow space’ of the
label: Paragraph

text: picture plane, as represented in his Composition with
label: Paragraph

text: Coloured Planes on a White Ground of 1917, Van der Leck
label: Caption

text: and Van Doesburg were to arrive at a linear structuring of
label: Paragraph

text: the picture plane itself, through the use of narrow bars of
label: Paragraph

text: colour, etched in a white field. Van Doesburg’s The Cow
label: Caption

text: dates from this period, as does his Rhythm of a Russian
label: Paragraph

text: Dance of 1918, both works being influenced by Van der
label: Paragraph

text: Leck.
label: Paragraph

text: The first architectural work associated with De Stijl was
label: Paragraph

text: created by Robert van ‘t Hoff, who had seen Wright’s work
label: Paragraph

text: on a visit to America before the war and in 1916 built a
label: Paragraph

text: remarkably convincing Wrightian villa on the outskirts of
label: Paragraph

text: Utrecht. Aside from this pioneering reinforced-concrete
label: Paragraph

text: house at Huis ter Heide and a number of less elegant
label: Paragraph

text: Wrightian works by Wils, there was comparatively little
label: Paragraph

text: architectural activity in the early phases of De Stijl. Oud,
label: Paragraph

text: who became City Architect to Rotterdam in 1918, at the age
label: Paragraph

text: of twenty-eight, was never wholeheartedly affiliated with
label: Paragraph

text: the movement. After abstaining from the 1918 manifesto he
label: Paragraph

text: took pains to establish his artistic independence. He seems
label: Paragraph

text: to have found in the compositions of the Austrian architect
label: Paragraph

text: Josef Hoffmann a means for detaching himself from the
label: Paragraph

text: more ‘structural’ interests of De Stijl. The single exception to
label: Paragraph

text: this was his Purmerend factory project of 1919, wherein
label: Paragraph

text: Neo-Plastic elements were rather diffidently applied to an
label: Paragraph

text: otherwise bland assembly of masses. There was, in effect,
label: Paragraph

text: very little Neo-Plastic architecture before 1920, when it
label: Paragraph

text: made its first appearance in the work of Rietveld. Prior to
label: Paragraph

text: 1915 Rietveld had taken courses with the architect PJ.
label: Paragraph

text: Klaarhamer, who, while never associated with De Stijl, was
label: Paragraph

text: collaborating at the time with Van der Leck.
label: Paragraph

text: The year 1917 saw the creation of the famous Red/Blue
label: Paragraph

text: chair designed by Rietveld. This simple piece of furniture,
label: Paragraph

text: based on a traditional folding bed-chair, provided the first
label: Paragraph

text: occasion for a projection of the Neo-Plastic aesthetic into
label: Paragraph

text: three dimensions. In its form, the bars and planes of Van der
label: Paragraph

text: Leck’s compositions were now realized as articulated and
label: Paragraph

text: displaced elements in space. Aside from its articulation, the
label: Paragraph

text: chair was distinguished by its exclusive use of primary
label: Paragraph

text: colours in conjunction with a black frame - a combination
label: Paragraph

text: which, with grey and white added, was to become the
label: Paragraph

text: standard colour scheme of the De Stijl movement. Its
label: Paragraph

text: structure enabled Rietveld to demonstrate an open
label: Paragraph

text: architectonic organization that was manifestly free from the
label: Paragraph

text: influence of Wright. It still predicated a Gesamtkunstwerk,
label: Paragraph

text: but one that was free from the biological analogies of 19th-
label: Paragraph

text: century synthetic Symbolism, that is to say, from Art
label: Paragraph

text: Nouveau.
label: Paragraph

text: Few, if any, of Rietveld’s colleagues could have foreseen
label: Paragraph

text: the full potential of the modest pieces of furniture that he
label: Paragraph

text: went on to design between 1918 and 1920 - the buffet
label: Paragraph

text: [127], baby cart and wheelbarrow which, as direct
label: Paragraph

text: developments of the Red/Blue chair, were assembled from
label: Paragraph

text: rectilinear wooden spars and planes, simply dowelled
label: Paragraph

text: together. None of these pieces, however, fully anticipated
label: Paragraph

text: the architectural environment attempted by Rietveld in his
label: Paragraph

text: design for Dr Hartog’s study, built at Maarssen in 1920. In
label: Paragraph

text: this work each piece of furniture, including the suspended
label: Paragraph

text: light fitting, appeared to be ‘elementarized’, and the effect
label: Paragraph

text: was to imply, like Mondrian’s later paintings, an infinite
label: Paragraph

text: series of coordinates in space.
label: Paragraph

text: 127 Rietveld, buffet, 1919.
label: Caption

text: In many respects Van Doesburg embodied the movement
label: Paragraph

text: in himself, for by 1921 the composition of the group had
label: Paragraph

text: radically altered. Van der Leck, Vantongerloo, Van ‘t Hoff,
label: Caption

text: Oud, Wils and Kok had all by then disassociated themselves
label: Paragraph

text: from De Stijl, while Mondrian had re-established himself as
label: Paragraph

text: an independent artist in Paris. This Dutch defection
label: Paragraph

text: convinced Van Doesburg that it was necessary to proselytize
label: Paragraph

text: for De Stijl abroad. The fresh blood brought into the
label: Paragraph

text: movement in 1922 reflected his international orientation. Of
label: Paragraph

text: the new members of that year only one was Dutch, the
label: Paragraph

text: architect Van Eesteren; the others were Russian and
label: Paragraph

text: German - the architect, painter and graphic designer El
label: Title

text: Lissitzky and the film-maker Hans Richter. It was at Richter’s
label: Paragraph

text: invitation that Van Doesburg first visited Germany in 1920,
label: Paragraph

text: and from this visit followed an invitation from Gropius to
label: Paragraph

text: come to the Bauhaus in the following year. Van Doesburg’s
label: Paragraph

text: brief stay in Weimar in 1921 engendered a crisis within the
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus, the repercussions of which have since become
label: Paragraph

text: legendary, for the impact of his ideas on the students and
label: Paragraph

text: faculty was both immediate and marked. Even Gropius who,
label: Paragraph

text: under the circumstances, had reason to be apprehensive,
label: Paragraph

text: designed in 1923 a suspended light for his own study which
label: Paragraph

text: displayed an undeniable affinity to the Rietveld fitting
label: Paragraph

text: designed for Hartog.
label: Caption

text: Of greater importance for the second phase of the De
label: Paragraph

text: Stijl movement, lasting until 1925, was Van Doesburg’s
label: Paragraph

text: meeting with Lissitzky. Just two years before this meeting
label: Paragraph

text: Lissitzky had developed his own form of Elementarist
label: Paragraph

text: expression, evolved in collaboration with Kasimir Malevich
label: Paragraph

text: at the Suprematist school in Vitebsk. Although Russian and
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch Elementarism had quite independent origins - the
label: Paragraph

text: one Suprematist, the other Neo-Plastic - Van Doesburg’s
label: Paragraph

text: work was transformed. After 1921, under the impact of
label: Paragraph

text: Lissitzky’s Proun compositions, both he and Van Eesteren
label: Paragraph

text: began to project, as axonometric drawings, a series of
label: Paragraph

text: hypothetical architectural constructs, each comprising an
label: Paragraph

text: asymmetrical cluster of articulated planar elements
label: Caption

text: suspended in space about a volumetric centre. Van
label: Caption

text: Doesburg invited Lissitzky to become a member of De Stijl
label: Paragraph

text: and in 1922 Lissitzky’s abstract-typographic children’s fable
label: Paragraph

text: of 1920, ‘The Story of Two Squares’, appeared in the pages
label: Paragraph

text: of the magazine. It is significant that the magazine itself
label: Paragraph

text: changed its format at this juncture, Van Doesburg replacing
label: Paragraph

text: the frontal composition and woodcut logotype designed by
label: Paragraph

text: Huszar with an asymmetrical, Elementarist layout and a
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Constructivist’ logo.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1923 Van Doesburg and Van Eesteren managed to
label: Paragraph

text: crystallize the architectural style of Neo-Plasticism in an
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition of their work, at L€once Rosenberg’s Paris gallery,
label: Caption

text: ‘L’Effort moderne’. This show was an immediate success
label: Paragraph

text: and in consequence was restaged elsewhere in Paris and
label: Paragraph

text: later in Nancy. Apart from the axonometric studies
label: Paragraph

text: previously mentioned it included their project for a house for
label: Paragraph

text: Rosenberg and two other seminal works, their study for the
label: Paragraph

text: interior of a university hall and their project for an artist’s
label: Caption

text: house [128].
label: Paragraph

text: 128 Van Eesteren and Van Doesburg, preparing for the Rosenberg exhibition in
label: Caption

text: Paris, 1923, with a model of their ‘artist’s house’.
label: Caption

text: Meanwhile in Holland, Huszar and Rietveld collaborated
label: Paragraph

text: on the design for a small room to be built as part of the
label: Paragraph

text: Grosse Berliner Kunstausstellung of 1923, Huszar designing
label: Caption

text: the environment and Rietveld the furniture, including the
label: Paragraph

text: important Berlin chair. Simultaneously, Rietveld began to
label: Paragraph

text: work on the design and detailing of the Schréder-Schrader
label: Caption

text: House in Utrecht [L29, 130]. This house, built at the end of
label: Caption

text: a late 19th-century terrace, was in many respects a
label: Paragraph

text: realization of Van Doesburg’s Naar een beeldende
label: Paragraph

text: architectuur (‘16 points of a Plastic Architecture’), published
label: Paragraph

text: at the time of its completion. It fulfilled his prescription,
label: Paragraph

text: being elementary, economic and functional, unmonumental
label: Paragraph

text: and dynamic; anti-cubic in its form and anti-decorative in its
label: Paragraph

text: colour. Its main living level on the top floor, with its open
label: Paragraph

text: ‘transformable plan’, exemplified, despite its traditional
label: Paragraph

text: brick and timber construction, his postulation of a dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: architecture liberated from the encumbrance of load-
label: Paragraph

text: bearing walls and the restrictions imposed by pierced
label: Title

text: openings. Van Doesburg’s eleventh point reads like an
label: Paragraph

text: idealized description of the house:
label: Paragraph

text: 129, 130 Rietveld, Schréder-Schrader House, Utrecht, 1924. Plans and general
label: Caption

text: view.
label: Paragraph

text: The new architecture is anti-cubic, that is to say, it does not
label: Paragraph

text: try to freeze the different functional space cells in one
label: Paragraph

text: closed cube. Rather, it throws the functional space cells (as
label: Paragraph

text: well as the overhanging planes, balcony volumes, etc.)
label: Paragraph

text: centrifugally from the core of the cube. And through this
label: Paragraph

text: means, height, width, depth, and time (/.e. an imaginary
label: Paragraph

text: four-dimensional entity) approaches a totally ‘new plastic
label: Paragraph

text: expression in open spaces’. In this way architecture acquires
label: Paragraph

text: a more or less floating aspect that, so to speak, works
label: Paragraph

text: against the gravitational forces of nature.?
label: Paragraph

text: The third and last phase of De Stijl activity, lasting from
label: Paragraph

text: 1925 to 1931, was announced by a dramatic rift between
label: Paragraph

text: Mondrian and Van Doesburg over the latter’s introduction of
label: Paragraph

text: the diagonal into his paintings, in a series of ‘counter-
label: Paragraph

text: compositions’ that he had completed in 1924. By now the
label: Paragraph

text: initial unity had been lost, as much by Van Doesburg’s
label: Paragraph

text: incessant polemical activity as by his arbitrary modification
label: Paragraph

text: of the Neo-Plastic canon. From his association with Lissitzky
label: Paragraph

text: he had come to regard social structure and technology as
label: Paragraph

text: among the prime determinants of form, irrespective of any
label: Paragraph

text: concerns he might still entertain for the De Stijl ideal of
label: Paragraph

text: universal harmony. By the mid-1920s he realized that
label: Paragraph

text: universality could, by itself, only produce an artificially
label: Paragraph

text: delimited culture, which by virtue of its antipathy to
label: Paragraph

text: everyday objects could only be against the initial De Stijl
label: Paragraph

text: concern - subscribed to even by Mondrian - for the
label: Paragraph

text: unification of art and life. Van Doesburg seems to have
label: Paragraph

text: opted for a Lissitzkian solution to this dilemma, whereby
label: Paragraph

text: both the environmental scale and status of the object
label: Paragraph

text: should determine the degree to which it may be
label: Paragraph

text: manipulated in accordance with an abstract conception.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus, while furniture and equipment as produced by the
label: Paragraph

text: society at large ought to be accepted as the ready-made
label: Paragraph

text: objects of the culture, the built environment itself could and
label: Paragraph

text: indeed should still be made to conform to a higher order.
label: Paragraph

text: Van Doesburg and Van Eesteren gave an idealized
label: Paragraph

text: version of this position in their essay Vers une construction
label: Paragraph

text: collective (‘Towards a Collective Construction’), published in
label: Paragraph

text: 1924, in which they tended towards a more objective and
label: Paragraph

text: technical solution to the problem of architectural synthesis:
label: Paragraph

text: We must realize that life and art are no longer separate
label: Paragraph

text: domains. That is why the ‘idea’ of ‘art’ as an illusion
label: Paragraph

text: separate from real life must disappear. The word ‘Art’ no
label: Paragraph

text: longer means anything to us. In its place we demand the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of our environment in accordance with creative
label: Title

text: laws based upon a fixed principle. These laws, following
label: Paragraph

text: those of economics, mathematics, technique, sanitation,
label: Paragraph

text: etc., are leading to a new plastic unity.?
label: Paragraph

text: Later one reads, under the seventh point of the
label: Paragraph

text: manifesto, the essence of the spirit that was to inform Van
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg’s last major work, the Café L’Aubette of 1928:
label: Paragraph

text: We have established the true place of colour in architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and we declare that painting, without architectural
label: Paragraph

text: construction (that is, easel painting), has no further reason
label: Paragraph

text: for existence.*
label: Paragraph

text: Rietveld had little association with Van Doesburg after
label: Paragraph

text: 1925. Nonetheless, his work developed in a similar
label: Paragraph

text: direction, away from the Elementarism of the Schréder
label: Paragraph

text: House and his early orthogonal furniture, towards more
label: Paragraph

text: ‘objective’ solutions arising out of the application of
label: Paragraph

text: technique. Rietveld started in this direction by redesigning
label: Paragraph

text: the seats and backs of his chairs as curved planes, not only
label: Paragraph

text: because such shapes were more comfortable, but also
label: Paragraph

text: because they possessed greater structural strength. This led
label: Paragraph

text: naturally to the technique of wood lamination and from
label: Paragraph

text: there it was but a step, once the inhibiting Neo-Plastic
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic had been relinquished, to moulding a chair out of
label: Paragraph

text: a single sheet of plywood. Rietveld’s two-storey chauffeur’s
label: Caption

text: house, built in Utrecht in 1927, was largely the product of a
label: Paragraph

text: similar approach, where despite - or rather because of - its
label: Paragraph

text: use of advanced technique, little of the original De Stijl
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic was left. Instead of primary colours, the exposed
label: Paragraph

text: steel frame and concrete panels were painted black, and the
label: Paragraph

text: surface of the panels themselves overpainted with a grid of
label: Paragraph

text: white squares. Removed from Van Doesburg’s conception of
label: Caption

text: anti-cubic space as set out in his ‘16 Points of a Plastic
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture’, it was more determined by technique than by
label: Paragraph

text: any drive towards universal form.
label: Paragraph

text: The Café L’Aubette in Strasbourg, designed in 1928,
label: Paragraph

text: comprised a sequence of two large public rooms and
label: Paragraph

text: ancillary spaces set within an 18th-century shell. These
label: Paragraph

text: rooms were designed and realized by Van Doesburg in
label: Paragraph

text: association with Hans Arp and Sophie Tauber Arp. While Van
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg controlled the general theme each artist was free
label: Paragraph

text: to design his or her own room. With the single exception of
label: Paragraph

text: Arp’s mural, all the rooms were modulated by shallow
label: Paragraph

text: abstract wall reliefs, colour, lighting and equipment being
label: Paragraph

text: integrated into each composition. Van Doesburg’s own
label: Paragraph

text: scheme [131] was, in effect, a reworking of his 1923 project
label: Paragraph

text: for a university hall, in which a diagonal Elementarist
label: Paragraph

text: composition had been deliberately imposed on all the
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces of a partially orthogonal space. Van Doesburg’s
label: Paragraph

text: interior in L’'Aubette was similarly dominated and distorted
label: Paragraph

text: by the lines of a huge diagonal relief or counter-
label: Paragraph

text: composition, passing obliquely over all the internal surfaces.
label: Paragraph

text: This fragmentation through relief - an extension of
label: Paragraph

text: Lissitzky’s Proun room approach of 1923 - was
label: Paragraph

text: complemented by the fact that the furnishing was free of
label: Paragraph

text: any Elementarist pieces. In their place Van Doesburg
label: Paragraph

text: designed ‘standard’ bentwood chairs and elsewhere
label: Caption

text: employed extremely objective detailing. The tubular railing
label: Paragraph

text: throughout was simply welded, while the main lighting
label: Paragraph

text: consisted of bare light bulbs bracketed off two metal tubes
label: Paragraph

text: suspended from the ceiling.
label: Paragraph

text: 131 Van Doesburg, Café L’Aubette, Strasbourg, 1928-29.
label: Caption

text: L’Aubette, finished in 1929, is the last Neo-Plastic
label: Paragraph

text: architectural work of any significance. Thereafter those
label: Paragraph

text: artists who were still affiliated with De Stijl, including Van
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg and Rietveld, came increasingly under the
label: Paragraph

text: influence of the Neue Sachlichkeit and thereby subject to
label: Paragraph

text: the cultural values of international socialism. Van
label: Caption

text: Doesburg’s own house, built in Meudon about 1929, barely
label: Paragraph

text: fulfils any of the sixteen points of his 1924 manifesto. It is
label: Paragraph

text: simply a utilitarian studio, of rendered reinforced-concrete
label: Paragraph

text: frame and block construction, superficially resembling the
label: Paragraph

text: type of artisan dwelling that had already been projected by
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier in the early 1920s. For fenestration Van
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg chose to use the standard French industrial sash,
label: Paragraph

text: and for furniture he designed his own version of a sachlich
label: Paragraph

text: chair in tubular steel. By 1930 the Neo-Plastic ideal of
label: Paragraph

text: uniting the arts and transcending the division of art and life
label: Paragraph

text: had been relinquished and returned to its origins in abstract
label: Paragraph

text: painting, to the art concert of Van Doesburg’s counter-
label: Paragraph

text: compositions hung on the walls of his studio in Meudon. Yet
label: Paragraph

text: Van Doesburg’s conscious concern for a universal order
label: Paragraph

text: remained alive, for in his last polemic, Manifeste sur I’art
label: Paragraph

text: concret (1930), he wrote: ‘If the means of expression are
label: Paragraph

text: liberated from all particularity, they are in harmony with the
label: Paragraph

text: ultimate end of art, which is to realize a universal language.’
label: Paragraph

text: How these means were to become liberated in the case of
label: Paragraph

text: applied art, such as furniture and equipment, was not made
label: Paragraph

text: clear. A year later, at the age of forty-eight, Van Doesburg
label: Paragraph

text: died in a sanatorium in Davos, Switzerland, and with him
label: Paragraph

text: died the moving force of Neo-Plasticism. Of the original De
label: Paragraph

text: Stijl artists only Mondrian seems to have remained
label: Paragraph

text: committed to the strict principles of the movement, to the
label: Paragraph

text: orthogonal and the primary colours which were the
label: Paragraph

text: constituent elements of his mature work. With these he
label: Paragraph

text: continued to represent the harmony of an unrealizable
label: Paragraph

text: utopia. As he wrote in his Plastic and Pure Plastic Art (1937):
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Art is only a substitute while the beauty of life is still
label: Paragraph

text: deficient. It will disappear in proportion, as life gains in
label: Paragraph

text: equilibrium.’
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 18
label: Title

text: Le Corbusier and the
label: Title

text: Esprit Nouveau 1907-31
label: Title

text: You employ stone, wood and concrete, and with these
label: Paragraph

text: materials you build houses and palaces. That is
label: Paragraph

text: construction. Ingenuity is at work.
label: Paragraph

text: But suddenly you touch my heart, you do me good, |am
label: Paragraph

text: happy and | say: ‘This is beautiful.’ That is Architecture. Art
label: Paragraph

text: enters in. My house is practical. | thank you, as | might
label: Paragraph

text: thank railway engineers or the telephone service. You have
label: Paragraph

text: not touched my heart. But suppose that walls rise towards
label: Paragraph

text: heaven in such a way that |am moved. | perceive your
label: Paragraph

text: intentions. Your mood has been gentle, brutal, charming or
label: Paragraph

text: noble, The stones you have erected tel/ me so. You fix me to
label: Paragraph

text: the place and my eyes regard it. They behold something
label: Paragraph

text: which expresses a thought. A thought which reveals itself
label: Paragraph

text: without word or sound, but solely by means of shapes which
label: Paragraph

text: stand in a certain relationship to one another. These shapes
label: Paragraph

text: are such that they are clearly revealed in light. The
label: Paragraph

text: relationships between them have not necessarily any
label: Paragraph

text: reference to what is practical or descriptive. They are a
label: Paragraph

text: mathematical creation of your mind. They are the language
label: Paragraph

text: of Architecture. By the use of raw materials and starting
label: Paragraph

text: from conditions more or less utilitarian, you have
label: Paragraph

text: established certain relationships which have aroused my
label: Paragraph

text: emotions. This is Architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier
label: Title

text: Vers une architecture, 19231
label: Caption

text: The absolutely central and seminal role played by Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier in the development of 20th-century architecture is
label: Paragraph

text: sufficient cause for us to examine his early development in
label: Paragraph

text: detail; and the fundamental significance of his achievement
label: Paragraph

text: only becomes apparent when it is seen against the
label: Paragraph

text: extremely varied and intense influences to which he was
label: Paragraph

text: subject in the decade between his first house, built in La
label: Paragraph

text: Chaux-de-Fonds in 1905, when he was eighteen, and his last
label: Paragraph

text: works realized there in 1916, one year before moving to
label: Paragraph

text: Paris. Above all it seems necessary to remark on the distant
label: Paragraph

text: Albigensian background of his otherwise Calvinist family, on
label: Paragraph

text: that half-forgotten but latent Manichean view of the world
label: Paragraph

text: which may well have been the origin of his ‘dialectical’ habit
label: Paragraph

text: of mind. | am referring to that ever-present play with
label: Paragraph

text: opposites - with the contrast between solid and void,
label: Paragraph

text: between light and dark, between Apollo and Medusa - that
label: Paragraph

text: permeates his architecture and is evident as a habit of mind
label: Paragraph

text: in most of his theoretical texts.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier was born in 1887 in the Swiss watchmaking
label: Paragraph

text: town of La Chaux-de-Fonds, which is situated in the Jura,
label: Paragraph

text: close to the French frontier. One of the prime images of his
label: Paragraph

text: adolescence must have been this highly rational gridded
label: Paragraph

text: industrial town that had been rebuilt after its destruction by
label: Paragraph

text: fire some twenty years before his birth. During his training
label: Paragraph

text: as a designer-engraver at the local school of arts and crafts,
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Edouard Jeanneret (as he then was) became
label: Paragraph

text: involved in his late teens in the last phases of the Arts and
label: Paragraph

text: Crafts movement. The Jugendstil manner of his first house,
label: Paragraph

text: the Villa Fallet of 1905, was a crystallization of all that he
label: Paragraph

text: had been taught by his master, Charles L’Eplattenier,
label: Paragraph

text: director of the cours supérieur at the applied art school in La
label: Caption

text: Chaux-de-Fonds. L’Eplattenier’s own point of departure had
label: Paragraph

text: been Owen Jones, whose book The Grammar of Ornament
label: Paragraph

text: (1856) was a definitive compendium of decorative art.
label: Paragraph

text: L’Eplattenier aimed to create a native school of applied art
label: Paragraph

text: and building for the Jura region and, after Jones, he taught
label: Paragraph

text: his students to derive all ornament from their immediate
label: Paragraph

text: natural environment. The vernacular type and décor of the
label: Paragraph

text: Villa Fallet were exemplary in this respect: its overall form
label: Paragraph

text: was essentially a variation on the wood and stone
label: Paragraph

text: farmhouses of the Jura, while its decorative elements were
label: Paragraph

text: derived from the flora and fauna of the region.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite his admiration for Owen Jones, for the Budapest-
label: Paragraph

text: trained L’Eplattenier the cultural centre of Europe remained
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna, and his one ambition was that his prime pupil
label: Paragraph

text: should be apprenticed there to Josef Hoffmann. Accordingly,
label: Paragraph

text: in the autumn of 1907 Le Corbusier was dispatched to
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna. He was cordially received, but he seems to have
label: Paragraph

text: rejected Hoffmann’s offer of work and with it the sophistries
label: Paragraph

text: of the now classicized Jugendstil. Certainly the designs that
label: Paragraph

text: he made in Vienna for further houses, to be completed in La
label: Paragraph

text: Chaux-de-Fonds in 1909, show little trace of Hoffmann’s
label: Paragraph

text: influence. This apparent disaffection with the Jugendstil in
label: Paragraph

text: its decline was encouraged by a meeting with Tony Garnier
label: Paragraph

text: in Lyons, in the winter of 1907, just as Garnier was
label: Paragraph

text: beginning to amplify his 1904 project for a Cité Industrielle.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s utopian socialist sympathies and his
label: Paragraph

text: susceptibility to a typological - not to say Classical -
label: Paragraph

text: approach to architecture certainly date from this meeting,
label: Paragraph

text: about which he wrote: ‘This man knew that the imminent
label: Paragraph

text: birth of a new architecture depended on social phenomena.
label: Paragraph

text: His plans displayed a great facility. They were the
label: Paragraph

text: consequence of one hundred years of architectural
label: Title

text: evolution in France.’
label: Paragraph

text: The year 1907 may be regarded as the turning point of
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s life, for in that year he not only met Garnier,
label: Paragraph

text: but he also made a crucial visit to the Charterhouse of Ema,
label: Paragraph

text: in Tuscany. There he experienced for the first time the living
label: Paragraph

text: ‘commune’ which was to become the socio-physical model
label: Paragraph

text: for his own reinterpretation of the utopian socialist ideas
label: Paragraph

text: that he had inherited in part from L’Eplattenier and in part
label: Paragraph

text: from Garnier. Later he was to describe the Charterhouse as
label: Paragraph

text: an institution in which ‘an authentic human aspiration was
label: Paragraph

text: fulfilled: silence, solitude, but also daily contact with men.’
label: Paragraph

text: In 1908, Le Corbusier obtained part-time employment
label: Paragraph

text: with Auguste Perret in Paris, whose reputation had already
label: Paragraph

text: been made through his ‘domestication’ of the reinforced-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete frame in his apartment block built in the Rue
label: Caption

text: Franklin in 1904. The fourteen months that Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: spent in Paris afforded him a totally new outlook on both life
label: Paragraph

text: and work. Aside from receiving a basic training in
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete technique the capital gave him the
label: Paragraph

text: chance to broaden his knowledge of French Classical
label: Paragraph

text: culture, by visiting the museums, libraries and lecture halls
label: Title

text: of the city. At the same time, much to the disapproval of
label: Paragraph

text: L’Eplattenier, he became convinced through his contact with
label: Paragraph

text: Perret, that béton armé was the material of the future. Aside
label: Paragraph

text: from its malleable monolithic nature, durability and inherent
label: Paragraph

text: economy, Perret valued the concrete frame as an agent for
label: Paragraph

text: resolving the age-old conflict between the structural
label: Paragraph

text: authenticity of the Gothic and the Humanist values of
label: Paragraph

text: Classical form.
label: Paragraph

text: The impact of all these diverse experiences may be
label: Paragraph

text: gauged from the project that he made for his alma mater,
label: Paragraph

text: on his return to La Chaux-de-Fonds in 1909. This building,
label: Paragraph

text: evidently conceived in reinforced concrete, consisted of
label: Paragraph

text: three stepped tiers of artists’ studios, each with its own
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed garden, arranged around a central communal
label: Paragraph

text: space covered by a pyramidal glass roof. This free
label: Paragraph

text: adaptation of the Carthusian cell form, with its connotations
label: Paragraph

text: of communality, was the first instance in which Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpreted a received type in order to accommodate the
label: Paragraph

text: programme of an entirely new type. Such typological
label: Paragraph

text: transformations, with their spatial and ideological
label: Paragraph

text: references, were to become an intrinsic part of his working
label: Paragraph

text: method. Since this synthetic procedure was impure by
label: Paragraph

text: definition, it was inevitable that his works should become
label: Paragraph

text: charged with references to a number of different
label: Paragraph

text: antecedents at once. For all that this process may at times
label: Paragraph

text: have been partly unconscious, the art school must be seen
label: Paragraph

text: as being as much an heir to Godin's Familistére of 1856 as it
label: Paragraph

text: was a reinterpretation of Ema. Nevertheless Ema was to
label: Paragraph

text: remain embedded in Le Corbusier’s imagination as an
label: Paragraph

text: image of harmony to be reinterpreted innumerable times,
label: Paragraph

text: first on a large scale in his ‘Immeuble-Villa’ project of 1922
label: Paragraph
