text: Le Corbusier went to Germany in 1910 ostensibly to
label: Paragraph

text: further his knowledge of reinforced-concrete technique, but
label: Paragraph

text: while he was there he was commissioned by the art school
label: Paragraph

text: of La Chaux-de-Fonds to study the state of decorative art.
label: Paragraph

text: This undertaking, which resulted in a book, brought him into
label: Paragraph

text: contact with all the major figures of the Deutsche
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund, above all with Peter Behrens and Heinrich
label: Paragraph

text: Tessenow, the two artists who were to exercise a strong
label: Paragraph

text: influence on two of his later works in La Chaux-de-Fonds -
label: Paragraph

text: the Villa Jeanneret Pére of 1912 and the Scala Cinema of
label: Paragraph

text: 1916. Aside from this, the Werkbund contact made him
label: Paragraph

text: conscious of the achievements of modern production
label: Title

text: engineering, the ships, automobiles and aircraft that were to
label: Paragraph

text: form the substance of his polemical essay ‘Des Yeux qui ne
label: Paragraph

text: voient pas.’ At the end of the year, after five months in the
label: Paragraph

text: office of Behrens, where he would certainly have met Mies
label: Paragraph

text: van der Rohe, he left Germany to take up a teaching post at
label: Paragraph

text: La Chaux-de-Fonds, offered him by L’Eplattenier. Before
label: Paragraph

text: returning to Switzerland, however, he made an extensive
label: Paragraph

text: tour of the Balkans and Asia Minor, and henceforth Ottoman
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was to be a muted but decided influence on his
label: Paragraph

text: work. This much is evident from his lyrical record of the trip,
label: Paragraph

text: his Voyage d’Orient of 1913.
label: Paragraph

text: The five years prior to 1916 shaped the orientation of his
label: Paragraph

text: future career in Paris. His final break with L’Eplattenier and
label: Paragraph

text: his simultaneous rejection of Frank Lloyd Wright, whose
label: Paragraph

text: work he would have known from the Wasmuth volumes of
label: Paragraph

text: 1910-11, enabled him to remain open to the possibilities for
label: Paragraph

text: rationalized production in reinforced concrete. In 1913 he
label: Paragraph

text: established his own office in La Chaux-de-Fonds, ostensibly
label: Paragraph

text: to specialize in béton armé.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1915, in conjunction with his boyhood friend, the Swiss
label: Paragraph

text: engineer Max du Bois, he evolved two ideas that were to
label: Paragraph

text: inform his development throughout the 1920s - his
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpretation of the Hennebique frame as the Maison
label: Paragraph

text: Dom-Ino, which was to be the structural basis of most of his
label: Paragraph

text: houses up to 1935, and the ‘Villes Pilotis’, a city projected as
label: Paragraph

text: being built on piles, the concept of the elevated street
label: Paragraph

text: evidently deriving from Eugéne Hénard’s ‘Rue Future’ of
label: Paragraph

text: The year 1916 saw the culmination of his early career in
label: Paragraph

text: La Chaux-de-Fonds with the building of the Villa Schwob,
label: Paragraph

text: which was an extraordinary synthesis of all that he had
label: Paragraph

text: experienced so far. It was, above all else, an elaborate
label: Paragraph

text: assimilation of the spatial potential of the Hennebique
label: Paragraph

text: system, permitting its author to impose on a skeleton
label: Paragraph

text: structure stylistic elements drawn from Hoffmann, Perret
label: Paragraph

text: and Tessenow. There was even an erotic evocation of a
label: Paragraph

text: seraglio, from which the building took its nickname of ‘Villa
label: Paragraph

text: Turque’. At the same time, it was the first occasion on which
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier conceived a house in honorific terms, that is,
label: Paragraph

text: as a palace. The alternately wide and narrow bay system
label: Paragraph

text: and the symmetrical organization of the plan bestowed on
label: Paragraph

text: the Villa Schwob a structure that was undeniably Palladian.
label: Paragraph

text: Similar Classical connotations were indicated in the text that
label: Paragraph

text: accompanied its publication in L’Esprit Nouveau in 1921,
label: Paragraph

text: wherein Julien Caron wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier had to resolve a delicate problem which was
label: Paragraph

text: contingent upon making a pure work of architecture, as
label: Paragraph

text: postulated by a design in which the masses were of a
label: Paragraph

text: primary geometry, the square and the circle. Such
label: Paragraph

text: speculation in building a house has rarely been attempted
label: Paragraph

text: except during the Renaissance.”
label: Paragraph

text: For the first time Le Corbusier employed ‘regulating
label: Paragraph

text: lines’, that Classical device used to maintain proportional
label: Paragraph

text: control over the facade, manifest for instance in the
label: Paragraph

text: disposition of the fenestration in accordance with the golden
label: Paragraph

text: section. In the years that followed, this ‘house-palace’
label: Paragraph

text: theme saw its fulfilment in Le Corbusier’s work on two
label: Paragraph

text: different scales, with related but separate socio-cultural
label: Paragraph

text: connotations. The first was the free-standing individual
label: Paragraph

text: bourgeois villa of Palladian precedent, as exemplified in the
label: Paragraph

text: masterly houses of the late 1920s; the second was the
label: Paragraph

text: collective dwelling, conceived as a Baroque palace that
label: Paragraph

text: could evoke through its ‘set-back’ plan the ideological
label: Paragraph

text: connotations of a phalanstery.
label: Paragraph

text: Soon after he moved to Paris in October 1916 to
label: Paragraph

text: establish a practice, Le Corbusier had the good fortune to be
label: Paragraph

text: introduced by Auguste Perret to the painter Amédée
label: Paragraph

text: Ozenfant, with whom he was to evolve the all-embracing
label: Paragraph

text: machine asthetic of Purism. Grounded in Neo-Platonic
label: Paragraph

text: philosophy, Purism extended its discourse to cover all forms
label: Paragraph

text: of plastic expression from salon painting to product design
label: Title

text: and architecture. It was nothing less than a comprehensive
label: Paragraph

text: theory of civilization which strenuously advocated the
label: Paragraph

text: conscious refinement of all existing types. Hence it was as
label: Paragraph

text: much against what Le Corbusier and Ozenfant regarded as
label: Paragraph

text: the unwarranted distortions of Cubism in painting (see their
label: Paragraph

text: first joint polemic entitled Aprés /e Cubisme of 1918) as it
label: Paragraph

text: was in favour of the ‘evolutionary’ perfection of, say, Thonet
label: Paragraph

text: bentwood furniture or standard café tableware. Their first
label: Paragraph

text: full formulation of this aesthetic came with their essay
label: Paragraph

text: entitled ‘Le Purisme’, which appeared in 1920, in the fourth
label: Paragraph

text: number of the magazine L’Fsprit Nouveau, a literary and
label: Paragraph

text: artistic journal which they were to continue to edit with the
label: Paragraph

text: poet Paul Dermée until 1925. Without doubt the most fertile
label: Paragraph

text: period of their collaboration came with the gestation of Vers
label: Paragraph

text: une architecture which, prior to its publication as a book in
label: Paragraph

text: 1923, was published in part in L’Esprit Nouveau under the
label: Paragraph

text: double pseudonym of Le Corbusier-Saugnier.
label: Paragraph

text: This text - the credit for which in book form was
label: Paragraph

text: appropriated by Le Corbusier - articulated the conceptual
label: Paragraph

text: duality around which the rest of his work was to revolve: on
label: Paragraph

text: the one hand the imperative need to satisfy functional
label: Paragraph

text: requirements through empirical form, and on the other the
label: Paragraph

text: impulse to use abstract elements to affect the senses and
label: Paragraph

text: nourish the intellect. This dialectical view of form,
label: Paragraph

text: introduced under the heading ‘Esthétique et architecture de
label: Paragraph

text: ingenieur’, was exemplified by the most advanced
label: Paragraph

text: engineering structures of the epoch, by Eiffel’s Garabit
label: Caption

text: Viaduct of 1884 and by Giacomo Matté Trucco’s Fiat Works
label: Caption

text: The other aspect of the Engineer’s Aesthetic - product
label: Paragraph

text: design - was represented by the ships, automobiles and
label: Paragraph

text: aircraft which were featured as separate subsections under
label: Paragraph

text: the general heading ‘Des Yeux qui ne voient pas’. The third
label: Paragraph

text: section returned the reader to the antithesis of Classical
label: Title

text: architecture, to the lucid poetry of the Athenian Acropolis,
label: Paragraph

text: which was appraised in the penultimate chapter under the
label: Paragraph

text: title ‘Architecture, pure création de l’esprit’. Such was Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s admiration of engineering exactitude that the
label: Paragraph

text: profiles of the Parthenon were presented as being analogous
label: Paragraph

text: to those now wrought by machine tools. He wrote: ‘All this
label: Paragraph

text: plastic machinery is realized in marble with the rigour that
label: Paragraph

text: we have learnt to apply in the machine. The impression is of
label: Paragraph

text: naked, polished steel.’
label: Paragraph

text: Over the first five years of his intense activity in Paris,
label: Paragraph

text: during which he painted and wrote in all his spare time, Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier earned his living during the day as the manager
label: Paragraph

text: of a brickworks and building materials plant at Alfortville. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1922 he relinquished this position to enter into practice with
label: Paragraph

text: his cousin Pierre Jeanneret, a contract which lasted until the
label: Paragraph

text: outbreak of the Second World War. One of the earliest
label: Paragraph

text: undertakings of the office was to advance the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘constructional’ idea first touched on with du Bois during the
label: Paragraph

text: early years of the First World War, namely the Maison Dom-
label: Paragraph

text: Ino [132, 133] and the Villes Pilotis.
label: Paragraph

text: 132, 133 Le Corbusier, Maison Dom-Lno, 1915. Be/fow, structure of ‘Dom-Ino’
label: Caption

text: unit; above, perspective and plan showing possible grouping.
label: Paragraph

text: The Dom-Ino prototype was evidently open to different
label: Paragraph

text: levels of interpretation. While on the one hand it was simply
label: Paragraph

text: a technical device for production, on the other it was a play
label: Paragraph

text: on the word ‘Dom-ino’ as a patent industrial name, denoting
label: Paragraph

text: a house as standardized as a domino. This play acquired the
label: Paragraph

text: force of a literal pun where the free-standing columns could
label: Paragraph

text: be regarded in plan as domino dots and where the zigzag
label: Paragraph

text: pattern of an aggregation of these houses resembled the
label: Paragraph

text: formations of dominoes in play. With their symmetrical
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement, however, such patterns could also acquire
label: Paragraph

text: specific connotations by either resembling the typical
label: Paragraph

text: Baroque palace plan of Fourier’s phalanstery or alternatively
label: Caption

text: by recalling Eugene Hénard’s ‘Boulevard a Redans’ of 1903.
label: Paragraph

text: With his own ‘rue a redents’ of 1920, Le Corbusier managed
label: Paragraph

text: to combine the image of the phalanstery with his own ‘anti-
label: Paragraph

text: corridor street’ polemic. At the same time he wished to see
label: Paragraph

text: the Dom-Ino as a piece of equipment, analogous in its form
label: Paragraph

text: and mode of assembly to a typical piece of product design.
label: Paragraph

text: Such elements were seen by Le Corbusier as objets-types,
label: Paragraph

text: whose forms had already become refined in response to
label: Paragraph

text: typical needs. In Vers une architecture he wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: lf we eliminate from our hearts and minds all dead concepts
label: Paragraph

text: in regard to the house, and look at the question from a
label: Paragraph

text: critical and objective point of view, we shall arrive at the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘House Machine’, the mass-production house, healthy (and
label: Paragraph

text: morally so too) and beautiful in the same way that the
label: Paragraph

text: working tools and instruments which accompany our
label: Paragraph

text: existence are beautiful.
label: Paragraph

text: The post-war attempt by the Voisin aeroplane company
label: Paragraph

text: to break into the French housing market with an assembly-
label: Paragraph

text: line production of timber houses was enthusiastically
label: Paragraph

text: acclaimed by Le Corbusier in the second issue of L’Esprit
label: Paragraph

text: Nouveau. Yet at the same time he realized that such
label: Paragraph

text: production could only be obtained through the exercise of
label: Paragraph

text: high-grade skills under factory conditions, a combination of
label: Paragraph

text: circumstances rare in the building industry. He
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledged these limitations in his Maison Dom-Ino
label: Paragraph

text: proposal which aside from the formwork and the steel
label: Paragraph

text: reinforcement was designed to be built by unskilled labour.
label: Paragraph

text: As early as 1919 he had adopted a comparable ‘collagist’
label: Paragraph

text: approach to construction, when he proposed to use
label: Paragraph

text: corrugated asbestos sheets as permanent shuttering for the
label: Paragraph

text: concrete vaulted roof of his Maison Monol.
label: Caption

text: In 1922 both the Maison Dom-Ino and the Villes Pilotis
label: Paragraph

text: were further developed as the ‘Maison Citrohan’ and the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Ville Contemporaine’, both projects being exhibited in the
label: Paragraph

text: Salon d’Automne of that year. Where the latter was directly
label: Paragraph

text: evolved, at least in section, out of Hénard’s Rue Future of
label: Paragraph

text: 1910, the former utilized the Hennebique frame to project a
label: Paragraph

text: long rectilinear volume, open at one end, which
label: Paragraph

text: approximated to the traditional megaron form of the
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean. Within this basic type - designed in two
label: Paragraph

text: successive versions - Le Corbusier projected for the first
label: Paragraph

text: time his characteristic double-height living space, complete
label: Paragraph

text: with a sleeping mezzanine and children’s bedrooms on the
label: Paragraph

text: roof. Aside from its roots in the Greek vernacular, this type,
label: Paragraph

text: which he first produced in 1920, seems to have been
label: Paragraph

text: derived from a workers’ café in Paris, in the Rue de
label: Paragraph

text: Babylone where he lunched each day with his cousin. From
label: Paragraph

text: this small restaurant they took the section and the basic
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement of the Maison Citrohan [134]: ‘Simplification of
label: Paragraph

text: the light source; one single bay at each end; two lateral
label: Paragraph

text: bearing walls; a flat roof over; a veritable box which could
label: Paragraph

text: be used as a house.’
label: Paragraph

text: 134 Le Corbusier, Maison Citrohan, 1920. Perspective, ground and floor plans.
label: Caption

text: While the Maison Citrohan, elevated on pilotis, came
label: Paragraph

text: close to anticipating Les 5 Points d’une architecture
label: Title

text: nouvelle, which Le Corbusier finally formulated in 1926, it
label: Paragraph

text: was hardly applicable to anything other than ‘suburban’
label: Paragraph

text: development. He was soon to use a version of it to this end
label: Paragraph

text: in the garden city estates he built at Liege and Pessac in
label: Paragraph

text: 1926 [136]. Among the 130 reinforced-concrete frame
label: Caption

text: houses built at Pessac for the industrialist Henri Frugés,
label: Paragraph

text: there was one prevalent type known as the ‘skyscraper’ unit
label: Paragraph

text: which was in effect a combination of the Maison Citrohan
label: Paragraph

text: and the back-to-back units that he had designed for the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘city’ of Audincourt in the same year. A true version of the
label: Paragraph

text: Citrohan type was not realized, however, until his work at
label: Paragraph

text: the Stuttgart Weissenhofsiedlung of 1927. Pessac, as its
label: Paragraph

text: mixture of unit types would indicate, was a culmination of
label: Paragraph

text: his incessant attempts in the early 1920s to put his various
label: Paragraph

text: designs for the standardized dwelling into production. The
label: Paragraph

text: name ‘Citrohan’ was a play on the patent name of the
label: Paragraph

text: famous automobile company, indicating that a house should
label: Paragraph

text: be as standardized as a car. Pessac showed the first
label: Paragraph

text: conscious integration of Purist colour displacements into
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The architect observed at the time:
label: Paragraph

text: The site at Pessac is very dry. The grey concrete houses
label: Paragraph

text: produce an insupportable compressed mass, lacking in air.
label: Paragraph

text: Colour is able to bring us space. Here’s how we have
label: Paragraph

text: established certain invariable points. Some facades are
label: Paragraph

text: painted in burnt sienna. We have made the lines of other
label: Paragraph

text: houses recede, through clear ultramarine blue. Again we
label: Paragraph

text: have confused certain sections with the foliage of gardens
label: Paragraph

text: and trees, through pale green facades.*
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike his European contemporaries, Gropius [135] and
label: Paragraph

text: Mies van der Rohe, Le Corbusier was anxious to develop the
label: Paragraph

text: urban connotations of his architecture. The Ville
label: Paragraph

text: Contemporaine for three million was the ultimate
label: Paragraph

text: demonstration of this aspect in his work up to 1922.
label: Paragraph

text: Influenced equally by the gridded skyscraper cities of the
label: Paragraph

text: United States and the image of the ‘city-crown’ as put
label: Paragraph

text: forward by Bruno Taut in his book Die Stadtkrone (1919), Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier projected the Ville Contemporaine as an élite
label: Paragraph

text: capitalist city of administration and control, with garden
label: Paragraph

text: cities for the workers being sited, along with industry,
label: Paragraph

text: beyond the ‘security zone’ of the green belt encompassing
label: Paragraph

text: the city.
label: Paragraph

text: 135 Gropius, Frau Gropius and Le Corbusier in a Paris café.
label: Caption

text: 136 Le Corbusier, Pessac housing estate, near Bordeaux, 1926, on opening day.
label: Caption

text: The city itself, textured like an oriental carpet and some
label: Paragraph

text: four times the surface area of Manhattan, consisted of
label: Paragraph

text: residential blocks some ten to twelve storeys in height plus
label: Paragraph

text: twenty-four sixty-storey office towers in the centre, the
label: Caption

text: whole surrounded by a Picturesque park which, like the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional g/acis, maintained the class separation of the
label: Paragraph

text: urban élite from the suburban proletariat. The cruciform
label: Paragraph

text: office towers themselves - the so-called Cartesian
label: Paragraph

text: skyscrapers - were reminiscent in their serrated plan profile
label: Paragraph

text: of stepped Khmer or Indian temple forms and as such they
label: Paragraph

text: were evidently intended to replace as secular centres of
label: Paragraph

text: power the religious structures of the traditional city. That
label: Paragraph

text: such an authority was attributed to these forms is
label: Paragraph

text: suggested by their proportional relation to the grid of the
label: Paragraph

text: city, where they take up a golden section of the surface area
label: Paragraph

text: in plan, within the double square occupied by the city as a
label: Paragraph

text: whole.
label: Paragraph

text: None of this was lost on the Communist newspaper
label: Paragraph

text: L’Humanité, which regarded the entire project as
label: Paragraph

text: reactionary. Their sense of Le Corbusier’s commitment to
label: Paragraph

text: Saint-Simonian methods of management and control was
label: Paragraph

text: entirely confirmed by the publication of his book Urbanisme
label: Paragraph

text: (The City of Tomorrow) in 1925, its last plate depicting Louis
label: Paragraph

text: XIV supervising the building of the Invalides. Even Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier was sufficiently embarrassed by this image to
label: Paragraph

text: place underneath its caption the rider that it was not to be
label: Paragraph

text: understood as support for the French Fascist party Action
label: Paragraph

text: Francaise.
label: Paragraph

text: The Ville Contemporaine was no less ideological in the
label: Paragraph

text: detailed organization of its residential districts, which were
label: Paragraph

text: made up of two different block prototypes - the perimeter
label: Paragraph

text: block [137] and the ‘set-back’ or redent formation - each
label: Paragraph

text: postulating a different conception of the city. The former
label: Paragraph

text: was still committed to the idea of a ‘walled’ city made up of
label: Paragraph

text: streets, while the latter pre-supposed a wall-less ‘open city’,
label: Paragraph

text: that vision finally to be achieved in the Ville Radieuse, of a
label: Paragraph

text: dense city elevated above the surface of a continuous park.
label: Paragraph

text: The implicitly anti-street polemic of this vision was finally
label: Paragraph

text: made explicit in an essay on the street that Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: wrote in 1929 for the Syndicalist newspaper L’/ntransigeant.
label: Paragraph

text: 137 Le Corbusier and Jeanneret, Ville Contemporaine, 1922. Cellular perimeter
label: Caption

text: block composed of Immeuble-Villa units.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from providing the ‘essential joys’ of sunlight and
label: Paragraph

text: green, the open city was supposed to facilitate locomotion,
label: Paragraph

text: in accordance with Le Corbusier’s entrepreneurial aphorism
label: Paragraph

text: that ‘A city made for speed is a city made for success.’ This
label: Paragraph

text: was part of the rhetoric that accompanied his ‘Plan Voisin’
label: Paragraph

text: proposal for Paris of 1925 [138] - the paradoxical notion
label: Paragraph

text: that the automobile having effectively destroyed the great
label: Paragraph

text: city could now be exploited as an instrument for its
label: Paragraph

text: salvation. Notwithstanding their financial support, the
label: Paragraph

text: car/aircraft cartel, Voisin was no doubt only too aware of the
label: Paragraph

text: economic and political impossibility of raising vast cruciform
label: Title

text: towers next to the lle de la Cité.
label: Caption

text: 138 Le Corbusier and Jeanneret, Plan Voisin proposal for Paris, 1925. The hand
label: Caption

text: points towards the new business centre of the city.
label: Paragraph

text: The most important and enduring contribution of the Ville
label: Paragraph

text: Contemporaine was its Immeuble-Villa unit, an adaptation of
label: Paragraph

text: the Maison Citrohan as a general type for high-rise, high-
label: Paragraph

text: density living. These units, stacked up on six double floors,
label: Paragraph

text: included garden terraces, one for each duplex, an
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement which today seems to be one of the few
label: Paragraph

text: acceptable solutions for high-rise family living. In the so-
label: Paragraph

text: called ‘cellular’ perimeter blocks of the Ville Contemporaine,
label: Paragraph

text: these terraced duplexes opened at ground level to bounded
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular green space, equipped with recreational
label: Paragraph

text: facilities for communal use. The marginal provision of
label: Paragraph

text: additional communal space within the block and around the
label: Paragraph

text: periphery of this area and the intended provision of hotel
label: Paragraph

text: service throughout situates this proposal somewhere
label: Paragraph

text: between the bourgeois apartment block and the socialist
label: Title

text: collective dwelling (compare the phalanstery and Borie’s
label: Paragraph

text: Aérodromes). The Immeuble-villa living unit was finally
label: Paragraph

text: worked out in detail and exhibited as a prototype in the form
label: Paragraph

text: of the Pavillon de L’Esprit Nouveau, built for the Exposition
label: Caption

text: des Arts Décoratifs held in Paris in 1925. Unfortunately,
label: Paragraph

text: subsequent attempts to market this unit, both as a freehold
label: Paragraph

text: maisonette in the city and as a free-standing villa in the
label: Paragraph

text: suburbs, did not meet with success. The Pavillon de L’Esprit
label: Paragraph

text: Nouveau was a condensation of the Purist sensibility: while
label: Paragraph

text: machinist in promise and urban by implication, since it was
label: Paragraph

text: designed ostensibly for mass production and aggregation at
label: Paragraph

text: high density, it was furnished in accordance with the Purist
label: Paragraph

text: canon of objets-types, that is with English club armchairs,
label: Paragraph

text: Thonet bentwood furniture and standard Parisian cast-iron
label: Title

text: park pieces, with objets-tableaux of Purist origin, with
label: Paragraph

text: oriental rugs and South American pottery [139]. This finely
label: Paragraph

text: balanced assembly of folk, craft and machine-made objects,
label: Paragraph

text: borrowed in spirit from Adolf Loos, was posited here under
label: Paragraph

text: the patronage of the Minister for the Arts as a polemical
label: Paragraph

text: gesture against the Art Deco movement.
label: Paragraph

text: 139 Le Corbusier, Pavillon de l’Esprit Nouveau, Exposition des Arts Décoratifs,
label: Caption

text: Paris, 1925, furnished with objets-types and Purist canvases by Léger and Le
label: Caption

text: Corbusier.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1925 Le Corbusier also returned to the theme of the
label: Paragraph

text: bourgeois villa, first in his Maison Cook, completed in the
label: Paragraph

text: following year as a demonstration of Les 5 points d’une
label: Paragraph

text: architecture nouvelle, which were published in 1926, and
label: Paragraph

text: then in the project for the Villa Meyer, which anticipated the
label: Paragraph

text: villa at Garches and the Villa Savoye at Poissy, completed in
label: Caption

text: 1927 and 1929 respectively.
label: Paragraph

text: All these houses depended for their expression on the
label: Paragraph

text: syntax of the ‘five points’: (1) the pilotis elevating the mass
label: Paragraph

text: off the ground, (2) the free plan, achieved through the
label: Paragraph

text: separation of the load-bearing columns from the walls
label: Paragraph

text: subdividing the space, (3) the free facade, the corollary of
label: Paragraph

text: the free plan in the vertical plane, (4) the long horizontal
label: Paragraph

text: Sliding window or fenétre en longueur, and finally (5) the
label: Paragraph

text: roof garden, restoring, supposedly, the area of ground
label: Caption

text: covered by the house.

text: The latent potential of the Hennebique frame in the
label: Paragraph

text: Maison Dom-Ino and the solid lateral walls of the Maison
label: Caption

text: Citrohan determined to an equal degree the basic parti of all
label: Paragraph

text: these houses, with the liberal use of free-standing columns,
label: Paragraph

text: strip-windowed facades and cantilevered floor slabs. The
label: Paragraph

text: structural subdivision of the Maison Dom-Ino (the rhythmic
label: Paragraph

text: formula AAB comprising two wide bays plus a narrow one
label: Paragraph

text: containing a Stair) links the overt Palladianism of the Villa
label: Paragraph

text: Schwob to the suppressed Palladianism of the villa at
label: Paragraph

text: Garches, both houses seemingly organized about the classic
label: Paragraph

text: Palladian ABABA rhythm remarked on by Colin Rowe.
label: Paragraph

text: Palladio’s Villa Malcontenta of 1560 and Le Corbusier’s villa
label: Title

text: at Garches [140, 141] of some 350 years later are equally
label: Paragraph

text: predicated in the longitudinal direction on alternating
label: Paragraph

text: double and single bays producing a rhythm of 2:1:2:1:2. As
label: Paragraph

text: Rowe has pointed out, a similar syncopation obtains in the
label: Paragraph

text: other dimension:

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: alternating single and double bays, are established; but the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier's use of the cantilever, differs slightly. At the villa
label: Caption

text: at Garches, it is %4:14%4:144:1%:% and at the Malcontenta
label: Paragraph

text: 1%:2:2:1¥%. In plan, Corbusier thus obtains a sort of
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Rowe goes on to contrast the centralization of the Villa
label: Paragraph

text: Malcontenta with the centrifugality of the villa at Garches:
label: Paragraph

text: At Garches the central focus has been consistently broken
label: Paragraph

text: up, concentration at one point is disintegrated, and replaced
label: Paragraph

text: by a peripheral dispersion of incident. The dismembered
label: Paragraph

text: fragments of the central focus become, in fact, a sort of
label: Paragraph

text: serial installation of interest round the extremities of the
label: Paragraph

text: plan.®
label: Paragraph

text: Aside from its Purist layering of frontalized planes in
label: Paragraph

text: space and its play with literal and phenomenal
label: Title

text: transparency, remarked on by Rowe and Robert Slutzky,
label: Paragraph

text: Garches was significant for its resolution of a problem that
label: Paragraph

text: had first been posed by Loos: how to combine the comfort
label: Paragraph

text: and informality of the Arts and Crafts plan with the
label: Paragraph

text: asperities of geometrical, if not Neo-Classical, form - how to
label: Paragraph

text: reconcile the private realm of modern convenience with the
label: Paragraph

text: public facade of architectural order. As Le Corbusier’s Four
label: Paragraph

text: Compositions of 1929 would indicate, Garches was able to
label: Paragraph

text: achieve this, with an elegance denied to Loos, through the
label: Paragraph

text: displacements afforded by the invention of the free plan.
label: Paragraph

text: The disjunction, so to speak, of the complex interior was
label: Paragraph

text: held away from the public front, by the elision of the free
label: Paragraph

text: facade.
label: Caption

text: If Garches is to be associated with the Villa Malcontenta,
label: Paragraph

text: the Villa Savoye [142], as Rowe again points out, may be
label: Paragraph

text: compared to Palladio’s Villa Rotonda. The almost square
label: Paragraph

text: plan of the Villa Savoye, with its elliptical ground floor and
label: Caption

text: centralized ramp, may be read as a complex metaphor for
label: Paragraph

text: the centralized and biaxial plan of the Rotonda. There,
label: Paragraph

text: however, all similarity ends, Palladio insisting on centrality
label: Paragraph

text: and Le Corbusier asserting, within his self-imposed square,
label: Paragraph

text: the spiralling qualities of asymmetry, rotation and
label: Paragraph

text: peripheral dispersal. Nevertheless, in his book Précisions sur
label: Paragraph

text: unétat présent de l’architecture et de l’urbanisme (1930) Le
label: Caption

text: Corbusier made the imminent Classicism of the Villa Savoye
label: Paragraph

text: abundantly clear:
label: Paragraph

text: 142 Le Corbusier and Jeanneret, Villa Savoye, Poissy, 1929-31. The first-floor
label: Caption

text: ‘jardin suspendu’.
label: Paragraph

text: The inhabitants come here because this rustic landscape
label: Paragraph

text: goes well with country life. They survey their whole domain
label: Paragraph

text: from the height of their jardin suspendu or from the four
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of their fenétres en longueur. Their domestic life is
label: Paragraph

text: inserted into a Virgilian dream.’
label: Paragraph

text: With the Villa Savoye, one arrives at the last of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s Four Compositions of 1929 [143]. The first was
label: Paragraph

text: his Maison La Roche of 1923, which he presented in 1929 as
label: Paragraph

text: a Purist version of the Gothic Revival L-plan - a ‘genre plutdt
label: Paragraph

text: facile, pittoresque, mouvementé’; the second was shown as
label: Paragraph

text: an ideal prism, and the third and fourth (the villa at Garches
label: Paragraph

text: and the Villa Savoye) as alternative strategies for
label: Paragraph

text: reconciling the first two, the former depending on a subtle
label: Paragraph

text: integration of the first and second and the latter on the
label: Paragraph

text: encompassing of the first by a prism.
label: Paragraph

text: 143 Le Corbusier, the Four Compositions of 1929: (1) Maison La Roche, (2) villa
label: Caption

text: at Garches, (3) Weissenhofsiedlung in Stuttgart, (4) Villa Savoye.
label: Caption

text: With their 1927 entry to the international competition for
label: Paragraph

text: the League of Nations (Société des Nations, or SdN)
label: Paragraph

text: headquarters in Geneva [144], Le Corbusier and Pierre
label: Paragraph

text: Jeanneret produced their first design for a large public
label: Paragraph

text: structure. Their attention had hitherto been focused on the
label: Paragraph

text: house and on the concomitant simplicity of a basic prism.
label: Paragraph

text: Now they addressed themselves to the necessary
label: Paragraph

text: complexity of the ‘palace’ as a type. The competition's
label: Paragraph

text: conditions stipulated two buildings, one for the secretariat
label: Paragraph

text: and one for the assembly, and this programmatic duality led
label: Paragraph

text: the architects to take an Elementarist approach to the
label: Paragraph

text: design: the constituent ‘elements’ being first established
label: Title

text: and then manipulated in order to generate a number of
label: Paragraph

text: alternative arrangements. This extension of the
label: Paragraph

text: Elementarism professed at the turn of the century by the
label: Paragraph

text: Beaux-Arts master Julien Guadet would have come to Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier via Guadet’s pupils, Garnier and Perret. That he
label: Paragraph

text: was to adopt this approach generally when dealing with
label: Paragraph

text: large complexes is shown by his preliminary studies for the
label: Paragraph

text: project for the Palace of the Soviets, Moscow, of 1931 [145].
label: Caption

text: There under eight alternative arrangements we read the
label: Paragraph

text: caption: ‘the various stages of the project, wherein one sees
label: Paragraph

text: the organs, already independently established, the one from
label: Paragraph

text: the other, take up little by little their reciprocal places to
label: Paragraph

text: culminate in a synthetic solution.’ We find a comparable
label: Paragraph

text: remark appended to an alternative scheme for the SdN
label: Paragraph

text: project published in Le Corbusier’s Une Maison, Un Palais (‘A
label: Paragraph

text: House, A Palace’) (1928). Under a symmetrical layout
label: Paragraph

text: (evidently more rational, from an operational point of view),
label: Paragraph

text: we read: ‘alternative proposition employing the same
label: Paragraph

text: elements of composition’. The asymmetrical organization
label: Paragraph

text: finally adopted suggests a conflict between the circulatory
label: Paragraph

text: logic of the symmetrical layout and a Classical preference
label: Title

text: for an axial approach to the representative facade of the
label: Paragraph

text: principal building.
label: Paragraph

text: 144 Le Corbusier and Jeanneret, project for the League of Nations Building,
label: Caption

text: Geneva, 1927. (Compare H. Meyer and Wittwer’s entry, p. 143.)
label: Caption

text: 145 Le Corbusier and Jeanneret, project for the Palace of the Soviets, Moscow,
label: Caption

text: 1931. Four alternative layouts using the same elements.
label: Caption

text: The SdN project is both the climax and the crisis point of
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier's early career: a moment of acclaim, denied (if
label: Paragraph

text: we are to believe him) by his disqualification on the grounds
label: Paragraph

text: that he had not submitted his entry in the appropriate
label: Paragraph

text: graphic medium. It represents the culmination of his Purist
label: Paragraph

text: period, since it virtually coincides with the introduction into
label: Paragraph

text: his painting of figurative elements and of what he later
label: Paragraph

text: called objets a réaction poétique, loosely translatable as
label: Paragraph

text: ‘objects evocative of poetic emotion’. From now on, while
label: Paragraph

text: his painting became organic and figurative, his architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: at a public level at least, became increasingly symmetrical.
label: Paragraph

text: In retrospect the League of Nations entry must be
label: Paragraph

text: considered as a watershed; as a point of division, not only
label: Paragraph

text: within his own work, but also between himself and his
label: Paragraph

text: following within the international Modern Movement,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly where this concerned the support of those
label: Paragraph

text: whose political convictions lay to the left. In 1927 the
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivist affinities of the League of Nations entry, its
label: Paragraph

text: commitment to free-floating asymmetry and technical
label: Title

text: innovation, its secretariat 2 pilotis (reminiscent, in plan, of
label: Paragraph

text: Lissitzky’s Wolkenbugel), its mechanized cleaning system,
label: Paragraph

text: its air-conditioned assembly hall (acoustically profiled, tuned
label: Paragraph

text: and flooded with light), could do nothing but command the
label: Paragraph

text: enthusiastic support of the young, irrespective of their
label: Paragraph

text: political allegiance. But the undeniable monumentality -
label: Paragraph

text: expressed in its stone facing and in the hierarchical, seven-
label: Paragraph

text: door, entry system proposed to conduct the various classes
label: Paragraph

text: of user to their appointed place within the auditorium -
label: Paragraph

text: seems to have had the effect of eventually arousing a
label: Paragraph

text: certain ideological mistrust.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s drive to resolve the dichotomy between
label: Paragraph

text: the Engineer’s Aesthetic and Architecture, to inform utility
label: Paragraph

text: with the hierarchy of myth, was bound to bring him into
label: Paragraph

text: conflict with the functionalist-socialist designers of the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s. His ‘Mundaneum’ or ‘Cité Mondiale’, designed in
label: Paragraph

text: 1929 for Geneva as a centre of world thought, provoked a
label: Paragraph

text: sharp reaction from his Czech admirer, the left-wing artist
label: Paragraph

text: and critic Karel Teige. It was not the content but the form of
label: Paragraph

text: the Cité that provoked Teige’s objections, particularly the
label: Paragraph

text: helicoidal ziggurat of the ‘Musée Mondial’. In 1927 Teige had
label: Paragraph

text: publicly supported Le Corbusier in the international dispute
label: Paragraph

text: over his League of Nations entry and had called on all other
label: Paragraph

text: Czech artists to do the same. Now, barely two years later,
label: Paragraph

text: he attacked him with such vehemence that Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: was prompted to reply, in the essay entitled ‘The Defence of
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture’, written for Teige’s journal, Stavba. In his
label: Paragraph

text: attack Teige had quoted from Hannes Meyer’s essay of
label: Paragraph

text: 1928, Bauen (‘Building’).
label: Caption

text: All things in the world are a product of the formula, function
label: Paragraph

text: times economics, so none of these things are works of art;
label: Paragraph

text: all art is composition and hence unsuited to a particular
label: Paragraph

text: end. All life is function and therefore not artistic, the idea of
label: Paragraph

text: the composition of a dock is enough to make a cat laugh.
label: Paragraph

text: But how is a town plan designed or the plan of a dwelling?
label: Paragraph

text: Competition or Function? Art or Life®
label: Title

text: Le Corbusier placed this quotation at the head of his
label: Paragraph

text: essay, Making it clear that his riposte was directed as much
label: Paragraph

text: to Meyer as to Teige. He then argued:
label: Paragraph

text: Today amongst the avant garde of the Neue Sachlichkeit,
label: Paragraph

text: one has killed two words: Baukunst (Architecture) and Kunst
label: Paragraph

text: (Art). One has replaced them by Bauen (To Build) and Leben
label: Paragraph

text: (To Live) ... Today, where mechanization brings us a gigantic
label: Paragraph

text: production, architecture is above all in the battleship.
label: Paragraph

text: Monsieur Hannes Meyer; as in the conduct of war or in the
label: Paragraph

text: shape of a pen, or in a telephone. Architecture is a
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenon of creation, according to an arrangement.
label: Paragraph

text: Whoever determines the arrangement, determines the
label: Paragraph

text: composition.?
label: Paragraph

text: In the same year as the Teige attack Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledged in his book Précisions that the Mundaneum
label: Paragraph

text: had been badly received by the German architectural Left,
label: Paragraph

text: but he saw no reason to modify his ultimate position and
label: Paragraph

text: therefore he maintained that
label: Paragraph

text: The buildings projected are strictly utilitarian - particularly
label: Paragraph

text: this helicoidal Musée Mondial so violently incriminated ...
label: Paragraph

text: The plans of the Cité Mondiale bring to buildings which are
label: Paragraph

text: true machines a certain magnificence wherein some wish to
label: Paragraph

text: discover at any cost an archaeological inspiration. But from
label: Paragraph

text: my point of view, this harmonious quality arises from
label: Paragraph

text: another thing, from a simple response to a problem well
label: Paragraph

text: stated,1°
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless he could not, and indeed did not, deny that
label: Paragraph

text: the site layout of the Cité Mondiale had been determined by
label: Paragraph

text: a network of tracés régulateurs, comparable to those used
label: Paragraph

text: to control the facade of the villa at Garches - a facade
label: Paragraph

text: which, however much it subscribed to the canons of the
label: Paragraph

text: Purist machine aesthetic, remained as Classical in its
label: Paragraph

text: affinities as the Palladian plan type from which its structure
label: Paragraph

text: had been derived.
label: Paragraph

text: Decorative art is a vague and inaccurate term by which we
label: Paragraph

text: represent all human object-members. These respond with a
label: Paragraph

text: certain accuracy to clearly objective needs. Extensions of
label: Paragraph

text: our members, they are adapted to human functions which
label: Paragraph

text: are standard functions. Standard needs, standard functions,
label: Paragraph

text: therefore standard objects, standard furniture. The human
label: Paragraph

text: member object is a docile servant. A good servant is
label: Paragraph

text: discreet and steps aside to leave his master free.
label: Paragraph

text: Decorative art is tools, beautiful tools.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier
label: Title

text: L’Art décoratif d’aujourd’hui, 19251
label: Caption

text: The sunflower motif applied to the street facade of Auguste
label: Paragraph

text: Perret’s 25 bis Rue Franklin embodied the crystallization of
label: Paragraph

text: Art Nouveau, which later morphed into the Art Deco
label: Paragraph

text: movement on the occasion of the Exposition Internationale
label: Paragraph

text: des Arts Décoratifs et Industriels Modernes of 1925 in Paris.
label: Caption

text: This exhibition, originally scheduled for 1915, had to be
label: Paragraph

text: postponed for a decade owing to the outbreak of the First
label: Paragraph

text: World War. Although Perret was by no means opposed to
label: Paragraph

text: ornament - particularly when it had a tectonic character, as
label: Paragraph

text: seen in his Notre-Dame du Raincy, completed in 1924 - he
label: Paragraph

text: was unequivocally opposed to the idea of decorative art. He
label: Paragraph

text: made this clear in a 1925 interview with Marie Dormoy, in
label: Paragraph

text: which he argued that ‘Decorative art should be forbidden. |
label: Paragraph

text: would like to know who struck these two words together: art
label: Paragraph

text: and decorative. Where there is true art, there is no need for
label: Paragraph

text: decoration.’
label: Paragraph

text: This antithesis between decorative art and architecture
label: Paragraph

text: was equally evident in the pavilions designed for the 1925
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition. They ranged from giant jewel boxes
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned by Parisian department stores, such as Henri
label: Paragraph

text: Sauvage’s pavilion for Le Printemps, to Perret’s structurally
label: Paragraph

text: classical Théatre de l’Exposition des Arts Décoratifs, a
label: Paragraph

text: temporary structure built expressly for the exhibition and
label: Paragraph

text: partly fabricated out of wood. Three other distinctly modern
label: Caption

text: pavilions could also be found within the confines of the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition: Le Corbusier’s Purist Pavillon de L’Esprit
label: Caption

text: Nouveau, Konstantin Melnikov’s Constructivist pavilion
label: Title

text: representing the USSR and Rob Mallet-Stevens’s cubistic
label: Paragraph

text: Pavillon du Tourisme. Among the three, Mallet-Stevens
label: Caption

text: showed how cubistic form could yield a sculpturally dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Despite the fact that decorative artists were
label: Paragraph

text: involved in the realization of this pavilion, including the
label: Paragraph

text: metalworkers Jan and Joél Martel, the whole building could
label: Paragraph

text: be read as if it had been designed by a single hand. A final
label: Paragraph

text: decorative touch was provided by mannequins wearing
label: Paragraph

text: Sonia Delaunay’s ‘Simultané’ collection; they were
label: Paragraph

text: photographed in front of the pavilion against abstract
label: Caption

text: concrete trees designed by Mallet-Stevens and the Martel
label: Caption

text: brothers for the Esplanade des Invalides [146].
label: Caption

text: 146 Mallet-Stevens, concrete trees realized by the Martel brothers for the
label: Caption

text: Exposition des Arts Décoratifs of 1925 in Paris. In the foreground, the model
label: Paragraph

text: Paulette Pax wears an outfit designed for the occasion by Sonia Delaunay.
label: Paragraph

text: Mallet-Stevens had already established himself as an
label: Paragraph

text: architect for the high bourgeoisie two years earlier with the
label: Paragraph

text: design of a large villa for the Vicomte de Noailles at Hyéres.
label: Caption

text: He followed this with a series of equally large luxurious
label: Paragraph

text: villas, culminating in a spectacular brick-faced house built at
label: Paragraph

text: Croix in 1932. Alongside these set pieces, Mallet-Stevens
label: Paragraph

text: was also able to apply his modernist manner to such
label: Paragraph

text: typically 20th-century programmes as the Alfa-Romeo
label: Paragraph

text: garage that he built in the Rue Marbeuf, Paris, in 1927. In
label: Paragraph

text: the same year he saw the completion of his civic set piece
label: Paragraph

text: in the Auteuil quarter of the city, a syncopated sequence of
label: Paragraph

text: four- to five-storey cubistic town houses lining both sides of
label: Paragraph

text: a street that would thereafter bear his name [147]. Unlike
label: Paragraph

text: the interpenetrating spaces of the Maison Cook and the
label: Paragraph

text: Rietveld Schréder House, Mallet-Stevens’s houses were
label: Paragraph

text: relatively static. As in the typical Loosian Raumplan, the
label: Paragraph

text: rooms themselves were almost conventional and were it not
label: Paragraph

text: for the occasional spiral stair, split level or double-height
label: Paragraph

text: space, there would have been little spatial interplay within
label: Paragraph

text: the rather staid volumetric character of his work. This may
label: Paragraph

text: explain why Sigfried Giedion was reluctant to accept the
label: Paragraph

text: candidacy of Mallet-Stevens as the official French delegate
label: Paragraph

text: to CIAM when Le Corbusier proposed him as his replacement
label: Paragraph

text: 147 Rue Mallet-Stevens, view from one end of the street.
label: Caption

text: Although he was twenty years younger than Mallet-
label: Paragraph

text: Stevens, André Lurcat made his debut at virtually the same
label: Paragraph

text: time, so that by the time he was thirty-two, in 1926, he had
label: Paragraph

text: already built a number of artists’ houses in the Villa Seurat
label: Paragraph

text: neighbourhood of Paris, together with the arresting form of
label: Paragraph

text: his Maison GuggenbUhl overlooking the Parc Montsouris.
label: Paragraph

text: Lurcat’s precocious talent finally became fully manifest in
label: Paragraph

text: the Hétel Nord-Sud erected to his designs in Calvi, Corsica,
label: Paragraph

text: in 1929, where a castellated, two-storey linear building,
label: Paragraph

text: housing eight studio apartments, each with its own balcony
label: Paragraph

text: facing the sea, was sensitively integrated into a rocky
label: Paragraph

text: coastline. There is a marked difference in this work between
label: Paragraph

text: the seaward versus the landward side: the latter maintained
label: Paragraph

text: the continuity of the form by remaining largely blank save
label: Paragraph

text: for vertical slot windows, rhythmically articulating the long
label: Paragraph

text: facade.
label: Caption

text: The triumph of Lurgat’s early career was the design of
label: Paragraph

text: the Karl Marx School [148], won in competition in 1930 and
label: Paragraph

text: realized for the municipality of Villejuif, then under the
label: Paragraph

text: mayoralty of Paul Vaillant-Couturier. Lurgat’s mythical status
label: Paragraph

text: as the architectural champion of Léon Blum’s short-lived
label: Paragraph

text: Front Populaire (Popular Front) government in France is
label: Paragraph

text: surely in part due to his design for this radically modern
label: Paragraph

text: school, conceived as a total antithesis of its typical 19th-
label: Paragraph

text: century predecessor. Envisaged as a civic community centre
label: Paragraph

text: as much as a school, it incorporated an unusual programme,
label: Paragraph

text: including a solarium, an aquarium and a stadium, as well as
label: Paragraph

text: a series of airy, well-lit classrooms, within its long, three-
label: Paragraph

text: storey form. The Communist Vaillant-Couturier (in whose
label: Paragraph

text: memory Le Corbusier later designed a monument) saw the
label: Paragraph

text: school as a ‘social-condenser’, and thereby arranged for its
label: Paragraph

text: inauguration in 1933 with a socialist féte for 20,000 people.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1930s it was publicized by the French Communist
label: Paragraph

text: Party throughout a series of photographs and films.
label: Paragraph

text: 148 Lurcgat, Karl Marx School, Villejuif, 1931-33, aerial view.
label: Caption

text: The year 1933 brought about a fundamental change in
label: Paragraph

text: Lurgat’s position as he reacted to attacks on modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in the French press. These came from such
label: Paragraph

text: figures as Camille Mauclair, art critic of the bourgeois
label: Paragraph

text: newspaper Le Figaro, and Waldemar George, who, shifting
label: Paragraph

text: to the political right, advocated a regionalist-nationalist,
label: Paragraph

text: proto-fascist architecture in his essay ‘Architecture, penser
label: Paragraph

text: francais’ (‘Architecture, think French’) of 1934. It is
label: Paragraph

text: significant that this reactionary outburst coincided with the
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of the Third Reich in Germany and the Stalinist
label: Title

text: eclipse of the avant garde in the Soviet Union. In June 1934
label: Paragraph

text: Lurcat reacted against this French critique by reorganizing
label: Paragraph

text: his studio as a collective and by visiting the Soviet Union,
label: Paragraph

text: assisted by the Association des Ecrivains et Artistes
label: Paragraph

text: Révolutionnaires (Association of Revolutionary Writers and
label: Title

text: Artists; AEAR). During this visit he was introduced by the
label: Paragraph

text: writer and critic Léon Moussinac to the major figures of the
label: Paragraph

text: Russian cinematic and theatrical avant garde, including the
label: Paragraph

text: cineastes Dziga Vertov, Vsevolod Pudovkin and Sergei
label: Title

text: Eisenstein, and the creator of the biomechanical stage,
label: Paragraph

text: Vsevolod Meyerhold. Despite these affinities, Lurcat adopted
label: Paragraph

text: a critical line towards modern architecture, including that of
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier regardless of his evident debt to the Franco-
label: Paragraph

text: Swiss architect, not only for his epoch-making Vers une
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of 1923 - which influenced the line that Lurcat
label: Paragraph

text: would adopt in his own book L’Architecture of 1929 - but
label: Paragraph

text: also for the Purist ‘Five Points of a New Architecture’ of
label: Paragraph

text: 1926, which clearly influenced Lurcat’s own style. In his
label: Paragraph

text: address to the Soviet Union of Architects, Lurgat denounced
label: Caption

text: Le Corbusier for his indifference towards the class struggle
label: Paragraph

text: and for his emphasis on rationalized mass production, that
label: Paragraph

text: is to say, the same technocratic emphasis of the German
label: Paragraph

text: refugee Marxist architects who by this date were already at
label: Paragraph

text: work in the USSR. And yet, despite his warm reception of
label: Paragraph

text: the quasi-Classical syntax of Boris lofan’s winning design for
label: Paragraph

text: the last Palace of the Soviets competition of 1931, Lurcat
label: Paragraph

text: continued to employ a variation of Neo-Purism in his own
label: Paragraph

text: work. This is evident from his design for a dom-kommuna
label: Paragraph

text: that he presented on his second visit to Moscow in 1934.
label: Paragraph

text: Lurgat’s unpublished text of that year, ‘Neoclassicism ou
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivism’, already outlined the cultural schism with
label: Paragraph

text: which he would be involved for the rest of his life. To this
label: Paragraph

text: end, in his designs for the Moscow medical school, Lurgat
label: Paragraph

text: returned to a Classical rational order similar to that of Tony
label: Paragraph

text: Garnier, an architect whom he admired throughout his life.
label: Paragraph

text: In the Paris of the 1930s a considerable number of
label: Paragraph

text: architects were of foreign origin and prominent among them
label: Paragraph

text: was the Anglo-lrish architect Eileen Gray, who came to the
label: Paragraph

text: fore with her vacation house E-1027 of 1929 at Roquebrune-
label: Paragraph

text: Cap-Martin in the south of France [149]. She designed it
label: Paragraph

text: with the Romanian émigré architect Jean Badovici, who first
label: Paragraph

text: encouraged Gray to venture beyond her successful career
label: Paragraph

text: as a furniture designer and into the field of architecture. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1923 Badovici had been appointed editor of the magazine
label: Paragraph

text: L’Architecture Vivante, which under his editorship became
label: Paragraph

text: the ultimate international record of the Modern Movement in
label: Paragraph

text: Europe, between 1923 and 1933. Something of their
label: Paragraph

text: enigmatic relationship may be adduced from the name of
label: Paragraph

text: the house, E-1027, which went beyond being a witty allusion
label: Paragraph

text: to an aircraft register number since it also encoded their
label: Paragraph

text: names: ‘E’ stood for Eileen and ‘10’ and ‘2’ respectively
label: Paragraph

text: represented the tenth and second letters of the alphabet -
label: Paragraph

text: ‘|’ and ‘B’ - and hence stood for Jean Badovici, followed by
label: Paragraph

text: ‘7’ representing ‘G’ for Gray.
label: Paragraph

text: 149 Eileen Gray, Maison E-1027 at Cap Martin, 1929, axonometric.
label: Caption

text: In E-1027, the lacquered screens and carpets that Gray
label: Paragraph

text: had produced in the 1920s are subtly integrated with
label: Paragraph

text: pivoting, chromium-plated, tubular-steel equipment. The
label: Paragraph

text: overall interior alludes to romantic wanderlust of the
label: Paragraph

text: modern world: the name of Gray’s Transat chair refers to
label: Paragraph

text: transatlantic liners and the form of her Bibendum chair was
label: Paragraph

text: seemingly based on the mascot trademark of the Michelin
label: Paragraph

text: tyre company. At the same time the house was designed to
label: Paragraph

text: respond to the fluctuating vicissitudes of the Mediterranean
label: Paragraph

text: climate.
label: Paragraph

text: E-1027 was followed in the early 1930s by the
label: Paragraph

text: exceptional work of two émigré architects of Polish origin:
label: Paragraph

text: Jean Ginsberg and Bruno Elkouken. After studying with
label: Paragraph

text: Mallet-Stevens, Ginsberg made his debut on the Parisian
label: Paragraph

text: scene with an eight-storey infill apartment building on the
label: Caption

text: Avenue de Versailles [150], designed in association with a
label: Paragraph

text: young émigré Russian architect, Berthold Lubetkin.
label: Paragraph

text: Influenced by Le Corbusier’s ‘five points’, the most original
label: Paragraph

text: aspect of this work is a sash-window version of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s fenétre en ljongueur, which was evidently
label: Paragraph

text: intended to enable the occupant to open up the front of
label: Paragraph

text: each apartment in high summer. Of the four elegant
label: Paragraph

text: apartment buildings that Elkouken designed in Paris before
label: Paragraph

text: migrating to the United States in 1937, the most striking
label: Paragraph

text: was a twin-tier composition of double-height artists’ studios
label: Paragraph

text: that were stacked seven floors high on either side of a 500-
label: Paragraph

text: seat cinema, the whole being known as the Studio Raspail,
label: Paragraph

text: realized in the Boulevard Raspail in 1933.
label: Paragraph

text: 150 Ginsberg and Lubetkin, apartment building, 25 Avenue de Versailles, Paris,
label: Caption

text: 1931-32. Avenue facade.
label: Caption

text: The denouement of the Société des Nations competition
label: Title

text: in 1927, and the subsequent formation of the Congrés
label: Paragraph

text: Internationaux d’Architecture Moderne (CIAM) in La Sarraz,
label: Caption

text: Switzerland, in 1928, was followed in the next year by the
label: Paragraph

text: formation of the Union des Artistes Modernes (UAM) in Paris
label: Paragraph

text: under the leadership of the furniture designer René Herbst.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike the relatively unified architectural front of CIAM, UAM
label: Paragraph

text: was made up of an extremely varied range of applied artists
label: Paragraph

text: sharing little in common, save for a mutual opposition to
label: Paragraph

text: both the Art Deco movement and French academic
label: Title

text: classicism. This much is suggested by the diversity of its
label: Paragraph

text: founding membership, which included, in addition to Herbst,
label: Paragraph

text: Pierre Chareau, Joseph Csaky, Sonia Delaunay, Eileen Gray,
label: Caption

text: Francis Jourdain, Rob Mallet-Stevens, Charlotte Perriand,
label: Caption

text: Jean Prouvé and Jean Puiforcat. Mallet-Stevens was the only
label: Paragraph

text: figure who had been trained as an architect; the others were
label: Paragraph

text: painters, decorators, ironworkers and furniture designers
label: Title

text: whose common aim was to undercut the all-powerful
label: Paragraph

text: Société des Artistes Décorateurs in order to develop a
label: Paragraph

text: totally new concept of interior space and a distinctly
label: Title

text: different culture of objects.
label: Paragraph

text: By the time of the UAM manifesto of 1934, the more
label: Paragraph

text: creative members had already left the association, in
label: Paragraph

text: particular Delaunay and Gray. Perhaps the ultimate
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic line of the UAM was to increase the use of metal
label: Paragraph

text: and glass in the modern world and from this standpoint
label: Paragraph

text: Chareau’s Maison de Verre of 1932 [151] has to be seen as
label: Paragraph

text: an exemplary work. Realized in collaboration with the Dutch
label: Paragraph

text: architect Bernard Bijvoet and the ironworker Louis Dalbert,
label: Paragraph

text: the Maison de Verre was the ne plus ultra of dematerialized
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivism. Up to this point in his career, Chareau had
label: Paragraph

text: worked almost exclusively as a designer of furniture and
label: Paragraph

text: high-bourgeois interiors and this surely accounts to some
label: Paragraph

text: degree for the extremely hybrid character of the work.
label: Paragraph

text: Chareau’s clients, Dr Jean Dalsace and his wife, Annie, had
label: Paragraph

text: intended to demolish an 18th-century three-storey town
label: Paragraph

text: house that stood on the site in order to erect their new
label: Paragraph

text: residence in its place, but this proved to be impossible due
label: Paragraph

text: to the fact that the top floor of the existing building was
label: Paragraph

text: occupied by an elderly lady who refused to leave. This left
label: Paragraph

text: Chareau and Bijvoet with no alternative but to insert a steel
label: Paragraph

text: frame so that they could demolish the two storeys below
label: Paragraph

text: and construct a new three-storey residence within the
label: Paragraph

text: available volume. In order to allow sufficient light to
label: Paragraph

text: penetrate within such a deep space the forecourt and
label: Paragraph

text: garden elevations were faced throughout in translucent
label: Paragraph

text: glass lenses, except for a fully glazed entrance hall facing
label: Caption

text: the forecourt and the occasional window or door opening to
label: Paragraph

text: the garden on the opposite side of the house. The resulting
label: Paragraph

text: exotic atmosphere of the interior, permeated by light that
label: Paragraph

text: became subaqueous in nature, was reinforced by the liberal
label: Paragraph

text: use of black lacquered storage cabinets on the second-floor
label: Caption

text: bedroom level overlooking the double-height salon of the
label: Paragraph

text: first floor. The translucent glass lenses making up the
label: Paragraph

text: envelope on both sides of the house were held in place by
label: Paragraph

text: thin metal subframes, which, like the exposed two-storey
label: Paragraph

text: steel columns of the salon, were finished in a standard red
label: Paragraph

text: oxide paint, giving the interior a discernibly Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: character. In this regard, the excessive number of bidets
label: Paragraph

text: distributed throughout the house surely suggests a kind of
label: Paragraph

text: unconscious irony given the fact that this was the residence
label: Paragraph

text: and the clinic of a leading gynaecologist. It is equally ironic
label: Paragraph

text: that, although ostensibly conceived as a prototype for
label: Paragraph

text: wholesale industrial prefabrication, the house should have
label: Paragraph

text: been largely handforged and painstakingly assembled piece
label: Paragraph

text: by piece.
label: Paragraph

text: 151 Chareau, Maison de Verre, Rue St-Guillaume, Paris, 1932. Axonometric.
label: Caption

text: Subject to the ubiquitous influence of Le Corbusier, who
label: Paragraph

text: allegedly visited the site during its construction, Chareau
label: Paragraph

text: and Bijvoet conceived of the house as a transformable
label: Paragraph

text: machine a habiter (‘machine for living’), exploiting the
label: Paragraph

text: concept of the free plan not only to differentiate between
label: Paragraph

text: the partition walls subdividing the space and the largely
label: Paragraph

text: free-standing supports of the exposed steel frame, but also
label: Paragraph

text: as a way of interconnecting the various spaces of the
label: Paragraph

text: interior so that they could be either ‘open’ or ‘closed’ to the
label: Paragraph

text: rest of the house through the manipulation of pivoting or
label: Paragraph

text: hinged doors, like the adjustable components deployed in E-
label: Paragraph

text: 1027. Shortly after its completion in 1932, the German
label: Paragraph

text: émigré critic Julius Posener, writing under the pseudonym of
label: Paragraph

text: Julien Lepage, praised the house for its poetic functionalism
label: Paragraph

text: despite the extensive use of mobile ferrovitreous
label: Paragraph

text: components throughout.
label: Paragraph

text: As much an exterior as an interior, this disconcertingly
label: Paragraph

text: introverted masterpiece was never revisited by Chareau or
label: Paragraph

text: by Bijvoet, despite the transformable interior of the latter’s
label: Paragraph

text: Gooiland Hotel built in Hilversum in 1936 after his return to
label: Paragraph

text: the Netherlands. This unlikely amalgam of fashionable high-
label: Paragraph

text: bourgeois taste and the French ferrovitreous tradition,
label: Paragraph

text: dating back to Victor Contamin’s Galerie des Machines of
label: Paragraph

text: 1889, had no followers prior to the Second World War,
label: Paragraph

text: except for the émigré architect Paul Nelson. He visited the
label: Paragraph

text: house soon after its completion and was so inspired as to
label: Paragraph

text: develop two significant projects in 1936: his somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: surrealist Maison Suspendue and his canopied, extensively
label: Paragraph

text: sunscreened proposal for a hospital in Ismailia, Egypt, for
label: Paragraph

text: the Suez Canal Company, with its four operating theatres
label: Paragraph

text: encapsulated behind glass block walls [152]. Nelson
label: Caption

text: returned to certain aspects of this project in his Franco-
label: Paragraph

text: American hospital built at Saint-L6 (1948-56).
label: Paragraph

text: 152 Nelson, hospital at Ismailia for the Suez Canal Company, 1936. Axonometric
label: Caption

text: of the surgical pavilion.
label: Paragraph

text: Other than the atelier of Le Corbusier and Pierre
label: Paragraph

text: Jeanneret, three distinctly different practices continued to
label: Paragraph

text: be active in France throughout the 1930s. In the first
label: Paragraph

text: instance was the atelier of Auguste Perret who, after
label: Paragraph

text: realizing the Théatre de l’Exposition des Arts Décoratifs,
label: Paragraph

text: went on to produce the structurally Classical Musée National
label: Paragraph

text: des Travaux Publics, Paris, under construction from 1936 to
label: Caption

text: 1939, but not finally completed until after 1945. Then there
label: Paragraph

text: was the more modernized Classical manner of Michel Roux-
label: Paragraph

text: Spitz, who, having been a pupil of Garnier, was awarded the
label: Paragraph

text: Grand Prix de Rome in 1920 and, following a mandatory
label: Paragraph

text: period of study at the Villa Medici in Rome, opened his
label: Paragraph

text: practice with an ingenious infill apartment building erected
label: Paragraph

text: in the Rue Guynemer, Paris, in 1925 [155]. Roux-Spitz was
label: Paragraph

text: particularly skilled at incorporating modern services -
label: Paragraph

text: including garages with car turntables and cleverly
label: Paragraph

text: integrated minimal kitchens - into such tightly packed infill
label: Paragraph

text: apartment buildings with Classical formats, and he repeated
label: Paragraph

text: this exercise elsewhere in the city. In his residential work
label: Paragraph

text: Roux-Spitz, like Ginsberg, displayed a preference for
label: Paragraph

text: elongated sash windows over Le Corbusier’s fenétre en
label: Caption

text: longueur. From 1932 onwards he received direct
label: Paragraph

text: commissions from the French state, beginning with his
label: Paragraph

text: annexe to the Bibliotheque Nationale in Versailles.
label: Caption

text: The third most productive practice of the 1930s was that
label: Paragraph

text: of Eugéne Beaudouin and Marcel Lods, in collaboration with
label: Paragraph

text: the designer-fabricator Jean Prouvé and the Russian émigré
label: Title

text: Vladimir Bodiansky. Together this team produced a
label: Paragraph

text: prefabricated, light-weight metal, mobile building,
label: Caption

text: comparable to Chareau’s Maison de Verre, but conceived for
label: Paragraph

text: an entirely different class of society. This exceptional
label: Paragraph

text: structure, the Maison du Peuple, was completed in the
label: Paragraph

text: working-class Paris suburb of Clichy in 1939 [153, 154].
label: Paragraph

text: This building, wholly transformable not only in plan but also
label: Paragraph

text: in section, was designed to function as a market hall during
label: Paragraph

text: the day and as a 700-seat cinema or a 2,000-person
label: Paragraph

text: reception hall at night. The primary transformation of the
label: Paragraph

text: double-height market hall into a cinema depended on seven
label: Paragraph

text: metal panels, normally stacked side by side, being lowered
label: Paragraph

text: into position from an overheard gantry in order to form the
label: Paragraph

text: elevated floor. This screening space was further enhanced
label: Paragraph

text: by a light-weight metal, full-height, sliding-folding wall
label: Caption

text: panel system. The literal conception of the building as a
label: Paragraph

text: machine was taken one step further with its ferrovitreous
label: Paragraph

text: roof, which could slide away in high summer, so as to create
label: Paragraph

text: an open-air theatre.
label: Paragraph

text: 153, 154 Beaudouin and Lods, Prouvé, Bodiansky, Maison du Peuple, Clichy,
label: Caption

text: 1939. View of the hall with the elevated floor in place above the market and the
label: Caption

text: peripheral partition opened (top); axonometric with the canopy removed.
label: Paragraph

text: 155 Roux-Spitz, apartment building, Rue Guynemer, Paris, 1925. Plans of the
label: Caption

text: ground floor, a typical upper floor and the street facade.
label: Paragraph

text: Nothing could be more removed from the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Beaudouin and Lods’s team than the architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: Auguste Perret over the same period, for from the beginning
label: Paragraph

text: Perret’s Structural Classicism was predicated on the
label: Paragraph

text: universality of a single material, namely reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete. As Leonardo Benevolo put it in 1960:
label: Paragraph

text: The French tradition ... was based on the correspondence
label: Paragraph

text: between classical rules and building practice ... Perret
label: Paragraph

text: steeped in this tradition was naturally led to identify
label: Paragraph

text: concrete framework ... with the framework as it was to
label: Paragraph

text: appear on the outside of a building ... He probably believed
label: Paragraph

text: that he had discovered the structural system best suited to
label: Paragraph

text: the realization of traditional works since the unity of its
label: Paragraph

text: elements was real not apparent as in the classical orders
label: Paragraph

text: composed of several blocks of stone.?
label: Paragraph

text: This was still the ethos of the Perret atelier when it was
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned after 1945 to rebuild the totally bombed-out
label: Paragraph

text: city of Le Havre, which was then still a major French
label: Paragraph

text: transatlantic port. This work, amounting to the
label: Paragraph

text: reconstruction of an entire city from scratch [156], was built
label: Paragraph

text: around the major axis of the Avenue Foch, with the Hétel de
label: Paragraph

text: Ville at one end and the port at the other. The surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: fabric depended on a somewhat awkward interplay between
label: Paragraph

text: a bush-hammered jn situ concrete frame and prefabricated
label: Caption

text: concrete window surrounds and infill wall panels. Needless
label: Caption

text: to say, the windows corresponded to Perret’s concept of /a
label: Paragraph

text: porte fenétre (‘window door’). Throughout his career, from
label: Paragraph

text: the turn of the century onwards, he saw this as literally
label: Paragraph

text: representing the presence of the human being framed by
label: Paragraph

text: the opening before the traditional full-height double doors of
label: Paragraph

text: a French window.
label: Caption

text: 156 Perret, reconstruction of Le Havre, general view in the 1950s with the
label: Caption

text: Avenue Foch in the foreground and, behind, the church of St Joseph.

text: lt then became clear to me that it was not the task of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture to invent form. | tried to understand what that
label: Paragraph

text: task was. | asked Peter Behrens, but he could not give me
label: Paragraph

text: an answer. He did not ask that question. The others said,
label: Paragraph

text: ‘What we build is architecture’, but we weren't satisfied with
label: Paragraph

text: this answer... since we knew that it was a question of truth,
label: Paragraph

text: we tried to find out what truth really was. We were very
label: Paragraph

text: delighted to find a definition of truth by St Thomas Aquinas:
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Adequatio intellectus et rei’, or as a modern philosopher
label: Paragraph

text: expresses it in the language of today: ‘Truth is the
label: Paragraph

text: significance of fact’.
label: Paragraph

text: Berlage was a man of great seriousness who would not
label: Paragraph

text: accept anything that was fake and it was he who had said
label: Paragraph

text: that nothing should be built that is not clearly constructed.
label: Paragraph

text: And Berlage did exactly that. And he did it to such an extent
label: Paragraph

text: that his famous building in Amsterdam, The Beurs, has a
label: Paragraph

text: medieval character without being medieval. He used brick
label: Paragraph

text: in the way the medieval people did. The idea of a clear
label: Paragraph

text: construction came to me there, as one of the fundamentals
label: Paragraph

text: we should accept. We can talk about that easily but to do it
label: Paragraph

text: is not easy. It is very difficult to stick to this fundamental
label: Paragraph

text: construction, and then to elevate it to a structure. | must
label: Paragraph

text: make it clear that in the English language you call
label: Paragraph

text: everything structure. In Europe we don’t. We call a shack a
label: Paragraph

text: shack and not a structure. By structure we have a
label: Paragraph

text: Philosophical idea. The structure is the whole from top to
label: Paragraph

text: bottom, to the last detail - with the same ideas. That is what
label: Paragraph

text: we call structure.
