text: Ludwig Mies van der Rohe
label: Title

text: (quoted by Peter Carter in Architectural Design, March
label: Caption

text: As the above quotation makes clear, Ludwig Mies - he later
label: Paragraph

text: added his mother’s name, Van der Rohe - was as much
label: Paragraph

text: inspired by the work of the Dutch architect Hendrik Petrus
label: Paragraph

text: Berlage as by that Prussian school of Neo-Classicism to
label: Paragraph

text: which he became the direct heir. Unlike his contemporary,
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier, he was not educated within the Arts and Crafts
label: Paragraph

text: ethos of the Jugendstil. At the age of fourteen he entered his
label: Paragraph

text: father’s stone-mason’s business and after two years at a
label: Paragraph

text: trade school and a subsequent period as a stucco designer
label: Paragraph

text: for a local builder, in 1905 he left his native town of Aachen
label: Paragraph

text: for Berlin where he worked for a minor architect specializing
label: Paragraph

text: in timber construction. There followed a further period of
label: Paragraph

text: apprenticeship with the furniture designer Bruno Paul before
label: Paragraph

text: he ventured briefly on his own in 1907, to build his first
label: Paragraph

text: house in a restrained englische manner, reminiscent of the
label: Paragraph

text: work of the Werkbund architect Hermann Muthesius. In the
label: Paragraph

text: following year he joined Peter Behrens, whose newly
label: Paragraph

text: established Berlin office was beginning to develop an overall
label: Paragraph

text: house style for the electrical combine AEG.
label: Caption

text: During his three years in Behrens’s office, Mies became
label: Paragraph

text: aware of the Schinkelschdler tradition, which, apart from its
label: Paragraph

text: Neo-Classical affiliation, was committed to the idea of
label: Paragraph

text: Baukunst, not only as an ideal of technical elegance but also
label: Paragraph

text: as a philosophical concept. Schinkel’s brick-faced
label: Paragraph

text: Bauakademie in Berlin, with its warehouse-like detailing,
label: Paragraph

text: was later compared by Mies to the articulate construction of
label: Paragraph

text: Berlage’s Amsterdam Beurs or Exchange, which he had first
label: Paragraph

text: seen when he visited Holland in 1912. On leaving Behrens’s
label: Paragraph

text: employ in 1911, after a brief stint as site architect on
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens’s German Embassy in St Petersburg, Mies opened
label: Paragraph

text: his own office with the Perls Haus, completed in Berlin-
label: Paragraph

text: Zehlendorf in that year. This was the first of a series of five
label: Paragraph

text: Schinkelesque houses to be designed by Mies before the
label: Paragraph

text: outbreak of the First World War. In 1912 he succeeded
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens as architect to Mrs H.E.L.J. Krdller, who wanted a
label: Paragraph

text: gallery and residence in The Hague to house the famous
label: Paragraph

text: Krdéller-Miller collection: the project was mocked up in
label: Paragraph

text: canvas and wood at full size before being inexplicably
label: Paragraph

text: abandoned. This year also saw his Boullée-like monument to
label: Paragraph

text: Bismarck, which was to be the last significant project of his
label: Paragraph

text: pre-war career.
label: Paragraph

text: The defeat and collapse of the German military-industrial
label: Title

text: imperium at the end of the First World War reduced the
label: Paragraph

text: country to a state of economic and political turmoil and
label: Paragraph

text: Mies, like every other architect who had fought in the war,
label: Paragraph

text: sought to create an architecture that was more organic than
label: Paragraph

text: that permitted by the autocratic canons of the Schinkel
label: Paragraph

text: tradition. In 1919 he began to direct the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: section of the radical Novembergruppe, named after the
label: Paragraph

text: month of the Republican revolution and dedicated to the
label: Title

text: revitalization of the arts throughout Germany. This
label: Paragraph

text: association brought him into contact with the Arbeitsrat fur
label: Paragraph

text: Kunst and with the ideas of Taut’s Glass Chain (see Chapter
label: Title

text: 13), and there can be little doubt that his first skyscraper
label: Paragraph

text: project of 1920 was made in response to Paul Scheerbart’s
label: Paragraph

text: Glasarchitektur of 1914. The same faceted, crystal
label: Caption

text: skyscraper theme occurred in his Friedrichstrasse
label: Paragraph

text: competition entry of 1921 [157], and the publication of both
label: Paragraph

text: of these projects in the last issue of Taut’s magazine
label: Paragraph

text: Frdhlicht confirmed his post-war Expressionist affiliation.
label: Paragraph

text: Mies’s intent at this time was to render glass as a complex
label: Paragraph

text: reflective surface which would be constantly subject to
label: Paragraph

text: transformation under the impact of light. This much is clear
label: Paragraph

text: from the description that accompanied the first publication
label: Paragraph

text: of his Friedrichstrasse proposal:
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Caption

label: Caption

text: Station in Berlin | used a prismatic form which seemed to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: glass walls at slight angles to each other to avoid the
label: Paragraph

text: monotony of over-large glass surfaces.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: were determined by three factors: sufficient illumination of
label: Paragraph

text: It is instructive in this context to compare Mies’s entry

text: Mies van der Rohe’s so-called ‘G’ period began in 1923
label: Paragraph

text: with his participation in the first issue of the magazine G,
label: Paragraph

text: subtitled Material zur elementaren Gestaltung and edited by
label: Paragraph

text: Hans Richter, Werner Graeff and El Lissitzky. His glass
label: Paragraph

text: skyscrapers of the previous year, with their kinetic
label: Paragraph

text: reflections on the surfaces of translucent forms, had already
label: Paragraph

text: anticipated something of the peculiar G sensibility which
label: Paragraph

text: seems to have combined a Constructivist objectivity with a
label: Paragraph

text: Dadaist feeling for chance. Yet the seven-storey office
label: Paragraph

text: building that Mies presented in the first issue of G broke
label: Paragraph

text: different ground, for now the primary expressive material
label: Paragraph

text: was not glass but concrete, projected in the form of
label: Paragraph

text: concrete ‘trays’ cantilevered off a reinforced-concrete
label: Caption

text: frame. As in Frank Lloyd Wright’s Larkin Building of 1904,
label: Paragraph

text: the upstands of these ‘trays’ were high enough to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate standard built-in filing cabinets, set below a
label: Paragraph

text: band of recessed clerestory glazing. With this project Mies
label: Caption

text: declared himself against formalism and aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: speculation and wrote with decidedly Hegelian overtones
label: Paragraph

text: that ‘Architecture is the will of the age conceived in spatial
label: Paragraph

text: terms. Living, changing, new.’ At the same time he went on
label: Paragraph

text: to declare: ‘The office building is a house of work ... of
label: Paragraph

text: organization, of clarity, of economy. Bright, wide,
label: Paragraph

text: workrooms, easy to oversee, undivided except as the
label: Paragraph

text: undertaking is divided. The maximum effect with the
label: Paragraph

text: minimum expenditure of means. The materials are concrete,
label: Paragraph

text: iron, glass.’
label: Paragraph

text: Despite this objective advocacy of a ‘skin-and-bones’
label: Paragraph

text: architecture reminiscent of Le Corbusier’s Dom-Ino proposal,
label: Paragraph

text: a vestige of academic tradition was visible in the project in
label: Paragraph

text: the widening of the end bays in order to ‘strengthen’ the
label: Paragraph

text: corners of the building. This, however, was Mies’s last overt
label: Paragraph

text: reference to the Neo-Classical principles of Schinkel until his
label: Paragraph

text: first gesture at a ‘new monumentality’ a decade later, with
label: Paragraph

text: his Reichsbank project of 1933.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from the ever-present undertones of Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Classicism, Mies’s work after 1923 displays, to a varying
label: Paragraph

text: degree, three main influences: (1) the Berlage brick
label: Paragraph

text: tradition and the dictum that ‘nothing should be built that is
label: Paragraph

text: not clearly constructed’; (2) the pre-1910 work of Frank
label: Paragraph

text: Lloyd Wright, as filtered through the De Stijl group - an
label: Paragraph

text: influence acknowledged in the horizontal profiles extending
label: Paragraph

text: into the landscape of Mies’s brick country house of 1923

text: [158]; and (3) Kasimir Malevich's Suprematism, as
label: Paragraph

text: interpreted through the work of Lissitzky. While the
label: Paragraph

text: Wrightian aesthetic could be readily absorbed within the
label: Paragraph

text: Schinkelschdler tradition of Baukunst - that is, according to
label: Paragraph

text: the highest standards of European masonry practice -
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the free plan. Where Mies’s Baukunst ideal was fulfilled in
label: Paragraph

text: the Karl Liebknecht and Rosa Luxemburg Monument (1926)
label: Caption

text: plan was to emerge fully armed, so to speak, in the
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona Pavilion of 1929 [159].

label: Caption

text: Despite these diverse and compelling influences, Mies
label: Paragraph

text: still seems to have experienced difficulty in relinquishing the
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionist aesthetic of his Novembergruppe period. A
label: Paragraph

text: comparable sensibility, touched by a somewhat Russian
label: Paragraph

text: sense of colour, is still evident in the 1927 Berlin Silk
label: Paragraph

text: Industry Exhibition, designed in collaboration with Lilly
label: Paragraph

text: Reich, who had initially trained as a fashion designer. The
label: Paragraph

text: black, orange and red velvets and the gold, silver, black and
label: Title

text: lemon-yellow silks no doubt reflected her taste, as did the
label: Paragraph

text: acid-green, cowhide upholstery used for the sitting-room
label: Caption

text: furniture of the Tugendhat House. A latent feeling for
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionism may still be detected, too, in the Deutsche
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund Weissenhofsiedlung Exhibition which opened in
label: Paragraph

text: Stuttgart in the same year. Despite a tendency to regard
label: Paragraph

text: every commission as a free-standing object, Mies initially
label: Paragraph

text: planned this exhibition as a continuous urban form, like a
label: Paragraph

text: medieval town. It even had a vestigial Stadtkrone, a pseudo-
label: Paragraph

text: Tautian gesture towards unity that had to be abandoned. In
label: Paragraph

text: the final version of the layout Mies divided the site into
label: Paragraph

text: rectilinear plots, on which free-standing ‘display’ houses
label: Paragraph

text: were erected to the designs of various Werkbund architects,
label: Paragraph

text: among them Walter Gropius and Hans Scharoun. A number
label: Paragraph

text: of foreign architects also participated, including Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier, Victor Bourgeois, J.J.P. Oud and Mart Stam.
label: Caption

text: Initially conceived in the spirit of the original Darmstadt
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition of 1901, ‘Ein Dokument Deutscher Kunst’, the
label: Paragraph

text: Weissenhofsiedlung became the first international
label: Paragraph

text: manifestation of that white, prismatic, flat-roofed mode of
label: Paragraph

text: building which was to be identified in 1932 as the
label: Paragraph

text: International Style. Mies’s contribution to both the style and
label: Paragraph

text: the content of the exhibition was an apartment house that
label: Paragraph

text: he designed as the centra/ armature of the scheme. This
label: Paragraph

text: five-storey structure was generally similar to the standard
label: Paragraph

text: Zeilenbau block being developed at the time, but it differed
label: Paragraph

text: from the typical row-house slab in the ease with which it
label: Paragraph

text: could be brought to accommodate a variety of different
label: Paragraph

text: apartment shapes and sizes. Of his solution Mies wrote in
label: Paragraph

text: Today the factor of economy makes rationalization and
label: Paragraph

text: standardization imperative in rental housing. On the other
label: Paragraph

text: hand, the increased complexity of our requirements
label: Paragraph

text: demands flexibility. The future will have to reckon with both.
label: Paragraph

text: For this purpose skeleton construction is the most suitable
label: Paragraph

text: system. It makes possible rationalized building methods and
label: Paragraph

text: allows the interior to be freely divided. If we regard kitchens
label: Paragraph

text: and bathrooms, because of their plumbing, as a fixed core,
label: Paragraph

text: then all other space may be partitioned by means of
label: Paragraph

text: movable walls. This should, | believe, satisfy all normal
label: Paragraph

text: requirements.3
label: Paragraph

text: The climax of Mies’s early career came with the three
label: Paragraph

text: masterworks that he designed in sequence after finishing
label: Paragraph

text: the Weissenhofsiedlung: the German State Pavilion at the
label: Title

text: Barcelona World Exhibition of 1929, the Tugendhat House at
label: Caption

text: Brno, Czechoslovakia, of 1930, and the model house erected
label: Caption

text: for the Berlin Building Exhibition of 1931. In all these works
label: Paragraph

text: a horizontal centrifugal spatial arrangement was subdivided
label: Paragraph

text: and articulated by free-standing planes and columns. While
label: Paragraph

text: this aesthetic (already anticipated in Mies’s country house
label: Paragraph

text: projects of 1922 and 1923) was basically Wrightian, it was
label: Paragraph

text: Wright as reinterpreted through the sensibility of the G
label: Paragraph

text: group and the metaphysical space conceptions of De Stijl.
label: Paragraph

text: As Alfred Barr observed, the load-bearing walls of Mies’s
label: Paragraph

text: brick country house were disposed in a pinwheel fashion like
label: Paragraph

text: the clustering elements of Van Doesburg’s painting of 1917,
label: Paragraph

text: Rhythms of a Russian Dance.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the Classical associations of its regular eight-
label: Paragraph

text: column grid and its liberal use of traditional materials, the
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona Pavilion was undeniably a Suprematist-
label: Paragraph

text: Elementarist composition (compare Malevich's Future
label: Title

text: Planets for Earth Dwellers of 1924 and the work of his
label: Paragraph

text: indirect pupil lvan Leonidov). Contemporary photographs
label: Paragraph

text: reveal the ambivalent and ineffable quality of its spatial and
label: Paragraph

text: material form [160]. From these records we may see that
label: Paragraph

text: certain displacements in its volume were brought about by
label: Paragraph

text: illusory surface readings such as that effected by the use of
label: Paragraph

text: green tinted glass screens, to emerge as the mirror
label: Paragraph

text: equivalents of the main bounding planes. These planes,
label: Paragraph

text: faced in polished green Tinian marble, in their turn reflected
label: Paragraph

text: the highlights of the chromium vertical glazing bars holding
label: Paragraph

text: the glass in place. A comparable play in terms of texture
label: Paragraph

text: and colour was effected by the contrast between the
label: Paragraph

text: internal core plane of polished onyx (the equivalent of
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s centrally placed chimney core) and the long
label: Paragraph

text: travertine wall that flanked the main terrace with its large
label: Paragraph

text: reflecting pool. Here, bounded by travertine and agitated by
label: Paragraph

text: the wind, the broken surface of the water distorted the
label: Paragraph

text: mirror image of the building. In contrast to this, the internal
label: Paragraph

text: space of the pavilion, modulated by columns and mullions,
label: Paragraph

text: terminated in an enclosed court, containing a reflecting pool
label: Caption

text: lined with black glass. Above and in this implacable, perfect
label: Paragraph

text: mirror, there stood the frozen form and image of Georg
label: Paragraph

text: Kolbe’s Dancer. Yet despite all these delicate aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: contrasts the building was simply structured about eight
label: Paragraph

text: free-standing cruciform columns that supported its flat roof.
label: Caption

text: The regularity of the structure and the solidity of its matt
label: Paragraph

text: travertine base evoked the Schinkelschdler tradition to
label: Paragraph

text: which Mies was to return.
label: Paragraph

text: 160 Mies van der Rohe, German Pavilion, World Exhibition, Barcelona, 1929.
label: Caption

text: Like the De Stijl room of 1923, the Barcelona Pavilion was
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona chair, which was one of five Schinkelesque pieces
label: Paragraph

text: that the architect designed in the years 1929-30 - the other
label: Paragraph

text: four being the Barcelona stool and table, the Tugendhat
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: integrated into the design of the pavilion as Rietveld’s
label: Paragraph

text: Red/Blue chair in the room designed for the Berlin
label: Caption

text: Exhibition.
label: Paragraph

text: The Tugendhat House, built in 1930 on a steeply sloping
label: Paragraph

text: site overlooking the city of Brno in Czechoslovakia, adapted
label: Caption

text: the spatial conception of the Barcelona Pavilion to a
label: Paragraph

text: domestic programme [161]. One may also see it as an
label: Paragraph

text: attempt to combine the layered, compartmentalized
label: Paragraph

text: planning of Wright’s Robie House - where the service block
label: Caption

text: slides behind the main living volume - with the typical
label: Paragraph

text: loggia form of the Schinkel Italianate Villa. In any event, the
label: Paragraph

text: free plan was reserved here solely for the horizontal living
label: Paragraph

text: volume, which, modulated once again by chromium
label: Paragraph

text: cruciform columns, opened on its long side to a panorama of
label: Paragraph

text: the city and on its short side to a conservatory faced in
label: Paragraph

text: large sheets of plate glass. While the mechanical lowering of
label: Paragraph

text: the long glass wall converted the whole of the living area
label: Paragraph

text: into a belvedere, the conservatory acted as a natural foil in
label: Paragraph

text: a symbolic scheme - as a mediation between natural
label: Paragraph

text: vegetation and the fossilized onyx of the interior. In a
label: Paragraph

text: comparable manner, the plywood dining alcove, faced in
label: Paragraph

text: ebony veneer, evoked the sustenance of life to which its
label: Paragraph

text: space was dedicated. Similarly, the rectilinear onyx plane
label: Paragraph

text: dividing the living volume of the house signified through its
label: Paragraph

text: surface the ‘worldliness’ of the spaces to be found on either
label: Paragraph

text: side of it - the sitting-room and the study. Such rhetoric
label: Paragraph

text: obtained only on the lower ground floor, the bedrooms on
label: Paragraph

text: the entrance level being treated simply as hermetic
label: Paragraph

text: volumes.
label: Paragraph

text: 161 Mies van der Rohe, Tugendhat House, Brno, 1930.
label: Caption

text: With the Berlin Building Exhibition house of 1931, on the
label: Paragraph

text: other hand, Mies demonstrated the possibility of extending
label: Paragraph

text: the free plan to the bedrooms, and for the next four years
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Mies van der Rohe’s idealism and his natural affinity for
label: Paragraph

text: German Romantic Classicism clearly served to remove him
label: Paragraph

text: from the mass-production approach of the Neue
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit. The sense of objectivity in each case was
label: Paragraph

text: patently different. As far as the Neue Sachlichkeit was
label: Paragraph

text: concerned, Mies declared the apolitical, not to say
label: Paragraph

text: reactionary, nature of his position when, in 1930, he
label: Paragraph

text: accepted the directorship of the Bauhaus, as Hannes
label: Paragraph

text: Meyer’s successor. In his essay The New Era, written on the
label: Paragraph

text: occasion of his appointment, he attempted to formulate his
label: Paragraph

text: own somewhat ambivalent position. In response to Hannes
label: Paragraph

text: Meyer’s ‘materialist’ essay, Bauen, he wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: The new era is a fact: it exists, irrespective of our ‘yes’ or
label: Paragraph

text: ‘no’, yet it is neither better nor worse than any other era. it
label: Paragraph

text: is pure datum, in itself without value content. Therefore |
label: Paragraph

text: will not try to define it or clarify its basic structure.
label: Paragraph

text: Let us not give undue importance to mechanization and
label: Paragraph

text: standardization.
label: Paragraph

text: Let us accept changed economic and social conditions as
label: Paragraph

text: a fact.
label: Paragraph

text: All these take their blind and fateful course.
label: Paragraph

text: One thing will be decisive: the way we assert ourselves in
label: Paragraph

text: the face of circumstance.
label: Paragraph

text: Here the problems of the spirit begin. The important
label: Paragraph

text: question to ask is not ‘what’ but ‘how’. What goods we
label: Paragraph

text: produce or what tools we use are not questions of spiritual
label: Paragraph

text: value.
label: Paragraph

text: How the question of skyscrapers versus low buildings is
label: Paragraph

text: settled, whether we build of glass or steel, are unimportant
label: Paragraph

text: questions from the point of view of spirit.
label: Paragraph

text: Whether we tend to centralization or decentralization in
label: Paragraph

text: city planning is a practical question, not a question of value.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet it is just the question of value that is decisive.
label: Paragraph

text: We must set up new values, fix our ultimate goals so that
label: Paragraph

text: we may establish standards.
label: Paragraph

text: For what is right and significant for any era - including
label: Paragraph

text: the new era - is this: to give the spirit the opportunity for
label: Paragraph

text: existence.4
label: Paragraph

text: This Neo-Classical concern for spiritual value seems to
label: Paragraph

text: have led directly to the idealized monumentality of Mies’s
label: Paragraph

text: Reichsbank proposal of 1933, submitted as a competition
label: Paragraph

text: entry in the year when the National Socialists came to
label: Paragraph

text: power. The non-Classical impulse that had sustained him up
label: Paragraph

text: to this time - the Suprematist-Elementarism that had
label: Paragraph

text: inspired his version of the free plan - now gave way to an
label: Paragraph

text: impassive monumentality which, aside from the neutrality of
label: Paragraph

text: its skin, intended nothing save the idealization of
label: Paragraph

text: bureaucratic authority. This Suprematist sensibility was to
label: Paragraph

text: remain suppressed in Mies’s work until 1939, when, on his
label: Paragraph

text: migration to the United States, it momentarily re-emerged
label: Paragraph

text: in the first sketches for the IIT campus in Chicago.

label: Title

text: The simple, classical concept of internationalism underwent
label: Paragraph

text: a considerable change towards the end of the 1920s, when
label: Paragraph

text: hopes of immediate world revolution receded and the more
label: Paragraph

text: autarchic stage of ‘the building of Socialism in one country’
label: Paragraph

text: was initiated. Simultaneously, the exuberant romantic
label: Paragraph

text: conception of technique gave way to a sober realization that
label: Paragraph

text: technique, in Russia, meant a hard uphill struggle to
label: Paragraph

text: transform a peasant economy into a modern industrial
label: Title

text: organism, starting with the most primitive means.
label: Paragraph

text: Their failure to understand the significance of these
label: Paragraph

text: changes, and to adjust themselves, led the profession, as
label: Paragraph

text: happened earlier in the case of the formalists, to the brink
label: Paragraph

text: of complete impotence.
label: Paragraph

text: Disarming itself by rejecting the whole of past
label: Paragraph

text: architectural tradition, the profession gradually lost all
label: Paragraph

text: confidence in itself and in its social purpose. Those
label: Paragraph

text: architects who were most honest with themselves drew
label: Paragraph

text: their own conclusion from the worship of the engineer and
label: Paragraph

text: the denial of all architectural tradition, and actually
label: Paragraph

text: abandoned their profession to become building technicians,
label: Paragraph

text: administrators and planners.
label: Paragraph

text: The disparity between the vision of a supercharged
label: Paragraph

text: technique and the reality of a primitive and backward
label: Title

text: building industry, in which, more and more, idealized
label: Paragraph

text: technology had to give way to ordinary ingenuity on a low
label: Paragraph

text: level, led others to a hollow and insincere aestheticism,
label: Paragraph

text: indistinguishable from that of the formalists they had set out
label: Paragraph

text: to replace, inasmuch as they were forced to reproduce the
label: Paragraph

text: adulterated forms of an advanced technique in the absence
label: Paragraph

text: of its real media.
label: Paragraph

text: All the aggressive self-assertion with which the
label: Paragraph

text: Functionalists enunciated their creed could mask neither the
label: Paragraph

text: barrenness of their doctrine nor the sterility of their
label: Paragraph

text: practice. The few remaining buildings of the period bear
label: Paragraph

text: witness to it.

text: The Russian pan-Slavic cultural movement that came into

text: the very year in which Kruchonykh’s Futurist play, ‘Victory
label: Paragraph

text: Over the Sun’, was first performed in St Petersburg with
label: Paragraph

text: music by Matyushin and costumes and sets by Kasimir
label: Caption

text: Malevich. Malevich’s curtain for this apocalyptic play
label: Paragraph

text: exhibited for the first time the black square motif that was
label: Paragraph

text: to become the quintessential icon of Suprematism.
label: Paragraph

text: By the eve of the First World War, avant-garde Russian
label: Paragraph

text: culture had already developed into two distinct but related
label: Paragraph

text: impulses. The first of these was represented by a non-
label: Paragraph

text: utilitarian synthetic art form that promised to transform
label: Paragraph

text: everyday life into that millennial future evoked by the
label: Paragraph

text: poetry of Kruchonykh and Malevich. The second, as
label: Paragraph

text: proposed by Bogdanov, was a post-Narodnik hypothesis that
label: Paragraph

text: sought to forge a new cultural unity from the material and
label: Paragraph

text: cultural exigencies of communal life and production. After
label: Paragraph

text: October 1917, the revolutionary reality of the newly formed
label: Title

text: Soviet state tended to bring these two positions - the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘apocalyptic’ and the ‘synthetic’ - into conflict, leading to
label: Paragraph

text: hybrid forms of socialist culture, such as Lissitzky’s
label: Paragraph

text: adaptation of Malevich’s ‘apocalyptic’ and highly abstract
label: Paragraph

text: art to the utilitarian ends of his self-styled Suprematist-
label: Paragraph

text: Elementarism.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1920 Inkhuk (the Institute for Artistic Culture) and
label: Paragraph

text: Vkhutemas (Higher Artistic and Technical Studios) were
label: Paragraph

text: founded in Moscow as institutes for comprehensive
label: Paragraph

text: education in art, architecture and design. Both these
label: Paragraph

text: institutions were to serve as arenas for public debate,
label: Paragraph

text: wherein mystical idealists such as Malevich and Wassily
label: Paragraph

text: Kandinsky and objective artists such as the brothers Pevsner
label: Paragraph

text: found themselves equally opposed by the so-called
label: Paragraph

text: Productivists, Vladimir Tatlin, Alexander Rodchenko and
label: Paragraph

text: Alexei Gan. In 1920 the challenge of the pure art position
label: Paragraph

text: was most eloquently formulated by Naum Gabo (Pevsner),
label: Paragraph

text: who later wrote of his critical reaction to the Tatlin Tower:
label: Paragraph

text: | showed them a photograph of the Eiffel Tower and said:
label: Paragraph

text: ‘That which you think is new has been done already. Either
label: Paragraph

text: build functional houses and bridges or create pure art or
label: Paragraph

text: both. Don’t confuse one with the other. Such art is not pure
label: Paragraph

text: constructive art, but merely an imitation of the machine’.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the persuasive logic of such rhetoric, idealists
label: Paragraph

text: such as Gabo and Kandinsky felt themselves constrained to
label: Paragraph

text: leave the Soviet Union even though Malevich had
label: Paragraph

text: succeeded in entrenching himself in Vitebsk, where shortly
label: Paragraph

text: after 1919 he had founded his Suprematist school, Unovis
label: Paragraph

text: (the School of the New Art). This institution was to exercise
label: Paragraph

text: a definitive influence on Lissitzky’s development, putting an
label: Paragraph

text: end to his expressionistic graphics and starting him on his
label: Paragraph

text: career as a Suprematist designer.
label: Paragraph

text: In the meantime, a specifically proletarian culture had
label: Paragraph

text: spontaneously emerged from the communicational needs of
label: Paragraph

text: the Revolution, imparting vitality to cultural forms which
label: Paragraph

text: might otherwise have remained remote from the actual
label: Paragraph

text: conditions of the period and from the real needs of a
label: Paragraph

text: population which was still basically ill-housed, ill-fed and
label: Paragraph

text: above all illiterate. Graphic art came to play a salient role in
label: Paragraph

text: spreading the message of the Revolution. It took the form of
label: Paragraph

text: large-scale street art, displayed in the Agit-Prop propaganda
label: Paragraph

text: trains [162] and boats designed by Proletkult artists and in
label: Paragraph

text: the ‘monumental propaganda plan’ launched by the
label: Paragraph

text: authorities shortly after the Revolution with the express
label: Paragraph

text: purpose of covering every available surface with
label: Paragraph

text: inflammatory slogans and evocative iconography. The
label: Paragraph

text: central task of Proletkult at this time was the propagation of
label: Paragraph

text: official information through theatrical production, film and
label: Title

text: exhortatory graphics, and its form was invariably nomadic
label: Paragraph

text: and demountable. Everything had to be easily transportable
label: Paragraph

text: and made at the simplest level of production. Apart from the
label: Paragraph

text: dissemination of propaganda, Productivist artists such as
label: Paragraph

text: Tatlin and Rodchenko addressed themselves to the design of
label: Paragraph

text: light collapsable furniture and to the fabrication of durable
label: Paragraph

text: clothing for workers. Tatlin designed a stove that was
label: Paragraph

text: supposed to give off maximum heat while consuming the
label: Paragraph

text: minimum of fuel. The universality of this ‘nomadic’ impulse
label: Paragraph

text: is reflected in the light-weight furniture designed by
label: Paragraph

text: European architects in the late 1920s - the conceptually
label: Paragraph

text: ‘knock-down’, if not actually demountable, chairs produced
label: Paragraph

text: by Mies van der Rohe, Le Corbusier, Mart Stam, Hannes
label: Caption

text: Meyer and Marcel Breuer. Breuer was particularly
label: Paragraph

text: susceptible to this influence: his famous Wassily chair of
label: Paragraph

text: 1926 coincided with an almost identical canvas and tube
label: Paragraph

text: chair of about the same date designed in Vkhutemas. It is
label: Caption

text: now clear, from recently discovered correspondence
label: Paragraph

text: between Moholy-Nagy and Rodchenko, that after 1923 the
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus was subject to direct influence from Vkhutemas.
label: Paragraph

text: 162 Agit-Prop train, 1919.
label: Caption

text: In the early 1920s, Proletkult attained its most synthetic
label: Paragraph

text: expression through the theatre, most notably in Nikolai
label: Paragraph

text: Evreinov’s ‘theatricalization of everyday life’, which used
label: Paragraph

text: the format of the tattoo to stage the annual re-enactment of
label: Paragraph

text: the storming of the Winter Palace. On less momentous
label: Paragraph

text: occasions, street parades were organized in which
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivist lay figures, invariably representing either the
label: Paragraph

text: Revolution or its capitalist enemies, served as the focusing
label: Paragraph

text: icons for mass demonstrations. An equally polemical
label: Paragraph

text: intention prompted V. Meyerhold’s proclamation of ‘The
label: Paragraph

text: October Theatre’, which attempted to translate such Agit-
label: Paragraph

text: Prop street activity into the principles of the agitatory stage.
label: Paragraph

text: Meyerhold’s ‘Octobrist’ proclamation of 1920 prescribed a
label: Paragraph

text: theatre comprised of the following elements and principles:
label: Paragraph

text: (1) the use of a permanently illuminated arena stage so as
label: Paragraph

text: to unite the audience with the actors; (2) an anti-naturalistic
label: Paragraph

text: mode of mechanized production, featuring the actor-
label: Paragraph

text: acrobat as the ideal type for Meyerhold’s ‘biomechanical’
label: Paragraph

text: stage - a stage form that had obvious affinities with the
label: Paragraph

text: circus; and finally, (3) the exclusion of illusion and the
label: Paragraph

text: elimination of any of the Symbolism that was then still
label: Paragraph

text: endemic to the bourgeois theatre, exemplified by
label: Paragraph

text: Stanislavsky’s Moscow Arts Theatre. Similar prescriptions
label: Paragraph

text: were to inform Erwin Piscator’s foundation of the Berlin
label: Paragraph

text: Proletarian Theatre in 1924.
label: Paragraph

text: Lenin came to distrust, if not to fear, Bogdanov’s radical
label: Paragraph

text: assertion that there were three independent roads to
label: Paragraph

text: socialism - the economic, the political and the cultural. Yet
label: Paragraph

text: despite the official repudiation of Bogdanov in 1920 and the
label: Paragraph

text: subsequent subjugation of the Proletkult movement to the
label: Paragraph

text: authority of Narkompros (People’s Commissariat for
label: Title

text: Education), the ethos of Agit-Prop culture persisted,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly in Meyerhold’s theatre. It also continued to find
label: Paragraph

text: expression in the numerous projects for kiosks, tribunes and
label: Paragraph

text: other didactic information-structures designed by
label: Paragraph

text: Productivist artists such as G. Klutsis and Rodchenko. These
label: Paragraph

text: projects constituted the first attempts to formulate a non-
label: Paragraph

text: professional socialist style of architecture. Although
label: Paragraph

text: intentionally ‘unrealizable’, Lissitzky’s 1920 design for a
label: Paragraph

text: Lenin Tribune (see p. 142), projected as a Proun, was an
label: Paragraph

text: alternative for such an architecture. Lissitzky had coined the
label: Paragraph

text: term Proun - from Pro-Unovis, ‘For the School of the New
label: Paragraph

text: Art’ - to indicate an unprecedented creative realm, situated
label: Paragraph

text: somewhere between painting and architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Paramount among such pioneer works was Tatlin’s 1919-
label: Paragraph

text: 20 design for a 400-metre (1,310-foot) high monument to
label: Caption

text: the Third International [163], projected as two interwining
label: Paragraph

text: lattice spirals within which were to be suspended four large
label: Paragraph

text: transparent volumes each rotating at progressively faster
label: Paragraph

text: speeds, once a year, once a month, once a day and,
label: Paragraph

text: presumably, once an hour. They were respectively dedicated
label: Paragraph

text: to the purposes of legislation, administration, information
label: Paragraph

text: and cinematic projection. On one level Tatlin’s Tower was a
label: Paragraph

text: monument to the constitution and function of the Soviet
label: Caption

text: state; on another it was intended to exemplify the
label: Paragraph

text: Productivist/Constructivist programme of considering
label: Title

text: ‘intellectual materials’, such as colour, line, point and plane,
label: Paragraph

text: and ‘physical materials’, such as iron, glass and wood, as
label: Paragraph

text: thematically equal elements. In this respect, one can hardly
label: Paragraph

text: regard the tower as a purely utilitarian object. In spite of the
label: Paragraph

text: anti-art and anti-religious slogans of the 1920 ‘Programme
label: Title

text: of the Productivist Group’, the tower remained as a
label: Paragraph

text: monumental metaphor for the harmony of a new social
label: Paragraph

text: order. It was first exhibited under a banner which bore the
label: Paragraph

text: slogan ‘Engineers Create New Forms’. The millennialistic
label: Paragraph

text: symbolism of both its form and its material are clearly
label: Paragraph

text: manifest in a contemporary description which presumably
label: Paragraph

text: paraphrased Tatlin’s own words:
label: Paragraph

text: 163 Tatlin, model of monument to the Third International, 1919-20. Tatlin stands
label: Caption

text: in the foreground, pipe in hand.
label: Caption

text: Just as the product of the number of oscillations and the
label: Paragraph

text: wavelength is the spatial measure of sound, so the
label: Paragraph

text: proportion between glass and iron is the measure of the
label: Paragraph

text: material rhythm. By the union of these fundamentally
label: Paragraph

text: important materials, a compact and imposing simplicity
label: Paragraph

text: and, at the same time, relation, is expressed, since these
label: Paragraph

text: materials, for both of which fire is the creator of life, form
label: Paragraph

text: the elements of modern art.3
label: Caption

text: In its use of the spiral theme, in its enclosure of a series
label: Paragraph

text: of progressively diminishing Platonic solids and in its
label: Paragraph

text: rhetorical exhibition of iron and glass and mechanized
label: Title

text: movement, as the very stuff of the millennium, Tatlin’s
label: Paragraph

text: Tower anticipated the work of two distinct tendencies in
label: Paragraph

text: Russian avant-garde architecture. One of these was the
label: Paragraph

text: school which established itself within Vkhutemas, as part of
label: Paragraph

text: the first- and second-year course given by Nikolai A.
label: Paragraph

text: Ladovsky. This structuralist, or rather formalist, school
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to evolve a totally new syntax of plastic form,
label: Paragraph

text: based ostensibly on the laws of human perception. The
label: Paragraph

text: other was a much more materialist and programmatic
label: Paragraph

text: approach which clearly emerged in 1925 under the
label: Paragraph

text: leadership of the architect Moisei Ginzburg.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1921 Ladovsky urged that a research institute be
label: Paragraph

text: established at Vkhutemas for the systematic study of the
label: Paragraph

text: perception of form. Vkhutemas basic designs, carried out
label: Paragraph

text: under his supervision, always featured some rhythmic
label: Paragraph

text: delineation of the surfaces of pure forms or, alternatively,
label: Paragraph

text: studies into the growth and diminution of dynamic form
label: Title

text: according to the laws of mathematical progression. These
label: Paragraph

text: Vkhutemas exercises often featured geometrically
label: Paragraph

text: progressing volumes, rising or falling in both size and
label: Paragraph

text: location. On occasions these studies were proposed as
label: Paragraph

text: designs for actual buildings, as in the suspended restaurant
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Simbirchev about 1923 [164], a project whose
label: Paragraph

text: total transparency and extravagant access system echoed
label: Title

text: the expressive utilitarianism of the Productivists. Such a
label: Paragraph

text: fantastic structure was patently beyond the capacity of
label: Paragraph

text: Soviet engineering at the time, while its numerous changes
label: Paragraph

text: in level would surely have limited its use as a restaurant.
label: Paragraph

text: 164 Simbirchev in the Vkhutemas atelier of Ladovsky, project for a suspended
label: Caption

text: restaurant, c. 1922-23.
label: Caption

text: Ladovsky’s so-called ‘rationalism’ was anything but
label: Paragraph

text: programmatic, for he ultimately sought, as Lubetkin has
label: Paragraph

text: observed, a universalism of the Larousse type. Like the Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Classical artists of the late 18th century, he preferred to use
label: Paragraph

text: geometrical entities such as spheres and cubes, forms that
label: Paragraph

text: could be hypothetically associated with specific
label: Paragraph

text: psychological states. In 1923 Ladovsky tried to propagate
label: Paragraph

text: his views through the foundation of Asnova (Association of
label: Paragraph

text: New Architects), a professional group centred on
label: Paragraph

text: Vkhutemas. This organization attained its greatest influence
label: Paragraph

text: about 1925, when both Lissitzky and the architect
label: Paragraph

text: Konstantin Melnikov were associated with it. Like the
label: Paragraph

text: wooden demountable market stalls that he designed in
label: Caption

text: 1924 [165], Melnikov’s USSR Pavilion for the Paris
label: Caption

text: Exposition des Arts Décoratifs of 1925 [166] was a
label: Paragraph

text: synthesis of the more progressive aspects of Soviet
label: Title

text: architecture to date. In its imaginative use of lap-jointed
label: Paragraph

text: timber struts and planks, it recalled not only the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular of the Steppes, but also those exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: pavilions which had been designed for the All-Russian
label: Paragraph

text: Agricultural and Craft Exhibition of 1923, including the
label: Paragraph

text: Izvestia kiosk by the artists A.A. Exter, Gladkov and
label: Caption

text: Stenberg, and Melnikov’s own Makhorka Pavilion. In its basic
label: Paragraph

text: conception, Melnikov’s Pavilion reflected the rhythmic
label: Paragraph

text: formalism of the Ladovsky school. Its rectangular plot was
label: Paragraph

text: animated by a staircase traversing the diagonal which
label: Paragraph

text: divided the ground floor into two identical triangles. This
label: Paragraph

text: staircase, rising and falling through an open timber
label: Caption

text: construction forming criss-crossing planes, gave access only
label: Paragraph

text: to the upper levels of the structure. Such an intersecting
label: Paragraph

text: roof form was soon to become as prevalent a ‘geometrically
label: Paragraph

text: progressive’ device among the Russian avant garde as the
label: Paragraph

text: logarithmic spiral of the Tatlin Tower. Melnikov’s dynamic
label: Caption

text: timber structure was complemented by Rodchenko’s interior
label: Paragraph

text: for an ideal workers’ club featuring typical light-weight
label: Paragraph

text: Productivist furniture, including a dialectically red and black
label: Paragraph

text: chess-playing suite consisting of a table and two chairs.
label: Paragraph

text: 165 Melnikov, Sucharev Market, Moscow, 1924-25.
label: Caption

text: 166 Melnikov, USSR Pavilion, Exposition des Arts Décoratifs, Paris, 1925. Ground
label: Caption

text: plan, first-floor plan and elevation.
label: Caption

text: The Asnova group sought not only to achieve a more
label: Paragraph

text: scientific aesthetic, but also to devise new building forms
label: Paragraph

text: which would satisfy and express the conditions of the new
label: Paragraph

text: socialist state. Hence the preoccupation with workers’ clubs
label: Paragraph

text: and recreational facilities designed to function as new
label: Paragraph

text: ‘social condensers’. This drive to invent new forms also
label: Paragraph

text: accounts for Lissitzky’s attempt to reconstitute the
label: Paragraph

text: American skyscraper in a socialist form, in his Wolkenbugel
label: Paragraph

text: (‘cloud-hanger’) project of 1924, conceived as an elevated
label: Paragraph

text: propylaeum opening onto the peripheral boulevard
label: Title

text: surrounding the centre of Moscow. This work, however
label: Paragraph

text: bizarre, was intended as a critical antithesis to both the
label: Paragraph

text: capitalist skyscraper and the Classical gate.
label: Paragraph

text: Melnikov’s early Productivist works were all built in the
label: Paragraph

text: period of relative economic stability that resulted from
label: Paragraph

text: Lenin’s New Economic Policy (NEP), introduced after the
label: Paragraph

text: Civil War in March 1921 as a way of attracting foreign
label: Paragraph

text: capital into partnership with the Soviet Union. Lenin’s death
label: Caption

text: in January 1924 not only brought the period of NEP culture
label: Paragraph

text: to an end, but also presented the Party with the ironic
label: Paragraph

text: problem of finding an appropriate style for his tomb. While
label: Paragraph

text: the Productivist manner could be considered adequate for
label: Paragraph

text: the representation of the Soviet Union at an international
label: Title

text: exhibition of decorative art, it was much too insubstantial to
label: Paragraph

text: enshrine the founder of the first socialist state. Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Classicism, with its idealistic connotations, was equally
label: Paragraph

text: inappropriate. Something of this uncertainty is reflected in
label: Paragraph

text: the designs that the Academician Shchusev produced for
label: Paragraph

text: Lenin’s mausoleum. The first was a temporary wooden
label: Paragraph

text: structure, which despite its symmetry displayed affinities
label: Paragraph

text: with the Productivist aesthetic. The second, permanent
label: Paragraph

text: version in stone was an attempt at recreating the form of a
label: Paragraph

text: Central Asian Tartar tomb.
label: Paragraph

text: With Lenin’s death the heroic period of the Revolution
label: Title

text: came to a close. By now the Revolution had acquired a
label: Paragraph

text: definitive history, from the hard-won victory over the Whites
label: Paragraph

text: in the Civil War to the tragic suppression of the Kronstadt
label: Paragraph

text: revolt against the Party and the NEP establishment of state
label: Title

text: capitalism within the proletarian state. Deprived of Lenin’s
label: Paragraph

text: charisma, the immediate prospect was one of conflict rather
label: Paragraph

text: than resolution - the fight for succession within the Party,
label: Paragraph

text: the modernization of industry and agriculture, the campaign
label: Title

text: against illiteracy, the daily struggle to provide shelter and
label: Paragraph

text: food, the drive to electrify the country and the ever-present
label: Paragraph

text: need to forge a real link between the industrial, urban
label: Paragraph

text: proletariat and a dispersed and vestigially feudal peasant
label: Title

text: society. Above all, there arose the annual battle to extract
label: Paragraph

text: sufficient food for the urban populace from a recalcitrant
label: Paragraph

text: and alienated countryside, which had stubbornly resisted
label: Paragraph

text: the inducements it had received under the provisions of the
label: Paragraph

text: NEP.
label: Paragraph

text: The most chronic problem from an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: standpoint was clearly housing. Nothing had been built
label: Paragraph

text: since the beginning of the First World War, and the degree
label: Paragraph

text: to which the pre-war stock had deteriorated was reflected in
label: Paragraph

text: the proceedings of the 13th Party Congress of 1924, where
label: Paragraph

text: housing was recognized as ‘the most important question in
label: Paragraph

text: the material life of the workers’. Faced with the task of
label: Paragraph

text: meeting this deficiency, certain members of the younger
label: Paragraph

text: generation of architects felt that they could no longer
label: Paragraph

text: indulge in the formalist preoccupations of the Vkhutemas,
label: Paragraph

text: still under the influence of Ladovsky.
label: Paragraph

text: This reaction precipitated the formation of a new group,
label: Paragraph

text: the Association of Contemporary Architects (OSA), whose
label: Paragraph

text: initial membership, under the leadership of Ginzburg,
label: Paragraph

text: comprised M. Barshch, A. Burov, L. Komarova, Y. Kornfeld, M.
label: Caption

text: Okhitovich, A. Pasternak, G. Vegman, V. Vladimirov and the
label: Caption

text: brothers A. and V. Vesnin [167]. Soon after its foundation
label: Paragraph

text: OSA began to admit members from related fields, such as
label: Paragraph

text: sociology and engineering. OSA’s essentially programmatic
label: Paragraph

text: orientation was as antipathetic to the Productivist culture of
label: Paragraph

text: the Proletkult as it was to the perceptual aestheticism of
label: Paragraph

text: Ladovsky. From the outset it attempted to change the
label: Paragraph

text: modus operandi of the architect, from one who traditionally
label: Paragraph

text: had a craftsmanlike relation to his client to a new type of
label: Paragraph

text: professional who was first a sociologist, second a politician
label: Paragraph

text: and third a technician.
label: Paragraph

text: 167 Typical Constructivist works of the 1920s: Korschev, Spartakiada Stadium,
label: Caption

text: Moscow, 1926 (left: section of stand), and Vesnin, Pravda Building, Moscow,
label: Caption

text: 1923 (right: plans, section and view).
label: Paragraph

text: In 1926 OSA began to propagate these views in its
label: Paragraph

text: magazine, Sovremennaya Arkhitektura (or SA:
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Contemporary Architecture’), dedicated to the
label: Paragraph

text: incorporation of scientific methods into architectural
label: Title

text: practice. In the fourth issue OSA conducted an international
label: Paragraph

text: inquiry into flat-roofed construction, wherein Taut, Behrens,
label: Paragraph

text: Oud and Le Corbusier were asked to comment on the
label: Paragraph

text: technical viability and advantages of flat roofs. OSA also set
label: Paragraph

text: itself the task of formulating the necessary programmes and
label: Paragraph

text: type forms for an emerging Socialist society, concerning
label: Paragraph

text: itself as well with the broader issues of energy distribution
label: Paragraph

text: and population dispersal. Thus its prime concerns were: first
label: Paragraph

text: the issue of communal housing and the creation of
label: Title

text: appropriate social units, and second, the process of
label: Paragraph

text: distribution, namely transit in all its forms.
label: Paragraph

text: In pursuit of the former, it launched a second inquiry in
label: Paragraph

text: SA in 1927, as to the appropriate form of the new communal
label: Paragraph

text: dwelling or domkommuna. The replies received were used
label: Paragraph

text: as the basis for a fraternal competition that attempted to
label: Paragraph

text: develop and refine a new residential prototype, something
label: Paragraph

text: along the lines of Fourier’s phalanstery [168]. Most of the
label: Paragraph

text: entries gave symbolic and operational importance to an
label: Paragraph

text: internal double-loaded corridor, a volume formed by the
label: Paragraph

text: interlocking of up- and down-going duplex apartments. A
label: Paragraph

text: version of this section came to be adopted by Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: after 1932 as the ‘cross-over’ section of the typical block of
label: Paragraph

text: his Ville Radieuse.
label: Paragraph

text: 168 Ol, Ivanov and Lavinsky, interlocking duplex flats with central corridor, OSA
label: Caption

text: competition, 1927.
label: Caption

text: All this activity prompted the government to set up a
label: Paragraph

text: research group for the standardization of housing, under the
label: Paragraph

text: leadership of Ginzburg [169]. The work of this group led to
label: Paragraph

text: the development of a series of Stroikem units, one of which
label: Paragraph

text: was adopted by Ginzburg for his Narkomfin apartment block
label: Paragraph

text: built in Moscow in 1929. While its internal street or deck
label: Paragraph

text: system gave direct access to an adjunct block containing a
label: Paragraph

text: canteen, a gymnasium, a library, a day nursery and a roof
label: Paragraph

text: garden, Ginzburg remained acutely aware that this implied
label: Paragraph

text: collectivity could not be imposed on the residents through
label: Paragraph

text: the built form alone. He wrote at the time:
label: Paragraph

text: 169 Design for a compact kitchen module with concealing screens, by the
label: Caption

text: Building Committee of the Economic Council of the USSR, 1928.
label: Caption

text: We can no longer compe! the occupants of a particular
label: Paragraph

text: building to live collectively, as we have attempted to do in
label: Paragraph

text: the past, generally with negative results. We must provide
label: Paragraph

text: for the possibility of a gradual, natural transition to
label: Paragraph

text: communal utilization in a number of different areas. That is
label: Paragraph

text: why we have tried to keep each unit isolated from the next,
label: Paragraph

text: that is why we found it necessary to design the kitchen
label: Paragraph

text: alcove as a standard element of minimum size that could be
label: Paragraph

text: removed bodily from the apartment to permit the
label: Paragraph

text: introduction of canteen catering at any given moment. We
label: Paragraph

text: considered it absolutely necessary to incorporate certain
label: Paragraph

text: features that would stimulate the transition to a socially
label: Paragraph

text: superior mode of life, stimulate but not dictate.*
label: Paragraph

text: In the previous year, OSA had turned its attention to the
label: Paragraph

text: design of another type of ‘social condenser’, the workers’
label: Paragraph

text: club. Anatole Kopp has observed:
label: Paragraph

text: The year 1928 witnessed a mutation in club architecture. In
label: Paragraph

text: spite of all their innovations, the existing clubs, even the
label: Paragraph

text: most modern such as those designed by Melnikov and
label: Paragraph

text: Golosov, were sharply criticized for being centred on the
label: Paragraph

text: stage and tied to the professional theatre.°
label: Paragraph

text: The reaction of Ginzburg’s protégé, Ivan Leonidov, was to
label: Paragraph

text: project a totally different type of club, one which focused
label: Paragraph

text: more on educational institutions and athletic facilities. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1928 he began to produce a series of designs that were all,
label: Paragraph

text: in effect, versions of his remarkable Lenin Institute projected
label: Paragraph

text: a year earlier for a site in the Lenin Hills outside Moscow. His
label: Paragraph

text: design for this institute of advanced studies consisted of two
label: Paragraph

text: primary glazed forms: a rectilinear library tower and a
label: Caption

text: spherical auditorium resting on a single point. The whole
label: Paragraph

text: suspended, floating complex, stabilized by guying cables,
label: Paragraph

text: was to have been linked to the city by an elevated monorail.
label: Paragraph

text: Leonidov’s science-fiction concept of the club as a
label: Paragraph

text: Suprematist megastructure - a vision clearly influenced by
label: Paragraph

text: the work of Malevich - reached its climax in 1930 in his
label: Paragraph

text: Palace of Culture project [170], whose glazed auditoriums,
label: Paragraph

text: planetariums, laboratories and winter gardens were laid out
label: Paragraph

text: ona gridded rectilinear matrix that made few concessions
label: Paragraph

text: to traditional landscaping. Its inscribed, almost
label: Paragraph

text: metaphysical surface was relieved by clumps of luxuriant
label: Paragraph

text: vegetation and by prisms whose transparent forms, while
label: Paragraph

text: revelatory of their interiors, were not functionally
label: Paragraph

text: determined. The dirigible and mooring mast included in the
label: Paragraph

text: composition were clearly intended to exemplify the same
label: Paragraph

text: light-weight technology as would be used for the
label: Paragraph

text: earthbound structures - buildings whose integrated space-
label: Paragraph

text: frame construction anticipated the mid-century work of
label: Paragraph

text: designers such as Konrad Wachsmann and Buckminster
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller.
label: Paragraph

text: 170 Leonidov, project for a Palace of Culture, from the cover of SA, 1930,
label: Caption

text: showing the ‘physical culture sector’, ‘field for demonstrations’ and ‘popular
label: Paragraph

text: activities sector’.
label: Paragraph

text: In such complexes, Leonidov envisaged the enactment of
label: Paragraph

text: a continual process of education and recreation: athletics,
label: Paragraph

text: scientific demonstrations, political meetings, films, botanical
label: Title

text: displays, manifestations, flying, gliding, car racing and
label: Title

text: military exercises. The very utopianism of this vision
label: Paragraph

text: brought him under attack from the pro-Stalin group known
label: Paragraph

text: as Vopra (‘All-Russian Association of Proletarian Architects’),
label: Paragraph

text: who condemned such schemes for their vain idealism.
label: Paragraph

text: Before the consolidation of the Party line in architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: instituted by the Ukase of April 1932, finally suppressed the
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinary diversity of the Soviet architectural avant
label: Title

text: garde, OSA became involved in the question of ‘social
label: Paragraph

text: condensation’ on a much larger scale, at the level of
label: Paragraph

text: regional planning, which was then still in its infancy as an
label: Paragraph

text: applied science. For the main OSA planning theorist,
label: Paragraph

text: Okhitovich, the projected electrification of the Soviet Union
label: Title

text: offered itself as an infrastructural model for all forms of
label: Paragraph

text: regional planning. His strategy for the disurbanization of the
label: Paragraph

text: country, to be carried out literally along the lines of the
label: Paragraph

text: power grid and the road system, implied a critical attitude
label: Paragraph

text: towards the dom-kommuna and the supercommunes or
label: Paragraph

text: kombinats then being proposed by the main theorist of
label: Paragraph

text: urbanization, L. Sabsovich. Okhitovich wrote in 1930:
label: Paragraph

text: We have now arrived at a moment of disenchantment with
label: Paragraph

text: the so-called ‘commune’ that deprives the worker of living
label: Paragraph

text: space in favor of corridors and heated passages. The
label: Paragraph

text: pseudo-commune that allows the worker to do no more than
label: Paragraph

text: sleep at home, the pseudo-commune that deprives him of
label: Paragraph

text: both living space and personal convenience (the lines that
label: Paragraph

text: form outside bath-rooms and cloakrooms and in the
label: Paragraph

text: canteen) is beginning to provoke mass unrest.®
label: Paragraph

text: In the event, the supercollective communes came to be
label: Paragraph

text: discredited, not only for their social unacceptability but also
label: Paragraph

text: because their massive scale would have entailed the use of
label: Paragraph

text: sophisticated technology and scarce material resources. For
label: Paragraph

text: a while the disurbanization proposals of Okhitovich and N.A.
label: Paragraph

text: Milyutin found a favourable hearing in official circles. It
label: Paragraph

text: proved easier, however, to gain acceptance for a theoretical
label: Paragraph

text: policy than to devise an economical land settlement pattern
label: Paragraph

text: that could be generally applied throughout the country, and
label: Paragraph

text: for the remainder of its existence the OSA group was
label: Paragraph

text: somewhat divided as to how this could be best achieved.
label: Paragraph

text: After the linear city schemes of Arturo Soria y Mata, they
label: Paragraph

text: finally proposed ribbonlike settlements which, however
label: Paragraph

text: imaginative, were often quite arbitrary in their specific
label: Paragraph

text: configuration. Typical of such proposals was Barshch and
label: Paragraph

text: Ginzburg’s Green City scheme for the extension of Moscow,
label: Paragraph

text: published in 1930. This rather eccentric project comprised a
label: Paragraph

text: cranked continuous spine of ‘bachelor’ units raised on stilts,
label: Paragraph

text: which, aside from providing residential accommodation, was
label: Paragraph

text: apparently conceived as signifying the presence of the city.
label: Paragraph

text: On both sides of this spine communal facilities were
label: Paragraph

text: provided at 500-metre (1,640-foot) intervals. These
label: Paragraph

text: buildings were flanked with the usual complement of sports
label: Paragraph

text: fields and swimming pools and sited within continuous park
label: Title

text: strips lying on either side of the central spine, green ‘bands’
label: Paragraph

text: of varying width which were delimited on their outer edges
label: Paragraph

text: by the flow and return of one-way roads giving access to the
label: Paragraph

text: entire system. Ginzburg’s overall strategy was to use such
label: Paragraph

text: arteries for the progressive decantation of the existing
label: Title

text: population of Moscow, thereby allowing the old capital to
label: Paragraph

text: deteriorate and to revert gradually to semirustic parkland
label: Paragraph

text: within which significant monuments would remain as
label: Paragraph

text: reminders of past culture.
label: Paragraph

text: By far the most abstract and theoretically consistent
label: Paragraph

text: proposition was the linear-city principle advanced by
label: Paragraph

text: Milyutin, who argued in 1930 for a continuous city
label: Paragraph

text: comprising six parallel strips or zones. These zones were to
label: Paragraph

text: be arranged in the following sequence: (1) a railway zone;
label: Paragraph

text: (2) an industrial zone containing within itself, in addition to
label: Paragraph

text: production, centres for education and research; (3) a green
label: Title

text: zone accommodating the highway; (4) a residential zone
label: Paragraph

text: subdivided into communal institutions, dwellings, and a
label: Paragraph

text: juvenile area containing schools and kindergartens; (5) a
label: Paragraph

text: park zone with sports facilities; and finally (6) an agricultural
label: Paragraph

text: zone.
label: Paragraph

text: A specific political and economic intent informed this
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement. Both industrial and agricultural workers were
label: Paragraph

text: to be unified in the same residential zone, while any surplus
label: Paragraph

text: production from either industry or agriculture would flow
label: Title

text: directly into the warehouses situated in the railway or green
label: Paragraph

text: zones, to be temporarily stored there and later redistributed
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the country. In accordance with the same
label: Paragraph

text: ‘biological’ model, solid waste from the residential zone
label: Title

text: would be channelled directly to the agricultural zone for
label: Paragraph

text: recycling into food. After the principles laid down in the
label: Paragraph

text: Communist Manifesto of 1848, all secondary and technical
label: Title

text: education was to be carried out in the place of work, thus
label: Paragraph

text: assuring the unity of theory and practice. Of this biological
label: Paragraph

text: schema Milyutin wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: There must be no departure from the sequence of these six
label: Paragraph

text: zones as this would not only upset the whole plan but would
label: Paragraph

text: make the development and extension of each individual unit
label: Paragraph

text: impossible, create unhealthy living conditions, and
label: Paragraph

text: completely nullify the important advantages in respect of
label: Paragraph

text: production that the linear system embodies.’
label: Paragraph

text: In January 1929 the Soviet Government declared its
label: Paragraph

text: intention to found the city of Magnitogorsk in the eastern
label: Paragraph

text: Urals for the exploitation of iron deposits, and Milyutin and
label: Paragraph

text: other OSA architects such as Ginzburg and Leonidov
label: Paragraph

text: submitted schematic proposals for the new city [171].
label: Paragraph

text: These variously abstract schemes were rejected by the
label: Paragraph

text: authorities, who chose instead to commission the German
label: Paragraph

text: architect Ernst May and his Frankfurt team to design the
label: Paragraph

text: official plan for the town. The endless theoretical disputes of
label: Paragraph

text: the Russian architectural avant garde - the complex
label: Title

text: arguments and counterarguments of the ‘urbanists’ and the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘disurbanists’ finally brought the Soviet authorities to
label: Paragraph

text: circumvent such factional issues and to invite the more
label: Paragraph

text: pragmatic and experienced left-wing architects of the
label: Paragraph

text: Weimar Republic to apply their normative methods of
label: Paragraph

text: planning and production (their Ze/fenbau layout and their
label: Paragraph

text: rationalized building methods) to the task of realizing the
label: Paragraph

text: building of the first Five-Year Plan.
label: Caption

text: 171 Leonidov, project for Magnitogorsk, 1930. A 20-mile (32-kilometre) road
label: Caption

text: links the industrial plant to an agricultural commune in the interior.
label: Paragraph

text: The failure of OSA to develop sufficiently concrete
label: Title

text: proposals for planning on a large scale or to evolve
label: Paragraph

text: residential building types which were appropriate to the
label: Paragraph

text: needs and resources of a beleaguered socialist state, in
label: Paragraph

text: conjunction with the paranoid tendency that emerged under
label: Paragraph

text: Stalin for state censorship and control, had the effect of
label: Paragraph

text: bringing about the eclipse of ‘modern’ architecture in the
label: Paragraph

text: Soviet Union. For all his justifications of the need for
label: Paragraph

text: proletarian culture to be based on the ‘organic development
label: Paragraph

text: of those stores of knowledge which humanity has
label: Paragraph

text: accumulated under the yoke of capitalism’, there is little
label: Paragraph

text: doubt that Lenin’s repression of the Proletkult in October
label: Paragraph

text: 1920 was something of an initial step in the other direction.
label: Paragraph

text: It was certainly the first attempt to control the remarkable
label: Paragraph

text: creative forces that had been released by the Revolution.
label: Paragraph

text: Lenin’s NEP programme was clearly a second step,
label: Paragraph

text: inasmuch as it set limits on the scope of participatory
label: Paragraph

text: Communism. Above all, the economic compromise of NEP
label: Paragraph

text: seems to have entailed the recall and employment of
label: Paragraph

text: ‘politically unreliable’ experts from the bourgeois era, men
label: Paragraph

text: such as Shchusev, ironically commissioned to design Lenin’s
label: Paragraph

text: mausoleum. For all its effectiveness, this co-option of
label: Paragraph

text: bourgeois professionals under state supervision involved a
label: Paragraph

text: deep compromise that not only prejudiced the principles of
label: Paragraph

text: the Revolution but also inhibited the development of a
label: Paragraph

text: collective culture. On the other hand, the historical
label: Paragraph

text: circumstances were such that the people were largely
label: Paragraph

text: incapable of adopting the way of life posited by the socialist
label: Paragraph

text: intelligentsia. Furthermore, the failure of the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: avant garde to match their visionary proposals for such a
label: Paragraph

text: life with adequate levels of technical performance led to
label: Paragraph

text: their loss of credibility with the authorities. Finally, their
label: Paragraph

text: appeal to an international socialist culture was clearly
label: Paragraph

text: antithetical to Soviet policy after 1925, when Stalin
label: Paragraph

text: announced the decision to ‘build socialism in one country’.
label: Paragraph

text: That Stalin had no use whatsoever for élitist
label: Paragraph

text: internationalism was officially confirmed by Anatole
label: Paragraph

text: Lunacharsky’s nationalist and populist cultural slogan of
label: Paragraph

text: 1932, his famous ‘pillars for the people’, which effectively
label: Paragraph

text: committed Soviet architecture to a regressive form of
label: Paragraph

text: historicism from which it has yet to emerge.
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 22
label: Title

text: Le Corbusier and the Ville
label: Title

text: Radieuse 1928-46
label: Title

text: The machinery of Society, profoundly out of gear, oscillates
label: Paragraph

text: between an amelioration, of historical importance, and a
label: Paragraph

text: catastrophe.
label: Paragraph

text: The primordial instinct of every human being is to assure
label: Paragraph

text: himself of a shelter. The various classes of workers in
label: Paragraph

text: society today no longer have dwellings adapted to their
label: Paragraph

text: needs; neither the artisan nor the intellectual. It is a
label: Paragraph

text: question of building which is at the root of the social unrest
label: Paragraph

text: of today; architecture or revolution.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier
label: Title

text: Vers une architecture, 19231
label: Caption

text: After the League of Nations competition of 1927 the
label: Paragraph

text: Engineer’s Aesthetic and Architecture seemed to refer
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly to a schism within Le Corbusier’s own ideology,
label: Paragraph

text: rather than to an opposition that was capable of synthesis.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1928, this split was most evident in the contrast between
label: Paragraph

text: the undeniable monumentality of the Cité Mondiale and
label: Paragraph

text: those delicate pieces of light-weight tubular steel furniture
label: Title

text: that he designed at the same time with Charlotte Perriand -
label: Paragraph

text: le fauteuil a dossier basculant, le grand confort, la chaise
label: Caption

text: longue, la table ‘tube d’avion’ and le siége tournant - all of
label: Paragraph

text: which were exhibited at the Salon d’Automne of 1929. A
label: Paragraph

text: certain rationalization of this difference in approach had
label: Paragraph

text: been anticipated already in Purist aesthetic theory, which
label: Paragraph

text: had argued that the more intimate the relation between the
label: Paragraph

text: man and the object, the more the latter must reflect the
label: Paragraph

text: contours of his form, that is, the more it must approximate
label: Paragraph

text: to being the ergonomic equivalent of the Engineer’s
label: Paragraph

text: Aesthetic - and that conversely the more distant the
label: Paragraph

text: relation, the more the object will tend towards abstraction -
label: Paragraph

text: that is, towards Architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: As far as building was concerned this determination of
label: Paragraph

text: form through proximity and use was complicated by the
label: Paragraph

text: demands of large-scale production and by the consequent
label: Paragraph

text: necessity to distinguish between the creation of the one-off
label: Paragraph

text: monument and the potential advantage of using
label: Title

text: rationalized production methods for the general provision of
label: Paragraph

text: shelter. Such a distinction seems to have been the motive
label: Paragraph

text: for Le Corbusier abandoning his perimeter block, otherwise
label: Paragraph

text: known as the Immeuble-Villa, in favour of a building form
label: Paragraph

text: more suited to mass production, namely his 2 redent Ville
label: Paragraph

text: Radieuse block projected as a continuous band of ‘on-line’
label: Paragraph

text: housing. Based on Eugéne Hénard’s Boulevard a Redans of
label: Paragraph

text: 1903 (the term redan being borrowed like the term
label: Paragraph

text: boulevard from the vocabulary of fortification), Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s redent form consisted of a continuous terrace
label: Paragraph

text: whose frontage was alternately and regularly set back from
label: Paragraph

text: or aligned with the outer limits of the street.
label: Paragraph

text: The difference in the organization of the dwelling units in
label: Paragraph

text: these two types was as significant as the difference
label: Paragraph

text: between their exterior form. Where the Immeuble-Villa was
label: Paragraph

text: predicated (as its name suggests) on the qualitative
label: Paragraph

text: provision of the house with its ‘hanging garden’ as an
label: Paragraph

text: autonomous unit, the Ville Radieuse type seems to have
label: Paragraph

text: been orientated towards more economic criteria, that is,
label: Paragraph

text: towards the quantitative standards of serial production.
label: Paragraph

text: Where the Immeuble-Villa incorporated an ample garden
label: Paragraph

text: terrace and a double-height living space, of fixed
label: Paragraph

text: dimensions irrespective of family size, the Ville Radieuse
label: Paragraph

text: (VR) unit was a flexible, single-storey apartment of varying
label: Paragraph

text: extent, more economical in terms of space than the double-
label: Paragraph

text: height duplex section [172]. The VR unit optimized every
label: Paragraph

text: available square centimetre of space, its partitions being
label: Paragraph

text: reduced in thickness to the point of becoming inadequate as
label: Paragraph

text: acoustical barriers. To similar ends, the service cores,
label: Paragraph

text: namely the kitchens and bathrooms, were reduced to a
label: Paragraph

text: minimum. Moreover, each apartment was made capable of
label: Paragraph

text: a certain transformation from night to day use, through the
label: Paragraph

text: withdrawal of sliding partitions. When closed these elements
label: Paragraph

text: subdivided the sleeping spaces and when open they yielded
label: Paragraph

text: a children’s play area that could be made continuous with
label: Paragraph

text: the living room. Through such devices the typical VR
label: Paragraph

text: apartment was designed to be as ergonomically efficient as
label: Paragraph

text: the sleeping cabins of a wagon-/it, and indeed Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: used many of the same space standards. With air
label: Paragraph

text: conditioning and sealed facades, this was clearly an attempt
label: Paragraph

text: to provide the normative equipment of a machine-age
label: Paragraph

text: civilization. Close to product design and remote from
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in the traditional sense, the VR block could
label: Paragraph

text: hardly have been further from the ethos of the Cité
label: Paragraph

text: Mondiale.
label: Paragraph

text: 172 Le Corbusier and Jeanneret, Ville Radieuse, 1931. Plan of a five-bedroom
label: Caption

text: unit.
label: Paragraph

text: This shift from the self-contained perimeter block to the
label: Paragraph

text: continuous housing terrace and from the bourgeois standard
label: Paragraph

text: of the ‘villa’ to an industrialized norm, may well have been a
label: Paragraph

text: response to the technocratic challenge of the left-wing of
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM - those German and Czech Neue Sachlichkeit
label: Title

text: architects whom Le Corbusier would have first encountered
label: Paragraph

text: at the founding CIAM congress of 1928 (see p. 146). These
label: Paragraph

text: ‘materialist’ designers challenged Le Corbusier again, at
label: Paragraph

text: Frankfurt in 1929, on the occasion of the first working
label: Paragraph

text: session of CIAM, dedicated under the title
label: Caption
