text: ‘Existenzminimum’ to determining optimum criteria for the
label: Paragraph

text: minimum standard dwelling. In repudiating the reductivist
label: Paragraph

text: approach of architects such as Ernst May and Hannes
label: Paragraph

text: Meyer, Le Corbusier rhetorically proclaimed the space
label: Paragraph

text: standards of his maison maximum, which happened to be
label: Paragraph

text: an ironic play with the name of the economy car, voiture
label: Paragraph

text: maximum, that he had designed with Pierre Jeanneret in the
label: Paragraph

text: previous year [173]. In this last respect they were to be
label: Paragraph

text: proven right, since their voiture maximum became the
label: Paragraph

text: prototype for the austerity vehicles that were to be
label: Paragraph

text: produced on a large scale in Europe after the Second World
label: Paragraph

text: War.
label: Paragraph

text: 173 Le Corbusier and Jeanneret, voiture maximum, 1928.
label: Caption

text: This Neue Sachlichkeit encounter and the three visits
label: Title

text: that Le Corbusier made to Russia between 1928 and 1930
label: Paragraph

text: brought him into close contact with the international Left, so
label: Paragraph

text: much so that a Western reactionary critic, Alexandre de
label: Paragraph

text: Senger, could denounce him soon after as being the Trojan
label: Paragraph

text: Horse of Bolshevism. Of greater consequence for his later
label: Paragraph

text: development, however, was his exposure to the Russian
label: Paragraph

text: OSA housing prototypes of 1927, with their interlocking
label: Paragraph

text: duplex units, and his further encounter with the linear-city
label: Paragraph

text: concepts of N.A. Milyutin. Both of these ideas soon emerged
label: Paragraph

text: in his own work, the ‘crossover’ duplex section in 1932 and
label: Paragraph

text: the ‘linear-industrial’ city in 1935. Once assimilated, they
label: Paragraph

text: were reformulated by him in the mid-1940s: the former as
label: Paragraph

text: the prototypical section of his Unité d’Habitation and the
label: Paragraph

text: latter as the Cité Industrielle that was central to his regional
label: Paragraph

text: planning thesis entitled Les Trois Etablissements humains.
label: Paragraph

text: By way of return, so to speak, he attempted to introduce the
label: Paragraph

text: glass curtain wall into the Soviet Union, as part of his
label: Paragraph

text: technically ‘progressive’ but ultimately troublesome
label: Paragraph

text: Tsentrosoyuz building erected in Moscow in 1929. This
label: Paragraph

text: double-layered glass wall (a standard technique of the Swiss
label: Paragraph

text: Jura and used by him in the Villa Schwob) could not in the
label: Paragraph

text: event withstand the rigours of a Russian winter. All the
label: Paragraph

text: same, it was still included as a technical element in his 1930
label: Paragraph

text: reply to a Moscow questionnaire, entitled Réponse a
label: Paragraph

text: Moscou, a document for which it seems the plates of the
label: Paragraph

text: Ville Radieuse were specially prepared.
label: Paragraph

text: Transformations in his urban prototypes in the 1920s, in
label: Paragraph

text: which the ‘hierarchic’ Ville Contemporaine of 1922 became
label: Paragraph

text: the ‘classless’ Ville Radieuse of 1930, involved significant
label: Paragraph

text: changes in Le Corbusier’s way of conceiving the machine-
label: Paragraph

text: age city: amongst which the most important was the move
label: Paragraph

text: away from a centralized city model to a theoretically
label: Title

text: limitless concept, whose principle of order stemmed from it
label: Paragraph

text: being zoned, like the Milyutin linear city, into parallel bands.
label: Paragraph

text: In the Ville Radieuse these bands were assigned to the
label: Paragraph

text: following uses [174]: (1) satellite cities dedicated to
label: Paragraph

text: education, (2) business zone, (3) transportation zone,
label: Paragraph

text: including passenger rail and air transport, (4) hotel and
label: Paragraph

text: embassy zone, (5) residential zone, (6) green zone, (7) light
label: Paragraph

text: industrial zone, (8) warehouses plus freight rail and (9)
label: Paragraph

text: heavy industry. It was paradoxical, to say the least, that
label: Paragraph

text: something of a Humanist, anthropomorphic metaphor was
label: Paragraph

text: still inserted into this model. This much is evident from his
label: Paragraph

text: explicatory sketches of the period which show the isolated
label: Paragraph

text: ‘head’ of the sixteen cruciform skyscrapers above the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘heart’ of the cultural centre, located between the two
label: Paragraph

text: halves or ‘lungs’ of the residential zone. Aside from the
label: Paragraph

text: distortions induced by such biological metaphors the linear
label: Paragraph

text: model was strictly adhered to, thereby allowing less
label: Paragraph

text: hierarchic zones to expand independently of one another.
label: Paragraph

text: 174 Le Corbusier and Jeanneret, Ville Radieuse, 1931. Plan showing zoning in
label: Caption

text: parallel bands: from offices (top) via housing (middle) to industry.
label: Paragraph

text: The Ville Radieuse took the open-city concept of the Ville
label: Paragraph

text: Contemporaine to its logical conclusion, and a typical
label: Paragraph

text: section through the entire city showed all the structures
label: Paragraph

text: raised clear of the ground, including the garages and the
label: Paragraph

text: access roads. By virtue of elevating everything on pi/lotis the
label: Paragraph

text: ground surface would have become a continuous park in
label: Paragraph

text: which the pedestrian would have been free to wander at
label: Paragraph

text: will. The typical transverse section of the VR block and the
label: Paragraph

text: glass curtain wall or pan-verre in which it was enveloped
label: Paragraph

text: were equally crucial to the provision of the ‘essential joys’ of
label: Paragraph

text: ‘sun’, ‘space’ and ‘green’, this last being guaranteed not
label: Paragraph

text: only by the park, but also by the roof garden, running along
label: Paragraph

text: the top of the continuous redent block.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1929, before finalizing his plans for the ‘radiant city’,
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier visited South America where, piloted by the
label: Paragraph

text: pioneer aviators Jean Mermoz and Antoine de Saint-Exupéry,
label: Paragraph

text: he had the stimulating experience of surveying a tropical
label: Paragraph

text: landscape from the air. From such a vantage point, Rio de
label: Paragraph

text: Janeiro impressed him as a natural linear city, laid out like a
label: Paragraph

text: narrow ribbon along its corniche, with the sea on one side
label: Paragraph

text: and steep, volcanic rocks on the other. The form of this
label: Paragraph

text: urban terrain seems to have spontaneously suggested the
label: Paragraph

text: idea of the viaduct city, and Le Corbusier immediately
label: Paragraph

text: sketched [176] an extension of Rio in the form of a coastal
label: Paragraph

text: highway, some 6 kilometres (3% miles) in length, elevated
label: Paragraph

text: 100 metres (305 feet) above the ground and comprising
label: Paragraph

text: fifteen floors of ‘artificial sites’ for residential use stacked
label: Caption

text: beneath its road surface. The resultant megastructure was
label: Paragraph

text: shown in section as elevated above the average roof height
label: Paragraph

text: of the city.
label: Paragraph

text: This inspired proposal led directly to the plans for Algiers
label: Paragraph

text: developed during the years 1930 to 1933. The first of these
label: Paragraph

text: projected a motorway megastructure for the entire length of
label: Paragraph

text: an equally spectacular corniche, given the code name
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Obus’ because its concave enclosure of the bay resembled
label: Paragraph

text: the trajectory of a shell [175]. (Note once again the
label: Paragraph

text: appropriation of a military term.) With six floors beneath its
label: Paragraph

text: road surface and twelve above the idea of the ‘viaduct city’
label: Paragraph

text: came into its own. Set some 5 metres (6 feet) apart, each of
label: Paragraph

text: these floors constituted an artificial site, on which individual
label: Paragraph

text: owners were envisaged as erecting two-storey units ‘in any
label: Paragraph

text: style they saw fit’. This provision of a public but pluralistic
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructure, designed for individual appropriation, was
label: Paragraph

text: destined to find considerable currency among the
label: Paragraph

text: anarchistic architectural avant garde of the post-Second
label: Title

text: World War period (for instance, in urban infrastructures
label: Paragraph

text: proposed by Yona Friedman and Nicolaas Habraken).
label: Paragraph

text: 175 Le Corbusier and Jeanneret, ‘Plan Obus’ for Algiers, 1930.
label: Caption

text: 176 Le Corbusier, corniche extensions for Rio de Janiero, 1930.
label: Caption

text: The ‘erotic’ plan configurations created for the cities of
label: Paragraph

text: Rio de Janeiro and Algiers seem to have been related to
label: Paragraph

text: certain transformations in the expressive structure of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s painting, which after 1926 began to move from
label: Paragraph

text: Purist abstraction towards sensuously figurative
label: Title

text: compositions, featuring his so-called objets a réaction
label: Paragraph

text: poétique. Female figures first appeared in his painting at
label: Paragraph

text: this time and the sensuous, heavy manner in which these
label: Paragraph

text: were rendered lent a certain substance to his claim that, like
label: Paragraph

text: Delacroix, he had rediscovered the essence of female
label: Paragraph

text: beauty in the casbah of Algiers.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s 1930 Algiers plan was his last urban
label: Paragraph

text: proposal of overwhelming grandeur. Reminiscent of the
label: Paragraph

text: sensuous spirit of Gaudi’s Park Guell, his ecstatic
label: Paragraph

text: enthusiasm seems to have spent itself here in a passionate
label: Paragraph

text: poem to the natural beauty of the Mediterranean. From now
label: Paragraph

text: on his approach to city planning was to be more pragmatic,
label: Paragraph

text: while his urban building types gradually assumed less
label: Paragraph

text: idealized forms. The cruciform Cartesian skyscraper was
label: Paragraph

text: abandoned in favour of the Y-shaped office block, with which
label: Paragraph

text: it was possible to achieve a more favourable distribution of
label: Paragraph

text: sun over the entire surface of the building. Similarly, his
label: Paragraph

text: typical VR redent block was distorted into an Arabesque
label: Paragraph

text: form in the Obus plan and then phased out entirely. This last
label: Paragraph

text: modification, which led to his adoption of the free-standing
label: Paragraph

text: slab as his basic residential type (compare the Unité slab of
label: Paragraph

text: 1952), came with his 1935 proposals for the towns of
label: Paragraph

text: Nemours in North Africa and Zlin in Czechoslovakia [177].
label: Paragraph

text: While both of these plans were projected for steeply sloping
label: Paragraph

text: sites - for which the free-standing slab was eminently
label: Paragraph

text: suitable - their chequerboard layout, set appropriately
label: Paragraph

text: against the fall of the land, became a formula which was
label: Paragraph

text: soon to be applied everywhere irrespective of the
label: Paragraph

text: topography. As the typical Corbusian solution to high-
label: Paragraph

text: density housing it was to be copied with disastrous
label: Paragraph

text: consequences in a great deal of subsequent urban
label: Paragraph

text: development, and the alienating environment created in
label: Paragraph

text: many of the post-war grands ensembles clearly owes much
label: Paragraph

text: to the influence of this model.
label: Paragraph

text: 177 Le Corbusier and Jeanneret, plan for Zlin, Czechoslovakia, 1935, showing it
label: Caption

text: organized as a linear city in parallel bands.
label: Paragraph

text: Aside from the context it afforded for the evolution of the
label: Paragraph

text: Unité slab form, the significance of Zlin, designed for the
label: Paragraph

text: shoe manufacturer Bata, lies in its ingenious adaptation of
label: Paragraph

text: the Milyutin linear-city proposal to a specific site. In linking
label: Paragraph

text: the old town and manufacturing centre of Zlin at the bottom
label: Paragraph

text: of the valley to the executive airport situated on the
label: Paragraph

text: plateau, the road and railway paralleled the length of the
label: Paragraph

text: valley, with the new industry on one side and the company
label: Paragraph

text: housing on the other. Zlin thus became Le Corbusier’s first
label: Paragraph

text: formulation of the linear city after the Soviet model, a type
label: Paragraph

text: to be designated by him later as one of the three productive
label: Paragraph

text: units (i.e. Etablissements humains), the other two being the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional radially planned city and the ‘agricultural co-
label: Paragraph

text: operative’.
label: Paragraph

text: The argument put forward in Les Trojs Etablissements
label: Paragraph

text: humains of 1944 was largely a reinterpretation of the
label: Paragraph

text: regional planning theses that had already been advanced by
label: Paragraph

text: the German geographer Walter Kristaller and the Spanish
label: Title

text: linear-city theorist Arturo Soria y Mata. Le Corbusier derived
label: Paragraph

text: his own regional model from Kristaller’s law of urban
label: Paragraph

text: development which held that, other factors being equal,
label: Paragraph

text: urban settlements in Germany had always occurred at the
label: Paragraph

text: intersections of triangular or hexagonal grids. Using Soria y
label: Paragraph

text: Mata’s idea of the linear suburb Le Corbusier merely
label: Paragraph

text: complemented the Kristaller analysis by proposing that all
label: Paragraph

text: links between existing radio-concentric cities should be
label: Paragraph

text: developed as linear-industrial settlements. He went on to
label: Paragraph

text: show that the interstices within the grid could then be
label: Paragraph

text: developed as agricultural cooperatives. For this
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensive-regional approach it was necessary to
label: Paragraph

text: develop a new typology on an increased scale. Zlin was to
label: Paragraph

text: serve as the generic ‘linear-industrial city’, and the ‘radiant
label: Paragraph

text: farm’ and the ‘radiant village’ designed in 1933 for the
label: Paragraph

text: Syndicalist agricultural worker Norbert Bezard were to be
label: Paragraph

text: posited as the constituent elements of the new agricultural
label: Paragraph

text: cooperative.
label: Paragraph

text: Les Trois Etablissements humains, with which, according
label: Paragraph

text: to Le Corbusier, one could both urbanize the town and
label: Paragraph

text: urbanize the country, was an attempt to resolve the conflict
label: Paragraph

text: that had bitterly divided the Russian urban planners of the
label: Paragraph

text: late 1920s, between the de-urbanists who had wanted to
label: Paragraph

text: redistribute the existing population throughout the Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: Union and the urbanists who had advocated the
label: Paragraph

text: maintenance of existing towns and the creation of additional
label: Title

text: urban centres.
label: Paragraph

text: While the radiant city was never realized, its influence as
label: Paragraph

text: an evolving model on post-war urban development in
label: Paragraph

text: Europe and elsewhere was extensive. In addition to
label: Paragraph

text: innumerable housing schemes, the specific organization of
label: Paragraph

text: two new capital cities was clearly indebted to ideas
label: Paragraph

text: embodied in the Ville Radieuse: namely Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: master plan for Chandigarh of 1950 and Lucio Costa's plan
label: Caption

text: for Brasilia of 1957. Le Corbusier’s basic acceptance of the
label: Paragraph

text: existing garden-city layout for Chandigarh, as produced by
label: Paragraph

text: the American planner Albert Mayer in the very same year,
label: Paragraph

text: made it sufficiently clear that he had effectively abandoned
label: Paragraph

text: any notion of creating a finite city of significant form and
label: Paragraph

text: that he had shifted his general approach to promoting
label: Paragraph

text: models of dynamic growth on a regional scale. For all his
label: Paragraph

text: modification of the Mayer plan, his ‘ideal city’ came to be
label: Paragraph

text: reduced at this juncture to the government centre alone, the
label: Paragraph

text: Chandigarh Capitol of 1950. This realist strategy had
label: Paragraph

text: already been anticipated in his plan for St-Dié of 1946. From
label: Paragraph

text: now on, like the masters of the Renaissance, he seems to
label: Paragraph

text: have been prepared to make up for the unrealizable whole
label: Paragraph

text: through the projection of a representational element on a
label: Paragraph

text: monumental scale.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout the first half of the 1930s this latent
label: Paragraph

text: monumentalizing tendency in no way diminished Le
label: Title

text: Corbusier’s interest in equipping the ‘machine-age’
label: Paragraph

text: civilization. He continued to address himself to industrialists
label: Paragraph

text: and called attention wherever possible to his capacity for
label: Paragraph

text: designing the large-scale objets-types, regarded by him as
label: Paragraph

text: being essential to the equipment of a new age. Such indeed
label: Paragraph

text: were the four major buildings that he realized between 1932
label: Paragraph

text: and 1933: the Maison Clarté apartments in Geneva, the
label: Caption

text: Pavillon Suisse in the Cité Universitaire, the Salvation Army
label: Caption

text: Building and his own Porte Molitor apartments [178], the
label: Paragraph

text: last three all being built in Paris. The modular, glass and
label: Paragraph

text: steel, pan-verre facade employed in each case was intended
label: Paragraph

text: to demonstrate the ‘machine-age’ aesthetic. As such it
label: Paragraph

text: represented a break with the concrete frame and rendered
label: Paragraph

text: blockwork used in the villas of the 1920s. This apotheosis of
label: Paragraph

text: the Engineer’s Aesthetic paradoxically occurred at just that
label: Paragraph

text: moment when Le Corbusier was beginning to lose his faith
label: Paragraph

text: in the inevitable triumph of the machine age. Soon after
label: Paragraph

text: 1933 he began to react against the rationalized production
label: Paragraph

text: of the machine a habiter, although whether from disillusion
label: Paragraph

text: with modern technique as such or from despair in the face
label: Paragraph

text: of a world torn apart by economic depression and political
label: Title

text: reaction it is hard to know. As Robert Fishman has pointed
label: Paragraph

text: out, he had always maintained a certain ambivalence with
label: Paragraph

text: regard to the promise of Taylorized mass production:
label: Paragraph

text: 178 Le Corbusier, Porte Molitor apartments. Paris, 1933.
label: Caption

text: Le Corbusier’s quest for Authority in the Thirties reflects
label: Paragraph

text: finally his deeply ambivalent attitude towards
label: Paragraph

text: industrialization. His social thought and his architecture
label: Paragraph

text: rested on the faith that industrial society had the inherent
label: Paragraph

text: capacity for a genuine and joyous order. But behind that
label: Paragraph

text: faith, there was the fear that a perverted, uncontrolled
label: Paragraph

text: industrialization could destroy civilization. As a young man
label: Paragraph

text: at La Chaux-de-Fonds he had seen ugly, mass-produced
label: Paragraph

text: time-pieces from Germany virtually wipe out the watch-
label: Paragraph

text: maker's crafts. The lesson was not forgotten.2
label: Caption

text: Whatever the ultimate cause, primitive technical
label: Paragraph

text: elements began to appear in his work with increasing
label: Paragraph

text: frequency and freedom of expression from 1930 onwards.
label: Paragraph

text: First in the pitched-roofed, timber and stone Errazuriz House
label: Caption

text: projected in 1930 for Chile [179], then in the rubble-walled
label: Paragraph

text: villa built for Madame Mandrot near Toulon in 1931, and
label: Paragraph

text: finally in two remarkable works of 1935 and 1937
label: Paragraph

text: respectively: a concrete, vaulted weekend house built in the
label: Paragraph

text: suburbs of Paris and his light-weight, canvas Pavillon des
label: Caption

text: Temps Nouveaux, erected for the Paris International
label: Caption

text: Exhibition of 1937. While the roof of the former recalled not
label: Paragraph

text: only his Maison Monol of 1919, but more profoundly the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional barrel-vaulted construction of the Mediterranean,
label: Paragraph

text: the latter evoked not only the nomadic tent but also that
label: Paragraph

text: reconstruction of the Hebraic temple in the wilderness which
label: Paragraph

text: he had chosen to illustrate in Vers une architecture as an
label: Paragraph

text: example of regulating lines. With this series of works the
label: Paragraph

text: burden of expression now shifted from abstract form to the
label: Paragraph

text: means of construction itself. As Le Corbusier was to remark
label: Paragraph

text: of his weekend house: ‘The planning of such a house
label: Title

text: demanded extreme care, the elements of construction were
label: Paragraph

text: the sole architectural means.’ Despite the archaic and
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular references, both works still exploited aspects of
label: Paragraph

text: advanced technology, the weekend house making telling
label: Title

text: use of reinforced concrete, plywood and glass lenses and
label: Paragraph

text: the pavilion making a spectacular demonstration of steel
label: Paragraph

text: cable suspension in such a way as to recall the jointing
label: Paragraph

text: techniques which were then the province of aeronautical
label: Paragraph

text: construction. Finally both works seemed to be sophisticated
label: Paragraph

text: metaphors for a less doctrinaire future when men would
label: Paragraph

text: freely mix primitive and advanced techniques according to
label: Paragraph

text: their needs and resources (see Chapter 27).
label: Paragraph

text: 179 Le Corbusier and Jeanneret, Errazuriz House, Chile, 1930.
label: Caption

text: How resources in general might best be allocated in
label: Paragraph

text: socio-political terms was first explicitly formulated by Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier in the contributions that he made from January
label: Paragraph

text: 1931 to the monthly Syndicalist journal, Plan, edited by
label: Caption

text: Philippe Lamour, Hubert Lagardelle, Francois Pierrefeu and
label: Title

text: Pierre Winter. In December 1931, in an essay entitled
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Décisions’, he established the political preconditions under
label: Paragraph

text: which his urban ideas might be fulfilled. His
label: Paragraph

text: recommendation that urban land should be requisitioned by
label: Paragraph

text: the state gave adequate ammunition to the forces of
label: Paragraph

text: reaction, who had already chosen to see him as a Bolshevik
label: Paragraph

text: in disguise; while his demand that the state should forbid by
label: Paragraph

text: edict the production of useless consumer goods must have
label: Paragraph

text: disturbed those on the technocratic right, who might
label: Paragraph

text: otherwise have taken him as an unequivocal representative
label: Paragraph

text: of their interests.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1932 Le Corbusier broke with Lamour and became a
label: Paragraph

text: member of the Committee for Regionalist and Syndicalist
label: Title

text: Action and a contributory editor of its journal Pré/ude, edited
label: Paragraph

text: by Hubert Lagardelle. As a protégé of Georges Sorel,
label: Paragraph

text: Lagardelle had close ties with the left wing of the Italian
label: Paragraph

text: Fascist movement and as such was cautiously pro-Fascist.
label: Paragraph

text: The text of La Ville Radieuse, issued as a book in 1933, had
label: Paragraph

text: previously appeared in instalments under the sign of an
label: Paragraph

text: authoritarian brand of Syndicalism, first in Plan and then,
label: Paragraph

text: after 1932, in Pré/ude. Le Corbusier, influenced no doubt by
label: Paragraph

text: the strong Syndicalist traditions of the Jura region,
label: Paragraph

text: vacillated, like his fellow Syndicalists, between the
label: Paragraph

text: authoritarian utopian socialism of Saint-Simon and the
label: Title

text: anarcho-socialist tendencies latent in the writings of Fourier.
label: Paragraph

text: In La Ville Radieuse, Le Corbusier advocated, along
label: Paragraph

text: Syndicalist lines, a direct system of government through the
label: Paragraph

text: métiers (trade guilds or unions), yet like his editorial
label: Paragraph

text: colleagues he seems to have had only the vaguest idea as
label: Paragraph

text: to how this reign of the métiers could be established.
label: Paragraph

text: Tacitly accepting yet forever postponing the eventuality
label: Paragraph

text: of a general strike as the only access to power, the French
label: Paragraph

text: Syndicalists of the 1930s were for reform rather than
label: Paragraph

text: revolution and for the rationalization of the state rather than
label: Title

text: its abolition. While pro-industrialist and progressive, they
label: Paragraph

text: remained nostalgic for a pre-industrial harmony; while anti-
label: Paragraph

text: capitalist, they were nonetheless promoters of a
label: Paragraph

text: technocratic élite; for while opposed to the oligarchy of the
label: Paragraph

text: Bolshevik state, they simultaneously advocated technocratic
label: Paragraph

text: authority. With greater consistency they were fervently
label: Paragraph

text: internationalist and pacifist and against the waste of
label: Title

text: armament production and laissez-faire consumption. In
label: Paragraph

text: support of the Syndicalist polemic, in 1938 Le Corbusier was
label: Paragraph

text: to write his most polemical book, bearing the prophetic, if
label: Paragraph

text: ironic, title Des canons, des munitions? Merci! Des logis ...
label: Paragraph

text: S.V.P. [180]. Despite their radical discourse, the Syndicalists
label: Paragraph

text: were unable to establish a popular base. The gap between
label: Paragraph

text: the provisions of a welfare state and the possibility of a
label: Title

text: mass culture of high quality did not escape Le Corbusier,
label: Paragraph

text: who with characteristic aloofness deprecated the ostensible
label: Paragraph

text: populism of the housing envisaged as being provided under
label: Paragraph

text: the auspices of the Loi Loucheur promulgated in 1929.
label: Paragraph

text: 180 Le Corbusier, ver of Des canons, des munitions? Merci! Des logis... S.V.P,
label: Caption

text: Chapter 23
label: Title

text: Frank Lloyd Wright and
label: Title

text: the Disappearing City
label: Title

text: According to reports in the press Henry Ford has issued an
label: Paragraph

text: order whereby all married workers and employees in their
label: Paragraph

text: spare time are to cultivate vegetables in their own gardens
label: Paragraph

text: to detailed instructions given by experts employed by him
label: Paragraph

text: for this purpose, the idea being that by this means they will
label: Paragraph

text: be able to supply the greater part of their own
label: Paragraph

text: requirements. The necessary garden land is to be placed at
label: Paragraph

text: their disposal. Henry Ford has said, ‘Self help is the only
label: Paragraph

text: means of combatting the economic depression. Anyone
label: Paragraph

text: refusing to cultivate his garden will be dismissed.’
label: Paragraph

text: Die Heimstatte, no. 10, 19311
label: Caption

text: The second significant phase of Wright’s career was initiated
label: Paragraph

text: by the completion of the last of his concrete-block houses,
label: Paragraph

text: in Tulsa, Oklahoma, in 1929, and by the first of his projects
label: Paragraph

text: to exploit to the limit the cantilevering capacity of reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete, his Elizabeth Noble Apartments projected for Los
label: Paragraph

text: Angeles. The crystalline aesthetic of these apartments had
label: Paragraph

text: already been anticipated in his National Life Insurance
label: Paragraph

text: Building project for Chicago of 1924 [181], whose
label: Paragraph

text: scintillating copper and glass facade was a direct translation
label: Paragraph

text: of his ‘textured concrete block’ aesthetic into glass.
label: Paragraph

text: 181 Wright, project for the National Life Insurance Building, Chicago, 1924.
label: Caption

text: The economic mass production of the automobile by
label: Paragraph

text: Henry Ford and the impact of the Depression seem to have
label: Paragraph

text: had the effect of rousing Wright from his Eldorado dreams,
label: Paragraph

text: from the ‘instant’ culture of his Mayan houses, built for rich,
label: Paragraph

text: displaced aesthetes in the lush hills of southern California.
label: Paragraph

text: Influenced by the role then being played by the Neue
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit in Europe, Wright was induced to formulate a
label: Paragraph

text: new role for architecture in restructuring the social order of
label: Paragraph

text: the United States.
label: Paragraph

text: Ever since his address ‘The Art and Craft of the Machine’
label: Paragraph

text: (1901), Wright had recognized that it was the destiny of the
label: Paragraph

text: machine to bring about a profound change in the nature of
label: Paragraph

text: civilization. His initial reaction, lasting until 1916, had been
label: Paragraph

text: to adapt the machine to the creation of a high-level craft
label: Paragraph

text: culture, that is, to apply it to the direct formation of his
label: Paragraph

text: Prairie Style. Despite the fact that, for Wright, ‘machine’
label: Paragraph

text: expression always seemed to involve a certain rhetorical
label: Paragraph

text: use of the cantilever (the Robie House of 1909 is a typical
label: Paragraph

text: example), he still insisted on the ultimate authority of
label: Paragraph

text: traditional materials and methods. Although anticipated in
label: Paragraph

text: the Coonley House (1908) and in Midway Gardens (1914) it
label: Paragraph

text: was the mid-1920s before Wright considered the assembly
label: Paragraph

text: of entire structures from mass-produced synthetic elements,
label: Paragraph

text: such as the concrete-block mosaic of his Californian houses
label: Paragraph

text: or the modular curtain wall system that he devised for the
label: Paragraph

text: enclosure of monolithic concrete structures.
label: Paragraph

text: In being forced by the economy to recognize the limits of
label: Paragraph

text: traditional materials and construction, Wright was caused to
label: Paragraph

text: abandon the earthbound syntax of his Prairie Style, and
label: Paragraph

text: through a singular combination of reinforced concrete and
label: Paragraph

text: glass he created a prismatic, faceted architecture whose
label: Paragraph

text: glass exterior, borne on an armature of floating planes,
label: Paragraph

text: conveyed an illusion of total weightlessness. It was as
label: Paragraph

text: though, like Paul Scheerbart before him, he had suddenly
label: Paragraph

text: been possessed by the expressive qualities of glass, whose
label: Paragraph

text: crystalline translucence could be best complemented by the
label: Paragraph

text: liberating attributes of the column-free plan. The first
label: Paragraph

text: occasion on which Wright, the master of masonry,
label: Paragraph

text: acclaimed glass as the modern material par excellence was
label: Paragraph

text: in his famous Kahn Lectures, given at Princeton University in
label: Paragraph

text: 1930. In ‘Style in Industry’ he stated:
label: Paragraph

text: Glass has now a perfect visibility, thin sheets of air
label: Paragraph

text: crystallized to keep air currents outside or inside. Glass
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces, too, may be modified to let the vision sweep
label: Paragraph

text: through to any extent up to perfection. Tradition left no
label: Paragraph

text: orders concerning this material as a means of perfect
label: Paragraph

text: visibility; hence the sense of glass as crystal has not, as
label: Paragraph

text: poetry, entered yet into Architecture. All the dignity of
label: Paragraph

text: colour and material available in any other material may be
label: Paragraph

text: discounted by glass as light and discounted with
label: Paragraph

text: permanence.
label: Paragraph

text: Shadows were the ‘brush work’ of the ancient Architect.
label: Paragraph

text: Let the Modern now work with light, light diffused, light
label: Paragraph

text: reflected, light for its own sake, shadows gratuitous. It is the
label: Paragraph

text: Machine that makes modern these rare new opportunities in
label: Paragraph

text: Glass.*
label: Paragraph

text: In 1928 Wright coined the term ‘Usonia’ to denote an
label: Paragraph

text: egalitarian culture that would spontaneously emerge in the
label: Paragraph

text: United States. By this he seems to have intended not only a
label: Paragraph

text: grassroots individualism but also the realization of a new,
label: Paragraph

text: dispersed form of civilization such as had recently been
label: Paragraph

text: made possible by mass ownership of the automobile. The
label: Paragraph

text: car as the ‘democratic’ mode of locomotion was to be the
label: Paragraph

text: deus ex machina of Wright’s anti-urban model, his
label: Paragraph

text: Broadacre City concept, in which the concentration of the
label: Paragraph

text: 19th-century city was to be redistributed over the network
label: Paragraph

text: of a regional agrarian grid (already anticipated in his entry
label: Paragraph

text: for the City Club, Chicago, competition of 1913 for a
label: Caption

text: subdivision on the outskirts of Chicago [182]). He had first
label: Paragraph

text: spoken out against the traditional city in the last of his Kahn
label: Paragraph

text: Lectures, which began: ‘Is the city a persistent form of social
label: Paragraph

text: disease, eventuating in the fate all cities have met?’ It is
label: Paragraph

text: one of the ironies of our century that Broadacre City
label: Paragraph

text: corresponded more closely than any other form of radical
label: Paragraph

text: urbanism to the central precepts of the Communist
label: Title

text: Manifesto of 1848, advocating ‘the gradual abolition of the
label: Paragraph

text: distinction between town and country by a more equable
label: Paragraph

text: distribution of the population over the land’.
label: Paragraph

text: 182 Wright, plan for the subdivision of a typical section of land, Chicago, 1913.
label: Caption

text: Nevertheless, Wright’s first building projects for this new
label: Paragraph

text: Usonian culture, the St Mark’s apartment tower and the
label: Paragraph

text: Capital Journal newspaper building [183], both of 1931,
label: Caption

text: were urban rather than agrarian in tone. Eventually realized
label: Paragraph

text: as the Price Tower in Bartlesville, Oklahoma (1952-55), and
label: Paragraph

text: as the Johnson Wax Administration Building in Racine,
label: Paragraph

text: Wisconsin (1936-39), both of these projects consisted of
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete cantilevered systems covered in a
label: Paragraph

text: crystalline membrane. At a symbolic level they embodied
label: Paragraph

text: the essential polarity that had been evident in Wright’s work
label: Paragraph

text: ever since his Martin House and Larkin Building of 1904 -
label: Paragraph

text: the fundamentalist assimilation of the building of the home
label: Title

text: to the processes of nature and of the workplace to the idea
label: Title

text: of sacrament. This polarization was to be brilliantly
label: Paragraph

text: reformulated in Wright’s Usonian period in two masterworks
label: Paragraph

text: of unsurpassed richness and generosity, the Kaufmann
label: Paragraph

text: weekend house at Bear Run, Pennsylvania, of 1936, better
label: Caption

text: known as Falling Water, and the Johnson Wax Administration
label: Paragraph

text: Building begun in the same year.

text: Section.

text: For Wright, the word ‘organic’ (which he first applied to
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in 1908) came to mean the use of the concrete
label: Paragraph

text: cantilever as though it were a natural, treelike form. He
label: Paragraph

text: seems to have conceived of such a form as a direct
label: Paragraph

text: extension of Louis Sullivan’s vitalist metaphor of the ‘seed
label: Paragraph

text: germ’, extended now to include the whole structure rather
label: Paragraph

text: than the ornament alone. Just before his death, Wright wrote
label: Paragraph

text: of the vulva-shaped pool in the foyer of the Guggenheim
label: Caption

text: Museum: ‘Typical of the details of this edifice, the symbolic
label: Paragraph

text: figure is the oval seed pod containing globular units.’
label: Paragraph

text: In the Johnson Wax Administration Building this organic
label: Paragraph

text: metaphor revealed itself in tall, slender mushroom columns
label: Paragraph

text: tapering towards their bases, which form the prime support
label: Paragraph

text: within a 9-metre (30-foot) high open-planned air-conditioned
label: Paragraph

text: office space [184]. These columns resolve themselves at
label: Paragraph

text: roof level into broad circular lily pads of concrete, between
label: Paragraph

text: which is ‘interwoven’ a membrane of Pyrex glass tubing.
label: Paragraph

text: These horizontal roof lights delicately supported by
label: Paragraph

text: columns, and the columns themselves (whose hollow cores
label: Paragraph

text: serve as storm water drains and whose hinged bases are
label: Paragraph

text: pin-jointed into bronze shoes), jointly represent the
label: Paragraph

text: apotheosis of Wright’s technical imagination. This was the
label: Paragraph

text: expressive destiny of Usonia, a poetry of miraculous
label: Paragraph

text: technique arising out of a daring inversion of the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: elements. Thus where one would have expected solid (the
label: Paragraph

text: roof) one found light; and where one would have expected
label: Paragraph

text: light (the walls) one found solid. Of this inversion Wright
label: Paragraph

text: wrote:
label: Title

text: 184 Wright, S.C. Johnson & Son Administration Building, Racine, Wisconsin,
label: Caption

text: 1936-39. Interior.
label: Caption

text: Glass tubing laid up like bricks in a wall composes all the
label: Paragraph

text: lighting surfaces. Light enters the building where the cornice
label: Paragraph

text: used to be. In the interior the box-like structure vanishes
label: Paragraph

text: completely. The walls carrying the glass ribbing are of hard
label: Paragraph

text: red brick and red Kasota sandstone. The entire fabric is
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete, cold-drawn mesh being used for the
label: Paragraph

text: reinforcement.3
label: Title

text: This concrete mushroom construction brought Wright to
label: Paragraph

text: develop, for the first time, a curved corner profile and a
label: Paragraph

text: predominantly circular vocabulary, which, executed in hard,
label: Paragraph

text: precise materials and lit throughout by translucent glass
label: Paragraph

text: tubing, imparted to the structure a Moderne streamlined
label: Paragraph

text: aura which time has done little to dispel. At the same time
label: Paragraph

text: this science-fiction atmosphere rendered the Johnson Wax
label: Paragraph

text: Building as a self-contained, monastic place of work. As
label: Paragraph

text: Henry-Russell Hitchcock wrote: ‘There is a certain illusion of
label: Paragraph

text: sky seen from the bottom of an aquarium.’ Here again, as in
label: Paragraph

text: his Larkin Building, Wright had created an hermetic
label: Paragraph

text: environment whose physical exclusion of the outside world
label: Paragraph

text: was reinforced by the form and colour of the special office
label: Paragraph

text: equipment designed for its furnishing.
label: Paragraph

text: While Johnson Wax reinterpreted the sacramental place
label: Paragraph

text: of work, Falling Water embodied Wright’s ideal of the place
label: Paragraph

text: of living fused into nature. Once again, reinforced concrete
label: Paragraph

text: afforded the point of departure; only this time the
label: Paragraph

text: cantilevering gesture was extravagant to the point of folly,
label: Paragraph

text: in contrast to the implacable calm of the mushroom
label: Paragraph

text: structure of Johnson Wax. Falling Water projected itself out
label: Paragraph

text: from the natural rock in which it was anchored, as a free-
label: Paragraph

text: floating platform poised over a small waterfall [185].
label: Caption

text: Designed in a single day, this dramatic structural gesture
label: Paragraph

text: was Wright’s ultimate romantic statement. No longer
label: Paragraph

text: restricted by the extended earth line of his Prairie Style, the
label: Paragraph

text: terraces of this house appeared as an agglomeration of
label: Paragraph

text: planes miraculously suspended in space, poised at varying
label: Paragraph

text: heights above the trees of a densely wooded valley. Tied
label: Paragraph

text: back into the escarpment by the reinforced-concrete
label: Paragraph

text: upstand beams of its terraces, Falling Water defies
label: Paragraph

text: photographic record. Its fusion with the landscape is total,
label: Paragraph

text: for, despite the extensive use of horizontal glazing, nature
label: Paragraph

text: permeates the structure at every turn. Its interior evokes
label: Paragraph

text: the atmosphere of a furnished cave rather than that of a
label: Paragraph

text: house in the traditional sense. That the rough stone walls
label: Paragraph

text: and flagged floors intend some primitive homage to the site
label: Paragraph

text: is borne out by the living-room stairs which, descending
label: Paragraph

text: through the floor to the waterfall below, have no function
label: Paragraph

text: other than to bring man into more intimate communion with
label: Paragraph

text: the surface of the stream. Wright’s perennial ambivalence
label: Paragraph

text: towards technique was never more singularly expressed
label: Paragraph

text: than in this house, for although concrete had made the
label: Paragraph

text: design feasible he still regarded it as an illegitimate material
label: Paragraph

text: - as a ‘conglomera’ that had ‘little quality in itself’. His initial
label: Paragraph

text: intent had been to cover the concrete of Falling Water in
label: Paragraph

text: gold leaf, a kitsch gesture from which he was dissuaded by
label: Paragraph

text: the discretion of the client. He finally settled for finishing its
label: Paragraph

text: surface in apricot paint!
label: Title

text: 185 Wright, Falling Water, Bear Run, Pa., 1936.
label: Caption

text: From now on, aside from his remarkably practical
label: Paragraph

text: Usonian houses, Wright continued to develop a curious kind
label: Paragraph

text: of science-fiction architecture which, judging from the exotic
label: Paragraph

text: style of his late renderings, seemed intended for occupation
label: Paragraph

text: by some extraterrestial species. This self-conscious
label: Paragraph

text: exoticism fell to the level of ultra-kitsch in his Marin County
label: Paragraph

text: Courthouse, California, commissioned in 1957 and finished
label: Caption

text: in 1963, four years after his death. Wright had already
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledged this compulsion towards the fantastic when
label: Paragraph

text: he wrote in 1928: ‘The fact remains Usonia wanted romance
label: Paragraph

text: and sentiment. The failure to get it is less significant than
label: Paragraph

text: the fact that it was sought.’
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s Usonian vision, first crystallized in his
label: Paragraph

text: masterworks of the mid-1930s, attained its fulfilment in his
label: Paragraph

text: Guggenheim Museum, New York, of 1943 [186]. The
label: Caption

text: structural idea and parti for the museum date back to his
label: Paragraph

text: sketch for the Gordon Strong Planetarium of 1925 -a
label: Caption

text: science-fiction proposal par excellence, a ‘ziggurat’ destined
label: Title

text: for the semireligious gratification of ‘nature-worshipping’
label: Paragraph

text: pilgrims. At the Guggenheim, he simply turned the
label: Paragraph

text: diminishing helix of the planetarium inside out, inverting
label: Paragraph

text: and thereby converting what had previously been a car
label: Paragraph

text: ramp into an internal, spiralling gallery, an extended spatial
label: Paragraph

text: helix which Wright later referred to as an ‘unbroken wave’.
label: Paragraph

text: The Guggenheim Museum must be regarded as the climax
label: Paragraph

text: of Wright’s later career, since it combines the structural and
label: Paragraph

text: spatial principles of Falling Water with the top-lit
label: Paragraph

text: containment of Johnson Wax. His declaration that the
label: Paragraph

text: museum was more like a temple in a park than a mundane
label: Paragraph

text: business building or residential structure may be seen as an
label: Paragraph

text: ironic reference to the building’s origin in these projects.
label: Paragraph

text: 186 Wright, preliminary project for the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, New
label: Caption

text: York, 1943.
label: Caption

text: In his first book on city planning, The Disappearing City
label: Paragraph

text: (entitled in the first draft The Industrial Revolution Runs
label: Paragraph

text: Away), published in 1932 on the completion of his Broadacre
label: Paragraph

text: City study [187], Wright declared that the future city will be
label: Paragraph

text: everywhere and nowhere, and that ‘it will be a city so
label: Paragraph

text: greatly different from the ancient city or from any city of
label: Paragraph

text: today that we will probably fail to recognize its coming as
label: Paragraph

text: the city at all’. Elsewhere he stated: ‘America needs no help
label: Paragraph

text: to build Broadacre City. It will build itself, haphazard.’ Wright
label: Paragraph

text: neither sought nor found any satisfactory resolution to the
label: Paragraph

text: inherent contradiction of this polemic. On the one hand, he
label: Paragraph

text: argued that men should consciously establish a new system
label: Paragraph

text: of dispersed land settlement, anti-urban by definition; on
label: Paragraph

text: the other, he stated that there was little need to do so since
label: Paragraph

text: this would happen spontaneously!
label: Paragraph

text: 187 Wright, Broadacre City project, 1934-58.
label: Caption

text: In his historical determinism, Wright looked to the
label: Paragraph

text: machine as the one agent with which the architect has no
label: Paragraph

text: choice but to come to terms. But the old dilemma remained:
label: Paragraph

text: how to do this without being brutalized? For Wright, this was
label: Paragraph

text: the constant cultural quest of his long career. Thus, in The
label: Paragraph

text: Living City (1958), we find him writing: ‘Miracles of technical
label: Paragraph

text: invention with which our “hit and run” culture has nothing to
label: Paragraph

text: do are - despite misuse - new forces with which any
label: Paragraph

text: indigenous culture must reckon.’ While he consigned steam
label: Paragraph

text: power and the railway to instant oblivion, he welcomed (like
label: Paragraph

text: the Soviet de-urbanists of his day) electricity as a source of
label: Paragraph

text: silent power and the automobile as the provider of limitless
label: Title

text: movement. He identified the new forces which would
label: Paragraph

text: transform the entire basis of Western civilization as follows:
label: Paragraph

text: (1) Electrification, the communicational annihilation of
label: Paragraph

text: distance and the constant illumination of human occupation;
label: Paragraph

text: (2) Mechanical Mobilization, the immeasurable widening of
label: Paragraph

text: human contact due to the invention of the airplane and the
label: Paragraph

text: automobile, and finally (3) Organic Architecture, which,
label: Paragraph

text: although it always escaped any precise definition, seems to
label: Paragraph

text: have eventually meant for Wright the economic creation of
label: Paragraph

text: built form and space in accordance with the latent principles
label: Paragraph

text: of nature as these may be revealed through the application
label: Paragraph

text: of the reinforced-concrete construction. On another
label: Paragraph

text: occasion, Wright characterized the resources that would
label: Paragraph

text: implacably shape Broadacre City as the car, the radio, the
label: Paragraph

text: telephone, the telegraph and, above all, standardized
label: Paragraph

text: machine shop production.
label: Paragraph

text: For Wright, Usonian culture and Broadacre City were
label: Paragraph

text: inseparable concepts, the former providing the prime
label: Paragraph

text: intention behind a whole range of buildings which were the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural substance of the latter. Falling Water and the
label: Paragraph

text: Johnson Wax Building would no doubt have found their
label: Paragraph

text: appointed places in Broadacre City. Yet, by Usonia, Wright
label: Paragraph

text: generally intended something altogether more modest:
label: Paragraph

text: warm, open-planned, small houses designed for
label: Paragraph

text: convenience, economy and comfort. The heart of the
label: Paragraph

text: Usonian house was the ‘time-and-motion’ kitchen, an alcove
label: Paragraph

text: work space freely planned off the living volume, which, as
label: Paragraph

text: Henry-Russell Hitchcock observed, was an important
label: Paragraph

text: contribution to American domestic planning. Of almost
label: Paragraph

text: equal import to the modern interior was Wright's
label: Paragraph

text: introduction at this time of continuous wall-seating to
label: Paragraph

text: maximize space in small houses. While single-family
label: Paragraph

text: Usonian homes were projected as the housing stock of
label: Paragraph

text: Broadacre City, they were also actually realized in the
label: Paragraph

text: numerous suburban houses that Wright designed and built
label: Paragraph

text: between 1932 and 1960, including the famous four-family
label: Paragraph

text: Suntop Homes, arranged in a pinwheel formation, that were
label: Paragraph

text: erected on the outskirts of Philadelphia in 1939.
label: Paragraph

text: By far the most important building type designed for
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s ideal city was not a house at all but the Walter
label: Paragraph

text: Davidson Model Farm projected in 1932. This unit, designed
label: Paragraph

text: to facilitate the economic management of both home and
label: Paragraph

text: land, was critical to the overall economy of Broadacre City,
label: Paragraph

text: where every man was to grow his own food on an acre of
label: Paragraph

text: land which, reserved at his birth, would be placed at his
label: Paragraph

text: disposal as soon as he was of age.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from a number of contingent social ideas such as
label: Paragraph

text: the single tax system or social credit - both popular
label: Paragraph

text: remedial notions in the Depression - Broadacre City was
label: Paragraph

text: above all an updating of that smallholding cottage-industry
label: Paragraph

text: economy first advocated by Peter Kropotkin in his Factories,
label: Paragraph

text: Fields and Workshops of 1898. In reviving such a proposition
label: Paragraph

text: there was at least one awkward contradiction which Wright,
label: Paragraph

text: like Henry Ford, stubbornly refused to recognize: namely,
label: Paragraph

text: that an individualistic quasi-agrarian economy would not
label: Paragraph

text: necessarily be able to guarantee to an industrialized society
label: Paragraph

text: either its subsistence or the benefits of mass production,
label: Paragraph

text: since the latter, despite automation, still demanded some
label: Paragraph

text: concentration in both labour and resources. Even Kropotkin
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledged the need to concentrate labour and resources
label: Paragraph

text: for the processes of heavy industry. Wright’s vision of a city
label: Paragraph

text: in which part-time smallholders would drive to work, to rural
label: Paragraph

text: factories, in secondhand Model T Fords, suggests that a
label: Paragraph

text: migrant, ‘sweat equity’ labour force would have been
label: Paragraph

text: essential for the success of the Broadacre economy.
label: Paragraph

text: As Meyer Schapiro pointed out at the time, Wright,
label: Paragraph

text: despite his unremitting attack on rent and profit and his
label: Paragraph

text: prescience in foreseeing the dissolution of the city, failed to
label: Paragraph

text: confront the urgent issue of power that was fundamental to
label: Paragraph

text: the Broadacre concept. Like Buckminster Fuller, who was
label: Paragraph

text: already active by this date, he could not bring himself to
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledge that architecture and planning must, of
label: Paragraph

text: necessity, address themselves to the class struggle.
label: Paragraph

text: Schapiro summed up Wright’s utopianism correctly in 1938,
label: Paragraph

text: when he wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: The economic conditions that determine freedom and a
label: Paragraph

text: decent living are largely ignored by Wright. He foresees, in
label: Paragraph

text: fact, the poverty of these new feudal settlements when he
label: Paragraph

text: provides that the worker set up his own factory-made
label: Paragraph

text: house, part by part, according to his means, beginning with
label: Paragraph

text: a toilet and kitchen, and adding other rooms as he earns the
label: Paragraph

text: means by his labor in the factory. His indifference to
label: Paragraph

text: property relations and the state, his admission of private
label: Paragraph

text: industry and second-hand Fords in this idyllic world of
label: Paragraph

text: amphibian labor, betray its reactionary character. Already
label: Paragraph

text: under the dictatorship of Napoleon III, the state farms,
label: Paragraph

text: partly inspired by the old Utopias, were the official solution
label: Paragraph

text: of unemployment. The democratic Wright may attack rent
label: Paragraph

text: and profit interest, but apart from some passing reference
label: Paragraph

text: to the single tax, he avoids the question of class and
label: Paragraph

text: power’

text: Alvar Aalto and the Nordic

text: Romanticism and the
