label: Title

text: The first essential feature of interest is Karelian
label: Paragraph

text: architecture's uniformity. There are few comparable
label: Paragraph

text: examples in Europe. It is a pure forest-settlement
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in which wood dominates almost one hundred
label: Paragraph

text: percent both as material and as jointing method. From the
label: Paragraph

text: roof, with its massive system of joists, to the movable
label: Paragraph

text: building parts, wood dominated, in most cases naked,
label: Paragraph

text: without the dematerializing effect that a layer of paint gives.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition, wood is often used in as natural proportions as
label: Paragraph

text: possible, on the scale typical of the material. A dilapidated
label: Paragraph

text: Karelian village is somehow similar in appearance to a
label: Paragraph

text: Greek ruin, where, also, the material’s uniformity is a
label: Paragraph

text: dominant feature, though marble replaces wood. ... Another
label: Paragraph

text: significant special feature is the manner in which the
label: Paragraph

text: Karelian house has come about, both its historical
label: Paragraph

text: development and its building methods. Without going
label: Paragraph

text: further into ethnographic details, we can conclude that the
label: Paragraph

text: inner system of construction results from a methodical
label: Paragraph

text: accommodation to circumstance. The Karelian house is ina
label: Paragraph

text: way a building that begins with a single modest cell or with
label: Paragraph

text: an imperfect embryo building, shelter for a man and
label: Paragraph

text: animals, and which then figuratively speaking grows year by
label: Paragraph

text: year. ‘The expanded Karelian house’ can in a way be
label: Paragraph

text: compared with a biological cell formation. The possibility of
label: Paragraph

text: a larger and more complete building is always open.
label: Paragraph

text: This remarkable ability to grow and adapt is best
label: Paragraph

text: reflected in the Karelian building’s main architectural
label: Paragraph

text: principle, the fact that the roof angle isn’t constant.
label: Paragraph

text: Alvar Aalto
label: Title

text: Architecture in Karelia, 19411
label: Title

text: In this perceptive essay on the farmhouse vernacular of
label: Paragraph

text: eastern Finland, Aalto evoked, almost by chance, the two
label: Paragraph

text: prominent architectural modes of the second half of the
label: Paragraph

text: 19th century, Romantic Classicism and the Gothic Revival.
label: Paragraph

text: Where Aalto’s account of native agrarian form with its stress
label: Paragraph

text: on the variation in roof pitches comes close to Pugin’s
label: Paragraph

text: original prescription for a revived medieval domestic style,
label: Paragraph

text: his characterization of a decayed Karelian village as a Greek
label: Paragraph

text: ruin rendered in wood rather than stone is a sort of mirror-
label: Paragraph

text: image of Auguste Choisy’s thesis that the metopes of the
label: Paragraph

text: Parthenon are nothing but vestigial forms of timber
label: Paragraph

text: construction. Aside from making us aware of his own
label: Paragraph

text: Classical consciousness and of his interest in an all but
label: Paragraph

text: primeval vernacular, this passage also serves to introduce
label: Paragraph

text: the two stylistic themes of the Nordic tradition: the National
label: Paragraph

text: Romantic manner dating from 1895 and the Doricist
label: Title

text: sensibility which emerged in Scandinavia about 1910.
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto’s long and brilliant career can scarcely be appreciated
label: Paragraph

text: without making explicit reference to these themes, for,
label: Paragraph

text: while he was never a committed participant in either, his
label: Paragraph

text: life’s work reflected a constant debt to either National
label: Paragraph

text: Romantic tactility or the astringencies of Doricist form.
label: Paragraph

text: The origin of these modes is significant, the one patently
label: Paragraph

text: stemming from the Gothic Revival, via the American Shingle
label: Paragraph

text: Style of H.H. Richardson, and the other arising out of the
label: Paragraph

text: Romantic Classicism of Schinkel. Helsinki, founded as the
label: Paragraph

text: Finnish capital in 1817 on the basis of J.A. Ehrenstr6m’s
label: Paragraph

text: orthogonal grid, was to be particularly prone to the
label: Paragraph

text: influence of the Romantic Classical style, since it was laid
label: Paragraph

text: out around an armature of representative Classical buildings
label: Paragraph

text: - the Senate House, the University and the Cathedral, all
label: Caption

text: built after 1818 to the designs of Schinkel’s fellow pupil, Carl
label: Paragraph

text: Ludwig Engel. As for National Romanticism, such is Aalto’s
label: Paragraph

text: debt to this movement that it is hardly possible to
label: Paragraph

text: appreciate his later career without first examining its origins
label: Paragraph

text: and aims.
label: Paragraph

text: Initially, National Romanticism was as prevalent in
label: Paragraph

text: Sweden as in Finland, particularly in the work of the
label: Paragraph

text: architect Gustaf Ferdinand Boberg, who was responsible in
label: Paragraph

text: his Gavle Fire Station of 1890 for introducing the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Richardson into Scandinavia. However, in general, Swedish
label: Paragraph

text: architects were incapable of transforming this Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Romanesque manner into a convincing national style. What
label: Paragraph

text: was true of Sweden was even more true of Denmark, where
label: Paragraph

text: Martin Nyrop’s popularly acclaimed neo-medieval
label: Title

text: Copenhagen Town Hall of 1892 remained complacently
label: Paragraph

text: rooted in a highly eclectic, if successful form of historicism,
label: Paragraph

text: totally unmoved by the conviction and integrity of
label: Paragraph

text: Richardson’s heroic example. Indeed the Swedes and the
label: Paragraph

text: Danes were only able to achieve an authentic national
label: Paragraph

text: revivalist manner after the main impulse of the nationalist
label: Paragraph

text: cultural movement was already over, most notably in
label: Paragraph

text: Ragnar Ostberg’s castle-like Stockholm City Hall (1909-23),
label: Paragraph

text: and in PV. Jensen-Klint’s proto-Expressionist Grundtvig
label: Paragraph

text: Church, Copenhagen, designed in 1913 but not realized until
label: Caption

text: National Romanticism in Finland had already become a
label: Paragraph

text: significant force by 1895, when a group of artists came to
label: Paragraph

text: their ideological and artistic maturity at the same time - the
label: Paragraph

text: composer Jean Sibelius, the painter Akseli Gallen-Kallela,
label: Paragraph

text: and the architects Eliel Saarinen, Herman Gesellius, Armas
label: Paragraph

text: Lindgren and, at some distance, Lars Sonck. The basic
label: Paragraph

text: inspiration behind all their work was the Finnish folk epic,
label: Paragraph

text: the Ka/eva/a, which had been collected and transcribed by
label: Paragraph

text: Elias L6nnroth at the beginning of the 19th century.
label: Paragraph

text: The compelling force behind National Romanticism in
label: Paragraph

text: Finland derived, in part at least, from the need to find a
label: Paragraph

text: national style other than Romantic Classicism, which was
label: Paragraph

text: the imperialist manner of Helsinki, built under Russian
label: Paragraph

text: auspices. A further cause for the particular form taken by
label: Paragraph

text: Finland’s rather ready acceptance of the Richardsonian
label: Title

text: syntax, derived from the need to exploit the abundance of
label: Paragraph

text: local granite, reflected in the dispatch of a mission to
label: Paragraph

text: Aberdeen in the early 1890s to study the Scottish technique
label: Paragraph

text: of building in this material. The first National Romantic
label: Paragraph

text: architect to use granite was Sonck, whose Neo-Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: church of St Michael, built in Turku in 1895, was enriched by
label: Paragraph

text: columns and furnishings in finely carved granite, in contrast
label: Paragraph

text: to its otherwise stark and sparsely decorated interior. That
label: Paragraph

text: this interior with its etched precision shows something of
label: Paragraph

text: the same surface articulation as is found, say, in Otto
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner’s Steinhof Church in Vienna built a decade later is
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps partly explained by the fact that Sonck’s generation
label: Paragraph

text: had been trained in the Finnish Polytechnic under the
label: Paragraph

text: tutorship of the technocratic but Classically educated Carl
label: Paragraph

text: Gustav Nystrém. Nystrém, aside from pioneering granite
label: Caption

text: construction, had established himself as a Wagnerian
label: Paragraph

text: ‘technocrat’ in his National Archives Building of 1890. He
label: Paragraph

text: was later to distinguish himself as a Structural Rationalist,
label: Paragraph

text: when in 1906 he added an exemplary steel and concrete
label: Paragraph

text: bookstack to the rear of C.L. Engel’s University Library.
label: Caption

text: Sonck’s major buildings, Tampere Cathedral (1902) [188]
label: Caption

text: and the Telephone Building in Helsinki (1905), were patently
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by the work of Richardson, whose masonry
label: Paragraph

text: syntax, as Asko Salokorpi has remarked, resembled the
label: Paragraph

text: Finnish medieval tradition. This Richardsonian manner was
label: Paragraph

text: soon to be adapted by Eliel Saarinen and Armas Lindgren, in
label: Paragraph

text: their orientalizing Neo-Romanesque Finnish Pavilion for the
label: Paragraph

text: Paris Exposition of 1900, and a domestic version of this
label: Paragraph

text: manner was used in their highly romantic Villa Hvittrask,
label: Paragraph

text: designed in 1902 in collaboration with Gesellius [190].
label: Paragraph

text: Inside, however, Hvittrask was less Richardsonian, and in
label: Paragraph

text: many respects a reworking of Gallén-Kallela’s log cabin
label: Paragraph

text: studio built at Ruovesi, in 1893 [189]. Aside from its spirited
label: Paragraph

text: interpretation of Finnish timber vernacular, the interior
label: Paragraph

text: décor of Hvittrask reiterated Gallén-Kallela’s attempt to
label: Paragraph

text: evoke the lost forms and images of Finno-Ugric culture. Two
label: Paragraph

text: years later, in 1904, the ‘guild’ idyll of Saarinen, Gesellius
label: Paragraph

text: and Lindgren - who, in anticipation of Wright, not only
label: Paragraph

text: worked but also lived together at Hvittrask - came to an
label: Paragraph

text: abrupt end. This happened when Saarinen, acting
label: Paragraph

text: independently, entered and won the competition for the
label: Paragraph

text: Helsinki Railway Terminus with a design whose architectonic
label: Paragraph

text: invention reflected the ‘crystallized’ Jugendstil of such
label: Paragraph

text: buildings as Hoffmann’s Palais Stoclet, Brussels, of 1905 and
label: Caption

text: Olbrich’s Hochzeitsturm, Darmstadt, of 1908. Saarinen was
label: Paragraph

text: not the only Finn to entertain the late Jugendstil manner:
label: Paragraph

text: Onni Tarjanne’s Wagnerschule style matched and in many
label: Paragraph

text: ways surpassed that of Saarinen, particularly in his
label: Paragraph

text: Takaharju Sanatorium of 1903. (It is a measure of Tarjanne’s
label: Paragraph

text: brilliance that he had designed the Finnish National Theatre
label: Paragraph

text: at Helsinki in a National Romantic, Richardsonian manner
label: Paragraph

text: only five years earlier.) The swansong of the Finnish
label: Paragraph

text: Jugendstil came with the extremely delicate Hoffmannesque
label: Paragraph

text: work of Selim A. Lindquist, as exemplified in Helsinki in the
label: Paragraph

text: Suvilhati Power Station of 1908 and the Villa Ensi of 1910.
label: Paragraph

text: 188 Sonck, Tampere Cathedral, 1902. Ground plan showing ‘log-cabin’ corners.
label: Caption

text: 189 Gallén-Kallela, the artist’s studio at Ruovesi, 1893. Ground plan and
label: Caption

text: elevation.
label: Paragraph

text: 190 Saarinen, Lindgren and Gesellius, Villa Hvittrask, near Helsinki, 1902.
label: Caption

text: Naturally enough, given Finland’s long history as an
label: Paragraph

text: imperial colony, first of Sweden and then of Russia, the
label: Paragraph

text: revival of Romantic Classicism in Scandinavia - the so-called
label: Paragraph

text: Doricist sensibility - began in Denmark. It came into being
label: Paragraph

text: there under the influence of writers such as Vilhelm
label: Paragraph

text: Wansher, whose first articles on Neo-Classicism appeared in
label: Paragraph

text: 1907, and the German Paul Mebes, whose book Um 1800
label: Paragraph

text: was published in 1908. The interest of these men (and
label: Paragraph

text: others including H. Kampmann and E. Thompsen) in a non-
label: Paragraph

text: historicist, primordial Doric simplicity, based on primal
label: Paragraph

text: architectonic elements which were neither Classic nor
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular, drew attention to the Danish school of Romantic
label: Paragraph

text: Classicism, to the work of Gottlieb Bindesbgll and Christian
label: Paragraph

text: Frederick Hansen. This whole sensibility crystallized in 1910,
label: Paragraph

text: after the Carlsberg Brewery had publicly demanded that a
label: Paragraph

text: spire be added to Hansen’s Fruekirche. The architect Carl
label: Caption

text: Petersen responded to their arrogant gesture by organizing
label: Paragraph

text: an exhibition of Hansen’s drawings. In the following year a
label: Paragraph

text: group of painters responded by commissioning Petersen to
label: Paragraph

text: design the Faaborg Museum, generally regarded as the first
label: Paragraph

text: building of the Romantic Classical Revival.
label: Caption

text: It was to take some time for this movement to enter
label: Paragraph

text: Sweden. The impulse is just discernible in Carl Westman’s
label: Paragraph

text: Stockholm Law Courts of 1915, a part- National Romantic,
label: Paragraph

text: part-Classical work, which was followed by Ivar Tengbom’s
label: Paragraph

text: Neo-Classical Stockholm Concert Hall (1920-26) and Gunnar
label: Title

text: Asplund’s Stockholm Public Library (1920-28), the
label: Paragraph

text: movement culminating in Finland at the point of its
label: Paragraph

text: exhaustion, with J.S. Sirén’s Finnish Parliament Building
label: Caption

text: (1926-31). In Sweden the Romantic Classical Revival, far
label: Paragraph

text: from being sachlich and normative, was distorted by a
label: Paragraph

text: tendency towards the inflection of the plan and by an
label: Paragraph

text: obsession with local allusion, such as had been established
label: Paragraph

text: in the skewed planning and iconography of Ostberg’s
label: Paragraph

text: National Romantic manner. This was a restrained and
label: Paragraph

text: synthetic form of expression that invariably alluded to the
label: Paragraph

text: topography and the genius loci. This drive towards distortion
label: Paragraph

text: was deeply engrained in Asplund who, having been
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by both Ostberg and Tengbom at the Klara
label: Paragraph

text: School, sought sporadically throughout his career to
label: Paragraph

text: transcend the ‘battle of styles’ by fusing the vernacular and
label: Paragraph

text: the Classical into a primitive and more authentic form of
label: Paragraph

text: expression. The first opportunity to do this came with his
label: Paragraph

text: Woodland Chapel (1918-20) in the Stockholm South
label: Paragraph

text: Cemetery, which he had planned as a competition design
label: Paragraph

text: with Sigurd Lewerentz in 1915. Basically Classical in design,
label: Paragraph

text: this small single-cell structure, with its crisply profiled
label: Paragraph

text: shingle roof set on a Tuscan peristyle, was in fact derived
label: Paragraph

text: from a ‘primitive hut’ that Asplund had happened to see ina
label: Paragraph

text: garden at Liselund. Up to the time of his brief ‘Functionalist’
label: Paragraph

text: period, lasting from 1928 to 1933, his work seems to have
label: Paragraph

text: been subject to influences as diverse and as separate in
label: Paragraph

text: time as the French Neo-Classicists, Josef Hoffmann and
label: Paragraph

text: above all Bindesbgll, whose Thorvaldsen Museum,
label: Paragraph

text: Copenhagen, of 1848 furnished Asplund with the Egyptoid
label: Paragraph

text: and Neo-Classical motifs that recur in his work throughout
label: Paragraph

text: the 1920s, first in the Carl Johan School at Goteborg of
label: Paragraph

text: 1915, then in the Skandia Cinema at Stockholm of 1921,
label: Paragraph

text: and finally in the Stockholm Public Library, completed in
label: Caption

text: 191 Asplund, Stockholm Public Library, 1920-28.
label: Caption

text: In Alvar Aalto’s early career it was Asplund who was the
label: Paragraph

text: catalyst, despite the Wagnerschule influence of Aalto’s
label: Paragraph

text: teacher, Usko Nystrém. By 1922, when he started on his
label: Paragraph

text: own, Aalto, like Asplund before him, appeared to be moving
label: Paragraph

text: in several directions. The four buildings that he designed for
label: Paragraph

text: the Industrial Exhibition held at Tampere in that year
label: Paragraph

text: obviously allude to quite different levels of cultural
label: Paragraph

text: development. In all the rhetorical diversity of his later
label: Paragraph

text: career, no contrast is so expressive as that to be found in
label: Paragraph

text: his work there, between, say, his ‘Classical’ industrial
label: Paragraph

text: pavilion, built of modular panels, along the lines of Otto
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner’s Karlsplatz Station of 1899, and his ‘vernacular’
label: Paragraph

text: thatched-roofed kiosk designed for the display of Finnish
label: Caption

text: handicrafts.
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto’s early practice in Jyvaskyla between 1923 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1927 was remarkably varied, including workers’ apartments
label: Paragraph

text: and a workers’ club (both built in 1924), a surprising number
label: Paragraph

text: of churches and church renovations, and two civilian
label: Paragraph

text: guardhouses, built at Seindjoki and Jyvaskyla in 1927. All
label: Caption

text: these works were carried out under Asplund’s influence in a
label: Paragraph

text: vaguely Doricist style, which, while compounded in part of
label: Paragraph

text: the local timber vernacular, was at the same time indebted
label: Paragraph

text: to Hoffmann’s austerity of line and to Schinkel’s Italianate
label: Paragraph

text: mode. In 1927 Aalto moved decisively towards Romantic
label: Paragraph

text: Classicism in his Viinika Church and his Viipuri Library
label: Title

text: competition entry [192]. The latter (realized in a modified
label: Paragraph

text: form in 1935) was unequivocally influenced by Asplund, its
label: Paragraph

text: form including features taken directly from the Stockholm
label: Paragraph

text: Public Library. Of these, the Neo-Classical plan with its axial
label: Paragraph

text: scala regia, the atectonic facade and its frieze, and the giant
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptoid door were patently items which Asplund in his turn
label: Paragraph

text: had drawn from Bindesball. It was Aalto’s prize-winning
label: Paragraph

text: entry for the Paimio Sanatorium of 1928 that firmly
label: Paragraph

text: established the fundamental Functionalist style of his first
label: Paragraph

text: mature period (1927-34).
label: Paragraph

text: 192 Aalto, project for Viipuri Library, 1927.
label: Caption

text: Aside from Asplund, the other catalytic figure in Aalto’s
label: Paragraph

text: early development was clearly the slightly older Finnish
label: Paragraph

text: architect Erik Bryggman, with whom Alvar and his wife,
label: Paragraph

text: Aino, briefly collaborated after their move to the booming
label: Paragraph

text: city of Turku in southern Finland at the end of 1927. Alvar
label: Caption

text: Aalto was soon to outdo the stripped Classicism of
label: Paragraph

text: Bryggman’s Atrium Apartments of 1925 in his own
label: Paragraph

text: Asplundian South-Western Agricultural Co-operative
label: Title

text: Building, realized in Turku in 1928. The colour scheme of the
label: Paragraph

text: theatre in this building - a dark blue auditorium offset by
label: Paragraph

text: grey and pink plush upholstery - is obviously taken from
label: Paragraph

text: Asplund’s Skandia Cinema, as is the frieze running below
label: Paragraph

text: the exterior cornice. The fruit of Aalto’s collaboration with
label: Caption

text: Bryggman was first an office building project for the town of
label: Paragraph

text: Vaasa and then, in 1929, an exhibition celebrating the 700th
label: Paragraph

text: anniversary of Turku. As in Asplund’s 1928 sketch proposals
label: Paragraph

text: for the Stockholm Exhibition, with their exposed, light-
label: Paragraph

text: weight, cantilevered trusses, suspended sky signs and
label: Caption

text: ‘agitatory’ graphics, this commission led Bryggman and
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto to follow the Soviet Agit-Prop lead in architectural
label: Paragraph

text: rhetoric.
label: Paragraph

text: After the realization of his Constructivist-influenced
label: Paragraph

text: Turun-Sanomat newspaper building at Turku in 1928
label: Caption

text: (reminiscent of the Vesnins’ Pravda project of 1923), Aalto
label: Paragraph

text: was able to take advantage of his growing reputation by
label: Paragraph

text: participating in international conferences on modem
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and construction. At a conference on reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete in Paris in 1928 he became acquainted with the
label: Paragraph

text: work of Duiker (see p. 145), whose reinforced-concrete
label: Paragraph

text: Zonnestraal Sanatorium was the point of departure for
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto’s own competition design for the Paimio Sanatorium,
label: Paragraph

text: submitted in January 1929. From this date on Aalto was
label: Paragraph

text: decidedly under the influence of both Dutch and Russian
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivism, particularly as it was manifest in the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Duiker and in the urban projects of N.A. Ladovsky’s Asnova
label: Paragraph

text: and ARU groups. The serial, geometrical schemes proposed
label: Paragraph

text: at different times by the ARU (Association of Urban
label: Paragraph

text: Architects), such as Ladovsky’s Kostino Quarter for Moscow
label: Paragraph

text: of 1926, are obviously the source for the entry trajectory
label: Paragraph

text: and the serial landscape formations that appear in Paimio.
label: Paragraph

text: As well as reflecting the urban approach of ARU, Paimio also
label: Paragraph

text: marked a turning point in the matter of detail, for it
label: Paragraph

text: abounded in Constructivist quotation.
label: Paragraph

text: Although he kept his distance from international
label: Paragraph

text: polemics, in this period Aalto drew surprisingly close to the
label: Paragraph

text: exclusively economic position adopted by the German Neue
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit architects at the 1929 Frankfurt CIAM Congress
label: Caption

text: on ‘Existenzminimum’, such concerns being reflected in his
label: Paragraph

text: 1930 apartment designs for the Finnish Arts and Crafts
label: Caption

text: Society, and in his prototypical minimum house for the
label: Paragraph

text: Nordic Building Conference of 1932.
label: Paragraph

text: At around the same time, Aalto met Harry and Mairea
label: Paragraph

text: Gullichsen, an event which opened up his practice to
label: Paragraph

text: industrial production. Mrs Gullichsen, heiress of the large
label: Paragraph

text: Ahlstr6é6m timber, paper and cellulose concern, had seen
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto’s earliest furniture in a Helsinki store, and invited him
label: Paragraph

text: to design a range of furniture for serial production. The
label: Paragraph

text: eventual consequences were the foundation in 1935 of the
label: Paragraph

text: Artek Furniture Company (to distribute Aalto’s furniture) and
label: Paragraph

text: the Sunila Pulp Mill and workers’ housing designed and
label: Paragraph

text: realized at Kotka between 1935 and 1939. Fortunately
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto’s pieces readily lent themselves to mass production.
label: Paragraph

text: He had already started to design plywood furniture as early
label: Paragraph

text: as 1926 when he produced a stacking chair for the Jyvaskyla
label: Paragraph

text: guardhouse, and he followed this success with a laminated
label: Paragraph

text: armchair for Paimio, a prototype which was finally put into
label: Paragraph

text: production in 1933. It is interesting to note that Aalto took
label: Paragraph

text: the technique of this design from the standard bent-plywood
label: Paragraph

text: seating that Otto Korhonen produced in the late 1920s.
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto’s patronage by the Finnish timber industry - the
label: Paragraph

text: large industrial concerns of Ahlstr6m and Enso-Gutzeit were
label: Paragraph

text: to be his patrons for the rest of his life - led him to re-
label: Paragraph

text: appraise the value of timber over concrete as a primary
label: Paragraph

text: expressive material. With this he seems to have gradually
label: Paragraph

text: returned to the highly textured architectural manner of the
label: Paragraph

text: Finnish National Romantic movement, to the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen, Gallén-Kallela and Sonck. The first indication of
label: Paragraph

text: this move away from international Constructivism came with
label: Paragraph

text: his own house built in Munkkiniemi, Helsinki, in 1936. This
label: Paragraph

text: somewhat irregular L-shaped building, executed as a collage
label: Paragraph

text: in rendered masonry, grooved planking and exposed
label: Paragraph

text: brickwork, was followed by his prizewinning entry design for
label: Paragraph

text: the Finnish Pavilion for the Paris World Exhibition of 1937
label: Title

text: [193], a timber structure significantly entitled ‘Le Bois est
label: Caption

text: en marche’. It was a rhetorical display of wooden
label: Paragraph

text: construction, its various bearing elements expressing the
label: Paragraph

text: specific characteristics of wood. The battened timber siding
label: Caption

text: of the main hall and the skeleton timber structure of the
label: Caption

text: perimeter exhibition space made up a virtuoso display of
label: Paragraph

text: different techniques for jointing in wood. Yet for all its
label: Paragraph

text: constructional ingenuity, the Finnish Pavilion was chiefly
label: Paragraph

text: important for its formulation of the site-planning principle of
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto’s later career, wherein a given building is invariably
label: Paragraph

text: separated into two distinct elements and the space between
label: Paragraph

text: is articulated as a space of human appearance (see the Villa
label: Paragraph

text: Mairea, Saynatsalo Town Hall, etc.: pp. 228-29). He wrote of
label: Paragraph

text: the pavilion in his collected works:
label: Paragraph

text: 193 Aalto, Finnish Pavilion, World Exhibition, Paris, 1937. Details show boarded
label: Caption

text: siding, a reinforced wooden column of the loggia and part of a column with
label: Paragraph

text: projecting reinforcement fins.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the most difficult architectural problems is the
label: Paragraph

text: shaping of the building’s surroundings to the human scale.
label: Paragraph

text: In modern architecture where the rationality of the
label: Paragraph

text: structural frame and the building masses threaten to
label: Paragraph

text: dominate, there is often an architectural vacuum in the left-
label: Paragraph

text: over portions of the site. It would be good if, instead of
label: Paragraph

text: filling up this vacuum with decorative gardens, the organic
label: Paragraph

text: movement of people could be incorporated in the shaping of
label: Paragraph

text: the site in order to create an intimate relationship between
label: Paragraph

text: Man and Architecture. In the case of the Paris Pavilion this
label: Paragraph

text: problem fortunately could be solved.”
label: Paragraph

text: In his later career, Aalto was to regard the shift from
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete expression to wood and natural
label: Paragraph

text: materials as being of the utmost importance for the
label: Paragraph

text: development of his architecture. He saw his laminated
label: Paragraph

text: furniture as exemplifying an intuitive, indirect and more
label: Paragraph

text: critical approach to design, which was capable of achieving
label: Paragraph

text: a more responsive and inflected environment than that
label: Paragraph

text: usually achieved by linear logic. Thus in 1946, on the
label: Paragraph

text: occasion of an exhibition of his furniture in ZUrich, he wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: In order to achieve practical goals and valid aesthetic forms
label: Paragraph

text: in connection with architecture, one cannot always start
label: Paragraph

text: from a rational and technical standpoint - perhaps even
label: Paragraph

text: never. Human imagination must have free room in which to
label: Paragraph

text: unfold. This was usually the case with my experiments in
label: Paragraph

text: wood. Pure playful forms, with no practical function
label: Paragraph

text: whatsoever, have, in some cases, led to a practical form
label: Paragraph

text: after ten years have elapsed.| ...
label: Paragraph

text: The first attempt to construct organic form from volumes
label: Paragraph

text: of wood without the use of cutting techniques led later, after
label: Paragraph

text: nearly ten years, to triangular solutions, considering the
label: Paragraph

text: orientation of wood fibres. The vertical bearing portion of
label: Paragraph

text: furniture forms is truly the smaller sister of the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: column.3
label: Title

text: This organic approach to design already lies behind the
label: Paragraph

text: detailing of the Viipuri Library and the Paimio Sanatorium,
label: Caption

text: those masterworks of the late 1920s, which, although they
label: Paragraph

text: were built of reinforced concrete, still afforded Aalto an
label: Paragraph

text: occasion for extending the precepts of Functionalism to
label: Paragraph

text: include the satisfaction of a full range of physical and
label: Paragraph

text: psychological needs (compare with Richard Neutra’s
label: Paragraph

text: ‘biological’ approach). Aalto’s lifelong concern for the overall
label: Paragraph

text: ambience of a space and for the way it may be modified
label: Paragraph

text: through the responsive filtration of heat, light and sound
label: Paragraph

text: was first fully formulated in these works. In Paimio the two-
label: Paragraph

text: person wards were carefully arranged to meet the patient’s
label: Paragraph

text: needs not only at the level of environmental control but also
label: Paragraph

text: in terms of identity and privacy, direct light and heat being
label: Paragraph

text: kept away from the patient’s head, while ceilings were
label: Paragraph

text: coloured to reduce glare, and handwash basins were
label: Paragraph

text: designed to function noiselessly. Similarly, the main reading
label: Paragraph

text: rooms of the Viipuri Library [194, 195] were indirectly lit at
label: Paragraph

text: all times - by day through the funnel-shaped roof lights, and
label: Paragraph

text: at night through retractable spotlights which bounced their
label: Paragraph

text: light off the walls opposite. Aalto gave equally careful
label: Paragraph

text: consideration to the library’s acoustical properties, isolating
label: Paragraph

text: reading rooms from traffic noise and equipping the
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular lecture hall with an undulating ceiling reflector
label: Caption

text: for the whole of its length. In general the ‘free planning’
label: Paragraph

text: principles adopted in the library and sanatorium established
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto’s organic approach to architecture, an approach which
label: Paragraph

text: for all its inherent freedom rarely suffered, in formal terms,
label: Paragraph

text: from a loss of control. His concern for the natural
label: Paragraph

text: modification of the environment and for the intrinsic nature
label: Title

text: of the site gave his work a unique continuity from his
label: Paragraph

text: Functionalist period in the late 1920s to the more expressive
label: Paragraph

text: phase of his work that started in the early 1950s. Of his
label: Paragraph

text: anti-mechanistic attitude he wrote in 1960:
label: Paragraph

text: 194 Aalto, Viipuri Library, 1927-35. Lending department, and reading room at
label: Caption

text: higher level.
label: Paragraph

text: 195 Aalto, Viipuri Library, 1927-35. First-floor plan.
label: Caption

text: To make architecture more human means better
label: Title

text: architecture, and it means a functionalism much larger than
label: Paragraph

text: the merely technical one. This goal can be accomplished
label: Paragraph

text: only by architectural methods - by the creation and
label: Paragraph

text: combination of different technical things in such a way that
label: Paragraph

text: they will provide for the human being the most harmonious
label: Paragraph

text: life.4
label: Title

text: In 1938, Aalto achieved the masterwork of his pre-war
label: Paragraph

text: career, the Villa Mairea [196, 197, 198], a summer home
label: Paragraph

text: built for Mairea Gullichsen at Noormarkku. The initial sketch
label: Caption

text: for this L-shaped building makes explicit reference to
label: Paragraph

text: National Romanticism: the plan of the main living hall refers
label: Title

text: directly to the plan of Gallén-Kallela’s Ruovesi studio of
label: Paragraph

text: 1893. Both works also feature a prominent, rendered,
label: Paragraph

text: sculptural fireplace and a stepped living level which
label: Caption

text: eventually leads to a mezzanine stair. Like his Munkkiniemi
label: Paragraph

text: House, the Villa Mairea is compounded out of a mixture of
label: Paragraph

text: brickwork, rendered masonry and timber siding.
label: Caption

text: 196 Aalto, Villa Mairea, Noormarkku, 1938-39.
label: Caption

text: 197, 198 Aalto, Villa Mairea, Noormarkku, 1938-39. View towards the living hall,
label: Caption

text: and exterior.
label: Paragraph

text: More than any other pre-war work of Aino and Alvar
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto, the villa represents a conceptual link between the
label: Paragraph

text: rational-constructivist tradition of the 20th century and the
label: Paragraph

text: evocative heritage of the National Romantic movement. Its
label: Paragraph

text: primary spaces, the dining and living rooms, border a
label: Paragraph

text: sheltered garden court, set within a roughly circular forest
label: Paragraph

text: clearing. The ‘geologically striated’ mass of the house and
label: Paragraph

text: the irregularly contoured perimeter of the sauna plunge pool
label: Caption

text: suggest a metaphorical opposition between artificial and
label: Paragraph

text: natural form, and this principle of duality obtains throughout
label: Paragraph

text: the work. Thus the ‘head’ of Mrs Gullichsen’s prowlike studio
label: Paragraph

text: opposes the ‘tail’ of the sauna, and the wooden siding of the
label: Paragraph

text: public rooms stands in strong contrast to the white
label: Paragraph

text: rendering of the private areas. Similarly complex formal
label: Paragraph

text: operations abound throughout the house: an example is the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘metonymy’ of the entrance canopy, the irregular rhythm of
label: Paragraph

text: its timber screen echoing the irregular spacing of the pine
label: Paragraph

text: trees in the forest - a device that is repeated in the railing of
label: Paragraph

text: the interior stair. This is followed, in terms of sequence, by
label: Paragraph

text: the repetition of the same plan form in the studio, the
label: Paragraph

text: entrance canopy and the plunge pool, all recalling the
label: Paragraph

text: sinuous perimeter of a typical Finnish lake. The finishes of
label: Paragraph

text: the ground floor are also coded as an internal landscape in
label: Paragraph

text: which changes from tiles to boarding or to rough paving
label: Paragraph

text: stones denote subtle transformations in mood and status, as
label: Paragraph

text: one moves from, say, the family hearth to the sitting room
label: Paragraph

text: and conservatory. Finally, structure itself is used
label: Paragraph

text: symbolically to refer to origins: as in the Villa Hvittrask, the
label: Paragraph

text: sauna represents the native culture - linked by an outriding
label: Paragraph

text: rubble wall to the main house, it is a traditional timber-sided
label: Paragraph

text: structure roofed with sod, and built according to the canons
label: Paragraph

text: of Finnish timber vernacular, in opposition to the
label: Paragraph

text: sophisticated tectonic of the house itself.
label: Paragraph

text: After the rhetorical exuberance of his pavilion for the
label: Paragraph

text: New York World’s Fair in 1939 and the somewhat unresolved
label: Paragraph

text: design of the Baker Dormitory, built for MIT at Cambridge,
label: Caption

text: Massachusetts, in 1947, there was an expressive
label: Paragraph

text: uncertainty in Aalto’s work, until 1949, when the second
label: Paragraph

text: phase of his career took decisive shape with his Saynatsalo
label: Paragraph

text: Town Hall [199]. Where the Villa Mairea had depended for
label: Paragraph

text: its articulation on wooden revetment, at Saynatsalo the
label: Paragraph

text: syncopation of the form depended on the rhythmic spacing
label: Paragraph

text: of the fenestration and on the subtle modelling of brickwork.
label: Paragraph

text: For all their differences, however, the works had the same
label: Paragraph

text: conceptual basis in their division into two parts, grouped
label: Paragraph

text: around an atrium. These elements, which took the form of
label: Paragraph

text: an L-shaped house and a plunge pool in the Villa Mairea, are
label: Paragraph

text: at Saynatsalo a U-shaped administration building and a free-
label: Paragraph

text: standing library block, the two forms enclosing a court
label: Paragraph

text: raised above the street level. This parti, which Aalto used
label: Paragraph

text: again in his National Pensions Institute at Helsinki, seems to
label: Paragraph

text: have been derived from the traditional Karelian farm and
label: Paragraph

text: village complexes that he had first written about in 1941.
label: Paragraph

text: Another source for the duality of these compositions may be
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto’s idiosyncratic view of the process of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: creation, of which he wrote in ‘The Trout and the Mountain
label: Paragraph

text: Stream’ (1947):
label: Title

text: 199 Aalto, Saynatsalo Town Hall, 1949-52.
label: Caption

text: | would like to add that architecture and its details are
label: Paragraph

text: connected in a way with biology. They are perhaps like large
label: Paragraph

text: salmon or trout. They are not born mature, they are not
label: Paragraph

text: even born in the sea or body of water where they will
label: Paragraph

text: normally live. They are born many hundreds of miles from
label: Paragraph

text: their proper living environment. Where the rivers are but
label: Paragraph

text: streams, small shining bodies of water between mountains
label: Paragraph

text: ... aS far from their normal environment as man’s spiritual
label: Paragraph

text: life and instincts are from his daily work. And as the fish
label: Paragraph

text: egg’s development to a mature organism requires time, so it
label: Paragraph

text: also requires time for all that develops and crystallizes in
label: Paragraph

text: our world of thoughts. Architecture needs this time to an
label: Paragraph

text: even greater degree than any other creative work.°
label: Paragraph

text: All these buildings seem to symbolize this duality of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural creation, wherein the enclosing L or U form of
label: Paragraph

text: the main mass, the ‘fish’ element, is contrasted with the
label: Paragraph

text: independent form of the adjacent ‘egg’. In the Villa Mairea
label: Paragraph

text: and Saynatsalo Town Hall the head of the fish form appears
label: Paragraph

text: to accommodate the most honorific public element - the
label: Paragraph

text: studio in the house, and the council chamber in the town
label: Paragraph

text: hall.
label: Paragraph

text: Such hierarchical differentiation is complemented by
label: Paragraph

text: changes in material and structure. At Saynatsalo the brick
label: Caption

text: paving of the ‘secular’ access corridor and stair gives way to
label: Paragraph

text: the suspended wooden floor of the ‘sacred’ council chamber
label: Caption

text: above. This change in status is confirmed by the elaborate
label: Paragraph

text: detailing of the roof trusses over the council room, an
label: Caption

text: obvious reference to medieval practice. Similar shifts in
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic content occur in the ‘egg’ element: in the Villa
label: Paragraph

text: Mairea the ‘egg’ is the swimming pool - the agent of
label: Paragraph

text: physical regeneration - while in Saynatsalo Town Hall it is
label: Paragraph

text: the library, the repository of intellectual nourishment.
label: Paragraph

text: Furthermore the detailing of the atrium itself, particularly at
label: Paragraph

text: Saynatsalo and in the Pensions Institute, reflects a
label: Paragraph

text: comparable mythic intent. In both instances the path
label: Paragraph

text: through the ‘acropolis’ is treated like a ‘rite of passage’,
label: Paragraph

text: between overcivilized urbanity on one side of the complex
label: Paragraph

text: and native rusticity on the other. In each instance, the space
label: Paragraph

text: is enriched by the presence of water, hinting again at the
label: Paragraph

text: process of birth and regeneration.
label: Paragraph

text: The Pensions Institute in Helsinki [200], designed for a
label: Paragraph

text: competition of 1948 and built in 1952-56, established Aalto
label: Paragraph

text: as one of the master architects of the post-war period. As
label: Paragraph

text: much as any work from the last twenty-five years of his
label: Paragraph

text: career, this large bureaucratic complex demonstrated an
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that would, in his own words, add ‘a more
label: Paragraph

text: sensitive structure to living’. This intent, evident in the
label: Paragraph

text: warmth and convenience of the smallest details, from the
label: Paragraph

text: foyer seats to the visitors’ coatracks and from the light
label: Caption

text: fittings to the built-in heating, was manifest above all in the
label: Paragraph

text: delicately scaled interviewing booths ranged in rows under
label: Paragraph

text: the skylit hall. This hall, paved in black and white marble,
label: Paragraph

text: established the honorific ‘key’ for the rest of the building.
label: Paragraph

text: Thereafter each space is colour-coded in order to suggest a
label: Paragraph

text: change in status - the main entry in white and dark blue
label: Title

text: wall tiles, the staff refectory in brown, white and beige, and
label: Paragraph

text: so on.
label: Paragraph

text: 200 Aalto, National Pensions Institute, Helsinki, 1952-56. Centre of south front.
label: Caption

text: Aalto’s resolve to serve the common man reappeared in
label: Paragraph

text: his adaptation of the ‘atrium’ concept to the design of a
label: Paragraph

text: multistorey apartment block, built for the Berlin
label: Caption

text: ‘Hansaviertel Interbau’ exhibition in 1955. This ingenious
label: Paragraph

text: design [201] comprised one of the most significant
label: Paragraph

text: apartment types to have been invented since the end of the
label: Paragraph

text: Second World War. Le Corbusier’s famous Unité maisonette
label: Paragraph

text: (so extensively copied in low-cost housing throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: world) compares with it rather unfavourably as a family
label: Paragraph

text: dwelling. The primary virtue of Aalto’s apartment type is
label: Paragraph

text: that it provides the attributes of the single-family home
label: Paragraph

text: within the confines of a small flat. Within its U-organization
label: Paragraph

text: a generous atrium terrace is flanked by the living and dining
label: Paragraph

text: rooms, while the whole is surrounded on two sides by
label: Paragraph

text: private spaces, such as bedrooms and bathrooms. The
label: Paragraph

text: disposition of these apartment units within the block is
label: Paragraph

text: equally good, their ‘clustering’ about naturally lit stair halls
label: Paragraph

text: enabling Aalto to avoid that sense of an infinite number of
label: Paragraph

text: ‘monotype’ apartments stacked in a single high-rise
label: Paragraph

text: structure.
label: Paragraph

text: 201 Aalto, Hansaviertel apartment block, Berlin, 1955.
label: Caption

text: Aalto’s lifelong attempt to satisfy social and
label: Paragraph

text: psychological criteria effectively set him apart from the
label: Paragraph

text: more dogmatic Functionalists of the 1920s, whose careers
label: Paragraph

text: were already established when he designed his first
label: Paragraph

text: significant works. Despite his initial response to the dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: forms of Soviet Constructivism, Aalto always focused his
label: Paragraph

text: attention on the creation of environments which would be
label: Paragraph

text: conducive to human well-being. Even his most Functionalist
label: Paragraph

text: works, such as his 7urun-Sanomat Building of 1928, reflect
label: Paragraph

text: his perennial sensitivity to light, constantly enriching a
label: Paragraph

text: structure that would otherwise be extremely dogmatic and
label: Paragraph

text: austere.
label: Paragraph

text: Such a consistently organic approach brought Aalto
label: Paragraph

text: conceptually close to the ethos of Bruno Taut’s Glass Chain,
label: Paragraph

text: above all to the work of Hans Scharoun and to Hugo Haring.
label: Paragraph

text: So he may be seen as belonging to that ‘group’ of Northern
label: Paragraph

text: European Expressionist architects who were concerned that
label: Paragraph

text: building should be life-giving rather than repressive. This
label: Paragraph

text: meant that the latent tyranny of the normative orthogonal
label: Paragraph

text: grid should always be fractured and inflected where the
label: Paragraph

text: idiosyncrasies of the site or the programme demanded it. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1960 Leonardo Benevolo effectively summed up Aalto’s
label: Paragraph

text: achievement from this standpoint in the following terms:
label: Paragraph

text: In the first modern buildings the constancy of the right
label: Paragraph

text: angle served mainly to generalize the compositional process
label: Paragraph

text: of instituting a priori geometrical relationships between all
label: Paragraph

text: the elements, which meant that all conflicts could be
label: Paragraph

text: resolved geometrically with the balancing of lines, surfaces,
label: Paragraph

text: and volumes. The use of the oblique (as at Paimio) pointed
label: Paragraph

text: the way towards the contrary process, that of making the
label: Paragraph

text: forms more individual and precise, allowing imbalance and
label: Paragraph

text: tension to exist and to be balanced by the physical
label: Paragraph

text: consistency of the elements and surroundings. Such
label: Paragraph

text: architecture lost in didactic rigours but gained in warmth,
label: Paragraph

text: richness, and feeling, and ultimately extended its field of
label: Paragraph

text: action because the process of individuation was based on
label: Paragraph

text: the already recognized generalizing method and indeed
label: Paragraph

text: presupposed it.®
label: Paragraph

text: At its best this was a discreet yet highly responsive mode
label: Paragraph

text: of building, one which continued the essential Nordic
label: Paragraph

text: tradition of fusing the vernacular with the Classical - the
label: Paragraph

text: idiosyncratic with the normative - through fifty years of
label: Paragraph

text: unbroken development, from Ostberg’s Bonnier Villa of 1909
label: Paragraph

text: to Aalto’s Finlandia Concert Hall, completed in Helsinki some
label: Caption

text: four years before his death in 1976.
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 25
label: Title

text: Giuseppe Terragni and the
label: Title

text: Architecture of Italian
label: Title

text: Rationalism 1926-43
label: Title

text: We no longer feel ourselves to be the men of the cathedrals
label: Paragraph

text: and the ancient moot halls, but men of the Grand Hotels,
label: Paragraph

text: railway stations, giant roads, colossal harbours, covered
label: Paragraph

text: markets, glittering arcades, reconstructed areas and
label: Paragraph

text: salutary slum clearances.
label: Paragraph

text: Antonio Sant’Elia
label: Title

text: Messaggio (text for the Citta Nuova, 1914)!
label: Caption

text: Our past and present are not incompatible. We do not wish
label: Paragraph

text: to ignore our traditional heritage. It is the tradition which
label: Paragraph

text: transforms itself and assumes new aspects recognizable
label: Paragraph

text: only to a few.
label: Paragraph

text: gruppo 7
label: Title

text: ‘Note’, in Rassegna Italiana, December 19262
label: Caption

text: The Classical and oneiric expression that emerged in Italy
label: Paragraph

text: after the end of the First World War - first in painting, in the
label: Paragraph

text: highly metaphysical Valori Plastici movement led by Giorgio
label: Paragraph

text: de Chirico, and then in architecture, with the Classical
label: Paragraph

text: Novecento movement started by the architect Giovanni
label: Paragraph

text: Muzio - was as much the complex point of departure for the
label: Paragraph

text: development of Italian Rationalism as was the heritage of
label: Paragraph

text: pre-war Futurist polemic.
label: Paragraph

text: The Rationalist ‘gruppo 7’, who first declared themselves,
label: Paragraph

text: after graduating from the Milan Polytechnic, in the Rassegna
label: Paragraph

text: Italiana, comprised the architects Sebastiano Larco, Guido
label: Paragraph

text: Frette, Carlo Enrico Rava, Adalberto Libera, Luigi Figini, Gino
label: Caption

text: Pollini and Giuseppe Terragni. All sought to achieve a new
label: Paragraph

text: and more rational synthesis between the nationalistic values
label: Title

text: of Italian Classicism and the structural logic of the machine
label: Title

text: age. In their ‘Note’ of 1926 they committed themselves to
label: Paragraph

text: exploring a middle ground between the arcane language of
label: Paragraph

text: the Novecento - of which Muzio’s Ca’ Brutta apartment
label: Paragraph

text: block built in Milan in 1923 was an influential example - and
label: Paragraph

text: the dynamic vocabulary of industrial form bequeathed to
label: Paragraph

text: them by the Futurists. The group also showed a certain
label: Paragraph

text: sympathy for the Deutsche Werkbund and for the works of
label: Paragraph

text: the Russian Constructivists. Yet for all their enthusiasm for
label: Paragraph

text: the machine age, the gruppo 7 gave more weight to a
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpretation of tradition than to modernity per se. Thus,
label: Paragraph

text: in 1926, they wrote critically of the Futurists:
label: Paragraph

text: The hallmark of the earlier avant garde was a contrived
label: Paragraph

text: impetus and a vain, destructive fury, mingling good and bad
label: Paragraph

text: elements: the hallmark of today’s youth is a desire for
label: Paragraph

text: lucidity and wisdom. ... This must be clear... we do not
label: Paragraph

text: intend to break with tradition. ... The new architecture, the
label: Paragraph

text: true architecture should be the result of a close association
label: Paragraph

text: between logic and rationality.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite this declaration of faith in tradition, the early
label: Paragraph

text: works of the Rationalists, particularly those projected by
label: Paragraph

text: Giuseppe Terragni, displayed a preference for compositions
label: Paragraph

text: based on industrial themes. Terragni’s projects for a
label: Paragraph

text: gasworks and a steel tube factory exhibited at the IIlrd
label: Caption

text: Monza Biennale of 1927 seem to have more to do with the
label: Paragraph

text: Engineer’s Aesthetic than with Architecture, to use the
label: Paragraph

text: polarities of Le Corbusier’s Vers une architecture, a book
label: Paragraph

text: which exercised considerable influence on the Rationailisti
label: Paragraph

text: after its publication in 1923. An early and naive response to
label: Paragraph

text: this influence was indubitably Pietro Lingeri’s boathouse,
label: Paragraph

text: built at Como in 1926, which, with its allusion to marine
label: Paragraph

text: engineering, paid somewhat simplistic homage to the work
label: Paragraph

text: of Le Corbusier.
label: Paragraph

text: More susceptible to the influence of Muzio, Terragni
label: Paragraph

text: established himself in 1928 with the completion of his
label: Paragraph

text: Novocomun apartments in Como. This symmetrical five-
label: Paragraph

text: storey composition, popularly known as the Transatlantico,
label: Paragraph

text: manifested that characteristic Rationalist concern for the
label: Paragraph

text: rhetorical displacement of mass. Where the corners of the
label: Paragraph

text: building should have been reinforced in accordance with
label: Paragraph

text: Classical canon, they were dramatically cut away so as to
label: Paragraph

text: expose glass cylinders, which were capped by the massive
label: Paragraph

text: weight of the oversailing top floor and bound into the
label: Paragraph

text: composition by the overruns of the third-floor balcony and
label: Caption

text: the mass of the second floor. This solution obviously owed
label: Paragraph

text: more to Russian Constructivism than to Purism, Golossov’s
label: Paragraph

text: initial project for his Zuyev Workers’ Club, completed in
label: Paragraph

text: Moscow in 1928, being the most obvious precedent.
label: Paragraph

text: The Italian Rationalist movement briefly constituted itself
label: Paragraph

text: as an official body in the Movimento Italiano per
label: Paragraph

text: l’Architettura Razionale (MIAR), founded in 1930 just one
label: Paragraph

text: year before the third exhibition of the gruppo 7 staged in
label: Paragraph

text: Bardi’s Galleria d’Arte in Rome. Its influence was short-lived
label: Paragraph

text: since it was soon to be undermined by the forces of cultural
label: Paragraph

text: reaction. Where earlier manifestations of Rationalist work
label: Paragraph

text: had left the more conservative professionals relatively
label: Paragraph

text: undisturbed, this show was accompanied by a provocative
label: Paragraph

text: pamphlet entitled ‘Report to Mussolini on Architecture’,
label: Paragraph

text: written by the art critic Pietro Maria Bardi. He claimed that
label: Paragraph

text: Rationalist architecture was the only true expression of
label: Paragraph

text: Fascist revolutionary principles. A MIAR declaration of the
label: Paragraph

text: period put forward an equally opportunistic assertion: ‘Our
label: Paragraph

text: movement has no other moral aim than that of serving the
label: Paragraph

text: [Fascist] Revolution in the prevailing harsh climate. We call
label: Paragraph

text: upon Mussolini’s good faith to enable us to achieve this.’
label: Paragraph

text: Mussolini opened the exhibition, but his faith was little
label: Paragraph

text: proof against the hostile reaction of the National Union of
label: Paragraph

text: Architects, subject to the influence of the classicist Marcello
label: Paragraph

text: Piacentini. Three weeks after the opening of the exhibition,
label: Paragraph

text: the National Union of Architects repudiated the very work
label: Paragraph

text: that it had previously sponsored, publicly declaring that
label: Paragraph

text: Rationalist architecture was incompatible with the rhetorical
label: Paragraph

text: demands of Fascism. It was left for Piacentini to mediate
label: Paragraph

text: between the metaphysical traditionalism of the Novecento
label: Title

text: and the avant gardism of the Rationalists and to propose his
label: Paragraph

text: highly eclectic Stile Littorio (Lictorial Style) as the ‘official’
label: Paragraph

text: party manner. First formulated in the Revolutionary Tower,
label: Paragraph

text: completed in Brescia to his designs in 1932, this manner
label: Paragraph

text: was finally consolidated in Piacentini’s Palace of Justice
label: Paragraph

text: started in Milan in 1932.
label: Paragraph

text: Piacentini’s position was reinforced by the founding of
label: Paragraph

text: the Fascist Raggruppamento Architetti Moderni, which
label: Paragraph

text: avoided any categorical condemnation of either the
label: Paragraph

text: Novecentisti or the Rationalists and gave its support to the
label: Paragraph

text: vestigial Classicism of the Stile Littorio. The guidelines that
label: Paragraph

text: Piacentini imposed on the nine architects who collaborated
label: Paragraph

text: with him in 1932 on the new University in Rome [202]
label: Caption

text: established, through the repetition of simple elements, the
label: Paragraph

text: rudiments of the official Fascist manner. This remarkably
label: Paragraph

text: consistent style was expressed almost always in four-storey
label: Paragraph

text: brick or stone masses, capped by rudimentary cornices and
label: Paragraph

text: articulated solely through a modulation of rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: openings. Since a certain irregularity and asymmetry was
label: Paragraph

text: permitted in the detailed planning, representative
label: Paragraph

text: expression was largely restricted to the entrances where,
label: Paragraph

text: with colonnades, bas reliefs and lettered friezes, it took a
label: Paragraph

text: Classical form. Although none of gruppo 7 worked on the
label: Paragraph

text: University, three buildings by the Piacentini team betrayed a
label: Paragraph

text: certain Rationalist affinity: Gio Ponti’s School of
label: Paragraph

text: Mathematics, Giovanni Michelucci’s Mineralogy Building
label: Title

text: and, above all, Giuseppe Pagano’s elegantly brick-faced
label: Paragraph

text: Institute of Physics.
label: Paragraph

text: 202 Piacentini and team, University of Rome, 1932. Senate building on
label: Caption

text: inauguration day.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1932 Pagano had already made his contribution to the
label: Paragraph

text: polemic surrounding the evolution of an appropriate
label: Title

text: national style, for in 1930 he had started to edit the
label: Paragraph

text: magazine Casabella in collaboration with the Turinese art
label: Paragraph

text: critic and designer Edoardo Persico. These men
label: Paragraph

text: endeavoured through their editorials to persuade the
label: Paragraph

text: undecided members of the Novecento to abandon the Stile
label: Paragraph

text: Littorio of Piacentini in favour of the Rationalism of Terragni.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1934 Persico wrote of the Rationalist predicament: ‘Today,
label: Paragraph

text: artists must tackle the thorniest problem of Italian life: the
label: Paragraph

text: capacity to believe in specific ideologies and the will to
label: Paragraph

text: pursue the struggle against the claims of an “anti-
label: Paragraph

text: modernist” majority.’
label: Paragraph

text: In 1932 Terragni produced the canonical work of the
label: Paragraph

text: Italian Rationalist movement, the Casa del Fascio (now the
label: Paragraph

text: Casa del Popolo) in Como. Planned within a perfect square
label: Paragraph

text: and half as high as its width of 33 metres (110 feet), the half
label: Paragraph

text: cube of the Casa del Fascio established the basis of strictly
label: Paragraph

text: rational geometry [203]. Within this volume, it not only
label: Paragraph

text: revealed the logic of its trabeated frame but also the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘rational’ code underlying the modelling of its layered
label: Paragraph

text: facade. On every side (except the south-east elevation
label: Caption

text: which stresses the main stair) the fenestration and the
label: Paragraph

text: external layers of the building are manipulated in such a
label: Paragraph

text: way as to express the presence of the internal atrium.
label: Paragraph

text: Earlier studies for the building reveal that like other works
label: Paragraph

text: by Terragni (such as his Sant’Elia School of 1936) it was
label: Paragraph

text: originally planned around an open courtyard, on the model
label: Paragraph

text: of the traditional palazzo. In subsequent stages of the
label: Paragraph

text: design this cortile became a central double-height meeting
label: Paragraph

text: hall, top-lit through a glazed concrete roof and surrounded
label: Caption

text: on four sides by galleries, offices and meeting rooms. As in
label: Paragraph

text: Mies van der Rohe’s Barcelona Pavilion of 1929, the
label: Paragraph

text: monumental status of the entire structure is established by
label: Paragraph

text: its slight elevation on a masonry base, described by Terragni
label: Paragraph

text: as a piano rialzato. The original political purpose of the
label: Paragraph

text: structure is expressed in almost literal terms through the
label: Paragraph

text: battery of glass doors which separates the entrance foyer
label: Caption

text: from the piazza. These, when simultaneously opened by an
label: Paragraph

text: electrical device, would have united the inner agora of the
label: Paragraph

text: cortile to the piazza, thereby permitting the uninterrupted
label: Paragraph

text: flow of mass demonstrations from street to interior (fig. 24,
label: Caption

text: p. 47). Comparable political connotations are evident in the
label: Paragraph

text: treatment of the main meeting room with its photomontage
label: Caption

text: relief by Mario Radice [204] and in the shrine
label: Caption

text: commemorating the fallen of the Fascist movement. There
label: Paragraph

text: is, needless to say, an aspect of this work which transcends
label: Paragraph

text: these ideological considerations to concern itself with the
label: Paragraph

text: creation of metaphysical spatial effects - the building is
label: Paragraph

text: treated as though it were a continuous spatial matrix,
label: Paragraph

text: without any particular orientation such as up or down, left or
label: Paragraph

text: right, etc. Thus the mirror effects of glass are used in the
label: Paragraph

text: lining of the foyer ceiling to create the illusion of an infinite
label: Paragraph

text: trabeated construction existing in volumes which are in fact
label: Paragraph

text: quite differently occupied. At the same time the subtle
label: Paragraph

text: implantation of the work in an historic urban core, its facing
label: Paragraph

text: throughout in Bolticino marble and its use of glass block to
label: Paragraph

text: designate its honorific space, combine to create a work
label: Paragraph

text: which is at once tectonic, meticulous and monumental.
label: Paragraph

text: 203 Terragni, Casa del Fascio, Como, 1932-36. Proportional system of facade,
label: Caption

text: and ground plan.
label: Paragraph

text: 204 Terragni, Casa del Fascio, Como, 1932-36. Main meeting room. The panel
label: Caption

text: on the end wall, by Radice, includes a portrait of Mussolini.
label: Caption

text: This ideal symbolization of Fascism was by no means
label: Paragraph

text: unique. Other rhetorical overtures to the movement were
label: Paragraph

text: made by the Rationalists before their final disillusionment in
label: Paragraph

text: the mid-1940s. Amongst these, mention must be made of
label: Paragraph

text: the building for the ‘Mostra della Rivoluzione Fascista’,
label: Paragraph

text: staged in Rome in 1932, on the occasion of the tenth
label: Paragraph

text: anniversary of the March on Rome. This temporary
label: Paragraph

text: structure, strongly reminiscent of the work of Leonidov and
label: Paragraph

text: built to the designs of Libera and De Renzi, contained along
label: Paragraph

text: with other set pieces the commemorative 1922 Room
label: Caption

text: designed by Terragni as a dynamic wall relief, combining
label: Paragraph

text: plastic, graphic and photographic elements in a manner
label: Paragraph

text: which recalled Lissitzky’s Soviet International Hygiene
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibit, staged in Dresden in 1930.
label: Paragraph

text: By the mid-1930s actual Rationalist architecture varied
label: Paragraph

text: widely from the highly intellectual work of Terragni to the
label: Paragraph

text: bland International Style of the short-lived Comasco group,
label: Paragraph

text: whose artist’s house was exhibited at the Vth Milan
label: Paragraph

text: Triennale of 1933. The participation of Terragni as a member
label: Paragraph

text: of this eight-man design team seems to have had little
label: Paragraph

text: effect on the quality of the outcome, and a comparable loss
label: Paragraph

text: of intensity can be detected when one compares the very
label: Paragraph

text: first work of Figini and Pollini, namely their Casa Elettrica
label: Paragraph

text: built for the Milan Triennale of 1930, to their artist’s house
label: Paragraph

text: built for the next Triennale in 1933. And indeed the facts
label: Paragraph

text: indicate that by the time of the Vth Triennale, Italian
label: Paragraph

text: Rationalism was already becoming compromised, either by
label: Paragraph

text: a banal modernism on the one hand or by a reactionary
label: Paragraph

text: historicism on the other.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1934 Persico and Marcello Nizzoli designed their
label: Paragraph

text: famous Medaglia d’Oro room for the Italian Aeronautical
label: Caption

text: Show in Milan [205]. An elegant labyrinth of white wooden
label: Caption

text: lattices, raised well above the floor, supported a field of
label: Paragraph

text: graphic and photographic images that appeared to float in
label: Paragraph

text: space and to advance and recede throughout the depth of
label: Paragraph

text: the hall. This suspended construction established a new
label: Paragraph

text: standard for exhibition design that was to exercise a strong
label: Paragraph

text: influence until well after the Second World War. By this date,
label: Paragraph

text: with the exception of such occasional masterpieces as this
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinary work by Persico and Nizzoli, Italian
label: Caption

text: Rationalism had entered its decline. This much is evident
label: Paragraph

text: from the subsequent work of Persico himself, who moved in
label: Paragraph

text: the space of two years from designs of great vivacity and
label: Paragraph

text: sophistication to the cold, atectonic monumentality of his
label: Paragraph

text: Salone d’Onore for the 1936 Triennale, designed in
label: Caption

text: collaboration with Nizzoli, Palanti and Fontana. Only
label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: Rationalist approach, with its concern for the total

label: Caption

text: Show, Milan, 1934.
label: Caption

text: After Persico’s untimely death in 1936, the political and
label: Paragraph

text: cultural difficulties of the Rationalists increased. Pagano,
label: Paragraph

text: always close to official circles, compromised himself further
label: Paragraph

text: through collaborating with Piacentini on the plan for the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Esposizione Universale Roma ’42’, to be held outside Rome
label: Paragraph

text: in 1942. Like the new Fascist towns of Littoria, Sabaudia,
label: Paragraph

text: Carbonia and Pontinia (this last being built in the Pontine
label: Paragraph

text: marshes), the permanent structures of the EUR ’42, the
label: Paragraph

text: museums, memorials and palaces, were designated by
label: Paragraph

text: Mussolini to form the core of the Third Rome. Not even
label: Paragraph

text: Pagano’s intelligence could prevent this extravagant
label: Paragraph

text: ideological gesture from degenerating into the most banal
label: Paragraph

text: assembly of Neo-Classical forms. Its major set-piece, the
label: Paragraph

text: Palazzo della Civilta Italiana by Guerrini, La Padula and
label: Caption

text: Romano, was nothing if not the ultimate vulgarization of the
label: Paragraph

text: Valori Plastici movement. One imagines that its empty,
label: Paragraph

text: cubic, arcuated forms could have hardly delighted any
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility more than that of De Chirico himself. Of the same
label: Paragraph

text: spirit as Mussolini’s 1931 plan for the Haussmannization of
label: Paragraph

text: Rome (a proposal for the wholesale removal of the medieval
label: Paragraph

text: urban tissue from the antique ruins) Piacentini’s EUR ‘42
label: Caption

text: plan was caught, like the various architectural factions
label: Paragraph

text: including the Rationalists, between a post-Futurist drive to
label: Paragraph

text: create a modern civilization and the need to legitimize this
label: Paragraph

text: same civilization through an appeal to the glories of the
label: Paragraph

text: Roman imperium. Thus the EUR complex turned its principal
label: Paragraph

text: axis towards the Tyrrhenian coast and inscribed one of its
label: Paragraph

text: monuments with the prophecy: ‘The Third Rome will spread
label: Title

text: over the other hills along the sacred river [Tiber] to the
label: Paragraph

text: beaches of the sea.’ As for the involvement of the
label: Paragraph

text: Rationalists in this Faustian enterprise, Leonardo Benevolo
label: Paragraph

text: has written:
label: Paragraph

text: The compromise attempted by Pagano was thus untenable:
label: Paragraph

text: by following ‘ideal links back to Roman times, architects
label: Paragraph

text: would arrive at one result only, neo-classical conformism;
label: Paragraph

text: the differences of tone between Brasini’s applied
label: Paragraph

text: archaeology and Foschini’s measured simplification,
label: Paragraph

text: between the sophisticated elegance of the young Romans
label: Paragraph

text: and the calculated rhythms of the young Milanese, which
label: Paragraph

text: seemed important in the plans, disappeared entirely in the
label: Paragraph

text: execution. What had happened in Germany, Russia, and
label: Paragraph

text: France was repeated here too: this was the internationale
label: Paragraph

text: des pompiers.4

text: The reactionary architectural and political climate
label: Title

text: prevailing in Italy in the mid-1930s was partly offset by the
label: Paragraph

text: Saint-Simonian aspirations of one man, Adriano Olivetti, who
label: Paragraph

text: had succeeded his father as director of the famous business
label: Paragraph

text: machines concern in 1932. In 1934 Adriano began to reveal
label: Paragraph

text: his concern for the contribution to be made by modern
label: Paragraph

text: design to industrial welfare by successively commissioning
label: Title

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: In the meantime, a set of closely related designs
label: Paragraph

text: continued to pour forth from Terragni’s studio, including his
label: Paragraph

text: competition entries for the Casa Littoria of 1937 and the
label: Paragraph

text: EUR Congress Building of 1938, both projects designed in
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration with Cattaneo and Lingeri. Around the same
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: entire career, his Danteum [206], projected in 1938 as a
label: Paragraph

text: monumental embellishment to the Via Del Impero cut by
label: Caption

text: Mussolini through the ancient city. This project, comprising
label: Paragraph

text: progressively less dense blocks of rectangular space
label: Paragraph

text: arranged as a labyrinth and symbolizing the stages of
label: Paragraph

text: Inferno, Purgatory and Paradise, was in many respects an
label: Paragraph

text: abstraction of the part/ used for the EUR building.

label: Caption

text: Terragni’s obsession with a ‘transparent’ architecture - a
label: Paragraph

text: sublimation of the Futurist programme of projecting the
label: Paragraph

text: street into the house - was first advanced in his Casa del
label: Paragraph

text: Fascio. Thereafter it reappeared as a constant drive
label: Paragraph

text: throughout all his public work, from the Sarfatti Monument,
label: Paragraph

text: built at Col d’Echele in 1934, to the final design for the EUR
label: Paragraph

text: Congress Building. Aside from the ultimate state of ‘lucidity’
label: Paragraph

text: attained in the Paradise volume of the Danteum, with its
label: Paragraph

text: thirty-three glass columns and its glass ceiling, Terragni
label: Caption

text: achieved a sense of conceptual transparency through two
label: Paragraph

text: basic devices which were ingeniously fused together in his
label: Paragraph

text: seven-storey apartment block, the Casa Rustici, Milan
label: Caption

text: (1936-37). These devices were (1) the use of a duality
label: Paragraph

text: which, following the form of his 1931 War Memorial in
label: Paragraph

text: Como, generally comprised two parallel rectilinear masses
label: Paragraph

text: with a slot of space in between, and (2) frontalized parallel
label: Paragraph

text: rectilinear voids or masses, receding like successive picture
label: Paragraph

text: planes from a given vantage point, as in the flying balconies
label: Paragraph

text: and bridges, etc., of the Casa Rustici or the glazed office
label: Caption

text: slabs of the Casa Littoria, whose receding spatial layers
label: Paragraph

text: established the domain of the ancillary ground-level
label: Paragraph

text: accommodation, the auditoria, etc.
label: Paragraph

text: This frontalized formula of alternately built and non-built
label: Paragraph

text: parallel volumes came to be asymmetrically rotated in the
label: Paragraph

text: EUR proposal and in a condensed form in Terragni’s last
label: Paragraph

text: building, his four-storey Giuliani Frigerio Apartments
label: Caption

text: completed in Como in 1940. As in the Casa del Fascio the
label: Paragraph

text: intention seems to have been to inflect the orientation of
label: Paragraph

text: the prism by arranging for a primary and secondary facade
label: Caption

text: to be placed at right angles to one another. A similar
label: Paragraph

text: rotatory ‘cubist’ composition had already appeared in
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni’s early villas and the same ‘format’ was adopted by
label: Paragraph

text: Cattaneo in his apartment house built in Cernobbio in 1938.
label: Paragraph

text: The final work of the series, in which Terragni did not
label: Paragraph

text: participate, is the Fascist Trades Union Building at Como
label: Paragraph

text: [207], under construction on a site next to the Casa del
label: Caption

text: Fascio from 1938 to 1943 and built to the designs of
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni’s prime pupil Cattaneo, in collaboration with
label: Paragraph

text: Lingeri, Augusto Magnagni, L. Origoni and Mario Terragni.
label: Caption

text: This orthogonal, trabeated structure, organized about a
label: Paragraph

text: Palladian ABABABABA grid in one direction and a regular but
label: Paragraph

text: partially syncopated modular grid in the other, is in many
label: Paragraph

text: respects the most sublime resolution of compositional and
label: Paragraph

text: typological themes initiated by the Como Rationalists, so
label: Paragraph

text: much so that one may even claim that this building is one of
label: Paragraph

text: the major inspirations behind the so-called ‘autonomous
label: Paragraph

text: architecture’ of the Italian Tendenza produced over the past
label: Paragraph

text: decade (compare Giorgio Grassi’s design for a Students’
label: Paragraph

text: Hostel at Chieti of 1974 with Monestiroli, Conti and
label: Paragraph

text: Guazzoni). The Trades Union Building consists of two five-
label: Paragraph

text: storey slabs separated by a courtyard in which a two-storey
label: Paragraph

text: ancillary block is suspended, comprising an entry podium, a
label: Paragraph

text: secretariat and a 500-seat auditorium.
