label: Caption

text: The completion of this building in 1943 coincided with
label: Paragraph

text: the premature and still somewhat mysterious deaths of both
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni and Cattaneo. Although their deaths brought the
label: Paragraph

text: movement to an abrupt close, their works still testify to their
label: Paragraph

text: efforts to realize an ideal setting for a society which would
label: Paragraph

text: be at one and the same time both rationally organized and
label: Paragraph

text: culturally classless. The fact that this ideal attained its
label: Paragraph

text: fulfilment in the transparent logic of their architecture rather
label: Paragraph

text: than in the society at large was touched on by Sylvia Danesi
label: Paragraph

text: when she wrote of the two men in 1977:
label: Paragraph

text: In both there is a complete trust in the guiding role of the
label: Paragraph

text: middle class and of its organizing capacity in its
label: Paragraph

text: administrative function as a pivot of the social contract.
label: Paragraph

text: They did not sense the crisis that was about to involve their
label: Paragraph

text: generation. They felt that the class to which they too
label: Paragraph

text: belonged would be perfectly capable of carrying out the
label: Paragraph

text: task delegated to them by the rest of the country. They did
label: Paragraph

text: not realize that the local industrial middle class was
label: Paragraph

text: gradually losing ground to the new State bourgeoisie that
label: Paragraph

text: was being formed on the strength of the 1929 crisis
label: Paragraph

text: (nationalization of banks, foundation of the IRI, etc.) and
label: Paragraph

text: which still governs us to this day; a class who got on fine
label: Paragraph

text: with big capital interests and felt at their ease with the
label: Paragraph

text: totalitarian regime.°

label: Caption

text: The modernist tendency to reduce all form to abstraction
label: Title

text: made it an unsatisfactory manner in which to represent the
label: Paragraph

text: power and ideology of the state. This iconographic
label: Paragraph

text: inadequacy largely accounts for the survival of an historicist
label: Paragraph

text: approach to building in the second half of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: It is to Henry-Russell Hitchcock’s credit as a historian that
label: Paragraph

text: long ago he felt it necessary to acknowledge the persistence
label: Paragraph

text: of this vestigial tradition. However, his term ‘The New
label: Paragraph

text: Tradition’, coined in 1929 in an effort to distinguish a certain
label: Paragraph

text: conservative trend from the works of the pioneers, has
label: Paragraph

text: hardly stood the test of time. The attributes and the
label: Paragraph

text: chronology that he attached to this tradition were too vague
label: Paragraph

text: to gain general acceptance. Nevertheless, the need to treat
label: Paragraph

text: the problems posed by representation or the lack of it has
label: Paragraph

text: increased rather than diminished over the years, and the
label: Paragraph

text: cultural predicament of Social Realism in its broadest sense
label: Paragraph

text: can now no longer be excluded from our critical scrutiny. In
label: Paragraph

text: a general sense, the term may be taken as evidence of the
label: Paragraph

text: failure of abstract form to communicate. In the face of this,
label: Paragraph

text: as Hitchcock wrote in 1958: ‘The historian must attempt to
label: Paragraph

text: give some sort of account of things like the Stockholm City
label: Paragraph

text: Hall or the Woolworth Building.’
label: Paragraph

text: The origin of the New Tradition, outside the main line of
label: Paragraph

text: the Modern Movement, can be seen to lie in the emergence
label: Paragraph

text: between 1900 and 1914 of a consciously ‘modernized’
label: Paragraph

text: historicist style. In the first place, the generic style of the
label: Paragraph

text: establishment, the late 19th-century public mode which
label: Paragraph

text: oscillated constantly between Neo-Gothic and Neo-Baroque,
label: Paragraph

text: began to lose its definition. In England and Germany, in
label: Paragraph

text: particular, it degenerated into an eclectic elaboration which
label: Paragraph

text: in the event demonstrated little capacity for achieving a
label: Paragraph

text: convincing architectural expression. At the same time the
label: Paragraph

text: main line of European Classicism, the Beaux-Arts, reached
label: Paragraph

text: its pompier dead end in the Paris Exhibition of 1900. The
label: Paragraph

text: scintillating yet over-blown rhetoric of the Grand Palais, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, was patently ill-equipped to represent the
label: Paragraph

text: progressive ideology of an advanced industrialized society.
label: Paragraph

text: What could after all be more symbolic of repression than the
label: Paragraph

text: ferrovitreous interior of the Grand Palais incarcerated in an
label: Paragraph

text: elaborate scenography of stone? The subsequent attempt to
label: Paragraph

text: revivify this perennial preference for lithic form with sinuous
label: Paragraph

text: floral motives drawn from Art Nouveau led to equally
label: Paragraph

text: lugubrious examples of petrified Classicism with heavy
label: Paragraph

text: Symbolist overtones, such as Boileau’s Hétel Lutetia, Paris
label: Paragraph

text: (1911), much despised by Le Corbusier.
label: Paragraph

text: On the other hand, the essentially anti-establishment
label: Paragraph

text: Anglo-Saxon Free Style or its even more liberated successor
label: Paragraph

text: on the Continent, generally known as Art Nouveau, had by
label: Paragraph

text: this time degenerated into a very rigid, crystallized form of
label: Paragraph

text: expression. In addition, as Henry van de Velde realized in
label: Paragraph

text: 1908, the very idea of a Gesamtskunstwerk had the
label: Paragraph

text: unfortunate consequence of privatizing the sociocultural
label: Paragraph

text: significance of the work in question. Neither the protracted
label: Paragraph

text: Pre-Raphaelite myth of a return to an agrarian craft
label: Paragraph

text: economy nor the urbane exoticism of Art Nouveau could be
label: Paragraph

text: exploited to represent either parliamentary democracy or
label: Paragraph

text: the ideological aspirations of a liberal and progressive
label: Title

text: society. Even Peter Behrens, who, about 1910, stood on the
label: Paragraph

text: threshold of a new normative style expressly conceived for
label: Paragraph

text: the representation of the cartel, if not of the modern
label: Paragraph

text: industrial state (Max Weber's Machtstaat), was to lose his
label: Paragraph

text: creative nerve by the time of the Werkbund Exhibition of
label: Paragraph

text: 1914 and to retreat into the security of the all but Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Classical formula of his Werkbund Festhalle.
label: Paragraph

text: Ragnar Ostberg’s unique adaptation of the principles of
label: Paragraph

text: the English Free Style to the purpose of representing a
label: Paragraph

text: public institution came with his Stockholm City Hall of 1909-
label: Paragraph

text: 23, an iconographic triumph that seems to have owed its
label: Paragraph

text: singular success to the fact that it represented a traditional
label: Paragraph

text: Burgher port rather than an industrial state. In this respect it
label: Paragraph

text: hinted at the architectural policies of the Third Reich, which
label: Paragraph

text: reserved certain styles for particular ideological ends.
label: Paragraph

text: The eve of the First World War saw the creation of a
label: Paragraph

text: number of works representative of the New Tradition,
label: Paragraph

text: ‘historicist’ buildings which were far from being historically
label: Paragraph

text: determined in their overall conception. Thus the Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: detailing of Cass Gilbert’s Woolworth Building in New York
label: Caption

text: (1913) was incidental compared to the way in which its
label: Paragraph

text: uncompromising organization and exotic profile were to
label: Paragraph

text: anticipate the post-war skyscraper developments of Frank
label: Paragraph

text: Lloyd Wright and Raymond Hood.
label: Paragraph

text: In Europe the inauguration of the New Tradition was more
label: Paragraph

text: self-conscious, marked by works which independently broke
label: Paragraph

text: with the received public style of the Neo-Baroque to return,
label: Paragraph

text: in spirit if not in form, to the gravity and clarity of ancient
label: Paragraph

text: Rome - typical examples include Paul Bonatz’s Stuttgart
label: Paragraph

text: Railway Station, built in 1913-27, and Edwin Lutyens’s New
label: Paragraph

text: Delhi, commissioned in 1912 but not realized in its final
label: Paragraph

text: form until 1931.
label: Paragraph

text: George V's proclamation, founding the capital of New
label: Paragraph

text: Delhi at a durbar or mass pageant held there in his honour,
label: Paragraph

text: was nothing if not an elaborate ideological gesture,
label: Paragraph

text: designed to mask the sheer expediency that lay behind the
label: Paragraph

text: British removal of their Indian capital from Calcutta to Delhi
label: Title

text: in 1911. Evidently the British hoped that by reviving the
label: Paragraph

text: pageantry of the Moghul Court - in the name of the Raj and
label: Paragraph

text: in the heart of the Empire - they might still pursue their
label: Paragraph

text: contradictory policy of welcoming home rule while
label: Paragraph

text: maintaining their colonial economy. The fact that much of
label: Paragraph

text: the imperial kudos was lost because the King entered the
label: Paragraph

text: city on a horse rather than an elephant is not without a
label: Paragraph

text: certain significance. The diplomatic effort at a liberal
label: Paragraph

text: compromise had altered the traditional code beyond
label: Paragraph

text: recognition and the King passed through the gates of Delhi
label: Paragraph

text: largely unobserved. That the building of New Delhi was a
label: Paragraph

text: reification of this fragile ideological gesture is evident from
label: Paragraph

text: the protracted efforts made between 1913 and 1918 to
label: Paragraph

text: arrive at a convincing Anglo-Indian style which would satisfy
label: Paragraph

text: all concerned. Above all, it had to convince Lutyens himself,
label: Paragraph

text: who finally decided that the Moghul city of Fatehpur Sikri
label: Paragraph

text: presented the only native architecture that could be
label: Paragraph

text: effectively incorporated into the humanist tradition.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: revalidated in English architectural culture after the turn of
label: Paragraph

text: the century, first in the architecture of Shaw and Lutyens
label: Paragraph

text: and then with great sophistication, at a theoretical level, in
label: Paragraph

text: Geoffrey Scott’s The Architecture of Humanism published in
label: Paragraph

text: The need to assimilate a powerful exotic culture while
label: Paragraph

text: asserting the standards of humanism brought Lutyens to a
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: attained before and which he was only to equal again in his
label: Paragraph

text: 1924 (fig. 30, p. 56). In the Viceroy’s House at New Delhi,

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: houses to postulate, like Wright, the possibility of a ‘frontier’
label: Paragraph

text: culture, a synthetic imperium on which the sun would never
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: As with Versailles, the commissioning of New Delhi in
label: Paragraph

text: 1912 inaugurated a period of building in which architecture
label: Paragraph

text: would once again be exploited in the cause of the state -
label: Paragraph

text: first, to represent new nations which had emerged as
label: Paragraph

text: independent democracies from the cataclysm of the First
label: Title

text: World War, and then to celebrate the revolutionary
label: Paragraph

text: ‘millennium’ as it became manifest in its various guises
label: Paragraph

text: between 1917 and 1933 - first in the Soviet Union, then in
label: Paragraph

text: 1922 in Fascist Italy and finally in the Third Reich. In more
label: Paragraph

text: general terms, it was called upon to represent the revival
label: Paragraph

text: and manifest destiny of monopoly capital both before and
label: Title

text: after the stock market disaster of 1929.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: aspirations of the Modern Movement, and in most instances
label: Paragraph

text: That Le Corbusier’s project (see p. 175) was the most
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivist of his entire career is evident from the
label: Paragraph

text: exposed roof structure of its auditoria and from the total
label: Paragraph

text: transparency of its external skin. Yet, despite the reductive
label: Paragraph

text: nature of these elements, the symbolism of the project was
label: Paragraph

text: quite explicit in the speaker’s tribune situated at the end of
label: Paragraph

text: the library block, overlooking the res publica podium, to the
label: Paragraph

text: rear of the larger auditorium. Few entries were so literal in
label: Paragraph

text: according symbolic value to the functionality of their various
label: Paragraph

text: components, and one recognizes here a work as didactic in
label: Paragraph

text: its organization and form as Gropius’s theatre for Piscator,
label: Paragraph

text: designed some four years earlier. However, the jury found
label: Paragraph

text: that Le Corbusier’s entry ‘indulged in a too pronounced cult
label: Paragraph

text: of machinism and aestheticization’.
label: Paragraph

text: This could also have been said of many of the Russian
label: Paragraph

text: projects, which were often little more than elaborate
label: Paragraph

text: exercises in technological rhetoric projected as metaphors
label: Title

text: for the newly industrialized socialist state. It is one of the
label: Paragraph

text: ironies of this competition that the monumental Socialist
label: Paragraph

text: Realist line, which was to be officially adopted by the
label: Paragraph

text: Central Committee of the Party in April 1932, was not
label: Paragraph

text: represented by the entry of the most left-wing faction, the
label: Paragraph

text: Proletkult group or All Russian Association of Proletarian
label: Title

text: Architects. Instead the Socialist Realist style was first
label: Paragraph

text: tentatively advanced in the winning entry of B.M. lofan,
label: Paragraph

text: whose Constructivist auditoria were shown as semicircular
label: Paragraph

text: terminal buildings delimiting the confines of a rectangular,
label: Paragraph

text: Classical court. From the centre of this enclosure rose an
label: Paragraph

text: equally Classical pylon surmounted by the statue of a
label: Paragraph

text: worker. This figure seems to have been a conscious
label: Paragraph

text: reference to the Statue of Liberty, its raised arm projecting
label: Paragraph

text: the light of revolt, if not of freedom. In the subsequent
label: Paragraph

text: development of the design after 1933, by lofan in
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration with the Academicians Gelfreikh and V.
label: Paragraph

text: Shchuko, it became increasingly rhetorical. By 1934, the two
label: Paragraph

text: auditoria of the original version had been absorbed into a
label: Paragraph

text: ‘wedding cake’ of colonnaded tiers and pinnacled statuary,
label: Paragraph

text: culminating in a gargantuan figure of Lenin offering his hand
label: Paragraph

text: to the universe, at a height of 450 metres (1,500 feet)
label: Paragraph

text: [210]. Three years later, although the general form
label: Paragraph

text: remained the same, the total mass was smaller and the
label: Paragraph

text: colonnades had been regrouped as Art Deco pilasters.
label: Paragraph

text: 210 lofan, project for the Palace of the Soviets, Moscow, 1934.
label: Caption

text: After 1932 those Academicians such as A.V. Shchusev
label: Paragraph

text: (whose eclectic National Romantic Kazan Station in Moscow
label: Paragraph

text: was under construction by 1913), who had established
label: Paragraph

text: themselves before the Revolution and had laid low since,
label: Paragraph

text: began to build one pseudo-Neo-Classical monument after
label: Paragraph

text: another. Shchuko’s Lenin State Library of 1938 typifies this
label: Paragraph

text: bastard style of asymmetrical volumes, stripped pilasters
label: Paragraph

text: and inconsequential Classical episodes enriched by
label: Paragraph

text: sculpure. The emergence of the New Tradition in the Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: Union was due to several contributory factors. First there
label: Paragraph

text: was the doctrinal and unanswerable challenge made by
label: Paragraph

text: Vopra against the Constructivist intellectuals to the effect
label: Title

text: that only the proletariat could create a proletarian culture;
label: Paragraph

text: then there were the rehabilitated pre-war Academicians
label: Paragraph

text: who, while technically indispensable to the building
label: Paragraph

text: programme, were to remain unsympathetic to
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivism; finally there was the Party itself which
label: Paragraph

text: sensed that the people were incapable of responding to the
label: Paragraph

text: abstract aesthetics of modern architecture. The absolute
label: Paragraph

text: ideological expediency of the Party Social Realist line
label: Title

text: instigated in 1932 accounts for Anatole Lunacharsky’s
label: Paragraph

text: sophistries of the following year, his over-elaborate apologia
label: Paragraph

text: for Social Realism in which, while acknowledging the
label: Paragraph

text: remoteness of Hellenic culture, he insisted that ‘this cradle
label: Paragraph

text: of civilization and art’ could still serve as a model for
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in the Soviet Union. The success of this state
label: Paragraph

text: culture, which was maintained as a consistent policy for
label: Paragraph

text: more than forty years, has perhaps never been more justly
label: Paragraph

text: assessed than by Berthold Lubetkin, who wrote in 1956:
label: Paragraph

text: Festooned as they are with haberdashery, draped in
label: Paragraph

text: theatrical marginalia, and wrapped in irrelevant pages from
label: Paragraph

text: a monumental mason’s catalogue, some of the Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: buildings (if by no means all) are yet able to form, by virtue
label: Paragraph

text: of vigorously conceived layouts, of prodigious use of open
label: Paragraph

text: spaces, of breathtaking scale, grand, orderly ensembles
label: Paragraph

text: whose impact is not easily forgotten by a Western architect
label: Paragraph

text: of the epoch of picturesque fragmentation and ‘mixed
label: Title

text: development’.2
label: Title

text: Fascist Italy 1931-42
label: Title

text: A similar conflict between modernity and tradition coloured
label: Paragraph

text: the architectural ideology of the Italian Fascist movement,
label: Paragraph

text: between Mussolini’s March on Rome in October 1922 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1931, when the government-backed Union of Architects
label: Paragraph

text: withdrew its support from the newly founded Movimento
label: Paragraph

text: Italiano per l’Architettura Razionale (MIAR) and rallied under
label: Paragraph

text: the leadership of Marcello Piacentini to support the cause of
label: Paragraph

text: reconciling the rival factions into a single ideological
label: Title

text: formation, the Raggruppamento Architetti Moderni Italiani.
label: Paragraph

text: The development of Fascist ideology after the war had
label: Paragraph

text: stemmed from two distinct aspects of the pre-war Futurist
label: Paragraph

text: movement: from its revolutionary concern for the
label: Title

text: restructuring of society, and from its cult of war and its
label: Paragraph

text: worship of the machine. Both aspects provided elements
label: Paragraph

text: that could be effectively incorporated into Fascist rhetoric,
label: Paragraph

text: but the war and its aftermath had been a disaster -
label: Paragraph

text: destructive even of Futurism itself - and the idea of a
label: Paragraph

text: ‘machine-culture’ was suddenly regarded with a good deal
label: Paragraph

text: of scepticism, and not only at a popular level but also by the
label: Paragraph

text: intelligentsia.
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, the cultural reaction against Futurism had been
label: Paragraph

text: formulated before Futurism had fully emerged, first with
label: Paragraph

text: Benedetto Croce’s Filosofia come scienza dello spirito (The
label: Caption

text: Philosophy of the Spirit) of 1908-17, which insisted on the
label: Paragraph

text: exclusively formal domain of art, and then with Giorgio de
label: Paragraph

text: Chirico’s painting The Enigma of the Hour (1912), which
label: Paragraph

text: depicted an arcuated peristyle in failing light - a haunting
label: Paragraph

text: metaphysical image which immediately seemed to prefigure
label: Paragraph

text: the form and the mood of the Italian New Tradition.
label: Paragraph

text: Influenced by De Chirico and by the metaphysical
label: Paragraph

text: painters of the Novecento movement, by men who were
label: Paragraph

text: cognizant of modernity but not seduced by it, the Milanese
label: Paragraph

text: architectural avant garde headed by Giovanni Muzio began
label: Paragraph

text: to reinterpret the Classical forms of the Mediterranean as a
label: Paragraph

text: conscious antithesis to the machine cult of Futurism. The
label: Paragraph

text: inaugural work of this movement, Muzio’s Ca’ Brutta
label: Caption

text: apartments built in the Via Moscova, Milan, in 1923, was as
label: Paragraph

text: much a point of departure for the work of the Italian
label: Paragraph

text: Rationalists as it was an influence on Piacentini’s Stile
label: Paragraph

text: Littorio, which emerged with the University of Rome begun
label: Paragraph

text: under his direction in 1932. Muzio’s defence of the Classical
label: Paragraph

text: tradition, written in 1931, displayed an awareness of the
label: Paragraph

text: universality of the New Tradition that transcended the
label: Paragraph

text: Piranesian conceits of his own style. He wrote of the
label: Paragraph

text: Novecento movement as being of an anti-Futurist
label: Paragraph

text: conviction. He argued that the Classical schemas of the past
label: Paragraph

text: would always be applicable, and asked: ‘Are we not perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: anticipating a movement whose imminent birth is
label: Paragraph

text: announced throughout Europe by hesitant but widespread
label: Paragraph

text: symptoms?’
label: Title

text: The conflict between modernity and tradition took a
label: Paragraph

text: peculiarly subtle form in Italy, since the young Rationalists
label: Paragraph

text: were just as committed as Muzio and Piacentini to a
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpretation of the Classical tradition. But the MIAR
label: Paragraph

text: approach was extremely intellectual and their austere works
label: Paragraph

text: lacked an iconography which could be readily understood.
label: Paragraph

text: Aware that Futurism could not represent a nationalistic
label: Paragraph

text: ideology, Fascist power opted, in 1931, for a simplified and
label: Paragraph

text: easily reproducible Classical style whose apotheosis came
label: Paragraph

text: with the ill-fated EUR of 1942 [211]. This wishful
label: Paragraph

text: implantation of a new capital, outside the limits of the
label: Paragraph

text: Eternal City, was as utopian and reactionary in its
label: Paragraph

text: aspirations as New Delhi. It posited a monumentality that
label: Paragraph

text: was totally divorced from social reality, De Chirico’s The
label: Paragraph

text: Enigma of the Hour [212] being almost literally realized in
label: Paragraph

text: the Palazzo della Civilta Italiana [213], the six-storey prism,
label: Caption

text: filled with arches, that terminated the main axis of the site.
label: Paragraph

text: 211 Poster for the Universal Exhibition, Rome (EUR), 1942, exhibiting Libera’s
label: Caption

text: project for an arch leading to the site and the future.
label: Caption

text: 212 De Chirico, The Enigma of the Hour, 1912.
label: Caption

text: 213 Guerrini, La Padula and Romano, Palazzo della Civilta Italiana, EUR, 1942.
label: Caption

text: The Third Reich 1929-41
label: Title

text: The Italian struggle between two alternative interpretations
label: Title

text: of the Classical tradition - the rationalist versus the
label: Title

text: historicist - was absent in Germany, where the rational line
label: Paragraph

text: of the Modern Movement suffered instant eclipse after the
label: Paragraph

text: National Socialist seizure of power in January 1933. Modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was dismissed as cosmopolitan and degenerate
label: Paragraph

text: save for those occasions when efficient industrial production
label: Paragraph

text: and factory welfare demanded a Functionalist approach; but
label: Paragraph

text: the question as to the appropriate style for Hitler’s ‘social
label: Paragraph

text: revolution’ could not be resolved, as in Italy or Russia, by an
label: Paragraph

text: open conflict ending in the adoption of a single style to be
label: Paragraph

text: used on almost all occasions. The subtle ideological policies
label: Paragraph

text: of the Third Reich were inimical to such a blanket solution.
label: Paragraph

text: While striving at a public level to represent National
label: Paragraph

text: Socialism as the heroic fulfilment of of German destiny, the
label: Paragraph

text: Nazis also wished to gratify the popular desire for an
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of psychological security and to compensate for
label: Paragraph

text: a world where industrialized warfare, inflation and political
label: Paragraph

text: upheaval had already undermined traditional society. This
label: Paragraph

text: initial stylistic dichotomy reflected, in a perverse form, the
label: Paragraph

text: ideological division that had permeated the history of the
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Movement - the split first identified by Pugin in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1830s as the opposition between the utilitarian, universal
label: Paragraph

text: standards of industrial production (reified in Neo-Classical
label: Paragraph

text: form) and a basic Christian desire to return to the rooted
label: Paragraph

text: values of an agrarian craft economy. For the former the
label: Paragraph

text: Nazis had only to look to the enlightened Prussian culture of
label: Paragraph

text: the authoritarian state, expressed in the philosophy of Hegel
label: Paragraph

text: and the architecture of Schinkel; for the latter they could
label: Paragraph

text: return to the Germanic myth of the Vo/k, to that anti-
label: Paragraph

text: Western cult first advanced by the Prussian patriot F.L. Jahn
label: Paragraph

text: The National Socialist updating of Jahn’s philosophy came
label: Paragraph

text: with the publication in 1929 of Richard Walter Darré’s book
label: Paragraph

text: Das Bauerntum als Lebensquell der nordischen Rassen (‘The
label: Title

text: Peasantry as the Life Source of the Nordic Race’), which first
label: Paragraph

text: advanced the idea of a ‘blood and soil’ culture, advocating a
label: Paragraph

text: return to the land. Darré, who had started his career as an
label: Paragraph

text: agronomist, was to play a salient role in developing the anti-
label: Paragraph

text: urban racial ideology of National Socialism, and although his
label: Paragraph

text: view was never fully embraced by the Nazi élite, it remained
label: Paragraph

text: the rationale behind the Heimatsti/ or vernacular housing
label: Paragraph

text: built under party auspices after 1933.
label: Paragraph

text: Given that the conflicting ideologies within the Third
label: Paragraph

text: Reich could not be adequately expressed in two polarized
label: Paragraph

text: styles, other modes had to be adduced. The remote party
label: Paragraph

text: political schools, the Ordensburgen, were built in a pseudo-
label: Paragraph

text: medieval castellated manner, and the various leisure
label: Paragraph

text: facilities of Robert Ley’s Kraft durch Freude (Strength
label: Paragraph

text: Through Joy) [214] movement demanded an escapist
label: Paragraph

text: environment of their own. A popular pseudo-Rococo décor
label: Paragraph

text: was applied indiscriminately to the interiors of theatres,
label: Paragraph

text: ships and other buildings dedicated to light recreation. This
label: Paragraph

text: stylistic schizophrenia frequently led to different parts of the
label: Paragraph

text: same development being treated in a totally different
label: Paragraph

text: manner, as in Herbert Rimpl’s Heinkel factory at
label: Paragraph

text: Oranienburg [215] of 1936, which ranged in its expression
label: Paragraph

text: from the Neo-Classical portico of the administration building
label: Caption

text: to the Heimatsti/ of the workers’ housing and the
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism of the plant itself.
label: Paragraph

text: 214 kraft durch Freude poster, 1936. The Volkswagen was an integral part of
label: Caption

text: Ley’s movement.
label: Paragraph

text: 215 Rimpl, Heinkel workers’ housing (above) and factory, Oranienburg, 1936.
label: Caption

text: The sudden shift in the style of state-sponsored housing,
label: Paragraph

text: from the cubic flat-roofed forms of the Weimar Republic to
label: Paragraph

text: the pitched-roofed forms of the Third Reich, was
label: Paragraph

text: enthusiastically supported by the architect Paul Schultze-
label: Paragraph

text: Naumburg, who, despite his own austere manner, had long
label: Paragraph

text: ago reacted against Functionalist architecture. An associate
label: Paragraph

text: of Heinrich Tessenow in the creation of a whitewashed,
label: Paragraph

text: pitched-roofed Heimatsti/ manner, Schultze-Naumburg
label: Caption

text: sought as early as the mid-1920s to resist the
label: Paragraph

text: internationalist and mechanistic tendencies of modern life.
label: Paragraph

text: His anti-rationalist rhetoric grew out of a late Arts and Crafts
label: Paragraph

text: concern for simple, earthbound organic forms subscribed to
label: Paragraph

text: equally by Tessenow, Haring and Scharoun. For Schultze-
label: Caption

text: Naumburg, however, the issue of form had political
label: Paragraph

text: connotations, and in opposing the Neue Sachlichkeit
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of the Weimar Republic he soon adopted right-
label: Paragraph

text: wing, not to say racist, attitudes that were readily
label: Paragraph

text: assimilable to the reactionary ideology of the Party. By
label: Paragraph

text: 1930, when Schultze-Naumburg finally joined Alfred
label: Paragraph

text: Rosenberg’s cultural front, the Kampfbund fur deutsche
label: Paragraph

text: Kultur, Darré had already cleared the field for an attack on
label: Paragraph

text: modern culture in general, with his diatribe against
label: Paragraph

text: industrial urbanization and the destruction of the peasantry.
label: Paragraph

text: For him the agrarian settlement was not only the stronghold
label: Paragraph

text: of patriotism but also the hypothetical habitat of a pure
label: Paragraph

text: Nordic race.
label: Paragraph

text: Schultze-Naumburg took up a parallel position in his
label: Paragraph

text: 1932 Kampfbund book, Kampf um die Kunst (‘The Struggle
label: Caption

text: over Art’), where he castigated those nomads of the
label: Paragraph

text: metropolis who had lost any concept of the homeland.
label: Paragraph

text: Elsewhere, almost paraphrasing Darré, he praised the
label: Paragraph

text: pitched-roofed German house with its roots sunk deep into
label: Paragraph

text: the soil, contrasting it to the flat-roofed architecture of an
label: Paragraph

text: uprooted people. He had announced these views as early as
label: Paragraph

text: 1926, when he wrote that the flat roof ‘is immediately
label: Paragraph

text: recognizable as the child of other skies and other blood’ - a
label: Paragraph

text: comment which seems to have inspired that sardonic
label: Paragraph

text: photomontage of the Stuttgart Weissenhofsiedlung in the
label: Paragraph

text: guise of an Arab village, complete with Bedouin and camels.
label: Paragraph

text: Schultze-Naumburg’s racial prejudice was made explicit in
label: Paragraph

text: his book Kunst und Rasse (‘Art and Race’) (1928), where he
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to prove that Germany’s cultural ‘decadence’
label: Paragraph

text: had a biological origin. In his second theoretical work, Das
label: Paragraph

text: Gesicht des deutschen Hauses (‘The Face of the German
label: Title

text: House’) of 1929, he wrote that the German dwelling
label: Paragraph

text: gives one the feeling that it grows out of the soil, like one of
label: Paragraph

text: its natural products, like a tree that sinks its roots deep in
label: Paragraph

text: the interior of the soil and forms a union with it. It is this
label: Paragraph

text: that gives us our understanding of home [Heimat], of a
label: Paragraph

text: bond with blood and earth [Erden], for one kind of men this
label: Paragraph

text: is the condition of their life and the meaning of their
label: Paragraph

text: existence.?
label: Paragraph

text: However appropriate for mass housing, a ‘blood and soil’
label: Paragraph

text: Heimatstil could hardly represent the myth of the thousand-
label: Paragraph

text: year Reich, and for this purpose the party exploited the
label: Paragraph

text: Classical heritage of Gilly, Langhans and Schinkel. Paul
label: Caption

text: Ludwig Troost and Albert Speer (successively Hitler’s
label: Title

text: personal architects from 1933 to the mid-1940s) effectively
label: Paragraph

text: established a reduced version of the Schinkelschiler
label: Paragraph

text: tradition as the representative style of the state. From
label: Paragraph

text: Troost’s embellishments of Munich as the ‘capital of the
label: Paragraph

text: party’ to Speer’s colossal set-pieces for the Nazi state in its
label: Paragraph

text: heyday, his Zeppelinfeld stadium for the Nuremberg rally of
label: Paragraph

text: 1937 and his new Chancellery in Berlin, completed in the
label: Paragraph

text: following year, the same spartan Classicism prevails.
label: Paragraph

text: The conscious elimination of Schinkel’s proportional
label: Title

text: delicacy in the name of the millennium evolved only slightly
label: Paragraph

text: as it passed from Troost’s frigid version of the Tuscan order
label: Paragraph

text: to Speer’s preference for plain or fluted rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: columns. This sterilization of Romantic Classicism - built
label: Paragraph

text: with fanatical precision - only came to life when these vast
label: Paragraph

text: set-pieces were used for mass assembly, for a style of
label: Paragraph

text: pageantry which Speer himself had first formulated in his
label: Paragraph

text: so-called ‘cathedral of ice’, a virtual column of flag
label: Paragraph

text: standards and searchlights created for the Tempelhof rally
label: Paragraph

text: at Berlin in 1935. Under Goebbels’s direction, such arenas
label: Paragraph

text: became the setting for the inculcation of Nazi ideology, not
label: Paragraph

text: only on the spot but throughout the Reich: for the first time
label: Paragraph

text: the ‘state as a work of art’ could be channelled into the
label: Paragraph

text: mass media of radio and film. Leni Riefenstahl’s
label: Paragraph

text: documentary film of the Nuremberg rally of 1934, Triumph
label: Title

text: des Willens (The Triumph of the Wil), was the first occasion
label: Paragraph

text: on which architecture, in the form of Speer’s temporary
label: Paragraph

text: setting, was pressed into the service of cinematic
label: Paragraph

text: propaganda. Henceforth Speer’s designs for stadia at
label: Paragraph

text: Nuremberg were determined as much by camera angles as
label: Paragraph

text: by architectural criteria. This cinematic exploitation of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was totally at variance with Speer’s insistence
label: Paragraph

text: on the use of load-bearing masonry to insure the future of
label: Paragraph

text: the Zeppelinfeld as a sublime ruin. This idiosyncratic ‘law of
label: Paragraph

text: the ruins’, forbidding the use of metal reinforcement, was a
label: Paragraph

text: nostalgic reference to the Enlightenment (he was thinking of
label: Paragraph

text: Piranesi’s Paestum engravings, for instance); so was
label: Paragraph

text: Wilhelm Kreis’s insistence that Neo-Classicism expressed
label: Paragraph

text: the spirit of the German earth, the people’s cult of the
label: Paragraph

text: Heimat.
label: Paragraph

text: The National Socialist version of the New Tradition could
label: Paragraph

text: not transcend this reduction of the ‘space of public
label: Paragraph

text: appearance’ to mass hysteria, this subordination of all real
label: Paragraph

text: relationships to the illusion of film or to the histrionic rituals
label: Paragraph

text: of the Thingp/latze - open-air arenas built after 1934 for
label: Paragraph

text: nature worship and the celebration of Teutonic rites. The
label: Paragraph

text: language of Romantic Classicism stripped of its
label: Paragraph

text: Enlightenment imagery and faith was now reduced to
label: Paragraph

text: scenography. With the notable exceptions of Werner March’s
label: Paragraph

text: Olympic Stadium of 1936 and Bonatz’s Autobahn bridges of
label: Paragraph

text: the same date, the New Tradition degenerated into
label: Paragraph

text: meaningless megalomania, terminating after 1941 in Kreis’s
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Totenburgen’, brilliantly conceived, Boullée-like ‘castles of
label: Paragraph

text: the dead’ built throughout Eastern Europe, whenever there
label: Paragraph

text: was time, to immortalize the remains of the fallen [216].
label: Paragraph

text: 216 Kreis, project for a war memorial, Kutno, 1942.
label: Caption

text: The Modernistic Style In America 1923-32
label: Title

text: That aspect of the New Tradition which took the form of a
label: Paragraph

text: stripped Classical style emerged as the ruling taste in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s, wherever power wished to represent itself in a
label: Paragraph

text: positive and progressive light. As Speer observed, the Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilion for the Paris World Exhibition of 1937 employed a
label: Paragraph

text: pseudo-Classical syntax almost identical to that of the
label: Paragraph

text: German Pavilion which Speer had designed for the same
label: Paragraph

text: occasion [217]. This taste for Neo-Classical monumentality
label: Paragraph

text: was not restricted, as Speer noted, to totalitarian states, but
label: Paragraph

text: could be seen in Paris, where it was displayed in such works
label: Paragraph

text: as J.C. Dondel’s Musée d’Art Moderne and Auguste Perret’s
label: Paragraph

text: Musée des Travaux Publics, both works completed in 1937.
label: Paragraph

text: It also made itself manifest in the United States, where it
label: Paragraph

text: gradually emerged out of Beaux-Arts Neo-Classicism - the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘official’ style in the States from the World’s Columbian
label: Title

text: Exposition of 1893 to the First World War. As one may judge
label: Paragraph

text: from the Neo-Classical embellishments of Washington, such
label: Paragraph

text: as Henry Bacon’s Lincoln Memorial of 1917, the Federal
label: Paragraph

text: Government was too conservative to become a patron of
label: Paragraph

text: the New Tradition. With the universities more or less
label: Paragraph

text: committed after the turn of the century to copybook Gothic,
label: Paragraph

text: the one patron capable of sponsoring a more adventurous
label: Paragraph

text: eclecticism seems to have been the railroads, from the
label: Paragraph

text: eclectic Romanism of the New York termini built in the
label: Paragraph

text: decade prior to the First World War - Warren and Wetmore’s
label: Paragraph

text: Grand Central Station (1903-13) and McKim, Mead and
label: Paragraph

text: White’s Pennsylvania Station (1906-10) - to such Moderne
label: Paragraph

text: pieces as the Cincinnati Union Station designed by
label: Caption

text: Feilheimer & Wagner in 1929.
label: Paragraph

text: 217 World Exhibition, Paris, 1937. Speer’s representation of the Third Reich (far
label: Caption

text: left) confronts lofan’s USSR Pavilion (far right).
label: Paragraph

text: The other source of patronage for a Moderne expression
label: Paragraph

text: was, of course, high-rise office development, and from the
label: Paragraph

text: time of Cass Gilbert’s Woolworth Building of 1913 the New
label: Caption

text: Tradition, as far as the skyscraper was concerned, displayed
label: Paragraph

text: a preference for the Gothic. This tendency was reinforced by
label: Paragraph

text: the results of the Chicago Tribune competition of 1922. Once
label: Paragraph

text: again the premiated designs of an international competition
label: Paragraph

text: seem to have been decisive in the formation of a ruling
label: Paragraph

text: style, Eliel Saarinen’s second-prize entry being as important
label: Paragraph

text: an influence on Raymond Hood’s subsequent career as
label: Paragraph

text: Hood and Howell’s own winning design. This can be seen in
label: Paragraph

text: the development of Hood’s ‘skyscraper style’ from his black-
label: Paragraph

text: and-gold American Radiator Building, New York, of 1924, to
label: Caption

text: his earliest sketches, made in 1930, for the Rockefeller
label: Paragraph

text: Center, New York. As Jacques Greber was to remark in 1920,
label: Paragraph

text: a ‘stripped Gothic’ enabled the architect to overcome the
label: Paragraph

text: problem of a large number of windows ‘by means of strongly
label: Paragraph

text: marked ribs which accentuated the verticalism and
label: Paragraph

text: therefore the impressive appearance of towers’.
label: Paragraph

text: The synthesis of the Art Deco or the Modernistic Style in
label: Paragraph

text: the States had just as many roots in the mainstream of the
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Movement as it did in the historicism of the turn of
label: Paragraph

text: the century. Above all its affinities lay with German
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionism (Poelzig, Héger, etc.), as we may judge from
label: Paragraph

text: the evolution of the New York work of McKenzie, Voorhees,
label: Paragraph

text: Gmelin and Walker, from their inaugural Barclay-Vesey
label: Paragraph

text: Building of 1923 to their Western Union Building of 1928.
label: Paragraph

text: However, no one source can ever be credited for this highly
label: Paragraph

text: synthetic style, the need for which seems to have arisen out
label: Paragraph

text: of a spontaneous desire to celebrate the triumph of
label: Paragraph

text: democracy and capitalism in the New World. From the
label: Paragraph

text: American point of view the First World War had been
label: Paragraph

text: favourably concluded; America had emerged a creditor
label: Paragraph

text: nation and the boom of the 1920s was about to start. In
label: Paragraph

text: what style could such an enthusiasm for ‘progress’ be
label: Paragraph

text: expressed? Certainly not in the historicist styles of waning
label: Paragraph

text: European power - nor for that matter could it adopt the
label: Paragraph

text: avant-garde mode of the new Europe. Its sources, as Forrest
label: Paragraph

text: F. Lisle has remarked of Chicago’s Century of Progress
label: Paragraph

text: Exposition of 1933, had to be more open and eclectic:
label: Paragraph

text: the Paris 1925 Fair, Frank Lloyd Wright, cubism, machine
label: Caption

text: ethics, Mayan forms, Pueblo patterns, Dudok, the Viennese
label: Title

text: Secession, modern interiors, the zoning-law set back. This
label: Paragraph

text: large number of weakly related sources, readily identified as
label: Paragraph

text: underlying the Moderne in America, begins to suggest the
label: Paragraph

text: loose, broad, inclusive, less intense, rather indiscriminate,
label: Paragraph

text: thus democratic, perimeters of the modern movement here
label: Paragraph

text: as opposed to the impersonal, reductive, exclusive, more
label: Paragraph

text: idealistic, more moralistic thrust of avant-garde Europe at
label: Paragraph

text: this time.*
label: Paragraph

text: Something of the intent behind the Modernistic Style may
label: Paragraph

text: be adduced from the way in which it was used. Aside from
label: Paragraph

text: domestic interiors, etc., it was reserved for the worldy realm
label: Paragraph

text: of offices, in-town apartment blocks, hotels, banks,
label: Paragraph

text: department stores, and buildings dedicated to modern
label: Title

text: media, newspapers, publishing ventures,
label: Title

text: telecommunications, etc. [218]. It was an exclusively urban
label: Paragraph

text: style: the suburban work of Moderne architects such as Ely-
label: Paragraph

text: Jacques Kahn and Raymond Hood - their private houses and
label: Title

text: country clubs - were usually carried out in variations of the
label: Paragraph

text: English Free Style, tempered by the occasional Colonial
label: Paragraph

text: portico. There was in fact a sense of stylistic propriety
label: Paragraph

text: comparable to that which obtained according to the ‘party
label: Paragraph

text: line’ in totalitarian countries: one style for the office,
label: Paragraph

text: another for the suburban retreat, and still another for the
label: Paragraph

text: idyll of the university - this last being more often than not
label: Paragraph

text: from the medieval hand of Ralph Adams Cram.
label: Caption

text: 218 Van Alen, Chrysler Building, New York, 1928-30, between the RCA Victor
label: Caption

text: (now G.E.) Building, by Cross & Cross, and Schultze and Weaver's Waldorf
label: Caption

text: Astoria, both of 1930-31.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the precise manner in which the Modernistic
label: Paragraph

text: Style was woven into the ideological and historical fabric of
label: Paragraph

text: its time is perhaps best revealed by the case history of the
label: Paragraph

text: Rockefeller Center, New York, which started off as a large
label: Paragraph

text: piece of real-estate development predicated on the
label: Paragraph

text: Metropolitan Opera Company’s desire for a new auditorium
label: Title

text: in a new location. It was completed as a precarious
label: Paragraph

text: speculation, in the midst of the Depression, significantly
label: Paragraph

text: enough without the opera, but with the aid of the newly
label: Paragraph

text: fledged and flourishing communications industry, the Radio
label: Paragraph

text: Corporation of America and its subsidiaries NBC and RKO, as
label: Paragraph

text: the primary client. Thus, instead of being focused about a
label: Paragraph

text: ‘city beautiful’ plaza before an Art Deco opera house facade,
label: Paragraph

text: as in the 1928 design by B.W. Morris, it was soon to be
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpreted both ideologically and architecturally as a
label: Paragraph

text: Radio City - ‘within a city’. The Rockefeller Center
label: Caption

text: management were only too aware that the economic threat
label: Paragraph

text: of such a huge development in the midst of a depression
label: Paragraph

text: would have to be presented as an unequivocal contribution
label: Paragraph

text: to the public weal. To this end they abetted their major
label: Paragraph

text: client in commissioning the vaudeville and radio personality
label: Paragraph

text: and impressario Roxy (Samuel Rothafel) to work in
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration with the architects on the creation of the
label: Paragraph

text: 6,200-seat Radio City Music Hall for the presentation of a
label: Caption

text: hybrid entertainment comprising vaudeville and film, and
label: Paragraph

text: the 3,500-seat luxury cinema known as the Center Theater.
label: Paragraph

text: The generally popular flavour of Radio City - the city of
label: Paragraph

text: illusion and distraction in the midst of crisis (Roxy’s slogan
label: Paragraph

text: was ‘a visit to Radio City is as good as a month in the
label: Paragraph

text: country’) - was reinforced in 1936 when the failure of the
label: Paragraph

text: shops in the sunken plaza led to the substitution of an open-
label: Paragraph

text: air skating rink with restaurants situated to either side.
label: Paragraph

text: It is to the lasting credit of Hood, as the prime designer
label: Paragraph

text: of the architectural troika of Reinhard & Hofmeister, Corbett
label: Caption

text: Harrison & Macmurray, and Hood & Fouilhoux, that he was
label: Paragraph

text: able to control not only the overall composition and the
label: Paragraph

text: detail but also a good deal of the programme; it was he, for
label: Paragraph

text: instance, who first suggested the idea of roof gardens.
label: Paragraph

text: Under his supervision, the Center, eventually amounting to
label: Paragraph

text: eight blocks and fourteen buildings, had its representative
label: Paragraph

text: core - the seventy-storey RCA slab and plaza and the Radio
label: Caption

text: City Music Hall - all completed in eighteen months, in time
label: Paragraph

text: for the gala opening at the end of 1932 [219].
label: Paragraph

text: 219 Reinhard & Hofmeister, Corbett Harrison & Macmurray, and Hood &
label: Caption

text: Fouilhoux, Rockefeller Center, New York, chiefly 1932-39. The tallest structure,
label: Caption

text: in the centre, is the RCA Building. Below it on the right is Radio City Music Hall.
label: Caption

text: Between the RCA Building and 5th Avenue are the sunken garden with
label: Paragraph

text: Prometheus statue and two low buildings with roof gardens flanking a fountain
label: Caption

text: walk.
label: Paragraph

text: Roxy’s formula of the Rockettes floor show plus a movie
label: Title

text: was as extemporary and transitional in its cultural nature as
label: Paragraph

text: the artistic programme of the entire Center, where one
label: Paragraph

text: artistic work after another, be it sculpture or mural, took as
label: Paragraph

text: its subject matter such themes as light, sound, radio,
label: Paragraph

text: television, aviation and progress in general, culminating in
label: Paragraph

text: two major setpieces on the central axis of the entire
label: Caption

text: composition. These were Paul Manship’s gilded Prometheus,
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by the Zodiac and overlooking the sunken plaza,
label: Paragraph

text: and Diego Rivera’s ill-fated mural to the entrance hall of the
label: Caption

text: RCA Building, Man at the Crossroads, which, with its
label: Paragraph

text: unequivocal revolutionary iconography including even an
label: Paragraph

text: image of Lenin, had the effect of placing his patrons in an
label: Paragraph

text: impossible public position, in which politically they had no
label: Paragraph

text: choice but to insist on its removal. This contradictory New
label: Paragraph

text: Deal gesture of monopoly capital consciously commissioning
label: Title

text: an emblematic work from a Communist artist seems now to
label: Paragraph

text: be as remote and fictitious as Hugh Ferriss’s vision of
label: Paragraph

text: Manhattan transformed into an endless repetition of
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper ziggurats, in his book The Metropolis of
label: Paragraph

text: Tomorrow of 1929 [220]. Recording Art Deco skyscrapers
label: Caption

text: that were then either completed or already under way and
label: Paragraph

text: anticipating the apotheosis of the Rockefeller Center, this
label: Paragraph

text: was a science-fiction vision of a city of towers as
label: Paragraph

text: scenographic and theatrical as the style itself - a New
label: Paragraph

text: Babylon born of euphoria, land values and the set-back
label: Paragraph

text: profiles imposed by the 1916 New York City zoning code.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: The New Monumentality 1943
label: Title

text: With the exception of the Soviet Union, Roosevelt’s New
label: Paragraph

text: Deal and the Second World War had the effect of bringing
label: Paragraph

text: the New Tradition to an abrupt end, but not before
label: Paragraph

text: architects like J.J.P. Oud had been touched by its influence
label: Paragraph

text: (see, for instance, his Shell Building, built at The Hague in
label: Paragraph

text: 1938). After the war the general ideological climate of the
label: Paragraph

text: West was hostile to any kind of monumentality. The League
label: Paragraph

text: of Nations had been discredited, the British had granted
label: Paragraph

text: India her independence and the regimes that had made the
label: Paragraph

text: New Tradition into an instrument of national policy were
label: Paragraph

text: regarded as anathema. Moreover, the manipulatory
label: Paragraph

text: advantages of less permanent but cheaper, more flexible
label: Paragraph

text: and more penetrating modes of ideological representation
label: Title

text: were soon seen as far surpassing the effectiveness of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. As anticipated by the intense and brilliant use
label: Paragraph

text: of radio and film in the propaganda of the Third Reich and in
label: Paragraph

text: the popular mass productions of RCA and Hollywood during
label: Paragraph

text: the Depression, governments after the Second World War
label: Paragraph

text: came to give increasing attention to the content and impact
label: Paragraph

text: of media rather than to built form. And where the former
label: Paragraph

text: became increasingly rhetorical and intense, the latter
label: Paragraph

text: became more and more abstract and devoid of
label: Paragraph

text: iconographical content. The highly abstract quality of the
label: Paragraph

text: post-1956 extension of the Rockefeller Center west of 6th
label: Caption

text: Avenue for Time Inc., Exxon and McGraw-Hill already
label: Paragraph

text: testifies to this reductive process.
label: Paragraph

text: The reasons for the eclipse of the Modernistic New
label: Title

text: Tradition in 1939 were not, however, entirely ideological; for
label: Paragraph

text: one thing the high-quality craftsmanship readily available
label: Paragraph

text: for the realization of such remarkable structures as William
label: Paragraph

text: van Alen’s Chrysler Building, New York (1930; see p. 251),
label: Caption

text: was largely absorbed and dispersed by the war effort. In
label: Paragraph

text: addition, the enthusiasm with which the American
label: Paragraph

text: establishment embraced the Modern Movement increased
label: Title

text: each successive year, after the Hitchcock and Johnson
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition ‘Modern Architecture’ of 1932, and, by 1945,
label: Paragraph

text: when the New Deal was at its height, the Functionalist line
label: Paragraph

text: in architecture was virtually the ruling style (see the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Lescaze, Neutra, the Bowman brothers, etc.).
label: Paragraph

text: It is ironic that the demise of the New Tradition and the
label: Paragraph

text: triumph of the Modern Movement should coincide with a
label: Paragraph

text: reaction in favour of monumentality coming from the heart
label: Title

text: of the movement itself. Only five years separate Giedion’s
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Eliot Norton Lectures, given at Harvard University in
label: Caption

text: 1938-39 (published as Space, Time and Architecture in
label: Paragraph

text: 1941), from his polemical Nine Points on Monumentality of
label: Paragraph

text: 1943, written in collaboration with Fernand Léger and José
label: Paragraph

text: Luis Sert. The most important articles of this document
label: Paragraph

text: read:
label: Title

text: (1) Monuments are human landmarks which men have
label: Paragraph

text: created as symbols for their ideals, for their aims, and for
label: Paragraph

text: their actions. They are intended to outlive the period which
label: Paragraph

text: originated them, and constitute a heritage for future
label: Paragraph

text: generations. As such, they form a link between the past and
label: Paragraph

text: the future.
label: Paragraph

text: (2) Monuments are the expression of man’s highest cultural
label: Paragraph

text: needs. They have to satisfy the eternal demand of the
label: Paragraph

text: people for translation of their collective force into symbols.
label: Paragraph

text: The most vital monuments are those which express the
label: Paragraph

text: feeling and thinking of this collective force - the people.
label: Paragraph

text: (4) The last hundred years have witnessed the devaluation
label: Paragraph

text: of monumentality. This does not mean that there is any lack
label: Paragraph

text: of formal monuments or architectural examples pretending
label: Paragraph

text: to serve this purpose; but the so-called monuments of
label: Paragraph

text: recent date have, with rare exceptions, become empty
label: Paragraph

text: shells. They in no way represent the spirit and the collective
label: Paragraph

text: feeling of modern times.
label: Paragraph

text: (6) A new step lies ahead. Postwar changes in the whole
label: Paragraph

text: economic structure of nations may bring with them the
label: Paragraph

text: organization of community life in the city which has been
label: Paragraph

text: practically neglected up to date.
label: Paragraph

text: (7) The people want the buildings that represent their social
label: Paragraph

text: and community life to give more than functional fulfilment.°
label: Paragraph

text: This position paper - destined to become the brief for
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM VIII of 1952 - formulated a sharply discriminative
label: Paragraph

text: approach to the problem of representation, which seems to
label: Paragraph

text: be as valid today as when it was first written. In the first
label: Paragraph

text: instance, there is its recognition of the fact that neither the
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality of the New Tradition nor the functionalism of
label: Paragraph

text: the Modern Movement was capable of representing the
label: Paragraph

text: collective aspirations of the people. In the second, there is
label: Paragraph

text: the implication, never explicitly stated, that a genuine
label: Paragraph

text: collectivity can only realize an appropriate expression of its
label: Paragraph

text: values and historical continuity at a ‘cantonal’ or municipal
label: Title

text: level, and that large centralized or authoritarian states are
label: Paragraph

text: incapable, by definition, of authentically representing the
label: Paragraph

text: hopes and desires of the people. In the years since 1943 the
label: Paragraph

text: issue of representation - the fundamental problem of
label: Title

text: meaning in architecture - has recurred again and again,
label: Paragraph

text: only to be met by repression and denial, or by escapist
label: Paragraph

text: withdrawal into the supposedly spontaneous and hence
label: Paragraph

text: popular significance of advertising and media in the
label: Paragraph

text: consumer economy. The practice of architecture now lapses
label: Paragraph

text: into ‘silence’ - see Manfredo Tafuri’s Progetto e Utopia
label: Caption

text: (Architecture and Utopia, Design and Capitalist
label: Title

text: Development) of 1973 - and even into disrepute solely
label: Paragraph

text: because one of the primary subjects of which it should
label: Paragraph

text: speak, namely the destiny of the society, is constantly
label: Paragraph

text: denied it. Unfortunately, the political institutions that would
label: Paragraph

text: be capable of rearticulating this particular form of
label: Paragraph

text: significance are today as fragile as the culture of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture itself.
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 27
label: Title

text: Le Corbusier and the
label: Title

text: Monumentalization of the
label: Title

text: Vernacular 1930-60
label: Title

text: This construction, built by local contractors, consists of
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete floors carried on exposed masonry walls
label: Caption

text: made of the local stone. Despite the use of ordinary
label: Paragraph

text: masonry, the usual conceptions employed in our houses
label: Paragraph

text: reappear here. That is to say, a complete distinction is
label: Paragraph

text: maintained between the bearing walls which are considered
label: Paragraph

text: as supports for the floors and the glazed partitions which fill
label: Paragraph

text: the empty spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: The composition is structured by the landscape. The
label: Paragraph

text: house occupies a small promontory dominating the plain
label: Paragraph

text: behind Toulon, backed by a magnificent silhouette of
label: Paragraph

text: mountains. The site offers the striking spectacle of a vast
label: Paragraph

text: unfolding landscape, and the unexpected nature of this has
label: Paragraph

text: been kept by walling in the principal rooms on the side to
label: Paragraph

text: the view and by having only a door that opens onto a
label: Paragraph

text: veranda from which the sudden vista is like an explosion. On
label: Paragraph

text: descending the small staircase that leads down to the
label: Paragraph

text: ground one sees a large stele by Lipschitz rising up, its
label: Paragraph

text: terminal palmette outlined against the sky above the
label: Caption

text: mountains.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier,
label: Title

text: Oeuvre compléte, 1929-34, 19351
label: Caption

text: Le Corbusier and Pierre Jeanneret had already thought of
label: Paragraph

text: their domestic architecture of the late 1920s as having a
label: Paragraph

text: strong link with the natural environment, but they had never
label: Paragraph

text: previously conceived of this connection as taking place on
label: Paragraph

text: such a monumental scale. Now, with this holiday house
label: Paragraph

text: designed for Héléne de Mandrot and built outside Toulon in
label: Caption

text: 1931, and their Errazuriz House projected for a remote site
label: Paragraph

text: in Chile (1930), they began to envisage their works as
label: Paragraph

text: reaching out across landscapes of titanic proportions. This
label: Paragraph

text: subtle shift towards a topographic sensibility contrasted
label: Paragraph

text: with their apparently spontaneous acceptance of
label: Paragraph

text: ‘vernacular’ construction as a mode of expression. Although
label: Paragraph

text: they had used load-bearing crosswalls before they had
label: Paragraph

text: never exploited the expressive qualities of rough-hewn
label: Paragraph

text: stonework.
label: Paragraph

text: This break with the dogmatic aesthetic of Purism (already
label: Paragraph

text: anticipated in Le Corbusier’s painting of 1926) coincides
label: Paragraph

text: with the conceptual point in his career when he began to
label: Paragraph

text: abandon his faith in the inevitably beneficient workings of a
label: Paragraph

text: machine-age civilization. From now on, disillusioned by
label: Paragraph

text: industrial reality and increasingly under the ‘Brutalist’
label: Title

text: influence of the painter Fernand Léger, his style began to
label: Paragraph

text: move in two opposite directions at once. On the one hand
label: Paragraph

text: he returned, at least in his domestic work, to the language
label: Paragraph

text: of the vernacular; on the other, as in his project for Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Otlet’s Cité Mondiale of 1929, he embraced a
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality of Classical, not to say Beaux-Arts, grandeur.
label: Paragraph

text: However, to think of this schism as a simple
label: Paragraph

text: differentiation in the expressive mode between ‘building’
label: Paragraph

text: and ‘architecture’ is to give an oversimplified account of the
label: Paragraph

text: practice at this time. For, despite the ‘inner doubt’, not only
label: Paragraph

text: had the machine aesthetic not been totally abandoned (as
label: Paragraph

text: we may judge from ‘curtain-walled’ structures built by the
label: Paragraph

text: practice between 1930 and 1933), but also works such as
label: Paragraph

text: the de Beistegui Penthouse unexpectedly revealed a
label: Paragraph

text: Surrealist side to Le Corbusier’s imagination. This dreamlike
label: Paragraph

text: exercise - reminiscent of Adolf Loos’s interiors for the Tristan
label: Paragraph

text: Tzara house of 1926 - manifested its ‘aesthetic’ disjunctions
label: Paragraph

text: on more than one level. While it emphasized the
label: Paragraph

text: strangeness of objects at a domestic scale (the lawn of the
label: Paragraph

text: solarium appeared like a living carpet!) it also evoked
label: Paragraph

text: unlikely urban (topographic) associations such as the
label: Paragraph

text: isomorphic similarity between the solarium’s false fireplace
label: Paragraph

text: and the Arc de Triomphe, poised on the artificial horizon of
label: Paragraph

text: the bounding wall. This Surrealist sensibility (compare
label: Paragraph

text: Magritte and Piranesi) is latent throughout the whole of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s return to the vernacular, from the de Mandrot
label: Paragraph

text: House of 1931 to the Ronchamp pilgrimage chapel built in
label: Caption

text: the mid-1950s.
label: Paragraph

text: In many of the ‘vernacular’ essays prior to Ronchamp the
label: Paragraph

text: remoteness of the site itself became the rationale for the
label: Paragraph

text: mode of building. The extreme example of this is the very
label: Paragraph

text: cheap house at Mathes, near Bordeaux (1935), which was
label: Paragraph

text: built from drawings without the architect visiting the site. Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: The impossibility of supervising the construction and the
label: Paragraph

text: necessity of employing a small contractor from the village
label: Paragraph

text: led even to the conception of the plan itself. The house had
label: Paragraph

text: three successive and absolutely separate stages of work:
label: Paragraph

text: (a) the masonry built at one time,
label: Paragraph

text: (b) the carpentry built at one time,
label: Paragraph

text: (c) the joinery, comprising windows, doors, shutters and
label: Paragraph

text: cupboards, all to a standard and to a unitary principle of
label: Paragraph

text: construction; assembled independently and variously
label: Paragraph

text: panelled in glass, plywood and asbestos cement.”
label: Paragraph

text: The same justification of limited resources could be put
label: Paragraph

text: forward in the case of the Errazuriz and de Mandrot houses,
label: Paragraph

text: but it could hardly apply to the weekend house built in the
label: Paragraph

text: Parisian suburbs in 1935 [221]. Here the vernacular was
label: Paragraph

text: being consciously embraced for its material articulation, for
label: Paragraph

text: its capacity to enrich the abstract and reductive nature of
label: Paragraph

text: the Purist style. Le Corbusier wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: 221 Le Corbusier and Jeanneret, weekend house, Paris, 1935.
label: Caption

text: The designing of such a house demanded extreme care
label: Paragraph

text: since the elements of construction were the only
label: Paragraph

text: architectonic means. The architectural theme was
label: Paragraph

text: established about a typical bay whose influence extended
label: Paragraph

text: as far as the little pavilion in the garden. Here one was
label: Paragraph

text: confronted by exposed stonework, natural on the outside,
label: Paragraph

text: white on the interior; wood on the walls and ceilings; and a
label: Caption

text: chimney out of rough brickwork, with white ceramic tiles on
label: Caption

text: the floor, Nevada glass block walls and a table of Cippolino
label: Caption

text: marble.?
label: Paragraph

text: In short, one experienced, as at Toulon and Mathes, an
label: Paragraph

text: expressive bricolage. From now on the juxtaposition of
label: Paragraph

text: contrasting materials became an essential aspect of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s style, not only as an expressive ‘palette’ but
label: Paragraph

text: also as a means of building.
label: Paragraph

text: This shift to natural materials and primitive methods had
label: Paragraph

text: consequences that went beyond a mere change in
label: Paragraph

text: technique or surface style. Above all it meant abandoning
label: Paragraph

text: the Classical envelope that had been used in the villas of
label: Paragraph

text: the late 1920s in favour of an architecture predicated on the
label: Paragraph

text: expressive force of a single architectonic element, be this a
label: Paragraph

text: monopitched roof supported by cross-walls or a barrel-
label: Paragraph

text: vaulted megaron. While the former mode (anticipated at
label: Paragraph

text: Mathes) appeared in the rammed-earth walls and lean-to
label: Paragraph

text: thatched roofs of the ‘Maisons Murondins’ proposed in 1940
label: Paragraph

text: for the accommodation of refugees, the latter was the basic
label: Paragraph

text: structural module of both the weekend house and the farm
label: Caption

text: complex projected for Cherchell, North Africa, in 1942. That
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s preoccupation with the Mediterranean after
label: Paragraph

text: the Second World War took a vernacular rather than a
label: Paragraph

text: Classical form is demonstrated by a sequence of works
label: Paragraph

text: stemming from the Cherchell project, and leading via the
label: Paragraph

text: Roq et Rob stepped-terrace housing designed for Cap Martin
label: Caption

text: in 1949 [222] to the Sarabhai House in Ahmedabad and the
label: Paragraph

text: Maisons Jaoul in Paris [223], these last two works being
label: Paragraph

text: completed in 1955.
