text: 222 Le Corbusier, Rog et Rob project, Cap Martin, 1949. A reinterpretation of the
label: Caption

text: weekend house as a housing prototype.
label: Paragraph

text: 223 Le Corbusier, Maisons Jaoul, Paris, 1955. North-east elevation.
label: Caption

text: As James Stirling was to make clear, the Maisons Jaoul
label: Paragraph

text: design was an affront to those sensibilities which had been
label: Paragraph

text: nurtured on the myth that modern architecture should
label: Paragraph

text: manifest itself as smooth, machine-wrought, planar surfaces
label: Paragraph

text: set within an articulated structural frame. It was disturbing
label: Paragraph

text: to find that this complex was ‘being built by Algerian
label: Paragraph

text: labourers equipped with ladders, hammers and nails’, and
label: Paragraph

text: that with the exception of glass no synthetic materials were
label: Paragraph

text: being used. For Stirling, the almost medieval level of the
label: Paragraph

text: technology was enough to relegate the work to the realm of
label: Paragraph

text: art for art’s sake, and he Saw it, justifiably, as being in direct
label: Paragraph

text: opposition to the Rationalist tradition of the Modern
label: Title

text: Movement. However, Le Corbusier's ‘arationality’ went
label: Paragraph

text: beyond the anachronistic, if expedient, application of
label: Paragraph

text: Catalan vaulting or exposed brickwork and concrete struck
label: Paragraph

text: directly from timber shuttering. The concrete waterheads,
label: Paragraph

text: the narrow openings in the cross-walls, and the transverse
label: Paragraph

text: bays (these last being largely filled with plywood panelling)
label: Paragraph

text: combined to create the impression of a consciously hostile
label: Paragraph

text: attitude to the outside world. The archetypal window was
label: Paragraph

text: now no longer the fenétre en longueur to be looked through,
label: Paragraph

text: but rather a framed and panelled insert to be looked at. ‘The
label: Paragraph

text: eye finding interest in every part of a surface impasto’,
label: Paragraph

text: wrote Stirling, ‘does not, as at Garches, seek relief from the
label: Paragraph

text: hard textureless finish by examining the contours and the
label: Paragraph

text: form of the plane.’ Instead of Purist form, the Maisons Jaoul
label: Paragraph

text: offered a tactile reality far removed from the utopian visions
label: Paragraph

text: of the late 1920s: a pragmatism which was ready to
label: Paragraph

text: embrace, as Reyner Banham has observed, the
label: Paragraph

text: contradictions and confusions of suburbia.
label: Paragraph

text: The Maisons Jaoul design was a monumental
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpretation of a Mediterranean vernacular, whose effect
label: Paragraph

text: stemmed as much from its introspective solemnity as from
label: Paragraph

text: its scale. This Surrealistic syntax could hardly be used for
label: Paragraph

text: the eighteen-storey Unité d’Habitation, built at Marseilles in
label: Paragraph

text: 1947-52 [224]. And yet in abandoning the lightweight
label: Paragraph

text: machine technology of the pre-war era the Unité showed
label: Paragraph

text: itself equally committed to ‘brutalist’ methods of
label: Paragraph

text: construction. This is especially evident in the casting of its
label: Paragraph

text: basic concrete superstructure from rough timber formwork,
label: Paragraph

text: a deliberate revelation of built process which Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: was to justify on grounds which were almost existential.
label: Paragraph

text: 224 Le Corbusier, Unité d’Habitation, Marseilles, 1947-52.
label: Caption

text: Aside from this béton brut appearance, the Unité was far
label: Paragraph

text: more complex in its organization than the typical pre-war
label: Paragraph

text: Ville Radieuse block. Where the Ville Radieuse slab was a
label: Paragraph

text: continuous horizontal volume, hermetically contained
label: Paragraph

text: behind glass, the Unité revealed its cellular structure
label: Paragraph

text: through the use of concrete sun-baffle balconies and
label: Paragraph

text: canopies projecting from the main body of the building.
label: Caption

text: These brises-solei/ with their side walls stressed the volume
label: Paragraph

text: of the two-storey units extending through the width of the
label: Paragraph

text: block - megaron forms constructed as independent
label: Paragraph

text: elements and suspended within the concrete frame in much
label: Paragraph

text: the same manner as bottles are set into a rack. Interior
label: Paragraph

text: ‘streets’ on every other floor provided the horizontal access
label: Paragraph

text: to these interlocking crossover units.
label: Paragraph

text: This cellular morphology automatically expressed an
label: Paragraph

text: agglomeration of private dwellings (compare Roq et Rob),
label: Paragraph

text: while the shopping arcade and the rooftop communal
label: Paragraph

text: facilities served to establish and represent the public realm.
label: Paragraph

text: The honorific status of this larger whole was expressed at
label: Paragraph

text: ground level in the carefully profiled columns supporting the
label: Paragraph

text: underbelly of the building. These pi/otis, precisely
label: Paragraph

text: proportioned in accordance with Le Corbusier’s Modulor,
label: Paragraph

text: suggested the invention of a new ‘Classical’ order. Uniting
label: Paragraph

text: its 337 dwellings with a shopping arcade, a hotel and a
label: Paragraph

text: roofdeck, a running track, a paddling pool [225], a
label: Paragraph

text: kindergarten and a gymnasium, the Unité was just as much
label: Paragraph

text: of a ‘social condenser’ as the Soviet commune blocks of the
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s. This total integration of community services recalled
label: Paragraph

text: the 19th-century model of Fourier’s phalanstery, not only
label: Paragraph

text: through its size but also in its isolation from the immediate
label: Paragraph

text: environment. And just as the phalanstery was intended to
label: Paragraph

text: house the ordinary man in a princely domain (Fourier
label: Paragraph

text: detesting the meanness of the individual house), so the
label: Paragraph

text: Unité was seen by its author as restoring the dignity of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture to the simplest private dwelling.
label: Paragraph

text: 225 Le Corbusier, Unité d’Habitation, Marseilles, 1947-52. Children’s pool on the
label: Caption

text: roof.
label: Paragraph

text: The pilgrimage chapel at Ronchamp, first projected in
label: Caption

text: 1950, and the Dominican monastery of La Tourette [226],
label: Paragraph

text: built at Eveux outside Lyons in 1960, represent the two
label: Paragraph

text: principal building types - the sacred building and the retreat
label: Title

text: - that preoccupied Le Corbusier throughout the 1950s. The
label: Paragraph

text: monastery, effectively combining both types, served to
label: Paragraph

text: remind him of that paradigm of ‘solitude and communion’
label: Paragraph

text: which had so deeply moved him when he first visited the
label: Paragraph

text: Charterhouse of Ema in 1907. La Tourette simply
label: Caption

text: reinterpreted this ideal model as a bipartite scheme
label: Paragraph

text: comprising ‘public’ church and ‘private’ cloister. Elevated off
label: Paragraph

text: the ground rather than terraced into its site, this opposition
label: Paragraph

text: between the vertical volume of the chapel and the
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal layer of the ambulatory was dramatically exposed
label: Paragraph

text: by the fall of the land. Colin Rowe has written:
label: Paragraph

text: 226 Le Corbusier, monastery of La Tourette, near Lyons, 1957-60. Section and
label: Caption

text: second-floor plan.
label: Caption

text: At La Tourette the site is everything and nothing. It is
label: Paragraph

text: equipped with an abrupt slope and a lavishly accidental
label: Paragraph

text: cross-fall. It is by no means a local condition which would
label: Paragraph

text: really justify the quintessential Dominican establishment
label: Paragraph

text: which seems to have been preconceived. Rather it is the
label: Paragraph

text: reverse; architecture and landscape, lucid and separate
label: Title

text: experiences, are like rival protagonists of a debate who
label: Paragraph

text: progressively contradict and clarify each other’s meaning.‘
label: Paragraph

text: Nothing could have been further from this than the
label: Paragraph

text: rapport established between building and site at Ronchamp,
label: Paragraph

text: where the crustacean forms which make up the whole - the
label: Paragraph

text: shell roof with its giant gargoyle, the side chapels and the
label: Paragraph

text: altar - were all precisely tuned to respond to the ‘visual
label: Paragraph

text: acoustics’ of an undulating landscape. Ronchamp brought
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier back to the 1930s, not only to the de Mandrot
label: Paragraph

text: House for its integration into the site but also to the basic
label: Paragraph

text: form of the Pavilion des Temps Nouveaux built for the Paris
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition of 1937 [227, 228]. Unlikely as it may seem, this
label: Paragraph

text: wire-cable suspension structure was the fundamental
label: Paragraph

text: prototype for Ronchamp, inasmuch as it was inspired by the
label: Paragraph

text: reconstruction of the Hebrew temple in the wilderness,
label: Paragraph

text: previously reproduced in Vers une architecture. As a further
label: Paragraph

text: transposition of the same metaphor, the dominant concrete
label: Paragraph

text: shell roof of Ronchamp echoed the profile of the canvas-
label: Paragraph

text: and-cable catenary roof to the 1937 pavilion. The recurrence
label: Caption

text: of this profile in the Chandigarh Capitol and elsewhere in his
label: Paragraph

text: later work makes it seem that Le Corbusier was trying to
label: Paragraph

text: establish this form as the 20th-century equivalent of the
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance dome, i.e. as a sign for the sacred.
label: Paragraph

text: 227 Le Corbusier and Jeanneret, Pavillon des Temps Nouveaux, World Exhibition,
label: Caption

text: Paris, 1937.
label: Caption

text: 228 Le Corbusier, Ronchamp Chapel, near Belfort, 1950-55.
label: Caption

text: Beyond this, Ronchamp resists analysis - in part Maltese
label: Paragraph

text: tomb, in part Ischian vernacular, its half-cylindrical side
label: Paragraph

text: chapels, toplit through spherical cowls and orientated
label: Caption

text: towards the trajectory of the sun, serve to remind one that
label: Paragraph

text: this Christian site was once the location of a sun temple.
label: Paragraph

text: Built as it is around a hidden reinforced-concrete frame, the
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular in this instance is simulated rather than
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpreted in monumental terms [230]. As in the villa at
label: Paragraph

text: Garches, the rough masonry infill is rendered over with
label: Paragraph

text: ‘gunite’, but the desired finish is no longer the machine
label: Paragraph

text: precision of Purism but the stippled, whitewashed texture of
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean folk building.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s concern for the sculptural resonance of a
label: Paragraph

text: building in relation to its site was first formulated in 1923,
label: Paragraph

text: when he characterized the Acropolis and its Propylea as that
label: Paragraph

text: point ‘when nothing more might be taken away, when
label: Paragraph

text: nothing would be left but these closely knit and violent
label: Paragraph

text: elements, sounding clear and tragic like brazen trumpets’.
label: Paragraph

text: This passionate image of the Acropolis, conveying a feeling
label: Paragraph

text: for unity just prior to breaking up, reappears as a constant
label: Paragraph

text: theme throughout his life and with heightened pathos
label: Paragraph

text: towards the end of his career. This was as much the
label: Paragraph

text: principle underlying Ronchamp’s ‘visual acoustics’ as it was
label: Paragraph

text: the reason for the diminutive volcanic, mountainous forms
label: Paragraph

text: that erupt on the roofdeck of the Unité.
label: Paragraph

text: A more Cartesian approach informed the design of
label: Paragraph

text: Chandigarh [229], the new administrative capital of the
label: Paragraph

text: Punjab, founded in 1951. Since the terrain here was flat, the
label: Paragraph

text: siting of the monuments was determined by the imposition
label: Paragraph

text: of a proportional grid. Le Corbusier had already used such
label: Paragraph

text: ‘regulating lines’ on an urban scale in his Cité Mondiale of
label: Paragraph

text: 1929 and in his centre for St-Dié of 1945. His description of
label: Paragraph

text: the Capitol makes it clear he was convinced that such
label: Paragraph

text: delicate refinements were perceptible, irrespective of the
label: Paragraph

text: distances involved. ‘The composition of the Park of the
label: Paragraph

text: Capitol, vast as it is, is today regulated to the centimetre in
label: Paragraph

text: nearly all of its dimensions both overall and in detail. Such
label: Paragraph

text: are the means, the powers, and the objectives of
label: Paragraph

text: “proportioning”.’ That similar modular devices had been
label: Paragraph

text: used by Sir Edwin Lutyens when designing New Delhi was
label: Paragraph

text: not lost on Le Corbusier, who wrote appreciatively of that
label: Paragraph

text: new capital that it was ‘built by Lutyens over thirty years
label: Paragraph

text: ago with extreme care, great talent, and with true success.
label: Paragraph

text: The critics may rant as they will, but the accomplishment of
label: Paragraph

text: such an undertaking earns respect.’
label: Paragraph

text: 229 Le Corbusier, with Jeanneret, Drew and Fry, Chandigarh, 1951-65. The
label: Caption

text: Capitol (top of plan) is represented as a wooden model in the foreground,
label: Paragraph

text: showing the Secretariat, Assembly, Governor’s Palace and High Court.
label: Caption

text: 230 Le Corbusier, Ronchamp Chapel, near Belfort, 1950-55.
label: Caption

text: Unlike New Delhi or the Cité Mondiale, Chandigarh
label: Paragraph

text: achieved monumentality without referring directly to the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional vocabulary of Western Classicism. The striking
label: Paragraph

text: profiles of its three monuments were derived, in the first
label: Paragraph

text: instance, from a direct response to the severity of the
label: Paragraph

text: climate. Unlike Lutyens, who had exploited only the
label: Paragraph

text: secondary elements of Moghul architecture, Le Corbusier
label: Caption

text: appropriated the traditional ‘parasol’ concept of Fatehpur
label: Paragraph

text: Sikri as a Monumental coding device to be varied from one
label: Paragraph

text: structure to the next. By using this shell form either as a
label: Paragraph

text: prelude (the Assembly entrance canopy), or as a constant
label: Paragraph

text: (the vaulted roof of the High Court), or as a dominant (the
label: Paragraph

text: crowning parasol of the Governor’s Palace), he was able to
label: Paragraph

text: suggest the character and status of each institution. The
label: Paragraph

text: subtle profiles of these shell forms were derived in part from
label: Paragraph

text: the livestock and landscape of the region [231]. The evident
label: Paragraph

text: intent was to represent a modern Indian identity that would
label: Paragraph

text: be free from any association with its colonial past.
label: Paragraph

text: 231 Le Corbusier, Chandigarh, c. 1951. Sketches of cattle and vernacular
label: Caption

text: building forms, and section through the Secretariat.
label: Paragraph

text: At the same time, the enormous scale of the Capitol
label: Paragraph

text: deprived it of those public attributes of the ‘heart of the city
label: Paragraph

text: which, at CIAM VIII, held at Hoddesdon, England, in 1952,
label: Paragraph

text: Sert had seen as being dependent on ‘walking distances
label: Paragraph

text: and man’s angle of vision’. Within the temenos of the
label: Paragraph

text: Capitol, where it takes over twenty minutes to walk from the
label: Paragraph

text: Secretariat to the High Court, the presence of man is more
label: Paragraph

text: metaphysical than real (once again recalling De Chirico). Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s Neo-Classical heritage had emerged to evoke
label: Paragraph

text: the landscape of the genre terrible: the representative
label: Title

text: buildings of the ‘three powers’ - the High Court, the
label: Paragraph

text: Assembly and the Secretariat [232] - were related not, as
label: Paragraph

text: on the Acropolis, by the configuration of the site, but rather
label: Paragraph

text: by abstract sight lines, receding across vast distances, a
label: Paragraph

text: progressive foreshortening whose only limits seemed to lie
label: Paragraph

text: with the mountains on the horizon.
label: Paragraph

text: 232 Le Corbusier with Jeanneret, Drew and Fry, Chandigarh Capitol, 1957-65.
label: Caption

text: Secretariat and Assembly Buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: The realization of Chandigarh proper, as an abstract and
label: Paragraph

text: ill-advised plan, can (as Stanislaus von Moos has argued)
label: Paragraph

text: hardly be separated from the political aspirations of India at
label: Paragraph

text: the time of its independence. For Chandigarh was more than
label: Paragraph

text: the capital of the Punjab: it was the symbol of the New
label: Paragraph

text: India. It epitomized the idea of a modern industrial state,
label: Paragraph

text: the utopian destiny which Nehru had envisaged for India in
label: Paragraph

text: total opposition to Gandhi's will. Thus Chandigarh had
label: Paragraph

text: already been laid out as a picturesque ‘motopian’ suburbia
label: Paragraph

text: by the American planner Albert Mayer before its hasty
label: Paragraph

text: rationalization into a more or less orthogonal road network
label: Title

text: at the hands of Le Corbusier, in association with Pierre
label: Paragraph

text: Jeanneret, Jane Drew and Maxwell Fry. The emerging crisis of
label: Paragraph

text: Western Enlightenment, its inability to nurture an existing
label: Paragraph

text: culture or even to sustain the significance of its own
label: Paragraph

text: Classical forms, its lack of any goal beyond constant
label: Paragraph

text: technical innovation and optimum economic growth, all
label: Paragraph

text: seem to be summed up in the tragedy of Chandigarh - a city
label: Paragraph

text: designed for automobiles in a country where many, as yet,
label: Paragraph

text: still lack a bicycle.
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 28
label: Title

text: Mies van der Rohe and the
label: Title

text: Monumentalization of
label: Title

text: Technique 1933-67
label: Title

text: In architecture there is only one man whom even the young
label: Paragraph

text: men can defend and that is Mies van der Rohe. Mies has
label: Paragraph

text: always kept out of politics and has always taken his stand
label: Paragraph

text: against functionalism. No one can accuse Mies’s houses of
label: Paragraph

text: looking like factories. Two factors especially make Mies’s
label: Paragraph

text: acceptance as the new architect possible. First, Mies is
label: Paragraph

text: respected by the conservatives. Even the Kampfbund fir
label: Paragraph

text: Deutsche Kultur has nothing against him. Secondly. Mies has
label: Paragraph

text: just won... a competition for the new building of the
label: Paragraph

text: Reichsbank. The jury were older architects and
label: Paragraph

text: representatives of the bank.
label: Paragraph

text: If (and it may be a long if) Mies should build this building
label: Paragraph

text: it would clinch his position. A good modern Reichsbank
label: Paragraph

text: would satisfy the new craving for monumentality, but above
label: Paragraph

text: it all it would prove to the German intellectuals and to
label: Paragraph

text: foreign countries that the new Germany is not bent on
label: Paragraph

text: destroying all the splendid modern arts which have been
label: Paragraph

text: built up in recent years.
label: Paragraph

text: Philip Johnson
label: Title

text: ‘Architecture in the Third Reich’, Horn and Hound, 19331
label: Caption

text: Mies van der Rohe’s entry for the Reichsbank competition of
label: Paragraph

text: 1933 [233] was the beginning of a transformation in his
label: Paragraph

text: work, from informal asymmetry to symmetrical
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality. This move towards the monumental
label: Paragraph

text: eventually culminated in the development of a highly
label: Paragraph

text: rationalized building method that was widely adopted in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s by the American building industry and its corporate
label: Title

text: clientele. The Reichsbank design hinted at this future
label: Paragraph

text: development in more ways than one, for it established a
label: Paragraph

text: preference not only for symmetry but also for a certain
label: Paragraph

text: tectonic which tended to move away from the dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: Spatial effects of his earlier career. At the same time the
label: Paragraph

text: client was the institutional establishment, a patron that Mies
label: Paragraph

text: was to serve throughout his practice in the United States.
label: Paragraph

text: 233 Mies van der Rohe, project for the Reichsbank, Berlin, 1933.
label: Caption

text: The Reichsbank design was not simply a return to
label: Paragraph

text: Schinkel, who, except in Mies’s work of the early 1920s, had
label: Paragraph

text: always been a latent influence. It was more a return to the
label: Paragraph

text: tectonics of Mies’s concrete office building, first published in
label: Paragraph

text: the magazine Gin 1923, the emphasis in both projects
label: Paragraph

text: being on the expressive qualities of an objective building
label: Paragraph

text: technique, logically conceived and rigorously executed. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1926 Mies had spoken of architecture as being ‘the will of
label: Paragraph

text: the epoch translated into space’. In Hegelian terms, he saw
label: Paragraph

text: this will as historically determined technique, as a self-
label: Paragraph

text: evident fact, only to be refined by the spirit. The intrinsic
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality of his later work was predicated on such a
label: Paragraph

text: refinement. For Mies, technology was the cultural
label: Paragraph

text: manifestation of modern man, and in this respect the
label: Paragraph

text: Reichsbank must be regarded as his first essay in the
label: Paragraph

text: monumentalization of technique. This accounts for its
label: Paragraph

text: warehouse-like appearance, for the neutral, scarcely
label: Paragraph

text: modulated treatment of its curtain wall.
label: Paragraph

text: Between 1933 and the early 1950s, Mies’s work was to
label: Paragraph

text: oscillate between asymmetry and symmetry, between
label: Paragraph

text: technique as found and the monumentalization of technique
label: Title

text: as form. This variation in expression occurred not only from
label: Paragraph

text: one building to the next but also within a single structure.
label: Paragraph

text: He summed up the over-riding cultural import that he
label: Paragraph

text: attached to technique in his address to the Illinois Institute
label: Paragraph

text: of Technology in 1950:
label: Title

text: Technology is rooted in the past. It dominates the present
label: Paragraph

text: and tends into the future. It is a real historical movement -
label: Paragraph

text: one of the great movements which shape and represent
label: Paragraph

text: their epoch.
label: Paragraph

text: It can be compared only with the classic discovery of
label: Paragraph

text: man as a person, the Roman will to power, and the religious
label: Paragraph

text: movement of the Middle Ages.
label: Paragraph

text: Technology is far more than a method, it is a world in
label: Paragraph

text: itself As a method it is superior in almost every respect. But
label: Paragraph

text: only where it is left to itself, as in gigantic structures of
label: Paragraph

text: engineering, there technology reveals its true nature. ...
label: Paragraph

text: Whenever technology reaches its real fulfilment, it
label: Paragraph

text: transcends into architecture. It is true that architecture
label: Paragraph

text: depends on facts, but its real field of activity is in the realm
label: Paragraph

text: of significance.2
label: Paragraph

text: Mies van der Rohe’s development after the mid-1930s
label: Paragraph

text: concerned itself with the conciliation of two opposed
label: Paragraph

text: systems. One was the heritage of Romantic Classicism
label: Paragraph

text: which, when translated into the skeleton steel frame,
label: Paragraph

text: pointed towards the dematerialization of architecture, to the
label: Paragraph

text: mutation of built form into shifting planes suspended in
label: Paragraph

text: diaphanous space - the image of Suprematism. The other
label: Paragraph

text: was the authority of trabeated architecture as it had been
label: Paragraph

text: inherited from the ancient world, the implacable elements of
label: Paragraph

text: roof, beam, column and wall. Caught, as it were, between
label: Paragraph

text: ‘space’ and ‘structure’, Mies constantly sought to express
label: Paragraph

text: simultaneously both transparency and corporeality. The
label: Paragraph

text: dichotomy revealed itself most sublimely in his attitude to
label: Paragraph

text: glass, which he used in such a way as to allow it to change
label: Paragraph

text: under light from the appearance of a reflective surface to
label: Paragraph

text: the disappearance of the surface into pure transparency: on
label: Paragraph

text: the one hand, the apparition of nothing, on the other, an
label: Paragraph

text: evident need for support.
label: Paragraph

text: In this respect, the preliminary scheme for the Illinois
label: Paragraph

text: Institute of Technology (IIT) campus in Chicago [234],
label: Paragraph

text: prepared in 1939, two years after his arrival in the United
label: Paragraph

text: States, is clearly as Suprematist in feeling as parts of the
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona Pavilion. As in the Reichsbank project, the plan is
label: Paragraph

text: disposed about a single axis of symmetry. All the structures
label: Paragraph

text: are four storeys high and rendered as pure prisms, faced in
label: Paragraph

text: graph paper curtain walls, their surfaces animated by
label: Paragraph

text: skyscape reflections. These walls are shown sliding behind
label: Paragraph

text: occasional clumps of trees, eliding into projecting ivy-clad
label: Paragraph

text: brick planes, poised on the edge of their stereometric
label: Paragraph

text: masses. Apart from a Neo-Classical insistence on the visual
label: Paragraph

text: reinforcement of corners with panels of brickwork, the effect
label: Paragraph

text: is close to the Suprematist aesthetic of lvan Leonidov, in
label: Paragraph

text: particular to his Culture Park project of 1930.
label: Paragraph

text: 234 Mies van der Rohe, preliminary scheme for the Illinois Institute of
label: Caption

text: Technology, Chicago, 1939.
label: Caption

text: At this point, Mies appears to be struggling with the
label: Paragraph

text: generic relation of column to wall, particularly where the
label: Paragraph

text: wall in question is largely of glass. The implicit solution in
label: Paragraph

text: the first IIT proposal (as in the Reichsbank project) is to set
label: Paragraph

text: the columns back from the glass face, but in the final 1940
label: Paragraph

text: version the columns are integrated into the wall. This
label: Paragraph

text: development becomes explicit in the first building for the
label: Paragraph

text: campus. The articulation of the column system in
label: Paragraph

text: conjunction with the glazed plane becomes increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: idealized and monumental with each successive structure.
label: Paragraph

text: This progressive idealization depended on the
label: Paragraph

text: replacement of Mies’s generic cruciform column section of
label: Paragraph

text: the early 1930s by the standard American I-beam. The
label: Paragraph

text: asymmetrical pinwheeling plans of the Barcelona Pavilion
label: Caption

text: and the Tugendhat House at Brno demanded a non-
label: Paragraph

text: directional column form, similar to the point supports that
label: Paragraph

text: Mies used in his Berlin Building Exhibition house of 1931. By
label: Paragraph

text: contrast, his preference from the Reichsbank onwards for a
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: The structural frame and its glass infill become
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: columns and mullion dimensions determine window widths.
label: Paragraph

text: The two central windows (in each structural bay) are,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: to this is added the alternating opacity of the steel and
label: Paragraph

text: reflectivity of the glass caused by the blinker quality of the
label: Paragraph

text: mullions en masse.?
label: Paragraph

text: In short, more than in any other work by Mies, the wall is
label: Paragraph

text: rendered here - after Semper’s prescription - as a woven

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: This restriction may well have contributed, as Colin Rowe
label: Paragraph

text: has suggested, to Mies’s preoccupation with the creation of
label: Paragraph

text: an unobstructed, clear-span, single-storey, unitary volume.
label: Caption

text: This, Mies’s other generic type, was to absorb him from the
label: Paragraph

text: IIT Library onwards. As an archetypal form it was inherently
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: programme. In domestic terms the type was first
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Farnsworth, realized four years later at Plano, Illinois [238].
label: Paragraph

text: Here a 23 X 9-metre (77 x 29-foot) single-volume house

text: was sandwiched, as it were, between floor and roof slabs

text: and raised some 1.5 metres (5 feet) above the ground on
label: Paragraph

text: exterior I-columns set 6.7 metres (22 feet) apart. The
label: Paragraph

text: resultant box was enclosed by a plate-glass skin, the
label: Paragraph

text: apotheosis of Mies’s phrase beinahe nichts, ‘almost
label: Paragraph

text: nothing’.
label: Paragraph

text: 238 Mies van der Rohe, Farnsworth House, Fox River, Plano, Illinois, 1946-50.
label: Caption

text: An evident asymmetry deriving in part from Suprematism

text: - the asymmetry being evident in the overlapping of two
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: welds. The windows were curtained in natural off-white
label: Paragraph

text: shantung silk. One is hardly surprised to learn that the
label: Paragraph

text: shrine.

text: At a public level Mies’s single-span volume found its most

label: Paragraph

text: Crown Hall, designed at about the same time as the

label: Caption

text: Colin Rowe has argued that the whole evolution of the
label: Paragraph

text: International Style in architecture was profoundly affected
label: Paragraph

text: by a conceptual schism between centripetal and centrifugal
label: Paragraph

text: space, the one stemming from Palladianism and the other
label: Paragraph

text: ultimately deriving from the anti-monumentality of Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: extension of the English Free Style plan. This schism, Rowe
label: Paragraph

text: claims, is demonstrated in Crown Hall (significantly enough,
label: Paragraph

text: the IIT school of architecture), where the 67 x 37-metre
label: Paragraph

text: (220 x 120-foot) span glazed box does not afford an
label: Paragraph

text: unequivocal reading of its centralized composition. As Rowe
label: Paragraph

text: has written:
label: Paragraph

text: Like the characteristic Palladian composition, Crown Hall is a
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrical and, probably, a mathematically regulated
label: Paragraph

text: volume. But, unlike the characteristic Palladian composition,
label: Paragraph

text: it is not a hierarchically ordered organization which projects
label: Paragraph

text: its centralized theme vertically in the form of a pyramidal
label: Paragraph

text: roof or dome. Unlike the Villa Rotonda, but like so many of
label: Paragraph

text: the compositions of the twenties, Crown Hall is provided
label: Paragraph

text: with no effective central area within which the observer can
label: Paragraph

text: stand and comprehend the whole ... once inside, rather than
label: Paragraph

text: any Spatial climax, the building offers a central solid, not
label: Paragraph

text: energetically stated, it is true, but still an isolated core
label: Paragraph

text: around which the space travels laterally with the enclosing
label: Paragraph

text: windows.
label: Paragraph

text: Also, the flat slab of the roof induces a certain outward
label: Paragraph

text: pull; and, for this reason, in spite of the centralizing activity
label: Paragraph

text: of the entrance vestibule, the space still remains, though in
label: Paragraph

text: very much simplified form, the rotary, peripheric
label: Paragraph

text: organization of the twenties, rather than the predominantly
label: Paragraph

text: centralized composition of the true Palladian or classical
label: Paragraph

text: plan.4
label: Caption

text: Mies’s typical suppression of all that was
label: Paragraph

text: programmatically incompatible with the monumental
label: Paragraph

text: manifested itself most strikingly at Crown Hall, where the
label: Paragraph

text: department of industrial design was banished to the
label: Paragraph

text: basement to rest, literally and symbolically, beneath the
label: Paragraph

text: grandeur of the department of architecture. Yet, despite the
label: Paragraph

text: impositions of an a priori idealism, Mies was never
label: Paragraph

text: grandiose and his structures were relatively inexpensive,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly when they entailed repetitious cellular elements
label: Paragraph

text: as found in multiple residential or office accommodation.
label: Paragraph

text: Mies’s approach offered the publicity-conscious client an
label: Paragraph

text: impeccable image of power and prestige. After the
label: Paragraph

text: completion of 860 Lake Shore Drive (built for the developer
label: Caption

text: Herbert Greenwald) in 1951, he began to work increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: for the real-estate and institutional establishment, the final
label: Paragraph

text: ‘breakthrough’ coming in 1958 when he was commissioned
label: Paragraph

text: through the agency of Phyllis Lambert to design the thirty-
label: Paragraph

text: nine-storey Seagram Building [241] in New York. In this
label: Caption

text: bronze and brown glass office tower, Mies once again
label: Caption

text: achieved that Semperian interweaving of fenestration with
label: Paragraph

text: structure. This time, however, unlike Lake Shore Drive, he
label: Paragraph

text: created a frontalized axial composition facing a granite
label: Paragraph

text: piazza, the slab itself being set back some 27 metres (90
label: Paragraph

text: feet) from the building line, as a compliment to the 1917
label: Paragraph

text: Racquet Club by McKim, Mead and White on the other side
label: Caption

text: of Park Avenue. This concession on the part of the client
label: Paragraph

text: enabled Mies to achieve his one and only monument in
label: Paragraph

text: Manhattan, and to rival, in grandeur, the one New York
label: Paragraph

text: structure that he had long since admired, the George
label: Paragraph

text: Washington Bridge.
label: Paragraph

text: 241 Mies van der Rohe and Johnson, Seagram Building, New York, 1958.
label: Caption

text: As director of the department of architecture at the IIT
label: Paragraph

text: from 1939 to 1959, Mies had ample opportunity to develop
label: Paragraph

text: a ‘school’ of architecture in the broadest possible sense and
label: Paragraph

text: to generate a culture of simple, logical building, amenable
label: Paragraph

text: to refinement (Baukunsf) and open in principle to the
label: Paragraph

text: optimum utilization of industrial technique. Unfortunately,
label: Paragraph

text: he could not transmit with equal force that Schinkelschtiler
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility which was second nature to him. And while the
label: Paragraph

text: great strength of the school lay in the clarity of its
label: Paragraph

text: principles, the followers of Mies, as recent events suggest,
label: Paragraph

text: were by and large unable to grasp the delicacy of his
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility, that feeling for the precise proportioning of
label: Paragraph

text: profiles that alone guaranteed his mastery over form.

label: Title

text: The European economic and political crises of the 1930s
label: Title

text: and the social provisions of Roosevelt’s New Deal brought to
label: Paragraph

text: the United States both a refugee intelligentsia and
label: Paragraph

text: extensive programmes for social welfare and reform. While
label: Paragraph

text: the Museum of Modern Art and Harvard University were to
label: Paragraph

text: play major roles in the cultural assimilation of this
label: Paragraph

text: migration, the Federal Government provided the
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructural basis for the numerous welfare works that
label: Paragraph

text: were to be executed between Roosevelt’s Housing Act of
label: Paragraph

text: 1934 and the end of the Second World War. The most
label: Paragraph

text: famous planning and settlement projects of the New Deal
label: Title

text: were the Tennessee Valley Authority and Clarence Stein’s
label: Paragraph

text: Greenbelt New Towns, the latter realized after 1936 under
label: Paragraph

text: the auspices of the Federal Resettlement Administration.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike the remarkable dams [242], gantries and slipways
label: Paragraph

text: built in the Tennessee Valley, Stein’s Greenbelt settlements
label: Paragraph

text: were not graced by works of architectural distinction. From
label: Paragraph

text: this point of view finer results were obtained in the workers’
label: Paragraph

text: villages financed over the same period by the Farm Security
label: Paragraph

text: Administration, a typical example being the adobe farm
label: Paragraph

text: community at Chandler, Arizona, built in 1937 to the
label: Paragraph

text: designs of Vernon de Mars. An equally efficient and elegant
label: Paragraph

text: housing standard was reached in other settlements financed
label: Paragraph

text: by similar government agencies, including New Kensington
label: Paragraph

text: village, Pennsylvania, built in 1940 to the designs of Walter
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius and Marcel Breuer, and Channel Heights, San Pedro,
label: Caption

text: Los Angeles, designed in 1943 by Richard Neutra. An
label: Paragraph

text: inexplicably ungainly work built under similar auspices was
label: Paragraph

text: Carver Court Housing at Coatesville, Pennsylvania, designed
label: Caption

text: in 1944 by George Howe, Oscar Stonorov and Louis Kahn.
label: Paragraph

text: This work seems all the more surprising when one realizes
label: Paragraph

text: that Kahn had already proven his ability while working for
label: Paragraph

text: Alfred Kastner on the Jersey Homesteads at Hightstown,
label: Caption

text: New Jersey, between 1935 and 1937.

label: Caption

text: Irrespective of their architectural merit, all of these works
label: Paragraph

text: evinced the presence of a ‘New Objectivity’ in the United
label: Paragraph

text: States. That this movement was hardly as self-conscious or
label: Paragraph

text: as polemical as its European counterpart was due to the fact
label: Paragraph

text: that a comparable ideological basis did not exist. The
label: Paragraph

text: ‘movement’ had, in any event, to be more sensitive to the
label: Paragraph

text: issue of popular acceptance and to this end its anti-
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality stemmed directly from its use of native
label: Paragraph

text: materials and from its response to the vagaries of
label: Paragraph

text: topography and climate.
label: Paragraph

text: A unique and contentious figure within the American
label: Paragraph

text: architectural avant garde during the New Deal, Richard
label: Paragraph

text: Buckminster Fuller had adopted a recognizably ‘objective’ -
label: Paragraph

text: not to say Constructivist - attitude as early as 1927, when
label: Paragraph

text: he designed the first version of his free-standing Dymaxion
label: Paragraph

text: House, the name being a neologism, signifying dynamism
label: Paragraph

text: plus efficiency. Fuller, like the more extreme members of the
label: Paragraph

text: Swiss ABC group, had no concern whatsoever for the
label: Paragraph

text: idiosyncrasies of any given context and projected his house
label: Paragraph

text: as though it were a prototype for serial production [243].
label: Paragraph

text: Hexagonal in plan and sandwiched between two hollow
label: Paragraph

text: decks, it was suspended and triangulated (on the wire wheel
label: Paragraph

text: principle) from a central mast. In this form, it was advanced,
label: Paragraph

text: like Fuller’s even more eccentric Dymaxion automobile of
label: Paragraph

text: 1933, as the one and only inevitable solution. Fuller, never
label: Paragraph

text: at a loss for rhetoric, described this light-weight metal
label: Paragraph

text: house in his Shelter magazine of May 1932 as a synthesis
label: Paragraph

text: between the American skyscraper and the oriental pagoda.
label: Paragraph

text: Ingeniously equipped with a hollow hexagonal mast
label: Paragraph

text: containing all the necessary services, it was the first in a
label: Paragraph

text: series of centralized structures which culminated in Fuller’s
label: Paragraph

text: much simpler geodesic dome, first adapted for domestic use
label: Paragraph

text: on his own account at Carbondale, Illinois, in 1959. The
label: Paragraph

text: rugged reductive ethic of the pioneering individualist is
label: Paragraph

text: evident from the doggerel chorus to be sung to the tune of
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Home on the Range’ that Fuller composed while teaching as
label: Paragraph

text: a visitor at Yale University in the mid-1950s:
label: Paragraph

text: The year 1945 appears as the watershed between the
label: Paragraph

text: socially committed ethos of the New Deal and an incipient
label: Paragraph

text: impulse towards monumentality. This last seems to have
label: Paragraph

text: emerged partly out of the demands of America’s status as a
label: Paragraph

text: world power and partly out of the cultural anxiety that
label: Paragraph

text: attended the end of the Second World War. Two texts
label: Paragraph

text: published in 1945 establish the climate of the period with
label: Paragraph

text: some precision: they are Built in U.S.A. 1932-1944, edited
label: Paragraph

text: by Elizabeth Mock, which accompanied an exhibition at the
label: Caption

text: Museum of Modern Art, New York - in which over half the
label: Paragraph

text: illustrations were devoted to the works of the New Deal -
label: Paragraph

text: and New Architecture and City Planning, edited by Paul
label: Title

text: Zucker, which recorded the proceedings of a symposium
label: Paragraph

text: conducted in the same year. This symposium was devoted
label: Paragraph

text: to the growing need for monumental expression, a theme
label: Paragraph

text: most elaborately formulated by Sigfried Giedion in his paper
label: Paragraph

text: of 1944, The Need for a New Monumentality. Kahn himself
label: Paragraph

text: had argued on the same occasion that
label: Paragraph

text: Monumentality is enigmatic. It cannot be intentionally
label: Paragraph

text: created. Neither the finest material nor the most advanced
label: Paragraph

text: technology need enter a work of monumental character for
label: Paragraph

text: the same reason that the finest ink was not required to draw
label: Paragraph

text: up the Magna Carta.”
label: Paragraph

text: The issue emerged again in 1950 in the first number of
label: Paragraph

text: Perspecta - The Yale Architectural Journal, founded by
label: Paragraph

text: George Howe, wherein Henry Hope Reed argued that the
label: Paragraph

text: New Deal had dealt a severe blow to the culture of
label: Paragraph

text: affluence, and that the provisions arising out of the
label: Paragraph

text: Depression had effectively inhibited any capacity for the
label: Paragraph

text: monumental:
label: Title

text: To be sure the New Deal proved to be the greatest patron of
label: Paragraph

text: the arts in that decade, but never on the basis of pomp and
label: Paragraph

text: ceremony, or for reasons of national prestige or democratic
label: Paragraph

text: grandeur. The government instead reached a charitable and
label: Paragraph

text: philanthropic hand to the starving artist, not that of a
label: Paragraph

text: magnificent and ‘wasteful’ patron.
label: Paragraph

text: It is hardly surprising that architects and city planners
label: Paragraph

text: were ripe for a message from across the waters about a new
label: Paragraph

text: style which banished ‘waste’, tolerated only the functional
label: Paragraph

text: and declared the house to be a machine for living, a fitting
label: Paragraph

text: phrase for a technocratic era.>
label: Paragraph

text: Although Reed concluded that the tools to create the
label: Paragraph

text: monument had been lost, he was soon to be proven wrong,
label: Paragraph

text: for America was about to enter on a spate of all but
label: Paragraph

text: unprecedented monument-building. Intimations of this in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1944 Zucker symposium were vindicated a few years
label: Paragraph

text: later, in 1949, when Philip Johnson built his small but
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: especially the corner treatment and the relation of the
label: Paragraph

text: column to the window frames. The use of standard steel
label: Paragraph

text: sections to make a strong and at the same time decorative
label: Paragraph

text: finish to the facade is typical of Mies’s Chicago work.
label: Caption

text: Perhaps if there is ever to be ‘decoration’ in our architecture
label: Paragraph

text: it may come from the manipulation of stock structural
label: Paragraph

text: elements such as this (may not Mannerism be next?).4
label: Caption

text: Johnson’s determination to obscure structure through
label: Paragraph

text: surface manipulation was to characterize his work
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the next decade. This approach, first fully
label: Paragraph

text: broached in monumental terms in his Port Chester
label: Paragraph

text: Synagogue, New York, of 1954, attained its fullest
label: Paragraph

text: development in his New York State Theater in Lincoln
label: Caption

text: Center, New York, and in his Klein Laboratory Tower built for
label: Caption

text: Yale University at New Haven, both of which were complete
label: Paragraph

text: for occupation by 1963.
label: Paragraph

text: While the Graduate School of Design at Harvard (under
label: Paragraph

text: the direction of Gropius after 1963) helped to consolidate
label: Paragraph

text: the anti-historicist and ‘objective’, Functionalist approach of
label: Paragraph

text: the New Deal, the School of Architecture at Yale, under
label: Paragraph

text: George Howe’s leadership after 1950, played a formative
label: Paragraph

text: role in the development of American post-war
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality. Howe’s own professional career had
label: Paragraph

text: certainly been as varied as Gropius’s, ranging from the arch
label: Paragraph

text: conservatism of his country house practice in Philadelphia
label: Paragraph

text: to the avant-garde Functionalism of his brief partnership in
label: Paragraph

text: 1929 with William Lescaze. Howe championed the cause of
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality not only through his founding of Perspecta,
label: Paragraph

text: but also through his influence on the selection of architects
label: Paragraph

text: for Yale’s expansion programme which began in the early
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s. Indeed, when Reed’s article appeared in Perspecta in
label: Paragraph

text: 1950, Louis Kahn had already been selected to design the
label: Paragraph

text: Yale Art Gallery.
label: Paragraph

text: With the completion of the art gallery in 1954, Kahn
label: Paragraph

text: established American post-war monumentality as a cultural
label: Paragraph

text: force in its own right. He did so with a building that was
label: Paragraph

text: hardly to be compared to the vulgar rhetoric generally
label: Paragraph

text: attained by American official architecture throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s. A typical ‘imperialistic’ monument of the period was
label: Paragraph

text: surely Edward Durell Stone’s U.S. Embassy built at New
label: Paragraph

text: Delhi in 1957, a work whose level of decorative, not to say
label: Paragraph

text: laboured, monumentality was to be surpassed in respect of
label: Paragraph

text: its authoritarian overtones only by Eero Saarinen’s far
label: Paragraph

text: superior U.S. Embassy in London, completed in 1960.
label: Caption

text: The Yale Art Gallery [246, 247], like Johnson's Glass
label: Paragraph

text: House, was based on a subtle transposition of the late
label: Paragraph

text: Miesian aesthetic. Yet where Mies had always given priority
label: Paragraph

text: to the direct expression of structural frame, both Kahn and
label: Paragraph

text: Johnson concealed the frame, at least externally, placing
label: Paragraph

text: their particular emphasis on the monumentalization of what
label: Paragraph

text: might be considered ‘secondary’ components, such as walls,
label: Paragraph

text: floors and ceilings. By a similar token, where Mies always
label: Paragraph

text: chose to emphasize the axiality of his composition, Kahn
label: Paragraph

text: and Johnson masked the inherent symmetrical order of
label: Paragraph

text: theirwork by suppressing the frame. Where Kahn used the
label: Paragraph

text: palpable opacity of brick for this purpose, Johnson relied on
label: Paragraph

text: the reflectivity of glass. He exploited its innate capacity,
label: Paragraph

text: when set flush with the surface, to appear as a continuous
label: Paragraph

text: membrane: to seem to be of the same metalled substance
label: Paragraph

text: and formal order as the supporting metal frame. However,
label: Paragraph

text: these two seminal works had more in common than their
label: Paragraph

text: ‘hermetic’ attitude to surface. In both instances the main
label: Paragraph

text: orthogonal volume was animated by a cylindrical form
label: Paragraph

text: housing primary service elements: the major access stair in
label: Paragraph

text: the case of the gallery, and the fireplace and bathroom in
label: Paragraph

text: the case of the house. And while the schema of the Glass
label: Paragraph

text: House - namely a circle in a rectangle - also served as the
label: Paragraph

text: essential parti of Kahn’s gallery, it was Kahn and not
label: Paragraph

text: Johnson who was to go on to elaborate the notion of the
label: Paragraph

text: cylinder as the servant and the rectangle as the served into
label: Paragraph

text: the dialectic of a general architectural theory.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: These early works of Johnson and Kahn created a kind of
label: Paragraph

text: post-Miesian space: an asymmetrical architecture of ‘almost
label: Paragraph

text: nothing’, which depended no longer on the manifestation of
label: Paragraph

text: structure as frame, but rather on the manipulation of
label: Paragraph

text: surface as the ultimate agent for the revelation of light,
label: Paragraph

text: space and support. Thus the space of Kahn's art gallery was
label: Paragraph

text: as much determined by the concrete tetrahedral space-
label: Paragraph

text: frame that constituted its floors as it was by the regular grid
label: Paragraph

text: of rectangular columns that divided its internal volume into
label: Paragraph

text: four basic sections.
label: Paragraph

text: From the early 1950s on, first Johnson and then Kahn
label: Paragraph

text: came to be increasingly concerned with reactivating the
label: Paragraph

text: formal systems of the past. Johnson’s own ‘historicism’ -
label: Paragraph

text: evident in the Neo-Classical qualities of the Glass House -
label: Paragraph

text: came directly from his understanding of late Mies and, again
label: Paragraph

text: after Mies, something of Schinkel’s Romantic Classicism.
label: Paragraph

text: The beginning of Kahn’s concern with the past is more
label: Paragraph

text: difficult to establish. Beaux-Arts-trained in Philadelphia
label: Paragraph

text: under Paul Cret but close in the late 1930s and 1940s to the
label: Paragraph

text: radicalism of men like Buckminster Fuller and Frederick
label: Title

text: Kiesler, Kahn was to return after the New Deal to a remote
label: Paragraph

text: historical tradition, through his preoccupation with the
label: Paragraph

text: creation of hierarchic order out of heavy structural form.
label: Paragraph

text: Certainly Kahn’s whole approach changed with his project
label: Paragraph

text: for the Trenton Jewish Community Centre of 1954, made
label: Paragraph

text: some two years after he had returned from his sabbatical at
label: Paragraph

text: the American Academy in Rome.
label: Caption

text: By the mid-1950s the points of reference were becoming
label: Paragraph

text: more complex, for while Johnson had shifted his attention
label: Paragraph

text: from Schinkel to Soane, simultaneously keeping his eye
label: Paragraph

text: fixed on the totally independent Baroque forays then being
label: Paragraph

text: made in Brasilia by Oscar Niemeyer, Kahn had begun to be
label: Paragraph

text: preoccupied with the concept of an architectural totality,
label: Paragraph

text: whose ultimate historical reference would prove Islamic
label: Paragraph

text: rather than Western.
label: Paragraph

text: At this juncture in Kahn’s career one encounters one of
label: Paragraph

text: the central paradoxes in the work and influence of
label: Paragraph

text: Buckminster Fuller. For whereas Fuller’s contribution was
label: Paragraph

text: posited by both himself and his followers as the only truly
label: Paragraph

text: functionalist approach of the age, it has since become
label: Paragraph

text: evident that his geodesic structural systems should be
label: Paragraph

text: regarded as evoking through their universal geometry an
label: Paragraph

text: attitude to both form and life that is fundamentally mystical.
label: Paragraph

text: It is clear from Kahn’s subsequent career that this side of
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller’s thought exercised a strong hold over his
label: Paragraph

text: development, and never more so than during the period of
label: Paragraph

text: his association with Ann Tyng, who was an ardent follower of
label: Paragraph

text: the Fuller line. The various versions of Kahn’s multistorey
label: Paragraph

text: triangulated city hall for Philadelphia [248], designed in
label: Caption

text: association with Tyng between 1952 and 1957, bracket the
label: Paragraph

text: period during which he was most directly under Fuller’s
label: Paragraph

text: influence. The basic concept of a geodesic skyscraper,
label: Paragraph

text: stabilized by tetrahedronal concrete floors - ‘a vertical truss
label: Paragraph

text: against the wind’ - enabled Kahn to return to an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural intention that would have been appreciated by
label: Paragraph

text: Viollet-le-Duc. This much is evident from one of the clearest
label: Paragraph

text: statements of intent that he ever produced:
label: Paragraph

text: 248 Kahn and Tyng, project for Philadelphia City Hall, 1952-57. Model.
label: Caption

text: In Gothic times, architects built in solid stones. Now we can
label: Paragraph

text: build with hollow stones. The spaces defined by the
label: Paragraph

text: members of a structure are as important as the members.
label: Paragraph

text: These spaces range in scale from the voids of an insulation
label: Paragraph

text: panel, voids for air, lighting and heat to circulate, to spaces
label: Paragraph

text: big enough to walk through and live in. The desire to
label: Paragraph

text: express voids positively in the design of structure is
label: Paragraph

text: evidenced by the growing interest and work in the
label: Paragraph

text: development of space-frames. The forms being
label: Paragraph

text: experimented with come from a closer knowledge of nature
label: Paragraph

text: and the outgrowth of the constant search for order. Design
label: Paragraph

text: habits leading to the concealment of structure have no
label: Paragraph

text: place in this implied order. Such habits retard the
label: Paragraph

text: development of an art. | believe that in architecture, as in all
label: Paragraph

text: art, the artist instinctively keeps the marks which reveal
label: Paragraph

text: how a thing was done. The feeling that our present day
label: Paragraph

text: architecture needs embellishment stems in part from our
label: Paragraph

text: tendency to fair joints out of sight, to conceal how parts are
label: Paragraph

text: put together. Structures should be devised which can
label: Paragraph

text: harbour the mechanical needs of rooms and spaces. ... If we
label: Paragraph

text: were to train ourselves to draw as we build, from the bottom
label: Paragraph

text: up, when we do, stopping our pencil to make a mark at the
label: Paragraph

text: joints of pouring or erecting, ornament would grow out of
label: Paragraph

text: our love for the expression of method. It would follow that
label: Paragraph

text: the pasting over the construction of lighting and acoustical
label: Paragraph

text: material, the burying of tortured unwanted ducts, conduits
label: Paragraph

text: and pipe lines, would become intolerable. The desire to
label: Paragraph

text: express how it is done would filter through the entire society
label: Paragraph

text: of building, to architect, engineer, builder and craftsman.°
label: Paragraph

text: The fundamental themes of Kahn’s subsequent career
label: Paragraph

text: are all basically outlined in this remarkable passage, from
label: Paragraph

text: the notion of conceptually transposing solid and void - see
label: Paragraph

text: the reference to hollow stones - to the idea of explicitly
label: Paragraph

text: integrating mechanical systems with the structure and the
label: Paragraph

text: important corollary that the universal ordering principle
label: Paragraph

text: (namely ‘what the building wants to be’) could only make
label: Paragraph

text: itself manifest through the revelation of the constructional
label: Paragraph

text: process.
label: Paragraph

text: The integrated development of these principles, from the
label: Paragraph

text: Yale Art Gallery to the Richards Laboratories [249] built for
label: Caption

text: the University of Pennsylvania between 1957 and 1964, led
label: Paragraph

text: to the first phase of Kahn’s postponed maturity. In both
label: Paragraph

text: works Kahn used a method and mode of expression where
label: Paragraph

text: the empirical details of the programme have little or no
label: Paragraph

text: impact on the overall form. It was in fact a case of discrete
label: Paragraph

text: function having to accommodate itself - as in the past - to
label: Paragraph

text: the form, but only insofar as the form itself had been
label: Paragraph

text: invented from a profound understanding of the overall task
label: Paragraph

text: in the first place. In the case of the Richards Laboratories,
label: Paragraph

text: the problematic aspect of Kahn’s method lay exactly in this
label: Paragraph

text: issue, as to whether or not the overall form was
label: Paragraph

text: typologically justified. The subsequent difficulties
label: Paragraph

text: encountered in using the building would suggest that it was
label: Paragraph

text: not. We seem to be confronted here with the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: American impulse to idealize the work place - to
label: Paragraph

text: monumentalize the space of process - an intention which is
label: Paragraph

text: as evident in the Richards Laboratories as it is in Johnson's
label: Paragraph

text: Klein Tower. The precedent for all this would seem, not
label: Paragraph

text: surprisingly, to be Wright, first in his Larkin Building at
label: Paragraph

text: Buffalo of 1904 and then in his complex for Johnson Wax,
label: Paragraph

text: built at Racine in Wisconsin, in 1936-39. It is an appropriate
label: Paragraph

text: irony, to say the least, that both Kahn and Johnson should
label: Paragraph

text: come to debate in Perspecta 2 (1953) the validity of
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s later addition to his Racine complex, namely the
label: Paragraph

text: laboratory tower built there in 1946. With marked
label: Caption

text: indifference to the status of the tower as it might be
label: Paragraph

text: determined by the programme in relation to the society,
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn remarked:
label: Paragraph

text: 249 Kahn, A.N. Richards Laboratories, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia,
label: Caption

text: 1957-61. Third-floor plan.
label: Caption

text: It has to do with the full complexity of making architecture
label: Paragraph

text: work in the fullest psychological sense. It works because it is
label: Paragraph

text: motivated. It fills the desires and the needs. And so should
label: Paragraph

text: the Tower work, as psychological satisfaction.®
label: Paragraph

text: Along more aesthetic lines and with greater
label: Paragraph

text: flamboyance, Johnson declared his own indifference to the
label: Paragraph

text: issue of function:
label: Title

text: It was the terrific problem of a man who wants a beautiful
label: Paragraph

text: building but the only thing he has to build is a laboratory.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright puts it into a tower. If doesn’t work: it doesn’t have
label: Paragraph

text: to work. Wright had that shape conceived long before he
label: Paragraph

text: knew what was going into it. | claim that is where
label: Paragraph

text: architecture starts, with the concept.’
label: Paragraph

text: It is a measure of Kahn’s achievement and of his
label: Paragraph

text: continuing influence today that the ‘concept’ was exactly
label: Paragraph

text: where architecture always started for him, even if he was
label: Paragraph

text: sufficiently flexible to allow the initial ‘Form’ (Kahn’s term
label: Paragraph

text: for ‘type’) to be modified by the exigencies of the
label: Paragraph

text: programme. For him, building remained a spiritual act, and
label: Paragraph

text: it is hardly an accident that his best work was reserved for
label: Paragraph

text: religious or extremely honorific structures. In many
label: Paragraph

text: subsequent commissions he ascribed a highly spiritual
label: Paragraph

text: connotation to the programme and never more so than in
label: Paragraph

text: the case of the research centre that he designed for Dr
label: Paragraph

text: Jonas Salk, at La Jolla, California, between 1959 and 1965
label: Caption

text: [250]. In this instance, the separation of the whole complex
label: Paragraph

text: into working, meeting and living sectors seems to have
label: Paragraph

text: released Kahn from the compulsive need to reduce the
label: Paragraph

text: laboratory space to an ideal form. The final version of the
label: Paragraph

text: Salk Laboratories brought him to accept a solution in which
label: Paragraph

text: the services were as ‘repressed’ or concealed as in any
label: Paragraph

text: office building by Mies van der Rohe. Kahn's provision of a
label: Caption

text: whole full-height service floor under each laboratory - a
label: Paragraph

text: provision which today is fully utilized - yielded a much more
label: Paragraph

text: flexible space than that generally achieved at Philadelphia.
label: Paragraph

text: The unbuilt Salk meeting complex was also the first
label: Paragraph

text: occasion on which Kahn had a chance to develop his anti-
label: Paragraph

text: glare concept of setting a ‘building within a building’, a
label: Paragraph

text: notion which he had first broached at a conceptual level in
label: Paragraph

text: his 1959 sketches for the American Consulate at Luanda,
label: Paragraph

text: Angola. This idea, destined to remain unbuilt even at La
label: Paragraph

text: Jolla, was to become the main theme of his magnificent
label: Paragraph

text: National Assembly Building, under construction at Dacca in
label: Caption

text: East Pakistan (now Bangladesh) from 1965 to 1974.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Kahn’s rejection of a simple-minded if socially committed
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism in favour of an architecture capable of
label: Paragraph

text: transcending utility led him to postulate a parallel approach
label: Paragraph

text: to urban form. Once again this shift reflected his own
label: Paragraph

text: development, in which he progressed from projecting the
label: Paragraph

text: Ville Radieuse onto the centre of Philadelphia - in his so-
label: Paragraph

text: called Rational City studies of 1939-48 - to postulating, in
label: Paragraph

text: his maturity, the need to make an explicit distinction
label: Paragraph

text: between the architecture of the ‘viaduct’ and building at a
label: Paragraph

text: human scale. This was perhaps never more dramatically
label: Paragraph

text: expressed than in his plan for midtown Philadelphia of 1956,
label: Paragraph

text: where he attempted to press the forms of Piranesi’s Rome of
label: Paragraph

text: 1762 into the service of the modern city. Yet for all the
label: Paragraph

text: rational poetry of this proposition, and the ingenuity of his
label: Paragraph

text: subtly rearranged traffic patterns (his distinction for
label: Paragraph

text: instance between the expressways as ‘rivers’ and the ‘stop-
label: Paragraph

text: go’ traffic-light-controlled streets as ‘canals’), Kahn’s
label: Paragraph

text: midtown planning proposals remained paradoxically
label: Paragraph

text: unspecific when it came to imagining the precise relations
label: Paragraph

text: that should obtain between the pedestrian and the
label: Paragraph

text: automobile. Kahn, conscious of the profound antipathy
label: Paragraph

text: between the automobile and the city and of the fatal link
label: Title

text: between consumerism, the suburban shopping centre and
label: Paragraph

text: the decline of the urban core (a link that stemmed
label: Paragraph

text: incidentally from the combined effects of the post-war
label: Paragraph

text: federal highway subsidy and the mortgage provisions of the
label: Title

text: G.I. Bill), was no more capable than any other architect of
label: Paragraph

text: conceiving a satisfactory interchange between the human
label: Paragraph

text: scale and the scale of the car. His Piranesian ‘dock’ proposal
label: Paragraph

text: [251] of 1956, comprising a six-storey cylindrical silo
label: Paragraph

text: housing 1,500 cars and surrounded on its perimeter by
label: Paragraph

text: eighteen-storey blocks, was as deprived as any other mega-
label: Paragraph

text: structure of the period of the necessary elements with
label: Paragraph

text: which to establish a human scale at its base. The limits of
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn's profound historicism were never more poignant than
label: Paragraph

text: in his likening of his Philadelphia midtown plan to
label: Paragraph

text: Carcassonne. It was surely a vain utopian hope to argue, as
label: Paragraph

text: he did, that the ordering of movement within a city would of
label: Paragraph

text: necessity assure its defence against destruction by the
label: Paragraph

text: automobile.

text: The effect of mass, of static solidity, hitherto the prime
label: Paragraph

text: quality of architecture, has all but disappeared: in its place
label: Paragraph

text: there is an effect of volume, or more accurately, of plane
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces bounding a volume. The prime architectural symbol
label: Paragraph

text: is no longer the dense brick, but the open box. Indeed, the
label: Paragraph

text: great majority of buildings are in reality, as well as in effect,
label: Paragraph

text: mere planes surrounding a volume. With skeleton
label: Paragraph

text: construction enveloped only by a protective screen, the
label: Paragraph

text: architect can hardly avoid achieving this effect of surface, of
label: Paragraph

text: volume, unless in deference to traditional design in terms of
label: Paragraph

text: mass he goes out of his way to obtain the contrary effect.
label: Paragraph

text: Henry-Russell Hitchcock and Philip Johnson
label: Title

text: The International Style, 1932 (exhibition catalogue, Museum
label: Caption

text: of Modern Art, New York)!
label: Paragraph

text: In many respects, the International Style was little more
label: Paragraph

text: than a convenient phrase denoting a cubistic mode of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture which had spread throughout the developed
label: Paragraph

text: world by the time of the Second World War. Its apparent
label: Paragraph

text: homogeneity was deceptive, since its stripped planar form
label: Paragraph

text: was subtly inflected so as to respond to different climatic
label: Paragraph

text: and cultural conditions. Unlike the Neo-Classical manner of
label: Paragraph

text: the Western world in the late 18th century, the International
label: Paragraph

text: Style never became truly universal. Nonetheless, it implied
label: Paragraph

text: a universality of approach which generally favoured light-
label: Paragraph

text: weight technique, synthetic modern materials and standard
label: Title

text: modular parts so as to facilitate fabrication and erection. It
label: Paragraph

text: tended as a general rule towards the hypothetical flexibility
label: Paragraph

text: of the free plan, and to this end it preferred skeleton frame
label: Paragraph

text: construction to masonry. This predisposition became
label: Paragraph

text: formalistic where specified conditions, be they climatic,
label: Paragraph

text: cultural or economic, could not support the application of
label: Paragraph

text: advanced light-weight technology. Le Corbusier’s ideal villas
label: Paragraph

text: of the late 1920s anticipated such formalism inasmuch as
label: Paragraph

text: they masqueraded as white, homogeneous, machine-made
label: Paragraph

text: forms, whereas they were in fact built of rendered concrete
label: Paragraph

text: blockwork held in place by a reinforced-concrete frame.
label: Caption

text: Dr Philip Lovell’s Health House [253], built in Los Angeles
label: Caption

text: in 1927 to the designs of the Austrian émigré architect
label: Paragraph

text: Richard Neutra, may be regarded as the apotheosis of the
label: Paragraph

text: International Style, its architectural expression deriving
label: Paragraph

text: directly from a skeleton steel frame, clad in a light-weight
label: Paragraph

text: synthetic skin. Set on a bluff overlooking a romantic, half-
label: Paragraph

text: wild parkscape, its asymmetrical composition of
label: Paragraph

text: dramatically suspended floors was reminiscent of Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: West Coast blockhouse style of the 1920s, and this formal
label: Paragraph

text: similarity already suggests the catholic sources from which
label: Paragraph

text: the supposed homogeneity of the International Style initially
label: Paragraph

text: derived.
label: Paragraph

text: 253 Neutra, Lovell Health House, Griffith Park, Los Angeles, 1927.
label: Caption

text: Almost incidentally, the open-plan form of the house was
label: Paragraph

text: an appropriate reflection of Lovell’s expansive personality
label: Paragraph

text: and served to represent his callisthenic lifestyle. As David
label: Paragraph

text: Gebhard suggests in his study of Neutra’s compatriot and
label: Paragraph

text: early partner Rudolph Schindler [255] (who had realized a
label: Paragraph

text: house at Newport Beach [254] for Lovell just one year
label: Caption

text: before), Lovell could have been regarded as embodying the
label: Paragraph

text: athletic and progressive attributes of the International Style
label: Title

text: Dr Lovell was a characteristic Southern California product. It
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: anywhere else. Through his Los Angeles Times co/umn,
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Care of the Body’... and through ‘Dr Lovell’s Physical
label: Paragraph

text: Culture Center’ he had an influence which extended far
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph
