text: The ideology of Lovell and its direct expression in the
label: Paragraph

text: Health House exercised a decisive influence over the rest of
label: Paragraph

text: Neutra’s career. From now on his work was at its best where
label: Paragraph

text: the building programme could be interpreted as making a
label: Paragraph

text: direct contribution to the psycho-physiological wellbeing of
label: Paragraph

text: its occupants. The central theme of both Neutra’s work and
label: Paragraph

text: his writings was the beneficial impact of a well-designed
label: Paragraph

text: environment upon the general health of the human nervous
label: Title

text: system. And while his so-called ‘bio-realism’ rested largely
label: Paragraph

text: on unproven arguments linking architectural form to overall
label: Title

text: health, it is difficult to discredit the extraordinary sensitivity
label: Paragraph

text: and supra-functional attitude that coloured his whole
label: Paragraph

text: approach. Nothing could be further removed from the
label: Paragraph

text: exclusively formal motivations attributed to the
label: Paragraph

text: International Style by Hitchcock and Johnson than the
label: Title

text: overall biological concerns addressed by Neutra in his book
label: Paragraph

text: Survival Through Design (1954), where he wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: lt has become imperative that in designing our physical
label: Paragraph

text: environment we should consciously raise the fundamental
label: Paragraph

text: question of survival in the broadest sense of the term. Any
label: Paragraph

text: design that impairs or imposes excessive strain on the
label: Paragraph

text: natural human equipment should be eliminated or modified
label: Title

text: in accordance with the requirements of our nervous and
label: Paragraph

text: more gradually, our total physiological functioning.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus, the primary concern for Schindler and Neutra alike
label: Paragraph

text: - both of whom had served their American apprenticeships
label: Paragraph

text: with Wright - was not abstract form as such, but rather the
label: Paragraph

text: modulation of sun and light and the sensitive articulation of
label: Paragraph

text: the screens of plants between the building and its general
label: Paragraph

text: context. This ambient hedonism was never more subtly
label: Paragraph

text: expressed than in the Sachs Apartments, Los Angeles, built
label: Paragraph

text: to Schindler’s design in 1929, or in Neutra’s second
label: Paragraph

text: masterwork, his Kaufmann Desert House [256], built at
label: Caption

text: Palm Springs, California, in 1946-47.
label: Caption

text: 256 Neutra, Kaufmann Desert House, Palm Springs, California, 1946-47.
label: Caption

text: For Alfred Roth, practising in ZUrich throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s, the essential touchstone of the International Style
label: Paragraph

text: was a sensitive and strictly doctrinaire approach to the
label: Paragraph

text: creation of built form. In his remarkable anthology of 1940,
label: Paragraph

text: The New Architecture, he attempted to show that the Neue
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit was at its best where neither advanced
label: Paragraph

text: technique nor the free plan was allowed to become an end
label: Paragraph

text: in itself. A well-formulated programme and a concern for the
label: Paragraph

text: environmental impact of detailing seem to have been more
label: Paragraph

text: highly valued by Roth than the achievement of spectacular
label: Paragraph

text: solutions in either spatial or technical terms. Roth thus gave
label: Paragraph

text: as much space to traditional techniques, such as load-
label: Paragraph

text: bearing masonry, as to advanced systems of frame
label: Paragraph

text: construction in timber and steel. And while the latter
label: Paragraph

text: included Neutra’s completely straightforward but beautifully
label: Paragraph

text: detailed open-air school in Los Angeles of 1934, the former
label: Paragraph

text: ranged from Vernon de Mars’s two-storey adobe terrace
label: Paragraph

text: housing built in New Mexico in 1939 to the 1932 Neubuhl
label: Paragraph

text: Siedlung [257] built in Zurich to the designs of Roth’s
label: Paragraph

text: compatriots Max Haefeli, Carl Hubacher, Rudolf Steiger,
label: Paragraph

text: Werner Moser, Paul Artaria and Hans Schmidt. While
label: Paragraph

text: meeting the non-rhetorical (anti-monumental), social and
label: Paragraph

text: technical criteria of the ABC group, by whose members it
label: Paragraph

text: was largely designed, the Neubuhl Estate was able to
label: Paragraph

text: humanize the rigorous Zei/enbau approach of the Neue
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit, not only through the stepped inflection of the
label: Paragraph

text: row-house unit over a sloping site, but also through the
label: Paragraph

text: delicacy of its landscaping.
label: Paragraph

text: 257 Haefeli, Hubacher, Steiger, Moser, Artaria and Schmidt, Neubuhl Siedlung,
label: Caption

text: Zurich, 1932. Site plan (sloping down from bottom to top) and stepped
label: Caption

text: elevations.
label: Paragraph

text: In featuring other equally restrained but elegant works,
label: Paragraph

text: such as the Bad-Allenmoos swimming facility in Zurich by
label: Paragraph

text: Werner Moser of 1935 or Roth’s own Doldertal apartments,
label: Paragraph

text: built for Sigfried Giedion in ZUrich in 1936 to designs made
label: Paragraph

text: with Marcel Breuer and his cousin Emil Roth, The New
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture proclaimed the maturity of the Swiss Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement. But despite its decided bias in favour of the
label: Paragraph

text: work of CIAM members, Roth’s anthology was just as
label: Paragraph

text: cosmopolitan as The International Style, featuring works
label: Paragraph

text: from Czechoslovakia, England, Finland, France, Holland, Italy
label: Title

text: and Sweden and thereby acknowledging the establishment
label: Paragraph

text: of the New Architecture (Roth’s own term) in all these
label: Paragraph

text: countries by the late 1930s. France was represented by two
label: Paragraph

text: works: by the Perretesque open-air school built at Suresnes
label: Caption

text: outside Paris to the design of Beaudouin and Lods, and by
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s proto-Brutalist rubble-walled and timber-
label: Paragraph

text: roofed house built at Mathes in 1935. Holland was
label: Paragraph

text: represented by the work of the Opbouw group (a Dutch wing
label: Paragraph

text: of CIAM), most notably by the practices of Brinkman and
label: Paragraph

text: Van der Vlugt, and Van Tijen and Maaskant. Britain was
label: Paragraph

text: accounted for in the singular masterwork of the engineer
label: Paragraph

text: Owen Williams, the famous Boots Pharmaceutical Plant
label: Title

text: [258], built at Beeston in 1932. Williams was an outsider in
label: Paragraph

text: the whole anthology since he was neither an architect nora
label: Paragraph

text: member of CIAM. Nonetheless, his reinforced-concrete and
label: Paragraph

text: glass factory rivalled the brilliance of Brinkman and Van der
label: Paragraph

text: Vlugt’s Van Nelle packing plant, built outside Rotterdam in
label: Paragraph

text: 1929. Williams’s audacious use of giant mushroom columns,
label: Caption

text: supporting bays up to 9.75 x 11 metres (31 x 36 feet) in
label: Paragraph

text: plan, gave to this four-storey industrial shed a sculptural
label: Paragraph

text: form of remarkable precision and energy. (The sculptural
label: Paragraph

text: effect derived from the 45° clipped setbacks in the floor
label: Paragraph

text: levels of the side elevation is an accident: the building was
label: Paragraph

text: to be extendable in that direction.)
label: Paragraph

text: 258 Williams, Boots Pharmaceutical Plant, Beeston, Nottinghamshire, 1932.
label: Caption

text: The one country which has always been inadequately
label: Paragraph

text: represented in any account of the International Style is
label: Paragraph

text: Czechoslovakia, and an adequate history of the
label: Paragraph

text: Czechoslovakian Functionalist movement has yet to be
label: Paragraph

text: written. Roth’s anthology did include the insurance offices
label: Paragraph

text: built in Prague in 1934 to the designs of J. Havli¢ek and K.
label: Paragraph

text: Honzik, and The International Style featured Otto Eisler’s
label: Paragraph

text: ‘double-house’ of 1926 and Bohuslav Fuchs’s ‘formalist’
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition pavilion of 1929, both built in Brno. Above all they
label: Paragraph

text: showed Ludvik Kysela’s eight-storey Bata shoe store [259]
label: Caption

text: in Prague, built in 1929 and faced entirely in plate glass.
label: Paragraph

text: Hitchcock and Johnson failed, however, to include such
label: Paragraph

text: brilliant figures as Jaromir Krejcar, although admittedly his
label: Paragraph

text: most spectacular work, his Czechoslovakian pavilion (fig.
label: Paragraph

text: 122, p. 153) for the 1937 Paris World Exhibition, had yet to
label: Paragraph

text: come. Perhaps most serious of all, they failed to mention
label: Paragraph

text: the catalytic role played by the critic Karel Teige, whose
label: Paragraph

text: Devétsil group was the driving force behind the
label: Paragraph

text: Czechoslovakian left-wing Functionalist movement.
label: Paragraph

text: 259 Kysela, Bata Shoe Store, Prague, 1929.
label: Caption

text: As in the United States, where the International Style was
label: Paragraph

text: first practised by Viennese and Swiss émigrés, in England it
label: Paragraph

text: had its origin in the work of outsiders. First and foremost
label: Paragraph

text: was Peter Behrens’s house for W.J. Bassett-Lowke, New
label: Caption

text: Ways, built at Northampton in 1926. Then came Amyas
label: Paragraph

text: Connell’s house, High and Over, built at Amersham in 1930
label: Caption

text: for the archaeologist Bernard Ashmole, Connell coming from
label: Paragraph

text: New Zealand in the late 1920s and soon after founding the
label: Paragraph

text: London firm of Connell, Ward and Lucas. By far the most
label: Paragraph

text: influential émigré to enter England at this moment was the
label: Paragraph

text: Russian architect Berthold Lubetkin, whose impact on the
label: Paragraph

text: development of modern architecture in England has never
label: Paragraph

text: been adequately appreciated. Lubetkin, who came from a
label: Paragraph

text: modest but brilliant career in Paris, brought to Tecton, the
label: Paragraph

text: firm that he founded in 1932, a capacity for logical
label: Paragraph

text: organization which has rarely graced English architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: His 1935 block of flats in Highgate, London, Highpoint 1
label: Caption

text: [260], remains a masterpiece even by the standards of
label: Paragraph

text: today, its internal layout and disposition on an awkward site
label: Paragraph

text: being a model of both formal and functional order. Despite
label: Paragraph

text: the success of their subsequent work for the London and
label: Paragraph

text: Whipsnade Zoos, Lubetkin and his Tecton team - Chitty,
label: Paragraph

text: Drake, Dugdale, Harding and Lasdun - never attained this
label: Paragraph

text: level again. Their Highpoint 2 block, built in 1938, already
label: Paragraph

text: shows a decided mannerist reaction. One is left to speculate
label: Paragraph

text: on the extent to which Lubetkin, as an architect of anarcho-
label: Paragraph

text: socialist persuasion, had become sensitive to Soviet Social
label: Paragraph

text: Realism, for certainly his essays on Soviet architecture
label: Paragraph

text: written in the 1950s reveal a sympathy in this direction. The
label: Paragraph

text: shift in expression between Highpoint 1 and Highpoint 2 was
label: Paragraph

text: noted at the time, and the ensuing discussion established
label: Paragraph

text: the ground rules for the ideological struggles of the 1950s.
label: Paragraph

text: Their central issue, that of the primacy of the formal
label: Paragraph

text: concept in architecture and the ultimate significance of built
label: Title

text: form, was touched on by Anthony Cox in 1938, when he
label: Paragraph

text: wrote of Highpoint 2:
label: Title

text: 260 Lubetkin and Tecton, Highpoint 1, Highgate, London, 1935.
label: Caption

text: Highpoint 1 stands on tiptoe and spreads its wings;
label: Paragraph

text: Highpoint 2 sits back on its haunches like Buddha. That this
label: Paragraph

text: effect is deliberate, Tecton themselves would probably be
label: Paragraph

text: the first to admit; one has the feeling that a form has been
label: Paragraph

text: imposed on the rooms (which is an altogether different thing
label: Paragraph

text: from giving the rooms form). It is as if, during the three
label: Paragraph

text: years that separate the buildings, rigid conclusions had
label: Paragraph

text: been reached as to what is formally necessary in
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The important point isn’t whether or not one
label: Paragraph

text: personally likes these formal conclusions, but whether one
label: Paragraph

text: thinks that any such rigid conclusions are expedient .... The
label: Paragraph

text: intellectual approach which has produced what we know as
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture is fundamentally a functionalist
label: Paragraph

text: approach. | take it that most of us do not need to argue
label: Paragraph

text: about that. Functionalism is a rotten name for the antithesis
label: Paragraph

text: of formalism, because it carries with it dehumanized ideas
label: Paragraph

text: which nobody wishes to defend - but interpreted in a wide
label: Paragraph

text: sense, | think the word conveys the method of work
label: Paragraph

text: underlying this movement. ... My contention is that the
label: Paragraph

text: recent work of Tecton shows a deviation from this approach.
label: Paragraph

text: lt is more than a deviation of appearance; it implies a
label: Paragraph

text: deviation of aim. It is more than an adjustment within
label: Paragraph

text: legitimate limits: it is prepared to set certain formal values
label: Paragraph

text: above the use values, and marks the re-emergence of the
label: Paragraph

text: idea as a motive force.4
label: Caption

text: Preoccupied with the need to create a generally
label: Paragraph

text: accessible modern architecture, Tecton’s work after 1938
label: Title

text: seems to have been determined by a conscious attempt to
label: Paragraph

text: assimilate the rhetorical tradition of the Baroque to the
label: Paragraph

text: rigours of a cubist syntax. The critical acceptance of
label: Paragraph

text: Tecton’s manneristic Corbusian style, as exemplified by their
label: Paragraph

text: Finsbury Health Centre, London, of 1938, gave Lubetkin a
label: Paragraph

text: position of ascendance in the British scene immediately
label: Paragraph

text: after the war, and the ten-year period following 1945 was
label: Paragraph

text: effectively dominated by the language invented by Lubetkin
label: Paragraph

text: and his colleagues in the previous decade. The Royal
label: Paragraph

text: Festival Hall, to take one of the most prominent examples,
label: Paragraph

text: designed in 1950 by a team including Leslie Martin, Robert
label: Paragraph

text: Matthew and Peter Moro, was obviously indebted to
label: Paragraph

text: Lubetkin throughout, as was the work of the young ex-
label: Paragraph

text: Tecton partnership of Lindsay Drake and Denys Lasdun,
label: Paragraph

text: whose Bishop’s Bridge housing, built in Paddington, London,
label: Paragraph

text: in 1953, extended Lubetkin’s fagadism to indulge in a crude
label: Paragraph

text: masking of reality, with syncopated fretwork facades and
label: Paragraph

text: appliqué columns.
label: Paragraph

text: MARS (Modern Architectural Research Group), the English
label: Paragraph

text: wing of CIAM, was founded in 1932, on the initiative of the
label: Paragraph

text: Canadian émigré Wells Coates, who represented MARS at
label: Paragraph

text: the 1933 Congress dedicated to the theme of ‘The
label: Paragraph

text: Functional City’. While the MARS group possessed, at least
label: Paragraph

text: initially, the necessary élan to attract the more avant-garde
label: Paragraph

text: members of the British profession - including Connell, Ward
label: Paragraph

text: and Lucas, Lubetkin, E. Maxwell Fry and the historian/critic P.
label: Paragraph

text: Morton Shand - its sole achievement aside from its ‘New
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture’ Exhibition staged in the Burlington Galleries in
label: Paragraph

text: 1938 was its brilliant, if highly utopian, plan for London,
label: Paragraph

text: drawn up in the early 1940s under the direction of the
label: Paragraph

text: German architect Arthur Korn and the Viennese engineer
label: Title

text: Felix Samuely. The MARS group naively hoped for a future
label: Paragraph

text: which, in the words of Coates, ‘must be planned, rather than
label: Paragraph

text: a past which must be patched up’; yet, unlike Tecton, it was
label: Paragraph

text: incapable of formulating a truly progressive methodology for
label: Paragraph

text: the organization of this future. Lubetkin seems to have been
label: Paragraph

text: the first to sense this lack of orientation, and he abandoned
label: Paragraph

text: MARS at the end of 1936 to become affiliated with the left-
label: Paragraph

text: wing ATO (Architects’ and Technicians’ Organization), which
label: Paragraph

text: up to the early 1950s was to concern itself exclusively with
label: Paragraph

text: the problem of working-class housing.
label: Paragraph

text: A parallel polemical movement developed in Spain after
label: Paragraph

text: 1930 under the leadership of the socialist architects José
label: Paragraph

text: Luis Sert and Garcia Mercadal. Initiated in 1929 as a Catalan
label: Paragraph

text: cultural movement, it was organized on a national basis, as
label: Paragraph

text: the Spanish wing of CIAM, under the abbreviation GATEPAC
label: Paragraph

text: (Grupo de Arquitectos y Técnicos Espafoles para el Progreso
label: Title

text: de la Arquitectura Contemporanea). Its membership
label: Paragraph

text: included important figures such as Sixte Yllescas, Germa
label: Paragraph

text: Rodriguez Arias and Torres Clave. Before the Spanish Civil
label: Caption

text: War, in the space of some eight years, these men produced
label: Paragraph

text: three major theoretical studies, including the Macia Plan for
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona, designed in collaboration with Le Corbusier in
label: Paragraph

text: 1933. This remarkable low-rise residential project achieved
label: Paragraph

text: the exceedingly high density of 1,000 persons per hectare
label: Paragraph

text: (400 per acre), without exceeding two storeys. The most
label: Paragraph

text: significant realization of GATEPAC was the seven-storey
label: Paragraph

text: Casa-Bloc communal dwelling, including duplexes, a library,
label: Paragraph

text: a créche, a kindergarten and a swimming pool - a type-form
label: Paragraph

text: that was clearly derived from the redent prototype of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s Ville Contemporaine.
label: Paragraph

text: The last significant gesture of the Spanish Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement was made under the aegis of the doomed
label: Paragraph

text: Second Republic, in the form of Sert’s Spanish Pavilion
label: Paragraph

text: designed for the Paris Exhibition of 1937 [261]. This pavilion
label: Paragraph

text: was the occasion for the first showing of Picasso’s Guernica,
label: Paragraph

text: which commemorated the aerial bombardment of this
label: Paragraph

text: Basque town earlier in the same year. Commissioned by the
label: Caption

text: Republican government, as a monument to the dead of
label: Paragraph

text: Guernica, this work was intended as a solemn rebuke to the
label: Paragraph

text: international betrayal of the Republican cause.
label: Paragraph

text: 261 Sert, Spanish Pavilion, World Exhibition, Paris, 1937, showing Picasso’s
label: Caption

text: Guernica.
label: Paragraph

text: After the Hitchcock and Johnson exhibition of 1932 the
label: Paragraph

text: International Style expanded outside Europe and North
label: Title

text: America and began to emerge in areas as far flung as South
label: Paragraph

text: Africa, South America and Japan. The pioneering South
label: Paragraph

text: African movement, lasting from 1929 to 1942, was a special
label: Paragraph

text: case since Le Corbusier associated himself with it directly by
label: Paragraph

text: dedicating the second edition of his first Oeuvre compléte to
label: Paragraph

text: Rex Martienssen and his Transvaal Group. He opened his
label: Paragraph

text: dedicatory letter of 1936 with the words:
label: Paragraph

text: It is a very moving experience to turn over the pages of
label: Paragraph

text: your South African Architectural Record. Firstly, because one
label: Paragraph

text: is amazed to find something so vital emanating from a
label: Paragraph

text: distant point in Africa which lies far beyond the equatorial
label: Paragraph

text: forests, but yet more because one can discover so much of
label: Paragraph

text: youth’s faith in it, such solicitude for architecture, and so
label: Paragraph

text: fervent a desire to attain a cosmic philosophy.>
label: Paragraph

text: By this date a close rapport had already been established
label: Paragraph

text: between Le Corbusier and the Transvaal Group, with Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier contributing a special article to the South African
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Record and men like Martienssen and Norman
label: Title

text: Hanson building houses in Johannesburg in an extremely
label: Paragraph

text: sophisticated post-Corbusian style. By 1942, however,
label: Paragraph

text: before the group could become the South African wing of
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM, Martienssen had died and Hanson had begun to
label: Paragraph

text: challenge the socio-economic validity of Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: planning, arguing against the in-vacuo abstraction of his
label: Paragraph

text: simplified urbanism.
label: Paragraph

text: In Brazil modern architecture had its origins in the mid-
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s partnership of Lucio Costa and Gregori Warchavchik,
label: Paragraph

text: an émigré Russian architect who had been influenced by
label: Paragraph

text: Futurism during his studies in Rome and who was
label: Paragraph

text: responsible for the first cubistic houses in Brazil. With the
label: Paragraph

text: revolution headed by Getulio Vargas in 1930 and the
label: Paragraph

text: appointment of Costa as head of the School of Fine Arts in
label: Paragraph

text: Rio de Janeiro in 1931, modern architecture came to be
label: Paragraph

text: welcomed in Brazil as a matter of national policy. In 1936 Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier had a direct impact on South America when he
label: Paragraph

text: was invited to Brazil to act as adviser for the design of a
label: Paragraph

text: new building for the Ministry of Education in Rio de Janeiro.
label: Caption

text: After working with Costa and his design team, Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: seems to have endorsed the sixteen-storey slab solution
label: Paragraph

text: which departed dramatically from his initial sketches. Yet
label: Paragraph

text: the final version, raised on a peristyle of pi/otis, was an
label: Paragraph

text: occasion for the first monumental application of many of the
label: Paragraph

text: characteristic Corbusian elements, including the to/t-jardin,
label: Paragraph

text: the brise-solei/ and the pan-verre. The young Brazilian
label: Paragraph

text: followers of Le Corbusier immediately transformed these
label: Paragraph

text: Purist components into a highly sensuous native expression
label: Paragraph

text: which echoed in its plastic exuberance the 18th-century
label: Paragraph

text: Brazilian Baroque. The most brilliant exponent of this
label: Paragraph

text: rhetorical manner was Oscar Niemeyer, who had worked
label: Paragraph

text: with Costa, Affonso Reidy, Jorge Moreira and others on the
label: Paragraph

text: design for the Ministry of Education. Niemeyer’s freely
label: Caption

text: planned Brazilian Pavilion for the 1939 New York World’s Fair
label: Caption

text: [263], designed with Costa and Paul Lester Wiener, gained
label: Paragraph

text: world recognition for the Brazilian movement and confirmed
label: Title

text: his own exceptional ability. Niemeyer brought Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: concept of the free plan to a new level of fluidity and
label: Paragraph

text: interpenetration. Initially planned around an exotic garden
label: Paragraph

text: court of Brazilian flora and fauna - a micro-Amazonian
label: Title

text: landscape complete with orchids and snakes - this plastic
label: Paragraph

text: concept evoked the tropical corniche of Rio itself. The
label: Paragraph

text: garden layout was the work of the painter Roberto Burle
label: Paragraph

text: Marx, whose landscapes after 1936 became a seminal force
label: Paragraph

text: in the Brazilian movement. Burle Marx exploited the Purist
label: Paragraph

text: concept of the mariage de contour in order to organize
label: Paragraph

text: ‘paradise gardens’, articulated and textured in many
label: Paragraph

text: instances with newly domesticated plants which he himself
label: Paragraph

text: had taken from the jungle. With Burle Marx’s landscape a
label: Paragraph

text: new national style came into being, based to a large extent
label: Paragraph

text: on indigenous Brazilian vegetation.
label: Paragraph

text: Niemeyer’s genius reached its height in 1942 when, at
label: Paragraph

text: the age of thirty-five, he achieved his first masterwork, the
label: Paragraph

text: Casino at Pampulha [262]. Here Niemeyer reinterpreted the
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusian notion of a promenade architecturale in a spatial
label: Paragraph

text: composition of remarkable balance and vivacity. This was a
label: Paragraph

text: narrative building in every respect, from the welcoming
label: Paragraph

text: double-height foyer to the gleaming ramps rising to the
label: Paragraph

text: gaming floor; from the elliptical corridors leading towards
label: Paragraph

text: the restaurant to the ingenious backstage access to the
label: Paragraph

text: dance area; in short, an explicit promenade which
label: Paragraph

text: articulated the space of the building as the structure of an
label: Paragraph

text: elaborate game, a game as intricate as the habits of the
label: Paragraph

text: society it was intended to serve. The restaurant with its
label: Paragraph

text: complex accessways, interlocking like the turns of a
label: Paragraph

text: labyrinth, established not only the routes but also the class
label: Paragraph

text: roles of the various ‘actors’ divided between clients,
label: Paragraph

text: entertainers and serving staff. Strong and hedonistic in its
label: Paragraph

text: general treatment, the building had a severe yet theatrical
label: Paragraph

text: atmosphere, a contrast in mood established by the propriety
label: Paragraph

text: of the facades faced in travertine and juparana stone and
label: Paragraph

text: the exoticism of an interior lined with pink glass, satin and
label: Paragraph

text: brilliantly coloured panels of traditional Portuguese tiles.
label: Caption

text: Rendered obsolete as a casino through a subsequent
label: Paragraph

text: interdiction on gambling, the building now serves as an art
label: Paragraph

text: museum. Niemeyer was well aware of the limitations of
label: Paragraph

text: working for such an underdeveloped society when he wrote
label: Paragraph

text: 262 Niemeyer, Casino, Pampulha, Belo Horizonte, Minas Gerais, Brazil, 1942.
label: Caption

text: Second-floor plan.
label: Caption

text: 263 Niemeyer, Costa and Wiener, Brazilian Pavilion, World’s Fair, New York,
label: Caption

text: Architecture must express the spirit of the technical and
label: Paragraph

text: social forces that are predominant in a given epoch; but
label: Paragraph

text: when such forces are not balanced, the resulting conflict is
label: Paragraph

text: prejudicial to the content of the work and to the work as a
label: Paragraph

text: whole. Only with this in mind may we understand the nature
label: Paragraph

text: of the plans and drawings which appear in this volume. |
label: Paragraph

text: should have very much liked to be in a position to present a
label: Paragraph

text: more realistic achievement: a kind of work which reflects
label: Paragraph

text: not only refinements and comfort but also a positive
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration between the architect and the whole society.®
label: Paragraph

text: For all that this collaboration was earnestly sought by the
label: Paragraph

text: reformist president Juscelino Kubitschek, for whom
label: Paragraph

text: Niemeyer had worked since 1942, such a balance remained
label: Paragraph

text: elusive. A singular achievement was Reidy’s Pedregulho
label: Paragraph

text: complex, built outside Rio between 1948 and 1954,
label: Paragraph

text: comprising apartments, a primary school, a gymnasium and
label: Paragraph

text: a swimming pool, the whole constituting a prototypical
label: Paragraph

text: neighbourhood unit. Throughout Kubitschek’s presidency,
label: Paragraph

text: from 1955 on, surprisingly little architecture was realized in
label: Paragraph

text: the name of the whole society.
label: Paragraph

text: Brasilia [264], planned by Costa in the mid-1950s,
label: Paragraph

text: brought the progressive development of Brazilian
label: Paragraph

text: architecture to a point of crisis. This crisis, destined
label: Paragraph

text: eventually to provoke a global reaction against the precepts
label: Paragraph

text: of the Modern Movement, permeated the entire project, not
label: Paragraph

text: only at the level of the individual building but also at the
label: Paragraph

text: scale of the plan itself. The conceptual schism that had
label: Paragraph

text: already occurred at Chandigarh in 1951, between the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the late work of Le Corbusier, determined the structure of
label: Paragraph

text: Brasilia with unfortunate consequences, at least from the
label: Paragraph

text: point of view of accessibility. Moreover, soon after its
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: city of government and big business to which the
label: Paragraph

text: bureaucrats commuted by air from Rio, and the ‘shanty
label: Paragraph

text: town’ or fave/a, whose inhabitants served the ‘radiance’ of
label: Paragraph

text: the high city. Even within its own confines, Brasilia, like Le
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: development at Chandigarh foreshadowed a critical point in
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Although Niemeyer could not return to the formal
label: Paragraph

text: delicacy of his Pampulha Casino, his command of free form,
label: Paragraph

text: deriving in part from his continual association with Burle
label: Paragraph

text: Marx, grew in its lyrical authority from the time of his
label: Paragraph

text: Pampulha restaurant of 1942 to the extraordinary ‘organic’
label: Paragraph

text: house that he built for himself in 1953-54 at Gavea,
label: Paragraph

text: overlooking Rio. At this juncture, however, Niemeyer broke
label: Paragraph

text: with the informal functionality on which his fluid plan forms
label: Paragraph

text: had been based, to concentrate on the creation of pure
label: Paragraph

text: form: to move closer, that is, to the Neo-Classical tradition.
label: Paragraph

text: One may date this break with his 1955 project for a Museum
label: Paragraph

text: of Modern Art in Caracas, where he proposed the dramatic
label: Paragraph

text: use of an inverted pyramid, to be poised on the edge of a
label: Paragraph

text: precipitous terrain. Inverted or not, this use of the pyramid
label: Paragraph

text: seems to have signalled a return to Classical absolutes, and
label: Paragraph

text: the same may be said of his work at Brasilia which, together
label: Paragraph

text: with Costa’s grid, evoked the aura of the genre terrible, the
label: Paragraph

text: assertion of implacable form against remorseless nature; for
label: Paragraph

text: beyond the order of Brasilia’s Capitol, edged by an artificial
label: Paragraph

text: lake, there lay the infinite extent of the savannah. In a direct
label: Paragraph

text: paraphrase of Chandigarh, Brasilia’s Three Powers Square,
label: Paragraph

text: at the head of the east-west axis, was assigned to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate the executive, legislative and judicial powers,
label: Paragraph

text: paralleling in content, if not in form, the Secretariat, High
label: Paragraph

text: Court and Assembly Building at Chandigarh. In both
label: Caption

text: instances, the Capitol was located exactly in the conceptual
label: Paragraph

text: ‘head’ position that had been zoned for administrative
label: Paragraph

text: purposes in the initial projection of the Ville Radieuse. The
label: Paragraph

text: ‘head’ at Brasilia, represented by Niemeyer’s twin-slab
label: Paragraph

text: Secretariat block, acted like a ‘gun sight’ marker for an axis
label: Paragraph

text: dividing the convex dome of the Senate from the concave
label: Paragraph

text: bowl of the House of Representatives.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Japan, susceptible to Western influence for over fifty
label: Paragraph

text: years, was well prepared for the assimilation of the
label: Paragraph

text: International Style, whose arrival may be dated to 1923,
label: Paragraph

text: with the realization of Antonin Raymond’s first reinforced-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete house, built in Tokyo for his own occupation [265].
label: Caption

text: Once again, it was a question of the style being introduced,
label: Paragraph

text: in its most accomplished form, by an émigré. Raymond was
label: Paragraph

text: a much-travelled Czech-American who had come to Tokyo at
label: Paragraph

text: the end of 1919 to work as the supervising architect on
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright’s Imperial Hotel. As in the case of the
label: Paragraph

text: careers of Neutra and Schindler in the States, the style
label: Paragraph

text: emerged from the hands of a Central European who had
label: Paragraph

text: been formally educated in Europe and afterwards trained by
label: Paragraph

text: Wright. It is interesting to note that Neutra, Schindler and
label: Paragraph

text: Raymond freed themselves from the constraints of Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: stylistic influence within a few years of leaving his employ.
label: Paragraph

text: 265 Raymond, the architect’s house, Reinanzaka, Tokyo, 1923.
label: Caption

text: Raymond’s own house was remarkable in a number of
label: Paragraph

text: ways. It was one of the first occasions on which a concrete
label: Paragraph

text: frame was detailed so as to recall traditional Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: wooden construction, a mannerism which was to become
label: Paragraph

text: the architectonic touchstone of Japanese architecture after
label: Paragraph

text: the Second World War. Its interior was equally in advance of
label: Paragraph

text: its time by the standards of the International Style, since
label: Paragraph

text: Raymond made one of the earliest uses of cantilevered
label: Paragraph

text: tubular steel furniture, antedating the pioneering chairs of
label: Paragraph

text: Mart Stam and Marcel Breuer. The house itself was detailed
label: Paragraph

text: with metal fenestration and tubular steel trellises. At the
label: Caption

text: same time, Raymond attempted to integrate into its form
label: Paragraph

text: elements taken straight from the local vernacular, such as
label: Paragraph

text: the use of rope rain leaders instead of traditional Western
label: Paragraph

text: downpipes. Otherwise, in the profiling of its window
label: Paragraph

text: canopies, the house still recalled something of Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: Unity Temple style of 1905.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the previous brilliance of Wright’s ‘reworking’ of
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese culture in America and Paul Mueller’s ingenious
label: Title

text: use of reinforced-concrete technique, the Imperial Hotel in
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo gave no indication as to how its ponderous
label: Paragraph

text: architectural style could ever contribute to an intelligent
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpretation of Japanese light-weight construction. Its
label: Paragraph

text: stylistic affinities were closer to the isolated castles of the
label: Paragraph

text: 16th and 17th centuries than to aristocratic Shinto building
label: Paragraph

text: of the Heian era; contrary to Louis Sullivan’s opinion of 1924
label: Paragraph

text: it remained firmly removed from the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: mainstream of the indigenous culture. Nonetheless, its
label: Paragraph

text: spectacular survival of the 1923 Tokyo earthquake disaster
label: Title

text: provided a post facto justification for the expense of anti-
label: Paragraph

text: seismic structure, particularly in the case of public buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: This ‘proof’ of reinforced monolithic construction enabled
label: Paragraph

text: Raymond to take full advantage of the latest concrete
label: Paragraph

text: technology in his major works of the late 1920s, including
label: Paragraph

text: his Rising Sun Petroleum Company offices of 1926 and his
label: Paragraph

text: elaborate and highly mannered Tokyo Golf Club, built
label: Caption

text: outside the capital in 1930. At this juncture Raymond seems
label: Paragraph

text: to have shifted his stylistic allegiance to Auguste Perret,
label: Paragraph

text: apparently sensing that an appropriate syntax for exposed
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete was hardly to be found in Wright.
label: Paragraph

text: With the Akaboshi and Fukui houses of 1933-35,
label: Paragraph

text: Raymond and his wife Noemi Pernessin reached the high
label: Paragraph

text: point of their early career in the service of an arriviste
label: Paragraph

text: industrialist class. Together they determined the design of
label: Paragraph

text: everything from the building itself to its furnishings and
label: Paragraph

text: fabrics. In these years, they produced a whole series of
label: Paragraph

text: houses for different members of the Akaboshi family, loosely
label: Paragraph

text: attempting to integrate their own rather tasteful furniture
label: Paragraph

text: with the severity of the traditional tatam/ floor and the
label: Paragraph

text: implacable surface of the shoji screen. Their unique
label: Paragraph

text: Eurasian style seems to have reached its apotheosis in a
label: Paragraph

text: house and bathing facility that the Raymonds designed for
label: Paragraph

text: the Fukui family at Atami Bay in 1935, where they
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpreted traditional forms in such a way as to liberate
label: Paragraph

text: themselves finally from the influence of both Wright and
label: Paragraph

text: Perret.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1926, a relatively independent Japanese movement
label: Paragraph

text: began to develop around the Japanese Secession Group,
label: Paragraph

text: which included among its early members Mamoru Yamada,
label: Paragraph

text: who designed the Central Telephone Office in Tokyo in 1926,
label: Paragraph

text: and Tetsuro Yoshida, who designed the Tokyo General Post
label: Paragraph

text: Office in 1931. At the same time, those of an even younger
label: Paragraph

text: generation, such as Kunio Mayekawa and Junzo Yoshimura,
label: Paragraph

text: began either to work for Raymond or to study abroad. A
label: Paragraph

text: number of Japanese even ended up by studying at the
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus in the late 1920s, while others such as Mayekawa
label: Paragraph

text: and Junzo Sakakura worked for Le Corbusier. Sakakura even
label: Paragraph

text: managed to complete his European experience with a work
label: Paragraph

text: of international importance, the Japanese Pavilion at the
label: Paragraph

text: Paris Exhibition of 1937, in which the architectonic order of
label: Paragraph

text: the traditional teahouse was reinterpreted in modern, not to
label: Paragraph

text: say Corbusian, terms. Sakakura’s open-space planning,
label: Paragraph

text: together with the clear articulation of his structure and its
label: Paragraph

text: ramped interconnection of exterior and interior space, bore
label: Paragraph

text: but a distant resemblance to the spatial order of traditional
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: A more restrained interpretation of tradition informed the
label: Paragraph

text: domestic practice of Isoya Yoshida, while against such
label: Paragraph

text: conservatism stood the conceptual boldness of men such as
label: Paragraph

text: Rentchitchiro Kavakita whose entry for the Soviet Kharkov
label: Title

text: Theatre competition of 1931 [266] was far removed from
label: Paragraph

text: the received modernism of the period; that is to say, it was
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: from the Japanese tradition. It was primarily concerned with
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Tange, a former assistant of Mayekawa, began his career
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Where Tokyo City Hall was a meticulous but nonetheless
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: International Style. This work, for all its historicism and its
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: could be farther apart than Niemeyer’s Three Powers Square
label: Paragraph

text: in Brasilia, with its simplistic Classicism, and Tange’s
label: Paragraph

text: Kagawa Prefecture, with its extraordinarily articulate
label: Paragraph

text: detailing. That he was acutely aware of the energy released
label: Paragraph

text: by the intense industrial development of Japan and of the
label: Paragraph

text: ambivalent role to be played by tradition in relation to this
label: Paragraph

text: socially ‘liberating’ force is born out by Tange’s incisive and
label: Paragraph

text: optimistic analysis made at the time of the Kagawa
label: Paragraph

text: Prefecture’s completion:

label: Caption

text: plan.
label: Paragraph

text: Until only very recently, Japan was constantly under the
label: Paragraph

text: control of an absolute state, and the cultural energy of the
label: Paragraph

text: people as a whole - the energy with which they might have
label: Paragraph

text: created new forms - was confined and suppressed. This was
label: Paragraph

text: especially true in the Tokugawa period, when the
label: Paragraph

text: government strove relentlessly to prevent social change.
label: Paragraph

text: Only in our own times has the energy of which | speak
label: Paragraph

text: begun to be released. It is still working in a confused
label: Paragraph

text: medium, and much remains to be done before real order is
label: Paragraph

text: achieved, but it is certain that this energy will do much to
label: Paragraph

text: convert Japanese tradition into something new and
label: Paragraph

text: creative.®
label: Paragraph

text: The older generation, the men born at the turn of the
label: Paragraph

text: century, such as Mayekawa and Sakakura, continued to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: theoretical work effectively challenging the whole
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: of Modern Art by Sakakura (1951) and the Harumi
label: Paragraph

text: Apartments, Tokyo [269], by Mayekawa (1957), were hybrid
label: Paragraph

text: works revealing a certain cultural dependency: the one
label: Paragraph

text: being truly Neo-Classical in a cross-cultural sense, the other
label: Paragraph

text: being derived from Le Corbusier's Unité d’Habitation at
label: Paragraph

text: Marseilles. Where Tange was ultimately to lose any sense of
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: proposal of 1961, Mayekawa was to make a bold attempt to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the Harumi apartment block, like the synthetic lifestyle it
label: Paragraph

text: was intended to house, could be, at best, only a qualified
label: Paragraph

text: success seems to have been acknowledged by Mayekawa
label: Paragraph

text: himself when in 1965, in an essay entitled Thoughts on
label: Paragraph

text: Civilization in Architecture, he came to the sobering
label: Paragraph

text: conclusion that:
label: Paragraph

text: 269 Mayekawa, Harumi Apartments, Tokyo, 1957.
label: Caption

text: Modern architecture is and must be squarely based on the
label: Paragraph

text: solid achievements of modern science, technology, and
label: Title

text: engineering. Why then does it so often tend to become
label: Paragraph

text: something inhuman? | believe that one of the main reasons
label: Paragraph

text: is that it is not always created merely to satisfy human
label: Paragraph

text: requirements, but rather for some other reason, such as the
label: Paragraph

text: profit motive. Or an attempt is made to cramp the
label: Paragraph

text: architecture into the framework of some budget formulated
label: Paragraph

text: by the mechanical operations of a powerful bureaucratic
label: Paragraph

text: system of the modern state, this budget having nothing to
label: Paragraph

text: do with human considerations. Another possibility is that
label: Paragraph

text: inhuman elements may be contained within science,
label: Paragraph

text: technology, and engineering themselves. When man
label: Paragraph

text: attempts to understand a certain phenomenon, science
label: Paragraph

text: analyses it, breaking it down into the simplest possible
label: Paragraph

text: elements. Thus, in structural engineering when one
label: Paragraph

text: attempts to understand a certain phenomenon, the methods
label: Paragraph

text: adopted are those of simplification and abstraction. The
label: Paragraph

text: question arises of whether the use of such methods may not
label: Paragraph

text: cause a departure from human realities ... Modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture must recall its rudiments, its initial principles as
label: Paragraph

text: a human architecture. Whereas science and engineering are
label: Paragraph

text: the products of human brains, the modern architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: the modern cities which are built by them tend to become
label: Paragraph

text: inhuman. That which has beclouded the rudimentary
label: Paragraph

text: principles of modern architecture, that which is distorting its
label: Paragraph

text: sense of mission is today’s ethical system regulating human
label: Paragraph

text: action, and the system of value judgments concealed
label: Title

text: behind this ethical system. These ethical and value criteria
label: Paragraph

text: are the forces which are moving modern civilization but are
label: Paragraph

text: also obliterating human dignity and making a mockery of
label: Paragraph

text: the Declaration of Human Rights. The conclusion of the
label: Paragraph

text: tragedy is by no means simple. We must go back to the
label: Paragraph

text: beginnings of Western civilization and discover whether the
label: Paragraph

text: power to bring about such an ethical revolution can really
label: Paragraph

text: be found in the inventory of Western civilization itself. If not,
label: Paragraph

text: then we must seek it, together with Toynbee, in the Orient,
label: Paragraph

text: or perhaps in Japan.9
label: Caption

text: With this paradoxical proposition, that traditional
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese culture may yet in its essence survive as the one
label: Paragraph

text: force capable of redeeming the technocratic excesses of the
label: Paragraph

text: West, the era of the International Style was brought to its
label: Paragraph

text: definitive close, not only in Japan but through out the rest of
label: Paragraph

text: the world.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph
