text: essence of British culture. This humanized version of the
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Movement even came to be propagated under the
label: Paragraph

text: title of ‘The New Humanism’ by the editorial of The
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Review.
label: Paragraph

text: The Festival of Britain in 1951 served to give this
label: Paragraph

text: undemanding cultural policy a progressive and modern
label: Title

text: dimension by parodying the heroic iconography of the
label: Paragraph

text: Soviet Constructivists. Its two most potent symbols, the
label: Paragraph

text: Skylon by Philip Powell and John Hidalgo Moya, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Dome of Discovery by Ralph Tubbs, represented nothing
label: Paragraph

text: more consequential through their structural rhetoric than
label: Paragraph

text: the ‘circus’ of life for which presumably the ‘bread’ was soon
label: Paragraph

text: to be provided. It was not that the exhibition was not
label: Paragraph

text: without content, but that its content was presented in a
label: Paragraph

text: gratuitious manner.
label: Paragraph

text: While the work of Edman and Holm may have sparked
label: Paragraph

text: the invention of the term ‘New Brutalism’, it was in England
label: Paragraph

text: rather than Sweden that the radical reaction that it denotes
label: Paragraph

text: first arose. The gratifying populism of the Festival of Britain
label: Paragraph

text: was rejected outright by Alison and Peter Smithson, the
label: Paragraph

text: initial proponents of the Brutalist ethos, who counted among
label: Paragraph

text: their sympathizers and colleagues many of the immediate
label: Paragraph

text: post-war generation, including Alan Colquhoun, William
label: Paragraph

text: Howell, Colin St John Wilson and Peter Carter, all of whom
label: Paragraph

text: were working in the early 1950s for the LCC Architects’
label: Paragraph

text: Department without subscribing to the ‘Swedish line’. Of
label: Paragraph

text: this situation Reyner Banham observed:
label: Paragraph

text: The negative aspect of the younger generation’s attitude
label: Title

text: may best be summed up in the exasperated statement by
label: Paragraph

text: James Stirling: ‘Let's face it, William Morris was a Swede!’
label: Title

text: The factual accuracy of this statement need not detain us
label: Paragraph

text: here: it is its emotional truth as a total rejection of the style
label: Paragraph

text: of all forms of Welfare architecture that is of consequence.
label: Paragraph

text: The William Morris revival or People’s Detailing or whatever
label: Title

text: term was commonly employed to satirise attempts to revive
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth-century brick-building techniques, complete with
label: Paragraph

text: small shoulder-arched windows, etc., was occasionally
label: Paragraph

text: dignified by the grandiose title of ‘The New Humanism’,
label: Paragraph

text: which was in itself a reworking of a title invented (by The
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Review) for the Swedish retreat from Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture: The New Empiricism.?
label: Paragraph

text: Inasmuch as Brutalism embraced an identifiable
label: Paragraph

text: Palladian tendency, the Brutalist response to the New
label: Paragraph

text: Humanism of The Architectural Review was to assert the old
label: Paragraph

text: Humanism, that had in any event always been latent in the
label: Paragraph

text: pre-war Modern Movement. The 1949 publication of Rudolf
label: Paragraph

text: Wittkower’s Architectural Principles in the Age of Humanism
label: Title

text: had the unexpected effect of engaging the interest of the
label: Paragraph

text: rising generation in the methodology and aims of Palladio.
label: Paragraph

text: On another level the Brutalists responded to the challenge
label: Paragraph

text: of ‘people’s detailing’ by making a direct reference to the
label: Paragraph

text: socio-anthropological roots of popular culture, while
label: Paragraph

text: rejecting outright the petit-bourgeois respectability of
label: Paragraph

text: Swedish empiricism. This anthropological aestheticism
label: Paragraph

text: (closely related as an impulse to the painter Jean Dubuffet’s
label: Paragraph

text: anti-art cult of art brut) brought the Smithsons into contact
label: Paragraph

text: in the early 1950s with the remarkable personalities of the
label: Paragraph

text: photographer Nigel Henderson and the sculptor Eduardo
label: Title

text: Paolozzi, from both of whom Brutalism derived much of its
label: Paragraph

text: existential character.
label: Paragraph

text: The years 1951-54 were crucial to the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: formation of this sensibility. Already heavily involved with
label: Paragraph

text: the realization of their Palladian-cum-Miesian school [270]
label: Caption

text: designed for Hunstanton in Norfolk in 1949 and completed
label: Caption

text: some five years later, the Smithsons followed their early
label: Paragraph

text: success with a sequence of highly original competition
label: Paragraph

text: entries - projects which, as Banham has remarked, can only
label: Paragraph

text: be seen as attempts to invent a totally ‘other’ kind of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Indeed, what little Palladianism there is left in
label: Paragraph

text: their projects of this period is heavily mediated, from their
label: Paragraph

text: Coventry Cathedral of 1951 to their Golden Lane housing,
label: Paragraph

text: London, of 1952, or their equally remarkable Sheffield
label: Paragraph

text: University extension [271] of the following year. If anything,
label: Paragraph

text: these projects are ‘Constructivist’ in their affinities, although
label: Paragraph

text: their restrained structural rhetoric seems in retrospect to
label: Paragraph

text: have been of Japanese rather than Russian persuasion. That
label: Paragraph

text: the failure to premiate any of these designs was a loss to
label: Paragraph

text: English architectural culture may be judged from the
label: Paragraph

text: absolute banality of the structures that were eventually
label: Paragraph

text: erected in their place.
label: Paragraph

text: 270 Alison and Peter Smithson, Secondary School, Hunstanton, Norfolk, 1949-
label: Caption

text: 271 Alison and Peter Smithson, Sheffield University extension, 1953.
label: Caption

text: The underlying ethos of the original Brutalist sensibility -
label: Paragraph

text: the cryptic element that transcended its Palladianism - first
label: Paragraph

text: came to public notice with the ‘Parallel of Life and Art’
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition, staged at the Institute of Contemporary Arts,
label: Caption

text: London, in 1953. This show comprised a didactic collection
label: Paragraph

text: of photographs assembled and annotated by Henderson,
label: Paragraph

text: Paolozzi and the Smithsons. Drawn from news photos and
label: Caption

text: arcane archaeological, anthropological and zoological
label: Title

text: sources, many of these images ‘offered scenes of violence
label: Paragraph

text: and distorted or anti-aesthetic views of the human figure,
label: Paragraph

text: and all had a coarse grainy texture which was clearly
label: Paragraph

text: regarded by the collaborators as one of their main virtues’.
label: Paragraph

text: There was something decidedly existential about an
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition that insisted on viewing the world as a landscape
label: Paragraph

text: laid waste by war, decay and disease - beneath whose
label: Paragraph

text: ashen layers one could still find traces of life, albeit
label: Paragraph

text: microscopic, pulsating within the ruins. Henderson, writing
label: Caption

text: of his work in this period, stated: ‘I feel happiest among
label: Paragraph

text: discarded things, vituperative fragments, cast casually from
label: Paragraph

text: life, with the fizz of vitality still about them. There is an irony
label: Paragraph

text: in this and it forms at least a partial symbol for an artist’s
label: Paragraph

text: activity.’
label: Paragraph

text: That this was the underlying motivation of Brutalism in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1950s was not lost on the visitors to ‘This Is Tomorrow’,
label: Paragraph

text: a show staged in 1956 by the ICA Independent Group at the
label: Paragraph

text: Whitechapel Art Gallery, under the leadership of Lawrence
label: Caption

text: Alloway. For this exhibition, the Smithsons, once again in
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration with Henderson and Paolozzi, designed a
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic temenos - a metaphorical shed in an equally
label: Paragraph

text: metaphorical backyard, an ironic reinterpretation of
label: Paragraph

text: Laugier’s primitive hut of 1753 in terms of the backyard
label: Paragraph

text: reality of Bethnal Green, London, about which Banham
label: Caption

text: remarked:
label: Title

text: One could not help feeling that this particular garden shed,
label: Paragraph

text: with its rusted bicycle wheels, a battered trumpet and other
label: Paragraph

text: homely junk, had been excavated after an atomic holocaust,
label: Paragraph

text: and discovered to be part of [a] European tradition of site
label: Paragraph

text: planning that went back to archaic Greece and beyond.?
label: Paragraph

text: But this gesture was by no means entirely retrospective,
label: Paragraph

text: for within this cryptic and almost casual metaphor of the
label: Paragraph

text: shed the distant past and the immediate future fused into
label: Paragraph

text: one. Thus the pavilion patio was furnished not only with an
label: Paragraph

text: old wheel and a toy aeroplane but also with a television set.
label: Paragraph

text: In brief, within a decayed and ravaged (i.e. bombed-out)
label: Paragraph

text: urban fabric, the ‘affluence’ of a mobile consumerism was
label: Paragraph

text: already being envisaged, and moreover welcomed, as the
label: Paragraph

text: life substance of a new industrial vernacular. Richard
label: Caption

text: Hamilton’s ironic collage for this exhibition, entitled just
label: Paragraph

text: what is it that makes today’s homes so different, so
label: Paragraph

text: appealing, not only inaugurated Pop culture but also
label: Paragraph

text: crystallized the domestic image of the Brutalist sensibility.
label: Paragraph

text: The Smithsons’ ‘House of the Future’, exhibited at the Daily
label: Caption

text: Mail |deal Home Exhibition in 1956, was evidently intended
label: Paragraph

text: as the ideal home for Hamilton’s muscle-bound ‘punch-bag’
label: Paragraph

text: natural man and his curvaceous companion.
label: Paragraph

text: Split between a sympathy for old-fashioned working-class
label: Paragraph

text: solidarity and the promise of consumerism, the Smithsons
label: Title

text: were ensnared in the intrinsic ambivalence of an assumed
label: Paragraph

text: populism. Throughout the second half of the 1950s they
label: Paragraph

text: moved away from their initial sympathy for the lifestyle of
label: Paragraph

text: the proletariat towards more middle-class ideals that
label: Paragraph

text: depended for their appeal on both conspicuous consumption
label: Paragraph

text: and mass ownership of the automobile. At the same time,
label: Paragraph

text: they remained far from sanguine about the evident potential
label: Paragraph

text: for such new-found ‘mobility’ to destroy both the structure
label: Paragraph

text: and the density of the traditional city. In their London Roads
label: Paragraph

text: Study of 1956 they attempted to resolve this dilemma by
label: Paragraph

text: projecting the elevated freeway as the new urban fix.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile at a domestic scale they continued to regard the
label: Paragraph

text: chromium consumer product in the crumbling tenement or
label: Paragraph

text: the plastic interior as the ultimate liberating icon of their
label: Paragraph

text: conciliatory style.
label: Paragraph

text: Up to the mid-1950s truth to materials remained an
label: Paragraph

text: essential precept of Brutalist architecture, manifesting itself
label: Paragraph

text: initially in an obsessive concern for the expressive
label: Paragraph

text: articulation of mechanical and structural elements, as in the
label: Paragraph

text: Smithsons’ Hunstanton school, and reasserting itself in a
label: Paragraph

text: more normative but nonetheless anti-aesthetic manner in
label: Paragraph

text: the small Soho house projected by the Smithsons in 1952.
label: Paragraph

text: Designed to be built in brick, with exposed concrete lintels
label: Paragraph

text: and an unplastered interior, this four-storey box made
label: Paragraph

text: numerous references to the British warehouse vernacular of
label: Paragraph

text: the late 19th century, antedating by a year the publication
label: Paragraph

text: of the equally brutal avant project for Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: Maisons Jaoul, Paris, and anticipating the various projects for
label: Paragraph

text: village infill housing designed by James Stirling, William
label: Caption

text: Howell and the Smithsons themselves, and exhibited at the
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM Aix-en-Provence Congress of 1953.
label: Caption

text: The mid-1950s clearly saw an extension of the Brutalist
label: Paragraph

text: base beyond the hermetic preoccupations of the Smithsons,
label: Paragraph

text: Henderson and Paolozzi. By 1955 both Howell and Stirling
label: Paragraph

text: were part of a Brutalist formation, although Stirling later
label: Paragraph

text: denied that he ever thought of himself as such. While his
label: Paragraph

text: Sheffield University entry of 1953 was indeed Tectonesque
label: Paragraph

text: his house project of the same year returned Stirling to the
label: Paragraph

text: utilitarian brick aesthetic of the 19th century, though this
label: Paragraph

text: work remained removed, in its Neo-Plastic composition of
label: Paragraph

text: interlocking squares, from the brutal anti-art aura of the
label: Paragraph

text: Smithsons’ Soho house. Meanwhile, within the LCC,
label: Paragraph

text: architects such as Colquhoun, Carter, Howell and John Killick
label: Paragraph

text: had begun to realize a number of Corbusian housing
label: Paragraph

text: schemes culminating in that parody of the ‘radiant city’, the
label: Paragraph

text: Alton East Estate built at Roehampton in 1958.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the fact that Mies’s IIT campus had been the
label: Paragraph

text: initial influence in shaping the Smithsons’ first building, the
label: Paragraph

text: subsequent development of the Brutalist style found much
label: Paragraph

text: of its vocabulary in the late work of Le Corbusier. His
label: Paragraph

text: revitalization of the Mediterranean vernacular, manifest in
label: Paragraph

text: his 1948 Rog et Rob project, proved seminal to the
label: Paragraph

text: formation of the Brutalist sensibility, and the Smithsons
label: Paragraph

text: followed their enthusiasm for Mies with a subtle reworking
label: Paragraph

text: of Le Corbusier’s béton brut manner: as they put it in 1959,
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Mies is great but Corb communicates.’ Similarly, the shock
label: Paragraph

text: first experienced by Stirling on visiting the Maisons Jaoul in
label: Paragraph

text: 1955 was soon outweighed by the enthusiasm with which
label: Paragraph

text: he followed its example. The close correspondence between
label: Paragraph

text: the syntax of the Maisons Jaoul and the style of Stirling’s
label: Paragraph

text: Ham Common housing of 1955 [272] can hardly be
label: Paragraph

text: disputed, although load-bearing cross walls were used in the
label: Paragraph

text: two cases to entirely different architectural ends.
label: Paragraph

text: 272 Stirling and Gowan, flats, Ham Common, Richmond, Surrey, 1955-58.
label: Caption

text: The ultimate integration of the British Brutalist aesthetic
label: Title

text: - the fusion of its contradictory ‘formalist’ and ‘populist’
label: Paragraph

text: aspects into a glass and brick ‘vernacular’ drawn from the
label: Paragraph

text: industrial structures of the 19th century - came with the
label: Paragraph

text: works of Stirling and his partner James Gowan in 1959, their
label: Paragraph

text: dormitory project for Selwyn College, Cambridge, and their
label: Paragraph

text: Engineering Building for Leicester University. Some
label: Caption

text: acknowledgment must be made here of the work of the late
label: Paragraph

text: Edward Reynolds, whose structurally expressive (not to say
label: Paragraph

text: expressionist) designs, which he made while still a student,
label: Paragraph

text: exerted a decisive influence on the development of
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalism, most notably in the Howell and Killick entry for
label: Paragraph

text: Churchill College, Cambridge, of 1958, and then in Stirling’s
label: Paragraph

text: Leicester project.
label: Paragraph

text: The Stirling and Gowan Selwyn College proposal [273]
label: Caption

text: not only introduced the crystalline plasticity of their initial
label: Paragraph

text: style but also presented for the first time the ‘front’ versus
label: Paragraph

text: ‘back’ theme that was to be typical of their characteristic
label: Paragraph

text: organization, a theme derived from the solid-versus-glazed
label: Paragraph

text: expression of the Ville Radieuse slab. Once again it was
label: Paragraph

text: Reynolds’s warehouse project of 1958 [274] that seems to
label: Paragraph

text: have been the key influence on the form of the Leicester
label: Paragraph

text: Engineering Building [275], a work in which Stirling and
label: Paragraph

text: Gowan finally arrived at their unique expression. What had
label: Paragraph

text: previously been the slab element in Le Corbusier’s Pavilion
label: Paragraph

text: Suisse was here transformed (via the Reynolds warehouse
label: Paragraph

text: scheme) into the horizontal form of a crystalline-roofed
label: Paragraph

text: laboratory block, while Le Corbusier’s free-standing access
label: Paragraph

text: tower reappeared as a vertical cluster, comprising flatted
label: Paragraph

text: laboratories, lecture halls and offices. Leicester absorbed
label: Caption

text: the fundamental contradictions of the initial Brutalist
label: Title

text: position by recombining the canonical forms of the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement with elements drawn from the industrial and
label: Paragraph

text: commercial vernacular of Stirling’s native Liverpool (see, for
label: Paragraph

text: instance, the pioneering work of Peter Ellis). All that now
label: Paragraph

text: remained of the Purist paradigm of the late 1920s was the
label: Paragraph

text: marine detailing - the deck rails, companion ladders and
label: Title

text: cowls that had been polemically illustrated in Vers une
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. For the rest, Leicester was an eclectic tour de
label: Paragraph

text: force that recalled, in its remarkable juxtaposition of diverse
label: Paragraph

text: elements, not only the work of Telford and Brunel but also
label: Paragraph

text: the work of William Butterfield as manifest in his All Saints’
label: Paragraph

text: Church, Margaret Street, London, of 1849. What other
label: Caption

text: strategy, one may argue, than the Gothic Revival could have
label: Paragraph

text: succeeded in combining Purist formal elements with the
label: Paragraph

text: Romantic imagery of Wright’s Johnson Wax complex of
label: Paragraph

text: 1936-39, while at the same time integrating such Brutal
label: Paragraph

text: structural components as the exposed diagrid floors drawn
label: Paragraph

text: from Kahn’s Richards Laboratories of 1958?
label: Title

text: 273 Stirling and Gowan, project for Selwyn College, Cambridge, 1959.
label: Caption

text: 274 Reynolds, project for a delivery warehouse, Bristol, 1958.
label: Caption

text: 275 Stirling and Gowan, Engineering Building, Leicester University, 1959.
label: Caption

text: While Leicester imposed, as it were, a 45° grid over an
label: Paragraph

text: otherwise orthogonal geometry, Stirling’s History Faculty
label: Title

text: Building [276] at Cambridge of 1964 rendered the diagonal
label: Paragraph

text: as the major organizing axis of the plan. At the same time,
label: Paragraph

text: the History Building stretched the brick and glass syntax of
label: Paragraph

text: Selwyn and Leicester until the crystalline form of the glass
label: Paragraph

text: began to overwhelm the controlling armature of the brick.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite this, it still displayed the coupled elevator stair
label: Paragraph

text: tower, not only as an articulation of access reminiscent of
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn's ‘servant’ element (see the Richards Laboratories)
label: Paragraph

text: but also as a typological device that denoted the Stirling
label: Paragraph

text: house style. This device was to be repeated in the last and
label: Paragraph

text: least successful of the brick and glass series, namely the
label: Paragraph

text: Florey Residential Building, designed by Stirling for Queen's
label: Caption

text: College, Oxford, in 1966. The major works of this series -
label: Paragraph

text: Selwyn, Leicester, the History Faculty and the Florey
label: Title

text: Building - follow one another as a catalogue of types for the
label: Paragraph

text: modern university. This typological orientation, with its
label: Paragraph

text: tendency to dismember and recombine discrete
label: Title

text: architectural elements, partly in response to empirical
label: Paragraph

text: demands and partly out of a determination to ‘deconstruct’
label: Paragraph

text: the received forms of the Modern Movement, shaped these
label: Paragraph

text: late ‘monuments’ of Brutalism to a far greater degree than
label: Paragraph

text: any concern for the attributes of place.
label: Paragraph

text: 276 Stirling, History Faculty Building, Cambridge University, 1964.
label: Caption

text: For all that programmatic demands have been invariably
label: Paragraph

text: met, Stirling’s significance to date has lain in the compelling
label: Paragraph

text: quality of his style: in the brilliant architectonic of his form
label: Paragraph

text: rather than in the consistent refinement of those ‘place’
label: Paragraph

text: attributes which do of necessity determine the quality of
label: Paragraph

text: life. Despite his reverence for Aalto, Stirling’s achievement
label: Paragraph

text: has been largely removed from the receptive ambience and
label: Paragraph

text: self-effacing sensibility of, say, Aalto’s Saynatsalo City Hall.
label: Paragraph

text: It is as though the formal mastery of his syntactical
label: Paragraph

text: imagination came to disown the critical ‘place-creating’
label: Paragraph

text: potential that he himself had once posited in his village infill
label: Paragraph

text: housing of the mid-1950s. As Manfredo Tafuri has written of
label: Paragraph

text: Stirling’s later work:
label: Title

text: Suspending the public destined to use his buildings in a
label: Paragraph

text: limbo of a space that ambiguously oscillates between the
label: Paragraph

text: emptiness of form and a ‘discourse on function’ - that is
label: Paragraph

text: architecture as an autonomous machine, as it is spelled out
label: Paragraph

text: in the History Building at Cambridge and made explicit in
label: Paragraph

text: the project for Siemens AG - Stirling carries out the most
label: Paragraph

text: cruel of acts by abandoning the sacred precinct in which the
label: Paragraph

text: semantic universe of the modern tradition has been
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed. Neither attracted nor repulsed by the independent
label: Paragraph

text: articulation of Stirling’s formal machines, the observer is
label: Paragraph

text: forced into a swinging course, itself just as oscillating as the
label: Paragraph

text: perverse play of the architect with the elements of his own
label: Paragraph

text: language.*
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 3
label: Title

text: The Vicissitudes of
label: Title

text: Ideology: CIAM and Team
label: Title

text: X, Critique and Counter-
label: Title

text: critique 1928-68
label: Title

text: 1. The idea of modern architecture includes the link
label: Title

text: between the phenomenon of architecture and that of the
label: Paragraph

text: general economic system.
label: Paragraph

text: 2. The idea of ‘economic efficiency’ does not imply
label: Title

text: production furnishing maximum commercial profit, but
label: Paragraph

text: production demanding a minimum working effort.
label: Paragraph

text: 3, The need for maximum economic efficiency is the
label: Paragraph

text: inevitable result of the impoverished state of the general
label: Paragraph

text: economy.
label: Paragraph

text: 4, The most efficient method of production is that which
label: Paragraph

text: arises from rationalization and standardization.
label: Paragraph

text: Rationalization and standardization act directly on working
label: Title

text: methods both in modern architecture (conception) and in
label: Paragraph

text: the building industry (realization).
label: Paragraph

text: 5. Rationalization and standardization react in a threefold
label: Title

text: manner:
label: Title

text: (a) they demand of architecture conceptions leading to
label: Paragraph

text: simplification of working methods on the site and in the
label: Paragraph

text: factory;
label: Paragraph

text: (b) they mean for building firms a reduction in the skilled
label: Paragraph

text: labour force; they lead to the employment of less
label: Paragraph

text: specialized labour working under the direction of highly
label: Title

text: Skilled technicians;
label: Paragraph

text: (c) they expect from the consumer (that is to say, the
label: Paragraph

text: customer who orders the house in which he will live) a
label: Paragraph

text: revision of his demands in the direction of a readjustment to
label: Paragraph

text: the new conditions of social life. Such a revision will be
label: Paragraph

text: manifested in the reduction of certain individual needs
label: Paragraph

text: henceforth devoid of real justification; the benefits of this
label: Paragraph

text: reduction will foster the maximum satisfaction of the needs
label: Paragraph

text: of the greatest number, which are at present restricted.
label: Paragraph

text: La Sarraz Declaration,
label: Title

text: Congrés Internationaux d’Architecture Moderne, 19281
label: Caption

text: The 1928 CIAM declaration, signed by twenty-four
label: Paragraph

text: architects, representing France (6), Switzerland (6),
label: Paragraph

text: Germany (3), Holland (3), Italy (2), Spain (2), Austria (1) and
label: Paragraph

text: Belgium (1), emphasized building rather than architecture
label: Paragraph

text: as ‘the elementary activity of man intimately linked with
label: Paragraph

text: evolution and the development of human life’. CIAM openly
label: Paragraph

text: asserted that architecture was unavoidably contingent on
label: Paragraph

text: the broader issues of politics and economics and that, far
label: Paragraph

text: from being removed from the realities of the industrialized
label: Paragraph

text: world, it would have to depend for its general level of
label: Paragraph

text: quality not on craftsmen but on the universal adoption of
label: Paragraph

text: rationalized production methods. Where four years later
label: Paragraph

text: Hitchcock and Johnson were to argue for the pre-eminence
label: Paragraph

text: of style as determined by technique, CIAM emphasized the
label: Paragraph

text: need for planned economy and industrialization, denouncing
label: Paragraph

text: as it did so efficiency as a means for maximizing profit.
label: Paragraph

text: Instead it advocated the introduction of normative
label: Paragraph

text: dimensions and efficient production methods as a
label: Paragraph

text: preliminary step towards a rationalization of the building
label: Title

text: industry. Thus, that which aesthetes would regard as a
label: Paragraph

text: formal preference for regularity was for CIAM the initial
label: Paragraph

text: prerequisite for increasing housing production and for
label: Paragraph

text: superseding the methods of a craft era. The La Sarraz
label: Paragraph

text: document took an equally radical attitude to town planning,
label: Paragraph

text: when it declared:
label: Paragraph

text: Urbanization cannot be conditioned by the claims of a pre-
label: Paragraph

text: existent aestheticism; its essence is of a functional order ...
label: Paragraph

text: The chaotic division of land, resulting from sales,
label: Paragraph

text: speculations, inheritances, must be abolished by a collective
label: Paragraph

text: and methodical land policy. This redistribution of the land,
label: Paragraph

text: the indispensable preliminary basis for any town planning,
label: Paragraph

text: must include the just division between the owners and the
label: Paragraph

text: community of the unearned increment resulting from works
label: Title

text: of joint interest.2
label: Caption

text: Between the La Sarraz declaration of 1928 and the last
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM conference held in Dubrovnik in 1956, CIAM passed
label: Paragraph

text: through three stages of development. The first, lasting from
label: Paragraph

text: 1928 to 1933 and comprising the CIAM congresses held in
label: Paragraph

text: Frankfurt in 1929 and Brussels in 1930, was in many
label: Paragraph

text: respects the most doctrinaire. Dominated by the German-
label: Paragraph

text: speaking Neue Sachlichkeit architects, who were mostly of
label: Paragraph

text: socialist persuasion, these congresses addressed
label: Paragraph

text: themselves first, at Frankfurt, under the title ‘Die Wohnung
label: Paragraph

text: fur das Existenzminimum’, to the problems of minimum
label: Paragraph

text: living standards, and then, at Brussels (CIAM III), under the
label: Paragraph

text: title ‘Rationelle Bebauungsweisen’, to the issues of optimum
label: Paragraph

text: height and block spacing for the most efficient use of both
label: Paragraph

text: land and material. CIAM II, initiated by the Frankfurt city
label: Caption

text: architect, Ernst May, also established a working party,
label: Paragraph

text: known as CIRPAC (Comité International pour la Résolution
label: Paragraph

text: du Probléme de I’Architecture Contemporaine), whose
label: Paragraph

text: primary task was to prepare themes for future congresses.
label: Paragraph

text: The second stage of CIAM, lasting from 1933 to 1947,
label: Paragraph

text: was dominated by the personality of Le Corbusier, who
label: Paragraph

text: consciously shifted the emphasis to town planning. CIAM IV
label: Paragraph

text: in 1933 was without doubt the most comprehensive
label: Paragraph

text: congress from an urbanistic standpoint, by virtue of its
label: Paragraph

text: comparative analysis of thirty-four European towns. Out of it
label: Paragraph

text: came the articles of the Athens Charter, which for
label: Paragraph

text: inexplicable reasons were not published until a decade later.
label: Paragraph

text: Reyner Banham characterized the achievements of this
label: Paragraph

text: congress in 1963 in the following, rather critical terms:
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM IV - theme ‘The Functional City’ - took place in July
label: Paragraph

text: and August 1933 aboard the S.S. Patris, in Athens, and in
label: Paragraph

text: Marseilles at the end of the voyage. It was the first of the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘romantic’ congresses, set against a background of scenic
label: Paragraph

text: splendour, not the reality of industrial Europe, and it was the
label: Paragraph

text: first Congrés to be dominated by Le Corbusier and the
label: Paragraph

text: French, rather than the tough German realists. The
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean cruise was Clearly a welcome relief from the
label: Paragraph

text: worsening situation of Europe and in this brief respite from
label: Paragraph

text: reality the delegates produced the most Olympian,
label: Paragraph

text: rhetorical, and ultimately destructive document to come out
label: Paragraph

text: of CIAM: the Athens Charter. The hundred and eleven
label: Caption

text: propositions that comprise the Charter consist in part of
label: Paragraph

text: statements about the conditions of towns, and in part of
label: Paragraph

text: proposals for the rectification of those conditions, grouped
label: Paragraph

text: under five main headings: Dwellings, Recreation, Work,
label: Paragraph

text: Transportation, and Historic Buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: The tone remains dogmatic, but is also generalized and
label: Paragraph

text: less specifically related to immediate practical problems
label: Paragraph

text: than were the Frankfurt and Brussels reports. The
label: Paragraph

text: generalization had its virtues, where it brought with ita
label: Paragraph

text: greater breadth of vision and insisted that cities could be
label: Paragraph

text: considered only in relation to their surrounding regions, but
label: Paragraph

text: this persuasive generality which gives the Athens Charter its
label: Paragraph

text: air of universal applicability conceals a very narrow
label: Paragraph

text: conception of both architecture and town planning and
label: Paragraph

text: committed CIAM unequivocally to: (a) rigid functional zoning
label: Paragraph

text: of city plans, with green belts between the areas reserved to
label: Paragraph

text: the different functions, and (b) a single type of urban
label: Paragraph

text: housing, expressed in the words of the Charter as ‘high,
label: Paragraph

text: widely-spaced apartment blocks wherever the necessity of
label: Paragraph

text: housing high density of population exists’. At a distance of
label: Paragraph

text: thirty years we recognize this as merely the expression of
label: Paragraph

text: an aesthetic preference, but at the time it had the power of
label: Paragraph

text: a Mosaic commandment and effectively paralyzed research
label: Paragraph

text: into other forms of housing.
label: Paragraph

text: While the summary consensus of the Athens Charter may
label: Paragraph

text: well have served to inhibit any further examination of
label: Paragraph

text: alternative housing models, the fact remains that there was
label: Paragraph

text: a noticeable shift in tone. The radical political demands of
label: Paragraph

text: the early movement had been dropped and while
label: Paragraph

text: Functionalism remained the general credo, the articles of
label: Paragraph

text: the Charter read like a neo-capitalist catechism, whose
label: Paragraph

text: edicts were as idealistically ‘rationalistic’ as they were
label: Paragraph

text: largely unrealizable. This idealistic approach acquired its
label: Paragraph

text: pre-war formulation in the fifth congress, dedicated to the
label: Paragraph

text: theme of dwelling and leisure and held in Paris in 1937. On
label: Paragraph

text: this occasion CIAM was prepared to acknowledge not only
label: Paragraph

text: the impact of historical structures but also the influence of
label: Paragraph

text: the region in which the city happened to be situated.
label: Paragraph

text: With the third and final stage of CIAM, liberal idealism
label: Paragraph

text: triumphed completely over the materialism of the early
label: Paragraph

text: period. In 1947, at CIAM VI, held at Bridgwater in England,
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM attempted to transcend the abstract sterility of the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘functional city’ by affirming that ‘the aim of CIAM is to work
label: Paragraph

text: for the creation of a physical environment that will satisfy
label: Paragraph

text: man’s emotional and material needs.’ This theme was
label: Paragraph

text: developed further under the auspices of the English MARS
label: Paragraph

text: group which prepared the topic ‘The Core’, for CIAM VIII,
label: Paragraph

text: held at Hoddesdon, England, in 1951. In choosing the theme
label: Paragraph

text: ‘The Heart of the City’, MARS caused the congress to
label: Paragraph

text: address itself to a topic that had already been broached by
label: Paragraph

text: Sigfried Giedion, José Luis Sert and Fernand Léger in their
label: Paragraph

text: manifesto of 1943, where they wrote: ‘The people want
label: Paragraph

text: buildings that represent their social and community life to
label: Paragraph

text: give more functional fulfilment. They want their aspiration
label: Paragraph

text: for monumentality, joy, pride and excitement to be
label: Paragraph

text: satisfied.’
label: Paragraph

text: For Giedion, as for Camillo Sitte, the ‘space of public
label: Paragraph

text: appearance’ was necessarily contingent on the monumental
label: Paragraph

text: counterform of the public institutions enclosing it and vice
label: Paragraph

text: versa. Yet, despite their now manifest concern for the
label: Paragraph

text: concrete qualities of place, the old guard of CIAM gave no
label: Paragraph

text: indication that they were capable of realistically appraising
label: Paragraph

text: the complexities of the post-war urban predicament; with
label: Paragraph

text: the result that new affiliates, drawn from the younger
label: Paragraph

text: generation, became increasingly disillusioned and restless.
label: Paragraph

text: The decisive split came with CIAM IX held at Aix-en-
label: Paragraph

text: Provence in 1953, when this generation, led by Alison and
label: Paragraph

text: Peter Smithson and Aldo van Eyck, challenged the four
label: Paragraph

text: Functionalist categories of the Athens Charter: Dwelling,
label: Paragraph

text: Work, Recreation and Transportation. Instead of proffering
label: Paragraph

text: an alternative set of abstractions, the Smithsons, Van Eyck,
label: Paragraph

text: Jacob Bakema, Georges Candilis, Shadrach Woods, John
label: Caption

text: Voelcker, and William and Jill Howell searched for the
label: Paragraph

text: structural principles of urban growth and for the next
label: Title

text: significant unit above the family cell. Their dissatisfaction
label: Paragraph

text: with the modified Functionalism of the old guard - with the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘idealism’ of Le Corbusier, Van Eesteren, Sert, Ernesto
label: Caption

text: Rogers, Alfred Roth, Kunio Mayekawa and Gropius - is
label: Paragraph

text: reflected in their critical reaction to the CIAM VIII report.
label: Paragraph

text: They responded to the simplistic model of the urban core by
label: Paragraph

text: positing a more complex pattern that would be, in their
label: Paragraph

text: view, more responsive to the need for identity. They wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: Man may readily identify himself with his own hearth, but
label: Paragraph

text: not easily with the town within which it is placed.
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Belonging’ is a basic emotional need - its associations are
label: Paragraph

text: of the simplest order. From ‘belonging’ - identity - comes
label: Paragraph

text: the enriching sense of neighbourliness. The short narrow
label: Paragraph

text: street of the slum succeeds where spacious redevelopment
label: Title

text: frequently fails.
label: Paragraph

text: In this singularly sharp paragraph they not only
label: Paragraph

text: dismissed the Sittesque sentimentality of the old guard, but
label: Paragraph

text: also the rationalism of the ‘functional city’. Their critical
label: Paragraph

text: drive to find a more precise relation between physical form
label: Paragraph

text: and socio-psychological need became the subject matter for
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM X, held at Dubrovnik in 1956 - the last CIAM meeting -
label: Paragraph

text: for which this group, thereafter known as Team X, was
label: Paragraph

text: basically responsible. The official demise of CIAM and the
label: Paragraph

text: succession of Team X were confirmed in a further meeting
label: Paragraph

text: that took place in 1959 in the elegiac setting of Van de
label: Paragraph

text: Velde’s Museum at Otterloo with the old master in
label: Paragraph

text: attendance. But the essential epitaph of CIAM had already
label: Paragraph

text: been written, in Le Corbusier’s letter to the Dubrovnik
label: Paragraph

text: congress, when he stated:
label: Paragraph

text: It is those who are now forty years old, born around 1916
label: Paragraph

text: during wars and revolutions, and those then unborn, now
label: Paragraph

text: twenty-five years old, born around 1930 during the
label: Paragraph

text: preparation for a new war and amidst a profound economic,
label: Paragraph

text: social, and political crisis, who thus find themselves in the
label: Paragraph

text: heart of the present period the only ones capable of feeling
label: Paragraph

text: actual problems, personally, profoundly, the goals to follow,
label: Paragraph

text: the means to reach them, the pathetic urgency of the
label: Paragraph

text: present situation. They are in the know. Their predecessors
label: Paragraph

text: no longer are, they are out, they are no longer subject to the
label: Paragraph

text: direct impact of the situation.*
label: Paragraph

text: The peculiar London cultural climate of the mid-1950s,
label: Paragraph

text: subject as it was to the influence of Parisian Existentialism,
label: Paragraph

text: not only decisively shaped the ethos of the British Brutalist
label: Paragraph

text: movement but also contributed to the Team X polemic with
label: Paragraph

text: which it was closely associated. In this respect credit must
label: Paragraph

text: be given to the photographer Nigel Henderson, whose
label: Paragraph

text: photographs of London street life were exhibited by the
label: Paragraph

text: Smithsons at Aix-en-Provence and whose perception and
label: Paragraph

text: way of life played such a crucial role in shaping the
label: Paragraph

text: Smithsons’ sensibility. That this sensibility was ultimately at
label: Paragraph

text: odds with the tabula rasa implications of Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM Grid, which was still being propagated as late as 1952,
label: Paragraph

text: must in no small part be attributed to Henderson’s record of
label: Paragraph

text: the social and physical reality of London’s East End - his
label: Paragraph

text: photographs of community life in Bethnal Green. The
label: Caption

text: Smithsons regularly visited Henderson’s home in Bethnal
label: Paragraph

text: Green from 1950 onwards and it was from their first-hand
label: Paragraph

text: experience of the street life in the area (now obliterated by
label: Paragraph

text: the high-rise housing blocks of the Welfare State) that they
label: Paragraph

text: drew their first notions of identity and association. Thus the
label: Paragraph

text: Bye-Law Street, albeit distorted by their own rationalization,
label: Paragraph

text: became the conceptual ‘armature’ for their Golden Lane
label: Paragraph

text: housing proposal of 1952.
label: Paragraph

text: For all its resemblance to Le Corbusier’s ‘llot Insalubre’
label: Paragraph

text: project of 1937, Golden Lane was clearly intended as a
label: Paragraph

text: critique of the Ville Radieuse and of the zoning of the four
label: Paragraph

text: functions of the city into Dwelling, Work, Recreation and
label: Paragraph

text: Transportation. The Smithsons opposed these functions with
label: Paragraph

text: the more phenomenological categories of House, Street,
label: Paragraph

text: District and City, although what they meant by these terms
label: Paragraph

text: grew vaguer as the scale increased. The house in their
label: Paragraph

text: Golden Lane project was clearly the family unit; the street
label: Paragraph

text: was evidently a system of one-sided gallery access of
label: Paragraph

text: generous width, elevated into the air. The district and the
label: Paragraph

text: city were understandably and realistically regarded as
label: Paragraph

text: variable domains that lay outside the bounds of physical
label: Paragraph

text: definition.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet, while remaining opposed to the pre-war determinism
label: Paragraph

text: of the ‘functional city’, the Smithsons in their Golden Lane
label: Paragraph

text: proposal became caught in a rationalization process
label: Paragraph

text: comparable to that of CIAM. For all that the ‘yards’ in their
label: Paragraph

text: Golden Lane scheme were indicated as adjunct areas to the
label: Paragraph

text: streets, it was clear that the ‘house in the air’ did not have a
label: Paragraph

text: yard that was in any way akin to the backyard of the Bye-
label: Paragraph

text: Law Street and that the street itself, now divorced from the
label: Paragraph

text: ground, could no longer accommodate community life.
label: Paragraph

text: Above all, its one-sided nature had only the capacity to
label: Paragraph

text: stress the linearity of the route rather than engender a
label: Paragraph

text: sense of place. The presence of life on both sides of the
label: Paragraph

text: Bye-Law Street had clearly been responsible for its social
label: Paragraph

text: vitality (as an early sketch by the Smithsons would
label: Paragraph

text: indicate), but the nature of Golden Lane - high density on a
label: Paragraph

text: small site - and the Smithsons’ own acceptance of
label: Paragraph

text: Functionalist norms precluded a solution that could have
label: Paragraph

text: sustained such a life.
label: Paragraph

text: From their postulation of this housing pattern as a
label: Paragraph

text: prototypical solution, one must conclude that the Smithsons
label: Paragraph

text: were largely unaware of these contradictions: they
label: Paragraph

text: proceeded to show their Golden Lane scheme, repeated ad
label: Paragraph

text: infinitum over the metropolitan area, as though it were the
label: Paragraph

text: manifest critical alternative to Le Corbusier’s Ville Radieuse.
label: Paragraph

text: And while its random, ‘twig-like’ distribution could no doubt
label: Paragraph

text: be taken as a polemic against wholesale demolition and as
label: Paragraph

text: an argument in favour of piecemeal development, their
label: Paragraph

text: collage of the Golden Lane prototype as a phantom
label: Paragraph

text: axonometric, apparently erecting itself amid the ruins of
label: Paragraph

text: Coventry, returned its authors to the central dilemma of
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM. As imposed on blitzed Coventry [277], Golden Lane
label: Paragraph

text: appeared to be as much against the continuity of the
label: Paragraph

text: existing city as the Haussmann-like projections of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s Plan Voisin of 1925. The axonometric depicted
label: Paragraph

text: the ‘edge conditions’ between the old street pattern and the
label: Paragraph

text: new work as a series of inevitable collisions. After the
label: Paragraph

text: building-out of the Golden Lane concept in 1961 at Park Hill
label: Paragraph

text: in Sheffield [278], to the design of Jack Lynn and Ivor Smith,
label: Paragraph

text: it became obvious that aside from the perimeter block form,
label: Paragraph

text: such as had been realized by Brinkman at Spangen,
label: Paragraph

text: Rotterdam, in 1919 (a scheme well known to the
label: Paragraph

text: Smithsons), there was little possibility of achieving any
label: Paragraph

text: continuity between decks in the air and streets on the
label: Paragraph

text: ground.
label: Paragraph

text: 277 Alison and Peter Smithson, Golden Lane Housing system applied to central
label: Caption

text: Coventry. (The parish church and ruined cathedral are on the left.)
label: Caption

text: 278 Lynn and Smith, Park Hill, Sheffield, 1961.
label: Caption

text: For all that Team X were committed to the multilevel city
label: Paragraph

text: - an idea stemming via Le Corbusier from Hénard’s visions
label: Paragraph

text: of 1910 - it was to the Smithsons’ credit that they remained
label: Paragraph

text: conscious of its limitations and in consequence produced
label: Paragraph

text: one of the most critical sketches of their early career,
label: Paragraph

text: namely a drawing which demonstrated that above the sixth
label: Paragraph

text: floor one lost all contact with the ground. While the
label: Paragraph

text: Smithsons were to use this sketch as a way of justifying a
label: Paragraph

text: megastructural approach, their recognition of tree height as
label: Paragraph

text: an experiential limit may well have exerted an influence in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1960s on the general adoption of ‘low rise, high density’
label: Paragraph

text: as the preferred policy for family residential development.
label: Paragraph

text: This critical awareness was amplified at the time by the
label: Paragraph

text: Smithsons’ own village-infill projects of the mid-1950s -
label: Paragraph

text: their ‘close’ and ‘fold’ houses - and by their insistence,
label: Paragraph

text: following the ‘ecological’ argument of their Doom Manifesto
label: Paragraph

text: of 1954, that ‘habitat should be integrated into the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape rather than isolated as an object within it’.
label: Paragraph

text: The sociocultural challenge of Bethnal Green was largely
label: Paragraph

text: lost on Bakema, despite the anti-Functionalism of his
label: Paragraph

text: pronouncements in the early 1940s. He was the one
label: Paragraph

text: member of Team X whose practice was hardly to deviate
label: Paragraph

text: from the site planning principles of the Neue Sachlichkeit -
label: Paragraph

text: the row-house principle of open-ended blocks of identical
label: Paragraph

text: height an optimum distance apart. Bakema’s constant point
label: Paragraph

text: of reference was clearly the Amsterdam South Plan of 1934
label: Paragraph

text: and the pre-war work of Dutch Functionalists such as
label: Paragraph

text: Merkelbach, Karsten and Stam. All the same, in the Opbouw
label: Caption

text: studies for Pendrecht (1949-51) and for Alexander Polder
label: Paragraph

text: (1953-56), in all of which Bakema participated, there was a
label: Paragraph

text: move away from the rigid principle of blocks of uniform
label: Paragraph

text: height and orientation to a more modulated layout,
label: Paragraph

text: comprising ‘swastika’ formations, grouped into
label: Paragraph

text: ‘neighbourhoods’ about clusters of public facilities,
label: Paragraph

text: swimming pools, schools, etc.
label: Paragraph

text: The Kennermerland project, designed by Bakema in
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration with J.M. Stokla and submitted to the Otterlo
label: Paragraph

text: Congress of 1959, was a culmination of this research work,
label: Paragraph

text: as Bakema admitted when challenged by Kenzo Tange as to
label: Paragraph

text: the origin of the proposal. Yet it says something for the
label: Paragraph

text: confusion of the time that both Tange and Bakema should
label: Paragraph

text: insist on Corbusian rationalism as its point of departure, for
label: Paragraph

text: clearly Kennermerland stemmed from the abstract
label: Paragraph

text: ‘neighbourhood’ concept first developed by German
label: Paragraph

text: planners such as Ernst May and Arthur Korn. Even as late as
label: Paragraph

text: the early 1960s, Bakema was still proposing an extremely
label: Paragraph

text: hierarchized form of neighbourhood planning as had first
label: Paragraph

text: appeared in Korn’s MARS plan for London of 1942.
label: Paragraph

text: Bakema did not truly come under Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: influence until his Tel Aviv proposal of 1963 [279], when he
label: Paragraph

text: used the megastructural Obus block projected for Algiers in
label: Paragraph

text: 1931 (fig. 175) as a means for giving order to the dispersed
label: Paragraph

text: form of the city. Paradoxically, this continuous superblock in
label: Paragraph

text: no way served to liberate Bakema from his deterministic
label: Paragraph

text: tendencies, for while the fiction of the neighbourhood unit
label: Paragraph

text: was given less importance, its structuring function was
label: Paragraph

text: replaced by megaforms that either cut across topography,
label: Paragraph

text: as in the case of his 1962 entry for Bochum University, or
label: Paragraph

text: alternatively, as in Tel Aviv, paralleled the trajectory of a
label: Paragraph

text: freeway spine running through the city.
label: Paragraph

text: 279 Bakema and Van den Broek, project for megastructural blocks in Tel Aviv,
label: Caption

text: It is one of the paradoxes of Team X that Bakema
label: Paragraph

text: proposed the megabuilding as the psychological ‘fix’ for the
label: Paragraph

text: megalopolitan landscape just when the Smithsons had
label: Paragraph

text: begun to entertain doubts as to the viability of such
label: Paragraph

text: structures. The Smithsons’ ‘open city’ thesis, influenced by
label: Paragraph

text: the urbanistic concepts of Louis Kahn, was first broached
label: Paragraph

text: after their initial visit to the States in 1958. In that year they
label: Paragraph

text: also designed (with Peter Sigmond) their competition entry
label: Paragraph

text: for the Hauptstadt district of Berlin. In this scheme
label: Paragraph

text: (strangely similar to that of Scharoun) they posited the
label: Paragraph

text: notion of the permanently ‘ruined’ city - ruined in the sense
label: Paragraph

text: that accelerated movement and change in the 20th century
label: Paragraph

text: were incapable of relating to the pattern of any pre-existing
label: Paragraph

text: fabric.
label: Paragraph

text: While both Bakema and the Smithsons were preoccupied
label: Paragraph

text: with the notion of ‘urban fix’ - with the sense of place to be
label: Paragraph

text: established by architecture within the ‘space endlessness’
label: Paragraph

text: of Motopia - the Smithsons, rather than continuing to
label: Paragraph

text: advocate the megastructure, opted for localized traffic-free
label: Paragraph

text: enclaves, be they the elevated podiums of their Hauptstadt
label: Paragraph

text: scheme [280, 281] or the Schinkelesque Paradep/atzen of
label: Paragraph

text: their Mehringplatz proposal of 1962. Either way round, both
label: Paragraph

text: Bakema and the Smithsons were, by this date, obsessed
label: Paragraph

text: with the liberating promise of mass mobility, whose
label: Paragraph

text: achievement they wanted to celebrate with an appropriate
label: Paragraph

text: architectural counterform.
label: Paragraph

text: 280, 281 Alison and Peter Smithson and Sigmond, project for Berlin-Haupstadt,
label: Caption

text: 1958. Above, southern portion of pedestrian net, showing the growth of
label: Caption

text: causeways above the old street grid; be/ow, escalator access to shopping level
label: Paragraph

text: and roof.
label: Paragraph

text: Of the various strategies proffered for dealing with this
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenon, those of the Smithsons seem to have been
label: Paragraph

text: the more feasible, and this is reflected in the partial
label: Paragraph

text: realization of both their Hauptstadt and Mehringplatz
label: Paragraph

text: prototypes - the one in their Economist office complex,
label: Paragraph

text: London, of 1965, and the other in their Robin Hood Gardens
label: Paragraph

text: housing, London, of 1969. Yet the sterile conditions imposed
label: Paragraph

text: by these developments, particularly in the case of Robin
label: Paragraph

text: Hood Gardens, which was as isolated from its urban context
label: Paragraph

text: as the towers of any ‘functional city’, would suggest that the
label: Paragraph

text: Smithsons had yet to come to terms with the urban
label: Paragraph

text: consequences of their ‘landcastle’ approach.
label: Paragraph

text: The essential pluralism of Team X found a direct
label: Paragraph

text: reflection in the very different approach of Aldo van Eyck
label: Title

text: whose entire career was devoted to evolving a ‘place form’
label: Paragraph

text: which would be appropriate to the second half of the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century. From the very outset Van Eyck addressed himself to
label: Paragraph

text: issues which the majority of Team X would have preferred to
label: Paragraph

text: have left unformulated, and where Team X kept its initial
label: Paragraph

text: buoyancy through a naive optimism Van Eyck was
label: Paragraph

text: motivated by a critical impulse which verged on the
label: Paragraph

text: pessimistic. No other Team X member seems to have been
label: Paragraph

text: prepared to attack the alienating abstraction of modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture at its roots, possibly because no one else had
label: Paragraph

text: had the benefit of Van Eyck’s ‘anthropological’ experience.
label: Paragraph

text: His personal preoccupation with ‘primitive’ cultures, and
label: Paragraph

text: with the timeless aspects of built form that such cultures
label: Paragraph

text: invariably reveal, dated from the early 1940s, so that by the
label: Paragraph

text: time he joined Team X he had already developed a unique
label: Paragraph

text: position. His statement at the Otterlo Congress of 1959, in
label: Paragraph

text: which he declared his concern for the timelessness of man,
label: Paragraph

text: was almost as foreign to the mainstream of Team X thought
label: Paragraph

text: as it was to the ideology of CIAM:
label: Paragraph

text: Man is always and everywhere essentially the same. He has
label: Paragraph

text: the same mental equipment though he uses it differently
label: Paragraph

text: according to his cultural or social background, according to
label: Paragraph

text: the particular life pattern of which he happens to be a part.
label: Paragraph

text: Modern architects have been harping continually on what is
label: Paragraph

text: different in our time to such an extent that even they have
label: Paragraph

text: lost touch with what is not different, with what is always
label: Paragraph

text: essentially the same.*
label: Paragraph

text: Van Eyck’s concern for transition, for the amplification of
label: Paragraph

text: the ‘threshold’ so as to mediate symbolically between such
label: Paragraph

text: universal twin phenomena as ‘inside versus outside’ and
label: Paragraph

text: ‘house versus city’, was to make itself manifest in his own
label: Paragraph

text: work of the late 1950s, most particularly in his children’s
label: Paragraph

text: home in Amsterdam which was then nearing completion. In
label: Paragraph

text: this school Van Eyck demonstrated his notion of
label: Paragraph

text: ‘labyrinthine clarity’ (see pp. 334-35) through an
label: Paragraph

text: interconnected sequence of domed ‘family’ units, all united
label: Paragraph

text: under a continuous roof.

text: By 1966, however, that which had been the cause for
label: Paragraph

text: enthusiasm became the occasion for despair. Five years of
label: Paragraph

text: intense urban development had been enough to convince
label: Paragraph

text: Van Eyck that the architectural profession, if not Western
label: Paragraph

text: man as a whole, had so far proved incapable of developing
label: Paragraph

text: either an aesthetic or a strategy for dealing with the urban
label: Paragraph

text: realities of mass society. Van Eyck stated: ‘We know nothing
label: Paragraph

text: of vast multiplicity - we cannot come to grips with it - not as
label: Paragraph

text: architects, planners or anybody else.’ Elsewhere Van Eyck
label: Paragraph

text: characterized this predicament in terms of the cultural void
label: Paragraph

text: left by the loss of the vernacular. In his various writings of
label: Paragraph

text: the period, he pointed to the role played by modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in the eradication of both style and place. He
label: Paragraph

text: argued that post-war Dutch planning had produced nothing
label: Paragraph

text: save the organized uninhabitable nowhere of the ‘functional
label: Title

text: city’. His doubts as to the ability of the profession to meet
label: Paragraph

text: the pluralistic demands of society, without the mediation of
label: Paragraph

text: a vernacular, led him to question the authenticity of the
label: Paragraph

text: society itself. In 1966 he asked: ‘If society has no form - how
label: Paragraph

text: can architects build its counterform?’
label: Paragraph

text: By 1963, Team X had already passed beyond the stage of
label: Paragraph

text: fertile exchange and collaboration, a transformation that
label: Paragraph

text: was intuitively acknowledged by the Smithsons in their 1962
label: Paragraph

text: publication of the 7eam X Primer. From now on, Team X
label: Paragraph

text: would continue as a movement in name only, since what
label: Paragraph

text: there had been to achieve through a creative critique of
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM had already been attained. Little more, in fact, was
label: Paragraph

text: now to be accomplished in the way of critical
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpretation, save possibly for the work of two men who
label: Paragraph

text: had hitherto remained somewhat to one side - an American,
label: Paragraph

text: Shadrach Woods, and an Italian, Giancarlo de Carlo.
label: Paragraph

text: The new departure made by Woods in his Frankfurt-
label: Paragraph

text: ROmerberg competition entry of 1963 [282] was a direct
label: Paragraph

text: response to Van Eyck’s appeal for ‘labyrinthine clarity’: for
label: Paragraph

text: what was being proffered in the Frankfurt proposal was a
label: Paragraph

text: ‘city in miniature’. In the place of the medieval centre
label: Caption

text: destroyed in the Second World War, Woods, in collaboration
label: Paragraph

text: with Manfred Schiedhelm, proposed an equally labyrinthine
label: Paragraph

text: configuration of shops, public spaces, offices and dwellings,
label: Paragraph

text: the whole being served by a double-decked basement
label: Paragraph

text: containing service and parking. If Frankfurt was an urban
label: Paragraph

text: ‘event’, it was certainly conceived in different terms from
label: Paragraph

text: those of the Smithsons or Bakema, for while presenting an
label: Paragraph

text: orthogonal counterform in opposition to the medieval form
label: Paragraph

text: of the city, it also embodied a three-dimensional ‘loft’
label: Paragraph

text: system, served by escalators, whose interstices could be
label: Paragraph

text: occupied according to demand. That this concept had been
label: Paragraph

text: anticipated by the infrastructures of Yona Friedman’s
label: Paragraph

text: L’Architecture mobile of 1958 in no way detracted from the
label: Paragraph

text: magnitude of Wood’s achievement.
label: Paragraph

text: 282 Candilis, Josic and Woods, project for Frankfurt-R6merberg, 1963. Model.
label: Caption

text: (Designers: Woods and Schiedhelm.)
label: Caption

text: Frankfurt-Ré6merberg, although it remained a project, was
label: Paragraph

text: without doubt the greatest accomplishment of Woods’s
label: Paragraph

text: career and is probably one of the most important prototypes
label: Paragraph

text: developed by Team X. In relating to the context of an
label: Paragraph

text: existing city and refusing the escapism of both ‘functional’
label: Paragraph

text: and ‘open’ city models, it endeavoured to put the
label: Paragraph

text: automobile in its place and to continue the tradition of
label: Paragraph

text: urban culture.
label: Paragraph

text: That this Frankfurt scheme as built out in the Free
label: Paragraph

text: University of Berlin in 1973 [283, 284] lost much of its
label: Paragraph

text: conviction stems largely from the absence of an urban
label: Paragraph

text: context. In Berlin-Dahlem it was deprived of that urban
label: Paragraph

text: culture for which it had been conceived and to which it
label: Paragraph

text: would have responded had it been built in Frankfurt.
label: Paragraph

text: However much a university may function like a city in
label: Paragraph

text: microcosm, it cannot generate the animated diversity of the
label: Paragraph

text: city proper. Aside from this, Frankfurt’s flexibility in terms of
label: Paragraph

text: Space was replaced in Berlin by an idealization of flexibility
label: Paragraph

text: in terms of technique - by the ‘poetic’ but somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: unserviceable detailing of Jean Prouvé’s modular clip-on
label: Paragraph

text: facade of Corten steel.

text: In 1964, the implicit ideology of Woods’s Frankfurt
label: Paragraph

text: scheme found its complement in De Carlo’s plan for Urbino.
label: Paragraph

text: This plan, preceded by an exhaustive topographical study,
label: Paragraph

text: devotes more space to the tactics of preservation and
label: Paragraph

text: rehabilitation than to the accommodation of new
label: Paragraph

text: development. With De Carlo’s Urbino, Team X finally arrived
label: Paragraph

text: at the complete antithesis to the Cartesian projections of
label: Paragraph

text: the Ville Radieuse. De Carlo’s concern for the reuse of
label: Paragraph

text: existing stock wherever possible has been confirmed as a
label: Paragraph

text: policy by recent housing studies, which have shown
label: Paragraph

text: conclusively that, despite the higher densities usually
label: Paragraph

text: attained, it may take as long as fifty years for new housing
label: Paragraph

text: to compensate for the statistical ‘housing loss’ incurred
label: Paragraph

text: through the time spent in demolition and construction.
label: Paragraph

text: Considerations such as these finally had the effect of
label: Paragraph

text: precipitating Team X into a realm that it had always
label: Paragraph

text: strenously avoided, namely politics. Never was this shift in
label: Paragraph

text: consciousness more manifest than at the Milan Triennale of
label: Paragraph

text: 1968 when Woods, in sympathy with student radicals,
label: Paragraph

text: assisted in the removal of his own work. Only one year
label: Paragraph

text: before, he had written:
label: Paragraph

text: What are we waiting for? To read the news about a new
label: Paragraph

text: armed attack with even more esoteric weapons, news which
label: Paragraph

text: comes to us through the air captured by our marvellous
label: Paragraph

text: transistorized instruments, somewhere deep in our more
label: Paragraph

text: and more savaged dwellings? Our weapons become more
label: Paragraph

text: sophisticated; our houses more and more brutish. Is that the
label: Paragraph

text: balance sheet for the richest civilization since time began?
label: Paragraph

text: This same theme was taken up by De Carlo in 1968 when
label: Paragraph

text: he wrote his synoptic analysis of the ideological
label: Paragraph

text: development of modern architecture, under the title
label: Paragraph

text: Legitimizing Architecture, wherein he reviewed the
label: Paragraph

text: consequences of the CIAM Declaration of 1928:
label: Title

text: Today, forty years after the Congress, we find that those
label: Paragraph

text: proposals have become houses and neighbourhoods and
label: Paragraph

text: suburbs and then entire cities, palpable manifestations of an
label: Paragraph

text: abuse perpetrated first on the poor and then even on the
label: Paragraph

text: not-so-poor: cultural alibis for the most ferocious economic
label: Title

text: speculation and the most obtuse political inefficiency. And
label: Paragraph

text: yet those ‘whys’ so nonchalantly forgotten in Frankfurt still
label: Paragraph

text: have trouble coming openly to the surface. At the same
label: Paragraph

text: time, we have a right to ask ‘why’ housing should be as
label: Paragraph

text: cheap as possible and not, for example, rather expensive;
label: Paragraph

text: ‘why’ instead of making every effort to reduce it to
label: Paragraph

text: minimum levels of surface, of thickness, of materials, we
label: Paragraph

text: should not try to make it spacious, protected, isolated,
label: Paragraph

text: comfortable, well equipped, rich in opportunities for privacy,
label: Paragraph

text: communication, exchange, personal creativity. No one, in
label: Paragraph

text: fact, can be satisfied by an answer which appeals to the
label: Paragraph

text: scarcity of available resources, when we all know how much
label: Paragraph

text: is spent on wars, on the construction of missiles and anti-
label: Paragraph

text: ballistic systems, on moon projects, on research for the
label: Paragraph

text: defoliation of forests inhabited by partisans and for the
label: Paragraph

text: paralyzation of the demonstrators emerging from the
label: Paragraph

text: ghettos, on hidden persuasion, on the invention of artificial
label: Paragraph

text: needs, etc.®
label: Paragraph

text: For De Carlo, the students’ revolt of 1968 was not only a
label: Paragraph

text: necessary culmination of the crisis in architectural
label: Paragraph

text: education, but also a reflection of the deeper and more
label: Paragraph

text: significant dysfunctions of architectural practice and theory
label: Title

text: - the latter often serving to mystify the true network of
label: Paragraph

text: power and exploitation permeating the entire society. As an
label: Paragraph

text: example of this, De Carlo cited the proceedings of CIAM VIII,
label: Paragraph

text: whose sentimental deliberations on ‘The Heart of the City’
label: Paragraph

text: were largely responsible for the ideology with which the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional city core was subsequently raped (an ironic, if not
label: Paragraph

text: cynical, procedure that did not gain its full momentum until
label: Paragraph

text: a decade later). As De Carlo argued, the Newspeak
label: Paragraph

text: overtones of this venture were not entirely lost on the critics
label: Paragraph

text: of Western society, who came to regard the process of
label: Paragraph

text: urban renewal as a euphemism for the dislocation of the
label: Paragraph

text: poor.
label: Paragraph

text: In the mid-1960s this point still largely escaped most
label: Paragraph

text: Team X members who, with the exception of Van Eyck,
label: Paragraph

text: Woods and De Carlo, seemed to prefer to ignore the
label: Paragraph

text: destruction of our urban heritage in the name of
label: Paragraph

text: speculation. The postulative capacities of Team X became
label: Paragraph

text: paralyzed at this juncture, their inventive energies
label: Paragraph

text: becoming depleted in the face of an impossible situation.
label: Paragraph

text: Paradoxically, what now endures from their work is not so
label: Paragraph

text: much their architectural vision as the suggestive power of
label: Paragraph

text: their cultural criticism.
label: Paragraph

text: Place, Production and

text: Scenography:
label: Title

label: Title
