label: Title

text: What the word for space, Raum, Rum, designates is said by
label: Paragraph

text: its ancient meaning. Raum means a place cleared or freed
label: Paragraph

text: for settlement and lodging. A space is something that has
label: Paragraph

text: been made room for, something that is cleared and free,
label: Paragraph

text: namely within a boundary, Greek peras. A boundary is not
label: Paragraph

text: that at which something stops but, as the Greeks
label: Paragraph

text: recognized, the boundary is that from which something
label: Paragraph

text: begins its presencing. That is why the concept is that of
label: Paragraph

text: horismos, that is, the horizon, the boundary. Space is in
label: Paragraph

text: essence that for which room has been made, that which is
label: Paragraph

text: let into its bounds. That for which room is made is always
label: Paragraph

text: granted and hence is joined, that is gathered, by virtue of a
label: Paragraph

text: location, that is by such a thing as the bridge. Accordingly
label: Paragraph

text: spaces receive their being from locations and not from
label: Paragraph

text: ‘space’.
label: Paragraph

text: Martin Heidegger
label: Title

text: ‘Building, Dwelling and Thinking’, 19541
label: Caption

text: No account of recent developments in architecture can fail
label: Paragraph

text: to mention the ambivalent role that the profession has
label: Paragraph

text: played since the mid-1960s - ambivalent not only in the
label: Paragraph

text: sense that while professing to act in the public interest it
label: Paragraph

text: has sometimes assisted uncritically in furthering the domain
label: Paragraph

text: of an optimized technology, but also in the sense that many
label: Paragraph

text: of its more intelligent members have abandoned traditional
label: Paragraph

text: practice, either to resort to direct social action or to indulge
label: Paragraph

text: in the projection of architecture as a form of art. As far as
label: Paragraph

text: this last aspect is concerned, one cannot help regarding it
label: Paragraph

text: as the return of a repressed creativity, as the implosion of
label: Paragraph

text: utopia upon itself. Architects have of course indulged in
label: Paragraph

text: such unrealizable projections before but, with the classic
label: Paragraph

text: exception of Piranesi or, more recently, the phantasmagoria
label: Paragraph

text: of Bruno Taut’s Glass Chain, rarely have they projected their
label: Paragraph

text: images in such inaccessible terms. Both before and after the
label: Paragraph

text: trauma of the First World War the positive aspirations of the
label: Paragraph

text: Enlightenment still had the power to carry a certain
label: Paragraph

text: conviction. Before that, at the threshold of the 19th century,
label: Paragraph

text: even the most grandiose of Boullée’s visions could, one
label: Paragraph

text: imagines, have been built had sufficient resources been
label: Paragraph

text: made available, and clearly Ledoux was as much a builder
label: Paragraph

text: as he was a visionary. What was true of Ledoux was
label: Paragraph

text: certainly no less true of Le Corbusier, whose vast urban
label: Paragraph

text: projections could no doubt all have been realized had
label: Paragraph

text: sufficient power been placed at his disposal. The 412-metre
label: Paragraph

text: (1,350-foot) World Trade Center, New York, a framed tube
label: Caption

text: structure in the form of twin towers completed to the
label: Paragraph

text: designs of Minoru Yamasaki in 1972, or the 30-metre (100-
label: Paragraph

text: foot) higher Sears Tower, Chicago, designed in 1971 by
label: Caption

text: Bruce Graham and Fazlur Khan of Skidmore, Owings and
label: Paragraph

text: Merrill, both served to demonstrate that possibly not even
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s 1,600-metre-high (1-mile) skyscraper of 1956 was
label: Paragraph

text: necessarily unfeasible. But such megabuildings are too
label: Paragraph

text: exceptional to serve as a model for general practice.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile, as Manfredo Tafuri has suggested, the aim of the
label: Paragraph

text: latter-day avant garde is either to validate itself through the
label: Paragraph

text: media or, alternatively, to redeem its guilt by executing the
label: Paragraph

text: rite of creative exorcism in isolation. The extent to which
label: Paragraph

text: this last may serve as a Subversive tactic (Archigram’s
label: Paragraph

text: ‘injecting noise into the system’) or as an elaborate
label: Paragraph

text: metaphor with critical implications depends of course on the
label: Paragraph

text: complexity of ideas involved and on the intent underlying
label: Paragraph

text: the whole enterprise.
label: Paragraph

text: In the case of the English Archigram group, who began to
label: Paragraph

text: project Neo-Futurist images just before the first issue of
label: Paragraph

text: their magazine Archigram in 1961, it is obvious that their
label: Paragraph

text: attitude was closely tied to the technocratic ideology of the
label: Paragraph

text: American designer Buckminster Fuller and to that of his
label: Paragraph

text: British apologists John McHale and Reyner Banham. By
label: Paragraph

text: 1960, at McHale’s suggestion, Banham had already
label: Paragraph

text: earmarked Fuller as the redeeming white knight of the
label: Paragraph

text: future, in the last chapter of his book Theory and Design in
label: Paragraph

text: the First Machine Age. Archigram’s subsequent commitment
label: Paragraph

text: to a ‘high-tech’, lightweight, infrastructural approach (the
label: Paragraph

text: kind of indeterminacy implicit in the work of Fuller and even
label: Paragraph

text: more evident in Yona Friedman's L’Architecture mobile of
label: Paragraph

text: 1958) brought them, rather paradoxically, to indulge in
label: Paragraph

text: ironic forms of science fiction, rather than to project
label: Paragraph

text: solutions that were either truly indeterminate or capable of
label: Paragraph

text: being realized and appropriated by society. It is this more
label: Paragraph

text: than anything else that distinguishes them from that other
label: Paragraph

text: prominent Fuller disciple on the British scene, Cedric Price,
label: Paragraph

text: whose Fun Palace of 1961 and Potteries Thinkbelt of 1964
label: Title

text: were nothing if not realizable and, in theory at least, both
label: Paragraph

text: indeterminate and capable, respectively, of meeting an
label: Paragraph

text: evident demand for popular entertainment and a readily
label: Paragraph

text: accessible system of higher education.
label: Paragraph

text: Aside from a certain subversive eroticism (the
label: Paragraph

text: biologically functionalist parody evident say in Michael
label: Title

text: Webb's ‘Sin Centre’ of 1962 [285]) Archigram was more
label: Paragraph

text: interested in the seductive appeal of space-age imagery
label: Paragraph

text: and, after Fuller, in the Armageddon overtones of survival
label: Paragraph

text: technology than in the processes of production or the
label: Paragraph

text: relevance of such sophisticated technique to the tasks of
label: Paragraph

text: the moment. For all their surface irony, Ron Herron’s
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Walking Cities’ of 1964 [286] were clearly projected as
label: Paragraph

text: stalking across a ruined world in the aftermath of a nuclear
label: Paragraph

text: war. Like Howard Hughes’s ‘Glomar Explorer’ they suggest
label: Paragraph

text: some sort of nightmarish salvation, rescuing both men and
label: Paragraph

text: artefacts after a cataclysmic disaster. These leviathans may
label: Paragraph

text: be regarded as parallelling Fuller’s 1962 proposal to erect a
label: Paragraph

text: giant dome over the whole of midtown Manhattan [287].
label: Caption

text: This urban iron lung was projected as a geodesic smog
label: Paragraph

text: shield, a device which could no doubt be made to double as
label: Paragraph

text: a fallout shelter in the unlikely event of a nuclear near-miss.
label: Paragraph

text: With comparable nonchalance, Archigram saw no reason to
label: Paragraph

text: concern themselves with the social and ecological
label: Paragraph

text: consequences of their various megastructural proposals, of
label: Paragraph

text: which Peter Cook’s ‘Plug-In City’ of 1964 was a typical
label: Paragraph

text: example. Similarly, in their obsession with suspended
label: Paragraph

text: space-age capsules, Dennis Crompton, Michael Webb,
label: Caption

text: Warren Chalk and David Greene felt under no obligation to
label: Paragraph

text: explain why one might choose to live in such expensive and
label: Paragraph

text: sophisticated hardware and yet at the same time in brutally
label: Paragraph

text: cramped conditions. Like Banham acting out the narcissistic
label: Paragraph

text: gestures of Vishnu in his solipsistic, inflatable bubble,
label: Paragraph

text: equipped with high fidelity and presumably other
label: Paragraph

text: conveniences (in homage probably to the philistine ethos of
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller’s ironic lyric ‘Roam Home to a Dome’: see p. 273),
label: Paragraph

text: they all proposed space standards that were well below the
label: Paragraph

text: Existenzminimum established by those pre-war
label: Paragraph

text: functionalists they supposedly despised.

label: Paragraph

text: cells projected by Archigram. Modelled on Fuller’s Dymaxion
label: Caption

text: House of 1927 or on his Dymaxion Bathroom of a decade
label: Paragraph

text: later (see p. 273), these units aspired to being ‘autonomous
label: Paragraph

text: packages’, in the sense that they were designed chiefly for
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: hardly critical, as the following passage from Peter Cook’s
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture: Action and Plan of 1967 makes evident:
label: Paragraph

text: it will often be part of the architect’s brief to investigate the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘possibilities’ of a site ... in other words to use the ingenuity
label: Paragraph

text: of the architectural concept to exploit the maximum profit
label: Paragraph

text: from a piece of land. In the past this would have been
label: Paragraph

text: considered an immoral use of the talents of an artist. It is
label: Paragraph

text: now simply part of the sophistication of the whole
label: Paragraph

text: environmental and building process in which finance can be
label: Paragraph

text: made into a creative element of the design.?
label: Paragraph

text: The work of Archigram was surprisingly close to that of
label: Paragraph

text: the Japanese Metabolists, who, reacting to the pressures of
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese overcrowding, started in the late 1950s to propose
label: Paragraph

text: constantly growing and adapting ‘plug-in’ megastructures
label: Paragraph

text: where the living cells, as in the work of Noriaki Kurokawa,
label: Paragraph

text: would be reduced to prefabricated pods clipped on to vast
label: Paragraph

text: helicoidal skyscrapers. Alternatively, as in the projects of
label: Paragraph

text: Kiyonori Kikutake [288], they would be attached like limpets
label: Paragraph

text: to the inner and outer surfaces of large cylinders floating in
label: Paragraph

text: or on the sea. Kikutake’s floating cities are surely among the
label: Paragraph

text: most poetic visions of the Metabolist movement. Yet,
label: Paragraph

text: despite the proliferation of offshore drilling rigs with their
label: Paragraph

text: working complement dedicated to the extraction of energy,
label: Paragraph

text: Kikutake’s marine cities seem even more remote and
label: Paragraph

text: inapplicable to everyday life than the megastructures of
label: Paragraph

text: Archigram. It testifies to the rhetorical avant gardism of the
label: Paragraph

text: movement that most of the Metabolists went on to establish
label: Paragraph

text: rather conventional practices. With the exception of
label: Paragraph

text: Kikutake’s Sky House of 1958 and Kurokawa’s Nagakin
label: Title

text: bachelor capsule tower [289], built in the Ginza, Tokyo, in
label: Caption

text: 1971 (see Kurokawa’s capsule apartments of 1962), very
label: Paragraph

text: few Metabolic concepts were realized. Although such frantic
label: Paragraph

text: futurism is to be distinguished from the intelligent additive
label: Paragraph

text: urban form proposals advanced by such moderates as
label: Paragraph

text: Fumihiko Maki and Masato Otaka, Gunther Nitschke had this
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Hollein, and thereafter his work displayed certain aspects of
label: Paragraph

text: these influences. From Archigram he took the ‘high-tech’
label: Paragraph

text: exuberance of his robot designed for Kenzo Tange’s Festival
label: Caption

text: Plaza in the Osaka Exhibition of 1970; from Hollein, his taste
label: Paragraph

text: for mixing materials with high crafted objects and ironic
label: Paragraph

text: artistic images, the latter first appearing in the Fukuoka
label: Paragraph

text: Sogo Bank headquarters in Kitakyushu (1968-71). Apart
label: Paragraph

text: from his penchant for elaborate interior finishes, Isozaki was
label: Paragraph

text: inspired, like Kahn, by the architecture parlante of Ledoux.
label: Paragraph

text: Taking Ledoux’s emblematic Neoplatonic geometry as his
label: Paragraph

text: point of departure, Isozaki pursued a gridded high-tech
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in a series of branch banks designed in the
label: Paragraph

text: early 1970s, culminating in the magnum opus of the Gunma
label: Paragraph

text: Museum. With this miragelike, scintillating architecture
label: Paragraph

text: Isozaki attempted to compensate for the loss of the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional Japanese ‘space of darkness’ - the dimly lit,
label: Paragraph

text: recessive domestic interior which Junichiro Tanizaki had
label: Paragraph

text: been among the first to lament, in his essay ‘In Praise of
label: Paragraph

text: Shadows’ (1933). Sympathetic with Tanizaki’s evaluation of
label: Paragraph

text: the underlit interiors of traditional Japanese buildings but
label: Paragraph

text: unable to accept the reactionary implications of his cultural
label: Paragraph

text: nostalgia, Isozaki attempted to evolve a modern equivalent
label: Paragraph

text: for this traditional illusionistic space. This development
label: Paragraph

text: reached its peak in the Nagamsami Home Bank (1971), of
label: Paragraph

text: which he wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: This building has almost no form; it is merely a gray
label: Paragraph

text: expanse. The multi-level grid guides one’s lines of sight but
label: Paragraph

text: does not focus them on anything in particular. At first
label: Paragraph

text: encounter, the vague gray expanse seems impossible to
label: Paragraph

text: decipher and utterly odd. The multi-level lattice disperses
label: Paragraph

text: vision throughout the space, much as various images might
label: Paragraph

text: be thrown around an area from a central projector. It
label: Paragraph

text: absorbs all individual spaces that establish strict order. It
label: Paragraph

text: conceals them, and when the concealment process is over,
label: Paragraph

text: only the gray expanse remains.*
label: Paragraph

text: Since the early 1970s Isozaki’s work has oscillated
label: Paragraph

text: constantly between gridded atectonic assemblies (grey
label: Paragraph

text: expanses) controlled by the superimposition of cubic forms,
label: Paragraph

text: as in the Gunma Museum and the Shukosha Building in
label: Paragraph

text: Fukuoka City (1974-75), and a series of barrel-vaulted
label: Paragraph

text: tectonic structures, such as the Fujimi Country Clubhouse
label: Paragraph

text: near Oita (1972-74) and the Central Library of Kitakyushu
label: Paragraph

text: City (1972-75). A version of this last paradigm is the
label: Paragraph

text: Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, completed in
label: Caption

text: 1986, which is probably one of his finest later works.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike the Metabolists, lsozaki and Shinohara and other
label: Paragraph

text: members of the Japanese New Wave accept the fact that
label: Paragraph

text: today one can hardly hope to achieve any meaningful
label: Paragraph

text: relationship between the one-off building and the urban
label: Title

text: fabric as a whole. This critical attitude has been expressed
label: Paragraph

text: in a series of extremely formal and introspective houses
label: Paragraph

text: designed by such architects as Tadao Ando, Hiromi Fujii,
label: Paragraph

text: Hiroshi Hara, Itsuko Hasegawa and Toyo Ito, in addition to
label: Paragraph

text: similarly introverted works by Isozaki and Shinohara (see
label: Paragraph

text: also pp. 362-63).
label: Paragraph

text: Ito, who has been influenced to an equal degree by both
label: Paragraph

text: Isozaki and Shinohara, can be seen as epitomizing the
label: Paragraph

text: general line of the Japanese New Wave; that is to say, his
label: Paragraph

text: work is both highly aesthetic and ideologically critical. Like
label: Paragraph

text: Isozaki and Shinohara he has assumed a fatalistic attitude
label: Paragraph

text: toward the megalopolis, regarding it as a manifestation of
label: Paragraph

text: environmental delirium, devoid of sense. He sees the sole
label: Paragraph

text: possibility for cultural significance to reside in the creation
label: Paragraph

text: of closed poetic domains, in contrast to the random disorder
label: Paragraph

text: of the ‘Non-Place Urban Realm’ (see p. 322). One of his
label: Paragraph

text: largest urban works, the PMT Building at Nagoya erected in
label: Paragraph

text: 1978, is a ‘paper-thin’ structural intervention whose
label: Paragraph

text: hermetic, largely top-lit form possesses a stoic and acerbic
label: Paragraph

text: beauty. What we have here is the aristocratic counterform
label: Paragraph

text: (Isozaki) rather than the mask of a patronizing Populism
label: Paragraph

text: (Venturi). This much is clear from Ito’s essay of 1978,
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Collage and Superficiality in Architecture’:
label: Title

text: Surface richness in a Japanese city does not consist of a
label: Paragraph

text: historical accumulation of buildings but rather arises out of
label: Paragraph

text: a nostalgia for our lost architectural past which is
label: Paragraph

text: indiscriminately mixed with the superficial icons of the
label: Paragraph

text: present. Behind an endless desire for nostalgic satisfaction
label: Paragraph

text: there resides a void without any substance. What | wish to
label: Paragraph

text: obtain in my architecture is not another nostalgic object, but
label: Paragraph

text: rather a certain superficiality of expression in order to reveal
label: Paragraph

text: the nature of the void hidden beneath.°
label: Paragraph

text: As we have seen, apart from the geodesic dome ‘drop-
label: Paragraph

text: out’ culture of the American West, Buckminster Fuller’s
label: Paragraph

text: greatest impact has been in Japan and, above all, in Britain,
label: Paragraph

text: where a continuous ‘Dymaxion’ development can be traced
label: Paragraph

text: from the first space-frame and dome projects of Cedric Price
label: Caption

text: and Peter Cook to the work of Foster Associates.
label: Paragraph

text: The paradigm of this movement is the Centre Pompidou
label: Paragraph

text: in Paris [291, 292], built in 1977 to the designs of the short-
label: Paragraph

text: lived Anglo-Italian partnership of Richard Rogers and Renzo
label: Paragraph

text: Piano. The building is obviously a realization of the
label: Paragraph

text: technological and infrastructural rhetoric of Archigram; and
label: Paragraph

text: while the full consequences of this approach have become
label: Paragraph

text: evident through everyday use, it is apparent that certain
label: Paragraph

text: paradoxical achievements may be claimed on its behalf. In
label: Paragraph

text: the first place, it is an outstanding popular success - as
label: Paragraph

text: much for its sensational nature as for anything else. In the
label: Paragraph

text: second, it is a brilliant tour de force in advanced technique,
label: Paragraph

text: looking for all the world like the oil refinery whose
label: Paragraph

text: technology it attempts to emulate. It seems, however, to
label: Paragraph

text: have come into being with the minimum regard for the
label: Paragraph

text: specificity of its brief - for the art and library holdings it was
label: Paragraph

text: destined to house. It represents the design approach of
label: Paragraph

text: indeterminacy and optimum flexibility taken to extremes.
label: Paragraph

text: Not only was it necessary to build another ‘building’ within
label: Paragraph

text: its skeletonal volume in order to provide sufficient wall
label: Paragraph

text: surface and enclosure for the exhibition of art; but also the
label: Paragraph

text: provision of 50-metre (165-foot) lattice truss spans
label: Paragraph

text: throughout, in order to ensure optimum flexibility, seems to
label: Paragraph

text: have proved excessive. In the first instance we have an
label: Paragraph

text: underprovision of wall surface, in the second an
label: Paragraph

text: overprovision of flexibility. The additional fact that the scale
label: Paragraph

text: of the building is quite indifferent to its urban context and
label: Paragraph

text: that it is incapable of representing its status as an institution
label: Paragraph

text: is consistent with the ideological position from which it
label: Paragraph

text: stems, since such concerns were always foreign to the
label: Paragraph

text: English Dymaxion school of design. One of the unintended
label: Paragraph

text: ironies of this work seems to derive from the spectacular
label: Paragraph

text: view of the city which may be gained from the glazed
label: Paragraph

text: escalator access tubes, hung off the west side of the
label: Caption

text: building. These access ways are now barely adequate to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate the average daily attendance of thousands of
label: Paragraph

text: visitors, a number of whom come not for the cultural
label: Paragraph

text: facilities offered but for the building and the view.
label: Paragraph

text: 291, 292 Piano and Rogers, Centre Pompidou, Paris, 1972-77.
label: Caption

text: An equally indeterminate approach was adopted in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1972 design of the English New Town, Milton Keynes [293].
label: Caption

text: This city, based on a somewhat irregular street grid, was
label: Paragraph

text: apparently conceived as an instant Los Angeles to be laid
label: Paragraph

text: over the agrarian landscape of Buckinghamshire. Its empty
label: Paragraph

text: irregular network, configurated after the topography, was
label: Paragraph

text: yet another exercise in indeterminacy pushed to absurdity.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the Neo-Classicism of its Miesian shopping centre,
label: Paragraph

text: its capacity to represent a municipal identity is virtually non-
label: Paragraph

text: existent. One has no notion of arrival here save for the
label: Paragraph

text: graphic indication of the legal boundary, and for the casual
label: Paragraph

text: visitor Milton Keynes seems nothing more than a rather
label: Paragraph

text: random collection of more or less well-designed housing
label: Paragraph

text: estates. One thinks by contrast of the orthogonal precision
label: Paragraph

text: of Wright’s Broadacre City, where, despite the relentless
label: Paragraph

text: dispersal of the urban fabric, places would have acquired a
label: Paragraph

text: certain definition by virtue of their orthogonal boundaries.
label: Paragraph

text: Here, needless to say, what boundaries there are fail to
label: Paragraph

text: correspond to any perceivable order, and this is hardly
label: Paragraph

text: surprising given that the structure of the town was
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by the planning theories of Melvin Webber,
label: Paragraph

text: whose slogan ‘Non-Place Urban Realm’ seems to have been
label: Paragraph

text: adopted as a credo by the official architects of the plan,
label: Paragraph

text: Llewelyn-Davies Weeks Forestier-Walker and Bor. The fact
label: Paragraph

text: that this slogan stemmed from Webber’s commitment to the
label: Paragraph

text: Kristaller-Losch central place location theory - then as now,
label: Paragraph

text: the most dynamic model available for the creation of
label: Paragraph

text: optimum marketing conditions - could hardly have escaped
label: Paragraph

text: either the architects or the City Corporation. This selection
label: Paragraph

text: of an open-ended planning model in accordance with the
label: Paragraph

text: hypothetical interests of a consumer society was surely a
label: Paragraph

text: conscious choice.
label: Paragraph

text: 293 Llewelyn-Davies Weeks Forestier-Walker and Bor, strategic plan for Milton
label: Caption

text: Keynes New Town, Buckinghamshire, 1972. Schematic road grid laid over the
label: Caption

text: landscape. Residential areas (pale shading) and employment areas (dark) are
label: Paragraph

text: irregularly intermingled.
label: Paragraph

text: Within the Hochschule flr Gestaltung (HfG) [294] at Ulm
label: Paragraph

text: in Germany, initially conceived in 1951 by the Swiss
label: Paragraph

text: architect Max Bill as the institutional successor to the
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus, a rigorous approach to design and technology
label: Paragraph

text: brought itself in the space of a decade to confront the
label: Paragraph

text: fundamental contradictions of designing for a consumer
label: Title

text: society. After Bill’s resignation as director in 1956, the HfG
label: Paragraph

text: embraced a form of ‘operational research’ by which it
label: Paragraph

text: intended to evolve a heuristic of design, whereby the forms
label: Paragraph

text: of objects would be determined in accordance with precise
label: Paragraph

text: methods for analyzing the nature of their production and
label: Paragraph

text: use. Unfortunately, this method rapidly degenerated into a
label: Paragraph

text: form of method-idolatry in which the methodological ‘purist’
label: Paragraph

text: was invariably prepared to forego a solution rather than
label: Paragraph

text: arrive at a design that had not been ergonomically
label: Paragraph

text: determined. As far as Herbert Ohl’s Department of
label: Paragraph

text: Industrialized Building was concerned, this led to an
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on the design of industrial components to the
label: Paragraph

text: exclusion of any comprehensive analysis of specific building
label: Title

text: tasks. Real needs were often overlooked in an effort to
label: Paragraph

text: produce extremely sophisticated, if relatively simple,
label: Paragraph

text: prototypical components for the rationalized production of
label: Paragraph

text: built form. By the mid-1960s the more critical faculty
label: Paragraph

text: members, Tomas Maldonado, Claude Schnaidt and Gui
label: Paragraph

text: Bonsiepe, had jointly recognized that this idealization of
label: Paragraph

text: product design was a dead end, conveniently overlooking in
label: Paragraph

text: the name of scientific method and functional aesthetics the
label: Paragraph

text: fundamental contradictions inherent in neo-capitalist
label: Title

text: society. As far as architecture was concerned this was never
label: Paragraph

text: more forcibly expressed than by Schnaidt, who in his essay
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Architecture and Political Commitment’ (1967) wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: 294 Bill, Hochschule fur Gestaltung, Ulm, 1953-55, showing workshop block,
label: Caption

text: library, administration building and student housing. In the distance is Ulm
label: Paragraph

text: Cathedral.
label: Paragraph

text: In the days when the pioneers of modern architecture were
label: Paragraph

text: still young they thought like William Morris that architecture
label: Paragraph

text: should be an ‘art of the people for the people’. Instead of
label: Paragraph

text: pandering to the tastes of the privileged few, they wanted
label: Paragraph

text: to satisfy the requirements of the community. They wanted
label: Paragraph

text: to build dwellings, matched to human needs, to erect a Cité
label: Paragraph

text: Radieuse. But they had reckoned without the commercial
label: Paragraph

text: instincts of the bourgeoisie who lost no time in arrogating
label: Paragraph

text: their theories to themselves and pressing them into service
label: Paragraph

text: for the purpose of money-making. Utility quickly became
label: Paragraph

text: synonymous with profitability. Anti-academic forms became
label: Paragraph

text: the new decor of the ruling classes. The rational dwelling
label: Paragraph

text: was transformed into the minimum dwelling, the Cité
label: Paragraph

text: Radieuse into the urban conglomeration and austerity of
label: Paragraph

text: line into poverty of form. The architects of the trade unions,
label: Paragraph

text: co-operatives, and socialist municipalities were enlisted in
label: Paragraph

text: the service of the whisky distillers, detergent
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturers, the bankers, and the Vatican. Modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, which wanted to play its part in the liberation
label: Paragraph

text: of mankind by creating a new environment to live in, was
label: Paragraph

text: transformed into a giant enterprise for the degradation of
label: Paragraph

text: the human habitat.®
label: Paragraph

text: Later in the same article Schnaidt criticized the
label: Paragraph

text: achievements of the ‘alternative’ avant garde of the 1960s:
label: Paragraph

text: It is their philosophy that even the most audacious concepts
label: Paragraph

text: in architecture and city planning are feasible with modern
label: Paragraph

text: technological aids. This is what lies behind their quest for
label: Paragraph

text: something resembling space ships, packing crates, filing
label: Paragraph

text: systems, refineries, or artificial islands. ...
label: Paragraph

text: These futurist architects may well have the merit of
label: Paragraph

text: taking technology to its logical conclusion but more often
label: Paragraph

text: than not their attitude ends up in technolatry. The refinery
label: Paragraph

text: and the space capsule may serve as models of technical
label: Paragraph

text: and formal perfection but if they become the objects of a
label: Paragraph

text: cult, the lessons they can teach will completely miss their
label: Paragraph

text: mark. This unlimited confidence in the potentialities of
label: Paragraph

text: technology goes hand in hand with a surprising degree of
label: Paragraph

text: disingenuousness concerning the future of man. ... Such
label: Paragraph

text: visions as these are soothing to many architects: braced by
label: Paragraph

text: so much technology, by such confidence in the future, they
label: Paragraph

text: feel reassured and justified in their social and political
label: Paragraph

text: abdication.’
label: Paragraph

text: Yet while one might challenge its effectiveness, the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural avant garde of the 1960s had not entirely
label: Paragraph

text: abdicated its social responsibility. Many factions existed
label: Paragraph

text: whose orientation was decidedly political and whose
label: Paragraph

text: attitude towards advanced technology was by no means
label: Paragraph

text: uncritical. Of these mention must be made of the Italian
label: Paragraph

text: Superstudio group, who were, in this respect, among the
label: Paragraph

text: most poetic. Influenced by the ‘unitary town planning’
label: Paragraph

text: concepts of the International Situationist Constant
label: Title

text: Nieuwenhuys, who, in his New Babylon of 1960, had
label: Paragraph

text: postulated a constantly changing urban fabric that would
label: Paragraph

text: respond to the ‘ludic’ tendency in man, Superstudio, led by
label: Paragraph

text: Adolfo Natalini, started in 1966 to produce a body of work
label: Paragraph

text: which was more or less divided between representing the
label: Paragraph

text: form of a ‘Continuous Monument’ as a mute urban sign and
label: Paragraph

text: producing a series of vignettes illustrating a world from
label: Paragraph

text: which consumer goods had been eliminated. Their work
label: Paragraph

text: varied from the projection of vast impenetrable megaliths,
label: Paragraph

text: faced in mirror-glass, to the depiction of a science-fiction
label: Paragraph

text: landscape in which nature had been rendered benevolent -
label: Paragraph

text: in short the quintessential anti-architectural utopia. In 1969
label: Paragraph

text: they wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: Beyond the convulsions of over-production a state can be
label: Paragraph

text: born of calm in which a world takes shape without products
label: Paragraph

text: and refuse, a zone in which the mind is energy and raw
label: Paragraph

text: material and is also the final product, the only intangible
label: Paragraph

text: object for consumption.®
label: Paragraph

text: And again in 1972:
label: Paragraph

text: The objects we will need will be only flags or talismans,
label: Paragraph

text: signals for an existence that continues, or simple utensils
label: Paragraph

text: for simple operations. Thus, on the one hand, there will
label: Paragraph

text: remain utensils ... on the other, such symbolic objects as
label: Paragraph

text: monuments or badges ... objects that can easily be carried
label: Paragraph

text: about if we should become nomads, or heavy and
label: Paragraph

text: immovable if we decide to stay in one place forever?
label: Paragraph

text: Beyond the rule of the performance principle, which the
label: Paragraph

text: philosopher Herbert Marcuse had already characterized as
label: Paragraph

text: defining life in terms of instruments and consumer goods,
label: Paragraph

text: Superstudio projected a silent, anti-futurist and
label: Paragraph

text: technologically optimistic utopia where, in the words of
label: Paragraph

text: Marcuse’s Eros and Civilization (1962),
label: Paragraph

text: The level of living would be measured by other criteria: the
label: Paragraph

text: universal gratification of the basic human needs, and
label: Paragraph

text: freedom from guilt and fear - internalized as well as
label: Paragraph

text: externalized, instinctual as well as ‘rational’. ... In this case
label: Paragraph

text: the quantum of instinctual energy still to be diverted to
label: Paragraph

text: necessary labor ... would be so small that a large area of
label: Paragraph

text: repressive constraints and modifications no longer sustained
label: Title

text: by external forces would collapse.‘°
label: Paragraph

text: It is significant that Superstudio chose to represent such
label: Paragraph

text: a non-repressive world in terms of an architecture that was
label: Paragraph

text: virtually invisible [295], or, where visible, totally useless
label: Paragraph

text: and by design auto-destructive (see their self-disintegrating
label: Paragraph

text: mirror-glass dam for Niagara Falls). For all that they
label: Paragraph

text: rendered the contradiction of the ‘Continuous Monument’ as
label: Paragraph

text: an impenetrable mass reminiscent of Boullée, it was
label: Paragraph

text: nonetheless a metaphysical image, as fleeting and as
label: Paragraph

text: cryptic as the Suprematist monuments of Malevich or the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘wrapped’ buildings of Christo, an artist who, after wrapping
label: Paragraph

text: the Kunsthalle at Berne in 1968, went on to package and
label: Paragraph

text: hence to ‘silence’ most of the institutional monuments of
label: Paragraph

text: the Western world.
label: Paragraph

text: 295 Superstudio, ‘A Journey from A to B’, 1969. ‘There will be no further reason
label: Caption

text: for roads or squares.’
label: Paragraph

text: The growing awareness in the early 1960s that in
label: Paragraph

text: common practice there was a fundamental lack of
label: Paragraph

text: correspondence between the values of the architect and the
label: Paragraph

text: needs and mores of the user led to a whole series of
label: Paragraph

text: reformist moves which sought in a variety of counterutopian
label: Paragraph

text: ways to overcome this divorce of the designer from
label: Paragraph

text: everyday society. These factions not only challenged the
label: Paragraph

text: inaccessibility of the abstract syntax of contemporary
label: Title

text: architecture but also tried to devise ways in which architects
label: Paragraph

text: could serve those poor sectors of the society not normally
label: Paragraph

text: addressed by the profession. In his book Supports: An
label: Paragraph

text: Alternative to Mass Housing (1972) N.J. Habraken first
label: Caption

text: tackled the problem of building residential stock that could
label: Paragraph

text: meet the variable needs of its users, and John Turner and
label: Paragraph

text: William Mangin began in 1963 to write up their experience
label: Paragraph

text: as consultants to the spontaneous ‘squatter’ cities then
label: Paragraph

text: coming into existence around the perimeters of large South
label: Paragraph

text: American towns. The following situation, as described by
label: Paragraph

text: Mangin at the time, may be taken as typical of many other
label: Paragraph

text: cities throughout the Continent:
label: Title

text: The tremendous population growth in Peru, together with
label: Paragraph

text: the centralization of social, political, economic and cultural
label: Title

text: rewards in Lima, the capital city, has led to recent
label: Paragraph

text: intensified migration from the provinces to Lima. It is safe to
label: Paragraph

text: say that at least a million of Lima’s two million people were
label: Paragraph

text: born outside the city. The increase in the numbers of
label: Paragraph

text: migrants to the city and the subsequent dramatic
label: Title

text: resettlement of many of them in ‘unaided self-help’ squatter
label: Paragraph

text: settlements, ‘barriadas’ ... have drawn considerable
label: Paragraph

text: attention locally and abroad and for the first time have
label: Paragraph

text: made many Peruvians aware of the situation. The city has
label: Paragraph

text: probably grown in the past in much the same way, but the
label: Paragraph

text: magnitude and the visibility of the recent influx make it
label: Paragraph

text: seem to be a new phenomenon. The migrants come from
label: Paragraph

text: practically all regions and all social classes and ethnic
label: Paragraph

text: groupings in the country."
label: Paragraph

text: Problems of this magnitude, of course, lie beyond the
label: Paragraph

text: province of architecture as an autonomous discipline and
label: Paragraph

text: even outside the process of land settlement and building as
label: Paragraph

text: it is commonly understood. All the same, the scale of the
label: Paragraph

text: problem, its visibility and the need to confront it in a way
label: Paragraph

text: that would assist the squatters to build in a more effective
label: Paragraph

text: manner (the provision in most instances of water and sewer
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructures), created a general climate in which the
label: Paragraph

text: forty-year-old Neue Sachlichkeit formula of slum clearance
label: Title

text: followed by massive rehousing was for the first time
label: Paragraph

text: subjected to radical reconsideration. Habraken argued that
label: Paragraph

text: the whole approach needed to be rethought, not only in
label: Paragraph

text: respect of the Third World but also in the face of growing
label: Paragraph

text: user discontent in industrialized economies.
label: Paragraph

text: The establishment of alternative modes of practice to
label: Paragraph

text: meet this situation, for both the developed and the
label: Paragraph

text: underdeveloped world, has proved elusive, and the panacea
label: Paragraph

text: of ‘user participation’ (hard to define appropriately and even
label: Paragraph

text: more difficult to achieve) has only served to make us
label: Paragraph

text: acutely aware of the intractability of the problem and of the
label: Paragraph

text: fact that probably it can be effectively tackled only ona
label: Paragraph

text: piecemeal basis, by responding appropriately to specific
label: Paragraph

text: situations. Nevertheless, advocacy planning remains with us
label: Paragraph

text: as a radical legacy of the 1960s, although the results of its
label: Paragraph

text: application have varied widely, from the political
label: Paragraph

text: manipulation of the underprivileged to the achievement of a
label: Paragraph

text: section of low-rise housing [296] in Terni north of Rome,
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Giancarlo de Carlo, in accordance with a brief
label: Caption

text: developed as a result of extensive discussions with the local
label: Paragraph

text: trade union. There is no doubt that this whole undertaking
label: Paragraph

text: has resulted in housing of remarkable quality and variety,
label: Paragraph

text: although the manner in which the users’ desires were finally
label: Paragraph

text: interpreted remains a controversial issue.
label: Paragraph

text: 296 De Carlo, Matteotti village, Terni, 1974-77.
label: Caption

text: As far as transforming the practice of the Neue
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit was concerned, Habraken and his Foundation
label: Paragraph

text: for Architectural Research (SAR) in Eindhoven did their
label: Paragraph

text: technocratic best to take the promise of Yona Friedman’s
label: Title

text: open infrastructural approach, his ‘mobile architecture’, to
label: Paragraph

text: its logical conclusion. To this end they proposed a low-rise,
label: Paragraph

text: multistorey, support structure, whose plan arrangement was
label: Paragraph

text: undetermined, save for fixed access, kitchen and bathroom
label: Caption

text: zones. Outside these zones the occupant would be free to
label: Paragraph

text: arrange the plan of his allocated volume in any way he
label: Paragraph

text: wished. Regrettably, Habraken intended to furnish this
label: Paragraph

text: spatial matrix with industrialized, modular components
label: Paragraph

text: fabricated along the lines of the car industry and brought to
label: Paragraph

text: a level of technical sophistication and structural tolerance
label: Title

text: which has yet to be attained, even in the wholesale
label: Paragraph

text: prefabricated building programmes of the Soviet Union.
label: Paragraph

text: Moreover, like Friedman, he tended to overlook the fact that
label: Paragraph

text: much of the inherent ‘freedom’ of the system would
label: Paragraph

text: automatically disappear once it came under the auspices of
label: Paragraph

text: monopoly capital. Housing after all has yet to become a
label: Paragraph

text: truly consumable item. Fortunately, the SAR concept does
label: Paragraph

text: not stand or fall by its technology alone, and Habraken has
label: Paragraph

text: opened up a line of research which has yet to be fully
label: Paragraph

text: explored. A quite remarkable work apparently influenced by
label: Paragraph

text: Habraken’s thought is the distinguished ‘expandable’
label: Paragraph

text: terrace housing built in Genterstrasse in Munich in 1971 by
label: Paragraph

text: Otto Steidle and Doris and Ralph Thut.
label: Paragraph

text: Populism
label: Title

text: The Loosian recognition of the loss of cultural identity that
label: Paragraph

text: urbanization had brought in its wake returned with a
label: Paragraph

text: vengeance in the mid-1960s as architects began to realize
label: Paragraph

text: that the reductive codes of contemporary architecture had
label: Paragraph

text: led to an impoverishment of the urban environment. The
label: Paragraph

text: exact manner in which this impoverishment has come
label: Paragraph

text: about, however - the extent to which it is due to abstract
label: Paragraph

text: tendencies present in Cartesian rationality itself or
label: Paragraph

text: alternatively to ruthless economic exploitation - is a
label: Paragraph

text: complex and critical issue which has yet to be judiciously
label: Paragraph

text: decided. It cannot be denied that the tabula rasa
label: Paragraph

text: reductivism of the Modern Movement has played a salient
label: Paragraph

text: role in the wholesale destruction of urban culture; thus the
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis that the ‘Post-Modernist’ critique has placed on
label: Paragraph

text: respecting the existing urban context can hardly be
label: Paragraph

text: discredited. This anti-utopian ‘contextualist’ critique was
label: Paragraph

text: already available in the 1960s, first in Colin Rowe’s neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Sittesque approach to urban form (as taught in Cornell
label: Paragraph

text: University and presented in his book of 1979, Collage City),
label: Paragraph

text: and then in Robert Venturi’s Complexity and Contradiction in
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture of 1966, in which he wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: The main justification for honky-tonk elements in
label: Paragraph

text: architectural order is their very existence. They are what we
label: Paragraph

text: have. Architects can bemoan or try to ignore them or even
label: Paragraph

text: try to abolish them, but they will not go away. Or they will
label: Paragraph

text: not go away for a long time, because architects do not have
label: Paragraph

text: the power to replace them (nor do they know what to
label: Paragraph

text: replace them with), and because these commonplace
label: Paragraph

text: elements accommodate existing needs for variety and
label: Paragraph

text: communication, The old clichés involving both banality and
label: Paragraph

text: mess will still be the context of our new architecture, and
label: Paragraph

text: our new architecture significantly will be the context for
label: Paragraph

text: them. | am taking the limited view, | admit, but the limited
label: Paragraph

text: view, which architects have tended to belittle, is as
label: Paragraph

text: important as the visionary view, which they have tended to
label: Paragraph

text: glorify but have not brought about. The short-term plan,
label: Paragraph

text: which expediently combines the old and the new, must
label: Paragraph

text: accompany the long-term plan. Architecture is evolutionary
label: Paragraph

text: as well as revolutionary. As an art it will acknowledge what
label: Paragraph

text: is and what ought to be, the immediate and the
label: Paragraph

text: speculative.!2
label: Paragraph

text: With the publication in 1972 of Learning from Las Vegas,
label: Paragraph

text: written by Venturi, Denise Scott Brown and Steve Izenour,
label: Caption

text: Venturi’s sensitive and sane assessment of the cultural
label: Title

text: realities confronting everyday practice - the need to set
label: Title

text: order against disorder and vice versa - shifted from an
label: Paragraph

text: acceptance of honky-tonk to its glorification; from a modest
label: Paragraph

text: appraisal of Main Street as being ‘almost all right’ toa
label: Paragraph

text: reading of the billboard strip as the transmogrified utopia of
label: Paragraph

text: the Enlightenment, lying there like a science-fiction
label: Paragraph

text: transposition in the midst of the desert!
label: Paragraph

text: This rhetoric, which would have us see A & P parking lots
label: Paragraph

text: as the tapis verts of Versailles, or Caesar’s Palace in Las
label: Paragraph

text: Vegas as the modern equivalent of Hadrian’s Villa, is
label: Paragraph

text: ideology in its purest form. The ambivalent manner in which
label: Paragraph

text: Venturi and Scott Brown exploit this ideology as a way of
label: Paragraph

text: bringing us to condone the ruthless kitsch of Las Vegas, as
label: Paragraph

text: an exemplary mask for the concealment of the brutality of
label: Paragraph

text: our own environment, testifies to the aestheticizing intent of
label: Paragraph

text: their thesis. And while their critical distance permits them
label: Paragraph

text: the luxury of describing the typical casino as a ruthless
label: Paragraph

text: landscape of seduction and control - they emphasize the
label: Paragraph

text: two-way mirrors and the boundless, dark, disorientating
label: Title

text: timelessness of its interior - they take care to disassociate
label: Paragraph

text: themselves from its values. This does not prevent them,
label: Paragraph

text: however, from positing it as a model for the restructuring of
label: Paragraph

text: urban form:
label: Title

text: Beyond the town the only transition between the Strip and
label: Paragraph

text: the Mojave Desert is a zone of rusting beer cans. Within the
label: Paragraph

text: town the transition is as ruthlessly sudden. Casinos whose
label: Paragraph

text: fronts relate so sensitively to the highway turn their ill-
label: Paragraph

text: kempt backsides towards the local environment, exposing
label: Paragraph

text: residual forms and spaces of mechanical equipment and
label: Title

text: service areas.'3
label: Paragraph

text: The irony with which architects from Lutyens to Venturi
label: Paragraph

text: have sought to transcend through wit the contradictory
label: Paragraph

text: circumstances under which they are asked to build here
label: Paragraph

text: seems to degenerate into total acquiescence; and the cult
label: Paragraph

text: of ‘the ugly and the ordinary’ becomes indistinguishable
label: Paragraph

text: from the environmental consequences of the market
label: Title

text: economy. Between the lines, the authors are brought to
label: Paragraph

text: concede the superfluity of architectural design in a society
label: Paragraph

text: that is exclusively motivated by ruthless economic drives, a
label: Paragraph

text: society which has nothing of greater significance to
label: Paragraph

text: represent than the giant neon-lit sky sign of the average
label: Paragraph

text: strip. At the end of their analysis they are almost brought to
label: Paragraph

text: concede that the loss of the monument is an absence that
label: Paragraph

text: can hardly be compensated for by the sophistries of the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘decorated shed’:
label: Title

text: The casino in Las Vegas is a big, low space. It is the
label: Paragraph

text: archetype for all public interior spaces whose heights are
label: Paragraph

text: diminished for reasons of budget or air conditioning ...
label: Paragraph

text: Today, span is easy to achieve, and volume is governed by
label: Paragraph

text: mechanical and economic limitations in height. But railroad
label: Paragraph

text: stations, restaurants, and shopping arcades only ten feet
label: Paragraph

text: high reflect as well a changing attitude to monumentality ...
label: Paragraph

text: We have replaced the monumental space of Pennsylvania
label: Paragraph

text: Station by a subway above ground, and that of Grand
label: Paragraph

text: Central Terminal remains mainly through its magnificent
label: Paragraph

text: conversion to an advertising vehicle.14
label: Caption

text: Venturi is determined to present Las Vegas as an
label: Paragraph

text: authentic outburst of popular fantasy. But, as Maldonado
label: Paragraph

text: has argued in his book La Speranza Progettuale (Design,
label: Paragraph

text: Nature and Revolution) of 1970, the reality would indicate
label: Paragraph

text: the contrary, that Las Vegas is the pseudo-communicative
label: Paragraph

text: culmination of ‘more than half a century of masked
label: Paragraph

text: manipulatory violence directed towards the formation of an
label: Paragraph

text: apparently free and playful urban environment in which men
label: Paragraph

text: are completely devoid of innovative will’.
label: Paragraph

text: Be this as it may, the Venturi faction did not take their
label: Paragraph

text: Populist stand in isolation. On the contrary, they soon
label: Paragraph

text: acquired a sympathetic following in both academic and
label: Paragraph

text: professional circles - from the historian/critic Vincent Scully,
label: Paragraph

text: who initially rallied to their cause with his laudatory
label: Paragraph

text: introduction to Venturi’s Complexity and Contradiction, and
label: Paragraph

text: who went on to confirm his continuing support with his
label: Paragraph

text: polemic The Shingle Style Revisited (1974), and from
label: Paragraph

text: architects such as Charles Moore and Robert Stern, who,
label: Paragraph

text: while adopting more varied ad hoc attitudes towards the
label: Paragraph

text: manipulation of form, were nonetheless equally open to
label: Paragraph

text: exploiting the essentially atectonic nature of the American
label: Paragraph

text: balloon-frame.
label: Paragraph

text: The net effect, at least in Anglo-Saxon circles, has been
label: Paragraph

text: to stimulate a rather indiscriminate reaction against all
label: Paragraph

text: forms of modernist expression in architecture, a situation
label: Paragraph

text: which the critic Charles Jencks was prompt to identify as
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Post-Modern’. In his book The Language of Post-Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture (1977), Jencks effectively characterized Post-
label: Paragraph

text: Modernism as being a Populist-Pluralist art of immediate
label: Paragraph

text: communicability. At the end of the first edition of this text,
label: Paragraph

text: he hailed Gaudi’s ‘pre-modern’ Casa Batll6 (1906) as an
label: Paragraph

text: exemplary work, which was readily accessible, inasmuch as
label: Paragraph

text: the populace could decipher and identify with the
label: Paragraph

text: iconography of Catalan separatism which it embodied
label: Paragraph

text: (Jencks is referring here to the lancelike tower and the
label: Paragraph

text: dragon’s back roof representing the ultimate triumph of the
label: Paragraph

text: Catalan hero St George over the ‘dragon’ of Madrid).
label: Paragraph

text: Nationalist mythologies cannot be invented overnight,
label: Paragraph

text: however, and the sobering fact remains that many so-called
label: Paragraph

text: Populist works have nothing more to convey than a
label: Paragraph

text: gratifying cosiness or an ironic comment on the absurdity of
label: Paragraph

text: suburban kitsch. More often than not Post-Modernist
label: Paragraph

text: architects use the private house as an occasion for indulging
label: Paragraph

text: in idiosyncratic obsessions, as is all too evident from the
label: Paragraph

text: triviality of Stanley Tigerman’s Hot Dog and Daisy houses of
label: Paragraph

text: the mid-1970s.
label: Paragraph

text: Each year American Populism seemed to grow
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly diffuse in its eclectic parodies from the Art Deco
label: Paragraph

text: conceits of say Venturi’s Brant House at Greenwich,
label: Caption

text: Connecticut (1971) and Stern’s closely related Ehrman
label: Title

text: House at Armonk, New York (1975), to the self-styled
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Popular Machinism’ (in effect, neo-Art Deco) of Helmut
label: Paragraph

text: Jahn’s typical crystal skyscraper, the high-rise, curtain-
label: Paragraph

text: walled structure rendered as a giant Wurlitzer organ [297].
label: Caption

text: These and other Populist divagations indicate that the
label: Paragraph

text: purging simplicity of ‘the dumb and the ordinary’ (in
label: Paragraph

text: Venturi’s phrase) has now been left behind, along with the
label: Paragraph

text: sparsely elegant Trubeck and Wislocki houses which Venturi
label: Paragraph

text: realized on Cape Cod in 1970.
label: Paragraph

text: 297 Jahn, Bank of the South West, Houston, 1982 ff.
label: Caption

text: By scenographically simulating the profiles of classical
label: Paragraph

text: and vernacular and thereby reducing the architectonics of
label: Paragraph

text: construction to pure parody, Populism tends to undermine
label: Paragraph

text: the society’s capacity for continuing with a significant
label: Paragraph

text: culture of built form. The consequence of this for the field as
label: Paragraph

text: a whole has been a seductive but decisive drift towards a
label: Paragraph

text: kind of ‘tawdry pathos’, to use Jencks’s felicitous yet
label: Paragraph

text: ambivalent assessment of the theatrical effects created by
label: Paragraph

text: Moore and Turnbull in their designs for Kresge College on
label: Paragraph

text: the University of California’s Santa Cruz campus of 1974.
label: Paragraph

text: The cynicism which ultimately motivated such scenographic
label: Paragraph

text: operations would be openly conceded by Moore.
label: Paragraph

text: In contrast to the flaccid eclecticism of Moore (who
label: Paragraph

text: abandoned the constructional purity of his Sea Ranch
label: Paragraph

text: complex in Sonoma County, California, of 1966 as soon as it
label: Paragraph

text: was completed), Frank Gehry’s domestic work, above all his
label: Paragraph

text: own deconstructed ‘anti-house’ (compare Marcel Duchamp’s
label: Paragraph

text: ‘anti-painting’) built in Santa Monica in 1979 [298],
label: Paragraph

text: introduced a genuinely subversive element into the
label: Paragraph

text: complacent decadence of American Populist architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: However, this creative resistance has been more than
label: Paragraph

text: balanced by the uncritical absorption of American Populism
label: Paragraph

text: into the European mainstream, a cultural transfer effected
label: Paragraph

text: by Paolo Portoghesi’s architectural section of the 1980
label: Caption

text: Venice Biennale which bore the seductive double title ‘The
label: Paragraph

text: Presence of the Past’ and ‘The End of Prohibition’. It is
label: Paragraph

text: significant that the full-size facades of Portoghesi’s ‘Strada
label: Paragraph

text: Novissima’ in the Arsenal (fig. 315) were realized by scene-
label: Paragraph

text: builders from the Italian film industry. The only exception
label: Paragraph

text: was the design by Léon Krier, who, no doubt out of ‘moral’
label: Paragraph

text: deference to his beloved Heinrich Tessenow (see the latter’s
label: Paragraph

text: Handwerk und Kleinstadt of 1910), insisted on building his
label: Paragraph

text: facade out of real materials.
label: Paragraph

text: 298 Gehry, Gehry House, Santa Monica, California, 1979.
label: Caption

text: Rationalism
label: Title

text: Nothing could be further from the Populist programme, at
label: Paragraph

text: least at its origin, than the Italian Neo-Rationalist
label: Paragraph

text: movement, the so-called ‘Tendenza’, which was clearly an
label: Paragraph

text: attempt to save both architecture and the city from being
label: Paragraph

text: overrun by the all-pervasive forces of megalopolitan
label: Paragraph

text: consumerism.
label: Paragraph

text: This return to the ‘limits’ of architecture was initiated by
label: Paragraph

text: the publication of two singularly seminal texts, Aldo Rossi’s
label: Paragraph

text: L’architettura della citta (1966) and Giorgio Grassi’s La
label: Paragraph

text: costruzione logica dell’architettura (1967). The first stressed
label: Paragraph

text: the part to be played by established building types in
label: Paragraph

text: determining the morphological structure of urban form as it
label: Paragraph

text: develops in time; the second attempted to formulate the
label: Paragraph

text: necessary compositional or combinatorial rules for
label: Title

text: architecture - the intrinsic logic by which Grassi himself had
label: Paragraph

text: arrived at his own highly restrained expression. While
label: Paragraph

text: insisting that everyday needs must be met, both men
label: Paragraph

text: rejected the principle by which form is supposed to follow
label: Paragraph

text: function - ergonomics - and asserted instead the relative
label: Paragraph

text: autonomy of architectural order. Aware of the tendency of
label: Paragraph

text: interested rationality to absorb and distort every significant
label: Paragraph

text: cultural gesture, Rossi structured his work about historical
label: Paragraph

text: architectonic elements that could recall and yet transcend
label: Paragraph

text: the rational if arbitrary paradigms of the Enlightenment -
label: Paragraph

text: the pure form postulated in the second half of the 18th
label: Paragraph

text: century by Piranesi, Ledoux, Boullée and Lequeu. The most
label: Paragraph

text: enigmatic, not to say hermetic, aspect of his thought resides
label: Paragraph

text: in his unstated preoccupation with the Panopticon (see
label: Paragraph

text: Michel Foucault’s Surveiller et punir of 1975) under the
label: Paragraph

text: rubric of which he would surely include - after Pugin’s
label: Paragraph

text: Contrasts of 1843 - the school, the hospital and the prison.
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi seems to have obsessively returned to these
label: Paragraph

text: regulatory, quasi-punitive institutions which for him, in
label: Paragraph

text: conjunction with the monument and cemetery, constitute
label: Paragraph

text: the only programmes capable of embodying the values of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture per se. After the thesis that Loos first set out in
label: Paragraph

text: his essay Architektur of 1910, Rossi has recognized that
label: Paragraph

text: most modern programmes are inappropriate vehicles for
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and for him this has meant having recourse to
label: Paragraph

text: a so-called analogical architecture whose referents and
label: Paragraph

text: elements are to be abstracted from the vernacular, in the
label: Paragraph

text: broadest possible sense. To this end his Gallaratese
label: Paragraph

text: apartment block [299], designed as part of Carlo
label: Caption

text: Aymonino’s housing complex built on the outskirts of Milan
label: Paragraph

text: in 1973, was an occasion to evoke the architecture of the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional Milanese tenement. Similarly his town hall for
label: Paragraph

text: Trieste, projected in the form of a penitentiary in 1973, was
label: Paragraph

text: both a homage to the local 19th-century building tradition
label: Paragraph

text: and a sardonic comment on the ultimate nature of modern
label: Paragraph

text: bureaucracy. Like Léon Krier, who has since taken a similar
label: Paragraph

text: path, Rossi attempts to evade the twin chimeras of
label: Paragraph

text: modernity - positivistic logic and a blind faith in progress -
label: Title

text: by returning to both the building typology and the
label: Paragraph

text: constructional forms of the second half of the 19th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Of his contribution to the Gallaratese complex, he wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: 299 Rossi, apartment block for the Gallaratese district of Milan, 1969-73.
label: Caption

text: In my design for the residential block in the Gallaratese
label: Caption

text: district of Milan (1969-73), there is an analogical
label: Paragraph

text: relationship with certain engineering works that mix freely
label: Paragraph

text: with both the corridor typology and a related feeling | have
label: Paragraph

text: always experienced in the architecture of the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: Milanese tenements, where the corridors signify a life-style
label: Paragraph

text: bathed in everyday occurrences, domestic intimacy and
label: Paragraph

text: varied personal relationships. However, another aspect of
label: Paragraph

text: this design was made clear to me by Fabio Reinhart driving
label: Paragraph

text: through the San Bernardino Pass, as we often did to reach
label: Paragraph

text: Zurich from the Ticino Valley. Reinhart noticed the repetitive
label: Paragraph

text: element in the system of open-sided tunnels, and therefore
label: Paragraph

text: the inherent pattern. | understood ... how | must have been
label: Paragraph

text: conscious of that particular structure ... without necessarily
label: Paragraph

text: intending to express it in a work of architecture.!°
label: Paragraph

text: This analogical approach, suspended, as Rossi himself
label: Paragraph

text: said, between ‘inventory and memory’, permeates his entire
label: Paragraph

text: oeuvre, from the bunker-like resistance monument projected
label: Paragraph

text: for Cuneo in 1962 to the Modena Cemetery of 1971 [300],
label: Paragraph

text: with its references not only to the traditional ossuary but
label: Paragraph

text: also, by association, to the factory and to the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: farm of the Lombardy region.
label: Paragraph

text: 300 Rossi, project for Modena Cemetery, 1971. Aerial perspective.
label: Caption

text: Other Italians who made important contributions to the
label: Paragraph

text: Tendenza were Vittorio Gregotti, whose book // territorio
label: Paragraph

text: dell’architettura (1966) had an extensive influence, and
label: Paragraph

text: Enzo Bonfanti, who with Massimo Scolari edited the Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Rationalist magazine Contraspazio in the second half of the
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s. Finally credit has to be accorded to Manfredo Tafuri,
label: Paragraph

text: whose writings were a major influence on the movement,
label: Paragraph

text: and to Franco Purini and Laura Thermes, whose theoretical
label: Paragraph

text: projects explored the potential range of the Neo-Rationalist
label: Paragraph

text: syntax. Paradoxically, the Tendenza has realized very little in
label: Paragraph

text: Italy, though it has had an impact on Italian city planning
label: Paragraph

text: and the historic preservation of urban centres, the classic
label: Paragraph

text: example being Cervellati and Scannarini’s analytical study
label: Paragraph

text: of Bologna, which influenced the development of that city
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the 1970s.
label: Paragraph

text: The most extensive realization of the Tendenza outside
label: Paragraph

text: Italy has undoubtedly been in the Swiss region of the Ticino,
label: Paragraph

text: where a ‘rationalist’ school of considerable vigour was
label: Paragraph

text: already flourishing in the early 1960s. While Bruno Reichlin
label: Paragraph

text: and Fabio Reinhart followed Rossi closely (see their Tonini
label: Paragraph

text: House in Torricella, 1974 [301]), the Ticino School included
label: Paragraph

text: architects whose work came into being under a much
label: Paragraph

text: broader Rationalist influence. Typical in this regard is Aurelio
label: Paragraph

text: Galfetti’s Corbusian Rotalinti House, Bellinzona (1961),
label: Caption

text: which predates the emergence of the Tendenza as an
label: Paragraph

text: influence by almost a decade. It should also be noted that
label: Paragraph

text: the Ticinese architects were privileged with links to the pre-
label: Paragraph

text: war Italian Rationalist movement, in particular Alberto
label: Paragraph

text: Sartoris and Rino Tami (see p. 360).
label: Paragraph

text: 301 Reichlin and Reinhart, Tonini House, Torricella, 1974.
label: Caption

text: Since the late 1960s Neo-Rationalism has attained a wide
label: Paragraph

text: following throughout Continental Europe. In France, its
label: Paragraph

text: influence is apparent in H.E. Ciriani’s Noisy 2 apartment
label: Paragraph

text: complex [302] in Marne-la-Vallée near Paris (1980). In
label: Paragraph

text: Germany, Neo-Rationalism has found its principal
label: Paragraph

text: manifestation in the typological work of Mathias Ungers,
label: Paragraph

text: Jurgen Sawade and J.P. Kleihues. Recent works of
label: Caption

text: consequence in this regard are Ungers’ extension to the
label: Paragraph

text: Messehalle (1983) and his Architecture Museum (1984),
label: Paragraph

text: both in Frankfurt. In Berlin a sampling of Rationalist work
label: Paragraph

text: would surely include Kleihues’ Vinetaplatz perimeter
label: Paragraph

text: housing block in Wedding (1978) [303] and his
label: Paragraph

text: megastructural hospital in Neukdélln (1984).
label: Paragraph

text: 302 Ciriani, detail of Noisy 2, Marne-la-Vallée, 1980.
label: Caption

text: 303 Kleihues, perimeter block housing, Berlin-Wedding, 1978. This residential
label: Caption

text: type has the capacity to engender both courtyards and streets.
label: Paragraph

text: Particularly significant in the German development was
label: Paragraph

text: Ungers’ adoption of a modified Neo-Rationalist approach to
label: Paragraph

text: urban form, after his return from the United States in 1975.
label: Paragraph

text: His thesis of that time, that in the future we shall often find
label: Paragraph

text: ourselves confronted with the problem of planned
label: Paragraph

text: metropolitan shrinkage, rather than expansion or renewal,
label: Paragraph

text: has imparted a certain urgency to his approach. Ungers
label: Paragraph

text: recommends a fragmentary urban strategy comprising
label: Paragraph

text: forms of development limited in accordance with the
label: Paragraph

text: topographical and institutional constraints of a specific task
label: Title

text: in a particular context. This appears in such projects as his
label: Paragraph

text: 1976 Hotel Berlin or his 1978 proposal for a multi-use
label: Title

text: building in the centre of Hildesheim. Where in the Hotel
label: Caption

text: Berlin he opted for a self-contained ‘city in miniature’, close
label: Paragraph

text: to the devastated urban landscape of the historic
label: Title

text: Lutzowplatz, at Hildesheim he attempted to rationalize and
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpret the received type of the medieval market hall
label: Paragraph

text: [304]. His Schillerstrasse perimeter block in Berlin,
label: Caption

text: completed in 1982, was his only truly contextual realization
label: Paragraph

text: of that period.
label: Paragraph

text: 304 Ungers, project for a ‘Stadtloggia’ in the marketplace at Hildesheim, 1980.
label: Caption

text: Ungers has been a major Neo-Rationalist theoretician
label: Paragraph

text: and teacher, first in the Technische Universitat in Berlin and
label: Paragraph

text: then at Cornell University, where from 1967 to 1974 he
label: Paragraph

text: directed the Department of Architecture. His consistent
label: Paragraph

text: application of the principle of typological transformation to
label: Paragraph

text: both teaching and practice gave his pedagogical method
label: Paragraph

text: great conviction. He made the full range of this
label: Paragraph

text: transformational precept explicit in 1982:
label: Paragraph

text: When architecture is seen as a continuous process, in which
label: Paragraph

text: theses and antitheses are dialectically integrated, or as a
label: Paragraph

text: process, in which history is as closely involved as
label: Paragraph

text: anticipation of history, in which the past has the same
label: Paragraph

text: weight as looking forward to the future, then the process of
label: Paragraph

text: transformation is not only the instrument of design, but it is
label: Paragraph

text: the very object of design. At the same time it becomes
label: Paragraph

text: possible to make reference to the specific reality of each
label: Paragraph

text: individual site where the architecture will be built - and
label: Paragraph

text: therefore to the genius loci and to discover the poetry of the
label: Paragraph

text: place and give it expression. In this way the site is used to
label: Paragraph

text: its best advantage.
label: Paragraph

text: The principle of transformation is active in all fields of
label: Paragraph

text: nature, life and art. It is the principle of formation
label: Paragraph

text: (Gestaltungsprinzip) capable of organizing divergent
label: Paragraph

text: elements into a planned totality. Thus the principle of
label: Paragraph

text: transformation as it can be grasped for example in the
label: Paragraph

text: historical transformations of the town plan of Trier -
label: Title

text: converts a given stabilized organization into chaos and
label: Paragraph

text: eventually, following the laws of chance, into a new order. ...
label: Paragraph

text: A differentiated and planned organisation is submerged over
label: Paragraph

text: the course of time by chance and spontaneity, which in the
label: Paragraph

text: end produce an organisation that is genuinely different and
label: Paragraph

text: contrasts with the previous one; an organisation, that is of
label: Paragraph

text: immediacy and pragmatic necessity.'®
label: Paragraph

text: This grounding of architecture in the dialectic of
label: Paragraph

text: typological transformation exerted a major influence on the
label: Paragraph

text: Luxembourg architect Robert Krier, who spent a number of
label: Paragraph

text: years in Ungers’ Cologne studio as his assistant. However
label: Paragraph

text: where Ungers was to remain open to the free interchange
label: Paragraph

text: and generation of both type and technique, including
label: Paragraph

text: industrial technique, Robert Krier and, to an even greater
label: Paragraph

text: extent, his brother Léon adopted an exclusively craft
label: Paragraph

text: approach to the generation of tectonic and urban form. Thus
label: Paragraph

text: we find Léon Krier writing in 1976:
label: Paragraph

text: The debate which both Robert Krier and | want to raise with
label: Paragraph

text: our projects is that of urban morphology as against the
label: Paragraph

text: zoning of planners. The restoration of precise forms of urban
label: Paragraph

text: space as against the wasteland which is created by zoning.
label: Paragraph

text: The design of urban spaces, both traffic and pedestrian,
label: Paragraph

text: linear and focal is, on the one hand, a method which is
label: Paragraph

text: general enough to allow flexibility and change and, on the
label: Paragraph

text: other, precise enough to create both spatial and built
label: Paragraph

text: continuity within the city ... we try in our projects to re-
label: Paragraph

text: establish the dialectic of building and public realm, of solid
label: Paragraph

text: and void, of the built organism and the spaces it necessarily
label: Paragraph

text: creates around itself... the architectural language we use
label: Paragraph

text: for fairly large urban parts is both simple and ambiguous. In
label: Paragraph

text: Echternach (1970) [305] we used the same craft which after
label: Paragraph

text: the war reconstructed the city, the Abbey, and the annex
label: Paragraph

text: buildings.
label: Paragraph
