text: Structuralism
label: Title

text: The Krier brothers’ credo that ‘function follows form’, their
label: Paragraph

text: anti-technocratic attitude and their insistence on the
label: Paragraph

text: cultural importance of place, all find a parallel in the work
label: Paragraph

text: and thought of the Dutch architect Herman Hertzberger,
label: Paragraph

text: who in every other respect could not be further removed
label: Paragraph

text: from the ethos of the Tendenza. The most crucial influence
label: Paragraph

text: on the thought and practice of Hertzberger has been Aldo
label: Paragraph

text: van Eyck, who is responsible for the most consistently
label: Paragraph

text: sustained and significant critique of modern architecture as
label: Paragraph

text: an inseparable part of the Enlightenment. In 1962 Van Eyck
label: Paragraph

text: delivered one of his sharpest attacks on Europocentrism and
label: Paragraph

text: on the bankruptcy of imperialist culture:
label: Title

text: Western civilization habitually identifies itself with
label: Paragraph

text: civilization as such on the pontifical assumption that what is
label: Paragraph

text: not like it, is a deviation, less advanced, ‘primitive’, or, at
label: Paragraph

text: best, exotically interesting at a safe distance.'’
label: Paragraph

text: Five years later, in his magazine Forum, Van Eyck
label: Paragraph

text: anticipated many of the arguments since advanced by the
label: Paragraph

text: Kriers, including a certain scepticism with regard to the
label: Paragraph

text: notion of progress:
label: Title

text: It seems to me that past, present and future must be active
label: Paragraph

text: in the mind’s interior as a continuum. If they are not the
label: Paragraph

text: artifacts we make will be without temporal depth or
label: Paragraph

text: associative perspective. ... Man after all has been
label: Paragraph

text: accommodating himself physically in this world for
label: Paragraph

text: thousands of years. His natural genius has neither increased
label: Paragraph

text: nor decreased during that time. It is obvious that the full
label: Paragraph

text: scope of this enormous environmental experience cannot be
label: Paragraph

text: combined unless we telescope the past. ... Architects
label: Paragraph

text: nowadays are pathologically addicted to change, regarding
label: Paragraph

text: it as something one either hinders, runs after, or at best
label: Paragraph

text: keeps up with. This, | suggest, is why they tend to sever the
label: Paragraph

text: past from the future, with the result that the present is
label: Paragraph

text: rendered emotionally inaccessible, without temporal
label: Paragraph

text: dimension. | dislike a sentimental antiquarian attitude
label: Paragraph

text: toward the past as much as | dislike a sentimental
label: Paragraph

text: technocratic one toward the future. Both are founded on a
label: Paragraph

text: Static, clockwork, notion of time (what antiquarians and
label: Paragraph

text: technocrats have in common), so let’s start with the past for
label: Paragraph

text: a change and discover the unchanging condition of man.*®
label: Paragraph

text: The unifying concept with which Dutch Structuralism
label: Paragraph

text: hoped to overcome the reductive aspect of Functionalism
label: Paragraph

text: was Characterized by Van Eyck as labyrinthine clarity, a
label: Paragraph

text: concept that has since been fully elaborated by his pupils.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus Hertzberger wrote of their common notion of
label: Paragraph

text: ‘polyvalent space’ in 1963:
label: Paragraph

text: What we must look for, in place of prototypes which are
label: Paragraph

text: collective interpretations of individual living patterns, are
label: Paragraph

text: prototypes which make individual interpretations of the
label: Paragraph

text: collective patterns possible; in other words, we must make
label: Paragraph

text: houses alike in a particular way, such that everyone can
label: Paragraph

text: bring into being his own interpretation of the collective
label: Paragraph

text: pattern. ... Because it is impossible (and it always was) to
label: Paragraph

text: make the individual setting that exactly suits everyone, we
label: Paragraph

text: have to create the possibility for personal interpretation, by
label: Paragraph

text: making things in such a way that they are indeed
label: Paragraph

text: interpretable.'9
label: Paragraph

text: This precept has been the point of departure from which
label: Paragraph

text: Hertzberger has evolved the rest of his work, culminating in
label: Paragraph

text: the erection in 1974 of the Centraal Beheer insurance
label: Paragraph

text: offices in Apeldoorn [306], built to his designs in the form of
label: Paragraph

text: a ‘city within a city’. This reinforced-concrete frame and
label: Paragraph

text: concrete-block structure is ordered about an irregular
label: Paragraph

text: cluster of working platforms set within a regular orthogonal
label: Paragraph

text: tartan grid comprising floors, columns, light slots and
label: Paragraph

text: service ducts. Top-lit gallery spaces of varying height
label: Caption

text: separate these 7.5-metre (24-foot) square platforms from
label: Paragraph

text: one another and allow natural light to filter down to the
label: Paragraph

text: lowest public levels. The suspended platforms provide a
label: Paragraph

text: network of activity spaces that may be appropriated as
label: Paragraph

text: either individual or group working stations, through the
label: Paragraph

text: rearrangement of modular elements comprising desks,
label: Paragraph

text: seats, light fittings, cabinets, couches and expresso
label: Caption

text: machines, etc. According to Hertzberger this bunker-like
label: Paragraph

text: labyrinth - reminiscent in its introspection of Wright’s Larkin
label: Paragraph

text: Building of 1904 - has been deliberately left unfinished so
label: Paragraph

text: as to encourage the ‘spontaneous’ appropriation and
label: Paragraph

text: decoration of the space by its immediate users.
label: Paragraph

text: Hertzberger’s antipathy to the mechanistic provision of
label: Paragraph

text: flexibility, as found in the sophisticated infrastructural
label: Paragraph

text: propositions of both Habraken and Friedman, seems to have
label: Paragraph

text: been vindicated here by the apparent spontaneity and ease
label: Paragraph

text: with which the working spaces have been taken over and
label: Paragraph

text: modified. And while one can only be circumspect about the
label: Paragraph

text: rhetorical comparison that Hertzberger draws between the
label: Paragraph

text: appropriation of space in the Centraal Beheer and the
label: Paragraph

text: Saussurian linguistic distinction between /angue and parole,
label: Paragraph

text: there is little doubt that his approach has done something to
label: Paragraph

text: overcome the chronic inaccessibility of the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: discourse in a Taylorized age.
label: Paragraph

text: 306 Hertzberger, Centraal Beheer Building, Apeldoorn. Holland, 1974.
label: Caption

text: The architects of the Tendenza would surely agree with
label: Paragraph

text: Hertzberger’s argument that the functionalist organization
label: Paragraph

text: of residential units into strictly subdivided areas for living,
label: Paragraph

text: dining, cooking, washing and sleeping is in itself a tyranny,
label: Paragraph

text: and that we should attempt to return to the pre-industrial
label: Paragraph

text: norm of interconnected rooms, offering an altogether looser
label: Paragraph

text: fit between volume and activity (see Hertzberger’s
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Diagoon’ experimental houses built in Delft in 1971). On
label: Paragraph

text: the other hand they would no doubt reject outright his
label: Paragraph

text: ‘casbah’ concept, particularly as this appears in the
label: Paragraph

text: Centraal Beheer, on the grounds that such an introverted
label: Paragraph

text: type-form is incapable of providing representative public
label: Paragraph

text: space at an urban scale. The Centraal Beheer is, indeed,
label: Paragraph

text: indifferently related to its urban context. The fact that these
label: Paragraph

text: Islamic ‘bazaar’ or ‘patio’ building types inherently afford no
label: Paragraph

text: architectural element with which to express the hierarchical
label: Paragraph

text: status of the entrance is also confirmed at the Centraal
label: Paragraph

text: Beheer, where the company found it necessary to put up
label: Paragraph

text: signs directing visitors to the point of entry.
label: Caption

text: Since the mid-1970s Hertzberger has modified his
label: Paragraph

text: structuralist paradigm, not only in terms of the labyrinthine
label: Paragraph

text: introspective model that has since appeared in an equally
label: Paragraph

text: complex but spatially more generous version in the Ministry
label: Paragraph

text: of Social Welfare realized in The Hague in 1990 [307], but
label: Paragraph

text: also in terms of the mass forms assumed by recent works
label: Paragraph

text: projected for and realized in Berlin - the unbuilt film centre
label: Caption

text: for the Esplanade (1984) and the realized Lindenstrasse
label: Paragraph

text: housing (1986), which are unified by circular or semicircular
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter forms. Similarly, the four-square introspective
label: Paragraph

text: school type developed in 1980 for his prototypical Apollo
label: Paragraph

text: School in Amsterdam evolved through superimposed
label: Paragraph

text: circular perimeters into the Ambonplein School, also in
label: Paragraph

text: Amsterdam (1986), and then through freer adaptation into
label: Paragraph

text: the curved and splayed classroom wings of a school
label: Paragraph

text: extension at Aerdenhout [308, 309] completed in 1989. Of
label: Paragraph

text: the Aerdenhout school extension building, which was
label: Paragraph

text: distantly related to the work of Duiker, Joseph Buch has
label: Paragraph

text: written:
label: Title

text: 307 Hertzberger, Ministry of Social Welfare and Employment, The Hague, 1990.
label: Caption

text: Transverse sectional perspective.
label: Paragraph

text: 308, 309 Hertzberger, school extension, Aerdenhout, 1989. Plan and section.
label: Caption

text: Visibility from the classrooms to the central mixing space
label: Caption

text: has been increased with more glazing; instead of a single,
label: Paragraph

text: massive masonry Stair, there is a mix of concrete seating
label: Paragraph

text: steps and a light-weight open metal stair to the upper floor.
label: Caption

text: Like the exterior stairs in the Amsterdam schools, this has
label: Paragraph

text: been carefully composed, with the help of detail models,
label: Paragraph

text: into a welded sculpture with roofs as in Berlage’s
label: Paragraph

text: Smeedwerk. Hertzberger’s metal stairways make a direct
label: Paragraph

text: link with nautical detailing; after all the modernists’
label: Paragraph

text: fascination with ocean liners was not only about
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism, but also the rich and complex spatial
label: Paragraph

text: requirements of ship-layout. And this is indeed a rich and
label: Paragraph

text: complex spatial experience - especially in such a small
label: Paragraph

text: building. Hertzberger’s recent work has complemented the
label: Paragraph

text: sound basis of structuralism with a constantly increasing
label: Paragraph

text: sense of narrative.?°
label: Paragraph

text: Productivism
label: Title

text: Nothing could be further from the Centraal Beheer than the
label: Paragraph

text: three-storey glass-walled Willis-Faber and Dumas insurance
label: Caption

text: offices [252, 310] built at Ipswich in 1974 to the designs of
label: Paragraph

text: Foster Associates. For here all the emphasis has been
label: Paragraph

text: placed on the elegance of the production itself, on realizing
label: Paragraph

text: that which Max Bill once defined as the Produktform. It is
label: Paragraph

text: interesting to note that Norman Foster cites just such
label: Paragraph

text: Produktformen as the antecedents for his work, listing for
label: Paragraph

text: instance Paxton’s Crystal Palace, Charles and Ray Eames’s
label: Caption

text: own house built of ‘off-the-peg’ components at Santa
label: Caption

text: Monica, California (1949), SOM’s Marine Gunnery School at
label: Paragraph

text: Great Lakes, Illinois (1954) [311], and Bill’s Lausanne
label: Caption

text: Exhibition Pavilion (1963). Following in this line, in
label: Paragraph

text: opposition to Venturi’s populism, Willis-Faber is the
label: Paragraph

text: undecorated shed par excellence; a form whose only
label: Paragraph

text: differentiation, aside from its faceted serpentine curtain wall
label: Paragraph

text: (fig. 252), resided in the swimming pool on the ground floor
label: Paragraph

text: and the garden terrace restaurant on the roof.
label: Paragraph

text: 310 Foster Associates, Willis-Faber and Dumas Building, Ipswich, Suffolk, 1974.
label: Caption

text: 311 Skidmore, Owings and Merrill, Marine Gunnery School, Great Lakes, Illinois,
label: Caption

text: If Centraal Beheer is a hybrid building - derived in part
label: Paragraph

text: from the 19th-century arcade (see Pomerantsev’s New
label: Paragraph

text: Trading Lines, Moscow, of 1893) and in part from the Middle
label: Paragraph

text: Eastern casbah - Willis-Faber with its central escalator
label: Paragraph

text: access hall lies somewhere between the 20th-century office
label: Paragraph

text: tower and the 19th-century department store. The case can
label: Paragraph

text: be made, as G.C. Argan has proposed, that building types
label: Paragraph

text: embody certain values which were inherent at their
label: Paragraph

text: inception and which survive any subsequent transposition. It
label: Paragraph

text: is surely pertinent to the cultural significance of these
label: Paragraph

text: buildings that in both cases the tertiary industry of
label: Paragraph

text: informational exchange has come to be housed in spatial
label: Paragraph

text: types which, in part at least, were once spaces of
label: Paragraph

text: consumption - the casbah and the department store. It is
label: Paragraph

text: against this background that Centraal Beheer can be seen
label: Paragraph

text: as an attempt to overcome the bureaucratic division of
label: Paragraph

text: labour through the ‘anthropological’ occupation of its
label: Paragraph

text: labyrinthine office landscape. As in the traditional casbah,
label: Paragraph

text: Hertzberger’s fragmented Burolandschaft encourages a
label: Paragraph

text: pattern of behaviour that oscillates constantly between
label: Paragraph

text: moments of work and moments of relaxation. In Willis-Faber,
label: Paragraph

text: on the other hand, we are confronted with a Burolandschaft
label: Paragraph

text: that is a natural successor to Bentham’s Panopticon of
label: Paragraph

text: 1791, an open-plan form whose unremitting panorama of
label: Paragraph

text: order and control is supposedly compensated for by the
label: Paragraph

text: provision of centralized amenities such as the staff
label: Paragraph

text: restaurant and the swimming pool. Since these facilities are
label: Paragraph

text: equally subject to company control the scope of the
label: Paragraph

text: Panoptic domain appears to be total.
label: Paragraph

text: The contrast between these buildings also extends to the
label: Paragraph

text: ambience established by their detailing. The exposed
label: Paragraph

text: concrete-block partitions used throughout the Centraal
label: Paragraph

text: Beheer are supposed to provoke the ‘anarchistic’
label: Paragraph

text: appropriation of the space while Willis-Faber posits the
label: Paragraph

text: corporate image of a hypothetically egalitarian and affluent
label: Paragraph

text: society through the absolute impeccability of its pristine
label: Paragraph

text: skin and interior. Willis-Faber’s undulating curtain wall
label: Caption

text: evokes Mies’s glass skyscraper proposals of the 1920s,
label: Paragraph

text: although the actual technique employed, namely frameless
label: Paragraph

text: glass sheets hung from the roof, like a necklace, connected
label: Paragraph

text: by weatherproof neoprene joints, invites comparison with
label: Paragraph

text: the achievements of those American minimalists who,
label: Paragraph

text: having been trained by Eero Saarinen, came to prominence
label: Paragraph

text: in the 1970s - Kevin Roche (Ford Foundation Building, New
label: Caption

text: York, 1968, and United Nations Plaza Hotel, New York, 1973),
label: Caption

text: Gunnar Birkerts (Federal Reserve Bank, Minneapolis, 1967),
label: Caption

text: Cesar Pelli (Pacific Design Center, Los Angeles, 1971, and
label: Caption

text: San Bernardino City Hall, 1972), and the talented but
label: Paragraph

text: underappreciated Anthony Lumsden, whose most brilliant
label: Paragraph

text: work remains largely unbuilt (e.g. his project for the Beverly
label: Paragraph

text: Wilshire Hotel, Los Angeles, 1973).
label: Caption

text: The Willis-Faber building is Mies van der Rohe’s ‘almost
label: Paragraph

text: nothing’ stripped of its Classicism and brought through the
label: Paragraph

text: use of mirror-glass not only to answer the contextual
label: Paragraph

text: imperative of relating to the scale and texture of the
label: Paragraph

text: existing urban environment - in this instance, by simply
label: Paragraph

text: reflecting it - but also to respond to the modernist
label: Paragraph

text: predicament of the total loss of any commonly accessible,
label: Paragraph

text: or acceptable, ‘received’ language. Instead Willis-Faber
label: Paragraph

text: proffers a range of constantly changing kinaesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: sensations, opaque and scintillating in overcast light,
label: Paragraph

text: reflective in the sun, transparent at night. And yet ina
label: Paragraph

text: paradoxical way it shares with its Dutch counterpart the lack
label: Paragraph

text: of any naturally inflective syntax, with the result that its
label: Paragraph

text: entry is almost as invisible as the entrance to the Centraal
label: Paragraph

text: Beheer.
label: Paragraph

text: Productivism in its purest sense is virtually
label: Paragraph

text: indistinguishable, as a ‘modernist’ position, from the view
label: Paragraph

text: which holds that an authentic modern architecture can and
label: Paragraph

text: should be nothing more than elegant engineering, or
label: Paragraph

text: certainly a product of industrial design on a giant scale. As |
label: Paragraph

text: have already indicated, this is a view that has many
label: Paragraph

text: antecedents in the history of the Modern Movement, not
label: Paragraph

text: least among them the pioneering work of the French
label: Paragraph

text: artisan/engineer Jean Prouvé, dating back to his curtain wall
label: Paragraph

text: detailing of the Roland Garros Aeroclub in Paris of 1935 and
label: Caption

text: his modifiable Maison du Peuple in Clichy, Paris, built in
label: Caption

text: 1939 to designs which were developed in collaboration with
label: Paragraph

text: the engineer Vladimir Bodiansky and the architects Marcel
label: Title

text: Lods and Eugéne Beaudouin.
label: Paragraph

text: In taking Mies literally at his word (i.e. in the cult of
label: Paragraph

text: ‘almost nothing’), one wing of Productivism has
label: Paragraph

text: concentrated on air-Supported, inflatable structures, as
label: Paragraph

text: exemplified by Yutaka Murata’s Fuji Pavilion for Expo ’70 at
label: Paragraph

text: Osaka, or on cable-suspended tent construction, of which
label: Paragraph

text: the leading exponent is the German architect/engineer Frei
label: Paragraph

text: Otto. Although Otto’s earliest tented structures date from
label: Paragraph

text: the mid-1950s, he came to prominence with the large tents
label: Paragraph

text: he designed for the International Horticultural Exhibition
label: Caption

text: staged in Hamburg in 1963 and with the German Pavilion
label: Paragraph

text: built for the Montreal World Exposition of 1967 [312].
label: Caption

text: Understandably, this whole approach has been largely
label: Paragraph

text: restricted to temporary constructions, the largest to date
label: Paragraph

text: being Otto’s roof covering the stadium for the Munich
label: Paragraph

text: Olympics of 1972.
label: Paragraph

text: 312 Otto, German Pavilion at Expo 67, Montreal, 1967.
label: Caption

text: The basic precepts of Productivism may be summarized
label: Paragraph

text: as follows. In the first place, the building ‘task’ should be
label: Paragraph

text: accommodated, as far as is feasible, in an undecorated shed
label: Paragraph

text: or hangar, this loft structure to be kept as open and as
label: Paragraph

text: flexible as possible (on the model of the post-Second World
label: Paragraph

text: War bdrolandschaft ideal). In the second place, the
label: Paragraph

text: adaptability of this volume should be maintained by the
label: Paragraph

text: provision of a homogeneous and integrated network of
label: Paragraph

text: services - power, light, heat and ventilation (see Cedric
label: Title

text: Price’s concept of well-serviced anonymity). The third
label: Paragraph

text: precept concerns the necessity of articulating and
label: Paragraph

text: expressing both the structure and the services, usually
label: Paragraph

text: achieved by following Kahn's famous separation of served
label: Paragraph

text: and servant spaces. This last precept is patently
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated in the larger works of Richard Rogers, in his
label: Paragraph

text: Centre Pompidou and later in his headquarters building for
label: Caption

text: Lloyd’s of London, designed in 1976 and completed some
label: Paragraph

text: eight years later. The same basic idea is given a more
label: Paragraph

text: discreet (and ultimately more serviceable) expression in
label: Paragraph

text: Foster’s Sainsbury Centre for the Visual Arts, completed at
label: Caption

text: the University of East Anglia outside Norwich in 1978. Here
label: Paragraph

text: the servant space is accommodated precisely within the
label: Paragraph

text: depth of the trussed tubular steel supporting frames and 33-
label: Caption

text: metre spans (see Kahn's Salk Institute at La Jolla of 1965:
label: Paragraph

text: fig. 250). The fourth and all-important precept of
label: Paragraph

text: Productivism is of course the ‘unimpeded’ manifestation of
label: Paragraph

text: production itself, that is the expression of all component
label: Paragraph

text: parts as Produktformen - a hardline rule which is rarely
label: Paragraph

text: obeyed within the buildings of American minimalists (who
label: Paragraph

text: show little interest in revealed construction), though both
label: Paragraph

text: American and British Productivists strive for a smooth all-
label: Paragraph

text: enveloping ‘consumerist’ skin. As Andrew Peckham
label: Paragraph

text: observed of the Sainsbury Centre, ‘[Foster’s] ability to
label: Paragraph

text: persuade us doesn’t hinge on the traditional language of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture but rather on the language of the modern
label: Paragraph

text: material world - of industrial production and consumable
label: Title

text: finishes’.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the few basic variables in the Productivist
label: Paragraph

text: approach is the extent to which the skin or the skeleton is
label: Paragraph

text: the dominant mode of expression. This differentiation
label: Paragraph

text: formerly permitted one to distinguish between the
label: Paragraph

text: respective rhetorical attitudes adopted by the Foster and
label: Paragraph

text: Rogers practices, with the former ultimately favouring the
label: Paragraph

text: skin and the latter placing the prime expressive burden on
label: Paragraph

text: the structure. Foster Associates modified their approach,
label: Paragraph

text: however, turning increasingly towards the extrinsic
label: Paragraph

text: expression of structure, most notably in their Renault
label: Paragraph

text: factory at Swindon, Wiltshire, completed in 1983, and in
label: Paragraph

text: their headquarters building for the Hongkong and Shanghai
label: Paragraph

text: Banking Corporation in Hong Kong, designed in 1979 [313].
label: Paragraph

text: More than any of the more fantastic structures envisaged by
label: Paragraph

text: Archigram or Buckminster Fuller, this layered skyscraper
label: Paragraph

text: (comprising three 16.2-metre [53-foot] deep slabs rising to
label: Paragraph

text: 28, 35 and 41 storeys respectively) invites comparison with
label: Paragraph

text: the rocket-launching structures of Cape Canaveral - not for
label: Paragraph

text: its overall size, but for the colossal scale of its articulated
label: Paragraph

text: components, above all for its double-height deep, giant
label: Paragraph

text: exposed tubular steel trusses, spanning 38.4 metres (126
label: Caption

text: feet), from which the floors are suspended, grouped in sets,
label: Paragraph

text: seven at the bottom, then six, then five, and finally four
label: Paragraph

text: floors which top out the structure. Foster’s own words are
label: Paragraph

text: only too eloquent of the strange mixture of reality and
label: Paragraph

text: techno-romanticism which determined this building’s form:
label: Paragraph

text: 313 Foster Associates, Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation
label: Caption

text: headquarters, Hong Kong, 1979-84.

text: The difficulties of building rapidly and quietly on a tight site

text: Post-Modernism
label: Title

text: The architectural section of the Venice Biennale of 1980,
label: Paragraph

text: ‘The Presence of the Past’, announced in various ways the
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of Post-Modernism at a global level [315]. While
label: Paragraph

text: it cannot be defined in terms of a specific set of stylistic and
label: Paragraph

text: ideological characteristics, the fact that it tends to proclaim
label: Paragraph

text: its legitimacy in exclusively formal - not to say superficial -
label: Paragraph

text: terms, rather than in terms of constructional, organizational
label: Paragraph

text: or socio-cultural considerations (such as were still central to
label: Paragraph

text: the revisionism of Team X), already separates it, as a modus
label: Paragraph

text: operandi, from the architectural production of the third
label: Paragraph

text: quarter of the century. Notwithstanding Portoghesi’s
label: Paragraph

text: Biennale thesis, however, the past was already a presence
label: Paragraph

text: in the major monuments of the period.
label: Paragraph

text: 315 Part of the ‘Strada Novissima’ at the Venice Biennale, 1980. From right to
label: Caption

text: left the facades are by Hollein, Kleihues, Léon Krier, and Venturi, Rauch & Scott
label: Caption

text: Brown.
label: Paragraph

text: Needless to say, the most distinguished American
label: Paragraph

text: architects of the preceding decades, Mies van der Rohe and
label: Paragraph

text: Louis Kahn, remained committed to a deconstruction of this
label: Paragraph

text: historical legacy and to a reassembly of its precepts and
label: Paragraph

text: components in accordance with the technological capacity
label: Paragraph

text: of the epoch: the work remained expressive of its time, even
label: Paragraph

text: if certain tectonic elements and compositional models were
label: Paragraph

text: patently (and even polemically) determined by historical
label: Paragraph

text: precedents. Mies van der Rohe’s Neue Nationalgalerie in
label: Paragraph

text: Berlin (commissioned 1961, built 1965-68) and Kahn’s
label: Paragraph

text: Kimbell Art Museum at Fort Worth, Texas (1967-72) illustrate
label: Caption

text: this, the one tied to Schinkel and 19th-century ferrovitreous
label: Paragraph

text: engineering, the other to Mediterranean vaulted
label: Title

text: construction and the tectonics of reinforced concrete.
label: Paragraph

text: Millennialistic utopianism is of course largely absent from
label: Paragraph

text: the later work of both men, the focus being instead upon
label: Paragraph

text: the irreducible nature of tectonic construction and upon its
label: Paragraph

text: sublime interaction with light, as the two transhistorical
label: Paragraph

text: conditions of architecture, and, in Kahn’s case, upon a form
label: Paragraph

text: of cosmological, cabbalistic mysticism. Both Mies and Kahn
label: Paragraph

text: would have seen the advent of Post-Modernism as cultural
label: Paragraph

text: decadence; and indeed we have Kahn's aphoristic reproach
label: Paragraph

text: to Venturi, on seeing his proposal for the Philadelphia
label: Paragraph

text: Bicentennial ‘strip’, to the effect that ‘colour ain’t
label: Paragraph

text: architecture’.
label: Paragraph

text: We may claim, in this regard, that no ‘master’ architects
label: Paragraph

text: in history were more misunderstood by their immediate
label: Paragraph

text: pupils and heirs than Mies and Kahn. Mies was patently
label: Paragraph

text: gratified by his success in formulating the normative
label: Paragraph

text: American mode of corporate building from 1950 to 1975,
label: Paragraph

text: the Miesian format becoming standard for a certain sector
label: Paragraph

text: of development in the post-war world (see Arthur Drexler’s
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Buildings for Business and Government’, MoMA, 1959), but
label: Paragraph

text: both he and Kahn tended to find that the latent qualities of
label: Paragraph

text: their work were better appreciated in Europe. Thus while the
label: Paragraph

text: Skidmore, Owings and Merrill-dominated Chicago School
label: Paragraph

text: succeeded in following Mies with verve and audacity,
label: Paragraph

text: architects like Myron Goldsmith (United Airlines, Des Plaines,
label: Paragraph

text: Illinois, 1962), Gene Summers (McCormick Place, Chicago,
label: Caption

text: 1971) and Arthur Takeuchi (Wendell Smith Elementary
label: Title

text: School, Chicago, 1973) all failed to arrive at a fresh point of
label: Paragraph

text: departure, possibly because they were unable to appreciate
label: Paragraph

text: sufficiently the Romantic Classical and Suprematist
label: Title

text: dimensions which lay hidden in Mies’s work. In the same
label: Paragraph

text: way Kahn, despite his disciples of the Philadelphia School
label: Paragraph

text: (Moore, Venturi, Vreeland and Giurgola), ultimately found a
label: Paragraph

text: more sensitive following in Italian Neo-Rationalism and
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch Structuralism.
label: Paragraph

text: This eclipse of Late Modernism in America, together with the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘consensus’ rejection of what Jurgen Habermas called the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘unfinished modern project’, as this had been so fervently
label: Paragraph

text: integrated into the myth and reality of American
label: Paragraph

text: development over the past century, is nowhere more
label: Paragraph

text: evident than in the current repudiation of Frank Lloyd
label: Paragraph

text: Wright, particularly when one considers Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: indisputable status as one of the most fertile architects of
label: Paragraph

text: this century. It is significant how, apart from the antiquarian
label: Paragraph

text: art market, Wright continues to be ignored by the American
label: Paragraph

text: protagonists of Post-Modernism, despite the efforts of
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Jencks to validate Michael Graves by way of Wright
label: Caption

text: in his book Kings of Infinite Space (1983). The reason for
label: Paragraph

text: this amnesia is not hard to find, since Wright has to be
label: Paragraph

text: counted among those modernists (Aalto would be another)
label: Paragraph

text: whose work can in no way be dismissed as reductive or
label: Paragraph

text: inaccessible. One may advance as evidence to the contrary
label: Paragraph

text: the 200 Usonian houses which Wright built in his own
label: Paragraph

text: lifetime and think of them as an attempt to render the
label: Paragraph

text: generic suburb as a cultivated domain.
label: Paragraph

text: It is difficult to arrive at the fundamental character of the
label: Paragraph

text: Post-Modern phenomenon as this has emerged in
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and almost every other cultural field. From one
label: Paragraph

text: point of view it has to be acknowledged as an
label: Paragraph

text: understandable reaction to the pressures of societal
label: Paragraph

text: modernization and thus as an escape from the tendency of
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary life to be totally dominated by the values of
label: Paragraph

text: the scientific-industrial complex. Yet while the utopian
label: Paragraph

text: emancipatory aims of the Enlightenment may now have to
label: Paragraph

text: be relinquished in the name of more effective and
label: Paragraph

text: reassuring forms of realism, there is little evidence that
label: Paragraph

text: modern society either can or, finally, wishes to renounce the
label: Paragraph

text: fundamental ‘benefits’ of modernization. Moreover, as
label: Paragraph

text: Habermas suggested in his Theodor Adorno Prize address of
label: Paragraph

text: 1980, it is the speed and rapacity of modern development,
label: Paragraph

text: rather than avant-gardist culture, that is responsible for
label: Paragraph

text: disruptions and disappointments, together with this
label: Paragraph

text: apparently popular rejection of the new. In the end, even the
label: Paragraph

text: staunchest Neo-Conservative will admit there is little chance
label: Paragraph

text: of resisting, in real terms, the relentless progress of
label: Paragraph

text: modernization.
label: Paragraph

text: If there is a general principle that can be said to
label: Paragraph

text: characterize Post-Modern architecture, it is the conscious
label: Paragraph

text: ruination of style and the cannibalization of architectural
label: Title

text: form, as though no value either traditional or otherwise can
label: Paragraph

text: withstand for long the tendency of the
label: Paragraph

text: production/consumption cycle to reduce every civic
label: Title

text: institution to some kind of consumerism and to undermine
label: Paragraph

text: every traditional quality. Today the division of labour and the
label: Paragraph

text: imperatives of ‘monopolized’ economy are such as to
label: Paragraph

text: reduce the practice of architecture to large-scale packaging;
label: Paragraph

text: and at least one Post-Modern architect, Helmut Jahn, has
label: Paragraph

text: frankly acknowledged that this is how he sees his role. At its
label: Paragraph

text: most predetermined, Post-Modernism reduces architecture
label: Paragraph

text: to a condition in which the ‘package deal’ arranged by the
label: Paragraph

text: builder/developer determines the carcass and the essential
label: Paragraph

text: substance of the work, while the architect is reduced to
label: Paragraph

text: contributing a suitably seductive mask. This is the
label: Paragraph

text: predominant situation in city-centre development in
label: Paragraph

text: America today, where high-rise towers are either reduced to
label: Paragraph

text: the ‘silence’ of their totally glazed, reflective envelopes or
label: Paragraph

text: alternatively dressed in devalued historical trappings of one
label: Paragraph

text: kind or another. Indeed Jahn’s Popular Machinism must be
label: Paragraph

text: regarded as an attempt to combine both strategies.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Michael Graves has been a symptomatic figure in this
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph
