text: projects in a number of French new towns - the urban
label: Paragraph

text: quarter known as Les Arcades du Lac in St Quentin-en-
label: Paragraph

text: Yvelines (1974-80) and the theatrical Abraxas perimeter
label: Title

text: block in Marne-la-Vallée (1979-83) - it would be hard to
label: Paragraph

text: imagine another contemporary Western practitioner who
label: Paragraph

text: has enjoyed such a close relationship with State power or
label: Paragraph

text: indeed one who is so simplistically identified with power at
label: Paragraph

text: this level. Needless to say this identification, together with
label: Paragraph

text: the worldly success which it inevitably entails, does nothing
label: Paragraph

text: to legitimize this ‘incarceration’ of collective dwelling units
label: Paragraph

text: within a carcass of kitsch classicism. This technically
label: Paragraph

text: accomplished parallel to Jahn’s Popular Machinism
label: Paragraph

text: understandably entails a total denial of the values placed on
label: Paragraph

text: the monument by the Tendenza, for while this is by no
label: Paragraph

text: means the first time that mass housing has been given a
label: Paragraph

text: monumental form (see Karl Ehn’s Karl Marx Hof, Vienna, of
label: Paragraph

text: 1927 and Le Corbusier’s Unité d’Habitation, Marseilles, of
label: Paragraph

text: 1952), not since the time of the Ringstrasse - Loos’s
label: Paragraph

text: Potemkinstadt - has the aggregation of dwelling units been
label: Paragraph

text: so scenographically rendered. It is surely symptomatic of
label: Paragraph

text: our reactionary period, both from a social and an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural point of view, that there is little
label: Paragraph

text: accommodation or representation in Bofill’s work of those
label: Paragraph

text: ‘social condensers’ - nursery schools, meeting rooms,
label: Caption

text: laundries and swimming pools - that public housing should
label: Paragraph

text: demand. The absence of such amenities is as reactionary as
label: Paragraph

text: the brutal nature of the standard apartments which are
label: Paragraph

text: wilfully encased in these false architraves and empty
label: Paragraph

text: columns. Deprived of a terrace, since this does not accord
label: Paragraph

text: with the assumed syntax, the upwardly mobile resident has
label: Paragraph

text: to be satisfied with the operatic illusion of living in a palace.
label: Paragraph

text: Neo-Avant-Gardism
label: Title

text: Despite the American following enjoyed by Aldo Rossi, Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Rationalism did not exert much influence on the evolution of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in the United States. In part this may be
label: Paragraph

text: attributed to its lack of relevance to the American city,
label: Paragraph

text: which has nowhere the same typological and morphological
label: Paragraph

text: complexity as its traditional European counterpart. The
label: Paragraph

text: Tendenza thesis about the ‘continuity of the monument’
label: Paragraph

text: could have little credibility in a society where the urban
label: Paragraph

text: context itself was so unstable. On the other hand, an
label: Paragraph

text: attempt was made in the second half of the 1960s to
label: Paragraph

text: develop a theoretical and artistic production as rigorous as
label: Paragraph

text: that achieved by the pre-war European avant garde. This
label: Paragraph

text: effort crystallized around the work of the Five Architects, a
label: Paragraph

text: loosely knit association of New York-based architects under
label: Paragraph

text: the leadership of Peter Eisenman. While two members of
label: Paragraph

text: this group were to ground their work in pre-war avant-
label: Paragraph

text: gardist aesthetic practice, namely Eisenman and John
label: Paragraph

text: Hejduk, who respectively took Giuseppe Terragni and Theo
label: Paragraph

text: van Doesburg as their models, the remaining three, Michael
label: Paragraph

text: Graves, Charles Gwathmey and Richard Meier, assumed the
label: Paragraph

text: Purist period of Le Corbusier as their point of departure. The
label: Paragraph

text: New York Five’s commitment to the idea of an autonomous
label: Title

text: architecture, removed from what they saw as the reductive
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism of the Neue Sachlichkeit, was most
label: Paragraph

text: categorically expressed in Eisenman’s House VI, the Frank
label: Paragraph

text: House, built at West Cornwall, Connecticut, in 1972, and in
label: Paragraph

text: certain polemical projects by Hejduk - his Diamond House
label: Caption

text: series (1963-67) and above all his Wall House (1970). While
label: Paragraph

text: Hejduk later abandoned his early formalism to devote his
label: Paragraph

text: energies to the creation of a series of mythical settings such
label: Paragraph

text: as his Berlin Masques of 1981, and Graves left behind his
label: Paragraph

text: early Neo-Purism in favour of a more decorative Post-
label: Paragraph

text: Modernist approach (e.g. his Disney Hotel in Orlando,
label: Paragraph

text: Florida, of 1991), Gwathmey and Meier remained faithful to
label: Paragraph

text: their Purist roots, above all perhaps Meier, whose High
label: Paragraph

text: Museum in Atlanta, Georgia (1980-83) [319], and Applied
label: Paragraph

text: Art Museum in Frankfurt (1979-84) have secured him a
label: Paragraph

text: reputation as one of the most civic-minded architects of his
label: Paragraph

text: generation. Indeed, he has since gone on to become an
label: Paragraph

text: architect of world renown with major public works in cities
label: Paragraph

text: as diverse as Los Angeles, Paris and Barcelona.
label: Paragraph

text: 319 Meier, High Museum, Atlanta, 1980-83.
label: Caption

text: The New York Five were not the only architects of the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s to ground their work in the aesthetic and ideological
label: Paragraph

text: premises of the 20th-century avant-garde. The role they
label: Paragraph

text: assumed in New York was echoed in London in the work of
label: Paragraph

text: OMA (Office for Metropolitan Architecture) [320], comprising
label: Paragraph

text: Rem Koolhaas, Elia and Zoe Zenghelis and Madelon
label: Title

text: Vriesendorp. Like Hejduk, whose early work was eclectically
label: Paragraph

text: inspired to an equal degree by Neo-Plasticism and the later
label: Paragraph

text: Mies, Koolhaas and Zenghelis predicated their urban
label: Paragraph

text: projects on the Suprematist architecture of lvan Leonidov
label: Caption

text: while at the same time turning to Surrealist practice for
label: Paragraph

text: ways of achieving what Roland Barthes termed a ‘répétition
label: Paragraph

text: différente’.
label: Paragraph

text: 320 Koolhaas (OMA), project for ferry terminal, Zeebrugge, 1990. Model.
label: Caption

text: Apart from giving rise through teaching to a further
label: Paragraph

text: generation of latter-day Neo-Suprematists, most notably
label: Paragraph

text: Laurinda Spear of Arquitectonica (Spear House, Miami,
label: Caption

text: 1979) and Zaha Hadid (Hong Kong Peak Competition, 1983),
label: Paragraph

text: OMA created major civic design projects in the early 1980s
label: Paragraph

text: including a villa colony for the Greek island of Antiparos and
label: Paragraph

text: a housing quarter for Kochstrasse in Berlin.
label: Paragraph

text: By this date Eisenman had already produced his radical
label: Paragraph

text: proposal for Cannaregio in Venice (1978), wherein rather
label: Paragraph

text: than relating to the existing fabric he chose to superimpose
label: Paragraph

text: an arbitrary grid on the city, one wilfully derived from Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s unrealized Venice hospital project of 1964.
label: Paragraph

text: Different-scaled versions of his House Xla, designed in the
label: Paragraph

text: previous year, were installed at intervals where
label: Paragraph

text: intersections of the grid coincided with existing open spaces
label: Paragraph

text: within the Cannaregio district. This anti-humanist play with
label: Paragraph

text: varying scales, for which Eisenman would later coin the
label: Paragraph

text: term ‘scaling’, was meant to subvert any received ideas as
label: Paragraph

text: to an appropriately anthropomorphic scale or civic
label: Paragraph

text: dimension. With this singularly apocalyptic work Eisenman
label: Paragraph

text: introduced the quasi-Dadaist modus operandi with which he
label: Paragraph

text: has been occupied ever since - namely, the derivation of
label: Paragraph

text: form from more or less arbitrary overlays of different grids,
label: Paragraph

text: axes, scales and contours, irrespective of whether these
label: Paragraph

text: happen to have any connection with the real context: see
label: Paragraph

text: his Berlin Friedrichstrasse housing (1982-86) and his
label: Paragraph

text: Wexner Center for the Visual Arts at Columbus, Ohio (1983-
label: Caption

text: 321 Eisenman, Wexner Center for the Visual Arts, Columbus, Ohio, 1983-89. Air
label: Caption

text: view showing the insertion of the new building into the existing campus fabric.
label: Caption

text: The year 1983 was decisive for Neo-Avant-Gardism, as
label: Paragraph

text: Rem Koolhaas and the American-based Swiss architect
label: Title

text: Bernard Tschumi competed openly in the final phases for the
label: Paragraph

text: commission to realize the Parc de la Villette in Paris as a
label: Paragraph

text: prototypical urban park for the 21st century. Significantly
label: Paragraph

text: enough, given the subsequent emergence of
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Deconstructivism’ in architecture, Tschumi’s premiated
label: Paragraph

text: design of 1984 drew its essential parti from two basic
label: Paragraph

text: paradigms: from Wassily Kandinsky’s didactic ‘point, line
label: Title

text: and plane’ as set forth in Bauhausbticher No. 9, and from an
label: Paragraph

text: attitude to disjunctive spatial narrative, as derived from the
label: Paragraph

text: non-sequential cutting technique pioneered by the Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: avant-gardist film-maker Kuleshov. Variously indebted to
label: Paragraph

text: Russian Constructivism and even to the mariage de contour
label: Title

text: to be found in the early landscapes of Roberto Burle Marx
label: Paragraph

text: and Oscar Niemeyer, Tschumi aspired to an anti-classical
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in which unexpected configurations and uses
label: Title

text: would arise out of the red constructivist ‘follies’ that
label: Paragraph

text: punctuate the park at regular intervals [322]. Tschumi
label: Caption

text: differentiates between one folly and the next by ringing the
label: Paragraph

text: changes on a series of prisms, cylinders, ramps, stairs and
label: Caption

text: canopies that reflect to a limited extent basic differences in
label: Paragraph

text: the structures’ content. This partial match and miss-match
label: Paragraph

text: between programme and form appears again in the running
label: Paragraph

text: track incongruously projected into the main volume of
label: Paragraph

text: Tschumi’s Bibliotheque de France competition design of
label: Paragraph

text: 322 Tschumi, Parc de La Villette, designed 1984.
label: Caption

text: Similar but by no means identical ‘Deconstructivist’
label: Paragraph

text: strategies were employed by other architects throughout
label: Paragraph

text: the 1980s, starting with Frank Gehry’s own house in Los
label: Paragraph

text: Angeles of 1978 and continuing with a number of works all
label: Paragraph

text: from the late 1980s, including Eisenman’s Bio-Center
label: Paragraph

text: projected for Frankfurt, OMA’s apartment block realized at
label: Paragraph

text: Checkpoint Charlie in Berlin, Daniel Libeskind’s apocalyptic
label: Title

text: City Edge proposal for the same city, and Koolhaas’s Dance
label: Paragraph

text: Theatre completed in The Hague in 1987. As Mark Wigley
label: Paragraph

text: wrote in his catalogue to the 1988 show at the Museum of
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Art, New York, entitled Deconstructivist Architecture,
label: Caption

text: The form is distorting itself. Yet this internal distortion does
label: Paragraph

text: not destroy the form. In a strange way, the form remains
label: Paragraph

text: intact. This is an architecture of disruption, dislocation,
label: Paragraph

text: deflection, deviation and distortion, rather than one of
label: Paragraph

text: demolition, dismantling, decay, decomposition and
label: Title

text: disintegration. It displaces structure instead of destroying it.
label: Paragraph

text: What is finally so unsettling about such work is precisely
label: Paragraph

text: that the form not only survives its torture but appears all
label: Paragraph

text: the stronger for it. Perhaps the form is even produced by it.
label: Paragraph

text: It becomes unclear which came first, the form or the
label: Paragraph

text: distortion, the host or the parasite. ... No surgical technique
label: Paragraph

text: can free the form; no clean incision can be made. To remove
label: Paragraph

text: the parasite would be to kill the host. They comprise one
label: Paragraph

text: symbiotic entity.23
label: Caption

text: For all its critical acuity, much of the theoretical
label: Paragraph

text: discourse that accompanies this work is both elitist and
label: Paragraph

text: detached, testifying to the self-alienation of an avant garde
label: Paragraph

text: without a cause: as the Dutch critic Arie Graafland
label: Paragraph

text: remarked, where Constructivism intended a synthesis - the
label: Paragraph

text: creation of a new architecture for a new society -
label: Paragraph

text: Deconstructivism’s anti-thesis derives, at least in part, from
label: Paragraph

text: the recognition that global modernization is pushing so-
label: Paragraph

text: called technocratic order beyond its rational limits. The
label: Paragraph

text: predicament finds reflection in the thought of the founding
label: Paragraph

text: father of Deconstruction, the philosopher Jacques Derrida,
label: Paragraph

text: who has collaborated with Eisenman and Tschumi on the
label: Paragraph

text: project for a small garden in the Parc de la Villette.
label: Caption

text: Disenchanted with the idealistic legacy of the
label: Paragraph

text: Enlightenment and caught as architecture is caught
label: Paragraph

text: between the conflicting demands of practical and poetic
label: Paragraph

text: reason, Derrida seems to aspire to an aporetic middle
label: Paragraph

text: ground somewhere between Heidegger's existentialist
label: Paragraph

text: critique and a form of social pragmatism loosely related to
label: Paragraph

text: the irreducible ambiguity of language.
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 5
label: Title

text: Critical Regionalism:
label: Title

text: Modern Architecture and
label: Title

text: Cultural Identity
label: Title

text: The phenomenon of universalization, while being an
label: Paragraph

text: advancement of mankind, at the same time constitutes a
label: Paragraph

text: sort of subtle destruction, not only of traditional cultures,
label: Paragraph

text: which might not be an irreparable wrong, but also of what |
label: Paragraph

text: shall call for the time being the creative nucleus of great
label: Paragraph

text: civilizations and great culture, that nucleus on the basis of
label: Paragraph

text: which we interpret life, what | shall call in advance the
label: Paragraph

text: ethical and mythical nucleus of mankind. The conflict
label: Paragraph

text: springs up from there. We have the feeling that this single
label: Paragraph

text: world civilization at the same time exerts a sort of attrition
label: Paragraph

text: or wearing away at the expense of the cultural resources
label: Paragraph

text: which have made the great civilizations of the past. This
label: Paragraph

text: threat is expressed, among other disturbing effects, by the
label: Paragraph

text: spreading before our eyes of a mediocre civilization which is
label: Paragraph

text: the absurd counterpart of what | was just calling elementary
label: Paragraph

text: culture. Everywhere throughout the world, one finds the
label: Paragraph

text: same bad movie, the same slot machines, the same plastic
label: Paragraph

text: or aluminum atrocities, the same twisting of language by
label: Paragraph

text: propaganda, etc. It seems as if mankind, by approaching en
label: Paragraph

text: masse a basic consumer culture, were also stopped en
label: Paragraph

text: masse at a subcultural level. Thus we come to the crucial
label: Paragraph

text: problem confronting nations just rising from
label: Title

text: underdevelopment. In order to get on to the road toward
label: Paragraph

text: modernization, is it necessary to jettison the old cultural
label: Paragraph

text: past which has been the raison d’étre of a nation? ...
label: Paragraph

text: Whence the paradox: on the one hand, it (the nation) has to
label: Paragraph

text: root itself in the soil of its past, forge a national spirit, and
label: Paragraph

text: unfurl this spiritual and cultural revendication before the
label: Paragraph

text: colonialist’s personality. But in order to take part in modern
label: Paragraph

text: civilization, it is necessary at the same time to take part in
label: Paragraph

text: scientific, technical, and political rationality, something
label: Paragraph

text: which very often requires the pure and simple abandon of a
label: Paragraph

text: whole cultural past. It is a fact: every culture cannot sustain
label: Paragraph

text: and absorb the shock of modern civilization. There is the
label: Paragraph

text: paradox: how to become modern and to return to sources;
label: Title

text: how to revive an old, dormant civilization and take part in
label: Paragraph

text: universal civilization. ...
label: Paragraph

text: No one can say what will become of our civilization when
label: Paragraph

text: it has really met different civilizations by means other than
label: Paragraph

text: the shock of conquest and domination. But we have to
label: Paragraph

text: admit that this encounter has not yet taken place at the
label: Paragraph

text: level of an authentic dialogue. That is why we are in a kind
label: Paragraph

text: of lull or interregnum in which we can no longer practice the
label: Paragraph

text: dogmatism of a single truth and in which we are not yet
label: Paragraph

text: capable of conquering the skepticism into which we have
label: Paragraph

text: stepped. We are in a tunnel, at the twilight of dogmatism
label: Paragraph

text: and the dawn of real dialogues.
label: Paragraph

text: Paul Ricoeur
label: Title

text: ‘Universal Civilization and National Cultures’, 19611
label: Caption

text: The term ‘Critical Regionalism’ is not intended to denote the
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular as this was once spontaneously produced by the
label: Paragraph

text: combined interaction of climate, culture, myth and craft, but
label: Paragraph

text: rather to identify those recent regional ‘schools’ whose
label: Paragraph

text: primary aim has been to reflect and serve the limited
label: Paragraph

text: constituencies in which they are grounded. Among other
label: Paragraph

text: factors contributing to the emergence of a regionalism of
label: Paragraph

text: this order is not only a certain prosperity but also some kind
label: Paragraph

text: of anti-centrist consensus - an aspiration at least to some
label: Paragraph

text: form of cultural, economic and political independence.
label: Paragraph

text: The concept of a local or national culture is a paradoxical
label: Paragraph

text: proposition not only because of the present obvious
label: Paragraph

text: antithesis between rooted culture and universal civilization
label: Title

text: but also because all cultures, both ancient and modern,
label: Paragraph

text: seem to have depended for their intrinsic development on a
label: Paragraph

text: certain cross-fertilization with other cultures. As Ricoeur
label: Paragraph

text: seems to imply in the passage quoted above, regional or
label: Paragraph

text: national cultures must today, more than ever, be ultimately
label: Paragraph

text: constituted as locally inflected manifestations of ‘world
label: Paragraph

text: culture’. It is surely no accident that this paradoxical
label: Paragraph

text: proposition arises at a time when global modernization
label: Paragraph

text: continues to undermine, with ever increasing force, all forms
label: Paragraph

text: of traditional, agrarian-based, autochthonous culture. From
label: Paragraph

text: the point of view of critical theory we have to regard
label: Paragraph

text: regional culture not as something given and relatively
label: Paragraph

text: immutable but rather as something which has, at least
label: Paragraph

text: today, to be self-consciously cultivated. Ricoeur suggests
label: Paragraph

text: that sustaining any kind of authentic culture in the future
label: Paragraph

text: will depend ultimately on our capacity to generate vital
label: Paragraph

text: forms of regional culture while appropriating alien influences
label: Paragraph

text: at the level of both culture and civilization.
label: Paragraph

text: Such a process of assimilation and reinterpretation
label: Paragraph

text: seems to be evident in the work of the Danish master Jgrn
label: Paragraph

text: Utzon, above all in his Bagsvaerd Church [323], completed
label: Caption

text: in a suburb outside Copenhagen in 1976, wherein precast
label: Paragraph

text: concrete infill elements of standardized dimensions are
label: Paragraph

text: combined, in a particularly articulate way, with /n-situ
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete shell vaults which span the principal
label: Caption

text: public volumes. And while this combination of modular
label: Paragraph

text: assembly and /n-situ casting may appear at first to be
label: Paragraph

text: nothing more than an appropriate integration of the full
label: Paragraph

text: range of concrete techniques which are now at our disposal,
label: Paragraph

text: the case can be made that the way in which these
label: Paragraph

text: techniques are combined alludes to a number of dialogically
label: Paragraph

text: opposed values.
label: Paragraph

text: 323 Utzon, Bagsvaerd Church, near Copenhagen, 1976: longitudinal section.
label: Caption

text: At one level, we may claim that prefabricated modular
label: Paragraph

text: assembly not only accords with the values of universal
label: Paragraph

text: civilization but also ‘represents’ its capacity for normative
label: Paragraph

text: application, whereas an in-situ shell vault is a ‘one-off’
label: Paragraph

text: structural invention built into a unique site. It may be
label: Paragraph

text: argued, in the light of Ricoeur, that where the one affirms
label: Paragraph

text: the norms of universal civilization, the other proclaims the
label: Paragraph

text: values of idiosyncratic culture. Similarly, we may construe
label: Paragraph

text: these different forms of concrete construction as setting the
label: Paragraph

text: rationality of normative technique against the arationality of
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic structure.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet another dialogue is evoked as soon as one passes
label: Paragraph

text: from the economically optimum modular cladding of the
label: Paragraph

text: exterior (be it the concrete panels or the patent glazing in
label: Paragraph

text: the roof) to the far from optimum /n-situ frame and shell
label: Paragraph

text: vault spanning the nave. Such vaulting, a relatively
label: Paragraph

text: uneconomic mode of construction when compared say to
label: Paragraph

text: steel trusswork, has been deliberately selected for its
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic capacity: the vault signifies the sacred in Western
label: Paragraph

text: culture. And yet the highly configurated section adopted in
label: Paragraph

text: this instance can hardly be regarded as Western. Indeed the
label: Paragraph

text: only precedent for such a section in a sacred context is
label: Paragraph

text: Eastern - the Chinese pagoda roof, cited by Utzon in his
label: Paragraph

text: seminal essay of 1962, ‘Platforms and Plateaus: Ideas of a
label: Paragraph

text: Danish Architect’.
label: Paragraph

text: The subtle and contrary allusions incorporated into this
label: Paragraph

text: folded concrete shell roof have far greater consequence
label: Paragraph

text: than the seeming perversity of reinterpreting an oriental
label: Paragraph

text: timber form in occidental concrete technology; for while the
label: Paragraph

text: main vault over the nave suggests by its scale and top
label: Caption

text: illumination the presence of a religious space, it does so in
label: Paragraph

text: such a way as to preclude an exclusively occidental or
label: Paragraph

text: oriental reading of the form by which it is constituted. A
label: Paragraph

text: similar occidental/oriental interpenetration also occurs in
label: Paragraph

text: the wooden fenestration and slatted partitions which seem
label: Paragraph

text: to allude both to the Nordic vernacular of the stave church
label: Paragraph

text: and to the fretted traditional timberwork of China and Japan.
label: Paragraph

text: The intention behind these procedures of deconstruction
label: Paragraph

text: and resynthesis seems to be as follows: first, to revitalize
label: Paragraph

text: certain devalued Occidental forms through an Oriental
label: Paragraph

text: recasting of their essential nature; and second to indicate
label: Paragraph

text: the secularization of the institutions represented by these
label: Paragraph

text: forms. This is arguably a more appropriate way to render a
label: Paragraph

text: church in a secular age, where traditional ecclesiastical
label: Paragraph

text: iconography always risks degenerating into kitsch.
label: Paragraph

text: This revitalization of occidental elements with oriental
label: Paragraph

text: profiles and vice versa by no means exhausts the ways in
label: Paragraph

text: which the Bagsvaerd Church is inflected with regard to its
label: Paragraph

text: situation in time and place. Utzon has also given ita
label: Paragraph

text: barnlike form, using an agricultural metaphor as a way of
label: Paragraph

text: giving public expression to a sacred institution. But this
label: Paragraph

text: somewhat cryptic metaphor, associating religion with
label: Paragraph

text: agrarian culture, may well change somewhat with the
label: Paragraph

text: passage of time, for when the surrounding saplings have
label: Paragraph

text: matured the church will for the first time appear within its
label: Paragraph

text: own proper boundaries. This natural temenos, established
label: Paragraph

text: by a veil of trees, will no doubt encourage a future reading
label: Paragraph

text: of the building as a temple rather than a barn.
label: Paragraph

text: Exemplary of an explicitly anti-centrist regionalism was
label: Paragraph

text: the Catalan nationalist movement which first emerged with
label: Paragraph

text: the foundation of Grup R in Barcelona in 1952. This group,
label: Paragraph

text: led by J.M. Sostres and Oriol Bohigas, found itself caught
label: Paragraph

text: from the beginning in a complex cultural situation. On the
label: Paragraph

text: one hand, it was obliged to revive the Rationalist, anti-
label: Paragraph

text: Fascist values and procedures of GATEPAC (the pre-war
label: Title

text: Spanish wing of CIAM); on the other, it remained aware of
label: Paragraph

text: the political responsibility to evoke a realistic regionalism,
label: Paragraph

text: accessible to the populace at large. This double-headed
label: Paragraph

text: programme was first publicly announced by Bohigas in his
label: Paragraph

text: essay, ‘Possibilities for a Barcelona Architecture’, published
label: Caption

text: in 1951. The various cultural impulses that made up this
label: Paragraph

text: heterogeneous Regionalism tend to confirm the unavoidably
label: Paragraph

text: hybrid nature of modern regional culture. In the first place,
label: Paragraph

text: there was the Catalan brick tradition which dated back to
label: Paragraph

text: the period of ‘Modernismo’; then there was the influence of
label: Paragraph

text: Neutra and Neo-Plasticism - the latter indubitably
label: Paragraph

text: stimulated by Bruno Zevi’s La Poetica dell’architettura
label: Paragraph

text: neoplastica of 1953. There followed the influential Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Realist style of the Italian architect Ignazio Gardella, who
label: Paragraph

text: employed traditional shutters, narrow windows and wide
label: Paragraph

text: overhanging eaves in his Casa Borsalino at Alessandria, Italy
label: Caption

text: (1951-53). To this must be added, particularly for the
label: Paragraph

text: practice of Mackay, Bohigas and Martorell, the influence of
label: Paragraph

text: British New Brutalism (see their Paseo de la Bonanova
label: Title

text: apartments in Barcelona of 1973).
label: Paragraph

text: The career of the Barcelona architect J.A. Coderch has
label: Paragraph

text: been typically regionalist inasmuch as it has oscillated, until
label: Paragraph

text: recent date, between a Mediterraneanized, modern brick
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular first formulated in his eight-storey ISM apartment
label: Paragraph

text: block [324, 325], built in Barcelona in the Paseo Nacional in
label: Caption

text: 1951 (‘traditionally’ articulated like the Casa Borsalino with
label: Paragraph

text: full-height shutters and thin overhanging cornices), and the
label: Paragraph

text: avant-gardist, Neo-Plastic cum Miesian composition of his
label: Paragraph

text: Casa Catasus completed at Sitges in 1956 [326].
label: Caption

text: 324, 325 Coderch, ISM apartment block, Barcelona, 1951: view and typical floor
label: Caption

text: plan.
label: Paragraph

text: 326 Coderch, Casa Catasus, Sitges, 1956: ground plan.
label: Caption

text: The more recent deliquescence of Catalan Regionalism is
label: Paragraph

text: possibly most evident in the work of Ricardo Bofill and the
label: Paragraph

text: Taller de Arquitectura. For where Bofill’s Calle Nicaragua
label: Caption

text: apartments of 1964 displayed an affinity for the
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpreted brick vernacular of Coderch, the Taller was to
label: Paragraph

text: adopt an overtly Gesamtkunstwerk approach in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s. With their Xanadu complex built in Calpe in 1967,
label: Paragraph

text: they indulged in a form of kitsch romanticism. This
label: Paragraph

text: obsession with castle images reached its apotheosis in their
label: Paragraph

text: heroic, but ostentatious, tile-faced Walden 7 complex at
label: Caption

text: Sant Just Desvern, Barcelona (1970-75). With its twelve-
label: Paragraph

text: storey voids, underlit living rooms, minuscule balconies and
label: Caption

text: its now disintegrating tile cladding, Walden 7 marks that
label: Paragraph

text: unfortunate boundary where what was initially a critical
label: Paragraph

text: impulse degenerates into highly photogenic scenography. In
label: Paragraph

text: the last analysis, despite its passing homage to Gaudi,
label: Paragraph

text: Walden 7 displays an affinity for admass seduction. It is an
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of narcissism par excellence, for the formal
label: Paragraph

text: rhetoric addresses itself to high fashion and to the mystique
label: Paragraph

text: of Bofill’s flamboyant personality. The Mediterranean
label: Paragraph

text: hedonistic utopia to which Walden 7 pretends collapses on
label: Paragraph

text: closer inspection, above all at the level of the roofscape
label: Paragraph

text: where a potentially sensuous environment has not been
label: Paragraph

text: realized in occupation (compare Le Corbusier's Unité
label: Paragraph

text: d’Habitation at Marseilles).
label: Paragraph

text: Nothing could be further from Bofill’s intentions than the
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of the Portuguese master Alvaro Siza Vieira,
label: Paragraph

text: whose career, beginning with his swimming pool at the
label: Paragraph

text: Quinta da Conceicgao, Matosinhos (1958-65), has been
label: Paragraph

text: anything but photogenic. This much can be discerned not
label: Paragraph

text: only from the fragmentary evasive nature of the published
label: Paragraph

text: images but also from a text written in 1979:
label: Paragraph

text: Most of my works were never published; some of the things
label: Paragraph

text: | did were only carried out in part, others were profoundly
label: Paragraph

text: changed or destroyed. That’s only to be expected. An
label: Paragraph

text: architectonic proposition whose aim is to go deep... a
label: Paragraph

text: proposition that intends to be more than a passive
label: Paragraph

text: materialization, refuses to reduce that same reality,
label: Paragraph

text: analysing each of its aspects, one by one; that proposition
label: Paragraph

text: can't find support in a fixed image, can’t follow a linear
label: Paragraph

text: evolution. ... Each design is bound to catch, with the utmost
label: Paragraph

text: rigour, a precise moment of the flittering image, in all its
label: Paragraph

text: shades, and the better you can recognize that flittering
label: Paragraph

text: quality of reality, the clearer your design will be. ...That may
label: Paragraph

text: be the reason why only marginal works (a quiet dwelling, a
label: Paragraph

text: holiday house miles away) have been kept as they were
label: Paragraph

text: originally designed. But something remains. Pieces are kept
label: Paragraph

text: here and there, inside ourselves, perhaps fathered by
label: Paragraph

text: someone, leaving marks on space and people, melting into
label: Paragraph

text: a process of total transformation.”
label: Paragraph

text: This hypersensitivity to the transformation of a fluid and
label: Paragraph

text: yet specific reality renders Siza’s work more layered and
label: Paragraph

text: rooted than the eclectic tendencies of the Barcelona School
label: Paragraph

text: for, by taking Aalto as his point of departure, he has
label: Paragraph

text: grounded his buildings in the configuration of a specific
label: Paragraph

text: topography and in the fine-grained texture of the local
label: Paragraph

text: fabric. To this end his pieces are tight responses to the
label: Paragraph

text: urban, land and marinescape of the Porto region. Other
label: Paragraph

text: important factors are his deference towards local material,
label: Paragraph

text: craftwork, and the subtleties of local light, a deference
label: Paragraph

text: which is sustained without falling into the sentimentality of
label: Paragraph

text: excluding rational form and modern technique. Like Aalto’s
label: Paragraph

text: Saynatsalo Town Hall, all of Siza’s buildings are delicately
label: Paragraph

text: laid into the topography of their sites. His approach is
label: Paragraph

text: patently tactile and tectonic, rather than visual and graphic,
label: Paragraph

text: from his Beires House built at P6voa de Varzim in 1973-77
label: Caption

text: [327-329] to his Bouca Residents’ Association Housing in
label: Paragraph

text: Porto (1973-77). Even his small urban buildings, of which
label: Paragraph

text: the best is probably the Pinto branch bank built at Oliveira
label: Paragraph

text: de Azemeis in 1974, are topographically structured.
label: Paragraph

text: 327-329 Siza, Beires House, Pévoa de Varzim, 1973-77: view, and plans of the
label: Caption

text: upper floor and ground floor.
label: Paragraph

text: The projected work of the New York-based Austrian
label: Paragraph

text: architect Raimund Abraham seems to be informed by similar
label: Paragraph

text: concerns, inasmuch as this architect has always stressed
label: Paragraph

text: place creation and the topographic aspects of built form.
label: Paragraph

text: The House with Three Walls (1972) and the House with
label: Paragraph

text: Flower Walls (1973) are typical of his pieces of the early
label: Paragraph

text: 1970s, wherein the project evokes an oneiric image while
label: Paragraph

text: insisting on the inescapable materiality of building. This
label: Paragraph

text: concern for tectonic form and for its capacity to transform
label: Paragraph

text: the surface of the earth has been carried over into
label: Paragraph

text: Abraham's designs made for the International Building
label: Caption

text: Exhibition in Berlin, above all into his project for South
label: Paragraph

text: Friedrichstadt designed in 1981 [330].
label: Paragraph

text: 330 Abraham, project for South Friedrichstadt, Berlin, 1981: detail showing half
label: Caption

text: the site.
label: Paragraph

text: An equally tactile attitude obtains in the work of the
label: Paragraph

text: veteran Mexican architect Luis Barragan, whose finest
label: Paragraph

text: houses (many of which have been erected in Mexico City, in
label: Paragraph

text: the suburb of Pedregal) assume a topographic form. As
label: Paragraph

text: much a landscape designer as an architect, Barragan has
label: Paragraph

text: always sought a sensual and earthbound architecture; an
label: Paragraph

text: architecture compounded of enclosures, stelae, fountains
label: Caption

text: and watercourses; an architecture laid into volcanic rock
label: Paragraph

text: and lush vegetation; an architecture that refers indirectly to
label: Paragraph

text: the Mexican estancia. Of Barragan’s feeling for mythic and
label: Paragraph

text: rooted beginnings it is sufficient to cite his memories of the
label: Paragraph

text: apocryphal pueb/o of his youth:
label: Paragraph

text: My earliest childhood memories are related to a ranch my
label: Paragraph

text: family owned near the village of Mazamitla. It was a pueblo
label: Paragraph

text: with hills, formed by houses with tile roofs and immense
label: Paragraph

text: eaves to shield passersby from the heavy rains which fall in
label: Paragraph

text: that area. Even the earth’s color was interesting because it
label: Paragraph

text: was red earth. In this village, the water distribution system
label: Paragraph

text: consisted of great gutted logs, in the form of troughs, which
label: Paragraph

text: ran on a support structure of tree forks, 5 meters high,
label: Paragraph

text: above the roofs. This aqueduct crossed over the town,
label: Paragraph

text: reaching the patios, where there were great stone fountains
label: Paragraph

text: to receive the water. The patios housed the stables, with
label: Paragraph

text: cows and chickens, all together Outside, in the street, there
label: Paragraph

text: were iron rings to tie the horses. The channeled logs,
label: Paragraph

text: covered with moss, dripped water all over town, of course. It
label: Paragraph

text: gave this village the ambience of a fairy tale. No, there are
label: Paragraph

text: no photographs. | have only its memory.3
label: Caption

text: This remembrance was surely influenced by Barragan’s
label: Paragraph

text: lifelong involvement with Islamic architecture. Similar
label: Paragraph

text: feelings and concerns are evident in his opposition to the
label: Paragraph

text: invasion of privacy in the modern world and in his criticism
label: Paragraph

text: of the subtle erosion of nature which has accompanied post-
label: Paragraph

text: war civilization:
label: Title

text: Everyday life is becoming much too public. Radio, TV,
label: Paragraph

text: telephone all invade privacy. Gardens should therefore be
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed, not open to public gaze. ... Architects are
label: Paragraph

text: forgetting the need of human beings for half-light, the sort
label: Paragraph

text: of light that imposes a tranquility, in their living rooms as
label: Paragraph

text: well as in their bedrooms. About half the glass that is used
label: Paragraph

text: in so many buildings - homes as well as offices - would have
label: Paragraph

text: to be removed in order to obtain the quality of light that
label: Paragraph

text: enables one to live and work in a more concentrated
label: Paragraph

text: manner...
label: Paragraph

text: Before the machine age, even in the middle of cities.
label: Paragraph

text: Nature was everybody’s trusted companion. ... Nowadays,
label: Paragraph

text: the situation is reversed. Man does not meet with Nature,
label: Paragraph

text: even when he leaves the city to commune with her.
label: Paragraph

text: Enclosed in his shiny automobile, his spirit stamped with the
label: Paragraph

text: mark of the world whence the automobile emerged, he is,
label: Paragraph

text: within Nature, a foreign body. A billboard is sufficient to
label: Paragraph

text: stifle the voice of Nature. Nature becomes a scrap of Nature
label: Paragraph

text: and man a scrap of man.4
label: Caption

text: By the time of his first house and studio built around an
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed court in Tacubaya, Mexico D.F., in 1947, Barragan
label: Caption

text: had already moved away from the syntax of the
label: Paragraph

text: International Style. And yet his work has always remained
label: Paragraph

text: committed to that abstract form which has characterized
label: Paragraph

text: the art of our era. Barragan’s penchant for large, almost
label: Paragraph

text: inscrutable abstract planes set into the landscape is
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps at its most intense in his gardens for the residential
label: Paragraph

text: districts of Las Arboleadas (1958-61) and Los Clubes (1961-
label: Paragraph

text: 64) and in his freeway monument, Satellite City Towers,
label: Caption

text: designed with Mathias Goeritz in 1957 [331].
label: Caption

text: 331 Barragan and Goeritz, Satellite City Towers, Mexico City, 1957.
label: Caption

text: Regionalism has, of course, manifested itself in other
label: Paragraph

text: parts of the Americas: in Brazil in the 1940s in the early
label: Paragraph

text: work of Oscar Niemeyer and Affonso Reidy; in Argentina in
label: Paragraph

text: the work of Amancio Williams, above all in Williams’s bridge
label: Caption

text: house in Mar del Plata of 1943-45 and more recently
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps in Clorindo Testa’s Bank of London and South
label: Caption

text: America, Buenos Aires (1959); in Venezuela, in the Ciudad
label: Paragraph

text: Universitaria built to the designs of Carlos Raul Villanueva
label: Paragraph

text: between 1945 and 1960; on the West Coast of the United
label: Paragraph

text: States, first in Los Angeles from the late 1920s in the work
label: Paragraph

text: of Neutra, Schindler, Weber and Gill, and then in the Bay
label: Paragraph

text: Area school founded by William Wurster and in the Southern
label: Paragraph

text: California work of Harwell Hamilton Harris. No-one has
label: Caption

text: perhaps expressed the idea of a Critical Regionalism more
label: Paragraph

text: forcefully than Harris, in ‘Regionalism and Nationalism’, an
label: Paragraph

text: address which he first gave to the North West Regional
label: Paragraph

text: Council of the AIA in Eugene, Oregon, in 1954. This was the
label: Paragraph

text: occasion when he first advanced his felicitous distinction
label: Paragraph

text: between restricted and liberated regionalism:
label: Title

text: Opposed to the Regionalism of Restriction is another type of
label: Paragraph

text: regionalism; the Regionalism of Liberation. This is the
label: Paragraph

text: manifestation of a region that is especially in tune with the
label: Paragraph

text: emerging thought of the time. We call such a manifestation
label: Paragraph

text: ‘regional’ only because it has not yet emerged elsewhere. It
label: Paragraph

text: is the genius of this region to be more than ordinarily aware
label: Paragraph

text: and more than ordinarily free. Its virtue is that its
label: Paragraph

text: manifestation has significance for the world outside itself. To
label: Paragraph

text: express this regionalism architecturally it is necessary that
label: Paragraph

text: there be building - preferably a lot of building - at one time.
label: Paragraph

text: Only so can the expression be sufficiently general,
label: Paragraph

text: sufficiently varied, sufficiently forceful to capture people’s
label: Paragraph

text: imaginations and provide a friendly climate long enough for
label: Paragraph

text: a new school of design to develop. ...
label: Paragraph

text: San Francisco was made for Maybeck Pasadena was
label: Paragraph

text: made for Greene and Greene. Neither could have
label: Paragraph

text: accomplished what he did in any other place or time. Each
label: Paragraph

text: used the materials of the place; but it is not the materials
label: Paragraph

text: that distinguish the work. ... A region may develop ideas. A
label: Paragraph

text: region may accept ideas. Imaginations and intelligence are
label: Paragraph

text: necessary for both. In California in the late Twenties and
label: Paragraph

text: Thirties modern European ideas met a still developing
label: Paragraph

text: regionalism. In New England, on the other hand, European
label: Paragraph

text: Modernism met a rigid and restrictive regionalism that at
label: Paragraph

text: first resisted and then surrendered. New England accepted
label: Paragraph

text: European Modernism whole because its own regionalism
label: Title

text: had been reduced to a collection of restrictions.°
label: Paragraph

text: Despite an apparent freedom of expression, such a level
label: Paragraph

text: of liberative regionalism is difficult to achieve in North
label: Paragraph

text: America today. Within the current proliferation of highly
label: Paragraph

text: individualistic forms of expression (work which is often
label: Paragraph

text: patronizing and self-indulgent rather than critical) only a few
label: Paragraph

text: firms today display any profound commitment to the
label: Paragraph

text: unsentimental cultivation of a rooted American culture. An
label: Paragraph

text: atypical example of current ‘regional’ work in North America
label: Paragraph

text: is the sensitively sited houses designed by Andrew Batey
label: Paragraph

text: and Mark Mack for the Napa Valley area in California;
label: Paragraph

text: another is the work of the architect Harry Wolf, whose
label: Paragraph

text: activity has been largely restricted to North Carolina. Wolf’s
label: Paragraph

text: metaphorical approach to place-making was polemically
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated in his 1982 competition entry for the Fort
label: Paragraph

text: Lauderdale Riverfront Plaza [332]. As his description
label: Paragraph

text: indicates, the intention was to inscribe Fort Lauderdale’s
label: Paragraph

text: history into the site through the incidence of light.
label: Paragraph

text: 332 Wolf, model for the Fort Lauderdale Riverfront Plaza, 1982.
label: Caption

text: The worship of the sun and the measurement of time from
label: Title

text: its light reach back to the earliest recorded history of man. It
label: Paragraph

text: is interesting to note in the case of Fort Lauderdale that if
label: Paragraph

text: one were to follow a 26° latitudinal line around the globe,
label: Paragraph

text: one would find Fort Lauderdale in the company of Ancient
label: Paragraph

text: Thebes - the throne of the Egyptian sun god, Ra. Further to
label: Paragraph

text: the East, one would find Jaipur. India, where heretofore, the
label: Paragraph

text: largest equinoctial sundial in the world was built 110 years
label: Paragraph

text: prior to the founding of Fort Lauderdale.
label: Paragraph

text: Mindful of these magnificent historical precedents, we
label: Paragraph

text: sought a symbol that would speak of the past, present and
label: Paragraph

text: future of Fort Lauderdale. ... To capture the sun in symbol a
label: Paragraph

text: great sundial is incised on the Plaza site and the gnomon of
label: Paragraph

text: the sundial bisects the site on its north-south axis. The
label: Paragraph

text: gnomon of the double blade rises from the south at 26° 5’
label: Paragraph

text: parallel to Fort Lauderdale’s /atitude. ...
label: Paragraph

text: Each of the significant dates in Fort Lauderdale’s history
label: Paragraph

text: is recorded in the great blade of the sundial. With careful
label: Paragraph

text: calculation the sun angles are perfectly aligned with
label: Paragraph

text: penetrations through the two blades to cast brilliant circles
label: Paragraph

text: of light, landing on the otherwise shadowy side of the
label: Paragraph

text: sundial. These shatts of light illuminate an appropriate
label: Paragraph

text: historical marker serving as annual historical reminders.®
label: Paragraph

text: In Europe the work of the architect Gino Valle may be
label: Paragraph

text: considered regional inasmuch as his career has always been
label: Paragraph

text: centred on the city of Udine. Aside from his concern for the
label: Paragraph

text: city, Valle made one of the earliest post-war
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpretations of the rural vernacular of Lombardy in his
label: Paragraph

text: Casa Quaglia, built at Sutrio in 1954-56 [334].
label: Caption

text: 333 Williams, bridge house, Mar del Plata, 1943-45.
label: Caption

text: 334 Valle, Casa Quaglia, Sutrio, 1954-56.
label: Caption

text: It is surely understandable that in Europe, where the
label: Paragraph

text: vestigial city-state was still very much alive, such a
label: Paragraph

text: regionalist impulse would emerge spontaneously after the
label: Paragraph

text: Second World War when a number of significant architects
label: Paragraph

text: were able to contribute to the culture of their native cities.
label: Paragraph

text: Among those of the post-war generation who remained
label: Paragraph

text: committed to a regional inflection one may count Ernst Gisel
label: Paragraph

text: in Zurich, Jarn Utzon in Copenhagen, Vittorio Gregotti in
label: Paragraph

text: Milan, Sverre Fehn in Oslo, Aris Konstantinidis in Athens, and
label: Paragraph

text: last but by no means least Carlo Scarpa in Venice [335].
label: Paragraph

text: 335 Scarpa, Querini Stampalia Gallery, Venice, 1961-63.
label: Caption

text: Switzerland, with its intricate linguistic boundaries and its
label: Paragraph

text: tradition of cosmopolitanism, has always displayed strong
label: Paragraph

text: regionalist tendencies. The cantonal principle of admission
label: Paragraph

text: and exclusion has always favoured extremely dense forms
label: Paragraph

text: of expression, with the canton favouring local culture and
label: Paragraph

text: the Federation facilitating the penetration and assimilation
label: Title

text: of foreign ideas. Dolf Schnebli’s Corbusian vaulted villa at
label: Caption

text: Campione d’ltalia on the Italo-Swiss frontier (1960) [336]
label: Caption

text: may be seen as initiating the resistance of Ticinese
label: Paragraph

text: architecture to the influence of commercialized modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: This resistance found an echo immediately in other parts of
label: Paragraph

text: Switzerland, in Aurelio Galfetti’s equally Corbusian Rotalinti
label: Paragraph

text: House in Bellinzona (1961) and in Atelier 5’s assumption of
label: Paragraph

text: the Corbusian béton brut manner, as this appeared in
label: Paragraph

text: Siedlung Halen, built outside Berne in 1960.
label: Caption

text: 336 Schnebli, Castioli House, Campione d'Italia, 1960.
label: Caption

text: Today’s Ticinese Regionalism has its ultimate origins in
label: Paragraph

text: the pre-war protagonists of the Italian Rationalist movement
label: Title

text: in Switzerland, above all the work of the Italian Alberto
label: Paragraph

text: Sartoris and the Ticinese Rino Tami. Sartoris’s main
label: Paragraph

text: realizations were in the Valais, most notably a church at
label: Paragraph

text: Lourtier (1932) and two small concrete-framed houses, built
label: Paragraph

text: in association with viticulture and under construction
label: Paragraph

text: between 1934 and 1939, of which the most renowned is the
label: Paragraph

text: Morand-Pasteur residence at Saillon (1935). Of the
label: Paragraph

text: compatibility between Rationalism and rural architecture
label: Title

text: Sartoris wrote: ‘Rural architecture, with its essentially
label: Paragraph

text: regional features, is perfectly at home with today’s
label: Paragraph

text: rationalism. In fact it embodies in practice all those
label: Paragraph

text: functional criteria on which modern building methods are
label: Paragraph

text: essentially based.’ Where Sartoris was primarily a polemicist
label: Paragraph

text: keeping the Rationalist precepts alive throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: Second World War and its aftermath, Tami was mainly a
label: Paragraph

text: builder, and the Ticinese architects of the 1960s were able
label: Paragraph

text: to take his Cantonal Library at Lugano (1936-40) as an
label: Paragraph

text: exemplary Rationalist work.
label: Paragraph

text: Ticinese practice in the mid-1950s, with the exception of
label: Paragraph

text: Galfetti, was orientated towards the work of Frank Lloyd
label: Paragraph

text: Wright rather than the prewar Italian Rationalists. Of this
label: Paragraph

text: period Tita Carloni wrote: ‘We naively set ourselves the
label: Paragraph

text: objective of an “organic” Ticino, in which the values of
label: Paragraph

text: modern culture were to be interwoven in a natural way with
label: Paragraph

text: local tradition.’ Of Ticinese Neo-Rationalism in the early
label: Paragraph

text: 1970s we find him writing:
label: Paragraph

text: The old Wrightian schemata were superseded, the chapter
label: Paragraph

text: of ‘big commissions’ for the State, with good reformist
label: Paragraph

text: intentions, was closed. It all had to be begun all over again,
label: Paragraph

text: from the ground upwards, housing, schools, minor didactic
label: Paragraph

text: restorations, competition entries as an opportunity to
label: Paragraph

text: investigate and critically assess the contents and forms of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. In the meantime cultural confrontation in Italy,
label: Paragraph

text: political commitment, and the exacting confrontation with
label: Paragraph

text: our own native intellectuals, especially Virgilio Gilardoni,
label: Paragraph

text: meant that history books started to appear on our desks,
label: Paragraph

text: and above all faced us with the challenge of critically
label: Paragraph

text: reappraising the whole evolution of modernism, most
label: Paragraph

text: especially that of the 1920s and 1930s.’
label: Paragraph

text: As Carloni suggests, the strength of provincial culture
label: Paragraph

text: resides in its capacity to condense the artistic and critical
label: Paragraph

text: potential of the region while assimilating and reinterpreting
label: Paragraph

text: outside influences. The work of Carloni’s prime pupil, Mario
label: Paragraph

text: Botta, is typical in this respect, with its concentration on
label: Paragraph

text: issues which relate directly to the specific place while
label: Paragraph

text: adapting methods and approaches drawn from outside.
label: Paragraph

text: Formally educated under Scarpa, Botta was fortunate
label: Paragraph

text: enough to work, however briefly, for both Kahn and Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier during the short period when they projected civic
label: Paragraph

text: works for Venice. Evidently influenced by these men, Botta
label: Paragraph

text: went on to appropriate the Italian Neo-Rationalist
label: Paragraph

text: methodology as his own, while simultaneously retaining,
label: Paragraph

text: through Scarpa, an unusual capacity for the craft
label: Paragraph

text: enrichment of his form. One of the most exotic examples of
label: Paragraph

text: this occurs in his application of intonaco lucido (polished
label: Paragraph

text: plaster) to the fireplace surrounds of a converted farmhouse
label: Caption

text: at Ligrignano in 1979.
label: Paragraph

text: Two other traits in Botta’s work may be seen as critical:
label: Paragraph

text: on the one hand, his constant preoccupation with what he
label: Paragraph

text: terms ‘building the site’, and on the other, his conviction
label: Paragraph

text: that the loss of the historical city can only be compensated
label: Paragraph

text: for by ‘cities in miniature’. Thus Botta’s school at Morbio
label: Paragraph

text: Inferiore is interpreted as a micro-urban realm - as a
label: Paragraph

text: cultural compensation for the evident loss of civic life in
label: Paragraph

text: Chiasso, the nearest large city. Primary references to the
label: Paragraph

text: culture of the Ticino landscape are also evoked by Botta at a
label: Paragraph

text: typological level, such as the house at Riva San Vitale
label: Paragraph

text: [337], which refers obliquely to the traditional towerlike
label: Paragraph

text: country summer houses or roco/i which were once plentiful
label: Paragraph

text: in the region.
label: Paragraph

text: 337 Botta, house at Riva San Vitale, 1972-73.
label: Caption

text: Aside from these references, Botta’s houses serve as
label: Paragraph

text: markers in the landscape - as indicators of limits or
label: Paragraph

text: boundaries. The house in Ligornetto, for example,
label: Paragraph

text: establishes the frontier where the village ends and the
label: Paragraph

text: agrarian system begins: its main aperture (a large ‘cut-out’
label: Paragraph

text: opening) turns away from the fields and towards the village.
label: Paragraph

text: Botta’s houses are often treated as bunker/belvederes,
label: Paragraph

text: where the fenestration opens onto choice views in the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape, concealing the rapacious suburban development
label: Paragraph

text: that has taken place in the Ticino since 1960. Instead of
label: Paragraph

text: being terraced into the site, they ‘build the site’, after the
label: Paragraph

text: thesis advanced by Vittorio Gregotti in // territorio
label: Paragraph

text: dell’architettura (1966). They declare themselves as
label: Paragraph

text: primary forms, set against the topography and the sky. Their
label: Paragraph

text: capacity to harmonize with the partially agricultural nature
label: Paragraph

text: of the region stems directly from their analogical form and
label: Paragraph

text: finish; that is to say, from the fair-faced concrete block of
label: Paragraph

text: their structure and from the silo or barnlike shells in which
label: Paragraph

text: they are housed, these last alluding to the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: agricultural structures from which they are derived.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite this feeling for a domestic sensibility which is at
label: Paragraph

text: once modern and traditional, the most critical aspect of
label: Paragraph

text: Botta’s achievement resides in his public projects; in
label: Paragraph

text: particular in the two large-scale proposals which he
label: Paragraph

text: designed in collaboration with Luigi Snozzi. Both of these
label: Paragraph

text: are ‘viaduct’ buildings and as such owe something to Kahn’s
label: Paragraph

text: Venice Congress Hall project of 1968 and to Rossi’s first
label: Paragraph

text: sketches for Gallaratese. The 1971 Botta/Snozzi project for
label: Caption

text: the Centro Direzionale, Perugia, is projected as a ‘city within
label: Paragraph

text: a city’, and the wider implications of this design clearly stem
label: Paragraph

text: from its potential applicability to many megalopolitan
label: Paragraph

text: situations throughout the world. Had it been realized, this
label: Paragraph

text: centre, conceived as a ‘viaduct-megastructure’, could have
label: Paragraph

text: established its presence in the urban region without
label: Paragraph

text: compromising the historic city or fusing with the chaos of
label: Paragraph

text: the surrounding suburban development. A comparable
label: Paragraph

text: clarity and appropriateness obtained in their Zurich Station
label: Paragraph

text: proposal of 1978, where a multilevel bridge concourse
label: Paragraph

text: would not only have accommodated shops, offices,
label: Paragraph

text: restaurants and parking but would also have constituted a
label: Paragraph

text: new head building while some of the original functions were
label: Paragraph

text: retained in the existing terminus [338].

text: It is no accident that Tadao Ando, who is one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: regionally conscious architects in Japan, should be based at
label: Paragraph

text: Osaka rather than Tokyo and that his theoretical writings
label: Paragraph

text: should formulate more clearly than any other architect of
label: Paragraph

text: his generation a set of precepts which come close to the
label: Paragraph

text: idea of Critical Regionalism. This is most evident in the
label: Paragraph

text: tension that he perceives as obtaining between universal
label: Paragraph

text: modernization and the idiosyncrasy of rooted culture. Thus
label: Paragraph

text: we find him writing in an essay entitled ‘From Self-Enclosed
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Architecture toward Universality’:
label: Title

text: Born and bred in Japan, | do my architectural work here. And
label: Paragraph

text: | suppose it would be possible to say that the method | have
label: Paragraph

text: selected is to apply the vocabulary and techniques
label: Paragraph

text: developed by an open, universalist Modernism in an
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed realm of individual life styles and regional
label: Title

text: differentiation. But it seems difficult to me to attempt to
label: Paragraph

text: express the sensibilities, customs, aesthetic awareness,
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive culture, and social traditions of a given race by
label: Paragraph

text: means of the open, internationalist vocabulary of
label: Paragraph

text: Modernism.8
label: Title

text: By ‘enclosed modern architecture’ Ando intends the
label: Paragraph

text: literal creation of walled enclaves by virtue of which man is
label: Paragraph

text: able to recover and sustain some vestige of his former
label: Paragraph

text: intimacy with both nature and culture. Thus he writes:
label: Paragraph

text: After World War Il, when Japan launched on a course of rapid
label: Paragraph

text: economic growth, the people’s value criteria changed. The
label: Paragraph

text: old, fundamentally feudal family system collapsed. Such
label: Paragraph

text: social alterations as concentration of information and places
label: Title

text: of work in cities led to overpopulation of urban centers and
label: Paragraph

text: underpopulation of agricultural and fishing villages and
label: Paragraph

text: towns (as was probably true in other parts of the world as
label: Paragraph

text: well). Overly dense urban and suburban populations made it
label: Paragraph

text: impossible to preserve a feature that was formerly most
label: Paragraph

text: characteristic of japanese residential architecture: intimate
label: Paragraph

text: connection with nature and openness to the natural world.
label: Paragraph

text: What | refer to as an enclosed Modern Architecture is a
label: Paragraph

text: restoration of the unity between house and nature that
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese houses have lost in the process of modernization.?
label: Paragraph

text: In his small courtyard houses, often set within dense
label: Paragraph

text: urban fabric, Ando employs concrete in such a way as to
label: Paragraph

text: stress the taut homogeneity of its surface rather than its
label: Paragraph

text: weight, since for him it is the most suitable material ‘for
label: Paragraph

text: realizing surfaces created by rays of sunlight ... [where]
label: Paragraph

text: walls become abstract, are negated, and approach the
label: Paragraph

text: ultimate limit of space. Their actuality is lost, and only the
label: Paragraph

text: space they enclose gives a sense of really existing.’
label: Paragraph

text: While the cardinal importance of light is stressed in
label: Paragraph

text: theoretical writings of both Kahn and Le Corbusier, Ando
label: Paragraph

text: sees the paradox of spatial limpidity emerging out of light as
label: Paragraph

text: being peculiarly pertinent to the Japanese character and
label: Paragraph

text: with this he makes explicit the broader meaning which he
label: Paragraph

text: attributes to the concept of a self-enclosed modernity:
label: Paragraph

text: Spaces of this kind are overlooked in the utilitarian affairs of
label: Paragraph

text: everyday and rarely make themselves known. Still they are
label: Paragraph

text: capable of stimulating recollection of their own innermost
label: Paragraph

text: forms and of stimulating new discoveries. This is the aim of
label: Paragraph

text: what | call closed modern architecture of this kind is likely to
label: Paragraph

text: alter with the region in which it sends out roots and to grow
label: Paragraph

text: in various distinctive individual ways. Still, though closed, |
label: Paragraph

text: feel convinced that as a methodology it is open in the
label: Paragraph

text: direction of universality.1°
label: Caption

text: What Ando has in mind is the development of an
label: Paragraph

text: architecture where the tactility of the work transcends the
label: Paragraph

text: initial perception of its geometric order. Precision and
label: Paragraph

text: density of detail are both crucial to the revelatory quality of
label: Paragraph

text: his forms under light. Thus he wrote of his Koshino House of
label: Paragraph

text: 339, 340 Ando, Koshino House, Osaka, 1981: view and ground plan.
label: Caption

text: Light changes expressions with time. | believe that the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural materials do not end with wood and concrete
label: Paragraph

text: that have tangible forms but go beyond to include light and
label: Paragraph

text: wind which appeal to our senses. ... Detail exists as the
label: Paragraph

text: most important element in expressing identity. ... Thus to
label: Paragraph

text: me, the detail is an element which achieves the physical
label: Paragraph

text: composition of architecture, but at the same time, it is a
label: Paragraph

text: generator of an image of architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: In their article on the Critical Regionalism of the Greek
label: Paragraph

text: architects Dimitris and Susana Antonakakis, entitled ‘The
label: Paragraph

text: Grid and the Pathway’ (Architecture in Greece, 1981), Alex
label: Caption

text: Tzonis and Liane Lefaivre demonstrate the ambiguous role
label: Paragraph

text: played by the Schinkelschidler in the building of Athens and
label: Caption

text: the founding of the Greek state:
label: Title

text: In Greece historicist regionalism in its neoclassical version
label: Paragraph

text: had already met with opposition before the arrival of the
label: Paragraph

text: Welfare State and of modern architecture. It is due to a very
label: Paragraph

text: peculiar crisis which explodes around the end of the
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth century. Historicist regionalism here had grown
label: Paragraph

text: not only out of a war of liberation; it had emerged out of
label: Paragraph

text: interests to develop an urban élite set apart from the
label: Paragraph

text: peasant world and its rural ‘backwardness’ and to create a
label: Paragraph

text: dominance of town over country: hence the special appeal
label: Paragraph

text: of historicist regionalism, based on the book rather than
label: Paragraph

text: experience, with its monumentality recalling another distant
label: Paragraph

text: and forlorn élite. Historical regionalism had united people
label: Paragraph

text: but it had also divided them."
label: Paragraph

text: The various reactions which followed the proliferation of
label: Paragraph

text: the 19th-century Greek Nationalist Neo-Classical style
label: Title

text: varied from the vernacular historicism of the 1920s to the
label: Paragraph

text: committed modernism of the 1930s as this became
label: Paragraph

text: manifest in the work of such architects as Stamo Papadaki
label: Paragraph

text: and J.G. Despotopoulos. As Tzonis points out, a consciously
label: Paragraph

text: regionalist modernism emerged in Greece with the earliest
label: Paragraph

text: works of Aris Konstantinidis (his Eleusis house of 1938 and
label: Paragraph

text: his Kifissia garden exhibition of 1940), and this line was
label: Paragraph

text: developed further by Konstantinidis in the 1950s, in various
label: Paragraph

text: low-cost housing schemes and in the hotels he designed for
label: Paragraph

text: the Xenia national tourist organization between 1956 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1966. In all of Konstantinidis’s public work a tension appears
label: Paragraph

text: between the universal rationality of the trabeated
label: Title

text: reinforced-concrete frame and the autochthonous tactility of
label: Paragraph

text: the native stone and blockwork which is used as infill. A
label: Paragraph

text: much less equivocal regionalist spirit permeates the park
label: Paragraph

text: and promenade that Dimitris Pikionis designed for the
label: Paragraph

text: Philopappou Hill in 1957, on a site adjacent to the Acropolis
label: Paragraph

text: in Athens [341]. In this archaic landscape, as Tzonis and
label: Paragraph

text: Lefaivre point out,
label: Paragraph

text: 341 Pikionis, park paving on the Philopappou Hill, Athens, 1957.
label: Caption

text: Pikionis proceeds to make a work of architecture free from
label: Paragraph

text: technological exhibitionism and compositional conceit (so
label: Paragraph

text: typical of the mainstream of architecture of the 1950s), a
label: Paragraph

text: stark naked object almost dematerialized, an ordering of
label: Paragraph

text: ‘places made for the occasion’, unfolding around the hill for
label: Paragraph

text: solitary contemplation, for intimate discussion, for a small
label: Paragraph

text: gathering, for a vast assembly. ... To weave this
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinary braid of niches and passages and situations,
label: Paragraph

text: Pikionis identifies appropriate components from the lived-in
label: Paragraph

text: spaces of folk architecture, but in this project the link with
label: Paragraph

text: the regional is not made out of tender emotion. In a
label: Paragraph

text: completely different attitude, these envelopes of concrete
label: Paragraph

text: events are studied with a cold empirical method, as if
label: Paragraph

text: documented by an archaeologist. Neither is their selection
label: Paragraph

text: and their positioning carried out to stir easy superficial
label: Paragraph

text: emotion. They are platforms to be used in an everyday
label: Paragraph

text: sense but to supply that which, in the context of
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary architecture, everyday life does not. The
label: Paragraph

text: investigation of the local is the condition for reaching the
label: Paragraph

text: concrete and the real, and for rehumanizing architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Tzonis sees the work of the Antonakakis partnership as
label: Paragraph

text: combining the topographic path of Pikionis with the
label: Paragraph

text: universal grid of Konstantinidis. This dialectical opposition
label: Paragraph

text: seems to reflect once again that split between culture and
label: Paragraph

text: civilization remarked on by Ricoeur. Perhaps no work
label: Paragraph

text: expresses this duality more directly than their Benaki Street
label: Paragraph

text: apartments built in Athens in 1975 [342, 343], a layered
label: Paragraph

text: structure wherein a labyrinthine route drawn from the Greek
label: Paragraph

text: island vernacular is woven into the regular grid of the
label: Paragraph

text: supporting concrete frame.
label: Paragraph

text: 342, 343 Antonakakis, apartment building in Benaki Street, Athens, 1975.
label: Caption

text: Transverse section and view.
label: Paragraph

text: As with the largely overlapping categories used in the
label: Paragraph

text: previous chapter, Critical Regionalism is not so much a style
label: Paragraph

text: as it is a critical category orientated towards certain
label: Paragraph

text: common features, which may not always be present in the
label: Paragraph

text: examples cited here. These features, or rather attitudes,
label: Paragraph

text: may perhaps be best summarized as follows.
label: Paragraph

text: (1) Critical Regionalism has to be understood as a marginal
label: Paragraph

text: practice, one which, while it is critical of modernization,
label: Paragraph

text: nonetheless still refuses to abandon the emancipatory and
label: Paragraph

text: progressive aspects of the modern architectural legacy. At
label: Paragraph

text: the same time, Critical Regionalism’s fragmentary and
label: Paragraph

text: marginal nature serves to distance it both from normative
label: Paragraph

text: optimization and from the naive utopianism of the early
label: Title

text: Modern Movement. In contrast to the line that runs from
label: Paragraph

text: Haussmann to Le Corbusier, it favours the small rather than
label: Paragraph

text: the big plan.
label: Paragraph

text: (2) In this regard Critical Regionalism manifests itself as a
label: Paragraph

text: consciously bounded architecture, one which rather than
label: Paragraph

text: emphasizing the building as a free-standing object places
label: Paragraph

text: the stress on the territory to be established by the structure
label: Paragraph

text: erected on the site. This ‘place-form’ means that the
label: Paragraph

text: architect must recognize the physical boundary of his work
label: Paragraph

text: as a kind of temporal limit - the point at which the present
label: Paragraph

text: act of building stops.
label: Paragraph

text: (3) Critical Regionalism favours the realization of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture as a tectonic fact rather than the reduction of
label: Paragraph

text: the built environment to a series of ill-assorted scenographic
label: Paragraph

text: episodes.
label: Paragraph

text: (4) It may be claimed that Critical Regionalism is regional to
label: Paragraph

text: the degree that it invariably stresses certain site-specific
label: Paragraph

text: factors, ranging from the topography, considered as a three-
label: Paragraph

text: dimensional matrix into which the structure is fitted, to the
label: Paragraph

text: varying play of local light across the structure. Light is
label: Paragraph

text: invariably understood as the primary agent by which the
label: Paragraph

text: volume and the tectonic value of the work are revealed. An
label: Paragraph

text: articulate response to climatic conditions is a necessary
label: Paragraph

text: corollary to this. Hence Critical Regionalism is opposed to
label: Paragraph

text: the tendency of ‘universal civilization’ to optimize the use of
label: Paragraph

text: air conditioning, etc. It tends to treat all openings as
label: Paragraph

text: delicate transitional zones with a capacity to respond to the
label: Paragraph

text: specific conditions imposed by the site, the climate and the
label: Paragraph

text: light.
label: Paragraph

text: (5) Critical Regionalism emphasizes the tactile as much as
label: Paragraph

text: the visual. It is aware that the environment can be
label: Paragraph

text: experienced in terms other than sight alone. It is sensitive
label: Paragraph

text: to such complementary perceptions as varying levels of
label: Paragraph

text: illumination, ambient sensations of heat, cold, humidity and
label: Title

text: air movement, varying aromas and sounds given off by
label: Paragraph

text: different materials in different volumes, and even the
label: Paragraph

text: varying sensations induced by floor finishes, which cause
label: Paragraph

text: the body to experience involuntary changes in posture, gait,
label: Paragraph

text: etc. It is opposed to the tendency in an age dominated by
label: Paragraph

text: media to the replacement of experience by information.
label: Paragraph

text: (6) While opposed to the sentimental simulation of local
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular, Critical Regionalism will, on occasion, insert
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpreted vernacular elements as disjunctive episodes
label: Paragraph

text: within the whole. It will moreover occasionally derive such
label: Paragraph

text: elements from foreign sources. In other words it will
label: Paragraph

text: endeavour to cultivate a contemporary place-orientated
label: Paragraph

text: culture without becoming unduly hermetic, either at the
label: Paragraph

text: level of formal reference or at the level of technology. In this
label: Paragraph

text: regard, it tends towards the paradoxical creation of a
label: Paragraph

text: regionally based ‘world culture’, almost as though this were
label: Paragraph

text: a precondition for achieving a relevant form of
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary practice.
label: Paragraph

text: (7) Critical Regionalism tends to flourish in those cultural
label: Paragraph

text: interstices which in one way or another are able to escape
label: Paragraph

text: the optimizing thrust of universal civilization. Its appearance
label: Paragraph

text: suggests that the received notion of the dominant cultural
label: Paragraph

text: centre surrounded by dependent, dominated satellites is
label: Paragraph

text: ultimately an inadequate model by which to assess the
label: Paragraph

text: present state of modern architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Part IV
label: Title

text: World Architecture and
label: Title

text: the Modern Movement
label: Title

text: 344 BBPR, Torre Velasca, Milan, 1956-58.
label: Caption

text: Two publications issued around the millennium attempted to
label: Paragraph

text: arrive at an assessment of the overall impact of modern
label: Paragraph

text: architectural culture on a world scale. The first of these
label: Paragraph

text: surveys consisted of ten volumes, under the series title
label: Paragraph

text: World Architecture: A Critical Mosaic, 1900-2000. This work
label: Caption

text: divided the world into ten ‘continental’ regions, with each of
