label: Paragraph

text: ten regional committees nominating 100 significant
label: Title

text: buildings, making 1,000 in total for the whole 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: A second publication, with a similar (but not identical)
label: Paragraph

text: aim, was Luis Fernandez-Galiano’s survey Atlas: Global
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture Circa 2000, published in Madrid in 2007. This
label: Paragraph

text: work also involved dividing the world into ten ‘continental’
label: Paragraph

text: regions, although it yielded rather different subsets. Galiano
label: Paragraph

text: expanded this survey three years later into four separate
label: Paragraph

text: volumes published under the title Atlas: Architectures of the
label: Paragraph

text: 21st Century. This taxonomy paradoxically broadened the
label: Paragraph

text: survey by breaking it down into four separate megaregions.
label: Paragraph

text: Each was further subdivided into ten separate segments,
label: Paragraph

text: with each segment illustrating works selected by a single
label: Paragraph

text: commentator who was also commissioned to write a
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensive critical essay.
label: Paragraph

text: Any such critical assessment under the rubric of a single
label: Paragraph

text: author is subjective. The general question arises as to what
label: Paragraph

text: criteria justify the selection of particular works and the
label: Paragraph

text: exclusion of others seemingly accorded a comparable value.
label: Paragraph

text: One may oppose any kind of reductive aestheticism
label: Paragraph

text: whereby architecture is conceived of as fine art writ large.
label: Paragraph

text: At the same time, we know that certain places at certain
label: Paragraph

text: times have the capacity to yield a particularly rich collective
label: Paragraph

text: culture of architecture and that, conversely, in other places
label: Paragraph

text: and at other times, the situation remains obdurately
label: Paragraph

text: unproductive and discordant.
label: Paragraph

text: Much of this has to do with the absence of consistent
label: Paragraph

text: patronage. Architecture is an expensive material culture,
label: Paragraph

text: one that is highly dependent on the development of a
label: Paragraph

text: society in a particular place over a specific time period. In
label: Paragraph

text: this regard the impact of underdevelopment and
label: Paragraph

text: overdevelopment in each instance must be acknowledged:
label: Paragraph

text: in the former, the lack of necessary wherewithal to develop
label: Paragraph

text: the society and in the latter, too much development at a
label: Paragraph

text: pace too fast to allow for the sufficiently critical level of
label: Paragraph

text: creative mediation.
label: Paragraph

text: Another anomalous condition arising out of globalization
label: Paragraph

text: is the fact that many architects work today outside their
label: Paragraph

text: home countries. Even if we exclude the spectacular work of
label: Paragraph

text: peripatetic, so-called ‘starchitects’ because they depend on
label: Paragraph

text: branding for their worldly success, we are nonetheless left
label: Paragraph

text: with the fact that a work designed by a foreign architect
label: Paragraph

text: should be considered part of the architectural culture of the
label: Paragraph

text: region in which it is realized.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the ensuing Part IV is devoted largely to works
label: Paragraph

text: produced in the last fifty years, on occasion | go back
label: Paragraph

text: another two decades to the aftermath of the Second World
label: Title

text: War in both Europe and the United States, or in the case of
label: Paragraph

text: China, by the Communist Revolution of 1949. Part IV should
label: Paragraph

text: therefore be read as a mosaic in more ways than one - an
label: Paragraph

text: assembly of pieces that have a necessarily disjunctive and
label: Paragraph

text: fragmentary character.
label: Paragraph

text: A culture of architectural quality is a relatively ineffable
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenon. It is sometimes carried forward by a single
label: Paragraph

text: exceptionally talented individual who will exercise an
label: Paragraph

text: extremely fertile influence on an entire epoch; or by a
label: Paragraph

text: school, whether a more literal academic establishment or a
label: Paragraph

text: shared architectural ethos or collective practice sustained
label: Title

text: intensely for a decade or more, but that will peter out owing
label: Paragraph

text: to a change in patronage or the swings of fashion and
label: Paragraph

text: economic fortune. Thus, one might identify another deeper
label: Paragraph

text: strand of ‘regionalism’ that is critically creative in itself, but
label: Paragraph

text: also ‘critical’ in the sense of its fragile and unique poetic
label: Paragraph

text: character. This is the key of momentary culture that | seek
label: Paragraph

text: to identify and recognize in Part IV of this global history.
label: Paragraph

text: Works that do not rise to this level do not make the cut.
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 1
label: Title

text: The Americas
label: Title

text: The architecture of the North American continent has
label: Paragraph

text: always been strongly influenced by that of Europe, above all
label: Paragraph

text: by the prestigious Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris. This school
label: Paragraph

text: played a crucial role in the formation of North American
label: Paragraph

text: architects throughout the last half of the 19th century,
label: Paragraph

text: especially such pioneering figures as Richard Morris Hunt,
label: Paragraph

text: who was the first American to study there. He was followed
label: Paragraph

text: by Henry Hobson Richardson and, briefly, Louis Sullivan. At
label: Caption

text: the same time, Frank Lloyd Wright’s affectionate reference
label: Paragraph

text: to Sullivan as his Lieber Meister (‘dear master’) testifies to
label: Paragraph

text: the extent to which Germanic culture was also influential in
label: Paragraph

text: the United States, particularly on the so-called Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: School. At the turn of the century, a third of the city’s
label: Paragraph

text: population was of German origin and many people still
label: Paragraph

text: spoke the language, which in turn served to sustain German
label: Paragraph

text: theatres and newspapers and, above all, performances of
label: Paragraph

text: Wagnerian operas in Adler and Sullivan’s Auditorium
label: Title

text: Building of 1889. This Teutonic influence would become
label: Paragraph

text: more widespread in the 20th century through successive
label: Paragraph

text: waves of talented German architects who escaped the Third
label: Paragraph

text: Reich after 1933 and who would eventually have a decisive
label: Paragraph

text: impact on the evolution of modern architecture in the
label: Paragraph

text: United States. Even so, the Ecole des Beaux-Arts still
label: Paragraph

text: exercised an influence, mainly through the activity of French
label: Paragraph

text: architects who, at the turn of the century, were appointed
label: Paragraph

text: as professors in a number of leading American universities.
label: Paragraph

text: The first German-speaking modernists to arrive in the States
label: Paragraph

text: after the First World War were the Austrians Rudolf Schindler
label: Paragraph

text: and Richard Neutra, who went to the Mid-West to work for
label: Paragraph

text: Wright in 1914 and 1923 respectively, and thereafter
label: Paragraph

text: established their own practices in Los Angeles. Apart from
label: Paragraph

text: Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, who arrived in Chicago in 1937
label: Paragraph

text: to take up the directorship of the Armour Institute (which
label: Paragraph

text: would later become the Illinois Institute of Technology, or
label: Paragraph

text: IIT), the next wave of influential Germans included the
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus refugees Walter Gropius and Marcel Breuer,
label: Paragraph

text: accompanied by the former Berlin planner Martin Wagner;
label: Paragraph

text: these three joined forces to establish the Graduate School of
label: Paragraph

text: Design (GSD) at Harvard University. They were soon
label: Paragraph

text: accompanied by the Swiss-German architectural historian
label: Paragraph

text: Sigfried Giedion, whose Charles Eliot Norton Lectures given
label: Paragraph

text: at Harvard in 1939 were published in 1941 under the title
label: Paragraph

text: Space, Time and Architecture, a book that would exercise a
label: Paragraph

text: major influence on all subsequent histories of the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement.
label: Paragraph

text: The main aim in this section has been to focus on those
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of the Modern Movement in the States that have
label: Paragraph

text: been omitted from previous editions, such as the role played
label: Paragraph

text: by the Catalan émigré José Luis Sert, particularly with
label: Paragraph

text: regard to the formulation of the discipline of urban design at
label: Paragraph

text: Harvard. An equally significant independent contribution
label: Paragraph

text: was made by the distinguished Finnish architect Eliel
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen, who went to the States after gaining second place
label: Paragraph

text: in the international competition of 1922 for the new
label: Paragraph

text: headquarters of the Chicago Tribune newspaper. Saarinen’s
label: Paragraph

text: design, in effect, established the set-back, attenuated high-
label: Paragraph

text: rise format of what would become the typical Art Deco
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper.
label: Paragraph

text: Absent in previous editions is the extent to which both
label: Paragraph

text: Mies van de Rohe at the IIT and Walter Gropius in Harvard
label: Caption

text: greatly influenced the education of architects in the States,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly during the first two decades (1945-65) of the
label: Paragraph

text: Pax Americana, the period of relative peace worldwide
label: Title

text: overseen by the United States. The scope of this influence is
label: Paragraph

text: indicated by the technologically advanced but expressively
label: Paragraph

text: discreet corporate practice of Skidmore, Owings and Merrill
label: Paragraph

text: (SOM) and by the works of Gropius’s post-war GSD protégés
label: Paragraph

text: such as John Johansen, Edward Larrabee Barnes, Ulrich
label: Paragraph

text: Franzen and Paul Rudolph, who in various ways produced
label: Paragraph

text: their own versions of the New Monumentality. As far as the
label: Paragraph

text: US is concerned, Rudolph is surely the most egregious
label: Paragraph

text: omission from previous editions of this history, above all for
label: Paragraph

text: his singular masterwork, the Art & Architecture Building for
label: Paragraph

text: Yale University in New Haven, Connecticut, of 1963.
label: Caption

text: Although modern architecture in the United States has
label: Paragraph

text: been prominently featured in previous editions of this work,
label: Paragraph

text: there were few references to its northern neighbour,
label: Paragraph

text: Canada. At the turn of the century, as Richard Ingersoll has
label: Paragraph

text: pointed out, Canadian architects were just as classically
label: Paragraph

text: trained as their American counterparts, although their
label: Paragraph

text: formation in this regard was as much British as it was
label: Paragraph

text: French, as is evident from John Lyle’s Union Station in
label: Paragraph

text: Toronto, completed in 1930, with its monumental enfilade of
label: Paragraph

text: Doric columns. At that time, the most sophisticated
label: Paragraph

text: classically trained architect in Canada was unquestionably
label: Paragraph

text: the Quebecois architect Ernest Cormier, whose magnificent
label: Paragraph

text: Supreme Court of Canada building in Ottawa, with its
label: Paragraph

text: monumental mansard roofs, was completed five years after
label: Paragraph

text: his crypto-modernist University of Montreal of 1944. The
label: Paragraph

text: proto-Art Deco aspects of Cormier’s work meant that the
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Movement per se did not fully emerge in Canada
label: Paragraph

text: until well after the Second World War, most decisively with
label: Paragraph

text: Arthur Erickson’s Simon Fraser University campus laid out
label: Paragraph

text: on high ground just outside Vancouver in 1962. However, a
label: Paragraph

text: more general adoption of modern architecture in Canada
label: Title

text: came with Expo ’67, built in Montreal on an island in the St
label: Paragraph

text: Lawrence River. This happens to be the last time that the US
label: Paragraph

text: participated seriously in a world exhibition, which it did via
label: Paragraph

text: the US Pavilion, a large geodesic sphere designed by R.
label: Paragraph

text: Buckminster Fuller. This technological tour de force was
label: Paragraph

text: matched by Moshe Safdie’s equally radical multistorey
label: Paragraph

text: housing scheme, known as Habitat ’67, which at great cost
label: Paragraph

text: to the Canadian government attempted to demonstrate the
label: Paragraph

text: potential for delivering some of the benefits of suburban
label: Paragraph

text: living in an otherwise dense, medium-rise residential
label: Paragraph

text: structure.
label: Paragraph

text: Both before and after the Second World War, South
label: Paragraph

text: America would be seen from Europe and even from the
label: Paragraph

text: United States as a kind of proving ground for the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement. This much became particularly evident with the
label: Paragraph

text: New York Museum of Modern Art’s exhibition ‘Brazil Builds’
label: Title

text: of 1943 and, twelve years later, ‘Latin American
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture since 1945’, curated by Henry-Russell
label: Caption

text: Hitchcock. Brazil has always occupied a privileged position
label: Paragraph

text: in the received histories of the Modern Movement since the
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s, as was borne out by the first edition of this history, in
label: Paragraph

text: which the works of Lucio Costa and Oscar Niemeyer were
label: Paragraph

text: highlighted, notably the Brazilian Pavilion at the New York
label: Paragraph

text: World’s Fair of 1939 and the Ministry of Education and
label: Title

text: Health Building in Rio de Janeiro of virtually the same date.
label: Paragraph

text: In this regard, Brazil has served as the template for my
label: Paragraph

text: analysis of the Modern Movement in other Latin American
label: Title

text: countries including Argentina, Chile, Colombia, Mexico, Peru,
label: Paragraph

text: Uruguay and Venezuela. As might be expected, the
label: Paragraph

text: breakthrough of the Modern Movement in each of these
label: Paragraph

text: countries occurred at a slightly different time and in
label: Paragraph

text: different initial works, ranging from Gregori Warchavchik’s
label: Paragraph

text: own house in Sao Paulo of 1927 to Carlos Raul Villanueva’s
label: Caption

text: Gran Colombia School built in the outskirts of Caracas in
label: Paragraph

text: 1939, a discernibly modern work following his return to
label: Paragraph

text: Venezuela after studying at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in
label: Paragraph

text: Paris. For each of the eight Latin American countries
label: Paragraph

text: included in this edition | have not been able to do more than
label: Paragraph

text: to trace the evolution of a singular manner of building in
label: Paragraph

text: relation to the modernization of society in general and the
label: Paragraph

text: ideological line adopted by those in power at a particular
label: Paragraph

text: moment in time; for example, when Getulio Vargas rose to
label: Paragraph

text: power in Brazil, becoming president in 1930, he
label: Paragraph

text: immediately commissioned Lucio Costa to go to Portugal,
label: Paragraph

text: with the naive aim of evolving an authentic national style
label: Paragraph

text: for Brazil to be ostensibly derived from the rooted
label: Paragraph

text: Portuguese vernacular.
label: Paragraph

text: It is remarkable that in Latin America, where the political
label: Paragraph

text: scene has often been in a state of turmoil, it has been
label: Paragraph

text: possible for successive governments to introduce significant
label: Paragraph

text: socio-economic reforms irrespective of whether they happen
label: Paragraph

text: to be implemented from the Left or the Right. A typical
label: Paragraph

text: leftist government in this regard was the presidency of
label: Paragraph

text: Lazaro Cardenas in Mexico. He redistributed land to
label: Paragraph

text: previously landless tenants and, further, in 1938,
label: Paragraph

text: expropriated the international oil companies that had
label: Paragraph

text: invested in the Mexican oilfields. This action was even
label: Paragraph

text: supported by President Franklin D. Roosevelt during the
label: Paragraph

text: height of the American New Deal, the programmes, public
label: Title

text: work projects and reforms designed to stimulate economic
label: Title

text: recovery after the Great Depression. It was in just such a
label: Paragraph

text: climate that the Mexican state constructed rural school
label: Paragraph

text: buildings throughout the country. Something similar would
label: Paragraph

text: happen during the presidency of Fernando Belaunde Terry in
label: Paragraph

text: Peru, over the years 1963-68, when his government backed
label: Paragraph

text: the international experimental housing settlement known as
label: Paragraph

text: PREVI, and again during the brief presidency of Salvador
label: Paragraph

text: Allende in Chile (1970-73), when an attempt was made to
label: Paragraph

text: build housing en masse through the adoption of Russian
label: Paragraph

text: prefabricated methods.
label: Paragraph

text: United States
label: Title

text: Apart from Frank Lloyd Wright, who became influential
label: Paragraph

text: worldwide following the publication of the Wasmuth volumes
label: Paragraph

text: of his work in 1910, the socially progressive ideology of the
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Movement first appeared in the US via European
label: Paragraph

text: émigrés. The first to arrive were the Viennese architects
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolf Schindler and Richard Neutra, both of whom went to
label: Paragraph

text: the States with the express purpose of working for Wright,
label: Paragraph

text: Schindler in 1914 and Neutra in 1924. The other figure of
label: Paragraph

text: consequence was the Finnish architect Eliel Saarinen, who
label: Paragraph

text: migrated to the States after gaining second place in the
label: Paragraph

text: international competition of 1922 for the design of the
label: Paragraph

text: multi-storey Chicago Tribune building with an abstract
label: Caption

text: mullioned design that anticipated the Art Deco skyscraper
label: Paragraph

text: manner of the 1920s. Soon after his arrival Saarinen met
label: Paragraph

text: the newspaper tycoon George Booth, who commissioned
label: Paragraph

text: him to design and direct the Cranbrook Academy of Art in
label: Paragraph

text: Michigan, which was conceived as a utopian educational
label: Paragraph

text: community, primarily dedicated to the teaching of applied
label: Paragraph

text: art. Similarly, in 1922 the young Swiss architect William
label: Paragraph

text: Lescaze also arrived in the US, where he eventually formed
label: Paragraph

text: a partnership with the Philadelphia architect George Howe;
label: Paragraph

text: together they designed the remarkable fifteen-storey
label: Paragraph

text: Philadelphia Savings Fund Society (PSFS) bank building of
label: Caption

text: 1936 [345], which for the next thirty years remained the
label: Paragraph

text: only high-rise structure in Philadelphia. These European
label: Paragraph

text: pioneers were followed by a wave of leading German
label: Paragraph

text: architects who, after the Nazi seizure of power in Germany
label: Paragraph

text: in 1933, immigrated either to the USSR or to the US,
label: Paragraph

text: depending on their ideological affinities. The first was
label: Paragraph

text: Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, who was invited to the US in
label: Paragraph

text: 1937 to head up the department of architecture in the
label: Paragraph

text: Armour Institute, Chicago, its name being soon changed to
label: Paragraph

text: the Illinois Institute of Technology, or IIT. Mies’s arrival in
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago was followed by that of Laszl6 Moholy-Nagy, who
label: Paragraph

text: would found the New Bauhaus in the same city in 1938.
label: Paragraph

text: 345 Howe & Lescaze, PSFS Bank Building, Philadelphia, 1936.
label: Caption

text: It is difficult to overstate the extent of Mies’s influence on
label: Paragraph

text: American post-war architecture, particularly on the post-
label: Paragraph

text: 1945 corporate practice of Skidmore, Owings and Merrill
label: Caption

text: (SOM). Even an architect as individualistic and eclectic as
label: Paragraph

text: Eero Saarinen, despite being a protégé of his father, Eliel,
label: Paragraph

text: was equally affected by Mies van der Rohe’s work, as is
label: Paragraph

text: evident from the GM Headquarters built to his design in
label: Paragraph

text: Detroit between 1949 and 1955. The one exceptional talent
label: Paragraph

text: in the Chicago office of SOM who had the independence to
label: Paragraph

text: depart from Mies, despite his professional formation at the
label: Paragraph

text: IIT, was Myron Goldsmith, whose Kitts Peak Observatory,
label: Paragraph

text: Arizona (1962), was a striking work of engineering
label: Paragraph

text: comparable in its originality to Fazlur Khan’s Hajj Terminal,
label: Paragraph

text: Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, of 1981, also designed by the Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: office of SOM.
label: Paragraph

text: Upon their arrival in the States, Walter Gropius and his
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus colleague Marcel Breuer jointly created a form of
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular modernism, which, while adhering to a white,
label: Paragraph

text: flat-roofed format, would incorporate a more tactile material
label: Paragraph

text: palette, invariably combining timber cladding with dry stone
label: Paragraph

text: (fieldstone) walls. This hybrid manner was recognized by
label: Paragraph

text: Henry-Russell Hitchcock in his essay ‘Marcel Breuer and the
label: Paragraph

text: American Tradition’, which accompanied a 1938 exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: of the same name, staged at the newly created Graduate
label: Paragraph

text: School of Design (GSD), Harvard University. Breuer had first
label: Paragraph

text: ventured into stone walling in his Gane Pavilion designed
label: Paragraph

text: with the British architect F.R.S. Yorke for the Royal
label: Caption

text: Agricultural Show at Bristol, England, in 1936, one year
label: Paragraph

text: before his migration to the States. However, his very first
label: Paragraph

text: attempt at a softer functional mode was manifest in his
label: Paragraph

text: Doldertal Apartments of the same year, designed in
label: Paragraph

text: association with Alfred Roth and Emil Roth and built for
label: Paragraph

text: Sigfried Giedion in the Doldertal, Zurich [347]. Breuer’s
label: Caption

text: move towards a more tactile use of traditional materials
label: Paragraph

text: would be consolidated in three houses that he and Gropius
label: Paragraph

text: designed for Lincoln, Massachusetts, in 1938 [346], one
label: Caption

text: each for their own occupation and one for the historian
label: Paragraph

text: James Ford, whose book The Modern House in America
label: Title

text: (1944) was an early documentation of the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement in the United States.
label: Paragraph

text: 346 Gropius, Gropius House, Lincoln, Massachusetts, 1938. Ground-floor plan.
label: Caption

text: 347 Breuer, with Emil Roth and Alfred Roth, Doldertal Apartments, Zurich, 1936.
label: Caption

text: At Gropius’s invitation, Sigfried Giedion gave the Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Eliot Norton Lectures at Harvard in 1939, which would
label: Paragraph

text: become the substance of his influential book Space, Time
label: Paragraph

text: and Architecture, published in 1941. Gropius and Breuer’s
label: Paragraph

text: Chamberlain Cottage [348, 349], built at Wayland,
label: Caption

text: Massachusetts, in the same year, was clad with redwood
label: Paragraph

text: boarding and incorporated a free-standing rubble-stone
label: Paragraph

text: chimney dividing the living from the dining areas in an
label: Paragraph

text: otherwise open plan. This format was repeated by Breuer in
label: Paragraph

text: his subsequent domestic practice, amounting to some fifty
label: Paragraph

text: houses in the States over the next two decades.
label: Paragraph

text: 348, 349 Breuer and Gropius, Chamberlain Cottage, Wayland, Massachusetts,
label: Caption

text: 1941. View and ground-floor plan.
label: Caption

text: Exiled from Spain by the Spanish Civil War (1936-39),
label: Paragraph

text: José Luis Sert also arrived in the States in 1939 and
label: Paragraph

text: published his polemical text Can Our Cities Survive? in
label: Paragraph

text: 1941. This, in effect, was a summation of the proceedings of
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM during the first decade of its existence. Once
label: Paragraph

text: appointed to a professorship at the GSD he pioneered the
label: Paragraph

text: field of urban design as a totally new discipline and this
label: Paragraph

text: would duly be the basis of his subsequent practice with Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Lester Weiner, especially with regard to their designs for a
label: Paragraph

text: number of new cities in Latin America. Later in his career
label: Paragraph

text: Sert designed one civic set piece after another, ranging
label: Paragraph

text: from the Holyoke Center (1958) to the Peabody Terrace
label: Caption

text: dormitories (1962) and the Science Center in 1968, with
label: Paragraph

text: Harvard University acting as the client in each instance. Sert
label: Paragraph

text: went on to achieve a similar kind of micro-urban form for
label: Paragraph

text: Boston University in 1966. A decade later Sert
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated his mastery as a housing architect with the
label: Paragraph

text: multistorey apartment buildings on Roosevelt Island, New
label: Caption

text: York City.
label: Paragraph

text: The GSD, under Gropius as chair of the Department of
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture from 1937, trained the leading American
label: Paragraph

text: architects of the immediate post-war generation, including
label: Paragraph

text: Eliot Noyes, Paul Rudolph, Philip Johnson, Edward Larrabee
label: Title

text: Barnes, Ulrich Franzen, I.M. Pei and John Johansen. These
label: Paragraph

text: architects not only followed Breuer’s lead in formulating the
label: Paragraph

text: post-war American middle-class modern house, but also
label: Paragraph

text: participated in the creation of the so-called New
label: Paragraph

text: Monumentality as is evident in a number of US embassies
label: Paragraph

text: designed by them: in London by Eero Saarinen (1960), in
label: Caption

text: Dublin by John Johansen (1964), in New Delhi by Edward
label: Caption

text: Durell Stone (1959) and in Athens (1961) by Walter Gropius
label: Caption

text: in association with TAC (The Architects Collaborative).
label: Paragraph

text: Equally monumental, Paul Rudolph’s School of Art and
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture for Yale University of 1963 [350] asserted its
label: Paragraph

text: proto-Brutalist expressivity through bush-hammered
label: Title

text: concrete in contrast to Louis Kahn’s brick-faced Yale
label: Paragraph

text: University Art Gallery, completed a decade earlier.
label: Paragraph

text: Something of this had been anticipated in Breuer’s own
label: Paragraph

text: version of the New Monumentality, beginning with the
label: Paragraph

text: folded-plate, reinforced-concrete UNESCO Building in Paris
label: Caption

text: of 1954 [351], designed in association with Bernard
label: Paragraph

text: Zehrfuss and the Italian engineer Pier Luigi Nervi. This work
label: Paragraph

text: was the prototype for a number of equally monumental
label: Paragraph

text: works by Breuer employing the same form of folded-plate
label: Paragraph

text: construction. St Francis de Salles Church in Muskegon
label: Caption

text: (1966) and the St John’s Abbey complex in Collegeville,
label: Paragraph

text: Minnesota (1968), are exemplary of Breuer’s work in this
label: Paragraph

text: regard.
label: Paragraph

text: 350 Rudolph, School of Art and Architecture, Yale University, New Haven,
label: Caption

text: Connecticut, 1963.
label: Caption

text: 351 Breuer, Zehrfuss and Nervi, UNESCO Building, Paris, 1954.
label: Caption

text: Richard Meier, who on graduation worked briefly for
label: Paragraph

text: Breuer, combined Breuer’s middle-class house type with a
label: Paragraph

text: species of Purism derived from Le Corbusier's Villa Savoye,
label: Paragraph

text: Poissy, of 1929. This hybrid not only determined the pristine
label: Paragraph

text: cubistic houses that made up his early career but also
label: Paragraph

text: constituted the point of departure for the public buildings of
label: Paragraph

text: his maturity: the High Museum of Art, Atlanta (1983); the
label: Paragraph

text: Museum of Applied Arts, Frankfurt (1984); the Hague City
label: Caption

text: Hall (1995); and the Getty Center for the History of Art and
label: Paragraph

text: the Humanities, completed as a city-in-miniature on an
label: Paragraph

text: undulating verdant site in Brentwood, Los Angeles, in 1997.
label: Caption

text: Throughout his later career Meier demonstrated a certain
label: Paragraph

text: capacity as an urban designer, most notably through the
label: Paragraph

text: large-scale urban projects that he conceived for various
label: Paragraph

text: industrial enterprises in Europe, including a campus for
label: Paragraph

text: Renault at Boulogne-Billancourt, Paris, and one for Siemens
label: Caption

text: in Munich. However, unlike the urban designs of Sert, none
label: Paragraph

text: of these civic set pieces would be realized. Instead, at the
label: Paragraph

text: end of the century, Meier found himself designing a series of
label: Paragraph

text: law courts for the US federal government, in Islip, New York
label: Caption

text: (1993), in Phoenix, Arizona (1994), and in San Diego,
label: Paragraph

text: California (2002).
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike the German émigré architects of the 1930s, Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier and Alvar Aalto completed only one building each
label: Paragraph

text: in the States, namely the former’s Carpenter Art Center,
label: Paragraph

text: Harvard University (1963), and the latter’s majestically
label: Paragraph

text: organic, brick-faced Baker House dormitory block [352] built
label: Caption

text: on the banks of the Charles River. Completed in 1949, it still
label: Paragraph

text: remains the most exemplary modern building on the
label: Paragraph

text: campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).
label: Paragraph

text: 352 Aalto, Baker House Dormitory, MIT, Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1949.
label: Caption

text: There were many manifestations of vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: modernism that proliferated in the States in the second half
label: Paragraph

text: of the 20th century, in works as varied as Edward Larrabee
label: Paragraph

text: Barnes’s minimalist Haystack Mountain School, clad in
label: Paragraph

text: shingles and built on Deer Isle, Maine, in 1961, and Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Moore’s timber-clad Sea Ranch, designed with Bill Turnbull
label: Caption

text: and Donlyn Lyndon and built on the northern Californian
label: Paragraph

text: coast in 1965. However, neither of these came close to the
label: Paragraph

text: tectonic complexity of Fay Jones’s all-timber Thorncrown
label: Paragraph

text: Chapel erected in the Ozark Mountains, Arkansas, in 1980.
label: Caption

text: This monumental structure and Frank Gehry’s deconstructed
label: Paragraph

text: ‘inside-out’ house in Santa Monica, California, of 1979
label: Caption

text: represent two totally different modes of expressive timber
label: Paragraph

text: construction, both removed from the European organic
label: Paragraph

text: tradition as represented by Alvar Aalto and Hans Scharoun.
label: Paragraph

text: An incomparable American architect who maintained his
label: Paragraph

text: creative independence throughout the second half of the
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century was Louis Kahn, particularly with regard to his
label: Paragraph

text: tectonic masterwork, the Kimbell Art Museum built at Fort
label: Caption

text: Worth, Texas, in 1972. Despite its location in the heart of a
label: Paragraph

text: vast city dominated by the car, it asserts its presence before
label: Paragraph

text: a picturesque park now unavoidably eclipsed by Renzo
label: Paragraph

text: Piano’s otherwise sensitive addition. Among the unique
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of the original Kimbell Museum was Kahn’s use of
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete cycloid vaults, as calculated by his
label: Paragraph

text: brilliant engineer August Komendant.
label: Paragraph

text: While architects of the East Coast were largely unable to
label: Paragraph

text: conceive of modern architecture as transcending the
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetics of style, Southern California, through the
label: Paragraph

text: pioneering work of Schindler and Neutra, proved itself
label: Paragraph

text: capable of cultivating a hedonistic environment suitable to
label: Paragraph

text: the climate and imbued with a socially liberal, reformist way
label: Paragraph

text: of living. This ethos carried over into the post-war era, as is
label: Paragraph

text: evident from John Entenza’s Case Study Houses, which were
label: Paragraph

text: realized in California as built illustrations of the lifestyle that
label: Paragraph

text: he projected through his magazine Arts and Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: (1945-49). This publication promoted such pioneering works
label: Paragraph

text: as Charles and Ray Eames’s Case Study House No. 8 [354],
label: Paragraph

text: which was a prefabricated, steel-framed house and studio,
label: Paragraph

text: assembled out of standard industrial components. The Case
label: Paragraph

text: Study Houses were mostly designed by such figures as
label: Paragraph

text: Gregory Ain, Raphael Soriano, R. Davidson, H. Harris and
label: Caption

text: Craig Ellwood. As editor of the magazine, Entenza
label: Paragraph

text: championed whenever possible the seemingly limitless
label: Paragraph

text: post-war potential for modular, industrially produced
label: Paragraph

text: prefabricated houses including Gropius and Konrad
label: Caption

text: Wachsmann’s ill-fated General Panel System House system,
label: Paragraph

text: patented in 1942 [353] and based on a 1-metre (3-foot 4-
label: Paragraph

text: inch) module. In many ways, the Case Study Houses were
label: Paragraph

text: an updating of Wright’s Usonian vision of transforming the
label: Paragraph

text: spontaneous suburbanization of the US into a utopian, car-
label: Paragraph

text: dominated pattern of land settlement, close to Ludwig
label: Paragraph

text: Hilberseimer’s low-rise, high-density green-city vision as
label: Paragraph

text: advanced in his book The New Regional Pattern of 1949. On
label: Paragraph

text: the East Coast, aside from Stein and Wright’s Greenbelt New
label: Paragraph

text: Towns (1924-50), perfected during the Roosevelt New Deal
label: Paragraph

text: era, a hypothetical alternative suburban pattern of land
label: Paragraph

text: settlement was proposed in Serge Chermayeff and
label: Paragraph

text: Christopher Alexander’s Community and Privacy of 1963.
label: Paragraph

text: 353 Gropius and Wachsmann, General Panel System House, 1942.
label: Caption

text: 354 Charles and Ray Eames, Case Study House No. 8, Los Angeles, California,
label: Caption

text: Notwithstanding the neo-avant-gardist abstract manner
label: Paragraph

text: adopted by the New York Five - Richard Meier, Peter
label: Paragraph

text: Eisenman, Michael Graves, Charles Gwathmey and John
label: Title

text: Hejduk - in the second half of the 1960s, the American
label: Paragraph

text: grassroots tradition of emphasizing materially expressive
label: Paragraph

text: form, dating back to the Shingle Style of the 1890s, re-
label: Paragraph

text: emerged in the 1980s as a ‘culture of materials’. This
label: Paragraph

text: practice was pursued by the East Coast modernists of the
label: Paragraph

text: next generation, above all by Steven Holl and by the New
label: Paragraph

text: York practice of Tod Williams and Billie Tsien. Holl’s initial
label: Paragraph

text: abstract approach, predicated on the idea of type, stemmed
label: Paragraph

text: from his admiration for the Italian Neo-Rationalist architect
label: Paragraph

text: Aldo Rossi. He modified this stance in favour of a species of
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular modernism evident in his first built work of
label: Paragraph

text: consequence, the Berkowitz House on Martha’s Vineyard
label: Caption

text: [355], in 1988. This work was inspired by the evocation of a
label: Paragraph

text: regional literary myth, namely Herman Melville’s Moby Dick,
label: Paragraph

text: which Holl regarded as being of relevance to the image of
label: Paragraph

text: the house, given the maritime affinities of the site and the
label: Paragraph

text: all but mythical Native American experience of transforming
label: Title

text: the skeleton of a whale into a dwelling. This long, single-
label: Paragraph

text: storey building terminated in a two-storey form at one end,
label: Paragraph

text: suggestive of a wheelhouse and thus embodying a nautical
label: Paragraph

text: metaphor. While evocative of a ruined vessel, the exposed
label: Paragraph

text: board and batten 4-inch by 6-inch construction also evokes
label: Paragraph

text: the framework of a primitive hut. In these multiple ways the
label: Paragraph

text: Berkowitz House exemplified Holl’s habitual, heuristic
label: Paragraph

text: method of introducing a mythical paradigm into the design
label: Paragraph

text: process.
label: Paragraph

text: 355 Holl, Berkowitz House, Martha’s Vineyard, Massachusetts, 1988.
label: Caption

text: A similar method is evident in Holl’s school of art and art
label: Paragraph

text: history [358] at the University of lowa (1999-2006), which,
label: Paragraph

text: apart from the unusual brief, was predicated formally on
label: Paragraph

text: Picasso’s metal sculpture Guitar of 1912. Holl and his
label: Paragraph

text: business partner, Chris McVoy, translated the rusted cubistic
label: Paragraph

text: form of this sculpture into a set of faceted planes in
label: Paragraph

text: weathered steel which they then employed to articulate the
label: Paragraph

text: building within and without. In addition, channel glass was
label: Paragraph

text: used extensively to illuminate and express the larger
label: Paragraph

text: volumes of the interior. This juxtaposition of contrasting
label: Paragraph

text: material surfaces in relation to dynamic form can be found
label: Paragraph

text: throughout Holl’s career from the mid-1980s onwards,
label: Paragraph

text: including his Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art, Kansas City,
label: Caption

text: which is also covered throughout in channel glass. Although
label: Paragraph

text: the socially progressive aspects of the Modern Movement
label: Title

text: are implicit throughout Holl’s work, there is a notable shift in
label: Paragraph

text: the scale and density of detailing as he passed, for example,
label: Paragraph

text: from the so-called ‘Void Space/Hinged Space’ housing that
label: Paragraph

text: he built in Osaka, Japan, in 1991, to the large urban works
label: Paragraph

text: that he has completed in China, above all the so-called
label: Paragraph

text: Linked Hybrid Building, Beijing, or the Vanke Center,
label: Caption

text: Shenzhen, both dating from 2009.
label: Paragraph

text: The practice of Tod Williams and Billie Tsien is equally
label: Paragraph

text: committed to a culture of materials, wherein the tactility of
label: Paragraph

text: their architecture enhances an inherently topographic
label: Paragraph

text: approach to the evolution of form. This is evident in their
label: Paragraph

text: New College dormitories, completed for the University of
label: Caption

text: Virginia in Charlottesville in 1992. In this instance, seven
label: Paragraph

text: dormitory blocks, clad in brick and of three to four storeys,
label: Paragraph

text: step down to culminate at the bottom of a slope in a brick-
label: Paragraph

text: clad dining hall with canted skylights. Three years later,
label: Paragraph

text: they followed this stepped assembly with an even more
label: Paragraph

text: organic composition for the Scripps Neuroscience Institute
label: Caption

text: [356, 357] in La Jolla, San Diego, California, constructed of
label: Caption

text: fair-faced concrete and partially clad with fossilized
label: Caption

text: limestone.
label: Paragraph

text: 356, 357 Williams and Tsien, Scripps Neuroscience Institute, San Diego,
label: Caption

text: California, 1995. Site plan and view.
label: Caption

text: 358 Holl, Art Building West, University of lowa, lowa City, lowa, 2006. An
label: Caption

text: unusual combination of the faculties of art and art history in one building.
label: Paragraph

text: The regionally inflected modernism that emerged on the
label: Paragraph

text: West Coast in the first quarter of the 20th century was
label: Paragraph

text: continued elsewhere in the States, reflecting to different
label: Paragraph

text: degrees the diversity of climate and landscape. Such an
label: Paragraph

text: impulse is evident in the work of, among others, O’Neil Ford
label: Paragraph

text: in San Antonio, Texas, and Fay Jones in Arkansas, largely of
label: Paragraph

text: brick in the first instance and timber in the second. These
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive inflections would be taken further by the next
label: Paragraph

text: generation, particularly David Lake and Ted Flato, both of
label: Paragraph

text: whom had worked for Ford, and Antoine Predock. The last
label: Paragraph

text: made his name with his low-rise, high-density housing
label: Paragraph

text: scheme in La Luz of 1972, which was constructed of adobe
label: Paragraph

text: and integrated into a sloping site overlooking the Rio
label: Paragraph

text: Grande, near Albuquerque, New Mexico. Lake and Flato also
label: Caption

text: turned to adobe construction for their first house built in
label: Paragraph

text: Santa Fe in 1990, but thereafter they would widen their
label: Paragraph

text: material palette to combine masonry with steel frame
label: Paragraph

text: construction, as in their Holt Headquarters, completed in
label: Paragraph

text: San Antonio in 1994. Of the same generation and using
label: Paragraph

text: similar materials, William Bruder realized his Phoenix
label: Paragraph

text: Central Library in Phoenix, Arizona, in 1995 with Wendell
label: Caption

text: Burnette and Rick Joy as assistants. In the same year
label: Paragraph

text: Burnette built an elegant prefabricated concrete house for
label: Paragraph

text: himself in a Phoenix suburban subdivision, while four years
label: Paragraph

text: later, Joy constructed his own studio in Tucson out of adobe.
label: Paragraph

text: Both men later collaborated with Marwan Al-Sayed on the
label: Paragraph

text: design of the Amangiri Resort [359] completed at Canyon
label: Caption

text: Point, Utah, in 2009: a thirty-four-room, single-storey, spa-
label: Paragraph

text: cum-hotel laid out at the foot of a monumental escarpment.
label: Paragraph

text: 359 Al-Sayed, Burnette and Joy, Amangiri Resort, Canyon Point, Utah, 2009.
label: Caption

text: A perennial virtue of the North American pragmatic
label: Paragraph

text: tradition has been its proclivity for inventing new
label: Paragraph

text: prototypes. These have come into being not only through
label: Paragraph

text: technical innovations, such as the balloon frame, the
label: Paragraph

text: elevator, fireproof steel construction, and the mass
label: Title

text: production and ownership of the car, but also through the
label: Paragraph

text: ways of working and living such as Taylorized production - a
label: Paragraph

text: factory management system developed in the late 19th
label: Paragraph

text: century to increase efficiency through specialized repeated
label: Title

text: tasks - the rise of the service industry and the proliferation
label: Title

text: of a suburban way of life, focused about the drive-in
label: Paragraph

text: shopping centre. At the same time North American
label: Paragraph

text: architects have intermittently devised totally unprecedented
label: Paragraph

text: building types such as Wright’s invention of the modern
label: Paragraph

text: office space in his Larkin building in Buffalo, New York, of
label: Caption

text: 1904, a generic type that led to Louis Kahn’s categoric
label: Paragraph

text: distinction between servant and served space. Certain
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of this pioneering repertoire have contributed to
label: Paragraph

text: such typological innovations as Harry Wolf's cylindrical
label: Paragraph

text: twenty-five-storey tower [360] standing out as a refreshing
label: Caption

text: exception in the banal high-rise skyline of Tampa, Florida, or
label: Paragraph

text: Stanley Saitowitz’s Yerba Buena bespoke artists’ lofts
label: Title

text: completed in 2002 as a new type of ‘social condenser’
label: Paragraph

text: within the downtown fabric of San Francisco [361, 362].
label: Paragraph

text: 360 Wolf, NCNB Banking Headquarters, Tampa, Florida, 1989.
label: Caption

text: 361, 362 Saitowitz, Yerba Buena Lofts, San Francisco, California, 2002. Section
label: Caption

text: and view.
label: Paragraph

text: Canada
label: Title

text: The mid-1960s saw the beginning of a new architectural
label: Paragraph

text: tradition in Canada, which took different forms across the
label: Paragraph

text: country, depending on the regional climate and the scope of
label: Paragraph

text: the work. At this time, a modern manner with few
label: Paragraph

text: precedents began to emerge in the three major cities:
label: Paragraph

text: Montreal in the east, Toronto - slightly further west - and
label: Paragraph

text: Vancouver in the far west.
label: Paragraph

text: Modern environmental culture first manifested itself in
label: Paragraph

text: Montreal in the work of the Quebecois Art Deco architect-
label: Paragraph

text: engineer Ernest Cormier, primarily through his Université de
label: Paragraph

text: Montreal, constructed between 1928 and 1955. After the
label: Paragraph

text: Second World War modern architecture appeared in
label: Paragraph

text: Montreal in two downtown mega-developments: the Place
label: Paragraph

text: Ville Marie (1958), an office and shopping complex by I.M.
label: Paragraph

text: Pei, and the merchandise mart and rooftop hotel, known as
label: Paragraph

text: the Place Bonaventure, built to the designs of Ray Affleck in
label: Paragraph

text: ‘corduroy’ bush-hammered concrete in 1964. Montreal
label: Caption

text: finally came to the fore with Expo '67, a state-sponsored
label: Paragraph

text: world exhibition staged in 1967 on an island in the middle of
label: Paragraph

text: the St Lawrence River. This exhibition was dominated by two
label: Paragraph

text: monumental works, the first being Buckminster Fuller’s US
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilion, which took the unique form of an enormous
label: Paragraph

text: geodesic sphere. As it happens, this was the last national
label: Paragraph

text: pavilion to be fully supported by the US government in a
label: Paragraph

text: world exhibition. The other prominent work, which was also
label: Paragraph

text: predicated on tetrahedral geometry, was Moshe Safdie’s
label: Paragraph

text: multistorey experimental housing complex, known as
label: Paragraph

text: Habitat ’67 [363]. Fuller’s sphere, penetrated by a monorail,
label: Paragraph

text: evoked the space-age condition of weightlessness through
label: Paragraph

text: the suspension of astronautical objects within its seemingly
label: Title

text: limitless volume. In this regard it unequivocally represented
label: Paragraph

text: the techno-scientific superiority of the United States, while
label: Paragraph

text: Safdie’s Habitat, subsidized by the Canadian government,
label: Paragraph

text: was an audacious demonstration of the stacking of duplex
label: Paragraph

text: apartments so as to provide roof terraces for each unit,
label: Paragraph

text: thereby affording the essential benefits of suburban living in
label: Paragraph

text: a high-density housing complex.
label: Paragraph

text: 363 Safdie, Habitat ‘67, Montreal, 1967. Section.
label: Caption

text: Just over a decade later, one of the more significant
label: Paragraph

text: architects to emerge in Montreal was the Romanian émigré
label: Paragraph

text: Dan Hanganu, who first made his mark with an elegant set
label: Paragraph

text: of two-storey, brick-faced terrace houses built in the Rue de
label: Caption

text: Gaspé on Nuns’ Island, close to the centre of the city in
label: Paragraph

text: 1980. Hanganu later added two other exceptional mid-rise
label: Paragraph

text: works to the downtown area: the UQAM (Université du
label: Paragraph

text: Québec a Montréal) Design School (1996) and the Pointe-a-
label: Paragraph

text: Calligre museum of archaeology and history [364],
label: Caption

text: completed in the old city in 1992.
label: Paragraph

text: 364 Hanganu, Musée d’Archéologie et d'Histoire Pointe-a-Calliére, Montreal,
label: Caption

text: Toronto’s entry into modernity began in 1958 with the
label: Paragraph

text: international competition for Toronto City Hall, won by the
label: Paragraph

text: Finnish architect Viljo Revell and realized over the next
label: Paragraph

text: decade. The asymmetrical composition of this work
label: Paragraph

text: consisted of two curved high-rise slabs of varying heights
label: Paragraph

text: embracing a shallow-domed, circular council chamber, the
label: Paragraph

text: whole being elevated on a podium well above the existing
label: Paragraph

text: street level. However, the first move towards a regionally
label: Paragraph

text: inflected Canadian architecture appeared in Toronto in the
label: Paragraph

text: work of Ron Thom, whose part-Brutalist, part-late Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: Revival enclave of Massey College was constructed in the
label: Paragraph

text: built-up area of the city in 1963. This was followed in 1965
label: Paragraph

text: by the equally Brutalist, organically planned Scarborough
label: Paragraph

text: College [366] built of concrete on a bucolic site outside the
label: Paragraph

text: city centre to the designs of the Australian architect John
label: Caption

text: Andrews.
label: Paragraph

text: On the west coast, the first figure of stature to emerge
label: Paragraph

text: during the post-war period was Arthur Erickson, whose
label: Paragraph

text: Simon Fraser University (1962-72) [365], conceived as a
label: Paragraph

text: landscaped megastructure, was integrated into the rising
label: Paragraph

text: site of a small mountain near Vancouver. Erickson followed
label: Paragraph

text: this achievement with two other megastructural works: his
label: Paragraph

text: bridge-like design for the University of Lethbridge in Alberta
label: Caption

text: (1972), and his Robson Square complex, completed as an
label: Paragraph

text: axial spine running through the centre of Vancouver in
label: Paragraph

text: 1986. This last, occupying three city blocks, consisted of a
label: Paragraph

text: continuous structure comprising a courthouse, municipal
label: Paragraph

text: offices and a stepped rooftop landscape culminating in an
label: Paragraph

text: ornamental pool and multiple waterfalls. These cascades
label: Paragraph

text: accompanied a sequence of stramps (stepped ramps),
label: Paragraph

text: which descended at an angle to street level before an
label: Paragraph

text: existing Beaux Arts museum. These gardens and water
label: Paragraph

text: features were designed by the landscape architect Cornelia
label: Paragraph

text: Oberlander, with whom Erickson would regularly collaborate
label: Paragraph

text: throughout his career.
label: Paragraph

text: 365 Erickson in collaboration with Massey, Simon Fraser University, Vancouver,
label: Caption

text: 366 Andrews, Scarborough College, Toronto, 1965.
label: Caption

text: Equally within the Canadian inventive tradition was a
label: Paragraph

text: uniquely seminal work by the then émigré American
label: Paragraph

text: architect Barton Myers, who, with Jack Diamond and Richard
label: Paragraph

text: Wilkin, designed a dormitory for the University of Alberta at
label: Paragraph

text: Edmonton. This was the so called HUB (Housing Union
label: Paragraph

text: Building) of 1973 [367], a 292-metre (958-foot) long,
label: Paragraph

text: climate-controlled, top-lit galleria with the students’ rooms
label: Caption

text: stacked in five floors on either side of a self-contained
label: Paragraph

text: volume, which was equipped with a full range of social
label: Paragraph

text: amenities at ground level. This typologically inventive work
label: Paragraph

text: was echoed in the ‘high-tech’, light steel-framed Wolf House
label: Paragraph

text: built to the designs of Myers in the inner suburbs of Toronto
label: Caption

text: in 1977; it was the second in a sequence of three steel
label: Paragraph

text: houses that he designed and built, with the first and last
label: Paragraph

text: being for his own occupation. Myers’s final domestic
label: Paragraph

text: exercise in steel was built in Toro Canyon, Montecito, in
label: Paragraph

text: 1999; this house and studio was designed for his southern
label: Paragraph

text: Californian retirement and constructed a full decade after
label: Paragraph

text: his return to the US and the establishment of his office in
label: Paragraph

text: Los Angeles in 1984. This singular monumental work seems
label: Paragraph

text: to refer to the Asian tradition of an open-air pleasure
label: Paragraph

text: pavilion.
label: Paragraph

text: 367 Myers, Diamond and Wilken, Housing Union Building, Alberta, Canada,
label: Caption

text: 1973. Sectional perspective.
label: Paragraph

text: The consistently distinguished Canadian practitioners of
label: Paragraph

text: the next generation are John and Patricia Patkau, who began
label: Paragraph

text: their significant career in Vancouver with their Seabird
label: Paragraph

text: Island School, built at Agassiz in 1991 for an Indian band
label: Paragraph

text: living in the Fraser Valley. The hump-backed, shingle-
label: Paragraph

text: covered, laminated timber roof of this school was conceived
label: Paragraph

text: in some measure as a topographic metaphor, consciously
label: Paragraph

text: harmonizing with the profile of an adjacent mountain range.
label: Paragraph

text: Its deep eaves sweep low over a south-facing porch and are
label: Paragraph

text: held in position by a canted pergola, which consciously
label: Paragraph

text: alludes to the fish-drying racks of the indigenous coastal
label: Paragraph

text: villages of the Pacific Northwest. Of this and similar
label: Paragraph

text: structures Patricia Patkau has remarked:
label: Paragraph

text: Many of our buildings have covered porches for various
label: Paragraph

text: purposes: to modify the sun, shed the rain, or to provide a
label: Paragraph

text: sense of shelter. Most of our roofs come down l/ow at their
label: Paragraph

text: edges; some, however, go up to capture light at the top.
label: Paragraph

text: Most cover an interior volume that is in shadow and lightens
label: Paragraph

text: toward the edges as an intermediary zone.
label: Paragraph

text: Such a ‘zone’ proved to be equally essential in the
label: Paragraph

text: peripheral organization of their Strawberry Vale School
label: Title

text: [369], built in Victoria, British Columbia, in 1996, where
label: Caption

text: paired classrooms open onto a common terrace sandwiched
label: Paragraph

text: between them and set before a local micro-landscape of
label: Paragraph

text: moss-covered rocks.
label: Paragraph

text: More than any of the other ‘pagoda’ structures designed
label: Paragraph

text: by Patkau Architects during the last decade of the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century the Gleneagles Community Centre in West
label: Caption

text: Vancouver [368] depends on the interaction of a whole
label: Paragraph

text: range of constructional components besides the laminated
label: Paragraph

text: timber trusses supporting the roof, thereby engendering a
label: Paragraph

text: symbiotic combination of environmental elements that is
label: Paragraph

text: inherently sustainable. Of this they have written:
label: Paragraph

text: 368 Patkau Architects, Gleneagles Community Centre, West Vancouver, 2003.
label: Caption

text: 369 Patkau Architects, Strawberry Vale School, Victoria, British Columbia, 1996.
label: Caption

text: Playing areas facing on to moss-covered rocks.
label: Paragraph

text: The structural system consists of cast-in-place concrete
label: Paragraph

text: floor slabs, insulated double-wythe, tilt-up concrete end
label: Caption

text: walls, and a heavy timber roof. This structure is an
label: Paragraph

text: important component of the interior climate-control system
label: Paragraph

text: of the building: it acts as a huge thermal-storage mass, a
label: Paragraph

text: giant static heat pump that absorbs, stores and releases
label: Paragraph

text: energy to create an extremely stable indoor climate,
label: Paragraph

text: regardless of the exterior environment. Radiant heating and
label: Paragraph

text: cooling in both floors and walls maintains a set temperature;
label: Paragraph

text: the concrete surfaces act alternately as emitters or
label: Paragraph

text: absorbers. The thermal energy for this system is provided
label: Paragraph

text: by water-to-water heat pumps via a ground-source heat
label: Paragraph

text: exchanger under the adjacent parking area. Since air is not
label: Paragraph

text: used for climate control, opening windows and doors does
label: Paragraph

text: not affect the performance of the heating and cooling
label: Paragraph

text: system.
label: Paragraph

text: The most significant public work to be completed by this
label: Paragraph

text: practice to date is their Grande Bibliotheque du Québec in
label: Paragraph

text: Montreal of 2005 [370], said to be the largest public library
label: Paragraph

text: in the French-speaking world. Built in the Latin Quarter of
label: Paragraph

text: Montreal, it comprises, in addition to the library, an
label: Paragraph

text: auditorium, an exhibition space, shops, a restaurant/café,
label: Paragraph

text: and a series of small stalls for booksellers, located along a
label: Paragraph

text: pedestrian lane behind the main body of the building.
label: Paragraph

text: Directly accessible from the city subway system, this long
label: Paragraph

text: building is served by an elevator shaft and a cable-
label: Paragraph

text: suspended staircase, both of which rise from the entrance to
label: Paragraph

text: serve the library above. Faced with locally fabricated
label: Paragraph

text: extruded glass channel planking, this building has, in many
label: Paragraph

text: respects, been treated as a structure within a structure, as
label: Paragraph

text: the open library stacks are housed in a louvred timber case
label: Caption

text: that in its turn is contained within a weatherproof glass
label: Paragraph

text: enclosure.
label: Paragraph

text: 370 Patkau Architects, Grande Bibliotheque du Québec, Montreal, 2005.
label: Caption

text: Two works by Patkau Architects dating from 2016 testify
label: Caption

text: to their continual inventiveness. The first of these is the
label: Paragraph

text: Audain Art Museum, projected as a bridge-like, pitched-roof
label: Paragraph

text: gallery spanning over the flood plan of Fitzsimmons Creek in
label: Caption

text: Whistler, British Columbia. The second is a visitors’ centre
label: Paragraph

text: close to the 200-year-old Fort York National Historic Site,
label: Paragraph

text: located adjacent to an elevated expressway feeding the
label: Paragraph

text: centre of Toronto. Parallel to the monumental autoroute, this
label: Paragraph

text: visitors’ centre is clad with inclined plates of corten steel
label: Paragraph

text: that house a reception area, a café, an orientation space
label: Paragraph

text: and a semi-subterranean ‘time-tunnel’ containing a video
label: Paragraph

text: history of the fort.
label: Title

text: One of the most significant Ontario practices of the 21st
label: Paragraph

text: century is that of Brigitte Shim and Howard Sutcliffe, who
label: Paragraph

text: opened their office in Toronto in 1994. Like Patkau Architects
label: Paragraph

text: they are acutely aware that their work is located in a vast
label: Paragraph

text: northern territory subject to the stresses of a harsh climate.
label: Paragraph

text: Shim has characterized the context of their practice in the
label: Paragraph

text: following terms:
label: Title

text: In Canada, we occupy an enormous landmass with a tiny
label: Paragraph

text: population. Whether one lives in the countryside or in the
label: Paragraph

text: city, the mythological Canadian landscape permeates our
label: Paragraph

text: lives. ... The majority of our work is located at the bottom
label: Paragraph

text: edge of the Canadian Shield, described as a stone necklace
label: Paragraph

text: of ancient metamorphic rock wrapping around Hudson's
label: Paragraph

text: Bay.”
label: Paragraph

text: Their first work on the Canadian Shield was their
label: Paragraph

text: Moorelands Camp dining hall of 2002, which took the form
label: Paragraph

text: of a large timber shed, built on Lake Kawagama at
label: Caption

text: Haliburton. It was designed for a long-established summer
label: Paragraph

text: camp catering to the needs of urban youth, and for this
label: Paragraph

text: reason it was fitted with large, top-hung louvred doors,
label: Paragraph

text: enabling the hall to be closed down completely at the end of
label: Paragraph

text: the season. Shim-Sutcliffe would parallel this exercise in
label: Paragraph

text: modular timber construction in their Harrison Island Camp
label: Paragraph

text: [371], built as a vacation house for their own occupation, on
label: Paragraph

text: Georgian Bay, Ontario, in 2010. This house was largely
label: Paragraph

text: composed of structural insulated panels, which were
label: Paragraph

text: shipped to the rocky site by barge and then assembled into
label: Paragraph

text: position.
label: Paragraph

text: 371 Shim-Sutcliffe, Harrison Island Camp, Georgian Bay, Ontario, 2010. Section.
label: Caption

text: Their most complex domestic work realized to date is the
label: Paragraph

text: so-called Integral House [372], built on the edge of a ravine
label: Paragraph

text: in the Don Valley, Toronto, in 2009. Built for the
label: Caption

text: mathematician and musician James Stewart, this is a
label: Paragraph

text: luxurious bachelor’s residence expressly designed around a
label: Paragraph

text: semi-public recital space, capable of accommodating an
label: Paragraph

text: audience of around 150 people. Indirectly influenced by
label: Paragraph

text: both Frank Lloyd Wright and Alvar Aalto’s works, the house
label: Paragraph

text: looks out over a heavily wooded ravine in the centre of the
label: Paragraph

text: city. Its organic, curvilinear form is intended as a reference
label: Paragraph

text: to integral calculus, a branch of mathematics from which
label: Paragraph

text: the house derives its name. An important feature of its
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter are the timber brises-so/ei/, which echo the
label: Paragraph

text: pattern of the tree clusters that line the ravine.
label: Paragraph

text: 372 Shim-Sutcliffe, Integral House, Don Valley, Toronto, 2009.
label: Caption

text: In their exceptional study 41° to 66°: Regional Responses
label: Paragraph

text: to Sustainable Architecture in Canada of 2006, John McMinn
label: Paragraph

text: and Marco Polo characterize the wet climate of Canada’s
label: Paragraph

text: Atlantic region as ‘subject to the warm Gulf Stream from the
label: Paragraph

text: south and the Labrador current from the north - which
label: Paragraph

text: brings the cooling influence of icebergs in the spring -
label: Paragraph

text: resulting in widely varying ocean temperatures and highly
label: Paragraph

text: variable weather’. No one has responded more creatively to
label: Paragraph

text: the fluctuating harshness of this climate than Brian MacKay-
label: Paragraph

text: Lyons, who set the stage for his reinterpretation of the local
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular in 1983, when he self-consciously returned to his
label: Paragraph

text: Acadian heritage with the purchase of a 1%-acre (0.6-
label: Paragraph

text: hectare) coastal farm at Shobac in Upper Kingsburg, near
label: Paragraph

text: Halifax, Nova Scotia. Five years later he would establish the
label: Paragraph

text: firm of MacKay-Lyons Sweetapple Architects. Typical of their
label: Paragraph

text: evolving domestic practice over the next two decades would
label: Paragraph

text: be the timber-framed and -clad Messenger House Il,
label: Paragraph

text: completed in 2003 on a drumliin (a low oval mound)
label: Paragraph

text: overlooking the Shobac Farm. To date, this practice has
label: Paragraph

text: designed and built some 300 timber-framed homes on the
label: Paragraph

text: Nova Scotia coast, ranging from long houses with roofs
label: Paragraph

text: sloping down for the entire length of the dwellings, to
label: Paragraph

text: residences with transverse monopitched roofs, such as the
label: Paragraph

text: Danielson Cottage, completed on an exposed site at Cape
label: Caption

text: Breton in 1996. Partially inspired by Wright’s Usonian
label: Paragraph

text: houses, this practice owes an equally substantial debt to a
label: Paragraph

text: more recent American master, namely Louis Kahn, for his
label: Paragraph

text: well-known distinction between servant and served spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: A typical MacKay-Lyons house has a ‘servant’ module
label: Paragraph

text: running throughout its length. In most instances this ‘thick
label: Paragraph

text: wall’ not only braces the building but also accommodates a
label: Paragraph

text: whole range of different service functions such as
label: Paragraph

text: staircases, toilets, showers, storage facilities, kitchenettes
label: Caption

text: and bathrooms. There is perhaps no single work that so
label: Paragraph

text: captures the unique character of the MacKay-Lyons
label: Paragraph

text: approach to formulating an image for Canada’s Atlantic
label: Title

text: coast than in his typical linear plan covered by a long-
label: Paragraph

text: spanning roof, seen, for example, in the Howard House
label: Paragraph

text: [373] built at West Pennant, Nova Scotia, in 1995.
label: Caption

text: 373 MacKay-Lyons Sweetapple Architects, Howard House, West Pennant, Nova
label: Caption

text: Scotia, 1995.
label: Caption

text: Mexico
label: Title

text: Despite the leading role played in Mexico by the Ecole des
label: Paragraph

text: Beaux-Arts well into the 1930s, as is evident from Adamo
label: Paragraph

text: Boari’s monumental Palace of the Fine Arts of 1934 and
label: Paragraph

text: Carlos Obregén Santacilia’s Monument to the Revolution of
label: Caption

text: 1938, the Modern Movement in Mexico came into being via
label: Paragraph

text: José Villagran Garcia’s Institute of Hygiene built in Mexico
label: Caption

text: City in 1925. The exposed jn situ concrete character of this
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrical two-storey building, with its regularly spaced
label: Paragraph

text: square windows and oversailing flat cornices - reminiscent
label: Paragraph

text: of Tony Garnier’s work in Lyons at the beginning of the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century - could hardly have been more removed from the
label: Paragraph

text: Mexican Pavilion erected for the Ibero-American Exhibition
label: Caption

text: staged in Seville in 1929. This pavilion, designed by Manuel
label: Paragraph

text: Amabilis, incorporated sculptural forms and decorative
label: Paragraph

text: elements of Aztec origin, a provocative assertion of pre-
label: Paragraph

text: Hispanic culture that did not find favour with the exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: authorities, who relegated the pavilion to a remote corner.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the indigenous roots of Mexican culture would
label: Paragraph

text: gather momentum with the Mexican Muralist movement,
label: Paragraph

text: which flourished through to the middle of the century, as is
label: Paragraph

text: evident from the Pre-Columbian iconography of the mosaic
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Juan O’Gorman in 1951 for the bookstack of the
label: Caption

text: National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM) [374].
label: Caption

text: 374 O'Gorman, National Autonomous University of Mexico Library, Mexico City,
label: Caption

text: Graduating from UNAM in 1925, after studying with
label: Paragraph

text: Villagran Garcia, O’Gorman began his independent career in
label: Paragraph

text: 1929 by designing a small studio for his father, Cecil
label: Paragraph

text: O’Gorman, which promptly led to his being commissioned
label: Paragraph

text: for the design of two adjoining studios on an adjacent site
label: Caption

text: for the artists Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera [376, 377]. All
label: Caption

text: three buildings were exercises in Le Corbusier’s Purist
label: Paragraph

text: manner as this had appeared in the Paris studio which Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier designed for the painter Amédée Ozenfant in
label: Caption

text: 1922. What O’Gorman added to the Purist syntax was an
label: Paragraph

text: exceptionally dynamic use of colour, the cubistic forms of
label: Paragraph

text: the studios being differentiated from one another by a
label: Paragraph

text: particularly vibrant contrast.
label: Paragraph

text: Convinced by the polemic advanced by Le Corbusier in
label: Paragraph

text: his Vers une architecture (1923), O’Gorman felt that the
label: Paragraph

text: priority for a post-revolutionary society was the mass
label: Paragraph

text: production of housing and schools to serve the needs of the
label: Paragraph

text: working class. Throughout the first half of the 1930s, on
label: Paragraph

text: Rivera’s recommendation, O’Gorman found himself
label: Paragraph

text: designing and building schools [375], which were elegant
label: Paragraph

text: functionalist essays in reinforced concrete frame
label: Title

text: construction. By the early 1940s, however, O’Gorman had
label: Paragraph

text: become totally disillusioned with the Modern Movement, not
label: Paragraph

text: only because it had been appropriated by real estate
label: Paragraph

text: developers but also because its austere abstract character
label: Paragraph

text: rendered it inimical to the more picturesque values of the
label: Paragraph

text: Mexican working class. This impasse led him to abandon
label: Paragraph

text: architecture altogether in favour of mural painting, and with
label: Paragraph

text: this shift he became increasingly preoccupied with folkloric
label: Paragraph

text: symbolism, overwhelmingly evident in the self-consciously
label: Paragraph

text: primitive, troglodyte house that he built for himself close to
label: Paragraph

text: El Pedregal in Mexico City in 1948. The form of this work
label: Paragraph

text: was as retrogressive as the equally cryptic studio that Diego
label: Paragraph

text: Rivera built for himself in Anahuacalli in 1957. Indifferent to
label: Paragraph

text: the latter-day populism of O’Gorman and Rivera, Villagran
label: Paragraph

text: Garcia continued to pursue his rationalist agenda in the
label: Paragraph

text: design of health facilities, beginning with a tuberculosis
label: Paragraph

text: hospital that he built in the manner of Garnier in 1929 and
label: Paragraph

text: continuing with a cardiological hospital in 1937 anda
label: Paragraph

text: children’s hospital in 1942, all of which were built in Mexico
label: Paragraph

text: City.
label: Paragraph

text: 375 O'Gorman, secondary school project, 1932.
label: Caption

text: 376 O'Gorman, house-studio of Frida Kahlo, Mexico City, 1929. Elevation.
label: Caption

text: 377 O'Gorman, house-studio of Diego Rivera, Mexico City, 1929. Elevation.
label: Caption

text: The Swiss-German architect Hannes Meyer and the
label: Paragraph

text: German architect Max Cetto were among the most
label: Paragraph

text: significant designers to come to Mexico in the late 1930s as
label: Paragraph

text: political refugees. Where Meyer's political reputation found
label: Paragraph

text: immediate favour with the left-wing government of Lazaro
label: Paragraph

text: Cardenas, leading on his arrival in 1938 to his appointment
label: Paragraph

text: as director of the State Institute of Urbanism and Planning,
label: Paragraph

text: the relatively apolitical Cetto would eventually find work
label: Paragraph

text: with Luis Barragan, collaborating on the design of the
label: Paragraph

text: apartment buildings that would characterize the beginning
label: Paragraph

text: of Barragan’s career in Mexico City. This association led to
label: Paragraph

text: their subsequent collaboration on the design of the El
label: Paragraph

text: Pedregal neighbourhood on a site that had hitherto been
label: Paragraph

text: regarded as an inhospitable volcanic terrain. Cetto built his
label: Paragraph

text: own house [378] there in 1948, dramatically combining
label: Paragraph

text: random rubble stone walling with an exposed reinforced
label: Caption

text: concrete frame.
label: Paragraph

text: 378 Cetto, Max Cetto House, El Pedregal, Mexico City, 1948.
label: Caption

text: Coming to Mexico in 1949, the German-born Mathias
label: Paragraph

text: Goeritz made his mark on the Mexican scene with his
label: Paragraph

text: polemical essay Emotional Architecture of 1953, in which he
label: Paragraph

text: was as critical of the received notion of integrating plastic
label: Paragraph

text: arts with architecture as he was opposed to the reductive
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism of the Modern Movement. Instead he favoured
label: Paragraph

text: the direct intervention of artists into the process of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural design such as he was to demonstrate in the
label: Paragraph

text: gateways and fountains that he designed in collaboration
label: Paragraph

text: with Barragan for El Pedregal in 1957. This led to his
label: Paragraph

text: subsequent work with Barragan on the design of the
label: Paragraph

text: multicoloured Satellite City Towers. These buildings were
label: Paragraph

text: conceived as a landmark within a large suburban
label: Paragraph

text: subdivision which had been laid out by Mario Pani on the
label: Paragraph

text: outskirts of Mexico City (fig. 331). These experiences
label: Paragraph

text: eventually led to Goeritz’s collaboration with Ricardo
label: Paragraph

text: Legorreta: first, on the twin cooling towers that he added to
label: Paragraph

text: Legorreta’s Automex Factory [379], built at Toluca, capital of
label: Paragraph

text: the State of Mexico, in 1964, and, second, on the entry
label: Paragraph

text: court and fountain that he designed for Legorreta’s Camino
label: Paragraph

text: Real hotel, completed in Mexico City in 1968.
label: Paragraph

text: 379 Legorreta and Goeritz, Automex Factory, Toluca, 1964.
label: Caption

text: Félix Candela, who graduated as an architect in 1935,
label: Paragraph

text: was among the 250,000 Spaniards who migrated to Mexico
label: Paragraph

text: as a result of the Spanish Civil War (1936-39). He was
label: Paragraph

text: obsessed with the pioneering work of the Spanish engineer
label: Paragraph

text: Eduardo Torroja, who had demonstrated his professional
label: Paragraph

text: prowess by building the cantilevered shell concrete
label: Paragraph

text: canopies over the tribune of the Madrid hippodrome in
label: Caption

text: 1935. Candela’s own first excursus in this genre came with
label: Paragraph

text: his 1951 construction of a diminutive shell over the Cosmic
label: Paragraph

text: Rays Laboratory in the UNAM campus. Designing and
label: Paragraph

text: realizing over 100 thin shell reinforced concrete structures
label: Paragraph

text: in Mexico between 1950 and 1971, Candela is still
label: Paragraph

text: insufficiently appreciated as an engineer, despite the fact
label: Paragraph

text: that the distinguished writer Carlos Fuentes would regard
label: Paragraph

text: Candela’s work as a continuation of the Ibero-American
label: Paragraph

text: Baroque tradition as directly expressed in his famous shell
label: Paragraph

text: concrete church, Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal [380],
label: Caption

text: completed in Navarte in 1955. At the height of his career
label: Paragraph

text: Candela collaborated as an engineer with many leading
label: Paragraph

text: Mexican architects, including with Pedro Ramirez Vazquez
label: Paragraph

text: on their design of the Coyoacan market dating from 1957.
label: Paragraph

text: Among the more elegant structures designed by Candela
label: Paragraph

text: alone was the Hernaiz warehouse of 1956, made up of
label: Paragraph

text: square hyperbolic umbrella roofs poised at alternating levels
label: Caption
