text: so as to allow for clerestory lighting between each square
label: Paragraph

text: roof unit. These cantilevered roofs, each poised on top of a
label: Paragraph

text: single column, were virtually identical to the trial concrete
label: Paragraph

text: mushroom canopies built by the Argentine architect
label: Caption

text: Amancio Williams at about the same time.
label: Paragraph

text: 380 Candela, Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal church, Navarte, 1955.
label: Caption

text: At the end of the Second World War, Mexico entered into
label: Paragraph

text: a period of intense industrialization as the political tenor of
label: Paragraph

text: its society shifted from the radical left to the centre. The
label: Paragraph

text: most prolific architect to come to the fore at this juncture
label: Paragraph

text: was Mario Pani. Prior to his conversion to the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement he had been commissioned for two prestigious
label: Paragraph

text: academic institutions which he designed and realized ina
label: Paragraph

text: quasi-Art Deco language: a music conservatory built around
label: Title

text: an open-air theatre (1946) and the Escuela Nacional de
label: Paragraph

text: Maestros (National School for Teachers; 1945), both erected
label: Paragraph

text: in Mexico City. Pani’s career as a modern architect began in
label: Paragraph

text: earnest with his 1946 plan for the UNAM campus, which he
label: Paragraph

text: designed in collaboration with the architect Enrique del
label: Caption

text: Moral. Pani’s first major housing development in Mexico City
label: Paragraph

text: was his Aleman housing complex, completed in 1950 [381],
label: Paragraph

text: in which a zigzag sequence of thirteen-storey blocks
label: Paragraph

text: accommodated 1,000 apartments plus a school, childcare
label: Paragraph

text: provision, public spaces and sports facilities. He followed
label: Paragraph

text: this achievement in the mid-1960s with the much larger
label: Paragraph

text: 11,000-unit Nonoalco-Tlatelolco development in Mexico City
label: Caption

text: built in anticipation of the 1968 Olympic Games.
label: Paragraph

text: 381 Pani, aerial view of the Aleman housing complex, Mexico City, 1950.
label: Caption

text: The other architect to have a major impact on the
label: Paragraph

text: development of Mexican architecture at this time was Pedro
label: Paragraph

text: Ramirez Vazquez, who in 1964 realized two major museums
label: Paragraph

text: within the prestigious Chapultepec Park in Mexico City - the
label: Paragraph

text: National Anthropological Museum and the Museum of
label: Title

text: Modern Art. Vazquez had been one of the designers of a
label: Paragraph

text: lightweight steel frame system expressly conceived as an
label: Paragraph

text: anti-seismic armature with which to facilitate the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of rural schools throughout the country, of
label: Paragraph

text: which some 35,000 units were built during the 1960s with
label: Paragraph

text: local materials and labour. Despite this excursion into light-
label: Paragraph

text: weight steel-framed construction, the next decade saw the
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of a decidedly Brutalist monumentality, as seen
label: Paragraph

text: in the two major institutional buildings that Teodoro
label: Paragraph

text: Gonzalez de Leén and Abraham Zabludovsky built in
label: Caption

text: Chapultepec Park, the Colegio de México of 1976 and Museo
label: Caption

text: Rufino Tamayo of 1981. A reinforced concrete architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: greater refinement was achieved with the National
label: Paragraph

text: Laboratory of Genomics [382] built in Guanajuato in 2009 to
label: Paragraph

text: the designs of TEN Arquitectos, wherein the pattern of the
label: Paragraph

text: timber formwork for the concrete corresponds to the
label: Paragraph

text: orthogonal form of the building.
label: Paragraph

text: 382 TEN Arquitectos, National Laboratory of Genomics, Guanajuato, 2009.
label: Caption

text: The traces of a highly sophisticated minimalism may be
label: Paragraph

text: found in Mexican architecture throughout the second half of
label: Paragraph

text: the 20th century in works as varied as the Quintana House
label: Paragraph

text: (1956) [383], the Jaysour Building (1964) and the Escuela
label: Paragraph

text: Bancaria y Comercial (1989), all three works being designed
label: Paragraph

text: by the brilliant yet still insufficiently recognized Augusto
label: Paragraph

text: Alvarez. Within this Mexican minimalist tradition can also be
label: Paragraph

text: counted the much later San Pablo Oztotepec Market in Milpa
label: Paragraph

text: Alta built to the designs of Mauricio Rocha in 2003.
label: Paragraph

text: 383 Alvarez, Quintana House, Jardines del Pedregal, 1956.
label: Caption

text: Programmatically inventive and meticulously detailed,
label: Paragraph

text: one of the the most arresting works of the first decade of
label: Paragraph

text: the 21st century is the Vasconcelos Library [384] in Mexico
label: Paragraph

text: City completed in 2008 to the designs of Alberto Kalach,
label: Paragraph

text: assisted by Gustavo Lipkau, Juan Palomar and Tonatiuh
label: Paragraph

text: Martinez. This technological tour de force, rendering the
label: Paragraph

text: national library as a mechanistic labyrinth, is comparable as
label: Paragraph

text: a high-tech manifestation to the Centre Pompidou, Paris, of
label: Paragraph

text: 1972, which was also treated as if a cultural institution were
label: Paragraph

text: merely a giant machine. In this instance, however, the
label: Paragraph

text: sublime scale recalls the monumentality of the 18th-century
label: Paragraph

text: French architect Etienne-Louis Boullée, an effect which is
label: Paragraph

text: paradoxically due to the extensive use of glass roof lights,
label: Paragraph

text: equally translucent floors and a continuously louvred glass
label: Paragraph

text: envelope. This is complemented by an array of suspended
label: Paragraph

text: steel bookcases and stairways that hang down ina
label: Paragraph

text: somewhat ominous way, so much so as to visually interrupt
label: Paragraph

text: the spatial thrust of the main axis. Despite the bold
label: Paragraph

text: cantilevered concrete canopy over the entrances, there is
label: Caption

text: little here of the civic deportment that accompanied such
label: Paragraph

text: institutions in the past. Instead this 300-metre long (984-
label: Paragraph

text: foot) long galleria, covered by a stepped canopy of
label: Paragraph

text: dematerialized bookcases, has a disturbingly Babelic
label: Paragraph

text: character. Fortunately, the megastructure as a whole is
label: Paragraph

text: parallelled by an a//ée of trees and a beautiful landscape
label: Paragraph

text: that permeates the site throughout, so as to temper the
label: Paragraph

text: technological severity of the work.
label: Paragraph

text: 384 Kalach, Vasconcelos Library, Mexico City, 2008.
label: Caption

text: Brazil
label: Title

text: In the late 1920s the Russian émigré architect Gregori
label: Paragraph

text: Warchavchik played a fundamental role in the development
label: Paragraph

text: of the Paulista School of architecture, initially by designing a
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrical, cubic villa for his own occupation in 1929
label: Paragraph

text: [385]. While stripped of ornament, this house was
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by one of the earliest cacti gardens in Brazil,
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Warchavchik’s wife, the autodidact landscape
label: Paragraph

text: architect Mina Klabin. Both Oscar Niemeyer and Lucio Costa
label: Caption

text: worked with Warchavchik during the late 1920s, Niemeyer
label: Paragraph

text: as his assistant and Costa as his business partner prior to
label: Paragraph

text: his appointment at the age of twenty-eight to head up the
label: Paragraph

text: Escola de Belas Artes (School of Fine Arts) in Rio de Janeiro.
label: Paragraph

text: 385 Warchavchik, Casa Mariana, Sao Paulo, 1929.
label: Caption

text: An intriguing aspect of Lucio Costa’s career is that he
label: Paragraph

text: was as much involved with historic preservation as with
label: Paragraph

text: modernism and to this end he became involved in research
label: Paragraph

text: into the Portuguese vernacular, first in 1948, when the
label: Paragraph

text: Brazilian government sent him to Portugal to study the
label: Paragraph

text: evolution of agrarian typologies in the ‘home country’. His
label: Paragraph

text: initial research in this area informed his contribution to the
label: Paragraph

text: 1950 Luso-Brazilian Congress in Washington, DC, when he
label: Paragraph

text: argued that masterpieces of the Minas Gerais region in
label: Paragraph

text: south-eastern Brazil should be seen as the colonial version
label: Paragraph

text: of the original Portuguese Baroque. His second visit to
label: Paragraph

text: Portugal in 1953 not only confirmed his initial findings but
label: Paragraph

text: also prompted the Salazar regime to conduct a Survey of its
label: Paragraph

text: own into the Portuguese vernacular with the similar aim of
label: Paragraph

text: deriving an authentic, yet hybrid national style, appropriate
label: Paragraph

text: to the modern epoch. Carlos Ramos, director of the School
label: Caption

text: of Architecture of Porto, became profoundly involved in
label: Paragraph

text: orchestrating this state-sponsored research into the
label: Paragraph

text: Portuguese vernacular.
label: Paragraph

text: As previously noted, Brazil first presented its baroque
label: Paragraph

text: version of modern architecture to the world with the
label: Paragraph

text: Brazilian Pavilion, built for the New York World’s Fair of 1939
label: Caption

text: to the designs of Costa and Niemeyer (fig. 263). The
label: Paragraph

text: pavilion was complemented by an equally organic aquatic
label: Paragraph

text: garden designed by Roberto Burle Marx, who had previously
label: Paragraph

text: been responsible for the roof garden of the Ministry of
label: Paragraph

text: Education and Health in Rio de Janeiro of 1938. This building
label: Caption

text: had been designed by a team of young architects under the
label: Paragraph

text: leadership of Costa and enriched with murals by the painter
label: Caption

text: Candido Portinari made of blue and white traditional
label: Paragraph

text: Portuguese tiles (azu/ejos) [386]. This was the first
label: Paragraph

text: synthesis of the lyrical manner that Niemeyer would
label: Paragraph

text: develop further with the various buildings he realized
label: Paragraph

text: around in Pampulha, a suburb of Belo Horizonte, between
label: Paragraph

text: 1942 and 1944, including the casino that he built on a
label: Paragraph

text: promontory in the centre of an artificial lake (fig. 262).
label: Caption

text: However, the one work that would be decisive in
label: Paragraph

text: transferring the plastically dynamic manner of Rio to Sao
label: Paragraph

text: Paulo was Affonso Eduardo Reidy’s Museum of Modern Art
label: Paragraph

text: [388], built in Rio de Janeiro in 1953 in the midst of Burle
label: Paragraph

text: Marx's Flamingo Park. Predicated on a reiteration of a single
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete portal frame, repeated throughout the
label: Caption

text: length of the museum, the main floor was held above the
label: Paragraph

text: ground on canted point supports, while the two exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: levels above were cable-suspended from the portal frames.
label: Paragraph

text: The tectonically expressive character of this building had a
label: Paragraph

text: profound influence on the Paulista School of architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: first on Joao Batista Vilanova Artigas, whose bold structural
label: Paragraph

text: approach would also have an impact on successive
label: Paragraph

text: architects, then on his younger colleague Paulo Mendes da
label: Paragraph

text: Rocha and subsequently on the leading architect of the next
label: Paragraph

text: generation, Angelo Bucci. One of the most direct
label: Paragraph

text: translations of Reidy’s reinforced-concrete portal system
label: Title

text: was the reinforced-concrete blade walls carrying the roof of
label: Paragraph

text: Mendes da Rocha’s Paulistano Stadium, realized in Sdo
label: Paragraph

text: Paulo in 1958 [387]. Artigas also took from Reidy the idea of
label: Paragraph

text: bringing the rigid-frame, reinforced-concrete portals down to
label: Paragraph

text: the ground on point supports, as found in his singular
label: Paragraph

text: architectural school, FAU-USP (Faculdade de Arquitetura e
label: Paragraph

text: Urbanismo da Universidade de Sao Paulo) [389], completed
label: Caption

text: in Sao Paulo in 1967. This consisted of a large reinforced-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete box elevated two floors above ground level on
label: Caption

text: fourteen tapering concrete columns. The unique feature of
label: Paragraph

text: this building was its monumental top-lit assembly hall,
label: Paragraph

text: which Artigas conceived as the political heart of the school.
label: Paragraph

text: 386 Costa, Ministry of Education and Health, Rio de Janeiro, 1938.
label: Caption

text: 387 Mendes da Rocha, Paulistano Stadium, Sao Paulo, 1958. Section.
label: Caption

text: 388 Reidy, Museum of Modern Art, Rio de Janeiro, 1953. Section.
label: Caption

text: 389 Artigas and Cascaldi, FAU-USP (School of Architecture and Urbanism),
label: Caption

text: University of Sdo Paulo, 1967.
label: Caption

text: Both Artigas and Mendes da Rocha shared a socio-
label: Paragraph

text: political commitment, which accounts for their dismissal
label: Paragraph

text: from the faculty of the architecture school by the US-backed
label: Paragraph

text: military junta that seized power in Brazil in 1964, thereby
label: Paragraph

text: inaugurating twenty-one years of military rule. This political
label: Paragraph

text: upheaval also led to Niemeyer’s exile, owing to his lifelong
label: Paragraph

text: adherence to the Communist cause (see his credo on p.
label: Paragraph

text: 290). It would seem that the exceptionally felicitous lyricism
label: Paragraph

text: of the Rio-based wing of the Brazilian Modern Movement in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1950s did not survive Niemeyer’s enforced exile, not
label: Paragraph

text: even in his own work. In this way, the sweeping, majestic
label: Paragraph

text: form of his Copan Building, a residential tower realized in
label: Paragraph

text: Sao Paulo in 1965, gave way to an arcuated formalism that
label: Paragraph

text: characterized the second half of his career.
label: Paragraph

text: Mendes da Rocha continued to work throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: period of military rule, building his gigantic Serra Dourada
label: Paragraph

text: stadium in Goiania in 1973 and going on in the 1980s to
label: Paragraph

text: realize a number of small but significant apartment
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. In perhaps no other work by Mendes da Rocha
label: Paragraph

text: does his civic commitment more patently express itself than
label: Paragraph

text: in his Poupatempo (‘Timesaver’) Public Service Centre [390,
label: Paragraph

text: 391], built in Sao Paulo in 1998. Equally accessible by metro
label: Paragraph

text: and car, this 300-metre (984-foot) long structure is rendered
label: Paragraph

text: as an elevated viaduct, referencing the heroic Brazilian
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete tradition as exemplified in the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Niemeyer and Reidy. The Poupatempo building is
label: Caption

text: distinguished by the way in which its cantilevered concrete
label: Paragraph

text: deck is carried on widely spaced pi/otis and is capped by a
label: Paragraph

text: light-weight, welded-steel roof. It is typical of Mendes da
label: Paragraph

text: Rocha’s sense of structural economy that this elegant steel
label: Paragraph

text: superstructure should overhang the viaduct upstands in
label: Paragraph

text: such a way as to obviate the need for brises-soleil.
label: Paragraph

text: 390, 391 Mendes da Rocha, Poupatempo Public Service Centre, Sao Paulo,
label: Caption

text: 1998. View, and section through elevated concrete deck with steel roof.
label: Caption

text: For Mendes da Rocha, the revelation of engineering form
label: Caption

text: is a precondition of endowing a work with civic significance,
label: Paragraph

text: as we find in the 60-metre (197-foot) portico spanning the
label: Paragraph

text: podium of the Brazilian Museum of Sculpture, built in Sao
label: Caption

text: Paulo in 1988. The other characteristic element of Mendes
label: Paragraph

text: da Rocha’s work is his penchant for designing waterscapes
label: Paragraph

text: at a territorial scale, such as his 1988 proposal for
label: Paragraph

text: transforming the bay of Montevideo into a perfect square. A
label: Paragraph

text: similar territorial scale obtains in the Sports Boulevard that
label: Paragraph

text: he planned for Paris in 2008 as part of the French bid for the
label: Paragraph

text: 2012 Olympic Games. This project stands out as a public
label: Paragraph

text: domain within the automotive megalopolitan chaos that
label: Paragraph

text: surrounds it on every side. Mendes da Rocha’s Arc of the
label: Paragraph

text: Patriarch [394], suspended over a subterranean
label: Paragraph

text: passageway in the centre of Sao Paulo, constitutes a similar
label: Paragraph

text: monumental impulse on a more modest scale: a welded
label: Title

text: steel aerofoil section measuring 19 by 23 metres (62 by 75
label: Caption

text: feet) in plan is hung from a 38-metre (125-feet) triangular
label: Paragraph

text: steel beam raised up on steel columns. For Mendes da
label: Caption

text: Rocha, the socio-cultural potential of a work is inseparable
label: Paragraph

text: from the symbolic generosity of its form combined with the
label: Paragraph

text: social programme of its spatial organization, so that for him
label: Paragraph

text: even a house may be given a public character, as we find in
label: Paragraph

text: his own house built in Butanta, Sao Paulo, in 1960 [392,
label: Caption

text: 392, 393 Mendes da Rocha, house in Butanta, SAo Paulo, 1960. Section and
label: Caption

text: plan.
label: Paragraph

text: 394 Mendes da Rocha, Arc of the Patriarch, Sdo Paulo, 2002.
label: Caption

text: The leading Brazilian architect of the next generation to
label: Paragraph

text: come out of the FAU-USP was Angelo Bucci [396, 397], who
label: Paragraph

text: started his career as a leading designer within the collective
label: Paragraph

text: practice of MMBB. This team would produce a number of
label: Paragraph

text: large-scale urban works in collaboration with Mendes da
label: Paragraph

text: Rocha, including the Dom Pedro II bus terminal in Sao Paulo,
label: Paragraph

text: completed in 2001 in the park bearing the same name. The
label: Paragraph

text: most impressive domestic work to date to be completed by
label: Paragraph

text: the MMBB practice is the exceptionally elegant Aldeia da
label: Paragraph

text: Serra House [395] of 2002, wherein - as with certain works
label: Paragraph

text: by Mendes da Rocha - reinforced-concrete construction is
label: Paragraph

text: combined with passerelles and stairs executed in welded
label: Paragraph

text: steel, the house being partially entered from above via an
label: Paragraph

text: adjoining earthwork. It is also accessible from the car park
label: Paragraph

text: beneath the house.
label: Paragraph

text: 395 MMBB with Bucci/SPBR, house in Aldeia da Serra, Sdo Paulo, 2001.
label: Caption

text: 396, 397 Bucci, house in Ubatuba, Sado Paulo, 2009. Plan and study model.
label: Caption

text: The heroic Paulista line in reinforced concrete is also
label: Paragraph

text: evident in the work of the Italian @migré architect Lina Bo
label: Paragraph

text: Bardi, who first came to prominence on the Brazilian scene
label: Paragraph

text: with her Sao Paulo Museum of Modern Art (MASP), which
label: Paragraph

text: was finally realized on the Avenida Paulista in 1968 after a
label: Paragraph

text: decade of development. This 75-metre (246-foot) span
label: Paragraph

text: bridge structure comprised two gallery floors, suspended
label: Paragraph

text: from two giant reinforced-concrete beams, which, together
label: Paragraph

text: with subterranean offices and other spaces, comprise the
label: Paragraph

text: museum proper. Beneath the bridge form, a public plaza
label: Caption

text: provides a heroic belvedere overlooking a park and a major
label: Paragraph

text: autoroute.
label: Paragraph

text: Traumatized by Fascism, which she had experienced in
label: Paragraph

text: Italy before migrating to Brazil at the end of the Second
label: Paragraph

text: World War, Bo Bardi moved to Salvador in the north-eastern
label: Paragraph

text: state of Bahia as soon as the military junta came to power
label: Paragraph

text: in Brazil. There she became involved with the African culture
label: Paragraph

text: that still existed in the Brazilian savannas, which coloured
label: Paragraph

text: her work long after her return to Sao Paulo in 1977. On her
label: Paragraph

text: return she received the second major commission of her life,
label: Paragraph

text: namely the conversion of an abandoned industrial complex
label: Paragraph

text: into a community centre and sports facility [398]. This so-
label: Paragraph

text: called SESC Fabrica de Pompéia not only involved restoring
label: Paragraph

text: and adapting obsolete factory buildings, but also entailed
label: Paragraph

text: constructing two reinforced-concrete towers, linked by a
label: Paragraph

text: diagonal stairway and a horizontal passerelle. These
label: Paragraph

text: monumental additions were cast from rough timber
label: Caption

text: formwork, in the so-called béton brut manner of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier. A quarter of a century later, this Brutalist tour de
label: Paragraph

text: force exerted some influence on the Portuguese architect
label: Paragraph

text: Alvaro Siza’s Iberé Camargo museum, built at Porto Alegre
label: Caption

text: in 2001. The irregularly shaped window openings that
label: Paragraph

text: punctuate the concrete walls of Bo Bardi’s SESC towers find
label: Paragraph

text: a subtle echo in the external concrete ramps of Siza’s
label: Paragraph

text: museum, which first fold out of and then crank back into the
label: Paragraph

text: main body of the building.
label: Caption

text: 398 Bo Bardi, Pompeia Factory Leisure Centre, Sado Paulo, 1987.
label: Caption

text: After graduating as an architect from the Faculdade
label: Paragraph

text: Nacional de Arquitetura (National Faculty of Architecture) in
label: Paragraph

text: Rio de Janeiro in 1955, Joao da Gama Filgueiras Lima,
label: Paragraph

text: popularly known as ‘Lelé’ [400], began his career as an
label: Paragraph

text: assistant to Oscar Niemeyer on the construction of Brasilia
label: Caption

text: (see pp. 290-91). In 1970 the junta decided to build a new
label: Paragraph

text: administrative centre in Bahia and hired Lucio Costa to
label: Paragraph

text: design the site plan amid the rolling hills north of the city.
label: Caption

text: Due to the tight schedule, Costa called on Lima to establish
label: Paragraph

text: a prefabricated concrete plant capable of realizing the
label: Paragraph

text: complex in a short time. After this experience, Lelé became
label: Paragraph

text: one of the most sophisticated masters of prefabricated
label: Paragraph

text: concrete construction, leading him in the late 1980s to
label: Paragraph

text: design and construct hospitals throughout the northern
label: Title

text: region. As Adrian Forty and Elisabetta Andreoli have written
label: Paragraph

text: of this achievement:
label: Title

text: 399 Herefhui + Ferroni Architects, Estadual Vilanova School, Sao Paulo, 2005.
label: Caption

text: 400 Lelé, Macapa Outpost, Macapa, 2001-05.
label: Caption

text: Easy to transport and handle, these precast units could be
label: Paragraph

text: effortlessly assembled in a variety of forms and combined
label: Paragraph

text: with lighter metallic elements, reducing both building costs
label: Paragraph

text: and production times while providing functional, pleasant,
label: Paragraph

text: and playful environments ... To avoid the use of costly
label: Paragraph

text: mechanical air conditioning systems, he designed a natural
label: Paragraph

text: cooling alternative in which fresh air was circulated through
label: Paragraph

text: an underground network of galleries, from where, once
label: Paragraph

text: warmed, it left the building through ducts formed by curved
label: Paragraph

text: openings in the roof.
label: Caption

text: One cannot conclude this account of the Brazilian Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement without acknowledging the other major urban
label: Paragraph

text: achievement apart from Brasilia, namely Jorge Wilheim’s
label: Paragraph

text: 1965 master plan for expanding Curitiba, the state capital of
label: Caption

text: Parana, a plan predicated on installing an economic and
label: Paragraph

text: feasible system of city-wide mass transit [401]. This system
label: Paragraph

text: was based on the provision of articulated buses, each with a
label: Paragraph

text: seating capacity of 100 and running on dedicated bus lanes.
label: Paragraph

text: Their access from elevated tubular boarding platforms at
label: Paragraph

text: the level of the bus floor speeded up the process of entry
label: Paragraph

text: and exit of passengers at each stop. Since ticketing was
label: Paragraph

text: handled in the access tubes, this enabled buses to arrive
label: Paragraph

text: and depart with great frequency. This system, combined
label: Paragraph

text: with the greater floor area ratios permitted for high-density
label: Paragraph

text: development adjacent to the transit corridors, proved to be
label: Paragraph

text: both profitable and socially beneficial at many levels: above
label: Paragraph

text: all, people received municipal inducements to bring their
label: Paragraph

text: rubbish out of the fave/as to centralized collection points in
label: Paragraph

text: exchange for either food or tickets for the transit system.
label: Paragraph

text: Such a welfare-state approach to urban planning under the
label: Paragraph

text: mayoralty of Jaime Lerner would not have been successful
label: Paragraph

text: without the support of the military government. As Luis
label: Paragraph

text: Carranza and Fernando Luiz Lara have noted, ‘The extent to
label: Paragraph

text: which such innovative policies could be applied under
label: Paragraph

text: normal democratic processes has been the subject of
label: Paragraph

text: heated and heavily politicized debates after the re-
label: Paragraph

text: democratization of Brazil in 1985.’! Despite the political
label: Paragraph

text: demands of enacting such an ambitious scheme, a similar
label: Paragraph

text: transit system of city-wide, high-speed buses running on
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated lanes would eventually be introduced to the
label: Paragraph

text: Colombian capital of Bogota in 1997 by the then mayor
label: Paragraph

text: Enrique Penalosa, under whose administration the city
label: Paragraph

text: would build 298 kilometres (185 miles) of bicycle routes and
label: Paragraph

text: add some 929,000 square metres (10 million square feet) of
label: Paragraph

text: new park space to the existing fabric. In Brazil the one other
label: Paragraph

text: radical career to benefit in paradoxical ways from the
label: Paragraph

text: military coup of 1964 was that of Severiano Porto, who,
label: Paragraph

text: going to the Amazon basin with the aim of building for its
label: Paragraph

text: impoverished population, was employed by the state to
label: Paragraph

text: build for what under military rule had become a tax-free
label: Paragraph

text: region, stimulating the local economy. This led Porto to
label: Paragraph

text: design several buildings for the University of Amazonas and
label: Caption

text: to build a 40,000-seat soccer stadium sunken some 10
label: Paragraph

text: metres (33 feet) in the ground.
label: Paragraph

text: 401 High-speed mass-transit bus system on designated bus lanes, Curitiba,
label: Caption

text: Parana.
label: Paragraph

text: Colombia
label: Title

text: The first school of architecture in Colombia was founded in
label: Paragraph

text: the National University of Bogota in 1935 and was staffed
label: Paragraph

text: largely by immigrant architects - Bruno Violi and Vicente
label: Paragraph

text: Nasi from Italy, the urban planner Karl Brunner from Austria
label: Paragraph

text: and Leopoldo Rother from Germany - with these last two
label: Paragraph

text: introducing an emphasis on urban design in the school.
label: Paragraph

text: From 1933 onwards Brunner had taken the lead in urban
label: Paragraph

text: planning in Colombia by designing plans for the expansion
label: Paragraph

text: of a number of prominent cities, including Barranquilla, Cali,
label: Paragraph

text: Medellin and Bogota itself, well before Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: projected a schematic plan for the capital in 1947. Rother
label: Paragraph

text: was responsible for the master plan of the campus of the
label: Paragraph

text: National University (1937-45) and for the design of a
label: Paragraph

text: number of its faculty buildings, including the School of
label: Paragraph

text: Engineering (1945), which he designed with Violi.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1948 Rogelio Salmona, who was of Franco-Spanish
label: Paragraph

text: origin and had been born in Paris in 1927, left the National
label: Paragraph

text: University to enter Le Corbusier’s atelier in Paris. There he
label: Paragraph

text: would work as an apprentice during a particularly fertile
label: Paragraph

text: period of Le Corbusier’s post-war career, extending from the
label: Paragraph

text: Unité d’Habitation at Marseille, already underway in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1940s, to the entirety of the architect’s work in India.
label: Paragraph

text: Towards the end of his apprenticeship, Salmona worked on
label: Paragraph

text: the design, detailing and site supervision of the Maisons
label: Caption

text: Jaoul (1952-57), and this experience influenced him for the
label: Paragraph

text: rest of his life.
label: Paragraph

text: On his return to Colombia in 1957, Salmona’s
label: Paragraph

text: disenchantment with what he saw as Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: formalism prompted him to work with the established
label: Paragraph

text: Colombian architect Fernando Martinez Sanabria on the
label: Caption

text: design of four houses for a steeply sloping site, north of
label: Caption

text: Bogota (1962-63). Built out of brick and linked to one
label: Paragraph

text: another by low brick walls, these Aaltoesque houses
label: Paragraph

text: anticipated the brick syntax of Salmona’s mature career.
label: Paragraph

text: Salmona followed this experience with the small three-
label: Paragraph

text: storey El Polo cluster housing that he designed with
label: Paragraph

text: Guillermo Bermudez and built in Bogota from 1960 to 1963.
label: Caption

text: After this came the Fundacion Cristiana de la Vivienda
label: Paragraph

text: (Christian Housing Foundation) complex [402] designed
label: Caption

text: with Hernan Vieco and built at San Cristébal, Bogota, in
label: Caption

text: 1966. Built on a flat site and comprising twin apartment
label: Caption

text: blocks set at an angle to each other with largely blank side
label: Paragraph

text: walls in brick, these inclined structures recall by association
label: Paragraph

text: the pyramidal profiles of Pre-Columbian architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: 402 Salmona, Fundacion Cristiana de la Vivienda, San Cristébal, Bogota, 1966.
label: Caption

text: Salmona’s next work of consequence was the public
label: Paragraph

text: housing Residencias El Parque (1965-70) [403, 404],
label: Paragraph

text: designed and realized with Luis Eduardo Torres. Overlooking
label: Caption

text: the bullring in Bogota, these three towers, ranging from
label: Paragraph

text: twenty to thirty-three storeys, make up a cluster of fan-
label: Paragraph

text: shaped spiralling apartment blocks that echo in their format
label: Paragraph

text: Hans Scharoun’s medium-rise Romeo and Juliet apartment
label: Title

text: blocks, built in Stuttgart in 1962. What is exceptional about
label: Paragraph

text: Salmona’s work is the multilevelled complexity of the entire
label: Paragraph

text: undertaking, evident not only in the apartment plans that
label: Paragraph

text: are stacked as spiralling assemblies gradually diminishing in
label: Paragraph

text: size as each tower block rises to its apex, but also, ata
label: Paragraph

text: micro-scale, in the brickwork, each course being an exercise
label: Paragraph

text: in solid geometry as the angle of each brick varied through
label: Paragraph

text: the arc of each wall as one course succeeds to the next.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the prestigious location, the actual floor area of the
label: Paragraph

text: apartments is relatively modest since this scheme was
label: Paragraph

text: intended to serve as social housing. A similar but simpler
label: Paragraph

text: section is evident in Salmona’s Alto de los Pinos apartments
label: Paragraph

text: of 1982, north of Bogota, arranged as a stepped formation
label: Paragraph

text: on either side of a communal garden which also steps down
label: Caption

text: in the form of terraces, following the natural slope of the
label: Paragraph

text: site and the location of the pre-existing pine trees on the
label: Paragraph

text: site that give the building its name.
label: Paragraph

text: 403, 404 Salmona, El Parque residential complex, Bogota, 1965-70. Unit plans
label: Caption

text: and aerial view.
label: Paragraph

text: In the early 1980s Salmona’s career moved away from
label: Paragraph

text: residential work to the design of a series of public buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: mostly cultural institutions, university faculties and
label: Paragraph

text: museums. Around this time he received the most
label: Paragraph

text: prestigious commission of his career, the Presidential State
label: Paragraph

text: Guest House, otherwise known as the Casa de Huespedes
label: Paragraph

text: (1980-82) [405], built on a peninsula projecting out into the
label: Paragraph

text: Bay of Cartagena, next to one of the fortifications of this
label: Caption

text: colonial city. Conceived as an austere, self-contained,
label: Paragraph

text: cloistered retreat for the president and his honoured guests,
label: Paragraph

text: it was constructed out of a mixture of bricks and local coral
label: Paragraph

text: stone. The most poetic aspect of this work is the way in
label: Paragraph

text: which it conveys the atmosphere of a Pre-Columbian ruin
label: Paragraph

text: embedded in a tropical landscape, which Salmona designed
label: Paragraph

text: with his wife, the landscape architect Maria Elvira Madrifan.
label: Paragraph

text: 405 Salmona, Casa de Huespedes, Cartagena, 1980-82.
label: Caption

text: After completing the state guest house, Salmona was
label: Paragraph

text: engaged with a social project in the Candelaria district of
label: Paragraph

text: Bogota. This exercise in urban renewal was based on nine
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter blocks, of which only four were built. Each block
label: Paragraph

text: was grouped around a courtyard which was at its corners
label: Paragraph

text: stepped in section so that one could pass through the
label: Paragraph

text: neighbourhood diagonally from one courtyard to the next.
label: Paragraph

text: This relatively open circulation testified to Salmona’s
label: Paragraph

text: lifelong opposition to gated communities.
label: Paragraph

text: Among the talented Colombian architects of the 1980s,
label: Paragraph

text: equally committed to the importance of the public realm,
label: Paragraph

text: one needs to acknowledge the work of Oscar Mesa, an
label: Paragraph

text: architect who was particularly influenced by the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Louis Kahn, as his Metropolitan Theatre in Medellin of 1986
label: Paragraph

text: [406] makes abundantly clear. Equally notable is the 1,500-
label: Paragraph

text: unit La Mota housing complex built in Medellin in 1987
label: Caption

text: [407] to the designs of Laureano Forero Ochoa, a rational
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalist three- to four-storey scheme, the units of which
label: Paragraph

text: were ingeniously organized.
label: Paragraph

text: 406 Oscar Mesa, Metropolitan Theatre, Medellin, 1986.
label: Caption

text: 407 Forero Ochoa, La Mota Residential Complex, Medellin, 1987. Plan.
label: Caption

text: Despite continual political strife in the country at large,
label: Paragraph

text: progressive policies were pursued in Bogota by one
label: Paragraph

text: government after another, beginning with Jaime Castro
label: Paragraph

text: Castro, who as mayor reorganized the administrative and
label: Paragraph

text: financial structure of the city to bring it into line with the
label: Paragraph

text: country’s new constitution in 1991. Castro was followed by
label: Paragraph

text: Antanas Mockus and Enrique Penalosa, the successive
label: Paragraph

text: mayors of the city from 1995 to 2003, with Penalosa greatly
label: Paragraph

text: expanding the city’s park system and the provision of public
label: Paragraph

text: libraries as well as introducing the TransMilenio bus rapid
label: Paragraph

text: transit system, modelled on the system developed for
label: Paragraph

text: Curitiba.
label: Paragraph

text: After an era of violence induced by the drug cartels, an
label: Paragraph

text: equally progressive policy was pursued in Medellin,
label: Paragraph

text: beginning with the mayoralty of Sergio Fajardo (2005-07),
label: Paragraph

text: who commissioned a number of public projects including the
label: Paragraph

text: so-called Four Sports Arena [408]. This was built in the
label: Paragraph

text: centre of the city in 2009 to the designs of Giancarlo
label: Paragraph

text: Mazzanti and Felipe Mesa, and comprises a partially open
label: Paragraph

text: area covered by a light-weight folded-plate structure
label: Paragraph

text: consisting of welded tubular steel latticework trusses.
label: Paragraph

text: 408 Mazzanti and Mesa, Four Sports Arena, Medellin, 1987.
label: Caption

text: Venezuela
label: Title

text: Carlos Raul Villanueva was the most internationally
label: Paragraph

text: renowned modernist architect practising in Venezuela
label: Paragraph

text: during the second half of the 20th century. Of Venezuelan
label: Paragraph

text: origin but born in London in 1900 to a diplomatic family and
label: Paragraph

text: educated in Paris at the Ecole de Beaux-Arts, Villanueva
label: Paragraph

text: returned to Caracas in 1929, where, after an apprenticeship
label: Paragraph

text: in the Ministry of Public Works, he would start his
label: Paragraph

text: independent practice in 1935 with the commission to design
label: Paragraph

text: the Museo de Bellas Artes for Los Caobos, Caracas. He
label: Caption

text: followed this work in 1939 with the design of the somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: Art Deco Gran Colombia School [410], built in Santa Teresa.
label: Caption

text: In 1942 he won the competition for an inexpensive,
label: Paragraph

text: medium-rise housing scheme in the newly emergent central
label: Paragraph

text: district of Caracas, known as El Silencio. This rambling
label: Paragraph

text: neighbourhood unit was a hybrid work, the front being
label: Paragraph

text: rendered in a muted Spanish colonial manner, while the rear
label: Paragraph

text: comprised an array of stacked terraces in reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete. In 1957 he was commissioned to design two large
label: Paragraph

text: high-rise, low-cost housing schemes on the outskirts of the
label: Paragraph

text: city. These were made up of free-standing slab blocks of
label: Paragraph

text: different heights set on undulating ground, the most
label: Paragraph

text: significant of which was the 23 de Enero estate,
label: Paragraph

text: commemorating the date of the 1958 coup d’etat, designed
label: Paragraph

text: in association with José Manuel Mijares.
label: Paragraph

text: 409 Dominguez, Centro Simén Bolivar, Caracas, 1949-57. Elevation.
label: Caption

text: 410 Villanueva, Gran Colombia School, Caracas, 1939.
label: Caption

text: Villanueva’s ultimate masterwork was the University City
label: Paragraph

text: of Caracas, built on the fringes of the city, the master plan
label: Paragraph

text: of which was first outlined in 1944. This plan was integrated
label: Paragraph

text: by a serpentine covered walkway linking the different
label: Paragraph

text: faculties. Villanueva subsequently designed all the principal
label: Paragraph

text: faculty buildings, including the Aula Magna - a large
label: Paragraph

text: auditorium- enlivened by a giant polychromatic mobile
label: Paragraph

text: specially created as a decorative acoustical device by the
label: Paragraph

text: celebrated American artist Alexander Calder [411]. The
label: Paragraph

text: cantilevered reinforced-concrete canopy meandering
label: Caption

text: through the campus [412] was interspersed with exotic
label: Paragraph

text: gardens, which were enriched by free-standing sculptures
label: Paragraph

text: and wall reliefs created by distinguished artists of the
label: Paragraph

text: international modernist avant garde, such as Henri Laurens,
label: Paragraph

text: Fernand Léger, Jean Arp, Victor Vasarely and Antoine
label: Title

text: Pevsner.
label: Paragraph

text: 411 Calder, acoustical artwork in the Aula Magna, University City of Caracas,
label: Caption

text: 412 Villanueva, University City of Caracas, 1944. Plan of covered walkways.
label: Caption

text: Villanueva’s lifelong commitment to abstract art was also
label: Paragraph

text: evident in the Venezuelan Pavilion that he designed for Expo
label: Paragraph

text: 67 in Montreal. It consisted of three interconnected, double-
label: Paragraph

text: height cubes fabricated out of welded-steel sheet, each one
label: Paragraph

text: painted in a different colour - yellow, blue or red - of the
label: Paragraph

text: Venezuelan national flag. Each cube was designed to exhibit
label: Paragraph

text: an aspect of contemporary Venezuelan culture. While the
label: Paragraph

text: first displayed a four-screen documentary dedicated to the
label: Paragraph

text: history of the country, the second contained a ‘rainforest’
label: Paragraph

text: sculpture designed by the Venezuelan artist Jesus Rafael
label: Caption

text: Soto. This was a maze of plastic cables hanging from the
label: Paragraph

text: ceiling through which visitors had to weave their way in
label: Paragraph

text: order to arrive at the third and final cube, which contained a
label: Paragraph

text: bar musicale where musicians played Venezuelan folk
label: Title

text: music.
label: Paragraph

text: Another important architect at work in Caracas during
label: Paragraph

text: the 1950s was Cipriano Dominguez, who designed the
label: Paragraph

text: monumental twin towers of the Centro Simén Bolivar [409],
label: Caption

text: situated at the head of the urban axis devised in 1939 by
label: Paragraph

text: the French planner Maurice Rotival. An equally prominent
label: Paragraph

text: architect who left his mark on the city was Tomas José
label: Paragraph

text: Sanabria, who designed the Hotel Humboldt (1956), located
label: Paragraph

text: at the top of the Avila mountain range that separates
label: Paragraph

text: Caracas from the sea and linked by cable car to the
label: Paragraph

text: downtown of the city. The exceptionally sensitive Jesus
label: Paragraph

text: Tenreiro-Degwitz was the first Venezuelan architect to make
label: Paragraph

text: a name for himself outside the capital with his headquarters
label: Paragraph

text: for the CVG electrical company [413], built in the boom
label: Paragraph

text: town of Guayana in 1968. This exceptional work took the
label: Paragraph

text: form of a dematerialized pyramid made up of thin brick
label: Paragraph

text: panels held in place by an equally delicate steel frame.
label: Paragraph

text: These panels served as brises-so/ei/ shielding the stacked
label: Paragraph

text: office floors within from the sun. With characteristic
label: Paragraph

text: melancholy Degwitz remarked:
label: Paragraph

text: 413 Jesus Tenreiro-Degwitz, CVG electrical company, Guayana, 1968.
label: Caption

text: The site is the highest point in Ciudad Guayana, and it was
label: Paragraph

text: barren, with nothing built around it. There was no city plan
label: Paragraph

text: establishing limitations on height or bulk. The CVG
label: Paragraph

text: architects requested something like a landmark, and the
label: Paragraph

text: pyramid came forth as a natural form for human beings
label: Paragraph

text: living in a difficult tropical climate ... The stepped pyramid
label: Paragraph

text: allows for the interaction of inner and outer space through a
label: Paragraph

text: facade of continuous balconies with shaded gardens, a
label: Caption

text: beautiful sight that is visible from almost all the working
label: Paragraph

text: areas inside. It was to be the first building in the future
label: Paragraph

text: centre of Alta Vista, the heart of the new city, so it had the
label: Paragraph

text: character of a foundation stone for an imagined beautiful
label: Paragraph

text: metropolis - one that ultimately never came to be.*
label: Paragraph

text: The ultimate manifestation of Degwitz’s architectural
label: Paragraph

text: maturity was the city hall of Barquisimeto [414], of 1967.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps the most remarkable aspect of this work is the
label: Paragraph

text: geometrical rationality of the /n-situ concrete walls by which
label: Paragraph

text: the building is organized in a manner reminiscent of the
label: Paragraph

text: rhythmic order to be found in the work of Louis Kahn.
label: Paragraph

text: 414 Jesus Tenreiro-Degwitz, Barquisimeto City Hall, Barquisimeto, 1967.
label: Caption

text: A tectonic and spatial probity of an entirely different kind
label: Paragraph

text: would appear much later in the work of his brother, Oscar
label: Paragraph

text: Tenreiro. Typical of this other Tenreiro is a multi-purpose
label: Paragraph

text: gymnasium [415] that he proposed for the Ciudad
label: Paragraph

text: Deportiva in San Carlos, Cojedes, in 2003. This hybrid steel
label: Paragraph

text: and concrete structure was ingeniously designed in
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration with his son, the structural engineer Esteban
label: Paragraph

text: Tenreiro.
label: Paragraph

text: 415 Oscar Tenreiro, covered gymnasium for Ciudad Deportiva, San Carlos,
label: Caption

text: Cojedes, 2003.
label: Caption

text: The one other Venezuelan architect of this generation to
label: Paragraph

text: have a prolific career was Walter James (Jimmy) Alcock,
label: Paragraph

text: who, although born in Caracas, spent his formative years in
label: Paragraph

text: England, where he took a master’s degree in chemistry in
label: Paragraph

text: Cambridge. On his return to Venezuela in 1953 he obtained
label: Paragraph

text: a master’s degree in architecture at the Central University
label: Paragraph

text: of Caracas and soon after began to work with Alexander
label: Paragraph

text: Pietri and Roberto Burle Marx on the development of Burle
label: Title

text: Marx's Parque del Este in Caracas. In 1959 he entered into a
label: Paragraph

text: partnership with José Miguel Galia and together they
label: Paragraph

text: designed parks for various provincial cities in Venezuela,
label: Paragraph

text: including San Felipe and Urachiche. Opening his own office
label: Paragraph

text: in 1962, Alcock achieved his breakthrough, typologically
label: Paragraph

text: speaking, with his Altolar housing built in 1965 on Bello
label: Paragraph

text: Monte [416] overlooking the valley of Caracas: a curved six-
label: Caption

text: storey block of apartments of brick-faced, reinforced-
label: Caption

text: concrete construction accessed from a galleria built against
label: Caption

text: a gigantic retaining wall. This topographic work was
label: Paragraph

text: distantly inspired by Le Corbusier’s Plan Obus for Algiers of
label: Paragraph

text: 1930 and Affonso Reidy’s Pedregulho housing complex, built
label: Caption

text: in Rio de Janeiro in 1951. A key trope in Alcock’s civic work
label: Paragraph

text: was his use of galleria, such as we find this type in his Hotel
label: Paragraph

text: Jirahara in Barquisimeto of 1972, designed in association
label: Caption

text: with Manuel Fuentes.
label: Caption

text: 416 Alcock, Bello Monte housing, Caracas, 1965. Detail of elevation.
label: Caption

text: Argentina
label: Title

text: The beginning of the Modern Movement in Argentina dates
label: Paragraph

text: from 1929, not only because it was the year in which Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier came to Buenos Aires to begin his Latin American
label: Paragraph

text: lectures, but also because it is the moment when certain
label: Paragraph

text: Argentinian modernists, notably Alejandro Virasoro and
label: Paragraph

text: Alberto Prebisch, made their own early forays into
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete construction. This was particularly
label: Paragraph

text: evident in Prebisch’s Casa Romanelli of 1936, which was
label: Paragraph

text: almost a replica of one of Le Corbusier’s so-called mass-
label: Paragraph

text: produced houses as these were featured in the penultimate
label: Paragraph

text: chapter of Vers une architecture of 1923.
label: Caption

text: The first émigré modern architect of calibre to arrive in
label: Paragraph

text: Argentina was the Catalan Antoni Bonet. Having worked for
label: Paragraph

text: José Luis Sert and Josep Torres Clavé in Barcelona, Bonet left
label: Paragraph

text: for Paris after the outbreak of the Spanish Civil War in 1936,
label: Paragraph

text: where, apart from assisting Sert on his design of the Pavilion
label: Paragraph

text: of the Spanish Republic for the Paris World Exhibition of
label: Caption

text: 1937, he worked in the office of Le Corbusier. In 1938 he
label: Paragraph

text: migrated to Buenos Aires in the company of two young
label: Paragraph

text: Argentines whom he had met in Le Corbusier's studio, Juan
label: Paragraph

text: Kurchan and Jorge Ferrari Hardoy. Together they formed the
label: Paragraph

text: partnership of BKF, which, within a year of its foundation,
label: Paragraph

text: realized a small mixed-use studio building in downtown
label: Paragraph

text: Buenos Aires. Later this practice became the nexus of the
label: Paragraph

text: Grupo Austral, which, inspired by Le Corbusier's program of
label: Paragraph

text: agrarian reform as set forth in his 1937 Pavillon des Temps
label: Paragraph

text: Nouveaux, was preoccupied with the design of rural
label: Paragraph

text: housing. BKF was also engaged in furniture design, including
label: Paragraph

text: its famous Sling Chair, which, fabricated out of canvas and
label: Paragraph

text: steel rod, was based on the traditional Italian Tripolina
label: Paragraph

text: campaign chair. In the interim Bonet emerged as an
label: Paragraph

text: architect of stature with a number of vacation houses on the
label: Paragraph

text: sand dunes of Punta Ballena at the mouth of the Rio de la
label: Caption

text: Plata in the 1940s. Bonet’s penchant for vaulted space
label: Paragraph

text: came into its own with his Berlingieri House [417, 418] of
label: Paragraph

text: 1947, wherein the shell vaults were designed by the young
label: Paragraph

text: Uruguayan engineer Eladio Dieste. Bonet’s feeling for the
label: Paragraph

text: integration of his work into the dune landscape was
label: Paragraph

text: particularly evident in his three-storey Hosteria La Solana
label: Paragraph

text: del Mar of 1947.
label: Paragraph

text: 417, 418 Bonet, Berlingieri House, Maldonado, Uruguay, 1947. View and detail
label: Caption

text: of vault to wall connection.
label: Paragraph

text: It is significant with regard to the continuity of the
label: Paragraph

text: modern tradition that the young architect Clorindo Testa
label: Paragraph

text: worked as an assistant in the office of BKF before going on
label: Paragraph

text: to design his reinforced-concrete tour de force, the Bank of
label: Paragraph

text: London and South America [419, 420], produced in
label: Paragraph

text: association with the well-established SEPRA practice and
label: Paragraph

text: realized on a tight site in downtown Buenos Aires in 1966.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from serving as the headquarters of a major bank, this
label: Paragraph

text: building evokes the idea of a city-in-miniature in which the
label: Paragraph

text: internal transactions are seen as being of virtually the same
label: Paragraph

text: order as the hustle and bustle of the adjacent street. The
label: Paragraph

text: free-floating concrete decks of the multistorey banking hall,
label: Caption

text: set back from the structural facade, are either cantilevered
label: Paragraph

text: from cylindrical columns descending into the basement or
label: Paragraph

text: cable-suspended from the structural ceiling of the hall.
label: Caption

text: Although Testa continued to practise both as an architect
label: Paragraph

text: and an artist throughout his life, he would never equal the
label: Paragraph

text: tectonic tour de force of the Bank of London and South
label: Title

text: America, except for the National Library in Buenos Aires,
label: Paragraph

text: designed in association with Francisco Bullrich and Alicia
label: Caption

text: Cazzaniga in 1962 but not completed until 1992.
label: Paragraph

text: 419, 420 Testa, Bank of London and South America, Buenos Aires, 1966.
label: Caption

text: Section and sketch of section.
label: Paragraph

text: Testa had first come to the fore in 1955 with his winning
label: Paragraph

text: entry for the civic centre for Santa Rosa de la Pampa,
label: Caption

text: designed with three other architects. The covered walkway
label: Caption

text: leading into this Corbusian building was made out of
label: Paragraph

text: cantilevered reinforced-concrete parasols like those
label: Paragraph

text: structures for shelter projected by Amancio Williams in an
label: Caption

text: audacious proposal for a hospital in Corrientes dating from
label: Paragraph

text: 1953. Similar concrete parasols appeared as a repetitive
label: Paragraph

text: canopy element in an aborted megastructural project for the
label: Paragraph

text: University of Tucuman designed by a team of architects
label: Caption

text: under the leadership of Horacio Caminos.
label: Paragraph

text: Williams was an exceptionally innovative designer, who,
label: Paragraph

text: after studying both engineering and architecture, began his
label: Paragraph

text: career in 1945 by designing a bridge house for his father,
label: Paragraph

text: the composer Alberto Williams. His unbuilt projects were just
label: Paragraph

text: as unorthodox and brilliant as his built work, including his
label: Paragraph

text: design for an airport suspended in the middle of the ocean,
label: Paragraph

text: close to Buenos Aires, and a twenty-eight-storey, high-rise
label: Paragraph

text: structure, the floors of which were suspended from a giant
label: Paragraph

text: Vierendeel truss at the top of the building [424]. This
label: Paragraph

text: project seems to have been the model for Norman Foster’s
label: Paragraph

text: HSBC bank headquarters, completed in Hong Kong in 1986.
label: Paragraph

text: Testa’s masterly bank building was not only as dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: as the architecture of the Brazilian Paulista School but also
label: Paragraph

text: seems to have been a seminal influence on the Argentine
label: Paragraph

text: practice of Manteola, Sanchez Gémez, Santos, Solsona and
label: Paragraph

text: Viholy (MSGSSV). This group designed a remarkable series
label: Paragraph

text: of buildings for the Banco Ciudad Casa Matriz [422],
label: Caption

text: beginning with the bank’s headquarters of 1969, a work
label: Paragraph

text: which may be seen as synthesizing the spatial paradigm of
label: Paragraph

text: Testa’s monumental bank with the constructional discourse
label: Title

text: of Stirling and Gowan’s Engineering Faculty built for
label: Paragraph

text: Leicester University in 1959. This capacity for combining
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic spatial effects with audacious structural expression
label: Title

text: reappeared in two exceptional housing complexes, both of
label: Paragraph

text: which were won in open competition. The first, comprising a
label: Paragraph

text: neighbourhood of ten towers, each of eighteen storeys and
label: Paragraph

text: linked to others by cable-tied, steel-framed aerial walkways,
label: Paragraph

text: was built in the Rioja area of Buenos Aires in 1973 [421],
label: Paragraph

text: while the second was built for an Argentine aluminium
label: Paragraph

text: company in Puerto Madryn on the windswept Atlantic coast
label: Caption

text: of Patagonia. The latter consisted of a low-rise, high-density
label: Paragraph

text: terrace complex which was cranked in plan against the
label: Paragraph

text: prevailing wind and stepped in section to follow the slope of
label: Paragraph

text: the site. Among the achievements of the MSGSSV office in
label: Paragraph

text: its prime must be the ingeniously elegant, grass-covered
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard of the Oks house of 1979 [423] and the four
label: Caption

text: Colored TV Studios realized as an integral part of a small
label: Paragraph

text: park in 1978.
label: Paragraph

text: 421 MSGSSV, Conjunto Rioja, Buenos Aires, 1973.
label: Caption

text: 422 MSGSSV, Ritero branch, Banco Ciudad Casa Matriz, 1969. Elevation and
label: Caption

text: section.
label: Paragraph

text: 423 MSGSSV, Casa Oks, La Luchila, Buenos Aires, 1979.
label: Caption

text: 424 Williams, project for suspended office building, Buenos Aires, 1946.
label: Caption

text: Argentine modern architecture from the 1950s to the
label: Title

text: 1970s was as vital as that of any other Latin American
label: Paragraph

text: nation, including among its canonical works the San Martin
label: Paragraph

text: Cultural Centre, Buenos Aires, built to the designs of Mario
label: Caption

text: Roberto Alvarez and Associates between 1953 and 1970.
label: Paragraph

text: This structure, occupying an entire city block, houses an
label: Paragraph

text: auditorium, a cinema and an art gallery, the common foyer
label: Title

text: of which is enhanced by polychromatic murals and
label: Paragraph

text: freestanding sculptures. Strangely enough this practice built
label: Paragraph

text: only one other structure of consequence, the twelve-storey
label: Paragraph

text: SOMISA corner building in Buenos Aires, of exposed steel-
label: Caption

text: frame construction inside and out.
label: Paragraph

text: The pioneering period of Argentine modernity was
label: Paragraph

text: brought to a fitting conclusion with Testa’s dramatically
label: Paragraph

text: cantilevered, top-heavy, reinforced-concrete National
label: Caption

text: Library in Buenos Aires, designed in association with
label: Caption

text: Francisco Bullrich and Alicia Cazzaniga in 1962, a work
label: Paragraph

text: which due to the unending political and economic upheavals
label: Paragraph

text: took some thirty years to complete.
label: Paragraph

text: Uruguay
label: Title

text: The modern architectural tradition of Uruguay originates
label: Paragraph

text: partly in the Escuela del Sur, the so-called ‘School of the
label: Paragraph

text: South’, established in Montevideo in 1934 by the
label: Paragraph

text: cosmopolitan Uruguayan architect-artist Joaquin Torres-
label: Title

text: Garcia, who first drew the map of South America upside
label: Paragraph

text: down as a cartographic symbol of a newly resurgent Latin
label: Paragraph

text: American identity [425]. This enigmatic icon would later be
label: Paragraph

text: adopted by Alberto Cruz and Godofredo lommi as the key
label: Paragraph

text: symbol of their new school of design founded at Vifhia del
label: Paragraph

text: Mar in Chile in 1948.
label: Paragraph

text: 425 Torres-Garcia, inverted map of South America, 1944.
label: Caption

text: Two figures played seminal roles in the emergence of
label: Paragraph

text: Uruguayan modern architecture in the early 1930s: Julio
label: Title

text: Vilamajé, who designed the Faculty of Engineering
label: Paragraph

text: completed in Montevideo in 1938, and Mauricio Cravotto,
label: Paragraph

text: who built a Neo-Purist villa for his own occupation in the
label: Paragraph

text: same city in 1933. Cravotto was also active as a theorist
label: Paragraph

text: contributing regularly with Leopoldo Artucio to the magazine
label: Paragraph

text: Arquitectura, which was founded in 1914 and published
label: Paragraph

text: monthly by the Sociedad de Arquitectos del Uruguay
label: Caption

text: between 1922 and 1931.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the most gifted Uruguayan architects in the
label: Paragraph

text: second half of the 20th century was Mario Payssé Reyes,
label: Paragraph

text: whose most important works were his own house in
label: Paragraph

text: Montevideo, of 1956 [427], and his church for the
label: Paragraph

text: Archdiocesan Seminary of Montevideo [426], realized in
label: Paragraph

text: Toledo in the same year. Payssé Reyes was profoundly
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by Torres-Garcia, as is evident from the
label: Paragraph

text: typographic, iconic low reliefs in cement designed by the
label: Paragraph

text: latter’s studio and incorporated separately into both the
label: Paragraph

text: house and the church. Apart from this striking decorative
label: Paragraph

text: element, the church was an extremely refined, reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: framed concrete basilica covered by a thin shell concrete
label: Caption

text: roof. The late works of Payssé Reyes’s career, the
label: Paragraph

text: Uruguayan Embassy in Brasilia of 1976 [428] and the
label: Paragraph

text: Uruguayan Chancellery in Buenos Aires of 1978, make an
label: Paragraph

text: equally disciplined use of in-situ reinforced concrete
label: Paragraph

text: construction.
label: Paragraph

text: 426 Payssé Reyes, Church of the Arquidiocesano de Montevideo, Toledo, 1956.
label: Caption

text: 427 Payssé Reyes, architect’s own house, Montevideo, 1956. Section.
label: Caption

text: 428 Payssé Reyes, Uruguayan Embassy, Brasilia, Brazil, 1976. Site plan.
label: Caption

text: An architect of equal stature in Montevideo was Nelson
label: Paragraph

text: Bayardo, who designed a reinforced concrete columbarium
label: Paragraph

text: for the north cemetery of the city in 1960. This work, with
label: Paragraph

text: its eight concrete blades carrying the four concrete walls of
label: Paragraph

text: the columbarium slightly above the ground, would exercise
label: Paragraph

text: a decisive influence on the work of the Brazilian architect
label: Paragraph

text: Jodo Vilanova Artigas, above all on his design of the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural school constructed on the campus of the
label: Paragraph

text: University of Sado Paulo in 1968. The interior face of
label: Caption

text: Bayardo’s columbarium was again treated as an abstract
label: Paragraph

text: relief in concrete, designed in the spirit of Torres-Garcia.
label: Caption

text: As in a number of other Latin American societies, the
label: Paragraph

text: rising middle classes in Uruguay seems to have accepted
label: Paragraph

text: the Modern Movement as a bourgeois /ingua franca in which
label: Paragraph

text: they could invest and with which they could identify. They
label: Paragraph

text: therefore became a secular clientele more than willing to
label: Paragraph

text: adopt the socially progressive, tectonic language of the so-
label: Paragraph

text: called International Style as a new norm. This explains the
label: Paragraph

text: prevalence in Montevideo of exemplary mid-rise modern
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, such as Luis Garcia Pardo’s diminutive El Pilar
label: Paragraph

text: apartment building of 1957 [429, 430]. Here a large
label: Paragraph

text: proportion of the available plan is taken up by a spiral
label: Paragraph

text: staircase with a cylindrical elevator rising for nine floors in
label: Caption

text: order to serve one two-bedroom unit: a modern folly of
label: Paragraph

text: exceptional elegance. Of equal elegance was Rafael Lorente
label: Paragraph

text: Escudero’s Edificio Berro of 1952, although here a three-
label: Paragraph

text: storey apartment building, with four apartments per floor
label: Paragraph

text: accessed in pairs, is a more rational proposition. A less
label: Paragraph

text: convincing aspect of the Uruguayan Modern Movement is
label: Paragraph

text: regrettably the large cooperative housing complex known as
label: Paragraph

text: Bulevar Artigas, designed by Ramiro Bascans, Thomas
label: Caption

text: Sprechmann, Héctor Vigliecca and Arturo Villaamil, which
label: Paragraph

text: fell way short of the sophisticated, rigorously structured
label: Paragraph

text: Puerto Madryn housing designed by the Argentinian practice
label: Caption

text: of Manteola, Sanchez Gémez, Santos, Solsona, Vifholy
label: Caption

text: around the same time.
label: Paragraph

text: 429, 430 Garcia Pardo, Pilar Apartments, Montevideo, 1957. View and typical
label: Caption

text: floor plan.
label: Paragraph

text: A tectonic and expressive trope of consequence in
label: Paragraph

text: Uruguay was the boveda tabicada vault, which arrived in
label: Paragraph

text: Latin America via the Catalan émigré architect Antonio
label: Title

text: Bonet, who asked the newly graduated Uruguayan engineer
label: Paragraph

text: Eladio Dieste to design such vaults for his Berlingieri House,
label: Paragraph

text: erected at Punta Ballena in 1947. Like José Luis Sert and Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier, Bonet would have been familiar with the boveda
label: Paragraph

text: tabicada through the work of Antoni Gaudi. For his part,
label: Paragraph

text: Dieste’s training in graphical statics in the Montevideo
label: Paragraph

text: Faculty of Engineering made him aware of the potential of
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced brick shell structures designed and calculated in
label: Paragraph

text: accordance with this method. This realization led him to the
label: Paragraph

text: design of doubly curved shells in brick having a similar form
label: Paragraph

text: to the reinforced-concrete shell structures built in Mexico by
label: Paragraph

text: the Spanish émigré engineer Félix Candela. The latter had,
label: Paragraph

text: in turn, been strongly influenced by the distinguished
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish engineer Eduardo Torroja, whose masterwork was
label: Paragraph

text: the Madrid hippodrome of 1941. These two exemplary
label: Paragraph

text: figures prompted Dieste to design wide-span, doubly curved
label: Paragraph

text: brick warehouses and factories, and above all the dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: monumental form of the Church of Christ the Worker [431,
label: Caption

text: 432], built at Atlantida in 1960. Rendering both the
label: Paragraph

text: continuous sidewalls and roof in undulating reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: brickwork, Dieste created a non-hierarchical space in this
label: Paragraph

text: church, bringing the priest closer to the people. This
label: Paragraph

text: anticipated the changes in the liturgical form of the Roman
label: Paragraph

text: Catholic Church that followed the Second Vatican Council of
label: Title

text: 1963, which effectively orientated the priest towards the
label: Paragraph

text: congregation rather than the altar.
label: Paragraph

text: 431, 432 Dieste, Church of Christ the Worker, Atlantida, 1960. Interior and
label: Caption

text: section.
label: Paragraph

text: What is truly remarkable about Dieste’s work is the way
label: Paragraph

text: in which his most civic structures came to be realized quite
label: Paragraph

text: early in his career, not only the church at Atlantida, but also
label: Paragraph

text: the church of San Pedro at Durazno (1974). However, his
label: Paragraph

text: reputation as a master builder depends in the final analysis
label: Paragraph

text: on the numerous industrial structures [433] that he
label: Paragraph

text: designed as a series of reinforced brick, curved and doubly
label: Paragraph

text: curved vaulted forms, beginning with a market hall in Porto
label: Paragraph

text: Alegre, Brazil, of 1972 and continuing with a bus depot at
label: Paragraph

text: Salto in 1974, warehouses in Montevideo and Juanico built
label: Paragraph

text: between 1976 and 1994, and maintenance sheds for the
label: Paragraph

text: Brazilian railways at Rio de Janeiro in 1979. Dieste built a
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable house for himself in 1968 out of the same brick
label: Paragraph

text: and reinforced-concrete technique that he had already
label: Paragraph

text: applied to his larger structures. One of the most significant
label: Paragraph

text: works of his late career is the parish centre of San Juan de
label: Paragraph

text: Avila built in Alcala de Henares, Spain, in 1998, where the
label: Paragraph

text: double-curved walls forming the sides of the ecclesiastical
label: Paragraph

text: volume undulate more dynamically than before in relation to
label: Paragraph

text: the vaults of the roof.
label: Paragraph

text: 433 Dieste, two typical shell structures: (a) Don Bosco School Gymnasium,
label: Caption

text: Montevideo, 1983-84; (b} Bus Terminal, Salto, 1973-74.
label: Caption

text: It is indicative of the stature of Dieste that he published a
label: Paragraph

text: book on his work in 1987 divided into three sections: a
label: Paragraph

text: photographic and graphic record of his built work; a detailed
label: Paragraph

text: presentation of the calculations involved in the design of the
label: Paragraph

text: brick vaults; and a political manifesto testifying to the
label: Paragraph

text: economic, ecological and human advantages in an
label: Paragraph

text: underdeveloped country such as Uruguay of building in
label: Paragraph

text: brick, rather than with the more advanced and expensive
label: Paragraph

text: modes of building in steel and reinforced concrete.
label: Paragraph

text: Peru
label: Title

text: Like many other Latin American countries, Peru had no
label: Paragraph

text: modern architectural culture before 1910, when an émigré
label: Paragraph

text: Polish architect, Ricardo de Jaxa Malachowski, who had been
label: Paragraph

text: trained at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris, was invited to
label: Paragraph

text: establish a department of architecture in the National
label: Paragraph

text: University of Engineering. The modernization of Peruvian
label: Title

text: society was a relatively slow process, for only after the end
label: Paragraph

text: of the Second World War was a centre-left government
label: Paragraph

text: voted into power under the presidency of José Bustamante y
label: Paragraph

text: Rivero. The liberal policies of the Bustamante presidency
label: Paragraph

text: came to an abrupt end in 1948 with a right-wing military
label: Paragraph

text: coup led by General Manuel Odria, although subsequently it
label: Paragraph

text: was a left-wing military government under the leadership of
label: Paragraph

text: Juan Velasco Alvarado (president from 1968 to 1975) that
label: Paragraph

text: finally brought about land reform in Peru.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1936 Fernando Belaunde Terry returned to Peru, his
label: Paragraph

text: family having been exiled since 1924 on political grounds.
label: Paragraph

text: After attending high school in France, Belaunde moved in
label: Paragraph

text: 1930 with his family to the United States, where he began
label: Paragraph

text: to study architecture, first at the University of Miami and
label: Paragraph

text: then at the University of Texas at Austin. Back in Peru in
label: Paragraph

text: 1937, he founded the magazine E/ Arquitecto Peruano,
label: Paragraph

text: which focused on the specific housing and urban problems
label: Paragraph

text: facing the country. This publication coincided with the
label: Paragraph

text: foundation of two key institutions: the Peruvian Architectural
label: Paragraph

text: Association and the Urban Institute of Peru. Belaunde
label: Caption

text: eventually started on a political career in 1944 by joining
label: Paragraph

text: the National Democratic Front. In 1956 he founded the
label: Paragraph

text: Accién Popular (Popular Action) Party, which, among other
label: Paragraph

text: things, aimed at recapturing the Inca traditions of
label: Paragraph

text: community and cooperation while occupying the middle
label: Title

text: ground between the traditional right-wing oligarchy and the
label: Paragraph

text: radical left. When Belaunde was first elected to the Peruvian
label: Paragraph

text: Congress in 1945 he introduced legislation expanding the
label: Paragraph

text: role of the state in the production of social housing. This
label: Paragraph

text: eventually led to the creation of the Corporacién Nacional
label: Paragraph

text: de Vivienda (CNV), the first completed project of which was
label: Paragraph

text: 1,200 apartments built as the Unidad Vecinal Numero 3
label: Caption

text: (UV3). These units were designed by a team of young
label: Paragraph

text: architects comprising Alfredo Dammert, Carlos Morales,
label: Paragraph

text: Manuel Valega, Luis Dorich, Eugenio Montagne and Juan
label: Title

text: Benites. The work was eventually integrated into Belaunde’s
label: Paragraph

text: plan for Lima. The CNV continued to function through
label: Paragraph

text: various periods of military rule, realizing several unidades
label: Paragraph

text: vecinales, although its name was frequently changed. Apart
label: Paragraph

text: from his salient engagement with the provision of low-cost
label: Paragraph

text: housing, BelaUnde was also involved in the upgrading of the
label: Paragraph

text: department of architecture in the National University of
label: Title

text: Engineering, which he conceived along the lines of the
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus. This led him to hire a progressive teaching staff,
label: Paragraph

text: which included Peruvian teachers as well as émigré
label: Paragraph

text: European talent. Belaunde invited Walter Gropius and José
label: Paragraph

text: Luis Sert to lecture in the school during the 1950s.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1960 the British architect Peter Land came to Lima to
label: Paragraph

text: work for two years as the field director of an inter-American,
label: Paragraph

text: multidisciplinary graduate programme in urban and regional
label: Title

text: planning sponsored by the Peruvian government and the
label: Paragraph

text: Organization of American States (OAS). The immediate
label: Paragraph

text: success of this programme encouraged Belaunde to
label: Paragraph

text: establish a department of urban planning under Land’s
label: Paragraph

text: direction within the school. In 1966 Belatinde took a further
label: Paragraph

text: proactive step by inviting Land to organize an international
label: Paragraph

text: low-rise, high-density housing exhibition, known as PREVI.
label: Paragraph

text: Land conceived this exhibition along the lines of the
label: Paragraph

text: Deutscher Werkbund Weissenhofsiedlung housing exhibition
label: Title

text: staged in Stuttgart of 1927. Carried out under the auspices
label: Paragraph

text: of the United Nations, PREVI involved contributions from
label: Paragraph

text: architects worldwide, including James Stirling (UK), German
label: Paragraph

text: Samper (Colombia), Candilis, Josic & Woods (France), Oskar
label: Caption

text: Hansen (Poland), Inguez/Vasquez (Spain), Aldo van Eyck
label: Paragraph

text: (The Netherlands), Atelier 5 (Switzerland), Charles Correa
label: Caption

text: (India), Toivo Korhonen (Finland), Herbert Ohl (Germany),
label: Paragraph

text: and Fumihiko Maki, Kisho Kurokawa and Kiyonori Kikutake
label: Title

text: (Japan) [434, 435]. Among the Peruvian architects, one of
label: Paragraph

text: the most exceptional designs was by a team comprising
label: Paragraph

text: José Garcia Bryce, Frederick Cooper Llosa, Antonio Grana
label: Caption

text: Acuna and Eugenio Nicolini Iglesias. This same practice later
label: Paragraph

text: also made a major contribution to the design of medical
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, above all their 500-bed hospital designed and
label: Paragraph

text: built in the centre of Cusco from 1978 to 1985. In advance
label: Paragraph

text: of its time, this work was exemplary in terms of both
label: Paragraph

text: sustainability and its sensitivity to the local context. The
label: Paragraph

text: architects were able to reduce energy consumption by
label: Paragraph

text: minimizing the use of lifts in a complex restricted to four
label: Paragraph

text: storeys in height, and by maximizing the provision of
label: Paragraph

text: natural ventilation by patios at frequent intervals within the
label: Paragraph

text: built form. Moreover, the four-storey form also harmonized
label: Paragraph

text: with the low-rise fabric of the city, a compatibility that was
label: Paragraph

text: further enhanced by roofing the building in traditional local
label: Paragraph

text: tiles.
label: Paragraph

text: 434 Kikutake, Kurokawa and Maki, PREVI Housing, Lima, 1969-74.
label: Caption

text: 435 de Ozofio and de Castro, PREVI Housing, Lima, 1969-74.
label: Caption

text: Apart from PREVI, there was a considerable amount of
label: Paragraph

text: housing built in Lima over the 1960s and 1970s, as is
label: Paragraph

text: evident from the four-storey Palomino housing complex
label: Caption
