text: (1964), designed by the architects Luis Miré Quesada,
label: Paragraph

text: Santiago Agurto, Fernando Correa and Fernando Sanchez
label: Title

text: Grinan [436]. Equally striking was a four-storey terrace,
label: Paragraph

text: executed in concrete and built in Callao in 1974 to the
label: Paragraph

text: designs of Miguel Rodrigo Mazuré with Emilio Soyer Nash
label: Caption

text: and Miguel Cruchaga Belaunde [437].
label: Paragraph

text: 436 Garland, Correa, Grifian and Agurto, Palomino Housing, Lima, 1964.
label: Caption

text: 437 Mazuré, Nash and Miguel Cruchaga Belatnde, social housing, Callao, 1974.
label: Caption

text: Since the millennium two sophisticated practices,
label: Paragraph

text: producing work of exceptional quality, have come to the
label: Paragraph

text: fore in Peru. One is the partnership of Sandra Barclay and
label: Paragraph

text: Jean Pierre Crousse, who began their practice with the Casa
label: Paragraph

text: Equis [438], built on a precipitous site overlooking
label: Paragraph

text: Escondida Beach at Canete in 2003. This was the first in a
label: Paragraph

text: series of luxurious vacation houses that the architects built
label: Paragraph

text: along this stretch of the Peruvian coast influenced by the
label: Paragraph

text: work of the Mexican architect Luis Barragan. These houses,
label: Paragraph

text: through their stepped terracing and framing of ocean views,
label: Paragraph

text: embody a sense of proportion and spatial displacement
label: Paragraph

text: derived from a cultivated feeling for the Pre-Columbian
label: Paragraph

text: Andean tradition. These architects have since applied this
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility at a monumental scale with their béton brut
label: Paragraph

text: UDEP campus [439, 440], completed in 2018 in an
label: Paragraph

text: equatorial dry forest of carob trees close to the city of Piura,
label: Paragraph

text: some 1,000 kilometres (621 miles) north of Lima. Here a 70
label: Paragraph

text: x 70-metre (230 x 230-foot) mat building comprising six
label: Paragraph

text: lecture halls and five ancillary academic structures, all of
label: Paragraph

text: the same height, is accessed by an interstitial labyrinth of
label: Paragraph

text: shaded, cross-ventilated green walkways partially covered
label: Caption

text: with concrete canopies. This academic caravanserai bodes
label: Paragraph

text: well for the future of Peru in as much as it is a publically
label: Paragraph

text: funded facility, expressly intended for low-income students
label: Paragraph

text: from rural areas.
label: Paragraph

text: 438 Barclay & Crousse, Casa Equis, Cafete, 2003.
label: Caption

text: 439, 440 Barclay & Crousse, UDEP, Piura, 2018. Plan of lecture halls at upper
label: Caption

text: level, and aerial view.
label: Paragraph

text: The second exceptionally productive Peruvian practice is
label: Paragraph

text: that of Oscar Borasino and Ruth Alvarado. This studio -
label: Paragraph

text: known by the acronym OB+RA, which wittily combines their
label: Paragraph

text: initials into the word for ‘work’ in Spanish (obra). Over the
label: Paragraph

text: last decade they have worked on a wide range of
label: Paragraph

text: commissions that are invariably brought to an exceptionally
label: Paragraph

text: high level of detailed resolution. This quality is surely
label: Paragraph

text: present in what is perhaps their most important civic work
label: Paragraph

text: to date, namely a four-storey regional headquarters for the
label: Paragraph

text: International Labour Organization in Lima, completed in
label: Caption

text: 2004 [441]. This building presents two distinctly different
label: Paragraph

text: elevations: a monumental stone-faced street facade with
label: Caption

text: horizontal ‘hooded’ windows and a lighter, steel-framed,
label: Paragraph

text: curtain-walled rear fagade overlooking a garden. What is
label: Paragraph

text: truly remarkable about this practice is the variety of
label: Paragraph

text: expression, which passes from the urbanity of Alvarado’s
label: Paragraph

text: seven-storey apartment block in béton brut, her Edificio Blas
label: Caption

text: of 1998 [442], to the rusticity of Borasino’s single-storey
label: Paragraph

text: visitor centre for the Moray archaeological complex, focused
label: Caption

text: on a patio and integrated into the tile-roofed context of
label: Paragraph

text: Cusco in 2010. What is remarkable about the work of
label: Paragraph

text: OB-+RA is the fact that they are equally skilled as urban
label: Paragraph

text: designers, as is evident from their transformation of a small,
label: Paragraph

text: leftover, triangular infill site in San Isidro into a rich three-
label: Paragraph

text: dimensional landscape [443].
label: Paragraph

text: 441 OB+RA, International Labour Organization headquarters, Lima, 2004.
label: Caption

text: 442 Alvarado (OB+RA), Edificio Blas, Lima, 1998.
label: Caption

text: 443 OB+RA, Jardin de Senderos, Lima, 2006.
label: Caption

text: Chile
label: Title

text: Chile’s turbulent political history is inseparable from the
label: Paragraph

text: vicissitudes of its economy, particularly after 1900, when
label: Paragraph

text: new smelting techniques gave rise to its dynamic copper
label: Paragraph

text: industry. This led in turn to the emergence of the working
label: Paragraph

text: class as a contentious faction in contentious Chilean politics,
label: Paragraph

text: alongside the traditional landowning élite and an urban
label: Paragraph

text: middle class. This volatile mixture often entailed frequent
label: Paragraph

text: confrontations between liberals and conservatives and at
label: Title

text: times political stalemates that would be invariably broken
label: Paragraph

text: by military intervention. Despite this struggle between right
label: Paragraph

text: and left, measures to encourage the building of socially
label: Paragraph

text: progressive housing were progressively implemented in
label: Paragraph

text: Chile, as the Argentine critic Jorge Francisco Liernur
label: Paragraph

text: explains:
label: Title

text: Since passing the Ley de Habitaciones Obreras [Workers’
label: Paragraph

text: Housing Law] in 1906 Chile had been one of the most active
label: Paragraph

text: countries in the Américas increasing government supported
label: Title

text: housing. The institutions created during the 1950’s and the
label: Paragraph

text: 1960’s such as the Caja de Habitacién Popular (Popular
label: Paragraph

text: Housing Fund) the Corporacion de la Vivienda, in particular
label: Paragraph

text: the Ministerio de Vivienda were critical to this effort.
label: Paragraph

text: Operacion Sitio, born during the presidency of Eduardo Frei,
label: Paragraph

text: encouraged self-construction with economic assistance from
label: Paragraph

text: the United States backed Alliance for Progress.
label: Paragraph

text: As elsewhere in Latin America, the Modern Movement
label: Paragraph

text: arrived in Chile via the ubiquitous influence of Le Corbusier,
label: Paragraph

text: whose radical vision of a new architecture first appeared
label: Paragraph

text: with his book Vers une architecture of 1923. Thereafter, as
label: Paragraph

text: Fernando Pérez Oyarzun has observed, Chilean architects
label: Paragraph

text: were active in Europe, the first example of their work there
label: Paragraph

text: being the Chilean Pavilion designed by Juan Martinez for the
label: Paragraph

text: Ibero-American Exposition staged in Seville in 1929. At the
label: Paragraph

text: same time Roberto Davila Carson studied in the Academy of
label: Paragraph

text: Fine Arts in Vienna prior to entering Le Corbusier’s studio in
label: Paragraph

text: Paris. There he worked on the Plan Obus for Algiers in 1930,
label: Paragraph

text: before returning to Chile in 1936 to design and build his
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusian Cap Ducal Restaurant [444] overlooking the
label: Caption

text: harbour in Vina del Mar. That year also saw the emergence
label: Paragraph

text: of the Popular Front in Chile, consolidated by the election of
label: Paragraph

text: Pedro Aguirre Cerda to the presidency in 1938. In the
label: Paragraph

text: following year the country suffered a tremendous
label: Paragraph

text: earthquake, which devastated the city of Chillan and
label: Paragraph

text: resulted in a death toll of 30,000, a traumatic event that
label: Paragraph

text: had the longer-term effect of boosting the production of
label: Paragraph

text: state-subsidized housing.
label: Paragraph

text: 444 Carson, Cap Ducal Restaurant, Vifia del Mar, 1936.
label: Caption

text: In 1949 the architectural students of the Pontifical
label: Paragraph

text: Catholic University in Santiago, encouraged by their teacher
label: Paragraph

text: Alberto Cruz, rebelled against the classical curriculum of the
label: Paragraph

text: school. In his attempt to restructure the curriculum Cruz
label: Paragraph

text: went to Europe in the early 1950s, where he met the Swiss
label: Paragraph

text: architect and designer Max Bill and the Argentine concrete
label: Title

text: painter Tomas Maldonado. In 1952, following an invitation
label: Paragraph

text: from the Catholic University of Valparaiso, Cruz - together
label: Caption

text: with the Argentinean poet Godofredo lommi, the architects
label: Paragraph

text: Arturo Baeza and Jaime Bellalta and the painter Francisco
label: Title

text: Méndez - established a new school of architecture in Vifia
label: Paragraph

text: del Mar, where they lived and worked together in the Cerro
label: Paragraph

text: Castillo. Their Institute for Architecture, which passed
label: Paragraph

text: through two phases of development, initially from 1952 to
label: Paragraph

text: 1970, was professional in its orientation. This phase began
label: Paragraph

text: with major works by Cruz himself, above all his Los Pajaritos
label: Paragraph

text: Chapel project [445] for Maipu, Santiago, in 1953 and his
label: Paragraph

text: 1954 study for the urbanization of the Achupallas coastline
label: Caption

text: near Vina del Mar. Where the former posited a new form of
label: Paragraph

text: liturgical space, the latter suggested an infrastructure that
label: Paragraph

text: would establish a link between the coastal topography and
label: Paragraph

text: the sea. This impulse was reflected in the Institute’s 1956
label: Paragraph

text: competition entry for a new naval academy collectively
label: Title

text: designed under the leadership of Francisco Méndez. The
label: Paragraph

text: unusually curved, medium-rise slab blocks were of an
label: Paragraph

text: ‘aerodynamic’ design which was profiled in such a way as to
label: Paragraph

text: deflect and break the force of the wind, while, at the same
label: Paragraph

text: time, being integrated into the undulating coastal
label: Paragraph

text: landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: 445 Cruz, Los Pajaritos Chapel, Maipt, Santiago, 1953.
label: Caption

text: Low-rise, high-density residential development first
label: Paragraph

text: appeared in Chile in 1959 with Mario Pérez de Arce and
label: Paragraph

text: Jaime Besa’s Salar del Carmen housing [447], built on the
label: Paragraph

text: outskirts of Antofagasta at the point where the Atacama
label: Paragraph

text: Desert meets the Pacific Ocean. This scheme was built
label: Paragraph

text: under the auspices of CORVI (Corporacidn de la Vivienda), a
label: Paragraph

text: government housing organization that was eclipsed by the
label: Paragraph

text: dictatorship (1973-90) of Augusto Pinochet. The Salar del
label: Paragraph

text: Carmen settlement comprised two-storey, low-cost houses
label: Paragraph

text: built on a terraced landscape directly above a former salt
label: Paragraph

text: deposit. In each house the living spaces were distributed
label: Paragraph

text: around a patio with a switchback stair rising up to a
label: Paragraph

text: bedroom floor poised above the open court. Unfortunately it
label: Paragraph

text: was not possible to plant shade trees due to the salty nature
label: Paragraph

text: of the ground. Nevertheless, the stepped form of the
label: Paragraph

text: terraces imparted the feeling of a time-honoured urbanity
label: Paragraph

text: that was rarely achieved in mass housing.
label: Paragraph

text: The traumatic effects of the earthquakes that habitually
label: Title

text: punctuate the history of Chile were never more evident than
label: Paragraph

text: in the destruction in 1960 of the city of Valdivia in the south
label: Paragraph

text: of the country, which was accompanied by extensive
label: Paragraph

text: damage in both Concepci6én and Puerto Montt. A significant
label: Paragraph

text: consequence of this particular disaster was the
label: Paragraph

text: commissioning of the Institute for Architecture with the
label: Paragraph

text: design of six new churches, of which the Church of La
label: Caption

text: Florida in Santiago (1960-65) [446], was the most original.
label: Paragraph

text: 446 Valparaiso School, Church of La Florida, Santiago, 1960-65. Plan.
label: Caption

text: 447 Pérez de Arce and Besa, Salar del Carmen housing, Antofagasta, 1959.
label: Caption

text: Section.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1965, inspired by an inverted map of South America
label: Paragraph

text: first drawn by the Uruguayan-Catalan artist Joaquin Torres-
label: Paragraph

text: Garcia, Godofredo lommi organized the first of his
label: Paragraph

text: educational journeys across the South American continent
label: Title

text: from Punta Arenas in the south to Santa Cruz de la Sierra in
label: Paragraph

text: Bolivia in the north. lommi regarded Santa Cruz de la Sierra
label: Paragraph

text: as the capital of the continent by virtue of his alchemical
label: Paragraph

text: superimposition of a figure of the Southern Cross on a map
label: Paragraph

text: of the continent. The first of lommi’s so-called traversias
label: Paragraph

text: had to be cut short owing to the guerrilla activities of Che
label: Paragraph

text: Guevara, which had also been one of the reasons for Cruz’s
label: Paragraph

text: decision to move his architectural institute to the fishing
label: Paragraph

text: village of Ritoque. There in the midst of a vast expanse of
label: Paragraph

text: sand dunes the Valparaiso School proclaimed their so-called
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Open City’. Over time, they would assemble a fragmentary
label: Paragraph

text: collection of timber-clad structures, housing either studios
label: Caption

text: or faculties, which had to be constantly reconstructed owing
label: Paragraph

text: to the shifting movement of the dunes impelled by the wind
label: Paragraph

text: coming off the sea. Among the mythical monuments
label: Paragraph

text: constructed on the high ground overlooking the ‘city’ was a
label: Paragraph

text: cenotaph composed of abstract concrete sculptures
label: Paragraph

text: designed by the artist Claudio Girola, a cemetery (1976)
label: Caption

text: built to the designs of Juan Ignacio Baixas, Juan Purcell and
label: Paragraph

text: Jorge Sanchez, and the so-called Palace of Dawn and Dusk
label: Title

text: of 1982 [448], which consisted of a ‘maze’ of low brick
label: Paragraph

text: walls. Simultaneously an experimental school and a
label: Paragraph

text: commune, the Open City, despite its later concentration on
label: Paragraph

text: industrial design, was largely conceived as a poetic project
label: Paragraph

text: removed from any larger modernizing goal. Such an
label: Paragraph

text: approach was intent on creating a new subjectivity while
label: Paragraph

text: remaining relatively detached from historical reality. After
label: Paragraph

text: 1984 the study trips designed to familiarize students with
label: Paragraph

text: the grandeur of the South American continent became a key
label: Paragraph

text: part of the basic design course. These travesias sought to
label: Paragraph

text: encourage an awareness of the potential destiny of Latin
label: Paragraph

text: America.
label: Paragraph

text: 448 Cruz, with the Valparaiso School, Palace of Dawn and Dusk, Ritoque,
label: Caption

text: Quintero, 1982.
label: Caption

text: In 1960 the French-educated Chilean architect Emilio
label: Paragraph

text: Duhart established himself in Santiago by winning the
label: Paragraph

text: competition for the prestigious CEPAL (Comisi6n Econémica
label: Paragraph

text: para América Latina) building [451], which he designed in
label: Paragraph

text: association with Christian de Groote, Roberto Goycoolea and
label: Paragraph

text: Oscar Santelices. Influenced by Le Corbusier’s monastery of
label: Paragraph

text: La Tourette and his Assembly Building in Chandigarh, the
label: Paragraph

text: CEPAL building consisted of a rectangular perimeter of
label: Paragraph

text: offices elevated on pi/otis with a conical assembly hall in the
label: Paragraph

text: middle of its central courtyard. In 1965 de Groote, who had
label: Paragraph

text: been trained in the US at IIT, started his practice with a
label: Paragraph

text: series of industrial commissions, along with the design of
label: Paragraph

text: the headquarters of the leading Chilean newspaper E/
label: Paragraph

text: Mercurio [449], located amid the foothills of the Santiago
label: Paragraph

text: Valley. Apart from the editorial offices and printing works
label: Paragraph

text: this complex would be under continuous development for
label: Paragraph

text: the next twenty years and would eventually include a
label: Paragraph

text: number of complementary elements such as a library, an
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition space and various sports facilities. During the rest
label: Paragraph

text: of his career de Groote was largely occupied with designing
label: Paragraph

text: and building luxurious residences for the élite. Inspired by
label: Paragraph

text: the work of the Mexican architect Luis Barragan, de Groote’s
label: Paragraph

text: houses were invariably organized around a single central
label: Paragraph

text: axis, beginning with his canonical Fuenzalida House of 1984
label: Paragraph

text: [450]. This two-storey residence built on a sloping site north
label: Caption

text: of Santiago comprised two parallel brick walls interrupted by
label: Paragraph

text: a transverse living space extending onto terraces on either
label: Paragraph

text: side. A more diffuse, stepped horizontal arrangement
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by the Kahnian distinction between servant and
label: Paragraph

text: served spaces occurs with de Groote’s Eliodoro Matte House
label: Paragraph

text: built in Zapallar in 1988.
label: Paragraph

text: 449 de Groote, El Mercurio headquarters, Santiago Valley, 1967. Section.
label: Caption

text: 450 de Groote, Fuenzalida House, Santiago, 1984.
label: Caption

text: 451 Duhart, de Groote, Goycoolea, Santelices, CEPAL Building, Santiago, 1960.
label: Caption

text: The reputation of Enrique Browne, a decade younger
label: Paragraph

text: than de Groote, stems from his commitment to sustainable
label: Paragraph

text: design, not only ecologically but also culturally. This concern
label: Paragraph

text: is already evident in one of his early houses built in Las
label: Paragraph

text: Condes, Santiago, as a single-storey brick and timber
label: Paragraph

text: Wrightian villa covered with vines. It will be echoed at a
label: Paragraph

text: larger scale with his Consorcio Building of 1990 [452],
label: Paragraph

text: designed with Borja Huidobro, and built on the edge of
label: Paragraph

text: downtown Santiago; this building has a double-skin curtain
label: Paragraph

text: wall, which is covered with climbing vegetation.
label: Paragraph

text: 452 Browne, Consorcio Building, Santiago, 1990. Section.
label: Caption

text: The most important building testifying to the short-lived,
label: Paragraph

text: democratically elected, left-wing government of Salvador
label: Title

text: Allende (1970-73) was the corten-steel framed complex
label: Paragraph

text: [453] erected on La Alameda, the main avenue in the
label: Caption

text: centre of Santiago, in 1972 in time for the United Nations
label: Paragraph

text: Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), for which
label: Paragraph

text: it had been expressly designed by a team of architects led
label: Paragraph

text: by José Medina. It consisted of two interconnected parts - a
label: Paragraph

text: twenty-two-storey office tower and a four-storey conference
label: Caption

text: building - housing a 2,300-seat assembly hall and two
label: Paragraph

text: dining halls with a seating capacity of 600 and 200 people,
label: Paragraph

text: plus delegates’ offices and public services in the low-rise
label: Paragraph

text: structure. This congress building was designed as a flexible
label: Paragraph

text: space under an all-encompassing ‘table-top’ space frame,
label: Paragraph

text: poised on hinged joints between widely spaced concrete
label: Caption

text: columns. From the outset the intention was for this structure
label: Paragraph

text: to be transformed into a community centre at the end of the
label: Paragraph

text: conference, which eventually happened. With Augusto
label: Paragraph

text: Pinochet's coup d’état of 1973 the socialist connotations of
label: Paragraph

text: the complex were entirely eradicated by its appropriation as
label: Paragraph

text: the centre of dictatorial power, the traditional governmental
label: Paragraph

text: palace La Moneda having been destroyed in the coup. After
label: Paragraph

text: the return of democracy in Chile in 1990, the building
label: Paragraph

text: became the defence ministry, a change that only
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized its ambiguous political history.
label: Paragraph

text: 453 Medina and others, UNCTAD Complex, Santiago, 1972. Section.
label: Caption

text: Mathias Klotz belongs to the post-Allende generation of
label: Paragraph

text: Chilean architects whose practice would be largely devoted
label: Paragraph

text: again to the design of vacation houses for the élite, initiated
label: Paragraph

text: in part by his own modest example built on Playa Grande,
label: Paragraph

text: Tongoy, in 1991. Of the luxurious homes that Klotz built on
label: Paragraph

text: spectacular sites over the next decade, one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: elegantly expressive is his Reutter House of 1998 [454], on
label: Paragraph

text: a site descending to the sea at Cantagua. As in the work of
label: Paragraph

text: the Brazilian practice MMBB this house is approached from
label: Paragraph

text: above via a light-weight steel passerelle. Apart from the
label: Caption

text: dynamic spatial organization, the plastic qualities of this
label: Paragraph

text: house derives from a dramatic interplay between the
label: Paragraph

text: different forms of revetment, ranging from horizontal timber
label: Paragraph

text: cladding to ribbed metal sheets, timber louvres, steel
label: Caption

text: windows and thin steel balustrading. Klotz eventually
label: Paragraph

text: complemented his domestic work with a number of Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Rationalist public buildings, including the Altamira School,
label: Paragraph

text: Santiago (2000), and the Economics Faculty and the Library
label: Paragraph

text: of the Diego Portales University, dating from 2006 and 2012
label: Caption

text: respectively.
label: Paragraph

text: 454 Klotz, Reutter House, Cantagua, 1998.
label: Caption

text: A distinguished Chilean architect and landscape architect
label: Paragraph

text: of a slightly earlier generation is Teodoro Fernandez
label: Paragraph

text: Larrahaga, who, after graduating from the department of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of the Catholic University in Santiago in 1972,
label: Paragraph

text: left Chile for Madrid following the military coup. Fernandez
label: Paragraph

text: Larrahaga remained in Spain until 1980, when he returned
label: Paragraph

text: to enter the Santiago office of Mario Pérez de Arce, for
label: Paragraph

text: whom he worked for the next nine years. At the beginning of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1990s he began to give courses at his alma mater in
label: Paragraph

text: both architecture and landscape design. He also competed
label: Paragraph

text: successfully in a series of competitions for the design of a
label: Paragraph

text: number of important buildings and parks within the city. As
label: Paragraph

text: a result he opened his own office in 1997, when he
label: Paragraph

text: collaborated with Cecilia Puga and Smiljan Radic on the
label: Paragraph

text: design of a semi-subterranean addition to the university
label: Caption

text: library in the Lo Contador campus of the Pontifical Catholic
label: Caption

text: University [457]. In addition to occasional domestic work
label: Paragraph

text: and landscape design, Fernandez Larrafaga received a
label: Paragraph

text: series of university commissions, beginning with an elegant
label: Paragraph

text: chapel designed in 1997 for the San Joaquin campus of the
label: Paragraph

text: Catholic University, Santiago [455]. He followed this at the
label: Paragraph

text: millennium with a new communications faculty and a library
label: Title

text: for the same campus. The exceptional range of this
label: Paragraph

text: architect may be judged from the constant dialectic in his
label: Paragraph

text: work between tectonic and topographic form.
label: Paragraph

text: 455 Fernandez, chapel for the San Joaquin campus of the Catholic University,
label: Caption

text: Santiago, 1997.
label: Caption

text: An eccentrically subtle brand of Post-Modernism emerged
label: Paragraph

text: in Chile with the Chilean Pavilion designed for the Seville
label: Paragraph

text: Expo of 1992 by José Cruz Ovalle and German del Sol. The
label: Paragraph

text: organic form of this building, lined in wood and covered with
label: Paragraph

text: copper, was designed to house the totally improbable
label: Paragraph

text: exhibit of an 85-ton artificial Antarctic iceberg, which the
label: Paragraph

text: critic Jorge Francisco Liernur would associate with the
label: Paragraph

text: countrywide campaign of 1988 that voted Pinochet out of
label: Paragraph

text: the presidency, if not exactly out of power. Thereafter the
label: Paragraph

text: two architects each developed their topographical approach
label: Paragraph

text: somewhat independently, with del Sol designing in 2007 a
label: Paragraph

text: ramped timber causeway linking a sequence of bathing huts
label: Caption

text: within the hot springs complex of the Villarrica National
label: Paragraph

text: Park. He followed this with the randomly timber-framed
label: Paragraph

text: ‘retaining walls’ of his Hotel Remota [456], built in Puerto
label: Caption

text: Natales in 2008. At virtually the same time Ovalle
label: Paragraph

text: completed his graduate centre for the Adolfo Ibanez
label: Paragraph

text: University [458] in Pefhalolén, which is set dramatically amid
label: Paragraph

text: the Andean foothills just outside Santiago. The multi-ramped
label: Paragraph

text: interior, which is intestinal in character, affords access to
label: Paragraph

text: the innumerable lecture halls and offices that make up the
label: Paragraph

text: serpentine sequence of this labyrinthine structure.
label: Paragraph

text: 456 del Sol, Hotel Remota, Puerto Natales, 2008.
label: Caption

text: 457 Fernandez, Radic, Puga and Mardones, Library at Lo Contador, Santiago,
label: Caption

text: 458 Ovalle, Adolfo Ibanez University Graduate Centre, Santiago, 2007.
label: Caption

text: Smiljan Radic is among the most talented of his
label: Paragraph

text: generation of Chilean architects, as can be judged from the
label: Paragraph

text: copper-clad Cobre House built at Talca in 2004 followed by
label: Paragraph

text: the monumentally topographic Casa Pite [459] completed
label: Caption

text: at Papudo in the Quinta region of Chile in 2005. The latter is
label: Paragraph

text: surely one of the most elegant domestic works of his career
label: Paragraph

text: to date, a work that was enriched by the careful disposition
label: Paragraph

text: of sculptural pieces created by his wife, Marcela Correa,
label: Paragraph

text: along the esplanade formed by the roof of the house, which
label: Paragraph

text: asserts itself as a horizontal plane before the line of the sea.
label: Paragraph

text: One of Radic’s later works of consequence is a music facility
label: Paragraph

text: [460] built close to Concepcién, some 500 kilometres (310
label: Paragraph

text: miles) south of Santiago. It consists of two concert halls of
label: Paragraph

text: 1,200 and 250 seats respectively, cradled within a concrete
label: Caption

text: skeleton made up of 3.9-metre (12-foot) cubic modules. This
label: Paragraph

text: building, dating from 2017, is faced in a synthetic
label: Paragraph

text: translucent membrane, which gives it a somewhat oneiric
label: Paragraph

text: character.
label: Paragraph

text: 459 Radic, Casa Pite, Papudo, Chile, 2005.

label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 2
label: Title

text: Africa and the Middle East
label: Title

text: It is not possible to broach the development of modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in Africa and the Middle East without
label: Title

text: acknowledging a debt to Udo Kultermann, whose pioneering
label: Paragraph

text: study New Architecture in Africa was first published in 1963.
label: Paragraph

text: While noting the extraordinary variations obtaining across
label: Paragraph

text: the continent with regard to topography, climate, vegetation
label: Paragraph

text: and inflected native traditions, Kultermann nonetheless
label: Paragraph

text: noted how architecture in the formal sense in Africa was
label: Paragraph

text: mainly being designed by European architects, with the
label: Paragraph

text: exception of such sophisticated practices as that of the
label: Paragraph

text: distinguished Nigerian architect Oluwole Olumuyiwa, who in
label: Paragraph

text: 1960 designed a particularly elegant cultural centre for
label: Paragraph

text: Lagos. Like Latin America, Africa is a Eurocentric construct
label: Paragraph

text: that has never been able to characterize adequately the
label: Paragraph

text: ethnic and geopolitical complexity of a vast and diverse
label: Paragraph

text: continent. This is even more the case today in the post-
label: Paragraph

text: colonial epoch, when many ostensibly democratic nation
label: Paragraph

text: states are still unable to achieve a more equitable society.
label: Paragraph

text: As this chapter suggests through its conventional
label: Paragraph

text: distinctions between South, East, West and North Africa, this
label: Paragraph

text: continent has remained somewhat inimical to the cultivation
label: Paragraph

text: of a modern sensibility in architecture, despite the fact that
label: Paragraph

text: modernization continues unabated. All of this may go some
label: Paragraph

text: way towards explaining the ad hoc, somewhat disconnected
label: Paragraph

text: character of this account, for unlike in my comparable
label: Paragraph

text: treatment of Latin America, the evolution of modern
label: Title

text: architecture in Africa cannot even be provisionally
label: Paragraph

text: assembled as a panorama of distinct national architectural
label: Paragraph

text: cultures dating back to the foundation of independent
label: Paragraph

text: states, as has seemingly transpired in South America. In this
label: Paragraph

text: respect it is perhaps significant that some of the more
label: Paragraph

text: convincing architectural solutions documented in this sector
label: Paragraph

text: have been achieved in smaller states - namely, Burkina
label: Paragraph

text: Faso, Guinea and Senegal - that make up the mosaic of
label: Paragraph

text: West Africa. Apart from the brilliant school buildings
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Francis Kéré for Burkina Faso and built by its
label: Caption

text: people, who not only cast the handmade bricks and laid
label: Paragraph

text: them in place, but also handwelded the steel trusses
label: Paragraph

text: supporting corrugated metal roofs, there have been equally
label: Paragraph

text: sensitive works designed by foreign architects in West
label: Paragraph

text: Africa, above all, surprisingly, Finnish architects.
label: Paragraph

text: Among the German refugees from the Third Reich who
label: Paragraph

text: came to East Africa during the Second World War was the
label: Paragraph

text: distinguished city architect of Frankfurt-am-Main, Ernst May,
label: Paragraph

text: who would then play a seminal role in cultivating a modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in Kenya and Uganda. Elsewhere Mussolini’s
label: Paragraph

text: colonial ambitions also affected building in East Africa, most
label: Paragraph

text: notably in Ethiopia and Eritrea. One should also emphasize
label: Paragraph

text: in this regard the much later extraordinary creative role
label: Paragraph

text: played by the Dutch Foreign Service in East Africa, above all
label: Paragraph

text: in the diplomatic compounds built by Claus en Kaan in
label: Paragraph

text: Ethiopia and by De Architectengroep in Mozambique.
label: Caption

text: One has to acknowledge that modern architectural
label: Paragraph

text: culture is possibly more deeply embedded in the north and
label: Paragraph

text: the south of the African continent rather than in either West
label: Paragraph

text: or East Africa, due largely to the socio-cultural institutions
label: Paragraph

text: installed by British, Dutch and French colonizers. Moreover,
label: Paragraph

text: North Africa, beyond the Atlas Mountains, is a distinct region
label: Paragraph

text: separated from the rest of the continent by the Sahara
label: Paragraph

text: Desert and by the fact that since time immemorial this has
label: Paragraph

text: been profoundly influenced by Mediterranean culture.
label: Paragraph

text: Paradoxically, the one exception is Egypt, which, across
label: Paragraph

text: time, has been focused on the River Nile rather than the
label: Paragraph

text: sea. For centuries Islam has also played a fundamental role
label: Paragraph

text: in the formation of North African architecture extending as
label: Paragraph

text: far south as the three great mosques of Timbuktu, Mali.
label: Paragraph

text: Of all the sections in Part IV of this book, the one treating
label: Paragraph

text: the Middle East is possibly the most inadequate, for so
label: Paragraph

text: much has transpired in the region since the dissolution of
label: Paragraph

text: the Ottoman Empire in 1917 that it is difficult to cover the
label: Paragraph

text: full impact of modernization in the space of a short essay.
label: Paragraph

text: The first figure to unequivocally embrace the modern
label: Paragraph

text: project in the Middle East was surely the soldier-statesman
label: Paragraph

text: Mustafa Kemal Ataturk. He created modern Turkey, first by
label: Paragraph

text: resisting the dismemberment of the country by Britain and
label: Paragraph

text: France after the collapse of the Ottoman Empire, and then
label: Paragraph

text: by establishing the state as a secular republic in 1923 and
label: Paragraph

text: adopting the Latin alphabet for the inscription of the
label: Paragraph

text: language. There followed, in short order, the emancipation
label: Paragraph

text: of women, the adoption of occidental dress, the
label: Paragraph

text: development of industry and the substitution of a new
label: Title

text: nationalism in place of the obsolete allegiances of
label: Paragraph

text: transnational Islam.
label: Paragraph

text: Elsewhere the Middle East has been such an
label: Paragraph

text: exceptionally complex and turbulent part of the world as to
label: Paragraph

text: make it a difficult environment in which to develop a
label: Paragraph

text: modern architectural culture. A modernizing cultural
label: Paragraph

text: impulse first appeared in the Middle East indirectly by virtue
label: Paragraph

text: of the Zionist movement founded in 1897 and the
label: Paragraph

text: subsequent migration of Jews to Palestine, particularly after
label: Paragraph

text: the foundation of the Jewish city of Tel Aviv in 1909 and the
label: Paragraph

text: Balfour Declaration of 1917, which announced the British
label: Paragraph

text: government’s support for the establishment of a ‘national
label: Title

text: home for the Jewish people’ in Palestine. This led to the
label: Paragraph

text: contradictory fusion of Zionism with socialism during the
label: Paragraph

text: foundation of Jewish agricultural settlements throughout the
label: Title

text: first part of the 20th century. The first vehicle for modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in this area were Jewish housing settlements
label: Paragraph

text: built during the interwar period, prior to the British
label: Paragraph

text: departure from Palestine and the ensuing conflict with the
label: Title

text: Arab League leading to Israel’s declaration of independence
label: Title

text: in 1948. It is clear that prior to the foundation of the state
label: Paragraph

text: German-Jewish architects played a fundamental role in the
label: Paragraph

text: development of modern architecture in Palestine.
label: Paragraph

text: My coverage of Saudi Arabia, Iraq, Iran and the Gulf
label: Title

text: States largely disregards the ideological and religious
label: Paragraph

text: differences and disagreements that have continually
label: Paragraph

text: plagued the region, except for references to Gamal Abdel
label: Paragraph

text: Nasser’s Pan-Arab movement of the 1950s. Twenty-five
label: Paragraph

text: years later this secular revolt was echoed by the Islamic
label: Paragraph

text: fundamentalist revolution in Iran of 1979, led by Ruhollah
label: Paragraph

text: Khomeini. While these fundamental political shifts are noted
label: Paragraph

text: in passing, this account does not emphasize the ‘global
label: Paragraph

text: flows’ that, fed by unprecedented oil wealth, led to the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of large megalopoli overnight in the Arabian
label: Paragraph

text: Peninsula, along with the phantasmagoric cities of Abu
label: Paragraph

text: Dhabi, Dubai and Doha, often replete with spectacular,
label: Paragraph

text: ostentatious, quasi-oriental institutional buildings, designed
label: Caption

text: by a wide array of international star architects.
label: Paragraph

text: South Africa
label: Title

text: The Union of South Africa came into being in 1910 after the
label: Paragraph

text: protracted Boer War, between the British and the Dutch,
label: Paragraph

text: finally ended. This was the occasion for the realization of
label: Paragraph

text: Herbert Baker’s monumental Union Building, constructed in
label: Caption

text: Pretoria in the space of a single year (1909-10). Baker’s
label: Paragraph

text: triumphant Beaux-Arts manner echoed that of his Cecil
label: Paragraph

text: Rhodes Memorial, completed on an equally spectacular site
label: Paragraph

text: in Cape Town two years before. This monumental set piece
label: Paragraph

text: was followed a decade later by James Solomon’s Cape Town
label: Paragraph

text: University Campus of 1918.
label: Paragraph

text: The Modern Movement first emerged in the African
label: Paragraph

text: continent in the work of South African architect Rex
label: Paragraph

text: Martienssen, whose Transvaal Group of architects was
label: Paragraph

text: brought to international attention in Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: introduction to the first volume of his Guvre comp/éte
label: Caption

text: (1910-29). Martienssen’s initial prowess as an architect is
label: Paragraph

text: evident from his masterly Corbusian Stern House [461],
label: Paragraph

text: built in Johannesburg in 1933. This building was matched for
label: Paragraph

text: its unequivocal modernity of expression by the work of a
label: Paragraph

text: number of other equally talented architects who had been
label: Paragraph

text: educated at the Witwatersrand University, among them John
label: Paragraph

text: Fassler, who became Martienssen’s partner in designing the
label: Paragraph

text: Peterhouse Flats built in Johannesburg in 1938. This had
label: Paragraph

text: been preceded by Norman Hanson's equally modernist
label: Paragraph

text: Hotpoint House, realized in the same city in 1936. This
label: Paragraph

text: generation exercised an influence on such post-war South
label: Paragraph

text: African architects as Gabriel Fagan in Cape Town and Adéle
label: Paragraph

text: Naudé Santos, whose dynamically plastic modern manner is
label: Paragraph

text: best exemplified by her low-rise, high-density Rowan Lane
label: Paragraph

text: housing [462, 463] built in Cape Town in 1972.
label: Paragraph

text: 461 Martienssen, Stern House, Johannesburg, 1933.
label: Caption

text: 462, 463 Naudé Santos, Rowan Lane Housing, Cape Town, 1972. Entry forecourt
label: Caption

text: and axonometric of four row houses.
label: Paragraph

text: Among South African architectural practices of the post-
label: Paragraph

text: apartheid period, none has been more aware of the dire
label: Paragraph

text: poverty that continues to prevail everywhere in South Africa
label: Paragraph

text: than the partnership of Jo Noero and Heinrich Wolff, who
label: Paragraph

text: have consistently striven for a socially accessible
label: Paragraph

text: architecture capable of mediating between civic institutions
label: Paragraph

text: sponsored by the state and the shanty towns in which they
label: Paragraph

text: happen to be situated. One of their first prominent attempts
label: Paragraph

text: in this regard was their Museum of the Struggle Against
label: Paragraph

text: Apartheid, the so-called Red Location Building [464] erected
label: Paragraph

text: in Port Elizabeth in 2005, the sawtooth roof of which alluded
label: Paragraph

text: to the buildings of the car industry that was once the
label: Paragraph

text: economic backbone of the city. This also happens to have
label: Paragraph

text: been the site of the first black township and the unusual
label: Paragraph

text: name of the building refers to the rusty corrugated iron
label: Paragraph

text: roofs of the shanty town, which are virtually identical to the
label: Paragraph

text: roofs of the first concentration camp built by the British
label: Caption

text: during the Boer War. Many of the prominent anti-apartheid
label: Paragraph

text: leaders hailed from here, including Nelson Mandela and
label: Paragraph

text: Govan Mbeki, and accordingly the Red Location Building
label: Paragraph

text: houses their archives along with those of others who were
label: Paragraph

text: active in the same movement. Although the building
label: Paragraph

text: received the RIBA Lubetkin Prize in 2006, its
label: Paragraph

text: commemorative purpose has since been thwarted due to its
label: Paragraph

text: closure from 2013. This was the result of daily protests by
label: Paragraph

text: the local population who were unwilling to accept such
label: Paragraph

text: extravagant expenditures on representational structures
label: Title

text: while they themselves continued to be ill-housed.
label: Paragraph

text: 464 Noero Wolff Architects, Red Location Building, Port Elizabeth, 2005.
label: Caption

text: Heinrich Wolff, now practising on his own, has since
label: Paragraph

text: applied a similar sawtooth profile to the design of two new
label: Paragraph

text: secondary schools: the Usasazo School in Khayelitsha
label: Title

text: Township (2003) and the Inkwenkwezi School in Du Noon
label: Paragraph

text: Township (2007) [465]. Both works were built by the
label: Paragraph

text: Western Cape government as part of a programme that
label: Paragraph

text: aims to combine general education with vocational training,
label: Paragraph

text: thereby enabling students to earn their livelihood
label: Paragraph

text: immediately on graduation. The Inkwenkwezi School is
label: Paragraph

text: cranked in plan not only to secure the playground but also
label: Paragraph

text: to break up the inevitable monotony of the long classroom
label: Paragraph

text: corridors. As with the Red Location building, the sawtooth
label: Paragraph

text: roof gives the school a strong sculptural presence that
label: Paragraph

text: distinguishes it as a public structure in contrast to the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding shanty town. Enriched by bands of colour
label: Paragraph

text: derived from African textiles, this unpretentious work
label: Paragraph

text: consists of a light-weight steel structure clad with
label: Paragraph

text: corrugated metal and filled in, here and there, by concrete
label: Paragraph

text: blocks, thereby through the use of ad hoc, relatively
label: Paragraph

text: inexpensive modes of construction making the work more
label: Paragraph

text: socially acceptable to the population at large. From 2010
label: Paragraph

text: Wolff practised with his wife, Ilze Wolff, and the range of
label: Paragraph

text: their work has expanded to include private houses, such as
label: Paragraph

text: their Phillips beach house of 2011, a work that vaguely
label: Paragraph

text: recalls the domestic work of Fagan and Pancho Guedes.
label: Paragraph

text: Otherwise, they continue to use their signature sawtooth
label: Paragraph

text: roof profile for public works, as their project for the Cheré
label: Paragraph

text: Botha School in the Western Cape of 2017 amply indicates.
label: Paragraph

text: 465 Wolff Architects, Inkwenkwezi School, Cape Town, 2007.
label: Caption

text: An equally dramatic roof profile, but closer to the form of
label: Paragraph

text: indigenous housing, may be found in the Interpretation
label: Paragraph

text: Centre, built to the designs of Peter Rich in the Mapungubwe
label: Paragraph

text: National Park, close to the border between South Africa,
label: Paragraph

text: Botswana and Zimbabwe. This World Heritage Site, first
label: Paragraph

text: excavated in 1933, contains the remains of an ancient
label: Paragraph

text: trading settlement, which it preserves and documents,
label: Paragraph

text: along with an exhibit featuring the local flora and fauna. The
label: Paragraph

text: pleated vaults that crown this semi-subterranean work are
label: Paragraph

text: built of handmade bricks, which are enriched by the
label: Paragraph

text: application of local multicoloured stones.
label: Paragraph

text: West Africa
label: Title

text: In the decade between 1957 and 1966, 32 countries within
label: Paragraph

text: the African continent became independent. First among
label: Paragraph

text: these, in 1957, was the West African state of Ghana, with
label: Paragraph

text: the electoral triumph of Kwame Nkrumah’s Trotskyite
label: Title

text: Convention People’s Party, which sought to transform the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional Ghanaian way of life into a technologically
label: Paragraph

text: modernized socialist state. In this aspiration he was
label: Paragraph

text: momentarily aided by the British architects Maxwell Fry and
label: Paragraph

text: Jane Drew, who had worked with Le Corbusier in
label: Paragraph

text: Chandigarh, and by two other London-based practices: that
label: Paragraph

text: of Drake and Lasdun, who would design the National
label: Paragraph

text: Museum in Accra, and that of James Cubitt and Partners,
label: Paragraph

text: whose laboratories, built for the School of Engineering in
label: Paragraph

text: Kumasi, remain one of the most sophisticated works of the
label: Paragraph

text: period. From the mid-1960s onwards newly independent
label: Paragraph

text: African states began to build a wide range of public
label: Paragraph

text: institutions on a large scale, ranging from conference
label: Paragraph

text: centres to trade fairs, tourist resorts and university
label: Title

text: campuses.
label: Paragraph

text: An important West African architect who has recently
label: Paragraph

text: emerged in this country is the German-trained Diébédo
label: Paragraph

text: Francis Kéré. Born in Burkina Faso and having studied in the
label: Paragraph

text: Technical University of Berlin, Kéré first came to public
label: Paragraph

text: attention with his single-storey, three-classroom primary
label: Paragraph

text: school that he designed and realized in Gando, Burkina
label: Paragraph

text: Faso, in 2001 [466]. Built of hand-pressed mud bricks, with
label: Paragraph

text: a corrugated iron shade roof fixed to hand-welded steel
label: Caption

text: trusswork, this structure was built by the local community.
label: Paragraph

text: Significantly enough for the architect and the people of
label: Paragraph

text: Burkina Faso, it was awarded an Aga Khan Prize in 2004.
label: Paragraph

text: The use of light-weight shade roofs on top of masonry
label: Paragraph

text: construction became common practice in Burkina Faso and
label: Paragraph

text: elsewhere in West Africa, as seen in the Women’s Health
label: Paragraph

text: Centre built in Ouagadougou at the millennium to the
label: Paragraph

text: designs of Riccardo Vannucci. Meanwhile, since the
label: Paragraph

text: completion of a primary school in Gando, Kéré’s practice has
label: Paragraph

text: greatly expanded, as is evident from a succession of welfare
label: Paragraph

text: facilities, such as schools, libraries, clinics and teachers’
label: Paragraph

text: housing, that he has realized in Burkina Faso, Mali,
label: Paragraph

text: Mozambique and Kenya.
label: Paragraph

text: 466 Kéré, school in Gando, Burkina Faso, 2001.
label: Caption

text: Equally sensitive interventions, by foreign architects,
label: Paragraph

text: may also be found in West Africa, particularly in a number of
label: Paragraph

text: small works designed by Finnish architects. One such is a
label: Paragraph

text: single-storey house [467-69] and a poultry farming school
label: Caption

text: [470-71], both built to the designs of the Helsinki practice
label: Paragraph

text: of Heikkinen and Komonen for their Finnish patron, Eila
label: Paragraph

text: Kivekas. The house was built for Kivekas’s own occupation
label: Paragraph

text: during her visits to Guinea and the school was erected to
label: Paragraph

text: the memory of her friend, the native-born agronomist Alpha
label: Paragraph

text: Diallo, who had spent a great deal of time in Finland working
label: Paragraph

text: on a translation of the Finnish folk epic the Kalevala into his
label: Paragraph

text: native language of Fula. Diallo was convinced that the only
label: Paragraph

text: way to improve the standard of living in Guinea would be
label: Paragraph

text: through an increase in the intake of protein by the general
label: Paragraph

text: population, and he insisted that poultry farming was the
label: Paragraph

text: fastest and cheapest means to achieve this. As a result,
label: Paragraph

text: Heikkinen and Komonen were commissioned by Kivekas to
label: Paragraph

text: design a poultry farming school assembled around a square
label: Paragraph

text: forecourt and a central lecture hall. One finds an equally
label: Paragraph

text: simple and direct tectonic approach in the Women’s Centre
label: Paragraph

text: [472-74], built in Rufisque, Senegal, in 2001 to the designs
label: Paragraph

text: of the young Finnish practice of Hollmén, Reuter and
label: Paragraph

text: Sandman. Like the poultry farming school, this single-storey
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard structure was executed in concrete block, which in
label: Paragraph

text: this instance was enlivened by being painted a luminous red
label: Paragraph

text: throughout.
label: Paragraph

text: 467, 468, 469 Heikkinen and Komonen, Villa Eila, Guinea, 1995. Section and
label: Caption

text: plan and interior detail.
label: Paragraph

text: 470, 471 Heikkinen and Komonen, School for Chicken Farmers, Guinea, 1999.
label: Caption

text: View and plan.
label: Paragraph

text: 472 Hollmén, Reuter and Sandman, Women’s Centre, Senegal, 2001. Plan.
label: Caption

text: 473 Hollmén, Reuter and Sandman, Women’s Centre, Senegal, 2001.
label: Caption

text: North Africa
label: Title

text: The modernization of Algeria and Morocco was already
label: Paragraph

text: underway by the second half of the 19th century, due to the
label: Paragraph

text: intensity of French investment in North Africa. Over time
label: Paragraph

text: Algeria became France’s most prosperous colony,
label: Paragraph

text: accommodating thousands of pied-nojrs: people who, over
label: Paragraph

text: the years, migrated from the French Republic to Algeria.
label: Paragraph

text: This process continued right up to the declaration of
label: Paragraph

text: independence in 1962, although by that date the pied-noirs
label: Paragraph

text: made up only one-tenth of the total population.
label: Paragraph

text: The French colonization of Morocco began in 1911, but
label: Paragraph

text: France did not take over the whole country until 1933. In
label: Paragraph

text: both of these North African colonies there was a continuous
label: Paragraph

text: migration from the Atlas Mountains to the coastal cities,
label: Paragraph

text: respectively Algiers and Casablanca. Thus over time, in both
label: Paragraph

text: cities, the original kasbahs and medinas were overrun by
label: Paragraph

text: shanty towns, or bidonvilles, which came into being
label: Paragraph

text: spontaneously in a never-ending attempt to accommodate
label: Paragraph

text: an ever-growing migrant population.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1907, the port city of Casablanca was already a boom
label: Paragraph

text: town, which prompted Henri Prost’s plans of 1914 and 1917;
label: Paragraph

text: these coincided with some of the earliest proposals for low-
label: Paragraph

text: rise, high-density patio housing expressly designed for the
label: Paragraph

text: Arab population. The Modern Movement as such did not
label: Paragraph

text: arrive in Casablanca until the 1950s, when it took the form
label: Paragraph

text: of luxury apartments and villas built for the new
label: Paragraph

text: bourgeoisie. Such luxurious development was countered by
label: Paragraph

text: the socially committed work of Michel Ecochard, who was
label: Paragraph

text: the author of the 1947 CIAM development plan for
label: Paragraph

text: Casablanca, a document which was accompanied by the
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of ATBAT-Afrique (Ateliers des Batisseurs), an
label: Paragraph

text: interdisciplinary office originally set up, in the first instance,
label: Paragraph

text: by the engineer Vladimir Bodiansky in order to realize Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s Unité d’Habitation in Marseille of 1952 (see pp.
label: Paragraph

text: 258 & 259). Having worked on the Unité, Shadrach Woods
label: Paragraph

text: and George Candilis joined Bodiansky in Casablanca, where
label: Paragraph

text: they designed prototypical, multistorey courtyard houses for
label: Paragraph

text: Arab occupation, in particular the so-called Semiramis [475]
label: Paragraph

text: and Nid d’Abeille blocks built between 1951 and 1955.
label: Paragraph

text: These designs constituted Bodiansky’s ‘housing for the
label: Paragraph

text: greatest number’, exhibited during the Team 10 meeting in
label: Paragraph

text: Aix-en-Provence of 1953. Not part of ATBAT-Afrique but
label: Paragraph

text: active in Morocco at the same time were the Swiss
label: Paragraph

text: architects Jean Hentsch and André Studer, who designed an
label: Paragraph

text: ingenious six-storey stacked courtyard housing block built
label: Caption

text: for the indigenous population in Sidi Othmane in 1955
label: Paragraph

text: [476]. It is somewhat ironic that the mid-rise housing
label: Paragraph

text: prototypes designed by Woods and Candilis for ATBAT-
label: Paragraph

text: Afrique were sited in the midst of single-storey carpet
label: Paragraph

text: housing, the Carriéres Centrales, designed by the office of
label: Paragraph

text: Ecochard, as a feasible alternative for decanting the ever
label: Paragraph

text: growing bidonville population into permanent, well-
label: Paragraph

text: organized, well-serviced settlements.
label: Paragraph

text: 475 Candilis, Woods and Bodiansky, Semiramis Housing, Casablanca, 1955.
label: Caption

text: Section.
label: Paragraph
