label: Caption

text: The work of ATBAT-Afrique in Morocco was paralleled in
label: Paragraph

text: Algiers at a larger scale and with a much more conventional
label: Paragraph

text: pattern of land settlement, of which the centrepiece was
label: Paragraph

text: known as the Climat de France. It comprised 6,000 units
label: Paragraph

text: built in 1957 to the designs of the French architect Fernand
label: Paragraph

text: Pouillon, who had studied with Auguste Perret. Consisting of
label: Paragraph

text: an aggregation of medium-rise apartments erected ona
label: Paragraph

text: steeply sloping site, this settlement was centred on a six- to
label: Paragraph

text: seven-storey perimeter block, known as deux cents
label: Caption

text: colonnes (‘200 columns’), the inner space of which was
label: Paragraph

text: lined on all four sides by a three-storey colonnade. This
label: Paragraph

text: space, conceived as a traditional maidan (public open
label: Paragraph

text: space) measuring 233 x 33 metres (764 x 108 feet), was the
label: Paragraph

text: apotheosis of Pouillon’s career as a housing architect. Over
label: Paragraph

text: the same period the Algerian architect Roland Simounet
label: Paragraph

text: assumed a much more modest approach in two low-rise,
label: Paragraph

text: high-density housing schemes realized on the outskirts of
label: Paragraph

text: Algiers in the early 1960s.
label: Paragraph

text: Many university campuses were established in North
label: Paragraph

text: Africa at the beginning of the 21st century, including two in
label: Paragraph

text: Morocco designed by the partnership of Saad El Kabbaj,
label: Paragraph

text: Driss Kettani and Mohamed Amine Siana: first the Ibn Zohr
label: Title

text: University in Taroudant in 2010 [478], and second the
label: Paragraph

text: Guelmim School of Technology of 2011 [477]. The quality of
label: Paragraph

text: the latter was considered as meriting an Aga Khan Award in
label: Paragraph

text: 2016. This compact, three-storey campus is located on the
label: Paragraph

text: edge of the Sahara Desert in southern Morocco, and close to
label: Paragraph

text: the Atlantic, which helps to mediate the desert climate. The
label: Paragraph

text: interior spaces are organized to maximize cross ventilation,
label: Paragraph

text: while the exterior of the /n situ concrete structure is finished
label: Paragraph

text: in red ochre cement, which affords a pleasing contrast to
label: Paragraph

text: the central greenway, replete with native plants. The whole
label: Paragraph

text: complex is arranged around a series of courts and shaded
label: Paragraph

text: walkways, while the cubic mass forms are broken up by
label: Paragraph

text: sunscreening pergolas.
label: Paragraph

text: 477 Kabbaj, Kettani & Siana, School of Technology, Guelmim, Morocco, 2011.
label: Caption

text: 478 Kabbaj, Kettani & Siana, Taroudant University Campus, Morocco, 2010.
label: Caption

text: Possibly the most important civic monument completed
label: Paragraph

text: in North Africa during this period is the Bibliotheca
label: Paragraph

text: Alexandrina [479], built close to the harbour of Alexandria,
label: Paragraph

text: Egypt, in 2001 as the result of the design of the Norwegian
label: Paragraph

text: firm of Snghetta winning the international competition. The
label: Paragraph

text: most impressive aspect of this work is the 20,000-square-
label: Paragraph

text: metre (215,278-square-foot), stepped, top-lit reading room,
label: Caption

text: 160 metres (525 feet) in diameter and 23 metres (75 feet)
label: Paragraph

text: in height, which accommodates desktop space for 3,000
label: Paragraph

text: readers.
label: Paragraph

text: 479 Snghetta, Bibliotheca Alexandrina, Egypt, 2001.
label: Caption

text: As Mercedes Volait makes clear in her revealing article of
label: Paragraph

text: 2006, ‘Mediating and Domesticating Modernity in Egypt’,
label: Paragraph

text: modernization in Egypt was largely dominated, as elsewhere
label: Paragraph

text: in North Africa, by France, evident in the first instance by
label: Paragraph

text: the cutting of the Saint-Simonian Suez Canal by Ferdinand
label: Title

text: de Lesseps (1859-69) followed by the Haussmannization of
label: Paragraph

text: Cairo from 1870 onwards. The French were also influential
label: Paragraph

text: when it came to architecture as is evident from the career of
label: Paragraph

text: Mustafa Fahmi, who, having graduated from the Ecole
label: Paragraph

text: Spéciale des Travaux Publics, Paris, in 1912, would play a
label: Paragraph

text: salient role in the Réunions internationales des architectes
label: Paragraph

text: (RIA). This organization, which was the forerunner of the
label: Paragraph

text: Union internationale des architectes (UIA) had been founded
label: Paragraph

text: in 1932 by the editors of L’Architecture d’Aujourd’hui, Pierre
label: Paragraph

text: Vago and André Bloch, in order to offset the domination of
label: Paragraph

text: the international scene by CIAM. Of greater consequence
label: Paragraph

text: stylistically however was the Exposition Internationale des
label: Paragraph

text: Arts Décoratifs et Industriels Modernes, Paris, of 1925, which
label: Caption

text: brought equally to the fore the Art Deco manner of Rob
label: Paragraph

text: Mallet-Stevens and the classical rationalism of Auguste
label: Title

text: Perret. These two architects greatly influenced upper-class
label: Paragraph

text: building in Egypt between the wars, as we may judge from
label: Paragraph

text: the élite Cairo garden suburb of Heliopolis and the luxury
label: Title

text: villas that Perret built in Egypt: the Aghion villa in Alexandria
label: Paragraph

text: in 1926 and the Elias Awad villa in Cairo in 1935. However,
label: Paragraph

text: as Volait notes, the Modern Movement truly showed itself in
label: Paragraph

text: Egypt for the first time with the figure of Said Korayem, who
label: Paragraph

text: had been trained in the ETH (Eidgendssische Technische
label: Paragraph

text: Hochschule) Zurich under the Swiss master architect Otto
label: Paragraph

text: Salvisberg and who, on graduating, continued to work for
label: Paragraph

text: him for a number of years. In 1939 Korayem founded the
label: Paragraph

text: first periodical proselytizing modern architecture in Arabic.
label: Paragraph

text: The appearance of this magazine, simply entitled a/-‘Iméra
label: Paragraph

text: (Architecture), coincided with the high point of a particularly
label: Paragraph

text: liberal spirit in Egypt, presaged by the subsidized housing
label: Paragraph

text: built by the Suez Canal Co. and Heliopolis Oasis Co. in the
label: Paragraph

text: early 1920s. Along similar lines the Misr textile group
label: Paragraph

text: started to build large company towns in the 1940s at
label: Paragraph

text: Mahalla al-Kubra, designed by Ali Labib Gabr; these
label: Paragraph

text: developments included restaurants, markets, welfare
label: Paragraph

text: centres, cinemas and sports facilities in addition to housing.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1950 well over twenty companies in Egypt had built
label: Paragraph

text: similar housing for their employees. Needless to say, these
label: Paragraph

text: company towns did little to improve the living conditions of
label: Paragraph

text: the larger part of the Egyptian rural population and it is only
label: Paragraph

text: with the model villages built under the auspices of the
label: Paragraph

text: Ministry of Social Affairs, in 1939, that any kind of
label: Paragraph

text: amelioration of rural conditions would emerge.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from the finest works of Said Korayem, such as his
label: Paragraph

text: Ouzounian Building erected in downtown Cairo in 1950, and
label: Paragraph

text: Ali Labib Gabr’s headquarters for the Misr textile company
label: Paragraph

text: of virtually the same date, the Modern Movement in Egypt
label: Paragraph

text: appears to have had a particularly chequered history, most
label: Paragraph

text: particularly after the Free Officers’ coup d’état of 1952 that
label: Paragraph

text: overthrew the monarchical regime of King Farouk. The fact
label: Paragraph

text: that a/-‘imara frequently published works by Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: and Frank Lloyd Wright, in addition to more general articles
label: Paragraph

text: on housing and planning, caused it to be viewed with
label: Paragraph

text: suspicion by the new military government, which subjected
label: Paragraph

text: it to increased censorship and eventually brought about its
label: Paragraph

text: closure in 1959. The 1956 appropriation of the Suez Canal
label: Paragraph

text: by the then president of the republic, Gamal Abdel Nasser,
label: Paragraph

text: led immediately to an abortive military intervention on the
label: Paragraph

text: part of Britain and France, which possibly accounts for
label: Paragraph

text: Nasser’s anti-colonial gesture of supporting the realization
label: Paragraph

text: of Conrad Hilton’s hotel, featuring Neo-Pharaonic kitsch
label: Caption

text: interiors, erected on a fine site on the banks of the Nile in
label: Caption

text: the centre of Cairo in 1957.
label: Paragraph

text: Notwithstanding such prejudiced gestures, the
label: Paragraph

text: modernization process continued to encounter sporadic
label: Paragraph

text: resistance in Egypt, to which the career of the distinguished
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian architect Hassan Fathy bears testament, given his
label: Paragraph

text: lifelong anti-modern stance. After graduating as an architect
label: Paragraph

text: in 1926, Fathy served as a municipal architect and teacher
label: Paragraph

text: until 1937, when he designed his first mud-brick dwelling. A
label: Paragraph

text: decade later, in 1946, he was commissioned by the
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian Department of Antiquities to design the village of
label: Caption

text: New Gourna [480] wherein he employed traditional sun-
label: Paragraph

text: dried bricks for a set of self-centring vaults and domes made
label: Paragraph

text: by local craftsmen. The purpose of this new village was to
label: Paragraph

text: move the existing population out of the Antiquities Zone so
label: Paragraph

text: as to enable tourists to gain access to the archaeological
label: Paragraph

text: sites without being harassed by the local population.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the ostensible aspirations to revive the pride of the
label: Paragraph

text: same local residents, and to regenerate the surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: countryside, the Gourni refused to move into their new
label: Paragraph

text: homes and two years later New Gourna was abandoned.
label: Paragraph

text: 480 Fathy, New Gourna, Egypt, 1947. Elevation and plan.
label: Caption

text: With the 1952 overthrow of the monarchy and the 1956
label: Paragraph

text: nationalization of the Suez Canal, Fathy felt increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: ostracized by the secular/socialist non-aligned Pan Arab
label: Paragraph

text: government and, in consequence, he moved to Athens,
label: Paragraph

text: where he joined the Ekistics research practice of
label: Paragraph

text: Constantinos Doxiadis. There he became engaged in a futile
label: Paragraph

text: attempt to reconcile his preference for vernacular building
label: Paragraph

text: with the rationalized design interests of a large-scale
label: Paragraph

text: international practice. After his return to Egypt in 1962 he
label: Paragraph

text: came to be recognized as an international cultural diplomat
label: Paragraph

text: and in 1976 he became a member of the steering
label: Paragraph

text: committee that conferred the first Aga Khan Award for
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture in 1980. Over time his approach went beyond
label: Paragraph

text: traditional Arab building to favour a form of generic
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular wherever it may occur, as is suggested by the
label: Paragraph

text: title of his last book, Natural Energy and Vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture, of 1986.
label: Paragraph

text: East Africa
label: Title

text: East Africa comprises twelve independent states, plus the
label: Paragraph

text: three island nations of Mauritius, the Comoros and the
label: Paragraph

text: Seychelles. As these countries achieved independence in
label: Paragraph

text: the early 1960s, they became aligned with the various
label: Paragraph

text: ideologies of the rival Cold War factions; thus, while
label: Paragraph

text: Tanzania and Zambia aspired to democratic ideals, Kenya,
label: Paragraph

text: Malawi and Uganda became right-wing dictatorships, and
label: Paragraph

text: Ethiopia and Mozambique established themselves as
label: Paragraph

text: socialist states.
label: Paragraph

text: The first evidence of modern architecture in East Africa
label: Paragraph

text: was buildings designed by the German émigré architect
label: Paragraph

text: Ernst May who, having fled the Third Reich in the 1930s,
label: Paragraph

text: first went to the Soviet Union and then to Africa. There he
label: Paragraph

text: designed two major works during the first half of the 1950s:
label: Paragraph

text: a cultural centre in Moshi, Tanzania, in 1952 and the
label: Paragraph

text: Oceanic Hotel, Mombasa, Kenya, completed in 1956 [482].
label: Caption

text: Where the form of the hotel is inflected towards the ocean,
label: Paragraph

text: the cultural centre was built around a traditional courtyard.
label: Paragraph

text: Among the major post-colonial works in East Africa were
label: Paragraph

text: the Kenyatta International Conference Centre, Nairobi,
label: Caption

text: Kenya (1969-73); the University of Zambia, Lusaka, Zambia
label: Caption

text: (1966-73); and the so-called African Riviera on the Ivory
label: Paragraph

text: Coast (1970-73), which, while initially planned for 120,000
label: Paragraph

text: people, topped out at a population of 5,000 before being
label: Paragraph

text: totally abandoned. Many of these ambitious mega-projects
label: Paragraph

text: would be brought to a similar end by the worldwide oil crisis
label: Paragraph

text: One of the most radically creative figures in Mozambique
label: Paragraph

text: was the Luso-African architect Pancho Guedes who, aware of
label: Paragraph

text: the vast gap between the ideals of the Modern Movement
label: Title

text: and the harsh realities of African life, attempted to combine
label: Paragraph

text: his own oneiric formal preferences with vernacular elements
label: Paragraph

text: [481]. However, despite his close association with the
label: Paragraph

text: Mozambique Surrealist painter Malangatana Ngwenya, the
label: Paragraph

text: left-wing triumph in the post-colonial civil war compelled
label: Paragraph

text: Guedes to leave the country and for the rest of his career he
label: Paragraph

text: taught in the architecture department of Witwatersrand
label: Paragraph

text: University. Irrespective of this, Portuguese modernists were
label: Paragraph

text: particularly active as architects in Mozambique throughout
label: Paragraph

text: the 1960s by virtue of the Portuguese leader Anténio
label: Paragraph

text: Salazar investing heavily in the colonies during the waning
label: Paragraph

text: years of his regime. Something of this Rationalist legacy is
label: Paragraph

text: still echoed in Mozambique, particularly in the work of the
label: Paragraph

text: local architect José Forjaz, who has created exceptionally
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic structures in welded tubular steel, as is found in
label: Paragraph

text: the Institute of International Relations [483], built in
label: Caption

text: Zimpeto in 2004.
label: Paragraph

text: 481 Guedes, House of Three Giraffes, Mozambique, 1953.
label: Caption

text: 482 May, Oceanic Hotel, Mombasa, Kenya, 1956.
label: Caption

text: 483 Forjaz, Institute of International Relations, Zimpeto, Mozambique, 2004.
label: Caption

text: Of the many embassies built in post-independence Africa
label: Paragraph

text: was the remarkable Dutch Embassy [484] at Addis Ababa,
label: Paragraph

text: built to the designs of Bjarne Mastenbroek and Dick van
label: Caption

text: Gameren in 2005. Set within a forested compound, of which
label: Paragraph

text: the only traditionally representative element was an existing
label: Paragraph

text: gateway, it comprises several residences for the staff and
label: Paragraph

text: the ambassador, plus a large, long bunker of a two-storey
label: Paragraph

text: building, containing offices and various reception spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: This structure is of in situ concrete dyed the same colour as
label: Paragraph

text: the surrounding earth. This exceptionally topographic form
label: Paragraph

text: bridges an internal roadway and features a monumental
label: Paragraph

text: stair rising to the belvedere roof inlaid with runnels, which,
label: Caption

text: when flooded in the rainy season, constitute a micro-
label: Paragraph

text: landscape echoing the form of a larger domain on every
label: Paragraph

text: side.
label: Paragraph

text: 484 Mastenbroek and Van Gameren, Dutch Embassy, Ethiopia, 2005.
label: Caption

text: Turkey
label: Title

text: Turkey’s defeat as an ally of Germany at the end of the First
label: Paragraph

text: World War led to the final disintegration of the Ottoman
label: Paragraph

text: Empire followed by the French and British occupation of
label: Paragraph

text: Istanbul and a wholesale invasion of the country by Greece.
label: Paragraph

text: The military genius of Mustafa Kemal, later known as
label: Paragraph

text: Ataturk, would become immediately evident during Turkey’s
label: Paragraph

text: so called War of Independence, which concluded with the
label: Paragraph

text: liberation of Istanbul and the total repulsion of the Greek
label: Title

text: invasion, culminating in Atattirk’s proclamation of Turkey as
label: Paragraph

text: a secular republic in 1923.
label: Paragraph

text: The affinity between Germany and Turkey no doubt arose
label: Paragraph

text: in part from the Prussian influence on the modernization of
label: Paragraph

text: the Turkish military. As a consequence of this one of the first
label: Paragraph

text: German architects to enter the service of the Kemalist
label: Paragraph

text: republic was Carl Lorcher, who issued his plan for a new
label: Paragraph

text: government centre in Ankara, Anatolia, in 1924. Lorcher was
label: Paragraph

text: followed by Hermann Jansen, who developed a master plan
label: Paragraph

text: for Ankara as an ideal garden city from 1928 to 1932 [486].
label: Paragraph

text: After these German urbanists came Austrian architects of
label: Paragraph

text: calibre: Ernst Egli and Clemens Holzmeister. Holzmeister
label: Caption

text: designed the National Assembly in Ankara as the result of
label: Paragraph

text: winning the competition entry in 1937, a work which, due to
label: Paragraph

text: various upheavals, would not be completed until 1961.
label: Paragraph

text: Various other Germanic architects followed, including the
label: Paragraph

text: illustrious Bruno Taut, who went to Ankara in 1935 after
label: Paragraph

text: spending three years in Japan. Taut was immediately called
label: Paragraph

text: on by the state to design and realize his subtly monumental
label: Paragraph

text: Faculty of the Humanities in Ankara University, which was
label: Paragraph

text: completed in 1937, one year before his death. This building
label: Paragraph

text: was Surely an influence on the Faculty of Sciences and
label: Paragraph

text: Literature building at Istanbul University [485] designed by
label: Caption

text: Sedad Hakki Eldem and Emin Onat in 1924, but not
label: Paragraph

text: completed until 1948. The Neo-Classical deportment of the
label: Paragraph

text: Istanbul University building, with its shallow-pitched Turkish
label: Paragraph

text: roofs and deep, overhanging eaves was simultaneously both
label: Paragraph

text: modern and traditional.
label: Paragraph

text: 485 Eldem and Onat, Faculty of Sciences and Literature, Istanbul University,
label: Caption

text: 486 Jansen, master plan for Ankara, 1932.
label: Caption

text: Although Eldem and Onat’s building has a hybrid
label: Paragraph

text: character touching on the vernacular, Ataturk in his prime
label: Paragraph

text: was an unabashed patron of the Modern Movement in all its
label: Paragraph

text: pristine functional purity, as evidenced by the work of his
label: Paragraph

text: favourite architect Seyfi Arkan. Apart from his Zeilenbau
label: Paragraph

text: workers’ housing proposed for the industrial city of
label: Paragraph

text: Zonguldak in 1935, Arkan designed one luxury residence
label: Paragraph

text: after another for the Kemalist elite, including Ataturk’s own
label: Paragraph

text: vacation house of 1935, at Florya, situated on the sea near
label: Paragraph

text: Istanbul. As in other countries at this time, AtatUrk’s
label: Paragraph

text: modernization of Turkey involved the state’s promotion of
label: Paragraph

text: sports and athletics, and irrigation of previously infertile arid
label: Title

text: areas such as the territory surrounding Ankara. In the first
label: Paragraph

text: instance this led to the construction of stadia and in the
label: Paragraph

text: second to the building of the Cubuk Dam near Ankara
label: Caption

text: Ataturk’s untimely death in 1938 virtually coincided with
label: Paragraph

text: the arrival of another German architect of exceptional
label: Paragraph

text: stature, namely Paul Bonatz, who first visited Turkey in 1942
label: Paragraph

text: as a juror on the competition for Ataturk’s mausoleum, won
label: Paragraph

text: by Emin Onat and Ahmet Orhan Arda. In 1943 Bonatz came
label: Paragraph

text: to Turkey and remained on the occasion of opening an
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition on the architecture of the Third Reich. German
label: Caption

text: involvement in Turkish architecture came to an end with the
label: Paragraph

text: German defeat at the end of the Second World War and with
label: Paragraph

text: the beginning of the Pax Americana. A decade later, the
label: Paragraph

text: Istanbul Hilton Hotel was built on a prime site overlooking
label: Paragraph

text: the Bosphorus, designed by Gordon Bunshaft of SOM in
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration with Sedad Hakki Eldem. As Suha Ozkan has
label: Paragraph

text: noted, ‘Here Eldem’s regionalism was confined to the
label: Paragraph

text: entrance canopy, ballroom and various decorative elements.
label: Caption

text: The building became a model to be repeated at various
label: Paragraph

text: scales all over Turkey.’
label: Paragraph

text: Despite Le Corbusier’s attachment to the Turkish
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular, as seen in his Voyage d’orient of 1912, he
label: Paragraph

text: seems to have had little influence on the development of
label: Paragraph

text: 20th-century Turkish architecture. Eldem offered a partial
label: Paragraph

text: explanation for this at an Aga Khan Award seminar in
label: Paragraph

text: Istanbul (1978):
label: Title

text: One might ask why it is necessary to look into the past. Why
label: Paragraph

text: can we not simply look forward? The answer is that Islam’s
label: Paragraph

text: only way into the future is through the past. The greatest
label: Paragraph

text: achievements of Islam are those of the past; since then we
label: Paragraph

text: have merely been marking time. It is a regrettable fact that
label: Paragraph

text: we must first journey into our past and seek our inspiration
label: Paragraph

text: there. Only then we can venture onto new ground. Our first
label: Paragraph

text: requirement is a solid foundation.
label: Paragraph

text: On the occasion of the first Venice Biennale of 1980, which,
label: Paragraph

text: under the curatorship of Paolo Portoghesi had a decidedly
label: Paragraph

text: Post-Modern cast, Eldem argued that the Modern Movement
label: Paragraph

text: was now in crisis. He contended that the only way forward
label: Paragraph

text: would be through a self-conscious regionalism such as he
label: Paragraph

text: himself practised, thereby evoking that which some have
label: Paragraph

text: since called ‘vernacular modernism’, Le Corbusier having
label: Paragraph

text: already shifted in this direction with his Maison Errazuriz
label: Paragraph

text: projected for Chile of 1931. When it came to his civic work
label: Paragraph

text: Eldem opted early for a Perretesque neo-monumental
label: Paragraph

text: manner as found in his very first building for the Kemalist
label: Paragraph

text: state, the State Monopolies General Directorate built in
label: Paragraph

text: Ankara (1934-37). It is interesting that thirty years later
label: Paragraph

text: Eldem again had recourse to Perret’s structural rationalism
label: Paragraph

text: in his remarkable Social Security Complex [487] built in the
label: Paragraph

text: Zeyrek district of Istanbul in 1968.
label: Paragraph

text: 487 Eldem, Social Security Complex, Istanbul, 1963-68.
label: Caption

text: Nearly forty years separate this masterwork by Eldem
label: Paragraph

text: from the earliest work of the most prominent 21st-century
label: Paragraph

text: Turkish architect, namely Emre Arolat, whose prolific
label: Paragraph

text: practice totally dwarfs the achievements of Eldem. Arolat is
label: Paragraph

text: one of the leading architects of a globalized Turkey, whose
label: Paragraph

text: reputation was assured by the 2010 Aga Khan Award for his
label: Paragraph

text: high-tech Ipekyol Textile Factory at Edirne in 2009. However,
label: Paragraph

text: some trace of Eldem’s tectonic sensibility may also be
label: Paragraph

text: detected in the vernacular modernism of the luxury
label: Paragraph

text: residential settlement that Arolat designed for Bodrum in
label: Paragraph

text: 488 Arolat, Vicem Bodrum Residences, Bodrum, 2010.
label: Caption

text: Lebanon
label: Title

text: The French would remain in control of Lebanon until the
label: Paragraph

text: country finally gained its independence in 1943. However,
label: Paragraph

text: French cultural influence lasted well into the 1950s, as is
label: Paragraph

text: clear from the presence of the ubiquitous Michel Ecochard in
label: Paragraph

text: Beirut. There he worked on a series of Corbusian buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: mostly schools, in collaboration with Amin Bizri, of which the
label: Paragraph

text: Collége Protestant Francais is the best known. In 1955 he
label: Paragraph

text: also realized a Corbusian office building in collaboration with
label: Paragraph

text: George Rayes and Theo Kannan. A decade later the French
label: Paragraph

text: architect André Wogenscky and the Lebanese practice of
label: Paragraph

text: Maurice Hindeh worked together on the design of the
label: Paragraph

text: Ministry of National Defence, built in Beirut from 1962 to
label: Caption

text: From 1975 to 1990 Lebanon was ravaged by a sectarian
label: Paragraph

text: civil war that totally eclipsed any form of cultural
label: Paragraph

text: development. In the uneasy respite that has followed, two
label: Paragraph

text: works promise a renewal of Lebanese architecture: Hashim
label: Title

text: Sarkis’s Housing for the Fishermen of Tyre of 2008 [489]
label: Caption

text: and Nabil Gholam’s colony of holiday chalets at Faqra of
label: Paragraph

text: 2010. The latter were built of load-bearing stone walls at
label: Paragraph

text: grade with timber cladding above, a syntax that Gholam
label: Paragraph

text: further refined in a three-storey villa that he built at Rabieh
label: Paragraph

text: in 2003 [490]. This divide between heavy-weight local
label: Paragraph

text: stonework below and light-weight timber modernity above
label: Caption

text: was echoed in the stone-faced buildings that Gholam
label: Paragraph

text: designed for Beirut’s historic district, as opposed to the
