text: Israel/Palestine
label: Title

text: During the British Mandate for Palestine (1918-48) - under
label: Paragraph

text: which the British occupied and administered territories
label: Paragraph

text: previously ruled by the Ottoman Empire - this area was one
label: Paragraph

text: of the first in the Middle East to adopt the white architecture
label: Paragraph

text: of the Modern Movement, above all in the so-called ‘White
label: Paragraph

text: City’ of Tel Aviv. The fabric of the city was essentially
label: Paragraph

text: composed of four-storey, walk-up apartment blocks, mostly
label: Paragraph

text: designed in the 1930s and 1940s by German-Jewish émigré
label: Paragraph

text: architects in the so called International Style. Migration of
label: Paragraph

text: accomplished architects to Palestine greatly increased after
label: Paragraph

text: the 1933 Nazi seizure of power in Germany, and among
label: Paragraph

text: them was Arieh Sharon, who had been a pupil of Hannes
label: Paragraph

text: Meyer in the Bauhaus and had previously worked for him on
label: Paragraph

text: the design of the Federal School of the General German
label: Paragraph

text: Trade Union Confederation (ADGB) in Bernau, Germany, of
label: Paragraph

text: 1930. On his arrival in Palestine, Sharon became
label: Paragraph

text: immediately involved with the design and development of
label: Paragraph

text: workers’ housing, comparable to Ze’ev Rechter’s five-storey
label: Paragraph

text: middle-class Engel apartment building, completed in Tel Aviv
label: Caption

text: in 1933 [494]. Both Sharon and Rechter were members of
label: Paragraph

text: the Tel Aviv Chug group, who were committed to a rigorous
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture capable of combining the values of
label: Paragraph

text: Zionism with socialism. After the foundation of the Israeli
label: Paragraph

text: state in 1948 this generation completed a number of
label: Paragraph

text: significant public buildings in Tel Aviv, most notably
label: Paragraph

text: Rechter’s Mann Auditorium of 1951 and Helena Rubinstein
label: Title

text: Gallery of 1957, both buildings combining with Oscar
label: Paragraph

text: Kaufmann’s Habima Theatre of 1937 to form a new cultural
label: Paragraph

text: core in the city. Dov Karmi also belonged to this generation
label: Paragraph

text: of architects, designing the administrative headquarters of
label: Paragraph

text: the Histadrut, the country’s all-powerful trades union
label: Paragraph

text: organization. After 1948 immigration to Israel greatly
label: Paragraph

text: increased the population - from 650,000 to nearly 5 million
label: Paragraph

text: in the space of five years - which meant that the next
label: Paragraph

text: generation of architects were largely involved in the design
label: Paragraph

text: of low-cost housing.
label: Paragraph

text: The German-Jewish architect who had the most incisive
label: Paragraph

text: cultural impact on Palestine was Erich Mendelsohn, whose
label: Paragraph

text: finest works were realized in Jerusalem: the Schocken
label: Paragraph

text: Library, built in the centre of the city in 1936, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Hadassah hospital, completed on Mount Scopus in 1939
label: Caption

text: [493]. Mendelsohn’s production in the region also included
label: Paragraph

text: a bank in Jerusalem, a hospital in Haifa and a house for the
label: Paragraph

text: scientist and politician (and later first President of Israel)
label: Paragraph

text: Chaim Weizmann in Rehovot, where he also designed the
label: Paragraph

text: Weizmann Institute before migrating to the United States in
label: Paragraph

text: 493 Mendelsohn, Hassan University Medical Center, Mount Scopus, Jerusalem,
label: Caption

text: 494 Rechter, Engel Apartment House, Tel Aviv, 1933.
label: Caption

text: Brutalism arrived in Israel in the 1950s with Ram Karmi,
label: Paragraph

text: the son of Dov Karmi, who had been trained at the
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Association School in London and who
label: Title

text: produced two seminal works in Tel Aviv during his early
label: Paragraph

text: career: the offices of the ZIM Shipping Company on
label: Title

text: Rothschild Boulevard and the ORT School built just outside
label: Caption

text: the city in 1956. Continually engaged in the design of
label: Paragraph

text: housing as the population of the country continued to grow,
label: Paragraph

text: Ram Karmi employed a mode of expression that became
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly monumental and nationalistic, particularly after
label: Paragraph

text: the Six Day War (5-10 June 1967). This tendency is
label: Paragraph

text: suggested by the somewhat Post-Modern character of the
label: Paragraph

text: Israeli Supreme Court in Jerusalem, dating from 1992, on
label: Paragraph

text: the design of which he collaborated with his sister Ada
label: Paragraph

text: Karmi-Melamede.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the most gifted architects to migrate to Israel was
label: Paragraph

text: the Czech Alfred Neumann. He had been trained by Peter
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens in Vienna in the 1920s, and first worked in Algiers
label: Paragraph

text: and then in Paris, before moving to Israel in 1949 as a
label: Paragraph

text: consequence of the Communist takeover in Prague in the
label: Paragraph

text: previous year. When the young Israeli architects Zvi Hecker
label: Paragraph

text: and Eldar Sharon won the competition for the town hall in
label: Paragraph

text: Bat Yam in 1956, they invited Neumann, who had been their
label: Paragraph

text: teacher in the Technion (Israel Institute of Technology), to
label: Paragraph

text: join them in the development of the design. Neumann
label: Paragraph

text: effectively transformed their initial proposal through the
label: Paragraph

text: superimposition of a 262-centimetre wide tetrahedral
label: Paragraph

text: modular unit, which was derived from his patent
label: Paragraph

text: proportional system. Each upper tier of the three-storey
label: Paragraph

text: town hall, with its square plan, was cantilevered out beyond
label: Paragraph

text: the tier below it, thereby yielding an inverted pyramid that
label: Paragraph

text: stepped out externally and stepped in internally to produce
label: Paragraph

text: a three-storey internal courtyard, which was lit and
label: Paragraph

text: ventilated from above via polyhedral ‘cowls’ built on the
label: Paragraph

text: roof. This part /n situ, part pre-cast concrete structure was
label: Paragraph

text: left exposed with certain interstitial areas coloured blue,
label: Paragraph

text: gold and red. Built from 1959 to 1963, it was originally
label: Paragraph

text: conceived as the central symbolic structure set within a
label: Paragraph

text: larger orthogonal piazza, which unfortunately was not
label: Paragraph

text: executed in the ultimate development of the city.
label: Paragraph

text: Neumann's ‘space-packing geometry’ perfected for the Bat
label: Paragraph

text: Yam Town Hall [495, 496] was continued throughout his
label: Paragraph

text: career, with the exception of the single-storey, narrow-
label: Paragraph

text: fronted housing that he designed for the Arab village of Ein
label: Paragraph

text: Rafa in Israel in 1962. It is incredible from today’s
label: Paragraph

text: standpoint that this diminutive housing scheme was
label: Paragraph

text: sponsored in the 1960s by the Israeli Ministry of Housing as
label: Paragraph

text: part of a nationwide initiative to upgrade Palestinian
label: Paragraph

text: housing. It was applied in some forty villages throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: country [497]. Neumann proposed a standard type of
label: Paragraph

text: dwelling with load-bearing stone cross walls and with a
label: Paragraph

text: corrugated iron sheet to be used as permanent formwork to
label: Paragraph

text: vault over the spaces between the walls. The economy of
label: Paragraph

text: this system depended on the labour of the tenants
label: Paragraph

text: themselves to reduce the overall building costs.
label: Paragraph

text: 495 Neumann, Bat Yam Town Hall, 1963.
label: Caption

text: 496 Neumann, Bat Yam Town Hall, 1963. Plan and section.
label: Caption

text: 497 Neumann, low-cost housing, 1963.
label: Caption

text: Like the Bat Yam Town Hall, Ein Rafa was conceived as a
label: Paragraph

text: place that would transcend the historic divisions between
label: Paragraph

text: Arabs and Jews. At the same time Neumann’s obsession
label: Paragraph

text: with tetrahedral geometry was not well received in Israel
label: Paragraph

text: and after further controversy over a mechanical engineering
label: Paragraph

text: faculty building that he designed for the Technion, Neumann
label: Paragraph

text: became disenchanted with the country. He began
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly to divide his time between Israel and Canada,
label: Paragraph

text: serving as a visiting professor at the Ecole d’Architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: the Université Laval, Quebec City, where he died
label: Caption

text: prematurely at the age of sixty-eight.
label: Paragraph

text: A much larger work conceived as if it were a ‘city in
label: Paragraph

text: miniature’ devoted to the exhibition of art would be realized
label: Paragraph

text: in Jerusalem over the next five decades as the Israel
label: Paragraph

text: Museum [498]. Designed by Alfred Mansfeld and Dora Gad,
label: Caption

text: it was built on a continuous ridge just outside the old city.
label: Paragraph

text: This building, predicated on a 6 x 6-metre (20 x 20-foot)
label: Paragraph

text: gallery module, was expanded tenfold during the next
label: Paragraph

text: decades on the same grid from an initial 4,500 square
label: Paragraph

text: metres (48,437 square feet) in 1959 to 45,000 square
label: Paragraph

text: metres (484,376 square feet) by the millennium. It was
label: Paragraph

text: conceived as the ultimate ‘mat building’, and each of its
label: Paragraph

text: stone-faced gallery modules was lit on at least two
label: Paragraph

text: contiguous sides by clerestory fenestration. The refined
label: Paragraph

text: detailing displays a distinctly Scandinavian character
label: Paragraph

text: throughout.
label: Paragraph

text: 498 Mansfeld and Gad, Israel Museum, Jerusalem, 1959-92.
label: Caption

text: The 1967 Six Day War, which greatly increased the area
label: Paragraph

text: of Palestine under Israeli control, had the effect of rendering
label: Paragraph

text: the contradictory Zionist/socialist ethos of the state that
label: Paragraph

text: prevailed during the waves of Jewish migration from 1920 to
label: Paragraph

text: 1960 suddenly as outdated. With the so-called subsequent
label: Paragraph

text: ‘civilian occupation’ of the West Bank, the Israeli state
label: Title

text: became an occupying power and a divided nation. As a
label: Paragraph

text: paradoxical result, Israeli architects became preoccupied
label: Paragraph

text: with the vernacular architecture of the region, and this has
label: Paragraph

text: had the effect of tipping the received architectural taste of
label: Paragraph

text: the country into a Post-Modern stylistic confusion. Nothing
label: Paragraph

text: could be more removed from this fate than Rafi Segal and
label: Paragraph

text: Zvi Hecker’s Palmach Museum of History [499] in Ramat
label: Caption

text: Aviv of 1993-98, which, while ostensibly representing the
label: Paragraph

text: past military prowess of the country, nonetheless evokes -
label: Paragraph

text: through its countervailing massive forms and deliberately
label: Paragraph

text: brutal detailing in brick and concrete - the deeply tragic
label: Paragraph

text: ethical quandary that continues to haunt the Israeli state.
label: Paragraph

text: 499 Hecker, with Segal, Palmach Museum of History, Tel Aviv, 1993-98.
label: Caption

text: Iraq
label: Title

text: As elsewhere in the Middle East, modern architecture was
label: Paragraph

text: introduced into Iraq by European architects, first by Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier, who designed a sports complex for Baghdad in
label: Paragraph

text: 1956, and then by José Luis Sert. Sert designed the U.S.
label: Paragraph

text: Embassy in Baghdad [500] as a landscaped, medium-rise
label: Paragraph

text: diplomatic oasis articulated by his tropical syntax of vaulted
label: Paragraph

text: and folded-plate roofs, elevated above the main mass of the
label: Paragraph

text: various structures so as to shield their internal volumes from
label: Paragraph

text: intense exposure to the sun.
label: Paragraph

text: 500 Sert, United States Embassy, Baghdad, 1960.
label: Caption

text: A locally mediated modern architecture first made itself
label: Paragraph

text: manifest in Iraq with Rifat Chadirji’s Tobacco Monopoly
label: Title

text: Building [501], completed in Baghdad in 1967 asa
label: Caption

text: reinforced-concrete form animated by cylindrical shafts of
label: Paragraph

text: precision brickwork jutting out from the main body of the
label: Paragraph

text: structure, along with a modern version of the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: mashrabiya (a projecting oriel window with wooden
label: Paragraph

text: latticework). Despite Chadirji’s ingenious, discreet, yet
label: Paragraph

text: arresting translations of traditional syntax in a modern
label: Paragraph

text: idiom, one of the most sophisticated buildings to be
label: Paragraph

text: completed in Baghdad in the 1980s was the Central Bank of
label: Paragraph

text: lrag, designed by the Danish architects Dissing and Weitling.
label: Paragraph

text: 501 Chadirji, Tobacco Monopoly Headquarters, Baghdad, 1967.
label: Caption

text: Saudi Arabia
label: Title

text: The dissolution of the Ottoman Empire in 1918 led to the
label: Paragraph

text: progressive fragmentation of the Arabian Peninsula into a
label: Title

text: number of territories of varying size and sovereignty,
label: Paragraph

text: including Saudi Arabia and the smaller Gulf states of what
label: Paragraph

text: eventually became Kuwait, Qatar, Oman, Bahrain, Yemen
label: Paragraph

text: and the United Arab Emirates. No one has perhaps summed
label: Paragraph

text: up the impact that oil exploitation has had on this region
label: Paragraph

text: more succinctly than Hasan-Uddin Khan, who wrote: In
label: Paragraph

text: Saudi Arabia, the largest country of the Arabian Peninsula,
label: Paragraph

text: the notion of architecture that expresses an Arab or Islamic
label: Paragraph

text: identity assumed great importance and became the centre
label: Paragraph

text: of its architectural agenda. The exploitation of oil made the
label: Paragraph

text: country extremely rich and allowed for the rebuilding of old
label: Paragraph

text: settlements and the establishment of new ones through
label: Title

text: five-year plans from the 1970’s onwards. The
label: Paragraph

text: unprecedented architectural activity of those decades
label: Paragraph

text: attracted architects and construction companies from all
label: Paragraph

text: over the world. At first modern international architecture
label: Paragraph

text: took hold as being new, shiny and progressive. This was
label: Paragraph

text: modernization was soon tempered by a nod towards
label: Paragraph

text: religious building traditions by foreign and Arab architects
label: Title

text: alike. The country’s architecture attempted to reflect a
label: Paragraph

text: sense of national pride and identity by referring to the Nadji
label: Paragraph

text: building tradition with its massive crenelated walls and deep
label: Paragraph

text: narrow openings.
label: Paragraph

text: It is symptomatic of this new oil wealth that the capital of
label: Paragraph

text: Saudi Arabia, Riyadh, which in 1940 was a small fortress
label: Paragraph

text: town of 25,000 people, should grow to a metropolis of 3
label: Paragraph

text: million by the end of the 20th century. One of the first works
label: Paragraph

text: of quality to be built in the emerging capital was designed
label: Paragraph

text: by the distinguished Danish architect Henning Larsen, who
label: Paragraph

text: in 1980 won a competition for the design of the new Saudi
label: Paragraph

text: Arabian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. This fortress-like,
label: Paragraph

text: virtually windowless, stone-faced monument occupied an
label: Paragraph

text: entire city block. Even more fortified, to the point of having
label: Paragraph

text: simulated battlements, was the Al-Kindi Plaza, completed in
label: Paragraph

text: Riyadh as a new diplomatic quarter in 1986 to the designs
label: Paragraph

text: of Ali Shuaibias. This was an urban megaform built around a
label: Paragraph

text: large central plaza with a mosque capable of housing a
label: Paragraph

text: congregation of 7,000 people. There followed in the same
label: Paragraph

text: vein the Justice Palace and Mosque [502] completed in
label: Caption

text: Riyadh in 1992 to the designs of the Jordanian architect
label: Paragraph

text: Rasem Badran. Although of reinforced-concrete
label: Caption

text: construction, the multi-block continuity of this megaform
label: Paragraph

text: was Clad throughout in local yellow stonework in such a
label: Paragraph

text: manner as to evoke the castellated Nadji fortress tradition.
label: Paragraph

text: Like the Al-Kindi Plaza this development, this complex was
label: Paragraph

text: conceived as a ‘city-in-miniature’, including a public square
label: Paragraph

text: and a vast mosque capable of accommodating 17,000
label: Paragraph

text: worshippers.
label: Paragraph

text: 502 Badran, Justice Palace and Mosque, Riyadh, 1985-92.
label: Caption

text: Two of the more prominent structures realized in Saudi
label: Paragraph

text: Arabia during this period were designed by the American
label: Paragraph

text: practice of SOM: first, the twenty-seven-storey National
label: Paragraph

text: Commercial Bank, built in Jeddah to the designs of Gordon
label: Caption

text: Bunshaft in 1983, and, second, the Hajj Terminal [503] of
label: Paragraph

text: 1981, designed by the engineer Fazlur Khan of SOM’s
label: Caption

text: Chicago office. Located 70 kilometres (43 miles) west of
label: Paragraph

text: Mecca and 60 kilometres (37 miles) north-west of Jeddah,
label: Paragraph

text: this terminal was designed to receive over one million
label: Paragraph

text: pilgrims to Mecca each year, a figure that has since
label: Paragraph

text: expanded exponentially as a result of the introduction of the
label: Paragraph

text: wide-bodied jet airliners in 1970. This terminal comprises
label: Paragraph

text: two pavilions; each one consists of five modules, with each
label: Paragraph

text: module being covered by twenty-one tents made out of
label: Paragraph

text: Teflon-coated fibreglass fabric. Each tent is 45 metres
label: Paragraph

text: square (484 feet square) and rises from a height of 20
label: Paragraph

text: metres (65 feet) to top out at 33 metres (108 feet) above
label: Paragraph

text: the ground. These elegant white cones are cable-suspended
label: Paragraph

text: from 45-metre (148-foot) high, cylindrical steel pylons, while
label: Paragraph

text: the fabric itself was designed to reflect 75 per cent of the
label: Paragraph

text: sun’s radiation and thus to maintain an internal temperature
label: Paragraph

text: of 85°F (29.4°C) when the mean temperature outside was
label: Paragraph

text: 503 Khan (SOM), Hajj Terminal, Jeddah, 1974-81.
label: Caption

text: The most significant early 21st-century work in Saudi
label: Paragraph

text: Arabia is the restoration from 2005 of the Wadi Hanifa
label: Paragraph

text: [504], a valley near Riyadh, which over time had become
label: Paragraph

text: toxic as the result of the wholesale dumping of sewage and
label: Paragraph

text: industrial waste. The Canadian environmental practice of
label: Paragraph

text: Moriyama and Teshima, in collaboration with engineers Buro
label: Paragraph

text: Happold, bioremediated the wad/ through series of weirs,
label: Paragraph

text: pools, aerating pumps, benthic substrates (at the lowest
label: Paragraph

text: level of the water) and riparian planting, so as to assimilate
label: Paragraph

text: contaminants and purify the water. In course of this large-
label: Paragraph

text: scale operation, ultimately covering 120 square km (46
label: Paragraph

text: square miles), they planted 4,500 palms and 35,000 shade
label: Paragraph

text: trees, thereby converting large parts of the wad into an
label: Paragraph

text: elaborate park system for the benefit of the city.
label: Paragraph

text: 504 Moriyama and Teshima, restoration of the Wadi Hanifa, Riyadh, 2005
label: Caption

text: onwards.
label: Paragraph

text: Iran
label: Title

text: The Modern Movement first appeared in Iran with the
label: Paragraph

text: Armenian architect Vartan Avanessian, who in 1935, after
label: Paragraph

text: having been educated in France, returned to Iran to win a
label: Paragraph

text: competition for the so-called Orphan School in Tehran. It
label: Paragraph

text: was built as a half-Art Deco, half-modern symmetrical
label: Paragraph

text: composition clad in precision brickwork and equipped with
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal steel windows. However, a quarter of a century
label: Paragraph

text: elapsed before a comparable modern work was realized in
label: Paragraph

text: Tehran, namely the Bank Melli [505] built to the designs of
label: Paragraph

text: the Danish architect Jorn Utzon in 1959. This was Utzon’s
label: Paragraph

text: first use of folded plates spaced out so as to admit natural
label: Paragraph

text: light and ventilation to the banking hall beneath. Of equal
label: Paragraph

text: tectonic consequence are the monumental steps that lead
label: Paragraph

text: up to the elevated level of the bank, the podium of the
label: Paragraph

text: banking hall, which is given a particularly local character
label: Paragraph

text: through the ingeniously geometrical patterning of its stone
label: Paragraph

text: floor.
label: Paragraph

text: 505 Utzon, Bank Melli, Tehran, 1959. Plan and sectional model.
label: Caption

text: However, paradoxically enough, modernity as such did
label: Paragraph

text: not emerge more generally in Iran until after the overthrow
label: Paragraph

text: of Mohammad Mosaddegh's democratically elected socialist
label: Title

text: government in 1953, through a coup orchestrated by the US
label: Paragraph

text: Central Intelligence Agency (CIA). This typical Cold War
label: Paragraph

text: intervention on the part of the US entailed the appointment
label: Paragraph

text: of a member of the Pahlavi dynasty as the new Shah of Iran,
label: Paragraph

text: a move that escalated the process of modernization under
label: Paragraph

text: the auspices of a monarchic government. Twenty years
label: Paragraph

text: later, in 1973, on the occasion of a contrived celebration of
label: Paragraph

text: the twenty-fifth centennial of the founding of the Persian
label: Title

text: Empire, two young architect-scholars, Nader Ardalan and
label: Paragraph

text: Laleh Bakhtiar, published their summation of the Sufi
label: Paragraph

text: tradition in Islamic architecture, entitled The Sense of Unity.
label: Paragraph

text: This book, focusing on the cosmological and geometrical
label: Paragraph

text: unity of the Islamic tradition, was a source of inspiration for
label: Paragraph

text: many modernizing Middle Eastern architects, including the
label: Paragraph

text: exceptionally talented Iranian Kamran Diba, who was also
label: Paragraph

text: active as a landscape architect. This moment of state-
label: Paragraph

text: backed revitalization gave rise to the Museum of
label: Paragraph

text: Contemporary Art [506] in Tehran (1967), which was
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Diba in collaboration with Ardalan. Influenced
label: Paragraph

text: by José Luis Sert, Diba organized the museum as a layered
label: Paragraph

text: concatenation of galleries lit by shell-concrete skylights
label: Paragraph

text: mixed with single-light towers of virtually the same section,
label: Paragraph

text: the latter alluding to the traditional ‘wind-catching’ towers
label: Paragraph

text: of the Middle East.
label: Paragraph

text: 506 Diba, Museum of Contemporary Art, Tehran, 1967.
label: Caption

text: Given his connections to the Pahlavi dynasty - he was a
label: Paragraph

text: cousin of Farah Pahlavi, then Empress of Iran - Diba was
label: Paragraph

text: compelled to leave the country with the Islamic Revolution
label: Title

text: of 1979, although he was able to design and supervise the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of the first phase of Shushtar New Town [507],
label: Paragraph

text: built in the Khuzestan Province of Iran between 1974 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1980. Erected as a company town for the workers of a local
label: Caption

text: sugarcane plant, Shushtar was made up of low-rise, high-
label: Paragraph

text: density housing blocks, except for a number of public
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. Built of local brick throughout with shallow brick
label: Paragraph

text: vaults supported by steel joists, these two-storey houses
label: Paragraph

text: were provided with roof terraces, where residents could
label: Paragraph

text: sleep in the open air in high summer. The orthogonal street
label: Caption

text: system, from which cars were excluded, served schools and
label: Paragraph

text: shops, with the town as a whole aggregated around a 100 x
label: Paragraph

text: 100-metre (328 x 328-foot) plaza in the centre of the plan.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite its unfinished state, this was in many respects the
label: Paragraph

text: most successful new town built anywhere in the second half
label: Paragraph

text: of the 20th century, particularly for the way in which it
label: Paragraph

text: combined a rational mode of assembly and construction
label: Paragraph

text: with a traditional way of life.
label: Paragraph

text: 507 Diba, Sushtar New Town, Khuzestan Province, 1974-80.
label: Caption

text: The recent practice of Iranian architects seems to have
label: Paragraph

text: been largely restricted to express themselves through the
label: Paragraph

text: design of middle-class residential apartment buildings, such
label: Paragraph

text: as the speculative development known as the Dollar II
label: Paragraph

text: apartments, built in Tehran to the designs of the Arsh
label: Paragraph

text: Design Group in 2010. This work, clad throughout in
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal timber battens, shields its fenestration behind a
label: Paragraph

text: screen of louvres. An equally expressive materiality is
label: Paragraph

text: evident in an apartment block built at around the same time
label: Paragraph

text: in Mahallat [508] to the designs of Ramin Mehdizadeh and
label: Paragraph

text: faced in a mixture of recycled stone waste and vertical
label: Paragraph

text: timber panelling. Apart from these occasional
label: Caption

text: achievements, the country has been largely incapable of
label: Paragraph

text: cultivating a significant architecture over the past four
label: Paragraph

text: decades. As Farrokh Derakhshani, Director of the Aga Khan
label: Paragraph

text: Award for Architecture, has written:
label: Paragraph

text: 508 Mehdizadeh, apartment building, Mahallat, 2010.
label: Caption

text: Since the mid-1980s the practice of architecture in the world
label: Paragraph

text: has somehow become transnational, and more and more
label: Paragraph

text: architectural projects are being developed and implemented
label: Paragraph

text: by non-local architects ... There are exceptions like Iran,
label: Paragraph

text: however, where foreign firms do not practice and all
label: Paragraph

text: professionals are local. The resultant lack of firsthand
label: Paragraph

text: exchange and the regime’s inability to present the
label: Title

text: ‘imagined’ alternative has pushed the majority of young
label: Paragraph

text: architecture students and architects to copy what they
label: Paragraph

text: encounter on the Internet, without really achieving an
label: Paragraph

text: understanding of the context underlying the projects that
label: Paragraph

text: they are copying. Because of this, the bulk of new
label: Paragraph

text: construction in Iran consists of bad copies of foreign models
label: Paragraph

text: by mediocre architects.
label: Caption

text: Gulf States
label: Title

text: Among the Gulf States none has been more receptive to the
label: Paragraph

text: best that Scandinavia can offer than Kuwait, which has
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned one distinguished Nordic practice after
label: Paragraph

text: another. The first project was the Kuwait Towers [509]
label: Paragraph

text: realized in 1969 by the Danish-Swedish architect Malene
label: Paragraph

text: Bjorn of the engineering firm VBB. Then in 1972 Jarn Utzon
label: Paragraph

text: won the international competition for the Kuwait National
label: Paragraph

text: Assembly. After this brilliant prestigious achievement, the
label: Paragraph

text: Finnish architects Reima and Raili Pietila were commissioned
label: Paragraph

text: to extend the Seif Palace in Kuwait City in order to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate miscellaneous ministries and at the same
label: Paragraph

text: time consciously evolve a possible strategy for creating a
label: Paragraph

text: new Islamic architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: 509 Malene Bjorn (VBB), Kuwait Towers, Kuwait City, 1969.
label: Caption

text: In effect, these three commissions dealt with much the
label: Paragraph

text: same issue, as may be seen in the Kuwait Towers, which
label: Paragraph

text: were completed by VBB in 1976. This striking composition of
label: Paragraph

text: three towers of differing heights, sited on a promontory
label: Caption

text: jutting out onto the bay of Kuwait, echoed the utopian
label: Paragraph

text: phantasmagoria of Bruno Taut’s A/pinearchitektur of 1919.
label: Paragraph

text: Two of the three towers carry spheres of different diameters;
label: Paragraph

text: the two spheres that constitute the highest forms
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate a restaurant and a viewing platform, while
label: Paragraph

text: the single sphere of the second-highest tower simply
label: Paragraph

text: functions as a water reservoir. The third tower is without a
label: Paragraph

text: sphere and accommodates devices to illuminate the other
label: Paragraph

text: two towers at night. These towers have become a singular
label: Paragraph

text: image of Kuwait in much the same way as the Eiffel Tower is
label: Paragraph

text: associated with Paris.
label: Paragraph

text: Utzon’s Kuwait National Assembly [510, 511] would
label: Paragraph

text: prove to be outstanding from both an engineering and an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural standpoint, since the two pre-cast concrete
label: Paragraph

text: roofs covering the ceremonial hall and the assembly are
label: Paragraph

text: both examples of ingenious post-tensioned, folded-plate,
label: Paragraph

text: catenary construction. As such, they proved to be as difficult
label: Paragraph

text: to hold in place during construction as the pre-cast shell
label: Paragraph

text: concrete roofs of the same architect’s Sydney Opera House.
label: Caption

text: The rest of this complex is essentially a two-storey mat
label: Paragraph

text: building, pierced by courtyards at regular intervals, a format
label: Paragraph

text: that loosely echoes the top-lit, interstitial form of the
label: Paragraph

text: typically labyrinthic pre-industrial Arab city. Although this
label: Paragraph

text: structure was damaged during the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait
label: Paragraph

text: in 1990-91, it has since been repaired and refurbished.
label: Paragraph

text: 510 Utzon, Kuwait National Assembly, Kuwait City, 1982.
label: Caption

text: 511 Utzon, Kuwait National Assembly under construction, Kuwait City, 1982.
label: Caption

text: One of the most extraordinary complexes realized in the
label: Paragraph

text: Middle East in the second half of the 20th century was Qatar
label: Paragraph

text: University [512], located 10 kilometres (6 miles) north of
label: Paragraph

text: Doha city and built to the competition designs of the
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian but Paris-based architect Kamal El-Kafrawi. This
label: Paragraph

text: geometrically consistent, two-storey mat building is made
label: Paragraph

text: up of repetitive, pre-cast concrete elements designed in
label: Paragraph

text: association with Ove Arup and Partners. These units are
label: Paragraph

text: based on two forms - an octagon 8.4 metres (27% feet)
label: Paragraph

text: wide and a square 3.5 metres (11 feet) wide - the two being
label: Paragraph

text: occasionally set adjacent to one another and connected by
label: Paragraph

text: two squares to form larger units. Each octagon is capped by
label: Paragraph

text: a cubic windcatcher with louvred openings. The speed and
label: Paragraph

text: efficiency of the construction system enabled the first
label: Paragraph

text: phase, covering a wide area, to be built and equipped in five
label: Paragraph

text: years (1980-85). Although the lower floors of the octagons
label: Paragraph

text: are of diagrid construction, the upper rooms are capped by
label: Paragraph

text: inclined planes beneath the windcatchers over each
label: Paragraph

text: chamber. The elevations of these elements, opening to the
label: Paragraph

text: courts, are covered by louvred timber screens.
label: Caption

text: 512 El-Kafrawi, Qatar University, Doha, Qatar, 1980-85.
label: Caption

text: Masdar City in Abu Dhabi, designed by Norman Foster, is
label: Paragraph

text: a mixed-use, low-rise, high-density development connected
label: Paragraph

text: to the capital city and the international airport by the
label: Paragraph

text: existing road and rail infrastructure. Within the city all
label: Paragraph

text: movement (apart from walking) will be by a rapid transit
label: Paragraph

text: system, since fossil-fuel vehicles will be prohibited.
label: Paragraph

text: Surrounding this densely inhabited square grid in the desert
label: Paragraph

text: will be photovoltaic farms and irrigated plantations,
label: Paragraph

text: intended to make Masdar self-sufficient in energy. Covering
label: Paragraph

text: 600 hectares (2.3 square miles) and theoretically capable of
label: Paragraph

text: accommodating 90,000 people, Masdar is predicated on the
label: Paragraph

text: time-honoured design principles of Arab settlements,
label: Paragraph

text: namely a compact, dense urban fabric with narrow streets
label: Paragraph

text: that serve to shield the interstitial spaces from the sun.
label: Paragraph

text: Chapter 3
label: Title

text: Asia and the Pacific
label: Title

text: The vast span of this geographical domain can perhaps only
label: Paragraph

text: be fully appreciated if one recognizes that it takes up three
label: Paragraph

text: volumes within the ten-volume survey entitled World
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture 1900-2000: A Critical Mosaic, which was
label: Paragraph

text: published by the China Architecture and Building Press at
label: Caption

text: the millennium. The territory covered in this account begins
label: Paragraph

text: with the development of modern architecture in South Asia
label: Title

text: after the declaration of Indian independence in 1947,
label: Paragraph

text: together with the partitioning of the former colony into
label: Paragraph

text: India, with its largely Hindu population, and the
label: Paragraph

text: predominantly Muslim societies of East Pakistan and West
label: Title

text: Pakistan, later to become Bangladesh. Modern architecture
label: Paragraph

text: in India was largely championed by the charismatic first
label: Paragraph

text: prime minister of the country, Jawaharlal Nehru, who,
label: Paragraph

text: having received an elite British education, returned to India
label: Paragraph

text: in 1912 to become the leader of the left wing of the Indian
label: Paragraph

text: National Congress. Thereafter, Nehru remained committed
label: Paragraph

text: to the development of India as a secular, multi-faith,
label: Paragraph

text: independent nation state. The implementation of this vision
label: Paragraph

text: caused him to become a patron of modern architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: which he saw as being capable of both embodying and
label: Paragraph

text: representing the Indian modern project. At the same time he
label: Paragraph

text: was interested in a modern manner of building that was not
label: Paragraph

text: only appropriate to the monsoon climate, but was also
label: Paragraph

text: enriched by the cultural legacies of the Hindu and Mughal
label: Paragraph

text: traditions. This led to his unequivocal support for the new
label: Paragraph

text: Punjabi capital of Chandigarh, designed and realized by Le
label: Caption

text: Corbusier, along with his patronage of a rising generation of
label: Paragraph

text: Indian architects who are prominently featured here, namely
label: Paragraph

text: Achyut Kanvinde, Charles Correa, Balkrishna Doshi and Raj
label: Title

text: Rewal. These talented professionals were followed by the
label: Paragraph

text: equally gifted representatives of the post-Nehru generation,
label: Paragraph

text: such as Bijoy Jain, Sanjay Mohe and Rahul Mehrotra.
label: Paragraph

text: The more varied developments in the other nations that
label: Paragraph

text: make up the South Asia subcontinent -Pakistan, Bangladesh
label: Title

text: and Sri Lanka - are in part due to the absence of a
label: Paragraph

text: comparable modernizing vision of the same power and
label: Paragraph

text: conviction as that of Nehru. Nevertheless, in the case of
label: Paragraph

text: Bangladesh, we have to nevertheless acknowledge the
label: Paragraph

text: equally exceptional leadership of the master architect
label: Paragraph

text: Muzharul Islam, who was not only a sensitive architect in his
label: Paragraph

text: own right, but also the primary inspiration for the successive
label: Paragraph

text: generation of Bengali architects, such as Kashef Chowdhury,
label: Paragraph

text: Marina Tabassum and Rafiq Azam. Similarly, the leading
label: Paragraph

text: Sinhalese architects who emerged in the 1950s, Minnette de
label: Paragraph

text: Silva and Geoffrey Bawa, would make seminal contributions
label: Paragraph

text: to the architectural culture and identity of Ceylon prior to its
label: Paragraph

text: declaration of independence in 1972 and its transformation
label: Title

text: into the independent state of Sri Lanka.
label: Paragraph

text: The development of a similarly inflected modern
label: Paragraph

text: architectural culture came into being much later in China,
label: Paragraph

text: partly because of its relatively undeveloped state prior to
label: Paragraph

text: the Second World War and then the subsequent civil war,
label: Paragraph

text: culminating in the triumph of the Communist Revolution in
label: Paragraph

text: 1949. Despite the pioneering efforts of the architect and
label: Paragraph

text: scholar Liang Sicheng in the late 1930s and 1940s to survey
label: Paragraph

text: and document traditional Chinese architecture, and his
label: Paragraph

text: subsequent attempts to dissuade Mao Zedong from
label: Paragraph

text: following the Socialist Realism of the Soviet line in
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, it proved impossible to overcome the cultural
label: Paragraph

text: hard line of the party. Given the reductive nature of
label: Paragraph

text: capitalist development, it is ironic that the cultivation of a
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture in China ultimately stems from Deng
label: Paragraph

text: Xiaoping’s opening up of the country to trade with the West
label: Paragraph

text: in 1983. Immediately after this Western corporate practices
label: Paragraph

text: arrived in China en masse to design and build one
label: Paragraph

text: spectacular building after another, while the central
label: Paragraph

text: committee of the Chinese government pursued a policy of
label: Paragraph

text: rapid large-scale urbanization, ultimately leading to an
label: Paragraph

text: environmentally unsustainable, maximizing pattern of urban
label: Paragraph

text: development virtually bereft of any redeeming features.
label: Paragraph

text: This policy has since been drastically changed as much
label: Paragraph

text: more attention is now being paid to the resuscitation of rural
label: Paragraph

text: China, with the restoration and economic expansion of
label: Paragraph

text: traditional settlements and villages. One of the
label: Paragraph

text: consequences of this has been the emergence of a new
label: Paragraph

text: generation of Chinese architects who have come to the fore
label: Paragraph

text: by designing and building exceptionally sensitive and
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate works in remote parts of the country.
label: Paragraph

text: A generalizable modern architectural culture has yet to
label: Paragraph

text: emerge in South East Asia. For most of the countries making
label: Paragraph

text: up the labyrinthic complexity of this region, including even
label: Paragraph

text: the authoritarian welfare state of Singapore, the cultivation
label: Paragraph

text: of a sophisticated culture of architecture has proven elusive.
label: Paragraph

text: Part of the reason for this has been the war-torn nature of
label: Paragraph

text: the region, as the Singaporean master architect William Lim
label: Paragraph

text: has written:
label: Paragraph

text: In the decades after World War II, the states of South Asia
label: Paragraph

text: became independent after the departure of colonial powers
label: Paragraph

text: - some like Malaysia and Philippines, in a relatively peaceful
label: Paragraph

text: manner, while others only after tragic and brutal struggles.
label: Paragraph

text: Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia were the unfortunate victims
label: Paragraph

text: of the cold war. These countries were to witness half a
label: Paragraph

text: century of great turmoil and ideological divisions. They have
label: Paragraph

text: been engulfed by an extremely bloody form of warfare and
label: Paragraph

text: destruction.
label: Paragraph

text: This traumatic experience, along with the fact that large
label: Paragraph

text: parts of South East Asia have since time immemorial been
label: Paragraph

text: water-based societies, has made it extremely difficult for
label: Paragraph

text: South East Asia to evolve and sustain a truly compelling
label: Paragraph

text: culture of modern architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Within this context Japan stands out as a civilization that
label: Paragraph

text: was able to transform itself in the space of half a century
label: Paragraph

text: from a feudal society into a modernized, quasi-industrialized
label: Paragraph

text: nation state, capable, as it happened, of overwhelming the
label: Paragraph

text: Russian imperial fleet in a single encounter during the
label: Paragraph

text: Russo-Japanese War of 1905, thereby paving the way for its
label: Paragraph

text: emergence as an East Asian colonizing power. After
label: Paragraph

text: occupying Manchuria in northeast Asia in 1931, Japan
label: Paragraph

text: launched the idea of its so-called Greater East Asia Co-
label: Paragraph

text: Prosperity Sphere, a concept created and promulgated for
label: Paragraph

text: Asian territories that it occupied, which would further
label: Paragraph

text: amplify its imperial ambitions and bring it into bitter conflict
label: Paragraph

text: not only with China but also more problematically, after
label: Paragraph

text: Pearl Harbor, with the United States. In 1945 Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: expansionism ended with the country being the involuntary
label: Paragraph

text: testing ground for the first use of the atomic bomb. The
label: Paragraph

text: post-war reconstruction of Japan enabled it to play a leading
label: Paragraph

text: role in the development of modern architecture, which
label: Paragraph

text: accounts for its inclusion in Part III of this history. However,
label: Paragraph

text: this section features the work of two Japanese architects
label: Paragraph

text: who belong to quite different generations: Fumihiko Maki
label: Paragraph

text: and the much younger Kengo Kuma. The first is celebrated
label: Paragraph

text: in this overview for the vitality and refinement of his
label: Paragraph

text: practice while the second is acknowledged for the particular
label: Paragraph

text: way in which he integrates traditional Japanese crafts into
label: Paragraph

text: his architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Korea has had a time-honoured role of acting as a
label: Paragraph

text: conduit for the introduction of Chinese civilization into
label: Title

text: Japan, but was also the first Asian country to be annexed by
label: Paragraph

text: Japan as early as 1910. Half a century later Korea became
label: Paragraph

text: the site of a bitter conflict lasting from 1950 to 1953
label: Paragraph

text: between the Communist government of North Korea, under
label: Paragraph

text: Soviet influence, and the American-aligned South Korea.
label: Paragraph

text: This war culminated in an uneasy peace, with the stalemate
label: Paragraph

text: of a demilitarized zone separating North and South Korea
label: Title

text: along the 38th parallel north.
label: Paragraph

text: This continental trajectory concludes with two
label: Paragraph

text: independent nations that throughout the first half of the
label: Paragraph

text: 19th century represented the most remote extent of the
label: Paragraph

text: British Empire, namely Australia and New Zealand. The first
label: Paragraph

text: significant architectural intervention in the largely barren
label: Paragraph

text: expanse of the former was the foundation of the Australian
label: Paragraph

text: capital of Canberra in 1912, designed by the American
label: Paragraph

text: architects Marion Mahony and Walter Burley Griffin. While
label: Paragraph

text: these same architects came up with a proto-modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture for Australia as early as 1917, a general culture
label: Paragraph

text: of modernism did not begin to evolve there until the 1950s,
label: Paragraph

text: when it emerged out of the domestic work of such architects
label: Paragraph

text: as Peter Muller, Ken Woolley, Robin Boyd and Harry Seidler.
label: Paragraph

text: A similar delayed effect also occurred in New Zealand; a
label: Paragraph

text: rigorous modern architecture appeared for the first time in
label: Paragraph

text: 1940 with the work of the émigré Austrian architect Ernst
label: Paragraph

text: Plischke.
label: Paragraph

text: India
label: Title

text: The India of today faces a growing phenomenon
label: Paragraph

text: perpetuating the reappearance of ancient practices in
label: Paragraph

text: numerous temples and an entire range of institutional
label: Paragraph

text: buildings being constructed across the country ... Many
label: Paragraph

text: religious buildings are powered by capital from the Indian
label: Paragraph

text: Diaspora which frequently places nationalism at the center
label: Paragraph

text: of its agenda, blurring the lines between religion, politics
label: Paragraph

text: and ungrounded or misplaced nostalgia. Furthermore with
label: Paragraph

text: globalization, communities, especially marginalized ones,
label: Paragraph

text: have become increasingly concerned about threats to their
label: Paragraph

text: identities as well as to their autonomy. This phenomenon
label: Paragraph

text: questions the very foundation of the nation state and its
label: Paragraph

text: time-tested capacity to absorb influences from the wider
label: Paragraph

text: world in constructing, enriching and perpetuating its own
label: Paragraph

text: identity.
label: Paragraph

text: Raoul Mehrotra, Architecture in India since 1900 (2011)1
label: Caption

text: We may date the beginning of modern architecture in India
label: Paragraph

text: with the return of Achyut Kanvinde to Delhi after his
label: Paragraph

text: graduation from Harvard, where he had been sent by
label: Paragraph

text: Jawaharlal Nehru (the first Prime Minister of India) to study
label: Paragraph

text: with Marcel Breuer and Walter Gropius. After he opened his
label: Paragraph

text: office in New Delhi in 1955, Kanvinde’s practice began to
label: Paragraph

text: expand around 1960 with the design of the Indian Institute
label: Paragraph

text: of Technology in Kanpur [513]. The design of this campus
label: Paragraph

text: may be seen as a synthesis of Le Corbusier’s 1950 master
label: Paragraph

text: plan for Chandigarh and Louis Kahn’s monumental brick
label: Caption

text: syntax of ‘servant’ and ‘served’ spaces, as first elaborated
label: Paragraph

text: in his Richards Laboratories, completed in Philadelphia in
label: Paragraph

text: 1961. Thereafter Kanvinde’s Kahnian approach would be
label: Paragraph

text: developed in a number of major megastructural works
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned by the Indian state: the National Dairy Plant
label: Paragraph

text: at Mehsana in the state of Gujarat (1970-73), the Nehru
label: Paragraph

text: Science Centre at Mumbai (1978-82) and the National
label: Paragraph

text: Science Centre, New Delhi (1986-90). All of these works
label: Caption

text: were predicated on distinguishing between servant and
label: Paragraph

text: served elements, both functionally and expressively, at
label: Paragraph

text: various scales, with Kanvinde giving the servant units a
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive turreted format reminiscent of the howdahs
label: Paragraph

text: found in Mughal architecture, such as the Agra Fort and
label: Paragraph

text: Emperor Akbar the Great’s 16th-century ideal city of
label: Paragraph

text: Fatehpur Sikri.
label: Paragraph

text: 513 Kanvinde, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, 1966. Section.
label: Caption

text: The New Delhi architect Raj Rewal elaborated a similar
label: Paragraph

text: New Brutalist format comprising a reinforced-concrete frame
label: Paragraph

text: with brick infill over the course of his extensive work as a
label: Paragraph

text: public architect from the late 1960s onwards. Despite his
label: Paragraph

text: distinguished career in this field, Rewal was to make his
label: Paragraph

text: initial contribution to the modern Indian tradition as a
label: Paragraph

text: housing architect, most particularly as a designer of low-
label: Paragraph

text: rise, high-density schemes. In this domain, he has been
label: Paragraph

text: exemplary, achieving works that were certainly as
label: Paragraph

text: distinguished as Atelier 5’s Siedlung Halen in Switzerland of
label: Paragraph

text: 1960, or Roland Rainer’s Puchenau housing complex, under
label: Paragraph

text: construction throughout the 1960s near Linz, Austria.
label: Paragraph

text: Rewal'’s first notable residential schemes were his Sheikh
label: Paragraph

text: Sarai housing (1970-82), Zakir Hussain housing (1979-84)
label: Paragraph

text: and his magisterial Asian Games Village housing [514, 515]
label: Paragraph

text: built in New Delhi (1980-82). With this work, Rewal was able
label: Paragraph

text: to achieve a low-rise, high-density pattern with more
label: Paragraph

text: extensive urban connotations than had hitherto been
label: Paragraph

text: achieved elsewhere. In his Asian Games housing Rewal
label: Paragraph

text: designed 500 units on a 35-acre (14-hectare) site,
label: Paragraph

text: engendering a labyrinth of narrow, shaded pedestrian
label: Paragraph

text: streets combined with judiciously placed courtyards.
label: Paragraph

text: Borrowing vernacular tropes from Rajasthani villages,
label: Paragraph

text: Rewal’s Asian Games housing was punctuated by units
label: Paragraph

text: bridging over gateways so as to mark the transitions from
label: Paragraph

text: one neighbourhood to the next.
label: Paragraph

text: 514 Rewal, Asian Games Village, New Delhi, 1980-82.
label: Caption

text: 515 Rewal, Asian Games Village, New Delhi, 1980-82.
label: Caption

text: After graduating from MIT Charles Correa returned to
label: Paragraph

text: India to establish his practice in Mumbai in 1958. Despite
label: Paragraph

text: his long-standing regard for Le Corbusier, Correa, like
label: Paragraph

text: Kanvinde and Rewal, looked to Kahn as his point of
label: Paragraph

text: departure, as is evident from his first major commission, the
label: Paragraph

text: Gandhi Smarak Sangrahalaya memorial (1958-63) [517],
label: Caption

text: derived from Kahn’s Trenton Bath House complex, built
label: Paragraph

text: outside Trenton, New Jersey, USA, in 1959. Correa’s
label: Caption

text: subsequent contribution to housing in India throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s ranged from the design of one-off middle-class
label: Paragraph

text: houses, to the building of a series of modest, low-rise, high-
label: Paragraph

text: density housing schemes. The one exception to Correa’s
label: Paragraph

text: low-cost, low-rise housing practice was his twenty-seven-
label: Paragraph

text: storey Kanchanjunga high-rise, completed on the Cumbaila
label: Caption

text: Hill in Mumbai in 1983 [516]. This unique tower block
label: Paragraph

text: comprised thirty-two large luxury apartments stacked in
label: Paragraph

text: pairs, with the duplex units stepped down or up in section
label: Paragraph

text: so as to provide two-storey external terraces at the corners
label: Paragraph

text: of the tower.
label: Paragraph

text: 516 Correa, Kanchanjunga Tower, Mumbai, 1983.

label: Caption

text: Of virtually the same generation, Balkrishna Doshi
label: Paragraph

text: worked in Le Corbusier’s Paris studio in the early 1950s, first
label: Paragraph

text: on the plan for Chandigarh and then on the three buildings
label: Caption

text: that Le Corbusier designed for Anmedabad, the construction
label: Paragraph

text: of which Doshi would supervise after his return to India in
label: Paragraph

text: 1955. Seven years later he began his own practice with a
label: Paragraph

text: commission for the Institute of Indology in Ahmedabad,
label: Caption

text: completed in 1962. Doshi finally transcended his long
label: Paragraph

text: apprenticeship with Le Corbusier in 1981, with the design of
label: Paragraph

text: his Sangath studio compound [519], comprising eleven
label: Paragraph

text: semicircular, shell concrete vaults partially locked one over
label: Caption

text: the other, accommodating his Vastu Shilpa office, where he
label: Paragraph

text: continues to practise. Doshi’s most successful attempt to
label: Paragraph

text: provide low-rise housing for the poor in India was his two-
label: Paragraph

text: storey Aranya residential quarter built in Indore, Madhya
label: Caption

text: Pradesh, in 1986 [518, 520]. Each dwelling in this dense,
label: Paragraph

text: two-storey urban complex, built of concrete block, rendered
label: Caption

text: with cement and painted red, was equipped with two
label: Paragraph

text: essential installations - a toilet and a kitchen sink - both
label: Paragraph

text: linked to the basic infrastructure, water supply and the
label: Paragraph

text: sewer system.
label: Paragraph

text: Rahul Mehrotra is perhaps the most prominent Indian
label: Paragraph

text: architect of the post-Nehru generation, which has had to
label: Paragraph

text: confront the political transformation of India from an
label: Title

text: enlightened, underdeveloped welfare state to a neo-liberal,
label: Paragraph

text: digital economy, inseparable from the rapid, but
label: Paragraph

text: nonetheless uneven development of the continent today.
label: Paragraph

text: This techno-economic shift has been accompanied by the
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of an exceptionally sophisticated Indian modern
label: Title

text: architecture, evident in such works as Sanjay Mohe’s NSR-
label: Paragraph

text: GIV Center at the Indian Institute of Management,
label: Paragraph

text: Bangalore, of 2003 [521] and in Mehrotra’s Tata Institute of
label: Paragraph

text: Social Sciences (TISS) University Campus in Tuljapur,
label: Paragraph

text: Maharashtra [522, 523], of the same date. Both of these
label: Paragraph

text: works are sensitively integrated with their respective
label: Paragraph

text: landscapes, either by syncopated monopitch roofs or the
label: Paragraph

text: rhythmic pattern of wind towers. The articulation of bonded
label: Paragraph

text: masonry also plays a major role in the expressive character
label: Paragraph

text: of these works, concrete block in the case of the Bangalore
label: Paragraph

text: research centre and the local stone in the case of the
label: Paragraph

text: Tuljapur campus.
label: Paragraph

text: 521 Mohe, NSR-GIV Center at Indian Institute of Management, Bangalore, 2003.
label: Caption

text: 522 Mehrotra, Tata Institute of Social Sciences Rural Campus, Tuljapur, 2004.
label: Caption

text: 523 Mehrotra, Tata Institute of Social Sciences Rural Campus, Tuljapur, 2004.

label: Paragraph

text: Three later works by Mehrotra further testify to the
label: Paragraph

text: diversity and refinement of his socio-tectonic vision: the
label: Paragraph

text: ongoing project of the so-called Hathigaon [524], or
label: Paragraph

text: ‘elephant village’, built on an arid plain close to the Amber
label: Paragraph

text: Palace near Jaipur; the six-storey, free-standing KMC office
label: Caption

text: building [525, 526], erected outside of Hyderabad in 2012;
label: Caption

text: and a monumental cantilevered metal roof, built in 2003 on
label: Paragraph

text: a rocky outcrop overlooking a tea plantation in Coonoor.
label: Caption

text: 524 Mehrotra, Hathigaon, Jaipur, 2010.
label: Caption

text: 525 Mehrotra, KMC Corporate Office, Hyderabad, 2012.
label: Caption

text: 526 Mehrotra, KMC Corporate Office, Hyderabad, 2012.
label: Caption

text: The Hathigaon is an improbable low-rise settlement built
label: Paragraph

text: to house 100 elephants with their mahouts (caretakers),
label: Paragraph

text: along with their families, within a relatively large compound
label: Paragraph

text: of two-storey houses, where each house is equipped with an
label: Paragraph

text: adjoining stable for the elephant. The entire complex is built
label: Paragraph

text: of local rubble stone. A key ecological feature of this project
label: Paragraph

text: is the harvesting of rainwater essential for the bathing and
label: Paragraph

text: cooling of the elephants, which also enables the irrigation of
label: Paragraph

text: an arid site so that it provides enough water to satisfy the
label: Paragraph

text: community, including animals’ outsized thirst. The flat roofs
label: Paragraph

text: of the patio houses are shielded from the sun by a layer of
label: Paragraph

text: light-weight, corrugated-iron roofing, which doubles as a
label: Paragraph

text: system of racks for storing hay. This not only provides an
label: Paragraph

text: additional layer of insulation, but is also a convenient
label: Paragraph

text: hayloft from which, with the aid of their trunks, the
label: Paragraph

text: elephants may help themselves.
label: Paragraph

text: Mehrotra’s high-tech, curtain-walled KMC office building
label: Paragraph

text: is surrounded on all four sides by an equally high-tech green
label: Paragraph

text: buffer zone that shields the building from the full force of
label: Paragraph

text: the sun. This is, in effect, an all-round conservatory
label: Paragraph

text: accommodating a rich variety of plants suspended within an
label: Paragraph

text: aluminium trellis and fed by hydroponic irrigation. This
label: Paragraph

text: space is equipped with an automatic misting system, which
label: Paragraph

text: not only sustains the plants but also cools the building
label: Paragraph

text: through an artificial microclimate. The presence of
label: Paragraph

text: gardeners, employed to look after the plants, has the effect
label: Paragraph

text: of juxtaposing different classes of workers on either side of
label: Paragraph

text: the curtain wall. This not only enlivens the building but also
label: Paragraph

text: serves, in some sense, to mitigate the caste and class
label: Paragraph

text: differences that still prevail in India.
label: Paragraph

text: Mehrotra’s comprehensive and wide ranging survey
label: Title

text: Architecture in India since 1990 (2011) appropriately ends
label: Title

text: with a stone temple [527] built to the designs of Sameep
label: Paragraph

text: Padora Architects near Wadeshwar village on the outskirts of
label: Paragraph

text: Pune in (2010). Largely built by village labour (shiram dan),
label: Paragraph

text: this temple was constructed of precisely dressed local
label: Paragraph

text: stone. The architects played a crucial role in determining
label: Paragraph

text: the scale of the stupa (shrine) and in detailing the
label: Paragraph

text: orthogonal timber portico that allows priests to enter into
label: Caption

text: the holiest part of the stupa. A stepped seating area in front
label: Paragraph

text: of the temple transforms a communal greensward into a
label: Paragraph

text: sacred space.
label: Paragraph

text: 527 Padora, Shiv Temple, Wadeshwar, near Pune, 2010. Section.
label: Caption

text: The other major talent to emerge in India in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1990s was Bijoy Jain, and his firm, Studio Mumbai, adopted
label: Paragraph

text: a unique ‘hands-on’ approach to design and construction,
label: Paragraph

text: thereby returning to the William Morris ideal of overcoming
label: Paragraph

text: the division of labour separating architects from craftsmen.
label: Paragraph

text: Having been trained as an architect in the United States,
label: Paragraph

text: where he worked for some time in the model shop of the Los
label: Paragraph

text: Angeles office of Richard Meier, Jain returned to India to
label: Paragraph

text: establish himself as a latter-day master builder. In this role
label: Paragraph

text: he worked not only as a designer but also as the coordinator
label: Paragraph

text: of a team of highly versatile Rajasthani carpenters, who
label: Paragraph

text: were to prove to be as capable of precise fabrication in steel
label: Paragraph

text: and ceramics as they were of executing traditional
label: Paragraph

text: components in wood, such as doors, windows and detailed
label: Paragraph

text: cabinetwork of all kinds. Through this uniquely integrated
label: Paragraph

text: approach, Studio Mumbai would not only demonstrate
label: Paragraph

text: mastery over the aforementioned crafts, but also equal skill
label: Paragraph

text: in the handling of masonry and milled stonework in
label: Paragraph

text: conjunction, if needs be, with paint and coloured plaster. As
label: Paragraph

text: Peter Wilson has written: Studio Mumbai's locus is in fact
label: Paragraph

text: not even a building, more a tin-roof held aloft by scaffolding
label: Paragraph

text: poles—A palm tree nonchalantly grows through the middle.
label: Paragraph

text: From the roofs hang fans and fluorescent tubes (working
label: Caption

text: through the night is not unknown, product continues seven
label: Paragraph

text: days a week). In May the roof gets an extra plastic layer in
label: Paragraph

text: preparation for the monsoon. Below the canopy is the
label: Paragraph

text: production stage, open on three sides, with a backdrop wall,
label: Paragraph

text: lined warehouse-like with materials—chairs wrapped for
label: Paragraph

text: shipping, flasks of pigment looking like an arsenal of colour
label: Paragraph

text: awaiting the Indian Holy festival, a tray of hand-made brass
label: Paragraph

text: switches, logs, slabs of dark uncut wood, ceramic basins,
label: Caption

text: etc. Studio Mumbai is a one-stop shop. They deliver
label: Paragraph

text: everything, the entire project, worldwide when necessary ...
label: Paragraph

text: Many of the craftsmen are traditional Rajasthanian
label: Paragraph

text: carpenters, sitting on the pressed-earth floor, holding a
label: Paragraph

text: piece of wood between their toes, chiselling a precise
label: Paragraph

text: dovetail joint ... Few drawings are produced. Details often
label: Paragraph

text: evolved on site and in dialogue with the craftsmen
label: Paragraph

text: entrusted with the realization. Bijoy Jain has issued
label: Paragraph

text: notebooks not only to carpenters but also to electricians and
label: Paragraph

text: other studio collaborators ... the architect’s role is to select
label: Paragraph

text: —a surprising reversal of the more familiar hierarchies of
label: Paragraph

text: invention, description and implementation.
label: Paragraph

text: At the same time, one has to recognize that, like Morris
label: Paragraph

text: before them, the output of Studio Mumbai has largely been
label: Paragraph

text: in the service of the élite in as much as they have built a
label: Paragraph

text: number of exquisitely detailed luxurious houses in the state
label: Paragraph

text: of Maharashtra, particularly the Tara and Palmyria Houses of
label: Paragraph

text: 2005 and 2007 [530, 531] respectively. The Tara House is a
label: Paragraph

text: rather traditional, low-pitched roof structure on a grand
label: Paragraph

text: scale, built around an underground water tank and
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by lush vegetation. In contrast, the Palmyria
label: Paragraph

text: compound consists of two long and elegantly planned flat-
label: Paragraph

text: roofed, timber-framed villas, their sides covered with timber
label: Paragraph

text: louvres so as to expose their subdivided interiors to cooling
label: Paragraph

text: breezes coming off the nearby beach and ocean.
label: Paragraph

text: 528 Mehrotra, Lilavati Lalbhai Library, CEPT, Anmedabad, 2017.
label: Caption

text: 529 Mehrotra, Lilavati Lalbhai Library, CEPT, Anmedabad, 2017.
label: Caption

text: 530 Studio Mumbai, Palmyria House, Nandgaon, 2007. Site plan.
label: Caption
