text: Pakistan
label: Title

text: After the departure of the British in 1947, India had the
label: Paragraph

text: fortune of being inspired by Nehru’s modernizing,
label: Paragraph

text: democratic vision, in which modern architecture was
label: Paragraph

text: destined to play a seminal role. Pakistan, however, had its
label: Paragraph

text: latent modernizing drive tempered by a military government
label: Paragraph

text: that until the early 21st century kept itself in power from
label: Paragraph

text: one generation to the next. A decade after partition, in
label: Paragraph

text: 1958, the military leader of the time, Ayub Khan, decided to
label: Paragraph

text: shift the capital from Karachi to Rawalpindi, where the state
label: Paragraph

text: would create adjacent to it the totally new city of Islamabad
label: Paragraph

text: on a gridiron plan prepared by the international planning
label: Paragraph

text: consultancy Doxiadis Associates, based in Athens. A number
label: Paragraph

text: of other foreign architects were involved in the design of
label: Paragraph

text: Islamabad, most notably the American architect Edward
label: Paragraph

text: Durell Stone, whose pyramidal presidential complex in the
label: Paragraph

text: centre of the plan is the most successful monumental work
label: Paragraph

text: of his career. Stone’s presidential residence dominates the
label: Paragraph

text: principal axis of the main square with the Assembly and
label: Paragraph

text: Foreign Office set at either end of the cross-axis. In the
label: Paragraph

text: development of this work Stone persuaded Ayub Khan to
label: Paragraph

text: avoid any literal evocation of Mughal architecture, and a
label: Paragraph

text: similar, somewhat secular interpretation seems to have led
label: Paragraph

text: to the selection of the Turkish architect Vedat Dalokay for
label: Paragraph

text: his entry to the 1970 international competition for the
label: Paragraph

text: design of the Shah Faisal national mosque in Islamabad
label: Caption

text: [532]. This highly refined, largely abstract work features
label: Paragraph

text: four inclined concrete roof plates covering the large space
label: Caption

text: of the mosque, attended by four equally abstract minarets.
label: Paragraph

text: 532 Dalokay, Shah Faisal Mosque, Islamabad, 1970-86.
label: Caption

text: Until the establishment of a department of architecture in
label: Paragraph

text: West Pakistan University of Engineering and Technology,
label: Title

text: Lahore, in 1965, Pakistan's architects were mostly trained
label: Paragraph

text: outside the country, either in the United Kingdom or United
label: Paragraph

text: States. Among these foreign-trained architects were Habib
label: Paragraph

text: Fida Ali and Yasmeen Lari. One of the finest works of Fida
label: Paragraph

text: Ali’s initial career was the Burmah-Shell oil company
label: Paragraph

text: headquarters in Karachi, won in competition in 1973 and
label: Paragraph

text: subsequently carefully developed and detailed, although not
label: Paragraph

text: finally completed until 1978 [532]. Removed from the
label: Paragraph

text: dramatic character of Fida Ali’s early work, Yasmeen Lari’s
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was equally finely detailed as is evident from
label: Paragraph

text: the houses that she built in the 1970s, including the
label: Paragraph

text: Commodore Haq house and her own house, both in Karachi.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps her most sensitive work to date has been the
label: Paragraph

text: Anguri Bagh housing in Lahore, which, save for its
label: Paragraph

text: underlying concrete superstructure, is faced entirely in brick
label: Paragraph

text: in much the same spirit as Ray Rewal’s Asian Games Village
label: Paragraph

text: housing, New Delhi (1980-82).
label: Caption

text: 533 Fida Ali, Pakistan Burmah-Shell Headquarters, Karachi, 1973-78.
label: Caption

text: Four other architects played key roles in the initial
label: Paragraph

text: development of Pakistan’s modern architecture: the locally
label: Title

text: trained Nayyar Ali Dada, who began his career by designing
label: Paragraph

text: and realizing the monumental Shakir Ali Auditorium in the
label: Paragraph

text: National College of Art in Lahore; the American William
label: Title

text: Perry, who designed the precisely detailed Business
label: Paragraph

text: Administration Institute in Karachi; the ubiquitous French
label: Paragraph

text: architect Michel Ecochard, who designed a Neo-Corbusian
label: Paragraph

text: complex for Karachi University; and finally the American
label: Paragraph

text: practice of Payette Associates, which designed the 700-bed
label: Paragraph

text: Aga Khan University Hospital in Karachi, under construction
label: Caption

text: from the mid-1970s to 1985. This treatment centre and
label: Paragraph

text: medical school has since been greatly expanded.
label: Paragraph

text: Bangladesh
label: Title

text: The leading architect of the post-independence generation
label: Paragraph

text: in Bangladesh was Muzharul Islam, who, after the 1971 war
label: Paragraph

text: of liberation, played a major role in devising a modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that would be appropriate to the heavy
label: Paragraph

text: monsoon climate of Bengal [534]. Throughout his life Islam
label: Paragraph

text: served intermittently as an architectural adviser to the
label: Paragraph

text: government, and this eventually led to the appointment of
label: Paragraph

text: Louis Kahn as the architect of the national assembly
label: Paragraph

text: building, the Sher-e-Bangla Nagar [535], finally completed
label: Paragraph

text: in Dhaka in 1963. Through his Chetana research group,
label: Paragraph

text: Islam combined architectural discourse with the cultural
label: Paragraph

text: aspirations of the 19th-century Bengal Renaissance, as
label: Paragraph

text: personified by the writer, musician and artist Rabindranath
label: Paragraph

text: Tagore, to which Islam added a left-wing critical sensibility
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate to his epoch.
label: Paragraph

text: 534 Islam, architect’s residence, Dhaka, 1969. Section.
label: Caption

text: 535 Kahn, National Assembly Building, Sher-e-Bangla Nagar, Dhaka, 1963.
label: Caption

text: Among the current generation of Bengali architects to
label: Paragraph

text: inherit this legacy was the partnership of Kashef Mahboob
label: Paragraph

text: Chowdhury and Marina Tabassum, who began their joint
label: Paragraph

text: career by winning the 1997 national competition for the
label: Paragraph

text: Independence Monument and the Liberation War Museum, a
label: Title

text: work which, after many delays, was finally completed to
label: Paragraph

text: their designs in the Suhrawardy Udyan in Dhaka in 2013.
label: Paragraph

text: Following the dissolution of this husband-and-wife
label: Paragraph

text: partnership at the millennium, Chowdhury designed and
label: Paragraph

text: built two outstanding works: the Chandgaon Mosque in
label: Paragraph

text: Chittagong (2005) and a training facility known as the
label: Paragraph

text: Friendship Centre [536, 537], built on a flood plain at
label: Paragraph

text: Gaibandha some 250 kilometres north of Dhaka. The
label: Paragraph

text: mosque, built amid rice paddies, consists of a single-storey
label: Paragraph

text: concrete structure with a double square plan divided
label: Caption

text: between an open-air forecourt and a domed prayer hall. In
label: Paragraph

text: contrast, the Friendship Centre is a single-storey, grass-
label: Paragraph

text: covered, load-bearing brick matrix, constructed as a
label: Paragraph

text: labyrinth of rooms interspersed with courts and rain-
label: Paragraph

text: harvesting tanks. Everywhere in the Bengal Delta, water is
label: Paragraph

text: both a precious resource and a threat. Thus, in addition to
label: Paragraph

text: the flood protection - an earthen berm surrounding the
label: Paragraph

text: orthogonal complex - it was necessary to implement an
label: Paragraph

text: elaborate network of water mains, service runs and septic
label: Paragraph

text: tanks in order to ensure that floodwater would not mix with
label: Paragraph

text: sewage during the monsoon season.
label: Paragraph

text: 536 Chowdhury, Friendship Centre, Gaibandha, 2011.
label: Caption

text: 537 Chowdhury, Friendship Centre, Gaibandha, 2011. Section.
label: Caption

text: Tabassum’s Bait Ur Rouf Mosque [538, 539], completed
label: Caption

text: in 2013 at Faidabad Uttara, in the northern extension of
label: Paragraph

text: Dhaka, is equally Kahnian both in its intrinsic geometry and
label: Paragraph

text: the load-bearing brickwork out of which it is largely built.
label: Paragraph

text: The form of this diminutive mosque - 75 feet (22.8 metres)
label: Paragraph

text: long on each side of its square plan and 25 feet (7.6 metres)
label: Paragraph

text: in height - is predicated on the rotation of a square within a
label: Paragraph

text: square, so that the prayer hall faces towards Mecca. The
label: Paragraph

text: prayer hall itself is of reinforced-concrete construction set
label: Paragraph

text: within a brick enclosure and surrounded by a two-storey
label: Paragraph

text: interstitial promenade also rendered in brick. Sunlight
label: Caption

text: enters the prayer hall from the sides through this space and
label: Paragraph

text: also from a proliferation of small apertures in the roof. Of
label: Paragraph

text: virtually the same date, Tabassum’s Eco Resort at Jessore
label: Paragraph

text: comprises a cluster of small, motel-like pavilions with
label: Paragraph

text: thatched roofs, on top of a system of raised platforms made
label: Paragraph

text: out of compacted earth. This tourist settlement embodies in
label: Paragraph

text: every respect the floodplain culture of the delta by which it
label: Paragraph

text: is surrounded on every side.
label: Paragraph

text: 538 Tabassum, Bait Ur Rouf Mosque, Dhaka, 2013. Plan.
label: Caption

text: 539 Tabassum, Bait Ur Rouf Mosque, Dhaka, 2013.
label: Caption

text: The other Bengali architect of distinction of
label: Paragraph

text: approximately the same generation as Chowdhury and
label: Paragraph

text: Tabassum is the architect-painter Rafiq Azam, who began
label: Paragraph

text: his career by expanding his childhood family home in Dhaka
label: Paragraph

text: while he was still a student in 1986. This was a traditional
label: Paragraph

text: brick courtyard house that had to be rearranged and
label: Paragraph

text: amplified so as to accommodate an enlarged family, a task
label: Paragraph

text: that he partially achieved by providing a terrace, opening
label: Paragraph

text: directly off the living space, on the first floor of the new
label: Caption

text: structure. As much Chowdhury, Azam has a particular
label: Paragraph

text: feeling for the vast floodplain of Bangladesh which finds
label: Paragraph

text: expression in the extraordinarily emotive watercolours
label: Paragraph

text: through which he expresses the constantly changing
label: Paragraph

text: seasons of the delta. Following his modifications to the
label: Paragraph

text: family home, and a period of apprenticeship, Azam’s early
label: Paragraph

text: practice led to a series of five- to six-storey, Kahnian
label: Paragraph

text: apartment buildings combining vertical shafts of precision
label: Paragraph

text: brickwork, cantilevered corner fenestration and oversailing
label: Caption

text: roofs at the crown of each apartment tower. He has since
label: Paragraph

text: adapted this format to a number of single family ‘tower’
label: Paragraph

text: houses. Influenced as much by Tadao Ando as by the work
label: Paragraph

text: of Kahn, Azam, in his maturity, has emerged as a
label: Paragraph

text: monumental architect and landscapist of calibre, first with a
label: Paragraph

text: family cemetery at Botkhil, Noakhali, of 2012 and then with
label: Paragraph

text: his sublime project of 2015 for the Bangladeshi Chancery
label: Paragraph

text: [540] in Islamabad, Pakistan.
label: Caption

text: 540 Azam, project for the Bangladesh Chancery complex, Islamabad, 2015.
label: Caption

text: Rendering.
label: Paragraph

text: Sri Lanka
label: Title

text: In Sri Lanka, formerly known as Ceylon, the most talented
label: Paragraph

text: exponent of what is now known as vernacular modernism
label: Paragraph

text: was the native-born, British-educated Geoffrey Bawa, who
label: Paragraph

text: first came to public notice with his wood-framed, pitched-
label: Paragraph

text: roof Bentota Beach Hotel of 1969. In the evolution of his
label: Paragraph

text: idiosyncratic regional manner Bawa would be influenced by
label: Paragraph

text: two seminal figures: first, the Sri Lankan architect Minnette
label: Paragraph

text: de Silva, who had studied at the Architectural Association
label: Paragraph

text: School in London and who in 1948 became the first Asian
label: Paragraph

text: female member of the RIBA; and, second, by the émigré
label: Paragraph

text: Danish architect Ulrik Plesner, who would work closely with
label: Paragraph

text: Bawa during the first half of the 1960s. As much esteemed
label: Paragraph

text: for his landscape design as for his architecture, Bawa would
label: Paragraph

text: begin work in 1948 on his country estate of Lunuganga, his
label: Paragraph

text: landscape masterwork, which occupied much of the rest of
label: Paragraph

text: his life.
label: Paragraph

text: Bawa’s luxurious tropical manner was elevated to
label: Paragraph

text: monumental status with his Sri Lankan Parliament complex
label: Paragraph

text: [541], built on a small island in the middle of an artificial
label: Paragraph

text: lake at Sri Jayawardenepura, Kotte, in 1982. He followed this
label: Paragraph

text: government commission with a plan for a new university at
label: Paragraph

text: Matara, under continuous development from 1980 to 1988.
label: Paragraph

text: The green wall of vegetation covering the exposed frame of
label: Paragraph

text: the Kandalama Hotel at Dambulla is one of his most
label: Paragraph

text: significant later works. Completed towards the end of his
label: Paragraph

text: life, it not only embodies the sense of tropical luxus for
label: Paragraph

text: which he was renowned but is also a kind of ecological tour
label: Paragraph

text: de force deceptively presenting the hotel as a quasi-ruin
label: Paragraph

text: about to be consumed by the exuberant tropical jungle of its
label: Paragraph

text: hilltop site.
label: Paragraph

text: 541 Bawa, Parliament Complex, Colombo, 1982.
label: Caption

text: A more recent regionally sensitive work in Sri Lanka is
label: Paragraph

text: the British High Commission [542] built in Colombo to the
label: Paragraph

text: designs of the Edinburgh-based architect Richard Murphy.
label: Paragraph

text: This work is not only passively responsive to the climate,
label: Paragraph

text: but also sensitively contextual by virtue of its use of native
label: Paragraph

text: kalugal stone, local terracotta tiles and coconut timber
label: Caption

text: panels. Equally local in character is its orthogonal
label: Paragraph

text: organization around water courts and fountain pools, which
label: Paragraph

text: contribute to the building’s natural ventilation and cooling.
label: Paragraph

text: This process is augmented by glass skylights set over the
label: Paragraph

text: central access corridors, which act as thermal chimneys,
label: Paragraph

text: venting hot air out of the offices they serve.
label: Paragraph

text: 542 Murphy, British High Commission, Colombo, 2008.
label: Caption

text: Among a rising generation of young Sri Lankan architects
label: Title

text: working within the distinctly local modern tradition initiated
label: Paragraph

text: by Geoffrey Bawa are such figures as Hirante Welandawe,
label: Paragraph

text: Channa Daswatte, Amila de Mel, Palinda Kannangara and
label: Caption

text: above all, perhaps, the practice of Team Architrave. Team
label: Paragraph

text: Architrave’s elegant, steel-framed, six-storey office building,
label: Paragraph

text: designed and realized in 2017 in the midst of Colombo’s
label: Paragraph

text: chaotic downtown, is a welcome realistic ‘green’ oasis.
label: Paragraph

text: China
label: Title

text: Maybe Team X and Archigram were, in the sixties, the last
label: Paragraph

text: real ‘movements’ in urbanism, the last to propose with
label: Paragraph

text: conviction new ideas and concepts for the organization of
label: Title

text: urban life. In the long interval since their time, there has
label: Paragraph

text: been a huge increase in our understanding of the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: city; there has been the usual ad hoc intelligence and
label: Paragraph

text: improvisation, and the development of a kind of plastic
label: Title

text: urbanism, increasingly capable of creating an urban
label: Paragraph

text: condition free of urbanity. At the same time, Asia has been
label: Paragraph

text: in the grip of a relentless process of building, on a scale that
label: Paragraph

text: has probably never been seen before. A maelstrom of
label: Paragraph

text: modernization is destroying everywhere the existing
label: Paragraph

text: conditions in Asia and everywhere creating a completely
label: Paragraph

text: new urban substance. The absence, on the other hand, of
label: Paragraph

text: plausible, universal doctrines and the presence, on the
label: Paragraph

text: other, of an unprecedented intensity of production have
label: Paragraph

text: created a unique, wrenching condition: the urban seems to
label: Paragraph

text: be least understood at the very moment of its apotheosis.
label: Paragraph

text: The result is a theoretical, critical, and operation
label: Paragraph

text: impasse, which forces both academia and practice into
label: Paragraph

text: postures of either confidence or indifference. In fact, the
label: Paragraph

text: entire discipline possesses no adequate terminology to
label: Paragraph

text: discuss the most pertinent, most crucial phenomena within
label: Paragraph

text: its domain nor any conceptual framework to describe,
label: Paragraph

text: interpret, and understand exactly those forces that could
label: Paragraph

text: redefine and revitalize it. The field is abandoned to ‘events’
label: Paragraph

text: considered indescribable or the creation of a synthetic idyll
label: Paragraph

text: in memory of the city. There is nothing left between chaos
label: Paragraph

text: and celebration.
label: Paragraph

text: Rem Koolhaas
label: Title

text: Project on the City |: Great Leap Forward (2001)!
label: Paragraph

text: The continuous turmoil that befell China with the foundation
label: Title

text: of the Republic in 1911, followed in short order by a civil war
label: Paragraph

text: (1927-49) and by the Japanese occupation (1931-45), was
label: Paragraph

text: hardly conducive to the cultivation of modern architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Moreover, twice in the 20th century the Chinese state opted
label: Paragraph

text: to represent itself in Western Classical terms: first, in the
label: Paragraph

text: mausoleum of the founder of the Republic of China, Sun Yat
label: Caption

text: Sen, built at Nanjing in 1929 to the designs of Lu Yanzhi; and
label: Paragraph

text: second, with the Ten Great Buildings erected in Beijing in
label: Paragraph

text: 1959 in celebration of the tenth anniversary of the
label: Paragraph

text: Communist Revolution, testifying to Mao Zedong’s affinity
label: Paragraph

text: for Soviet Socialist Realism that made any creative
label: Paragraph

text: discourse on architecture in China virtually impossible until
label: Paragraph

text: well after his death in 1976. The one figure who attempted
label: Paragraph

text: to evolve an appropriate modern architectural culture in
label: Paragraph

text: China under Mao was the American-trained architect-
label: Paragraph

text: scholar Liang Sicheng, and it would be another seven years
label: Paragraph

text: after Mao’s death before Deng Xiaoping, who succeeded
label: Paragraph

text: Mao as leader of the People’s Republic of China, was able to
label: Paragraph

text: overcome the ideological impasse and open up China to
label: Paragraph

text: international trade and cultural exchange in 1983.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the first foreign architects to build in the People’s
label: Paragraph

text: Republic of China was the Chinese-American I.M. Pei, who
label: Paragraph

text: completed his Fragrant Hill Hotel on the outskirts of Beijing
label: Caption

text: in 1982. One year later the American corporate practice of
label: Paragraph

text: Ellerbe Becket built a mediocre multi-storey hotel next to
label: Paragraph

text: the time-honoured Great Wall. It would be another decade
label: Paragraph

text: before China’s new-found ‘open-door’ policy was able to
label: Paragraph

text: expand exponentially, beginning with the government of
label: Paragraph

text: Shanghai, which opted to transform the former horticultural
label: Paragraph

text: area of Pudong into a new business centre. This decision led
label: Paragraph

text: in short order to the building of multiple skyscrapers there,
label: Paragraph

text: including the eighty-eight-storey, pagoda-like skyscraper
label: Paragraph

text: known as the Jin Mao Tower to the designs of SOM in 1998,
label: Paragraph

text: which was followed by the audacious ‘sci-fi’ form of the
label: Paragraph

text: spectacular 492-metre high World Financial Center,
label: Caption

text: designed by the New York corporate practice of Kohn
label: Caption

text: Pedersen Fox in 2007. By this date Deng Xiaoping’s ‘open-
label: Paragraph

text: door’ policy was in full swing, with one Western architectural
label: Paragraph

text: practice after another establishing itself in China. They
label: Paragraph

text: included the French architect Paul Andreu, who was
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned to design the prestigious National Grand
label: Caption

text: Theatre of China, just off the main axis of the capital, linking
label: Paragraph

text: the Forbidden City to Tiananmen Square. Completed in
label: Caption

text: 2002, this 144-metre span, titanium-clad ellipsoid shell
label: Caption

text: housed three separate performance spaces under a single
label: Paragraph

text: roof: a 2,416-seat opera house, a 2,017-seat concert hall
label: Caption

text: and a 1,040-seat theatre. This architectural extravaganza,
label: Paragraph

text: poised in the middle of a large reflecting pool, was
label: Paragraph

text: accessible only by car via a subterranean tunnel. It was
label: Paragraph

text: typical of a number of equally prestigious gargantuan
label: Paragraph

text: structures to be built by foreign architects over the next
label: Paragraph

text: decade, including Norman Foster’s Beijing International
label: Paragraph

text: Airport of 2007, with its dynamic chevron, aerodynamic
label: Paragraph

text: layout in plan. The rapacity of China’s development at this
label: Paragraph

text: time may be judged from the fact that a decade after the
label: Paragraph

text: millennium, the country was consuming 54 per cent of the
label: Paragraph

text: world’s concrete and 36 per cent of the world’s steel. This
label: Paragraph

text: frenetic production, with building sites kept active day and
label: Paragraph

text: night, entailed an enormous amount of wilful destruction
label: Paragraph

text: and demolition that affected the countryside as much as the
label: Paragraph

text: city. According to research carried out in Tianjin University,
label: Paragraph

text: between 2000 and 2010, the number of villages in China
label: Paragraph

text: dropped from 3.7 million to 2.6 million, with rural areas
label: Paragraph

text: losing villages at the rate of 300 a day.
label: Paragraph

text: Between 2000 and 2002 a number of young Chinese and
label: Paragraph

text: Asian architects were invited to design exhibition houses on
label: Paragraph

text: a site close to the capital. This showpiece settlement,
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned by the developer couple Zhang Xin and Pan
label: Caption

text: Shiyi, was given the name Commune-by-the Wall. Among
label: Paragraph

text: the architects who built houses there was Yung Ho Chang
label: Paragraph

text: [543], whose Split House, constructed of adobe walls and
label: Paragraph

text: timber framing, was one of the most original and elegant
label: Paragraph

text: pieces on the site. The only other house on this site to
label: Paragraph

text: display a similar level of tectonic expressiveness was the
label: Paragraph

text: Bamboo House designed by the Japanese architect Kengo
label: Caption

text: Kuma [544]. Of the same period, an exceptionally original
label: Paragraph

text: and authentic house with respect to its structural clarity and
label: Paragraph

text: material richness was Qingyun Ma’s Father’s House of 2002
label: Paragraph

text: [545], built in the Jade Valley in the rural enclave of Lantian.
label: Paragraph

text: This was a reinforced-concrete-framed, two-storey structure,
label: Paragraph

text: fleshed out with masonry and full-height timber shutters,
label: Paragraph

text: and with flanking walls finished with smooth pebbles
label: Paragraph

text: gleaned from a nearby river.
label: Paragraph

text: 543 Yung Ho Chang, Split House, Beijing, 2002. Ground-floor plan.
label: Caption

text: 544 Kuma, Bamboo House, Commune at the Great Wall, Beijing, 2002.
label: Caption

text: 545 Qingyun Ma, Father’s House, Lantian, Xian, 2002.
label: Caption

text: In many respects Hong Kong has been fertile ground for
label: Paragraph

text: the development of a compelling culture of late modern
label: Title

text: architecture in China, not only for the established practice of
label: Paragraph

text: Hong Kong-born Rocco Yim, who works as much in the
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese mainland as in Hong Kong, but also the research
label: Paragraph

text: and design collaborative practice Rural Urban Framework
label: Title

text: (RUF), based in the University of Hong Kong and founded by
label: Paragraph

text: Joshua Bolchover and John Lin. To date RUF have achieved
label: Paragraph

text: two remarkable works: the Angdong Hospital, built in
label: Paragraph

text: Xiangxi in Hunan Province in 2011, and the House for All
label: Paragraph

text: Seasons, built in Shija village in the north-western province
label: Paragraph

text: of Shaanxi in 2012. Angdong Hospital’s main innovation is
label: Paragraph

text: its organization around a continuous concrete ramp, which
label: Paragraph

text: facilitates pedestrian circulation throughout its five-storey
label: Paragraph

text: form without the use of an elevator. Like the hospital the
label: Paragraph

text: two-storey courtyard house in Shija is clad in perforated
label: Paragraph

text: brickwork. Its stepped, multi-functional flat roof serves as
label: Paragraph

text: both a space for drying agricultural produce and as a means
label: Paragraph

text: of collecting rainwater.
label: Paragraph

text: The Taiwanese architect Wang Weijen, who is also based
label: Paragraph

text: in Hong Kong, has had to confront extremely dense urban
label: Paragraph

text: conditions, particularly when designing college campuses on
label: Paragraph

text: exceptionally congested sites in the city such as the Lingnan
label: Paragraph

text: University in Tuen Mun (2005) or the Hong Kong Polytechnic
label: Paragraph

text: University (2008). In both instances, he met the spatial
label: Paragraph

text: requirements by piling modular units into tower-like forms
label: Paragraph

text: overlaid by syncopated fenestration, which imparted a
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic plasticity to the final mass-form. A similar
label: Paragraph

text: counterpoint of skin versus structure is evident in the
label: Paragraph

text: twelve-storey dormitory block that Wang designed and built
label: Caption

text: in Shenzhen, Guangdong Province, in 2016 for the Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: University of Hong Kong. Wang has also been responsive to
label: Paragraph

text: demanding topographical conditions, for example in the
label: Paragraph

text: Baishawan Beach facility in Taipei, Taiwan, of 2002 [546],
label: Paragraph

text: where a syncopated pattern of monopitched, grass-covered
label: Paragraph

text: roofs fuse with the landscape, or in the Xixi Wetlands Artist
label: Paragraph

text: Village in Hangzhou (2012). There, inspired by a local
label: Paragraph

text: tradition of 12th-century landscape painting, clusters of two-
label: Paragraph

text: to three-storey-high studios with large picture windows
label: Caption

text: jointly afford framed views over the surrounding wetlands
label: Paragraph

text: that are conceived as a linked sequence of kinetic landscape
label: Paragraph

text: images.
label: Paragraph

text: 546 Wang Weijen, Baishawan Beach Visitor Centre, Taipei, 2002.
label: Caption

text: The Amateur Architecture Studio of Wang Shu and Lu
label: Title

text: Wenyu has adopted an equally topographic approach
label: Paragraph

text: towards the environmental devastation wrought by the
label: Title

text: Chinese building boom around the millennium. Wang Shu
label: Caption

text: and Lu Wenyu are preoccupied with recovering something of
label: Paragraph

text: traditional Chinese building culture in their work, as is
label: Paragraph

text: partially evident from their Ningbo Historical Museum [547],
label: Paragraph

text: built in Yinzhou on the outskirts of Ningbo in 2008.
label: Paragraph

text: Conceived as if it were a medieval fortification surrounded
label: Paragraph

text: by moat, this museum has 24-metre high concrete walls
label: Paragraph

text: faced with the traditional wa pan technique. In this method,
label: Paragraph

text: the surface is covered by a mosaic of grey, red and brown
label: Paragraph

text: bricks and tiles, integrally cast into the concrete walls, the
label: Paragraph

text: ceramic and terracotta material having been salvaged from
label: Paragraph

text: demolished farmers’ houses that previously existed on the
label: Paragraph

text: site and elsewhere in the immediate vicinity.
label: Paragraph

text: 547 Wang Shu, Ningbo Historical Museum, Yinzhou, 2008.
label: Caption

text: Following this achievement, the Amateur Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: Studio designed and built the largest single work carried out
label: Paragraph

text: by any architect of their generation, namely the Xiangshan
label: Paragraph

text: Campus of the China Academy of Art. This was constructed
label: Paragraph

text: as a continuously unfolding assembly of faculties close to
label: Paragraph

text: the centre of Hangzhou from 2008 onwards. Arranged
label: Paragraph

text: around a shallow hill known as the Elephant Mountain and
label: Paragraph

text: inspired by traditional Chinese scroll painting, this campus
label: Paragraph

text: unfolds as a concatenation of somewhat disjunctive mass-
label: Paragraph

text: forms that have boldly undulating roofs and are accessed by
label: Paragraph

text: an elaborate system of staircases hung off the sides of the
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. Despite this scenographic tour de force, the most
label: Paragraph

text: sophisticated work to be designed and completed by the
label: Paragraph

text: studio to date is a guest house-cum-conference centre
label: Paragraph

text: conceived by Wang Shu as the social heart of the campus.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the most arresting features of this complex is its
label: Paragraph

text: continuously folded timber roof, which is in effect a space
label: Paragraph

text: frame made up of innumerable timber trusses, stacked side
label: Paragraph

text: by side and stabilized transversely by wire cables. This
label: Paragraph

text: floating roof is carried on steel frames that rest, in turn, on
label: Paragraph

text: cross walls comprised of yellow and red rammed earth,
label: Paragraph

text: quarried locally and braced at intervals by a reinforced-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete frame. Apart from its vernacular connotations, this
label: Paragraph

text: large oversailing roof seems to have been distantly inspired
label: Paragraph

text: by Carlo Scarpa’s Castelvecchio Museum, built in Verona in
label: Caption

text: 1965. The other conscious Italian reference, according to
label: Paragraph

text: the architects, was Giovanni Battista Piranesi’s etchings of
label: Paragraph

text: imaginary prisons (Le Carceri d’Invenzione) of 1760, the
label: Paragraph

text: influence of which is evoked by the transverse internal
label: Paragraph

text: staircases that intertwine with one another before climbing
label: Paragraph

text: up into the cavernous expanse of the roof and finally
label: Paragraph

text: ending, in some instances, on the very top of the roof itself.
label: Paragraph

text: The other remarkable work by the Amateur Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: Studio is its ongoing reconstruction of Wencun Village [549,
label: Paragraph

text: 550], situated some 1% hours from Hangzhou by car. This
label: Paragraph

text: work, begun in 2013, comprises a linear sequence of cubic
label: Paragraph

text: houses standing on their original sites and loosely following
label: Paragraph

text: the course of a nearby river. These houses are now in the
label: Paragraph

text: process of being restored and/or rebuilt according to the
label: Paragraph

text: designs of Wang Shu and Lu Wenyu. What is remarkable is
label: Paragraph

text: the way in which the repair and rebuilding of these houses
label: Paragraph

text: has been handled as a répétition différente, in which new
label: Paragraph

text: structures maintain the continuity and rhythm of the original
label: Paragraph

text: linear form of the village.
label: Paragraph

text: Endorsing Wang Shu’s reaction against the wanton
label: Paragraph

text: destruction of China’s traditional urban and architectural
label: Title

text: culture, a new generation of Chinese architects have opted
label: Paragraph

text: to work in relatively remote rural communities in search of
label: Paragraph

text: another kind of modernity. Thus, as the architect Li
label: Paragraph

text: Xiangning has written:
label: Paragraph

text: From villages to cities, from cultural architecture to
label: Paragraph

text: residential architecture, in the wake of two decades of
label: Paragraph

text: destructive construction, China’s contemporary
label: Title

text: architectural practice wishes to consolidate a new tradition
label: Paragraph

text: of architecture. It is a careful borrowing rather than a literal,
label: Paragraph

text: direct, shallow appropriation of traditional building culture; a
label: Paragraph

text: cultural renaissance after the apogee of modern western
label: Title

text: architecture rather than a conservative subjective
label: Title

text: construction; a coexistence of diverse solutions rather than
label: Paragraph

text: a mere duplication of mainstream experience. Sooner or
label: Paragraph

text: later, the practices of these independent architects will
label: Paragraph

text: generate an effect similar to acupuncture: individual cases
label: Paragraph

text: will make China’s building industry, and even the public at
label: Paragraph

text: large, recognize their own traditions in a critical and
label: Paragraph

text: innovative way.
label: Paragraph

text: By far the most radical urban work to be realized in China
label: Paragraph

text: of recent date is Liu Jiakun’s West Village Basis Yard
label: Paragraph

text: complex, completed in Chengdu in 2016 [548]. This is a six-
label: Paragraph

text: storey, 237- by 178-metre perimeter block comprising
label: Caption

text: institutional and commercial accommodation on all three
label: Paragraph

text: sides, linked together in terms of circulation by an open-air
label: Paragraph

text: intersecting bicycle ramp on the fourth side, connecting to
label: Paragraph

text: all six floors of the building. This medium-rise complex is
label: Paragraph

text: enriched by carefully landscaped vegetation that also
label: Paragraph

text: serves to subdivide and articulate the various sports
label: Paragraph

text: facilities - for basketball, tennis and so on - occuping the
label: Paragraph

text: overall interior of the block at grade. These play courts are
label: Paragraph

text: both separated and served by staircases and elevated
label: Paragraph

text: passerelles. In retrospect, this work may be seen as a 21st-
label: Paragraph

text: century reincarnation of the Soviet ideal of both the
label: Paragraph

text: workers’ club and the collective dwelling (dom-kommuna),
label: Paragraph

text: both being conceived in the 1920s as a new institutional
label: Paragraph

text: form capable of providing points of social condensation, i.e.
label: Paragraph

text: societal cohesion.
label: Paragraph

text: 548 Jiakun, West Village Basis Yard, Chendu, 2016. Section.
label: Caption

text: 549 Wang Shu, Wencun Village, Zhejiang, 2013.
label: Caption

text: 550 Wang Shu, Wencun Village, Zhejiang, 2013. Site plan.
label: Caption

text: This entire complex is posited as a critical stratagem,
label: Paragraph

text: mediating between the universality of market capitalism
label: Title

text: and the still-viable attributes of socialism that continue to
label: Paragraph

text: provide a certain security within the relatively ruthless neo-
label: Paragraph

text: liberal economy of the Chinese People’s Republic. Under the
label: Paragraph

text: slogan ‘People Mountain, People Sea - A Celebration of
label: Paragraph

text: Everyday Life’, Jiakun has written:
label: Paragraph

text: The city grows madly; memories are vanishing; public space
label: Paragraph

text: has been slowly eroded; so does the genius loci and
label: Paragraph

text: conventional lifestyles. The so-called architectural tradition
label: Paragraph

text: has become merely a symbolic existence. Daily life,
label: Paragraph

text: especially people’s leisure activities, is no more than a
label: Paragraph

text: normative by-product of consumer culture. ... The hierarchy
label: Paragraph

text: of spatial configuration downgrades public spaces and
label: Paragraph

text: severely undermines the local spirit. It seems that creativity,
label: Paragraph

text: imagination and passion for life can only thrive in leftover
label: Paragraph

text: spaces. ... Is it possible to transfer the all-consuming nature
label: Paragraph

text: of capitalism into a win-win case of sharing? Thrive on the
label: Paragraph

text: gathering of the often overlooked daily life contents? To
label: Paragraph

text: regain the initiative of today’s vulnerable public spaces? To
label: Paragraph

text: keep up the traditional cultural genes in contemporary
label: Title

text: cities? To turn the marketplace into art? This is our
label: Paragraph

text: challenge.
label: Paragraph

text: In effect, the West Village complex is an unspecified
label: Paragraph

text: mixture of retail, ‘start-up’ spaces and hotel
label: Paragraph

text: accommodation, while such public facilities as a cinema ora
label: Paragraph

text: gymnasium are unfortunately relegated into the basement
label: Paragraph

text: along with the prerequisite parking one floor below. At the
label: Paragraph

text: same time this complex indulges in a tough use of raw
label: Paragraph

text: material, ranging from an exposed jn situ reinforced-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete frame to a steel-reinforced, hollow-core brick slab,
label: Paragraph

text: seeded with grass so as to counter the ‘heat island’ effect
label: Paragraph

text: on the roof.
label: Paragraph

text: Another recent typologically pertinent invention at the
label: Paragraph

text: scale of a city block is the Garden School [551, 552]
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Li Hu of the OPEN Architecture Studio and built
label: Caption

text: in the Fangshan district of Beijing in 2017. Here the most
label: Paragraph

text: radical move is the covering of half of the available site in
label: Paragraph

text: an artificial landscape of undulating concrete roofs covered
label: Paragraph

text: with grass so as to create a park-like setting for the main
label: Paragraph

text: body of the school. The school itself consists of a continuous
label: Paragraph

text: organic assembly of four-storey classroom blocks suspended
label: Caption

text: over an artificial undercroft accommodating three storeys of
label: Caption

text: communal facilities beneath the greensward: that is, the
label: Paragraph

text: cafeteria and the main lecture hall, plus gymnasia,
label: Paragraph

text: basketball courts, kitchen, storage, and parking facilities for
label: Paragraph

text: both bicycles and cars. Here the overall sustainability
label: Paragraph

text: strategy ranges from rainwater harvesting and geothermal
label: Paragraph

text: heating to design of the green roofs of the classroom blocks
label: Caption

text: in order to accommodate urban agriculture.
label: Paragraph

text: 551 OPEN Architecture, Garden School, Beijing, 2017.
label: Caption

text: 552 OPEN Architecture, Garden School, Beijing, 2017.
label: Caption

text: Some of the more sensitive and innovative examples of
label: Paragraph

text: recent architecture in China may be found in the area of
label: Paragraph

text: housing, particularly in the form of low-rise estates, which
label: Paragraph

text: have revived the Chinese tradition of combining residential
label: Paragraph

text: fabric with waterscape. We encounter this trope in the Evian
label: Paragraph

text: New Town, built outside Suzhou in 2006 to the designs of
label: Paragraph

text: the RMJM office, or in their 2005 extension of the famous
label: Paragraph

text: historic camel-town of Zhujiajiao, near Shanghai, the so-
label: Paragraph

text: called Oriental Garden [553], comprising two- to three-
label: Paragraph

text: storey houses, divided by waterways, pedestrian alleys and
label: Paragraph

text: parking. However, such estates are by no means the only
label: Paragraph

text: recent middle-class residential paradigm, as is evident from
label: Paragraph

text: the twenty-storey slab blocks built on the outskirts of
label: Paragraph

text: Shanghai in 2003 to the designs of Qingyun Ma’s MADA
label: Paragraph

text: studio. A more traditionally collective form was realized in
label: Paragraph

text: 2008 at Guangzhou with the Tulou Collective Housing, built
label: Caption

text: to the designs of Lin Xiaodu and Meng Yen of the URBANUS
label: Paragraph

text: practice. This work, inspired by the traditional circular
label: Paragraph

text: fortified tufou houses of Fujian Province, received the 2010
label: Paragraph

text: Aga Khan Award. Its 287 two-bedroom units were, in effect,
label: Paragraph

text: a modernized middle-class version of ancient peasant
label: Paragraph

text: housing.
label: Paragraph

text: 553 RMJM, Oriental Garden, Shanghai, 2005.
label: Caption

text: The devastating 2008 Wenchuan earthquake in Sichuan
label: Title

text: Province mobilized architects from all over China, including
label: Paragraph

text: the Rural Architecture Studio led by the Taiwanese architect
label: Paragraph

text: Hsieh Ying-Chun, who was able to construct virtually
label: Paragraph

text: overnight some two million dwelling units through the
label: Paragraph

text: expeditious use of a prefabricated, light-steel frame
label: Paragraph

text: construction. These seismic-resistant skeletons were
label: Paragraph

text: subsequently developed by the people themselves with a
label: Paragraph

text: wide variety of building materials drawing on the local
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular, from rammed earth to stone, brick and bamboo.
label: Paragraph

text: It should also be noted that some of the emerging
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese practices have assimilated the European
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivist syntax of the 1930s, as is the case in the
label: Paragraph

text: Dashawan Beach complex [554] completed in 2009 on Lian
label: Caption

text: Island in Lianyungang to the designs of Scenic Architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Here three reinforced-concrete, single-storey slabs, Y-
label: Caption

text: shaped in plan, step down one partially top of another as
label: Paragraph

text: the structure descends towards the beach: in effect a
label: Paragraph

text: continuous sequence of ramped prisms, the uppermost of
label: Paragraph

text: which houses a seventeen-bed hotel while a second level
label: Paragraph

text: provides a restaurant and club facilities. This spatial
label: Paragraph

text: invention is based on a series of wooden decks, cascading
label: Paragraph

text: down towards the sea.
label: Paragraph

text: 554 Scenic Architecture Office, Dashawan Beach Complex, Lian Island, 2009.
label: Caption

text: An equally powerful and exceptionally sensitive
label: Paragraph

text: reworking of the received language of the European Modern
label: Title

text: Movement is evident in the recent work of Vector Architects,
label: Paragraph

text: headed by Gong Dong, even in their Courtyard Hybrid
label: Paragraph

text: project of 2015 in which they achieved a significant and
label: Paragraph

text: sensitive restoration of a traditional courtyard house
label: Title

text: (hutong). Here the house, with a double-pitched tiled roof,
label: Paragraph

text: has been restored as an art gallery. Its open courtyard
label: Paragraph

text: contains two light-weight timber pavilions, one used for a
label: Caption

text: small café and the other for a multi-purpose facility. They
label: Paragraph

text: followed this achievement with a ‘rationalist’ béton brut
label: Paragraph

text: Seashore Library built on the beach of Hebei (2015) [557]
label: Caption

text: and, in the following year, two works in which an assumed
label: Paragraph

text: rationalist language of jn situ reinforced concrete is broken
label: Title

text: up and manipulated so as to become integrated with the
label: Paragraph

text: topographic context: first, the Suzhou Intangible Heritage
label: Title

text: Museum (2016) [555, 556] and, second, the Chongqing
label: Paragraph

text: Taoyuanju Community Centre (2015). This centre creates
label: Paragraph

text: many alternative itineraries in, around and over the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape. Of this last building they have written:
label: Paragraph

text: 555 Vector Architects, Suzhou Intangible Heritage Museum, Suzhou, 2016.
label: Caption

text: Section.
label: Paragraph

text: 556 Vector Architects, Suzhou Intangible Heritage Museum, Suzhou, 2016.
label: Caption

text: 557 Vector Architects, Seashore Library, Qinhuangdao, 2015.
label: Caption

text: The public nature of the community centre brings various
label: Paragraph

text: types of people including regular citizens ... they have
label: Paragraph

text: different behavioral patterns in the building, such as
label: Paragraph

text: strolling, gathering, reading, tutoring, training, exercising,
label: Paragraph

text: health counselling etc. People have designated space for
label: Paragraph

text: each such behaviors, which are also able to interact actively
label: Paragraph

text: with each other in open fluid space.
label: Paragraph

text: Zhang Ke of the practice ZAO/standardarchitecture is
label: Paragraph

text: equally committed to hutong restoration and reuse and to
label: Paragraph

text: the revitalization of remote regional culture, as seen in his
label: Paragraph

text: numerous works in the Tibet region. Two of his works dating
label: Paragraph

text: from 2008 are typical in this regard: the Namcha Barwa
label: Paragraph

text: Visitor Center and the Yarlung Tsangpo Boat Terminal [560,
label: Caption

text: 561]. The latter is typical of his work in this region in that
label: Paragraph

text: here, as elsewhere, three characteristics come to the fore:
label: Paragraph

text: (1) the topographic sensitivity with which the work is
label: Paragraph

text: integrated into the landscape; (2) the use of reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete as the underlying substructure; and (3) the use of
label: Paragraph

text: both local materials and native craftsmanship; i.e. rubble-
label: Paragraph

text: stone cladding, gathered on site and assembled by local
label: Paragraph

text: masons.
label: Paragraph

text: Of all the figures who have recently engaged in the
label: Paragraph

text: recovery of Chinese environmental culture, traditional or
label: Paragraph

text: otherwise, none has been more outspoken and critically
label: Paragraph

text: influential than the distinguished Chinese landscape
label: Title

text: architect Kongjian Yu. Perhaps the most compelling aspect
label: Paragraph

text: of his wide-ranging topographic approach is the importance
label: Paragraph

text: he attaches to the development of an ecological
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructure, by which term he refers not only to transport
label: Paragraph

text: but also to something closer to the time-honoured Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: agrarian traditions of crop rotation and flood control, which
label: Paragraph

text: he deems to be of greater importance than the venerable
label: Paragraph

text: traditions in China of gardening and landscape painting. In
label: Paragraph

text: this regard, Yu has developed the strategy of ‘sponge cities’
label: Paragraph

text: as a means for combating the current drop in the water
label: Paragraph

text: table - at the rate of 1.5 to 2 metres (5 to 6% feet) every
label: Paragraph

text: year - throughout urbanized China. Yu's ‘sponge city’
label: Paragraph

text: principle involves harvesting rainwater and filtering it
label: Paragraph

text: through a wetland system. Typical of Yu’s approach is his
label: Paragraph

text: Yongning River Park in Taizhou City, a city that like many
label: Paragraph

text: others on the Chinese mainland has been subject to the
label: Paragraph

text: combined ecologically destructive forces of industrialization
label: Title

text: and urbanization, leading to the simultaneous maximization
label: Paragraph

text: of both profit and pollution. In Taizhou City, Kongjian Yu
label: Paragraph

text: reinstated the riverbed by removing the concrete channel
label: Paragraph

text: and replacing it with a partially inundated landscape of
label: Paragraph

text: native plants, combined with a graded river bank to afford
label: Paragraph

text: people access to the water as a continuous riverfront park.
label: Paragraph

text: Something similar obtains in his Rice Campus [559], built
label: Paragraph

text: for Shenyang Jianzhu University, where rice paddies are
label: Paragraph

text: interspersed with gridded pedestrian pathways across the
label: Paragraph

text: campus. In this way the students participate collectively in
label: Paragraph

text: the planting and harvesting of rice in spring and autumn
label: Title

text: respectively. In his book The Art of Survival, Kongjian Yu
label: Paragraph

text: evokes the idea of a ‘non-imperial’ Chinese identity and in
label: Paragraph

text: so doing returns the reader to the ideals of the democratic
label: Paragraph

text: revolution that grew out of student protests in China on 4
label: Title

text: 558 DnA_Design and Architecture, Brown Sugar Factory, Songyang Province,
label: Caption

text: 559 Yu, Rice Campus of Shenyang Jianzhu University, Shenyang, 2004.
label: Caption

text: Japan
label: Title

text: The Modern Movement arrived in Japan over the years
label: Paragraph

text: 1921-31 through the activity of the Japanese Secession, the
label: Paragraph

text: so-called Bunriha faction of which Sutemi Horiguchi and
label: Paragraph

text: Mamoru Yamada were the most prominent figures. After
label: Paragraph

text: graduating as architects, both men designed reinforced-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete, earthquake-proof structures: the Perretesque
label: Title

text: Kikkakan House (1925-30) in the case of Horiguchi and the
label: Paragraph

text: Tsurumi House (1931) by Yamada. The other key figure
label: Paragraph

text: active in Tokyo at this time was the émigré Czech-American
label: Paragraph

text: architect Antonin Raymond, who had arrived in Japan to
label: Paragraph

text: work as job captain on the building of Frank Lloyd Wright’s
label: Caption

text: Imperial Hotel. Raymond designed and built his own
label: Paragraph

text: exceptional reinforced-concrete building in 1923 (fig. 265, p.
label: Caption

text: 292) and maintained an extensive and remarkably fertile
label: Paragraph

text: modern practice in Japan until the advent of the Second
label: Paragraph

text: World War compelled him to return to the United States. A
label: Paragraph

text: number of leading post-war Japanese architects, including
label: Paragraph

text: Kunio Maekawa, gained their initial training as assistants in
label: Paragraph

text: Raymond's office prior to the war. The other pioneering
label: Paragraph

text: modernist of this moment was Junzo Sakakura, who, after
label: Paragraph

text: working in the office of Le Corbusier, designed the Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilion for the Paris World Exhibition of 1937 [562]. Aside
label: Caption

text: from being a categorically modern work making extensive
label: Paragraph

text: use of ramped circulation, it may be seen as the first
label: Paragraph

text: attempt at the aggressively nationalist Imperial Crown Style
label: Title

text: favoured by the right-wing, imperialist regime during the
label: Paragraph

text: early part of the reign of the Emperor Showa (Hirohito), who
label: Paragraph

text: acceded in 1926.
label: Paragraph

text: 562 Sakakura, Japanese Pavilion, Paris World Exhibition of 1937.
label: Caption

text: After the end of the Second World War, when Allied
label: Paragraph

text: occupation forces reestablished democracy in Japan, the
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese government played a prominent role in
label: Paragraph

text: commissioning new projects, a patronage which would
label: Paragraph

text: continue throughout the rest of the 20th century, as we may
label: Paragraph

text: judge from the construction of an international airport on a
label: Paragraph

text: landfill site in the middle of Osaka Bay from 1988 to 1994.
label: Paragraph

text: The funds for this protean enterprise, including the runways
label: Paragraph

text: and a terminal building designed by Renzo Piano, were
label: Paragraph

text: partially paid for by the state, with the rest coming from the
label: Paragraph

text: Kansai airport authority. It is difficult to imagine something
label: Paragraph

text: more Promethean than the building of an international
label: Paragraph

text: airport in the middle of the sea and it is a joint tribute to
label: Paragraph

text: Japan’s engineering genius and the prowess of its building
label: Title

text: industry that this project was completed within a relatively
label: Paragraph

text: short time. Moreover, it is a testament to post-war Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: democracy that the motivation behind this audacious
label: Paragraph

text: undertaking was pressure from the local population, which
label: Paragraph

text: rejected a land-based international airport on acoustic
label: Paragraph

text: grounds.
label: Paragraph

text: A similar political commitment to a large-scale building
label: Paragraph

text: operation, although this time land-based, is the Makuhari
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition Centre, built in Chibu Prefecture in 1989 to the
label: Paragraph

text: designs of Fumihiko Maki, along with in an equally ambitious
label: Paragraph

text: megastructure of virtually the same date, the Tokyo
label: Paragraph

text: International Forum [563], which contains five auditoria
label: Paragraph

text: under one roof. This design was the result of an
label: Paragraph

text: international competition, won by the New York-based
label: Paragraph

text: Argentinian architect Rafael Vifholy, with the Tokyo regional
label: Paragraph

text: government being the major funding partner for both of
label: Paragraph

text: these developments.
label: Paragraph

text: 563 Vifholy, Tokyo International Forum, Tokyo, 1996. Plan.
label: Caption

text: A predisposing factor affecting the quality of Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: architectural production has been the unique capacity of the
label: Paragraph

text: country’s building industry to synthesize craft methods with
label: Paragraph

text: rationalized industrial production, combined with research
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated to the evolution of new materials and methods
label: Title

text: and supported by high levels of public and private funding.
label: Paragraph

text: The corporate za/batsu structure of the building industry,
label: Paragraph

text: whereby large contractors have their own architectural and
label: Paragraph

text: engineering offices, is complemented at an ideological level
label: Paragraph

text: by a set of influential architectural magazines, such as
label: Paragraph

text: Shinkenchiku, Kenchiku Bunka, A+U, Telescope, GA and SD.
label: Paragraph

text: While spectacular Post-Modern architectural fashion is as
label: Paragraph

text: prevalent here as in any other advanced, industrialized
label: Paragraph

text: nation, the country is still able to produce a considerable
label: Paragraph

text: number of works that are conceived and executed to the
label: Paragraph

text: highest standards, while still being subtly imbued with a
label: Paragraph

text: discernible Japanese character.
label: Paragraph

text: Nothing could be further from these large-scale, publicly
label: Paragraph

text: funded megaprojects than the small-scale, independent
label: Paragraph

text: works of Kazuo Shinohara, who has always maintained an
label: Paragraph

text: aloof attitude towards conventional practice. He distanced
label: Paragraph

text: himself not only from the Corbusian state architecture
label: Paragraph

text: pioneered by Kenzo Tange and Kunio Maekawa, but also
label: Paragraph

text: from the post-war revival of the Japanese domestic timber
label: Paragraph

text: tradition. He was involved with the reinterpretation of this
label: Paragraph

text: tradition during the early 1960s, but in the private houses
label: Paragraph

text: that he has built since then Shinohara has subtly alluded,
label: Paragraph

text: like the Japanese writer KObo Abe, to the chaos and violence
label: Paragraph

text: lying beneath the surface of an all too homogeneous and
label: Paragraph

text: seemingly tranquil technological society. His most public
label: Paragraph

text: work to date, the metal-clad Centennial Hall erected in 1988
label: Paragraph

text: opposite the main entrance of the Tokyo Institute of
label: Caption

text: Technology, epitomizes Shinohara’s typical juxtaposition of
label: Paragraph

text: dissonant form with advanced technology.
label: Paragraph

text: A similar critical impulse can be detected beneath the
label: Paragraph

text: high-tech aestheticism of Shinohara’s most distinguished
label: Paragraph

text: followers: Kazunari Sakamoto, Itsuko Hasegawa and Toyo
label: Title

text: Ito. Ito’s own house in Nakano, a space-frame covered
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard house known as the Silver Hut (built in 1984 but
label: Paragraph

text: later demolished and rebuilt on another site), combines
label: Paragraph

text: ‘high technology’ with a reference to nomadic tented
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. This individualistic expression is foreign to the
label: Paragraph

text: work of Fumihiko Maki, who, aside from his aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: concerns, has always been occupied with the urban
label: Paragraph

text: potential of what he came to define as ‘group form’, as
label: Paragraph

text: articulated in his 1964 essay ‘Some Thoughts on Collective
label: Paragraph

text: Forms’: We had long deplored the separation of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and planning. Perhaps the static compositional methods of
label: Paragraph

text: the past have been completely outmoded now by the rapid
label: Paragraph

text: demands of a new technology and a new social organization
label: Title

text: ... One makes static compositions of individual buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: and only subsequently can they become aspects of the
label: Paragraph

text: grain of the City. The vital images of group form, on the
label: Paragraph

text: other hand, derives from the dynamic equilibrium of
label: Paragraph

text: generative elements and not a composition of stylized and
label: Paragraph

text: finished objects.!
label: Paragraph

text: While Maki’s concept was as much indebted to Team X as to
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese Metabolism, his distinctive approach towards the
label: Paragraph

text: aggregation of urban form came from his formative
label: Paragraph

text: experience in the Graduate School of Design (GSD) at
label: Paragraph

text: Harvard University. Between 1954 and 1968 he was
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by José Luis Sert, as is evident from the slowly
label: Paragraph

text: aggregated civic form of Maki’s Hillside Terrace apartments,
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo, on which he worked for over two decades with the
label: Paragraph

text: same developer, from 1969 to 1992. Predicated on Tange’s
label: Paragraph

text: National Olympic Stadium of 1964, Maki’s smaller Fujisawa
label: Paragraph

text: Municipal Gymnasium, Tokyo [564], of 1986 was, in effect, a
label: Paragraph

text: confirmation of the same heroic engineering tradition, only
label: Paragraph

text: executed this time as a light-weight steel structure with
label: Paragraph

text: stainless-steel cladding in order to achieve an economic
label: Paragraph

text: shell form. As Serge Lalat informs us:
label: Paragraph

text: 564 Maki, Fujisawa Municipal Gymnasium, Tokyo, 1986. Section.
label: Caption

text: The great vault of the roof has an unsupported span of 80
label: Caption

text: meters (262 feet). It is made up of a network of steel H-
label: Paragraph

text: girders which support a stainless steel envelope 0.4
label: Paragraph

text: millimetres (1/64 inch) thick. Inside the large arena...
label: Paragraph

text: creates a dilated interior space in which the wall surfaces
label: Paragraph

text: recede from the centre of the building. Four swaths of light,
label: Paragraph

text: taut and dynamic, divide the membranes of the main hall
label: Paragraph

text: into self-contained curved surfaces whose imaginary
label: Paragraph

text: continuations enlarge and stretch the space.*
label: Paragraph

text: Maki’s highly refined tectonic approach moved him in two
label: Paragraph

text: different but complementary directions: first, towards taut
label: Paragraph

text: orthogonal volumes, clad with thin metal skins that
label: Paragraph

text: dematerialize at their extremities into paper-thin louvres
label: Paragraph

text: and perforated translucent screens, as in his Tepia Pavilion,
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo, of 1990; and, second, towards light-weight
label: Paragraph

text: engineering forms that display an affinity for the European
label: Paragraph

text: Gothic tradition. An architect with an equally
label: Paragraph

text: dematerializing approach at a monumental scale is Yoshio
label: Paragraph

text: Taniguchi, most particularly in his Tokyo Kasai Rinkai Park
label: Paragraph

text: Visitors’ Centre [565] and his exceptionally monumental
label: Paragraph

text: Toyota Municipal Museum of Art, both of 1995.
label: Caption

text: 565 Taniguchi, Tokyo Kasai Rinkai Park Visitors’ Centre, Tokyo, 1995.
label: Caption

text: 566 Maki, Republic Polytechnic Campus, Singapore, 2007.
label: Caption

text: The most prominent Japanese architect of virtually the
label: Paragraph

text: same generation has unquestionably been Tadao Ando,
label: Paragraph

text: whose excursion into landscaped pieces in the 1980s was
label: Paragraph

text: evidently among some of the finest civic works built
label: Paragraph

text: anywhere in the decade, above all his Chapel-on-the-Water
label: Paragraph

text: at Tomamu, Hokkaido [567]. Opening on to an artificial lake,
label: Caption

text: the surface of which is kept moving by a gravitational feed
label: Paragraph

text: descending over a series of weirs, this chapel evokes the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional Japanese concept of oku, by virtue of which a
label: Paragraph

text: series of auspicious sites may be metaphysically linked over
label: Paragraph

text: great distances. A number of features in this work, above all
label: Paragraph

text: the large sliding wall and the free-standing cross, serve to
label: Paragraph

text: integrate the form into the surrounding natural
label: Paragraph

text: environment. As Ando put it in 1989, ‘My goal has not been
label: Paragraph

text: to commune with nature as it is, but rather to change the
label: Paragraph

text: meaning of nature through architecture. | believe when that
label: Paragraph

text: happens, man will discover a new relationship with nature.’
label: Paragraph

text: 567 Ando, Chapel-on-the-Water, Tomamu, 1985-88.
label: Caption

text: It would be hard to find a contemporary Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: architect who is more concerned with integrating Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: traditional crafts into his work than Kengo Kuma. In this
label: Paragraph

text: regard Ando, who is only thirteen years older, seems to
label: Paragraph

text: belong to a different generation, a division that is reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: by Kuma’s antipathy for reinforced concrete. Kuma’s
label: Paragraph

text: aversion dates back to Ando’s Row House in Sumiyoshi of
label: Paragraph

text: 1976, for which Ando was awarded the much-coveted Japan
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Prize.
label: Paragraph

text: In contrast, Kuma’s parti pris - his so-called Water/Glass
label: Paragraph

text: project of 1995, an addition to a villa overlooking Atami Bay
label: Paragraph

text: - depended on a paradoxical illusory combination of glass
label: Paragraph

text: and water. Kuma’s Hiroshige Ando Museum, completed at
label: Caption

text: the millennium in Nasu-gun in Tochigi Prefecture, was built
label: Paragraph

text: of wood in such a way as to exemplify the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: tectonic propensity of timber construction through an
label: Paragraph

text: obsessive reiteration of wooden louvres. This aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: assembly not only depends upon a rain-proof membrane of
label: Paragraph

text: plate glass but also on the support of a structural steel
label: Paragraph

text: frame throughout, in effect a technological subterfuge by
label: Paragraph

text: which Kuma was able to evoke in built form Hiroshige’s
label: Paragraph

text: ukiyo-e vision of the world wherein rain is rendered as
label: Paragraph

text: ‘particlized’ phenomena.
label: Paragraph

text: For successive generations of Japanese architects the
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpretation of tradition has been an integral part of the
label: Paragraph

text: modernization process and in this regard Kuma is no
label: Paragraph

text: exception, as we may judge from his Noh Stage of 1995,
label: Paragraph

text: built at Tomoya in Miyagi Prefecture or his Takayanagi
label: Caption

text: Community Centre of 1998 in Niigata Prefecture. The latter,
label: Paragraph

text: situated in the midst of an unspoiled traditional village,
label: Paragraph

text: emulates the form of a traditional farmhouse (minka), with
label: Paragraph

text: its heavy timber frame covered with washi rice paper, a
label: Paragraph

text: traditional craft of the region. In spring the surrounding rice
label: Paragraph

text: paddies afford a bright green background in contrast to the
label: Paragraph

text: grey of the thatch and the luminosity of the rice paper.
label: Paragraph

text: Kuma’s involvement with tradition as a répétition
label: Paragraph

text: différente would come to the fore with his Yusuhara Town
label: Paragraph

text: Hall of 2006 [568], built for the village of Takaoka in Koichi
label: Caption

text: Prefecture. This structure, built out of local cedar, afforded
label: Paragraph

text: the architect a unique opportunity in which to employ
label: Paragraph

text: double-laminated timber beams spanning 18 metres (59
label: Caption

text: feet) and supported by laminated, ‘quadripartite’ composite
label: Paragraph

text: timber columns. This two-storey building, evocative of the
label: Caption

text: ancient Juomon tradition of timber construction,
label: Paragraph

text: accommodates a bank, a farmers’ cooperative and a local
label: Paragraph

text: chamber of commerce. It is clad in 60-millimetre (27-inch)
label: Paragraph

text: thick wooden panels. Kuma has since completed two other
label: Paragraph

text: civic pieces for the same community, dating from 2010: the
label: Caption

text: Yusuhara Wooden Bridge Museum and the Yusuhara Marche,
label: Title

text: the latter combining a market hall with a small hotel. The
label: Paragraph

text: Wooden Bridge Museum is a highly ingenious construction,
label: Paragraph

text: designed in collaboration with the engineer Katsao Nakata,
label: Paragraph

text: with a 40-metre (131-foot) timber span supported at its
label: Paragraph

text: ends by piers and in the centre by a free-standing timber
label: Caption

text: construction. Built of Japanese cedar, this feature involves a
label: Paragraph

text: concatenation of cantilevering timber brackets of increasing
label: Paragraph

text: span, similar to the traditional Japanese masugumi block
label: Paragraph

text: and bracket system. He has since completed a third civic
label: Paragraph

text: work, namely a library, for the same community.
label: Paragraph

text: 568 Kuma, Yusuhara Town Hall, Takaoka, 2006.
label: Caption

text: South Korea
label: Title

text: The arrival of modern architectural culture in Korea was
label: Paragraph

text: delayed by many factors, including in the first half of the
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century Russian and Sino-Japanese rivalry over the
label: Paragraph

text: country’s colonization, dating back to the Russo-Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: War of 1905, which resulted in Japan annexing the country
label: Paragraph

text: five years later. The Korean War between the Russian-
label: Paragraph

text: dominated North and the American-sponsored South, from
label: Paragraph

text: 1950 to 1953, ended in an uneasy truce that split the
label: Paragraph

text: country in two just north of Seoul on the 38th parallel.
label: Paragraph

text: Owing to the war, the Korean post-war master Swoo-Geun
label: Paragraph

text: Kim went to Tokyo in 1951 to study at the Tokyo University
label: Paragraph

text: of the Arts and then to Tokyo University, from which he
label: Paragraph

text: graduated as an architect in 1960. In the same year he won
label: Paragraph

text: the competition for the design of the Korean National
label: Title

text: Assembly, which in the event was never realized.
label: Paragraph

text: Nevertheless, on the strength of this success he returned to
label: Paragraph

text: Seoul in 1961 to open his own office and establish his Space
label: Paragraph

text: Design research group. His first work of consequence in
label: Paragraph

text: Korea was his concrete Freedom Centre of 1963, which was
label: Paragraph

text: evidently influenced by Le Corbusier’s Assembly Building in
label: Paragraph

text: Chandigarh. Equally ‘baroque’ was his Buyeo National
label: Paragraph

text: Museum built in Seoul in 1967. However, the work that
label: Paragraph

text: established his ultimate leadership in the field of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was his 1971 concrete-framed Space Group
label: Paragraph

text: building in Seoul [570, 571], clad in fair-faced brickwork
label: Caption

text: inside and out. This building not only housed his
label: Paragraph

text: professional office but also the editorial offices of Space
label: Paragraph

text: Design (SD) magazine, a journal of art and architecture that
label: Paragraph

text: Kim had founded in 1966. This publication was dedicated to
label: Paragraph

text: cultivating a modern Korean cultural identity in part through
label: Paragraph

text: scholarly research and in part through evaluating the native
label: Paragraph

text: tradition in relation to international developments. The SD
label: Paragraph

text: building also housed an art gallery and an experimental
label: Paragraph

text: theatre and in its prime was one of the city’s most
label: Paragraph

text: important cultural centres.
label: Paragraph

text: In retrospect it becomes clear that the Space Group
label: Paragraph

text: building was only the beginning of Kim’s mastery over a
label: Paragraph

text: medium-rise built form, invariably composed of rhythmically
label: Paragraph

text: arranged and articulated brick masses set on a concrete
label: Paragraph

text: frame, as is found in the School of Fine Arts complex for the
label: Paragraph

text: Seoul National University (1973) and in similar works
label: Paragraph

text: designed to accommodate large institutions, for example his
label: Paragraph

text: Korean Culture and Arts Foundation building of 1979. Such
label: Paragraph

text: syncopated brick masses also appear in his domestic work,
label: Paragraph

text: including the large houses that he built north of Seoul in a
label: Paragraph

text: forested landscape as an early gated community. Typical of
label: Paragraph

text: such work is his Chang Am Jang House of 1974 [569, 572],
label: Paragraph

text: which, although influenced by Dutch Neo-Plasticism, was
label: Paragraph

text: given a Korean character through the use of local timber
label: Paragraph

text: boarding and grey brick. Kim’s last major accomplishments
label: Paragraph

text: in Korea were his brick-faced Seoul Teachers’ College of
label: Paragraph

text: 1975 and three projects dating from 1977: the Seoul Sports
label: Paragraph

text: Complex, the Dae Woo Arcade and the Korean National
label: Title

text: Museum Tea House. Much like Kenzo Tange after Osaka
label: Paragraph

text: 1970, he was destined to end his career with large built
label: Paragraph

text: works outside the country, mostly in Iran.
label: Paragraph

text: 569 Swoo-Geun Kim, Chang Am Jang Residence, Seoul, 1974.
label: Caption

text: 570 Swoo-Geun Kim, Space Group Building, Seoul, 1971. Section.
label: Caption

text: 571 Swoo-Geun Kim, Space Group Building, Seoul, 1971.
label: Caption

text: 572 Swoo-Geun Kim, Chang Am Jang Residence, Seoul, 1974.
label: Caption

text: The next architect of stature to emerge on the South
label: Paragraph

text: Korean scene was Byoung Cho, who graduated from the
label: Paragraph

text: Graduate School of Design at Harvard in 1991, working
label: Paragraph

text: briefly afterwards with Mario Campi in Lugano and studying
label: Paragraph

text: as a postgraduate student under Elia Zenghelis at the ETH
label: Paragraph

text: in Zurich, before returning to Korea in 1993. There he would
label: Paragraph

text: meet Seung Hyo-Sang and Min Hyun Sik, members of the
label: Paragraph

text: avant-garde 4.3 Group, who, after Kim’s untimely death in
label: Paragraph

text: 1986, came to the fore as the next generation of
label: Paragraph

text: modernists. Cho’s first work in Korea was his Village of the
label: Paragraph

text: Dancing Fish [573], an aggregation of dormitories capped
label: Paragraph

text: by oversailing timber roofs and built on a hilltop ridge in
label: Paragraph

text: Paju, north of Seoul, in 1999. This collective was designed
label: Paragraph

text: for mentally disabled adults. It was predicated on the
label: Paragraph

text: therapeutic benefits to be obtained by working in
label: Paragraph

text: agriculture.
label: Paragraph

text: 573 Byoung Cho, Village of the Dancing Fish, Paju, 1999.
label: Caption

text: Thereafter Cho’s career was devoted to the design of
label: Paragraph

text: modest middle-class houses, beginning with the U-Shaped
label: Paragraph

text: House that he built at Yangpyeong in 2002. This was a
label: Paragraph

text: single-storey courtyard house enclosed on two sides by a
label: Caption

text: wooded fence. He followed this with the most important
label: Paragraph

text: project of his early career, namely the Camerata Music
label: Paragraph

text: Studio, built in Heyri Art Valley in Paju in 2003 [575, 576].
label: Paragraph

text: This tour de force in fair-faced reinforced concrete is
label: Paragraph

text: situated barely 4.8 kilometres (3 miles) from the Korean
label: Paragraph

text: Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) separating North and South
label: Paragraph

text: Korea. Commissioned by Hwang In-Young, a retired,
label: Paragraph

text: nationally renowned disc jockey, this work is essentially
label: Paragraph

text: another large courtyard house, complemented by a semi-
label: Paragraph

text: public volume comprising a music space with a café anda
label: Paragraph

text: suspended mezzanine that doubles as an art gallery.
label: Paragraph

text: Following this, Cho designed a sequence of middle-class
label: Paragraph

text: patio houses, including a weekend house [574, 577] built
label: Paragraph

text: for his own occupation at Yangpyeong in 2004. This 14 x 14-
label: Paragraph

text: metre (46 x 46-foot), reinforced-concrete courtyard house
label: Caption

text: encloses a patio 7.4 x 7.4 metres (24 x 24 feet), which
label: Paragraph

text: happens to be the size of a traditional Korean patio or
label: Paragraph

text: madang, and exemplifies in different ways the subtle
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of the Korean aesthetic tradition as exemplified by
label: Paragraph

text: the terms mak and bium. This work is accompanied by
label: Paragraph

text: Cho’s Stone Wall house, also in Yangpyeong and of 2004
label: Caption

text: [578], which exemplifies his ability to mix and contrast
label: Paragraph

text: different materials effectively: in this instance metal
label: Paragraph

text: sheeting, wood cladding and dressed stonework. On other
label: Caption

text: occasions he used similar materials in different ways
label: Paragraph

text: expressively, as in his Hanil Visitors’ Center and Guest
label: Paragraph

text: House in Danyang-gun of 2009 [579].
