text: Soon after the millennium Cho received his first
label: Paragraph

text: corporate commission in the form of the Kiswire company
label: Paragraph

text: headquarters, erected in Tokyo in 2009. It was followed by a
label: Paragraph

text: succession of works for the same company, including a
label: Paragraph

text: Kiswire research facility, built at Johor Bahru, Malaysia, in
label: Paragraph

text: 2012, and a museum/training centre at Busan, Korea, in
label: Caption

text: 2013. Here a nine-storey building, clad with steel wire, not
label: Caption

text: only represents a company which specializes in the
label: Paragraph

text: production of steel wire but also uses wire in such a way as
label: Paragraph

text: to suggest a dematerialized mass, rendered partially in
label: Paragraph

text: woven wire components. Later Cho turned away from high-
label: Paragraph

text: tech materials in favour of wood - the traditional building
label: Paragraph

text: material with the least embodied energy - as in his design
label: Paragraph

text: for the NHN Kindergarten [580] located in a small valley
label: Paragraph

text: beside Bundang, south-east of Seoul. This nursery school
label: Paragraph

text: straddles a small river lined with cottonwood trees and
label: Paragraph

text: irrigating farmland. The overall pedagogical aim is to bring
label: Paragraph

text: nature into the classroom.
label: Paragraph

text: 580 Byoung Cho, NHN Kindergarten, Bundang, 2017.
label: Caption

text: The leading architectural studio from the next generation
label: Title

text: is the practice known as Mass Studies, comprising five
label: Paragraph

text: partners of which the leading figure is Minsuk Cho. Their
label: Paragraph

text: Daejeon University Residential College [581, 582], built on
label: Caption

text: a sloping site within an existing campus, is surely a seminal
label: Paragraph

text: work. Finished in 2017, this complex accommodates some
label: Paragraph

text: 600 students next to another equally compact dormitory
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Seung Hyo-Sang. Minsuk Cho’s reinforced-
label: Caption

text: concrete megaform, faced in traditional Korean black brick,
label: Paragraph

text: is an extraordinarily ingenious response responding to the
label: Paragraph

text: intractable challenge of building a large student dormitory
label: Paragraph

text: ona steeply sloping site. The final design solution consisted
label: Paragraph

text: of a parallelogram, stepped in plan and section and based
label: Paragraph

text: ona 5.4 x 5.4-metre (18 x 18-foot) module, with each
label: Paragraph

text: module housing four students. These modules are separated
label: Paragraph

text: from one another by a 2.4-metre (674-foot) wide ‘pocket’
label: Paragraph

text: space, the primary function of which is to light and ventilate
label: Paragraph

text: the corridor and occasionally to serve as a ‘built-in’ balcony.
label: Paragraph

text: The total complex comprises two segments: a four-storey
label: Paragraph

text: lower tier that rises directly from grade and is allocated to
label: Paragraph

text: male students and a five-storey upper tier reserved for
label: Paragraph

text: female students. These two tiers are separated by a
label: Paragraph

text: common student foyer, surrounded by seminar rooms and
label: Paragraph

text: linked to a central dining hall one floor above, which is
label: Paragraph

text: accessed by stairs directly from a campus road at the top of
label: Paragraph

text: the site.
label: Paragraph

text: 581 Mass Studies, Daejeon University Residential College, Daejeon, 2017.

text: Australia
label: Title

text: The first architecturally modern moment in the dominion of
label: Paragraph

text: Australia came in 1912 with the prize-winning entry
label: Paragraph

text: submitted for the new capital of Canberra by the American
label: Caption

text: architects Walter Burley Griffin and Marion Mahony.
label: Caption

text: Although Griffin and Mahony had both worked for Frank
label: Paragraph

text: Lloyd Wright during the high point of Wright’s Prairie Style
label: Title

text: (1898-1910), their plans for Canberra made virtually no
label: Paragraph

text: reference to his work. The same applied to the eclectic,
label: Paragraph

text: crypto-Gothic character of their Newman College, built for
label: Paragraph

text: the University of Melbourne in 1917. This reinforced-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete, stone-faced structure, oddly similar to the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Antoni Gaudi, found little following in the Antipodes, where
label: Paragraph

text: the Ecole des Beaux-Arts manner still held sway as far as
label: Paragraph

text: public works were concerned. As the Australian critic
label: Paragraph

text: Jennifer Taylor reminds us in her comprehensive study
label: Paragraph

text: Australian Architecture since 1960 the Modern Movement
label: Title

text: was slow to arrive in Australia and the work of Griffin and
label: Paragraph

text: Mahony was too individualistic to have a following. The first
label: Paragraph

text: glimmer of a more up-to-date modernity came with the
label: Paragraph

text: Swiss émigré Frederick Romberg’s Standhill flats,
label: Paragraph

text: Melbourne, of 1942-50, but it was a later migrant, Harry
label: Paragraph

text: Seidler, who would advance the modern cause in the design
label: Paragraph

text: of a house for his parents built next to a nature reserve in
label: Paragraph

text: Sydney in 1950. This house is virtually identical to the
label: Paragraph

text: unbuilt house in Foxborough, Massachusetts, that Seidler
label: Caption

text: designed in 1947 for Roland Thompson, who was also
label: Paragraph

text: working for Breuer at the time. Born in Vienna and educated
label: Paragraph

text: at the Graduate School of Design at Harvard under Gropius
label: Paragraph

text: and Breuer, Seidler arrived in Australia in 1948 and brought
label: Paragraph

text: with him Breuer’s neo-vernacular modern manner, as is
label: Paragraph

text: evident from the open plan of his parents’ house [583] in
label: Paragraph

text: which the living is separated from the dining via a free-
label: Paragraph

text: standing stone chimney. Travelling to Australia via Rio de
label: Caption

text: Janeiro, Seidler had also the opportunity to work briefly for
label: Paragraph

text: Oscar Niemeyer, whose baroque Corbusian manner is
label: Paragraph

text: echoed in the terrace mural of the Sydney house. Otherwise
label: Paragraph

text: the light tubular-steel p//oti and the long ramp linking the
label: Paragraph

text: terrace to the garden are variously derived from Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s Purist syntax and from Gropius’s own house
label: Title

text: built in Lincoln, Massachusetts, in 1938.
label: Caption

text: 583 Seidler, Rose House, Sydney, New South Wales, 1950. Plan.
label: Caption

text: The Australian-born architect John Andrews, a near
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary of Seidler, designed and built two exceptional
label: Paragraph

text: works in North America before moving back to Australia at
label: Paragraph

text: the end of the 1960s. The first was Scarborough College,
label: Paragraph

text: completed outside Toronto in 1969, and the second was
label: Paragraph

text: Gund Hall, built opposite Memorial Hall in Cambridge,
label: Caption

text: Massachusetts, and completed for the GSD in 1972. The
label: Paragraph

text: most brilliant work of Andrews’s equally fertile career in
label: Paragraph

text: Australia was his Technical and Further Education Complex
label: Paragraph

text: built at Woden, New South Wales, in 1981 [584]. The high-
label: Paragraph

text: tech hexagonal module on which this work is based was
label: Paragraph

text: surely more inspired in its realization than any of the
label: Paragraph

text: phantasmagorical images imagined by Archigram, as
label: Paragraph

text: Jennifer Taylor made clear in her description of the cable-
label: Paragraph

text: suspension principle on which it was based:
label: Paragraph

text: 584 Andrews, Technical and Further Education Complex, Woden, New South
label: Caption

text: Wales, 1981.
label: Caption

text: The complex is arranged on three levels with one level
label: Paragraph

text: above and one level below the public walkway. The main
label: Caption

text: units are those of the general office spaces. Each hexagonal
label: Paragraph

text: block is supported on four central columns which rise above
label: Paragraph

text: the height of the roof and serve as masts from which the
label: Paragraph

text: floors are suspended. Maximum strength is thus provided at
label: Paragraph

text: the cores and this allows for heavy loading in the centres,
label: Paragraph

text: leaving the perimeters free as work spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Both Andrews and Seidler would go on to build
label: Paragraph

text: structurally articulate, long-span, post-tensioned, medium-
label: Paragraph

text: rise offices for the government complex in Canberra just
label: Paragraph

text: before the completion in 1988 of the new Australian
label: Paragraph

text: Parliament Building. This giant earthwork-cum-monumental
label: Paragraph

text: roofwork, with spread-eagled ministerial wings opening out
label: Paragraph

text: from the parliamentary chamber, was designed by the
label: Paragraph

text: Italian-born Romaldo Giurgola and the Australian architect
label: Paragraph

text: Richard Thorp, who jointly won the 1980 competition for the
label: Paragraph

text: building (restricted to Australian architects) with a design
label: Paragraph

text: which endorsed, as it were, the topographic nexus at the
label: Paragraph

text: centre of the Griffin-Mahony 1912 plan. However, in terms
label: Paragraph

text: of identity the cascading shell vaults of Jorn Utzon’s Sydney
label: Caption

text: Opera House, designed in 1957 and completed in 1973,
label: Paragraph

text: would prove to be a much more powerful symbol for an
label: Paragraph

text: aspiring nation than the telluric form of the Parliament.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from responding to the challenging profile of Sydney
label: Paragraph

text: Harbour Bridge, the opera house may have been
label: Paragraph

text: responsible, in the long run, for the cult of the expressive
label: Paragraph

text: roof as this appears in Australian domestic architecture
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the 1970s.
label: Paragraph

text: It is significant in this regard that the mythical ‘outback’
label: Paragraph

text: sheep-shearing shed should first appear as a self-conscious
label: Paragraph

text: trope in Glenn Murcutt’s Marie Short House [585], built in
label: Caption

text: 1974 on a 700-acre (2.8-square-kilometre) farm at Kempsey,
label: Caption

text: New South Wales, some 500 kilometres (310 miles) north of
label: Paragraph

text: Sydney. Like Mies van der Rohe’s Farnsworth House of 1950,
label: Paragraph

text: by which it was surely influenced, the timber superstructure
label: Paragraph

text: of this house was elevated 80 centimetres (2 feet 7 inches)
label: Paragraph

text: above grade, not only to raise the building above the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding floodplain, but also to prevent poisonous snakes
label: Paragraph

text: from entering. This was Murcutt’s first application of a
label: Paragraph

text: corrugated-iron roof to a timber-framed, single-storey
label: Caption

text: house, a formula that he would repeat with variations in
label: Paragraph

text: both framing and roof form over the next two decades. The
label: Paragraph

text: 61-centimetre (24-inch) radius of the bent, corrugated-iron
label: Caption

text: sheet that Murcutt employed to cap the ridge of the Marie
label: Paragraph

text: Short House was the tightest bend one could press into a
label: Paragraph

text: corrugated sheet. Due to the relative remoteness of his
label: Paragraph

text: houses, Murcutt was often obliged to employ a
label: Paragraph

text: constructional repertoire with which rural builders were
label: Paragraph

text: familiar - above all timber framing and corrugated-iron
label: Paragraph

text: roofing - to which he habitually added multiple layers of
label: Paragraph

text: protective screens, a filtering layer derived from the
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese domestic tradition. It is interesting to observe in
label: Paragraph

text: this regard that the Marie Short House has three
label: Paragraph

text: membranes: a sliding sunscreen outer layer of adjustable
label: Title

text: louvres; an intermediate sliding screen to keep out insects;
label: Paragraph

text: and another layer of adjustable louvres in metal and glass in
label: Paragraph

text: order to secure the house at night or during the winter
label: Paragraph

text: months. Perhaps no one has written more appreciatively of
label: Paragraph

text: Murcutt’s use of multiple membranes combined with sheet-
label: Paragraph

text: metal roofs than Philip Drew in his 1987 study of Murcutt’s
label: Paragraph

text: work entitled Leaves of /ron, with its knowing allusion to
label: Paragraph

text: John Ruskin’s Stones of Venice of 1851. As Drew put it:
label: Paragraph

text: 585 Murcutt, Marie Short / Glenn Murcutt House, Kempsey, New South Wales,
label: Caption

text: One of the consequences of the side use of louvered
label: Paragraph

text: screens is to enhance the continuity of the building surface
label: Paragraph

text: since the louvers read as a change in the surface texture
label: Paragraph

text: rather than as a break in the material. Moreover, the louvers
label: Paragraph

text: add to the delicacy of the forms. The thinness of the iron
label: Paragraph

text: sheets and the hard leaf-like character of the buildings is
label: Paragraph

text: advanced by expressing the edges of the sheets and
label: Paragraph

text: projecting the profile end sections of the break-pressed
label: Paragraph

text: gutters.?
label: Paragraph

text: Drew explains how Murcutt enhanced the ecological
label: Paragraph

text: profile of his roofs by using skylights covered with fixed
label: Paragraph

text: louvres, raised clear of the glass and angled at 32 degrees
label: Caption

text: so as to exclude summer sun while permitting the entry of
label: Paragraph

text: winter sunlight. Moreover, a second layer of break-pressed,
label: Paragraph

text: corrugated iron was invariably added to the apex of the roof
label: Paragraph

text: as a means of evacuating hot air from the house. Break
label: Paragraph

text: pressing is a technique employed to bend metal sheet into
label: Paragraph

text: the required profiles.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout his career, Murcutt has built in wood save for
label: Paragraph

text: the structural frame and metal roof as we find in his Marika-
label: Paragraph

text: Alderton House [586, 587], erected on the beach in Yirrkala
label: Caption

text: in the Northern Territory in 1994. Commissioned by the
label: Paragraph

text: aboriginal leader Banduk Marika, this single-storey house
label: Caption

text: was also raised off the ground, not only to avoid flooding but
label: Paragraph

text: also to provide a clear view of the horizon - a defensive
label: Paragraph

text: feature that remains particularly important in aboriginal
label: Paragraph

text: culture. Its location, 12% degrees south of the equator,
label: Paragraph

text: where humidity reaches eighty per cent, demanded that the
label: Paragraph

text: house should be as open as possible in order to facilitate
label: Paragraph

text: cross ventilation. This entailed full-height, counterbalanced,
label: Paragraph

text: pivoting, louvred shutters, which also doubled as a means of
label: Paragraph

text: securing the house at night or in the off season. In addition
label: Paragraph

text: a slatted timber floor was provided throughout to filter out
label: Paragraph

text: sand tracked in from the beach. This permeability was
label: Paragraph

text: combined with roof vents capable of releasing the build up
label: Paragraph

text: of air pressure when the house is exposed to winds of
label: Paragraph

text: cyclonic force. Large timber-faced panels extended beyond
label: Caption

text: the house at every structural bay, in order to provide
label: Paragraph

text: privacy for the occupants. Reminiscent of Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: brise-solei/, these of cantilevered timber fins reappear as
label: Paragraph

text: formal devices in the dormitory block that Murcutt built for
label: Paragraph

text: the Boyd Education Centre on a bucolic riverside site in
label: Paragraph

text: West Cambewarra, New South Wales, in 1999. Designed in
label: Caption

text: collaboration with Reg Lark and his wife, the architect
label: Paragraph

text: Wendy Lewin, this was a dormitory block where visiting
label: Paragraph

text: students could stay overnight. At one end of this two- to
label: Paragraph

text: four-storey building is a portal frame in steel spanning over
label: Paragraph

text: the dining hall and kitchen. The large scale and the frontal
label: Paragraph

text: placement of the frame make this the first public work of
label: Paragraph

text: Murcutt’s career, and in many respects it is one of his finest
label: Paragraph

text: achievements. The dormitory’s furnishings were a tour de
label: Paragraph

text: force in well-crafted cabinetwork, as Haig Beck and Jackie
label: Paragraph

text: Cooper have remarked:
label: Paragraph

text: 586 Murcutt, Marika-Alderton House, Eastern Arnhem Land, Northern Territory,
label: Caption

text: 587 Murcutt, Marika-Alderton House, Eastern Arnhem Land, Northern Territory,
label: Caption

text: 1991-94. Sketch section showing the pertinent climatological factors and
label: Caption

text: orientation that influenced the design.
label: Paragraph

text: The floors, bed supports and windows of the bedrooms are
label: Paragraph

text: in natural timber. The brushwood box floors are pink. Doors,
label: Paragraph

text: cupboards and ceilings are yellow hoop pine ply ... The deep
label: Paragraph

text: window sills are beveled - framelike - making the edges
label: Paragraph

text: finer, which, in addition to containing views, affects the way
label: Paragraph

text: the timber takes the light ... Except for plywood, recycled
label: Paragraph

text: timbers are used throughout the building. Columns are
label: Paragraph

text: brush-box. Beams and purlins are blackbutt. The big doors
label: Caption

text: of the hall are old growth Oregon, twenty recycled timbers
label: Caption

text: forming the 170mm x 75mm jambs.*
label: Paragraph

text: Peter Stutchbury and Richard Leplastrier, Murcutt’s
label: Caption

text: closest colleagues, have played key roles in the
label: Paragraph

text: development of the ‘outback’ character of the modern
label: Paragraph

text: Australian house. Upon graduating in 1963, Leplastrier went
label: Paragraph

text: to work immediately for the Utzon office on the
label: Paragraph

text: development of the opera house prior to going to Japan to
label: Paragraph

text: study traditional Japanese architecture under the tutelage of
label: Paragraph

text: Tomoya Masuda. As a result of these formative experiences
label: Paragraph

text: and the influence of Murcutt, Leplastrier’s houses are
label: Paragraph

text: invariably modular, timber-framed structures, raised clear of
label: Paragraph

text: the ground and covered by pitched roofs. A similar ad hoc
label: Paragraph

text: programmatic approach is evident in the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Stutchbury, although the most evident reference to Japan is
label: Paragraph

text: his West Head House of 1991, situated on an undulating site
label: Paragraph

text: overlooking Clareville Beach, New South Wales. However,
label: Paragraph

text: Stutchbury’s most compelling work to date is agricultural,
label: Paragraph

text: that is to say his all-metal, Neo-Constructivist, demountable
label: Paragraph

text: sheep-shearing shed, the so-called Deepwater Woolshed
label: Title

text: [588], built at Bulls Run, near Wagga Wagga, New South
label: Caption

text: Wales, in 2003.
label: Paragraph

text: 588 Stutchbury, Deepwater Woolshed, Wagga Wagga, New South Wales, 2003.
label: Caption

text: As much part of the Australian ‘bush’ tradition as Murcutt
label: Paragraph

text: or Stutchbury, Lindsay and Kerry Clare were apprenticed to
label: Paragraph

text: the Queensland architect Gabriel Poole before establishing
label: Paragraph

text: their own practice on the Sunshine Coast in 1979. Although
label: Paragraph

text: Poole had worked for Powell and Moya in London in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s, on returning to Australia he assumed the paradigm
label: Paragraph

text: of the light-weight, ‘outback’ shed as is evident from his
label: Paragraph

text: Dobie House, built on a precipitous site at Buderim on the
label: Caption

text: Sunshine Coast in 1970. The Clares followed suite with their
label: Paragraph

text: own house at Buderim (1991), making a similar use of a
label: Paragraph

text: bowed sheet-iron roof. They used a flat version of the same
label: Paragraph

text: material for their ‘surf-side’ housing built on Rainbow Beach
label: Paragraph

text: [589] in the following year, its staggered chevron layout
label: Paragraph

text: being capped by a reiteration of monopitched corrugated-
label: Paragraph

text: iron roofs. A larger and more complex version of a similar
label: Paragraph

text: roof crowns their most public building, the Queensland
label: Paragraph

text: Gallery of Modern Art (GOMA), completed in 2006.
label: Paragraph

text: 589 Clare Design (Lindsay + Kerry Clare), Rainbow Beach Housing, Sunshine
label: Caption

text: Coast, Queensland, 1992.
label: Caption

text: Richard Francis-Jones, the founding partner and leading
label: Paragraph

text: designer of the Sydney-based practice of Francis-Jones
label: Paragraph

text: Morehen Thorp (FJMT), was also influenced by the ‘outback’
label: Paragraph

text: iron roof as this appears in his early work in the glass and
label: Paragraph

text: timber portico that he designed for the main entrance into
label: Caption

text: the John Niland Scientia Building [592] on the University of
label: Caption

text: New South Wales campus in Sydney, completed at the
label: Paragraph

text: millennium. A similar concept, only this time reiterated as
label: Paragraph

text: four consecutive parasols and built exclusively of laminated
label: Paragraph

text: wood, constituted the portico of his addition to the Auckland
label: Paragraph

text: Art Museum, New Zealand, of 2011. However, Francis-Jones
label: Paragraph

text: has possibly been at his best in civic works where the trope
label: Paragraph

text: of the detached monopitched roof was no longer the
label: Paragraph

text: sculptural parti pris of the design, as in the Law Faculty that
label: Paragraph

text: he added to the Gothic Revival campus of the University of
label: Caption

text: Sydney in 2003. A similar emphasis on the mass form of the
label: Paragraph

text: building rather than the roof is evident in the library-cum-
label: Paragraph

text: community centre that he designed and built for the Surry
label: Paragraph

text: Hills suburb of Sydney in 2009 [590, 591]. Both works were
label: Paragraph

text: conceived as sustainable environments with full-height,
label: Paragraph

text: adjustable vertical louvres mounted either behind a fully
label: Caption

text: glazed curtain wall (in the law faculty) or in front of a similar
label: Paragraph

text: double wall (in the Surry Hills library). In both instances the
label: Paragraph

text: angle of the brise soleil is controlled automatically by servo-
label: Paragraph

text: mechanisms reacting to the movement of the sun and to
label: Paragraph

text: the difference between outside and inside temperatures.
label: Paragraph

text: 590 FJMT, Surry Hills Library, Sydney, New South Wales, 2009. Section.
label: Caption

text: 591 FJMT, Surry Hills Library, Sydney, New South Wales, 2009.
label: Caption

text: 592 FJMT, John Niland Scientia Building, UNSW, New South Wales, 2000.
label: Caption

text: More than any other contemporary practice of
label: Paragraph

text: comparable calibre in Australia, FIMT has been consistently
label: Paragraph

text: engaged in the design and construction of large-scale public
label: Paragraph

text: and/or commercial buildings. Among these works the most
label: Paragraph

text: distinguished are the Owen G. Glenn Business School,
label: Paragraph

text: Auckland, New Zealand (2003); the School of Information
label: Paragraph

text: Technologies for UNSW, Sydney (2011); and the Tyree
label: Paragraph

text: Energy Technologies building, also for UNSW (2012). Many
label: Paragraph

text: of these works derive their plastic character from the
label: Paragraph

text: unique, rather theatrical concept of lateral exfoliation, that
label: Paragraph

text: is to say the folding out of brises solei! so as to visually
label: Paragraph

text: engage the surrounding landscape, thereby emphasizing a
label: Paragraph

text: topographical affinity between the building and its context.
label: Paragraph

text: In all of this work the issue of sustainability is given priority,
label: Paragraph

text: as it was in the UNSW Red Centre, designed by Francis-Jones
label: Paragraph

text: in collaboration with Romaldo Giurgola soon after he
label: Paragraph

text: returned to Australia in 1992.
label: Paragraph

text: Another figure of consequence on the Sydney scene is
label: Paragraph

text: Alex Popov, whose controlled tectonic manner is surely due
label: Paragraph

text: to his formation in the Royal Danish Academy, from which
label: Paragraph

text: he graduated in 1971. Popov worked for both Henning
label: Paragraph

text: Larsen and Je@rn Utzon, before finally migrating to Australia
label: Paragraph

text: to start his own practice in 1984. Popov has perhaps been at
label: Paragraph

text: his best in low- to medium-rise, high-density housing
label: Paragraph

text: estates, although one of his finest private houses is his
label: Paragraph

text: Martin-Weber residence in Mittagong, New South Wales, of
label: Caption

text: One of the most independent architects of the younger
label: Paragraph

text: generation is Sean Godsell, who opened his office in
label: Paragraph

text: Melbourne in 1994 and completed his first characteristically
label: Paragraph

text: timber-louvred vacation house, the Carter Tucker House in
label: Caption

text: Breamlea, Victoria [593], in 2000. One of the most
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive features of his domestic work was the capacity of
label: Paragraph

text: his houses to be opened or closed at will by virtue of top-
label: Paragraph

text: hinged louvred panels that may be readily raised, or
label: Paragraph

text: dropped down so as to appear flush with the rest of the
label: Paragraph

text: louvred timber envelope. A more sophisticated version of
label: Paragraph

text: the same idea was Godsell’s Peninsula House of 2003,
label: Paragraph

text: situated 60 miles (96.5 kilometres) south of Melbourne.
label: Paragraph

text: Godsell’s domestic aesthetic assumed a more monumental
label: Paragraph

text: character in his larger institutional structures, such as his
label: Paragraph

text: Woodleigh School science building erected at Baxter,
label: Caption

text: Victoria, in 2002. Here the building is treated as a galleria
label: Paragraph

text: housing a series of laboratories. It is faced with a reiteration
label: Paragraph

text: of vertical timber louvres which have a certain thickness
label: Paragraph

text: and are placed about one foot apart. The floor of the
label: Paragraph

text: building rises and falls with the shape of the land, while the
label: Paragraph

text: roof is maintained as a horizontal datum against which the
label: Paragraph

text: topography is revealed.
label: Paragraph

text: 593 Godsell, Carter Tucker House, Breamlea, Victoria, 2000.
label: Caption

text: One of the most the distinguished Australian architects
label: Paragraph

text: was Kerry Hill, who, with offices in Perth and Singapore,
label: Paragraph

text: largely built outside of Australia, realizing a series of luxury
label: Paragraph

text: hotels across the Asian continent. Born and brought up in
label: Paragraph

text: Perth, Western Australia, Hill was surely one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: prolific and culturally sensitive architects of his generation,
label: Paragraph

text: although due to his residence in Singapore and the fact that
label: Paragraph

text: most of his work is in Asia he is rarely acknowledged as an
label: Paragraph

text: Australian architect. Profoundly influenced by Geoffrey Bawa
label: Paragraph

text: and by his hotel client Adrian Zecha, Hill became involved
label: Paragraph

text: with ancient Asian culture over a wide front as is evident
label: Paragraph

text: from his luxury hotel and guest house of 1994 known as the
label: Paragraph

text: Datai [594]. Distantly related to Wright’s Imperial Hotel and
label: Paragraph

text: subtly influenced by the local vernacular, this complex was
label: Paragraph

text: implanted amid the tropical foothills of the Teluk Datai and
label: Paragraph

text: elevated some 300 metres (984 feet) above the ocean; the
label: Paragraph

text: élite clientele have to walk through a rainforest in order to
label: Paragraph

text: gain access to the beach club. Towards the end of his life Hill
label: Paragraph

text: returned to his native Perth after winning the 2005
label: Paragraph

text: competition for the State Theatre of Western Australia,
label: Caption

text: which he saw realized in 2010 and seems to share an
label: Paragraph

text: affinity with the aesthetic work of Sean Godsell.
label: Paragraph

text: 594 Hill, Datai, Malaysia, 1994.
label: Caption

text: New Zealand
label: Title

text: One of the first indications of a sophisticated architectural
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility in New Zealand at the end of the 19th century
label: Paragraph

text: was John Campbell’s Dunedin police station of 1896, subtly
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by Richard Norman Shaw’s New Scotland Yard,
label: Paragraph

text: London, of 1890. Susceptible to the same English Free Style,
label: Paragraph

text: but closer to Philip Webb and C.F.A. Voysey rather than
label: Paragraph

text: Shaw, was the architect R.K. Binney, who, after working for
label: Paragraph

text: Edwin Lutyens in London, returned to New Zealand in 1912
label: Paragraph

text: to design and build in 1922 a remarkable Voyseyesque
label: Paragraph

text: house at Remuera, near Auckland. However, the British Arts
label: Paragraph

text: and Crafts was not the only inspiration at this time, as is
label: Paragraph

text: evident from the University College, Auckland, of 1921,
label: Paragraph

text: designed by the American architect R.A. Lippincott. Its forms
label: Paragraph

text: and rhythms owed something to Walter Burley Griffin’s
label: Paragraph

text: Newman College, Melbourne, harking back in terms of
label: Paragraph

text: tradition to Frank Lloyd Wright, for whom Griffin had worked
label: Paragraph

text: before migrating to Australia on winning the Canberra
label: Paragraph

text: competition in 1912. Other American architects exercised an
label: Paragraph

text: influence on New Zealand architecture, as may be seen in
label: Paragraph

text: the Wellington railway station, designed by William Gray
label: Caption

text: Young in 1929 in a Beaux-Arts manner, patently indebted to
label: Paragraph

text: McKim, Mead and White’s Pennsylvania Station, New York, of
label: Caption

text: Modernism in the continental European sense did not
label: Paragraph

text: begin to emerge in New Zealand until the second half of the
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s and the early 1940s, when it came into being as part
label: Paragraph

text: of a socio-cultural transformation inspired by the
label: Paragraph

text: ascendancy of a socialist government in New Zealand,
label: Paragraph

text: which came to power as a result of the worldwide stock
label: Paragraph

text: market crash of 1929. This political shift was responsible for
label: Paragraph

text: the sympathetic environment which welcomed the Austrian
label: Paragraph

text: architect Ernst Plischke when he migrated to New Zealand
label: Paragraph

text: in 1939, just in time to witness the 1940 Art Deco
label: Paragraph

text: Centennial Exhibition, which celebrated the foundation of
label: Paragraph

text: the nation in 1840. As Julia Gatley informs us in her book
label: Paragraph

text: Long Live the Modern (2003), Plischke was not the only
label: Paragraph

text: German-speaking architect fleeing from the Third Reich to
label: Paragraph

text: New Zealand, since among others was his compatriot
label: Paragraph

text: Heinrich Kulka, close to Adolf Loos, who had supervised the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of Loos’s last works, the semi-detached houses
label: Paragraph

text: built for the Austrian Werkbund Exhibition of 1933. (Plischke
label: Caption

text: for his part had been trained by Peter Behrens in Vienna and
label: Paragraph

text: had thereafter worked for Behrens and briefly for the
label: Paragraph

text: Austrian architects Karl Ehn and Josef Frank.) Much of the
label: Paragraph

text: modern initiative in New Zealand during this period was due
label: Paragraph

text: to the newly established Department of Housing
label: Title

text: Construction (DHC), for which Plischke started to work soon
label: Paragraph

text: after his arrival, designing multi-unit housing projects,
label: Paragraph

text: community centres, and workers’ housing sponsored by the
label: Paragraph

text: state in connection with the construction of hydro-electric
label: Paragraph

text: dams from 1939 to 1947. The most striking DHC housing
label: Paragraph

text: schemes in which he was involved are the Orakei
label: Paragraph

text: apartments (1941), the Mount Eden apartments (1942) and
label: Paragraph

text: the Greys Avenue flats (1947), all built in Auckland, plus the
label: Paragraph

text: Dixon Street flats [597], completed in Wellington in 1944.
label: Caption

text: Plischke’s beautifully proportioned, free-standing Kahn
label: Paragraph

text: House [595], built in 1942 for a highly cultivated German
label: Paragraph

text: client in Ngaio, Wellington, also dates from this period. That
label: Paragraph

text: year also saw the realization of his design for the Tasman
label: Paragraph

text: Memorial [596]: a thin orthogonal tower rising from a plaza,
label: Paragraph

text: both built of concrete and erected on a high, forested bluff
label: Paragraph

text: overlooking Golden Bay at Tarakohe.
label: Caption

text: 595 Plischke, Kahn House, Ngaio, Wellington, 1942.
label: Caption

text: 596 Plischke, Tasman Memorial, Tarakohe, 1942.
label: Caption

text: 597 Plischke, Dixon Street Flats, Wellington, 1944.
label: Caption

text: In 1948 Plischke left the DHC to form a partnership with
label: Paragraph

text: the New Zealand architect Cedric Firth that endured until
label: Paragraph

text: 1963, when he finally returned to Vienna, where he lived out
label: Paragraph

text: the rest of his life as a professor of architecture totally
label: Paragraph

text: removed from practice. Plischke’s fifteen-year partnership
label: Paragraph

text: with Firth led to the design of some forty houses of a
label: Paragraph

text: delicate, timber-framed, pavilioned format. These works
label: Caption

text: contributed to the evolution of a modern New Zealand
label: Paragraph

text: domestic manner, comparable to the Southern Californian
label: Paragraph

text: modern house of virtually the same date, as developed by
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolf Schindler, Richard Neutra, J.R. Davidson, Gregory Ain
label: Caption

text: and Raphael Soriano. Other than these modest modern
label: Paragraph

text: houses, the high point of the Plischke-Firth practice was the
label: Paragraph

text: eight-storey Massey House [598] built in downtown
label: Caption

text: Wellington between 1951 and 1957. This work stands out
label: Paragraph

text: not only for its urban location and height but also for the
label: Paragraph

text: fact that it was the first application of curtain walling in New
label: Paragraph

text: Zealand. This type of cladding was developed further in the
label: Paragraph

text: Dunedin Hospital boiler house of 1959 designed by
label: Caption

text: Stephenson and Turner and in Jack Manning’s ultra-elegant
label: Title

text: AMP Building built in Auckland in 1962. Following Plischke’s
label: Paragraph

text: departure, Firth practised independently, proving his
label: Paragraph

text: capacity as a civic architect with a beautifully proportioned,
label: Paragraph

text: three-storey, box-framed concrete office building realized in
label: Caption

text: Nelson in 1966 and known as the Monro State Building.
label: Paragraph

text: 598 Plischke and Firth, Massey House, Wellington, 1951-57.
label: Caption

text: The most fertile architect of the next generation was
label: Paragraph

text: Michael Warren, who, as the design partner of Warren and
label: Paragraph

text: Mahoney, pioneered what has been called the ‘New Zealand
label: Paragraph

text: shed’ style, first exhibited in the monopitched timber
label: Paragraph

text: structure that he built in Christchurch in 1962 as his
label: Paragraph

text: combined residence and studio [599]. In his later university
label: Paragraph

text: work Warren was greatly influenced by British New
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalism, which he had experienced in London in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s while working for Powell & Moya. Typical of his
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalist manner are the three-storey dormitory blocks that
label: Paragraph

text: he built for Christchurch College in the University of
label: Paragraph

text: Canterbury in 1964. A more refined tectonic version of
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalism can be found in the Wellington Meteorological
label: Paragraph

text: Office [600] built in Wellington in 1968 to the designs of
label: Paragraph

text: William Alington while he was employed by the Ministry of
label: Paragraph

text: Works.
label: Paragraph

text: 599 Warren, Warren House and Studio, Christchurch, 1962.
label: Caption

text: 600 Alington, Meteorological Office, Wellington, 1968.
label: Caption

text: A certain species of vernacular modernism is detectable
label: Paragraph

text: in New Zealand’s residential architecture, particularly after
label: Paragraph

text: the building of John Scott’s Patterson House in Hawke’s Bay
label: Caption

text: in 1967 and in 1965 with the first phase of lan Athfield’s
label: Paragraph

text: own ever-changing house and studio [601] that cascades
label: Paragraph

text: down from the hills above Wellington. This ad hoc approach
label: Paragraph

text: to building can also be found in Roger Walker’s Britten
label: Paragraph

text: House built in Wellington in 1974 and in the best work of the
label: Paragraph

text: Queensland architect John Blair, when he had the
label: Paragraph

text: opportunity to build largely in timber on spectacular
label: Paragraph

text: panoramic landscapes of great natural beauty. This
label: Paragraph

text: montage-like assembly of idiosyncratic architectural forms,
label: Paragraph

text: inspired by a largely fictitious New Zealand vernacular,
label: Paragraph

text: surely also accounts for the catatonic character of the air
label: Paragraph

text: terminal building that Roger Walker designed for Whakatane
label: Caption

text: Airport in 1971.
label: Paragraph

text: 601 Athfield, Athfield House and Studio, Wellington, 1965.
label: Caption

text: Chapter 4
label: Title

text: Europe
label: Title

text: It is surely paradoxical to indulge in such extensive
label: Paragraph

text: coverage here of European modern architecture, given that
label: Paragraph

text: the main aim of expanding this history is to go beyond its
label: Paragraph

text: former Eurocentric/transatlantic bias. However, until this
label: Paragraph

text: edition, a number of European countries were excluded from
label: Paragraph

text: the account, in particular all the Nordic countries except
label: Paragraph

text: Finland. This blanket omission led to the absence of
label: Paragraph

text: architects who, after the Second World War, made major
label: Paragraph

text: contributions to the evolution of the Modern Movement,
label: Paragraph

text: such as the distinguished architect Arne Jacobsen from
label: Paragraph

text: Denmark or the Norwegian Sverre Fehn. Earlier editions also
label: Paragraph

text: failed to acknowledge the importance of the Stockholm
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition of 1930, which not only transformed the scope of
label: Paragraph

text: Swedish architecture but also inaugurated the visual and
label: Paragraph

text: material culture of Swedish social democracy.
label: Paragraph

text: This section also features such eccentric achievements
label: Paragraph

text: as P.V. Jensen-Klint’s Grundtvig’s Church, Copenhagen, of
label: Caption

text: 1926-40 and Dimitri Pikionis’s archaeologically inspired
label: Paragraph

text: Karamanos House, built in Athens in 1925, plus such major
label: Paragraph

text: urban interventions as Karl Ehn’s Karl Marx-Hof perimeter
label: Title

text: housing block in Vienna of 1930. Also different to the
label: Paragraph

text: dominant approach of the Modern Movement was Joze
label: Paragraph

text: Pleénik’s extraordinary transformation of Prague Castle,
label: Paragraph

text: which he converted into a presidential residence for the
label: Paragraph

text: newly founded Czech state. Other outstanding but
label: Paragraph

text: somewhat atypical European works appear here, such as
label: Paragraph

text: Erich Mendelsohn’s and Serge Chermayeff’s De La Warr
label: Title

text: Pavilion at Bexhill-on-Sea in the UK and Henry van de
label: Caption

text: Velde’s Kréller-Muller Museum in Otterlo.
label: Caption

text: Another shortfall that this edition seeks to redress is the
label: Paragraph

text: second modernity that came into being with the
label: Paragraph

text: reconstruction of Italy after 1945. This saw the rise of such
label: Paragraph

text: committed intellectuals as Bruno Zevi and Ernesto Rogers,
label: Paragraph

text: and the architectural practices of Carlo Scarpa in Venice and
label: Paragraph

text: of BBPR, Franco Albini, Gio Ponti, Giancarlo de Carlo and Pier
label: Paragraph

text: Luigi Nervi in Milan. This Italian generation would be
label: Paragraph

text: followed by equally significant figures including the
label: Paragraph

text: historian-theorist Manfredo Tafuri, who, together with the
label: Paragraph

text: philosopher Massimo Carriari, transformed the discourse of
label: Paragraph

text: the Italian architectural scene in the 1960s. They and such
label: Paragraph

text: architects as Vittorio Gregotti, Aldo Rossi and Giorgio Grassi
label: Paragraph

text: were barely mentioned in previous editions. Although
label: Paragraph

text: developments towards the end of the 20th century were
label: Paragraph

text: featured in the fourth edition - notably those in Finland,
label: Paragraph

text: France, Spain and Japan - among the mid-century European
label: Paragraph

text: architects previously left out of this account were a number
label: Paragraph

text: of distinguished Germans who came into their own during
label: Paragraph

text: the famous West German economic miracle of the 1950s;
label: Paragraph

text: they included figures such as Hans Scharoun, Egon
label: Paragraph

text: Eiermann, Gunter Behnisch, Frei Otto and Oswald Mathias
label: Title

text: Ungers.
label: Paragraph

text: Because much of the first edition of this work was written
label: Paragraph

text: during the last quarter of the 20th century, | have felt it
label: Paragraph

text: necessary to return to a particularly fertile moment in
label: Paragraph

text: British architecture dating back to the 1930s but continuing
label: Paragraph

text: into the 1950s. The zenith of this period remains for me the
label: Paragraph

text: Royal Festival Hall in London of 1951, one of the finest
label: Caption

text: public buildings completed in Britain since 1945. Britain has
label: Paragraph

text: been given a particular focus in this revisitation of Europe
label: Paragraph

text: because | wanted to demonstrate the way in which there
label: Paragraph

text: has been a continuous, though fluctuating modern tradition
label: Paragraph

text: in the UK: from the pioneering architecture of the 1930s to
label: Title

text: the Brutalist episode of the mid-1960s, followed at the
label: Paragraph

text: beginning of the 1970s by the Anglo-Italian High-Tech
label: Paragraph

text: movement pioneered by Richard Rogers, Norman Foster and
label: Paragraph

text: Renzo Piano.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps the most prejudicial aspect of this European
label: Paragraph

text: overview is the inclusion of Belgium and the exclusion of the
label: Paragraph

text: Netherlands. | have given space to Belgium in this expanded
label: Paragraph

text: history on two counts: first, because between the two world
label: Paragraph

text: wars it played a particularly fertile role in the evolution of
label: Paragraph

text: the Modern Movement and, second, because it has
label: Paragraph

text: invariably been given short shrift in recent accounts of this
label: Paragraph

text: topic. The Netherlands, on the other hand, has been omitted
label: Paragraph

text: because much Dutch work has been covered in earlier
label: Paragraph

text: editions and because the country’s pioneering architectural
label: Title

text: tradition does not seem to have survived the neo-liberal
label: Paragraph

text: destruction of its hitherto long-standing socialist traditions.
label: Paragraph

text: The other evident omission from this European overview is
label: Paragraph

text: the federation of Switzerland, which has been covered
label: Paragraph

text: intermittently in previous editions.
label: Paragraph

text: United Kingdom
label: Title

text: Apart from houses at Silver End, Essex, of 1927, expressly
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Sir John Burnet & Partners for the British steel
label: Caption

text: window manufacturer Francis Henry Crittall, the Modern
label: Caption

text: Movement in England was initially the work of talented
label: Paragraph

text: émigrés. These architects came to the country in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s and early 1930s, either because they were political
label: Paragraph

text: refugees or because they felt stifled by the provincialism of
label: Paragraph

text: the British Commonwealth, as was the case with the New
label: Paragraph

text: Zealanders Amyas Connell and Basil Ward, who arrived in
label: Paragraph

text: the UK in 1929, and the Canadian architect-engineer Wells
label: Paragraph

text: Coates, who came to London in 1927. Connell began with
label: Paragraph

text: his spread-eagled design of High and Over [602], built at
label: Paragraph

text: Amersham, Buckinghamshire, for the archaeologist Bernard
label: Caption

text: Ashmole in 1931. Connell and Ward later joined forces with
label: Paragraph

text: Colin Lucas on the strength of a concrete house that the
label: Paragraph

text: latter built at Platt, Kent, in 1933 [603]. Throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: second half of the 1930s, this partnership produced a
label: Paragraph

text: succession of steel-framed, cement-rendered houses, the
label: Paragraph

text: elegant character of which was largely derived from their
label: Paragraph

text: rhythmically detailed steel fenestration and balustrading.
label: Caption

text: 602 Connell, High and Over, Amersham, Buckinghamshire, 1931.
label: Caption

text: 603 Lucas, house in Kent, 1933.
label: Caption

text: First among the continental émigrés to have an impact
label: Paragraph

text: on the British scene was the Russian-Jewish émigré Berthold
label: Paragraph

text: Lubetkin, not least with his founding of the Tecton office
label: Paragraph

text: upon his arrival from Paris in 1931; this led to the design
label: Paragraph

text: and realization in 1935 of the first Highpoint apartment
label: Paragraph

text: block in Highgate, London (fig. 260), with its structure and
label: Paragraph

text: mode of erection devised by the young engineer Ove Arup,
label: Paragraph

text: born in Britain of Danish-Norwegian parents. Lubetkin
label: Paragraph

text: followed this achievement with the design of a number of
label: Paragraph

text: equally inventive reinforced-concrete structures for the
label: Paragraph

text: London Zoo, including the famous Penguin Pool with its
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement of interlocking reinforced-concrete ramps
label: Caption

text: calculated by the newly arrived German-Jewish engineer
label: Paragraph

text: Felix Samuely. Lubetkin and his colleagues were followed on
label: Paragraph

text: the British scene by Erich Mendelsohn, who, together with
label: Paragraph

text: the Russian-born, British-educated Serge Chermayeff,
label: Paragraph

text: designed the remarkably dynamic De La Warr Pavilion [605]
label: Caption

text: built at Bexhill-on-Sea, East Sussex, in 1935.
label: Caption

text: In 1937 Samuely collaborated with the émigré German-
label: Paragraph

text: Jewish architect Arthur Korn on the extremely radical MARS
label: Title

text: plan for London. MARS (Modern Architecture Research
label: Caption

text: Society) effectively became the British wing of the CIAM
label: Paragraph

text: through the initiative of Wells Coates, who represented
label: Paragraph

text: Britain at the third CIAM congress, which took place on the
label: Paragraph

text: SS Patris during its voyage from Marseille to Athens in 1933.
label: Paragraph

text: At its inception MARS was totally committed to the socialist
label: Paragraph

text: cause of public housing, as was made clear in its first
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition of 1934 and again in its last show of 1938, just
label: Paragraph

text: prior to its eclipse by the Second World War. A number of
label: Paragraph

text: equally talented, native British architects were also part of
label: Paragraph

text: MARS, including Maxwell Fry, who designed the
label: Paragraph

text: exceptionally elegant Sun House [604] in Frognal, London,
label: Caption

text: in 1935, and Joseph Emberton, who, with Samuely, designed
label: Paragraph

text: the long-span, flood-lit Simpsons department store in
label: Paragraph

text: Piccadilly, London, in 1936. Despite the inventiveness and
label: Paragraph

text: rigour of the British architectural scene throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s, the only British building to be included in Alfred
label: Paragraph

text: Roth’s anthology The New Architecture of 1940 was the
label: Paragraph

text: dramatically cantilevered, reinforced-concrete Boots Factory
label: Caption

text: built in Beeston in 1932 to the designs of the engineer Sir
label: Paragraph

text: Owen Williams (fig. 258).
label: Paragraph

text: 604 Fry, Sun House, Frognal, Hampstead, London, 1935.
label: Caption

text: 605 Mendelsohn and Chermayeff, De La Warr Pavilion, Bexhill-on-Sea, East
label: Caption

text: Sussex, 1935.
label: Caption

text: The vital spirit of the British Modern Movement did not
label: Paragraph

text: survive the war and not even the sophisticated Lubetkin was
label: Paragraph

text: able to resume where he left off in 1938, as is evident from
label: Paragraph

text: the formalistic low-cost, medium-rise, brick-faced housing
label: Paragraph

text: schemes that Tecton designed and built throughout the East
label: Paragraph

text: End of London during the first decade and a half after 1945.
label: Paragraph

text: The sole exception to this loss of confidence was the Royal
label: Paragraph

text: Festival Hall [606, 607] of 1951; it is credited to the chief
label: Paragraph

text: architects of the London County Council (LCC), Robert
label: Caption

text: Matthew and Leslie Martin, but was largely designed by
label: Paragraph

text: Peter Moro, who significantly enough had worked for Tecton
label: Paragraph

text: before the war. Another trace of the pre-war ethos is
label: Paragraph

text: detectable in the Brynmawr Rubber Factory in Wales,
label: Paragraph

text: designed by the Architects Co-Partnership in 1946, with a
label: Paragraph

text: brilliant shell concrete top-lit roofing system designed by
label: Caption

text: Arup. Equally reminiscent of the heroic period of the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement was the Dome of Discovery erected for the
label: Paragraph

text: Festival of Britain in 1951, designed by Ralph Tubbs.
label: Caption

text: Together with the Skylon, designed by Powell and Moya, this
label: Paragraph

text: incongruously echoed the ethos of the Soviet Constructivist
label: Paragraph

text: avant garde of the 1920s.
label: Paragraph

text: 606 Martin and Moro, Royal Festival Hall, London, 1951.
label: Caption

text: 607 Martin and Moro, Royal Festival Hall, London, 1951.
label: Caption

text: After the Town and Country Planning Act of 1947, the
label: Paragraph

text: white rationalist architecture of the pre-war period was
label: Paragraph

text: replaced by the New Empiricism, a term coined by the social
label: Paragraph

text: democratic Swedish housing architect Sven Backstrém in an
label: Title

text: article that appeared in the Architectural Review in 1947.
label: Paragraph

text: What the New Empiricism meant in the British context was
label: Paragraph

text: low-rise, low-density, two-storey housing units in brick with
label: Paragraph

text: low, double-pitched, tile-hung roofs and wood-framed
label: Caption

text: picture windows - in short, a syntax partially derived from
label: Paragraph

text: Sven Markelius’s country house built outside of Stockholm in
label: Paragraph

text: 1933. However, ten- to twelve-storey brick-faced apartment
label: Paragraph

text: blocks had also to be included in the received domestic
label: Paragraph

text: typology of the British post-war new towns in order to
label: Paragraph

text: increase population density. This pattern was present even
label: Paragraph

text: in the LCC’s Alton East estate built at Roehampton [608] on
label: Paragraph

text: an idyllic park site in 1958, which, while not exactly a new
label: Paragraph

text: town, nonetheless exhibited a similar typological range. This
label: Paragraph

text: was largely influenced by the New Empiricism except for the
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusian manner evident in the gallery-access duplex
label: Paragraph

text: apartment blocks laid out in chevron formation; these were
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Bill Howell and Colin St John Wilson, who were
label: Caption

text: then representative of rising talent in the LCC architects’
label: Paragraph

text: department. This mixed development, combining low- and
label: Paragraph

text: high-rise housing stock accessed by car, was averse to any
label: Paragraph

text: trace of traditional street space and in this regard was
label: Paragraph

text: typical of post-war housing in Britain.
label: Paragraph

text: 608 London County Council, Alton West, Roehampton, 1958.
label: Caption

text: It would take another generation for any kind of low-rise,
label: Paragraph

text: high-density, street-orientated land settlement pattern to
label: Paragraph

text: emerge in the UK and when it finally appeared it was greatly
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by the canonical Sied/ung Halen housing estate
label: Paragraph

text: completed outside Berne in Switzerland in 1960. This
label: Paragraph

text: paradigm of stepped terrace housing, between exposed
label: Paragraph

text: cross-walls, had a direct influence on the compact housing
label: Paragraph

text: schemes that Neave Brown designed for the London
label: Paragraph

text: Borough of Camden, first his Fleet Road housing of 1966
label: Caption

text: [612] and then his much larger Alexandra Road complex
label: Paragraph

text: [611], under construction from 1967. The latter consists of
label: Paragraph

text: stepped seven- and four-storey parallel blocks affording
label: Caption

text: ample external terraces for every dwelling. However, with
label: Paragraph

text: the exception of Michael Neylan’s Bishopsfield low-rise
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard housing [609], built in Harlow New Town in 1960,
label: Paragraph

text: and Michael Browne, Edward Jones, Michael Gold and Paul
label: Title

text: Simpson’s brilliant but unfortunately unrealized entry for the
label: Paragraph

text: Portsdown housing competition of 1966, there were few
label: Paragraph

text: examples of low-rise, high-density housing in Britain, either
label: Paragraph

text: projected or built. Nonetheless, a stepped section would be
label: Paragraph

text: integral to the continuous terraces of the dormitories built
label: Paragraph

text: for Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge [610], to the
label: Caption

text: designs of Patrick Hodgkinson (working in the office of Leslie
label: Caption

text: Martin and Colin St John Wilson), and the same section was
label: Paragraph

text: adopted by Hodgkinson for his seminal perimeter housing
label: Paragraph

text: block, the Brunswick Centre, finally completed in
label: Paragraph

text: Bloomsbury, London, in 1970.

text: Martin played a key role during his tenure as head of the
label: Paragraph

text: architecture school at Cambridge University in supporting
label: Title

text: rising talent, not only that of his own office, but also through
label: Paragraph

text: his advisory position on the University Grants Committee,
label: Paragraph

text: which, amongst other things, commissioned James Stirling
label: Paragraph

text: and James Gowan in 1957 to design the Engineering
label: Paragraph

text: Building at the University of Leicester, completed in 1963
label: Caption

text: (fig. 275). During this period, Martin also recommended
label: Paragraph

text: Alison and Peter Smithson as contenders for the design of
label: Paragraph

text: The Economist Building in London, which, in retrospect,
label: Paragraph

text: turned out to be their last significant work, realized in 1964.
label: Paragraph

text: This building, much like their Hunstanton School in Norfolk
label: Paragraph

text: (fig. 270), was a Miesian exercise in as much as its
label: Paragraph

text: structural mullions were set back as the building rose in
label: Paragraph

text: height as in Mies’s Promontory Apartments, Chicago, of
label: Paragraph

text: 1949. Of equal import, however, was the facing of these
label: Paragraph

text: concrete mullions in roach Portland stone. This use of stone
label: Paragraph

text: revetment to protect the exposed concrete against uneven
label: Paragraph

text: weathering was echoed in Stirling’s St Andrews University
label: Paragraph

text: dormitories [613, 614], also dating from 1964, where the
label: Paragraph

text: facing of diagonally striated prefabricated concrete panels,
label: Caption

text: cast from welded steel moulds, was intended as a metaphor
label: Paragraph

text: for rusticated stonework. This work was effectively Stirling’s
label: Paragraph

text: last Brutalist statement before his adoption of Post-
label: Paragraph

text: Modernism, as in his project for Derby Civic Centre of 1970,
label: Paragraph

text: designed in association with Léon Krier.
label: Caption

text: 613 Stirling, dormitory for St Andrews University, Scotland, 1964.

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: window and striated precast concrete panels.
label: Caption

text: In retrospect it is evident that British Brutalism
label: Paragraph

text: represented a concerted effort to arrive at a socially
label: Paragraph

text: accessible and yet rigorous architecture in opposition to the
label: Paragraph

text: overtly popular appeal of the New Empiricism, which
label: Paragraph

text: possibly explains Stirling’s remark, ‘Let’s face it, William
label: Paragraph

text: Morris was a Swede!’, with its double irony in the fact that
label: Paragraph

text: Morris was preoccupied with the tradition of Nordic culture
label: Paragraph

text: and the Swedish welfare state was preoccupied with the
label: Paragraph

text: social accessibility of architecture. Even so, among the early
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalist works that testify to a concern for social relevance
label: Paragraph

text: are the Smithsons’ SoHo House project of 1952, with its so-
label: Paragraph

text: called ‘warehouse’ aesthetic, and Stirling and Gowan’s
label: Paragraph

text: social housing built in Preston, Lancashire, in 1957 [615].
label: Paragraph

text: These ‘down-to-earth’ exercises in brick and exposed
label: Paragraph

text: concrete floor slabs are typical of this moment, as is Alan
label: Paragraph

text: Colquhoun and John Miller’s Kahnian Forest Gate School
label: Title

text: [616], built in the East End of London in 1963, not to
label: Paragraph

text: mention the organic Aaltoesque line generally adopted by
label: Paragraph

text: the Martin office in Cambridge in its effort to evolve a
label: Paragraph

text: normative modern brick manner appropriate to the English
label: Paragraph

text: climate.
label: Paragraph

text: 615 Stirling and Gowan, housing, Preston, Lancashire, 1957.
label: Caption

text: 616 Colquhoun and Miller, Forest Gate School, Newham, London, 1963.
label: Caption

text: Paradoxically this heroic cultural stance was at odds with
label: Paragraph

text: a shift to populism in British politics, first with the 1964
label: Paragraph

text: election victory of Harold Wilson’s Labour Party, followed by
label: Paragraph

text: the Conservative Party’s victory of 1970. The latter first
label: Paragraph

text: brought Margaret Thatcher to the fore as education
label: Paragraph

text: secretary, in which capacity she eliminated government
label: Paragraph

text: funding for British students aspiring to enter the
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Association School of Architecture, London.
label: Caption

text: This was the beginning of the influence of the economist
label: Paragraph

text: Friedrich Hayek on the British government: an anti-socialist
label: Title

text: ideology opposed to the Keynesian economics of the welfare
label: Title

text: state. This stance was reinforced by the rise of Anglo-
label: Paragraph

text: American neo-liberalism, following the election of Ronald
label: Paragraph

text: Reagan to the US presidency in 1981 and Thatcher’s
label: Title

text: election as UK premier in 1979. The Thatcher government
label: Paragraph

text: liquidated the British coal industry and undermined the
label: Paragraph

text: power of local authorities throughout the country,
label: Paragraph

text: culminating in the eclipse of the Greater London Council
label: Paragraph

text: (GLC) and the elimination of government subsidies for
label: Title

text: affordable housing.
label: Paragraph

text: Although one cannot claim a direct relationship between
label: Paragraph

text: politics and architecture, it is surely no accident that the last
label: Paragraph

text: British New Town of Milton Keynes, dating from 1972, was
label: Paragraph

text: planned according to the American planner Melvin Webber’s
label: Paragraph

text: concept of the ‘non-place urban realm’, by which he had in
label: Paragraph

text: mind the dispersed megalopolis of Los Angeles, the total
label: Paragraph

text: antithesis of the unrealized new town of Hook, proposed by
label: Paragraph

text: the LCC in 1961 [617]. In contrast to this compact urban
label: Paragraph

text: model, Milton Keynes consisted of a 1-kilometre (0.4-mile)
label: Paragraph

text: square grid laid over the Buckinghamshire countryside (fig.
label: Paragraph

text: 617 London County Council, Hook New Town, 1961. Masterplan.
label: Caption

text: The 1960s saw the emergence of the Anglo-Italian High-
label: Paragraph

text: Tech Movement in architecture. It began with Team 4’s
label: Paragraph

text: realization of the steel-framed, cable-braced factory for the
label: Paragraph

text: Reliance Controls Company built in Swindon, Wiltshire, in
label: Caption

text: 1966, an approach taken further in Richard Rogers and
label: Paragraph

text: Renzo Piano’s winning competition entry for the Centre
label: Title

text: Pompidou in Paris of 1972 (figs 291 & 292) followed in short
label: Paragraph

text: order by Norman Foster’s building for the Willis Faber &
label: Caption

text: Dumas insurance company in Ipswich, Suffolk, of 1975 (figs
label: Caption

text: Significantly enough, Rogers and Foster, as leading
label: Paragraph

text: British High-Tech architects, worked, like Piano in Italy, more
label: Paragraph

text: outside the country than within it. This was also the case
label: Paragraph

text: later with the distinguished British architect David
label: Paragraph

text: Chipperfield, who, while not affiliated with High-Tech,
label: Paragraph

text: nonetheless worked at different times for both Rogers and
label: Paragraph

text: Foster before beginning his own practice with luxury shop
label: Paragraph

text: interiors and with small works in concrete, built in Japan -
label: Paragraph

text: such as his Toyota showroom in Kyoto of 1990 and his Gotoh
label: Paragraph

text: Museum in Chiba of 1991. He returned to the British scene
label: Paragraph

text: with his Japanese-proportioned River and Rowing Museum at
label: Paragraph

text: Henley-on-Thames, Oxfordshire, of 1997 [618]. By virtue of
label: Caption

text: Chipperfield working mostly in Europe but outside the UK,
label: Paragraph

text: Germany became the main patron of his work [620], with
label: Paragraph

text: such buildings as the German Literature Museum built at
label: Paragraph

text: Marbach am Neckar, close to Stuttgart, in 2006.
label: Paragraph

text: 618 Chipperfield, River and Rowing Museum, Henley-on-Thames, Oxfordshire,
label: Caption

text: 619 Fretton, Fuglsang Art Museum, Lolland, Denmark, 2008.
label: Caption

text: 620 Chipperfield, James Simon Gallery, Berlin, 2018.
label: Caption

text: Like Chipperfield, Tony Fretton has been, in practice,
label: Paragraph

text: more of a European architect than a British one, particularly
label: Paragraph

text: after his appointment to a professorship in the Delft
label: Paragraph

text: University of Technology (TU Delft) in 1999, in a series of
label: Paragraph

text: works and projects designed for the Netherlands and
label: Paragraph

text: Scandinavia. Fretton’s most significant work at an urban
label: Paragraph

text: scale had been achieved in Amsterdam, notably in two
label: Paragraph

text: medium-rise apartment blocks: the six-storey Solid 11 and
label: Paragraph

text: the seven-storey Andreas Ensemble. The latter is finished in
label: Paragraph

text: a material palette that strongly reflects Fretton’s taste:
label: Paragraph

text: Danish grey brick with aluminium windows anodized in light
label: Caption

text: bronze and blue-green, combined with the penthouse of
label: Paragraph

text: pale green pre-cast concrete. However, his well-established
label: Paragraph

text: prowess as a designer of gallery space has perhaps never
label: Paragraph

text: been better demonstrated than in the diminutive Fuglsang
label: Paragraph

text: Art Museum [619], built at Lolland, Denmark, in 2008, in
label: Paragraph

text: which the architect was able to establish an unusually
label: Paragraph

text: strong relationship between the exhibition of sculpture and
label: Paragraph

text: subtly framed views of the surrounding landscape. Fretton’s
label: Paragraph

text: largest and most monumental complex work to date is his
label: Paragraph

text: British Embassy and Ambassadorial Residence built in
label: Caption

text: Warsaw in two phases between 2003 and 2009. In this work
label: Paragraph

text: the offices were seen as being just as representative of the
label: Paragraph

text: national ethos as the spaces devoted to public reception
label: Paragraph

text: and diplomacy.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps the most prolific and varied London-based
label: Paragraph

text: practice of the early 21st century has been that of Eric Parry
label: Paragraph

text: Architects (EPA). Founded in 1986, it has managed over the
label: Paragraph

text: past three decades to maintain a rigorously professional
label: Paragraph

text: service over a wide front, extending from medium-rise
label: Paragraph

text: middle-class housing in Kuala Lumpur to a range of
label: Paragraph

text: incidental adaptations for academic and artistic clients, plus
label: Paragraph

text: the occasional restoration-cum-conservation of a country
label: Title

text: seat in both the UK and France. Apart from this broad
label: Paragraph

text: spectrum of work, the main focus of the practice has been
label: Paragraph

text: its piecemeal restoration of the London street fabric,
label: Paragraph

text: beginning with a syncopated prefabricated facade for 30
label: Caption

text: Finsbury Square, completed in 2003, and followed by a more
label: Paragraph

text: classically tectonic front for 23 Savile Row, built at around
label: Caption

text: the same time. Apart from Kuala Lumpur, all of EPA’s work
label: Paragraph

text: has been contextual. However, with a Miesian steel-framed,
label: Paragraph

text: free-standing, eleven-storey office building at 4 Pancras
label: Caption

text: Square, London [623], close to the refurbished King’s Cross
label: Caption

text: Station, EPA have realized a more architectonic statement;
label: Paragraph

text: the ground floor is recessed behind a monumental long-
label: Paragraph

text: span Vierendeel truss that sets the tone for the rest of the
label: Paragraph

text: building, not only for the front facing onto the square, but
label: Paragraph

text: also for the other three sides emphasizing the widely
label: Paragraph

text: spaced monumental steel stanchions upon which the
label: Paragraph

text: building rests.
label: Paragraph

text: If there is a London-based architect whose work brings to
label: Paragraph

text: mind the elusive nature of architecture in an age that is
label: Paragraph

text: transfixed by the spectacular, then it is the Irish architect
label: Paragraph

text: Niall McLaughlin, who has been practising in the UK since
label: Paragraph

text: the mid-1990s. His hyper-sensitive approach invariably
label: Paragraph

text: alludes to the time-honoured crafted tradition of building in
label: Paragraph

text: wood. McLaughlin unequivocally evokes this in his Bishop
label: Paragraph

text: Edward King Chapel built in 2013 for a theological college in
label: Paragraph

text: Cuddleson, Oxfordshire, wherein a cruck-timber frame,
label: Caption

text: supporting a carinated roof, is encompassed by a concrete
label: Paragraph

text: shell faced with brick tiles. At the same time, a timber
label: Paragraph

text: fishing hut that he built in Hampshire two years later pays
label: Paragraph

text: homage to both the Japanese timber tradition and to
label: Paragraph

text: medieval oak framing. The Sultan Nazrin Shah Centre that
label: Caption

text: McLaughlin built for Worcester College, Oxford, in 2017
label: Caption

text: [621, 622] demonstrates the comprehensive range of his
label: Paragraph

text: vision. The symmetrical front of the building, facing onto a
label: Paragraph

text: lawn, is related at the rear to the existing dormitories
label: Paragraph

text: asymmetrically, the two axes being reconciled through the
label: Paragraph

text: light-weight timber framing of the foyer about the quadrant
label: Caption

text: of the central auditorium.
label: Paragraph

text: Ireland
label: Title

text: After the Easter Rising in 1916 and the declaration of
label: Paragraph

text: independence in 1921, followed by two years of civil war,
label: Paragraph

text: the Irish Free State did not emerge as a fully independent
label: Paragraph

text: constitutional republic until 1937. It was first represented
label: Paragraph

text: architecturally in the Irish Pavilion, designed by Michael
label: Caption

text: Scott for the New York World’s Fair of 1939, the plan of
label: Paragraph

text: which was conceived with the outline of a shamrock. After
label: Paragraph

text: the Second World War, the Scott office took a more
label: Paragraph

text: sophisticated line in the form of a Corbusian bus terminal
label: Paragraph

text: (1953) in the centre of Dublin, designed in collaboration
label: Caption

text: with the engineer Ove Arup. In the 1960s Scott’s young
label: Paragraph

text: partners, Ronald Tallon and Robin Walker, having worked in
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago, shifted the practice away from the influence of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier towards that of the practice of Mies van der Rohe
label: Paragraph

text: in Chicago, beginning with the RTE (Irish state radio and
label: Paragraph

text: television) headquarters in Dublin (1967).
label: Paragraph

text: The hiatus generated by the economic slump of the next
label: Paragraph

text: decade would be offset by Noel Dowley’s Kahnian Kilfrush
label: Paragraph

text: House, built in Limerick in 1970. After graduating, Dowley
label: Paragraph

text: had studied with Kahn in the United States; and it was he
label: Paragraph

text: who, while teaching at University College Dublin, persuaded
label: Paragraph

text: Shane de Blacam to follow suit and work for Kahn upon
label: Paragraph

text: completing his degree. In the meantime John Meagher
label: Paragraph

text: graduated as an architect from the Helsinki University of
label: Paragraph

text: Technology and went to Philadelphia to work in the office of
label: Paragraph

text: Venturi, Rauch and Scott Brown. On their return to Ireland,
label: Paragraph

text: De Blacam and Meagher established their joint practice in
label: Paragraph

text: the early 1980s, with a commission to reconstruct the dining
label: Paragraph

text: hall of Trinity College Dublin following a disastrous fire. A
label: Caption

text: decade later they would build for the same client their
label: Paragraph

text: Kahnian, timber-clad Samuel Beckett Theatre (1992),
label: Caption

text: capped by an Irish vernacular barn roof and erected on a
label: Caption

text: prominent site in the Trinity College campus. Later Alvar
label: Caption

text: Aalto influenced their architecture, for example their
label: Paragraph

text: building at 1 Castle Street [625], inserted into the urban
label: Caption

text: fabric of Dublin in 1999. Here the two influences are
label: Paragraph

text: synthesized in a particularly compelling way, combining
label: Paragraph

text: Kahnian timber panelling with Aalto’s cantilevered,
label: Caption

text: castellated brickwork (comparable to Aalto’s Saynatsalo City
label: Paragraph

text: Hall of 1950). A similar syntax is evident in their ten-storey
label: Paragraph

text: apartment building of 2000 in the Temple Bar district of
label: Caption

text: Dublin: the so-called Wooden Building [624], where the
label: Paragraph

text: synthesis is enriched by brickwork with pronounced mortar
label: Paragraph

text: joints in the walls of the vertical access tower.
label: Caption

text: 624 De Blacam and Meagher, Wooden Building, Dublin, 2000. Elevation.
label: Caption

text: 625 De Blacam and Meagher, 1 Castle Street, Dublin, 1999.
label: Caption

text: The exceptionally fertile architectural culture of Dublin
label: Title

text: seems to have emerged not only because of the EU-backed
label: Paragraph

text: Irish economic boom of the 1990s, but also because of the
label: Paragraph

text: tectonic and topographic discourse of the School of
label: Title

text: Architecture of University College Dublin. From here the
label: Paragraph

text: most talented members of the so-called Group 91 came
label: Paragraph

text: forward, above all Grafton Architects, the practice founded
label: Paragraph

text: by Shelley McNamara and Yvonne Farrell, and John Tuomey
label: Caption

text: and Sheila O’Donnell, who, after studying and working in
label: Paragraph

text: London, returned to Dublin in 1981 to establish their own
label: Paragraph

text: partnership.
label: Paragraph

text: Like the British Brutalists of the mid-1950s, Group 91
label: Paragraph

text: renounced the perennial Miesian influence on Irish
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in favour of a series of measured references to
label: Paragraph

text: the vernacular; however, much of this was permeated here
label: Paragraph

text: and there by classicism, as in the symmetrical Ranelagh
label: Paragraph

text: School built in Dublin to the designs of O’Donnell and
label: Paragraph

text: Tuomey in 1998. Making a refined use of recycled brickwork,
label: Paragraph

text: the language of this school owes something to Stirling’s
label: Paragraph

text: Ham Common apartments and their syntax of exposed
label: Title

text: concrete and load-bearing brickwork that preceded his later
label: Paragraph

text: Post-Modern work (see p. 301).
label: Paragraph

text: The next project that effectively consummated O’Donnell
label: Paragraph

text: and Tuomey as leading practitioners of the ‘School of
label: Paragraph

text: Dublin’ is their timber-clad, pinwheeling Glucksman Gallery
label: Paragraph

text: [626] built in 2004 for University College Cork ona
label: Caption

text: floodplain close to the main entrance to the campus. This
label: Paragraph

text: ingeniously planned, concrete-framed structure makes an
label: Paragraph

text: indirect allusion to Stirling’s Leicester Engineering Building
label: Paragraph

text: of 1959 (see p. 303). However, they soon followed this
label: Paragraph

text: achievement with two works that decisively depart from any
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalist antecedent. Although both of these buildings were
label: Paragraph

text: completed in the 2000s, their context and subject matter
label: Paragraph

text: were quite different, one being a monopitched, timber-
label: Paragraph

text: framed and -clad machine shop built on a former reform
label: Paragraph

text: school in the mountainous landscape of Connemara [627],
label: Paragraph

text: and the other a brick-clad, concrete-framed, cliff-like
label: Paragraph

text: complex, known as Timberyard Housing [628, 629],
label: Paragraph

text: ingeniously inserted into the dense urban fabric of Dublin.
label: Paragraph

text: 626 O'Donnell and Tuomey, Glucksman Gallery, University College Cork, 2004.
label: Caption
