label: Caption

text: Grafton Architects, who were also part of Group 91,
label: Paragraph

text: developed their own somewhat Aaltoesque manner, as in
label: Paragraph

text: their Urban Land Institute building of 2002 and three-storey
label: Paragraph

text: Waterloo Lane Mews built in Dublin in 2008. However, they
label: Paragraph

text: attained another scale entirely with their Bocconi University
label: Paragraph

text: extension, Milan, won in competition and completed in
label: Paragraph

text: 2008. They were the only architects in a limited competition
label: Paragraph

text: who were able to meet the mandatory requirement that the
label: Paragraph

text: main auditorium should be equally accessible to the
label: Paragraph

text: university and the city. Aside from fulfilling this condition the
label: Paragraph

text: architects also met the requirement of providing 100 faculty
label: Paragraph

text: offices. With this commission Grafton Architects were invited
label: Paragraph

text: to enter - and won - one academic competition after
label: Paragraph

text: another, including those for a school of economics in
label: Paragraph

text: Toulouse, France (2009-16), and a technical university in
label: Paragraph

text: Lima, Peru (2011-15) [630, 631]. Inspired by the Brazilian
label: Paragraph

text: architect Paulo Mendes da Rocha, they conceived the latter
label: Paragraph

text: as an audaciously tectonic, cantilevered, reinforced-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete megastructure. They took a similar tectonic
label: Paragraph

text: approach in their eight-storey faculty building projected for
label: Paragraph

text: the London School of Economics in Lincoln’s Inn Fields, and
label: Paragraph

text: in their proposal for a new City Library for Parnell Square,
label: Paragraph

text: Dublin [632]; both were won in competition, in 2015 and
label: Paragraph

text: 2014 respectively. Like their UTEC building in Lima these
label: Paragraph

text: last two works have been conceived largely in section as
label: Paragraph

text: expressively structured public space.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: France
label: Title

text: The revival of architecture in France dates from the student
label: Paragraph

text: revolt and civil unrest of May 1968, which was accompanied
label: Paragraph

text: by a total breakdown of the Ecole des Beaux Arts into a
label: Paragraph

text: series of smaller ‘unités pédagogiques’ (UP), not only in
label: Paragraph

text: Paris but also in the provinces. This decentralization
label: Paragraph

text: transformed French architectural education and led to the
label: Paragraph

text: creation of UP 8 and UP 3 in Paris, led respectively by the
label: Paragraph

text: architects Henri Ciriani and Henri Gaudin. The 1972
label: Paragraph

text: international competition for the Centre Pompidou in Paris
label: Caption

text: inaugurated a programme of government-sponsored
label: Paragraph

text: construction that would culminate in the so-called ‘Grands
label: Paragraph

text: Travaux’ built in Paris and elsewhere in France during the
label: Paragraph

text: 1980s, during the presidency of Francois Mitterrand. Among
label: Paragraph

text: the embellishments to the French capital at this time were
label: Paragraph

text: two works, built at either end of the Champs-Elysées: first, a
label: Paragraph

text: new entrance to the Louvre by the American architect I.M.
label: Caption

text: Pei in 1989 in the form of a monumental glass pyramid, and,
label: Paragraph

text: second, a giant arch completed in the same year at La
label: Paragraph

text: Défense, on the same axis as the Arc de Triomphe and
label: Paragraph

text: Louvre, to the designs of the Danish architect Johan Otto
label: Caption

text: von Spreckelsen. Other important competition designs
label: Caption

text: constructed during the 1980s were Bernard Tschumi’s Parc
label: Paragraph

text: de la Villette (see p. 350); the new Opéra at the Bastille,
label: Caption

text: designed by the Canadian architect Carlos Ott; and the
label: Paragraph

text: Musée d’Orsay, built within the Baroque shell of the Gare
label: Caption

text: d'Orsay, a railway station by the river Seine, to the designs
label: Caption

text: of the Italian architect Gae Aulenti. The City of Paris also
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned important works from the younger
label: Paragraph

text: generation, including Jean Nouvel’s Institut du Monde Arabe
label: Paragraph

text: (1987), Christian de Portzamparc’s Cité de la Musique
label: Caption

text: (1991) and Dominique Perrault’s new national library, the
label: Paragraph

text: Bibliotheque de France (1995).
label: Caption

text: The government-backed revitalization of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: education and research also had an impact on the leading
label: Paragraph

text: magazines of the period, namely L’Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: d’aujourd’hui, under the editorship of Bernard Huet and AMC
label: Paragraph

text: (Architecture, mouvement, continuité), directed by Jacques
label: Caption

text: Lucan. These editors spearheaded a reappraisal of the
label: Paragraph

text: French modern tradition, from the pioneering reinforced-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete works of Auguste Perret, Tony Garnier and Eugéne
label: Caption

text: Freyssinet, to the quasi-Art Deco line pursued by Michel
label: Paragraph

text: Roux-Spitz and Rob Mallet-Stevens. Attention was also given
label: Paragraph

text: to the ferrovitreous constructions of Eugéne Beaudouin and
label: Paragraph

text: Marcel Lods - above all their Maison du Peuple, designed
label: Paragraph

text: with Jean Prouvé and built at Clichy in 1936.
label: Paragraph

text: A new awareness of the work of Le Corbusier manifested
label: Paragraph

text: itself in various ways in France in the 1980s: in the first
label: Paragraph

text: instance, two important works were realized by the last
label: Paragraph

text: members of Le Corbusier’s studio, the French Embassy at
label: Paragraph

text: Rabat by Guillermo Jullian de la Fuente (1985) and the
label: Caption

text: French Cultural Centre in Damascus by José Oubrerie (1986)
label: Caption

text: [634]. In the second instance, the Corbusian syntax was
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpreted by such figures as Henri Ciriani, not only in his
label: Paragraph

text: own work, but also in that of his pupils, for example the Cité
label: Paragraph

text: d’Artistes, Paris, which was won in competition by Michel
label: Caption

text: Kagan in 1989. The typological line of the Italian Tendenza
label: Paragraph

text: (see p. 330) also influenced Ciriani’s concept of la piéce
label: Paragraph

text: urbaine: an intervention that was capable of engendering a
label: Paragraph

text: self-contained micro-urbanity, as in his Noisy Il complex
label: Paragraph

text: built in Marne-la-Vallée in 1980 (fig. 302). A similar intent
label: Paragraph

text: informs the archaeological museum [633] that he designed
label: Paragraph

text: for Arles in 1991. At the same time, Le Corbusier was not
label: Paragraph

text: the only influence, however, for where Christian Devillers’s
label: Paragraph

text: glass-lensed parking garage built at Saint-Denis, Paris, in
label: Caption

text: 1983 [636] aspired to a Constructivist rigour, Laurent
label: Paragraph

text: Beaudouin, Christine Rousselot and Jean-Marie Roussel’s
label: Title

text: batiment dangle, built in Nancy in the same year [635],
label: Paragraph

text: was inspired by the topographic architecture of Alvaro Siza.
label: Paragraph

text: 633 Ciriani, Archaeological Museum, Arles, 1991.
label: Caption

text: | i
label: Title

text: 634 Oubrerie, French Cultural Centre, Damascus, Syria, 1986. Elevation.
label: Caption

text: 635 Beaudouin, Rousselot and Roussel, apartment block, Rue des Fabriques,
label: Caption

text: Nancy, 1983.
label: Caption

label: Caption

text: From the 1980s four particularly distinctive practices
label: Paragraph

text: emerged in France, two of which experienced the untimely
label: Paragraph

text: deaths of their founding partners, the first being Michel
label: Paragraph

text: Kagan and the second Francoise-Héléne Jourda. Kagan
label: Caption

text: belonged to that generation who, graduating in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1970s after the reorganization of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts,
label: Paragraph

text: would be inspired by the French modern tradition to such a
label: Paragraph

text: degree that he was able to transcend the aesthetic legacy
label: Paragraph

text: of Le Corbusier’s Purism. Kagan, along with Beaudouin,
label: Paragraph

text: became increasingly aware of the way in which Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s achievements of the 1920s and 1930s were well
label: Paragraph

text: matched by the works of a number of talented Parisian
label: Paragraph

text: architects, including Rob Mallet-Stevens, Eileen Gray, Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Nelson, Jean Ginsberg and Michel Roux-Spitz, the last being
label: Paragraph

text: the designer of outstanding mid-rise apartment buildings for
label: Paragraph

text: which Kagan had great respect. Kagan was also influenced
label: Paragraph

text: by André Lurcat, above all by his masterly Karl Marx School
label: Paragraph

text: of 1930 in Villejuif, as is evident from the university building
label: Paragraph

text: that Kagan designed for Cergy-Pontoise in 1999 [639].
label: Paragraph

text: Kagan’s Cité d’Artistes [637], completed in 1993, posited a
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic synthesis of interpenetrating three-dimensional
label: Paragraph

text: forms that he continued to refine over the next two decades
label: Paragraph

text: in a series of rationally organized, Corbusian complexes
label: Paragraph

text: built between 2000 to 2007; the first was a nine-storey
label: Paragraph

text: residential block that he completed in Rue de |’Amiral
label: Caption

text: Mouchez, Paris, at the millennium [638].
label: Caption

text: 637 Kagan, Cité d’Artistes, Citroén Cevennes, Paris, 1993.
label: Caption

text: 638 Kagan, 70 Logements, Rue de I’Amiral Mouchez, Paris, 2000.
label: Caption

text: 639 Kagan, Université neuville Ill.1, Cergy-Pontoise, France, 1999.
label: Caption

text: The Lyons practice of Francoise-Héléne Jourda and Gilles
label: Paragraph

text: Perraudin first became known on the European scene in the
label: Paragraph

text: early 1990s with their design for the Mont-Cenis Training
label: Paragraph

text: Centre, completed at Herne-Sodingen, Germany, in 1999.
label: Paragraph

text: This enormous greenhouse, carried on an intercolumnar
label: Paragraph

text: system of stripped tree trucks with cable-stayed, lattice
label: Paragraph

text: timber beams above, and faced in channel glass, was large
label: Paragraph

text: enough to maintain a Mediterranean microclimate
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the year. It opened up to facilitate cross
label: Paragraph

text: ventilation in the summer and closed down in winter, when
label: Paragraph

text: it is heated by solar radiation combined with air brought into
label: Paragraph

text: the building through underground tunnels. This large
label: Paragraph

text: wooden structure, named after the now defunct Mont-Cenis
label: Caption

text: coal mine, was part of the Emscher Park remediation of the
label: Paragraph

text: Ruhrgebiet, an area that was formerly the industrial
label: Paragraph

text: powerhouse of Germany. Following this achievement,
label: Paragraph

text: Francoise-Héléne Jourda opened her own studio specializing
label: Paragraph

text: in sustainable timber structures. This gave rise to two more
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable civic works designed and constructed before her
label: Paragraph

text: death: a covered and open-sided market building erected in
label: Caption

text: Lyons in 2001 [640] and a new botanical garden for
label: Paragraph

text: Bordeaux clad in channel glass and built in 2003 [641].
label: Paragraph

text: Although both structures are carried on roughly dressed
label: Paragraph

text: timber columns, those supporting the market building are
label: Paragraph

text: tapered and socketed into metal casings, which both anchor
label: Paragraph

text: them to the ground and connect them to transverse timber
label: Paragraph

text: beams supporting a monopitched polycarbonate roof above,
label: Paragraph

text: through which comes the necessary natural light for the
label: Paragraph

text: stalls below.
label: Caption

text: 640 Jourda, market hall, Place du 8 Mai 1945, Lyons, 2001.
label: Caption

text: 641 Jourda, Botanical Museum of Bordeaux, 2003.
label: Caption

text: The third notable practice is that of Anne Lacaton and
label: Paragraph

text: Jean Philippe Vassal, who came to the fore with their Latapie
label: Paragraph

text: House built at Floirac in 1993. This was their first minimal
label: Paragraph

text: dwelling, which was promptly supplemented by a
label: Paragraph

text: conservatory with the same plan area. This provision of
label: Paragraph

text: additional space at minimal cost was the raison d’étre
label: Paragraph

text: behind their habitual use of ‘off-the-peg’ greenhouse
label: Paragraph

text: technology as the key motif of their practice. This technique
label: Paragraph

text: made up the poetic ethos of their steel-framed single-storey
label: Paragraph

text: Cap Ferret house [642], built at Lege in 1998 on a pine-
label: Paragraph

text: covered dune site overlooking Arcachon Bay to the west of
label: Caption

text: Bordeaux. Here they were able to preserve six existing trees
label: Paragraph

text: on the site by incorporating them into the house: an
label: Paragraph

text: ingenious solution that was achieved through the invention
label: Paragraph

text: of flexible collars to allow the trees, which rise up through
label: Paragraph

text: the roof, to move with the wind. The kitchen/bathroom and
label: Paragraph

text: the sleeping space are both reduced to the minimum to
label: Paragraph

text: afford generous living space. Lacaton and Vassal followed
label: Paragraph

text: this achievement with their restoration and transformation
label: Paragraph

text: of an eleven-storey apartment tower at La Chesnaie, near
label: Caption

text: Saint-Nazaire [643]. Between 2006 and 2017 the plan of
label: Paragraph

text: this building, dating from the 1970s, was rearranged and its
label: Paragraph

text: balconies converted into conservatories, affording, in effect,
label: Paragraph

text: a glazed extension of the living space, a provision that was
label: Paragraph

text: more appropriate to the rainy, windswept climate of
label: Paragraph

text: northern France. Their gloss on this achievement clearly
label: Paragraph

text: outlines the ethical and economic rationale of their overall
label: Paragraph

text: approach:
label: Title

text: 642 Lacaton & Vassal, house at Cap Ferret, 1998. This single-storey house is
label: Caption

text: ingeniously designed to incorporate existing trees.
label: Paragraph

text: 643 Lacaton & Vassal, apartment tower transformation, La Chesnaie, France,
label: Caption

text: 2006-17. The existing building is in grey with the additions built around it.
label: Caption

text: The global cost of 40 transformed apartments is very much
label: Paragraph

text: below the cost of their demolition and reconstruction. The
label: Paragraph

text: savings made by the transformation enable most of the new
label: Paragraph

text: apartments to be financed. We hope that the project
label: Paragraph

text: sufficiently demonstrates that the demolition of the four
label: Paragraph

text: towers can be avoided to the benefit of their
label: Paragraph

text: transformation.
label: Paragraph

text: Other than their design and realization of one curtain-
label: Paragraph

text: walled residential work after another, their most successful
label: Paragraph

text: public work to date has been the new architecture school
label: Paragraph

text: built in Nantes of 2009 [644]. This building, as with most of
label: Paragraph

text: their work, may be seen as continuing the French light-
label: Paragraph

text: weight, metallic tradition dating back to the pioneering
label: Paragraph

text: figures of Jean Prouvé and Edouard Albert.
label: Paragraph

text: 644 Lacaton & Vassal, Ecole d’Architecture, Nantes, 2009.
label: Caption

text: Philippe Madec has long been dedicated to the cultural
label: Paragraph

text: and economic regeneration of the French countryside, as is
label: Paragraph

text: evident from a number of sustainable works that he has
label: Paragraph

text: designed and realized since 2006, beginning with a new
label: Paragraph

text: village centre for Saint-Christol in the Languedoc. This work
label: Paragraph

text: comprises seven timber-framed, free-standing structures
label: Caption

text: that are arranged in relation to one another so as to
label: Paragraph

text: constitute a new communal hub for the existing village. This
label: Paragraph

text: complex, known as Vivanino, is dedicated to the local
label: Paragraph

text: economy of viticulture and comprises a gourmet restaurant,
label: Paragraph

text: a wine boutique, a communal hall, an interactive exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: space and an information centre. In 2017 Madec completed
label: Paragraph

text: a larger cultural centre [645] for Cornebarrieu, near
label: Paragraph

text: Toulouse, using adobe construction for the small-scale
label: Paragraph

text: ancillary spaces and a timber-framed superstructure for the
label: Caption

text: main public volumes. Comprising a 328-seat auditorium and
label: Paragraph

text: a 150-seat conference room, plus offices and other
label: Paragraph

text: functions, this complex is raised on a concrete deck 60
label: Paragraph

text: centimetres (23% inches) above the high point of the
label: Paragraph

text: floodplain. Apart from the adobe, a significant sustainable
label: Paragraph

text: aspect of this work is its construction from locally sourced
label: Paragraph

text: larch and Douglas fir, imported from sustainably managed
label: Paragraph

text: forests.
label: Paragraph

text: 645 Madec, cultural centre, Cornebarrieu, Toulouse, 2017.
label: Caption

text: Belgium
label: Title

text: The division in the modern state of Belgium, created in
label: Paragraph

text: 1831, between the French- and the Flemish-speaking
label: Paragraph

text: populations had repercussions for the development of
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture after the First World War. The French-
label: Paragraph

text: speaking architects were more susceptible to the influence
label: Paragraph

text: of Le Corbusier, while their Flemish counterparts gravitated
label: Paragraph

text: either towards the Wrightian line emanating from the
label: Paragraph

text: architect Hendricus Theodorus Wijdeveld’s magazine
label: Title

text: Wendingen or to the abstractions of Dutch Neo-Plasticism.
label: Paragraph

text: Distanced from these affinities was the patrician figure of
label: Paragraph

text: Henry van de Velde, who, on returning to the country in
label: Paragraph

text: 1925 after his exile in Switzerland, built a modest brick
label: Paragraph

text: house for his own occupation in Brussels, before becoming
label: Paragraph

text: in 1927 the director of the newly formed Institut Supérieur
label: Paragraph

text: des Arts Décoratifs in Brussels, known as La Cambre after
label: Paragraph

text: the ancient abbey in which it was housed. In 1929 he
label: Paragraph

text: designed and realized a remarkable home for the elderly in
label: Paragraph

text: Hannover, Germany, featuring a syncopated sequence of
label: Paragraph

text: bay windows in brick, before adopting fair-faced concrete for
label: Paragraph

text: the library that he built for the University of Ghent in 1936.
label: Paragraph

text: Van de Velde combined concrete with brick cladding in his
label: Paragraph

text: final masterwork, the Krdller-Muller Museum in Otterlo in the
label: Caption

text: Netherlands, under construction from 1937 to 1953 [646].
label: Paragraph

text: 646 Van de Velde, Krdller-Muller Museum, Otterlo, The Netherlands, 1937-53.
label: Caption

text: Belgium’s reconstruction after German occupation and
label: Title

text: bombardment in the First World War was greatly influenced
label: Paragraph

text: by the Anglo-Saxon garden city movement, particularly as it
label: Paragraph

text: was embodied by Raymond Unwin’s Town Planning in
label: Paragraph

text: Practice of 1909, the main precepts of which were reiterated
label: Paragraph

text: by the landscape architect Louis van der Swaelmen in his
label: Paragraph

text: Préliminaries d’art civique of 1916. He put these principles
label: Paragraph

text: into practice in two successive settlements designed with
label: Paragraph

text: the Bruges architect Huib Hoste: the Klein Rusland garden
label: Caption

text: estate of 1921 and the Kapelleveld garden city of 1923-26.
label: Paragraph

text: These works parallel Victor Bourgeois’s much more didactic
label: Paragraph

text: Cité Moderne built outside Brussels between 1922 and 1925
label: Paragraph

text: [647] and also enriched with a landscape by van der
label: Caption

text: Swaelmen. This seminal work, reminiscent of Tony Garnier,
label: Paragraph

text: was published in the Belgium town planning magazine La
label: Paragraph

text: Cité, which had been founded in 1919 by the urbanist
label: Paragraph

text: Raphaél Verwilghen as the official organ of the Société des
label: Paragraph

text: Urbanistes Belges. However, the social utopianism of these
label: Paragraph

text: post-war years gave way in the early 1920s to the innate
label: Paragraph

text: conservatism of the Belgium middle class, indicated by the
label: Paragraph

text: withdrawal of state funding for social housing in 1923. After
label: Paragraph

text: this Bourgeois’s activity became increasingly diverse,
label: Paragraph

text: ranging from the cubistic house and studio that he designed
label: Paragraph

text: and built for the sculptor Oscar Jespers in Woluwe-Saint-
label: Caption

text: Lambert in 1928 [648] to the utopian World City that he
label: Paragraph

text: proposed under the patronage of Paul Otlet for Tervuren
label: Caption

text: Park, Brussels, in 1932.
label: Caption

text: 647 Bourgeois, Cité Moderne, Brussels, 1922-25.
label: Caption

text: 648 Bourgeois, Oscar Jespers’s House, Woluwe-Saint-Lambert, 1928.
label: Caption

text: The next generation of Belgian modernists included Léon
label: Paragraph

text: Stynen, Louis Herman De Koninck and Gaston Eysselinck,
label: Paragraph

text: who were all at different times influenced by Le Corbusier,
label: Paragraph

text: although this inspiration did not by any means determine
label: Paragraph

text: their entire careers. Among them Eysselinck, on graduating
label: Paragraph

text: from the Academy of Ghent in 1928, first made an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural pilgrimage to the Netherlands, where he
label: Paragraph

text: encountered not only the De Stijl Movement, but also the
label: Paragraph

text: Amsterdam School and the work of W.M. Dudok, as is
label: Paragraph

text: evident from the brick-faced Serbruyns House that he
label: Paragraph

text: completed in Ghent in 1930. However, this achievement
label: Paragraph

text: coincided with his first full encounter with the work of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier through the publication of the latter’s Oeuvre
label: Paragraph

text: compléte 1910-1929. This accounts for Eysselinck’s sudden
label: Paragraph

text: adoption of Le Corbusier's ‘Five Points of a New
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture’ of 1926, as is evident in Eysselinck’s own
label: Paragraph

text: house built in Ghent on a triangular, leftover site in 1931
label: Paragraph

text: [649]. However, in the second half of the 1930s he returned
label: Paragraph

text: to the use of precision brickwork combined with elegant
label: Paragraph

text: steel-framed windows: a fall-back position adopted by many
label: Paragraph

text: Belgian modernists during the interwar period. After the
label: Paragraph

text: Second World War, Eysselinck briefly returned to Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier with his Central Post Office for Ostend, dating
label: Caption

text: from 1945, the ultimate development of which displayed
label: Paragraph

text: something of the monumental character of Le Corbusier's
label: Paragraph

text: entry for the League of Nations competition of 1927.
label: Paragraph

text: 649 Eysselinck, Eysselinck House, Ghent, 1931.
label: Caption

text: The Antwerp architect Léon Stynen fully embraced the
label: Paragraph

text: work of Le Corbusier only after a visit in 1952 to the Unité
label: Paragraph

text: d’Habitation at Marseilles. He was so inspired by the Unité
label: Paragraph

text: as to propose a diminutive version of the same concept with
label: Paragraph

text: central corridors and double-height living spaces, but
label: Paragraph

text: without the characteristic cross-over units and communal
label: Paragraph

text: facilities. Stynen, like many other Belgian architects of his
label: Paragraph

text: generation, such as Eduard Van Steenbergen, Robert
label: Paragraph

text: Puttemans and Jean-Jules Eggericx, finally settled for a well-
label: Paragraph

text: proportioned domestic format in precision brickwork, as
label: Paragraph

text: found in his own house in Antwerp of 1932, and in a small
label: Paragraph

text: estate of six two-storey houses that he built in two-tone
label: Paragraph

text: brick on the left bank of the river Escaut in Antwerp in 1939.
label: Caption

text: Apart from his domestic work [651], Stynen specialized in
label: Paragraph

text: the design of casinos, including those in Knokke,
label: Paragraph

text: Chaudfontaine, Blankenberge and Ostend [650], all of which
label: Paragraph

text: were predicated on a Neo-Classical parti overlaid with a
label: Paragraph

text: modernist syntax.
label: Paragraph

text: 650 Stynen, Casino in Ostend, 1950.
label: Caption

text: 651 Stynen, Immeuble d’habitation, Kessel-Lo, 1956. Section.
label: Caption

text: A sole exception to this Belgian pursuit of a conservative
label: Paragraph

text: modernity was Louis Herman De Koninck, who envisaged his
label: Paragraph

text: work being constructed of patent concrete blocks, such as
label: Paragraph

text: those being produced by the building contractor Firmin De
label: Paragraph

text: Smaele. The firm had developed the patent Gebablocks for
label: Paragraph

text: the purpose of the reconstruction of the country after the
label: Paragraph

text: devastation of the 1914-18 war. This was the material that
label: Paragraph

text: De Koninck used to build his own two-storey house and
label: Paragraph

text: studio at Uccle, near Brussels, in 1924 [652]. Planned within
label: Caption

text: a square, this residence, built on the edge of a precipitous
label: Paragraph

text: drop, comprised an architect’s office and a bedroom at the
label: Paragraph

text: entrance level, with a sequence of living, dining and kitchen
label: Paragraph

text: areas accommodated at the garden level one floor below.
label: Paragraph

text: Although De Koninck was always looking for practical ways
label: Paragraph

text: to achieve optimum ergonomic arrangements at minimum
label: Paragraph

text: cost, he was also a member of the Belgian wing of CIAM and
label: Paragraph

text: thus played a key role in the categorically Functionalist
label: Paragraph

text: Brussels CIAM congress of 1930. For this occasion he
label: Paragraph

text: designed, like Eysselinck, a suite of chromium-plated,
label: Paragraph

text: tubular-steel chairs after prototypes initially designed by
label: Paragraph

text: Ludwig Mies van der Rohe and Marcel Breuer, the
label: Paragraph

text: dimensions being discreetly modified in order to avoid
label: Paragraph

text: infringing the patent rights.
label: Paragraph

text: 652 De Koninck, De Koninck House, Brussels, 1924.
label: Caption

text: The masterwork of De Koninck’s career was
label: Paragraph

text: unquestionably the house [653, 654] he designed in 1929
label: Paragraph

text: for the Belgian landscape architect Jean Canneel-Claes. This
label: Paragraph

text: work, completed in 1931, has to be ranked as one of the
label: Paragraph

text: most economical houses built anywhere in Europe during
label: Paragraph

text: the high modern period of the 1930s. By the ingenious use
label: Paragraph

text: of sliding/folding doors, De Koninck was able to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate within the living room a separate section for
label: Paragraph

text: Canneel-Claes’s office. A spiral stair gave immediate access
label: Caption

text: to the bedrooms and bathroom on the floor above, with an
label: Paragraph

text: additional flight giving access to the roof terrace. Unlike Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier, who had first received the commission, De
label: Paragraph

text: Koninck met Canneel-Claes’s condition of affording direct
label: Paragraph

text: access to his cubistic parterre, which as a landscape
label: Paragraph

text: architect Canneel-Claes had conceived in opposition to both
label: Paragraph

text: the French formal garden tradition and the Anglo-Saxon
label: Title

text: Picturesque manner. De Koninck was always trying out the
label: Paragraph

text: latest technical innovations, which included on this occasion
label: Paragraph

text: walls of pumice concrete. Concrete floors were finished in
label: Paragraph

text: linoleum throughout, and patent Vera-Lux glass lenses,
label: Paragraph

text: designed by H.P. Berlage, were used to light the corner
label: Paragraph

text: staircase. During the 1930s this house was the most
label: Paragraph

text: published work of the Belgian Modern Movement, appearing
label: Paragraph

text: in both La Cité and in the Dutch magazine De 8 en Opbouw
label: Paragraph

text: in 1932. Two years later it was included in F.R.S. Yorke’s
label: Paragraph

text: publication The Modern House. Despite this international
label: Paragraph

text: triumph, the second half of the 1930s saw the gradual
label: Paragraph

text: stagnation of the Modern Movement in Belgium for, as
label: Paragraph

text: Pierre Puttemans wrote in 1976:
label: Paragraph

text: 653 De Koninck, Canneel House, Brussels, 1931.
label: Caption

text: 654 De Koninck, Canneel House, Brussels, 1931.
label: Caption

text: Despite the basic function as understood by the Cubist
label: Paragraph

text: architects, luxury was inherent in the bourgeois system
label: Paragraph

text: which did not expect architecture to establish that the
label: Paragraph

text: bodily measurements and biological needs of a worker were
label: Paragraph

text: similar to those of his employer, but wanted it, on the
label: Paragraph

text: contrary, to emphasize the difference ... So there we were
label: Paragraph

text: at the end of a great epoch for architecture. Modernism ...
label: Paragraph

text: was only represented by a small band of followers, it had
label: Paragraph

text: been accepted neither by the bourgeoisie, nor by extension
label: Paragraph

text: by the masses ... It was as though the bourgeoisie when
label: Paragraph

text: first threatened by the socialist wave of modernism, relied
label: Paragraph

text: on the latter’s own internal contradictions so that (as Marcel
label: Paragraph

text: Smets emphasized) the battle had been enjoined strictly on
label: Paragraph

text: the grounds of form.1
label: Caption

text: Nothing could be further removed from De Koninck than
label: Paragraph

text: the hardline socialist Antwerp architect Renaat Braem, who
label: Paragraph

text: was inspired by N.A. Milyutin’s linear city paradigm as set
label: Paragraph

text: forth in his book Sotsgorod (Socialist Towns) of 1930. This
label: Paragraph

text: was the primary inspiration behind the linear city that
label: Paragraph

text: Braem proposed in the mid-1930s: his 100-kilometre (62-
label: Paragraph

text: mile) canal, road and rail infrastructure linking Antwerp to
label: Paragraph

text: Liege. Braem’s commitment to the main planning precept of
label: Paragraph

text: the Soviet avant garde seems to have prompted him to
label: Paragraph

text: enter Le Corbusier’s studio in Paris, where he worked on
label: Paragraph

text: designing modular shop prototypes for Bata and on the art
label: Paragraph

text: museum that Le Corbusier projected for Paris in 1935. By
label: Paragraph

text: this date Le Corbusier had already become a prominent
label: Paragraph

text: figure on the Antwerp scene by virtue of his project for the
label: Paragraph

text: urbanization of the left bank of the Escaut [655], which was
label: Paragraph

text: designed in association with the architects Huib Hoste and
label: Paragraph

text: Félix Loquet.
label: Paragraph

text: 655 Le Corbusier, plan for the left bank of the river Escaut, Antwerp, 1933.
label: Caption

text: Braem inspired the post-war generation with his project
label: Paragraph

text: of Kiel Park City development for Antwerp (1950), which
label: Paragraph

text: provided 7,500 units in a series of thirteen-storey, free-
label: Paragraph

text: standing slab blocks designed in association with the
label: Caption

text: architects Maevement and Maes. This project led to the
label: Paragraph

text: invention of a gallery access system in which the external
label: Paragraph

text: gallery was set lower than the living level in order to ensure
label: Paragraph

text: privacy. Despite the emerging policy of the central
label: Paragraph

text: government, favouring wholesale suburbanization, the
label: Paragraph

text: municipalities of Antwerp and Brussels still commissioned
label: Title

text: large housing schemes, designed by Braem in association
label: Paragraph

text: with other architects.
label: Paragraph

text: The international exhibition staged in Brussels in 1958
label: Title

text: represented a moment of renewed confidence in Europe, as
label: Paragraph

text: was evident from the pavilions designed by leading
label: Paragraph

text: international architects, such as the elegant German
label: Paragraph

text: pavilion by Egon Eiermann and Le Corbusier’s reinforced-
label: Caption

text: concrete Philips Pavilion [656, 657], a hyperbolic shell

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Second World War. A rather extreme version of this ethos
label: Paragraph

text: was evident in the work of Juliaan Lampens, who, after

label: Paragraph

text: 1940 to 1950, immediately opened his own office to spend

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: designing a series of single-storey, reinforced-concrete
label: Paragraph

text: houses, beginning with his own house built in Eke about
label: Paragraph

text: 1960. Lampens’ radical anti-bourgeois attitude attained its
label: Paragraph

text: apotheosis in his Van Wassenhove House built at Sint-
label: Paragraph

text: Martens-Latem in 1974: articulated into an open living
label: Title

text: volume with a semicircular sleeping area enclosed by a
label: Paragraph

text: achieved through thin concrete partitions, which
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: roof. On this occasion a concrete pitched roof discharges
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: tank within the living-room terrace. This béton brut bunker
label: Paragraph

text: is Lampen’s ultimate existentialist statement, totally
label: Paragraph

text: outstripping in its audacity the ideology of Brutalism.
label: Paragraph

text: Stéphane Beel, one of the leading Belgian architects of
label: Paragraph

text: the next generation, established his minimalist reputation
label: Paragraph

text: overnight in 1993 with the so-called Villa M in Z [658], a 50-
label: Paragraph

text: metre (164-foot) long, single-storey luxury house built along
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: clear of the ground, this house is entered from one end via a
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: second house of consequence, the Villa P in R [659]; in
label: Paragraph

text: typological terms this is a single-storey courtyard house that
label: Paragraph

text: has paradoxically lost its patio by virtue of it being partly
label: Paragraph

text: raised on pilotis and situated on a bluff within a densely
label: Paragraph

text: wooded site. Beel’s early houses are symptomatic of the so-
label: Paragraph

text: called New Simplicity that he developed in collaboration
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the spectacularity of the latter-day Dutch avant garde led by
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: laconic approach over a wide front, designing in addition to
label: Paragraph

text: private houses large-scale civic works such as the new law
label: Paragraph

text: courts built in Ghent in 2010. In an interview with Moritz
label: Paragraph

text: King in 2005, Beel set forth the substance of his approach in
label: Paragraph

text: the following terms:

label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps the most critical aspect of Beel’s architecture is its
label: Paragraph

text: ‘anti-spectacular’ character, which has enabled him to insert
label: Paragraph

text: significant cultural institutions into leftover, interstitial paces
label: Paragraph

text: within the traditional urban fabric.
label: Paragraph

text: More susceptible than Beel to the profoundly Surrealist
label: Paragraph

text: tradition in Belgian artistic culture, the Ghent architects Raul
label: Paragraph

text: Robbrecht and Hilde Daem have often operated at the
label: Paragraph

text: interface between architecture and art, perhaps nowhere
label: Title

text: more effectively than in their light-weight demountable
label: Paragraph

text: pavilions. These were designed for the exhibition of art or as
label: Paragraph

text: artistic exhibits in themselves, or as combinations of both,
label: Paragraph

text: as in the Aue Pavilions in plywood. These pavilions were
label: Paragraph

text: erected first in Aue Park, Kassel, for the contemporary art
label: Caption

text: exhibition Documenta IX in 1992, where they temporarily
label: Paragraph

text: housed an exhibit by Dan Graham, and later in the
label: Paragraph

text: Netherlands at Almere in 1994 and Amersfoort in 2014.
label: Paragraph

text: These works were paralleled by their setting for René
label: Paragraph

text: Heyvaert’s exhibition ‘The Things | See’, staged in St Peter’s
label: Caption

text: Abbey, Ghent, in 1986. It is equally typical of Robbrecht and
label: Paragraph

text: Daem’s work that they would adopt an eccentric
label: Paragraph

text: proportional system for the design of buildings, based on
label: Paragraph

text: the numbers 3, 5 and 7, a system supposedly adopted by
label: Paragraph

text: Louis Kahn. When the numbers are multiplied together they
label: Paragraph

text: produce the total of 105, which the architects are in the
label: Paragraph

text: habit of adopting as an alternative to the standard metre.
label: Paragraph

text: The most significant work that these architects have
label: Paragraph

text: produced to date is the 1,700-seat auditorium and concert
label: Paragraph

text: hall that they deftly added to the traditional fabric of Bruges
label: Paragraph

text: Spain
label: Title

text: The Modern Movement in Spain was initiated by progressive
label: Paragraph

text: Catalan architects who constituted the group named
label: Paragraph

text: GATCPAC, an acronym that was changed in 1930 to
label: Paragraph

text: GATEPAC (Grupo Arquitectos y Técnicos Espafioles para el
label: Title

text: Progreso de la Arquitectura Contemporanea; ‘Group of
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish Architects and Technicians for the Progress of
label: Title

text: Contemporary Architecture’), in order to widen the
label: Paragraph

text: movement beyond Catalonia to include Spanish modern
label: Title

text: architects in general, above all Fernando Garcia Mercadal
label: Paragraph

text: from Madrid and José Manuel Aizpurua and Joaquin Labayen
label: Title

text: from San Sebastian, who jointly designed the first
label: Paragraph

text: discernibly modern building in Spain: the Royal Nautical
label: Title

text: Club of 1931 built in San Sebastian. In that year GATEPAC
label: Paragraph

text: published the first issue of its magazine AC: Documentos de
label: Paragraph

text: Actividad Contemporénea, significantly featuring on its
label: Paragraph

text: cover Leendert van der Vlugt and Mart Stam’s Van Nelle
label: Caption

text: Factory of 1929 in Rotterdam (see p. 145). Edited by José
label: Caption

text: Luis Sert and Josep Torres i Clavé, AC had an international
label: Paragraph

text: agenda, reproducing material from the third CIAM meeting
label: Paragraph

text: on the SS Patras of 1933. The last issue of AC, no. 25 of June
label: Caption

text: 1937, carried a photograph of a political demonstration on
label: Paragraph

text: its cover confirming that the editorial would be aligned with
label: Paragraph

text: the Republican side in the Spanish Civil War (1936-39).
label: Paragraph

text: The renewal of modern architecture in Spain has its
label: Paragraph

text: origin in the early 1950s, when, after a decade of stagnation
label: Paragraph

text: following Franco’s victory in the Civil War, the country’s
label: Paragraph

text: architects began to pick up the threads of a progressive
label: Paragraph

text: culture, beginning with Francisco Cabrero’s monumental
label: Paragraph

text: Union Building, Madrid, of 1949 and Josep Antoni Coderch’s
label: Caption

text: apartment block erected in Barcelonetta in 1951 and
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by the post-war manner of Ignacio Gardella.
label: Paragraph

text: Equally influenced by Italy, Alejandro de la Sota’s
label: Paragraph

text: Governor’s Palace built in Tarragona [661] in 1957 owed
label: Caption

text: something to Giuseppe Terragni’s Casa del Fascio of 1936.
label: Paragraph

text: The overall appeal of De la Sota’s approach stemmed from
label: Paragraph

text: his penchant for the precise articulation of constructional
label: Paragraph

text: form and from his ability to create stimulating spatial
label: Paragraph

text: constructs within the confines of a minimalist envelope. It is
label: Paragraph

text: a measure of de la Sota’s sophistication that he would see
label: Paragraph

text: the Governor’s Palace as a point of transition in terms of
label: Paragraph

text: political representation, since it epitomized a moment when
label: Paragraph

text: the traditional monumentality of stone, commonly
label: Paragraph

text: associated with the authority of the state, could now be
label: Paragraph

text: rendered as a dynamic, abstract envelope, similar in its
label: Paragraph

text: effect to the seemingly weightless marble planes that Mies
label: Paragraph

text: had deployed in his Barcelona Pavilion of 1929.
label: Paragraph

text: 661 De la Sota, Governor’s Palace, Tarragona, 1957.
label: Caption

text: Whether through the effect of his teaching in Madrid or of
label: Paragraph

text: the gymnasium that he built for the Colegio Maravillas in
label: Paragraph

text: Madrid (1962), de la Sota’s austere but dynamic syntax
label: Paragraph

text: became for a while something of a normative architectural
label: Paragraph

text: method in Spain. Among his more accomplished followers
label: Paragraph

text: were Victor Lopez Cotelo and Carlos Puente, particularly for
label: Paragraph

text: their library in Zaragoza (1984). De la Sota’s influence first
label: Paragraph

text: became manifest in Catalonia with Josep Llinas’s School of
label: Paragraph

text: Civil Engineering built in Barcelona in 1990. The Mora d’Ebre
label: Paragraph

text: Hospital [662] built two years before in Tarragona, to the
label: Paragraph

text: design of Elias Torres Tur and José Antonio Martinez Lapefa,
label: Caption

text: also seems to have been subject to this inspiration,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly for the way in which they were able to
label: Paragraph

text: transcend the hyper-technological character of the modern
label: Paragraph

text: hospital into one of the most humanly scaled works built
label: Paragraph

text: anywhere in the second half of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: 662 Martinez Lapefa and Torres Tur, Mora d’Ebre Hospital, Tarragona, 1982-88.
label: Caption

text: De la Sota’s influence was mediated by two other lines
label: Paragraph

text: emanating from the faculty of the leading architectural
label: Paragraph

text: school in Madrid: | have in mind the Aaltoesque approach of
label: Paragraph

text: Antonio Fernandez Alba, evident in his El Rollo monastery
label: Paragraph

text: built at Salamanca in 1962, or Francisco Javier Saenz de
label: Paragraph

text: Oiza’s Wrightian Torres Blancas apartments built in the
label: Paragraph

text: outskirts of Madrid in 1968 and his Banco de Bilbao office
label: Paragraph

text: tower [663] completed in the centre of the city in 1981,
label: Paragraph

text: vaguely reminiscent of Wright’s Johnson Wax Research
label: Paragraph

text: Tower of 1946. Largely faced in corten steel, with rounded
label: Caption

text: corners, this mid-rise tower is one of the few skyscrapers of
label: Paragraph

text: the post-war era to break with the post-1945, Miesian
label: Paragraph

text: paradigm of the curtain-walled, four-square, minimalist,
label: Paragraph

text: orthogonal office building.

label: Caption

text: Among the Madrilenian architects who emerged in the
label: Paragraph

text: mid-1970s, one of the most sophisticated was surely Rafael
label: Paragraph

text: Moneo, who - taught by Saenz de Oiza and apprenticed with
label: Paragraph

text: Jgrn Utzon - was as much influenced by Nordic architecture
label: Paragraph

text: as Alba had been before him. Moneo’s unique manner,
label: Paragraph

text: combining aspects of the works of Gunnar Asplund and
label: Paragraph

text: Wright, first appeared in his brick-clad Bankinter in Madrid,
label: Paragraph

text: realized in collaboration with Ramén Bescés in 1977.
label: Paragraph

text: Moneo’s capacity to synthesize diverse traditions into new
label: Paragraph

text: forms is evident in his National Museum of Roman Art [664]
label: Paragraph

text: built in Mérida in 1985, where a brick-tiled interior of Roman
label: Paragraph

text: proportions and a brick-clad, buttressed exterior allude to
label: Paragraph

text: both the Roman past and the mosque at Cérdoba dating
label: Paragraph

text: from the Arab occupation of Spain. This museum was
label: Paragraph

text: superimposed over the newly excavated remains of the
label: Paragraph

text: Roman city in such a way that its piers are set down on the
label: Paragraph

text: ancient footings: an audacious gesture that contaminated,
label: Paragraph

text: as it were, the purity of the archaeological excavation.
label: Paragraph

text: Moneo added a subterranean tunnel to this undercroft in
label: Paragraph

text: order to permit direct access on foot to the nearby open-air
label: Paragraph

text: remains of a Roman theatre and amphitheatre, thereby
label: Paragraph

text: simulating the experience of walking through the ancient
label: Paragraph

text: city.
label: Paragraph

text: 664 Moneo, National Museum of Roman Art, Mérida, 1980-85. Aerial view of the
label: Caption

text: museum under construction, showing its relationship to the town centre and the
label: Paragraph

text: Roman amphitheatre and theatre.
label: Paragraph

text: Through his teaching in Barcelona and Madrid, Moneo
label: Paragraph

text: exercised a decisive influence on the next generation,
label: Paragraph

text: including the Seville-based practice of Antonio Cruz and
label: Paragraph

text: Antonio Ortiz. This is evident from their earliest work, a four-
label: Paragraph

text: storey apartment building that they ingeniously inserted
label: Paragraph

text: into the dense fabric of Seville in 1976, to their much larger
label: Paragraph

text: four-storey, brick-faced Carabanchel housing estate
label: Caption

text: completed in Madrid in 1989 [665]. Their national
label: Paragraph

text: reputation was consolidated around this time by the
label: Paragraph

text: realization of the monumental Santa Justa railway terminal
label: Caption

text: in Seville [666]. Thereafter their prestige as civic architects
label: Paragraph

text: would be reinforced through one public commission after
label: Paragraph

text: another, culminating in the calm, symmetrical
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality of the Olympic Stadium that they saw
label: Paragraph

text: completed in Seville at the millennium. In between these
label: Paragraph

text: achievements they produced a number of designs for
label: Paragraph

text: housing schemes, including their Novo Sancti Petri project in
label: Paragraph

text: Cadiz, which was a reinterpretation of Jorn Utzon’s Kingo
label: Paragraph

text: typology of 1958. Cruz and Ortiz adapted Utzon’s single-
label: Paragraph

text: storey courtyard house to a multi-storey format, with units
label: Paragraph

text: grouped together so as to shield both the individual home
label: Paragraph

text: and the estate from its exposure on a windswept coastal
label: Paragraph

text: site.
label: Paragraph

text: 665 Cruz and Ortiz, Carabanchel housing estate, Madrid, 1986-89.

label: Caption

text: While the critical culture of Madrid in the post-Franco
label: Paragraph

text: period after 1975 stemmed from Juan Daniel Fullaondo’s
label: Paragraph

text: journal Nueva Forma, the critical discourse in Barcelona was
label: Paragraph

text: energized by the magazine Arquitecturas Bis founded by
label: Paragraph

text: Rosa Regas in 1974. The editorial line of this newspaper
label: Paragraph

text: represented the combined efforts of a closely knit editorial
label: Paragraph

text: board under the leadership of the architect-historian Oriol
label: Paragraph

text: Bohigas, including figures teaching at the ETSAB faculty of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in Barcelona, such as the architects Federico
label: Paragraph

text: Correa, Helio Pifén, Ignasi de Sola-Morales and Rafael
label: Title

text: Moneo, and the aesthetic philosopher Tomas Llorens.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1982 Bohigas, as city architect, published a plan for
label: Paragraph

text: the restructuring of Barcelona under the title Plans /
label: Title

text: Projectes per a Barcelona. Two factors made this programme
label: Paragraph

text: unique: firstly, the aim to refurbish the city on a piecemeal
label: Paragraph

text: basis and, secondly, a determination on the part of the
label: Paragraph

text: municipality to turn the plan into reality. Bohigas’s
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona plan led to the realization of ten parks, two major
label: Paragraph

text: avenues and numerous plazas of varying size, including one
label: Paragraph

text: facing the Sants Station, rendered as a minimalist public
label: Caption

text: Space in 1986 to the designs of Helio Pifén and Albert
label: Paragraph

text: Viaplana with Enric Miralles and Carme Pinds as assistants.
label: Paragraph

text: Carefully graded and furnished so as to reinforce the
label: Paragraph

text: character of the site, this work is typical of the stress that is
label: Paragraph

text: placed on topography in Spanish architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The selection of Barcelona as the site for the 1992
label: Title

text: Olympics had the effect of expanding Bohigas’s city plan,
label: Paragraph

text: entailing not only a totally new residential quarter for
label: Paragraph

text: 10,000 people, to serve as the Olympic Village and later as
label: Paragraph

text: regular housing stock, but also to create a new relationship
label: Paragraph

text: between the city and the sea by diverting a major rail link
label: Paragraph

text: inland away from the coast. Called upon to design sports
label: Paragraph

text: facilities for the Olympics, many Catalan architects
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated a capacity to build in the manner of French
label: Paragraph

text: grands constructeurs, among them Esteban Bonell and
label: Paragraph

text: Francesc Rius in their velodrome built at Vall d’Hebron in
label: Paragraph

text: 1984 [667] and basketball arena at Badalona of 1991 [668],
label: Paragraph

text: as civic monuments capable of consolidating the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding urban fabric.
label: Paragraph

text: 667 Bonell and Rius, Horta Velodrome, Vall d’Hebron, Barcelona, 1984.
label: Caption

label: Caption

text: workers’ housing in Madrid of 1961 to Josep Antoni
label: Caption

text: Coderch’s multi-storey upper-middle-class housing realized

label: Caption

text: 1974, the building of residential stock for an increasingly
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: their traditional skill in the organization of domestic space.
label: Paragraph

text: The typological approach of the Italian Tendenza, as
label: Paragraph

text: proselytized through the Barcelona magazine 2C
label: Title

text: Construccién de la Ciudad, had a decisive influence on the
label: Paragraph

text: new housing types developed during this period, from
label: Paragraph

text: Francisco Barrionuevo’s perimeter blocks in Seville of 1980
label: Caption

text: to the high-rise slabs built in the Palomeras district of
label: Paragraph

text: Madrid in 1983 to the designs of Estanislao Pérez Pita and
label: Paragraph

text: Jerénimo Junquera. Equally inventive solutions
label: Paragraph

text: wereprojected for institutional buildings, such as the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: One should not underestimate the important cultural role
label: Paragraph

text: that was once played by the co/egio system in Spain, prior
label: Paragraph

text: to its deregulation by the European Union, since these guild-
label: Paragraph

text: like institutions guaranteed the Spanish profession a level of
label: Paragraph

text: protection that hardly existed in any other country. The
label: Paragraph

text: regionally based co/egios exercised a powerful influence
label: Paragraph

text: over the entire construction industry, having jurisdiction not
label: Paragraph

text: only over building permits but also over professional fees
label: Paragraph

text: from which they subtracted a small percentage for its
label: Paragraph

text: services. This system was thus able to patronize local
label: Paragraph

text: architectural culture through exhibitions, lectures and
label: Paragraph

text: subsidized magazines. The continuing validity of the
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish tradition in architectural reportage and criticism
label: Title

text: largely derived from this patronage, as is still reflected even
label: Paragraph

text: now in outstanding Spanish publications including E/ Croquis
label: Paragraph

text: and Arquitectura Viva. Not only did this erstwhile
label: Paragraph

text: institutional support assure Spanish architects of their
label: Paragraph

text: prestige, but it also encouraged them to design with
label: Paragraph

text: reference to an immediate reality rather than to become
label: Paragraph

text: preoccupied, as elsewhere, with either an inaccessible
label: Paragraph

text: future or an equally remote past.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the unfortunate deregulation of this system, the
label: Paragraph

text: capacity of Spanish architects to make a realistic
label: Paragraph

text: contribution to society persists, for while Spanish work has
label: Paragraph

text: become more varied, the profession still retains an ability to
label: Paragraph

text: build in an exceptionally rich and effective manner, as may
label: Paragraph

text: be seen in the work of the Galician architect Manuel
label: Paragraph

text: Gallego. He graduated from the ETSA (Escuela Técnica
label: Paragraph

text: Superior de Arquitectura) Madrid in 1963 and thereafter
label: Paragraph

text: worked as an assistant to de la Sota before becoming an
label: Paragraph

text: architect within the Galician ministry of housing, while still
label: Paragraph

text: maintaining a small practice that would allow him to realize
label: Paragraph

text: the occasional piece of urban infill in remote parts of Galicia.
label: Paragraph

text: His most important work to date is the Galician presidential
label: Paragraph

text: complex that he realized for Santiago de Compostela in
label: Paragraph

text: 1999-2002 [669]. Built on a diminutive acropolis elevated
label: Caption

text: above the city, this carefully inlaid topographic work is as
label: Paragraph

text: much a beautifully articulated landscape as it is the seat of
label: Paragraph

text: provincial government. This greensward site, structured by
label: Paragraph

text: low retaining walls executed in rough-hewn local stone,
label: Paragraph

text: serves to ground the low-rise, ashlar-faced buildings, the
label: Paragraph

text: character of which is enlivened by well-detailed, generously
label: Paragraph

text: proportioned timber windows.
label: Caption

text: 669 Gallego, Galician Presidential Complex, Santiago de Compostela, 1999-
label: Caption

text: Owing to the cultural vitality of the Spanish provincial
label: Paragraph

text: city, Spain continues to nurture a strong civic tradition,
label: Paragraph

text: amply reflected in Rafael Moneo’s wide-ranging career, from
label: Paragraph

text: the Kursaal complex in San Sebastian to his delicate
label: Paragraph

text: insertion of a multi-storey city hall into the medieval fabric
label: Paragraph

text: of Murcia in 1998. And what is true of Moneo also applies to
label: Paragraph

text: the careers of many other Spanish architects who have
label: Paragraph

text: been engaged over the past two decades in generating an
label: Paragraph

text: exceptional spectrum of civic buildings, from the Usera
label: Paragraph

text: Library, Madrid, by Abalos and Herreros, to Francisco
label: Caption

text: Mangado’s Baluarte Auditorium, completed on a trapezoidal
label: Caption

text: site in the centre of Pamplona, both works dating from 2003.
label: Caption

text: Among the more accomplished civic structures to be
label: Paragraph

text: completed in Spain is a small public library in the Madrid
label: Paragraph

text: suburb of Villanueva de la Canada, realized to the designs of
label: Paragraph

text: Churtichaga and Quadra-Salcedo in the same year. Here,
label: Paragraph

text: the open book stacks have been treated as a Spiralling
label: Paragraph

text: street-space, the ramped floors and walls of which are built
label: Paragraph

text: of reinforced brickwork by way of a homage to the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Eladio Dieste. A comparable evolution of regional culture
label: Paragraph

text: may be traced in the work of Guillermo Vazquez Consuegra,
label: Paragraph

text: who, having graduated from the ETSA Seville in 1972, first
label: Paragraph

text: made his reputation with a long, four-storey, low-cost
label: Paragraph

text: housing block completed as a single urban element in 1987
label: Paragraph

text: [672]. Entirely finished in white rendering, this building
label: Caption

text: became a symbol of a renewed modernity in southern
label: Paragraph

text: Spain, and he consolidated his position in this regard with
label: Paragraph

text: an equally striking telecommunications tower built in Cadiz
label: Paragraph

text: 670 Consuegra, telecommunications tower, Cadiz, 1993. Elevation.

text: The Madrid School yielded a new generation of architects
label: Paragraph

text: who were pupils of both SAenz de Oiza and Moneo, among
label: Paragraph

text: them the practice of Luis Mansilla and Emilio Tunén. They
label: Paragraph

text: began in the 1990s with their exceptionally rational Zamora
label: Paragraph

text: Museum [673, 674], inserted into the heart of a traditional
label: Paragraph

text: urban fabric in 1996, followed by the closely related
label: Paragraph

text: Castell6n Museum of Fine Arts completed in the heart of
label: Caption

text: that city at the millennium. Of a similar, slightly younger
label: Paragraph

text: generation coming out of the same school are Enrique
label: Paragraph

text: Sobejano and Fuensanta Nieto, who, now based in Madrid
label: Paragraph

text: and Berlin, have enjoyed a particularly successful career.
label: Paragraph

text: Their first project was a university chancellery for Vigo,
label: Paragraph

text: which they won in competition in 1996, and was followed by
label: Paragraph

text: an equally rigorous housing complex built by the side of a
label: Paragraph

text: motorway in Seville in 2001 [676]. Perhaps their most
label: Paragraph

text: sublime work to date is their Madinat Al Zahara Museum
label: Paragraph

text: [675], completed in 2008 on the site of an Islamic city,
label: Paragraph

text: dating from ad 936, the remains of which were discovered in
label: Paragraph

text: 1911. The quiet elegance of this building stems from its
label: Paragraph

text: white, labyrinthic, ‘mat-building’ form, which - closely
label: Paragraph

text: integrated with the topography - may be read not only as a
label: Paragraph

text: museum but also as a metaphor for the original settlement.
label: Paragraph

text: Another Madrilenian practice coming into its own is that
label: Paragraph

text: of Angela Garcia de Paredes and Ignacio Garcia Pedrosa,
label: Paragraph

text: who - having been apprenticed to the architect of the
label: Paragraph

text: National Theatre, José Maria Garcia de Paredes - produced
label: Caption

text: as their first independent work the Valdemaqueda Town Hall
label: Paragraph

text: in 1998: a small, rationalist work comprising two low-rise
label: Paragraph

text: structures set in the midst of a historic fabric. This would be
label: Paragraph

text: the first in a series of civic buildings that they completed
label: Paragraph

text: around the millennium, ranging from a congress centre for
label: Paragraph

text: Murcia (2002) to a museum in Almeria of virtually the same
label: Paragraph

text: date. Perhaps their most subtle and accomplished work to
label: Paragraph

text: date is the public library of Ceuta [671], built in Algeciras in
label: Paragraph

text: 2014 over the excavated remains of a medieval city.
label: Caption

text: 671 Paredes Pedrosa, Ceuta Public Library, 2007-14.

text: Portugal
label: Title

text: Any appraisal of the evolution of modern architecture in
label: Paragraph

text: Portugal has to acknowledge the didactic and creative
label: Paragraph

text: contribution of Fernando Tavora, who, together with Carlos
label: Paragraph

text: Ramos, was the prime mover of the reformation of the Porto
label: Paragraph

text: School of architecture throughout the 1950s. Tavora’s
label: Paragraph

text: lifelong preoccupation was to combine the functionality of
label: Paragraph

text: the Modern Movement with the equally reasonable, but less
label: Paragraph

text: abstract, rationality of vernacular culture, an ambition that
label: Paragraph

text: he perhaps came closest to realizing in the pousada (hotel)
label: Paragraph

text: [677] that he added in 1984 to the 18th-century Santa
label: Paragraph

text: Marinha da Costa Convent in Guimaraes.
label: Caption

text: 677 Tavora, Santa Marinha da Costa Convent hotel addition, Guimaraes, 1975-
label: Caption

text: Although the Porto School has largely shaped the
label: Paragraph

text: perception of Portuguese architecture over the past forty
label: Title

text: years, a number of other architects across the country also
label: Paragraph

text: accomplished significant works in the same period, above
label: Paragraph

text: all the practices of the Lisbon-based architects Gongalo
label: Paragraph

text: Byrne and Jodo Luis Carrilho da Graca. Starting within a
label: Paragraph

text: decade of each other, they both established the lines of
label: Paragraph

text: their respective practices early in their careers, with the first
label: Paragraph

text: largely focused on the design of university campuses and
label: Paragraph

text: the second orientated towards museological commissions.
label: Paragraph

text: Byrne’s career began with a continuous six- to eight-storey
label: Paragraph

text: housing complex built in the relatively low-rise Chelas
label: Paragraph

text: district of Lisbon from 1972 to 1974. However, Byrne came
label: Paragraph

text: into his own as a civic architect with the faculty buildings
label: Paragraph

text: that he designed for the universities of Oeiras and Coimbra
label: Paragraph

text: over the years 1988-96; one of his finest works from this
label: Paragraph

text: period is the Department of Electrical and Computer
label: Paragraph

text: Engineering built for the University of Coimbra in 1991. The
label: Paragraph

text: most sculptural aspect of Byrne’s career to date has been
label: Paragraph

text: the maritime control tower that he designed for the port of
label: Paragraph

text: Lisbon in 2001 [678].
label: Paragraph

text: 678 Byrne, Torre APL, Lisbon, 2001.
label: Caption

text: Carrilho da Graga’s career began with a hilltop swimming
label: Paragraph

text: pool, designed with Carlos Miguel Dias for Campo Maior in
label: Caption

text: 1990 [679]. Thereafter he assumed a more minimalist
label: Paragraph

text: approach than that of Byrne, first with a theatre and concert
label: Paragraph

text: hall that he designed in Poitiers, France, in 2008 and then
label: Paragraph

text: with an archaeological museum completed in Lisbon the
label: Paragraph

text: same year [680]. The latter is typical of the architect’s
label: Paragraph

text: penchant for superimposing circulation on top of an
label: Paragraph

text: archaeological site so as to focus the visitor’s attention on
label: Paragraph

text: the stone foundations that remain. The seemingly thick
label: Paragraph

text: walls of this design are built up out of corten-steel plates
label: Paragraph

text: and are covered with translucent glass roofs.
label: Paragraph

text: 679 Carrilho da Graca, Municipal Swimming Pool, Campo Maior, 1990.
label: Caption

text: 680 Carrilho da Graca, Praga Nova, Archaeological Museum, Lisbon, 2008.
label: Caption

text: Section.
label: Paragraph

text: An atypical work equally removed from both Porto and
label: Paragraph

text: Lisbon is the Paula Rego Museum built in Cascais between
label: Paragraph

text: 2005 and 2009 to the designs of Eduardo Souto de Moura
label: Caption

text: [681, 682]. This building, housing the work of Rego,
label: Caption

text: establishes its unique architectural presence through two
label: Paragraph

text: shell concrete volumes Superimposed in each instance over
label: Paragraph

text: square plans, respectively housing a library and a café. The
label: Paragraph

text: in situ concrete of these forms is dyed red in contrast to the
label: Paragraph

text: lawn and trees onto which the building opens.
label: Paragraph

text: 681 Souto de Moura, Paula Rego Museum, Cascais, 2005-09. Elevation.
label: Caption

text: 682 Souto de Moura, Paula Rego Museum, Cascais, 2005-09. Roof plan.

text: One of the little-acknowledged Portuguese achievements
label: Paragraph

text: in the 21st century are the new schools designed and
label: Paragraph

text: realized for the municipality of Obidos between 1989 and
label: Paragraph

text: 2010, beginning with a school built adjacent to a stadium in
label: Paragraph

text: the centre of the city. Hyper-aware that the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: school is now rapidly evolving under the impact of digital
label: Paragraph

text: technology, the municipality elected to build four new
label: Paragraph

text: schools, designed by the émigré architect Claudio Sat [683,
label: Paragraph

text: 684], instead of upgrading or replacing older, under-
label: Paragraph

text: equipped schools in the rural hinterland. Like the schools
label: Paragraph

text: built in Sao Paulo, Brazil, during the first decade of the 21st
label: Paragraph

text: century, these schools have also been conceived in such a
label: Paragraph

text: way as to function as community centres in the evening.
label: Paragraph

text: 683 Sat, Furadouro School, Obidos, 2010.
label: Caption

text: 684 Sat, Furadouro School, Obidos, 2010. Site plan.
label: Caption

text: At this juncture one also needs to acknowledge the
label: Paragraph

text: important contribution made by the leading Portuguese
label: Paragraph

text: landscape architect Jodo Gomes da Silva, who has worked
label: Paragraph

text: on a number of seminal projects in collaboration with such
label: Paragraph

text: architects as Alvaro Siza and Carrilho da Graca. Among his
label: Paragraph

text: key works in this regard is the parkscape that he created for
label: Paragraph

text: both Siza’s Malagueira housing in Evora in 1997.
