text: Italy
label: Title

text: After Benito Mussolini’s assumption of dictatorial power in
label: Paragraph

text: 1922, the rise of the Modern Movement in Italy was
label: Paragraph

text: inseparable from the modernizing architectural and
label: Paragraph

text: urbanistic aspirations of the Fascist state as outlined by the
label: Paragraph

text: engineer Gaetano Ciocca and the architect-editor Ernesto
label: Title

text: Nathan Rogers in their article ‘Per la citta corporativa’,
label: Paragraph

text: published in Pietro Maria Bardi’s magazine Quadrante in
label: Caption

text: 1934. It was essentially this urban vision that the
label: Paragraph

text: industrialist Adriano Olivetti advanced in 1937, when he
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned the practice of BBPR - Gianluigi Banfi,
label: Paragraph

text: Lodovico Barbiano di Belgiojoso, Enrico Peressutti and
label: Caption

text: Ernesto Rogers - along with the architects Luigi Figini and
label: Paragraph

text: Gino Pollini, to produce a regulatory plan for the Valle
label: Paragraph

text: d'Aosta region. This idea would be further elaborated in a
label: Paragraph

text: subsequent article that appeared in the same year in
label: Paragraph

text: Quadrante written by Banfi and Belgiojoso, entitled
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Urbanistica corporativa’. The earliest fruits of the Valle
label: Paragraph

text: d'Aosta plan were the housing and schools designed for the
label: Paragraph

text: new industrial town of Ivrea by Figini and Pollini from 1939
label: Caption

text: to 1942. It is significant that Olivetti’s ultimate split from
label: Paragraph

text: Mussolini occurred only in 1943, the year in which both he
label: Paragraph

text: and Rogers went into exile in Switzerland. It is equally
label: Paragraph

text: telling that after the war Olivetti resuscitated his Saint-
label: Paragraph

text: Simonian model of an ideal industrialized society through a
label: Paragraph

text: didactic emphasis on the idea of a cooperative community
label: Paragraph

text: as promulgated in his journal Comunita, first published in
label: Paragraph

text: The intense and complex Italian architectural debate
label: Title

text: from 1945 onwards was initiated by two exceptional
label: Paragraph

text: personalities: Bruno Zevi, the architectural historian, and
label: Paragraph

text: Ernesto Rogers. Given that both had Jewish origins, they
label: Paragraph

text: were compelled eventually to leave Italy following
label: Paragraph

text: Mussolini’s alliance with the Third Reich in 1936. Zevi went
label: Paragraph

text: to London in 1939, where he briefly attended the
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Association School of Architecture, before
label: Title

text: going on to the United States, where he studied with Walter
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius at the Graduate School of Design, Harvard
label: Caption

text: University, receiving his BArch degree in 1942. Whereas
label: Paragraph

text: Rogers remained until the pending defeat and destruction of
label: Paragraph

text: Italy forced him to leave in 1943 for Zurich, where he spent
label: Paragraph

text: his enforced exile in the company of Sigfried Giedion, Max
label: Paragraph

text: Bill and Alfred Roth.
label: Paragraph

text: The publication of Henry-Russell Hitchcock’s pioneering
label: Title

text: study of Frank Lloyd Wright, /n the Nature of Materials
label: Title

text: (1941), convinced Zevi as to the inherently liberating
label: Paragraph

text: dimensions of Wright’s organic architecture, although he did
label: Paragraph

text: not meet Wright until 1945, the year in which he published
label: Paragraph

text: his basic thesis Verso un’architettura organica, featuring an
label: Paragraph

text: image of Wright’s Fallingwater on its cover. On returning to
label: Caption

text: Italy in that year he founded his school for organic
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and, more importantly, the Associazione Per
label: Paragraph

text: l’Architettura Organica (APAO). Following Wright, by the
label: Paragraph

text: term ‘organic’ Zevi had in mind a functionally and
label: Paragraph

text: structurally expressive architecture which was
label: Paragraph

text: simultaneously responsive to the topography of the site and
label: Paragraph

text: the exigencies of the local climate.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1948 Zevi was appointed by Giuseppe Samona, the
label: Paragraph

text: director of the Venice School of Architecture, to take over
label: Paragraph

text: the teaching of history and theory as part of a new
label: Paragraph

text: curriculum. Zevi would remain in Venice for the next fifteen
label: Paragraph

text: years before going to the University of Rome in 1960 to take
label: Paragraph

text: up the professorship left vacant by the death in 1960 of
label: Paragraph

text: Marcello Piacentini. One of the most paradoxical figures to
label: Paragraph

text: be seemingly influenced by Zevi's organicism was Luigi
label: Paragraph

text: Moretti, whose masterly Girasole apartment building [685],
label: Paragraph

text: erected in Rome in 1950, remains - despite its organic
label: Paragraph

text: character - as paradoxically removed from Wright as it is
label: Paragraph

text: distant from the Rationalism of Moretti’s pre-war career.
label: Paragraph

text: 685 Moretti, Casa II Girasole, Rome, 1950.
label: Caption

text: Rogers, nine years older than Zevi, had been a founding
label: Paragraph

text: partner of BBPR, the first realized work of which was a
label: Paragraph

text: weekend house exhibited at the fifth Milan Triennale, in
label: Paragraph

text: 1933. It is clear that the partners of BBPR, like many other
label: Paragraph

text: Italian architects of the time, were committed to the
label: Paragraph

text: modernization of Italy under Fascism and they completed
label: Paragraph

text: four major works for the Mussolini regime prior to the
label: Caption

text: outbreak of the Second World War: an eleven-storey
label: Title

text: Milanese apartment block; a state-sponsored children’s
label: Paragraph

text: health centre and a medium-rise, low-cost housing estate,
label: Paragraph

text: both in Legnano; and a design for the Palazzo della Poste
label: Caption

text: built for the site of the ill-fated E42 exhibition, the planned
label: Paragraph

text: world’s fair of 1942, to be staged near Rome. Given this
label: Paragraph

text: beginning, it is a tragic irony that the first commission
label: Paragraph

text: realized by BBPR after the war should be a monument to
label: Paragraph

text: concentration camp victims [686], particularly since both
label: Paragraph

text: Banfi and Belgiojoso had suffered incarceration for their
label: Paragraph

text: anti-Fascism during the war, with Banfi dying in a camp in
label: Paragraph

text: 1943. This small monument erected in a Milanese cemetery
label: Caption

text: in 1945 comprised a welded, tubular-steel frame and free-
label: Paragraph

text: floating planes pinwheeling asymmetrically about an urn
label: Paragraph

text: was contained within a virtual cube on a stone base. The
label: Paragraph

text: quasi-Neo-Plastic character of this monument anticipated
label: Paragraph

text: the 1951 reappraisal of the Dutch De Stijl movement
label: Title

text: initiated by the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam with an
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition which, designed by Carlo Scarpa, was restaged in
label: Paragraph

text: Rome in the following year. One year later, in 1953, Zevi
label: Paragraph

text: published his own appreciation of De Stijl in a book entitled
label: Paragraph

text: La Poetica dell’architettura neoplastica.
label: Caption

text: 686 BBPR, Monument for the Victims of Nazi Concentration Camps, Milan, 1945.
label: Caption

text: The established Milanese architect Gio Ponti, founder of
label: Paragraph

text: the magazine Domus in 1928, played a key role in Rogers’s
label: Paragraph

text: post-war career by twice appointing him as editor of leading
label: Paragraph

text: magazines, first Domus in 1945 and then Casabella in 1953,
label: Paragraph

text: an avant-garde journal that had been previously edited by
label: Paragraph

text: the heroic figure of Giuseppe Pagano, who had not survived
label: Paragraph

text: the war. Rogers added the subtitle continuita (‘continuity’)
label: Paragraph

text: to the name Casabella, signifying the intent of critically
label: Paragraph

text: cultivating the legacy of the Modern Movement as it had
label: Paragraph

text: evolved during the first four decades of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: This re-evaluation of the movement led to a sequence of
label: Paragraph

text: special issues devoted to the work of such proto-modernists
label: Paragraph

text: as Henry van der Velde, Hendrik Petrus Berlage, Hans
label: Paragraph

text: Poelzig and Adolf Loos, while at the same time featuring the
label: Paragraph

text: works of emerging talented post-war architects such as
label: Paragraph

text: Kenzo Tange, Max Bill and O.M. Ungers. A number of young
label: Caption

text: architectural intellectuals were adopted by Rogers as
label: Paragraph

text: editorial assistants and essayists, among them Aldo Rossi,
label: Paragraph

text: Giorgio Grassi, Vittorio Gregotti and Guido Canella. These
label: Paragraph

text: four made up the core of Rogers’s Centro Stud/: a seminar
label: Paragraph

text: that met regularly to formulate the agenda of the magazine
label: Paragraph

text: with some of them going on to stake out theoretical
label: Paragraph

text: positions of their own, leading to such works as Rossi’s
label: Paragraph

text: L’architettura della citta and Gregotti’s // territorio
label: Caption

text: dell’architettura, both dating from 1966, and Grassi’s La
label: Paragraph

text: costruzione logica dell’architettura of 1967. These architects
label: Paragraph

text: would start to practise independently, the first, Rossi, with
label: Paragraph

text: the metaphysical form of the apartment building that he
label: Paragraph

text: integrated into Carlo Aymonino’s constructivist Gallaratese
label: Paragraph

text: complex in Milan. He was followed by Gregotti, with his
label: Paragraph

text: projection of the University of Cosenza as a continuous
label: Paragraph

text: linear city, built 1973-80 as a straight line across the virgin
label: Paragraph

text: open landscape of Calabria for some 3.2 kilometres (2
label: Paragraph

text: miles), thereby demonstrating his concept that architecture
label: Paragraph

text: had to be closely integrated with the existing landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: Three years later Grassi, in collaboration with Antonio
label: Paragraph

text: Monestiroli, realized at Chieti an austerely rational student
label: Paragraph

text: dormitory [688], somewhat reminiscent of Schinkel’s Altes
label: Paragraph

text: Museum of 1834 (see p. 20).
label: Paragraph

text: At variance with both Gregotti’s topographically inflected
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and Grassi’s rational assembly of trabeated
label: Title

text: orthogonal elements, Carlo Aymonino’s housing complex
label: Caption

text: [687, 689], built in Milan (1967-72) and inspired by the
label: Paragraph

text: Russian avant garde of the 1920s, was an ensemble
label: Paragraph

text: comprising duplexes, apartments and an open-air theatre. It
label: Paragraph

text: was extensively served by stairs, ramps and aerial bridges
label: Paragraph

text: in such a way as to echo the Soviet concept of a ‘social
label: Paragraph

text: condenser’.
label: Paragraph

text: 687 Aymonino, Monte Amiata housing complex, Gallaratese 2, Milan, 1967-72.
label: Caption

text: 688 Grassi and Monestiroli, student dormitory, Chieti, 1976-79.
label: Caption

text: 689 Aymonino, Monte Amiata housing complex, Gallaratese 2, Milan, 1967-72.
label: Caption

text: Site plan.
label: Paragraph

text: Ernesto Rogers’s most significant post-war contribution
label: Title

text: as an architect was his twenty-six-storey Torre Velasca
label: Paragraph

text: apartment building, built in the centre of Milan in 1956, a
label: Paragraph

text: work that featured an exposed steel frame structure
label: Paragraph

text: inspired by the structural rationalism of Auguste Perret. The
label: Paragraph

text: shaft of the tower was crowned by a seven-storey element
label: Caption

text: cantilevered out on all four sides so as to resemble the
label: Paragraph

text: silhouette of a 14th-century fortified turret. Although this
label: Paragraph

text: was not the most exotic example of the Neo-Liberty style,
label: Paragraph

text: which the British critic Reyner Banham attacked in his
label: Paragraph

text: provocative essay ‘Neoliberty: The Italian Retreat from
label: Title

text: Modern Architecture’, published in The Architectural Review
label: Paragraph

text: in 1959, it was nonetheless symptomatic of the historicizing
label: Paragraph

text: mannerism that was prominent in Italian work at the time
label: Paragraph

text: (compare Franco Albini’s La Rinascente store in Rome of
label: Caption

text: 1961). What Banham failed to acknowledge, however, was
label: Paragraph

text: that for the architects of Rogers’s generation the legacy of
label: Paragraph

text: the Modern Movement in Italy had been profoundly
label: Paragraph

text: compromised by its association with Fascism. This unease
label: Paragraph

text: with the Rationalist architecture of the interwar period
label: Paragraph

text: surely also accounts for Zevi's reluctance to acknowledge
label: Paragraph

text: the importance of Giuseppe Terragni, which he did not do
label: Paragraph

text: until 1968 when he devoted an entire issue of his magazine
label: Paragraph

text: L’architettura: cronache e storia to documenting Terragni’s
label: Title

text: work.
label: Paragraph

text: Banham was not alone in his critique of Neo-Liberty, as is
label: Paragraph

text: evident from the British and Dutch criticism of the Torre
label: Paragraph

text: Velasca during the last CIAM meeting in Otterlo in 1959. By
label: Paragraph

text: then Rogers had already outlined the nature of the Italian
label: Paragraph

text: dilemma two years earlier in the editorial he wrote for
label: Paragraph

text: Casabella (issue 215), entitled ‘Continuity or Crisis’. In this
label: Paragraph

text: piece, subject to the influence of Enzo Paci’s
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenology, Rogers had first posed the problem of how
label: Paragraph

text: one may develop a humanist mode of building without
label: Paragraph

text: succumbing to the materialist logic of reductive
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism. The critical humanism advocated by both
label: Paragraph

text: Rogers and Zevi would be repudiated by Zevi’s prime pupil
label: Paragraph

text: at the University of Rome, namely Manfredo Tafuri, whose
label: Paragraph

text: critical judgement, fully articulated in his books Theory and
label: Paragraph

text: History (1968) and Architecture and Utopia: Design and
label: Title

text: Capitalist Development (1973), challenged the very idea of
label: Paragraph

text: an operative history upon which Zevi had placed so much
label: Paragraph

text: store. Instead Tafuri, profoundly influenced by Marxism,
label: Paragraph

text: advocated a radical modernity in which any trace of
label: Paragraph

text: bourgeois humanism would be eliminated - the evocation of
label: Paragraph

text: a socialist ‘degree zero’ that foreclosed on the possibility of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture participating in any kind of ameliorative
label: Title

text: practice in the interim.
label: Paragraph

text: To one side of this closure lay the independent position of
label: Paragraph

text: Giancarlo de Carlo, who was both a critical intellectual and
label: Paragraph

text: an architect - first via his editing of his journal Spazio e
label: Paragraph

text: societa, published from 1978 to 2001, and second through
label: Paragraph

text: his lifelong commitment to the development of Urbino,
label: Paragraph

text: typical of which were the new university classrooms and a
label: Paragraph

text: lecture hall that he built into the historical fabric of the city.
label: Paragraph

text: Later De Carlo was commissioned to design a new
label: Paragraph

text: residential college for the University of Urbino [690], which
label: Paragraph

text: he proceeded to organize as if it were a terraced
label: Paragraph

text: interpretation of an Italian hill town. There followed further
label: Paragraph

text: colleges for the university on nearby hilltop sites, with
label: Paragraph

text: circulation built into the dormitories as they descend the
label: Paragraph

text: slopes.
label: Paragraph

text: 690 De Carlo, Nuovi Collegi Universitari (University of Urbino), 1956. Plan and
label: Caption

text: section.
label: Paragraph

text: From 1969 to 1974 De Carlo was involved with the design
label: Paragraph

text: of social housing for the Villaggio Matteotti at Terni, sited
label: Caption

text: some 100 kilometres (62 miles) north-west of Rome.
label: Paragraph

text: Commissioned by a state-owned steelworks, this housing
label: Paragraph

text: was ultimately successful largely due to the fact that De
label: Paragraph

text: Carlo had stipulated that the future inhabitants should be
label: Paragraph

text: allowed to participate in the design process and moreover
label: Paragraph

text: should be paid for doing so.
label: Paragraph

text: As rooted as De Carlo was, one of the most fertile
label: Paragraph

text: practices in Italy in the 1960s was that of Gino Valle, whose
label: Paragraph

text: work was restricted for the most part to Udine and its
label: Paragraph

text: immediate vicinity, where one of his most arresting
label: Paragraph

text: buildings was the Zanussi Rex offices [691] that he built in
label: Paragraph

text: Pordenone in 1961. Of all the Italian post-war architectural
label: Paragraph

text: practices, the ones that came closest to the American
label: Paragraph

text: corporate practice were those of Gregotti Associati and
label: Paragraph

text: Renzo Piano Building Workshop, based in Genoa. However,
label: Paragraph

text: unlike Piano, Gregotti was always involved with historical
label: Paragraph

text: sedimentation and with the catalytic effect of form on the
label: Paragraph

text: articulation of the landscape as in his project for the
label: Paragraph

text: University of Florence [692], dating from 1971, and in the
label: Caption

text: parallel blocks of his Zen Housing, built outside Palermo in
label: Paragraph

text: 691 Valle, Zanussi Rex, Pordenone, 1959-61.
label: Caption

text: 692 Gregotti Associati, proposal for the University of Florence, 1971.
label: Caption

text: Greece
label: Title

text: Although the influence of Classical Greece on the German
label: Paragraph

text: Enlightenment is well known, the reciprocal influence of
label: Paragraph

text: German Neo-Classicism on Greek architecture after the
label: Paragraph

text: nation gained its independence from the Ottoman Empire in
label: Paragraph

text: 1829 is less familiar. This cultural transfer, so to speak, is
label: Paragraph

text: partly explained by the superimposition of Prince Otto of
label: Paragraph

text: Bavaria as a monarch for the newly constituted Greek state
label: Title

text: in 1832. This new nationalistic culture was accompanied by
label: Paragraph

text: the adoption of Demotic Greek as the spoken language of
label: Paragraph

text: the country, which conversely possibly accounts for the
label: Paragraph

text: attempt to arrive at a modern architecture for Greece based
label: Paragraph

text: on an inflection of the native vernacular.
label: Paragraph

text: The pioneer in this endeavour was Dimitris Pikionis, who
label: Paragraph

text: became a member of the architectural faculty at the
label: Paragraph

text: National Technical University in Athens in 1921. He took his
label: Paragraph

text: students on trips to Aegina in order to study the vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of the Greek islands. There he came across the
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular stone ruin of the Rhodakis House, which became
label: Caption

text: a symbol of his unattainable ideal in architecture. However,
label: Paragraph

text: Pikionis’s quasi-archaeological attempt at a new
label: Title

text: autochthonous modern manner was his 1925 Karamanos
label: Paragraph

text: House in Athens [693], ultimately based on the remains of a
label: Paragraph

text: Greek house excavated in the ancient city of Priene. This
label: Paragraph

text: house had a discernibly metaphysical character, stemming
label: Paragraph

text: from his association with the painter Giorgio de Chirico,
label: Paragraph

text: whom he had met when they were both students at the
label: Paragraph

text: Athens Polytechnic in 1904.
label: Paragraph

text: 693 Pikionis, Karamanos House, Athens, 1925.
label: Caption

text: The year 1922 was a disastrous one for Greece, when,
label: Paragraph

text: abetted by Britain and France, it invaded Turkey only to
label: Paragraph

text: have its army routed at Smyrna by the forces of Kemal
label: Paragraph

text: Ataturk, who consequently expelled the Greek population
label: Paragraph

text: from Asia Minor. This debacle placed an enormous burden
label: Paragraph

text: on the Greek state, which had to absorb a large number of
label: Paragraph

text: refugees overnight. Moreover, no adequate accommodation
label: Paragraph

text: seems to have been made for them until the early 1930s,
label: Paragraph

text: when some low-rise housing was built for the refugee
label: Paragraph

text: population [694]. This kind of housing was subsequently
label: Paragraph

text: matched by an extensive school building programme
label: Paragraph

text: initiated by Eleftherios Venizelos’s government, which was
label: Paragraph

text: the first to be democratically elected in Greece after the
label: Paragraph

text: proclamation of the new constitution in 1927. This led to the
label: Paragraph

text: stage for the emergence of a modern, rationalist
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in Greece that first appeared in a number of
label: Paragraph

text: new schools designed by emerging architects including
label: Paragraph

text: Nikos Mitsakis, Patroklos Karantinos, Kyriakos Panayotakos
label: Caption

text: and Dimitris Pikionis. Pikionis’s rationalist school built on the
label: Paragraph

text: lower slopes of Mount Lycabettus, Athens, in 1932 was his
label: Paragraph

text: only unequivocally modern building. All of this activity would
label: Paragraph

text: be documented and celebrated in Karantinos’s book, The
label: Paragraph

text: School Buildings, published in Greek in 1938.
label: Paragraph

text: 694 Kyriakos and Laskaris, apartment block for refugees, Athens, 1933-35. Plan.
label: Caption

text: These schools came to the attention of the Swiss
label: Paragraph

text: aficionado of the Modern Movement Alberto Sartoris, who
label: Paragraph

text: published these schools in his first international survey of
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture, L’architettura funzionale of 1932. This
label: Paragraph

text: book came out just before the fourth congress of CIAM that
label: Paragraph

text: took place in 1933 on the SS Patris en route from Marseille
label: Paragraph

text: to Athens and subsequently in Athens itself, by virtue of
label: Paragraph

text: Stalin’s refusal to host the congress in Moscow. As the
label: Paragraph

text: architect and historian Andreas Giacumacatos informs us,
label: Paragraph

text: the Berlin architect Fred Forbat had already prepared the
label: Paragraph

text: ground for this change in venue by virtue of his familiarity
label: Paragraph

text: with modern architecture in Greece. A small Greek CIAM
label: Paragraph

text: group had been formed in Athens in 1932 by Stamo
label: Paragraph

text: Papadaki, whose own modern house, completed in Glyfada
label: Paragraph

text: in 1933 [695], was of reinforced-concrete frame
label: Paragraph

text: construction with brickwork, all rendered and painted white.
label: Paragraph

text: As Giacumacatos has written, CIAM IV was a resounding
label: Paragraph

text: SUCCESS:
label: Title

text: 695 Papadaki, K.F. House, Glyfada, Athens, 1932-33.
label: Caption

text: the reception accorded to the Congress was an outstanding
label: Paragraph

text: example of Greek hospitality at its best and, at the same
label: Paragraph

text: time, resulted from an enthusiasm dictated by the vision of
label: Paragraph

text: modernization which had become mature and urgent in
label: Paragraph

text: Greek society. The 1930s in Greece were rather similar to
label: Paragraph

text: the 1960s: the first part of the decade, down to 1936 (as to
label: Paragraph

text: 1967), was one of a strong progressive drive forward which,
label: Paragraph

text: however, was doomed to be cancelled out by politics and by
label: Paragraph

text: the totalitarian governments on which the drive ran
label: Paragraph

text: aground.
label: Paragraph

text: The worldwide economic depression that followed the
label: Paragraph

text: stock market crash of 1929 would ultimately undermine
label: Paragraph

text: Greek democracy, leading to the fall of the Venizelos
label: Paragraph

text: government and then to the military dictatorship of General
label: Title

text: loannis Metaxas, which endured from 1936 to his death in
label: Paragraph

text: 1941. These events led up to the Second World War, during
label: Paragraph

text: which the the country was occupied in rapid succession by
label: Paragraph

text: the Italians in 1940 and by the Germans in 1941. This last
label: Paragraph

text: humiliation seems to have been ironically anticipated by the
label: Paragraph

text: first exhibition of German-inspired Neo-Classical Greek
label: Caption

text: architecture staged in Athens in 1938 by the Hellenic-
label: Paragraph

text: Germanic League. From 1942 onwards, rival monarchist and
label: Paragraph

text: communist partisans sustained a continuous guerrilla war
label: Title

text: against the German occupiers until the liberation of Athens
label: Paragraph

text: in 1944. After an uneasy post-war interregnum, the Greek
label: Paragraph

text: Civil War broke out between these rival factions and lasted
label: Paragraph

text: from May 1946 to October 1949, a conflict that was finally
label: Paragraph

text: settled in favour of the monarchist faction; the
label: Paragraph

text: superimposed Greek monarchy lasted for another twenty-
label: Paragraph

text: five years before it was finally abolished in 1974.
label: Paragraph

text: Among the works of the Greek Rationalists, one work -
label: Paragraph

text: namely the Archaeological Museum of Heraklion in Crete -
label: Paragraph

text: stands out not only for its architectonic and technical
label: Paragraph

text: brilliance, but also for its protracted construction, passing
label: Paragraph

text: through the turmoil of the Metaxas regime, the Second
label: Paragraph

text: World War and the Civil War. It was completed in 1958, its
label: Paragraph

text: final form much as it had been designed by Karantinos in
label: Paragraph

text: 1933 [696]. This building was surely comparable in terms of
label: Paragraph

text: its architectonic precision and rhythmic order to Giuseppe
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni’s Casa del Fascio, Como, of 1936. The unity of the
label: Paragraph

text: formal and functional logic of the Heraklion museum makes
label: Paragraph

text: it an exemplary rationalist work, as was the school that
label: Paragraph

text: Karantinos proposed for Heraklion in 1933.
label: Paragraph

text: 696 Karantinos, Archaeological Museum, Heraklion, Crete, 1933.
label: Caption

text: An ultimate standoff between the universal rationalism of
label: Paragraph

text: the Modern Movement and a locally inflected functionalism
label: Title

text: inspired by the vernacular would be represented by two
label: Paragraph

text: schools built in Thessaloniki between 1933 and 1937, first,
label: Paragraph

text: an eminently rational girls’ school designed by Nikos
label: Paragraph

text: Mitsakis in 1935, predicated on the regular spacing of its
label: Paragraph

text: concrete frame, and Pikionis’s experimental school [699],
label: Paragraph

text: completed two years later. Although the latter was just as
label: Paragraph

text: logically arranged in section and plan, Pikionis was able to
label: Paragraph

text: take advantage of a sloping site to provide the school with
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard/playgrounds at different levels. At the same time
label: Paragraph

text: the building reflected the climate and the vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of northern Greece, through its use of shallow-
label: Paragraph

text: pitched tiled roofs with deep eaves plus delicately detailed
label: Caption

text: timber verandas and fenestrations which testified to the
label: Paragraph

text: rainy, colder climate. Irrespective of these climatic
label: Paragraph

text: differences, Pikionis adopted virtually the same syntax in
label: Paragraph

text: Athens in 1953, shortly after the Civil War, when he
label: Paragraph

text: completed his Potamianos House in Filothei [697]. In this
label: Paragraph

text: instance the stylistic trope of tiled roofs and timber
label: Paragraph

text: verandas contrasted with an underlying reinforced-concrete
label: Paragraph

text: frame, faced in random fieldstone. Something of this same
label: Paragraph

text: rustic aesthetic was featured in a children’s garden that he
label: Paragraph

text: built in Filothei [698] shortly after and in the timber pavilion
label: Caption

text: erected on Philopappou Hill [700] in the landscape that he
label: Paragraph

text: created adjacent to the Acropolis in 1957. The tactile
label: Caption

text: poetics of these works can be traced back to Pikionis’s
label: Paragraph

text: essay ‘A Sentimental Topography’, first published in the
label: Paragraph

text: Greek magazine The Third Eye in 1935.
label: Paragraph

text: 697 Pikionis, Potamianos House, Filothei, Athens, 1953.
label: Caption

text: 698 Pikionis, Children’s Garden, Filothei, Athens, 1960-65.
label: Caption

text: 699 Pikionis, Experimental School, Thessaloniki, Athens, 1937.
label: Caption

text: 700 Pikionis, Philopappou park adjacent to the Acropolis, Athens, 1957.
label: Caption

text: As his holiday houses of the 1950s and the 1960s amply
label: Paragraph

text: testify, Aris Konstantinidis was just as committed as Pikionis
label: Paragraph

text: to the cultivation of a Greek modern architecture derived
label: Title

text: from the specificity of the site and climate and from the
label: Paragraph

text: polemical adoption of a primitive building technique derived
label: Paragraph

text: from the local vernacular, an ‘architecture degree zero’, as
label: Paragraph

text: we find in the reinforced-concrete frame and roof and the
label: Paragraph

text: rubble-stone infill of Konstantinidis’s Sykia House of 1951
label: Caption

text: [701, 702]. A similar tectonic sensibility informs the site-
label: Paragraph

text: sensitive hotels and motels that he designed for the Greek
label: Paragraph

text: government tourist organization, Xenia, among them a
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable hotel built in the 1960s in the treeless
label: Paragraph

text: mountainous landscape of Meteora at Kalambaka [704].
label: Caption

text: Around this time Konstantinidis published the first in a series
label: Paragraph

text: of small books devoted to documenting the specific
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular of Athens and Mykonos, which he followed in
label: Paragraph

text: 1975 with a photographic survey of the country’s vernacular
label: Caption

text: as a whole in his book Elements for Self#Knowledge.
label: Paragraph

text: 701 Konstantinidis, Vacation House, Sykia, Korinthia, 1951. Details.
label: Caption

text: 702 Konstantinidis, Vacation House, Sykia, Korinthia, 1951.
label: Caption

text: 703 Konstantinidis, Holiday House, Anavyssos, Attica, 1961-62.
label: Caption

text: 704 Konstantinidis, Xenia Motel, Kalambaka, 1960.
label: Caption

text: Two totally contrasting talented architects of the second
label: Paragraph

text: half of the 20th century were Takis Zenetos and Kyriakos
label: Paragraph

text: Krokos: the first was notable for his unequivocally avant-
label: Paragraph

text: gardist, technological stance and the second for his
label: Paragraph

text: tectonically rationalist reference to Byzantine building in his
label: Paragraph

text: Museum of Byzantine Culture, designed and built in
label: Caption

text: Thessaloniki between 1978 and 1993. Through Krokos’s
label: Paragraph

text: intricate use of red brick, this work metaphorically
label: Paragraph

text: represented the Byzantine culture it was destined to house.
label: Paragraph

text: No one has characterized the essence of this work better
label: Paragraph

text: than Savas Condaratos: The basic theme of the building is
label: Paragraph

text: perpendicular access: a spiral upward route - a kind of
label: Paragraph

text: internal street - leads to the various gallery levels, though
label: Paragraph

text: without making it compulsory to visit them. The gentle
label: Paragraph

text: tunnel-like progression is transformed into an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: tour and takes on a symbolic nature ... The Museum of
label: Paragraph

text: Byzantine Culture is one of the most important buildings in
label: Paragraph

text: post-War Greek architecture because it embarks on an
label: Paragraph

text: exemplary dialogue with history ... It stands out for the
label: Paragraph

text: meditatic sobriety which pervades it and for its ability to
label: Paragraph

text: transverse the entire Greek tectonic tradition and to
label: Paragraph

text: reconstruct its archetypal essence.?
label: Paragraph

text: Krokos returned to this particularly articulate syntax of brick
label: Paragraph

text: and béton brut in a house that he designed for Filothei,
label: Paragraph

text: Athens, in 1989 [705].
label: Paragraph

text: 705 Krokos, Vettas Residence, Filothei, Athens, 1989-91.
label: Caption

text: Educated in Paris, Zenetos was committed to the direct
label: Paragraph

text: expression of modern technology, as found in the light-
label: Paragraph

text: weight, stripped-down, steel-framed theatre that he built on
label: Paragraph

text: the lower slopes of Lycabettus in 1965. Zenetos’s first built
label: Paragraph

text: work in Athens was the large, curtain-walled industrial plant
label: Paragraph

text: that he designed for the Fix Brewery in Athens in 1957. He
label: Paragraph

text: followed this technological tour de force with a six-storey
label: Paragraph

text: apartment block with plate-glass balustrading that he built
label: Paragraph

text: on the prestigious Amalias Avenue in Athens in 1959. Two
label: Caption

text: years later he realized a dramatically cantilevered, steel-
label: Paragraph

text: framed house overlooking a pine forest beside the sea in
label: Caption

text: Kavouri in Attica. Thereafter came his ultra-experimental
label: Paragraph

text: steel-framed Agios Dimitrios School [706] of the first half of
label: Caption

text: the 1970s. The multi-layered circular plan-form of this
label: Paragraph

text: building allows a seemingly endless rearrangement of the
label: Paragraph

text: available space, while the horizontal louvres at the eaves
label: Paragraph

text: vary both in angle and density according to the trajectory of
label: Paragraph

text: the sun.
label: Paragraph

text: 706 Zenetos, Agios Dimitrios School, Athens, 1975.
label: Caption

text: Apart from the influence of post-war Miesianism,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly evident in the work of Nicos Valsamakis,
label: Paragraph

text: namely, his elegant Lanaras House built in Anavyssos,
label: Paragraph

text: Attica, in 1963 [707], Greek modern architecture in the last
label: Paragraph

text: quarter of the 20th century seems to have been an
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinarily sensitive reiteration and elaboration of the
label: Paragraph

text: syntactical legacy of 1930s Greek Rationalism. This
label: Paragraph

text: répétition différente is especially manifest in the six- to
label: Paragraph

text: eight-storey infill apartment buildings (polykatoikia) that
label: Paragraph

text: proliferated in Athens throughout the late 1950s, amounting
label: Paragraph

text: to a kind of contemporary vernacular that would be as much
label: Paragraph

text: designed by enlightened builders as by professional
label: Paragraph

text: architects. Conforming to the typical height and width of the
label: Paragraph

text: average plot and featuring a range of standard balconies,
label: Paragraph

text: canopies and roof terraces, along with horizontal windows,
label: Paragraph

text: shaded by retractable sunblinds, this modern architectural
label: Paragraph

text: repertoire, set within an existing orthogonal street grid,
label: Paragraph

text: spontaneously created a modern urban continuum
label: Title

text: comparable to the uniformity of Tony Garnier’s Etats-Unis
label: Paragraph

text: neighbourhood built in Lyons between 1924 and 1935.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps no single Athenian building so succinctly captures
label: Paragraph

text: this normative syntax as does Constantinos Doxiadis’s
label: Paragraph

text: Ekistics research office built on the lower slopes of
label: Paragraph

text: Lycabettus in 1961 [709]. It is disconcerting to realize that
label: Paragraph

text: this received /ingua franca of modern Greek architecture has
label: Paragraph

text: now become routine, largely restricted to speculative
label: Paragraph

text: development and to accommodation of the ever-expanding
label: Paragraph

text: tourist industry that totally exceeds the modest
label: Paragraph

text: programmes that Konstantinidis envisaged when he worked
label: Paragraph

text: for the Xenia organization in the 1950s.
label: Paragraph

text: 707 Valsamakis, Lanaras Residence, Attica, 1961-63.
label: Caption

text: An exception has been Agnes Couvelas, who has sought
label: Paragraph

text: to predicate her architecture on a particular climate and
label: Paragraph

text: topography and on the islands’ extant craft culture, as found
label: Paragraph

text: in her own house in Santorini of 1994 [708]. As Karin
label: Paragraph

text: Skousbgll has written:
label: Paragraph

text: 708 Couvelas, House of the Winds, Santorini, 1994. Elevation.
label: Caption

text: 709 Doxiadis, Kouravelos and Scheepers, Ekistics research office, Athens, 1955-
label: Caption

text: Throughout the synthesis of this house the context... was a
label: Paragraph

text: constant reference point: the monolithic rocks of the beach,
label: Paragraph

text: the strong breeze (meltemi) in the caldera, the
label: Paragraph

text: characteristic fortress (goulas) at Emboreion ... The handling
label: Paragraph

text: of the strong winds was of great importance, so the outer
label: Paragraph

text: shell of the house had to be sturdy without being sealed...
label: Paragraph

text: As a consequence the shell of the building was eroded and
label: Paragraph

text: perforated in order to trap the wind and light and yet
label: Paragraph

text: continue to protect ... The character of the mass alludes to
label: Paragraph

text: the local technique of dug out dwellings, the so-called
label: Paragraph

text: hyposkapha.?
label: Paragraph

text: After completing this work, Couvelas produced a number of
label: Paragraph

text: larger site-specific civic projects in the islands, including the
label: Paragraph

text: Prehistoric Museum at Thera (1998-2000) and an
label: Paragraph

text: Archaeological Museum of Naxos in 1994, where the
label: Paragraph

text: expansion of the museum also necessitated the
label: Paragraph

text: reconstruction of the central public square.
label: Caption

text: Former Yugoslavia
label: Title

text: Yugoslavia was the one European nation in which a liberal
label: Paragraph

text: socialist society - as this had been envisaged by the pre-war
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Movement - endured for nearly forty years, from the
label: Paragraph

text: end of the Second World War to the death of its leader,
label: Paragraph

text: Marshal Josip Broz Tito, in 1980. Key to Tito’s success was
label: Paragraph

text: his prestige as a triumphant leader of the partisans during
label: Paragraph

text: the war and the fact that - after the expulsion of Yugoslavia
label: Title

text: from the Soviet Bloc in 1948 - he was able to maintain a
label: Paragraph

text: one-party state while unifying six distinct ethnic identities.
label: Paragraph

text: Of the six republics that made up Tito’s Yugoslavia,
label: Paragraph

text: Slovenia was the most cosmopolitan by virtue of bordering
label: Paragraph

text: on Italy and Austria, which border it to the west and the
label: Paragraph

text: north. At the same time it seems to have had an affinity
label: Paragraph

text: post-1918 for the then newly created state of
label: Paragraph

text: Czechoslovakia, with which the Slovenian master architect
label: Paragraph

text: Joze Plecnik was profoundly involved by virtue of being
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned by the first Czech president, Tomas Masaryk,
label: Paragraph

text: with the task of transforming Prague Castle into a
label: Paragraph

text: presidential residence [710]. By way of responding to this
label: Paragraph

text: task, Pleénik designed a number of Neo-Baroque set pieces
label: Paragraph

text: of varying size and extent with which to convert and
label: Paragraph

text: embellish the castle, in such a way as to erase all traces of
label: Paragraph

text: the former Austro-Hungarian Empire. First among the cryptic
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic elements that Pleénik added to the castle was a
label: Paragraph

text: monumentally symbolic stone basin resting precariously on
label: Caption

text: two stone blocks. This was followed by a sequence of
label: Paragraph

text: equally oneiric works that Plecénik designed for the castle
label: Paragraph

text: before returning definitively in 1921 to found and direct a
label: Paragraph

text: school of architecture in Ljubljana. Under Tito post-war
label: Caption

text: Yugoslavia under Tito became a modernist utopia both
label: Paragraph

text: socially and architecturally. As Vladimir Kuli€é has written:
label: Paragraph

text: 710 Pleénik, Prague Castle, 1931.
label: Caption

text: In the early post-war years, mass volunteer labor was a
label: Paragraph

text: matter of practical necessity in a war-ravaged country
label: Title

text: sorely lacking an education cadre and modern technology ...
label: Paragraph

text: there was a great deal of genuine enthusiasm in this period
label: Paragraph

text: as young brigadiers built new roads, railway lines, dams,
label: Paragraph

text: irrigation canals, factories and cities. One of the largest
label: Paragraph

text: early sites of volunteer labor was New Belgrade, where in
label: Paragraph

text: the late 1940s bare-handed youths from all over the country
label: Paragraph

text: filled in the marshland with sand to consolidate the unstable
label: Paragraph

text: terrain of the new federal capital. Another example was the
label: Paragraph

text: Adriatic Highway whose route along the coast from Slovenia
label: Paragraph

text: through Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, to Montenegro
label: Title

text: enabled the emergence of mass tourism. As the country
label: Paragraph

text: developed, however, the practical need for mass volunteer
label: Paragraph

text: labor abated, and youth labor campaigns shifted to less
label: Paragraph

text: physically taxing projects such as afforestation, the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of youth resorts or archeological excavation. At
label: Paragraph

text: the same time, the motivation to participate also shifted to
label: Paragraph

text: travel in the country, as volunteering in effect became a
label: Paragraph

text: form of active vacationing under the banner of brotherhood
label: Paragraph

text: and unity.+
label: Paragraph

text: It is clear that between 1945 and the mid-1960s, amid a
label: Paragraph

text: major socio-economic transformation, a remarkable panoply
label: Paragraph

text: of modern architecture was achieved in Yugoslavia,
label: Paragraph

text: including such distinguished works as the Federal Executive
label: Paragraph

text: Building, designed by a team led by Vladimir Potoénjak and
label: Paragraph

text: erected in New Belgrade from 1947 to 1962 [711]. This six-
label: Paragraph

text: storey work was modelled in part on Le Corbusier's
label: Paragraph

text: Tsentrosoyuz Building erected in Moscow in 1930 and in part
label: Paragraph

text: on the UNESCO Headquarters completed in 1956 in Paris to
label: Paragraph

text: the designs of Marcel Breuer, Pier Luigi Nervi and Bernard
label: Paragraph

text: Zehrfuss.
label: Paragraph

text: 711 Potoénjak, Government Building, New Belgrade, Serbia, 1947-62.
label: Caption

text: During this same period two particular building types
label: Paragraph

text: emerged in Yugoslavia: first, apartment buildings of
label: Paragraph

text: exceptional ingenuity, reflecting the state’s guarantee to
label: Paragraph

text: provide a high-quality apartment for every Yugoslav citizen,
label: Paragraph

text: and, second, tourist hotels as a reiteration of the idea of the
label: Paragraph

text: social condenser, found in the Soviet dom kommuna and
label: Paragraph

text: workers’ clubs of the late 1920s. The former were
label: Paragraph

text: exemplified by the mid-rise apartment blocks of New
label: Paragraph

text: Belgrade [712], and in the extraordinary twenty-three-
label: Paragraph

text: storey slab blocks designed by Vladimir Braco Musié and
label: Caption

text: built in the industrial city of Split from 1968 to 1980 [717].
label: Paragraph

text: The latter were manifest in the sophisticated medium-rise
label: Paragraph

text: modernist hotels built at intervals on the motorway running
label: Paragraph

text: down the Adriatic Coast from Slovenia to Dubrovnik and
label: Paragraph

text: beyond, such as the Solaris Hotel, designed by Boris Magal
label: Paragraph

text: and built at Sibenik, Croatia, in 1968. Of this hotel building
label: Paragraph

text: boom, Maroje Mrduljas has written:
label: Paragraph

text: 712 Music and others, Block 23, New Belgrade, Serbia, 1968-74. Plan.
label: Caption

text: The Yugoslav model of modernization managed to channel
label: Paragraph

text: the development of mass tourism toward the creation of a
label: Paragraph

text: new urban layer, one that was both culturally compelling
label: Paragraph

text: and competitive on the international market. Thanks to the
label: Paragraph

text: policy of free access to all types of interior and exterior
label: Title

text: public spaces, locals were able to appropriate tourism
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructure for everyday use. Supported by reasonable
label: Paragraph

text: planning and preservation, the architects of Yugoslavia
label: Title

text: merged modernist concepts with lessons of the
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean and utilized the hotel typology for research in
label: Paragraph

text: cultural, and in some extent, social authenticity.”
label: Paragraph

text: Like Pleénik, Edvard Ravnikar was initially trained in
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna, from 1926 to 1930. He returned to Ljubljana to
label: Paragraph

text: study with Plecnik for another five years. Thereafter he
label: Paragraph

text: worked as an assistant on Plec¢nik’s National Library, under
label: Paragraph

text: construction from 1936 to 1941, and completed a memorial
label: Paragraph

text: to the fallen of the 1914-18 war in a manner reminiscent of
label: Paragraph

text: Pleénik. In 1939 Ravnikar went to Paris where he worked
label: Paragraph

text: briefly for Le Corbusier on the Quartier de la Marine project
label: Caption

text: for Algiers. Ravnikar’s Modern Gallery, designed for
label: Caption

text: Ljubljana in 1939, was an exemplary rationalist work with a
label: Paragraph

text: classical stone fagade, recalling the stonework of Otto
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner. After the formation of the republic of Yugoslavia in
label: Paragraph

text: 1945, Ravnikar was involved in various state projects
label: Paragraph

text: including the new town of Nova Gorica, situated on the
label: Paragraph

text: Italian-Slovenian frontier. In 1952 he designed a series of
label: Paragraph

text: war memorials, the most majestic being that at Kampor on
label: Paragraph

text: the island of Rab, on the site of a notorious Italian
label: Paragraph

text: concentration camp [713].
label: Paragraph

text: 713 Ravnikar, Rab Memorial Complex, Kampor, Island of Rab, 1952.
label: Caption

text: Apart from his penchant for contrapuntal form, a key
label: Paragraph

text: aspect of Ravnikar’s architecture is its tectonic expressivity
label: Paragraph

text: evident in both the basic structural form and in its surface
label: Paragraph

text: treatment. This brilliant articulation is never more vital than
label: Paragraph

text: in his design for the Revolution Square complex in Ljubljana
label: Caption

text: (1961-74) [714]. There Ravnikar was able to evoke the
label: Paragraph

text: image of Bruno Taut’s mythical ‘city crown’ (see p. 124)
label: Caption

text: through two seventeen-storey office towers, which face
label: Paragraph

text: each other across the central axis of the square. Each tower
label: Paragraph

text: comprises a curtain-walled office space wrapped around
label: Paragraph

text: three sides of a triangular service core from which the floors
label: Caption

text: are cantilevered.
label: Paragraph

text: 714 Ravnikar, Revolution Square, Ljubljana, 1961-74.
label: Caption

text: A complement to this monumental twin-tower
label: Paragraph

text: configuration is the adjacent Cultural Congress Centre [715,
label: Paragraph

text: 716], which consists of three auditoria built around a
label: Paragraph

text: smaller central circular auditorium. The whole is accessed
label: Paragraph

text: by a generous common reception foyer, linked to a galleria,
label: Paragraph

text: a department store and a bank running up one side of the
label: Paragraph

text: square. Other than the magnificent civic centres built by
label: Paragraph

text: Alvar Aalto at the same time, it is difficult to find another
label: Paragraph

text: urban intervention in the European continent that is
label: Paragraph

text: comparable to what Ravnikar achieved in Ljubljana during
label: Paragraph

text: the heyday of Tito’s non-aligned Yugoslavia.
label: Paragraph

text: 715 Ravnikar, Cultural Congress Centre, Ljubljana, 1983.
label: Caption

text: 716 Ravnikar, Cultural Congress Centre, Ljubljana, 1983.

text: Austria
label: Title

text: It was Otto Wagner who first coined the term ‘Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement’ in his book Moderne Architektur of 1899. Yet
label: Paragraph

text: towards the end of his life he seems to have sensed the
label: Paragraph

text: pending denouement of modernity on the eve of the first
label: Paragraph

text: industrialized war of 1914-18, as is suggested by the more
label: Paragraph

text: measured title, Die Baukunst unserer Zeit, of the fourth
label: Paragraph

text: edition of his book of 1914. He could hardly have foreseen,
label: Paragraph

text: however, the economic devastation that befell Austria along
label: Paragraph

text: with the dismantling of the Austro-Hungarian Empire in
label: Paragraph

text: 1918, the year of his death. As a result, Vienna suffered
label: Paragraph

text: both housing and food shortages, which led to the election
label: Paragraph

text: of a socialist government under Mayor Jakob Reumann.
label: Paragraph

text: Under Neumann ‘Red Vienna’, as the city was then known,
label: Paragraph

text: entered into an extensive programme of building workers’
label: Paragraph

text: housing in the form of a loose ‘ring’ of mid-rise perimeter
label: Paragraph

text: blocks on the city fringes. The most monumental of these
label: Paragraph

text: developments was the Karl Marx-Hof (1926-30), built to the
label: Paragraph

text: designs of Karl Ehn [718], who had been a pupil of Wagner.
label: Paragraph

text: 718 Ehn, Karl Marx-Hof, Vienna, 1930.
label: Caption

text: Soon after its completion the Karl Marx-Hof was besieged by
label: Paragraph

text: artillery in a show of force by the government to repress a
label: Paragraph

text: workers’ rebellion. Despite this violent hiatus the emphasis
label: Paragraph

text: on social housing reappeared in the Wiener
label: Title

text: Werkbundsiedlung of 1930-32, which, under the direction of
label: Paragraph

text: the architect Josef Frank, was modelled on the Deutscher
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund housing exhibition staged in Stuttgart in 1927.
label: Paragraph

text: This Viennese model settlement featured amongst other
label: Paragraph

text: works a row of five terrace houses by Gerrit Rietveld, a free-
label: Caption

text: standing house by Richard Neutra and a pair of semi-
label: Caption

text: detached houses by Adolf Loos, which were the last works of
label: Paragraph

text: his life. A key figure in Vienna in the late 1920s and early
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s was Peter Behrens, who, after being appointed
label: Paragraph

text: professor in the Vienna Academy of Fine Arts, practised as
label: Paragraph

text: an industrial architect designing factories and warehouses in
label: Paragraph

text: a manner somewhat reminiscent of Erich Mendelsohn. A
label: Paragraph

text: much younger Austrian figure of comparable stature at the
label: Paragraph

text: time was the Tyrolean architect Lois Welzenbacher, whose
label: Paragraph

text: Heyrovsky House [719, 720] at Thumersbach, near Zell am
label: Caption

text: See, of 1932 was an organic masterwork equal to the finest
label: Paragraph

text: contemporaneous houses designed by Hans Scharoun.
label: Caption

text: 719 Welzenbacher, Heyrovsky House, Thumersbach, 1932.
label: Caption

text: 720 Welzenbacher, Heyrovsky House, Thumersbach, 1932.
label: Caption

text: Austrian architecture did not easily recover from the
label: Paragraph

text: country’s annexation by the Third Reich in 1938 and from
label: Paragraph

text: the Second World War until the early 1950s, when Roland
label: Paragraph

text: Rainer came to the fore with his Sports Hall, Vienna, of 1952
label: Paragraph

text: and his prefabricated, timber-framed Fertighaus Siedlung of
label: Paragraph

text: 1953. Thereafter Rainer’s practice was largely devoted to
label: Paragraph

text: the development of low-rise, high-density housing as a new
label: Paragraph

text: universally valid form of land settlement appropriate to an
label: Paragraph

text: automotive age, as he demonstrated most persuasively in
label: Paragraph

text: his Puchenau housing estate [723], under continuous
label: Paragraph

text: development on the banks of the river Danube between
label: Paragraph

text: 1963 and 1995. The cultural ecological advantages of this
label: Paragraph

text: approach were fully documented in his book Livable
label: Paragraph

text: Environments of 1972.
label: Paragraph

text: After graduating from Clemens Holzmeister’s masterclass
label: Paragraph

text: in the Vienna Academy of Fine Arts in 1955, Gustav Peichl
label: Paragraph

text: became an influential figure on the Austrian scene in 1964
label: Paragraph

text: by founding the magazine Bau along with Hans Hollein,
label: Paragraph

text: Walter Pichler and Oswald Oberhuber. Four years later he
label: Paragraph

text: won a competition for the design of a group of provincial
label: Paragraph

text: radio stations [721], which were built between 1969 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1984 as five concentrically planned stations in Eisenstadt,
label: Paragraph

text: Salzburg, Innsbruck, Linz and Dornbirn, with Peichl giving
label: Caption

text: each one a precisely detailed, machine-like, metallic
label: Paragraph

text: identity.
label: Paragraph

text: 721 Peichl, typical ORF Regional Studio, 1969-81.
label: Caption

text: Anton Schweighofer was equally committed as Peichl to
label: Paragraph

text: the invention of new building types, hence the stepped
label: Paragraph

text: format of his Neo-Constructivist orphanage proposed for
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna in 1969 [722]. In retrospect this may be read as a
label: Paragraph

text: transitional work between Rainer’s ecological rationalism
label: Title

text: and the emerging anarchic artist-architects of the Graz
label: Paragraph

text: School of architecture of whom the most extreme was
label: Paragraph

text: Gunther Domenig. The Steinhaus of 1986, designed for his
label: Caption

text: Domenig’s occupation, veered towards sculpture rather than
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, although its internal spaces were of a liveable
label: Paragraph

text: size and generous proportions. Coop Himmelb(l)au’s steel
label: Paragraph

text: construction Blazing Wing, installed in Graz in 1980, was
label: Paragraph

text: equally artistic. However, the overall Neo-Constructivist line
label: Paragraph

text: of the Graz School, as represented by the work of Volker
label: Paragraph

text: Giencke, Helmut Richter and Klaus Kada, would distinguish
label: Paragraph

text: itself from the de-constructivist approach of Coop
label: Paragraph

text: Himmelb(l)au as we first encounter this in 1986 in the
label: Paragraph

text: penthouse lawyer’s office that they designed for the top of a
label: Paragraph

text: classical block in Vienna as a cataclysmic concatenation of
label: Paragraph

text: steel and glass [725]. Nothing could be more removed from
label: Paragraph

text: this than Kada’s glass museum at Barnbach of 1988 or
label: Paragraph

text: Giencke’s conservatory for the botanical garden of Graz of
label: Paragraph

text: 1992, where the necessary hothouse heating was integrated
label: Paragraph

text: with the tubular metal framing supporting the glass.
label: Paragraph

text: Giencke’s collage-like, multi-material approach to building
label: Paragraph

text: was distinguishable from Richter’s maximizing use of glass,
label: Paragraph

text: as this is found in the long, entirely glazed facade of his
label: Paragraph

text: Brunnerstrasse housing in Vienna of 1990 or in the large
label: Paragraph

text: secondary school that he built in Kinkplatz in the same city
label: Paragraph

text: in 1994. Again, as with Peichl’s radio stations, there is a
label: Paragraph

text: discernible affinity with Anglo-Italian High-Tech architects
label: Paragraph

text: but without the same concern for typological invention or
label: Paragraph

text: functional technique. Coop Himmelb(l)au, for its part, would
label: Paragraph

text: eventually arrive at a modus operandi that was as much
label: Paragraph

text: constructivist as deconstructivist, for example in the
label: Paragraph

text: concatenation of planar surfaces of the office building that
label: Paragraph

text: they erected at Seibersdorf in Lower Austria in 1995. Of an
label: Paragraph

text: equally organic but much more plastic character,
label: Paragraph

text: reminiscent of Welzenbacher, was the winter sports
label: Paragraph

text: gymnasium built at Stams in the Tyrol in 1982 to the designs
label: Paragraph

text: of Othmar Barth [726].
label: Caption

text: 722 Schweighofer, City for Children, Vienna, 1969.
label: Caption

text: Despite the fact that he spent most of his professional
label: Paragraph

text: career in the United States, Raimund Abraham was also a
label: Paragraph

text: graduate of the Graz School, as is suggested by the
label: Paragraph

text: nuanced Neo-Constructivist character of the twenty-three-
label: Paragraph

text: storey Austrian Cultural Foundation [724] that he finally
label: Paragraph

text: completed in New York in 2002. Abraham received this
label: Paragraph

text: commission through winning the 1992 state competition,
label: Paragraph

text: open exclusively to Austrian architects, for which there were
label: Paragraph

text: 226 entries. Built on an extremely difficult, narrow-fronted
label: Caption

text: site, this remains one of the first buildings of exceptional
label: Paragraph

text: quality to be constructed in Manhattan after the
label: Paragraph

text: achievement of Wright’s Guggenheim Museum in 1959.
label: Paragraph

text: 723 Rainer, low-rise, high-density housing, Puchenau, first phase, 1965-67.
label: Caption

text: 724 Abraham, Austrian Cultural Institute, New York, 1992-2002. Section.
label: Caption

text: 725 Coop Himmelb(l)au, Rooftop Remodelling, Falkestrasse, Vienna, 1986.
label: Caption

text: Section.
label: Paragraph

text: 726 Barth, Sports Gymnasium, Tyrol, 1982. Section.

text: Germany
label: Title

text: The ‘Man and Space’ symposium, held in Darmstadt in
label: Paragraph

text: 1951, was the first gathering of German architects and
label: Paragraph

text: intellectuals after the apocalyptic destruction and defeat of
label: Paragraph

text: the Third Reich in 1945. The philosopher Martin Heidegger
label: Paragraph

text: made a significant contribution to this event with his
label: Paragraph

text: seminal essay ‘Building, Dwelling, Thinking’, which
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized the importance of the place-form as a bounded
label: Paragraph

text: domain rather than the abstract and functional space
label: Paragraph

text: favoured by modern architecture throughout the late 1920s
label: Paragraph

text: and the 1930s.! Heidegger’s emphasis on the bounded
label: Paragraph

text: domain was matched by Hans Scharoun’s presentation of
label: Paragraph

text: one of his first organically planned schools with the
label: Paragraph

text: implication that Darmstadt might be persuaded to build a
label: Paragraph

text: prototype [727]. This building was a categorical departure
label: Paragraph

text: from the reductive functionalism of the Neue Sachlichkeit,
label: Paragraph

text: which had been a dominant feature of modernism in the
label: Paragraph

text: Weimar Republic. Scharoun’s subsequent practice was
label: Paragraph

text: mostly devoted to the design of schools and housing. The
label: Paragraph

text: most consummate example of the former was his
label: Paragraph

text: Geschwister-Scholl School built at Linen (1959-62), named
label: Paragraph

text: after Hans and Sophie Scholl - the anti-Nazi martyrs of the
label: Paragraph

text: White Rose movement - while the most striking example of
label: Paragraph

text: the latter was his Romeo and Juliet apartments built in
label: Paragraph

text: Stuttgart in 1959 [728]. However, his masterwork was the
label: Paragraph

text: Philharmonie concert hall, built in the Berlin Tiergarten in
label: Caption

text: 1963 [729]. This work was predicated on the radical
label: Paragraph

text: concept of placing the orchestra in the middle of the
label: Paragraph

text: chamber, surrounded on all sides by inclined planes of
label: Paragraph

text: ‘vineyard’ seating. Beneath the seating was suspended a
label: Paragraph

text: sequence of cascading foyers, provided to accommodate
label: Paragraph

text: the audience during the intermission. The outstanding
label: Paragraph

text: acoustics of the chamber made it one of the most successful
label: Paragraph

text: concert halls of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: 727 Scharoun, prototype organic school projected for Darmstadt, 1951. Plan.
label: Caption

text: 728 Scharoun, Romeo and Juliet apartments, Stuttgart, 1959.
label: Caption

text: 729 Scharoun, Philharmonie Hall, Berlin, 1963.
label: Caption

text: Another accomplished German architect to emerge
label: Paragraph

text: immediately after the war was Egon Eiermann, who, having
label: Paragraph

text: studied with Hans Poelzig in the early 1930s, had enjoyed a
label: Paragraph

text: modest pre-war career. In 1947 Eiermann was appointed to
label: Paragraph

text: the professorship of architecture at Karlsruhe University,
label: Paragraph

text: which greatly facilitated his post-war practice. From the
label: Paragraph

text: outset his work was characterized by an elegantly
label: Paragraph

text: proportioned rationalism, which was already evident in the
label: Paragraph

text: single-storey weaving shed, faced in corrugated asbestos,
label: Caption

text: that he built in the Schwarzwald in 1951. He followed this
label: Paragraph

text: simple, elegant structure with one powerfully rhythmic work
label: Paragraph

text: after another, including the Neckermann mail order
label: Paragraph

text: warehouse in Frankfurt (1951) [730], the German Pavilion at
label: Paragraph

text: the Brussels World’s Fair (1958), his own house in Baden-
label: Paragraph

text: Baden (1962) and the Olivetti Training Centre in Frankfurt
label: Paragraph

text: (1968-72). Eiermann’s key contribution to West Berlin was
label: Paragraph

text: his Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church of 1962 [731], built
label: Caption

text: next to the bombed-out shell of a 19th-century Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Romanesque church of the same name. This took the form
label: Paragraph

text: of a steel-framed octagonal nave and campanile, each prism
label: Paragraph

text: being faced in coloured glass lenses, which were back-lit at
label: Paragraph

text: night.
label: Paragraph

text: 730 Eiermann, Neckermann Mail Order Building, Frankfurt, 1951.
label: Caption

text: 731 Eiermann, Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church, Berlin, 1962. Section.
label: Caption

text: One of the most prominent talents to emerge from
label: Paragraph

text: Eiermann’s teaching in Karlsruhe was Oswald Mathias
label: Paragraph

text: Ungers, who by the early 1960s had already designed and
label: Paragraph

text: executed a considerable amount of brick-faced housing in
label: Paragraph

text: Cologne, most of which was around six storeys in height,
label: Paragraph

text: including an exceptionally elegant mixed-use block in
label: Paragraph

text: Hansaring [733], of 1959, with projecting balconies and
label: Paragraph

text: exposed concrete floor slabs. This Brutalist brick syntax
label: Paragraph

text: culminated in his own pinwheeling house [732] built in the
label: Paragraph

text: MUungersdorf district of the city in the same year. This was
label: Paragraph

text: Ungers’s Brutalist signature before he moved to Berlin in
label: Paragraph

text: 1965 and then to Cornell University in the United States in
label: Paragraph

text: 1968, when he adopted a more rationalist, hardline
label: Paragraph

text: approach indirectly inspired by his passing interest in
label: Paragraph

text: Russian Constructivism. He abandoned this reductive
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism after his return to Berlin in 1975, when he
label: Paragraph

text: embraced a kind of Post-Modern classicism that remained
label: Paragraph

text: his modus operandi until the end of his career.
label: Paragraph

text: 732 Ungers, Ungers House, Cologne, 1959.
label: Caption

text: 733 Ungers, housing block in Hansaring, Cologne, 1959.
label: Caption

text: Another important figure on the German post-war scene
label: Paragraph

text: was the engineer-constructor Frei Otto, who began his
label: Paragraph

text: career with the design of translucent canvas tents erected
label: Paragraph

text: as temporary tensile structures for German flower shows.
label: Paragraph

text: The characteristic undulating form of these tents depended
label: Paragraph

text: as much on the domed apices, held in place by tent poles,
label: Paragraph

text: as on the pull of guy-lines clustered around circular concrete
label: Paragraph

text: sumps that allowed water to drain off the roofs. Otto later
label: Paragraph

text: devised a transparent acrylic undulating roof similarly held
label: Paragraph

text: in place over a wire network on tubular-steel pylons and tied
label: Paragraph

text: back by wire cables to the perimeter of Gunter Behnisch’s
label: Paragraph

text: stadium erected for the Munich Olympic Games in 1972
label: Caption

text: [734]. This almost dematerialized organic roof form
label: Paragraph

text: sheltering the stadium was seen as being symbolic of the
label: Paragraph

text: new democratic Germany, in contrast to the monumental
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrical stadium designed by Werner March for the
label: Caption

text: Reichssportfeld, Berlin, for the Nazi Olympic Games of 1936.
label: Caption

text: Behnisch’s equally organic, High-Tech ferrovitreous manner
label: Paragraph

text: attained its apotheosis in his Hysolar Research Institute built
label: Paragraph

text: for Stuttgart University in 1987.
label: Paragraph

text: 734 Behnisch and Otto, Olympic Park, Munich, 1967-72.
label: Caption

text: The year 1972 saw the completion of a unique
label: Paragraph

text: experimental housing complex in Munich, built to the
label: Paragraph

text: designs of Otto Steidle in collaboration with Doris and Ralph
label: Caption

text: Thut [735]. Predicated on a 7.2 x 8.8-metre (23% x 29-foot)
label: Paragraph

text: prefabricated concrete frame, this three-storey matrix was
label: Paragraph

text: realized as a flexible modular system, modelled on the so-
label: Paragraph

text: called ‘supports’ system developed by the Dutch architect
label: Paragraph

text: John Habraken. Habraken’s concept was that residents
label: Paragraph

text: would be free to modify their living units over time in
label: Paragraph

text: accordance with their changing needs by adding or
label: Paragraph

text: subtracting components, conforming dimensionally to the
label: Paragraph

text: modularity of the basic structure. This technological ideal
label: Paragraph

text: proved impossible to achieve, largely because such
label: Paragraph

text: components were never industrially produced, although this
label: Paragraph

text: stepped apartment block in Munich with set-back terraces
label: Caption

text: for each unit still remains fully occupied.
label: Paragraph

text: 735 Steidle, with Doris and Ralph Thut, Genter Strasse housing, Munich, 1968-
label: Caption

text: 72. Section.
label: Paragraph

text: Around this time Josef Paul Kleihues arrived on the Berlin
label: Paragraph

text: architectural scene, where he established his standing with
label: Paragraph

text: two exceptional works: his five-storey, brick-faced,
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter apartment block erected in Vinetaplatz in 1977
label: Caption

text: (fig. 303) and the immaculately detailed, curtain-walled
label: Paragraph

text: vehicle repair shop built for the Berlin street cleaning
label: Caption

text: department in 1978. Thereafter Kleihues’s career was
label: Paragraph

text: devoted, between 1984 and 1987, to directing the Berlin
label: Paragraph

text: Internationale Bauausstellung (IBA; International Building
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition), a para-governmental operation similar in its
label: Paragraph

text: administrative capacity to the authority of the Hansaviertel
label: Title

text: building exhibition that was built adjacent to the Berlin Wall
label: Paragraph

text: The municipalities of Barcelona and Bologna were
label: Paragraph

text: similarly dedicated to the modernization of the obsolete
label: Paragraph

text: European city, partially echoing in actual practice the so-
label: Paragraph

text: called reconstruction of the traditional city advocated by
label: Paragraph

text: Leon Krier and Maurice Culot. However, unlike Krier and
label: Paragraph

text: Culot, and even Ungers, Kleihues did not consider the pre-
label: Paragraph

text: war Modern Movement as negative. Instead, as the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural historian Winfried Nerdinger explains, Kleihues
label: Paragraph

text: envisaged the reconstruction of the city as a dialectical
label: Paragraph

text: confrontation between a progressive modernity and the
label: Title

text: traditional ‘place-form’ provided by the streets and blocks of
label: Paragraph

text: the 18th- and 19th-century urban fabric.
label: Paragraph

text: The unexpected fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989 effectively
label: Paragraph

text: brought Kleihues’s reconstruction of Berlin to a close and,
label: Paragraph

text: regrettably, the building boom that followed favoured a
label: Paragraph

text: return to one-off free-standing buildings. This trend was
label: Paragraph

text: exacerbated by the neo-liberal laissez-faire economic
label: Paragraph

text: policies emanating from the US and the UK, and this led to
label: Paragraph

text: the growth of suburban fabric, accompanied by the
label: Paragraph

text: supermarket, which had the effect of undermining
label: Paragraph

text: traditional shopping frontage and with it the viability of the
label: Paragraph

text: city as a whole. With the reunification of Germany in 1989
label: Paragraph

text: the tax base and the purchasing power of the society shifted
label: Paragraph

text: from the traditional city to the suburbs.
label: Paragraph

text: This transformation led to the rise of the ecological
label: Paragraph

text: movement as a critical alternative, divided between a
label: Paragraph

text: technological approach and a ‘greener’ socio-cultural
label: Title

text: stance. The limitations of the former are suggested by the
label: Paragraph

text: cold character of Werner Sobek’s steel-framed, totally
label: Paragraph

text: glazed, zero-carbon house built in Stuttgart at the
label: Caption

text: millennium [736]. A more comprehensive alternative is
label: Paragraph

text: evident in the sustainable practice of Thomas Herzog, such
label: Paragraph

text: as in his twenty-storey Deutsche Messe building erected for
label: Paragraph

text: the Hannover Fair in 1999 [737, 739]. The remarkable
label: Paragraph

text: aspect of this ‘sustainable’ office prototype is the way in
label: Paragraph

text: which the 24 x 24-metre (979 x 979-foot) plan office space
label: Paragraph

text: may be arranged either as totally open space, articulated
label: Paragraph

text: solely by office furniture, or subdivided into individual
label: Paragraph

text: offices, or even as a mixture of both. Either way round all
label: Paragraph

text: users can enjoy a modicum of natural ventilation by opening
label: Paragraph

text: the glazed full-height, sliding doors separating the interior
label: Caption

text: and exterior glazed skins, with the outer envelope being
label: Paragraph

text: open at the corners to allow for the natural movement of
label: Paragraph

text: air, while simultaneously shielding the space from
label: Paragraph

text: turbulence induced by the wind. Since the building is still
label: Paragraph

text: air-conditioned, this allows for 85 per cent of thermal energy
label: Paragraph

text: contained in the extracted air to be used for pre-heating the
label: Paragraph

text: fresh air entering the void between the inner and outer
label: Paragraph

text: skins. For ease of maintenance, sunshading is installed
label: Paragraph

text: behind the double-glazed outer facade with the result that
label: Paragraph

text: the cantilevered floor slab does not have to be thermally
label: Paragraph

text: isolated from the main slab.
label: Paragraph

text: 736 Sobek, House R128, Stuttgart, 2000.
label: Caption

text: 737 Thomas Herzog, Deutsche Messe AG Administration Building, Hannover,
label: Caption

text: Herzog’s Halle 26 was built for the Hannover Fair of 1996
label: Caption

text: [738]. In this instance the achievement was as much
label: Paragraph

text: tectonic as environmental, with the distinguished engineer
label: Paragraph

text: Jorge Schlaich acting as structural consultant; the catenary
label: Paragraph

text: roof of the building was determined by the need to erect the
label: Paragraph

text: structure rapidly rather than by the environmental
label: Paragraph

text: attributes of its section. The main support for the three-bay
label: Paragraph

text: catenary roof, with each bay spanning 55 metres (180 feet),
label: Paragraph

text: was provided by three triangulated steel trestles 30 metres
label: Paragraph

text: (100 feet) high, with a fourth set somewhat lower. The wire
label: Paragraph

text: cable structure carrying the roof was covered by two layers
label: Paragraph

text: of wood, with gravel in between in order to add stabilizing

text: Denmark
label: Title

text: Two factors influenced the emergence of the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement in Denmark: first, the exceptional standards
label: Title

text: maintained by the architecture department in the Royal
label: Caption

text: Academy of Art, Copenhagen, which even in the early 21st
label: Caption

text: century remains one of the most distinguished schools in
label: Paragraph

text: Europe; and second, the Skgnvirke (‘beautiful work’)
label: Paragraph

text: movement led by the rebellious figure of Peder Vilhelm
label: Paragraph

text: Jensen-Klint, who, influenced by the German architects Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Mebes, Paul Schultze-Naumburg and Heinrich Tessenow,
label: Caption

text: sought to establish a new building tradition based on the
label: Paragraph

text: Danish vernacular. Jensen-Klint, who was antithetical to both
label: Paragraph

text: the Royal Academy and the aesthetic sophistry of the
label: Paragraph

text: Scandinavian National Romantic movement, fully articulated
label: Paragraph

text: his position with a striking masterwork built of concrete-
label: Paragraph

text: frame construction in the centre of Copenhagen and faced
label: Paragraph

text: inside and out in precision brickwork. This was his cathedral-
label: Paragraph

text: scaled Grundtvig’s Church, under continuous construction
label: Caption

text: from 1920 to 1940 [740]. Jensen-Klint remained opposed to
label: Paragraph

text: the European classical tradition throughout his life and it is
label: Paragraph

text: significant in this regard that Denmark remains one of the
label: Paragraph

text: few European countries where brick production and
label: Paragraph

text: construction still play a major role in building culture, as
label: Paragraph

text: opposed to stone, which remains associated with
label: Paragraph

text: Classicism. In an age that seems to be totally dedicated to
label: Paragraph

text: the elimination of craftsmanship, Denmark is the one
label: Paragraph

text: country capable of producing an exceptionally diverse range
label: Paragraph

text: of quality bricks, and the well-trained graduates of the Royal
label: Paragraph

text: Academy continue to demonstrate their capacity to build in
label: Paragraph

text: this material, all of which testifies to the craft-based
label: Paragraph

text: character of Danish architectural education and practice.
label: Paragraph
