label: Paragraph

text: Nevertheless, during the first decade of the 20th century
label: Paragraph

text: the Academy also trained a generation of architects who
label: Paragraph

text: became involved in the cultivation of Nordic Classicism, a
label: Paragraph

text: style capable of continuing the dense, built-up character of
label: Paragraph

text: the European city. The prime mover behind this movement
label: Paragraph

text: in Denmark was Carl Petersen, whose Faaborg Art Museum
label: Paragraph

text: has generally been seen as the beginning of Nordic
label: Paragraph

text: Classicism. In 1919 he joined forces with Ivar Bentsen to
label: Paragraph

text: design a multi-block megastructural scheme for the former
label: Paragraph

text: railway station site in Copenhagen. Equally monumental and
label: Paragraph

text: of a similarly stripped Neo-Classical manner was Hack
label: Paragraph

text: Kampmann’s police headquarters posthumously completed
label: Caption

text: in Copenhagen in 1924 [742]. The unifying concept behind
label: Paragraph

text: all of these works was a medium-rise perimeter block,
label: Paragraph

text: dressed in stone - as in Kampmann’s masterwork - but
label: Paragraph

text: more often rendered in cement as in Povl Baumann’s large
label: Paragraph

text: five-storey apartment block in Copenhagen of 1921. The
label: Paragraph

text: prolific Kay Fisker, who graduated from the Academy in
label: Paragraph

text: 1920, became the ultimate master of the brick-faced
label: Paragraph

text: residential perimeter block as is evident from the six-storey
label: Paragraph

text: housing block that he built on a large triangular site in
label: Paragraph

text: Copenhagen in 1932 [741]. However, the ultimate Nordic
label: Paragraph

text: Classical work from a monumental standpoint was Edvard
label: Paragraph

text: Thomsen’s @regard School of 1924 [743] was close in its
label: Paragraph

text: stripped-down abstraction to the form of Giuseppe
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni’s Casa del Fascio, Como, of 1936 (figs 203 & 204).

text: Having been a protégé of Edvard Thomsen, Vilhelm
label: Paragraph

text: Lauritzen begun his own practice in 1922 by winning a
label: Paragraph

text: competition for a department store in the Nordic Classical
label: Title

text: manner. However, after visiting Walter Gropius’s Bauhaus in
label: Paragraph

text: Dessau of 1925 and the Weissenhofsiedlung in Stuttgart of
label: Paragraph

text: 1927, he shifted his modus operandi to functionalism, as is
label: Paragraph

text: evident from the glare-free light fittings that he designed
label: Paragraph

text: with Fritz Schlegel in 1929 as an alternative to Poul
label: Paragraph

text: Henningsen’s famous PH lamp produced in the same year.
label: Paragraph

text: Five years later, Lauritzen’s breakthrough came with his
label: Paragraph

text: 1934 design of the Radio Building in Copenhagen, which he
label: Caption

text: followed in 1936 with a design for a new air terminal at
label: Paragraph

text: Kastrup [744, 746], just outside the city. Lauritzen’s Radio
label: Caption

text: Building was influenced by the architecture of other earlier
label: Paragraph

text: radio stations in Europe, ranging from G. Val Myers’s BBC
label: Paragraph

text: Building, London, to Hans Poelzig’s Haus des Rundfunks,
label: Caption

text: Berlin, both dating from 1931. Lauritzen was aware of the
label: Paragraph

text: acoustical advantages of non-parallel walls in recording
label: Paragraph

text: studios and incorporated them into his building, which was
label: Paragraph

text: flanked on one side by a wing of multi-storey offices and on
label: Paragraph

text: the other by a large concert hall. The design of this hall
label: Caption

text: involved a new concept of illuminating orchestral space,
label: Paragraph

text: worked out with the lighting engineer Mogens Voltelen, the
label: Paragraph

text: main principle of which was to avoid hanging lamps so as to
label: Paragraph

text: facilitate the installation of microphones while otherwise
label: Paragraph

text: maintaining an uninterrupted ceiling.

text: The Kastrup air terminal exemplified the machine
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic of the period, but not to the same extent as other
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary European airports, which was surely due to
label: Paragraph

text: the influence of the functional, but ludic spirit of Gunnar
label: Paragraph

text: Asplund’s Stockholm Exhibition of 1930. Lauritzen strove for
label: Paragraph

text: a similar popular functionalism, which accounts for the
label: Paragraph

text: organic inflection of the terminal's plan and the undulating
label: Paragraph

text: ceiling of the departure hall, representing the turbulent
label: Caption

text: movement generated by aircraft in flight. Accompanying
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Arne Jacobsen graduated from the Royal Academy in
label: Paragraph

text: 1928, and, after working briefly for the city architect Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Holsoe, opened his own office in 1930 on the strength of his
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: House built at Klampenborg in 1930. Unlike other modern
label: Paragraph

text: architects of his generation Jacobsen tended in the first
label: Paragraph

text: decade of his practice towards Nordic Classicism, although
label: Paragraph

text: on occasion he would also favour the brick architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: the Skgnvirke movement, as found in his Monrad-Aas House
label: Paragraph

text: in Copenhagen, dating from 1930.
label: Caption

text: Jacobsen first adopted an unequivocally modern manner
label: Paragraph

text: in the Bellevue seaside resort that he built in successive
label: Paragraph

text: stages at Klampenborg in the 1930s, including the
label: Paragraph

text: ingeniously planned Bellavista housing of 1936 [747] and
label: Paragraph

text: the crowning element of the Bellevue Theatre and
label: Paragraph

text: Restaurant completed in 1937. This unequivocal modernity
label: Paragraph

text: would be tempered in the same year by his winning design
label: Paragraph

text: for Aarhus City Hall [745], designed with Erik Moller, which
label: Caption

text: unequivocally demonstrated a modern version of the town
label: Paragraph

text: hall while engaging in Nordic Classicism as a language
label: Paragraph

text: capable of expressing democratic values. The building was
label: Paragraph

text: organized into three basic units which differentiated the
label: Paragraph

text: main entrance and council chamber from the council offices
label: Caption

text: and the six-storey archive block accessed from a secondary
label: Paragraph

text: entrance. As Kjeld Vindum points out, the gently arched
label: Paragraph

text: laylight of diffused glass covering the main entrance was
label: Paragraph

text: derived from Thomsen’s @regard School.

label: Caption

text: Jacobsen’s post-1945 career begins with the Sgholm
label: Paragraph

text: Housing built in load-bearing brick at Klampenborg in 1950
label: Paragraph

text: [748], a development in which he lived for the rest of his
label: Paragraph

text: life. In this work Jacobsen was able to evoke a discreet
label: Paragraph

text: sense of domestic comfort and luxury in a largely
label: Paragraph

text: windowless cluster of cross-wall houses arranged in chevron
label: Caption

text: formation, the whole producing a rhythmic silhouette of
label: Paragraph

text: monopitched roofs and chimneys. This feeling for a modern
label: Paragraph

text: domesticity is most evident in the double-height dining
label: Paragraph

text: room, which (as in Jacobsen’s own home) was invariably
label: Paragraph

text: furnished with one of his circular tables, surrounded by his
label: Paragraph

text: famous Ant chairs, fabricated out of bent plywood with three
label: Caption

text: steel legs. This chair, first produced in 1952, established
label: Paragraph

text: Jacobsen’s reputation as an industrial designer, capable of
label: Paragraph

text: creating in addition to furniture a popular range of domestic
label: Paragraph

text: items in metal, glass and ceramics.

text: The late 1950s and mid-1960s saw the emergence of Jorn

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Sweden
label: Title

text: Both National Romanticism and Nordic Classicism attained
label: Title

text: their ultimate expression in Stockholm in the mid-1920s: the
label: Paragraph

text: first in the Stockholm Town Hall, completed to the designs of
label: Paragraph

text: Ragnar Ostberg in 1923, and the second with the Stockholm
label: Paragraph

text: Public Library by Gunnar Asplund, finished in 1928 after six
label: Caption

text: years of construction. However, the Modern Movement
label: Paragraph

text: arrived seemingly overnight with the Stockholm Exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: of 1930 [753-55], designed by a team of young architects
label: Paragraph

text: under the leadership of Asplund and inspired by a
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensive cultural programme conceived by Gregor
label: Title

text: Paulson, who was the director of the Swedish Society of
label: Paragraph

text: Craft and Design. Paulson had been in Berlin during the first
label: Paragraph

text: years of the Deutsche Werkbund, an experience that
label: Paragraph

text: convinced him of the necessity of reconciling the elegance
label: Paragraph

text: of industrial production with more traditional arts and crafts
label: Paragraph

text: values. Stockholm 1930 was the beginning of a warmer,
label: Paragraph

text: more accessible functionalism consciously opposed to the
label: Paragraph

text: reductive, economic, standard functionalism of the Neue
label: Title

text: Sachlichkeit. This spiritual difference was beautifully
label: Paragraph

text: summed up by Alvar Aalto when he wrote of the exhibition:
label: Paragraph

text: ‘This is not a composition of glass, stone and steel, as a
label: Paragraph

text: visitor who despises functionalism might imagine. It is a
label: Paragraph

text: composition of houses, flags, floodlights, flowers, fireworks,
label: Paragraph

text: happy people and clean table cloths.’
label: Paragraph

text: The exhibition was the spearhead of a popular
label: Paragraph

text: environmental culture, with the Social Democratic Party
label: Title

text: being elected in 1931 and henceforth establishing the full
label: Paragraph

text: scope of its welfare state policy. The party effectively
label: Paragraph

text: remained in power in Sweden until the assassination of the
label: Paragraph

text: prime minister, Olof Palme, in 1986. In his 1931 essay,
label: Paragraph

text: ‘White Industry’ Paulson set forth his strategy of
label: Paragraph

text: transforming social values, raising the level of popular taste
label: Paragraph

text: and generally improving the living conditions of the working
label: Paragraph

text: class. This gradualist approach to the task of changing
label: Paragraph

text: society was further articulated in a polemical tract
label: Paragraph

text: accompanying the exhibition. Entitled Acceptera, it urged
label: Paragraph

text: society ‘to accept reality that exists’, arguing that ‘only in
label: Paragraph

text: that way do we have any prospect of mastering it, taking it
label: Paragraph

text: in hand and altering it to create a culture that offers an
label: Paragraph

text: adaptable tool for life.’
label: Paragraph

text: There is no compact survey of the architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: planning achievements of the first two decades of Swedish
label: Title

text: social democracy to rival the American architect G.E. Kidder
label: Paragraph

text: Smith’s book Sweden Builds (1950). In it he demonstrated
label: Paragraph

text: though his didactic photographs the syntactical range of the
label: Paragraph

text: softer Scandinavian functionalist line (funkis) capable of
label: Paragraph

text: combining the rational organization of space and the logic of
label: Paragraph

text: engineering forms with softer internal timber finishes and
label: Paragraph

text: furniture and correspondingly subtle, rhythmically
label: Paragraph

text: positioned light fittings such as the famous PH series of
label: Paragraph

text: pendant lamps, designed by the Danish cultural critic Poul
label: Caption

text: Henningsen. This funkis culture arising directly out of the
label: Paragraph

text: Stockholm Exhibition of 1930 was elaborated further over
label: Paragraph

text: the next two decades to a Swedish environmental /ingua
label: Paragraph

text: franca in which a whole generation of architects and
label: Paragraph

text: engineers, led by the architects of the government-backed
label: Paragraph

text: Swedish co-operative movement, built a social democratic
label: Paragraph

text: architectural culture. In this it is difficult to discern any trace
label: Paragraph

text: of a separate personal style, whether it is the work of Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Hedqvist, Hans Westman, Eskil Sundahl or the practice of
label: Paragraph

text: Lallerstedt, Lewerentz and Helldén, who were responsible
label: Paragraph

text: for the City Theatre of 1943 in Malmé6 [757, 758], where the
label: Paragraph

text: size of the auditorium could be varied from 110 to 100 seats
label: Paragraph

text: through a flexible, undulating screen wall. One of the only
label: Paragraph

text: architects to pull back from this approach was Asplund
label: Paragraph

text: himself in his Forest Crematorium crowning the Woodland
label: Paragraph

text: Cemetery [756], with which his career had begun. This
label: Paragraph

text: trabeated peristyle of the atrium before the main chapel
label: Caption

text: signals a decisive return to Nordic Classicism. It is a tragic
label: Paragraph

text: irony that he was the first person to be cremated there at its
label: Paragraph

text: completion in 1940.

text: Born in 1914 in London and educated at a Quaker school
label: Paragraph

text: before studying architecture, Ralph Erskine went to Sweden
label: Paragraph

text: in 1937 in order to familiarize himself with the new
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of the Swedish welfare state. Unable to return
label: Paragraph

text: to the UK owing to the outbreak of the Second World War,
label: Paragraph

text: he would remain in Sweden for the rest of his life.
label: Paragraph

text: More than any other contemporary British or Swedish
label: Paragraph

text: architect Erskine demonstrated an exceptional capacity
label: Paragraph

text: early in his career to work at different scales, from enclaves
label: Paragraph

text: providing a protective microcosm capable of sustaining a
label: Paragraph

text: community in a hostile natural environment to large, self-
label: Paragraph

text: contained forms in otherwise rather placeless contexts, such
label: Paragraph

text: as his well-known theoretical project for an arctic town
label: Paragraph

text: [759] as an enclave, enclosed by a thick perimeter wall
label: Paragraph

text: stacked with housing facing within the artificial crater. This
label: Paragraph

text: audacious project gained him a hearing within the elite
label: Paragraph

text: Team 10 circle dominated by Aldo van Eyck and the
label: Title

text: Smithsons. This idea of conceiving housing as a continuous
label: Paragraph

text: landscape form reoccurred throughout his prolific career: at
label: Paragraph

text: Kiruna in Lapland (1961-66); in Clare College, Cambridge
label: Paragraph

text: (1968-69); in Resolute Bay in the Northwest Territories of
label: Paragraph

text: Canada (1973-77); and finally in the Byker Wall complex in
label: Paragraph

text: Newcastle, England, in 1981. However, this preoccupation
label: Paragraph

text: with residential megaforms did not prevent Erskine from
label: Paragraph

text: also designing, when appropriate, relatively small-scale
label: Paragraph

text: urban complexes comprising medium-rise residential
label: Title

text: perimeter blocks. Erskine practised throughout his life as a
label: Paragraph

text: brilliantly inventive, pragmatic architect, whose organic
label: Paragraph

text: syntax came close to that of Aalto, as in his paper-making
label: Paragraph

text: factory at Avesta of 1953, faced in brick, and in the
label: Paragraph

text: beautifully detailed, prefabricated concrete flats that he
label: Paragraph

text: built at Vaxj6 in 1954. He was also capable of giving his
label: Paragraph

text: work a powerful, almost Constructivist character, as in the
label: Paragraph

text: ski hotel built early in his career at Borgafjall in 1950 [760].
label: Paragraph

text: Although the building of Swedish social democratic housing
label: Paragraph

text: became increasingly bureaucratized after 1945, Erskine
label: Paragraph

text: never stopped demonstrating how ‘place-creation’ must be

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Peter's at Klippan [763], both designed and built from 1962

text: Lewerentz, apparently concerned only with a dogged
label: Paragraph

text: working out of an issue in terms of building construction, in
label: Paragraph

text: the end arrives at a figure pregnant with symbolic meaning
label: Paragraph

text: - its form irresistibly evoking the form of the cross with a
label: Paragraph

text: harshness for which we are quite unprepared... | know of no
label: Paragraph

text: precedent in the architecture of our time for the sheer
label: Paragraph

text: impact of a way of building transformed into symbolic
label: Paragraph

text: statement. It seems worthwhile therefore to look closer at
label: Paragraph

text: the building rules that Lewerentz set himself. In the first
label: Paragraph

text: space we find that the use of brick is subject to three
label: Paragraph

text: propositions stringently applied in the teeth of common-
label: Paragraph

text: sense compromise. First, Lewerentz proposes to use it for all
label: Paragraph

text: purposes: wall, floor, vault, roof light, altar, pulpit, seat.
label: Caption

text: Second, he will use only the standard, full-size brick; there
label: Paragraph

text: will be no specially shaped bricks. Third, no brick is to be
label: Paragraph

text: cut. The only way these conditions can be met is by a very
label: Paragraph

text: free proportioning in the ratio of mortar to brick; to achieve
label: Paragraph

text: such jointing (often very large) a very dry mortar mix that
label: Paragraph

text: included ground slate was employed.
label: Paragraph

text: The work of Peter Celsing seems, in many respects, to be
label: Paragraph

text: an uncanny synthesis of the work of Asplund and Lewerentz,
label: Paragraph

text: although Celsing himself seems to have never have worked
label: Paragraph

text: for either of them. Despite this, his brick churches, built
label: Paragraph

text: between 1952 and 1959, anticipated the atmosphere of
label: Paragraph

text: Lewerentz’s late churches, even featuring, in the case of the
label: Paragraph

text: church he built in Vallingby new town, Lewerentz’s penchant
label: Caption

text: for thick mortar joints. At the same time, he proved himself
label: Paragraph

text: to be a heroic public architect within the long tradition of
label: Paragraph

text: the Swedish welfare state, above all in his Film House,
label: Paragraph

text: Stockholm (1964-70) [764, 766], and in his Culture Centre,
label: Paragraph

text: completed in 1976 on the south side of Sergels torg square
label: Caption

text: in the centre of the capital - a building that briefly served as
label: Paragraph

text: the seat of the Swedish Parliament while its own building
label: Paragraph

text: was under restoration. Both of these Stockholm works are
label: Paragraph

text: rationally and ingeniously planned and without any
label: Paragraph

text: superfluous ornament. They recall through the generosity
label: Paragraph

text: and boldness of their form the paradigm of the social
label: Paragraph

text: condenser as envisaged in the Soviet Union in the 1920s. At
label: Paragraph

text: the same time Celsing suddenly abandoned his former
label: Paragraph

text: funkis manner with the Bank of Sweden [765] on the same
label: Paragraph

text: side of the square as the Culture Centre. Although this work
label: Paragraph

text: was a gridded eight-storey prism, it also featured a highly
label: Paragraph

text: mannered use of black granite revetment hewn in such a
label: Paragraph

text: way as to create a highly textured, ornamental surface. The
label: Paragraph

text: inner court of this building was conversely faced in a
label: Paragraph

text: faceted, metallic curtain wall, rising up over the attic of the
label: Paragraph

text: building to enclose the recreational facilities on the roof. It
label: Paragraph

text: seems that at the end of his short but intensely creative life
label: Paragraph

text: Celsing was beginning to pull away from the heroic ideals of
label: Paragraph

text: Stockholm 1930 to embrace a ludic, even decorative,
label: Paragraph

text: approach to tectonic form.

text: Norway
label: Title

text: Modern architectural culture was first consciously developed
label: Paragraph

text: in Norway by the cosmopolitan architect Arne Korsmo, who
label: Paragraph

text: began his career by working as an assistant for Arnstein
label: Paragraph

text: Arneberg and Magnus Poulisson, who designed the Oslo City
label: Paragraph

text: Hall, which was completed in 1931, in the National Romantic
label: Paragraph

text: manner. In fact, the studio of these architects overlooked
label: Paragraph

text: the first functionalist building in Norway, the Skansen
label: Paragraph

text: restaurant of 1925 designed by Lars Backer. Despite this
label: Paragraph

text: prestigious beginning much of Korsmo’s early professional
label: Paragraph

text: life was shaped by his expertise in timber construction,
label: Paragraph

text: which led to his appointment in 1936 as a lecturer in the
label: Paragraph

text: timber-orientated design programme of the National College
label: Caption

text: of Applied Arts in Oslo. Throughout the 1930s Korsmo
label: Paragraph

text: designed and built a number of distinguished modern
label: Paragraph

text: houses, of which the finest was the Dammann House, Oslo,
label: Paragraph

text: of 1932 [767], which the distinguished Norwegian architect
label: Paragraph

text: Sverre Fehn would later acquire and live in.
label: Paragraph

text: 767 Korsmo, Dammann House, Oslo, 1932.
label: Caption

text: Unable to practise during the German occupation of
label: Paragraph

text: Norway (1940-45), Korsmo fled to Stockholm in 1944, where
label: Paragraph

text: he worked for Paul Hedqvist. Upon returning to Oslo, he
label: Paragraph

text: welcomed the opportunity in 1949 to travel to the United
label: Paragraph

text: States on a Fulbright Scholarship in the company of his wife,
label: Paragraph

text: the enamel artist Grete Prytz. America proved to bea
label: Paragraph

text: stimulating experience for both of them, above all for the
label: Paragraph

text: nascent industrial design culture of Moholy-Nagy’s Institute
label: Title

text: of Design in Chicago, which by then had been incorporated
label: Paragraph

text: into Mies van der Rohe’s department of architecture at the
label: Paragraph

text: Illinois Institute of Technology (IIT). The other American city
label: Paragraph

text: that would have an enduring influence on Korsmo’s work
label: Paragraph

text: was Los Angeles, where he and Grete were duly impressed
label: Paragraph

text: by Charles and Ray Eames’ house in Pacific Palisades. They
label: Caption

text: were equally captivated by other houses built in the city
label: Paragraph

text: under the sponsorship of John Entenza’s Case Study House
label: Paragraph

text: programme. Despite the enduring influence of his American
label: Paragraph

text: experience, Korsmo remained in close contact with the
label: Paragraph

text: Danish architect Jorn Utzon, whom he had first met in
label: Paragraph

text: Stockholm in 1944, and with whom he subsequently
label: Paragraph

text: collaborated on a number of projects in the late 1940s. The
label: Paragraph

text: ultimate outcome of his US tour was the twin houses that he
label: Paragraph

text: built in Planetveien (1953-55), outside Oslo [768]: one for
label: Paragraph

text: the architect-historian Christian Norberg-Schulz and the
label: Paragraph

text: other for his own occupation. The timber-lined interiors of
label: Paragraph

text: Korsmo’s own house went beyond the light-weight,
label: Paragraph

text: technological rationality of Mies and Eames by which he was
label: Paragraph

text: patently influenced. This is particularly evident in the
label: Paragraph

text: importance that he attached to the hearth as the spiritual
label: Paragraph

text: core of the house, of which he wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: 768 Korsmo, Twin Houses, Planetveien, 1955.
label: Caption

text: The fireplace satisfies, for example, the need to come to
label: Paragraph

text: rest before the movement and sounds of a fire. It gathers
label: Paragraph

text: everyone who comes to the house in a ritual similar to that
label: Paragraph

text: of the tea ceremony, a simple ‘in-between’ moment of
label: Paragraph

text: heightened contemplative quiet - even though many are
label: Paragraph

text: gathered together.
label: Paragraph

text: The other rationalist line of the post-war Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement in Norway was that of PAGON (Progressive
label: Paragraph

text: Architects Group Oslo Norway), organized in 1948 by
label: Paragraph

text: Korsmo’s students, including Sverre Fehn, Geir Grung and
label: Paragraph

text: Odd Kjeld @stbye, who had qualified as architects under his
label: Paragraph

text: tutelage. Fehn rose to the fore in the 1950s as the one
label: Paragraph

text: architect able to develop the industrial modular rationality
label: Paragraph

text: generally favoured by the PAGON group into a material
label: Paragraph

text: expressivity: first with his laminated timber-framed
label: Paragraph

text: Norwegian Pavilion, built for the Brussels Universal
label: Caption

text: Exhibition of 1958; then with his timber-framed Schreiner
label: Paragraph

text: House, Oslo, of 1963; and, above all, with the monumental,
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete Nordic Pavilion in the gardens of the
label: Caption

text: Venice Biennale in 1968. In the Schreiner House, which
label: Caption

text: possesses a distinctly Japanese flavour, Fehn arrived at a
label: Paragraph

text: surprisingly articulate interaction between the exposed
label: Paragraph

text: timber framing of the roof - which accommodated a brick
label: Caption

text: core housing a free-standing chimney shaft and an adjacent
label: Paragraph

text: bathroom and kitchen. This structurally expressive language
label: Paragraph

text: was developed further in the Underland and Wessel Houses
label: Paragraph

text: (1960-65), close to Oslo, culminating in his quasi-Palladian
label: Paragraph

text: house built at Norrképing in Sweden in 1964 [769, 770].
label: Caption

text: This symmetrical exercise in load-bearing brickwork and
label: Paragraph

text: timber framing is based on a ‘square-within-a-square’ plan,
label: Paragraph

text: which is beautifully articulated by the built-in cabinetwork of
label: Paragraph

text: its four corner windows. This precision had the effect of
label: Paragraph

text: giving a single-storey house a formal presence comparable
label: Paragraph

text: to that of Mies van der Rohe’s Farnsworth House of 1953.
label: Paragraph

text: Equally tectonic, though of a more majestic public
label: Paragraph

text: character, the Nordic Pavilion in Venice [771] is predicated
label: Paragraph

text: on a number of extremely simple moves: the first being the
label: Paragraph

text: 2.5-metre (8-foot), double post-tensioned reinforced-
label: Caption

text: concrete beams that bear onto two concrete piers and then
label: Paragraph

text: divide into twin cantilevered, reinforced-concrete brackets,
label: Caption

text: which pass around two sides of an existing tree. This
label: Paragraph

text: magnanimous structural gesture supports a grid of thin,
label: Paragraph

text: prefabricated, long-span concrete planks forming the roof.
label: Caption

text: These primal elements establish the main volume of the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition space, which is top lit through plastic gutters
label: Paragraph

text: hung between the concrete planks. The genius /oci of this
label: Paragraph

text: solution derives not only from its intimate relationship with
label: Paragraph

text: a mature tree but also from the need to accommodate a
label: Paragraph

text: major change in level at this point in the gardens.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: The key defining work of the first half of Fehn’s career is
label: Paragraph

text: the Hedmark Archaeological Museum at Hamar, completed
label: Caption

text: in 1979 [772-774]. This museum is built within the remains
label: Paragraph

text: of an 18th-century farmhouse and a medieval monastery.
label: Paragraph

text: Fehn introduced a reinforced-concrete passerelle into this
label: Paragraph

text: complex as a way of conducting the visitor through this
label: Paragraph

text: history, beginning with a concrete entrance ramp that rises
label: Paragraph

text: out of the rubble of the courtyard. This bridge-like form
label: Paragraph

text: establishes a relationship between the béton brut of its
label: Paragraph

text: construction and the articulate, triangulated timber
label: Title

text: trusswork and purlins of the reconstructed double-pitched
label: Caption

text: barn roof overhead, elegantly suspended above the ruined
label: Caption

text: stonework of the original foundation.
label: Caption

text: 772 Fehn, Hedmark Archaeological Museum, Hamar, 1979.
label: Caption

text: 773 Fehn, Hedmark Archaeological Museum, Hamar, 1979. Section.
label: Caption

text: 774 Fehn, Hedmark Archaeological Museum, Hamar, 1979. Plan.
label: Caption

text: Like Carlo Scarpa, by whom he was patently influenced,
label: Paragraph

text: Fehn was henceforth destined to become a museum
label: Paragraph

text: architect, designing and executing a whole sequence of
label: Paragraph

text: exceptional institutions in remote parts of Norway, including
label: Paragraph

text: the Glacier Museum, built at Fjazerland in 1991 [775].
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps the most dynamic and rigorously unified of these
label: Paragraph

text: works was the combined museum and study centre [776]
label: Paragraph

text: commemorating the 19th-century Norwegian polymath Ivar
label: Paragraph

text: Aasen (1813-96). Here the concrete plastic dynamism of the
label: Paragraph

text: outer form, integrated with its alpine site, fuses with the
label: Paragraph

text: exposed concrete bulkhead of the interior, within which is
label: Caption

text: exhibited the memorabilia of Aasen’s life.
label: Paragraph

text: 775 Fehn, Glacier Museum, Fjzerland, 1991.

text: Finland
label: Title

text: Since the Second World War Finland has seen two main
label: Paragraph

text: trends in architecture: on the one hand sensitive variations
label: Title

text: on the organicism of Alvar Aalto, and on the other a
label: Paragraph

text: constructivist swerve away from his pervasive influence. In
label: Paragraph

text: the former, the main problem has been how to pursue the
label: Paragraph

text: native organic tradition while keeping a distance from the
label: Paragraph

text: idiosyncratic tropes of the master. This predicament has led
label: Paragraph

text: to a geometrically inflected, stripped organicism, found, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, in Kaija and Heikki Siren’s Otaniemi Church (1957)
label: Paragraph

text: and later in Kapy and Simo Paavilainen’s Olari Church
label: Paragraph

text: (1976). A similar line is also evident in the work of Juha
label: Paragraph

text: Leiviska, above all in his masterly twin churches - St
label: Paragraph

text: Thomas’s Church at Oulu (1975) and Myyrmaki Church at
label: Paragraph

text: Vantaa (1985) [780-782] - both of which are as much
label: Paragraph

text: indebted to Dutch Neo-Plasticism as to Aalto. However, the
label: Paragraph

text: primary drive in Leiviska’s architecture is the modulation of
label: Paragraph

text: light, which no doubt explains his personal affinity with Erik
label: Paragraph

text: Bryggman’s Turku Chapel of 1941, where light plays an
label: Paragraph

text: equally central role.
label: Paragraph

text: While Aarno Ruusuvuori was the first to move away from
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto in the audaciously cantilevered, minimalist steel
label: Paragraph

text: structure of the printing works that he built in Tapiola in
label: Paragraph

text: 1964 [778], the pursuit of such an overtly constructivist
label: Paragraph

text: expression was continued in the industrial buildings
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Erkki Kairamo of Gullichsen, Kairamo and
label: Caption

text: Vormala, most particularly in his Marimekko textile plant,
label: Paragraph

text: Helsinki, of 1974 [779]. This high-tech approach is
label: Paragraph

text: combined with a flair for an articulated expressivity that is
label: Paragraph

text: particularly evident in Gullichsen, Kairamo and Vormala’s
label: Paragraph

text: Westend housing at Espoo of 1982 [777] and in their office
label: Paragraph

text: tower for the Itakeskus shopping centre on the outskirts of
label: Caption

text: Helsinki in 1987. A softer Neo-Constructivist trend aspiring
label: Paragraph

text: to a cooler, more abstract expression than that of the Italo-
label: Paragraph

text: British High-Tech architects may be found in the Jyvaskyla
label: Paragraph

text: Airport (1988) by Pekka Helin and Tuomo Siitonen, who also
label: Paragraph

text: designed a prototypical collective dwelling in the form of a
label: Paragraph

text: stepped housing block, built on the Hestra Estate, near
label: Caption

text: Boras in Sweden, in 1992. An equally abstract tendency is
label: Paragraph

text: evident in the work of Mikko Heikkinen and Markku
label: Paragraph

text: Komonen, above all in their Science Centre built at Vantaa in
label: Paragraph

text: 1986, which is somewhat reminiscent of the work of Rem
label: Paragraph

text: Koolhaas but with detailing taken to a higher resolution.
label: Paragraph

text: 777 Gullichsen, Kairamo and Vormala, Liinasaaren-kuja housing, Westend,
label: Caption

text: Espoo, 1982.
label: Caption

text: 778 Ruusuvuori, Printing Works, Tapiola, 1964.
label: Caption

text: 779 Kairamo, Marimekko Textile Works, Helsinki, 1974.
label: Caption

text: Many reasons besides prosperity may be invoked to
label: Paragraph

text: account for the manifestation of so much talent in such a
label: Paragraph

text: small country. In the first place, there is the evident
label: Paragraph

text: influence of one of the most rigorous architectural schools in
label: Paragraph

text: the world, that of the Helsinki Technical University, with its
label: Paragraph

text: traditions going back to the leadership of Usko Nystrém (see
label: Paragraph

text: p. 224). Other predisposing factors are: (1) the enormous
label: Paragraph

text: national prestige enjoyed by Aalto in his lifetime; (2) the
label: Paragraph

text: long-established principle of holding open competitions for
label: Paragraph

text: virtually every public building in Finland; and (3) the high
label: Paragraph

text: design standards established by such furnishing firms as
label: Paragraph

text: Marimekko and Artek. To all this must be added the didactic
label: Paragraph

text: cultural support provided by the Museum of Finnish
label: Title

text: Architecture under a series of directorships, namely, Juhani
label: Paragraph

text: Pallasmaa, Asko Salokorpi, Aarno Ruusuvuori, Markku
label: Caption

text: Komonen and Marja-Riitta Norri - particularly for the
label: Paragraph

text: editorial support they successively gave to the journals
label: Paragraph

text: Abacus and Arkkitehti, with which the museum was
label: Paragraph

text: associated. The international influence of the Aalto Prize and
label: Paragraph

text: the associated Aalto Symposium held every three years in
label: Paragraph

text: Jyvaskyla should also be acknowledged as a crucial cultural
label: Paragraph

text: influence. The choice of recipients of this award testifies to
label: Paragraph

text: the vitality and perspicacity of the architectural debate in
label: Paragraph

text: Finland and to the Finnish ability to recognize quality
label: Title

text: wherever it occurs. Finally, as in Japan, the state has played
label: Paragraph

text: a fundamentally significant role, above all through its
label: Paragraph

text: patronage of architecture, maintained as part of the
label: Paragraph

text: country’s post-war diplomatic balancing act between the
label: Paragraph

text: United States and the USSR.
label: Paragraph

text: The celebration of Post-Modernism in the Venice Biennale
label: Title

text: of 1980, followed by the collapse of the Soviet Union and
label: Paragraph

text: the corresponding fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989, provoked a
label: Paragraph

text: critical reflection on the current state of architecture in
label: Title

text: Finland in the form of a retrospective in 1992 of the leading
label: Paragraph

text: architects practising in Helsinki. This exhibition, staged by
label: Paragraph

text: the Museum of Finnish Architecture and entitled
label: Title

text: ‘Architecture Present: 7 Approaches’, featured the
label: Paragraph

text: contributions of: Gullichsen, Kairamo and Vormala; Juha
label: Paragraph

text: Leiviska; Helin and Siitonen; Heikkinen and Komonen; Kapy
label: Paragraph

text: and Sino Paavilainen; and, lastly, Georg Grotenfelt, with his
label: Paragraph

text: unique domestic manner, synthesizing Aaltoesque tropes
label: Paragraph

text: with elements directly taken from the Finnish agricultural
label: Paragraph

text: tradition. Also in 1992, Scott Poole’s canonical assessment
label: Paragraph

text: of Finnish practice after Alvar Aalto was published under the
label: Paragraph

text: title The New Finnish Architecture, to which Colin St John
label: Paragraph

text: Wilson would add the following provocative evaluation: All in
label: Paragraph

text: all, the status of contemporary architecture in Finland
label: Paragraph

text: constitutes a certain reproach to the reactionary nostalgia,
label: Paragraph

text: the dithering and scuttling, the lost sense of common
label: Paragraph

text: purpose, and the instant kitsch that dominate the scene and
label: Paragraph

text: are fostered elsewhere by those whom Habermas has rightly
label: Paragraph

text: stigmatized as ‘the Avant-Garde of the Great Retreat’.
label: Paragraph

text: 780 Leiviska, Myyrmaki Church and Community Centre, Vantaa, 1985.
label: Caption

text: 781 Leiviska, Myyrmaki Church and Community Centre, Vantaa, 1985. Section.
label: Caption

text: 782 Leiviska, Myyrmaki Church and Community Centre, Vantaa, 1985.
label: Caption

text: Distant from the Helsinki scene celebrated in the 1992
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition, there is the equally accomplished practice of the
label: Paragraph

text: Oulu-based architects Mikko Kaira, IImari Lahdelma and
label: Paragraph

text: Rainer Mahlamaki, above all surely for their masterly Finnish
label: Paragraph

text: Forest Museum and Information Centre [783], built at
label: Caption

text: Punkaharju, near the country’s eastern border, in 1996.
label: Paragraph

text: Appropriately clad throughout in wood - in the form of
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal boarding and louvres - this complex comprises a
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete frame, supplemented by an articulate
label: Paragraph

text: use of light steel components. As Peter MacKeith has
label: Paragraph

text: written:
label: Title

text: 783 Lahdelma and Mahlamaki, Finnish Forest Museum and Information Centre,
label: Caption

text: 1996. Site plan.
label: Caption

text: The consideration of construction and materials deepens
label: Title

text: the counterpoint at all scales of design. The sound intention
label: Paragraph

text: has been to steer clear of literal uses of wood. Geometry as
label: Paragraph

text: well as function determines the contrast of materials used;
label: Paragraph

text: stairs and ramps, for instance, are of concrete structure and
label: Paragraph

text: glass enclosure and grey-painted steel is used in an
label: Paragraph

text: understated support role. ... The interior experience of the
label: Paragraph

text: museum is enlivened by sectional slices through the roof of
label: Paragraph

text: the drum to admit natural light. ... The curved rooflight
label: Paragraph

text: functions as a kind of sundial for the visitor, who, entering
label: Paragraph

text: at the top level of the entrance court, is propelled down the
label: Paragraph

text: switchback ramp into the exhibition levels themselves. The
label: Paragraph

text: overlapping of spaces and visible interconnection through
label: Paragraph

text: slots between walls and bridges is inventive; the visitor is
label: Paragraph

text: always returned for orientation to the absolute centre of the
label: Paragraph

text: drum, tracing and retracing their steps across a giant
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal slice of tree-trunk embedded in the floor,
label: Paragraph

text: metaphorically always returned to the life of wood itself.
label: Paragraph

text: Three other works by this practice merit particular
label: Paragraph

text: mention: an addition to the Tampere University of
label: Caption

text: Technology (1995); the Folk Art Centre at Kaustinen (1997);
label: Paragraph

text: and the Museum of the History of Polish Jews in Warsaw
label: Title

text: (2013). Each of these works manifests the capacity to
label: Paragraph

text: combine dynamic plastic form with a rational organization of
label: Paragraph

text: the plan in a way that ultimately harks back to the Russian
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivist avant garde.
label: Paragraph

text: Pekka Helin has to be counted among the most
label: Paragraph

text: accomplished ‘high-tech’ architects practising in Finland. His
label: Paragraph

text: work is notable for its rational modularity, invariably
label: Paragraph

text: enriched by an articulate use of material, as in the patented
label: Paragraph

text: copper revetment of his Sello Library and Music Hall of 2003
label: Caption

text: or his timber-clad Finnforest Modular Office of 2005, both
label: Paragraph

text: works being built in Espoo. It is difficult to overestimate the
label: Paragraph

text: technical and aesthetic prowess of Helin’s practice,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly the remarkable range, precision and richness of
label: Paragraph

text: his detailing, from the Shipboy Housing, Helsinki, of 1995
label: Paragraph

text: [785, 786] to the brick-faced offices of the Kamppi
label: Caption

text: headquarters in downtown Helsinki of 2006. Moreover, the
label: Paragraph

text: scope of this practice includes the sensitive rendering of
label: Paragraph

text: private villas, such as the Villa Krona in Kimito6n (2010)
label: Paragraph

text: [784], built in the Gullkrona Archipelago. Here the geometry
label: Paragraph

text: of the villa’s form is closely related to the bedrock of the
label: Paragraph

text: site, with its variegated colours and glaciated surface, while
label: Paragraph

text: Afterword
label: Title

text: Architecture in the Age of
label: Title

text: Globalization
label: Title

text: The globalization of capital is, of course, somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: spurious. Yet it is an important ideological innovation. The
label: Paragraph

text: capitalist system undergoes a kind of mutation to its
label: Paragraph

text: essential form, the culmination of which would be the
label: Paragraph

text: complete (notional) capitalization of nature in which there
label: Paragraph

text: no longer remains any domain external to capital. This is
label: Paragraph

text: tantamount to the assumption that an external nature does
label: Paragraph

text: not exist. The image is no longer Marx’s (or the classical
label: Paragraph

text: economists’) of human beings acting on external nature to
label: Paragraph

text: produce value. Rather, the image is of the diverse elements
label: Paragraph

text: of nature (including human nature) themselves codified as
label: Paragraph

text: capital. Nature is capital, or, rather, nature is conceived in
label: Paragraph

text: the image of capital. The logic of the system is thus the
label: Paragraph

text: subsumption of all the elements of nature-considered-as-
label: Paragraph

text: capital to the finality of capital’s expanded reproduction.
label: Paragraph

text: Theoretical difficulties immediately arise as a result of
label: Paragraph

text: the fact that this is a largely imaginary functional
label: Paragraph

text: integration. The rhetoric stresses harmonization and
label: Paragraph

text: optimization, the reality is disorder and conflict. As
label: Paragraph

text: Baudrillard remarks, ‘Everything is potentially functional and
label: Paragraph

text: nothing is in fact.’ Two sources of contradiction are inherent
label: Paragraph

text: in the process of the capitalization of nature, which furnish
label: Paragraph

text: our justifications for proposing a shift from an industrial to
label: Paragraph

text: an ecological Marxist perspective on production, on the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘eventual’ and ‘inevitable’ collapse of capitalism, and thence
label: Paragraph

text: on the conditions for some sort of socialism. The first is the
label: Paragraph

text: fact that the planet is materially finite, a situation that
label: Paragraph

text: creates biophysical limits to the accumulation process. The
label: Paragraph

text: second, which is synergetic with the first, is the fact that
label: Paragraph

text: capital does not and cannot control the reproduction and
label: Paragraph

text: modification of the ‘natural’ conditions of production in the
label: Paragraph

text: same way it purports to regulate industrial commodity
label: Paragraph

text: production.
label: Paragraph

text: Martin O’Connor /s Capitalism Sustainable?, 19941
label: Caption

text: The diverse phenomena that accompany globalization are
label: Paragraph

text: closely associated with the ever-escalating rate of telematic
label: Paragraph

text: communication and the constant increase in
label: Title

text: transcontinental air travel. As a consequence, the practice
label: Paragraph

text: of architecture today is as global as it is local, as we may
label: Paragraph

text: judge from the international celebrity architects who are
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly active all over the world, directly responding to
label: Paragraph

text: the flow of capital investment. Our current susceptibility to
label: Paragraph

text: spectacular imagery is such that today the worldwide
label: Paragraph

text: reputation of an architect is as much due to his or her
label: Paragraph

text: iconographic flair as it is to their organizational and/or
label: Paragraph

text: technical ability. This worldwide phenomenon has been
label: Paragraph

text: termed the ‘Bilbao effect’ - so coined for the way in which,
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the 1990s, provincial cities vied with one
label: Paragraph

text: another to have a ‘brand’ building designed by a celebrated
label: Paragraph

text: architect, largely as a result of the media acclaim accorded
label: Paragraph

text: to Frank Gehry’s sensational Guggenheim Museum, realized
label: Paragraph

text: in Bilbao in 1995. During the decades that have succeeded
label: Paragraph

text: this triumph, the scope of the celebrity architect has
label: Paragraph

text: widened immeasurably, with signature architects travelling
label: Paragraph

text: all over the globe in order to supervise the erection of iconic
label: Paragraph

text: structures, thousands of miles apart, in totally different
label: Paragraph

text: cultural and political contexts. This has been particularly
label: Paragraph

text: evident in China and the Arabian Gulf today, where diverse
label: Paragraph

text: architectural stars rival one another with the projection of
label: Paragraph

text: one spectacular building after another, from Paul Andreu’s
label: Caption

text: National Grand Theatre of China, with its three auditoria
label: Paragraph

text: housed under a single titanium dome (2006), to Jacques
label: Caption

text: Herzog and Pierre de Meuron’s overstructured Beijing
label: Title

text: National Stadium for the 2008 Olympic Games.
label: Paragraph

text: For its equally gargantuan size, structural audacity and
label: Paragraph

text: perverse shape, it would be difficult to imagine a more
label: Paragraph

text: dramatic structure than Rem Koolhaas’s seventy-storey
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese Television Headquarters (CCTV) in Beijing, with its
label: Paragraph

text: inclined trapezoidal profile crowned by a 70-metre (230-
label: Paragraph

text: foot) cantilever some 230 metres (755 feet) in the air. Such
label: Paragraph

text: technological ostentation recalls the audacity of the Eiffel
label: Paragraph

text: Tower, along with El Lissitzky’s Wolkenbigel proposal of
label: Paragraph

text: 1924, by which the CCTV seems to have been inspired.
label: Paragraph

text: However totally removed from the axiality of both Eiffel’s
label: Paragraph

text: tower and Lissitzky’s ‘anti-skyscraper’, the imbalanced,
label: Paragraph

text: asymmetrical nature and arbitrary siting of Koolhaas’s
label: Paragraph

text: television megastructure preclude it from having any
label: Paragraph

text: urbanistic or symbolic significance, except as a gargantuan
label: Paragraph

text: representation of manipulative media power. It was
label: Paragraph

text: designed to house a working population of 10,000, engaged
label: Paragraph

text: in the programming of some 250 channels streaming out to
label: Paragraph

text: a billion people a day.
label: Paragraph

text: Skyscrapers of a much greater height are equally
label: Paragraph

text: symptomatic of our ‘society of spectacle’, in which cities
label: Paragraph

text: compete for the dubious honour of realizing the world’s
label: Paragraph

text: tallest building. Dubai has been the leading contender, with
label: Paragraph

text: its 160-storey Burj Tower designed by Skidmore, Owings and
label: Paragraph

text: Merrill. While such extravagances seem increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: irresistible in capital cities throughout the developed world,
label: Paragraph

text: global megalopoli are ever more attended by large masses
label: Paragraph

text: of impoverished people, particularly in countries under
label: Paragraph

text: development. Here, cities with already congested
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructures continue to become denser, so that the
label: Paragraph

text: population within the metropolitan region of Mexico City
label: Paragraph

text: now stands at 21 million, along with that of Beijing and
label: Paragraph

text: Mumbai at around 20 million each, Sao Paulo at 12 million,
label: Paragraph

text: Jakarta at 9 million, Tehran at 8 million, Bogota at 7 million,
label: Paragraph

text: and Caracas at 2 million. To these statistics we may add the
label: Paragraph

text: alarming prediction that within the next fifteen years some
label: Paragraph

text: 300 million rural Chinese will migrate into cities within the
label: Paragraph

text: Republic of China. A transfiguration on such a scale will only
label: Paragraph

text: exacerbate the fact that Asian cities are among the most
label: Paragraph

text: polluted in the world: the air quality in Beijing, for example,
label: Paragraph

text: is six times worse than that of the average European
label: Paragraph

text: capital.
label: Paragraph

text: With equally wasteful consequences as far as gasoline
label: Paragraph

text: consumption is concerned, cities in the United States such
label: Paragraph

text: as Houston (7 million), Atlanta (6 million) and Phoenix 4.8
label: Paragraph

text: million) continue to lose population in their centres while
label: Paragraph

text: constantly expanding their suburban hinterland with little or
label: Paragraph

text: no provision for public transport. The negative socio-
label: Paragraph

text: ecological nature of such settlement patterns is only too
label: Paragraph

text: familiar. In the United States alone well over 1.2 million
label: Paragraph

text: hectares (3 million acres) of open land are lost each year to
label: Paragraph

text: suburbanization. This situation is not helped by the current
label: Paragraph

text: pattern of government subsidy in the United States, which is
label: Paragraph

text: skewed 4 to 1 in favour of autoroutes rather than rail or bus
label: Paragraph

text: transit.
label: Paragraph

text: Topography
label: Title

text: Two seminal publications dating from the mid-1960s and
label: Paragraph

text: early 1970s announce the emergence of topography and
label: Paragraph

text: sustainability as the two environmental meta-discourses of
label: Paragraph

text: our time; together they exercise a pervasive influence not
label: Paragraph

text: only on landscape and urban design, but also on the field of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in general. The two texts in question, Vittorio
label: Paragraph

text: Gregotti’s // territorio dell’architettura, of 1966, and lan
label: Paragraph

text: McHarg’s Design with Nature, of 1971, were to emphasize in
label: Paragraph

text: different ways the significant integration of man-made form
label: Paragraph

text: with the Earth’s surface. Gregotti saw the marking of ground
label: Paragraph

text: as a primordial act, undertaken in order to establish a man-
label: Paragraph

text: made cosmos in the face of the chaos of nature; he
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized the fabrication of territory as a strategy for
label: Paragraph

text: establishing a public place-form in the face of the new
label: Paragraph

text: nature brought into being by the emergence of the
label: Paragraph

text: urbanized region. He first demonstrated this thesis in his
label: Paragraph

text: designs for the University of Calabria, built as a linear
label: Caption

text: megastructure across a large swathe of agricultural land in
label: Paragraph

text: Cosenza, southern Italy, in 1973. Eschewing architectonic
label: Paragraph

text: intervention, McHarg’s research was focused more on the
label: Paragraph

text: need for a comprehensive approach to the biosphere in
label: Paragraph

text: order to facilitate and maintain the mutual interdependence
label: Paragraph

text: of regional ecosystems across a wide front. In retrospect,
label: Paragraph

text: both approaches were attempts to mediate the effect of the
label: Paragraph

text: continual expansion of megalopoli throughout the world.
label: Paragraph

text: Today, they may still be regarded as viable strategies with
label: Paragraph

text: which to resist the reduction of the man-made world to a
label: Paragraph

text: limitless diffusion of ill-related, freestanding objects, as
label: Paragraph

text: alienated from the needs of humans as from the processes
label: Paragraph

text: of nature.
label: Paragraph

text: To advance territorial modification as the basis of a new
label: Paragraph

text: cultural discipline is to accord a compensatory status not
label: Paragraph

text: only to the art of landscape but also to built work
label: Paragraph

text: formulated as if it were a landscape in itself or,
label: Paragraph

text: alternatively, an object so integrated into the ground as to
label: Paragraph

text: be inseparable from the surrounding topography. It is just
label: Paragraph

text: such a reconception of the scope of landscape that currently
label: Paragraph

text: favours the emergence of the new subdiscipline of
label: Paragraph

text: landscape urbanism, conceived as a mode of intervention
label: Paragraph

text: with a totally different strategic aim from the now largely
label: Paragraph

text: discredited practice of master planning. The American
label: Caption

text: landscape architect Peter Walker was able to demonstrate
label: Paragraph

text: this in an exemplary way in his 324-hectare (800-acre)
label: Paragraph

text: layout for the IBM Campus in Solana, west Texas (1992)
label: Caption

text: [787], realized in collaboration with the architects Romaldo
label: Caption

text: Giurgola, Ricardo Legorreta and Barton Myers. Walker
label: Caption

text: characterized the reparatory scope of his intervention in the
label: Paragraph

text: following terms:
label: Title

text: 787 Walker, IBM Campus, Solana, Texas, 1992.
label: Caption

text: When we found the site, it was not a particularly rich
label: Paragraph

text: meadow. It had been grazed very heavily and over half the
label: Paragraph

text: topsoil had been lost. There were a few handsome trees that
label: Paragraph

text: stood up to the grazing and somehow survived ... To repair
label: Paragraph

text: the rest of it, we took the topsoil off of every single road,
label: Paragraph

text: building, or parking lot site, stockpiled it, and put it on the
label: Paragraph

text: meadow, thereby doubling the amount of topsoil.2
label: Paragraph

text: Walker pursued an equally large-scale topographic
label: Paragraph

text: transformation in his Marina Linear Park, San Diego,
label: Caption

text: California (1988), designed with Martha Schwartz, where the
label: Paragraph

text: right of way of an existing light rail system was converted
label: Paragraph

text: into an exotic subtropical park. Comparable infrastructural
label: Paragraph

text: landscape interventions have been standard policy in
label: Paragraph

text: France, where one third of the state budget allocated to
label: Paragraph

text: either regional high-speed transit or local light rail has been
label: Paragraph

text: given over to the design of landscape settings that are
label: Paragraph

text: capable of integrating new infrastructure into the existing
label: Paragraph

text: topography. Michel Desvigne and Christine Dalnoky’s
label: Caption

text: implantation of a new TGV station outside Avignon in 1995
label: Paragraph

text: is typical in this regard, as are numerous other works
label: Paragraph

text: executed by them in relation to public transit. In Avignon,
label: Paragraph

text: plane trees were employed to reinforce the linear extent of
label: Paragraph

text: the station, while the adjacent parking lots were shaded by
label: Paragraph

text: rows of lime trees selected for their resemblance to the
label: Paragraph

text: orchards of the surrounding apple-growing region, thereby
label: Paragraph

text: integrating the station into the character of the existing
label: Paragraph

text: landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the popular success of both the American
label: Paragraph

text: parkway and the German Autobahn in the 1930s, the
label: Paragraph

text: universal expansion of autoroutes over the last half-century
label: Paragraph

text: has not always been accompanied by environmental design
label: Paragraph

text: of a comparable quality. An exception to this in Europe is the
label: Paragraph

text: concrete viaducts and tunnel entrances that the Swiss
label: Paragraph

text: architect Rino Tami designed for the Ticinese motorway
label: Caption

text: extending from the St Gotthard Tunnel in the Alps to the
label: Paragraph

text: Italian frontier at Chiasso - a large-scale infrastructure
label: Paragraph

text: realized over a twenty-year period between 1963 and 1983.
label: Paragraph

text: More recent, and of more limited scope, are interventions
label: Paragraph

text: such as Bernard Lassus’s somewhat exotic autoscapes in
label: Paragraph

text: north-western France.
label: Paragraph

text: A comparable awareness of the impact of the automobile
label: Paragraph

text: was evident in the early bridges of Santiago Calatrava, with
label: Paragraph

text: which he demonstrated that he was as much concerned
label: Paragraph

text: with the urban footprint of his bridges as with their
label: Paragraph

text: structural articulation. This was especially true of his Bach
label: Paragraph

text: de Roda bridge, built just outside Barcelona in 1987, in
label: Paragraph

text: which the four coupled pairs of bowspring arches in
label: Paragraph

text: concrete and steel carried the roadbed and also provided for
label: Paragraph

text: pedestrian viewing platforms on either side of the span.
label: Caption

text: Both the bridge and the axiality of the railway that it
label: Paragraph

text: traversed were mutually enhanced by pocket parks that the
label: Paragraph

text: engineer established on either side of the cutting. As part of
label: Paragraph

text: the bridge abutment, pairs of concrete stairs at either end
label: Caption

text: of the span provided direct access to these parks from the
label: Paragraph

text: bridge. It is significant from both a cultural and an
label: Paragraph

text: environmental standpoint that the pedestrian footpaths
label: Paragraph

text: were elevated above the roadbed so that a person crossing
label: Paragraph

text: the bridge could see over traffic to the landscape on either
label: Paragraph

text: side. Moreover, the provision of such panoramic views was
label: Paragraph

text: combined with raising the pedestrian above the level of the
label: Paragraph

text: exhaust fumes.
label: Paragraph

text: The cultivation of landscape as a matter of ecological
label: Paragraph

text: policy at a regional scale has become almost second nature
label: Paragraph

text: in Germany, where the extension of Peter Latz’s Emscher
label: Paragraph

text: Park, which started as a demonstration project for the
label: Paragraph

text: detoxification and reuse of obsolete industrial plants, has
label: Paragraph

text: evolved to become a recreational area stretching some 70
label: Paragraph

text: kilometres (43 miles) on either side of the Emscher River
label: Paragraph

text: near the Ruhr Valley. It is significant that Karl Ganser, one of
label: Paragraph

text: the main architects of the Emscher reclamation programme,
label: Paragraph

text: would come to regard the universal megalopolis as another
label: Paragraph

text: ‘brownfield’ site in the making, one that will prove to be
label: Paragraph

text: even more resistant to future decontamination and adaptive
label: Paragraph

text: reuse.
label: Paragraph

text: As in much of Alvar Aalto’s architecture, large and
label: Paragraph

text: complex buildings may be rendered as though they were
label: Paragraph

text: natural extensions of the topography in which they are
label: Paragraph

text: situated. This paradigm was surely the primary motivation
label: Paragraph

text: behind Arthur Erickson’s Robson Square development,
label: Paragraph

text: Vancouver (1983), wherein a megaform comprising law
label: Paragraph

text: courts and municipal offices was integrated with a parking
label: Paragraph

text: garage in such a way as to assume the profile of a stepped
label: Paragraph

text: escarpment.
label: Paragraph

text: A more modestly scaled megaform was realized in
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona, in the form of the L’Illa complex [788, 789],
label: Paragraph

text: completed on the Avenida Diagonal in 1992 to the designs
label: Paragraph

text: of José Rafael Moneo and Manuel de Sola-Morales. This
label: Paragraph

text: block, 800 metres (2,600 feet) in length, houses a five-
label: Paragraph

text: storey shopping mall in addition to commercial frontage on
label: Paragraph

text: the avenue itself, and accommodates offices and a hotel as
label: Paragraph

text: an integral part of the medium-rise slab. Built at the edge of
label: Paragraph

text: Cerda’s original Eixample and served by a multistorey
label: Paragraph

text: subterranean car park running the entire length of the
label: Paragraph

text: complex, the block was designed to respond to the scale of
label: Paragraph

text: both the existing 19th-century urban grid and the random,
label: Paragraph

text: ad hoc suburban development surrounding the historic core
label: Title

text: of the city. The stepped profile of this building enabled it to
label: Paragraph

text: be read as a prominent landmark, particularly when seen
label: Paragraph

text: from the inner suburban high ground overlooking the city.
label: Paragraph

text: This megadevelopment effectively demonstrated Sola-
label: Paragraph

text: Morales’ concept of urban acupuncture - namely a
label: Paragraph

text: strategically limited urban intervention, programmed and
label: Paragraph

text: conceived in such a way as to augment an existing urban
label: Paragraph

text: condition in a defined but open-ended manner.
label: Paragraph

text: 788 Moneo and Sola-Morales, L'Illa complex, Barcelona, 1992. Panoramic view.
label: Caption

text: 789 Moneo and Sola-Morales, L’Illa complex, Barcelona, 1992. Transverse
label: Caption

text: section through galleria.
label: Paragraph

text: Urban acupuncture was also a term adopted by the
label: Paragraph

text: Brazilian architect-politician Jaime Lerner in order to
label: Paragraph

text: introduce an efficient public transit system into the city of
label: Paragraph

text: Curitiba during his tenure as mayor between 1971 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1992. Among the most innovative aspects of this system are
label: Paragraph

text: the use of doubly articulated 100-seat buses, and elevated,
label: Paragraph

text: totally glazed boarding-tubes that facilitate the efficient
label: Paragraph

text: boarding of such vehicles at each stop. Today this network
label: Paragraph

text: comprises 72 kilometres (45 miles) of designated bus lanes
label: Paragraph

text: plus numerous other feeder lines. Over the same twenty-
label: Paragraph

text: year period, Lerner was also able to introduce many other
label: Paragraph

text: socially beneficial services in the areas of public health,
label: Paragraph

text: education, food distribution and waste management. At the
label: Paragraph

text: same time, despite the city’s population having tripled, the
label: Paragraph

text: administration was able to achieve a hundred-fold increase
label: Paragraph

text: in the amount of green space per capita: a provision of 52
label: Paragraph

text: square metres (560 square feet) per person, in the form of
label: Paragraph

text: an extensive network of parks running through the city. This
label: Paragraph

text: general upgrading of public facilities, accompanied by the
label: Paragraph

text: introduction of a high-speed bus system, was replicated in
label: Paragraph

text: Bogota, Colombia, during the successive political
label: Paragraph

text: leaderships of Enrique Penalosa and Antanas Mockus.
label: Paragraph

text: Megaforms conceived as cities-in-miniature may also be
label: Paragraph

text: used to emphasize the structure of existing topography and
label: Paragraph

text: to establish identifiable places. The Mexican architect
label: Paragraph

text: Ricardo Legorreta has demonstrated this approach on a
label: Paragraph

text: number of occasions, from the stepped formation of his
label: Paragraph

text: Camino Real Hotel overlooking the beach in Ixtapa (1981) to
label: Caption

text: the Renault assembly plant that he realized as an ochre-
label: Paragraph

text: coloured, virtually windowless horizontal form in the arid
label: Paragraph

text: landscape of Gémez Palacio, Durango, in 1985. Similar
label: Caption

text: large-scale megaforms set against dramatic topographies
label: Paragraph

text: can be found in a great deal of Latin American work, from
label: Paragraph

text: Lina Bo Bardi’s bridge-like Museum of Modern Art,
label: Paragraph

text: completed for the centre of Sao Paulo in 1968, to the even
label: Paragraph

text: more dramatic 108-room linear dormitory block and
label: Caption

text: astronomical research centre realized by the German
label: Paragraph

text: architects Auer and Weber in 2001. Cutting across the
label: Paragraph

text: Atacama desert in Cerro Paranal, Chile, it constitutes a
label: Paragraph

text: latterday testament to Gregotti’s thesis that architecture
label: Paragraph

text: begins with the marking of ground.
label: Paragraph

text: A propensity for landscape with an urban character is
label: Paragraph

text: evident in the architecture of Enric Miralles and Carme
label: Paragraph

text: Pinéds, who came into their own with two brilliant
label: Paragraph

text: competition designs of the late 1980s: an archery complex
label: Title

text: destined for the Barcelona Olympics of 1992, and a proposal
label: Paragraph

text: for transforming a disused quarry in the nearby town of
label: Paragraph

text: Igualada into a cemetery [790]. The former design, inspired
label: Paragraph

text: by Gaudi and the structurally rationalist precepts of Viollet-
label: Paragraph

text: le-Duc, demonstrated a newfound capacity for folded-plate
label: Paragraph

text: construction in concrete, ingeniously supported by tubular-
label: Paragraph

text: steel columns. The result was legible both as undulating
label: Paragraph

text: roofwork and as a Surrogate landscape. In Igualada, with
label: Paragraph

text: similar ingenuity, the architects were able to exploit the
label: Paragraph

text: quarry’s jn situ concrete retaining walls as the armature for
label: Paragraph

text: an inclined prefabricated columbarium. Elsewhere, in the
label: Caption

text: lower part of the quarry, serpentine retaining walls of
label: Caption

text: gabion stonework formed embankments housing private
label: Caption

text: mausolea. In sum, the entire cemetery was subject to a
label: Paragraph

text: highly differentiated tactile aesthetic, from the Corten steel
label: Paragraph

text: sliding doors that secured the mausolea to disused rail ties,
label: Paragraph

text: set in a weak mix of cement and gravel and scattered
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the ramped floor of the necropolis.
label: Caption

text: 790 Miralles and Pinds, lgualada Cemetery, near Barcelona, 1994.
label: Caption

text: An increasing number of architects have displayed a
label: Paragraph

text: particularly refined sensitivity towards the integration of
label: Paragraph

text: landscape with built form, among them the American
label: Paragraph

text: architect Rick Joy, whose Tyler House, near Tubac (2000)
label: Caption

text: [791], was laid into a gently sloping site in the southern
label: Paragraph

text: Arizona desert. There, set before a distant mountain range
label: Paragraph

text: and accompanied by a small cactus garden, the house
label: Paragraph

text: comprises two single-storey enclosures roofed and faced in
label: Paragraph

text: Corten steel, their orthogonal masses converging on a
label: Paragraph

text: common terrace and a swimming pool. The coarseness of
label: Paragraph

text: the rough steel exterior contrasts with the refinement of the
label: Paragraph

text: interior palette of white plaster, stainless steel, maple and
label: Caption

text: translucent glass. This juxtaposition of materials owes
label: Paragraph

text: something to the tactile materiality of Will Bruder’s Phoenix
label: Paragraph

text: Public Library (1995), on which Joy collaborated as an
label: Paragraph

text: assistant.
label: Paragraph

text: 791 Joy, Tyler House, near Tubac, Arizona, 2000. Entry court.
label: Caption

text: Peter Eisenman’s enigmatic Memorial to the Murdered
label: Title

text: Jews of Europe [792], realized in the centre of Berlin in
label: Paragraph

text: 2005, is essentially an artificial topography, consisting of a
label: Paragraph

text: field of 2,511 concrete slabs, set 95 centimetres (37%
label: Paragraph

text: inches) apart in such a way that no more than one person at
label: Paragraph

text: a time can pass comfortably between them. Varying
label: Paragraph

text: unevenly in height, these stelae assume the form of a
label: Paragraph

text: gently undulating wave that responds to the fall of the land
label: Paragraph

text: from one end of the memorial to the other. Save for a
label: Caption

text: subterranean visitors’ centre, there is no representational
label: Paragraph

text: element of any kind.
label: Paragraph

text: 792 Eisenman, Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe, Berlin, 2005.
label: Caption

text: Between the topographic, which pertains to the contours
label: Paragraph

text: of the Earth’s surface, and the morphological, which
label: Paragraph

text: seemingly emulates the structure of biological and botanical
label: Paragraph

text: form, there exists a plastic affinity that has been of
label: Paragraph

text: consequence for architecture ever since the Baroque period.
label: Paragraph

text: The fact that the primary reference tends to be natural
label: Paragraph

text: rather than cultural is evinced in the amorphous, tentacular
label: Paragraph

text: shape of Frank Gehry’s Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao.
label: Caption

text: Apart from any allusion that this distorted ‘hull’ might make
label: Paragraph

text: to the pre-existing shipyards, it is obvious that its
label: Paragraph

text: exceptionally fluid shape, along with its seductive titanium
label: Paragraph

text: skin, exists quite independently of anything that takes place
label: Paragraph

text: within its interior. In other words, notwithstanding its organic
label: Paragraph

text: shape, it is paradoxically removed from any kind of
label: Paragraph

text: interstitial biomorphic organization that is potentially as
label: Paragraph

text: much a formative presence in architecture as it is in nature.
label: Paragraph

text: All of this is apparent from the disjunctive, inelegant
label: Paragraph

text: conditions that this shape engenders, from the perverse,
label: Paragraph

text: inconvenient system of pedestrian circulation that leads
label: Paragraph

text: from the river walk to the main entrance, to the total
label: Paragraph

text: indifference the building displays towards the topographic
label: Paragraph

text: context in which it is situated. We may count among its
label: Paragraph

text: infelicities not only the ill-proportioned top-lit galleries, but
label: Paragraph

text: also the uneconomic and inelegant steel frame that was
label: Paragraph

text: devised to prop up the extravagant configuration of the
label: Paragraph

text: skin. Thus an unbridgeable gulf separates the emptiness of
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s Bilbao from the organic interdependence of the
label: Paragraph

text: interior and exterior, that is the Organwerk versus the
label: Paragraph

text: Gestaltwerk, as Hugo Haring termed this symbiotic
label: Paragraph

text: relationship in his Gut Garkau farm of 1924.
label: Paragraph

text: Morphology
label: Title

text: One encounters this syndrome not only in the architecture
label: Paragraph

text: of Gehry, but also in the work of many other contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: architects, ranging from Ben van Berkel and Lars Spuybroek
label: Paragraph

text: in the Netherlands to Daniel Libeskind, Greg Lynn and Hani
label: Paragraph

text: Rashid in the United States, and the London-based practice
label: Paragraph

text: of the Iraqi architect Zaha Hadid, whose unique talent first
label: Paragraph

text: came to the fore with her winning entry for the Hong Kong
label: Paragraph

text: Peak competition of 1983. A decade later Hadid would
label: Paragraph

text: translate the dynamic manner of her multicoloured Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Suprematist graphics into an exceptionally plastic but rather
label: Paragraph

text: unfunctional reinforced-concrete fire station, which
label: Paragraph

text: nonetheless assumed its rhetorical place as one more ‘star’
label: Paragraph

text: architect folly within Rolf Fehlbaum’s Vitra industrial estate
label: Caption

text: in Weil am Rhein.
label: Caption

text: As preoccupied with sculptural shape as Gehry, Hadid’s
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was at its best when produced on a small scale
label: Paragraph

text: or when a horizontal, topographic dimension takes
label: Paragraph

text: precedence over the sculptural, as in the transport
label: Paragraph

text: interchange that she built on the outskirts of Strasbourg in
label: Paragraph

text: 2001 [793]. This exceptionally sensitive work was
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned by a local authority as a measure to reduce
label: Paragraph

text: city-centre traffic and pollution by encouraging commuters
label: Paragraph

text: to park their cars on the periphery and continue their
label: Paragraph

text: journey into the city by light rail. Here, well-engineered
label: Paragraph

text: access roads are combined with the trajectory of a rail link
label: Paragraph

text: and the sweeping pattern of parked cars to create a three-
label: Paragraph

text: dimensional megalopolitan set-piece that is as poetic as it is
label: Paragraph

text: efficient.
label: Paragraph

text: 793 Hadid, Car Park and Terminal, Hoenheim-Nord, Strasbourg, 2001.
label: Caption

text: The main theoretician of the morphological as an end in
label: Paragraph

text: itself has been the architect Greg Lynn, whose writings have
label: Paragraph

text: appeared in two successive publications, Folds, Bodies and
label: Paragraph

text: Blobs of 1998 and Animate Form of 1999. As far as
label: Paragraph

text: architecture is concerned, certain unavoidable problems
label: Paragraph

text: arise with this kind of analogical reasoning - not only the
label: Paragraph

text: dubious stratagem of positing the metabolic processes of
label: Paragraph

text: nature as the basis of a new architecture, but also the
label: Paragraph

text: implicit repudiation of building culture as it has emerged
label: Paragraph

text: overtime as a pragmatic response to the constraints of
label: Paragraph

text: climate, topography and available material, not to mention
label: Paragraph

text: those implacable forces of nature such as gravity and
label: Paragraph

text: climate that always tend to undermine the durability of
label: Paragraph

text: man-made form.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike Lynn’s biomorphic approach, the London-based
label: Paragraph

text: practice of Foreign Office Architects (FOA), led by Alejandro
label: Paragraph

text: Zaera Polo and Farshid Moussavi, developed their own
label: Paragraph

text: pragmatic design method for their Yokohama International
label: Paragraph

text: Port Terminal (2002) [794] on the basis of a topological
label: Paragraph

text: interplay between earthwork and roofwork. In an account of
label: Paragraph

text: their first seven years of practice, entitled Phylogenesis:
label: Paragraph

text: FOA’s Ark (2003), they write:
label: Paragraph

text: 794 Zaera Polo and Moussavi (Foreign Office Architects), Yokohama International
label: Caption

text: Port Terminal, 2002.
label: Caption
