text: The Yokohama project started from the possibility of
label: Paragraph

text: generating organization from a circulation pattern, as a
label: Paragraph

text: development of the idea of a hybridization between a shed -
label: Paragraph

text: a more or less undetermined container - and a ground...
label: Paragraph

text: Our first move was to set the circulation diagram as a
label: Paragraph

text: structure of interlaced loops that allow for multiple return
label: Paragraph

text: paths... .
label: Paragraph

text: The second decision in the process was that the building
label: Paragraph

text: should not appear on the skyline, to be consistent with the
label: Paragraph

text: idea of not making a gate on a semantic level as well, by
label: Paragraph

text: avoiding the building becoming a sign. This immediately led
label: Paragraph

text: to the idea of making a very flat building, and from there we
label: Paragraph

text: moved into turning the building into a ground. Once we
label: Paragraph

text: decided that the building would be a warped surface, we
label: Paragraph

text: sought to produce an argument of consistency between the
label: Paragraph

text: no-return diagram and the surface ... To spread the building
label: Paragraph

text: mass as thin as possible, we occupied the maximum area
label: Paragraph

text: possible within the site. This and the requirement of placing
label: Paragraph

text: straight boarding decks 15m from the pier’s edge along
label: Paragraph

text: both sides of the building to connect to moving bridges is
label: Paragraph

text: what determined the rectangular footprint of the building ...
label: Paragraph

text: The next decision was how to make the form structural. The
label: Paragraph

text: obvious solution of supporting the surfaces with columns
label: Paragraph

text: was not consistent with the aim to produce space and
label: Paragraph

text: organization literally out of the circulatory diagram, and a
label: Paragraph

text: more interesting possibility was to try to develop a
label: Paragraph

text: structural system out of the warped surface.?
label: Paragraph

text: As far as the contemporary pursuit of a morphological
label: Paragraph

text: architecture is concerned, what puts the Yokohama terminal
label: Paragraph

text: in a class of its own is the way in which a constantly warping
label: Paragraph

text: complex of inclined roofs, ramps and open-air promenades
label: Caption

text: is generated out of faceted bifurcating planes held in place
label: Paragraph

text: by a geometrically coherent steel-framed superstructure.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike almost all of the morphological works cited above,
label: Paragraph

text: this superstructure provides not only for the spatial
label: Paragraph

text: articulation of the interior, but also for the
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenological character of the work, including, in this
label: Paragraph

text: instance, a large passenger-transit hall covered by wide-
label: Paragraph

text: span, folded-plate roofs in sheet steel.
label: Paragraph

text: The method by which FOA were able to generate and
label: Paragraph

text: realize this complex work led them to appropriate the
label: Paragraph

text: concept of phylogenesis as a transformable ‘evolutionary’
label: Paragraph

text: system, with which they were able to approach a wide
label: Paragraph

text: spectrum of programmes in an equally diverse range of
label: Paragraph

text: sites and climatic conditions. What is evoked by the term
label: Paragraph

text: ‘phylogenesis’ is an aspiration towards the postulation of an
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate geometrical scheme rather than the selection of
label: Paragraph

text: an arbitrary shape. Thus the work of FOA was distinguished
label: Paragraph

text: by the fact that each new commission, together with its
label: Paragraph

text: topographic context, was used not only to engender a
label: Paragraph

text: different parti but also to imagine mathematically distinct
label: Paragraph

text: spatiotectonic networks, so that the received programme
label: Paragraph

text: was invariably transformed through an unforeseen
label: Paragraph

text: geometrical format that, however much it may have been
label: Paragraph

text: derived from typological precedent, was equally likely to
label: Paragraph

text: have been conditioned by the morphology of the site. In the
label: Paragraph

text: case of the Yokohama terminal, the tectonic play between
label: Paragraph

text: earthwork and roofwork is so symbiotic as to become a
label: Paragraph

text: multilayered topography, rising and falling along the length
label: Paragraph

text: of the pier. This undulation tends to confirm the fact that it
label: Paragraph

text: is the superstructure rather than the earthwork that lends
label: Paragraph

text: itself most readily to being treated as a topological surface.
label: Paragraph

text: A comparable topological ethos characterizes the glazed,
label: Paragraph

text: undulating canopy that runs down the circulation spine of
label: Paragraph

text: the Fiera di Milano complex [795], built outside Milan in
label: Paragraph

text: 2005 to the designs of Massimiliano Fuksas. A large-span
label: Caption

text: glazed roof of slightly varying profile in section also covers
label: Paragraph

text: Nicholas Grimshaw’s former Eurostar Terminal [796], added
label: Paragraph

text: to Waterloo Station in London in 1993. In this instance the
label: Paragraph

text: sectional variation is a direct consequence of the changing
label: Paragraph

text: configuration of the site in plan. In this context one should
label: Paragraph

text: also remember the trope of the crustacean glass roof as it
label: Paragraph

text: was variously pursued by Austrian architects during the
label: Paragraph

text: 1980s and 1990s; examples are the crystalline penthouse
label: Paragraph

text: that Coop Himmelblau planted on top of a traditional Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Classical building in the centre of Vienna in 1981-89, and
label: Paragraph

text: the dynamic structural profile of Volker Giencke’s
label: Paragraph

text: greenhouse erected in the botanical gardens of Graz in
label: Caption

text: 795 Fuksas, Fiera di Milano, Milan, 2005. Aerial view of the galleria linking the
label: Caption

text: exhibition halls.
label: Paragraph

text: 796 Grimshaw, Eurostar Terminal, Waterloo Station, London, 1993. Transverse
label: Caption

text: section.
label: Paragraph

text: Sustainability
label: Title

text: In his study Ten Shades of Green: Architecture and the
label: Paragraph

text: Natural World (2000-05), Peter Buchanan supplements his
label: Paragraph

text: descriptive analysis of ten exemplary green buildings with
label: Paragraph

text: ten precepts that cover a wide spectrum of sustainable
label: Paragraph

text: practices, from the optimization of natural shade, light and
label: Paragraph

text: ventilation to the use of renewable sources of natural
label: Title

text: energy; from the elimination of waste and pollution to the
label: Paragraph

text: reduction of the amount of energy embodied in the
label: Paragraph

text: construction materials themselves. Buchanan writes:
label: Paragraph

text: The common building material with the least embodied
label: Paragraph

text: energy is wood, with about 640 kilowatt-hours per ton...
label: Paragraph

text: Hence the greenest building material is wood from
label: Paragraph

text: sustainably managed forests. Brick is the material with the
label: Paragraph

text: next lowest amount of embodied energy, 4 times (X) that of
label: Paragraph

text: wood, then concrete (5X), plastic (6X), glass (14X), steel
label: Paragraph

text: (24X), aluminum (126xX). A building with a high proportion of
label: Paragraph

text: aluminum components can hardly be green when
label: Paragraph

text: considered from the perspective of total life cycle costing,
label: Paragraph

text: no matter how energy-efficient it might be.*
label: Paragraph

text: Statistics such as these should certainly give us pause for
label: Paragraph

text: thought, including the sobering fact that the built
label: Paragraph

text: environment accounts for some 40 per cent of total energy
label: Paragraph

text: consumption in the developed world, comparable to what is
label: Paragraph

text: consumed by road and jet travel. Much of this profligate use
label: Paragraph

text: is due to artificial lighting, which swallows up some 65 per
label: Paragraph

text: cent of our total consumption of electricity, with air
label: Paragraph

text: conditioning and digital equipment coming a close second.
label: Paragraph

text: It is equally sobering that a large part of any contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: land-fill is invariably made up of building waste: it accounts
label: Paragraph

text: for some 33 per cent of the average municipal waste stream
label: Paragraph

text: in the United States.
label: Paragraph

text: In the face of these dystopic statistics, Buchanan’s
label: Paragraph

text: recommendations have a markedly cultural character, such
label: Paragraph

text: as his advocacy of building according to the anti-ergonomic
label: Paragraph

text: principle of ‘long life/loose fit’. This precept was naturally
label: Paragraph

text: integral to the load-bearing masonry structures of the past,
label: Paragraph

text: bequeathing us a legacy of eminently adaptable buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: mostly dating from the 18th and 19th centuries, many of
label: Paragraph

text: which we have been able to put to new uses. Such residual
label: Paragraph

text: value is more difficult to achieve today on account of our
label: Paragraph

text: standards of minimal space and our commitment to the
label: Title

text: paradoxically inflexible lightweight building techniques of
label: Paragraph

text: our time.
label: Paragraph

text: Buchanan insists that every building should be closely
label: Paragraph

text: integrated into its context. He therefore urges architects to
label: Paragraph

text: pay as much attention to such factors as microclimate,
label: Paragraph

text: topography and vegetation as to the more familiar
label: Paragraph

text: functional and formal concerns addressed in standard
label: Title

text: practice. Exemplary in this regard is Renzo Piano’s Jean-
label: Paragraph

text: Marie Tjibaou Cultural Centre [797], built in Noumea, New
label: Caption

text: Caledonia, in 1998, where the so-called laminated timber
label: Paragraph

text: ‘cases’, 20 to 30 metres (65 to 88 feet) in height, refer, at a
label: Paragraph

text: giant scale, to the traditional Kanak hut. These cases are
label: Paragraph

text: capped halfway up by sloping roofs that are either solid or
label: Paragraph

text: glazed according to the function of the spaces beneath,
label: Paragraph

text: which range from meeting halls to exhibition spaces and
label: Paragraph

text: dance studios. The inclined roofs are framed and stiffened
label: Paragraph

text: by steel rings, and, where glazed, are covered by a layer of
label: Paragraph

text: external louvres. The remainder of the complex consists of a
label: Caption

text: single-storey orthogonal structure, housing exhibition space,
label: Caption

text: administration and research offices, and a 400-seat lecture
label: Paragraph

text: hall. Informally arranged along one side of this mat-building,
label: Paragraph

text: the timber cases evoke through their spire-like forms of
label: Paragraph

text: varying height the profile of a traditional Kanak village.
label: Paragraph

text: While this allusion was endorsed by the Kanak themselves,
label: Paragraph

text: one can hardly overlook the post-colonial context of this
label: Paragraph

text: work - above all the paradoxical fact that, funded by the
label: Paragraph

text: French state, it stands as a memorial to the Kanak freedom
label: Paragraph

text: fighter Tjibaou.
label: Paragraph

text: 797 Piano, Jean-Marie Tjibaou Cultural Centre, Noumea, New Caledonia, 1998.
label: Caption

text: The timber ‘cases’ simulate the profile of the traditional Kanak hut.
label: Paragraph

text: Buchanan’s eighth precept stresses the crucial role to be
label: Paragraph

text: played by public transport in sustaining the ecological
label: Paragraph

text: balance of any particular land settlement pattern, since
label: Paragraph

text: urban sprawl, no matter how green it might be in itself, can
label: Paragraph

text: hardly outweigh the energy consumed in the daily commute
label: Paragraph

text: by automobile between home and work and its
label: Paragraph

text: accompanying environmental pollution. In opposing this
label: Paragraph

text: entropic prospect, Buchanan stresses the benefits to public
label: Paragraph

text: health that derive from dense urban form that is well served
label: Paragraph

text: by public transport and thus sustainable in the wider sense
label: Paragraph

text: of the term.
label: Paragraph

text: An entirely different stratagem towards sustainability is
label: Paragraph

text: evident in the forty-five-storey Commerzbank [798, 799],
label: Paragraph

text: realized by Foster Associates in Frankfurt in 1997, structured
label: Paragraph

text: around an atrium rising for the full height of the building,
label: Paragraph

text: with four-storey-high sky-gardens alternating from one side
label: Paragraph

text: of the atrium to the other to admit light and air into the
label: Paragraph

text: central shaft. The Commerzbank is also clad in double
label: Paragraph

text: glazing throughout. Here, the outer skin serves to buffer the
label: Paragraph

text: wind and weather, so that the manually operated lights of
label: Paragraph

text: the inner skin may be opened at will to ventilate the offices.
label: Paragraph

text: The building is automatically sealed and air-conditioned only
label: Paragraph

text: when the climate is extremely hot or cold. The design’s
label: Paragraph

text: most radical spatio-social innovation turns on the
label: Paragraph

text: displacement of the service core to the apices of the
label: Paragraph

text: triangular plan, thereby affording visual access across the
label: Paragraph

text: atrium to the elevated sky gardens and vice versa. These
label: Paragraph

text: garden terraces not only serve to ventilate the atrium but
label: Paragraph

text: also to provide an interim semi-public breakout space.
label: Paragraph

text: Adjustable glass dampers span the atrium at the level of
label: Paragraph

text: every twelve floors in order to modulate the Venturi effect of
label: Paragraph

text: air movement within the central shaft.
label: Paragraph

text: 798 Foster Associates, Commerzbank, Frankfurt, 1997. Section showing air
label: Caption

text: movement through the atrium.
label: Paragraph

text: 799 Foster Associates, Commerzbank, Frankfurt, 1997. Sketch of a typical view
label: Caption

text: across the offices into the ‘sky-gardens’.
label: Paragraph

text: In the United States, where 5 per cent of the world’s
label: Paragraph

text: population consumes 24 per cent of the world’s energy,
label: Paragraph

text: there has been a tendency to deny the reality of global
label: Paragraph

text: warming and to continue with the maximized consumption
label: Paragraph

text: of non-renewable energy. This denial is evident in the
label: Paragraph

text: reluctance of the American government to enforce
label: Title

text: progressive environmental regulations as a standard mode
label: Title

text: of practice, an obtuseness that has sometimes been
label: Paragraph

text: welcomed by architects on the grounds that sustainable
label: Paragraph

text: design curbs their freedom of expression. Such an attitude
label: Paragraph

text: is as reactionary as it is perverse, given that responding
label: Paragraph

text: symbiotically to the exigencies of both climate and context
label: Paragraph

text: has invariably served as a mainspring for tectonic invention
label: Paragraph

text: since time immemorable. Equally sustainable - given our
label: Paragraph

text: proliferating of building waste through wanton destruction -
label: Paragraph

text: is, as Buchanan implies, the potential for conservation,
label: Paragraph

text: conversion, repair and reuse of existing buildings. This is
label: Paragraph

text: exemplified by the brilliant restoration, expansion and
label: Paragraph

text: refurbishment in 2012 of Astley Castle, Nuneaton,
label: Caption

text: Warwickshire, UK, by the architects Witherford Watson
label: Caption

text: Mann, for which they were awarded the Stirling Prize in
label: Paragraph

text: Materiality
label: Title

text: Unlike the ubiquitous white architecture of the early Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement, when buildings were invariably rendered in
label: Paragraph

text: cement over a light skeleton frame and treated as though
label: Paragraph

text: they were made of a neutral material verging on the
label: Paragraph

text: immaterial (a condition that was virtually achieved after
label: Paragraph

text: 1945 with the ubiquitous, totally glazed Miesian office
label: Paragraph

text: building), the expressive materiality to which this section
label: Paragraph

text: alludes has at least some of its origins in the load-bearing
label: Paragraph

text: brick churches that the Swedish master Sigurd Lewerentz
label: Caption

text: designed during the last two decades of his life: St Mark’s in
label: Caption

text: Bjorkhagen (1958-60) and St Peter’s, Klippan (1963-66). No
label: Caption

text: one has written more perceptively of the expressive role
label: Paragraph

text: played by brick in these works than Richard Weston:
label: Paragraph

text: the sense of containment by bricks is overwhelming. You
label: Paragraph

text: walk on brick floors, between walls of brick, beneath brick
label: Paragraph

text: vaults, which span between steel joists, swelling gently like
label: Paragraph

text: ocean waves ... what photographs cannot convey is the
label: Paragraph

text: almost preternatural darkness, which binds the fabric into
label: Paragraph

text: an all-enveloping unity.°
label: Paragraph

text: Among the most accomplished practitioners of this
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on material have been the Swiss-German
label: Paragraph

text: minimalists Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron, beginning
label: Paragraph

text: with their holiday house in Tavole, Italy (1988), in which
label: Paragraph

text: stones from the site were loosely packed into a delicate
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete frame, and their Ricola Warehouse in
label: Paragraph

text: Laufen, Switzerland (1987), which, set before the cliff-face
label: Paragraph

text: of a disused quarry, was faced by way of contrast with fibre-
label: Paragraph

text: cement planks of varying depth. The simple spatial
label: Paragraph

text: requirements in each instance enabled the architects to
label: Paragraph

text: treat the material as the primary aesthetic presence in
label: Paragraph

text: contrast to the rather passive character of the space-form.
label: Paragraph

text: This emphasis on the tactile character of material would
label: Paragraph

text: henceforth become the hallmark of their practice, a mode
label: Paragraph

text: that invariably has been at its most effective in small and
label: Paragraph

text: Spatially unified commissions, from their copper-sheathed
label: Paragraph

text: six-storey signal tower in Basel (1995) to their Dominus
label: Caption

text: Winery [800], in Yountville, California, of 1997, a simple
label: Paragraph

text: single-storey masonry enclosure made out of granite rocks
label: Caption

text: of varying size held in place by wire mesh. This highly
label: Paragraph

text: aestheticized approach, with its tendency to emphasize the
label: Paragraph

text: external surface rather than the internal structure or space,
label: Paragraph

text: has since become an increasingly decorative aspect of their
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: 800 Herzog and de Meuron, Dominus Winery, Yountville, California, 1997.
label: Caption

text: Gabion construction in granite.
label: Paragraph

text: Peter Zumthor, practising out of Haldenstein in the
label: Paragraph

text: Graubtinden, is the other leading Swiss-German minimalist
label: Paragraph

text: architect. He first rose to prominence with his all-timber
label: Paragraph

text: shingle-clad St Benedict Chapel built in Sumvitg in 1988. He
label: Caption

text: would go on to consolidate his emerging craft-based
label: Paragraph

text: reputation with his thermal baths at Vals of 1996, where thin
label: Paragraph

text: layers of precisely cut stone (locally quarried gneiss) were
label: Paragraph

text: used to encase the massive concrete matrix of a
label: Paragraph

text: reconstituted bathing establishment, yielding a sombre yet
label: Paragraph

text: sensuously introspective interior partially hidden within the
label: Paragraph

text: interstices of a rather remote Swiss Alpine village.
label: Paragraph

text: Trained as a cabinetmaker and with years of experience
label: Paragraph

text: in conservation work before beginning to practise as an
label: Paragraph

text: independent architect, Zumthor could hardly be more
label: Paragraph

text: removed from the sceptical aestheticism of Herzog and de
label: Paragraph

text: Meuron, even though he too displays a tendency to favour
label: Paragraph

text: surface effect over either spatial or structural values.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite subtle differences in their approach, both Herzog
label: Paragraph

text: and de Meuron and Zumthor have nonetheless exercised a
label: Paragraph

text: common influence on a whole generation of Swiss
label: Paragraph

text: architects, including, to varying degrees, Diener and Diener,
label: Paragraph

text: Gigon/Guyer, Peter Markli, Marcel Meili and the firm of
label: Paragraph

text: Burckhalter and Sumi. Where the practice of Annette Gigon
label: Paragraph

text: and Mark Guyer is concerned, among their finest work to
label: Paragraph

text: date has been the Kirchner Museum in Davos, Switzerland,
label: Paragraph

text: with which they made their name in 1992. A decade later
label: Paragraph

text: they capped this triumph with an equally tectonic
label: Paragraph

text: archaeological park built in Osnabruck, Germany, to
label: Paragraph

text: commemorate the battle of Varus in AD 9. Both works are
label: Paragraph

text: predicated on the striking use of contrasting materials: fair
label: Paragraph

text: faced concrete with panels of steel-framed translucent glass
label: Caption

text: in the case of the Davos museum, and marine plywood plus
label: Paragraph

text: Corten steel retaining walls in Osnabruck.
label: Caption

text: Swiss-German minimalism would also seem to have
label: Paragraph

text: exercised a certain influence outside the country, notably
label: Paragraph

text: affecting the work of the Dutch architect Wiel Arets, whose
label: Paragraph

text: Maastricht Academy of Art (1989-93) [801] was deftly
label: Paragraph

text: inserted into the historic core of the city. The complex
label: Paragraph

text: configuration of this building consists of a four-storey
label: Paragraph

text: trabeated reinforced-concrete frame filled with glass blocks.
label: Caption

text: 801 Arets, Maastricht Academy of Art, 1989-93.
label: Caption

text: A comparable emphasis on a single all-enveloping
label: Paragraph

text: material also characterizes the work of the Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: architect Kengo Kuma, whose Stone Museum in Nasu in the
label: Paragraph

text: Tochigi Prefecture (2000) is constructed out of narrow bands
label: Paragraph

text: of stone. A very similar emphasis is present in Kuma’s
label: Paragraph

text: stone-faced extension of the Victoria and Albert Museum in
label: Caption

text: Dundee, Scotland, completed in 2016.
label: Caption

text: While a mineral origin is still perceivable in brick, glass,
label: Paragraph

text: concrete and even metal, it is surely undeniable that stone
label: Paragraph

text: and wood display their original in nature with a
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenological intensity that can hardly be rivalled; it is
label: Paragraph

text: this intensity that endows them with a primordial sensibility
label: Paragraph

text: that other building materials lack.
label: Paragraph

text: Timber has also played a remarkable role in recent
label: Paragraph

text: bridge construction, particularly in Switzerland, in the hands
label: Paragraph

text: of such distinguished engineers as Jurg Conzett and Walter
label: Paragraph

text: Bieler - the former for the inverted, cable-tied timber
label: Paragraph

text: trusswork of his Traversina footbridge, erected in 1996
label: Caption

text: across the deep Via Mala ravine in the Graubunden, and the
label: Paragraph

text: latter for a 30-metre (98-foot) laminated straight-timber
label: Paragraph

text: span built across the river Thur at Bonaduz in the same
label: Caption

text: year.
label: Paragraph

text: An additional factor that has completely transformed the
label: Paragraph

text: scope of material expression today is the greatly increased
label: Paragraph

text: ease with which materials can be transported across the
label: Paragraph

text: globe, from their site of origin to the point of their final
label: Paragraph

text: application, with stops for specialized fabrication in
label: Paragraph

text: between. This was already the case with Arata Isozaki’s
label: Paragraph

text: Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, of 1984, which
label: Caption

text: was clad with a red sandstone quarried in India and
label: Paragraph

text: machine-cut in Italy. A similar but even more dramatic
label: Paragraph

text: exercise in global production was the totally glazed
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition pavilion built in the grounds of the Toledo
label: Caption

text: Museum of Art, Ohio, in 2006 to the designs of the Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: architects Kazuyo Sejima and Ryue Nishizawa (SANAA).
label: Paragraph

text: Storey-height sheets of iron-free plate glass were rolled in
label: Paragraph

text: Germany, shipped to China where they were laminated,
label: Paragraph

text: tempered, cut and bent, then transported to the United
label: Paragraph

text: States where, to add insult to injury, they now enclose the
label: Paragraph

text: Toledo Glass Museum in a city which, prior to the deskilling
label: Paragraph

text: of American industry, had been one of the primary centres
label: Paragraph

text: for glass production in North America.
label: Paragraph

text: Habitat
label: Title

text: Our failure to develop a sustainable, homeostatic pattern of
label: Paragraph

text: residential land settlement over the past half-century is the
label: Paragraph

text: tragic corollary of our incapacity to curb our appetite for
label: Paragraph

text: consuming every possible resource. Towards an Urban
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance, pointedly published by the British government
label: Paragraph

text: at the millennium, estimated that 3.8 million new
label: Paragraph

text: households would be required in the UK up to 2025. It
label: Paragraph

text: recommended that two-thirds of these units should be built
label: Paragraph

text: on existing intra-urban detoxified brownfield sites rather
label: Paragraph

text: than be allowed to contribute to the subdivision of formerly
label: Paragraph

text: agricultural greenfield land. A rider to the report published
label: Paragraph

text: in 2005 showed that 70 per cent of then-current British
label: Paragraph

text: development was on brownfield sites, as opposed to 56 per
label: Paragraph

text: cent in 1997.
label: Paragraph

text: Although aspiration to a middle-class way of life tends
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly to be the norm irrespective of class, the
label: Paragraph

text: challenge for architects is how to create a sense of ‘home’
label: Paragraph

text: without resorting to kitsch or indulging in a nostalgic
label: Paragraph

text: iconography that has no relation to our contemporary way
label: Paragraph

text: of life. Low-rise, high-density housing has long been a viable
label: Paragraph

text: option: one thinks of the Siedlung Halen, Berne, built to the
label: Paragraph

text: designs of Atelier 5 in 1960 (see p. 360), and the equally
label: Paragraph

text: canonical, more extensive Puchenau settlement built in
label: Paragraph

text: stages along the Danube near Linz to the designs of the
label: Paragraph

text: Austrian architect Roland Rainer (see p. 587), the first phase
label: Paragraph

text: of which was completed between 1964 and 1967. What is
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable about this carpet housing model is the way in
label: Paragraph

text: which it may be brought to serve the housing needs of
label: Paragraph

text: different classes, from the urban poor of the developing
label: Paragraph

text: world, who continue to construct low-rise ‘squatter’
label: Paragraph

text: settlements, to the urbanized middle classes of the
label: Paragraph

text: developed world, who are served by the car and
label: Paragraph

text: occasionally by public transport. It is perhaps indicative of
label: Paragraph

text: certain cultural differences that while this mode of
label: Paragraph

text: settlement may be found fairly frequently throughout
label: Paragraph

text: Continental Europe, it has generally been resisted as a
label: Paragraph

text: residential pattern in Anglo-American society. As the
label: Paragraph

text: transportation specialist Brian Richards noted in his first
label: Paragraph

text: study, New Movement in Cities of 1966, it is economically
label: Paragraph

text: impossible for public transport to complement car use
label: Title

text: without the residential land-settlement pattern having a
label: Paragraph

text: much higher density than the average suburban
label: Paragraph

text: subdivision.
label: Paragraph

text: While considering the genre of low-rise, high-density
label: Paragraph

text: housing as designed for low-income urban populations, we
label: Paragraph

text: should acknowledge two separate experimental housing
label: Paragraph

text: estates, built in Latin America some forty years apart, that
label: Paragraph

text: now appear as mirror images of one another: the Previ
label: Paragraph

text: estate outside Lima, Peru, built in 1974 during the
label: Paragraph

text: government of Fernando Belaunde Terry, under the direction
label: Caption

text: of the British architect Peter Land; and the realization of a
label: Paragraph

text: prototypical settlement, designed by the Chilean architect
label: Paragraph

text: Alejandro Aravena and built under the auspices of the
label: Paragraph

text: Chilean Ministry of Housing in Iquique, Tarapaca, in 2004
label: Caption

text: [802]. The Previ estate entailed the construction of twenty-
label: Paragraph

text: three different types of low-rise units designed by various
label: Paragraph

text: teams of Peruvian and international architects, while the
label: Paragraph

text: Elemental project represented a collective effort to provide
label: Paragraph

text: affordable dwellings without overloading the occupants with
label: Paragraph

text: debt. The first phase at Iquique comprised one hundred
label: Paragraph

text: ‘starter’ units, each 30 square metres (323 square feet) in
label: Paragraph

text: area and built at the cost of $7,500 per unit. These three-
label: Paragraph

text: storey narrow-fronted megara, built of concrete block,
label: Caption

text: provide for a living room/kitchen, a bathroom, a bedroom
label: Paragraph

text: and an access stair. In order to allow for enlargements by
label: Paragraph

text: the occupants themselves, the units are spaced apart at
label: Paragraph

text: intervals equal to their width, so that additional rooms may
label: Paragraph

text: be constructed easily between the party walls. The block
label: Paragraph

text: layout also yields a series of small squares capable of
label: Paragraph

text: functioning as communal spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: 802 Aravena, housing project, Iquique, Tarapaca, 2004. Elevation.
label: Caption

text: The most crucial change that has occurred in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 20th and early 21st centuries is the engineered eclipse of
label: Paragraph

text: subsidized rental housing, which had been central to welfare
label: Paragraph

text: state policy between 1945 and 1975. This has now been
label: Paragraph

text: replaced, more or less universally, by the ‘housing market’,
label: Paragraph

text: which has done little to alleviate either the perennial
label: Paragraph

text: housing crisis or the proliferation of suburban sprawl. A one-
label: Paragraph

text: off exception is the medium-rise Quartier McNair [803],
label: Paragraph

text: completed in the Zehlendorf district of Berlin in 2003 to the
label: Paragraph

text: designs of Baumschlager and Eberle together with the Swiss
label: Paragraph

text: architect Anatole du Fresne, who was formerly a member of
label: Paragraph

text: Atelier 5. The settlement consists of an orthogonal
label: Paragraph

text: permutation of 263 dwellings of two to three storeys, of
label: Paragraph

text: varying plan type and size, arranged in an alternating block
label: Paragraph

text: pattern reminiscent of Le Corbusier’s Pessac housing of
label: Paragraph

text: 1926 (see p. 168). Despite the green roofs and the
label: Paragraph

text: deployment of solar panels, it is regrettable from the
label: Paragraph

text: viewpoint of sustainability that the parking areas were not
label: Paragraph

text: finished with permeable perforated-concrete paving rather
label: Paragraph

text: than asphalt. In Switzerland this method, facilitating the
label: Paragraph

text: absorption of storm water and the seeding of parking areas
label: Title

text: with grass, is virtually a standard technique; it is only
label: Paragraph

text: marginally more expensive and is capable of offsetting the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘urban heat-island effect’ that is exacerbated by the use of
label: Paragraph

text: asphalt. In the final analysis, it is the overall form rather
label: Paragraph

text: than the detail that allows the Quartier McNair to function as
label: Paragraph

text: a potential alternative ‘market’ model for inner-city housing.
label: Paragraph

text: Not least among its virtues is the fact that it is but twenty
label: Paragraph

text: minutes by public transport from the centre of Berlin.
label: Caption

text: 803 Baumschlager, Eberle and du Fresne, Quartier McNair, Zehlendorf, Berlin,
label: Caption

text: In terms of providing for the housing needs of the middle
label: Paragraph

text: classes, Baumschlager and Eberle have designed some of
label: Paragraph

text: the most viable medium-rise housing settlements of any
label: Paragraph

text: practice in Europe over the past two decades. Nowhere
label: Paragraph

text: have they been more successful in this regard than in their
label: Paragraph

text: Lohbach Siedlung in Innsbruck, Austria (2000) [804]. This
label: Caption

text: generic four- to six-storey development is predicated on
label: Paragraph

text: apartments of varying size, planned around four sides of a
label: Paragraph

text: light-court. What imparts a culturally ecological dimension
label: Paragraph

text: to these blocks is the fact that apartment balconies on the
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter may be closed off with full-height folding shutters
label: Paragraph

text: so that, depending on the movement of the sun and on the
label: Paragraph

text: presence or absence of the occupants, the blocks appear as
label: Paragraph

text: forms of varying opacity. The overall composition has been
label: Paragraph

text: carefully considered in relation to the alpine backdrop, while
label: Paragraph

text: pedestrian movement at ground level has been enhanced
label: Paragraph

text: by sensitively landscaped gardens. In addition to the folding
label: Paragraph

text: shutters, the sustainability of this project stems from the
label: Paragraph

text: provision of photovoltaic panels, from the harvesting of
label: Paragraph

text: rainwater, and from the provision of a heat-recovery plant in
label: Paragraph

text: the basement. At the same time the luxurious ambience of
label: Paragraph

text: the whole derives from its facing materials: from the
label: Paragraph

text: combination of copper-clad shutters, glass balustrading, and
label: Paragraph

text: the sliding full-height timber-louvred screens that cover the
label: Paragraph

text: window openings.
label: Paragraph

text: 804 Baumschlager and Eberle, Lohbach Siedlung, Innsbruck, 2000.
label: Caption

text: All of these housing schemes are but various attempts to
label: Paragraph

text: reintegrate the individual dwelling into some kind of
label: Paragraph

text: collective whole, and it is just this drive to recover a former
label: Paragraph

text: unity that has led late modern architects like Steven Holl to
label: Paragraph

text: search for new forms of residential aggregation, from his
label: Paragraph

text: Fukuoka housing complex, completed in Japan in 1992, to
label: Paragraph

text: his Hybrid Building in Beijing. The latter comprises a self-
label: Paragraph

text: contained urban fragment of 728 apartments housing 2,500
label: Paragraph

text: people together with the essential services required by a
label: Paragraph

text: neighbourhood of this size. These services are housed partly
label: Paragraph

text: in glazed bridges that link the eight apartment towers,
label: Paragraph

text: ranging from twelve to twenty-two storeys in height, so as
label: Paragraph

text: to form a loop around the central open space at ground
label: Paragraph

text: level. The latter is focused about a cinema complex,
label: Paragraph

text: suspended above a reflecting pool. The harvesting of
label: Paragraph

text: rainwater in this ornamental retention basin is only part of
label: Paragraph

text: the comprehensive sustainable strategy adopted in this
label: Paragraph

text: development, which includes green roofs, naturally
label: Paragraph

text: ventilated and illuminated underground parking, external
label: Caption

text: sun blinds, openable windows, and, above all, geothermal
label: Paragraph

text: heating and cooling.
label: Paragraph

text: Civic Form
label: Title

text: In a world increasingly depoliticized by the media, ‘the
label: Paragraph

text: space of public appearance’ (to use Hannah Arendt’s
label: Paragraph

text: memorable phrase) still remains as a democratic ideal for
label: Paragraph

text: both architecture and society, particularly at a time when a
label: Paragraph

text: homeostatically balanced way of life is increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: undermined by the commodification of both the natural and
label: Paragraph

text: the man-made worlds. What Arendt intends by this term is
label: Paragraph

text: made explicit in her study The Human Condition of 1958:
label: Paragraph

text: The only indispensable material factor in the generation of
label: Paragraph

text: power is the living together of people. Only when men live
label: Paragraph

text: so close together that the potentialities of action are always
label: Paragraph

text: present can power remain with them, and the foundation of
label: Paragraph

text: cities, which as city-states have remained paradigmatic for
label: Paragraph

text: all Western political organization, is therefore indeed the
label: Paragraph

text: most important material prerequisite for power.©
label: Paragraph

text: With these words Arendt characterized not only the latent
label: Paragraph

text: political and cultural potential of civic form, but also the
label: Paragraph

text: space of assembly wherever this may still be found within
label: Paragraph

text: public institutions in general. Over the past few decades
label: Paragraph

text: civic building of quality has been particularly noticeable in
label: Paragraph

text: France, above all in the work of Henri Ciriani and Jean
label: Paragraph

text: Nouvel, with the former subtly continuing the programmatic
label: Paragraph

text: approach of Le Corbusier, and the latter favouring a
label: Paragraph

text: technocratic aesthetic that is, at times, equally concerned
label: Paragraph

text: with the representation of the cultural institution as a space
label: Paragraph

text: of public appearance.
label: Paragraph

text: In the case of Ciriani, the emphasis has fallen not only on
label: Paragraph

text: the museum as a microcosmos, but also on its potential to
label: Paragraph

text: serve as a surrogate for the socially unifying religious
label: Paragraph

text: building. This aspect manifests itself particularly forcefully in
label: Paragraph

text: two museums realized by Ciriani towards the end of his
label: Caption

text: career: the Archaeological Museum at Arles, completed in
label: Caption

text: 1991, and the Museum for the First World War at Peronne
label: Caption

text: [806, 807], which was integrated into the remains of a
label: Paragraph

text: 17th-century fortress in 1994. Notwithstanding the
label: Paragraph

text: undeniably arresting image of a building faced completely in
label: Paragraph

text: cobalt-blue glass, the museum in Arles is not easily
label: Paragraph

text: accessible, largely because, detached from the urban core,
label: Paragraph

text: it can only be approached via a ring road encircling the city.
label: Paragraph

text: The articulation of its internal space, with freestanding
label: Paragraph

text: cylindrical columns, conveys the impression of a Neo-Purist
label: Paragraph

text: enclave, as removed from everyday life as the collection it
label: Paragraph

text: houses. Such hermeticism does not arise in the case of the
label: Paragraph

text: Peronne museum, on account of the immediate proximity of
label: Paragraph

text: the urban fabric and the presence of an adjacent riverside
label: Paragraph

text: park. Moreover, the elevation of its concrete mass on pilotis
label: Paragraph

text: enables a carefully orchestrated promenade through the
label: Paragraph

text: sombre relics of the 1914-18 war to be relieved by views
label: Paragraph

text: over the park that flanks the building on its south-western
label: Paragraph

text: face.
label: Paragraph

text: 805 Holl, Linked Hybrid, Beijing, 2003-09.
label: Caption

text: 806 Ciriani, Museum for the First World War, Peronne, 1994. Transverse section.
label: Caption

text: 807 Ciriani, Museum for the First World War, Peronne, 1994. General view.
label: Caption

text: The eventual size of museums is limited if they are to
label: Paragraph

text: retain their institutional viability and civic significance. As Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s 1934 proposal for a ‘Musée a croissance
label: Paragraph

text: illimitée’ demonstrated, a museum of unlimited expansion is
label: Paragraph

text: self-contradictory both conceptually and urbanistically. This
label: Paragraph

text: limit, difficult to specify in advance, may partially explain
label: Paragraph

text: why the new Museum of Modern Art in New York (2004) has
label: Paragraph

text: now attained a size at which it has begun to lose its
label: Paragraph

text: capacity to be read within the city as a discrete civic
label: Paragraph

text: institution. This has come about despite the brilliant
label: Paragraph

text: orchestration of its penultimate extension by the Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: architect Yoshio Taniguchi, who attempted to compensate
label: Paragraph

text: for its extraordinary size and scale by introducing a public
label: Paragraph

text: galleria, as a virtual right of way through the building, within
label: Paragraph

text: the street grid of its Manhattan mid-block site.
label: Paragraph

text: Richard Meier’s Getty Center, completed as a city-in-
label: Paragraph

text: miniature on a prominent hilltop site in the Brentwood area
label: Caption

text: of Los Angeles in 1997, has an indisputable civic character,
label: Paragraph

text: as does his Hague City Hall complex, realized in 1995. Apart
label: Paragraph

text: from being a megaform accommodating offices, shops, a
label: Paragraph

text: municipal library and a council chamber, what is decisive
label: Paragraph

text: about this institution is the fact that its thirteen-storey mass
label: Paragraph

text: encloses a top-lit galleria [809] 183 metres (600 feet) long,
label: Paragraph

text: modulated by footbridges, fed by freestanding elevators,
label: Paragraph

text: which link the corridors of the flanking offices. This is a civic
label: Paragraph

text: volume rivalling in its extent and height the largest galleria
label: Paragraph

text: of the 19th century, the Galleria Umberto | erected in Naples
label: Paragraph

text: in 1891. In a city that in recent years has seen its intimate,
label: Paragraph

text: low-rise, brick-lined street fabric overwhelmed by random
label: Paragraph

text: high-rise development, Meier’s City Hall presents itself as a
label: Paragraph

text: civic oasis, capable of consolidating a new scale around
label: Paragraph

text: itself while compensating for the loss of urbanity in the city
label: Paragraph

text: as a whole. The civic appeal of the galleria itself stems in no
label: Paragraph

text: small measure from the fact that it is a large, top-lit public
label: Paragraph

text: space permanently shielded from the inclemencies of the
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch climate.
label: Paragraph

text: A sense of civitas on a heroic scale is to be found in the
label: Paragraph

text: work of the Berlin architects Axel Schultes and Charlotte
label: Caption

text: Frank, most notably in their winning Spreebogen
label: Paragraph

text: competition entry of 1993. The scheme assumed the form of
label: Paragraph

text: a temenos - a strip of federal buildings to be known as the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Band des Bundes’ - initially projected as the administrative
label: Paragraph

text: centre of a reunified Germany four years after the fall of the
label: Paragraph

text: Berlin Wall in 1989. The Wall had hitherto divided not only
label: Paragraph

text: East and West Berlin, but also, on a global scale, the
label: Paragraph

text: democratic West from the Communist East. The Schultes-
label: Paragraph

text: Frank entry for this international competition was the only
label: Paragraph

text: scheme to capture the urbanistic and symbolic importance
label: Paragraph

text: of the site, in terms both of the history of the previous half-
label: Paragraph

text: century and of the way in which this void in the heart of the
label: Paragraph

text: city had served repeatedly as the context for tragically
label: Paragraph

text: contrasting conceptions of Germany’s destiny.
label: Paragraph

text: Out of this proposal came the architects’ German
label: Paragraph

text: Chancellery [808], completed in 2001 as a partial
label: Paragraph

text: realization of their original scheme, the full extent of which
label: Paragraph

text: will not now be realized - a regrettable circumstance given
label: Paragraph

text: the representational status of the building, remarkable not
label: Paragraph

text: only for its vivacity but also for the lightness of its Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Baroque manner, executed in concrete and painted white.
label: Paragraph

text: Defying convention, the architects chose to represent the
label: Paragraph

text: German state through an allusion to the scale and
label: Paragraph

text: deportment the Ali Qapu palace in Isfahan. Bounded by five-
label: Caption

text: storey ministerial offices to the north and south, this central
label: Paragraph

text: pavilion faces eastwards onto a cour d’honneur and
label: Paragraph

text: westwards onto the Spree River. Patently influenced by
label: Paragraph

text: Louis Kahn’s sense of monumentality but totally removed
label: Paragraph

text: from his syntax, the sky lobby of the Chancellery affords a
label: Paragraph

text: panoramic view over the new Reichstag realized to the
label: Paragraph

text: designs of Paul Wallot in 1894 and reconstructed by Foster
label: Caption

text: Associates in 1999.
label: Paragraph

text: 808 Schultes and Frank, German Chancellery, Berlin, 2001. Axial view of the
label: Caption

text: cour d'honneur with offices.
label: Paragraph

text: 809 Meier, City Hall, The Hague, 1995. View of galleria.
label: Caption

text: The manifestation of civil society in built form is difficult
label: Paragraph

text: to achieve in our commodified world of universal
label: Paragraph

text: consumerism, wherein - as Arendt wrote in 1958 - ‘we
label: Paragraph

text: consume ... our houses and furniture and cars as though
label: Paragraph

text: they were the “good things” of nature which would spoil
label: Paragraph

text: uselessly if they are not drawn swiftly into the neverending
label: Paragraph

text: cycle of man’s metabolism with nature’.
label: Paragraph

text: Nothing could be further from this than Colin St John
label: Paragraph

text: Wilson’s British Library [811], realized in London at virtually
label: Paragraph

text: the same time as the French Bibliotheque Nationale after a
label: Paragraph

text: delay of more than two decades. Strongly influenced by the
label: Paragraph

text: work of Alvar Aalto, this building assumes a more overtly
label: Paragraph

text: contextual character on account of its organic composition
label: Paragraph

text: and its facing in red brick, which links it empathetically, in
label: Paragraph

text: terms of both material and scale, to the Gothic Revival head
label: Paragraph

text: building of the adjacent St Pancras Station, completed in
label: Caption

text: 1874. While it lacks the axial monumentality of its Parisian
label: Paragraph

text: counterpart, the British Library is obviously predicated on a
label: Paragraph

text: more expressively organic and contextual articulation of the
label: Paragraph

text: institution. Within and without, the vast scale and
label: Paragraph

text: complexity of the programme are broken down into a
label: Paragraph

text: number of discretely articulated collections, each subtly
label: Paragraph

text: connected to the others.
label: Paragraph

text: 810 Schultes and Frank, Baumschulenweg Crematorium, Treptow, Berlin, 1999.
label: Caption

text: View of central hypostyle hall.
label: Caption

text: 811 St John Wilson, British Library, London, 1995.
label: Caption

text: Like most of the works featured in this postscript, the
label: Paragraph

text: British Library may be seen as a megaform, that is to say as
label: Paragraph

text: a civic institution that may be experienced by the society as
label: Paragraph

text: a representation and as a ‘space of public appearance’,
label: Paragraph

text: while having, at the same time, the typographic character
label: Paragraph

text: and the scale of a landmark. It is evident that certain
label: Paragraph

text: programmes lend themselves to this form of embodiment
label: Paragraph

text: and interpretation more readily than others. | have in mind
label: Paragraph

text: such institutions as town halls, theatres, museums,
label: Paragraph

text: hospitals, universities and airports, of which Richard
label: Paragraph

text: Rogers’s ultimate masterwork, his Barajas Airport, Madrid
label: Caption

text: (2006) [813], is an outstanding example.
label: Paragraph

text: It is fitting given their mutual authorship of the Centre
label: Paragraph

text: Pompidou at the very beginning of their separate careers
label: Paragraph

text: that an equally arresting megaform should have been
label: Paragraph

text: realized recently to the designs of Renzo Piano, namely the
label: Paragraph

text: half-kilometre-long Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural
label: Caption

text: Center [812], built just outside Athens as a gargantuan
label: Paragraph

text: earthwork in 2016. Within this lushly landscaped artificial
label: Paragraph

text: outcrop are housed two subterranean auditoria, which may
label: Paragraph

text: be accessed on foot at grade via a so-called agora let into
label: Paragraph

text: the side of the earthwork. These large and small auditoria
label: Paragraph

text: have seating capacities of 2,000 and 400 respectively. The
label: Paragraph

text: other civic institution situated within the body of the
label: Paragraph

text: megaform is the Greek Library, in addition to the provision
label: Paragraph

text: of parking. It is perhaps even more pertinent, given the
label: Paragraph

text: context, that this ‘acropolis’ should culminate at its highest
label: Paragraph

text: point in a belvedere, sheltered by a typical ‘high-tech’,
label: Paragraph

text: lightweight canopy set before the turbulence of a wine-dark
label: Paragraph

text: sea.
label: Paragraph
